To drown his sorrows he paid a visit to the famous restaurant “21.” In the lobby, he ran into Sam Goldwyn, who offered the somewhat impractical advice that he should buy racehorses. At the bar Arlen met Louis B. Mayer, an old acquaintance, who asked him what were his plans for the future. “1 was just talking to Sam Goldwyn ...” began Arlen. “How much did he offer you ” interrupted Mayer. “Not enough,” he replied evasively. “Would you take fifteen thousand for thirty weeks” asked Mayer. No hesitation this time. “Yes,” said Arlen.
时运不济的编剧迈克尔·阿伦于1944年去了纽约。为了借酒消愁，他去了著名的“21”餐厅。在大厅里，他碰到了萨姆·戈德温，戈德温给了他一个不太实际的建议：买赛马。在吧台，阿伦遇到了老相识路易斯·B·梅耶，梅耶问他未来的打算。“我刚才和萨姆·戈德温聊过……”阿伦开口道。“他给你开出了多少钱？”梅耶打断他。“不够。”他含糊其辞地回答。“你愿意接受15000美元，工作30周吗？”梅耶问道。这次阿伦没有丝毫犹豫。“愿意。”阿伦说道。
the little, brown
那只小小的棕色
book of anecdotes,
轶事集
Clifton Fadiman,
克利夫顿·法迪曼
f.d., 1985
f.d.，1985
One oft-told tale about
一个经常被讲述的故事
Kissinger...
基辛格……
involved a report that
涉及一份报告，
Winston Lord had
温斯顿·洛德
worked on for days.
花了几天时间。
After giving it to
把它交给
Kissinger, he got it
基辛格，他明白了。
back with the notation,
回到符号说明，
"Is this the best you
这是你最好的选择吗？
can do" Lord rewrote
可以做到” 主改写了
and polished and
并且经过抛光
finally resubmitted it;
最后重新提交了；
back it came with the
它回来的时候带着
same curt question.
同样简短的问题。
After redrafting it one
重写之后
more timeand once
更多次，一次
again getting the same
再次得到相同的结果
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Gnaeus Marcius, also known as Coriolanus, was a great military hero of ancient Rome. In die first half of the fifth century B.C. he won many important battles, saving the city from calamity time and time again. Because he spent most of his time on the batdefield, few Romans knew him personally, making him something of a legendary figure.
格奈乌斯·马尔基乌斯，又名科里奥兰纳斯，是古罗马一位伟大的军事英雄。公元前五世纪上半叶，他赢得了许多重要战役，一次又一次地拯救罗马城于危难之中。由于他大部分时间都活跃在战场上，很少有罗马人真正了解他，这使他成为了一位传奇人物。
In 454 B.C., Coriolanus decided it was time to exploit his reputation and enter politics. He stood for election to the high rank of consul. Candidates for this position traditionally made a public address early in the race, and when Coriolanus came before the people, he began by displaying the dozens of scars he had accumulated over seventeen years of fighting for Rome. Few in the crowd really heard the lengthy speech diat followed; those scars, proof of his valor and patriotism, moved the people to tears. Coriolanus's election seemed certain.
公元前454年，科里奥兰纳斯决定利用自己的声望投身政坛。他竞选执政官这一要职。按照惯例，执政官候选人会在竞选初期发表公开演讲。科里奥兰纳斯来到民众面前，首先展示了他为罗马征战十七年来积累的数十道伤疤。人群中几乎无人真正听清他随后冗长的演讲；那些伤疤，作为他英勇和爱国情怀的证明，感动得人们热泪盈眶。科里奥兰纳斯的当选似乎已成定局。
When die polling day arrived, however, Coriolanus made an entry into the forum escorted by the entire senate and by the city's patricians, the aristocracy. The common people who saw this were disturbed by such a blustering show of confidence on election day.
然而，到了投票日，科里奥兰纳斯却在全体元老院议员和城中贵族（即上层阶级）的护送下进入了广场。目睹此景的平民百姓对选举日如此张扬的自信感到不安。
And then Coriolanus spoke again, mostly addressing the wealthy citizens who had accompanied him. His words were arrogant and insolent. Claiming certain victory in die vote, he boasted of his battlefield exploits, made sour jokes that appealed only to die patricians, voiced angry accusations against his opponents, and speculated on the riches he would bring to Rome. This time the people listened: They had not realized diat tins legendary soldier was also a common braggart.
然后科里奥兰纳斯再次开口，主要对着随行的富裕市民讲话。他的言辞傲慢无礼。他声称自己必胜无疑，吹嘘着自己的战场功绩，讲着只有贵族才能听懂的尖酸刻薄的笑话，愤怒地指责对手，并臆测着自己将为罗马带来的财富。这一次，民众听进去了：他们之前并没有意识到，这位传奇战士竟然也是个只会吹牛的普通人。
News of Coriolanus's second speech spread quickly dirough Rome, and the people turned out in great numbers to make sure he was not elected. Defeated, Coriolanus returned to the battlefield, bitter and vowing revenge on the common folk who had voted against him. Some weeks later a large shipment of grain arrived in Rome. The senate was ready to distribute this food to die people, for free, but just as they were preparing to vote on die question Coriolanus appeared on the scene and took the senate floor. The distribution, he argued, would have a harmful effect on the city as a whole. Several senators appeared won over, and the vote on the distribution fell into doubt. Coriolanus did not stop diere: He went on to condemn die concept of democracy itself. He advocated getting rid of the people's representativesdie tribunesand turning over the governing of the city to the patricians.
科里奥兰纳斯第二次演讲的消息迅速传遍罗马，民众纷纷涌上街头，誓要阻止他当选。科里奥兰纳斯败北后，满怀怨恨地重返战场，发誓要向那些投票反对他的平民百姓复仇。几周后，一大批粮食运抵罗马。元老院准备将这些粮食免费分发给民众，但就在他们即将就此事进行投票表决时，科里奥兰纳斯突然出现，登上了元老院的讲台。他辩称，粮食分发会对整个城市造成损害。几位元老似乎被他说服了，关于粮食分发的投票结果变得扑朔迷离。科里奥兰纳斯并未就此罢休：他继续抨击民主制度本身。他主张废除人民代表——保民官，并将城市的统治权移交给贵族。
When word of Coriolanus's latest speech reached the people, their anger knew no bounds. The tribunes were sent to the senate to demand diat Coriolanus appear before them. He refused. Riots broke out all over the city. The senate, fearing die people's wrath, finally voted in favor of the grain distribution. The tribunes were appeased, but the people still demanded that Coriolanus speak to them and apologize. If he repented, and agreed to keep his opinions to himself, he would be allowed to return to the batdefield.
科里奥兰纳斯最新演说的消息传到民众耳中，顿时群情激愤。保民官们奉命前往元老院，要求科里奥兰纳斯到场。他断然拒绝。全城爆发骚乱。元老院惧怕民众的怒火，最终投票通过了粮食分配方案。保民官们的怒火得以平息，但民众仍然要求科里奥兰纳斯向他们道歉。如果他真心悔改，并承诺不再发表不当言论，就可以重返战场。
Coriolanus did appear one last time before the people, who listened to
科里奥兰纳斯最后一次出现在民众面前，民众聆听了他的演讲。
him in rapt silence. He started slowly and softly, but as the speech went on, he became more and more blunt. Yet again he hurled insults! His tone was arrogant, his expression disdainful. The more he spoke, the angrier the people became. Finally they shouted him down and silenced him.
他被吓得鸦雀无声。起初他说话轻声细语，但随着演讲的进行，他的语气越来越尖锐。他又一次出言不逊！他的语气傲慢，表情轻蔑。他讲得越多，人们就越愤怒。最后，他们齐声高喊，让他哑口无言。
The tribunes conferred, condemned Coriolanus to death, and ordered the magistrates to take him at once to the top of the Tarpeian rock and throw him over. The delighted crowd seconded the decision. The patricians, however, managed to intervene, and the sentence was commuted to a lifelong banishment. When the people found out that Rome's great military hero would never return to the city, they celebrated in the streets. In fact no one had ever seen such a celebration, not even after the defeat of a foreign enemy.
护民官们商议后，判处科里奥兰纳斯死刑，并命令地方官吏立即将他押往塔尔佩亚岩顶，扔下去。欢呼雀跃的民众赞同这一判决。然而，贵族们设法从中斡旋，最终将死刑改为终身流放。当人们得知这位罗马的伟大军事英雄将永远无法返回罗马城时，他们走上街头，欢庆不已。事实上，如此盛大的庆祝活动前所未见，即使是击败外敌之后也未曾出现过。
question from KissingerLord snapped, “Damn it, yes, it's the best I can do.” To which Kissinger replied: “Fine, then I guess I'll read it this time.”
基辛格问道：“该死，是的，这是我能做到的最好水平了。”基辛格回答说：“好吧，那我这次就读读吧。”
kissinger, Walter Isaacson, 1992
基辛格，沃尔特·艾萨克森，1992年
Interpretation
解释
Before his entrance into politics, the name of Coriolanus evoked awe.
在科里奥兰纳斯步入政坛之前，他的名字就令人敬畏。
His battlefield accomplishments showed him as a man of great bravery. Since the citizens knew little about him, all kinds of legends became attached to his name. The moment he appeared before the Roman citizens, however, and spoke his mind, all that grandeur and mystery vanished. He bragged and blustered like a common soldier. He insulted and slandered people, as if he felt threatened and insecure. Suddenly he was not at all what the people had imagined. The discrepancy between the legend and the reality proved immensely disappointing to those who wanted to believe in their hero. The more Coriolanus said, the less powerful he appeareda person who cannot control his words shows that he cannot control himself, and is unworthy of respect.
他在战场上的功绩证明他是一位英勇无畏的战士。由于民众对他知之甚少，各种各样的传说便围绕着他流传开来。然而，当他出现在罗马民众面前，坦诚地表达自己的想法时，所有的威严和神秘感都荡然无存。他像个普通士兵一样吹嘘虚张声势，侮辱诽谤他人，仿佛感到威胁和不安。突然间，他完全不像人们想象中的那样英勇无畏。传说与现实的落差令那些想要相信自己英雄的人感到无比失望。科里奥兰纳斯说得越多，就越显得软弱无力——一个无法控制自己言辞的人，恰恰暴露了他自身也缺乏自制力，不值得人们尊敬。
Had Coriolanus said less, the people would never have had cause to be offended by him, would never have known his true feelings. He would have maintained his powerful aura, would certainly have been elected consul, and would have been able to accomplish his antidemocratic goals. But the human tongue is a beast that few can master. It strains constantly to break out of its cage, and if it is not tamed, it will run wild and cause you grief. Power cannot accrue to those who squander their treasure of words.
如果科里奥兰纳斯少说些话，民众就不会有理由被他冒犯，也不会了解他的真实想法。他本可以维持他强大的威望，肯定会当选执政官，并实现他反民主的目标。然而，人的舌头是一头野兽，很少有人能驾驭它。它总是渴望挣脱牢笼，如果不加以驯服，它就会肆意妄为，给你带来痛苦。挥霍语言宝藏的人，无法获得权力。
Oysters open completely when the moon is full; and when the crab sees one
牡蛎在满月时完全张开；而当螃蟹看到一个牡蛎时，它就会张开嘴。
it throws a piece of stone or seaweed into it and the oyster cannot close
它会往牡蛎壳里扔一块石头或海藻，导致牡蛎无法闭合。
again so that it serves the crab for meat. Such is the fate of him who opens
再次如此，以至于它把螃蟹当作肉来享用。这就是那些打开……的人的下场。
his mouth too much and thereby puts himself at the mercy of the listener.
他话太多，因此让自己受制于听众。
Leonardo da Vinci, 1452-1519
列奥纳多·达·芬奇，1452-1519年
The King [Louis XIV] maintains the most impenetrable secrecy about affairs of Slate. The ministers attend council meetings, but he confides his plans to them only when he has reflected at length upon them and has come to a definite decision. 1 wish you might see the King. His expression is inscrutable; his eyes like those of a fox. He never discusses State affairs except with his ministers in Council. When he speaks to courtiers he refers only to their respective prerogatives or duties. Even the most frivolous of his utterances has the air of being the pronouncement of an oracle.
国王（路易十四）对国事守口如瓶，严加保密。大臣们会出席枢密会议，但他只有在深思熟虑、做出最终决定后，才会将计划告知他们。我真希望您能见到国王。他的表情难以捉摸，眼神如狐狸般锐利。他从不在枢密会议上与大臣们讨论国事。即使与朝臣交谈，他也只提及他们各自的特权或职责。就连他最轻佻的话语，也仿佛是神谕一般。
Primi Visconti, quoted in louis xiv, Louis Bertrand, 1928
普里米·维斯康蒂，引自路易十四，路易·贝特朗，1928年
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In the court of Louis XIV, nobles and ministers would spend days and nights debating issues of state. They would confer, argue, make and break alliances, and argue again, until finally the critical moment arrived: Two of them would be chosen to represent the different sides to Louis himself, who would decide what should be done. After these persons were chosen,
在路易十四的宫廷里，贵族和大臣们日夜辩论国家大事。他们商议、争论、结盟又决裂，如此反复，直到最终的关键时刻到来：他们之中会选出两人分别代表双方，觐见路易十四本人，由他来决定下一步的行动。这些人选出之后，
Undutiful words of a
不敬的言语
subject do often take
主题经常会
deeper root than the
比……更深的根
memory of ill deeds....
对恶行的记忆……
The late Earl of Essex
已故的埃塞克斯伯爵
told Queen Elizabeth
告诉伊丽莎白女王
that her conditions
她的条件
were as crooked as her
和她一样狡猾
carcass; but it cost him
尸体；但这让他付出了代价
his head, which his
他的头，他的
insurrection had not
叛乱尚未发生
cost him but for that
但这让他付出了代价。
speech.
演讲。
Sir Walter Ralhioh,
沃尔特·拉利奥爵士
1554-1618
everyone would argue some more: How should the issues be phrased What would appeal to Louis, what would annoy him At what time of day should the representatives approach him, and in what part of the Versailles palace What expression should they have on their faces
大家又开始争论起来：问题应该如何措辞？什么能吸引路易，什么会惹恼他？代表们应该在一天中的什么时间，在凡尔赛宫的哪个地方去见他？他们脸上应该带着怎样的表情？
Finally, after all this was settled, the fateful moment would finally arrive. The two men would approach Louisalways a delicate matterand when they finally had his ear, they would talk about the issue at hand, spelling out the options in detail.
最终，一切尘埃落定之后，决定命运的时刻终于到来。两人会去找路易——这向来是个棘手的问题——当他们终于有机会与路易交谈时，便会详细阐述各种方案，探讨当前的问题。
Louis would listen in silence, a most enigmatic look on his face. Finally, when each had finished his presentation and had asked for the king's opinion, he would look at them botii and say, “I shall see.” Then he would walk away.
路易会默默地听着，脸上带着一种难以捉摸的表情。最后，当每个人都说完话并征求国王的意见后，他会看着他们，说：“我再想想。”然后便转身离开。
The ministers and courtiers would never hear another word on this subject from the kingthey would simply see the result, weeks later, when he would come to a decision and act. He would never bother to consult them on the matter again.
大臣和朝臣们再也听不到国王关于此事的任何消息——他们只会眼睁睁地看着几周后国王做出决定并采取行动。他再也不会就此事征求他们的意见了。
Interpretation
解释
Louis XIV was a man of very few words. His most famous remark is “L'etat, c'est moi”ll am the state“); nothing could be more pithy yet more eloquent. His infamous ”I shall see" was one of several extremely short phrases that he would apply to all manner of requests.
路易十四是个寡言少语的人。他最著名的格言是“L'etat, c'est moi”ll am the state”（国家即我），这句话简洁精辟，却又意味深长。他那句著名的“I shall see”（我拭目以待）只是他用来回应各种请求的众多简短短语之一。
Louis was not always this way; as a young man he was known for talking at length, delighting in his own eloquence. His later taciturnity was self-imposed, an act, a mask he used to keep everybody below him off-balance. No one knew exactly where he stood, or could predict his reactions. No one could try to deceive him by saying what they thought he wanted to hear, because no one knew what he wanted to hear. As they talked on and on to the silent Louis, they revealed more and more about themselves, information he would later use against them to great effect.
路易并非一直如此；年轻时，他以滔滔不绝著称，并沉醉于自己的雄辩。他后来的沉默寡言是他自己强加的，是一种伪装，一种面具，用来迷惑他之下的人。没有人真正了解他的立场，也无法预测他的反应。没有人能用他爱听的话来欺骗他，因为没有人知道他真正想听什么。当他们对着沉默的路易喋喋不休时，他们也逐渐暴露了自己越来越多的秘密，而这些信息后来被他用来对付他们，并取得了巨大的成效。
In the end, Louis's silence kept those around him terrified and under his thumb. It was one of the foundations of his power. As Saint-Simon wrote, “No one knew as well as he how to sell his words, his smile, even his glances. Everything in him was valuable because he created differences, and his majesty was enhanced by the sparseness of his words.”
最终，路易的沉默让周围的人感到恐惧，并受他掌控。这正是他权力的基石之一。正如圣西蒙所写：“没有人比他更懂得如何运用言语、微笑，甚至眼神。他的一切都弥足珍贵，因为他能制造差异，而他寡言少语更增添了他的威严。”
It is even more damaging for a minister to say foolish things than to do them.
对于一位牧师来说，说出愚蠢的话比做出愚蠢的事危害更大。
Cardinal de Retz, 1613-1679
雷茨枢机主教，1613-1679年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Power is in many ways a game of appearances, and when you say less than necessary, you inevitably appear greater and more powerful than you are. Your silence will make other people uncomfortable. Humans are machines of interpretation and explanation; they have to know what you are thinking. When you carefully control what you reveal, they cannot pierce your intentions or your meaning.
权力在很多方面都是一种表象游戏，当你言简意赅时，你自然会显得比实际更强大、更有权力。你的沉默会让别人感到不自在。人类是解读和解释的机器；他们必须知道你在想什么。当你谨慎地控制自己透露的信息时，他们就无法洞悉你的意图或含义。
Your short answers and silences will put them on the defensive, and they will jump in, nervously filling the silence with all kinds of comments that will reveal valuable information about them and their weaknesses. They will leave a meeting with you feeling as if they had been robbed, and they will go home and ponder your every word. This extra attention to your brief comments will only add to your power.
你的简短回答和沉默会让他们产生防御心理，他们会紧张地插话，用各种各样的评论来填补沉默，而这些评论往往会暴露他们自身的信息和弱点。他们会带着被窃取信息的感觉离开，回家后会反复琢磨你说的每一句话。这种对你简短评论的格外关注只会增强你的影响力。
Saying less than necessary is not for kings and statesmen only. In most areas of life, the less you say, the more profound and mysterious you appear. As a young man, the artist Andy Warhol had the revelation that it was generally impossible to get people to do what you wanted them to do by talking to them. They would turn against you, subvert your wishes, disobey you out of sheer perversity. He once told a friend, “I learned that you actually have more power when you shut up.”
少言寡语并非君王和政治家的专属。在生活的大多数领域，你越是沉默寡言，就越显得深邃神秘。年轻时的艺术家安迪·沃霍尔曾顿悟，想要通过言语说服他人几乎是不可能的。他们会反抗你，违背你的意愿，甚至出于某种纯粹的叛逆而违抗你。他曾对一位朋友说：“我发现，沉默反而更能掌控一切。”
In his later life Warhol employed this strategy with great success. His interviews were exercises in oracular speech: He would say something vague and ambiguous, and the interviewer would twist in circles trying to figure it out, imagining there was something profound behind his often meaningless phrases. Warhol rarely talked about his work; he let others do the interpreting. He claimed to have learned this technique from that master of enigma Marcel Duchamp, anotiier twentieth-century artist who realized early on that the less he said about his work, the more people talked about it. And the more they talked, the more valuable his work became.
沃霍尔晚年将这种策略运用得炉火纯青。他的访谈就像一场预言式的演讲：他会说一些含糊不清、模棱两可的话，而采访者则会绞尽脑汁地试图理解，想象着他那些看似毫无意义的话语背后隐藏着某种深刻的含义。沃霍尔很少谈论自己的作品；他让别人来解读。他声称自己是从那位神秘大师马塞尔·杜尚那里学到了这种技巧。杜尚是另一位二十世纪艺术家，他很早就意识到，自己对作品谈论得越少，人们就越会谈论它。而人们谈论得越多，他的作品就越有价值。
By saying less than necessary you create the appearance of meaning and power. Also, the less you say, the less risk you run of saying something foolish, even dangerous. In 1825 a new czar, Nicholas I, ascended the throne of Russia. A rebellion immediately broke out, led by liberals demanding that the country modernizethat its industries and civil structures catch up with the rest of Europe. Brutally crushing this rebellion (the Decembrist Uprising), Nicholas I sentenced one of its leaders, Kondraty Ryleyev, to death. On the day of the execution Ryleyev stood on the gallows, the noose around his neck. The trapdoor openedbut as Ryleyev dangled, the rope broke, dashing him to the ground. At the time, events like this were considered signs of providence or heavenly will, and a man saved from execution this way was usually pardoned. As Ryleyev got to his feet, bruised and dirtied but believing his neck had been saved, he called out to the crowd, “You see, in Russia they don't know how to do anything properly, not even how to make rope!”
少说多做，反而能营造出意义深远、气势十足的假象。而且，说得越少，说出蠢话甚至危险话的风险就越小。1825年，新沙皇尼古拉一世登上俄罗斯皇位。随即爆发了一场由自由派领导的叛乱，他们要求国家现代化，使其工业和公共设施赶上欧洲其他国家。尼古拉一世残酷镇压了这场叛乱（十二月党人起义），并判处其领导人之一康德拉季·雷列耶夫死刑。行刑当天，雷列耶夫站在绞刑架上，脖子上套着绳索。活板门打开了，但雷列耶夫悬在半空中时，绳索断裂，他重重地摔在地上。在当时，这类事件被认为是天意或神迹，以这种方式免于一死的人通常会被赦免。雷列耶夫站起身来，浑身是伤，满身污垢，但他相信自己的脖子保住了，于是向人群喊道：“你们看，在俄罗斯，他们什么都做不好，连绳子都不会做！”
A messenger immediately went to the Winter Palace with news of the failed hanging. Vexed by this disappointing turnabout, Nicholas I nevertheless began to sign the pardon. But then: “Did Ryleyev say anything after this miracle” the czar asked the messenger. “Sire,” the messenger replied, “he said that in Russia they don't even know how to make rope.”
一名信使立即前往冬宫，禀报绞刑失败的消息。尼古拉一世虽然对这一令人失望的变故感到恼怒，但还是开始签署赦免令。这时，沙皇问信使：“雷列耶夫在这次奇迹之后说了什么？”信使回答说：“陛下，他说在俄罗斯，他们甚至连绳子都不会做。”
“In that case,” said the Czar, “let us prove the contrary,” and he tore up the pardon. The next day Ryleyev was hanged again. This time the rope did not break.
“既然如此，”沙皇说，“那就让我们证明事实并非如此。”说完，他撕毁了赦免令。第二天，雷列耶夫再次被绞死。这一次，绳子没有断。
Learn the lesson: Once the words are out, you cannot take them back. Keep them under control. Be particularly careful with sarcasm: The mo-
吸取教训：话一出口，就收不回来了。谨言慎行。尤其要注意讽刺：讽刺的威力不容小觑。
mentary satisfaction you gain with your biting words will be outweighed by the price you pay.
你用尖刻的言辞获得的快感，终将被你付出的代价所抵消。
Image :
图像 ：
The Oracle at Delphi.
Delphi 的 Oracle。
When visitors consulted the
当访客咨询时
Oracle, the priestess would utter
女祭司会念诵神谕
a few enigmatic words that seemed
几句晦涩难懂的话语，似乎
full of meaning and import. No one
意义深远，不可忽视。
disobeyed the words of the Oracle
他违背了神谕。
they held power over life and death.
他们掌握着生杀大权。
Authority: Never start moving your own lips and teeth before the subordinates do. The longer I keep quiet, the sooner others move their lips and teeth. As they move their lips and teeth, I can thereby understand tiieir real intentions.... If the sovereign is not mysterious, the ministers will find opportunity to take and take. (Han-fei-tzu, Chinese philosopher, third century B.C.)
权威：切勿在下属开口之前先开口。我越是保持沉默，下属就越早开口。当他们开口时，我便能了解他们的真实意图……君主若不神秘，臣子便会伺机而动。（韩非子，中国哲学家，公元前三世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
There are times when it is unwise to be silent. Silence can arouse suspicion and even insecurity, especially in your superiors; a vague or ambiguous comment can open you up to interpretations you had not bargained for. Silence and saying less than necessary must be practiced with caution, then, and in the right situations. It is occasionally wiser to imitate the court jester, who plays the fool but knows he is smarter than the king. He talks and talks and entertains, and no one suspects that he is more than just a fool.
有些时候保持沉默并不明智。沉默会引起怀疑甚至不安，尤其是在上级面前；含糊不清的评论可能会招致意想不到的解读。因此，沉默和少言少语必须谨慎运用，并且要选择合适的场合。有时，效仿宫廷弄臣或许更为明智。他装傻充愣，却深知自己比国王更聪明。他滔滔不绝，逗人开心，没有人会怀疑他其实只是个傻瓜。
Also, words can sometimes act as a kind of smoke screen for any deception you might practice. By bending your listener's ear with talk, you can distract and mesmerize them; the more you talk, in fact, the less suspicious of you they become. The verbose are not perceived as sly and manipulative but as helpless and unsophisticated. This is the reverse of the silent policy employed by the powerful: By talking more, and making yourself appear weaker and less intelligent than your mark, you can practice deception with greater ease.
此外，言语有时可以成为你实施欺骗的烟幕弹。通过滔滔不绝的谈话，你可以分散听者的注意力，让他们着迷；事实上，你说得越多，他们就越不怀疑你。话多的人不会被视为狡猾奸诈，反而会被视为无助愚钝。这与强者惯用的沉默策略截然相反：通过多说话，让自己显得比目标人物更弱小、更不聪明，你就能更容易地实施欺骗。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 5
第五条
SO MUCH DEPENDS ON
很多事情都取决于……
REPUTATIONGUARD IT
声誉卫士
WITH YOUR LIFE
用你的生命
JUDGMENT
判断
Reputation is the cornerstone of power. Through reputation alone you can intimidate and win; once it slips, however, you are vulnerable, and will be attacked on all sides. Make your reputation unassailable. Always be alert to potential attacks and thwart them before they happen. Meanwhile, learn to destroy your enemies by opening holes in their own reputations. Then stand aside and let public opinion hang them.
声誉是权力的基石。仅凭声誉，你就能震慑对手，赢得胜利；然而，一旦声誉受损，你便会变得不堪一击，四面楚歌。务必确保你的声誉坚不可摧。时刻警惕潜在的攻击，并在其发生之前将其化解。同时，学会通过攻击敌人的声誉来摧毁他们。然后袖手旁观，让舆论来审判他们。
A frightful epidemic sent To earth by Heaven intent to vent Its fury on a sinful world, to call It by its rightful name, the pestilence, That Acheron-filling vial of virulence Had fallen on every animal. Not all were dead, but all lay near to dying, And none was any longer trying To find new fuel to feed life's flickering fires. No foods excited their desires; No more did wolves and foxes rove In search of harmless, helpless prey; And dove would not consort with dove, For love and joy had flown away. The Lion assumed the chair to say: "Dear friends, I doubt not it's for heaven's high ends That on us sinners woe must fall. Let him of us who's sinned the most Fall victim to the avenging heavenly host, And may he win salvation for us all; For history teaches us that in these crises We must make sacrifices. Undeceived and stern-eyed, let's inspect Our conscience. As I recollect, To put my greedy appetite to sleep, I've banqueted on
一场可怕的瘟疫降临人间，仿佛上天降下怒火，要将这罪恶的世界彻底摧毁。它本该被称为瘟疫，这盛满毒液的阿刻戎河之瓶，已倾泻在所有动物身上。并非所有动物都已死去，但都奄奄一息，再也没有人试图寻找新的燃料来点燃生命摇曳的火焰。食物不再能激起它们的欲望；狼和狐狸不再四处游荡，寻找无害的猎物；鸽子也不再与鸽子相伴，因为爱与欢乐早已消逝。狮子坐上椅子说道：“亲爱的朋友们，我毫不怀疑，这苦难必将降临在我们这些罪人身上，乃是上天的旨意。愿我们当中罪孽最深重的人，成为天庭复仇之军的牺牲品，愿他为我们所有人赢得救赎；因为历史告诉我们，在这些危机时刻，我们必须做出牺牲。让我们保持清醒和严肃，审视我们的良心。我记得，为了平息我贪婪的欲望，我曾大吃大喝……”
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
During China's War of the Three Kingdoms (a.D. 207-265), the great general Chuko Liang, leading the forces of the Shu Kingdom, dispatched his vast army to a distant camp while he rested in a small town with a handful of soldiers. Suddenly sentinels hurried in with the alarming news that an enemy force of over 150,000 troops under Sima Yi was approaching. With only a hundred men to defend him, Chuko Liang's situation was hopeless. The enemy would finally capture this renowned leader.
在中国三国时期（公元207-265年），蜀国名将朱可梁率领大军前往远方营地休整，自己则率领少数士兵在一座小镇休养。突然，哨兵匆匆赶来，带来令人震惊的消息：司马懿率领的十五万余大军正逼近。朱可梁仅剩百余人守卫，处境岌岌可危。这位名将最终难逃被俘的命运。
Without lamenting his fate, or wasting time trying to figure out how he had been caught, Liang ordered his troops to take down their flags, throw open the city gates, and hide. He himself men took a seat on the most visible part of the city's wall, wearing a Taoist robe. He lit some incense, strummed his lute, and began to chant. Minutes later he could see the vast enemy army approaching, an endless phalanx of soldiers. Pretending not to notice them, he continued to sing and play the lute.
梁无怨无悔，也未费心思琢磨自己为何落网，便下令士兵降旗、敞开城门，藏匿起来。他自己则身着道服，率部坐在城墙最显眼的位置。他点燃香烛，弹奏琵琶，开始吟唱。片刻之后，他便看到敌军浩浩荡荡地逼近，一长串士兵密密麻麻地排列成行。他装作若无其事，继续吟唱弹奏琵琶。
Soon the army stood at the town gates. At its head was Sima Yi, who instantly recognized the man on the wall.
很快，军队就守在了城门口。率领军队的是司马懿，他一眼就认出了城墙上的人。
Even so, as his soldiers itched to enter the unguarded town through its open gates, Sima Yi hesitated, held them back, and studied Liang on the wall. Then, he ordered an immediate and speedy retreat.
即便如此，当司马懿的士兵们跃跃欲试，想要从敞开的城门冲入这座毫无防备的城池时，他却犹豫了，拦住了他们，仔细观察城墙上的梁。随后，他下令立即迅速撤退。
Interpretation
解释
Chuko Liang was commonly known as the “Sleeping Dragon.” His exploits in the War of the Three Kingdoms were legendary. Once a man claiming to be a disaffected enemy lieutenant came to his camp, offering help and information. Liang instantly recognized the situation as a setup; this man was a false deserter, and should be beheaded. At the last minute, though, as the ax was about to fall, Liang stopped the execution and offered to spare the man's life if he agreed to become a double agent. Grateful and terrified, the man agreed, and began supplying false information to the enemy. Liang won battle after battle.
楚可梁素有“睡龙”之称，他在三国时期的功绩堪称传奇。一次，一个自称是叛逃敌军将领的人来到他的营地，声称要提供帮助和情报。梁一眼就识破了诡计，此人是假逃兵，理应被斩首。然而，就在斧头即将落下之际，梁叫停了行刑，并提出如果此人愿意成为他的双面间谍，就饶他一命。此人既感激又恐惧，只得答应，开始向敌军提供虚假情报。梁的战功卓著，所向披靡。
On another occasion Liang stole a military seal and created false documents dispatching his enemy's troops to distant locations. Once the troops had dispersed, he was able to capture three cities, so that he controlled an entire corridor of the enemy's kingdom. He also once tricked the enemy into believing one of its best generals was a traitor, forcing the man to escape and join forces with Liang. The Sleeping Dragon carefully cultivated his reputation of being the cleverest man in China, one who always had a trick up his sleeve. As powerful as any weapon, this reputation struck fear into his enemy.
另一次，梁氏偷取一枚军印，伪造文书，将敌军调往远方。敌军溃散后，他趁机攻占三座城池，控制了敌国境内的一条重要通道。他还曾欺骗敌军，使其误以为一位得力将领是叛徒，迫使其逃亡并投靠自己。梁氏精心打造了自己“中国最聪明的人”的名声，他总是能出奇制胜。这种名声如同任何武器一般，令敌人胆寒。
Sima Yi had fought against Chuko Liang dozens of times and knew him well. When he came on the empty city, with Liang praying on the wall, he was stunned. The Taoist robes, the chanting, the incensethis had to be a game of intimidation. The man was obviously taunting him, daring him to walk into a trap. The game was so obvious that for one moment it crossed Yi's mind that Liang actually was alone, and desperate. But so great was his fear of Liang that he dared not risk finding out. Such is the
司马懿与楚可梁交手过数十次，对他十分了解。当他来到这座空城，看到楚可梁在城墙上祈祷时，他惊愕不已。道袍、诵经声、香火——这一定是楚可梁的恐吓伎俩。这人显然是在挑衅他，引诱他落入陷阱。这伎俩如此明显，以至于司马懿一时竟怀疑楚可梁真的孤身一人，走投无路。但他对楚可梁的恐惧如此之深，以至于他不敢冒险去验证。这就是……
power of reputation. It can put a vast army on the defensive, even force them into retreat, without a single arrow being fired.
声望的力量。它能让一支庞大的军队转入防守，甚至迫使他们撤退，而无需射出一箭。
For, as Cicero says, even those who argue against fame still want the books they
正如西塞罗所说，即使是那些反对名声的人，也仍然想要他们所拥有的书籍。
write against it to bear their name in the title and hope to become famous for
反对者撰写文章，要求将自己的名字印在标题中，并希望因此成名。
despising it. Everything else is subject to barter: we will let our friends have
我们鄙视它。其他一切都可以交换：我们会让朋友们拥有
our goods and our lives if need be; but a case of sharing our fame and
必要时，我们可以牺牲财产甚至生命；但分享我们的名誉和……
making someone else the gift of our reputation is hardly to be found.
将自己的名誉拱手让给他人，这种做法实属罕见。
Montaigne, 1533-1592
蒙田，1533-1592年
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW II
遵守法律 II
In 1841 the young P. T. Barnum, trying to establish his reputation as America's premier showman, decided to purchase the American Museum in Manhattan and turn it into a collection of curiosities that would secure his fame. The problem was that he had no money. The museum's asking price was $15,000, but Barnum was able to put together a proposal that appealed to the institution's owners even though it replaced cash up front with dozens of guarantees and references. The owners came to a verbal agreement with Barnum, but at the last minute, the principal partner changed his mind, and the museum and its collection were sold to the directors of Peale's Museum. Barnum was infuriated, but the partner explained that business was businessthe museum had been sold to Peale's because Peale's had a reputation and Barnum had none.
1841年，年轻的P·T·巴纳姆为了确立自己作为美国顶级表演家的地位，决定收购位于曼哈顿的美国博物馆，并将其改造成一座收藏奇珍异宝的场所，以此巩固自己的名声。问题是他身无分文。博物馆的要价是15000美元，但巴纳姆设法拟定了一份方案，尽管方案中用数十份担保和推荐信代替了预付款，但仍然打动了博物馆的所有者。所有者与巴纳姆达成了口头协议，但在最后一刻，主要合伙人反悔了，博物馆及其藏品被卖给了皮尔博物馆的馆长。巴纳姆勃然大怒，但合伙人解释说，生意就是生意——博物馆卖给皮尔博物馆是因为皮尔博物馆名声显赫，而巴纳姆一无所有。
Barnum immediately decided that if he had no reputation to bank on, his only recourse was to ruin die reputation of Peale's. Accordingly he launched a letter-writing campaign in the newspapers, calling the owners a bunch of “broken-down bank directors” who had no idea how to run a museum or entertain people. He warned the public against buying Peale's stock, since the business's purchase of another museum would invariably spread its resources thin. The campaign was effective, die stock plummeted, and widi no more confidence in Peale's track record and reputation, the owners of die American Museum reneged on their deal and sold the whole thing to Barnum.
巴纳姆立刻意识到，既然自己没有可以依靠的声誉，唯一的办法就是败坏皮尔博物馆的名声。于是，他发起了一场报纸连载的舆论攻势，称博物馆老板是一群“落魄的银行董事”，根本不懂如何经营博物馆，也不懂如何招待观众。他警告公众不要购买皮尔博物馆的股票，因为该公司收购另一家博物馆必然会分散其资源。这场攻势奏效了，皮尔博物馆的股价暴跌，而美国博物馆的老板们也对皮尔博物馆的过往业绩和声誉彻底失去了信心，最终他们反悔了，将整个博物馆卖给了巴纳姆。
It took years for Peale's to recover, and they never forgot what Barnum had done. Mr. Peale himself decided to attack Barnum by building a reputation for “high-brow entertainment,” promoting his museum's programs as more scientific than those of his vulgar competitor. Mesmerism (hypnotism) was one of Peale's “scientific” attractions, and for a while it drew big crowds and was quite successful. To fight back, Barnum decided to attack Peale's reputation yet again.
皮尔博物馆花了数年时间才恢复元气，他们始终没有忘记巴纳姆的所作所为。皮尔先生决定反击巴纳姆，他致力于打造“高雅娱乐”的形象，并宣称自己的博物馆项目比庸俗的竞争对手更具科学性。催眠术是皮尔博物馆的“科学”项目之一，一度吸引了大量观众，取得了相当大的成功。为了反击，巴纳姆决定再次攻击皮尔的声誉。
Barnum organized a rival mesmeric performance in which he himself apparently put a little girl into a trance. Once she seemed to have fallen deeply under, he tried to hypnotize members of the audiencebut no matter how hard he tried, none of the spectators fell under his spell, and many of them began to laugh. A frustrated Barnum finally announced that to prove the little girl's trance was real, he would cut off one of her fingers
巴纳姆组织了一场与他之前的催眠表演针锋相对的演出，他亲自让一个小女孩进入了催眠状态。女孩似乎完全进入催眠状态后，他试图催眠观众，但无论他如何努力，没有一个观众被催眠，许多人反而开始大笑。沮丧的巴纳姆最终宣布，为了证明小女孩的催眠状态是真实的，他将砍掉她的一根手指。
many a sheep Who'd injured me in no respect, And even in my time been known to try Shepherd pie. If need be, then, I'll die. Yet I suspect That others also ought to own their sins. It's only fair that all should do their best To single out the guiltiest."
许多绵羊，从未伤害过我，甚至在我那个年代，它们也曾尝试过牧羊人馅饼。如果必要，我愿赴死。但我认为其他人也应该承认自己的罪过。每个人都应该尽力找出罪魁祸首，这才是公平的。
“Sire, you're too good a king,” the Fox begins; "Such scruples are too delicate. My word, To eat sheep, that profane and vulgar herd,
“陛下，您真是个好国王，”狐狸开口道，“这种顾虑太过敏感。我的天哪，吃羊，吃那些亵渎神灵、庸俗不堪的羊群，
That's sin Nay, Sire, enough for such a crew To be devoured by such as you; While of the shepherds we may say That they deserved the worst they got, Theirs being the lot that over us beasts plot A flimsy dream-begotten sway." Thus spake the Fox, and toady cheers rose high,
“陛下，这罪孽深重，足以让这样一群人被您这样的人吞噬；至于那些牧羊人，我们只能说他们罪有应得，他们注定要遭受野兽般的阴谋，妄图在我们之上建立一种脆弱的、虚幻的统治。”狐狸说完，谄媚的欢呼声响起。
While none dared cast too cold an eye On Tiger's, Bear's, and other em in en ces' Most unpardonable offences.
虽然没有人敢对老虎、熊和其他恶魔最不可饶恕的罪行冷眼相待。
Each, of never mind what currish breed, Was really a saint, they all agreed.
无论是什么品种的柯基犬，它们都确实是圣人，这一点它们一致认为。
Then came the Ass, to say: “I do recall How once 1 crossed an abbey-mead Where hunger, grass in plenty, and withal, I have no doubt, some imp of greed, Assailed me, and I shaved a tongue's-breadth wide Where frankly I'd no right to any grass. ”
然后驴子来了，说道：“我记得有一次我穿过一片修道院草地，那里饥饿难耐，青草遍地，而且，毫无疑问，还有一些贪婪的念头，它们袭击了我，我剃掉了舌头那么宽的一块草，坦白说，我根本不配吃那里的草。”
All forthwith fell full cry upon the Ass: A Wolf of some book-learning testified That that curst beast must suffer their despite, That gallskinned author of their piteous plight. They judged him fit for nought but gallows-bait: How vile, another's grass to sequestrate! His death alone could expiate A crime so heinous, as full well he learns. The court, as you're of great or poor estate, Will paint you either white or black by turns.
众人立刻对驴子群起而攻之：一头略有学问的狼作证说，这可恶的畜生必须遭受他们的唾弃，这头胆小鬼是他们悲惨境遇的罪魁祸首。他们判他死刑，只配上绞刑架：多么卑鄙，竟要夺走别人的草！他深知，只有他的死才能赎清如此滔天的罪行。法庭，无论你家境富裕还是贫穷，都会把你判为义人或罪犯。
the best fables
最好的寓言
of la fontaine,
拉方丹
Jean de La Fontaine,
让·德·拉封丹
1621-1695
witiiout her noticing. But as he sharpened die knife, die litde girl's eyes popped open and she ran away, to die audience's delight. He repeated diis and otiier parodies for several weeks. Soon no one could take Peale's show seriously, and attendance went way down. Within a few weeks, the show closed. Over the next few years Barnum established a reputation for audacity and consummate showmanship that lasted his whole life. Peale's reputation, on the otiier hand, never recovered.
她浑然不觉。但当他磨刀时，小女孩突然睁开眼睛，拔腿就跑，引得观众一片欢呼。他连续几周重复表演这个和其他一些滑稽戏。很快，没人再把皮尔的表演当回事，观众人数也大幅下降。几周之内，演出就停演了。在接下来的几年里，巴纳姆凭借其大胆的表演和精湛的技艺，建立了终身难忘的声誉。而皮尔的名声，则从此一蹶不振。
Interpretation
解释
Barnum used two different tactics to ruin Peale's reputation. The first was simple: He sowed doubts about die museum's stability and solvency. Doubt is a powerful weapon: Once you let it out of die bag with insidious rumors, your opponents are in a horrible dilemma. On the one hand they can deny the rumors, even prove diat you have slandered diem. But a layer of suspicion will remain: Why are they defending themselves so desperately Maybe die rumor has some trudi to it If, on die otiier hand, tiiey take the high road and ignore you, die doubts, unrefuted, will be even stronger. If done correctiy, the sowing of rumors can so infuriate and unsettle your rivals that in defending tiiemselves they will make numerous mistakes. This is die perfect weapon for those who have no reputation of their own to work from.
巴纳姆用了两种不同的策略来败坏皮尔的名声。第一种很简单：他散布关于博物馆稳定性和偿付能力的怀疑。怀疑是一种强大的武器：一旦你用阴险的谣言散布它，你的对手就会陷入进退两难的境地。一方面，他们可以否认谣言，甚至证明你诽谤了他们。但一层疑虑会一直存在：他们为什么如此拼命地为自己辩护？也许谣言里有些许真相。另一方面，如果他们选择置之不理，不予理睬，那么这些未经反驳的怀疑反而会更加根深蒂固。如果运用得当，散布谣言可以激怒并动摇你的对手，使他们在为自己辩护时犯下诸多错误。对于那些自身声誉不佳的人来说，这无疑是完美的武器。
Once Barnum did have a reputation of his own, he used die second, gender tactic, the fake hypnotism demonstration: He ridiculed his rivals' reputation. This too was extremely successful. Once you have a solid base of respect, ridiculing your opponent botii puts him on die defensive and draws more attention to you, enhancing your own reputation. Outright slander and insult are too strong at diis point; tiiey are ugly, and may hurt you more tiian help you. But gentie barbs and mockery suggest that you have a strong enough sense of your own worth to enjoy a good laugh at your rival's expense. A humorous front can make you out as a harmless entertainer while poking holes in die reputation of your rival.
巴纳姆一旦建立起自己的名声，便采用了第二种策略——性别策略，即伪催眠术表演：他嘲讽竞争对手的名声。这一策略也极其成功。一旦你拥有了稳固的尊重基础，嘲讽对手就能让他陷入被动，并吸引更多人关注你，从而提升你自身的声誉。此时，直接的诽谤和侮辱过于激烈；它们丑陋不堪，而且可能弊大于利。但温和的讽刺和嘲弄表明你对自己足够自信，能够以对手的失败为乐。幽默的外表可以让你看起来像个无害的娱乐者，同时又能巧妙地揭穿对手的谎言。
It is easier to cope with a bad conscience than with a bad reputation.
良心不安总比名誉受损容易忍受。
Friedrich Nietzsche, 1844-1900
弗里德里希·尼采，1844-1900 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The people around us, even our closest friends, will always to some extent remain mysterious and unfathomable. Their characters have secret recesses that they never reveal. The unknowableness of other people could prove disturbing if we thought about it long enough, since it would make it impossible for us really to judge otiier people. So we prefer to ignore this fact, and to judge people on their appearances, on what is most visible to our eyesclotiies, gestures, words, actions. In the social realm, appearances are die barometer of almost all of our judgments, and you must never be misled into believing otiierwise. One false slip, one awkward or sudden change in your appearance, can prove disastrous.
我们身边的人，即使是最亲密的朋友，在某种程度上也总是神秘莫测、难以捉摸。他们的性格中隐藏着不为人知的秘密，他们永远不会轻易示人。如果我们仔细思考，这种他人不可知的特质可能会令人不安，因为它使我们无法真正地评判他人。因此，我们宁愿忽略这一事实，转而根据外表，根据我们最容易看到的东西——衣着、举止、言语和行为——来评判他人。在社交领域，外表几乎是我们所有判断的晴雨表，你绝不能被误导，相信其他说法。一个小小的失误，一次尴尬或突如其来的外表变化，都可能带来灾难性的后果。
This is the reason for the supreme importance of making and maintaining a reputation that is of your own creation.
这就是为什么建立和维护属于你自己的声誉至关重要的原因。
That reputation will protect you in the dangerous game of appearances, distracting the probing eyes of others from knowing what you are really like, and giving you a degree of control over how the world judges youa powerful position to be in. Reputation has a power like magic: Widi one stroke of its wand, it can double your strengtfi. It can also send people scurrying away from you. Whether the exact same deeds appear brilliant or dreadful can depend entirely on the reputation of the doer.
在充满危险的“表象游戏”中，声誉能保护你，使他人无法窥探你的真实面目，并让你在一定程度上掌控世人对你的看法——这无疑是一种强大的力量。声誉如同魔法一般：只需轻轻一挥，就能让你的力量倍增；也能让人避之不及。同样的行为，在他人眼中是光彩夺目还是丑陋不堪，完全取决于行为者的声誉。
In the ancient Chinese court of the Wei kingdom there was a man named Mi Tzu-hsia who had a reputation for supreme civility and gracious-ness. He became the ruler's favorite. It was a law in Wei that “whoever rides secretly in the ruler's coach shall have his feet cut off,” but when Mi Tzu-hsia's mother fell ill, he used the royal coach to visit her, pretending that the ruler had given him permission. When the ruler found out, he said, “How dutiful is Mi Tzu-hsia! For his mother's sake he even forgot that he was committing a crime making him liable to lose his feet!”
在中国古代魏国的朝廷里，有一位名叫米子夏的男子，他以彬彬有礼、温文尔雅而闻名，深受君主宠爱。魏国有一条法律，禁止“偷乘君主马车者砍脚”，但米子夏的母亲生病时，他却乘坐御马去探望，并谎称得到了君主的许可。君主得知真相后，说道：“米子夏真是孝顺！为了母亲，他甚至忘记了自己犯了断脚之罪！”
Another time the two of them took a stroll in an orchard. Mi Tzu-hsia began eating a peach that he could not finish, and he gave the ruler die other half to eat. The ruler remarked, “You love me so much mat you would even forget your own saliva taste and let me eat the rest of the peach!”
还有一次，两人在果园里散步。米子夏吃了一个桃子，吃不完，就把剩下的一半给了君主。君主说：“你爱我爱到连自己的口水味都忘了，让我把剩下的桃子都吃完！”
Later, however, envious fellow courtiers, spreading word that Mi Tzu-hsia was actually devious and arrogant, succeeded in damaging his reputation; the ruler came to see his actions in a new light. “This fellow once rode in my coach under pretense of my order,” he told the courtiers angrily, “and another time he gave me a half-eaten peach.” For the same actions that had charmed the ruler when he was the favorite, Mi Tzu-hsia now had to suffer the penalties. The fate of his feet depended solely on the strength of his reputation.
然而，后来心怀嫉妒的朝臣散布谣言，说米子夏其实诡计多端、傲慢自大，成功地败坏了他的名声；君主这才重新审视了自己的所作所为。“这家伙曾假借我的命令乘坐我的马车，”他怒气冲冲地对朝臣们说，“还有一次，他给了我一个吃了一半的桃子。”米子夏曾经受宠时，正是这些举动让他赢得了君主的喜爱，如今却要为此付出代价。他的命运完全取决于他的名声。
In the beginning, you must work to establish a reputation for one outstanding quality, whether generosity or honesty or cunning. This quality sets you apart and gets other people to talk about you. You then make your reputation known to as many people as possible (subtly, though; take care to build slowly, and widi a firm foundation), and watch as it spreads like wildfire.
一开始，你必须努力树立一项杰出品质的声誉，无论是慷慨、诚实还是机敏。这项品质会让你脱颖而出，并引发人们对你的谈论。然后，你要尽可能地让更多人知道你的声誉（但要巧妙地；务必循序渐进，打好坚实的基础），并看着它像野火一样迅速传播开来。
A solid reputation increases your presence and exaggerates your strengths without your having to spend much energy. It can also create an aura around you that will instill respect, even fear. In the fighting in the North African desert during World War II, the German general Erwin Rommel had a reputation for cunning and for deceptive maneuvering that struck terror into everyone who faced him. Even when his forces were depleted, and when British tanks outnumbered his by five to one, entire cities would be evacuated at the news of his approach.
良好的声誉能提升你的影响力，无需耗费太多精力就能放大你的优势。它还能在你周围营造一种威慑力，使人敬畏，甚至恐惧。二战期间，在北非沙漠的战斗中，德国将军埃尔温·隆美尔以其狡诈和诡计多端的战术而闻名，令所有与他交战的人都胆寒。即使他的部队已经精疲力竭，英军的坦克数量是他的五倍，只要隆美尔逼近的消息传来，整座城市都会被疏散。
As they say, your reputation inevitably precedes you, and if it inspires respect, a lot of your work is done for you before you arrive on the scene, or utter a single word.
正如人们常说的，你的名声总会先于你而来；如果你赢得了尊重，那么在你出现之前，甚至在你开口说话之前，很多工作就已经为你完成了。
Your success seems destined by your past triumphs. Much of the sue-
你的成功似乎注定由你过去的辉煌成就所铸就。许多诉讼——
cess of Henry Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy rested on his reputation for ironing out differences; no one wanted to be seen as so unreasonable that Kissinger could not sway him. A peace treaty seemed a fait accompli as soon as Kissinger's name became involved in the negotiations.
亨利·基辛格的穿梭外交之所以成功，是因为他以善于化解分歧而闻名；没有人愿意被视为如此不讲道理，以至于基辛格都无法说服自己。只要基辛格的名字出现在谈判中，和平条约似乎就已成定局。
Make your reputation simple and base it on one sterling quality. This single qualityefficiency, say, or seductivenessbecomes a kind of calling card that announces your presence and places others under a spell. A reputation for honesty will allow you to practice all manner of deception. Casanova used his reputation as a great seducer to pave die way for his future conquests; women who had heard of his powers became immensely curious, and wanted to discover for memselves what had made him so romantically successful.
让你的名声简单明了，并建立在一个卓越的品质之上。这个单一的品质——比如高效或魅力——就像一张名片，宣告你的存在，并让别人为之倾倒。诚实的名声会让你可以施展各种各样的欺骗手段。卡萨诺瓦利用他作为情圣的名声为他未来的征服铺平了道路；那些听闻他风流韵事的女人都充满了好奇，想要亲自探寻他如此风流成性的秘诀。
Perhaps you have already stained your reputation, so that you are prevented from establishing a new one. In such cases it is wise to associate with someone whose image counteracts your own, using dieir good name to whitewash and elevate yours. It is hard, for example, to erase a reputation for dishonesty by yourself; but a paragon of honesty can help. When P. T. Barnum wanted to clean up a reputation for promoting vulgar entertainment, he brought the singer Jenny Lind over from Europe. She had a stellar, high-class reputation, and die American tour Barnum sponsored for her gready enhanced his own image. Similarly the great robber barons of nineteendi-century America were long unable to rid diemselves of a reputation for cruelty and mean-spiritedness. Only when tiiey began collecting art, so that the names of Morgan and Frick became permanendy associated with tiiose of da Vinci and Rembrandt, were they able to soften dieir unpleasant image.
或许你已经名誉受损，以至于无法重塑形象。在这种情况下，明智的做法是与形象与你截然相反的人交往，利用他们的良好声誉来洗白和提升自己的名声。例如，靠自己很难消除不诚实的名声；但一位诚实的典范可以助你一臂之力。当P·T·巴纳姆想要洗刷他推广低俗娱乐的恶名时，他从欧洲请来了歌手珍妮·林德。她拥有卓越的声誉，巴纳姆赞助她在美国巡演，也提升了他自己的形象。同样，19世纪美国的那些大盗大亨们长期以来都无法摆脱残忍和卑鄙的名声。只有当他们开始收藏艺术品，以至于摩根和弗里克的名字与达·芬奇和伦勃朗等人的作品永久联系在一起时，他们才得以缓和自己不光彩的形象。
Reputation is a treasure to be carefully collected and hoarded. Especially when you are first establishing it, you must protect it strictiy, anticipating all attacks on it. Once it is solid, do not let yourself get angry or defensive at the slanderous comments of your enemiestiiat reveals insecurity, not confidence in your reputation. Take die high road instead, and never appear desperate in your self-defense. On die other hand, an attack on another man's reputation is a potent weapon, particularly when you have less power than he does. He has much more to lose in such a battie, and your own thus-far-small reputation gives him a small target when he tries to return your fire. Barnum used such campaigns to great effect in his early career. But this tactic must be practiced with skill; you must not seem to engage in petty vengeance. If you do not break your enemy's reputation cleverly, you will inadvertentiy ruin your own.
名誉是一笔需要精心收集和珍藏的财富。尤其是在初建之时，更要严加守护，预先防范一切攻击。一旦名誉稳固，面对敌人的诽谤，切勿愤怒或辩解——这只会暴露你的不安全感，而非对自身名誉的自信。相反，要保持风度，切勿在自卫时显得孤注一掷。另一方面，攻击他人的名誉也是一种强有力的武器，尤其是在你实力不如对方的情况下。在这种争斗中，对方的损失更大，而你自身目前尚不显赫的名誉，在他试图反击时，目标也相对较小。巴纳姆在其职业生涯早期就曾巧妙地运用过这种策略，并取得了显著成效。但这种策略必须运用技巧；切忌显得是在进行卑劣的报复。如果你不能巧妙地摧毁敌人的名誉，最终也会在无意中毁掉自己的名誉。
Thomas Edison, considered the inventor who harnessed electricity, believed that a workable system would have to be based on direct current (DC). When the Serbian scientist Nikola Tesla appeared to have succeeded in creating a system based on alternating current (AC), Edison was furious. He determined to ruin Tesla's reputation, by making the public believe tiiat die AC system was inherendy unsafe, and Tesla irresponsible in promoting it.
托马斯·爱迪生被认为是驾驭电力的发明家，他认为一个可行的电力系统必须基于直流电（DC）。当塞尔维亚科学家尼古拉·特斯拉似乎成功研制出基于交流电（AC）的系统时，爱迪生勃然大怒。他决心败坏特斯拉的名声，散布谣言，声称交流电系统本身就不安全，并指责特斯拉推广交流电系统是不负责任的。
To this end he captured all kinds of household pets and electrocuted
为此，他捕捉了各种家养宠物，并用电击处死它们。
them to death with an AC current. When this wasn't enough, in 1890 he got New York State prison authorities to organize die world's first execution by electrocution, using an AC current. But Edison's electrocution experiments had all been widi small creatures; the charge was too weak, and the man was only half killed. In perhaps die country's crudest state-authorized execution, the procedure had to be repeated. It was an awful spectacle.
用交流电将他们电死。当这还不够时，1890年，他促使纽约州监狱当局组织了世界上首次使用交流电执行死刑。但爱迪生的电刑实验对象都是小型动物；电流太弱，行刑者只被电死了一半。这或许是美国历史上最粗糙的官方死刑，行刑程序不得不重复进行。那是一场惨绝人寰的景象。
Although, in the long run, it is Edison's name that has survived, at die time his campaign damaged his own reputation more than Tesla's. He backed off. The lesson is simplenever go too far in attacks like these, for that will draw more attention to your own vengefulness than to the person you are slandering. When your own reputation is solid, use subtler tactics, such as satire and ridicule, to weaken your opponent while making you out as a charming rogue. The mighty lion toys widi die mouse that crosses his pathany otiier reaction would mar his fearsome reputation.
虽然最终爱迪生的名字流传了下来，但当时他的攻击对自身声誉的损害远大于对特斯拉的损害。他最终退缩了。教训很简单：在类似的攻击中切勿过火，否则只会让人们更加关注你的报复心，而不是你诽谤的对象。当你的声誉稳固时，要运用更巧妙的策略，例如讽刺和嘲弄，来削弱对手，同时将自己塑造成一个魅力十足的“恶棍”。就像威猛的狮子戏弄挡路的老鼠一样，任何其他反应都会损害它令人畏惧的威名。
Image".
图像”。
A Mine Full of
一座满是……的矿井
Diamonds and Rubies.
钻石和红宝石。
You dug for it, you found it,
你挖了它，你找到了它。
and your wealth is now assured.
你的财富从此有了保障。
Guard it with your life. Robbers and thieves
用生命守护它。强盗和小偷
will appear from all sides. Never take your wealth
它会从四面八方出现。永远不要拿走你的财富。
for granted, and constantly renew ittime
理所当然，并且不断更新它的时间
will diminish the jewels' luster,
会削弱珠宝的光泽，
and bury them from sight.
并将它们埋葬在人们看不见的地方。
Authority: Therefore I should wish our courtier to bolster up his inherent worth with skill and cunning, and ensure that whenever he has to go where he is a stranger, he is preceded by a good reputation. . . . For the fame which appears to rest on the opinions of many fosters a certain unshakable belief in a man's worth which is then easily strengthened in minds already thus disposed and prepared. (Baldassare Castiglione, 1478-1529)
权威：因此，我希望我们的廷臣能以技巧和谋略来提升自身的价值，并确保无论何时前往陌生之地，都能凭借良好的声誉赢得赞誉……因为建立在众人评价之上的名声，会助长人们对一个人价值的坚定信念，而这种信念在那些早已抱有这种观念的人心中，更容易得到强化。（巴尔达萨雷·卡斯蒂廖内，1478-1529）
REVERSAL
逆转
There is no possible Reversal. Reputation is critical; there are no exceptions to this law. Perhaps, not caring what others think of you, you gain a reputation for insolence and arrogance, but that can be a valuable image in itselfOscar Wilde used it to great advantage. Since we must live in society and must depend on the opinions of others, there is nothing to be gained by neglecting your reputation. By not caring how you are perceived, you let others decide this for you. Be the master of your fate, and also of your reputation.
覆水难收。名誉至关重要，这条法则没有例外。或许，不在乎别人怎么看你，会让你落得傲慢无礼的名声，但这本身也可以成为一种宝贵的形象——奥斯卡·王尔德就曾巧妙地运用过这一点。既然我们生活在社会中，不得不依赖他人的评价，那么忽视名誉就毫无益处。不在乎别人如何看待你，就等于让别人替你做决定。要掌控自己的命运，也要掌控自己的名誉。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 6
法律 6
COURT ATTENTION AT ALL COST
务必引起法庭注意
JUDGMENT
判断
Everything is judged by its appearance; what is unseen counts for nothing. Never let yourself get lost in the crowd, then, or buried in oblivion. Stand out. Be conspicuous, at all cost. Make yourself a magnet of attention by appearing larger, more colorful, more mysterious than the bland and timid masses.
一切都以貌取人；看不见的东西毫无价值。所以，千万不要让自己淹没在人群中，或被遗忘。要脱颖而出，不惜一切代价引人注目。让自己比那些平庸胆怯的人群更加高大、更加耀眼、更加神秘，成为众人瞩目的焦点。
PART I: SURROUND YOUR NAME WITH THE SENSATIONAL AND SCANDALOUS
第一部分：用耸人听闻和丑闻来包装你的名字
Draw attention to yourself by creating an unforgettable, even controversial image. Court scandal. Do anything to make yourself seem larger than life and shine more brightly than those around you. Make no distinction between kinds of attentionnotoriety of any sort will bring you power. Better to be slandered and attacked than ignored.
打造令人难忘甚至引发争议的形象，以此吸引眼球。制造丑闻。不择手段地让自己显得光芒四射，比周围的人更加耀眼。不要区分各种形式的关注——任何形式的恶名都能为你带来权力。与其被人忽视，不如被人诽谤和攻击。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
P. T. Barnum, America's premier nineteenth-century showman, started his career as an assistant to the owner of a circus, Aaron Turner. In 1836 die circus stopped in Annapolis, Maryland, for a series of performances. On the morning of opening day, Barnum took a stroll through town, wearing a new black suit. People started to follow him. Someone in the gathering crowd shouted out that he was the Reverend Ephraim K. Avery, infamous as a man acquitted of the charge of murder but still believed guilty by most Americans. The angry mob tore off Barnum's suit and was ready to lynch him. After desperate appeals, Barnum finally convinced them to follow him to the circus, where he could verify his identity.
P·T·巴纳姆，美国十九世纪首屈一指的表演家，他的职业生涯始于担任马戏团老板亚伦·特纳的助手。1836年，马戏团在马里兰州安纳波利斯进行一系列演出。开幕当天早上，巴纳姆身着一套崭新的黑色西装在镇上漫步。人们开始尾随他。人群中有人高喊，他是埃弗雷姆·K·艾弗里牧师，此人因被判无罪释放而臭名昭著，但大多数美国人仍然认为他有罪。愤怒的暴民撕破了巴纳姆的西装，准备将他私刑处死。经过一番苦苦哀求，巴纳姆最终说服他们跟随他前往马戏团，在那里他可以证明自己的身份。
Once there, old Turner confirmed that this was all a practical jokehe himself had spread the rumor that Barnum was Avery. The crowd dispersed, but Barnum, who had nearly been killed, was not amused. He wanted to know what could have induced his boss to play such a trick. “My dear Mr. Barnum,” Turner replied, “it was all for our good. Remember, all we need to ensure success is notoriety.” And indeed everyone in town was talking about the joke, and the circus was packed that night and every night it stayed in Annapolis. Barnum had learned a lesson he would never forget.
到了那里，老特纳证实这一切都是个恶作剧——是他自己散布的谣言，说巴纳姆就是艾弗里。人群散去，但差点丧命的巴纳姆却一点也笑不出来。他想知道是什么让他的老板开了这个玩笑。“亲爱的巴纳姆先生，”特纳回答说，“这一切都是为了我们好。记住，我们要想成功，只需要出名。”果然，镇上每个人都在谈论这个玩笑，马戏团当晚座无虚席，而且之后每晚都在安纳波利斯演出。巴纳姆吸取了一个他永远不会忘记的教训。
Barnum's first big venture of his own was the American Museuma collection of curiosities, located in New York. One day a beggar approached Barnum in die street. Instead of giving him money, Barnum decided to employ him. Taking him back to the museum, he gave die man five bricks and told him to make a slow circuit of several blocks. At certain points he was to lay down a brick on the sidewalk, always keeping one brick in hand. On the return journey he was to replace each brick on the street with the one he held. Meanwhile he was to remain serious of countenance and to answer no questions. Once back at the museum, he was to enter, walk around inside, then leave dirough the back door and make the same bricklaying circuit again.
巴纳姆的第一个大型项目是位于纽约的美国博物馆，一个收藏奇珍异宝的博物馆。一天，一个乞丐在街上拦住了巴纳姆。巴纳姆没有给他钱，而是决定雇用他。他把乞丐带回博物馆，给了他五块砖，让他慢慢地绕几个街区走一圈。每到一个地方，他都要在人行道上放一块砖，手里始终要拿着一块。回来的时候，他要把街上每块砖都换成手里拿着的那块。期间，他必须保持严肃的表情，不能回答任何问题。回到博物馆后，他要进去走一圈，然后从后门出来，再重复一遍刚才的砌砖路线。
On the man's first walk through the streets, several hundred people watched his mysterious movements. By his fourth circuit, onlookers swarmed around him, debating what he was doing. Every time he entered the museum he was followed by people who bought tickets to keep watching him. Many of diem were distracted by the museum's collections, and stayed inside. By the end of the first day, the brick man had drawn over a
男子第一次走上街头时，数百人注视着他神秘的举动。到了第四圈，围观者蜂拥而至，议论纷纷，猜测他究竟在做什么。每次他走进博物馆，都有人买票跟随，只为继续观看。许多人被博物馆的藏品吸引，留在了馆内。第一天结束时，这位砖人已经画出了一幅……
T1IK WASP AND 11 IK PKINCE
T1IK 黄蜂和 11 I PKINCE
A wasp named Pin Tail was long in quest of some deed that would make him forever famous. So one day he entered the king's palace and stung the little prince, who was in bed. The prince awoke with loud cries. The king and his courtiers rushed in to see what had happened. The prince was yelling as the wasp stung him again and again. The courtiers tried to catch the wasp, and each in turn was stung. The whole royal household rushed in, the news soon spread, and people flocked to the palace. The city was in an uproar, all business suspended. Said the wasp to itself, before it expired from its efforts, “A name without fame is like fire without flame. There is nothing like attracting notice at any cost.” Indian fable
一只名叫针尾的黄蜂一直渴望做一件能让自己名垂青史的事。一天，它闯入国王的宫殿，蛰了正在床上睡觉的小王子。王子被惊醒，发出凄厉的哭喊。国王和大臣们急忙赶来查看发生了什么事。王子一边哭喊，一边被黄蜂不停地蛰。大臣们试图抓住黄蜂，结果每个人都被蛰了一下。整个王室都跑了进来，消息很快传开，人们纷纷涌向宫殿。全城一片哗然，所有事务都停滞了。黄蜂在奄奄一息之际自言自语道：“没有名声的名声就像没有火焰的火。没有什么比不惜一切代价博取关注更重要的了。”（印度寓言）
Even when I'm railed
即使我被强奸
at, I get my quota of
我达到了我的配额。
renown.
名声。
Pihtro Arhiino. 1492-1556
皮赫特罗·阿尔基诺，1492-1556年
A work that was voluntarily presented to a prince was bound to seem in some way special. The artist himself might also try to attract the attention of the court through his behaviour. In Vasari's judgment Sodoma was “well known both for his personal eccentricities and for his reputation as a good painter.” Because Pope Leo X “found pleasure in such strange, harebrained individuals,” he made Sodoma a knight, causing the artist to go completely out of his mind. Van Mander found it odd that the products of Cornells Ketel 's experiments in mouth and foot painting were bought by notable persons “because of their oddity,” yet Ketel was only adding a variation to similar experiments by Titian, Ugo da Carpi and Talma Giovane, who, according to Boschini painted with their fingers “because they wished to imitate the method used by the Supreme Creator.” Van Mander
一幅自愿献给王子的作品必然会显得有些特殊。艺术家本人也可能试图通过自己的行为来吸引宫廷的注意。瓦萨里认为，索多玛“既以其个人怪癖闻名，也以其精湛的绘画技艺而著称”。由于教皇利奥十世“对这种古怪、异想天开的人颇感兴趣”，他册封索多玛为骑士，这令这位艺术家彻底精神失常。范·曼德觉得康奈尔斯·凯特尔用嘴和脚作画的实验成果之所以被名人购买，是因为“它们很奇特”，这很奇怪。然而，凯特尔只不过是在提香、乌戈·达·卡尔皮和塔尔玛·乔瓦内等人的类似实验的基础上进行了一种变体而已。根据博斯基尼的说法，这些人用手指作画“是因为他们想模仿至高无上的造物主所使用的方法”。
thousand people into the museum. A few days later die police ordered him to cease and desist from his walksthe crowds were blocking traffic. The bricklaying stopped but thousands of New Yorkers had entered the museum, and many of those had become P. T. Barnum converts.
成千上万的人涌入博物馆。几天后，警方勒令他停止巡游，因为人群已经堵塞了交通。砌砖工作停止了，但成千上万的纽约市民已经进入博物馆，其中许多人成为了P·T·巴纳姆的拥趸。
Barnum would put a band of musicians on a balcony overlooking the street, beneath a huge banner proclaiming FREE music for the millions. What generosity, New Yorkers thought, and they flocked to hear the free concerts. But Barnum took pains to hire the worst musicians he could find, and soon after the band struck up, people would hurry to buy tickets to the museum, where they would be out of earshot of the band's noise, and of the booing of the crowd.
巴纳姆会安排一支乐队在俯瞰街道的阳台上演奏，阳台上挂着一条巨大的横幅，上面写着“为数百万民众提供免费音乐”。纽约人觉得这真是慷慨，纷纷涌向这些免费音乐会。但巴纳姆却煞费苦心地雇佣他能找到的最差劲的乐手，乐队刚一奏响，人们就争先恐后地去买博物馆的门票，因为在那里他们既听不到乐队的喧闹声，也听不到人群的嘘声。
One of the first oddities Bamum toured around the country was Joice Heth, a woman he claimed was 161 years old, and whom he advertised as a slave who had once been George Washington's nurse. After several months the crowds began to dwindle, so Barnum sent an anonymous letter to the papers, claiming that Heth was a clever fraud. ^Joice Heth,“ he wrote, ”is not a human being but an automaton, made up of whalebone, india-rubber, and numberless springs." Those who had not bothered to see her before were immediately curious, and those who had already seen her paid to see her again, to find out whether the rumor that she was a robot was true.
巴纳姆巡回全国的首批奇人之一是乔伊斯·赫斯，他声称她已经161岁了，并宣传她曾是乔治·华盛顿的护士，也是一名奴隶。几个月后，参观的人开始减少，于是巴纳姆匿名给报社写信，声称赫斯是个狡猾的骗子。“乔伊斯·赫斯，”他写道，“不是人，而是一个由鲸骨、橡胶和无数弹簧组成的自动装置。” 那些之前没看过她的人立刻感到好奇，而那些已经看过她的人则花钱再次观看，想看看她是不是真的机器人。
In 1842, Barnum purchased the carcass of what was purported to be a mermaid. This creature resembled a monkey with the body of a fish, but the head and body were perfecdy joinedit was truly a wonder. After some research Barnum discovered that die creature had been experdy put together in Japan, where the hoax had caused quite a stir.
1842年，巴纳姆买下了一具据称是美人鱼的尸体。这具尸体长得像猴子，身体却像鱼，但头和身体却完美地结合在一起——真是个奇迹。经过一番调查，巴纳姆发现这具尸体是在日本被匆匆拼凑起来的，而这个骗局在日本曾引起不小的轰动。
He nevertheless planted articles in newspapers around the country claiming the capture of a mermaid in the Fiji Islands. He also sent the papers woodcut prints of paintings showing mermaids. By the time he showed the specimen in his museum, a national debate had been sparked over the existence of these mythical creatures. A few months before Barnum's campaign, no one had cared or even known about mermaids; now everyone was talking about them as if they were real. Crowds flocked in record numbers to see the Fiji Mermaid, and to hear debates on the subject.
尽管如此，他还是在全国各地的报纸上刊登文章，声称在斐济群岛捕获了一条美人鱼。他还向报社寄送了描绘美人鱼的木刻版画。等到他在博物馆展出这条“美人鱼”时，一场关于这种神话生物是否存在的全国性辩论已经爆发。在巴纳姆发起这场宣传活动的几个月前，没有人关心甚至听说过美人鱼；而现在，每个人都在谈论它们，仿佛它们真的存在一样。蜂拥而至的人群数量创下了纪录，他们都想一睹“斐济美人鱼”的风采，并聆听关于这个话题的辩论。
A few years later, Barnum toured Europe with General Tom Thumb, a five-year-old dwarf from Connecticut whom Barnum claimed was an eleven-year-old English boy, and whom he had trained to do many remarkable acts. During this tour Barnum's name attracted such attention that Queen Victoria, that paragon of sobriety, requested a private audience with him and his talented dwarf at Buckingham Palace. The English press may have ridiculed Barnum, but Victoria was royally entertained by him, and respected him ever after.
几年后，巴纳姆带着汤姆·拇指将军——一个来自康涅狄格州的五岁侏儒——巡演欧洲。巴纳姆声称汤姆·拇指是一个十一岁的英国男孩，并训练他表演了许多精彩绝伦的节目。巡演期间，巴纳姆的名声大噪，就连一向以严谨著称的维多利亚女王也要求在白金汉宫与他和他的天才侏儒进行私人会面。尽管英国媒体对巴纳姆冷嘲热讽，但维多利亚女王却受到了女王的盛情款待，并从此对他十分敬重。
Interpretation
解释
Barnum understood the fundamental truth about attracting attention:
巴纳姆明白吸引注意力的基本道理：
Once people's eyes are on you, you have a special legitimacy. For Barnum,
一旦人们的目光聚焦在你身上，你就拥有了一种特殊的合法性。对巴纳姆来说，
creating interest meant creating a crowd; as he later wrote, “Every crowd has a silver lining.” And crowds tend to act in conjunction. If one person stops to see your beggarman laying bricks in the street, more will do the same. They will gather like dust bunnies. Then, given a gentle push, they will enter your museum or watch your show. To create a crowd you have to do sometiiing different and odd. Any kind of curiosity will serve the purpose, for crowds are magnetically attracted by the unusual and inexplicable. And once you have their attention, never let it go. If it veers toward other people, it does so at your expense. Barnum would ruthlessly suck attention from his competitors, knowing what a valuable commodity it is.
制造兴趣意味着吸引人群；正如他后来所写，“任何人群都有其闪光点。”而且人群往往会协同行动。如果一个人停下来观看你的乞丐在街上砌砖，就会有更多的人效仿。他们会像灰尘一样聚集起来。然后，只要轻轻一推，他们就会走进你的博物馆或观看你的表演。要吸引人群，你必须做一些与众不同、不同寻常的事情。任何形式的好奇心都能达到目的，因为人群会被不寻常和难以解释的事物深深吸引。一旦你吸引了他们的注意力，就千万不要放手。如果注意力转移到其他人身上，那将是以你的损失为代价的。巴纳姆深知注意力的宝贵价值，因此他会毫不留情地从竞争对手那里夺走它。
At the beginning of your rise to the top, then, spend all your energy on attracting attention. Most important: The quality of the attention is irrelevant. No matter how badly his shows were reviewed, or how slanderously personal were the attacks on his hoaxes, Barnum would never complain. If a newspaper critic reviled him particularly badly, in fact, he made sure to invite the man to an opening and to give him the best seat in the house. He would even write anonymous attacks on his own work, just to keep his name in the papers. From Barnum's vantage, attentionwhether negative or positivewas the main ingredient of his success. The worst fate in the world for a man who yearns fame, glory, and, of course, power is to be ignored.
因此，在你攀登事业巅峰之初，务必将所有精力都投入到吸引关注上。最重要的是：关注的质量无关紧要。无论他的演出评价多么糟糕，或者针对他骗局的攻击多么恶毒，巴纳姆都从不抱怨。事实上，如果某个报纸评论家对他恶语相向，他反而会邀请此人参加首演，并安排他坐在最好的位置。他甚至会匿名撰写文章攻击自己的作品，只为让自己的名字出现在报纸上。在巴纳姆看来，关注——无论是正面的还是负面的——都是他成功的关键因素。对于一个渴望名利、荣耀，当然还有权力的人来说，世界上最糟糕的命运莫过于被人忽视。
reports that Gossaert attracted the attention of Emperor Charles V by wearing a fantastic paper costume. In doing so he was adopting the tactics used by Dinocrates, who, in order to gain access to Alexander the Great, is said to have appeared disguised as the naked Hercules when the monarch was sitting in judgment.
据报道，戈萨特身着一套奇特的纸质服装，吸引了查理五世皇帝的注意。他此举效仿了迪诺克拉底的策略。据说，迪诺克拉底为了接近亚历山大大帝，曾在君主审判时乔装成裸体的赫拉克勒斯出现。
the court artist, Martin Warnke. 1993
宫廷画家马丁·沃恩克。1993年
If the courtier happens to engage in arms in some public spectacle
如果朝臣碰巧在公开场合动用武力
such as jousting. . . he will ensure that the horse he has is beautifully
例如马上长矛比武……他会确保他拥有的马匹非常漂亮。
caparisoned, that he himself is suitably attired, with appropriate
盛装打扮，他本人也穿着得体，佩戴合适的饰品
mottoes and ingenious devices to attract the eyes of the onlookers
吸引旁观者目光的标语和巧妙设计
in his direction as surely as the lodestone attracts iron.
就像磁石吸引铁一样，他必定会朝着那个方向前进。
Baldassare Castiglione., 1478-1529
巴尔达萨·郎世宁，1478-1529 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Burning more brighdy than those around you is a skill that no one is born with. You have to learn to attract attention, “as surely as the lodestone attracts iron.” At the start of your career, you must attach your name and reputation to a quality, an image, that sets you apart from other people. This image can be something like a characteristic style of dress, or a personality quirk that amuses people and gets talked about. Once the image is established, you have an appearance, a place in the sky for your star.
比周围的人更耀眼夺目并非与生俱来。你必须学会吸引眼球，“就像磁石吸引铁一样”。在职业生涯初期，你必须将自己的名字和声誉与某种特质、某种形象联系起来，使你脱颖而出。这种形象可以是独特的着装风格，也可以是能逗人发笑、引人津津乐道的个性怪癖。一旦形象确立，你就拥有了属于自己的独特风采，如同天上的一颗璀璨明星。
It is a common mistake to imagine that this peculiar appearance of yours should not be controversial, mat to be attacked is somehow bad. Nothing could be further from the truth. To avoid being a flash in the pan, and having your notoriety eclipsed by another, you must not discriminate between different types of attention; in the end, every kind will work in your favor. Barnum, we have seen, welcomed personal attacks and felt no need to defend himself. He deliberately courted the image of being a humbug.
认为你这种奇特的外表不应该引起争议，被攻击反而是件坏事，这是一种常见的误解。事实远非如此。为了避免昙花一现，你的名声被他人掩盖，你不应该区别对待不同类型的关注；最终，每一种关注都会对你有利。我们看到，巴纳姆欣然接受人身攻击，并且觉得没有必要为自己辩护。他刻意营造了一种骗子的形象。
The court of Louis XIV contained many talented writers, artists, great beauties, and men and women of impeccable virtue, but no one was more talked about than the singular Due de Lauzun. The duke was short, almost dwarfish, and he was prone to the most insolent kinds of behaviorhe slept with the king's mistress, and openly insulted not only other courtiers but the king himself. Louis, however, was so beguiled by the duke's eccentricities that he could not bear his absences from the court. It was simple: The strangeness of the duke's character attracted attention. Once people were enthralled by him, they wanted him around at any cost.
路易十四的宫廷里人才济济，作家、艺术家、绝世佳人以及品德高尚的男女云集，但最引人注目的莫过于那位特立独行的洛赞公爵。这位公爵身材矮小，几乎像个侏儒，而且行为极其傲慢无礼——他与国王的情妇有染，不仅公开侮辱其他朝臣，甚至连国王本人也不放过。然而，路易十四却被公爵的古怪性格深深吸引，以至于无法忍受他离开宫廷。原因很简单：公爵的奇特个性引人注目。一旦人们被他迷住，便会不惜一切代价也要让他留在身边。
Society craves larger-dian-life figures, people who stand above the general mediocrity. Never be afraid, then, of the qualities that set you apart and draw attention to you. Court controversy, even scandal. It is better to be attacked, even slandered, than ignored. All professions are ruled by diis law, and all professionals must have a bit of the showman about diem.
社会渴望那些特立独行、卓尔不群的人物，那些超越平庸之辈。因此，永远不要害怕那些让你与众不同、引人注目的特质。要敢于制造争议，甚至丑闻。被攻击，甚至被诽谤，总比被忽视要好。所有行业都受此法则约束，所有专业人士都必须具备一定的表演天赋。
The great scientist Thomas Edison knew that to raise money he had to remain in die public eye at any cost. Almost as important as die inventions diemselves was how he presented diem to the public and courted attention.
伟大的科学家托马斯·爱迪生深知，为了筹集资金，他必须不惜一切代价保持公众关注度。几乎与他的发明本身同等重要的是，他如何向公众展示这些发明并博取关注。
Edison would design visually dazzling experiments to display his discoveries widi electricity. He would talk of future inventions mat seemed fantastic at the timerobots, and machines that could photograph thoughtand that he had no intention of wasting his energy on, but tiiat made the public talk about him. He did everything he could to make sure diat he received more attention than his great rival Nikola Tesla, who may actually have been more brilliant tiian he was but whose name was far less known. In 1915, it was rumored that Edison and Tesla would be joint recipients of mat year's Nobel Prize in physics. The prize was eventually given to a pair of English physicists; only later was it discovered mat die prize committee had actually approached Edison, but he had turned tiiem down, refusing to share the prize widi Tesla. By that time his fame was more secure than Tesla's, and he thought it better to refuse the honor than to allow his rival die attention that would have come even from sharing die prize.
爱迪生会设计一些视觉效果惊艳的实验来展示他在电学方面的发现。他会谈论一些当时看来天马行空的未来发明——机器人、能拍摄思想的机器等等，虽然他并不打算把精力浪费在这些发明上，但这却让公众对他议论纷纷。他竭尽所能确保自己比伟大的竞争对手尼古拉·特斯拉获得更多关注。特斯拉或许比他更有才华，但他的名气却远不如爱迪生。1915年，曾有传言说爱迪生和特斯拉将共同获得当年的诺贝尔物理学奖。最终，该奖项颁给了两位英国物理学家；后来人们才发现，诺贝尔奖委员会实际上曾联系过爱迪生，但他拒绝了，不愿与特斯拉分享奖项。那时，爱迪生的名声已经比特斯拉稳固得多，他认为与其让竞争对手获得哪怕是分享奖项所带来的关注，不如拒绝这份荣誉。
If you find yourself in a lowly position tiiat offers little opportunity for you to draw attention, an effective trick is to attack die most visible, most famous, most powerful person you can find. When Pietro Aretino, a young Roman servant boy of die early sixteenth century, wanted to get attention as a writer of verses, he decided to publish a series of satirical poems ridiculing die pope and his affection for a pet elephant. The attack put Aretino in the public eye immediately. A slanderous attack on a person in a position of power would have a similar effect. Remember, however, to use such tactics sparingly after you have die public's attention, when die act can wear thin.
如果你身处卑微地位，几乎没有机会引人注目，一个有效的策略就是攻击你能找到的最显眼、最有名、最有权势的人。十六世纪初，年轻的罗马仆人皮埃特罗·阿雷蒂诺（Pietro Aretino）为了以诗人的身份获得关注，决定发表一系列讽刺诗，嘲讽教皇及其对宠物象的喜爱。这一举动使阿雷蒂诺迅速成为公众关注的焦点。对身居要职者进行诽谤攻击也能产生类似的效果。然而，请记住，在获得公众关注之后，应谨慎使用此类策略，因为此时这种伎俩的效果会逐渐减弱。
Once in the limelight you must constantiy renew it by adapting and varying your method of courting attention. If you don't, die public will grow tired, will take you for granted, and will move on to a newer star. The game requires constant vigilance and creativity. Pablo Picasso never allowed himself to fade into die background; if his name became too at-
一旦成为焦点，就必须不断调整和改变吸引关注的方式，以此来保持热度。否则，公众会感到厌倦，把你视为理所当然，然后转向新的明星。这场游戏需要持续的警惕和创造力。毕加索从不让自己被遗忘；如果他的名字变得太过响亮——
tached to a particular style, he would deliberately upset die public with a new series of paintings that went against all expectations. Better to create somediing ugly and disturbing, he believed, than to let viewers grow too familiar with his work. Understand: People feel superior to die person whose actions diey can predict. If you show diem who is in control by playing against their expectations, you bodi gain their respect and tighten your hold on dieir fleeting attention.
他固守某种风格，却故意创作一系列出人意料的新画作，令公众感到不安。他认为，与其让观众对他的作品过于熟悉，不如创作一些丑陋且令人不安的作品。要知道：人们会觉得自己比那些行为可预测的人更有优势。如果你通过打破他们的预期来展现掌控力，你就能赢得他们的尊重，并牢牢抓住他们稍纵即逝的注意力。
Image: The Limelight. The actor who steps into this brilliant light attains a heightened presence. All eyes are on him. There is room for only one actor at a time in the limelight's narrow beam; do whatever it takes to make yourself its focus. Make your gestures so large, amusing, and scandalous that the light stays on you while the other actors are left in the shadows.
图片：聚光灯。踏入这耀眼灯光下的演员，气场倍增。所有人的目光都聚焦在他身上。聚光灯的狭窄光束一次只能容纳一位演员；想尽一切办法让自己成为焦点。让你的举止夸张、滑稽、甚至惊世骇俗，让灯光始终照在你身上，而其他演员则黯然失色。
Authority: Be ostentatious and be seen. . . . What is not seen is as diough it did not exist. ... It was light that first caused all creation to shine forth. Display fills up many blanks, covers up deficiencies, and gives everything a second life, especially when it is backed by genuine merit. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：要张扬，要引人注目……不被人看见的，就如同不存在一样……最初是光使万物显现。炫耀可以填补许多空白，掩盖缺陷，赋予万物第二次生命，尤其当它有真正的价值支撑时。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
PART II: CREATE AN AIR OF MYSTERY
第二部分：营造神秘氛围
In a world growing increasingly banal and familiar, what seems enigmatic instantly draws attention. Never make it too clear what you are doing or about to do. Do not show all your cards. An air of mystery heightens your presence; it also creates anticipationeveryone will be watching you to see what happens next. Use mystery to beguile, seduce, even frighten.
在一个日益平庸乏味的世界里，任何神秘的事物都能瞬间吸引眼球。永远不要让你的所作所为或即将要做的事情昭然若揭。不要亮出你的底牌。神秘感能增强你的存在感，也能引发期待——每个人都会注视着你，想知道接下来会发生什么。利用神秘感来迷惑、诱惑，甚至恐吓他人。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Beginning in 1905, rumors started to spread throughout Paris of a young Oriental girl who danced in a private home, wrapped in veils mat she gradually discarded. A local journalist who had seen her dancing reported tiiat “a woman from the Far East had come to Europe laden with perfume and jewels, to introduce some of the richness of the Oriental colour and life into the satiated society of European cities.” Soon everyone knew die dancer's name: Mata Hari.
从1905年开始，巴黎开始流传着一个关于一位东方少女的传闻：她身披薄纱，在私人住宅里翩翩起舞，之后逐渐褪去面纱。一位曾目睹她舞姿的当地记者报道说：“一位来自远东的女子带着香水和珠宝来到欧洲，将东方丰富多彩的色彩和生活带入欧洲城市中沉闷的人群。”很快，人人都知道了这位舞者的名字：玛塔·哈里。
Early that year, in the winter, small and select audiences would gather in a salon filled with Indian statues and other relics while an orchestra played music inspired by Hindu and Javanese melodies. After keeping the audience waiting and wondering, Mata Hari would suddenly appear, in a startling costume: a white cotton brassiere covered with Indian-type jewels; jeweled bands at the waist supporting a sarong that revealed as much as it concealed; bracelets up the arms. Then Mata Hari would dance, in a style no one in France had seen before, her whole body swaying as if she were in a trance. She told her excited and curious audience that her dances told stories from Indian mythology and Javanese folktales. Soon the cream of Paris, and ambassadors from far-off lands, were competing for invitations to the salon, where it was rumored that Mata Hari was actually performing sacred dances in the nude.
那年年初的冬天，一小群受邀的观众聚集在一个摆满了印度雕像和其他文物的沙龙里，一支管弦乐队演奏着受印度教和爪哇旋律启发而创作的音乐。在让观众们翘首以盼、充满好奇之后，玛塔·哈丽突然出现，身着一套令人惊艳的服装：一件缀满印度风格珠宝的白色棉质胸罩；腰间系着镶满珠宝的腰带，支撑着一条既遮掩又展现身材的纱笼；手臂上戴着手镯。然后，玛塔·哈丽开始跳舞，她的舞姿在法国前所未见，整个人仿佛进入了某种恍惚状态，随着舞步摇曳生姿。她告诉兴奋而好奇的观众，她的舞蹈讲述的是印度神话和爪哇民间故事。很快，巴黎的精英人士和来自遥远国度的使节都争相受邀参加这场沙龙表演，坊间传闻玛塔·哈丽实际上是在裸体表演神圣的舞蹈。
The public wanted to know more about her. She told journalists that she was actually Dutch in origin, but had grown up on the island of Java. She would also talk about time spent in India, how she had learned sacred Hindu dances there, and how Indian women “can shoot straight, ride horseback, and are capable of doing logarithms and talk philosophy.” By the summer of 1905, although few Parisians had actually seen Mata Hari dance, her name was on everyone's lips.
公众渴望了解更多关于她的信息。她告诉记者，她其实是荷兰人，但在爪哇岛长大。她还会谈起在印度的时光，讲述她如何在那里学习神圣的印度教舞蹈，以及印度女性如何“枪法精准、骑术精湛、精通对数运算，还能谈论哲学”。到了1905年夏天，尽管鲜有巴黎人亲眼见过玛塔·哈丽的舞蹈，但她的名字却已家喻户晓。
As Mata Hari gave more interviews, the story of her origins kept changing: She had grown up in India, her grandmother was the daughter of a Javanese princess, she had lived on the island of Sumatra where she had spent her time “horseback riding, gun in hand, and risking her life.” No one knew anything certain about her, but journalists did not mind these changes in her biography. They compared her to an Indian goddess, a creature from the pages of Baudelairewhatever their imagination wanted to see in this mysterious woman from the East.
随着玛塔·哈丽接受的采访越来越多，她的身世也随之不断变化：有人说她在印度长大，有人说她的祖母是爪哇公主的女儿，还有人说她曾在苏门答腊岛生活，在那里她“骑马、持枪、冒着生命危险”。没有人真正了解她的过去，但记者们并不在意她生平的这些变化。他们把她比作印度女神，比作波德莱尔笔下的人物——总之，他们把这位来自东方的神秘女子描绘成他们想象中的样子。
In August of 1905, Mata Hari performed for the first time in public.
1905年8月，玛塔·哈里首次公开演出。
Crowds thronging to see her on opening night caused a riot. She had now become a cult figure, spawning many imitations. One reviewer wrote, “Mata Hari personifies all die poetry of India, its mysticism, its voluptuousness, its hypnotizing charm.” Anodier noted, “If India possesses such unexpected treasures, men all Frenchmen will emigrate to the shores of the Ganges.”
首演之夜，蜂拥而至的人群引发了骚乱。她从此成为偶像，模仿者层出不穷。一位评论家写道：“玛塔·哈里是印度所有诗意的化身，它的神秘、它的性感、它令人着迷的魅力。”阿诺迪耶则评论道：“如果印度拥有如此意想不到的宝藏，那么所有法国男人都会移居恒河岸边。”
Soon the fame of Mata Hari and her sacred Indian dances spread beyond Paris. She was invited to Berlin, Vienna, Milan. Over the next few years she performed throughout Europe, mixed with the highest social circles, and earned an income that gave her an independence rarely enjoyed by a woman of the period. Then, near die end of World War I, she was arrested in France, tried, convicted, and finally executed as a German spy. Only during the trial did the truth come out: Mata Hari was not from Java or India, had not grown up in the Orient, did not have a drop of Eastern blood in her body. Her real name was Margaredia Zelle, and she came from die stolid northern province of Friesland, Holland.
很快，玛塔·哈丽和她神圣的印度舞蹈的名声便传遍了巴黎以外的地方。她受邀前往柏林、维也纳和米兰演出。在接下来的几年里，她周游欧洲各地，与上流社会人士交往，并获得了当时女性鲜少拥有的独立生活。然而，第一次世界大战即将结束时，她在法国被捕，随后被审判、定罪，最终被处决，罪名是德国间谍。直到审判期间，真相才得以揭露：玛塔·哈丽并非来自爪哇或印度，她没有在东方长大，身上也没有一丝东方血统。她的真名是玛格丽迪亚·泽勒，来自荷兰北部沉闷的弗里斯兰省。
Interpretation
解释
When Margaretha Zelle arrived in Paris, in 1904, she had half a franc in her pocket. She was one of the thousands of beautiful young girls who flocked to Paris every year, taking work as artists' models, nightclub dancers, or vaudeville performers at die Folies Bergere. After a few years they would inevitably be replaced by younger girls, and would often end up on die streets, turning to prostitution, or else returning to the town they came from, older and chastened.
1904年，玛格丽特·泽勒抵达巴黎时，口袋里只有半法郎。每年都有成千上万的漂亮女孩涌入巴黎，她们或是做艺术模特，或是夜总会的舞女，或是红磨坊歌舞杂耍演员，而她只是其中之一。几年之后，她们不可避免地会被更年轻的女孩取代，最终往往流落街头，沦为妓女，或是回到她们的故乡，变得年老而憔悴。
Zelle had higher ambitions. She had no dance experience and had never performed in the theater, but as a young girl she had traveled with her family and had witnessed local dances in Java and Sumatra. Zelle clearly understood that what was important in her act was not the dance itself, or even her face or figure, but her ability to create an air of mystery about herself. The mystery she created lay not just in her dancing, or her costumes, or die stories she would tell, or her endless lies about her origins; it lay in an atmosphere enveloping everything she did. There was notiiing you could say for sure about hershe was always changing, always surprising her audience witii new costumes, new dances, new stories. This air of mystery left die public always wanting to know more, always wondering about her next move. Mata Hari was no more beautiful tiian many of die otiier young girls who came to Paris, and she was not a particularly good dancer. What separated her from die mass, what attracted and held die public's attention and made her famous and wealtiiy, was her mystery. People are enthralled by mystery; because it invites constant interpretation, diey never tire of it. The mysterious cannot be grasped. And what cannot be seized and consumed creates power.
泽尔的野心远大。她没有舞蹈经验，也从未在剧院演出过，但少女时期，她曾随家人游历爪哇岛和苏门答腊岛，亲眼目睹过当地的舞蹈。泽尔清楚地知道，她表演中最重要的并非舞蹈本身，甚至不是她的容貌或身材，而是她营造神秘感的能力。这种神秘感不仅体现在她的舞姿、服饰、故事，或是她关于身世的无休止的谎言中，更在于她一举一动都笼罩着的氛围。你无法确切地了解她——她总是在变化，总是用新的服饰、新的舞蹈、新的故事给观众带来惊喜。这种神秘感让观众总是渴望了解更多，总是好奇她的下一步行动。玛塔·哈里并不比许多来到巴黎的年轻女孩更漂亮，她的舞技也并非特别出色。真正让她与大众区分开来，吸引并持续赢得公众关注，最终使她名利双收的，是她身上的神秘感。人们为神秘所着迷；因为它引人不断解读，所以他们永远不会厌倦。神秘无法被把握。而那些无法被攫取和消耗的事物，恰恰蕴藏着力量。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In die past, the world was filled with the terrifying and unknowable diseases, disasters, capricious despots, the mystery of death itself. What we could not understand we reimagined as myths and spirits. Over the centuries, though, we have managed, through science and reason, to illuminate the darkness; what was mysterious and forbidding has grown familiar and comfortable. Yet diis light has a price: in a world diat is ever more banal, diat has had its mystery and myth squeezed out of it, we secretly crave enigmas, people or things that cannot be instantiy interpreted, seized, and consumed.
过去，世界充斥着可怕而又难以捉摸的疾病、灾难、反复无常的暴君，以及死亡本身的神秘。我们无法理解的事物，便被我们重新想象成神话和精灵。然而，几个世纪以来，我们凭借科学和理性，逐渐照亮了黑暗；曾经神秘莫测、令人畏惧的事物，如今变得熟悉而舒适。然而，这光明是有代价的：在一个日渐平庸的世界里，日渐失去了神秘和神话的色彩，我们内心深处渴望着谜团，渴望那些无法被立即解读、掌控和消费的人或事物。
That is the power of die mysterious: It invites layers of interpretation, excites our imagination, seduces us into believing that it conceals something marvelous. The world has become so familiar and its inhabitants so predictable that what wraps itself in mystery will almost always draw die limelight to it and make us watch it.
这就是神秘的力量：它能引发层层解读，激发我们的想象力，诱使我们相信其中隐藏着奇妙之物。世界变得如此熟悉，生活在其中的人们也如此可预测，因此，任何披着神秘外衣的事物几乎总能吸引人们的目光，让我们为之侧目。
Do not imagine diat to create an air of mystery you have to be grand and awe-inspiring. Mystery that is woven into your day-to-day demeanor, and is subde, has mat much more power to fascinate and attract attention. Remember: Most people are upfront, can be read like an open book, take little care to control their words or image, and are hopelessly predictable. By simply holding back, keeping silent, occasionally uttering ambiguous phrases, deliberately appearing inconsistent, and acting odd in die subdest of ways, you will emanate an aura of mystery. The people around you will men magnify diat aura by constantiy trying to interpret you.
不要以为营造神秘感就必须气场强大、令人敬畏。融入日常举止、含蓄内敛的神秘感，反而更能吸引眼球，令人着迷。记住：大多数人直来直去，就像一本打开的书，他们很少注意自己的言辞和形象，而且毫无新意。你只需稍加克制，保持沉默，偶尔说些模棱两可的话，故意表现得前后矛盾，以最微妙的方式做出一些古怪的举动，就能散发出神秘的气息。你周围的人会不断地试图解读你，从而放大这种神秘感。
Both artists and con artists understand the vital link between being mysterious and attracting interest. Count Victor Lustig, the aristocrat of swindlers, played die game to perfection. He was always doing things mat were different, or seemed to make no sense. He would show up at die best hotels in a limo driven by a Japanese chauffeur; no one had ever seen a Japanese chauffeur before, so this seemed exotic and strange. Lustig would dress in die most expensive clothing, but always widi sometiiinga medal, a flower, an armbandout of place, at least in conventional terms. This was seen not as tasteless but as odd and intriguing. In hotels he would be seen receiving telegrams at all hours, one after the other, brought to him by his Japanese chauffeurtelegrams he would tear up widi utter nonchalance. (In fact they were fakes, completely blank.) He would sit alone in the dining room, reading a large and impressive-looking book, smiling at people yet remaining aloof. Widiin a few days, of course, die entire hotel would be abuzz with interest in diis strange man.
艺术家和骗子都深谙神秘感与吸引眼球之间的关键联系。诈骗界的贵族维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵将这套把戏玩得炉火纯青。他总是做一些与众不同、甚至看似毫无道理的事情。他会乘坐由日本司机驾驶的豪华轿车出现在最好的酒店；此前从未有人见过日本司机，因此这显得既异域风情又古怪离奇。卢斯蒂格身着最昂贵的服饰，但总会佩戴一些不合时宜的饰品，比如勋章、鲜花或臂章，至少在传统意义上是如此。这并非被视为品味低俗，而是显得古怪而引人入胜。在酒店里，人们经常看到他随时接收电报，一份接一份，都是由他的日本司机送来的——他会漫不经心地撕碎这些电报。（事实上，这些都是伪造的，内容一片空白。）他会独自坐在餐厅里，阅读一本厚重而精美的书籍，面带微笑地与人交谈，却始终保持着疏离感。当然，几天之内，整个酒店都会因为这个奇怪的男人而沸腾起来。
All this attention allowed Lustig to lure suckers in with ease. They would beg for his confidence and his company. Everyone wanted to be seen widi diis mysterious aristocrat. And in the presence of diis distracting enigma, they wouldn't even notice that diey were being robbed blind.
这一切关注让卢斯蒂格轻而易举地引诱傻瓜上钩。他们会乞求他的信任和陪伴。每个人都想和这位神秘的贵族在一起。在这位令人分神、充满谜团的人物面前，他们甚至不会注意到自己正被洗劫一空。
An air of mystery can make the mediocre appear intelligent and profound. It made Mata Hari, a woman of average appearance and intelligence, seem like a goddess, and her dancing divinely inspired. An air of
神秘的气息能让平庸之人显得睿智深邃。它让相貌和智力都平平的玛塔·哈丽宛如女神，她的舞蹈仿佛是神赐的。
mystery about an artist makes his or her artwork immediately more intriguing, a trick Marcel Duchamp played to great effect.
