It is all very easy to dosay little about your work, tease and titillate with alluring, even contradictory comments, then stand back and let others try to make sense of it all.
艺术家身上的神秘感会立刻让他或她的作品更引人入胜，马塞尔·杜尚就曾巧妙地运用过这一技巧。其实，对自己的作品少言少语，用诱人甚至自相矛盾的评论来吊足观众胃口，然后袖手旁观，让别人去解读这一切，这很容易做到。
Mysterious people put others in a kind of inferior positionthat of trying to figure them out. To degrees that they can control, diey also elicit die fear surrounding anything uncertain or unknown. All great leaders know that an aura of mystery draws attention to them and creates an intimidating presence. Mao Tse-tung, for example, cleverly cultivated an enigmatic image; he had no worries about seeming inconsistent or contradicting himselfthe very contradictoriness of his actions and words meant that he always had the upper hand. No one, not even his own wife, ever felt diey understood him, and he therefore seemed larger than life. This also meant that the public paid constant attention to him, ever anxious to witness his next move.
神秘的人会让别人感到一种自卑感，仿佛在试图了解他们。在他们力所能及的范围内，他们还会引发人们对任何不确定或未知事物的恐惧。所有伟大的领袖都明白，神秘的气质能够吸引人们的注意，并营造出一种令人敬畏的气场。例如，毛泽东就巧妙地塑造了一种谜一般的形象；他从不担心自己言行不一或自相矛盾——他言行的矛盾性恰恰使他始终占据上风。没有人，甚至连他的妻子，都觉得无法真正理解他，因此他显得超凡脱俗。这也意味着公众始终关注着他，渴望见证他的下一步行动。
If your social position prevents you from completely wrapping your actions in mystery, you must at least learn to make yourself less obvious. Every now and men, act in a way that does not mesh with other people's perception of you. This way you keep those around you on the defensive, eliciting the kind of attention that makes you powerful. Done right, the creation of enigma can also draw the kind of attention that strikes terror into your enemy.
如果你的社会地位让你无法完全将自己的行为隐藏起来，至少要学会让自己不那么引人注目。时不时地，做出一些与他人对你的固有印象不符的举动。这样一来，你就能让周围的人保持警惕，从而吸引到那种能让你变得强大的关注。如果运用得当，制造谜团甚至可以吸引到令敌人胆寒的关注。
During the Second Punic War (219-202 B.C.), the great Carthaginian general Hannibal was wreaking havoc in his march on Rome. Hannibal was known for his cleverness and duplicity.
第二次布匿战争（公元前219-202年）期间，迦太基名将汉尼拔在进军罗马的途中所到之处，战火纷飞。汉尼拔以其足智多谋和诡计多端而闻名。
Under his leadership Carthage's army, though smaller than those of the Romans, had constandy outmaneuvered them. On one occasion, though, Hannibal's scouts made a horrible blunder, leading his troops into a marshy terrain with the sea at their back. The Roman army blocked the mountain passes mat led inland, and its general, Fabius, was ecstaticat last he had Hannibal trapped. Posting his best sentries on the passes, he worked on a plan to destroy Hannibal's forces. But in the middle of the night, die sentries looked down to see a mysterious sight: A huge procession of lights was heading up die mountain. Thousands and thousands of lights. If this was Hannibal's army, it had suddenly grown a hundredfold.
在他的领导下，迦太基军队虽然规模小于罗马军队，却一直占据上风。然而有一次，汉尼拔的侦察兵犯了一个可怕的错误，将部队引入了一片沼泽地带，背靠大海。罗马军队封锁了通往内陆的山口，其将领法比乌斯欣喜若狂——他终于将汉尼拔困住了。他将最精锐的哨兵部署在山口，并着手制定歼灭汉尼拔军队的计划。但在半夜，哨兵们向下望去，看到了一幅奇异的景象：一支庞大的光队正沿着山路向上行进。成千上万的光点。如果这真的是汉尼拔的军队，那么它的规模已经瞬间扩大了百倍。
The sentries argued heatedly about what this could mean: Reinforcements from the sea Troops tiiat had been hidden in die area Ghosts No explanation made sense.
哨兵们激烈地争论着这可能意味着什么：来自海上的增援部队，隐藏在该区域的幽灵部队。没有任何解释是合理的。
As they watched, fires broke out all over the mountain, and a horrible noise drifted up to them from below, like the blowing of a million horns. Demons, they thought. The sentries, the bravest and most sensible in the Roman army, fled their posts in a panic.
他们眼睁睁地看着山上燃起熊熊大火，山下传来一阵可怕的巨响，如同百万个号角齐鸣。他们心想，一定是恶魔作祟。罗马军队中最勇敢、最明智的哨兵们惊慌失措地逃离了岗位。
By the next day, Hannibal had escaped from the marshland. What was his trick Had he really conjured up demons Actually what he had done was order bundles of twigs to be fastened to the horns of the thousands of oxen that traveled with his troops as beasts of burden. The twigs were then
第二天，汉尼拔就逃出了沼泽地。他究竟用了什么计谋？难道他真的召唤了恶魔？实际上，他只是命令将一捆捆树枝绑在随军行进的数千头驮牛的角上。然后，树枝……
lit, giving the impression of the torches of a vast army heading up the mountain. When the flames burned down to the oxen's skin, they stampeded in all directions, bellowing like mad and setting fires all over the mountainside. The key to mis device's success was not the torches, the fires, or the noises in themselves, however, but the fact that Hannibal had created a puzzle that captivated the sentries' attention and gradually terrified them. From the mountaintop there was no way to explain this bizarre sight. If the sentries could have explained it they would have stayed at their posts.
火炬点燃，仿佛一支庞大的军队正举着火把向山顶进发。当火焰烧到牛皮时，牛群四散奔逃，疯狂地嘶吼着，在山坡上燃起熊熊大火。然而，这套计谋成功的关键并非火炬、火焰或噪音本身，而是汉尼拔精心设计的谜题，它吸引了哨兵们的注意力，并逐渐将他们吓得魂飞魄散。从山顶上，根本无法解释这诡异的景象。如果哨兵们能够解释这一切，他们就会坚守岗位了。
If you find yourself trapped, cornered, and on the defensive in some situation, try a simple experiment: Do something that cannot be easily explained or interpreted. Choose a simple action, but carry it out in a way that unsettles your opponent, a way with many possible interpretations, making your intentions obscure. Don't just be unpredictable (although this tactic too can be successfulsee Law 17); like Hannibal, create a scene that cannot be read. There will seem to be no method to your madness, no rhyme or reason, no single explanation. If you do this right, you will inspire fear and trembling and the sentries will abandon their posts. Call it the “feigned madness of Hamlet” tactic, for Hamlet uses it to great effect in Shakespeare's play, frightening his stepfather Claudius through die mystery of his behavior. The mysterious makes your forces seem larger, your power more terrifying.
如果你发现自己陷入困境，被逼到墙角，处于守势，不妨试试一个简单的实验：做一些难以解释或解读的事情。选择一个简单的行动，但要以一种令对手不安的方式执行，一种可以有多种解读的方式，让你的意图变得扑朔迷离。不要只是让人捉摸不透（虽然这种策略也可能奏效——参见法则17）；像汉尼拔那样，制造一场无法解读的闹剧。你的疯狂看起来毫无章法，毫无逻辑可言，没有任何解释。如果你做得好，就能让敌人胆战心惊，守卫者也会弃守岗位。你可以称之为“哈姆雷特式的装疯卖傻”策略，因为哈姆雷特在莎士比亚的戏剧中就巧妙地运用了这一策略，通过神秘的行为吓唬他的继父克劳狄斯。神秘感会让你的力量显得更加强大，让你的威力更加可怕。
Image: The Dance of the Veilsthe veils envelop the dancer. What they reveal causes excitement. What they conceal heightens interest. The essence of mystery.
图片：面纱之舞——面纱包裹着舞者。面纱所揭示的令人兴奋，面纱所隐藏的则更引人遐想。这就是神秘的本质。
Authority: If you do not declare yourself immediately, you arouse expectation. . . . Mix a little mystery with everything, and the very mystery stirs up veneration. And when you explain, be not too explicit. ... In this manner you imitate the Divine way when you cause men to wonder and watch. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：如果你不立即表明身份，就会激起人们的期待……凡事都略带神秘，而神秘本身就能激起敬畏。解释时，切勿过于直白……如此，你便效法了神圣之道，使人惊叹不已，驻足观看。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
In the beginning of your rise to the top, you must attract attention at all cost, but as you rise higher you must constantly adapt. Never wear the public out with the same tactic. An air of mystery works wonders for those who need to develop an aura of power and get themselves noticed, but it must seem measured and under control. Mata Hari went too far with her fabrications; although the accusation that she was a spy was false, at the time it was a reasonable presumption because all her lies made her seem suspicious and nefarious. Do not let your air of mystery be slowly transformed into a reputation for deceit. The mystery you create must seem a game, playful and unthreatening. Recognize when it goes too far, and pull back.
在你攀登事业巅峰的初期，你必须不惜一切代价吸引关注，但随着地位的提升，你必须不断调整策略。切勿使用同样的伎俩，以免公众感到厌倦。神秘感对于那些需要营造权力氛围、博取关注的人来说非常有效，但这种神秘感必须显得恰到好处、在掌控之中。玛塔·哈里就曾因谎言而走火入魔；尽管她是间谍的指控是虚假的，但在当时，这种怀疑并非毫无道理，因为她所有的谎言都让她显得可疑且邪恶。不要让你的神秘感慢慢演变成欺骗的名声。你营造的神秘感必须像一场游戏，轻松愉快，毫无威胁。要意识到何时玩火自焚，并及时收手。
There are times when the need for attention must be deferred, and when scandal and notoriety are the last things you want to create. The attention you attract must never offend or challenge the reputation of those above younot, at any rate, if they are secure. You will seem not only paltry but desperate by comparison. There is an art to knowing when to draw notice and when to wididraw.
有些时候，你需要克制自己不去博取关注，丑闻和恶名是你最不想制造的。你所吸引的关注绝不能冒犯或挑战你上级的声誉——至少在他们地位稳固的情况下是如此。否则，你不仅会显得卑微，还会显得急于求成。何时该引人注目，何时该保持低调，这其中蕴含着一门艺术。
Lola Montez was one of die great practitioners of the art of attracting attention. She managed to rise from a middle-class Irish background to being the lover of Franz Liszt and then the mistress and political adviser of King Ludwig of Bavaria. In her later years, though, she lost her sense of proportion.
洛拉·蒙特兹是吸引眼球的高手之一。她出身爱尔兰中产阶级，一路攀升，先是成为弗朗茨·李斯特的情人，后又成为巴伐利亚国王路德维希的情妇和政治顾问。然而，晚年她却失去了分寸感。
In London in 1850 there was to be a performance of Shakespeare's Macbeth featuring the greatest actor of the time, Charles John Kean. Everyone of consequence in English society was to be there; it was rumored that even Queen Victoria and Prince Albert were to make a public appearance. The custom of the period demanded that everyone be seated before the queen arrived. So the audience got there a little early, and when the queen entered her royal box, diey observed die convention of standing up and applauding her. The royal couple waited, then bowed. Everyone sat down and the lights were dimmed. Then, suddenly, all eyes turned to a box opposite Queen Victoria's: A woman appeared from the shadows, taking her seat later tiian the queen. It was Lola Montez. She wore a diamond tiara on her dark hair and a long fur coat over her shoulders. People whispered in amazement as the ermine cloak was dropped to reveal a low-necked gown of crimson velvet. By turning tfieir heads, the audience could see that the royal couple deliberately avoided looking at Lola's box. They followed Victoria's example, and for the rest of the evening Lola Montez was ignored. After that evening no one in fashionable society dared to be seen with her. All her magnetic powers were reversed. People would flee her sight. Her future in England was finished.
1850年的伦敦，莎士比亚的《麦克白》即将上演，由当时最伟大的演员查尔斯·约翰·基恩领衔主演。英国社会各界名流都将出席；甚至有传言说，维多利亚女王和阿尔伯特亲王也将公开露面。当时的习俗是，女王到来之前所有人都必须入座。因此，观众们提前到达，当女王步入她的皇家包厢时，他们遵循惯例起立鼓掌。皇室夫妇稍作等待，然后鞠躬致意。众人落座，灯光渐暗。突然，所有人的目光都转向了维多利亚女王对面的包厢：一位女子从阴影中走出，在女王之后入座。她就是洛拉·蒙特兹。她深色的头发上戴着一顶钻石冠冕，肩上披着一件长长的皮草大衣。当貂皮大衣滑落，露出里面一件深红色低领天鹅绒长裙时，人们发出惊叹的低语。通过扭头，观众们可以看出这对皇室夫妇刻意避开了洛拉的包厢。他们效仿维多利亚的做法，当晚余下的时间里，洛拉·蒙特兹无人问津。此后，上流社会无人敢与她接触。她所有的魅力都荡然无存。人们避之不及。她在英国的生涯就此终结。
Never appear overly greedy for attention, then, for it signals insecurity, and insecurity drives power away. Understand that there are times when it is not in your interest to be the center of attention. When in the presence of a king or queen, for instance, or the equivalent thereof, bow and retreat to the shadows; never compete.
因此，切勿表现得过于渴望关注，因为这会暴露你的不安全感，而不安全感会让你失去力量。你要明白，有些时候，成为众人瞩目的焦点对你并无益处。例如，在国王或女王，或者地位相当的人面前，要低头鞠躬，退到阴影处；切勿争锋相对。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 7
第七条
GET OTHERS TO DO THE
让其他人去做
WORK FOR YOU, BUT
为你工作，但是
ALWAYS TAKE THE CREDIT
永远要邀功
JUDGMENT
判断
Use the wisdom, knowledge, and legwork of other people to further your own cause. Not only will such assistance save you valuable time and energy, it will give you a godlike aura of efficiency and speed. In the end your helpers will be forgotten and you will be remembered. Never do yourself what others can do for you.
借助他人的智慧、知识和努力来推进自己的事业。这样的帮助不仅能为你节省宝贵的时间和精力，还能让你拥有神一般的效率和速度。最终，你的帮手会被遗忘，而你将被铭记。永远不要自己去做别人能为你做的事。
TRANSGRESSION AND OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW In 1883 a young Serbian scientist named Nikola Tesla was working for the European division of die Continental Edison Company. He was a brilliant inventor, and Charles Batchelor, a plant manager and a personal friend of Thomas Edison, persuaded him he should seek his fortune in America, giving him a letter of introduction to Edison himself. So began a life of woe and tribulation mat lasted until Tesla's death.
违法与守法 1883年，一位名叫尼古拉·特斯拉的年轻塞尔维亚科学家在大陆爱迪生公司欧洲分部工作。他是一位才华横溢的发明家，工厂经理查尔斯·巴切勒是托马斯·爱迪生的私人朋友，他劝说特斯拉去美国闯荡，并亲自给他写了一封介绍信，让他去见爱迪生。就这样，特斯拉开始了充满苦难的一生，直至他去世。
When Tesla met Edison in New York, the famous inventor hired him on the spot. Tesla worked eighteen-hour days, finding ways to improve the primitive Edison dynamos. Finally he offered to redesign diem completely. To Edison diis seemed a monumental task mat could last years wimout paying off, but he told Tesla, “There's fifty diousand dollars in it for you if you can do it.” Tesla labored day and night on the project and after only a year he produced a greatiy improved version of the dynamo, complete with automatic controls. He went to Edison to break the good news and receive his $50,000. Edison was pleased with the improvement, for which he and his company would take credit, but when it came to the issue of the money he told the young Serb, “Tesla, you don't understand our American humor!,” and offered a small raise instead.
特斯拉在纽约与爱迪生会面时，这位著名发明家当场聘用了他。特斯拉每天工作十八个小时，不断改进爱迪生原始的发电机。最终，他提出要彻底重新设计发电机。在爱迪生看来，这似乎是一项艰巨的任务，可能要耗费数年时间才能见效，但他告诉特斯拉：“如果你能做到，就能得到五万美元。”特斯拉日夜辛勤工作，仅仅一年后，他就研制出了改进幅度极大的发电机，并配备了自动控制系统。他去见爱迪生，宣布了这个好消息，并领取了五万美元的报酬。爱迪生对改进后的发电机非常满意，他和他的公司也乐于接受这份荣誉。但当谈到报酬时，爱迪生对这位年轻的塞尔维亚人说：“特斯拉，你不懂我们美国人的幽默！”，并提出只给特斯拉略微加薪。
Tesla's obsession was to create an alternating-current system (AC) of electricity. Edison believed in the direct-current system (DC), and not only refused to support Tesla's research but later did all he could to sabotage him. Tesla turned to die great Pittsburgh magnate George Westinghouse, who had started his own electricity company. Westinghouse completely funded Tesla's research and offered him a generous royalty agreement on future profits. The AC system Tesla developed is still the standard today but after patents were filed in his name, other scientists came forward to take credit for the invention, claiming mat they had laid the groundwork for him. His name was lost in the shuffle, and the public came to associate the invention widi Westinghouse himself.
特斯拉毕生致力于研发交流电系统。爱迪生信奉直流电系统，不仅拒绝支持特斯拉的研究，后来还想方设法阻挠他。特斯拉转而寻求匹兹堡巨头乔治·威斯汀豪斯的帮助，后者创办了自己的电力公司。威斯汀豪斯全额资助了特斯拉的研究，并承诺未来利润将以丰厚的版税形式支付给他。特斯拉研发的交流电系统至今仍是标准配置，但在以他的名义申请专利后，其他科学家纷纷站出来声称自己才是这项发明的真正功臣，并表示他们为特斯拉奠定了基础。特斯拉的名字就这样被淹没在了这场争论中，公众开始将这项发明与威斯汀豪斯本人联系起来。
A year later, Westinghouse was caught in a takeover bid from J. Pierpont Morgan, who made him rescind the generous royalty contract he had signed widi Tesla. Westinghouse explained to the scientist mat his company would not survive if it had to pay him his full royalties; he persuaded Tesla to accept a buyout of his patents for $216,000a large sum, no doubt, but far less dian the $12 million mey were worth at the time. The financiers had divested Tesla of the riches, the patents, and essentially me credit for the greatest invention of his career.
一年后，西屋公司遭遇了J·P·摩根的收购，摩根迫使他撤销了与特斯拉签订的慷慨的专利使用费合同。西屋向特斯拉解释说，如果公司必须支付他全部的专利使用费，公司将无法生存；他最终说服特斯拉接受以21.6万美元的价格买断他的专利——这无疑是一笔巨款，但远不及当时这些专利价值1200万美元。金融家们剥夺了特斯拉的财富、专利，以及他毕生最伟大发明的功劳。
The name of Guglielmo Marconi is forever linked widi the invention of radio. But few know mat in producing his inventionhe broadcast a signal across the English Channel in 1899Marconi made use of a patent Tesla had filed in 1897, and that his work depended on Tesla's research. Once again Tesla received no money and no credit. Tesla invented an induction motor as well as the AC power system, and he is die real “fatiier of radio.” Yet none of diese discoveries bear his name. As an old man, he lived in poverty.
古列尔莫·马可尼的名字永远与无线电的发明联系在一起。但鲜为人知的是，马可尼在1899年跨越英吉利海峡发射无线电信号时，利用了特斯拉于1897年申请的专利，他的工作也依赖于特斯拉的研究成果。特斯拉再次没有获得任何报酬和荣誉。特斯拉发明了感应电机和交流电系统，他才是真正的“无线电之父”。然而，这些发明都没有以他的名字命名。晚年，他生活贫困。
THE TORTOISE. THE ELEPHANT AND THE HIPPOPOTAMI'S
乌龟、大象和河马
One day the tortoise met the elephant, who trumpeted, “Out of my way, you weakling / might step on you!” The tortoise was not afraid and stayed where he was, so the elephant stepped on him, but could not crush him. “Do not boast, Mr. Elephant, I am as strong as you are!”said the tortoise, but the elephant just laughed. So the tortoise asked him to come to his hill the next morning.
有一天，乌龟遇到了大象。大象吼道：“让开，你这弱鸡！/我就要踩死你了！”乌龟并不害怕，依然站在原地。于是大象踩了上去，却踩不死它。“别吹牛了，大象先生，我和你一样强壮！”乌龟说道。大象只是哈哈大笑。于是，乌龟邀请大象第二天早上到它的山丘来。
The next day, before sunrise, the tortoise ran down the hill to the river, where he met the hippopotamus, who was just on his way back into the water after his nocturnal feeding. “Mr Hippo! Shall we have a tug-of-war I bet I'm as strong as you are!” said the tortoise. The hippopotamus laughed at this ridiculous idea, but agreed. The tortoise produced a long rope and told the hippo to hold it in his mouth until the tortoise shouted “Hey!” Then the tortoise ran back up the hill where he found the elephant, who was getting impatient. He gave the elephant the other end of the rope and said, “When I say 'Hey!' pull, and you'll see which of us is the strongest.” Then he ran halfway back down the
第二天，天还没亮，乌龟就跑下山来到河边，遇到了刚吃完夜宵、正要下水的河马。“河马先生！我们来比比拔河吧，我敢打赌我和你一样强壮！”乌龟说道。河马觉得这个提议很荒谬，哈哈大笑，但还是答应了。乌龟拿出一根长绳子，让河马用嘴叼着，直到乌龟喊一声“嘿！”。然后，乌龟跑回山上，遇到了已经不耐烦的大象。乌龟把绳子的另一端递给大象，说道：“我说‘嘿！’的时候你就拉，看看我们谁更强壮。”说完，乌龟又跑回了半山腰。
hill, to a place where he couldn be seen, and shouted, “Hey!” The elephant and the hippopotamus pulled and pulled, but neither could budge the otherthey were of equal strength. They both agreed that the tortoise was as strong as thev were. Never do what others can do for you. The tortoise let others do the work for him while he got the credit.
他爬上山坡，走到一个看不见的地方，大喊一声：“嘿！”大象和河马使劲拉扯，却谁也拉不动对方——它们力气相当。它们都认为乌龟和它们一样强壮。永远不要做别人能为你做的事。乌龟让别人替他干活，自己却独揽功劳。
ZaIRHAN FAlil.h
ZaAIRHAN FALIL.h
To be sure, if the hunter relies on the security of the carriage, utilizes the legs of the six horses, and makes Wang Liang hold their reins, then he will not tire himself and will find it easy to overtake swift animals. Now supposing he discarded the advantage of the carriage, gave up the useful legs of the horses and the skill of Wang Liang, and alighted to run after the animals, then even though his legs were as quick as Lou Chi's, he would not be in time to overtake the animals. In fact, if good horses and strong carriages are taken into use, then mere bondmen and bondwomen will be good enough to catch the animals.
诚然，如果猎人依靠马车的稳固，利用六匹骏马的腿力，再让王良拉缰，那么他便不会疲惫，也能轻松追上迅捷的猎物。然而，假设他舍弃了马车的优势，放弃了骏马的腿力和王良的技巧，下车追赶猎物，即便他的腿力堪比娄其，也难以追上。事实上，只要使用良驹和坚固的马车，哪怕是普通的奴婢也能轻松追上猎物。
Han-lki-tzi;,
There-lki-tzi;,
Chinlsk philosopher,
钦斯克哲学家
third (tintury b.c.
第三（公元前）
In 1917, during his later impoverished years, Tesla was told he was to receive the Edison Medal of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. He turned the medal down. “You propose,” he said, “to honor me with a medal which I could pin upon my coat and strut for a vain hour before the members of your Institute. You would decorate my body and continue to let starve, for failure to supply recognition, my mind and its creative products, which have supplied the foundation upon which the major portion of your Institute exists.”
1917年，在特斯拉晚年贫困潦倒之际，有人告诉他，他将获得美国电气工程师学会颁发的爱迪生奖章。他拒绝了。“你们想，”他说，“给我颁发一枚奖章，让我别在外套上，在你们学会的成员面前虚张声势地炫耀一个小时。你们装饰我的身体，却让我的思想和创造性成果继续遭受饥饿的折磨，因为你们没有给予应有的认可，而这些正是你们学会赖以生存的基石。”
Interpretation
解释
Many harbor the illusion that science, dealing with facts as it does, is beyond the petty rivalries that trouble the rest of the world. Nikola Tesla was one of those. He believed science had nothing to do with politics, and claimed not to care for fame and riches. As he grew older, though, this ruined his scientific work. Not associated with any particular discovery, he could attract no investors to his many ideas. While he pondered great inventions for the future, others stole the patents he had already developed and got the glory for themselves.
许多人抱有幻想，认为科学处理事实的方式使其超脱于困扰世界其他领域的琐碎纷争之外。尼古拉·特斯拉就是其中之一。他坚信科学与政治无关，并声称自己不在乎名利。然而，随着年龄的增长，这种想法却毁了他的科学事业。由于没有与任何具体的发现联系在一起，他的众多想法无法吸引投资者。当他还在思考未来伟大的发明时，其他人却窃取了他已经开发的专利，并独揽了荣耀。
He wanted to do everything on his own, but merely exhausted and impoverished himself in the process.
他想事事亲力亲为，结果却让自己精疲力竭、家道中落。
Edison was Tesla's polar opposite. He wasn't actually much of a scientific thinker or inventor; he once said that he had no need to be a mathematician because he could always hire one. That was Edison's main method. He was really a businessman and publicist, spotting the trends and the opportunities that were out there, then hiring the best in the field to do the work for him. If he had to he would steal from his competitors. Yet his name is much better known than Tesla's, and is associated with more inventions.
爱迪生与特斯拉截然相反。他其实算不上什么科学思想家或发明家；他曾说过，自己没必要成为数学家，因为他总能雇到。这正是爱迪生的主要策略。他本质上是一位商人兼公关高手，善于发现市场趋势和机遇，然后聘请业内顶尖人才为他效力。必要时，他甚至会窃取竞争对手的成果。然而，他的名字却比特斯拉更为人熟知，而且与更多发明联系在一起。
The lesson is twofold: First, the credit for an invention or creation is as important, if not more important, than the invention itself. You must secure the credit for yourself and keep others from stealing it away, or from piggybacking on your hard work. To accomplish this you must always be vigilant and ruthless, keeping your creation quiet until you can be sure there are no vultures circling overhead. Second, learn to take advantage of other people's work to further your own cause. Time is precious and life is short. If you try to do it all on your own, you run yourself ragged, waste energy, and burn yourself out. It is far better to conserve your forces, pounce on the work others have done, and find a way to make it your own.
这条教训包含两方面：首先，发明或创造的荣誉与发明本身同等重要，甚至更为重要。你必须确保自己的荣誉得到认可，防止他人窃取或搭便车，窃取你的劳动成果。为了做到这一点，你必须时刻保持警惕，毫不留情，在确定无人觊觎之前，务必将你的作品保密。其次，要学会利用他人的劳动成果来推进自己的事业。时间宝贵，生命短暂。如果你试图事事亲力亲为，只会让自己精疲力竭，浪费精力，最终耗尽心力。更好的做法是保存体力，充分利用他人的成果，并将其转化为自己的作品。
Everybody steals in commerce and industry.
在商业和工业领域，人人都在偷窃。
I've stolen a lot myself.
我自己也偷过很多东西。
But I know how to steal.
但我知道怎么偷东西。
Thomas Edison, 1847-1931
托马斯·爱迪生，1847-1931年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
A hen who had lost her sight, and was accustomed to scratching up
一只失明的母鸡，以前习惯于刨地觅食。
till continued to scratch awav most diligently. Of what use was
直到它继续非常勤奋地刮擦。这有什么用呢？
sighted hen who spared her tender feet never moved from her side,
那只视力正常的母鸡没有伤害她娇嫩的脚，一直待在她身边。
The world of power has the dynamics of the jungle: There are those who live by hunting and killing, and there are also vast numbers of creatures (hyenas, vultures) who live off the hunting of others. These latter, less imaginative types are often incapable of doing the work that is essential for the creation of power. They understand early on, though, mat if they wait the earth in search of long enough, they can always find another animal to do the work for them. /'Ç"' although Mind, Do not be naive: At this very moment, while you are slaving away on some project, there are vultures circling above trying to figure out a way to survive and even thrive off your creativity. It is useless to complain about this, it to the industrious or to wear yourself ragged with bitterness, as Tesla did. Better to protect fool Another sharp yourself and join the game. Once you have established a power base, become a vulture yourself, and save yourself a lot of time and energy.
权力世界如同丛林法则：有人靠狩猎和杀戮为生，也有无数的生物（鬣狗、秃鹫）以猎杀他人为生。后者往往缺乏想象力，无法完成创造权力所必需的工作。然而，他们很早就明白，只要在地球上苦苦等待足够长的时间，总能找到其他动物替他们干活。/'Ç"' 记住，不要天真：就在你为某个项目辛勤劳作的此刻，有秃鹫在你头顶盘旋，试图找到生存之道，甚至利用你的创造力来发家致富。抱怨对勤奋的人来说毫无意义，像特斯拉那样让自己被怨恨折磨得筋疲力尽也无济于事。不如保护自己，让自己变得敏锐，加入这场游戏。一旦你建立了自己的权力基础，就让自己也变成一只秃鹫，这样就能节省大量的时间和精力。
Of the two poles of this game, one can be illustrated by the example of and enjoyed, without the explorer Vasco Nunez de Balboa. Balboa had an obsessionthe dis- scratching, the fruit of covery of El Dorado, a legendary city of vast riches.
这场游戏的两极，其中一极可以用探险家瓦斯科·努涅斯·德·巴尔博亚的例子来说明，他没有享受到游戏的乐趣。巴尔博亚痴迷于发现黄金国——一座传说中拥有巨额财富的城市。
Early in the sixteenth century, after countless hardships and brushes
十六世纪初，经历了无数的艰难困苦和争斗
often as the blind hen scratched up a barlcv-
就像瞎眼的母鸡刨出一根小棍子一样——
TABLKS,
片剂，
GOTTIIOl.D Ll-SSIMi.
GOTTIIOl.D Ll-SSIMi。
1729-1781
with death, he found evidence of a great and wealthy empire to the south corn, her watchful of Mexico, in present-day Peru. By conquering this empire, the Incan, and companion devoured seizing its gold, he would make himself the next Cortes. The problem was that even as he made this discovery, word of it spread among hundreds of other conquistadors. He did not understand diat half the game was keeping it quiet, and carefully watching those around him. A few years after he discovered the location of the Incan empire, a soldier in his own army, Francisco Pizarro, helped to get him beheaded for treason. Pizarro went on to take what Balboa had spent so many years trying to find.
在一次死亡中，他发现了一个位于南方、与墨西哥接壤的庞大而富饶的帝国——今秘鲁境内——的证据。他心想，如果征服这个印加帝国，掠夺其黄金，他就能成为下一任科尔特斯。然而，问题在于，就在他发现印加帝国的同时，消息也迅速传遍了数百名征服者之间。他并不明白，征服的关键在于保持低调，并密切关注周围的人。几年后，在他发现印加帝国的遗址后，他军队中的一名士兵弗朗西斯科·皮萨罗竟然帮助陷害他，让他以叛国罪被斩首。皮萨罗最终夺走了巴尔博亚多年来苦苦寻觅的宝藏。
The other pole is that of the artist Peter Paul Rubens, who, late in his career, found himself deluged with requests for paintings. He created a system: In his large studio he employed dozens of outstanding painters, one specializing in robes, another in backgrounds, and so on. He created a vast production line in which a large number of canvases would be worked on at the same time. When an important client visited the studio, Rubens would shoo his hired painters out for the day. While the client watched from a balcony, Rubens would work at an incredible pace, with unbelievable energy. The client would leave in awe of this prodigious man, who could paint so many masterpieces in so short a time.
另一个极端是艺术家彼得·保罗·鲁本斯。在他职业生涯后期，他发现自己收到了大量的绘画委托。他建立了一套系统：在他宽敞的工作室里，他雇佣了数十位杰出的画家，有的专门绘制人物长袍，有的负责背景，等等。他创建了一条庞大的生产线，可以同时绘制大量的画布。当一位重要的客户来访时，鲁本斯会把雇佣的画家们请出去。客户则在阳台上观看，而鲁本斯则以惊人的速度和精力投入到绘画中。客户离开时，都会对这位能在如此短的时间内创作出如此多杰作的天才艺术家感到敬畏。
This is the essence of the Law: Learn to get others to do the work for you while you take the credit, and you appear to be of godlike strength and power. If you think it important to do all the work yourself, you will never get far, and you will suffer the fate of the Balboas and Teslas of the world. Find people with the skills and creativity you lack. Either hire them, while putting your own name on top of theirs, or find a way to take their work and make it your own. Their creativity thus becomes yours, and you seem a genius to the world.
这就是这条法则的精髓：学会让别人为你工作，自己独揽功劳，这样你就能显得拥有神一般的力量和权力。如果你认为所有工作都必须亲力亲为，你永远不会成功，最终会落得像巴尔博亚和特斯拉那样的下场。找到那些拥有你所缺乏的技能和创造力的人。要么雇佣他们，同时署上你的名字；要么想办法窃取他们的劳动成果，并将其据为己有。这样，他们的创造力就变成了你的，你在世人眼中也成了天才。
There is another application of this law that does not require the parasitic use of your contemporaries' labor: Use the past, a vast storehouse of
这条法则还有另一种应用，它不需要寄生性地利用同时代人的劳动：那就是利用过去，一个庞大的宝库。
knowledge and wisdom. Isaac Newton called this “standing on the shoulders of giants.” He meant that in making his discoveries he had built on the achievements of others. A great part of his aura of genius, he knew, was attributable to his shrewd ability to make the most of the insights of ancient, medieval, and Renaissance scientists. Shakespeare borrowed plots, characterizations, and even dialogue from Plutarch, among other writers, for he knew that nobody surpassed Plutarch in the writing of subde psychology and witty quotes. How many later writers have in their tarn borrowed from plagiarized Shakespeare
知识和智慧。艾萨克·牛顿称之为“站在巨人的肩膀上”。他的意思是，他的发现建立在前人的成就之上。他深知，他天才的光环很大程度上归功于他敏锐地汲取古代、中世纪和文艺复兴时期科学家们的真知灼见。莎士比亚借鉴了普鲁塔克等人的情节、人物塑造，甚至对话，因为他知道在描写心理学和妙语连珠方面，无人能及普鲁塔克。有多少后世作家在他们的作品中借鉴了莎士比亚的抄袭之作呢？
We all know how few of today's politicians write their own speeches. Their own words would not win them a single vote; their eloquence and wit, whatever diere is of it, they owe to a speech writer. Other people do the work, they take the credit. The upside of this is that it is a kind of power that is available to everyone. Learn to use the knowledge of the past and you will look like a genius, even when you are really just a clever borrower.
我们都知道，如今的政治家很少有人自己撰写演讲稿。他们自己写的演讲稿根本无法赢得任何选票；他们的雄辩和机智，无论有多少，都得归功于演讲稿撰写人。别人做了工作，他们却坐享其成。好处在于，这种权力人人皆可掌握。学会运用历史经验，即使你实际上只是个聪明的借鉴者，也能显得像个天才。
Writers who have delved into human nature, ancient masters of strategy, historians of human stupidity and folly, kings and queens who have learned the hard way how to handle the burdens of powertheir knowledge is gathering dust, waiting for you to come and stand on their shoulders. Their wit can be your wit, their skill can be your skill, and they will never come around to tell people how unoriginal you really are. You can slog through life, making endless mistakes, wasting time and energy trying to do things from your own experience. Or you can use the armies of die past. As Bismarck once said, “Fools say that they learn by experience. I prefer to profit by others' experience.”
那些深入剖析人性的作家，那些古代的战略大师，那些记录人类愚昧和愚行的历史学家，那些历经磨难才学会如何驾驭权力重担的君王——他们的知识如今已蒙尘，等待着你前来，站在他们的肩膀上。他们的智慧可以成为你的智慧，他们的技能可以成为你的技能，而他们永远不会来指责你缺乏原创性。你可以跌跌撞撞地走过一生，犯下无数错误，浪费时间和精力，试图凭自身经验行事。或者，你可以利用前人的智慧。正如俾斯麦所说：“愚人说他们从经验中学习。我更喜欢从他人的经验中获益。”
Image: The Vulture. Of all the creatures in the jungle, he has it the easiest. The hard work of others becomes his work; their failure to survive becomes his nourishment. Keep an eye on the Vulturewhile you are hard at work, he is circling above. Do not fight him, join him.
图片：秃鹫。在丛林的所有生物中，它的日子最轻松。其他生物的辛勤劳作成了它的劳动；它们的死亡成了它的养分。当你辛勤劳作时，要留意秃鹫，它正盘旋在你头顶。不要与它对抗，加入它吧。
Authority: There is much to be known, life is short, and life is not life without knowledge. It is therefore an excellent device to acquire knowledge from everybody. Thus, by the sweat of another's brow, you win the reputation of being an oracle. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：世间万物浩瀚无垠，人生苦短，而没有知识的人生便不完整。因此，向所有人汲取知识是极佳的途径。如此一来，便能凭借他人的汗水，赢得先知般的声誉。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
There are times when taking the credit for work that others have done is not the wise course: If your power is not firmly enough established, you will seem to be pushing people out of the limelight. To be a brilliant exploiter of talent your position must be unshakable, or you will be accused of deception.
有时候，窃取他人劳动成果并非明智之举：如果你的权力不够稳固，就会显得你在排挤他人。要想成为一位高明的人才发掘者，你的地位必须牢不可破，否则就会被指控欺骗。
Be sure you know when letting other people share the credit serves your purpose. It is especially important to not be greedy when you have a master above you. President Richard Nixon's historic visit to the People's Republic of China was originally his idea, but it might never have come off but for the deft diplomacy of Henry Kissinger. Nor would it have been as successful without Kissinger's skills. Still, when the time came to take credit, Kissinger adroitiy let Nixon take die lion's share. Knowing that the truth would come out later, he was careful not to jeopardize his standing in the short term by hogging the limelight. Kissinger played the game expertly: He took credit for the work of those below him while graciously giving credit for his own labors to those above. That is the way to play the game.
要确保你清楚何时应该让别人分享功劳，这符合你的目的。尤其是在你拥有上级领导时，更要避免贪婪。尼克松总统对中华人民共和国的历史性访问最初是他的主意，但如果没有基辛格高超的外交手腕，这次访问或许根本无法实现。即使没有基辛格的才能，这次访问也不会如此成功。然而，当需要邀功的时候，基辛格巧妙地让尼克松独揽了大部分功劳。他知道真相终会水落石出，所以小心翼翼地避免因独占风头而危及自己的短期地位。基辛格玩弄权术高明：他把下属的功劳据为己有，同时又谦逊地把自己的功劳归于上级。这才是玩转权术的正确方式。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 8
第八条
MAKE OTHER PEOPLE
让其他人
COME TO YOU
来找你
USE BAIT IF NECESSARY
必要时使用诱饵
JUDGMENT
判断
When you force the other person to act, you are the one in control. It is always better to make your opponent come to you, abandoning his own plans in the process. Lure him with fabulous gainsthen attack. You hold the cards.
当你迫使对方采取行动时，你就掌握了主动权。最好是让对手主动投降，从而放弃他原有的计划。用诱人的优势引诱他，然后发起进攻。你才是主动权的掌控者。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
At die Congress of Vienna in 1814, die major powers of Europe gadiered to carve up the remains of Napoleon's fallen Empire. The city was full of gaiety and die balls were die most splendid in memory. Hovering over die proceedings, however, was die shadow of Napoleon himself. Instead of being executed or exiled far away, he had been sent to die island of Elba, not far from die coast of Italy.
1814年维也纳会议上，欧洲列强齐聚一堂，瓜分拿破仑帝国的残余势力。整座城市洋溢着欢乐的气氛，舞会盛况空前，令人难忘。然而，拿破仑的阴影始终笼罩着整个会议。他没有被处决或流放，而是被流放到离意大利海岸不远的厄尔巴岛。
Even imprisoned on an island, a man as bold and creative as Napoleon Bonaparte made everyone nervous. The Austrians plotted to kill him on Elba, but decided it was too risky. Alexander I, Russia's temperamental czar, heightened die anxiety by dirowing a fit during the congress when a part of Poland was denied him: “Beware, I shall loose die monster!” he mreatened. Everyone knew he meant Napoleon. Of all die statesmen gadiered in Vienna, only Talleyrand, Napoleon's former foreign minister, seemed calm and unconcerned. It was as if he knew somediing the odiers did not.
即使被囚禁在岛上，像拿破仑·波拿巴这样胆识过人、富有创造力的人也让所有人感到不安。奥地利人曾密谋在厄尔巴岛刺杀他，但最终认为风险太大而作罢。俄国性情暴躁的沙皇亚历山大一世在维也纳会议上因波兰部分领土被剥夺而大发雷霆，加剧了人们的焦虑：“小心，我要放出那个怪物！”他咆哮道。人人都知道他指的是拿破仑。在维也纳聚集的所有政治家中，只有拿破仑的前外交大臣塔列朗显得平静而淡定。仿佛他知道一些其他人不知道的事情。
Meanwhile, on die island of Elba, Napoleon's life was a mockery of his previous glory. As Elba's “king,” he had been allowed to form a court there was a cook, a wardrobe mistress, an official pianist, and a handful of courtiers. All this was designed to humiliate Napoleon, and it seemed to work.
与此同时，在厄尔巴岛上，拿破仑的生活与他昔日的辉煌形成了鲜明的对比。作为厄尔巴岛的“国王”，他被允许组建一个朝廷，里面有厨师、服装管理员、官方钢琴师和寥寥几位侍臣。这一切都是为了羞辱拿破仑，而且似乎奏效了。
That winter, however, there occurred a series of events so strange and dramatic they might have been scripted in a play. Elba was surrounded by British ships, dieir cannons covering all possible exit points. Yet somehow, in broad daylight on 26 February 1815, a ship with nine hundred men on board picked up Napoleon and put to sea. The English gave chase but the ship got away. This almost impossible escape astonished die public throughout Europe, and terrified die statesmen at the Congress of Vienna.
然而，那年冬天发生了一系列离奇而戏剧性的事件，简直像是剧本里的情节。厄尔巴岛被英国军舰包围，所有可能的出口都被大炮封锁。然而，就在1815年2月26日光天化日之下，一艘载有九百人的船只接走了拿破仑，驶向大海。英国人奋力追击，但船只最终逃脱了。这次几乎不可能的逃脱震惊了整个欧洲，也让维也纳会议上的政治家们惊恐万分。
Akhough it would have been safer to leave Europe, Napoleon not only chose to return to France, he raised die odds by marching on Paris with a tiny army, in hopes of recapturing the throne. His strategy workedpeople of all classes direw themselves at his feet. An army under Marshal Ney sped from Paris to arrest him, but when die soldiers saw dieir beloved former leader, diey changed sides. Napoleon was declared emperor again. Volunteers swelled the ranks of his new army. Delirium swept the country. In Paris, crowds went wild. The king who had replaced Napoleon fled the country.
尽管离开欧洲更为安全，拿破仑不仅选择返回法国，还率领一支人数不多的军队向巴黎进军，企图夺回皇位，这无疑增加了获胜的几率。他的策略令各阶层的劳动人民都对他趋之若鹜。内伊元帅率领的军队从巴黎疾驰而来，试图逮捕他，但当士兵们见到他们敬爱的昔日领袖时，他们纷纷倒戈。拿破仑再次被拥立为皇帝。志愿者们迅速壮大了他的新军。举国上下陷入狂热。巴黎的民众更是欣喜若狂。取代拿破仑的国王被迫逃离法国。
For die next hundred days, Napoleon ruled France. Soon, however, the giddiness subsided. France was bankrupt, its resources nearly exhausted, and diere was little Napoleon could do about mis. At die Batde of Waterloo, in June of diat year, he was finally defeated for good. This time his enemies had learned dieir lesson: They exiled him to the barren island of Saint Helena, off the west coast of Africa. There he had no more hope of escape.
接下来的100天里，拿破仑统治着法国。然而，这种狂喜很快就消退了。法国已经破产，资源几乎耗尽，拿破仑对此也无能为力。在同年6月的滑铁卢战役中，他最终彻底战败。这一次，他的敌人吸取了教训：他们把他流放到非洲西海岸荒凉的圣赫勒拿岛。在那里，他再也没有逃脱的希望。
Interpretation
解释
Only years later did the facts of Napoleon's dramatic escape from Elba come to light. Before he decided to attempt diis bold move, visitors to his court had told him diat he was more popular in France than ever, and diat
多年以后，拿破仑戏剧性地逃离厄尔巴岛的真相才为人所知。在他决定尝试这一大胆举动之前，来访的宫廷人士告诉他，他在法国的声望比以往任何时候都高，而且……
the country would embrace him again. One of tiiese visitors was Austria's General Koller, who convinced Napoleon that if he escaped, the European powers, England included, would welcome him back into power. Napoleon was tipped off that the English would let him go, and indeed his escape occurred in the middle of the afternoon, in full view of English spyglasses.
这个国家会再次接纳他。其中一位访客是奥地利将军科勒，他向拿破仑保证，如果他能逃脱，包括英国在内的欧洲列强都会欢迎他重返权力中心。拿破仑事先得到消息，英国人会放他走，而他的逃脱也确实发生在下午，就在英国人的望远镜的注视下。
What Napoleon did not know was that there was a man behind it all, pulling the strings, and that this man was his former minister, Talleyrand. And Talleyrand was doing all this not to bring back the glory days but to crush Napoleon once and for all. Considering the emperor's ambition unsettling to Europe's stability, he had turned against him long ago. When Napoleon was exiled to Elba, Talleyrand had protested. Napoleon should be sent farther away, he argued, or Europe would never have peace. But no one listened.
拿破仑并不知道，这一切背后有一个人在操纵，而这个人正是他以前的大臣塔列朗。塔列朗这样做并非为了重现昔日的辉煌，而是为了彻底击垮拿破仑。他认为皇帝的野心会扰乱欧洲的稳定，因此很久以前就与他反目成仇。当拿破仑被流放到厄尔巴岛时，塔列朗曾提出抗议。他认为，应该把拿破仑流放到更远的地方，否则欧洲将永无宁日。但无人理会他的意见。
Instead of pushing his opinion, Talleyrand bided his time. Working quiedy, he eventually won over Casdereagh and Metternich, the foreign ministers of England and Austria.
塔列朗没有强加自己的观点，而是耐心等待时机。他巧妙地游说，最终赢得了英国外交大臣卡斯德雷和奥地利外交大臣梅特涅的支持。
Together these men baited Napoleon into escaping. Even Roller's visit, to whisper the promise of glory in die exile's ear, was part of the plan. Like a master cardplayer, Talleyrand figured eveiything out in advance. He knew Napoleon would fall into the trap he had set. He also foresaw that Napoleon would lead the country into a war, which, given France's weakened condition, could only last a few mondis. One diplomat in Vienna, who understood that Talleyrand was behind it all, said, “He has set the house ablaze in order to save it from the plague.”
这些人合谋诱使拿破仑逃亡。就连罗勒的来访——在流亡者耳边低语荣耀的承诺——也是计划的一部分。塔列朗就像一位技艺高超的牌手，事先就已洞悉一切。他知道拿破仑会落入他设下的陷阱。他还预见到拿破仑会将国家拖入战争，而鉴于法国当时的虚弱状态，这场战争只会持续几个世纪。一位身在维也纳的外交官明白这一切都是塔列朗的阴谋，他说：“他放火烧房子是为了拯救它免遭瘟疫。”
When I have laid bait for deer,
当我放置诱饵引诱鹿群时，
I don't shoot at the first doe that comes to sniff,
我不会对第一只过来嗅闻的母鹿开枪。
but wait until the whole herd has gathered round.
但要等到所有牛群都聚集过来。
Otto von Bismarck, 1815-1898
奥托·冯·俾斯麦，1815-1898
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
How many times has this scenario played itself out in history: An aggressive leader initiates a series of bold moves mat begin by bringing him much power. Slowly, however, his power reaches a peak, and soon everything turns against him. His numerous enemies band together; trying to maintain his power, he exhausts himself going in this direction and that, and inevitably he collapses. The reason for this pattern is that the aggressive person is rarely in full control. He cannot see more than a couple of moves ahead, cannot see the consequences of diis bold move or that one. Because he is constantiy being forced to react to the moves of his evergrowing host of enemies, and to the unforeseen consequences of his own rash actions, his aggressive energy is turned against him.
历史上，这样的场景上演过多少次：一位咄咄逼人的领导者发起一系列大胆的行动，起初或许能让他迅速掌握权力。然而，随着权力逐渐达到顶峰，一切很快便开始对他不利。他的众多敌人联合起来；为了保住权力，他疲于奔命，疲于奔命，最终必然走向崩溃。这种模式的根源在于，咄咄逼人者很少能完全掌控局面。他无法预见未来几步以上的行动，也无法预知这一步或那一步大胆行动的后果。由于他不得不不断应对日益增多的敌人的行动，以及自身鲁莽行为带来的不可预见的后果，他的咄咄逼人的能量最终反噬自身。
In the realm of power, you must ask yourself, what is the point of chasing here and mere, trying to solve problems and defeat my enemies, if I never feel in control Why am I always having to react to events instead of directing them The answer is simple: Your idea of power is wrong. You
在权力领域，你必须扪心自问：如果我从未感到掌控一切，那么追逐、解决问题、击败敌人又有何意义？为什么我总是被动地应对事件，而不是主动地引导它们？答案很简单：你对权力的理解是错误的。
have mistaken aggressive action for effective action. And most often the most effective action is to stay back, keep calm, and let others be frustrated by the traps you lay for them, playing for long-term power rather than quick victory.
他们常常把咄咄逼人的行动误认为有效的行动。而大多数情况下，最有效的行动是保持冷静，按兵不动，让对手因你设下的陷阱而感到沮丧，着眼于长远的权力而非短暂的胜利。
Remember: The essence of power is the ability to keep the initiative, to get others to react to your moves, to keep your opponent and those around you on the defensive. When you make other people come to you, you suddenly become the one controlling the situation. And the one who has control has power. Two things must happen to place you in this position: You yourself must learn to master your emotions, and never to be influenced by anger; meanwhile, however, you must play on people's natural tendency to react angrily when pushed and baited. In the long run, the ability to make others come to you is a weapon far more powerful than any tool of aggression.
记住：权力的本质在于掌握主动权，让别人对你的行动做出反应，让你的对手和周围的人都处于被动防守的状态。当你让别人向你靠拢时，你就突然掌控了局面。而掌控局面的人就拥有了权力。要做到这一点，必须做到两点：首先，你必须学会控制自己的情绪，绝不被愤怒左右；其次，你必须利用人们在受到挑衅和激怒时容易愤怒的本能。从长远来看，让别人向你靠拢的能力，远比任何攻击手段都更有力量。
Study how Talleyrand, the master of the art, performed this delicate trick. First, he overcame the urge to try to convince his fellow statesmen that they needed to banish Napoleon far away. It is only natural to want to persuade people by pleading your case, imposing your will with words. But this often turns against you. Few of Talleyrand's contemporaries believed Napoleon was still a threat, so that if he had spent a lot of energy trying to convince them, he would only have made himself look foolish. Instead, he held his tongue and his emotions in check. Most important of all, he laid Napoleon a sweet and irresistible trap. He knew the man's weakness, his impetuosity, his need for glory and the love of the masses, and he played all this to perfection. When Napoleon went for the bait, there was no danger that he might succeed and turn the tables on Talleyrand, who better than anyone knew France's depleted state. And even had Napoleon been able to overcome these difficulties, the likelihood of his success would have been greater were he able to choose his time and place of action. By setting the proper trap, Talleyrand took the time and place into his own hands.
研究一下政治大师塔列朗是如何施展这一精妙计的。首先，他克制住了想要说服同僚们将拿破仑驱逐出境的冲动。人之常情，都想通过恳求、言辞强加意志来说服他人。但这往往会适得其反。塔列朗的同代人中，几乎没人相信拿破仑仍然构成威胁，所以如果他费尽心思去说服他们，只会显得愚蠢。相反，他克制住了自己的言辞和情绪。最重要的是，他为拿破仑设下了一个甜蜜而又无法抗拒的陷阱。他深谙拿破仑的弱点、冲动、对荣耀的渴望以及对民众爱戴的渴求，并将这一切运用得炉火纯青。当拿破仑落入圈套时，他完全没有可能得逞，从而反败为胜，因为塔列朗比任何人都更了解法国当时的窘境。即便拿破仑能够克服这些困难，如果他能选择行动的时机和地点，成功的可能性也会更大。塔列朗通过设下合适的陷阱，将时间和地点掌握在了自己手中。
All of us have only so much energy, and there is a moment when our energies are at their peak. When you make the other person come to you, he wears himself out, wasting his energy on the trip. In the year 1905, Russia and Japan were at war. The Japanese had only recently begun to modernize their warships, so that the Russians had a stronger navy, but by spreading false information the Japanese marshal Togo Heihachiro baited the Russians into leaving their docks in the Baltic Sea, making them believe they could wipe out the Japanese fleet in one swift attack. The Russian fleet could not reach Japan by the quickest routethrough the Strait of Gibraltar and then the Suez Canal into the Indian Oceanbecause these were controlled by the British, and Japan was an ally of Great Britain. They had to go around the Cape of Good Hope, at die southern tip of Africa, adding over more than six thousand miles to die voyage. Once the fleet passed the Cape, the Japanese spread another false story: They were sailing to launch a counterattack. So the Russians made the entire journey to Japan on combat alert. By the time diey arrived, their seamen were tense, exhausted, and overworked, while the Japanese had been waiting at their ease. Despite die
我们每个人的精力都是有限的，而且精力充沛的时刻也终有尽头。如果你强迫对方来找你，他会筋疲力尽，把精力浪费在路上。1905年，俄国和日本正处于战争状态。日本人不久前才开始对其军舰进行现代化改造，这使得俄国海军实力有所增强。然而，日本元帅东乡平八郎散布虚假情报，诱使俄国人离开波罗的海的船坞，让他们误以为可以一举歼灭日本舰队。俄国舰队无法通过直布罗陀海峡和苏伊士运河进入印度洋的最快路线抵达日本，因为这些海峡当时由英国控制，而日本是英国的盟友。他们不得不绕过非洲南端的开普敦，航程增加了六千多英里。舰队越过好望角后，日本人又散布了另一个谎言：他们正准备发动反击。因此，俄国人全程处于战备状态，驶往日本。当他们抵达时，他们的水手们已经筋疲力竭、紧张不已，而日本人却早已悠然自得地等待着。尽管如此，俄国人还是……
odds and their lack of experience in modern naval warfare, the Japanese crushed the Russians.
尽管日军实力悬殊，且缺乏现代海战经验，但日军仍然击败了俄军。
One added benefit of making the opponent come to you, as the Japanese discovered with the Russians, is that it forces him to operate in your territory. Being on hostile ground will make him nervous and often he will rush his actions and make mistakes. For negotiations or meetings, it is always wise to lure others into your territory, or the territory of your choice. You have your bearings, while they see nothing familiar and are subdy placed on the defensive.
让对手主动进攻的另一个好处，正如日本人对付俄国人所发现的那样，是迫使对手在你的领土上行动。身处敌对地带会令对手紧张不安，他们往往会仓促行事，犯下错误。进行谈判或会晤时，明智的做法是将对方引诱到你的领土，或者你选择的领土。你对周围环境了如指掌，而对手则一无所知，只能被动地处于守势。
Manipulation is a dangerous game. Once someone suspects he is being manipulated, it becomes harder and harder to control him. But when you make your opponent come to you, you create the illusion that he is controlling the situation. He does not feel the strings that pull him, just as Napoleon imagined that he himself was the master of his daring escape and return to power.
操纵是一种危险的游戏。一旦有人怀疑自己被操纵，就越来越难以控制他。但当你让对手主动靠近你时，你就制造了一种错觉，让他觉得自己掌控着局面。他感觉不到自己被牵着鼻子走，就像拿破仑想象自己才是那次大胆逃亡和重返权力巅峰的幕后主使一样。
Everything depends on the sweetness of your bait. If your trap is attractive enough, the turbulence of your enemies' emotions and desires will blind them to reality. The greedier they become, the more they can be led around.
一切都取决于你的诱饵有多诱人。如果你的陷阱足够吸引人，敌人的情绪和欲望就会蒙蔽他们的双眼，让他们看不清现实。他们越贪婪，就越容易被你牵着鼻子走。
The great nineteenth-century robber baron Daniel Drew was a master at playing the stock market. When he wanted a particular stock to be bought or sold, driving prices up or down, he rarely resorted to the direct approach. One of his tricks was to hurry through an exclusive club near Wall Street, obviously on his way to the stock exchange, and to pull out his customary red bandanna to wipe his perspiring brow. A slip of paper would fall from this bandanna that he would pretend not to notice. The club's members were always trying to foresee Drew's moves, and they would pounce on the paper, which invariably seemed to contain an inside tip on a stock. Word would spread, and members would buy or sell the stock in droves, playing perfectly into Drew's hands.
十九世纪的“强盗大亨”丹尼尔·德鲁是操纵股市的高手。当他想让别人买入或卖出某只股票，从而推高或压低股价时，他很少直接出手。他的惯用伎俩之一是匆匆穿过华尔街附近的一家高级俱乐部，显然是要去证券交易所，然后掏出他惯用的红色头巾擦汗。这时，一张纸条会从头巾里掉出来，他假装没看见。俱乐部的成员总是试图预测德鲁的动向，他们会迅速抢夺这张纸条，因为纸条上总是包含着某只股票的内幕消息。消息一传开，俱乐部成员就会成群结队地买卖这只股票，正中德鲁的下怀。
If you can get other people to dig their own graves, why sweat yourself Pickpockets work this to perfection. The key to picking a pocket is knowing which pocket contains the wallet. Experienced pickpockets often ply their trade in train stations and other places where there is a clearly marked sign reading BEWARE OF PICKPOCKETS. Passersby seeing the sign invariably feel for their wallet to make sure it is still there. For the watching pickpockets, this is like shooting fish in a barrel. Pickpockets have even been known to place their own BEWARE OF PICKPOCKETS signs to ensure their success.
如果能让别人自掘坟墓，何必自己费心呢？扒手们把这套伎俩运用得炉火纯青。扒窃的关键在于知道钱包在哪个口袋里。经验丰富的扒手经常在火车站和其他设有“小心扒手”标志的地方作案。路人看到标志后，总会下意识地摸摸钱包，确认它还在。对伺机而动的扒手来说，这简直易如反掌。为了确保行窃成功，扒手们甚至会自己放置“小心扒手”的标志。
When you are making people come to you, it is sometimes better to let them know you are forcing their hand. You give up deception for overt manipulation. The psychological ramifications are profound: The person who makes others come to him appears powerful, and demands respect.
当你想让别人主动靠近你时，有时最好让他们知道你是在逼他们。你放弃了欺骗，转而采用公开的操控。这种做法的心理影响深远：能够让别人主动靠近自己的人会显得更有力量，也更能赢得尊重。
Filippo Brunelleschi, the great Renaissance artist and architect, was a great practitioner of the art of making others come to him as a sign of his power. On one occasion he had been engaged to repair the dome of die Santa Maria del Fiore cathedral in Florence. The commission was impor-
伟大的文艺复兴时期艺术家和建筑师菲利波·布鲁内莱斯基，是一位善于运用人脉关系来彰显自身影响力的大师。他曾受聘修复佛罗伦萨圣母百花大教堂的穹顶。这项委托意义重大——
tant and prestigious. But when the city officials hired a second man, Lorenzo Ghiberti, to work with Brunelleschi, the great artist brooded in secret. He knew that Ghiberti had gotten the job through his connections, and that he would do none of the work and get half the credit. At a critical moment of the construction, then, Brunelleschi suddenly developed a mysterious illness. He had to stop work, but pointed out to city officials that they had hired Ghiberti, who should have been able to continue the work on his own. Soon it became clear that Ghiberti was useless and the officials came begging to Brunelleschi. He ignored mem, insisting that Ghiberti should finish the project, until finally they realized the problem: They fired Ghiberti.
布鲁内莱斯基的艺术生涯辉煌而卓著。然而，当市政官员聘请了第二位工匠洛伦佐·吉贝尔蒂与布鲁内莱斯基合作时，这位伟大的艺术家却暗自思忖。他知道吉贝尔蒂是靠关系才得到这份工作的，他不会付出任何努力，却能分走一半的功劳。就在工程的关键时刻，布鲁内莱斯基突然患上了一种神秘的疾病。他不得不停工，但他向市政官员指出，他们聘请了吉贝尔蒂，而吉贝尔蒂本应能够独自完成这项工作。很快，吉贝尔蒂的无能就暴露无遗，官员们纷纷前来恳求布鲁内莱斯基。他置之不理，坚持让吉贝尔蒂完成工程，直到最后他们才意识到问题的症结所在：他们解雇了吉贝尔蒂。
By some miracle, Brunelleschi recovered within days. He did not have to throw a tantrum or make a fool of himself; he simply practiced the art of “making others come to you.”
奇迹般地，布鲁内莱斯基几天之内就康复了。他无需大发脾气或出丑；他只是运用了“让别人主动靠近你”的艺术。
If on one occasion you make it a point of dignity that others must come to you and you succeed, they will continue to do so even after you stop trying.
如果你有一次表现得很有尊严，让别人不得不来找你，并且你成功了，即使你不再努力，他们也会继续这样做。
Image: The Honeyed Bear Trap. The bear hunter does not chase his prey; a bear that knows it is hunted is nearly impossible to catch and is ferocious if cornered. Instead, the hunter lays traps baited with honey. He does not exhaust himself and risk his life in pursuit He baits, then waits.
图片：蜜熊陷阱。猎熊人不会追逐猎物；一头知道自己被猎杀的熊几乎不可能被抓住，而且如果被逼到角落会非常凶猛。因此，猎熊人会设置用蜂蜜作诱饵的陷阱。他不会让自己筋疲力尽、冒着生命危险去追逐猎物，而是放置诱饵，然后静静等待。
Authority: Good warriors make others come to them, and do not go to others. This is the principle of emptiness and fullness of others and self. When you induce opponents to come to you, then their force is always empty; as long as you do not go to them, your force is always full. Attacking emptiness with fullness is like throwing stones on eggs. (Zhang Yu, eleventh-century commentator on The Art of War)
权威：优秀的战士让对手来袭，而不是主动出击。这就是他者与自身空与满的原则。当你诱敌前来时，他们的力量总是空虚的；只要你不主动出击，你的力量就总是满满的。以满攻空，如同用石头砸鸡蛋。（张羽，《孙子兵法》十一世纪注释者）
REVERSAL
逆转
Although it is generally the wiser policy to make others exhaust themselves chasing you, there are opposite cases where striking suddenly and aggressively at the enemy so demoralizes him that his energies sink. Instead of making others come to you, you go to them, force the issue, take the lead. Fast attack can be an awesome weapon, for it forces the other person to react without the time to tiiink or plan. With no time to think, people make errors of judgment, and are thrown on die defensive. This tactic is the obverse of waiting and baiting, but it serves die same function: You make your enemy respond on your terms.
虽然通常来说，让对手疲于奔命地追击自己才是更明智的策略，但也存在相反的情况：突然而猛烈地攻击敌人，会极大地打击其士气，使其精疲力竭。与其被动地等待对手，不如主动出击，掌控局面，占据主动。快速攻击是一种威力强大的武器，因为它迫使对手在毫无思考或计划的情况下做出反应。在缺乏思考时间的情况下，人们容易做出错误的判断，并被迫转入被动防守。这种策略与等待和诱敌截然相反，但其作用相同：迫使敌人按照你的节奏做出反应。
Men like Cesare Borgia and Napoleon used tiie element of speed to intimidate and control. A rapid and unforeseen move is terrifying and demoralizing. You must choose your tactics depending on the situation. If you have time on your side, and know that you and your enemies are at least at equal strength, then deplete their strength by making them come to you. If time is against youyour enemies are weaker, and waiting will only give them the chance to recovergive tiiem no such chance. Strike quickly and they have nowhere to go. As the boxer Joe Louis put it, “He can run, but he can't hide.”
像切萨雷·博尔吉亚和拿破仑这样的人都利用速度来恐吓和控制对手。快速而出其不意的行动令人胆寒，也能瓦解敌人的士气。你必须根据形势选择战术。如果你时间充裕，并且知道你和敌人实力至少相当，那么就通过迫使他们主动进攻来消耗他们的实力。如果时间对你不利，你的敌人就比较虚弱，等待只会给他们喘息的机会——不要给他们这样的机会。迅速出击，让他们无处可逃。正如拳击手乔·路易斯所说：“他能跑，但他躲不掉。”
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 9
法律9
WIN THROUGH YOUR
通过你的努力赢得胜利
ACTIONS, NEVER THROUGH ARGUMENT
行动胜于争论
JUDGMENT
判断
Any momentary triumph you think you have gained through argument is really a Pyrrhic victory: The resentment and ill will you stir up is stronger and lasts longer than any momentary change of opinion. It is much more powerful to get others to agree with you through your actions, without saying a word. Demonstrate, do not explicate.
你以为通过争论获得的短暂胜利，其实是得不偿失的：你激起的怨恨和敌意远比任何短暂的观点转变都更加强烈、更加持久。用行动而非言语赢得他人的认同，远比任何解释都更有力量。用行动证明，而非空谈。
A vizier had served his master for some thirty years and was known and admired for his loyalty, truthfulness, and devotion to God. His honesty, however, had made him many enemies in the court, who spread stories of his duplicity and perfidy. They worked on the sultan dav in and day out until he loo came to distrust the innocent vizier and finally ordered the man who had served him so well to he put to death. In this realm, those condemned to death were tied up and thrown into the pen where the sultan kept his fiercest hunting dogs. The dogs would promptly tear the victim to pieces. Before being thrown to the dogs, however, the vizier asked for one last request. “I would like ten days' respite,”he said, “so that I can pay tnv debts, collect any monev due to me, return items that people have put in my care, and share out my goods among the mendiers of tnv family and mv children and appoint a guardian for them. ” After receiving a guar antee that the vizier would not try to escape, the sultan granted this request. The vizier hurried home, collected one hundred gold pieces, then paid a visit to the huntsman who looked after the sultan \s
一位维齐尔侍奉他的君主约三十年，以忠诚、诚实和对真主的虔诚而闻名遐迩，备受敬仰。然而，他的正直也为他在朝廷中树敌众多，这些人四处散播他两面三刀、背信弃义的谣言。他们日复一日地向苏丹散布谣言，直到苏丹最终对这位清白的维齐尔彻底失去了信任，下令处死这位曾为他效力多年的臣子。在那个国度里，被判处死刑的人会被捆绑起来，扔进苏丹饲养最凶猛猎犬的犬舍。猎犬会立刻将他们撕成碎片。然而，在被扔进犬舍之前，维齐尔提出了最后一个请求。 “我请求十天的宽限，”他说，“以便偿还债务，收回欠款，归还人们委托我保管的物品，并将我的财产分配给我的家人和孩子们，并为他们指定监护人。”在得到维齐尔不会逃跑的保证后，苏丹批准了他的请求。维齐尔匆匆赶回家，取了一百枚金币，然后去拜访了照顾苏丹的猎人。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In 131 B.C., the Roman consul Publius Crassus Dives Mucianus, laying siege to the Greek town of Pergamus, found himself in need of a battering ram to force through the town's walls. He had seen a couple of hefty ship's masts in a shipyard in Athens a few days before, and he ordered that the larger of these be sent to him immediately. The military engineer in Athens who received the order felt certain that the consul really wanted the smaller of the masts. He argued endlessly with the soldiers who delivered the request: The smaller mast, he told them, was much better suited to the task. And indeed it would be easier to transport.
公元前131年，罗马执政官普布利乌斯·克拉苏·迪夫·穆西亚努斯围攻希腊城邦帕加马时，急需一架攻城槌来攻破城墙。几天前，他在雅典的一个造船厂看到几根粗壮的船桅，便下令立即将其中较大的一根送来。接到命令的雅典军事工程师却认为执政官真正想要的是较小的那根桅杆。他与前来送信的士兵争论不休：他告诉他们，较小的桅杆更适合这项任务，而且也更容易运输。
The soldiers warned the engineer that their master was not a man to argue with, but he insisted that the smaller mast would be the only one that would work with a machine that he was constructing to go with it. He drew diagram after diagram, and went so far as to say that he was the expert and they had no clue what they were talking about. The soldiers knew their leader and at last convinced the engineer that it would be better to swallow his expertise and obey.
士兵们警告工程师，他们的上司不是好争辩的，但他坚持说只有那根小桅杆才能与他正在建造的配套机器配合使用。他画了一张又一张图，甚至声称自己才是专家，而他们根本不懂。士兵们了解他们的首领，最终说服了工程师，让他听从自己的“专家”之言，服从命令才是上司的最好选择。
After they left, though, the engineer thought about it some more. What was the point, he asked himself, in obeying an order that would lead to failure And so he sent the smaller mast, confident that the consul would see how much more effective it was and reward him jusdy.
他们走后，工程师又仔细想了想。他问自己，服从一个注定失败的命令有什么意义呢？于是，他派出了较小的桅杆，相信领事会看到它更有效的用途，并会给予他应有的奖励。
When the smaller mast arrived, Mucianus asked his soldiers for an explanation. They described to him how the engineer had argued endlessly for the smaller mast, but had finally promised to send the larger one. Mucianus went into a rage. He could not concentrate on the siege, or consider the importance of breaching the walls before the town received reinforcements. All he could think about was the impudent engineer, whom he ordered to be brought to him immediately.
当较小的桅杆运到时，穆恰努斯询问士兵们缘由。士兵们向他解释说，工程师之前一直坚持要用较小的桅杆，但最终还是答应送来较大的。穆恰努斯勃然大怒。他无法集中精力围城，也无法考虑在援军到达之前攻破城墙的重要性。他满脑子想的都是那个厚颜无耻的工程师，并下令立即将他带到自己面前。
Arriving a few days later, the engineer gladly explained to the consul, one more time, the reasons for the smaller mast. He went on and on, using me same arguments he had made with the soldiers. He said it was wise to listen to experts in these matters, and if the attack was only tried with the battering ram he had sent, die consul would not regret it. Mucianus let him finish, then had him stripped naked before the soldiers and flogged and scourged with rods until he died.
几天后，工程师再次兴高采烈地向执政官解释了桅杆较小的原因。他滔滔不绝地讲着，用的还是之前跟士兵们说的那些理由。他说，听取专家的意见是明智之举，如果只用他派来的攻城槌来尝试进攻，执政官肯定不会后悔。穆西亚努斯让他说完，然后下令把他剥光衣服，当着士兵的面用棍棒鞭打，直到他死去。
Interpretation
解释
The engineer, whose name has not been recorded by history, had spent his life designing masts and pillars, and was respected as the finest engineer in a city that had excelled in the science. He knew that he was right. A smaller ram would allow more speed and carry more force. Larger is not necessarily better. Of course the consul would see his logic, and would eventually understand that science is neutral and reason superior. How could the consul possibly persist in his ignorance if the engineer showed him detailed diagrams and explained the theories behind his advice
这位工程师的名字已无从考证，他毕生致力于设计桅杆和柱子，在科学造诣颇深的城市中，他被尊为最杰出的工程师。他深知自己的判断是正确的：较小的撞角能带来更高的速度和更大的推力。并非越大越好。当然，执政官会理解他的逻辑，最终明白科学是中立的，理性才是至高无上的。如果这位工程师向他展示了详细的图纸，并解释了其建议背后的理论，执政官又怎能执迷不悟呢？
The military engineer was the quintessence of die Arguer, a type found everywhere among us. The Arguer does not understand that words
这位军事工程师是“争论者”的典型代表，这种人在我们身边随处可见。“争论者”不理解言语的含义。
are never neutral, and that by arguing with a superior he impugns the intelligence of one more powerful than he. He also has no awareness of the person he is dealing with. Since each man believes that he is right, and words will rarely convince him otherwise, the arguer's reasoning falls on deaf ears. When cornered, he only argues more, digging his own grave. Once he has made the other person feel insecure and inferior in his beliefs, the eloquence of Socrates could not save the situation.
人永远不会保持中立，与比自己地位更高的人争论，实际上是在质疑对方的智慧。而且，他根本不了解自己面对的是谁。因为每个人都坚信自己是对的，言语也很难让他们改变想法，所以争论者的论证往往无人理睬。一旦陷入困境，他只会更加争辩，最终自取灭亡。一旦他让对方感到不安，觉得自己不如对方，即使苏格拉底的雄辩也无济于事。
It is not simply a question of avoiding an argument with those who stand above you. We all believe we are masters in the realm of opinions and reasoning. You must be careful, then: Learn to demonstrate the correctness of your ideas indirectiy.
这不仅仅是避免与地位高于你的人争论的问题。我们都认为自己是观点和推理领域的专家。因此，你必须谨慎：学会间接地证明你的观点是正确的。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In 1502, in Florence, Italy, an enormous block of marble stood in the works department of the church of Santa Maria del Fiore. It had once been a magnificent piece of raw stone, but an unskillful sculptor had mistakenly bored a hole through it where there should have been a figure's legs, generally mutilating it. Piero Soderini, Florence's mayor, had contemplated trying to save die block by commissioning Leonardo da Vinci to work on it, or some other master, but had given up, since everyone agreed mat die stone had been ruined. So, despite the money that had been wasted on it, it gathered dust in the dark halls of the church.
1502年，在意大利佛罗伦萨，圣母百花大教堂的工坊里矗立着一块巨大的大理石。它原本是一块精美的原石，但一位技艺拙劣的雕塑家误将原本应该雕刻人物腿部的地方凿穿，彻底毁坏了这块石头。佛罗伦萨市长皮耶罗·索德里尼曾考虑委托达·芬奇或其他大师来修复这块石头，但最终放弃了，因为所有人都认为这块石头已经毁了。于是，尽管在这块石头上浪费了不少钱，它最终还是在教堂阴暗的大厅里蒙上了灰尘。
This was where things stood until some Florentine friends of the great Michelangelo decided to write to the artist, then living in Rome. He alone, they said, could do sometiiing wim die marble, which was still magnificent raw material. Michelangelo traveled to Florence, examined die stone, and came to the conclusion mat he could in fact carve a fine figure from it, by adapting the pose to the way the rock had been mutilated. Soderini argued that this was a waste of timenobody could salvage such a disasterbut he finally agreed to let the artist work on it. Michelangelo decided he would depict a young David, sling in hand.
事情就这样发展下去，直到伟大的米开朗基罗的一些佛罗伦萨朋友决定写信给当时住在罗马的他。他们说，只有他才能用这块大理石创作出一些作品，因为那块大理石仍然是绝佳的原材料。米开朗基罗前往佛罗伦萨，仔细查看了这块石头，并得出结论：他确实可以从中雕刻出一个精美的雕像，方法是根据石头被破坏的方式调整姿势。索德里尼认为这是浪费时间——没有人能挽救这样一块残缺不全的石头——但他最终还是同意让这位艺术家进行创作。米开朗基罗决定雕刻一个手持投石索的年轻的大卫像。
Weeks later, as Michelangelo was putting the final touches on the statue, Soderini entered the studio. Fancying himself a bit of a connoisseur, he studied the huge work, and told Michelangelo that while he thought it was magnificent, die nose, he judged, was too big. Michelangelo realized that Soderini was standing in a place right under the giant figure and did not have the proper perspective. Without a word, he gestured for Soderini to follow him up the scaffolding. Reaching the nose, he picked up his chisel, as well as a bit of marble dust mat lay on the planks. Wim Soderini just a few feet below him on the scaffolding, Michelangelo started to tap lightly with the chisel, letting the bits of dust he had gathered in his hand to fall littie by litde. He actually did nothing to change the nose, but gave every appearance of working on it. After a few minutes of this charade he stood aside: “Look at it now.” “I like it better,” replied Soderini, “you've made it come alive.”
几周后，当米开朗基罗正在为雕像做最后的润色时，索德里尼走进了工作室。他自诩为艺术鉴赏家，仔细端详着这件巨作，并告诉米开朗基罗，虽然他认为雕像非常精美，但鼻子太大了。米开朗基罗意识到索德里尼正站在雕像正下方，视角不对。他一言不发，示意索德里尼跟他一起爬上脚手架。到达鼻子的位置后，他拿起凿子，以及铺在木板上的一些大理石粉。索德里尼就在他下方几英尺的脚手架上，米开朗基罗开始用凿子轻轻敲击，让手中收集的粉尘一点一点地落下。他实际上并没有改变鼻子，只是装出一副正在修整的样子。几分钟后，他走到一边，说道：“现在看看吧。” “我更喜欢这样，”索德里尼回答说，“你让它鲜活了起来。”
dogs. He offered this man the one hundred gold pieces and said, “Let me look after the dogs for ten days. ” The huntsman agreed, and for the next ten days the vizier cared for the beasts with great attention, grooming them well and feeding them handsomely. By the end of the ten days they were eating out of his hand.
他给了那人一百枚金币，说：“让我照看这些狗十天吧。”猎人答应了，接下来的十天里，宰相悉心照料这些牲畜，给它们梳理毛发，喂食丰盛。十天后，它们已经能从他手中取食了。
On the. eleventh day the vizier was called before the sultan, the charges were repeated, and the sultan watched as the vizier was tied up and thrown to the dogs. Yet when the beasts saw him, they ran up to him with wagging tails. They nibbled affectionately at his shoulders and began playing with him. The sultan and the other witnesses were amazed, and the sultan asked the vizier why the dogs had spared his life. The vizier replied, 'I have looked after these dogs for ten days. The sultan has seen the result for himself. I have looked after you for thirty years, and what is the result I am condemned to death on the strength of accusations brought by my enemies. " The sultan blushed with shame. He not only pardoned the vizier but gave him a fine set of clothes and handed over to him the men who had slandered his reputation. The noble vizier set them free and continued to treat them with kindness.
第十一天，维齐尔被召到苏丹面前，罪名再次被提起。苏丹亲眼目睹维齐尔被捆绑起来扔给狗。然而，当狗儿们看到他时，它们摇着尾巴跑了过来，亲昵地啃咬他的肩膀，和他玩耍起来。苏丹和其他目击者都感到惊讶，苏丹问维齐尔，为什么狗儿们饶了他一命。维齐尔回答说：“我照顾这些狗十天了，苏丹亲眼看到了结果。我照顾你们三十年了，结果呢？我却因为敌人的诬告而被判处死刑。”苏丹羞愧得满脸通红。他不仅赦免了维齐尔，还赐给他一套华服，并将诽谤他名誉的人交给了他。这位高贵的维齐尔释放了他们，并继续善待他们。
THE .SUBTLE RUSE: THE BOOK OF ARABIC WISDOM AND (HULK, THIRTEENTH CENTURY
《微妙的诡计：阿拉伯智慧之书》和（绿巨人，十三世纪）
'run works of a.masls
'运行 a.masls 的作品
When Apries had been deposed in the way I have described, Amasis came to the throne. He belonged to the district ofSais and was a native of the town called Siuph. At first the Egyptians were inclined to be contemptuous, and did not think much of him because of his humble and undistinguished origin; but later on he cleverly brought them to heel, without having recourse to harsh measures. Amongst his innumerable treasures, he had a gold footbath, which he and his guests used on occasion to wash their feet in. This he broke up, and with the material had a statue made to one of the gods, which he then set up in what he thought the most suitable spot in the city. The Egyptians constantly coming upon the statue, treated it with profound reverence, and as soon as Amasis heard of the effect it had upon them, he called a meeting and revealed the fact that the deeply revered statue was once a footbath, which they washed their feet and pissed and vomited in. He went on to say that his own case was much the same, in that once he had been only an ordinary person and was now their king; so that just as they had come to revere the transformed footbath, so they had better pay
阿普里斯被废黜后，阿马西斯继位。他来自赛斯地区，是锡乌夫城人。起初，埃及人对他颇为轻蔑，因为他出身卑微，不怎么看得起他；但后来，他巧妙地制服了他们，却并未采取任何强硬手段。在他数不胜数的珍宝中，有一个金制足浴盆，他和宾客偶尔会用它来洗脚。后来，他把足浴盆砸碎，用这些材料打造了一尊神像，并将其安放在他认为城中最合适的地方。埃及人经常看到那尊雕像，对它无比敬畏。阿玛西斯一听说这尊雕像对他们的影响，就召集大家开会，揭露了这尊备受尊崇的雕像原本是一个洗脚池，他们过去在里面洗脚、小便、呕吐。他还说，他自己的情况也差不多，他曾经只是个普通人，如今却成了他们的国王；既然他们敬畏这尊经过改造的洗脚池，他们也应该好好对待它。
Interpretation
解释
Michelangelo knew that by changing the shape of the nose he might ruin the entire sculpture. Yet Soderini was a patron who prided himself on his aesthetic judgment. To offend such a man by arguing would not only gain Michelangelo nothing, it would put future commissions in jeopardy. Michelangelo was too clever to argue. His solution was to change Soderini's perspective (literally bringing him closer to the nose) without making him realize that this was the cause of his misperception.
米开朗基罗深知，改变鼻子的形状可能会毁掉整座雕塑。然而，索德里尼是一位以审美眼光自负的赞助人。与这样的人争论不仅对米开朗基罗毫无益处，还会危及他未来的委托。米开朗基罗聪明过人，不会轻易与他争辩。他的解决办法是改变索德里尼的视角（实际上是让他更靠近鼻子），却不让他意识到这正是造成误解的原因。
Fortunately for posterity, Michelangelo found a way to keep the perfection of the statue intact while at the same time making Soderini believe he had improved it Such is the double power of winning through actions rather than argument: No one is offended, and your point is proven.
幸运的是，米开朗基罗找到了一种方法，既能保持雕像的完美，又能让索德里尼相信他已经改进了雕像。这就是用行动而不是争论来赢得胜利的双重力量：没有人会感到被冒犯，而且你的观点也得到了证明。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In the realm of power you must learn to judge your moves by their long-term effects on other people. The problem in trying to prove a point or gain a victory through argument is mat in the end you can never be certain how it affects the people you're arguing with: They may appear to agree with you politely, but inside they may resent you. Or perhaps something you said inadvertently even offended themwords have that insidious ability to be interpreted according to the other person's mood and insecurities. Even the best argument has no solid foundation, for we have all come to distrust the slippery nature of words. And days after agreeing with someone, we often revert to our old opinion out of sheer habit.
在权力领域，你必须学会根据你的行动对他人产生的长期影响来判断其后果。试图通过争论来证明观点或赢得胜利的问题在于，你最终永远无法确定这会对与你争论的人产生怎样的影响：他们表面上可能礼貌地同意你的观点，但内心可能对你心怀怨恨。或者，你无意中说的某些话甚至可能冒犯了他们——言语具有这种阴险的力量，可以根据对方的情绪和不安全感来解读。即使是最好的论点也没有坚实的基础，因为我们都开始怀疑言语的不可预测性。而且，即便几天前我们还同意某人的观点，但出于习惯，我们往往会回到之前的想法。
Understand this: Words are a dime a dozen. Everyone knows that in the heat of an argument, we will all say anything to support our cause. We will quote the Bible, refer to unverifiable statistics. Who can be persuaded by bags of air like that Action and demonstration are much more powerful and meaningful. They are there, before our eyes, for us to see“Yes, now the statue's nose does look just right.” There are no offensive words, no possibility of misinterpretation. No one can argue with a demonstrated proof. As Baltasar Gracian remarks, “The truth is generally seen, rarely heard.”
请记住：言语俯拾皆是。人人都知道，在激烈的争论中，为了支持自己的观点，我们什么话都说得出口。我们会引用《圣经》，会提及未经证实的统计数据。谁会被这种空洞的言辞所说服呢？行动和论证要强大得多，也更有意义。它们就摆在我们眼前，让我们亲眼所见：“没错，现在雕像的鼻子看起来确实很合适。”这里没有冒犯性的言辞，也没有误解的可能。没有人能反驳确凿的证据。正如巴尔塔萨·格拉西安所说：“真理通常是看得见的，却很少被听到。”
Sir Christopher Wren was England's version of the Renaissance man. He had mastered the sciences of mathematics, astronomy, physics, and physiology. Yet during his extremely long career as England's most celebrated architect he was often told by his patrons to make impractical changes in his designs. Never once did he argue or offend. He had other ways of proving his point.
克里斯托弗·雷恩爵士是英国的文艺复兴式人物。他精通数学、天文学、物理学和生理学。然而，在他漫长的职业生涯中，作为英国最负盛名的建筑师，他经常被赞助人要求修改设计方案，而这些修改往往不切实际。但他从未争辩或冒犯过他们。他有其他方式来证明自己的观点。
In 1688 Wren designed a magnificent town hall for the city of Westminster. The mayor, however, was not satisfied; in fact he was nervous. He told Wren he was afraid the second floor was not secure, and that it could all come crashing down on his office on the first floor. He demanded that Wren add two stone columns for extra support. Wren, the consummate engineer, knew that these columns would serve no purpose, and that the
1688年，雷恩为威斯敏斯特市设计了一座宏伟的市政厅。然而，市长并不满意，实际上他很紧张。他告诉雷恩，他担心二楼不够牢固，随时可能坍塌到他位于一楼的办公室。他要求雷恩加装两根石柱以加强支撑。雷恩是一位技艺精湛的工程师，他知道这些石柱毫无用处，而且……
mayor's fears were baseless. But build them he did, and the mayor was grateful. It was only years later that workmen on a high scaffold saw that the columns stopped just short of the ceiling.
市长的担忧毫无根据。但他还是把柱子建好了，市长对此感激不尽。直到多年以后，工人们在高高的脚手架上才发现，柱子离天花板还差一点。
They were dummies. But both men got what they wanted: The mayor could relax, and Wren knew posterity would understand that his original design worked and the columns were unnecessary.
他们是笨蛋。但两人都如愿以偿：市长可以放松了，而雷恩也知道后人会明白他最初的设计是成功的，那些柱子是多余的。
The power of demonstrating your idea is that your opponents do not get defensive, and are therefore more open to persuasion. Making them literally and physically feel your meaning is infinitely more powerful than argument.
用实际行动来展现你的观点，其力量在于让对手不再抱有防御心理，从而更容易被说服。让他们切身感受到你的意思，远比单纯的争论更有说服力。
A heckler once interrupted Nikita Khrushchev in the middle of a speech in which he was denouncing the crimes of Stalin. “You were a colleague of Stalin's,” the heckler yelled, “why didn't you stop him then” Khrushschev apparently could not see the heckler and barked out, “Who said that” No hand went up. No one moved a muscle. After a few seconds of tense silence, Khrushchev finally said in a quiet voice, “Now you know why I didn't stop him.” Instead of just arguing that anyone facing Stalin was afraid, knowing that the slightest sign of rebellion would mean certain death, he had made them feel what it was like to face Stalinhad made them feel the paranoia, the fear of speaking up, the terror of confronting the leader, in this case Khrushchev. The demonstration was visceral and no more argument was necessary.
赫鲁晓夫正在谴责斯大林的罪行，一位捣乱者突然打断了他的演讲。“你曾是斯大林的同事，”捣乱者喊道，“那你当时为什么不阻止他？”赫鲁晓夫显然没看到捣乱者，厉声问道：“谁说的？” 无人举手，也无人动弹。几秒钟紧张的沉默后，赫鲁晓夫终于平静地说：“现在你们知道我为什么没阻止他了吧。” 他没有仅仅辩解说，任何面对斯大林的人都会感到恐惧，因为哪怕最轻微的反抗都意味着死亡，而是让他们切身体会到了面对斯大林的感受——让他们感受到那种偏执、那种不敢发声的恐惧、那种与领导人（在这个例子中是赫鲁晓夫本人）对抗的恐惧。这种演示如此震撼人心，无需再多辩解。
The most powerful persuasion goes beyond action into symbol. The power of a symbola flag, a mythic story, a monument to some emotional eventis that everyone understands you without anything being said. In 1975, when Henry Kissinger was engaged in some frustrating negotiations with the Israelis over the return of part of the Sinai desert that they had seized in the 1967 war, he suddenly broke off a tense meeting and decided to do some sight-seeing. He paid a visit to the ruins of the ancient fortress of Masada, known to all Israelis as the place where seven hundred Jewish warriors committed mass suicide in A.D. 73 rather than give in to the Roman troops besieging them. The Israelis instantly understood the message of Kissinger's visit: He was indirecdy accusing them of courting mass suicide. Although the visit did not by itself change their minds, it made them think far more seriously than any direct warning would have. Symbols like this one carry great emotional significance.
最有力的说服力超越了行动，转向了象征意义。象征的力量——一面旗帜、一个神话故事、一座纪念某个感人事件的纪念碑——在于无需言语，人人都能理解你的意思。1975年，亨利·基辛格与以色列就归还1967年战争中占领的西奈半岛部分地区进行着令人沮丧的谈判。他突然中断了一场气氛紧张的会议，决定去观光。他参观了马萨达古堡的遗址。所有以色列人都知道，公元73年，七百名犹太战士为了不向围困他们的罗马军队投降，集体自杀。以色列人立刻明白了基辛格此行的用意：他是在间接地指责他们正在走向集体自杀。虽然这次参观本身并没有改变他们的想法，但它让他们比任何直接的警告都更加认真地思考。像这样的象征意义蕴含着巨大的情感价值。
When aiming for power, or trying to conserve it, always look for the indirect route. And also choose your batdes carefully. If it does not matter in the long run whemer the other person agrees with youor if time and their own experience will make them understand what you meanthen it is best not even to bother with a demonstration. Save your energy and walk away.
无论是为了获取权力还是为了保住权力，都要尽量选择迂回的方式。同时，也要谨慎选择你的对手。如果从长远来看，对方是否同意你的观点并不重要，或者随着时间的推移和他们自身的经验会让他们理解你的意思，那么最好不要费力去证明什么。省下你的精力，转身离开。
honor and respect to him, too. In this way the Egyptians were persuaded to accept him as their master.
他也赢得了人们的尊敬和爱戴。就这样，埃及人被说服，接受他为他们的主人。
the histories, Herodotus, fifth century b.c.
《历史》，希罗多德，公元前五世纪
COD AND ABRAHAM
鳕鱼和亚伯拉罕
The Most High God had promised that He would not take Abraham 's soul unless the man wanted to die and asked Him to do so. When Abraham's life was drawing to a close, and God determined to seize him, He sent an angel in the guise of a decrepit old man who was almost entirely incapacitated. The old man stopped outside Abraham's door and said to him, “Oh Abraham, I would like something to eat.” Abraham was amazed to hear him say this. “Die,” exclaimed Abraham. “It would be better for you than to go on living in that condition.” Abraham always kept food ready at his home for passing guests. So he gave the old man a bowl containing broth and meat with bread crumbs. The old man sat down to eat. He swallowed laboriously, with great effort, and once when he took some food it dropped from his hand, scattering on the ground. “Oh Abraham,” he said,
至高无上的上帝曾应许，除非亚伯拉罕自己想死并请求祂这样做，否则祂不会取走他的灵魂。当亚伯拉罕的生命即将走到尽头，上帝决定带走他时，祂差遣一位天使化作一位衰老虚弱、几乎完全丧失行动能力的老人。老人停在亚伯拉罕的门外，对他说：“哦，亚伯拉罕，我想吃点东西。”亚伯拉罕听到这话，感到非常惊讶。“去死吧，”亚伯拉罕喊道，“你这样活着比死了好。”亚伯拉罕总是在家中为过往的客人准备食物。于是，他给了老人一碗肉汤，里面有肉和面包屑。老人坐下来吃。他吃得很吃力，非常吃力，有一次他拿起一些食物时，食物从他手中掉落，散落在地上。“哦，亚伯拉罕，”他说，
“help me to eat.”Abraham took the food in his hand and lifted it to the old man's lips. But it slid down his beard and over his chest. “What i.s your age, old man” asked Abraham. The old man mentioned a number of years slightly greater than Abraham '.v old age. Then Abraham exclaimed: “Oh Lord Our God, take me unto You before I reach this man Is age and .sink into the same condition as he is in now. ” No sooner had Abraham spoken those words than God took possession of his soul.
“帮我吃点东西吧。”亚伯拉罕接过手中的食物，送到老人嘴边。食物却顺着老人的胡须滑落到胸前。“老人家，您多大年纪了？”亚伯拉罕问道。老人报出一个比亚伯拉罕略大的年纪。亚伯拉罕随即呼喊道：“主啊，我们的神啊，在我达到老人的年纪，堕落到他现在的境地之前，求您接我到您那里去。”亚伯拉罕话音刚落，神就占据了他的灵魂。
THE SUBTLH RUSE:
巧妙的计谋：
THE HOOK OK ARABIC
钩子 OK 阿拉伯语
WISDOM AND GUILE,
智慧与诡计
THIRTEENTH CENTURY
十三世纪
Image: The Seesaw. Up and down and up and down go the arguers, getting nowhere fast. Get off the seesaw and show them your meaning without kick ing or pushing. Leave them at the top and let gravity bring them gently to the ground.
图片：跷跷板。争论者们上下摇摆，却毫无进展。从跷跷板上下来，用行动向他们阐明你的意思，无需踢打或推搡。让他们留在顶端，让重力轻轻地将他们拉回地面。
Authority: Never argue. In society nothing must be discussed; give only results. (Benjamin Disraeli, 1804-1881)
权威：不要争论。在社会上，任何事情都不应该讨论；只给出结果。（本杰明·迪斯雷利，1804-1881）
REVERSAL
逆转
Verbal argument has one vital use in the realm of power: To distract and cover your tracks when you are practicing deception or are caught in a lie. In such cases it is to your advantage to argue with all the conviction you can muster. Draw the other person into an argument to distract them from your deceptive move. When caught in a lie, the more emotional and certain you appear, the less likely it seems that you are lying.
在权力领域，言语辩论有一个至关重要的用途：当你实施欺骗或谎言被揭穿时，它可以分散对方的注意力并掩盖你的行踪。在这种情况下，尽可能地展现出你的自信对你有利。将对方引入争论，以此来分散他们对你欺骗行为的注意力。当谎言被揭穿时，你表现得越激动、越自信，就越不容易让人相信你在说谎。
This technique has saved the hide of many a con artist. Once Count Victor Lustig, swindler par excellence, had sold dozens of suckers around the country a phony box with which he claimed to be able to copy money. Discovering their mistake, the suckers generally chose not to go the police, rather than risk the embarrassment of publicity. But one Sheriff Richards,
这项技术曾让许多骗子死里逃生。曾几何时，诈骗高手维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵向全国各地数十名冤大头兜售一种假盒子，声称可以用它复制钞票。这些冤大头发现上当后，通常选择不去报警，以免名誉扫地。但理查兹警长却……
LAW 9
法律9
of Remsen County, Oklahoma, was not the kind of man to accept being conned out of $ 10,000, and one morning he tracked Lustig down to a hotel in Chicago.
来自俄克拉荷马州雷姆森县的卢斯蒂格不是那种会被骗走 10,000 美元的人，一天早上，他追踪卢斯蒂格到了芝加哥的一家酒店。
Lustig heard a knock on the door. When he opened it he was looking down the barrel of a gun. “What seems to be the problem” he calmly asked. “You son of a bitch,” yelled the sheriff, “I'm going to kill you. You conned me with that damn box of yours!” Lustig feigned confusion. “You mean it's not working” he asked. “You know it's not working,” replied the sheriff. “But that's impossible,” said Lustig. “There's no way it couldn't be working. Did you operate it properly” “I did exactly what you told me to do,” said the sheriff. “No, you must have done something wrong,” said Lustig. The argument went in circles. The barrel of the gun was gently lowered.
卢斯蒂格听到敲门声。他打开门，发现一把枪正对着他。“出了什么事？”他平静地问道。“你这狗娘养的！”警长吼道，“我要杀了你！你用你那该死的盒子骗了我！”卢斯蒂格假装困惑。“你是说它坏了？”他问道。“你知道它坏了。”警长回答。“但这不可能。”卢斯蒂格说，“它怎么可能坏呢？你操作正确吗？”“我完全按照你说的做了。”警长说。“不，你肯定哪里做错了。”卢斯蒂格说。争论陷入了僵局。枪口缓缓下移。
Lustig next went to phase two in the argument tactic: He poured out a whole bunch of technical gobbledygook about the box's operation, completely beguiling the sheriff, who now appeared less sure of himself and argued less forcefully. “Look,” said Lustig, “I'll give you your money back right now. I'll also give you written instructions on how to work the machine and I'll come out to Oklahoma to make sure it's working properly. There's no way you can lose on that.” The sheriff reluctandy agreed. To satisfy him totally, Lustig took out a hundred one-hundred-dollar bills and gave diem to him, telling him to relax and have a fun weekend in Chicago. Calmer and a littie confused, the sheriff finally left. Over die next few days Lustig checked the paper every morning. He finally found what he was looking for: A short article reporting Sheriff Richards's arrest, trial, and conviction for passing counterfeit notes. Lustig had won the argument; the sheriff never bodiered him again.
接下来，卢斯蒂格进入了辩论策略的第二阶段：他滔滔不绝地讲了一大堆关于机器操作的技术术语，彻底迷惑了警长。警长此时显得信心不足，辩解的力度也减弱了。“听着，”卢斯蒂格说，“我现在就把钱还给你。我还会给你一份机器操作的书面说明，而且我会亲自去俄克拉荷马州检查机器是否正常运转。你肯定不会亏的。”警长勉强同意了。为了让他彻底满意，卢斯蒂格掏出一百张一百美元的钞票给了他，并告诉他放松一下，在芝加哥好好享受一个周末。警长平静下来，但仍然有些困惑，最终离开了。接下来的几天，卢斯蒂格每天早上都查看报纸。他终于找到了他想要的东西：一篇报道理查兹警长因使用假钞而被捕、受审和定罪的短文。卢斯蒂格赢得了这场辩论。警长再也没有对他进行过任何殴打。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 10
第十条
INFECTION: AVOID THE UNHAPPY AND UNLUCKY
感染：远离不幸和不幸的人
JUDGMENT
判断
You can die from someone else's miseryemotional states are as infectious as diseases. You may feel you are helping the drowning man but you are only precipitating your own disaster. The unfortunate sometimes draw misfortune on themselves; they will also draw it on you. Associate with the happy and fortunate instead.
他人的痛苦会害死你——情绪如同疾病般具有传染性。你或许觉得自己在帮助溺水者，但实际上只是在加速自己的灾难。不幸的人有时会招致厄运，他们也会将厄运带给你。不如多与快乐幸运的人交往。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Born in Limerick, Ireland, in 1818, Marie Gilbert came to Paris in the
玛丽·吉尔伯特于1818年出生于爱尔兰利默里克，后于同年来到巴黎。
1840s to make her fortune as a dancer and performer. Taking the name
19世纪40年代，她以舞蹈演员和表演者的身份发家致富。她取了这个名字
Lola Montez (her mother was of distant Spanish descent), she claimed to
洛拉·蒙特斯（她的母亲有远西班牙血统），她声称
be a flamenco dancer from Spain. By 1845 her career was languishing, and
她是一位来自西班牙的弗拉明戈舞者。到1845年，她的事业已步入低谷，
to survive she became a courtesanquickly one of the more successful in
为了生存，她成为了一名交际花，并很快成为其中比较成功的一位。
Paris.
巴黎。
Only one man could salvage Lola's dancing career: Alexandre Dujarier, owner of die newspaper with the largest circulation in France, and also the newspaper's drama critic. She decided to woo and conquer him. Investigating his habits, she discovered mat he went riding every morning. An excellent horsewoman herself, she rode out one morning and “accidentally” ran into him. Soon they were riding together every day. A few weeks later Lola moved into his apartment.
只有一个人能挽救洛拉的舞蹈生涯：亚历山大·杜雅里埃，法国发行量最大的报纸的老板，同时也是该报的戏剧评论家。洛拉决定追求并征服他。她调查了他的生活习惯，发现他每天早上都去骑马。洛拉自己也是一位优秀的骑手，一天早上她骑马外出时“偶然”遇到了他。很快，他们每天都一起骑马。几周后，洛拉搬进了他的公寓。
For a while the two were happy together. With Dujarier's help, Lola began to revive her dancing career. Despite the risk to his social standing, Dujarier told friends he would marry her in the spring. (Lola had never told him mat she had eloped at age nineteen with an Englishman, and was still legally married.) Although Dujarier was deeply in love, his life started to slide downhill.
