两人曾有过一段幸福的时光。在杜雅里耶的帮助下，洛拉开始重拾舞蹈事业。尽管此举可能危及自己的社会地位，杜雅里耶还是告诉朋友们他将在春天迎娶洛拉。（洛拉从未告诉他，她十九岁时就与一位英国人私奔，而且在法律上仍处于婚姻关系中。）尽管杜雅里耶深爱着洛拉，但他的生活却开始走下坡路。
His fortunes in business changed and influential friends began to avoid him. One night Dujarier was invited to a party, attended by some of the wealthiest young men in Paris. Lola wanted to go too but he would not allow it. They had their first quarrel, and Dujarier attended the party by himself. There, hopelessly drunk, he insulted an influential drama critic, Jean-Baptiste Rosemond de Beauvallon, perhaps because of something the critic had said about Lola. The following morning Beauvallon challenged him to a duel. Beauvallon was one of the best pistol shots in France. Dujarier tried to apologize, but the duel took place, and he was shot and killed. Thus ended the life of one of the most promising young men of Paris society. Devastated, Lola left Paris.
他的生意境遇发生了变化，一些有影响力的朋友开始疏远他。一天晚上，杜雅里埃受邀参加一个派对，巴黎一些最富有的年轻人都出席了。洛拉也想去，但他不允许。两人因此发生了第一次争吵，杜雅里埃只好独自一人去参加派对。在那里，他喝得酩酊大醉，侮辱了一位颇具影响力的戏剧评论家让-巴蒂斯特·罗塞蒙德·德·博瓦隆，或许是因为这位评论家曾说过洛拉的坏话。第二天早上，博瓦隆向他发起决斗挑战。博瓦隆是法国最优秀的枪手之一。杜雅里埃试图道歉，但决斗还是发生了，他被枪杀。巴黎社交界一位前途无量的年轻人就这样陨落了。悲痛欲绝的洛拉离开了巴黎。
In 1846 Lola Montez found herself in Munich, where she decided to woo and conquer King Ludwig of Bavaria. The best way to Ludwig, she discovered, was through his aide-de-camp, Count Otto von Rechberg, a man with a fondness for pretty girls. One day when the count was breakfasting at an outdoor cafe, Lola rode by on her horse, was “accidentally” thrown from the saddle, and landed at Rechberg's feet. The count rushed to help her and was enchanted. He promised to introduce her to Ludwig.
1846年，萝拉·蒙特兹来到慕尼黑，决心追求巴伐利亚国王路德维希。她发现，接近路德维希的最佳途径是通过他的副官奥托·冯·雷希贝格伯爵，此人酷爱漂亮姑娘。一天，伯爵在一家露天咖啡馆享用早餐时，萝拉骑马经过，却“意外”从马鞍上摔了下来，跌落在雷希贝格伯爵脚边。伯爵急忙上前扶起她，并被她的美貌深深吸引。他答应将她引荐给路德维希。
Rechberg arranged an audience with die king for Lola, but when she arrived in the anteroom, she could hear the king saying he was too busy to meet a favor-seeking stranger. Lola pushed aside the sentries and entered his room anyway. In the process, die front of her dress somehow got torn (perhaps by her, perhaps by one of the sentries), and to the astonishment of all, most especially the king, her bare breasts were brazenly exposed. Lola was granted her audience widi Ludwig. Fifty-five hours later she made her debut on the Bavarian stage; the reviews were terrible, but that did not stop Ludwig from arranging more performances.
雷希贝格为罗拉安排了觐见国王，但当她到达前厅时，却听到国王说他太忙，无暇接见一个前来求助的陌生人。罗拉推开卫兵，径直走进了国王的房间。在这个过程中，她的裙子前襟不知何故被撕破了（也许是她自己撕的，也许是某个卫兵撕的），令所有人，尤其是国王，都大吃一惊的是，她的胸部竟如此暴露。罗拉最终还是觐见了路德维希。五十五小时后，她在巴伐利亚的舞台上首次亮相；评论糟糕透顶，但这并没有阻止路德维希安排她继续演出。
A mil found itself carried by a crow to the top of a tall campanile, and by falling into a crevice succeeded in escaping its dread fate. It then besought the wall to shelter it, by appealing to it by the grace of God, and praising its height, and the beauty and noble tone of its bells. “Alas,” it went on, “as I have not been able to drop beneath the green branches of my old Father and to lie in the fallow earth covered bv his fallen leaves, do you, at least, not abandon me. When 1 found myself in the beak of the cruel crow 1 made a vow, that if I escaped I would end my life in a little hole. ” At these words, the wall, moved with compassion, was content to shelter the nut in the spot where it had fallen. Within a short time, the nut burst open: Its roots reached in between the crevices of the stones and began to push them apart; its-shoots pressed up toward the sky. Thev soon rose above the building, and as the twisted roots grew thicker they began to thrust the walls apart and force the ancient stones from their old places. Then the wall, loo late and in vain, bewailed the cause of its destruction, and in short time it fell in ruin.
一颗坚果被乌鸦叼到高耸的钟楼顶端，掉进一个缝隙里，侥幸逃脱了厄运。它恳求墙壁庇护自己，以神的名义祈求，赞美墙壁的高耸，以及钟声的优美和高贵。“唉，”它继续说道，“我没能落到老父亲绿荫下，躺在落叶覆盖的荒地上，至少请你不要抛弃我。当我落入那只残忍的乌鸦嘴里时，我发誓，如果我能逃脱，我愿死在一个小洞里。” 墙壁被这番话感动了，心生怜悯，便将坚果留在它掉落的地方。不久，坚果裂开了：它的根扎进石缝，撑开石缝；它的嫩芽向上生长，直冲云霄。它们很快便长到了建筑物之上，随着盘根错节的根系愈发粗壮，它们开始撑开墙壁，将古老的石块从原处拔出。于是，墙壁姗姗来迟，徒劳地哀叹着毁灭它的原因，不久便轰然倒塌。
Leonardo da Vinci. 1452-1519
列奥纳多·达·芬奇，1452-1519年
Ill Itis own time Simon Thomas was a great doctor. I remember that I happened to meet him one day at the home of a rich old consumptive: He told his patient when discussing ways to cure him that one means was to provide occasions for me to enjoy his company: He could then fix his eves on the freshness of my countenance and his thoughts on the overflowing cheerfulness and vigor of my young manhood; by filling all his senses with the flower of my youth his condition might improve. He forgot to add that mine might get worse.
西蒙·托马斯是一位伟大的医生。我记得有一天，我在一位富有的老肺结核患者家中偶然遇见了他。他告诉病人，在讨论治疗方法时，其中一个办法就是让我有机会陪伴他。这样，他就能欣赏我容光焕发的面容，感受我青春洋溢的活力和愉悦；通过感受我青春的芬芳，他的病情或许会有所好转。但他忘了补充一点：我的病情可能会因此恶化。
MONTAIGNF,
蒙田，
1533-1592
Many things are said to be infectious. Sleepiness can be infectious, and yawning as well. In large-scale strategy. when the enemy is agitated and shows an inclination to rush, do not mind in the least. Make a show of complete calmness, and the enemy will be taken by this and will become relaxed. You infect their spirit. You can infect them with a carefree, drunklike spirit, with boredom, or even weakness.
据说很多东西都具有传染性。困倦会传染，打哈欠也会传染。在大规模战略中，当敌人焦躁不安、急于进攻时，千万不要在意。要表现得完全冷静，敌人会被这种冷静所迷惑，放松下来。你就能感染他们的精神。你可以让他们变得无忧无虑、醉醺醺的，也可以让他们感到无聊，甚至让他们变得软弱。
Ludwig was, in his own words, “bewitched” by Lola. He started to appear in public with her on his arm, and then he bought and furnished an apartment for her on one of Munich's most fashionable boulevards. Although he had been known as a miser, and was not given to flights of fancy, he started to shower Lola with gifts and to write poetry for her. Now his favored mistress, she catapulted to fame and fortune overnight.
路德维希用他自己的话说，被罗拉“迷住了”。他开始带着她公开露面，后来还在慕尼黑最繁华的林荫大道上为她购置并布置了一套公寓。尽管他素来以吝啬著称，也并非一个爱幻想的人，但他开始对罗拉百般宠爱，赠送礼物，并为她写诗。如今，作为他最宠爱的情妇，罗拉一夜之间名利双收。
Lola began to lose her sense of proportion. One day when she was out riding, an elderly man rode ahead of her, a bit too slowly for her liking. Unable to pass him, she began to slash him with her riding crop. On another occasion she took her dog, unleashed, out for a stroll. The dog attacked a passerby, but instead of helping the man get the dog away, she whipped him with the leash. Incidents like this infuriated the stolid citizens of Bavaria, but Ludwig stood by Lola and even had her naturalized as a Bavarian citizen. The king's entourage tried to wake him to the dangers of the affair, but those who criticized Lola were summarily fired.
萝拉开始失去理智。一天，她骑马外出，一位老者骑在她前面，速度慢得让她不满意。她无法超过他，便用马鞭抽打他。还有一次，她没拴狗绳，牵着狗出去散步。狗攻击了一位路人，但她非但没有帮助那人把狗赶走，反而用狗绳抽打他。诸如此类的事件激怒了巴伐利亚那些固执的民众，但路德维希国王却力挺萝拉，甚至让她入籍巴伐利亚。国王的随从试图让他意识到此事的危险性，但那些批评萝拉的人都被立即解雇了。
While Bavarians who had loved their king now outwardly disrespected him, Lola was made a countess, had a new palace built for herself, and began to dabble in politics, advising Ludwig on policy. She was the most powerful force in the kingdom. Her influence in the king's cabinet continued to grow, and she treated the other ministers with disdain. As a result, riots broke out throughout the realm. A once peaceful land was virtually in the grip of civil war, and students everywhere were chanting, “Raus mit Lola!”
巴伐利亚人原本爱戴国王，如今却对他公开表示不敬。与此同时，罗拉被封为伯爵夫人，为自己建造了一座新宫殿，并开始涉足政坛，为路德维希出谋划策。她成了王国中最有权势的人物。她在国王内阁中的影响力与日俱增，对其他大臣更是不屑一顾。结果，全国各地爆发了骚乱。这片曾经和平的土地几乎陷入了内战，各地的学生都在高喊：“罗拉滚出去！”
By February of 1848, Ludwig was finally unable to withstand the pressure. With great sadness he ordered Lola to leave Bavaria immediately. She left, but not until she was paid off. For the next five weeks the Bavarians' wrath was turned against their formerly beloved king. In March of that year he was forced to abdicate.
到了1848年2月，路德维希终于无法承受压力。他悲痛地命令洛拉立即离开巴伐利亚。洛拉离开了，但前提是她必须得到一笔补偿金。接下来的五个星期里，巴伐利亚人的怒火转向了他们曾经敬爱的国王。同年3月，他被迫退位。
Lola Montez moved to England. More than anything she needed respectability, and despite being married (she still had not arranged a divorce from the Englishman she had wed years before), she set her sights on George Trafford Heald, a promising young army officer who was the son of an influential barrister. Although he was ten years younger than Lola, and could have chosen a wife among the prettiest and wealthiest young girls of English society, Heald fell under her spell. They were married in 1849. Soon arrested on the charge of bigamy, she skipped bail, and she and Heald made their way to Spain. They quarreled horribly and on one occasion Lola slashed him with a knife. Finally, she drove him away. Returning to England, he found he had lost his position in the army. Ostracized from English society, he moved to Portugal, where he lived in poverty. After a few months his short life ended in a boating accident.
洛拉·蒙特兹移居英国。她最渴望的是体面，尽管已婚（她与多年前嫁给的英国人尚未正式离婚），她还是将目光投向了乔治·特拉福德·希尔德，一位前途无量的年轻军官，他的父亲是一位颇具影响力的律师。希尔德比洛拉小十岁，完全可以从英国上流社会最漂亮、最富有的年轻女孩中挑选妻子，但他却被洛拉迷住了。他们于1849年结婚。不久后，洛拉因重婚罪被捕，她弃保潜逃，与希尔德一起前往西班牙。两人争吵不断，有一次洛拉甚至用刀划伤了他。最终，她将他赶走了。希尔德回到英国后，发现自己失去了军职。被英国社会排斥后，他搬到了葡萄牙，在那里过着贫困的生活。几个月后，他因一场船难而英年早逝。
A few years later the man who published Lola Montez's autobiography went bankrupt
几年后，出版洛拉·蒙特斯自传的那个人破产了。
In 1853 Lola moved to California, where she met and married a man named Pat Hull. Their relationship was as stormy as all the others, and she left Hull for another man. He took to drink and fell into a deep depression that lasted until he died, four years later, still a relatively young man.
1853年，洛拉搬到加利福尼亚州，在那里她遇到了帕特·赫尔并与之结婚。他们的婚姻和其他婚姻一样充满波折，洛拉最终离开了赫尔，投入了另一个男人的怀抱。赫尔开始酗酒，陷入了深深的抑郁之中，直到四年后去世，当时他还很年轻。
At the age of forty-one, Lola gave away her clothes and finery and turned to God. She toured America, lecturing on religious topics, dressed in white and wearing a halolike white headgear. She died two years later, in 1861.
四十一岁时，罗拉舍弃了所有衣物和华服，皈依基督教。她身着白衣，头戴光环状的白色头饰，在美国各地巡回演讲，宣讲宗教教义。两年后，即1861年，她与世长辞。
Interpretation
解释
Lola Montez attracted men witii her wiles, but her power over them went beyond the sexual. It was through the force of her character tiiat she kept her lovers enthralled. Men were sucked into the maelstrom she churned up around her. They felt confused, upset, but die strength of the emotions she stirred also made diem feel more alive.
洛拉·蒙特兹凭借她的魅力吸引男人，但她对他们的掌控远不止于性。她凭借自身强大的魅力牢牢吸引着她的爱人。男人们被卷入她周围掀起的漩涡之中。他们感到困惑、不安，但她激起的强烈情感也让他们感到自己更加鲜活。
As is often the case widi infection, die problems would only arise over time. Lola's inherent instability would begin to get under her lovers' skin. They would find diemselves drawn into her problems, but dieir emotional attachment to her would make diem want to help her. This was the crucial point of die diseasefor Lola Montez could not be helped. Her problems were too deep. Once die lover identified widi diem, he was lost. He would find himself embroiled in quarrels. The infection would spread to his family and friends, or, in die case of Ludwig, to an entire nation. The only solution would be to cut her off, or suffer an eventual collapse.
就像其他感染一样，问题只会随着时间的推移而逐渐显现。洛拉与生俱来的不稳定性会逐渐侵蚀她爱人的内心。他们会发现自己被卷入她的困境，但对她的情感依恋又让他们想要帮助她。这正是这种疾病的关键所在——洛拉·蒙特兹无药可救。她的问题根深蒂固。一旦爱人意识到这一点，他就彻底迷失了方向。他会发现自己深陷争吵之中。这种“感染”会蔓延到他的家人和朋友，或者，就像路德维希那样，蔓延到整个国家。唯一的解决办法就是与她断绝关系，否则最终将走向崩溃。
The infecting-character type is not restricted to women; it has notiiing to do with gender. It stems from an inward instability tiiat radiates outward, drawing disaster upon itself. There is almost a desire to destroy and unsettle. You could spend a lifetime studying die pathology of infecting characters, but don't waste your time-just learn die lesson. When you suspect you are in die presence of an infector, don't argue, don't try to help, don't pass die person on to your friends, or you will become enmeshed. Flee die infector's presence or suffer the consequences.
这种传染型人格并非女性专属，与性别无关。它源于一种内在的不稳定性，这种不稳定性会向外扩散，最终招致灾难。他们几乎有一种破坏和扰乱他人的欲望。你或许可以用一生去研究传染型人格的病理，但不要浪费时间——只需吸取教训。当你怀疑自己身处传染型人格之中时，不要争辩，不要试图帮助，不要把这个人介绍给你的朋友，否则你会深陷其中。远离传染型人格，否则后果自负。
Regard no foolish man as cultured, though you may reckon a gifted man as wise; and esteem no ignorant abstainer a true ascetic. Do not consort with fools, especially those who consider themselves wise. And be not self-satisfied with your own ignorance. Let your intercourse be only with men of good repute; for it is by such association that men themselves attain to good repute. Do you not observe how .sesame-oil is mingled with roses or violets and how, when it has been for some time in association with roses or violets, it ceases to be sesame-oil and is called oil of roses or oil of violets
不要把愚昧之人视为有教养之人，即使你可能认为才华横溢之人是智者；也不要把无知的禁欲者视为真正的苦行僧。不要与愚人为伍，尤其是那些自以为聪明的人。不要自满于自己的无知。只与品行端正之人交往；因为正是通过这样的交往，人们才能获得良好的声誉。难道你没有注意到，芝麻油是如何与玫瑰或紫罗兰混合的，当它与玫瑰或紫罗兰混合一段时间后，它就不再是芝麻油，而被称为玫瑰油或紫罗兰油了吗？
a mirror for princks, Kai Ka'us Ibn
王子的镜子，凯·考斯·伊本
Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look. He thinks too much. . . .
约恩德·卡西乌斯面容消瘦，眼神充满渴望。他想得太多……
I do not know the man I should avoid so soon as that spare Cassius. . . .
我不知道除了那个备用的卡西乌斯之外，我应该避开的还有谁……
Such men as he be never at heart's ease whiles they behold a greater
像他这样的人，只要看到更伟大的事物，就永远无法感到内心平静。
than themselves, and therefore are they very dangerous.
它们比自身更危险，因此非常危险。
Julius Caesar, William, Shakespeare, 1564-1616
尤利乌斯·凯撒，威廉·莎士比亚，1564-1616
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Those misfortunates among us who have been brought down by circumstances beyond their control deserve all die help and sympathy we can give diem. But diere are otiiers who are not born to misfortune or unhappi-ness, but who draw it upon diemselves by tiieir destructive actions and un-setding effect on odiers. It would be a great tiling if we could raise diem up, change tiieir patterns, but more often tiian not it is their patterns tiiat end up getting inside and changing us. The reason is simplehumans are extremely susceptible to the moods, emotions, and even the ways of thinking of tiiose with whom tiiey spend tiieir time.
那些不幸遭遇无法掌控的境遇的人，理应得到我们所能给予的一切帮助和同情。然而，有些人并非生来就注定不幸或痛苦，却因其破坏性的行为和对他人造成的负面影响而招致厄运。如果我们能够帮助他们振作起来，改变他们的行为模式，那将是一件多么美好的事情。但更多时候，并非如此，而是他们的行为模式最终潜移默化地影响着我们。原因很简单：人类极易受到身边人的情绪、情感，甚至是思维方式的影响。
The incurably unhappy and unstable have a particularly strong infect-
那些无可救药的不快乐和情绪不稳定的人特别容易受到感染。
ing power because their characters and emotions are so intense. They often present themselves as victims, making it difficult, at first, to see their miseries as self-inflicted. Before you realize the real nature of their problems you have been infected by them.
他们之所以能产生如此强大的感染力，是因为他们的性格和情感都非常强烈。他们常常把自己塑造成受害者，这使得人们一开始很难将他们的痛苦视为咎由自取。在你意识到他们问题的真正本质之前，你已经受到了他们的影响。
Understand this: In the game of power, the people you associate with are critical. The risk of associating with infectors is that you will waste valuable time and energy trying to free yourself. Through a kind of guilt by association, you will also suffer in the eyes of others. Never underestimate the dangers of infection.
明白这一点：在权力游戏中，你交往的人至关重要。与传染者交往的风险在于，你会浪费宝贵的时间和精力试图摆脱困境。此外，由于某种形式的牵连，你也会在他人眼中遭受牵连。永远不要低估传染的危险。
There are many kinds of infector to be aware of, but one of the most insidious is the sufferer from chronic dissatisfaction. Cassius, the Roman conspirator against Julius Caesar, had the discontent that comes from deep envy. He simply could not endure the presence of anyone of greater talent. Probably because Caesar sensed the man's interminable sourness, he passed him up for the position of first praetorship, and gave the position to Brutus instead. Cassius brooded and brooded, his hatred for Caesar becoming pathological. Brutus himself, a devoted republican, disliked Caesar's dictatorship; had he had the patience to wait, he would have become the first man in Rome after Caesar's death, and could have undone the evil that the leader had wrought. But Cassius infected him with his own rancor, bending his ear daily with tales of Caesar's evil. He finally won Brutus over to the conspiracy. It was the beginning of a great tragedy. How many misfortunes could have been avoided had Brutus learned to fear the power of infection.
需要警惕的传染源有很多种，但其中最阴险的一种莫过于长期心怀不满的人。罗马阴谋反对凯撒的卡西乌斯，就怀有源于深切嫉妒的不满。他根本无法忍受任何比他更有才华的人。或许正是因为凯撒察觉到了他那无休止的怨恨，才没有让他担任首席裁判官，而是给了布鲁图斯。卡西乌斯日复一日地闷闷不乐，他对凯撒的仇恨最终病态化。布鲁图斯本人是一位忠诚的共和主义者，他厌恶凯撒的独裁统治；如果他能耐心等待，凯撒死后他本可以成为罗马的第一人，并有机会纠正这位领袖所犯下的罪恶。但卡西乌斯将自己的怨恨传染给了他，每天都向他讲述凯撒的种种恶行。他最终说服布鲁图斯加入阴谋。这是一场巨大悲剧的开端。如果布鲁图斯能学会畏惧传染病的威力，多少不幸本可以避免。
There is only one solution to infection: quarantine. But by the time you recognize the problem it is often too late. A Lola Montez overwhelms you with her forceful personality. Cassius intrigues you with his confiding nature and the depth of his feelings. How can you protect yourself against such insidious viruses The answer lies in judging people on the effects they have on the world and not on the reasons they give for their prob-
对抗感染的唯一办法就是隔离。但当你意识到问题时，往往为时已晚。洛拉·蒙特兹强势的个性令人难以招架。卡西乌斯坦诚的性格和深沉的情感令人着迷。你该如何保护自己免受这些阴险病毒的侵害？答案在于评判一个人，看他对世界的影响，而不是他为自己的问题给出的理由。
Image: A Virus. Unseen, it lems. Infectors can be recognized by the misfortune they draw on them-
图片：一种病毒。它看不见，却能造成伤害。感染者可以通过它们给人们带来的不幸来识别。
enters your pores without selves, their turbulent past, their long line of broken relationships, their un-
他们悄无声息地渗入你的毛孔，带着他们动荡的过去、他们漫长的破碎关系、他们不为人知的过往。
warning, spreading silently and stable careers, and the very force of their character, which sweeps you up
警告，悄然传播稳定的职业生涯，以及他们性格本身的力量，这种力量会席卷你。
slowly. Before you are aware of and makes you lose your reason. Be forewarned by these signs of an infec-
慢慢地。在你意识到之前，它会让你失去理智。请注意这些感染迹象。
the infection, it is deep inside you. tor; learn to see the discontent in their eye. Most important of all, do not take pity. Do not enmesh yourself in trying to help. The infector will remain unchanged, but you will be unhinged.
感染已经深入你的内心。学会观察他们眼中的不满。最重要的是，不要怜悯他们。不要让自己深陷于帮助他们的泥潭。感染者不会有任何改变，但你会精神崩溃。
The other side of infection is equally valid, and perhaps more readily understood: There are people who attract happiness to themselves by their good cheer, natural buoyancy, and intelligence. They are a source of pleasure, and you must associate with them to share in the prosperity they draw upon themselves.
感染的另一面同样成立，而且或许更容易理解：有些人凭借乐观开朗、天生乐观和智慧，自然而然地吸引着快乐。他们是快乐的源泉，你必须与他们交往，才能分享他们所获得的繁荣。
This applies to more than good cheer and success: All positive qualities can infect us. Talleyrand had many strange and intimidating traits, but most agreed that he surpassed all Frenchmen in graciousness, aristocratic charm, and wit. Indeed he came from one of the oldest noble families in the country, and despite his belief in democracy and the French Republic, he retained his courtly manners. His contemporary Napoleon was in many ways the oppositea peasant from Corsica, taciturn and ungracious, even violent.
这不仅仅适用于乐观和成功：所有积极的品质都会感染我们。塔列朗有很多古怪甚至令人畏惧的特质，但大多数人都认为，他在优雅、贵族魅力和机智方面超越了所有法国人。事实上，他出身于法国最古老的贵族世家之一，尽管他信仰民主和法兰西共和国，却依然保持着宫廷礼仪。与他同时代的拿破仑在许多方面都截然相反——他是一位来自科西嘉岛的农民，沉默寡言，缺乏风度，甚至有些残暴。
There was no one Napoleon admired more than Talleyrand. He envied his minister's way with people, his wit and his ability to charm women, and as best he could, he kept Talleyrand around him, hoping to soak up the culture he lacked. There is no doubt that Napoleon changed as his rule continued. Many of the rough edges were smoothed by his constant association with Talleyrand.
拿破仑最欣赏的人莫过于塔列朗。他羡慕这位大臣的处事之道、机智幽默以及讨女人欢心的能力，并竭尽所能地将塔列朗留在身边，希望从中汲取自己所缺乏的文化修养。毫无疑问，随着拿破仑统治的延续，他自身也发生了变化。而与塔列朗的长期交往，也磨平了他性格中的许多棱角。
Use the positive side of this emotional osmosis to advantage. If, for example, you are miserly by nature, you will never go beyond a certain limit; only generous souls attain greatness. Associate with the generous, then, and they will infect you, opening up everything that is tight and restricted in you. If you are gloomy, gravitate to the cheerful. If you are prone to isolation, force yourself to befriend the gregarious. Never associate with those who share your defectsthey will reinforce everything that holds you back. Only create associations with positive affinities. Make this a rule of life and you will benefit more than from all the therapy in the world.
善用这种情感渗透的积极一面。例如，如果你天性吝啬，你永远无法突破某种界限；只有慷慨的人才能成就伟大。因此，与慷慨的人交往，他们会感染你，打开你内心所有紧绷和受限的部分。如果你忧郁，就靠近开朗的人。如果你容易孤僻，就强迫自己与善于交际的人交朋友。永远不要与那些和你一样有缺点的人交往——他们会强化所有阻碍你前进的因素。只与那些与你志趣相投的人交往。将此作为人生准则，你将受益匪浅，胜过世上所有的心理治疗。
Authority: Recognize the fortunate so that you may choose their company, and the unfortunate so that you may avoid them. Misfortune is usually the crime of folly, and among those who suffer from it there is no malady more contagious: Never open your door to the least of misfortunes, for, if you do, many others will follow in its train.. . . Do not die of another's misery. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：认清幸运者，以便与之交往；认清不幸者，以便远离他们。不幸通常是愚蠢的罪过，在遭受不幸的人当中，没有比这更具传染性的疾病了：永远不要向哪怕是最轻微的不幸敞开大门，因为如果你这样做了，就会有更多不幸接踵而至……不要死于他人的痛苦。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
This law admits of no reversal. Its application is universal. There is nothing to be gained by associating with those who infect you with their misery; there is only power and good fortune to be obtained by associating with the fortunate. Ignore this law at your peril.
这条法则不容更改，它适用于所有人。与那些将痛苦传染给你的人为伍，你一无所获；只有与幸运的人为伍，你才能获得力量和好运。忽视这条法则，后果自负。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 11
第11条
LEARN TO KEEP PEOPLE DEPENDENT ON YOU
学会让别人依赖你
JUDGMENT
判断
To maintain your independence you must always be needed and wanted. The more you are relied on, the more freedom you have. Make people depend on you for their happiness and prosperity and you have nothing to fear. Never teach them enough so that they can do without you.
要想保持独立，你必须始终被需要、被需要。越是受人信赖，你就越自由。让人们的幸福和成功都依赖于你，你就无所畏惧。永远不要让他们学会足够多的东西，以至于他们可以脱离你而独立生活。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Sometime in the Middle Ages, a mercenary soldier (a condottiere) , whose name has not been recorded, saved the town of Siena from a foreign aggressor. How could the good citizens of Siena reward him No amount of money or honor could possibly compare in value to the preservation of a city's liberty. The citizens thought of making the mercenary the lord of the city, but even that, they decided, wasn't recompense enough. At last one of them stood before the assembly called to debate this matter and said, “Let us kill him and then worship him as our patron saint.” And so they did.
中世纪的某个时期，一位不知名的雇佣兵（雇佣兵首领）从外敌手中拯救了锡耶纳城。锡耶纳的善良市民该如何报答他呢？任何金钱或荣誉都无法与保全一座城市的自由相提并论。市民们曾想过拥立这位雇佣兵为城主，但他们觉得即便如此也远远不够。最后，一位市民站在为此事召开的公民大会上说道：“不如我们杀了他，然后把他奉为守护圣人吧。”于是，他们照做了。
The Count of Carmagnola was cue of the bravest and most successful of all the condottieri. In 1442, late in his life, he was in the employ of the city of Venice, which was in the midst of a long war with Florence. The count was suddenly recalled to Venice. A favorite of the people, he was received there with all kinds of honor and splendor. That evening he was to dine with the doge himself, in the doge's palace. On the way into die palace, however, he noticed diat die guard was leading him in a different direction from usual. Crossing the famous Bridge of Sighs, he suddenly realized where they were taking himto die dungeon. He was convicted on a trumped-up charge and the next day in the Piazza San Marco, before a horrified crowd who could not understand how his fate had changed so drastically, he was beheaded.
卡尔马尼奥拉伯爵是所有雇佣兵首领中最勇敢、最成功的一位。1442年，在他晚年，他受雇于威尼斯城，当时威尼斯正与佛罗伦萨进行着旷日持久的战争。伯爵突然被召回威尼斯。由于深受民众爱戴，他受到了盛情款待。当晚，他本应在总督府与总督共进晚餐。然而，在进入宫殿的路上，他注意到卫兵带他去的方向与往常不同。当他穿过著名的叹息桥时，他突然意识到他们要把他带到哪里——地牢。他被以莫须有的罪名定罪，第二天，在圣马可广场，在惊恐万分、无法理解他命运为何如此剧变的民众面前，他被斩首。
Interpretation
解释
Many of the great condottieri of Renaissance Italy suffered die same fate as the patron saint of Siena and the Count of Carmagnola: They won batde after battle for their employers only to find themselves banished, imprisoned, or executed. The problem was not ingratitude; it was diat there were so many other condottieri as able and valiant as diey were. They were replaceable. Nodiing was lost by killing diem. Meanwhile, the older among them had grown powerful themselves, and wanted more and more money for their services. How much better, then, to do away with them and hire a younger, cheaper mercenary. That was the fate of the Count of Carmagnola, who had started to act impudendy and independendy. He had taken his power for granted widiout making sure that he was truly indispensable.
文艺复兴时期意大利许多伟大的雇佣兵首领都遭遇了与锡耶纳守护圣人和卡尔马尼奥拉伯爵同样的命运：他们为雇主屡战屡胜，最终却被流放、监禁或处决。问题不在于忘恩负义，而在于当时有太多其他同样能干英勇的雇佣兵首领。他们是可以被替代的，杀掉他们并不会造成什么损失。与此同时，他们当中年纪较大的人自身势力也日益壮大，并索要越来越高的报酬。那么，何不除掉他们，雇佣一个更年轻、更便宜的雇佣兵呢？卡尔马尼奥拉伯爵的命运正是如此，他开始行事傲慢自大，独断专行。他把自己的权力视为理所当然，却没有意识到自己是否真的不可或缺。
Such is the fate (to a less violent degree, one hopes) of diose who do not make otiiers dependent on them. Sooner or later someone comes along who can do the job as well as they cansomeone younger, fresher, less expensive, less threatening.
这就是那些不让别人依赖自己的人的命运（但愿程度不会那么惨烈）。迟早会有人出现，能像他们一样胜任这份工作——更年轻、更有活力、更便宜、更不具威胁性。
Be die only one who can do what you do, and make the fate of diose who hire you so entwined with yours that they cannot possibly get rid of you. Otherwise you will someday be forced to cross your own Bridge of Sighs.
成为唯一能做到你所做之事的人，让那些雇佣你的人的命运与你紧紧相连，让他们根本无法摆脱你。否则，你终有一天会被迫走过你自己的叹息桥。
Two horses were carrying two loads. The [rout Horse went well, but the rear Horse was lazy. I he men began to pile the rear Horse's load on the front Horse; when thev had transferred it all. the rear Horse found it easv going, and he said to the front Horse: “Toil and sweat! The more you trv, the more von have to suffer. ” When thev reached the tavern, the owner said; “Whv should I fodder two horses when I carry all on one I had better give the one all the food it wants, and cut the throat of the other; at least I shall have the hide. ”And so he ditl.
两匹马驮着两车货物。领头的马跑得很快，但后面的马却很懒。于是，人们开始把后面马的货物堆到前面的马背上；当他们把货物全部转移过去后，后面的马觉得轻松多了，便对前面的马说：“辛苦劳作！你越努力，我就越要受苦。”当他们到达客栈时，老板说：“既然所有货物都驮在一匹马身上，我何必喂两匹马呢？我不如把所有食物都喂给其中一匹，然后割下另一匹的喉咙；至少我还能得到它的皮。”于是，他就这样做了。
.
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
When Otto von Bismarck became a deputy in die Prussian parliament in
当奥托·冯·俾斯麦成为普鲁士议会的议员时
1847, he was thirty-two years old and without an ally or friend. Looking
1847年，他32岁，举目无亲。
INK CAT THAT WALKKI) in 1II \1SI. 1.1
INK CAT THAT WAKKI) 在 1II \1SI。 1.1
Then the Woman laughed and set the Cat a bowl of the warm while milk and said, “O Cat, you are as clever as a man, but remember that your bargain was not made with the Man or the Dog, and I do not know what they will do when they come home. ” “What is that to me ” said the Cat. “If I have my place in the Cave by the fire and my warm white milk three times a day, I do not care what the Man or the Dog can do.” . . . And from that day to this. Best Beloved, three proper Men out of five will always throw things at a Cat whenever they meet him, and all proper Dogs will chase him up a tree. But the Cat keeps his side of the bargain too. He will kill mice, and he will be kind to Babies when he is in the house, just as long as they do not pull his tail too hard. But when he has done that, and between times, and when the moon gets up and the night comes, he is the Cat that walks by himself, and all places are alike to him. Then he goes out to the Wet Wild Woods or up the Wet Wild Trees or on the Wet Wild Roofs, waving his wild tail and walking by his wild lone.
于是，女人笑了，给猫端来一碗温热的白牛奶，说道：“猫啊，你和人一样聪明，但记住，你和人或狗之间的约定并非如此，我不知道他们回家后会做什么。” “那与我何干？”猫说，“只要我能在山洞里，在火炉旁安家，一天三顿喝到温热的白牛奶，我才不在乎人或狗会做什么。”……从那天起，直到今天。亲爱的，五个正经男人中总有三个会在见到猫时朝它扔东西，所有正经狗都会把它追到树上。但猫也信守约定。它会捕杀老鼠，在屋里时也会善待婴儿，只要他们不使劲拽它的尾巴。但当它做了这些事，在平常时光里，当月亮升起，夜幕降临之时，它就是那只独自漫步的猫，对它来说，所有地方都一样。然后他走到湿野树林里，或者爬上湿野树，或者爬上湿野屋顶，摇着狂野的尾巴，独自狂野地走着。
just so stories,
就是这样的故事，
Rudyard Kipling,
鲁德亚德·吉卜林
1865-1936
around him, he decided that the side to ally himself with was not the parliament's liberals or conservatives, not any particular minister, and certainly not the people. It was with the king, Frederick William IV. This was an odd choice to say the least, for Frederick was at a low point of his power. A weak, indecisive man, he consistently gave in to the liberals in parliament; in fact he was spineless, and stood for much that Bismarck disliked, personally and politically. Yet Bismarck courted Frederick night and day. When other deputies attacked the king for his many inept moves, only Bismarck stood by him.
他环顾四周，最终决定效忠的既不是议会的自由派也不是保守派，不是任何一位大臣，当然也不是民众。他选择效忠的是国王腓特烈·威廉四世。这至少可以说是一个奇怪的选择，因为腓特烈当时正处于权力的低谷。他软弱无能，优柔寡断，总是向议会中的自由派妥协；事实上，他毫无骨气，他的许多立场都令俾斯麦在个人和政治上都深恶痛绝。然而，俾斯麦却日夜讨好腓特烈。当其他议员抨击国王的诸多拙劣举措时，只有俾斯麦始终站在他一边。
Finally, it all paid off: In 1851 Bismarck was made a minister in the king's cabinet. Now he went to work. Time and again he forced the king's hand, getting him to build up the military, to stand up to the liberals, to do exactly as Bismarck wished. He worked on Frederick's insecurity about his manliness, challenging him to be firm and to rule with pride. And he slowly restored the king's powers until die monarchy was once again the most powerful force in Prussia.
最终，一切努力都得到了回报：1851年，俾斯麦被任命为国王内阁大臣。他开始大展拳脚。他一次又一次地迫使国王扩充军备，对抗自由派，并完全按照俾斯麦的意愿行事。他努力消除腓特烈对自身男子气概的不自信，挑战他要坚定果断，以尊严统治国家。他逐步恢复了国王的权力，最终使君主制再次成为普鲁士最强大的力量。
When Frederick died, in 1861, his brother William assumed the throne. William disliked Bismarck intensely and had no intention of keeping him around. But he also inherited the same situation his brother had: enemies galore, who wanted to nibble his power away. He actually considered abdicating, feeling he lacked the strength to deal with this dangerous and precarious position. But Bismarck insinuated himself once again. He stood by the new king, gave him strength, and urged him into firm and decisive action. The king grew dependent on Bismarck's strong-arm tactics to keep his enemies at bay, and despite his antipathy toward the man, he soon made him his prime minister. The two quarreled often over policy Bismarck was much more conservativebut the king understood his own dependency. Whenever the prime minister threatened to resign, the king gave in to him, time after time. It was in fact Bismarck who set state policy.
1861年，腓特烈去世，他的弟弟威廉继承王位。威廉极其厌恶俾斯麦，根本不想留住他。但他继承了哥哥同样的处境：敌人众多，都想蚕食他的权力。他甚至考虑过退位，觉得自己无力应对这危险而岌岌可危的处境。但俾斯麦再次潜入。他支持新国王，给予他力量，并敦促他采取坚定果断的行动。国王越来越依赖俾斯麦的强硬手段来遏制敌人，尽管他厌恶俾斯麦，但很快就任命他为首相。两人经常在政策上争吵——俾斯麦的政策更为保守——但国王明白自己对俾斯麦的依赖。每当首相威胁辞职时，国王总是妥协，一次又一次。事实上，是俾斯麦制定了国家政策。
Years later, Bismarck's actions as Prussia's prime minister led die various German state" to be united into one country. Now Bismarck finagled the king into letting himself be crowned emperor of Germany. Yet it was really Bismarck who had reached the heights of power. As right-hand man to the emperor, and as imperial chancellor and knighted prince, he pulled all the levers.
多年后，俾斯麦担任普鲁士首相期间的举措促成了各个德意志邦国的统一。如今，俾斯麦又巧妙地让国王同意自己加冕为德意志皇帝。然而，真正掌握权力巅峰的却是俾斯麦本人。作为皇帝的得力助手、帝国宰相和受封骑士的亲王，他掌控着一切权力。
Interpretation
解释
Most young and ambitious politicians looking out on the political landscape of 1840s Germany would have tried to build a power base among those with the most power. Bismarck saw different. Joining forces with the powerful can be foolish: They will swallow you up, just as the doge of Venice swallowed up the Count of Carmagnola. No one will come to depend on you if they are already strong. If you are ambitious, it is much wiser to seek out weak rulers or masters with whom you can create a relationship of dependency. You become their strength, their intelligence, their spine. What power you hold! If they got rid of you die whole edifice would collapse.
大多数年轻有为的政治家，在19世纪40年代的德国政坛，都会试图在权贵中建立自己的势力基础。但俾斯麦却不这么认为。与权贵结盟或许是愚蠢的：他们会像威尼斯总督吞并卡尔马尼奥拉伯爵那样，将你反噬。如果对方已经强大，没有人会依赖你。如果你野心勃勃，更明智的做法是寻找软弱的统治者或主人，与他们建立依附关系。你将成为他们的力量、智慧和脊梁。你将拥有何等的权力！如果他们除掉你，整个帝国都将崩塌。
Necessity rules the world. People rarely act unless compelled to. If you create no need for yourself, then you will be done away widi at first opportunity. If, on the other hand, you understand the Laws of Power and make others depend on you for their welfare, if you can counteract their weakness with your own “iron and blood,” in Bismarck's phrase, then you will survive your masters as Bismarck did. You will have all the benefits of power without the thorns that come from being a master.
需求主宰着世界。人们很少主动行动，除非迫不得已。如果你不为自己创造需求，那么一旦有机会，你就会被除掉。反之，如果你懂得权力的法则，让别人依赖你才能获得福祉，如果你能用俾斯麦所说的“铁血”来对抗他们的弱点，那么你就能像俾斯麦一样，在被统治者摆布后依然屹立不倒。你将拥有权力带来的所有好处，却不必承受成为统治者所带来的种种弊端。
Thus a wise prince will think of ways to keep his citizens of every sort
因此，一位明智的君主会想方设法留住各种各样的臣民。
and under every circumstance dependent on the state and on him;
在任何情况下，都取决于国家和他本人；
and then they will always be trustworthy.
这样他们就永远值得信赖了。
Niccolb Machiavelli, 1469-1527
尼科尔布·马基雅维利，1469-1527 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The ultimate power is the power to get people to do as you wish. When you can do this without having to force people or hurt them, when they willingly grant you what you desire, then your power is untouchable. The best way to achieve this position is to create a relationship of dependence. The master requires your services; he is weak, or unable to function without you; you have enmeshed yourself in his work so deeply that doing away with you would bring him great difficulty, or at least would mean valuable time lost in training another to replace you. Once such a relationship is established you have the upper hand, the leverage to make the master do as you wish. It is the classic case of the man behind the tbrone, the servant of the king who actually controls the king. Bismarck did not have to bully either Frederick or William into doing his bidding. He simply made it clear that unless he got what he wanted he would walk away, leaving the king to twist in the wind. Both kings soon danced to Bismarck's tune.
终极权力就是让人按你的意愿行事的权力。当你无需强迫或伤害他人，就能做到这一点，当他们心甘情愿地满足你的愿望时，你的权力便无人能及。获得这种权力的最佳途径是建立一种依赖关系。主人需要你的服务；他软弱无力，或者没有你便无法运转；你已经深深地融入了他的工作，以至于除掉你对他来说会造成极大的困难，或者至少意味着要浪费宝贵的时间来培养另一个人来取代你。一旦这种关系建立起来，你就掌握了主动权，拥有了让主人听命于你的筹码。这正是“幕后操纵者”的经典案例，真正掌控国王的是幕后仆人。俾斯麦无需胁迫腓特烈或威廉为他效力。他只是明确表示，除非他得到想要的东西，否则他就会离开，让国王们自生自灭。两位国王很快就乖乖地听从了俾斯麦的摆布。
Do not be one of the many who mistakenly believe that the ultimate form of power is independence. Power involves a relationship between people; you will always need others as allies, pawns, or even as weak masters who serve as your front. The completely independent man would live in a cabin in the woodshe would have the freedom to come and go as he pleased, but he would have no power. The best you can hope for is that others will grow so dependent on you diat you enjoy a kind of reverse independence: Their need for you frees you.
不要成为众多误以为权力终极形式是独立的人之一。权力源于人际关系；你永远需要他人作为盟友、棋子，甚至是你的傀儡。一个完全独立的人会住在森林深处的小木屋里——他可以自由出入，但他将毫无权力。你所能期望的最好结果是，他人对你产生极大的依赖，从而让你获得一种反向的独立：他们对你的需求反而解放了你。
Louis XI (1423-1483), the great Spider King of France, had a weakness for astrology. He kept a court astrologer whom he admired, until one day the man predicted mat a lady of the court would die within eight days. When the prophecy came true, Louis was terrified, thinking that either the man had murdered the woman to prove his accuracy or that he was so versed in his science that his powers threatened Louis himself. In either case he had to be killed.
法国伟大的“蜘蛛王”路易十一（1423-1483）酷爱占星术。他豢养了一位宫廷占星师，并十分欣赏他。直到有一天，这位占星师预言宫廷中一位贵妇将在八天内去世。预言应验后，路易惊恐万分，他认为要么是占星师为了证明自己的预言准确而杀害了那位贵妇，要么是占星师的技艺过于精湛，以至于威胁到了他自身。无论如何，他都必须除掉占星师。
One evening Louis summoned the astrologer to his room, high in the castle. Before the man arrived, the king told his servants that when he gave
一天晚上，路易召见占星家到他位于城堡高处的房间里。在占星家到来之前，国王告诉仆人们，当他……
An extravagant young Vine, vainly ambitious of independence, and fond of rambling at large, despised the alliance of a stately elm that grew near, and courted her embraces. Having risen to some small height without any kind of support, she shot forth her flimsy branches to a very uncommon and superfluous length; calling on her neighbour to take notice how little she wanted his assistance. “Poor infatuated shrub, ” replied the elm, “how inconsistent is thy conduct! Wouldst thou be truly independent, thou shouldst carefully apply those juices to the enlargement of thy stem, which thou lavishest in vain upon unnecessary foliage. 1 shortly shall behold thee grovelling on the ground; yet countenanced. indeed, by many of the human race, who, intoxicated with vanity, have despised economy; and who, to support for a moment their empty boast of independence, have exhausted the very source of it in frivolous expenses. ”
一株挥霍无度的年轻葡萄藤，妄图独立，喜欢四处游荡，它轻视附近一棵高大挺拔的榆树，并试图与它结盟。它不借助任何支撑，长到一定高度后，便肆意伸展纤细的枝条，长得异常冗长，仿佛在向邻居炫耀自己根本不需要它的帮助。“可怜的痴情灌木，”榆树回答道，“你的行为多么自相矛盾！如果你真的想要独立，就应该把那些汁液用在枝干的生长上，而不是浪费在不必要的枝叶上。不久之后，我就会看到你匍匐在地，而许多人却依然对你毕恭毕敬，他们沉醉于虚荣，不思节俭，为了维持自己空洞的独立，不惜挥霍无度，耗尽了独立的源泉。”
FABLES,
寓言故事
Robert Dodslhy,
罗伯特·多德斯利
1703-1764
the signal they were to pick the astrologer up, carry him to the window, and hurl him to the ground, hundreds of feet below.
他们收到信号后，要把占星家抬到窗边，然后把他扔到几百英尺下的地面上。
The astrologer soon arrived, but before giving the signal, Louis decided to ask him one last question: “You claim to understand astrology and to know the fate of others, so tell me what your fate will be and how long you have to live.”
占星家很快就到了，但在发出信号之前，路易斯决定问他最后一个问题：“你声称自己懂占星术，知道别人的命运，那么告诉我你的命运是什么，你还能活多久。”
“I shall die just three days before Your Majesty,” the astrologer replied. The king's signal was never given. The man's life was spared. The Spider King not only protected his astrologer for as long as he was alive, he lavished him with gifts and had him tended by the finest court doctors.
“我将在陛下驾崩前三天去世。”占星家答道。国王始终没有发出信号，占星家得以幸免。蜘蛛王不仅在占星家有生之年一直保护着他，还慷慨地赏赐他，并安排宫廷中最优秀的御医为他诊治。
The astrologer survived Louis by several years, disproving his power of prophecy but proving his mastery of power.
这位占星家比路易多活了好几年，这证明了他预言的能力是错误的，但却证明了他掌控权力的能力。
This is the model: Make others dependent on you. To get rid of you might spell disaster, even death, and your master dares not tempt fate by finding out. There are many ways to obtain such a position. Foremost among them is to possess a talent and creative skill that simply cannot be replaced.
这就是模式：让别人依赖你。摆脱你可能会带来灾难，甚至是死亡，你的主人不敢冒险去试探命运。获得这种地位的方法有很多，其中最重要的是拥有无法替代的天赋和创造力。
During the Renaissance, the major obstacle to a painter's success was finding the right patron. Michelangelo did this better man anyone else: His patron was Pope Julius II. But he and the pope quarreled over the building of the pope's marble tomb, and Michelangelo left Rome in disgust. To the amazement of those in the pope's circle, not only did the pope not fire him, he sought him out and in his own haughty way begged the artist to stay. Michelangelo, he knew, could find anomer patron, but he could never find another Michelangelo.
文艺复兴时期，画家成功的最大障碍在于找到合适的赞助人。米开朗基罗在这方面无人能及：他的赞助人是教皇尤利乌斯二世。然而，他与教皇因建造教皇大理石陵墓一事发生争执，米开朗基罗愤然离开罗马。令教皇身边的人惊讶的是，教皇不仅没有解雇他，反而亲自找到他，以他一贯傲慢的姿态恳求这位艺术家留下。米开朗基罗深知，他可以找到另一个赞助人，却再也找不到另一个米开朗基罗。
You do not have to have the talent of a Michelangelo; you do have to have a skill that sets you apart from the crowd. You should create a situation in which you can always latch on to another master or patron but your master cannot easily find another servant with your particular talent. And if, in reality, you are not actually indispensable, you must find a way to make it look as if you are. Having the appearance of specialized knowledge and skill gives you leeway in your ability to deceive those above you into thinking they cannot do without you. Real dependence on your master's part, however, leaves him more vulnerable to you than the faked variety, and it is always within your power to make your skill indispensable.
你不必拥有米开朗基罗那样的天赋，但你必须拥有一项能让你脱颖而出的技能。你应该创造一种局面：你总能找到新的主人或赞助人，而你的主人却很难找到另一个拥有你这种特殊才能的仆人。如果实际上你并非不可或缺，你必须想办法让自己看起来像是。拥有专业知识和技能的假象，能让你在欺骗上级时更有优势，让他们觉得没有你就无法工作。然而，主人真正依赖你，反而比虚假的依赖更容易被你利用，而你始终有能力让自己的技能变得不可或缺。
This is what is meant by the intertwining of fates: Like creeping ivy, you have wrapped yourself around the source of power, so that it would cause great trauma to cut you away. And you do not necessarily have to entwine yourself around the master; another person will do, as long as he or she too is indispensable in the chain.
这就是命运交织的含义：你如同攀援的常春藤，将自己缠绕在力量的源泉周围，以至于一旦被斩断，便会带来巨大的痛苦。你不一定要依附于主人；其他人也可以，只要他或她也是这条链条中不可或缺的一部分。
One day Harry Cohn, president of Columbia Pictures, was visited in his office by a gloomy group of his executives. It was 1951, when die witchhunt against Communists in Hollywood, carried on by the U.S. Congress's House Un-American Activities Committee, was at its height. The executives had bad news: One of their employees, the screenwriter John Howard Lawson, had been singled out as a Communist. They had to get rid of him right away or suffer the wrath of me committee.
一天，哥伦比亚电影公司总裁哈里·科恩的办公室里来了一群神情沮丧的高管。那是1951年，美国国会众议院非美活动委员会对好莱坞共产党的迫害正值高峰。高管们带来了坏消息：他们的一名员工，编剧约翰·霍华德·劳森，被认定为共产党员。他们必须立即解雇他，否则将面临委员会的严厉惩罚。
Harry Cohn was no bleeding-heart liberal; in fact, he had always been a die-hard Republican.
哈里·科恩并非心软的自由派；事实上，他一直是一位铁杆共和党人。
His favorite politician was Benito Mussolini, whom he had once visited, and whose framed photo hung on his wall. If there was someone he hated Cohn would call him a “Communist bastard.” But to the executives' amazement Cohn told them he would not fire Lawson. He did not keep the screenwriter on because he was a good writerthere were many good writers in Hollywood. He kept him because of a chain of dependence: Lawson was Humphrey Bogart's writer and Bogart was Columbia's star. If Cohn messed with Lawson he would ruin an immensely profitable relationship. That was worth more dian the terrible publicity brought to him by his defiance of the committee.
他最喜欢的政治人物是贝尼托·墨索里尼，他曾拜访过墨索里尼，墨索里尼的照片就挂在他家的墙上。如果说他恨谁，科恩会骂他是“共产主义混蛋”。但令高管们惊讶的是，科恩告诉他们他不会解雇劳森。他留住这位编剧并非因为他文笔好——好莱坞有很多优秀的编剧。他留住劳森是因为一条相互依存的关系链：劳森是亨弗莱·鲍嘉的编剧，而鲍嘉是哥伦比亚影业的明星。如果科恩动了劳森，就会毁掉一段利润丰厚的合作关系。这比他违抗委员会的决定所带来的糟糕名声更有价值。
Henry Kissinger managed to survive the many bloodlettings that went on in the Nixon White House not because he was the best diplomat Nixon could findthere were other fine negotiatorsand not because the two men got along so well: They did not. Nor did they share their beliefs and politics. Kissinger survived because he entrenched himself in so many areas of the political structure drat to do away with him would lead to chaos. Michelangelo's power was intensive, depending on one skill, his ability as an artist; Kissinger's was extensive. He got himself involved in so many aspects and departments of the administration that his involvement became a card in his hand. It also made him many allies. If you can arrange such a position for yourself, getting rid of you becomes dangerousall sorts of interdependencies will unravel. Still, the intensive form of power provides more freedom tiian the extensive, because those who have it depend on no particular master, or particular position of power, for their security.
亨利·基辛格之所以能在尼克松白宫的多次权力斗争中幸存下来，并非因为他是尼克松能找到的最优秀的外交官——尼克松还有其他优秀的谈判者——也并非因为两人关系融洽：事实并非如此。他们的信仰和政治立场也截然不同。基辛格之所以能幸存，是因为他深入渗透到政治结构的诸多领域，一旦除掉他，必将引发混乱。米开朗基罗的权力是集中式的，依赖于他作为艺术家的才能；而基辛格的权力则是广泛式的。他涉足政府的诸多方面和部门，以至于这种参与本身就成了一张王牌。这也为他赢得了众多盟友。如果你能为自己建立起这样的地位，那么除掉你就非常危险——各种相互依存的关系都会瓦解。然而，集中式的权力比广泛式的权力更能带来自由，因为拥有集中式权力的人无需依赖任何特定的主人或权力地位来保障自身安全。
To make others dependent on you, one route to take is the secret-intelligence tactic. By knowing other people's secrets, by holding information that they wouldn't want broadcast, you seal your fate with theirs. You are untouchable. Ministers of secret police have held this position throughout the ages: They can make or break a king, or, as in the case of J. Edgar Hoover, a president. But the role is so full of insecurities and paranoia that the power it provides almost cancels itself out. You cannot rest at ease, and what good is power if it brings you no peace
要想让别人依赖你，一条途径就是秘密情报策略。通过掌握他人的秘密，通过掌握他们不愿公开的信息，你便能将自己的命运与他们的命运紧紧相连。你将无人能撼动。秘密警察的官员们历来都占据着这样的地位：他们可以左右君王的命运，也可以像埃德加·胡佛那样左右总统的命运。然而，这个角色充满了不安全感和妄想，以至于它所带来的权力几乎完全抵消了自身的价值。你无法安宁，如果权力不能给你带来平静，那它又有什么用呢？
One last warning: Do not imagine that your master's dependence on you will make him love you. In fact, he may resent and fear you. But, as Machiavelli said, it is better to be feared man loved. Fear you can control; love, never. Depending on an emotion as subde and changeable as love or friendship will only make you insecure. Better to have others depend on you out of fear of the consequences of losing you man out of love of your company.
最后一条警告：不要以为主人对你的依赖就会让他爱你。事实上，他可能会怨恨你、惧怕你。但正如马基雅维利所说，被人畏惧总比被人爱戴要好。恐惧你可以控制，爱却永远无法掌控。依赖像爱或友谊这样易变的情感只会让你更加缺乏安全感。与其让别人因为害怕失去你而依赖你，不如让别人因为爱慕你而依赖你。
Image: Vines with Many Thorns. Below, the roots grow deep and wide. Above, the vines push through bushes, entwine themselves
图片：带刺的藤蔓。下方，根系深扎大地；上方，藤蔓穿过灌木丛，相互缠绕。
around trees and poles and window ledges. To get rid of them would cost such toil and blood, it is easier to let them climb.
它们爬满树木、电线杆和窗台。要清除它们需要耗费大量精力和体力，还不如任由它们攀爬来得省事。
Authority: Make people depend on you. More is to be gained from such dependence than courtesy. He who has slaked his thirst, immediately turns his back on the well, no longer needing it. When dependence disappears, so does civility and decency, and then respect. The first lesson which experience should teach you is to keep hope alive but never satisfied, keeping even a royal patron ever in need of you. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：使人依赖你。这种依赖比礼貌更有价值。解渴之人，会立刻背弃井水，不再需要它。依赖消失，礼貌和体面也随之消失，尊重亦然。经验教会你的第一课，就是要保持希望，但永不满足，即使是皇室赞助人，也要始终对你有所依赖。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
The weakness of making others depend on you is that you are in some measure dependent on them. But trying to move beyond that point means getting rid of those above youit means standing alone, depending on no one. Such is die monopolistic drive of a J. P. Morgan or a John D. Rockefellerto drive out all competition, to be in complete control. If you can corner the market, so much the better.
让别人依赖你的弊端在于，你在某种程度上也依赖于他们。但要超越这一点，就意味着摆脱上级——意味着独立自主，不依赖任何人。摩根大通或洛克菲勒的垄断野心正是如此：排挤所有竞争对手，实现完全掌控。如果能垄断市场，那就再好不过了。
No such independence comes without a price. You are forced to isolate yourself. Monopolies often turn inward and destroy themselves from die internal pressure. They also stir up powerful resentment, making tiieir enemies bond together to fight them. The drive for complete control is often ruinous and fruitless. Interdependence remains die law, independence a rare and often fatal exception. Better to place yourself in a position of mutual dependence, then, and to follow this critical law ratfier dian look for its reversal. You will not have die unbearable pressure of being on top, and die master above you will in essence be your slave, for he will depend on you.
任何独立都是有代价的。你会被迫孤立自己。垄断企业往往会因内部压力而走向自我毁灭。它们还会激起强烈的怨恨，使敌人联合起来对抗它们。追求完全控制往往是毁灭性的，也是徒劳的。相互依存才是常态，独立是一种罕见且往往致命的例外。因此，最好让自己处于相互依存的地位，并遵循这条至关重要的规律，而不是寻求它的逆转。你将不会承受高高在上的巨大压力，而你的上级实际上会成为你的奴隶，因为他将依赖于你。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 12
第十二条
USE SELECTIVE HONESTY AND GENEROSITY TO DISARM YOUR VICTIM
运用选择性的诚实和慷慨来解除受害者的戒备
JUDGMENT
判断
One sincere and honest move will cover over dozens of dishonest ones. Open-hearted gestures of honesty and generosity bring down the guard of even the most suspicious people. Once your selective honesty opens a hole in their armor, you can deceive and manipulate them at will. A timely gifta Trojan horsewill serve the same purpose.
一次真诚坦率的举动足以掩盖几十次不诚实的行为。发自内心的诚实和慷慨，即使是最多疑的人也会放下戒备。一旦你选择性的诚实在他们的防线中打开了一个缺口，你就可以随心所欲地欺骗和操纵他们。一份及时的礼物——一个特洛伊木马——也能起到同样的作用。
IKWCKSCO liOKUI. COI lil 1KB CIIAUI.VIW
IKWCKSCO liOKUI。 COI 文件 1KB CIIAUI.VIW
Francesco Giuseppe Borri of Milan, whose death in 1695 fell just within the seventeenth century . . . was a forerunner of that special type of charlatunical adventurer, the courtier or “cavalier” impostor. . . . His real period of glory began after he moved to Amsterdam. There he assumed the title of Medico Universale, maintained a great retinue, and drove about in a coach with six horses.. .. Patients streamed to him, and some invalids had themselves carried in sedan chairs all the way from Paris to his place in Amsterdam. Borri took no payment for his consultations: He distributed great sums among the poor and was never known to receive any money through the post or bills of exchange. As he continued to live with such splendor, nevertheless, it was presumed that he possessed the philosophers' stone. Suddenly this benefactor disappeared from Amsterdam. Then it was discovered that he had taken with him money and diamonds that had been placed in his charge.
米兰的弗朗切斯科·朱塞佩·博里，于1695年去世，正值十七世纪……他是那种特殊类型的江湖骗子——宫廷或“骑士”骗子的先驱……他真正的辉煌时期始于移居阿姆斯特丹之后。在那里，他自称“全科医生”，拥有庞大的随从，乘坐六匹马拉的马车四处巡视……病人蜂拥而至，甚至有些病人乘坐轿子从巴黎一路抬到他在阿姆斯特丹的住所。博里从不收取诊费：他将大量钱财分发给穷人，而且从未有人知道他通过邮政或汇票收取过任何款项。然而，由于他继续过着如此奢华的生活，人们都认为他拥有点石成金的魔力。突然间，这位慈善家从阿姆斯特丹消失了。后来人们发现，他带走了委托他保管的钱财和钻石。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Sometime in 1926, a tall, dapperly dressed man paid a visit to Al Capone, the most feared gangster of his time. Speaking with an elegant Continental accent, the man introduced himself as Count Victor Lustig. He promised that if Capone gave him $50,000 he could double it. Capone had more than enough funds to cover the “investment,” but he wasn't in die habit of entrusting large sums to total strangers. He looked the count over: Something about the man was differenthis classy style, his mannerand so Capone decided to play along. He counted out the bills personally and handed them to Lustig. “Okay, Count,” said Capone. “Double it in sixty days like you said.” Lustig left with the money, put it in a safe-deposit box in Chicago, then headed to New York, where he had several other money-making schemes in progress.
1926年的某一天，一位身材高大、衣着考究的男子拜访了当时最令人闻风丧胆的黑帮老大阿尔·卡彭。他操着一口优雅的欧陆口音，自称维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵。他承诺，如果卡彭给他五万美元，他就能翻倍。卡彭的钱绰绰有余，足以支付这笔“投资”，但他向来不习惯把大笔钱托付给完全陌生的人。卡彭上下打量着卢斯蒂格：这个人有些不同寻常——他优雅的气质，他的举止——于是卡彭决定配合他演戏。他亲自数了数钞票，递给了卢斯蒂格。“好的，伯爵，”卡彭说，“就像你说的，六十天之内翻倍。”卢斯蒂格带着钱离开了，把钱存进了芝加哥的一个保险箱，然后前往纽约，他在那里还有其他几个赚钱的计划正在进行中。
The $50,000 remained in the bank box untouched. Lustig made no effort to double it. Two months later he returned to Chicago, took die money from die box, and paid Capone anodier visit. He looked at the gangster's stony-faced bodyguards, smiled apologetically, and said, “Please accept my profound regrets, Mr. Capone. I'm sorry to report that die plan failed ... I failed.”
那五万美元仍然原封不动地躺在银行金库里。卢斯蒂格没有试图把它翻倍。两个月后，他回到芝加哥，从金库里取出那笔钱，再次拜访了卡彭。他看着卡彭面无表情的保镖们，歉意地笑了笑，说道：“卡彭先生，请接受我深深的遗憾。很抱歉地告诉你，计划失败了……我失败了。”
Capone slowly stood up. He glowered at Lustig, debating which part of the river to throw him in. But the count reached into his coat pocket, withdrew the $50,000, and placed it on the desk. “Here, sir, is your money, to die penny. Again, my sincere apologies. This is most embarrassing. Things didn't work out die way I tiiought diey would. I would have loved to have doubled your money for you and for myselfLord knows I need itbut die plan just didn't materialize.”
卡彭缓缓站起身来。他怒视着卢斯蒂格，琢磨着该把他扔到河的哪条河里去。但伯爵伸手从外套口袋里掏出五万美元，放在桌上。“先生，这是您的钱，一分钱一分货。再次向您致歉。这真是太尴尬了。事情并没有像我预想的那样发展。我本想把您的钱翻倍，也给自己留点——上帝知道我有多需要这笔钱——但计划最终未能实现。”
Capone sagged back into his chair, confused. “I know you're a con man, Count,” said Capone. “I knew it die moment you walked in here. I expected either one hundred thousand dollars or nodiing. But this .. . getting my money back . . . well.” “Again my apologies, Mr. Capone,” said Lustig, as he picked up his hat and began to leave. “My God! You're honest!” yelled Capone. “If you're on the spot, here's five to help you along.” He counted out five one-tiiousand-dollar bills out of die $50,000. The count seemed stunned, bowed deeply, mumbled his tiianks, and left, taking die money.
卡彭一脸茫然地靠回椅子上。“我知道你是个骗子，伯爵，”卡彭说，“你一进门我就知道。我以为你会给我十万美元，或者点点头。但是……要回我的钱……好吧。”“再次向您道歉，卡彭先生，”卢斯蒂格说着，拿起帽子准备离开。“我的天哪！你居然诚实！”卡彭喊道，“如果你现在不知所措，这里有五美元帮你一把。”他从五万美元中数出五张一美元的钞票。伯爵似乎愣住了，深深鞠了一躬，咕哝了几句，然后拿着钱离开了。
The $5,000 was what Lustig had been after all along.
那5000美元正是卢斯蒂格一直以来想要得到的。
Interpretation
解释
Count Victor Lustig, a man who spoke several languages and prided himself on his refinement and culture, was one of die great con artists of modern times. He was known for his audacity, his fearlessness, and, most important, his knowledge of human psychology. He could size up a man in minutes, discovering his weaknesses, and he had radar for suckers. Lustig knew tiiat most men build up defenses against crooks and odier troublemakers. The con artist's job is to bring tiiose defenses down.
维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵精通多国语言，自诩举止优雅、学识渊博，是近代最伟大的骗子之一。他以胆大妄为、无所畏惧著称，更重要的是，他深谙人性。他能在几分钟内看透一个人，发现其弱点，并且对傻瓜有着敏锐的洞察力。卢斯蒂格深知，大多数人都会筑起防线来抵御骗子和其他麻烦制造者。而骗子的工作就是瓦解这些防线。
One sure way to do diis is tiirough an act of apparent sincerity and honesty. Who will distrust a person literally caught in die act of being hon-
做到这一点的一个可靠方法是表现出真诚和诚实。谁会不信任一个被当场抓到表现得诚实的人呢？
est Lustig used selective honesty many times, but with Capone he went a step further. No normal con man would have dared such a con; he would have chosen his suckers for their meekness, for that look about them that says they will take their medicine without complaint. Con Capone and you would spend the rest of your life (whatever remained of it) afraid. But Lustig understood that a man like Capone spends his life mistrusting others. No one around him is honest or generous, and being so much in the company of wolves is exhausting, even depressing. A man like Capone yearns to be the recipient of an honest or generous gesture, to feel that not everyone has an angle or is out to rob him.
卢斯蒂格多次运用选择性诚实，但在卡彭身上，他更进一步。任何普通的骗子都不敢如此行骗；他会选择那些唯唯诺诺、逆来顺受的傻瓜作为目标。要是骗了卡彭，你余生（无论剩余多少）都将生活在恐惧之中。但卢斯蒂格明白，像卡彭这样的人一生都在不信任他人。他身边没有一个诚实或慷慨的人，与一群豺狼为伍令人精疲力竭，甚至感到沮丧。像卡彭这样的人渴望得到真诚或慷慨的对待，渴望感受到并非每个人都心怀不轨或一心想抢劫他。
Lustig's act of selective honesty disarmed Capone because it was so unexpected. A con artist loves conflicting emotions like these, since the person caught up in them is so easily distracted and deceived.
卢斯蒂格的选择性诚实让卡彭措手不及，因为这完全出乎意料。骗子最喜欢利用这种矛盾的情绪，因为被这种情绪所困扰的人很容易分心和受骗。
Do not shy away from practicing this law on the Capones of the world. With a well-timed gesture of honesty or generosity, you will have the most brutal and cynical beast in the kingdom eating out of your hand.
不要害怕对付像卡彭这样的恶棍。只要你适时地展现出诚实或慷慨的姿态，即使是王国里最残暴、最冷酷的野兽也会对你言听计从。
Everything turns gray when I don't have at least one mark on the horizon.
当地平线上连一个目标都没有时，一切都变得灰蒙蒙的。
Life then seems empty and depressing. I cannot understand honest men.
那时生活似乎空虚而令人沮丧。我无法理解诚实的人。
They lead desperate lives, full of boredom.
他们过着绝望、无聊的生活。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The essence of deception is distraction. Distracting the people you want to deceive gives you the time and space to do something tiiey won't notice. An act of kindness, generosity, or honesty is often the most powerful form of distraction because it disarms other people's suspicions. It turns them into children, eagerly lapping up any kind of affectionate gesture.
欺骗的本质在于分散注意力。分散你想欺骗的人的注意力，就能给你时间和空间去做一些他们几乎察觉不到的事情。善意、慷慨或诚实的行为往往是最有效的分散注意力的方式，因为它能消除他人的疑虑。它能让他们像孩子一样，欣然接受任何亲昵的举动。
In ancient China this was called “giving before you take”the giving makes it hard for die other person to notice the taking. It is a device with infinite practical uses. Brazenly taking something from someone is dangerous, even for the powerful. The victim will plot revenge. It is also dangerous simply to ask for what you need, no matter how politely: Unless the other person sees some gain for themselves, they may come to resent your neediness. Learn to give before you take. It softens the ground, takes the bite out of a future request, or simply creates a distraction. And the giving can take many forms: an actual gift, a generous act, a kind favor, an “honest” admissionwhatever it takes.
在中国古代，这被称为“先付出后索取”。付出能让对方难以察觉你的索取。这是一种用途广泛的技巧。即使对于权势人物而言，肆无忌惮地从他人那里索取也是危险的。受害者会伺机报复。仅仅提出你的需求也是危险的，无论你的措辞多么礼貌：除非对方能从中获益，否则他们可能会对你的渴求感到不满。学会先付出后索取。这能缓和局面，减轻未来索取的难度，或者仅仅是转移对方的注意力。付出可以采取多种形式：一份实实在在的礼物、慷慨的行为、善意的帮助、坦诚的承认——总之，不惜一切代价。
Selective honesty is best employed on your first encounter with someone. We are all creatures of habit, and our first impressions last a long time. If someone believes you are honest at die start of your relationship it takes a lot to convince them otherwise. This gives you room to maneuver.
选择性诚实最好在初次见面时使用。我们都是习惯的奴隶，第一印象往往影响深远。如果对方在关系初期就相信你诚实，那么想要改变他们的想法就难上加难。这给了你回旋的余地。
Jay Gould, like Al Capone, was a man who distrusted everyone. By die time he was thirty-three he was already a multimillionaire, mostly dirough deception and strong-arming. In the late 1860s, Gould invested heavily in the Erie Railroad, then discovered tiiat the market had
杰伊·古尔德和阿尔·卡彭一样，是个不信任任何人的人。33岁时，他已是亿万富翁，主要靠欺骗和胁迫得来。19世纪60年代末，古尔德大量投资伊利铁路，后来发现市场……
been flooded with a vast amount of phony stock certificates for the company. He stood to lose a fortune and to suffer a lot of embarrassment.
他收到了大量该公司伪造的股票证书。他不仅可能损失惨重，还会颜面尽失。
In the midst of this crisis, a man named Lord John Gordon-Gordon offered to help. Gordon-Gordon, a Scottish lord, had apparendy made a small fortune investing in railroads.
在这场危机之中，一位名叫约翰·戈登-戈登勋爵的人主动提出帮忙。戈登-戈登是一位苏格兰勋爵，据说他通过投资铁路发了一笔小财。
By hiring some handwriting experts "Gordon-Gordon was able to prove to Gould that the culprits for the phony stock certificates were actually several top executives with the Erie Railroad itself. Gould was grateful. Gordon-Gordon then proposed that he and Gould join forces to buy up a controlling interest in Erie. Gould agreed. For a while the venture appeared to prosper. The two men were now good friends, and every time Gordon-Gordon came to Gould asking for money to buy more stock, Gould gave it to him. In 1873, however, Gordon-Gordon suddenly dumped all of his stock, making a fortune but drastically lowering the value of Gould's own holdings. Then he disappeared from sight.
通过聘请笔迹专家，戈登-戈登向古尔德证明，伪造股票证书的罪魁祸首实际上是伊利铁路公司的几位高管。古尔德对此感激不尽。戈登-戈登随后提议与古尔德联手收购伊利铁路公司的控股权。古尔德同意了。起初，这项投资似乎进展顺利。两人成了好朋友，每次戈登-戈登来找古尔德借钱购买更多股票时，古尔德都会慷慨解囊。然而，到了1873年，戈登-戈登突然抛售了所有股票，从中牟取暴利，但也大幅拉低了古尔德所持股票的价值。之后，他便销声匿迹了。
Upon investigation, Gould found out that Gordon-Gordon's real name was John Crowningsfield, and that he was the bastard son of a merchant seaman and a London barmaid. There had been many clues before then that Gordon-Gordon was a con man, but his initial act of honesty and support had so blinded Gould that it took the loss of millions for him to see through the scheme.
经过调查，古尔德发现戈登-戈登的真名是约翰·克朗宁斯菲尔德，他是海员和伦敦酒吧女招待的私生子。此前已有许多线索表明戈登-戈登是个骗子，但他最初的诚实和支持蒙蔽了古尔德的双眼，以至于损失数百万英镑后，古尔德才看穿了他的骗局。
A single act of honesty is often not enough. What is required is a reputation for honesty, built on a series of actsbut these can be quite inconsequential. Once this reputation is established, as with first impressions, it is hard to shake.
一次诚实的行为往往不够。需要的是一种诚实的声誉，而这种声誉建立在一系列行为之上——尽管这些行为可能微不足道。一旦这种声誉建立起来，就像第一印象一样，就很难改变。
In ancient China, Duke Wu of Cheng decided it was time to take over the increasingly powerful kingdom of Hu. Telling no one of his plan, he married his daughter to Hu's ruler. He then called a council and asked his ministers, “I am considering a military campaign. Which country should we invade” As he had expected, one of his ministers replied, “Hu should be invaded.” The duke seemed angry, and said, “Hu is a sister state now. Why do you suggest invading her” He had the minister executed for his impolitic remark. The ruler of Hu heard about this, and considering other tokens of Wu's honesty and the marriage with his daughter, he took no precautions to defend himself from Cheng. A few weeks later, Cheng forces swept through Hu and took die country, never to relinquish it.
在中国古代，成武公认为时机成熟，可以吞并日益强大的胡国。他没有将计划告诉任何人，而是将女儿嫁给了胡国君主。之后，他召集大臣，问道：“我正在考虑发动军事行动，我们应该入侵哪个国家？”不出所料，一位大臣回答说：“应该入侵胡国。”成武公似乎很生气，说道：“胡国现在是我们的姐妹国，你为何建议入侵她？”他因这位大臣的失言而将其处死。胡国君主得知此事后，考虑到成武公其他的诚意以及女儿的婚事，并未采取任何防御措施。几周后，成军席卷胡国，夺取了胡国，从此再也没有放弃过它。
Honesty is one of the best ways to disarm the wary, but it is not the only one. Any kind of noble, apparently selfless act will serve. Perhaps the best such act, though, is one of generosity. Few people can resist a gift, even from die most hardened enemy, which is why it is often the perfect way to disarm people. A gift brings out the child in us, instandy lowering our defenses. Although we often view other people's actions in the most cynical light, we rarely see the Machiavellian element of a gift, which quite often hides ulterior motives. A gift is the perfect object in which to hide a deceptive move.
诚实是化解戒备的最佳方法之一，但并非唯一途径。任何高尚的、看似无私的行为都能奏效。然而，或许最好的方法莫过于慷慨。很少有人能抵挡礼物的诱惑，即使是来自最顽固的敌人，因此礼物往往是化解戒备的完美手段。礼物能唤醒我们内心深处的童真，瞬间卸下我们的防备。尽管我们常常以最愤世嫉俗的眼光看待他人的行为，却很少看到礼物背后隐藏的权谋，而这往往掩盖着不可告人的动机。礼物是掩盖欺骗行为的绝佳载体。
Over three thousand years ago the ancient Greeks traveled across die sea to recapture the beautiful Helen, stolen away from them by Paris, and
三千多年前，古希腊人渡过大海，去夺回被帕里斯掳走的美丽女子海伦。
to destroy Paris's city, Troy. The siege lasted ten years, many heroes died, yet neither side had come close to victory. One day, the prophet Calchas assembled the Greeks.
为了摧毁帕里斯的故乡特洛伊城，希腊人发动了围城战。这场围城战持续了十年，无数英雄牺牲，但双方都未能取得胜利。一天，先知卡尔卡斯召集了希腊人。
“Stop battering away at these walls!” he told them. "You must find
“别再猛砸这些墙了！”他告诉他们。“你们必须找到
ruse. We cannot take must find some cunning ning Greek leader with the idea of building hiding soldiers inside it, Trojans as a gift. Achilles, was disgusted unmanly. Better for battlefield than to gain But the soldiers, faced another ten years of death, on the one hand the other, chose the
诡计。我们不能接受，必须找到一些狡猾的希腊领袖，提出在城墙内藏匿士兵的想法，把特洛伊人当作礼物送给他们。阿喀琉斯对此感到厌恶，认为这有失男子气概。与其为了获得利益而牺牲，不如为了战场而牺牲。但士兵们一方面面临着又十年的死亡，另一方面，他们选择了……
Image: The Trojan Horse. Your guile is hidden inside a magnificent gift that proves irresistible to your opponent. The walls open. Once inside, wreak havoc.
图片：特洛伊木马。你的诡计隐藏在一份令对手无法抗拒的精美礼物之中。墙壁打开了。一旦进入，尽情破坏吧。
some other way, some Troy by force alone. We stratagem." The cun-Odysseus fhen came up a giant wooden horse, then offering it to the Neoptolemus, son of with this idea; it was thousands to die on the victory so deceitfully. with a choice between manliness, honor, and and a quick victory on
另辟蹊径，单凭武力攻克特洛伊。我们运用计谋。”奥德修斯想出了一个计谋，他带来了一匹巨大的木马，然后把它献给了尼奥普托勒摩斯，也就是特洛伊的儿子。他想出这个计策；成千上万的人将因此丧命，而胜利却如此虚伪。他面临着在男子气概、荣誉和速胜之间做出选择。
horse, which was prompdy built. The trick was successful and Troy fell. One gift did more for the Greek cause than ten years of fighting.
那匹马很快就造好了。计策奏效了，特洛伊陷落了。这份礼物比希腊十年的战争更有价值。
Selective kindness should also be part of your arsenal of deception. For years the ancient Romans had besieged the city of the Faliscans, always unsuccessfully. One day, however, when the Roman general Camillus was encamped outside the city, he suddenly saw a man leading some children toward him. The man was a Faliscan teacher, and the children, it turned out, were the sons and daughters of the noblest and wealthiest citizens of the town. On the pretense of taking these children out for a walk, he had led them straight to the Romans, offering them as hostages in hopes of ingratiating himself with Camillus, the city's enemy.
选择性的善意也应成为你欺骗手段的一部分。多年来，古罗马人围攻法利斯坎人的城市，却始终未能攻克。然而有一天，当罗马将军卡米卢斯在城外扎营时，他突然看到一个人带着几个孩子朝他走来。这个人是法利斯坎的一位教师，而这些孩子，原来是城里最尊贵、最富有的公民的子女。他假装带孩子们出去散步，实则将他们直接带到了罗马人面前，想把他们当作人质，以此博取卡米卢斯——这座城市的敌人——的好感。
Camillus did not take the children hostage. He stripped the teacher, tied his hands behind his back, gave each child a rod, and let them whip him all the way back to the city. The gesture had an immediate effect on the Faliscans. Had Camillus used die children as hostages, some in the city would have voted to surrender. And even if the Faliscans had gone on fighting, their resistance would have been halfhearted. Camillus's refusal to take advantage of die situation broke down the Faliscans' resistance, and they surrendered. The general had calculated correcdy. And in any case he had had nothing to lose: He knew mat the hostage ploy would not have ended die war, at least not right away. By turning die situation around, he earned his enemy's trust and respect, disarming them. Selective kindness will often break down even the most stubborn foe: Aiming right for the heart, it corrodes the will to fight back.
卡米卢斯并没有劫持孩子为人质。他剥光了老师的衣服，把他的双手反绑在背后，给每个孩子一根棍子，让他们一路鞭打他回到城里。这一举动立刻对法利斯坎人产生了影响。如果卡米卢斯真的把孩子当作人质，城里有些人就会投票投降。即使法利斯坎人继续抵抗，他们的抵抗也会显得软弱无力。卡米卢斯拒绝利用这一局面，瓦解了法利斯坎人的抵抗，他们最终投降了。这位将军的算计是正确的。而且，反正他也没什么可失去的：他知道劫持人质的计谋并不能结束战争，至少不会立刻结束。通过扭转局势，他赢得了敌人的信任和尊重，解除了他们的武装。有选择地施以仁慈往往能瓦解最顽固的敌人：直击人心，就能腐蚀其反抗的意志。
Remember: By playing on people's emotions, calculated acts of kindness can turn a Capone into a gullible child. As with any emotional approach, the tactic must be practiced with caution: If people see through it, their disappointed feelings of gratitude and warmth will become the most violent hatred and distrust. Unless you can make the gesture seem sincere and heartfelt, do not play with fire.
记住：善意之举，若能巧妙地利用人们的情感，就能将卡彭变成一个容易上当受骗的孩子。但任何情感操控都需谨慎，切勿轻信。一旦人们识破你的伎俩，原本的感激和温暖之情便会转化为最强烈的仇恨和不信任。除非你的举动真诚而发自内心，否则切勿玩火。
Authority: When Duke Hsien of Chin was about to raid Yii, he presented to them a jade and a team of horses. When Earl Chih was about to raid Ch'ou-yu, he presented to them grand chariots. Hence the saying: “When you are about to take, you should give.” (Han-fei-tzu, Chinese philosopher, third century B.C.)
出处：秦宪公攻打义国时，送上玉器和骏马；赤伯爵攻打州虞时，送上豪车。故有“欲取而先施”之言。（韩非子，中国哲学家，公元前三世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
When you have a history of deceit behind you, no amount of honesty, generosity, or kindness will fool people. In fact it will only call attention to itself. Once people have come to see you as deceitful, to act honest all of a sudden is simply suspicious. In these cases it is better to play the rogue.
如果你有过欺骗的记录，再多的诚实、慷慨或善良也骗不了人。事实上，这些只会更加引人注目。一旦人们认定你是个骗子，突然表现得诚实只会让人怀疑。在这种情况下，装作不靠谱反而更好。
Count Lustig, pulling the biggest con of his career, was about to sell the Eiffel Tower to an unsuspecting industrialist who believed the government was auctioning it off for scrap metal. The industrialist was prepared to hand over a huge sum of money to Lustig, who had successfully impersonated a government official. At the last minute, however, the mark was suspicious. Something about Lustig bothered him. At die meeting in which he was to hand over the money, Lustig sensed his sudden distrust.
卢斯蒂格伯爵正上演他职业生涯中最大的骗局，准备把埃菲尔铁塔卖给一位毫不知情的实业家。这位实业家以为政府要把铁塔当废铁拍卖。他准备把一大笔钱交给卢斯蒂格，而卢斯蒂格成功地冒充了一位政府官员。然而，就在最后一刻，这位“目标”起了疑心。卢斯蒂格身上似乎有什么地方让他感到不安。在即将交付钱款的会面中，卢斯蒂格察觉到了他突然的不信任。
Leaning over to fhe industrialist, Lustig explained, in a low whisper, how low his salary was, how difficult his finances were, on and on. After a few minutes of this, the industrialist realized that Lustig was asking for a bribe. For the first time he relaxed. Now he knew he could trust Lustig: Since all government officials were dishonest, Lustig had to be real. The man forked over the money. By acting dishonest, Lustig seemed the real McCoy. In this case selective honesty would have had the opposite effect.
卢斯蒂格俯身靠近那位实业家，低声细语地诉说着自己的薪水有多低，经济状况有多拮据等等。几分钟后，实业家意识到卢斯蒂格是在索要贿赂。他第一次放松下来。现在他知道可以信任卢斯蒂格了：既然所有政府官员都不诚实，那么卢斯蒂格一定是真的。他掏出了钱。卢斯蒂格通过装作不诚实，反而显得更加真诚。在这种情况下，选择性诚实反而会适得其反。
As the French diplomat Talleyrand grew older, his reputation as a master liar and deceiver spread. At the Congress of Vienna (1814-1815), he would spin fabulous stories and make impossible remarks to people who knew he had to be lying. His dishonesty had no purpose except to cloak the moments when he really was deceiving them. One day, for example, among friends, Talleyrand said with apparent sincerity, “In business one ought to show one's hand.” No one who heard him could believe their ears: A man who never once in his life had shown his cards was telling other people to show theirs. Tactics like this made it impossible to distinguish Talleyrand's real deceptions from his fake ones. By embracing his reputation for dishonesty, he preserved his ability to deceive.
随着法国外交官塔列朗年纪渐长，他“撒谎高手”的名声也越来越响亮。在维也纳会议（1814-1815）期间，他会编造各种离奇的故事，发表一些匪夷所思的言论，而那些人明知他是在撒谎。他的谎言毫无意义，只是为了掩盖他真正欺骗他人的时刻。例如，有一天，塔列朗在朋友面前一本正经地说：“做生意就应该亮出底牌。”所有听到的人都难以置信：一个一生从未亮出底牌的人，竟然在劝别人亮牌。诸如此类的伎俩使得人们根本无法分辨塔列朗的真假。正是通过接受自己“不诚实”的名声，他才得以继续行骗。
Nothing in the realm of power is set in stone. Overt deceptiveness will sometimes cover your tracks, even making you admired for the honesty of your dishonesty.
在权力领域，没有什么是一成不变的。明目张胆的欺骗有时反而能掩盖你的行径，甚至让你因这种“诚实”的欺骗而赢得赞赏。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 13
第13条
WHEN ASKING FOR HELP,
寻求帮助时，
APPEAL TO PEOPLE'S
诉诸人民
SELF-INTEREST,
自利，
NEVER TO THEIR MERCY
绝不向他们屈服
OR GRATITUDE
或者感恩
JUDGMENT
判断
If you need to turn to an ally for help, do not bother to remind him of your past assistance and good deeds. He will find a way to ignore you. Instead, uncover something in your request, or in your alliance with him, that will benefit him, and emphasize it out of all proportion. He will respond enthusiastically when he sees something to be gained for himself
如果你需要向盟友寻求帮助，不要费心提醒他你过去对他的帮助和善行。他会想方设法忽略你。相反，你应该在你的请求或你们的联盟中找出对他有利的因素，并极力强调这一点。当他看到自己能从中获利时，他会热情回应。
A peasant had in his garden an apple-tree, which bore no fruit, but only served as a perch for the sparrows and grasshoppers. He resolved to cut it down, and, taking his ax in hand, made a bold stroke at its roots. The grasshoppers and sparrows entreated him not to cut down the tree that sheltered them, but to spare it, and they would sing to him and lighten his labors. He paid no attention to their request, but gave the tree a second and a third blow with his ax. When he reached the hollow of the tree, he found a hive full of honey. Having tasted the honeycomb, he threw down his ax, and, looking on the tree as sacred, took great care of it. Self-interest alone moves some men.
一位农夫的花园里有一棵苹果树，它不结果实，只是麻雀和蚱蜢的栖息之处。他决定把它砍掉，于是拿起斧头，狠狠地砍向树根。蚱蜢和麻雀恳求他不要砍掉这棵庇护它们的树，饶它一命，说它们会唱歌给他听，减轻他的劳作。他没有理会它们的请求，又用斧头砍了第二下、第三下。当他砍到树洞时，发现里面有一个装满蜂蜜的蜂巢。尝了尝蜂蜜后，他扔下斧头，把这棵树视为神圣之物，从此悉心照料它。有些人只顾自身利益。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop, sixth century b.c.
伊索，公元前六世纪
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In the early fourteendi century, a young man named Castruccio Castracani rose from the rank of common soldier to become lord of the great city of Lucca, Italy. One of the most powerful families in the city, the Poggios, had been instrumental in his climb (which succeeded through treachery and bloodshed), but after he came to power, they came to feel he had forgotten them. His ambition outweighed any gratitude he felt. In 1325, while Castruccio was away fighting Lucca's main rival, Florence, the Poggios conspired with other noble families in the city to rid themselves of this troublesome and ambitious prince.
十四世纪初，一位名叫卡斯特鲁乔·卡斯特拉卡尼的年轻人从一名普通士兵一路晋升，最终成为意大利卢卡城的领主。城中最有权势的家族之一——波焦家族，曾助他一步步登上权力巅峰（他的成功是通过背叛和流血实现的），但卡斯特鲁乔掌权后，波焦家族却觉得他已经将他们遗忘。他的野心远胜于任何感激之情。1325年，卡斯特鲁乔远征佛罗伦萨，与卢卡的主要对手交战之际，波焦家族联合城中其他贵族家族，密谋除掉这位桀骜不驯、野心勃勃的君主。
Mounting an insurrection, the plotters attacked and murdered the governor whom Castruccio had left behind to rule the city. Riots broke out, and the Castruccio supporters and the Poggio supporters were poised to do battle. At die height of the tension, however, Stefano di Poggio, the oldest member of the family, intervened, and made both sides lay down their arms.
阴谋者发动叛乱，袭击并杀害了卡斯特鲁乔留下来统治这座城市的总督。骚乱爆发，卡斯特鲁乔的支持者和波焦的支持者剑拔弩张，一触即发。然而，在局势最为紧张之际，波焦家族中最年长的成员斯特凡诺·迪·波焦出面干预，迫使双方放下武器。
A peaceful man, Stefano had not taken part in the conspiracy. He had told his family it would end in a useless bloodbath. Now he insisted he should intercede on the family's behalf and persuade Castruccio to listen to their complaints and satisfy their demands. Stefano was the oldest and wisest member of the clan, and his family agreed to put their trust in his diplomacy rather man in their weapons.
斯蒂法诺生性爱好和平，并未参与这场阴谋。他曾告诉家人，这场阴谋最终只会演变成一场毫无意义的血腥屠杀。如今，他却坚持要代表家人出面，劝说卡斯特鲁乔倾听他们的诉求，满足他们的要求。斯蒂法诺是家族中最年长、最睿智的成员，家人也同意相信他的外交手腕，而不是依靠武力。
When news of the rebellion reached Castruccio, he hurried back to Lucca. By the time he arrived, however, the fighting had ceased, through Stefano's agency, and he was surprised by the city's calm and peace. Stefano di Poggio had imagined that Castruccio would be grateful to him for his part in quelling die rebellion, so he paid die prince a visit. He explained how he had brought peace, then begged for Castruccio's mercy. He said mat die rebels in his family were young and impetuous, hungry for power yet inexperienced; he recalled his family's past generosity to Castruccio. For all tiiese reasons, he said, the great prince should pardon the Poggios and listen to their complaints. This, he said, was the only just thing to do, since the family had willingly laid down their arms and had always supported him.
当卡斯特鲁乔得知叛乱的消息后，便匆匆赶回卢卡。然而，在他抵达时，战斗已在斯蒂法诺的帮助下停止，城中的平静祥和令他感到惊讶。斯蒂法诺·迪·波焦原本以为卡斯特鲁乔会感激他平息叛乱的功劳，于是便去拜访了这位王子。他解释了自己如何带来和平，然后恳求卡斯特鲁乔的宽恕。他说，他家族中的叛乱者年轻气盛，渴望权力却缺乏经验；他还回忆起家族过去对卡斯特鲁乔的慷慨相助。他说，鉴于以上种种原因，伟大的王子应该赦免波焦家族，并倾听他们的诉求。他表示，这是唯一公正的做法，因为他们家族自愿放下武器，并且一直支持着他。
Castruccio listened patiendy. He seemed not the slightest bit angry or resentful. Instead, he told Stefano to rest assured that justice would prevail, and he asked him to bring his entire family to die palace to talk over their grievances and come to an agreement. As diey took leave of one another, Castruccio said he thanked God for the chance he had been given to show his clemency and kindness. That evening die entire Poggio family came to die palace. Castruccio immediately had them imprisoned and a few days later all were executed, including Stefano.
卡斯特鲁乔耐心地听着。他似乎丝毫没有生气或怨恨。相反，他告诉斯特凡诺，让他放心，正义终将得到伸张，并请他把全家都带到宫里来，商讨他们的冤情，达成和解。临别之际，卡斯特鲁乔说，他感谢上帝给了他展现仁慈和善意的机会。当晚，波焦一家人都来到了宫里。卡斯特鲁乔立即下令将他们监禁，几天后，包括斯特凡诺在内的所有人都被处决了。
Interpretation
解释
Stefano di Poggio is die embodiment of all those who believe that the justice and nobility of dieir cause will prevail. Certainly appeals to justice and gratitude have occasionally succeeded in the past, but more often than not
斯特凡诺·迪·波焦正是那些坚信正义和高尚的事业终将胜利的人的化身。诚然，诉诸正义和感恩之心在过去偶尔也能奏效，但更多时候却并非如此。
they have had dire consequences, especially in dealings with the Castruc-cios of the world. Stefano knew that the prince had risen to power through treachery and ruthlessness. This was a man, after all, who had put a close and devoted friend to death. When Castruccio was told that it had been a terrible wrong to kill such an old friend, he replied that he had executed not an old friend but a new enemy.
这些行为造成了极其严重的后果，尤其是在与卡斯特鲁乔之流打交道时。斯蒂法诺深知，这位王子是靠着背信弃义和残暴手段才登上权力巅峰的。毕竟，这个人曾亲手处死过一位挚友。当有人告诉卡斯特鲁乔，杀害这样一位老朋友是极其错误的，他却回答说，他处死的不是老朋友，而是一个新敌人。
A man like Castruccio knows only force and self-interest. When the rebellion began, to end it and place oneself at his mercy was the most dangerous possible move. Even once Stefano di Poggio had made that fatal mistake, however, he still had options: He could have offered money to Castruccio, could have made promises for the future, could have pointed out what the Poggios could still contribute to Castruccio's powertheir influence with the most influential families of Rome, for example, and die great marriage they could have brokered.
像卡斯特鲁乔这样的人，眼里只有武力和私利。叛乱爆发之初，结束叛乱、让自己落入他的掌控，是最危险的举动。然而，即便斯蒂法诺·迪·波焦犯下了这个致命的错误，他仍然有其他选择：他可以给卡斯特鲁乔钱财，可以许下未来的承诺，可以指出波焦家族还能为卡斯特鲁乔的权力做出哪些贡献——例如，他们与罗马最有权势的家族的联系，以及他们本可以促成的联姻。
Instead Stefano brought up the past, and debts that carried no obligation. Not only is a man not obliged to be grateful, gratitude is often a terrible burden that he gladly discards. And in this case Castruccio rid himself of his obligations to the Poggios by eliminating the Poggios.
相反，斯特凡诺却提起了往事，以及那些根本不存在的债务。一个人不仅没有义务心存感激，而且感激之情往往是一种沉重的负担，他乐于摆脱它。在这个例子中，卡斯特鲁乔通过除掉波焦家族来摆脱了对波焦家族的债务。
Most men are so thoroughly subjective that nothing really interests them but themselves. They always think of their own case as soon as ever any remark is made, and their whole attention is engrossed and absorbed by the merest chance reference to anything which affects them personally, be it never so remote.
大多数男人都非常主观，除了自己之外，其他任何事情都无法真正引起他们的兴趣。只要有人提起任何事，他们立刻就会想到自己，哪怕只是偶然提及与自己有关的事情，无论多么微不足道，都会让他们全神贯注。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In 433 B.C., just before the Peloponnesian War, the island of Corcyra (later called Corfu) and the Greek city-state of Corinth stood on the brink of conflict. Both parties sent ambassadors to Athens to try to win over the Athenians to their side. The stakes were high, since whoever had Athens on his side was sure to win. And whoever won the war would certainly give the defeated side no mercy.
公元前433年，就在伯罗奔尼撒战争爆发前夕，科西拉岛（后称科孚岛）和希腊城邦科林斯之间剑拔弩张。双方都派遣使节前往雅典，试图争取雅典人的支持。这场战争意义重大，因为谁能赢得雅典的支持，谁就必胜无疑。而最终的胜利者，也必将毫不留情地惩罚战败方。
Corcyra spoke first. Its ambassador began by admitting that the island had never helped Athens before, and in fact had allied itself with Athens's enemies. There were no ties of friendship or gratitude between Corcyra and Athens. Yes, the ambassador admitted, he had come to Athens now out of fear and concern for Corcyra's safety. The only thing he could offer was an alliance of mutual interests. Corcyra had a navy only surpassed in size and strengdi by Athens's own; an alliance between the two states would create a formidable force, one that could intimidate the rival state of Sparta. That, unfortunately, was all Corcyra had to offer.
科基拉首先发言。其使节首先承认，该岛此前从未帮助过雅典，事实上，它还曾与雅典的敌人结盟。科基拉与雅典之间并无友谊或恩情。使节坦言，他此次前来雅典，是出于对科基拉安全的担忧和恐惧。他唯一能提供的，便是建立互利共赢的联盟。科基拉的海军规模和实力仅次于雅典；两国结盟将形成一支强大的力量，足以震慑其宿敌斯巴达。遗憾的是，这便是科基拉所能提供的全部。
The representative from Corinth then gave a brilliant, passionate speech, in sharp contrast to the dry, colorless approach of the Corcyran. He talked of everything Corinth had done for Athens in die past. He asked how it would look to Athens's other allies if the city put an agreement with a former enemy over one with a present friend, one that had served Athens's interest loyally: Perhaps those allies would break their agreements with Athens if tiiey saw that their loyalty was not valued. He referred to Hellenic law, and the need to repay Corinth for all its good deeds. He finally went on to list the many services Corinth had performed for Athens, and the importance of showing gratitude to one's friends.
科林斯代表随后发表了一篇精彩而充满激情的演讲，与科尔基拉代表枯燥乏味的发言形成了鲜明对比。他回顾了科林斯过去为雅典所做的一切。他质问道，如果雅典为了与昔日的敌人达成协议，而放弃与一位忠诚地为雅典利益服务的盟友，其他盟友会作何感想？如果这些盟友看到自己的忠诚不被重视，他们或许也会撕毁与雅典的协议。他援引希腊法律，强调必须回报科林斯的所有恩惠。最后，他列举了科林斯为雅典提供的诸多服务，并强调了对朋友表达感激之情的重要性。
After the speech, the Athenians debated the issue in an assembly. On
演讲结束后，雅典人在公民大会上就此问题展开辩论。
the second round, they voted overwhelmingly to ally with Corcyra and drop Corinth.
在第二轮投票中，他们以压倒性多数投票决定与科尔西拉结盟，放弃科林斯。
Interpretation
解释
History has remembered the Atiienians nobly, but they were the preeminent realists of classical Greece. With them, all the rhetoric, all the emotional appeals in the world, could not match a good pragmatic argument, especially one that added to their power.
历史对阿提埃尼亚人给予了崇高的评价，但他们也是古典希腊最杰出的现实主义者。对他们而言，世间所有的雄辩和情感诉求都无法与一个切实可行的论证相提并论，尤其是一个能够增强他们力量的论证。
What the Corinthian ambassador did not realize was that his references to Corinth's past generosity to Athens only irritated the Athenians, subdy asking them to feel guilty and putting them under obligation. The Athenians couldn't care less about past favors and friendly feelings. At the same time, they knew that if their other allies thought them ungrateful for abandoning Corinth, these city-states would still be unlikely to break their ties to Athens, the preeminent power in Greece. Atiiens ruled its empire by force, and would simply compel any rebellious ally to return to the fold.
科林斯使节没有意识到，他提及科林斯过去对雅典的慷慨，只会激怒雅典人，这实际上是在暗示他们感到愧疚和有义务回报。雅典人根本不在乎过去的恩惠和友谊。与此同时，他们也明白，即便其他盟友认为他们抛弃科林斯是忘恩负义，这些城邦也不太可能断绝与雅典——希腊的霸主——的关系。雅典以武力统治帝国，任何反叛的盟友都会被强迫回归。
When people choose between talk about the past and talk about the future, a pragmatic person will always opt for the future and forget the past. As die Corcyrans realized, it is always best to speak pragmatically to a pragmatic person. And in the end, most people are in fact pragmaticthey will rarely act against their own self-interest.
当人们在谈论过去和谈论未来之间做出选择时，务实的人总是会选择未来，而将过去抛诸脑后。正如科西拉人所认识到的，与务实的人交谈，务实永远是最佳选择。最终，大多数人实际上都是务实的——他们很少会做出违背自身利益的事情。
It has always been a rule that the weak should be subject to the strong;
弱者服从强者一直是一条不成文的规则；
and besides, we consider that we are worthy of our power. Up till the
而且，我们认为我们配得上我们所拥有的权力。直到……
present moment you, too, used to think that we were; but now, after
此刻，你也曾以为我们是；但现在，在……之后
calculating your own interest, you are beginning to talk in terms of right
当你计算自己的利益时，你就开始谈论权利了。
and wrong. Considerations of this kind have never yet turned people aside
而且是错误的。这类考虑从未使人们退缩过。
from the opportunities of aggrandizement offered by superior strength.
