利用优势实力带来的扩张机会。
Athenian representative to Sparta,
雅典派往斯巴达的代表
quoted in The Peloponnesian War, Thucydide.s, c. 465-395 B.C.
引自修昔底德的《伯罗奔尼撒战争史》，约公元前 465-395 年。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In your quest for power, you will constantiy find yourself in the position of asking for help from those more powerful than you. There is an art to asking for help, an art that depends on your ability to understand the person you are dealing with, and to not confuse your needs with theirs.
在你追求权力的过程中，你会不断发现自己需要向比你更有权势的人寻求帮助。寻求帮助是一门艺术，这门艺术取决于你理解你所面对的人的能力，以及区分自身需求与对方需求的能力。
Most people never succeed at this, because they are completely trapped in their own wants and desires. They start from the assumption that the people they are appealing to have a selfless interest in helping them. They talk as if their needs mattered to these peoplewho probably couldn't care less. Sometimes they refer to larger issues: a great cause, or grand emotions such as love and gratitude. They go for the big picture when simple, everyday realities would have much more appeal. What they do not realize is that even the most powerful person is locked inside needs of his own, and that if you make no appeal to his self-interest, he merely sees you as desperate or, at best, a waste of time.
大多数人永远无法成功，因为他们完全被自身的欲望所束缚。他们一开始就假定自己所求助的人会无私地帮助他们。他们说话的口气好像自己的需求对那些可能根本不在乎的人至关重要。有时他们会提及一些更宏大的问题：一项伟大的事业，或者诸如爱和感恩之类的强烈情感。他们总是追求宏大的愿景，却忽略了简单、日常的现实其实更有吸引力。他们没有意识到，即使是最有权势的人也受制于自身的需要，如果你不迎合他们的私利，他们只会觉得你很绝望，或者充其量只是在浪费时间。
In die sixteendi century, Portuguese missionaries tried for years to convert the people of Japan to Catholicism, while at the same time Portugal had a monopoly on trade between Japan and Europe. Although the missionaries did have some success, they never got far among the ruling elite; by the beginning of the seventeenth century, in fact, tiieir proselytizing had completely antagonized the Japanese emperor Ieyasu. When the Dutch began to arrive in Japan in great numbers, Ieyasu was much relieved. He needed Europeans for their know-how in guns and navigation, and here at last were Europeans who cared nothing for spreading religiondie Dutch wanted only to trade. Ieyasu swifdy moved to evict die Portuguese. From then on, he would only deal with the practical-minded Dutch.
十六世纪，葡萄牙传教士多年来试图将日本人皈依天主教，与此同时，葡萄牙垄断了日本与欧洲之间的贸易。尽管传教士取得了一些成功，但他们始终未能深入统治精英阶层；事实上，到了十七世纪初，他们的传教活动已经彻底激怒了日本天皇德川家康。当荷兰人开始大量涌入日本时，家康如释重负。他需要欧洲人在枪炮和航海方面的技术，而荷兰人终于满足了他的需求——他们不关心传播宗教，只想进行贸易。家康迅速采取行动驱逐葡萄牙人。从此以后，他只与务实的荷兰人打交道。
Japan and Holland were vasdy different cultures, but each shared a timeless and universal concern: self-interest. Every person you deal with is like anotiier culture, an alien land with a past tiiat has nothing to do witii yours. Yet you can bypass die differences between you and him by appealing to his self-interest. Do not be subde: You have valuable knowledge to share, you will fill his coffers with gold, you will make him live longer and happier. This is a language mat all of us speak and understand.
日本和荷兰是截然不同的文化，但它们都拥有一个永恒且普遍的共同点：利己主义。你遇到的每个人都像另一种文化，一个与你历史毫不相干的异域。然而，你可以通过诉诸对方的利己主义来跨越彼此间的差异。不要屈服：你拥有宝贵的知识可以分享，你会让他财源滚滚，你会让他活得更长久、更幸福。这是我们所有人都能理解的语言。
A key step in die process is to understand die other person's psychology. Is he vain Is he concerned about his reputation or his social standing Does he have enemies you could help him vanquish Is he simply motivated by money and power
在这个过程中，关键的一步是了解对方的心理。他是否虚荣？他是否在意自己的名誉或社会地位？他是否有你可以帮他战胜的敌人？他是否仅仅被金钱和权力所驱使？
When die Mongols invaded China in the twelfth century, they threat-ened to obliterate a culture that had thrived for over two thousand years. Their leader, Genghis Khan, saw nothing in China but a country tiiat lacked pasturing for his horses, and he decided to destroy die place, leveling all its cities, for “it would be better to exterminate the Chinese and let the grass grow.” It was not a soldier, a general, or a king who saved die Chinese from devastation, but a man named Yelu Ch'u-Ts'ai. A foreigner himself, Ch'u-Ts'ai had come to appreciate die superiority of Chinese culture. He managed to make himself a trusted adviser to Genghis Khan, and persuaded him that he would reap riches out of the place if, instead of destroying it, he simply taxed everyone who lived tiiere. Khan saw the wisdom in diis and did as Ch'u-Ts'ai advised.
十二世纪蒙古入侵中国时，他们几乎摧毁了一个繁荣了两千多年的文明。他们的首领成吉思汗认为中国不过是一个缺乏牧场供马匹放牧的地方，于是决定摧毁这片土地，夷平所有城市，因为他认为“与其让中国人灭绝，不如让草地生长”。拯救中国人免于灭亡的并非士兵、将军或国王，而是一位名叫耶律楚才的人。楚才本人也是外国人，但他逐渐领悟到中国文化的优越性。他设法成为成吉思汗的得力助手，并说服他，与其摧毁这片土地，不如向所有居民征税，这样就能从中获取财富。成吉思汗领悟了楚才的智慧，采纳了他的建议。
When Khan took the city of Kaifeng, after a long siege, and decided to massacre its inhabitants (as he had in otiier cities diat had resisted him), Ch'u-Ts'ai told him tiiat the finest craftsmen and engineers in China had fled to Kaifeng, and it would be better to put them to use. Kaifeng was spared. Never before had Genghis Khan shown such mercy, but then it really wasn't mercy tiiat saved Kaifeng. Ch'u-Ts'ai knew Khan well. He was a barbaric peasant who cared nothing for culture, or indeed for anytiiing otiier than warfare and practical results. Ch'u-Ts'ai chose to appeal to the only emotion that would work on such a man: greed.
成吉思汗经过长期围攻攻克开封后，决定屠杀城中居民（就像他在其他抵抗他的城市所做的那样）。楚载告诉他，中国最优秀的工匠和工程师都逃到了开封，不如好好利用他们。开封因此得以幸免。成吉思汗从未如此仁慈过，但实际上拯救开封的并非仁慈。楚载深知成吉思汗的为人。他是一个野蛮的农民，对文化漠不关心，除了战争和实际利益之外，对任何事物都漠不关心。楚载选择诉诸于唯一能打动成吉思汗的情感：贪婪。
Self-interest is the lever tiiat will move people. Once you make them see how you can in some way meet their needs or advance their cause, their resistance to your requests for help will magically fall away. At each step on die way to acquiring power, you must train yourself to tiiink your
利己主义是影响他人的杠杆。一旦你让他们看到你能以某种方式满足他们的需求或推进他们的事业，他们对你帮助请求的抵触情绪就会神奇地消失。在获取权力的每一步，你都必须训练自己思考……
way inside the other person's mind, to see their needs and interests, to get rid of the screen of your own feelings that obscure the truth. Master tiiis art and there will be no limits to what you can accomplish.
深入他人的内心世界，洞察他们的需求和兴趣，摒除自身情感的迷雾，看清真相。掌握这门艺术，你的成就将无可限量。
Image: A Cord that Binds. The cord of mercy and gratitude is threadbare, and will break at the first shock. Do not throw such a lifeline. The cord of mutual self-interest is woven of many fibers and cannot easily be severed. It will serve you well for years.
图片：一条维系的绳索。仁慈与感恩的绳索脆弱不堪，稍有冲击便会断裂。切勿轻易放弃这样的救命稻草。互惠互利的绳索由众多纤维交织而成，不易被斩断。它将伴你多年。
Authority: The shortest and best way to make your fortune is to let people see clearly that it is in their interests to promote yours. (Jean de La Bruyere, 1645-1696)
权威：致富最快捷、最有效的方法就是让人们清楚地看到，促进你的利益符合他们的利益。（让·德·拉布吕耶尔，1645-1696）
REVERSAL
逆转
Some people will see an appeal to their self-interest as ugly and ignoble. They actually prefer to be able to exercise charity, mercy, and justice, which are their ways of feeling superior to you: When you beg them for help, you emphasize their power and position. They are strong enough to need nothing from you except the chance to feel superior. This is the wine that intoxicates them. They are dying to fund your project, to introduce you to powerful peopleprovided, of course, that all this is done in public, and for a good cause (usually the more public, the better). Not everyone, then, can be approached through cynical self-interest. Some people will be put off by it, because they don't want to seem to be motivated by such things. They need opportunities to display their good heart.
有些人会觉得诉诸私利是丑陋且卑鄙的。他们其实更喜欢行善、展现仁慈和伸张正义，因为这是他们获得优越感的方式：当你向他们乞求帮助时，你反而凸显了他们的权力和地位。他们足够强大，不需要你提供任何东西，只需要一个让他们感觉高人一等的机会。这就像美酒一样让他们陶醉。他们渴望资助你的项目，渴望把你介绍给有权有势的人——当然，前提是这一切都要公开进行，并且是为了一个正当的目标（通常来说，越公开越好）。因此，并非所有人都适合用这种冷酷的私利来打动。有些人会因此反感，因为他们不想显得自己是出于这种目的。他们需要机会来展现自己的善良。
Do not be shy. Give them that opportunity. It's not as if you are conning them by asking for helpit is really their pleasure to give, and to be seen giving. You must distinguish the differences among powerful people and figure out what makes them tick. When they ooze greed, do not appeal to meir charity. When they want to look charitable and noble, do not appeal to their greed.
不要害羞，给他们这个机会。你请求他们的帮助并不是在欺骗他们——给予是他们的本能，而且他们也乐于被人看到他们乐于助人。你必须分辨出有权势的人之间的差异，弄清楚他们的动机。当他们贪婪成性时，不要诉诸于他们的善意；当他们想要展现慈善高尚的形象时，不要迎合他们的贪婪。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 14
第14条
POSE AS A FRIEND, WORK AS A SPY
假扮朋友，实则从事间谍活动
JUDGMENT
判断
Knowing about your rival is critical. Use spies to gather valuable information that will keep you a step ahead. Better still: Play the spy yourself. In polite social encounters, learn to probe. Ask indirect questions to get people to reveal their weaknesses and intentions. There is no occasion that is not an opportunity for artful spying.
了解你的对手至关重要。利用间谍收集有价值的情报，让你始终领先一步。更妙的是：你自己也扮演间谍的角色。在礼貌的社交场合，学会试探。提出间接的问题，引导人们暴露弱点和意图。任何场合都是巧妙进行间谍活动的良机。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Joseph Duveen was undoubtedly the greatest art dealer of his timefrom 1904 to 1940 he almost single-handedly monopolized America's millionaire art-collecting market. But one prize plum eluded him: the industrialist Andrew Mellon. Before he died, Duveen was determined to make Mellon a client.
约瑟夫·杜维恩无疑是他那个时代最伟大的艺术品经销商，从1904年到1940年，他几乎凭借一己之力垄断了美国百万富翁的艺术收藏市场。然而，有一位重量级人物却始终与他失之交臂：实业家安德鲁·梅隆。在去世前，杜维恩决心要让梅隆成为他的客户。
Duveen's friends said this was an impossible dream. Mellon was a stiff, taciturn man. The stories he had heard about the congenial, talkative Duveen rubbed him die wrong wayhe had made it clear he had no desire to meet the man. Yet Duveen told his doubting friends, “Not only will Mellon buy from me but he will buy only from me.” For several years he tracked his prey, learning the man's habits, tastes, phobias. To do this, he secredy put several of Mellon's staff on his own payroll, worming valuable information out of them. By the time he moved into action, he knew Mellon about as well as Mellon's wife did.
杜维恩的朋友们都说这是天方夜谭。梅隆是个性格僵硬、沉默寡言的人。他听说的那些关于热情健谈的杜维恩的故事，让他非常反感——他已经明确表示过自己不想见这个人。然而，杜维恩却对那些心存疑虑的朋友们说：“梅隆不仅会从我这里买东西，而且只会从我这里买。”他跟踪梅隆好几年，摸清了他的习惯、喜好和恐惧。为了达到目的，他暗中安排梅隆的几名员工进入自己的公司，从他们口中套取有价值的信息。等到他开始行动时，他对梅隆的了解几乎和梅隆的妻子一样透彻。
In 1921 Mellon was visiting London, and staying in a palatial suite on the third floor of Claridge's Hotel. Duveen booked himself into the suite just below Mellon's, on the second floor. He had arranged for his valet to befriend Mellon's valet, and on the fateful day he had chosen to make his move, Mellon's valet told Duveen's valet, who told Duveen, that he had just helped Mellon on with his overcoat, and that the industrialist was making his way down the corridor to ring for the lift.
1921年，梅隆到访伦敦，下榻于克拉里奇酒店三楼的豪华套房。杜维恩则预订了梅隆套房楼下的二楼套房。他事先安排了自己的贴身男仆与梅隆的贴身男仆套近乎。在杜维恩决定采取行动的那天，梅隆的贴身男仆告诉了杜维恩的贴身男仆，后者又转告杜维恩，说他刚刚帮梅隆穿上了大衣，这位实业家正沿着走廊走向电梯。
Duveen's valet hurriedly helped Duveen witii his own overcoat. Seconds later, Duveen entered the lift, and lo and behold, there was Mellon. “How do you do, Mr. Mellon” said Duveen, introducing himself. “I am on my way to die National Gallery to look at some pictures.” How uncanny diat was precisely where Mellon was headed. And so Duveen was able to accompany his prey to the one location that would ensure his success. He knew Mellon's taste inside and out, and while the two men wandered through the museum, he dazzled the magnate with his knowledge. Once again quite uncannily, they seemed to have remarkably similar tastes.
杜维恩的贴身男仆赶紧帮他穿上大衣。几秒钟后，杜维恩走进电梯，瞧，梅隆就在那里。“您好，梅隆先生，”杜维恩自我介绍道，“我正要去国家美术馆看几幅画。”多么巧合，梅隆的目的地竟然也正是那里。于是，杜维恩得以陪同他的猎物前往那个能确保他成功的地方。他对梅隆的品味了如指掌，两人在博物馆里漫步时，他用渊博的知识让这位大亨惊叹不已。再一次，他们似乎有着惊人的相似之处，这真是不可思议。
Mellon was pleasantiy surprised: This was not the Duveen he had expected. The man was charming and agreeable, and clearly had exquisite taste. When they returned to New York, Mellon visited Duveen's exclusive gallery and fell in love with the collection. Everything, surprisingly enough, seemed to be precisely the kind of work he wanted to collect. For the rest of his life he was Duveen's best and most generous client.
梅隆惊喜万分：这并非他预想中的杜维恩。他风度翩翩，和蔼可亲，而且显然品味非凡。回到纽约后，梅隆参观了杜维恩的高级画廊，并深深地被那里的藏品所吸引。令人惊讶的是，所有藏品似乎都正是他梦寐以求的收藏品。此后，他终生都是杜维恩最忠实、最慷慨的客户。
Interpretation
解释
A man as ambitious and competitive as Joseph Duveen left nothing to chance. What's the point of winging it, of just hoping you may be able to charm this or that client It's like shooting ducks blindfolded. Arm yourself with a litde knowledge and your aim improves.
像约瑟夫·杜维恩这样雄心勃勃、争强好胜的人，绝不会放过任何机会。凭感觉行事，指望靠运气讨好这个客户或那个客户，有什么意义呢？这就像蒙着眼睛打鸭子。掌握一些基本知识，你的准头自然会更好。
Mellon was the most spectacular of Duveen's catches, but he spied on many a millionaire. By secredy putting members of his clients' household staffs on his own payroll, he would gain constant access to valuable infor-
梅隆是杜维恩最引人注目的猎物，但他监视过许多百万富翁。他秘密地将客户家中的佣人安插到自己的工资单上，从而不断获取有价值的信息。
mation about dieir masters' comings and goings, changes in taste, and other such tidbits of information that would put him a step ahead. A rival of Duveen's who wanted to make Henry Frick a client noticed that whenever he visited this wealthy New Yorker, Duveen was there before him, as if he had a sixth sense. To otiier dealers Duveen seemed to be everywhere, and to know everything before they did. His powers discouraged and disheartened them, until many simply gave up going after the wealthy clients who could make a dealer rich.
他掌握着关于客户行踪、品味变化以及其他各种蛛丝马迹的信息，这些都能让他先人一步。杜维恩的一位竞争对手想把亨利·弗里克招为客户，他注意到，每当他拜访这位富有的纽约客时，杜维恩总是先他一步到达，仿佛拥有某种第六感。对其他古董商来说，杜维恩似乎无处不在，而且总是比他们更早知道一切。他的这种能力令他们感到沮丧和灰心，以至于许多人干脆放弃了争取那些能让他们一夜暴富的富裕客户。
Such is the power of artful spying: It makes you seem all-powerful, clairvoyant. Your knowledge of your mark can also make you seem charming, so well can you anticipate his desires. No one sees the source of your power, and what they cannot see they cannot fight.
这就是高明间谍手段的力量：它让你显得无所不能，洞悉一切。你对目标的了解还能让你显得魅力四射，因为你能够精准地预判他的欲望。没有人能看穿你力量的来源，而他们看不到的东西，也就无从反抗。
Rulers see through spies, as cows through smell, Brahmins through scriptures and the rest oj the people through their normal eyes.
统治者能识破间谍，就像牛能闻到气味，婆罗门能读懂经文，而其他人则用自己的双眼看待事物一样。
Knutilya, Indian philosopher, third century B.C.
克努提利亚，印度哲学家，公元前三世纪
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In the realm of power, your goal is a degree of control over future events. Part of die problem you face, then, is that people won't tell you all their thoughts, emotions, and plans. Controlling what they say, they often keep the most critical parts of their character hiddentheir weaknesses, ulterior motives, obsessions. The result is that you cannot predict their moves, and are constandy in the dark. The trick is to find a way to probe them, to find out their secrets and hidden intentions, without letting them know what you are up to.
在权力领域，你的目标是对未来事件有一定的掌控力。因此，你面临的部分问题在于，人们不会告诉你他们所有的想法、情感和计划。为了控制自己的言辞，他们往往会隐藏自己性格中最关键的部分——弱点、不可告人的动机和执念。结果就是你无法预测他们的行动，始终一无所知。诀窍在于找到一种方法来试探他们，找出他们的秘密和隐藏的意图，同时又不让他们察觉你的意图。
This is not as difficult as you might think. A friendly front will let you secredy gather information on friends and enemies alike. Let odiers consult the horoscope, or read tarot cards: You have more concrete means of seeing into the future.
这并不像你想象的那么难。一个友好的前线可以让你暗中收集关于朋友和敌人的信息。让其他人去研究星座运势或塔罗牌吧：你有更具体的方法来预测未来。
The most common way of spying is to use other people, as Duveen did. The method is simple, powerful, but risky: You will certainly gamer information, but you have litde control over the people who are doing die work. Perhaps diey will inepdy reveal your spying, or even secretly turn against you. It is far better to be die spy yourself, to pose as a friend while secredy gathering information.
最常见的间谍手段是利用他人，就像杜维恩那样。这种方法简单有效，但也风险极高：你肯定能获取情报，但你对替你执行任务的人几乎没有控制权。他们或许会无意中暴露你的间谍活动，甚至暗中与你作对。因此，最好还是自己当间谍，伪装成朋友，暗中收集情报。
The French politician Talleyrand was one of the greatest practitioners of diis art. He had an uncanny ability to worm secrets out of people in polite conversation. A contemporary of his, Baron de Vitrolles, wrote, “Wit and grace marked his conversation. He possessed die art of concealing his thoughts or his malice beneath a transparent veil of insinuations, words diat imply something more than they express. Only when necessary did he inject his own personality.” The key here is Talleyrand's ability to suppress himself in the conversation, to make odiers talk endlessly about diemselves and inadvertendy reveal dieir intentions and plans.
法国政治家塔列朗是这门艺术的杰出实践者之一。他有一种不可思议的能力，能在彬彬有礼的谈话中套取他人的秘密。他的同代人维特罗勒男爵写道：“他的谈吐机智优雅。他精于用含蓄的暗示掩盖自己的想法或恶意，言辞往往言外之意远超字面意思。只有在必要时，他才会流露出自己的个性。”关键在于塔列朗能够在谈话中克制自己，让对方滔滔不绝地谈论自己，从而无意间暴露他们的意图和计划。
If you have reason to suspect that a person is telling you a lie, look as though you believed every word he said. This will give him courage to go on; he will become more vehement in his assertions, and in the end betray himself. Again, if you perceive that a person is trying to conceal something from you, but with only partial success, look as though you did not believe him. The opposition on your part will provoke him into leading out his reserve of truth and bringing the whole force of it to bear upon your incredulity.
如果你怀疑某人对你说谎，就装作相信他说的每一个字。这会让他更加肆无忌惮，更加坚持己见，最终露出马脚。同样，如果你察觉到某人试图对你隐瞒某些事情，但只成功了一部分，就装作不相信他。你的质疑会激起他的怀疑，让他使出浑身解数，用尽全力来揭穿你的谎言。
Arthur
亚瑟
1788-1860
Throughout Talleyrand's life, people said he was a superb conversationalistyet he actually said very httle. He never talked about his own ideas; he got others to reveal theirs. He would organize friendly games of charades for foreign diplomats, social gatherings where, however, he would carefully weigh their words, cajole confidences out of them, and gather information invaluable to his work as France's foreign minister. At die Congress of Vienna (1814-1815) he did his spying in other ways: He would blurt out what seemed to be a secret (actually something he had made up), dien watch his listeners' reactions. He might tell a gathering of diplomats, for instance, mat a reliable source had revealed to him mat the czar of Russia was planning to arrest his top general for treason. By watching the diplomats' reactions to this made-up story, he would know which ones were most excited by the weakening of the Russian armyperhaps their goverments had designs on Russia As Baron von Stetten said, “Monsieur Talleyrand fires a pistol into the air to see who will jump out the window.”
在塔列朗的一生中，人们都说他是一位出色的健谈者，但实际上他说话非常谨慎。他从不谈论自己的想法，而是引导他人吐露心声。他会为外国外交官组织一些友好的猜谜游戏，这些社交聚会中，他会仔细斟酌他们的言辞，巧妙地套取他们的秘密，从而收集对他担任法国外交部长的工作至关重要的信息。在维也纳会议（1814-1815）期间，他以另一种方式进行间谍活动：他会突然说出一些看似秘密的事情（实际上是他编造的），然后观察听众的反应。例如，他可能会告诉一群外交官，一位可靠的消息人士透露，俄国沙皇正计划以叛国罪逮捕他的高级将领。通过观察外交官们对这个编造的故事的反应，他就能知道哪些外交官对俄国军队的削弱最为兴奋——也许他们的政府对俄国另有图谋。正如施泰滕男爵所说：“塔列朗先生朝空中鸣枪，看看谁会跳窗逃走。”
During social gamerings and innocuous encounters, pay attention. This is when people's guards are down. By suppressing your own personality, you can make them reveal things. The brilliance of the maneuver is that they will mistake your interest in them for friendship, so that you not only learn, you make allies.
在社交游戏和日常偶遇中，要格外留意。这时人们的戒备心往往比较低。通过抑制自己的个性，你可以让他们吐露心声。这种策略的妙处在于，他们会误以为你对他们感兴趣是出于友谊，这样你不仅能了解情况，还能结交盟友。
Nevertheless, you should practice this tactic with caution and care. If people begin to suspect you are worming secrets out of them under the cover of conversation, they will stricdy avoid you. Emphasize friendly chatter, not valuable information. Your search for gems of information cannot be too obvious, or your probing questions will reveal more about yourself and your intentions than about the information you hope to find.
然而，你务必谨慎使用这种策略。如果人们开始怀疑你是在借聊天套取他们的秘密，他们会刻意避开你。要注重友好的闲聊，而不是提供有价值的信息。你探寻信息的方式不能太明显，否则你刨根问底的问题反而会暴露你自身的意图，而不是你想要获取的信息。
A trick to try in spying comes from La Rochefoucauld, who wrote, “Sincerity is found in very few men, and is often the cleverest of ruses one is sincere in order to draw out the confidence and secrets of the other.” By pretending to bare your heart to another person, in other words, you make mem more likely to reveal their own secrets. Give them a false confession and they will give you a real one. Another trick was identified by the philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer, who suggested vehemendy contradicting people you're in conversation with as a way of irritating mem, stirring them up so that mey lose some of the control over dieir words. In their emotional reaction they will reveal all kinds of truths about themselves, truths you can later use against them.
间谍技巧中有一个来自拉罗什福科的妙招，他写道：“真诚的人寥寥无几，而真诚往往是最巧妙的伎俩——假装真诚是为了套取对方的信任和秘密。”换句话说，假装向他人敞开心扉，就能让他们更容易吐露自己的秘密。给他们一个虚假的告白，他们就会给你一个真实的告白。哲学家叔本华也提出了另一个技巧：激烈地反驳与你交谈的人，以此激怒他们，激起他们的情绪，让他们失去对言语的控制。在他们情绪激动的反应中，他们会透露出各种各样的真相，而这些真相之后你可以用它们来对付他们。
Another method of indirect spying is to test people, to lay litde traps that make them reveal things about themselves. Chosroes II, a notoriously clever seventh-century king of the Persians, had many ways of seeing through his subjects without raising suspicion. If he noticed, for instance, mat two of his courtiers had become particularly friendly, he would call one of them aside and say he had information that the other was a traitor, and would soon be killed. The king would tell the courtier he trusted him more tiian anyone, and that he must keep this information secret. Then he
另一种间接监视的方法是试探他人，设置一些小陷阱，让他们透露自己的信息。波斯七世纪一位出了名的精明君主霍斯劳二世就有很多方法可以看穿他的臣民而不引起怀疑。例如，如果他注意到两位廷臣变得格外亲近，他就会把其中一位叫到一边，告诉他自己掌握了另一个是叛徒的情报，很快就会被处死。国王会告诉这位廷臣，他最信任他，并且必须保守这个秘密。然后他
would watch the two men carefully. If he saw that the second courtier had not changed in his behavior toward the king, he would conclude that the first courtier had kept the secret, and he would quickly promote the man, later taking him aside to confess, “I meant to kill your friend because of certain information that had reached me, but, when I investigated the matter, I found it was untrue.” If, on the odier hand, the second courtier started to avoid the king, acting aloof and tense, Chosroes would know that the secret had been revealed. He would ban the second courtier from his court, letting him know that the whole business had only been a test, but that even though the man had done nothing wrong, he could no longer trust him. The first courtier, however, had revealed a secret, and him Chosroes would ban from his entire kingdom.
他会仔细观察这两个人。如果他发现第二个朝臣对国王的态度没有改变，他就会断定第一个朝臣保守了秘密，于是会迅速提拔他，之后再把他叫到一边坦白：“我原本打算杀了你的朋友，因为我得到了一些消息，但当我调查后发现消息不实。” 反之，如果第二个朝臣开始躲避国王，表现得冷漠而紧张，霍斯劳就会知道秘密已经泄露。他会将第二个朝臣逐出宫廷，让他明白这一切只是一次考验，虽然他没有做错任何事，但他再也无法信任他了。然而，第一个朝臣泄露了秘密，霍斯劳会将他驱逐出境。
It may seem an odd form of spying that reveals not empirical information but a person's character. Often, however, it is the best way of solving problems before they arise.
这种侦查方式看似怪异，因为它揭示的并非经验信息，而是人的性格。然而，很多时候，这却是防患于未然、解决问题的最佳途径。
By tempting people into certain acts, you learn about their loyalty, their honesty, and so on. And this kind of knowledge is often the most valuable of all: Armed with it, you can predict their actions in the future.
通过引诱人们做出某些行为，你可以了解他们的忠诚度、诚实度等等。而这类信息往往是最有价值的：掌握了这些信息，你就能预测他们未来的行为。
Image:
图像：
The Third Eye of
第三只眼
the Spy. In the land of
间谍。在……之地
the two-eyed, the third eye
双眼人，第三只眼
gives you the omniscience
赋予你全知全能
of a god. You see further than
如同神明一般。你的视野比神更广阔。
others, and you see deeper
其他人，你会看到更深层次的东西。
into them. Nobody is
进入它们。没有人
safe from the eye
安全无虞，免受眼部伤害
but you.
但是你。
Authority: Now, the reason a brilliant sovereign and a wise general conquer the enemy whenever they move, and their achievements surpass those of ordinary men, is their foreknowledge of the enemy situation. This “foreknowledge” cannot be elicited from spirits, nor from gods, nor by analogy with past events, nor by astrologic calculations. It must be obtained from men who know the enemy situationfrom spies. (Sun-tzu, The Art of War, fourth century B.C.)
权威：如今，一位英明的君主和一位睿智的将领之所以能够所向披靡，其功绩远超常人，是因为他们预知敌情。这种“预知”并非来自神灵，也非来自神明，更非来自对过往事件的类比，或来自星象推算，而是来自那些了解敌情的人——例如间谍。（孙子，《孙子兵法》，公元前四世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
Information is critical to power, but just as you spy on other people, you must be prepared for them to spy on you. One of the most potent weapons in the batde for information, dien, is giving out false information. As Winston Churchill said, “Truth is so precious mat she should always be attended by a bodyguard of lies.” You must surround yourself with such a bodyguard, so that your truth cannot be penetrated. By planting the information of your choice, you control the game.
信息对权力至关重要，但正如你监视他人一样，你也必须做好被他人监视的准备。在争夺信息的战场上，散布虚假信息是最有效的武器之一。正如温斯顿·丘吉尔所说：“真理如此珍贵，以至于她需要谎言的护卫。”你必须让自己被这样的“护卫”包围，这样你的“真理”才不会被渗透。通过散布你想要的信息，你就能掌控局面。
In 1944 the Nazis' rocket-bomb attacks on London suddenly escalated. Over two diousand V-l flying bombs fell on the city, killing more than five thousand people and wounding many more. Somehow, however, the Germans consistendy missed their targets. Bombs that were intended for Tower Bridge, or Piccadilly, would fall well short of the city, landing in die less populated suburbs. This was because, in fixing tfieir targets, the Germans relied on secret agents they had planted in England. They did not know that these agents had been discovered, and that in their place, English-controlled agents were feeding them subdy deceptive information.
1944年，纳粹对伦敦的火箭弹袭击突然升级。超过两千枚V1型飞弹落入伦敦，造成五千多人死亡，更多人受伤。然而，不知何故，德军的炸弹总是偏离目标。原本瞄准塔桥或皮卡迪利大街的炸弹，却总是落在人口稀少的郊区，远离市区。这是因为，德军在确定目标时，依赖于他们安插在英国的秘密特工。他们并不知道这些特工已被发现，取而代之的是受英国控制的特工，他们正在向德军提供隐蔽的情报。
The bombs would hit farther and farther from their targets every time they fell. By the end of the campaign they were landing on cows in the country. By feeding people wrong information, then, you gain a potent advantage. While spying gives you a third eye, disinformation puts out one of your enemy's eyes. A cyclops, he always misses his target.
炸弹每次落下都会离目标越来越远。到了战役后期，它们甚至落在了乡下的牛群身上。由此可见，散布虚假信息能带来巨大的优势。间谍活动能让你拥有第三只眼，而虚假信息则会蒙蔽敌人的一只眼睛。就像独眼巨人一样，他总是无法击中目标。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 15
第15条
CRUSH YOUR ENEMY TOTALLY
彻底粉碎你的敌人
JUDGMENT
判断
All great leaders since Moses have known that a feared enemy must be crushed completely. (Sometimes they have learned this the hard way.) If one ember is left alight, no matter how dimly it smolders, afire will eventually break out. More is lost through stopping halfway than through total annihilation: The enemy will recover, and will seek revenge. Crush him, not only in body but in spirit.
自摩西以来，所有伟大的领袖都明白，必须彻底击溃令人畏惧的敌人。（有时，他们为此付出了惨痛的代价。）即使只剩一丝余烬，哪怕只是微弱的火苗，最终也会燃成燎原之势。半途而废的损失远大于彻底歼灭：敌人会卷土重来，伺机报复。不仅要摧毁敌人的肉体，更要摧毁他们的精神。
The remnants of an enemy can become active like those of a disease or fire. Hence, these should be exterminated completely.... One should never ignore an enemy, knowing him to be weak. He becomes dangerous in due course, like the spark of fire in a haystack.
敌人的残余势力会像瘟疫或火灾一样重新活跃起来。因此，必须将其彻底消灭……切不可因为敌人虚弱就轻视他。他迟早会变得危险，就像干草堆里的火星一样。
Kautilya,
考底利耶
Indian philosopher,
印度哲学家，
third c'kntury b.c.
公元前第三个 c'kntury
tiik thai' at si\k;a
tiik thai' 在 si\k;a
On the day Ramiro was executed, Cesare I Borgia) quit Cesena, leaving the mutilated body on the town square, and marched south. Three days later he arrived at Fano, where he received the envoys of the city of Ancona, who assured him of their loyalty. A messenger from Vitellozzo Vitelli announced that the little A driatic port of Sinigaglia had surrendered to the condottieri [mercenary soldiers]. Only the citadel, in charge of the Genoese Andrea Doria, still held out, and Doria refused to hand it over to anyone except Cesare himself. [Borgia] sent word that he would arrive the next day, which was just what the
拉米罗被处决的那天，切萨雷·博尔吉亚一世离开了切塞纳，将残缺的尸体留在城广场上，然后向南进军。三天后，他抵达法诺，在那里接见了安科纳城的使者，使者们向他保证效忠。来自维泰洛佐·维泰利的信使宣布，亚得里亚海沿岸的小港口锡尼加利亚已经向雇佣兵投降。只有由热那亚人安德烈亚·多利亚把守的城堡仍在抵抗，多利亚拒绝将城堡交给除切萨雷本人以外的任何人。博尔吉亚派人传话说他将于次日抵达，而这正是……
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
No rivalry between leaders is more celebrated in Chinese history than the struggle between Hsiang Yu and Liu Pang. These two generals began their careers as friends, fighting on the same side. Hsiang Yu came from the nobility; large and powerful, given to bouts of violence and temper, a bit dull-witted, he was yet a mighty warrior who always fought at the head of his troops. Liu Pang came from peasant stock. He had never been much of a soldier, and preferred women and wine to fighting; in fact, he was something of a scoundrel. But he was wily, and he had the ability to recognize the best strategists, keep them as his advisers, and listen to their advice. He had risen in the army through these strengths.
在中国历史上，没有哪两位将领之间的竞争比项羽和刘邦的较量更为人津津乐道。这两位将领最初是朋友，并肩作战。项羽出身贵族，身材魁梧，力大无穷，性情暴躁易怒，略显迟钝，但他却是一位骁勇善战的将领，总是身先士卒。刘邦则出身农民，他并非什么将领，比起战争，他更喜欢女人和美酒；事实上，他甚至有些无赖。但他足智多谋，善于识别最优秀的战略家，将他们招入麾下，并听取他们的建议。正是凭借这些能力，他在军中步步高升。
In 208 B.C., the king of Ch'u sent two massive armies to conquer the powerful kingdom of Ch'in. One army went north, under the generalship of Sung Yi, with Hsiang Yu second in command; the other, led by Liu Pang, headed straight toward Ch'in. The target was the kingdom's splendid capital, Hsien-yang. And Hsiang Yu, ever violent and impatient, could not stand the idea that Liu Pang would get to Hsien-yang first, and perhaps would assume command of the entire army.
公元前208年，楚王派遣两支庞大的军队征服强大的秦国。一支军队北上，由宋仪统帅，项羽担任副将；另一支军队由刘庞率领，直奔秦国而去。他们的目标是秦国繁华的都城咸阳。而性情暴烈、性急的项羽，无法容忍刘庞先一步攻占咸阳，甚至可能夺取整个军队的指挥权。
At one point on the northern front, Hsiang's commander, Sung Yi, hesitated in sending his troops into batde. Furious, Hsiang entered Sung Yi's tent, proclaimed him a traitor, cut off his head, and assumed sole command of the army. Without waiting for orders, he left the northern front and marched direcdy on Hsien-yang. He felt certain he was the better soldier and general than Liu, but, to his utter astonishment, his rival, leading a smaller, swifter army, managed to reach Hsien-yang first. Hsiang had an adviser, Fan Tseng, who warned him, “This village headman [Liu Pang] used to be greedy only for riches and women, but since entering the capital he has not been led astray by wealth, wine, or sex. That shows he is aiming high.”
在北线战场上，项的将领宋宜一度犹豫不决，迟迟不肯派兵迎战。项勃然大怒，闯入宋宜的帐篷，宣布他是叛徒，砍下他的头颅，独揽大权。他不等命令，便离开北线，直奔咸阳。他自认为比刘邦更胜一筹，更擅长作战，但令他万万没想到，他的对手刘邦率领一支规模更小、速度更快的军队，竟先一步抵达咸阳。项的谋士樊增曾告诫他：“这个村长（刘邦）以前贪图钱财和女人，但自从入都以来，他并没有被金钱、美酒和情欲所迷惑，这表明他志存高远。”
Fan Tseng urged Hsiang to kill his rival before it was too late. He told the general to invite the wily peasant to a banquet at their camp outside Hsien-yang, and, in the midst of a celebratory sword dance, to have his head cut off. The invitation was sent; Liu fell for the trap, and came to the banquet. But Hsiang hesitated in ordering the sword dance, and by the time he gave the signal, Liu had sensed a trap, and managed to escape. “Bah!” cried Fan Tseng in disgust, seeing that Hsiang had botched the plot. “One cannot plan with a simpleton. Liu Pang will steal your empire yet and make us all his prisoners.”
樊麾力劝项军趁早除掉他的对手。他吩咐项军邀请狡猾的刘邦到咸阳城外的营地赴宴，趁着舞剑庆祝之时，将他斩首。邀请函发出后，刘邦果然上当赴宴。但项军迟迟没有下令舞剑，等他发出信号时，刘邦已察觉到陷阱，侥幸逃脱。樊麾见项军的计谋败坏，不禁怒道：“呸！”他说道：“愚钝之人，岂能算计？刘邦迟早会夺取你们的帝国，把我们都变成他的俘虏。”
Realizing his mistake, Hsiang hurriedly marched on Hsien-yang, this time determined to hack off his rival's head. Liu was never one to fight when the odds were against him, and he abandoned the city. Hsiang captured Hsien-yang, murdered the young prince of Ch'in, and burned the city to the ground. Liu was now Hsiang's bitter enemy, and he pursued him for many months, finally cornering him in a walled city. Lacking food, his army in disarray, Liu sued for peace.
意识到自己犯了错误，项王急忙进军咸阳，这次他决心要斩下对手的首级。刘氏向来不喜寡敌众，于是弃城而逃。项王攻占咸阳，杀害了秦王，并将城池夷为平地。刘氏从此成为项王的死敌，项王追击他数月之久，最终将他逼入一座城墙之内。由于粮草匮乏，军队溃不成军，刘氏被迫求和。
Again Fan Tseng warned Hsiang, "Crush him now! If you let him go
范曾再次警告项：“现在就把他打死！要是你放了他……”
again, you will be sorry later.“ But Hsiang decided to be merciful. He wanted to bring Liu back to Ch'u alive, and to force his former friend to acknowledge him as master. But Fan proved right: Liu managed to use the negotiations for his surrender as a distraction, and he escaped with a small army. Hsiang, amazed that he had yet again let his rival slip away, once more set out after Liu, this time with such ferocity diat he seemed to have lost his mind. At one point, having captured Liu's father in battle, Hsiang stood the old man up during the fighting and yelled to Liu across the line of troops, ”Surrender now, or I shall boil your father alive!“ Liu calmly answered, ”But we are sworn brothers. So my father is your father also. If you insist on boiling your own father, send me a bowl of the soup!" Hsiang backed down, and the struggle continued.
“你以后会后悔的。”但项决定手下留情。他想把刘活捉回楚国，逼迫这位昔日好友认他为师。但范的预言果然应验：刘利用投降谈判分散了众人的注意力，带着一小队军队逃走了。项惊讶于自己又一次让对手溜走，于是再次出动追击刘，这次他凶狠得近乎疯狂。有一次，项在战斗中俘虏了刘的父亲，他把老人扶起来，隔着战线对着刘大喊：“现在投降，否则我就把你父亲活活煮死！”刘平静地回答：“我们是结拜兄弟，我的父亲也是你的父亲。如果你非要煮自己的父亲，那就给我一碗煮熟的汤！”项只好作罢，战斗继续进行。
A few weeks later, in the thick of the hunt, Hsiang scattered his forces unwisely, and in a surprise attack Liu was able to surround his main garrison. For the first time the tables were turned. Now it was Hsiang who sued for peace. Liu's top adviser urged him to destroy Hsiang, crush his army, show no mercy. “To let him go would be like rearing a tigerit will devour you later,” the adviser said. Liu agreed.
几周后，在激战正酣之际，项氏不慎分散兵力，刘军趁机发动突袭，包围了他的主力驻军。局势第一次逆转，现在轮到项氏求和了。刘军的首席顾问力劝他除掉项氏，彻底击溃他的军队，毫不留情。“放他走就如同养虎，日后必反噬自身。”顾问说道。刘军同意了。
Making a false treaty, he lured Hsiang into relaxing his defense, then slaughtered almost all of his army. Hsiang managed to escape. Alone and on foot, knowing mat Liu had put a bounty on his head, he came upon a small group of his own retreating soldiers, and cried out, “I hear Liu Pang has offered one thousand pieces of gold and a fief of ten thousand families for my head. Let me do you a favor.” Then he slit his own throat and died.
他签订虚假条约，诱使项放松警惕，然后屠杀了项军几乎全军。项侥幸逃脱。他孤身一人徒步逃亡，知道刘邦悬赏捉拿他，途中遇到一小队撤退的士兵，便喊道：“我听说刘邦悬赏一千块金子和一万户人家的封地要我的命。让我帮你们一个忙吧。”说完，他割喉自尽。
Interpretation
解释
Hsiang Yu had proven his ruthlessness on many an occasion. He rarely hesitated in doing away witii a rival if it served his purposes. But with Liu Pang he acted differently. He respected his rival, and did not want to defeat him through deception; he wanted to prove his superiority on the battlefield, even to force the clever Liu to surrender and to serve him. Every time he had his rival in his hands, something made him hesitatea fatal sympathy with or respect for the man who, after all, had once been a friend and comrade in arms. But the moment Hsiang made it clear that he intended to do away with Liu, yet failed to accomplish it, he sealed his own doom. Liu would not suffer the same hesitation once the tables were turned.
项羽的冷酷无情早已昭示于众。只要符合自身利益，他几乎从不犹豫除掉任何对手。但面对刘邦，他却截然不同。他敬重刘邦，不愿用计谋取胜；他想在战场上证明自己的实力，甚至要逼迫足智多谋的刘邦投降，为他效力。每当他将刘邦掌握在手中，总会有些东西让他犹豫——一种致命的同情或敬意，毕竟，刘邦曾是他的朋友和战友。但当项羽明确表示要除掉刘邦却未能得逞时，他便自取灭亡。一旦形势逆转，刘邦绝不会再有同样的犹豫。
This is the fate that faces all of us when we sympathize with our enemies, when pity, or the hope of reconciliation, makes us pull back from doing away with them. We only strengthen their fear and hatred of us. We have beaten them, and they are humiliated; yet we nurture these resentful vipers who will one day kill us. Power cannot be dealt with this way. It must be exterminated, crushed, and denied the chance to return to haunt us. This is all the truer with a former friend who has become an enemy. The law governing fatal antagonisms reads: Reconcihation is out of die question. Only one side can win, and it must win totally.
当我们同情敌人，当怜悯或和解的希望让我们退缩，放弃彻底消灭他们时，我们所有人都将面临这样的命运。我们只会加深他们对我们的恐惧和仇恨。我们击败了他们，他们蒙受了耻辱；然而，我们却在滋养这些怨恨的毒蛇，他们终有一天会杀死我们。权力绝不能这样处理。它必须被彻底消灭、粉碎，不给它任何卷土重来的机会。对于曾经的朋友变成敌人，这一点尤其如此。致命的敌对关系遵循着一条法则：和解毫无可能。只有一方能够获胜，而且必须彻底胜利。
Liu Pang learned this lesson well. After defeating Hsiang Yu, this son
刘庞很好地吸取了这个教训。在击败项羽之后，这个儿子
condottieri wanted to hear. Once he reached Sinigagliu, Ccsare would be an easy prey, caught between the citadel and their forces ringing the town.... The condottieri were sure they had military superiority, believing that the departure of the French troops had left Cesare with only a small force. In fact, according to Machiavelli, [Borgia] had left Cesena with ten thousand infantrymen and three thousand horse, taking pains to split up his men so that they would march along parallel routes before converging on Sinigaglia. The reason for such a large force was that he knew, from a confession extracted from Ramiro de Lorca, what the condottieri had up their sleeve. He therefore decided to turn their own trap against them. This was the masterpiece of trickery that the historian Paolo Giovio later called “the magnificent deceit.” At dawn on December 3111502], Cesare reached the outskirts of Sinigaglia.... Led by Michelotto Corella, Cesare's advance guard of two hundred lances took up its position on the canal bridge.... This control of the bridge effectively prevented the conspira-tors' troops from withdrawing. . . . Cesare greeted the condottieri effusively and invited them to join him.... Michelotto
雇佣兵首领们想听到这样的消息。一旦切萨雷抵达锡尼加利亚，他就会成为唾手可得的猎物，被困在城堡和包围城镇的敌军之间……雇佣兵首领们确信自己拥有军事优势，认为法军撤离后，切萨雷只剩下少量兵力。事实上，根据马基雅维利的说法，博尔吉亚离开切塞纳时率领了一万步兵和三千骑兵，他精心安排兵力分散，让他们沿着平行路线行军，最终汇聚到锡尼加利亚。他之所以投入如此庞大的兵力，是因为他从拉米罗·德·洛尔卡的供词中得知了雇佣兵首领们的阴谋。因此，他决定以其人之道还治其人之身。这就是历史学家保罗·乔维奥后来称之为“宏伟的欺骗”的诡计之作。 1502年12月31日黎明，切萨雷抵达锡尼加利亚郊外……在米凯洛托·科雷拉的率领下，切萨雷的两百名长矛兵先头部队占据了运河桥……控制这座桥有效地阻止了阴谋者的撤退……切萨雷热情地迎接了雇佣兵首领们，并邀请他们加入他的队伍……米凯洛托
had prepared the
已经准备好了
Palazzo Bernardino
贝尔纳迪诺宫
for Cesare's use, and
供切萨雷使用，并且
the duke invited the
公爵邀请了
condottieri inside....
内部领导层……
Once indoors the men
男人们一进屋就……
were quietlv arrested
被悄悄逮捕
by guards who crept up
被悄悄靠近的守卫
from the rear.. . .

jCesare/ gave orders
jCesare/下达命令
for an attack on

维泰利和奥尔西尼

外围的士兵

地区……那天晚上，
while their troops were
而他们的部队
being crushed, Miche-
被压扁，米歇尔-
lotto throttled Olive-
彩票限制了奥利弗-
retto and Vitelli in the
直肠和小腿
Bernardino palace. . . .
贝尔纳迪诺宫……
A t one fell swoop,
一举之间，

IBorgiaj 已经摆脱了

他以前的将军们和

thh boroias,
thh boroias，

伊万·克劳伊。
To have ultimate
拥有终极
victory, you must be
胜利，你必须是
ruthless.
无情。
Napolkon Bonaparte. 1769-L821
拿破仑·波拿巴。1769-1821年
of a farmer went on to become supreme commander of the armies of Ch'u. Crushing his next rivalthe king of Ch'u, his own former leaderhe crowned himself emperor, defeated everyone in his path, and went down in history as one of the greatest rulers of China, the immortal Han Kao-tsu, founder of the Han Dynasty.
一个农民出身的君主，后来成为楚国军队的最高统帅。他击败了下一个对手——楚王，也就是他以前的领袖，加冕称帝，一路横扫所有挡路之人，最终成为中国历史上最伟大的统治者之一，不朽的汉高祖，汉朝的缔造者。
Those who seek to achieve things should show no mercy.
那些渴望有所成就的人不应该手下留情。
Kautilya, Indian philosopher, third century B.C.
考底利耶，印度哲学家，公元前三世纪
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Wu Chao, born in A.D. 625, was the daughter of a duke, and as a beautiful young woman of many charms, she was accordingly attached to the harem of Emperor T'ai Tsung.
吴朝生于公元625年，是公爵之女，她容貌美丽，魅力非凡，因此被纳入了太宗皇帝的后宫。
The imperial harem was a dangerous place, full of young concubines vying to become the emperor's favorite. Wu's beauty and forceful character quickly won her this battle, but, knowing that an emperor, like other powerful men, is a creature of whim, and that she could easily be replaced, she kept her eye on the future.
皇宫后宫是个危险的地方，到处都是争相成为皇帝宠妃的年轻妃嫔。武的美貌和强势性格很快让她赢得了这场争夺，但她深知皇帝和其他有权势的男人一样，喜怒无常，自己随时可能被取代，所以她始终着眼于未来。
Wu managed to seduce the emperor's dissolute son, Kao Tsung, on the only possible occasion when she could find him alone: while he was relieving himself at the royal urinal. Even so, when the emperor died and Kao Tsung took over the throne, she still suffered the fate to which all wives and concubines of a deceased emperor were bound by tradition and law: Her head shaven, she entered a convent, for what was supposed to be the rest of her life. For seven years Wu schemed to escape. By communicating in secret with the new emperor, and by befriending his wife, the empress, she managed to get a highly unusual royal edict allowing her to return to the palace and to the royal harem. Once there, she fawned on the empress, while still sleeping with the emperor. The empress did not discourage thisshe had yet to provide the emperor with an heir, her position was vulnerable, and Wu was a valuable ally.
吴氏趁着皇帝放荡不羁的儿子高宗在宫廷小便池方便时，成功勾引了他。然而，皇帝驾崩后，高宗继位，吴氏依然难逃所有已故皇帝的妃嫔的命运：剃光头发，入寺，从此隐居。七年来，吴氏一直想方设法逃脱。她暗中与新皇帝联络，并结识了皇后，最终获得了一份极为罕见的诏令，允许她重返宫廷，回到后宫。回到后宫后，她一边讨好皇后，一边继续与皇帝保持着亲密关系。皇后并没有阻止她——她尚未为皇帝诞下继承人，地位岌岌可危，而吴氏是她重要的盟友。
In 654 Wu Chao gave birth to a child. One day the empress came to visit, and as soon as she had left, Wu smothered the newbornher own baby. When the murder was discovered, suspicion immediately fell on the empress, who had been on the scene moments earlier, and whose jealous nature was known by all. This was precisely Wu's plan. Shortly thereafter, the empress was charged with murder and executed. Wu Chao was crowned empress in her place. Her new husband, addicted to his life of pleasure, gladly gave up the reins of government to Wu Chao, who was from then on known as Empress Wu.
公元654年，武则天生子。一日皇后前来探望，皇后刚一离开，武则天便将新生儿闷死。命案败露后，人们立刻怀疑皇后，因为她事发前曾到过现场，而且众所周知她生性多疑。这正是武则天的计划。不久之后，皇后被控谋杀并处死。武则天取而代之，成为皇后。她的新夫沉迷于享乐，欣然将朝政大权交给武则天，武则天从此被称为武则天。
Although now in a position of great power, Wu hardly felt secure. There were enemies everywhere; she could not let down her guard for one moment. Indeed, when she was forty-one, she began to fear that her beautiful young niece was becoming the emperor's favorite. She poisoned the woman with a clay mixed into her food. In 675 her own son, touted as the
尽管武则天如今位高权重，却丝毫不感到安全。敌人无处不在，她一刻也不能放松警惕。事实上，在她四十一岁那年，她开始担心自己年轻貌美的侄女会成为皇帝的宠儿。她便在侄女的食物中掺入泥土，毒死了她。公元675年，她自己的儿子，被誉为……
heir apparent, was poisoned as well. The next-eldest sonillegitimate, but now the crown princewas exiled a little later on trumped-up charges. And when the emperor died, in 683, Wu managed to have the son after that declared unfit for the throne. All this meant that it was her youngest, most ineffectual son who finally became emperor. In this way she continued to rule.
皇太子也被毒死了。次子是私生子，但不久后太子又因莫须有的罪名被流放。公元683年皇帝驾崩后，武则天设法让其子被宣布为无能之辈。这一切最终导致她最小、最无能的儿子登上了皇位。她就这样继续统治着皇位。
Over the next five years there were innumerable palace coups. All of them failed, and all of the conspirators were executed. By 688 mere was no one left to challenge Wu. She proclaimed herself a divine descendant of Buddha, and in 690 her wishes were finally granted: She was named Holy and Divine “Emperor” of China.
在接下来的五年里，宫廷政变层出不穷，但都以失败告终，所有阴谋者都被处决。到了公元688年，已无人能挑战武则天。她自称是佛陀的后裔，并在公元690年如愿以偿：她被尊为中国神圣的“皇帝”。
Wu became emperor because there was literally nobody left from the previous T'ang dynasty. And so she ruled unchallenged, for over a decade of relative peace. In 705, at the age of eighty, she was forced to abdicate.
武则天之所以能成为皇帝，是因为唐朝的后裔几乎全部去世。因此，她统治时期无人挑战，享受了十余年的相对和平。公元705年，她八十岁高龄时被迫退位。
Interpretation
解释
All who knew Empress Wu remarked on her energy and intelligence. At the time, there was no glory available for an ambitious woman beyond a few years in the imperial harem, then a lifetime walled up in a convent. In Wu's gradual but remarkable rise to the top, she was never naive. She knew that any hesitation, any momentary weakness, would spell her end. If, every time she got rid of a rival a new one appeared, the solution was simple: She had to crush them all or be killed herself. Other emperors before her had followed the same path to the top, but Wuwho, as a woman, had next to no chance to gain powerhad to be more ruthless still.
所有认识武则天的人都称赞她的精力和智慧。在那个时代，对于一个有抱负的女人来说，除了在后宫待上几年，然后终生被囚禁在寺院之外，别无其他荣耀可言。武则天一步步走向巅峰，但她从未天真过分。她深知，任何犹豫，任何一时的软弱，都可能让她走向灭亡。如果每次除掉一个对手，新的对手就会出现，那么解决办法很简单：她必须将他们全部消灭，否则就会被杀。在她之前，其他皇帝也曾走过类似的上位之路，但武则天作为一个女人，几乎没有任何机会获得权力，因此她必须更加冷酷无情。
Empress Wu's forty-year reign was one of the longest in Chinese history. Although the story of her bloody rise to power is well known, in China she is considered one of the period's most able and effective rulers.
武则天四十年的统治是中国历史上最长的统治时期之一。虽然她血腥夺权的历程广为人知，但在中国，她被认为是这一时期最有能力、最有效的统治者之一。
A priest asked the dying Spanish statesman and general Ramon Maria Narvdez
一位神父问垂死的西班牙政治家兼将军拉蒙·玛丽亚·纳尔维兹
(1800-1868), “Does your Excellency forgive all your enemies ” “I do not have to forgive my enemies, ” answered Narvdez, “J have had them all shot. ”
（1800-1868）“阁下是否宽恕了您所有的敌人？”“我不必宽恕我的敌人，”纳尔维兹回答说，“我已经把他们都枪毙了。”
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
It is no accident that die two stories illustrating this law come from China: Chinese history abounds with examples of enemies who were left alive and returned to haunt the lenient. “Crush the enemy” is a key strategic tenet of Sun-tzu, the fourth-century-B.C. author of The Art of War. The idea is simple: Your enemies wish you ill. There is nothing they want more than to eliminate you. If, in your struggles with them, you stop halfway or even three quarters of the way, out of mercy or hope of reconciliation, you only make them more determined, more embittered, and tiiey will someday take revenge. They may act friendly for the time being, but this is only because you have defeated them. They have no choice but to bide their time.
有两个故事恰好印证了这条法则，而且都来自中国，这绝非偶然：中国历史上不乏这样的例子：一些敌人被饶恕，最终却死后反扑。“灭敌”是公元前四世纪《孙子兵法》作者孙子兵法的核心战略原则。其理念很简单：你的敌人对你怀有恶意。他们最渴望的就是消灭你。如果你在与他们的战斗中，因为心软或希望和解而中途停战，甚至中途退缩，只会让他们更加坚定，更加愤恨，他们终有一天会报复。他们或许会暂时表现友好，但这仅仅是因为你已经击败了他们。他们别无选择，只能伺机而动。
The solution: Have no mercy. Crush your enemies as totally as they
解决办法：毫不留情。像他们一样彻底粉碎你的敌人。
would crush you. Ultimately the only peace and security you can hope for from your enemies is their disappearance.
会彻底摧毁你。最终，你唯一能指望从敌人那里获得的和平与安全，就是他们的消失。
Mao Tse-tung, a devoted reader of Sun-tzu and of Chinese history generally, knew the importance of this law. In 1934 the Communist leader and some 75,000 poorly equipped soldiers fled into the desolate mountains of western China to escape Chiang Kai-shek's much larger army, in what has since been called the Long March.
毛泽东酷爱阅读孙子兵法，也对中国历史颇有研究，他深知这条定律的重要性。1934年，这位共产党领导人率领约7.5万名装备简陋的士兵，为了躲避蒋介石兵力远胜于己的军队，逃入了中国西部荒凉的山区，史称“长征”。
Chiang was determined to eliminate every last Communist, and by a few years later Mao had less than 10,000 soldiers left. By 1937, in fact, when China was invaded by Japan, Chiang calculated that the Communists were no longer a threat. He chose to give up the chase and concentrate on the Japanese. Ten years later the Communists had recovered enough to rout Chiang's army. Chiang had forgotten the ancient wisdom of crushing the enemy; Mao had not. Chiang was pursued until he and his entire army fled to the island of Taiwan. Nothing remains of his regime in mainland China to this day.
蒋介石决心消灭所有共产党人，几年后，毛泽东的军队只剩下不到一万人。事实上，到了1937年日本入侵中国时，蒋介石认为共产党已不再构成威胁，于是放弃了追击，转而集中精力对付日本人。十年后，共产党恢复了实力，击溃了蒋介石的军队。蒋介石忘记了“以牙还牙”的古老智慧，而毛泽东却铭记于心。蒋介石遭到追击，最终他和他的全部军队逃往台湾岛。时至今日，他在中国大陆的政权已荡然无存。
The wisdom behind “crushing the enemy” is as ancient as the Bible: Its first practitioner may have been Moses, who learned it from God Himself, when He parted the Red Sea for the Jews, then let the water flow back over the pursuing Egyptians so that “not so much as one of them remained.” When Moses returned from Mount Sinai with the Ten Commandments and found his people worshipping the Golden Calf, he had every last offender slaughtered. And just before he died, he told his followers, finally about to enter the Promised Land, that when they had defeated the tribes of Canaan they should “utterly destroy them . . . make no covenant with them, and show no mercy to them.”
“彻底击败敌人”的智慧与《圣经》一样古老：其首创者或许是摩西，他从上帝那里学到了这一智慧。上帝曾为犹太人分开红海，然后又让海水倒流，淹没追赶的埃及人，以至于“他们一个也没有留下”。摩西带着十诫从西奈山回来后，发现他的百姓正在崇拜金牛犊，便下令将所有犯错的人全部屠杀。临终前，他告诉即将进入应许之地的门徒，当他们击败迦南各支派时，要“彻底消灭他们……不可与他们立约，也不可怜悯他们”。
The goal of total victory is an axiom of modern warfare, and was codified as such by Carl von Clausewitz, the premier philosopher of war. Analyzing the campaigns of Napoleon, von Clausewitz wrote, “We do claim that direct annihilation of the enemy's forces must always be the dominant consideration.... Once a major victory is achieved there must be no talk of rest, of breathing space . . . but only of the pursuit, going for the enemy again, seizing his capital, attacking his reserves and anything else that might give his country aid and comfort.” The reason for this is that after war come negotiation and the division of territory. If you have only won a partial victory, you will inevitably lose in negotiation what you have gained by war.
全面胜利是现代战争的一条基本原则，由战争哲学大师卡尔·冯·克劳塞维茨正式确立。在分析拿破仑的战役时，克劳塞维茨写道：“我们认为，直接歼灭敌军必须始终是首要考虑……一旦取得重大胜利，就绝不能谈论休整、喘息……而只能专注于追击，再次进攻敌人，夺取其首都，攻击其后备力量，以及任何可能为其国家提供援助和支持的目标。” 其原因在于，战后必然是谈判和领土分割。如果只取得部分胜利，那么在谈判中，你最终必然会失去战争所获得的成果。
The solution is simple: Allow your enemies no options. Annihilate them and their territory is yours to carve. The goal of power is to control your enemies completely, to make them obey your will. You cannot afford to go halfway. If they have no options, they will be forced to do your bidding. This law has applications far beyond the battlefield. Negotiation is the insidious viper that will eat away at your victory, so give your enemies nothing to negotiate, no hope, no room to maneuver. They are crushed and that is that.
解决之道很简单：不给敌人任何选择余地。彻底消灭他们，他们的领土就任你瓜分。权力的最终目的在于完全掌控敌人，让他们臣服于你的意志。你绝不能半途而废。如果他们别无选择，就只能听命于你。这条法则的适用范围远不止战场。谈判如同毒蛇，会蚕食你的胜利，所以不要给敌人任何谈判的余地，不要给他们任何希望，不要给他们任何回旋的余地。他们必败无疑，一切就此结束。
Realize this: In your struggle for power you will stir up rivalries and
你要明白：在争夺权力的过程中，你会挑起纷争，引发敌对情绪。
create enemies. There will be people you cannot win over, who will remain your enemies no matter what. But whatever wound you inflicted on them, deliberately or not, do not take their hatred personally. Just recognize that there is no possibility of peace between you, especially as long as you stay in power. If you let them stick around, they will seek revenge, as certainly as night follows day. To wait for diem to show their cards is just silly; as Empress Wu understood, by then it will be too late.
树立敌人。总会有一些人你无法说服，无论如何他们都会是你的敌人。但无论你有意无意地给他们造成了怎样的伤害，都不要把他们的仇恨放在心上。你只需要明白，你们之间不可能和平共处，尤其是在你掌权期间。如果你放任他们，他们一定会报复，就像黑夜之后必然是白天一样。等着他们亮出底牌是愚蠢的；正如武则天所明白的，到那时一切都太迟了。
Be realistic: With an enemy like this around, you will never be secure. Remember the lessons of history, and the wisdom of Moses and Mao: Never go halfway.
要现实一点：有这样的敌人在身边，你永远不会安全。记住历史的教训，记住摩西和毛泽东的智慧：永远不要半途而废。
It is not, of course, a question of murder, it is a question of banishment. Sufficiently weakened and then exiled from your court forever, your enemies are rendered harmless. They have no hope of recovering, insinuating themselves and hurting you. And if they cannot be banished, at least understand that they are plotting against you, and pay no heed to whatever friendliness they feign. Your only weapon in such a situation is your own wariness. If you cannot banish them immediately, then plot for the best time to act.
当然，这并非谋杀的问题，而是放逐的问题。只要将敌人削弱到一定程度，并永远驱逐出你的宫廷，他们便不再构成威胁。他们再也没有机会卷土重来，对你造成伤害。即便无法将他们放逐，至少也要明白他们正在密谋对付你，不要理会他们伪装的任何友好。在这种情况下，你唯一的武器就是你自身的警惕。如果不能立即将他们放逐，那就伺机而动，寻找最佳时机。
Image: A Viper crushed beneadi your foot but left alive, will rear up and bite you with a double dose of venom. An enemy that is left around is like a half-dead viper that you nurse back to health. Time makes the venom grow stronger.
图片：一条毒蛇咬伤了你的脚，但没咬死你，它会抬起头，用双倍的毒液咬你。被你放过的敌人就像一条半死不活的毒蛇，你得把它救活。时间会让毒液变得更强。
Authority: For it must be noted, that men must either be caressed or else annihilated; they will revenge themselves for small injuries, but cannot do so for great ones; the injury therefore that we do to a man must be such that we need not fear his vengeance. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：必须指出，人要么被温柔以待，要么被彻底毁灭；他们会为小伤报复，但不会为大伤报复；因此，我们对人造成的伤害必须足够小，以至于我们不必担心他的报复。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
This law should very rarely be ignored, but it does sometimes happen that it is better to let your enemies destroy themselves, if such a thing is possible, than to make them suffer by your hand. In warfare, for example, a good general knows that if he attacks an army when it is cornered, its soldiers will fight much more fiercely. It is sometimes better, then, to leave them an escape route, a way out. As they retreat, they wear themselves out, and are ultimately more demoralized by the retreat than by any defeat he might inflict on the battlefield. When you have someone on the ropes, thenbut only when you are sure they have no chance of recoveryyou might let them hang themselves. Let them be the agents of their own destruction. The result will be the same, and you won't feel half as bad.
这条法则极少应被忽视，但有时，如果可能的话，让敌人自取灭亡比亲手让他们遭受痛苦要好得多。例如，在战争中，一位优秀的将领明白，如果他攻击一支被逼入绝境的军队，士兵们会更加顽强地抵抗。因此，有时最好给他们留一条退路。撤退的过程中，他们会消耗殆尽，最终，撤退带来的挫败感远胜于战场上的任何失败。当你把敌人逼到绝境时——只有在你确信他们毫无翻身希望的情况下——你才可以让他们自取灭亡。让他们成为自己毁灭的始作俑者。结果是一样的，而你也不会感到那么痛苦。
Finally, sometimes by crushing an enemy, you embitter them so much that they spend years and years plotting revenge. The Treaty of Versailles had such an effect on the Germans. Some would argue that in the long run it would be better to show some leniency. The problem is, your leniency involves another riskit may embolden the enemy, which still harbors a grudge, but now has some room to operate. It is almost always wiser to crush your enemy. If tfiey plot revenge years later, do not let your guard down, but simply crush them again.
最后，有时彻底击溃敌人反而会让他们怨恨不已，以至于他们多年来都在策划复仇。《凡尔赛条约》对德国人的影响就是如此。有人认为，从长远来看，展现一些宽容或许更好。但问题在于，你的宽容会带来另一种风险——它可能会助长敌人的气焰，他们虽然仍然怀恨在心，但现在有了更大的活动空间。几乎在所有情况下，彻底击溃敌人才是更明智的选择。如果他们多年后策划复仇，切勿放松警惕，只需再次彻底击溃他们即可。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 16
第16条
USE ABSENCE TO
利用缺席
INCREASE RESPECT
提高尊重
AND HONOR
以及荣誉
JUDGMENT
判断
Too much circulation makes the price go down: The more you are seen and heard from, the more common you appear. If you are already established in a group, temporary withdrawal from it will make you more talked about, even more admired. You must learn when to leave. Create value through scarcity.
过度曝光反而会降低价值：曝光率越高，曝光度就越高，你就越显得平庸。如果你已经在某个群体中站稳脚跟，暂时退出反而会让你更受关注，甚至更受人敬仰。你必须学会何时离开。通过稀缺性创造价值。
The first man who saw a camel fled; The second ventured within distance; The third dared slip a halter round its head. Familiarity in this existence Makes all things tame, for what may seem Terrible or bizarre, when once our eyes Have had time to acclimatize, Becomes quite commonplace. Since I'm on this theme, I've heard of sentinels posted by the shore Who, spotting something far-away afloat, Couldn 't resist the shout: “A sail! A sail! A mighty man-of-war!” Five minutes later it's a packet boat, And then a skiff, and then a bale, And finally some sticks bobbing about. I know of plenty such To whom this story applies People whom distance magnifies, Who, close to, don 7 amount to much.
第一个见到骆驼的人吓得逃跑了；第二个冒险靠近；第三个胆敢给它套上缰绳。在这个世界上，熟悉使万物变得温顺，因为那些曾经看起来可怕或怪异的事物，一旦我们的眼睛适应了，就会变得司空见惯。既然说到这个话题，我听说过一些哨兵驻守在岸边，他们发现远处有东西漂浮，忍不住大喊：“帆！帆！一艘巨大的战舰！”五分钟后，它变成了一艘客船，然后是一艘小艇，然后是一个包裹，最后是一些漂浮的木棍。我知道有很多这样的人，这个故事适用于他们——距离越远，他们越显眼，近距离观察，他们却显得微不足道。
SELECTED IABLHS,
选定的 IABLHS，
JhAN nv. La Fontaine. 1621-1695
JhAN nv。拉封丹。 1621-1695
TRANSGRESSION AND OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW Sir Guillaume de Balaun was a troubadour who roamed the South of France in the Middle Ages, going from castle to castle, reciting poetry, and playing the perfect knight. At the castle of Javiac he met and fell in love with the beautiful lady of the house, Madame Guillelma de Javiac. He sang her his songs, recited his poetry, played chess with her, and little by little she in turn fell in love with him. Guillaume had a friend, Sir Pierre de Bar-jac, who traveled with him and who was also received at the casde. And Pierre too fell in love with a lady in Javiac, the gracious but temperamental Viernetta.
违背律法与恪守律法 吉约姆·德·巴朗爵士是一位游吟诗人，中世纪时他游历于法国南部，辗转于各个城堡之间，吟诵诗歌，扮演着完美的骑士。在雅维亚克城堡，他邂逅了美丽的女主人吉列尔玛·德·雅维亚克夫人，并坠入爱河。他为她歌唱，吟诵诗歌，与她下棋，渐渐地，她也爱上了他。吉约姆还有一位朋友，皮埃尔·德·巴尔雅克爵士，他与吉约姆同行，也受到了城堡的款待。皮埃尔也爱上了雅维亚克的一位女士，优雅却性情多变的维尔内塔。
Then one day Pierre and Viernetta had a violent quarrel. The lady dismissed him, and he sought out his friend Guillaume to help heal the breach and get him back in her good graces. Guillaume was about to leave the castle for a while, but on his return, several weeks later, he worked his magic, and Pierre and the lady were reconciled. Pierre felt that his love had increased tenfoldthat there was no stronger love, in fact, than the love that follows reconciliation. The stronger and longer the disagreement, he told Guillaume, the sweeter the feeling that comes with peace and rapprochement.
一天，皮埃尔和维尔内塔大吵了一架。维尔内塔把他赶走了，皮埃尔只好去找朋友纪尧姆帮忙，希望他能化解矛盾，重新赢得维尔内塔的欢心。纪尧姆原本打算离开城堡一段时间，但几周后他回来时，施展了他的“魔法”，皮埃尔和维尔内塔重归于好。皮埃尔觉得他对维尔内塔的爱比以前深了十倍——事实上，世上再也没有比和解后的爱更浓烈的爱了。他告诉纪尧姆，争吵越激烈、持续时间越长，和解后带来的平静和甜蜜就越发令人欣喜。
As a troubadour, Sir Guillaume prided himself on experiencing all the joys and sorrows of love. On hearing his friend's talk, he too wanted know the bliss of reconciliation after a quarrel. He therefore feigned great anger with Lady Guillelma, stopped sending her love letters, and abruptly left the casde and stayed away, even during the festivals and hunts. This drove the young lady wild.
作为一名游吟诗人，吉约姆爵士以体验过爱情的一切喜怒哀乐而自豪。听了朋友的讲述后，他也渴望感受争吵后和解的甜蜜。于是，他假装对吉列尔玛小姐大发雷霆，停止给她写情书，并突然离开城堡，甚至在节日和狩猎期间也刻意疏远她。这令这位年轻的小姐心烦意乱。
Guillelma sent messengers to Guillaume to find out what had happened, but he turned the messengers away. He thought all this would make her angry, forcing him to plead for reconciliation as Pierre had. Instead, however, his absence had the opposite effect: It made Guillelma love him all the more. Now the lady pursued her knight, sending messengers and love notes of her own. This was almost unheard ofa lady never pursued her troubadour. And Guillaume did not like it. Guillelma's forwardness made him feel she had lost some of her dignity. Not only was he no longer sure of his plan, he was no longer sure of his lady.
吉耶尔玛派人去见纪尧姆，想弄清楚发生了什么事，但他却把信使拒之门外。他以为这一切会激怒她，迫使他像皮埃尔那样恳求她和好。然而，他的缺席却产生了截然相反的效果：这反而让吉耶尔玛更加爱他。如今，这位女士主动追求她的骑士，派人送信，还写情书。这几乎闻所未闻——一位女士从未主动追求过她的吟游诗人。而纪尧姆对此很不高兴。吉耶尔玛的主动让他觉得她失去了些许尊严。他不仅对自己的计划失去了信心，也对自己的女士失去了信心。
Finally, after several months of not hearing from Guillaume, Guillelma gave up. She sent him no more messengers, and he began to wonderperhaps she was angry Perhaps the plan had worked after all So much the better if she was. He would wait no moreit was time to reconcile. So he put on his best robe, decked the horse in its fanciest caparison, chose a magnificent helmet, and rode off to Javiac.
几个月杳无音信后，吉耶尔玛终于放弃了。她不再派人送信，吉耶尔玛开始怀疑——或许她生气了？或许计划最终奏效了？如果真是这样，那就再好不过了。他不再等待——是时候和解了。于是，他穿上最好的长袍，给马披上最华丽的马衣，选了一顶精美的头盔，骑马前往雅维亚克。
On hearing that her beloved had returned, Guillelma rushed to see him, knelt before him, dropped her veil to kiss him, and begged forgiveness for whatever slight had caused his anger. Imagine his confusion and despairhis plan had failed abysmally. She was not angry, she had never been angry, she was only deeper in love, and he would never experience the joy of reconciliation after a quarrel. Seeing her now, and still desperate
听到心上人归来，吉列尔玛急忙赶去见他，跪在他面前，褪下面纱吻他，恳求他原谅任何让他生气的过错。可想而知他当时的困惑和绝望——他的计划彻底失败了。她并没有生气，她从未生气过，她只是更加深爱着他，而他永远也无法体会到争吵后和好的喜悦。如今，他看着她，依然绝望。
to taste that joy, he decided to try one more time: He drove her away with harsh words and threatening gestures. She left, this time vowing never to see him again.
为了再次体验那种快感，他决定再试一次：他用恶毒的言语和威胁的举动把她赶走了。她离开了，这一次她发誓再也不见他。
The next morning the troubadour regretted what he had done. He rode back to Javiac, but the lady would not receive him, and ordered her servants to chase him away, across the drawbridge and over the hill. Guil-laume fled. Back in his chamber he collapsed and started to cry: He had made a terrible mistake. Over the next year, unable to see his lady, he experienced the absence, the terrible absence, that can only inflame love. He wrote one of his most beautiful poems, “My song ascends for mercy praying.” And he sent many letters to Guillelma, explaining what he had done, and begging forgiveness.
第二天早晨，吟游诗人后悔不已。他骑马返回雅维亚克，但夫人不肯接见他，并吩咐仆人将他赶走，越过吊桥，翻过山丘。吉耶尔玛逃走了。回到房间后，他瘫倒在地，痛哭流涕：他犯了一个可怕的错误。接下来的一年里，他无法见到爱人，饱受分离之苦，这种痛苦的分离只会更加激发他的爱意。他写下了他最美的诗篇之一——《我的歌声升腾，祈求怜悯》。他还给吉耶尔玛写了许多信，解释自己的所作所为，恳求她的原谅。
After a great deal of this, Lady Guillelma, remembering his beautiful songs, his handsome figure, and his skills in dancing and falconry, found herself yearning to have him back. As penance for his cruelty, she ordered him to remove the nail from the little finger of his right hand, and to send it to her along with a poem describing his miseries.
经历了这一切之后，吉列尔玛夫人想起他动听的歌声、英俊的身姿以及精湛的舞技和猎鹰技艺，不禁渴望他能回到她身边。为了弥补他之前的残忍，她命令他拔下右手小指的指甲，连同一首描述他苦难经历的诗一起送给她。
He did as she asked. Finally Guillaume de Balaun was able to taste the ultimate sensationa reconciliation even surpassing that of his friend Pierre.
他照她说的做了。最终，吉约姆·德·巴朗品尝到了极致的和解之乐，甚至超越了他朋友皮埃尔的和解。
Interpretation
解释
Trying to discover the joys of reconciliation, Guillaume de Balaun inadvertently experienced the truth of the law of absence and presence. At the start of an affair, you need to heighten your presence in the eyes of the other. If you absent yourself too early, you may be forgotten. But once your lover's emotions are engaged, and the feeling of love has crystallized, absence inflames and excites. Giving no reason for your absence excites even more: The other person assumes he or she is at fault. While you are away, die lover's imagination takes flight, and a stimulated imagination cannot help but make love grow stronger. Conversely, the more Guillelma pursued Guillaume, the less he loved hershe had become too present, too accessible, leaving no room for his imagination and fancy, so that his feelings were suffocating. When she finally stopped sending messengers, he was able to breathe again, and to return to his plan.
吉约姆·德·巴朗试图体会和解的喜悦，却无意间领悟了缺席与在场法则的真谛。在一段婚外情的开始，你需要在对方眼中营造一种强烈的存在感。如果你过早地离开，可能会被遗忘。但一旦爱人的情感被点燃，爱意凝结成形，缺席反而会激发激情，令人兴奋。不解释你的缺席，更能激起对方的渴望：对方会认为错在自己。在你离开的这段时间里，爱人的想象力自由驰骋，而想象力的激发必然会让爱情更加浓烈。反之，吉列尔玛越是追求吉约姆，他就越不爱她——她变得太过亲近，太过触手可及，让他的想象力和幻想无处遁形，以至于他的感情几乎窒息。当她最终停止派人来信时，他才得以喘息，重新回到自己的计划中。
What witiidraws, what becomes scarce, suddenly seems to deserve our respect and honor. What stays too long, inundating us with its presence, makes us disdain it. In the Middle Ages, ladies were constantiy putting their knights through trials of love, sending them on some long and arduous questall to create a pattern of absence and presence. Indeed, had Guillaume not left his lady in the first place, she might have been forced to send him away, creating an absence of her own.
那些转瞬即逝、变得稀少的事物，突然间似乎更值得我们尊重和敬仰。而那些停留过久、充斥着我们存在的事物，则令我们厌恶。在中世纪，淑女们常常让她们的骑士经历爱情的考验，派遣他们踏上漫长而艰辛的征程，以此来营造一种时而缺席时而出现的模式。的确，如果纪尧姆当初没有离开他的爱人，她或许也会被迫将他送走，从而制造出她自己的缺席。
Absence diminishes minor passions and inflames great ones, as the wind douses a candle and fans afire.
分离会削弱细微的情感，却会激起强烈的情感，就像风吹灭蜡烛却助燃火焰一样。
La Rochefoucauld, 1613-1680
拉罗什福科，1613-1680
While serving under the Duke Ai of Lit, Tien Jao, resenting his obscure position, said to his master, “I am going to wander far away like a snow goose. ”
天昭在立哀公手下任职期间，不满自己卑微的地位，对他的主公说：“我要像雪雁一样远走他乡。”
“What do you mean by thai ” inquired the Duke.
“你说的‘泰国’是什么意思？”公爵问道。
“Do you see the cock ” said T'ien Jao in reply. “Its crest is a symbol of civility; its powerful talons suggest strength; its daring to fight any enemy denotes courage; its instinct to invite others whenever food is obtained shows benevolence; and, last but not least, its punctuality in keeping the time through the night gives us an example of veracity. In spite, however, of these five virtues, the cock is daily killed to fill a dish on your table. Why The reason is that it is found within our reach. On the other hand, the snow goose traverses in one flight a thousand li. Resting in your garden, it preys on your fishes and turtles and pecks your millet. Though devoid of any of the cock's five virtues, yet you prize this bird for the sake of its scarcity. This being so, I shall fly far like a snow goose. ”
“你看见那只公鸡了吗？”天照答道，“它的冠羽象征着礼貌；它强劲的爪子象征着力量；它敢于与任何敌人战斗象征着勇气；它一有食物就邀请同伴，象征着仁慈；最后，它整夜守时，象征着诚实。然而，尽管公鸡拥有这五种美德，你却每天都要宰杀它，只为填满你餐桌上的一盘。为什么呢？因为它唾手可得。另一方面，雪雁一飞千里，栖息在你的花园里，捕食你的鱼龟，啄食你的小米。虽然它不具备公鸡的五种美德，但你却因为它的稀有而珍视它。既然如此，我就要像雪雁一样飞得更远。”
ANCIFNT CHINESE PARABLES,
古代中国寓言故事
Yu Hsiu Sen, eix, 1974
余秀森，轴，1974
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
For many centuries the Assyrians ruled upper Asia widi an iron fist. In the eighth century B.C., however, the people of Medea (now northwestern Iran) revolted against them, and finally broke free. Now the Medes had to establish a new government. Determined to avoid any form of despotism, they refused to give ultimate power to any one man, or to establish a monarchy. Without a leader, however, the country soon fell into chaos, and fractured into small kingdoms, with village fighting against village.
几个世纪以来，亚述人以铁腕统治着亚洲北部。然而，公元前八世纪，米底亚（今伊朗西北部）人民起义反抗，最终摆脱了亚述的统治。米底人不得不建立新的政府。他们决心避免任何形式的专制统治，拒绝将最高权力赋予任何人，也拒绝建立君主制。然而，由于缺乏统一的领袖，国家很快陷入混乱，分裂成许多小王国，村庄之间互相征战。
In one such village lived a man named Deioces, who began to make a name for himself for fair dealing and the ability to settle disputes.
在其中一个村庄里住着一个名叫戴奥塞斯的人，他因公平交易和解决纠纷的能力而声名鹊起。
He did this so successfully, in fact, that soon any legal conflict in the area was brought to him, and his power increased. Throughout the land, the law had fallen into disreputethe judges were corrupt, and no one entrusted their cases to the courts any more, resorting to violence instead. When news spread of Deioces' wisdom, incorruptibility, and unshakable impartiality, Medean villages far and wide turned to him to settle all manner of cases. Soon he became the sole arbiter of justice in the land.
事实上，他这样做非常成功，以至于很快该地区的所有法律纠纷都由他来处理，他的权力也随之增长。当时，整个国家的法律都已声名狼藉——法官腐败不堪，人们不再将案件委托给法庭，而是诉诸暴力。当戴奥斯的智慧、廉洁和绝对公正的消息传开后，麦地那各地的村庄都纷纷前来寻求他的帮助，以解决各种案件。很快，他就成了这片土地上唯一的司法仲裁者。
At the height of his power, Deioces suddenly decided he had had enough. He would no longer sit in the chair of judgment, would hear no more suits, setde no more disputes between brother and brother, village and village. Complaining that he was spending so much time dealing with other people's problems that he had neglected his own affairs, he retired. The country once again descended into chaos. With the sudden withdrawal of a powerful arbiter like Deioces, crime increased, and contempt for the law was never greater. The Medes held a meeting of all the villages to decide how to get out of their predicament. “We cannot continue to live in this country under these conditions,” said one tribal leader. “Let us appoint one of our number to rule so that we can live under orderly government, rather man losing our homes altogedier in the present chaos.”
在权力巅峰时期，狄奥塞斯突然决定不再执掌大权。他不再担任审判官，不再审理诉讼，不再调解兄弟之间、村庄之间的纠纷。他抱怨自己把太多时间花在处理别人的问题上，以至于忽略了自己的事务，于是隐退了。国家再次陷入混乱。随着狄奥塞斯这样一位权势滔天的仲裁者的突然离去，犯罪率飙升，人们对法律的蔑视也达到了前所未有的程度。米底人召集所有村庄开会，商讨如何摆脱困境。“我们不能再这样生活下去了，”一位部落首领说道，“让我们推选一位族人来统治，这样我们就能生活在一个秩序井然的政府之下，而不是在如今的混乱中失去家园。”
And so, despite all that the Medes had suffered under the Assyrian despotism, they decided to set up a monarchy and name a king. And the man they most wanted to rule, of course, was the fair-minded Deioces. He was hard to convince, for he wanted nothing more to do with the villages' infighting and bickering, but the Medes begged and pleadedwithout him die country had descended into a state of lawlessness. Deioces finally agreed.
因此，尽管米底人饱受亚述专制统治之苦，他们还是决定建立君主制，拥立一位国王。而他们最想拥立的，自然是公正无私的戴伊奥斯。他起初并不情愿，因为他厌倦了各村落间的争斗和纷争，但米底人苦苦哀求，说没有他，国家已经陷入了混乱。戴伊奥斯最终同意了。
Yet he also imposed conditions. An enormous palace was to be constructed for him, he was to be provided with bodyguards, and a capital city was to be built from which he could rule. All of this was done, and Deioces settled into his palace. In the center of the capital, the palace was surrounded by walls, and completely inaccessible to ordinary people. Deioces then established the terms of his rule: Admission to his presence was forbidden. Communication with the king was only possible through messengers. No one in the royal court could see him more than once a week, and then only by permission.
然而，他也提出了条件。他要为他建造一座宏伟的宫殿，配备贴身卫队，并建造一座都城供他统治。这一切都完成了，戴伊奥塞斯也安顿进了宫殿。宫殿位于都城中心，四周环绕着城墙，普通百姓根本无法进入。戴伊奥塞斯随后确立了他的统治条件：任何人不得觐见他。与国王的沟通只能通过信使。宫廷中任何人每周只能见他一次，而且每次都必须获得许可。
Deioces ruled for fifty-three years, extended the Medean empire, and established die foundation for what would later be the Persian empire, under his great-great-grandson Cyrus. During Deioces' reign, the people's
戴伊奥斯统治了五十三年，扩张了米底帝国的版图，并为后来在他曾曾孙居鲁士统治下建立的波斯帝国奠定了基础。在戴伊奥斯统治时期，人民的……
respect for him gradually turned into a form of worship: He was not a mere mortal, they believed, but the son of a god.
人们逐渐对他产生了敬意，这种敬意变成了崇拜：他们相信他不是一个普通的凡人，而是神的儿子。
Interpretation
解释
Deioces was a man of great ambition. He determined early on that the
迪奥塞斯是个雄心勃勃的人。他很早就认定……
country needed a strong ruler, and that he was die man for the job.
国家需要一位强有力的统治者，而他正是胜任这项工作的最佳人选。
In a land plagued with anarchy, the most powerful man is the judge and arbiter. So Deioces began his career by making his reputation as a man of impeccable fairness.
在一个饱受无政府状态困扰的国度里，最有权势的人就是法官和仲裁者。因此，迪奥塞斯一开始就以公正无私的形象而闻名。
At the height of his power as a judge, however, Deioces realized die truth of the law of absence and presence: By serving so many clients, he had become too noticeable, too available, and had lost die respect he had earlier enjoyed. People were taking his services for granted. The only way to regain the veneration and power he wanted was to witiidraw completely, and let die Medes taste what life was like widiout him. As he expected, diey came begging for him to rule.
然而，在法官权力的巅峰时期，迪奥塞斯却领悟到了缺席与在场法则的真谛：由于服务了太多委托人，他变得过于引人注目，过于平易近人，反而失去了之前享有的尊重。人们开始将他的服务视为理所当然。要想重获他渴望的尊崇和权力，唯一的办法就是彻底隐退，让米底人尝尝没有他的生活滋味。正如他所料，米底人纷纷前来恳求他统治。
Once Deioces had discovered the truth of this law, he carried it to its ultimate realization. In the palace his people had built for him, none could see him except a few courtiers, and those only rarely. As Herodotus wrote, “There was a risk that if they saw him habitually, it might lead to jealousy and resentment, and plots would follow; but if nobody saw him, the legend would grow that he was a being of a different order from mere men.”
戴伊奥塞斯一旦发现了这条法则的真谛，便将其发挥到了极致。在他臣民为他建造的宫殿里，除了少数朝臣之外，无人能够见到他，而且这些人也只是偶尔才能见到他。正如希罗多德所写：“如果人们经常见到他，可能会引发嫉妒和怨恨，进而招致阴谋；但如果无人见到他，那么关于他并非凡人的传说就会流传开来。”
A man said to a Dervish: “Why do I not see you more often ” The Dervish
一个人问一位苦行僧：“为什么我不常见到你？” 苦行僧
replied, "Because the words 'Why have you not been to see me' are
回答说：“因为‘你为什么不来看我’这句话……”
sweeter to my ear than the words 'Why have you come again'"
比起“你为什么又来了”，这话听起来更悦耳。
Mulla Jami, quoted in Idries Shah's Caravan of Dreams, 1968
穆拉·贾米，引自伊德里斯·沙阿的《梦想之旅》，1968年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Everything in the world depends on absence and presence. A strong presence will draw power and attention to youyou shine more brighdy man those around you. But a point is inevitably reached where too much presence creates me opposite effect: The more you are seen and heard from, die more your value degrades. You become a habit. No matter how hard you try to be different, subdy, without your knowing why, people respect you less and less. At the right moment you must learn to witiidraw yourself before diey unconsciously push you away. It is a game of hide-and-seek.
世间万物都取决于存在与缺席。强大的存在感能为你吸引力量和关注，让你在周围的人眼中更加耀眼。但存在感过强终究会适得其反：你越是引人注目、越是发声，你的价值反而越是贬值。你会变成一种习惯。无论你多么努力地想要与众不同、低调行事，不知不觉中，人们对你的尊重却越来越少。你必须在合适的时机学会收敛，以免被人们无意识地推开。这就像一场捉迷藏的游戏。
The truth of this law can most easily be appreciated in matters of love and seduction. In the beginning stages of an affair, the lover's absence stimulates your imagination, forming a sort of aura around him or her. But mis aura fades when you know too muchwhen your imagination no longer has room to roam. The loved one becomes a person like anyone else, a person whose presence is taken for granted. This is why the seventeenth-century French courtesan Ninon de Lenclos advised constant feints at withdrawal from one's lover. “Love never dies of starvation,” she wrote, “but often of indigestion.”
这条法则的真谛在爱情和诱惑中体现得最为淋漓尽致。在一段恋情的初期，爱人的缺席会激发你的想象力，在他/她周围形成一种神秘的光环。但当你了解得太多，想象力不再自由驰骋时，这种光环便会消散。爱人会变得和普通人一样，成为一个理所当然存在的人。正因如此，十七世纪的法国交际花尼侬·德·朗克洛才建议人们要不断地假装疏远爱人。“爱情不会因饥饿而消亡，”她写道，“但常常会因消化不良而消亡。”
The moment you allow yourself to be treated like anyone else, it is too lateyou are swallowed and digested. To prevent this you need to starve the other person of your presence. Force their respect by threatening them with the possibility that they will lose you for good; create a pattern of presence and absence.
当你允许自己被像其他人一样对待时，就太晚了——你会被吞噬、被消化。为了避免这种情况，你需要让对方感到你的存在感缺失。通过威胁他们可能会永远失去你，来迫使他们尊重你；建立一种时而出现时而消失的模式。
Once you die, everything about you will seem different You will be surrounded by an instant aura of respect. People will remember their criticisms of you, their arguments with you, and will be filled with regret and guilt. They are missing a presence mat will never return. But you do not have to wait until you die: By completely withdrawing for a while, you create a kind of death before death. And when you come back, it will be as if you had come back from the deadan air of resurrection will cling to you, and people will be relieved at your return. This is how Deioces made himself king.
一旦你死去，你的一切都会变得不同。你会立刻被一种敬畏的光环所包围。人们会想起他们曾经对你的批评，与你的争论，并充满悔恨和愧疚。他们失去了一位永不复返的存在。但你无需等到死亡：通过暂时彻底隐退，你便创造了一种“死前之死”。当你回归时，仿佛是从死里复生，复活的气息将萦绕在你身上，人们会因你的归来而感到欣慰。这就是迪奥塞斯称王的方式。
Napoleon was recognizing the law of absence and presence when he said, “If I am often seen at the theater, people will cease to notice me.” Today, in a world inundated with presence through the flood of images, the game of withdrawal is all the more powerful. We rarely know when to witiidraw anymore, and nothing seems private, so we are awed by anyone who is able to disappear by choice. Novelists J. D. Salinger and Thomas Pynchon have created cultlike followings by knowing when to disappear.
拿破仑曾说过：“如果我经常出现在剧院，人们就会不再注意到我。”他深谙“缺席与在场”的法则。如今，在信息爆炸、图像泛滥的时代，隐退的策略显得尤为重要。我们很少知道何时该隐退，似乎没有什么隐私可言，因此，任何能够主动消失的人都令我们敬畏。小说家J·D·塞林格和托马斯·品钦正是凭借这种隐退的技巧，吸引了一批忠实的追随者。
Another, more everyday side of this law, but one that demonstrates its truth even further, is the law of scarcity in the science of economics. By withdrawing something from the market, you create instant value. In seventeenth-century Holland, the upper classes wanted to make die tulip more than just a beautiful flowerthey wanted it to be a kind of status symbol. Making the flower scarce, indeed almost impossible to obtain, they sparked what was later called tulipomania. A single flower was now worth more than its weight in gold. In our own century, similarly, the art dealer Joseph Duveen insisted on making the paintings he sold as scarce and rare as possible. To keep their prices elevated and their status high, he bought up whole collections and stored them in his basement. The paintings that he sold became more than just paintings!they were fetish objects, their value increased by their rarity. “You can get all the pictures you want at fifty thousand dollars apiecethat's easy,” he once said. “But to get pictures at a quarter of a million apiecethat wants doing!”
这条定律的另一个更贴近日常生活的方面，也更能体现其真谛，那就是经济学中的稀缺性定律。通过从市场中移除某种商品，就能立即创造价值。在十七世纪的荷兰，上流社会希望郁金香不仅仅是一朵美丽的花，更是一种身份的象征。他们人为地制造郁金香的稀缺性，甚至使其几乎绝迹，从而引发了后来被称为“郁金香狂热”的风潮。一朵郁金香的价值甚至超过了同等重量的黄金。同样，在我们这个世纪，艺术品经销商约瑟夫·杜维恩也坚持让他出售的画作尽可能稀有。为了维持画作的高价和地位，他大量收购画作，并将它们储存在地下室。他出售的画作不再仅仅是画作，而是成为了具有特殊意义的物品，其价值因稀缺性而增加。“你可以花五万美元买到所有你想要的画作——这很容易，”他曾说过，“但要花二十五万美元买到画作，那就难上加难了！”
Image:
图像：
The Sun. It can only be
太阳。它只能是
appreciated by its absence.
它的缺席反而更令人欣喜。
The longer the days of rain, the
雨天越长，
more the sun is craved. But too many
人们越来越渴望阳光。但太多了。
hot days and the sun overwhelms.
炎热的天气，烈日当空。
Learn to keep yourself obscure and
学会保持低调，
make people demand your return.
让人们要求你回归。
Extend the law of scarcity to your own skills. Make what you are offering the world rare and hard to find, and you instandy increase its value.
将稀缺性法则运用到你自身的技能上。让你提供给世界的技能变得稀缺且难以寻觅，你就能立即提升它的价值。
There always comes a moment when those in power overstay their welcome. We have grown tired of them, lost respect for them; we see them as no different from the rest of mankind, which is to say that we see them as rather worse, since we inevitably compare their current status in our eyes to their former one. There is an art to knowing when to retire. If it is done right, you regain the respect you had lost, and retain a part of your power.
总有那么一个时刻，掌权者会变得不受欢迎。我们厌倦了他们，对他们失去了尊重；我们觉得他们和其他人没什么两样，甚至更糟，因为我们总会不由自主地将他们现在的地位与他们过去的地位作比较。懂得何时退休是一门艺术。如果处理得当，你就能重新赢得失去的尊重，并保留一部分权力。
The greatest ruler of the sixteenth century was Charles V. King of Spain, Hapsburg emperor, he governed an empire tiiat at one point included much of Europe and the New World. Yet at the height of his power, in 1557, he retired to die monastery of Yuste. All of Europe was captivated by his sudden wididrawal; people who had hated and feared him suddenly called him great, and he came to be seen as a saint. In more recent times, die film actress Greta Garbo was never more admired dian when she retired, in 1941. For some her absence came too soonshe was in her mid-thirtiesbut she wisely preferred to leave on her own terms, rather dian waiting for her audience to grow tired of her.
十六世纪最伟大的统治者是西班牙国王、哈布斯堡王朝皇帝查理五世，他统治的帝国鼎盛时期囊括了欧洲大部分地区和新大陆。然而，在他权力的巅峰时期，1557年，他却隐居于尤斯特修道院。他的突然隐退令整个欧洲为之震惊；那些曾经憎恨和畏惧他的人突然称他为伟人，他甚至被视为圣人。近代，电影女演员葛丽泰·嘉宝在1941年息影时，人们对她的敬仰之情达到了顶峰。对一些人来说，她的离开来得太早了——当时她才三十五岁左右——但她明智地选择按照自己的意愿离开，而不是等到观众对她感到厌倦。
Make yourself too available and die aura of power you have created around yourself will wear away. Turn the game around: Make yourself less accessible and you increase die value of your presence.
如果你让自己过于平易近人，你营造的强大气场就会逐渐消散。反之，让自己保持一定的神秘感，你的存在价值就会提升。
Authority. Use absence to create respect and esteem. If presence diminishes fame, absence augments it. A man who when absent is regarded as a lion becomes when present something common and ridiculous. Talents lose their luster if we become too familiar with them, for the outer shell of the mind is more readily seen than its rich inner kernel. Even the outstanding genius makes use of retirement so that men may honor him and so that the yearning aroused by his absence may cause him to be esteemed. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威。利用缺席来赢得尊重和敬仰。如果说在场会削弱名声，那么缺席则会提升名声。一个人，不在场时被视为雄狮，在场时却变得平庸可笑。如果我们对才华过于熟悉，它就会失去光彩，因为人们更容易看到心灵的外壳，而不是其丰富的内在内核。即使是杰出的天才也会利用隐居，以便人们能够敬重他，并通过他的缺席激起人们的渴望，使他受到人们的敬仰。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
This law only applies once a certain level of power has been attained. The need to withdraw only comes after you have established your presence; leave too early and you do not increase your respect, you are simply forgotten. When you are first entering onto the world's stage, create an image that is recognizable, reproducible, and is seen everywhere. Until that status is attained, absence is dangerousinstead of fanning the flames, it will extinguish them.
这条法则只适用于达到一定权力水平之后。只有在你确立了自己的地位之后，才需要退出；过早离开，你不会赢得更多尊重，只会被人遗忘。当你初登世界舞台时，要塑造一个辨识度高、易于复制、无处不在的形象。在达到这种地位之前，缺席是危险的——它非但不会助长你的影响力，反而会将其扼杀。
In love and seduction, similarly, absence is only effective once you have surrounded the other with your image, been seen by him or her everywhere. Everything must remind your lover of your presence, so that when you do choose to be away, the lover will always be thinking of you, will always be seeing you in his or her mind's eye.
同样，在爱情和诱惑中，只有当你让对方时刻感受到你的存在，你的缺席才能真正奏效。一切都必须让你的爱人想起你的存在，这样，即使你选择离开，爱人也会一直想着你，一直把你的身影留在脑海中。
Remember: In the beginning, make yourself not scarce but omnipresent. Only what is seen, appreciated, and loved will be missed in its absence.
记住：一开始，不要让自己变得稀松平常，而要无处不在。只有那些被看见、被欣赏、被爱的事物，才会因为失去而感到惋惜。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 17
第17条
KEEP OTHERS IN
让其他人待在里面
SUSPENDED TERROR:
悬置的恐怖：
CULTIVATE AN AIR OF
营造一种氛围
UNPREDICTABILITY
不可预测性
JUDGMENT
判断
Humans are creatures of habit with an insatiable need to see familiarity in other people's actions. Your predictability gives them a sense of control. Turn the tables: Be deliberately unpredictable. Behavior that seems to have no consistency or purpose will keep them off-balance, and they will wear themselves out trying to explain your moves. Taken to an extreme, this strategy can intimidate and terrorize.
人类是习惯性动物，他们渴望在他人行为中看到熟悉感。你的可预测性会让他们感到掌控一切。不妨反其道而行之：刻意制造不可预测性。看似毫无规律或目的的行为会让他们感到不安，他们会疲于应对，试图解释你的举动。如果运用得当，这种策略甚至可以起到恐吓和威慑作用。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In May of 1972, chess champion Boris Spassky anxiously awaited his rival Bobby Fischer in Reykjavik, Iceland. The two men had been scheduled to meet for the World Championship of Chess, but Fischer had not arrived on time and the match was on hold.
