Fischer had problems with the size of the prize money, problems with the way the money was to be distributed, problems with the logistics of holding the match in Iceland. He might back out at any moment.
1972年5月，国际象棋冠军鲍里斯·斯帕斯基在冰岛雷克雅未克焦急地等待着他的对手鲍比·菲舍尔。两人原定进行世界国际象棋锦标赛的角逐，但菲舍尔未能按时抵达，比赛被迫暂停。菲舍尔对奖金数额、奖金分配方式以及在冰岛举办比赛的后勤安排都颇有微词。他随时都有可能退出比赛。
Spassky tried to be patient. His Russian bosses felt that Fischer was humiliating him and told him to walk away, but Spassky wanted this match. He knew he could destroy Fischer, and nothing was going to spoil die greatest victory of his career. “So it seems that all our work may come to nothing,” Spassky told a comrade. “But what can we do It is Bobby's move. If he comes, we play. If he does not come; we do not play. A man who is willing to commit suicide has the initiative.”
斯帕斯基努力保持耐心。他的俄国上司觉得菲舍尔在羞辱他，让他退出比赛，但斯帕斯基想要这场比赛。他知道自己可以击败菲舍尔，没有什么能破坏他职业生涯中最伟大的胜利。“看来我们所有的努力都可能付诸东流了，”斯帕斯基对一位同志说，“但我们又能怎么办呢？现在轮到鲍比了。他来，我们就下；他不来，我们就不下。一个愿意自杀的人掌握着主动权。”
Fischer finally arrived in Reykjavik, but the problems, and the threat of cancellation, continued. He disliked the hall where the match was to be fought, he criticized the lighting, he complained about die noise of the cameras, he even hated the chairs in which he and Spassky were to sit. Now the Soviet Union took the initiative and threatened to withdraw their man.
菲舍尔终于抵达雷克雅未克，但问题依然存在，比赛也面临取消的威胁。他不喜欢比赛场地，批评灯光，抱怨摄像机的噪音，甚至连他和斯帕斯基要坐的椅子都让他难以忍受。现在，苏联方面采取了行动，威胁要撤回他们的参赛选手。
The bluff apparendy worked: After all die weeks of waiting, the endless and infuriating negotiations, Fischer agreed to play. Everyone was relieved, no one more than Spassky. But on die day of the official introductions, Fischer arrived very late, and on the day when the “Match of the Century” was to begin, he was late again. This time, however, the consequences would be dire: If he showed up too late he would forfeit die first game. What was going on Was he playing some sort of mind game Or was Bobby Fischer perhaps afraid of Boris Spassky It seemed to the assembled grand masters, and to Spassky, that this young kid from Brooklyn had a terrible case of the jitters. At 5:09 Fischer showed up, exactly one minute before die match was to be canceled.
虚张声势似乎奏效了：经过数周的等待，以及没完没了、令人恼火的谈判之后，菲舍尔终于同意参赛。所有人都松了一口气，尤其是斯帕斯基。然而，在正式介绍环节，菲舍尔迟到了很久；到了“世纪之战”开赛当天，他又一次迟到了。但这一次，后果不堪设想：如果他迟到太久，就将被判负第一局。这究竟是怎么回事？他是在玩什么心理战吗？还是鲍比·菲舍尔真的害怕鲍里斯·斯帕斯基？在场的国际象棋大师们，以及斯帕斯基看来，这个来自布鲁克林的年轻人似乎紧张得要命。下午5点09分，菲舍尔终于出现了，距离比赛取消只剩一分钟。
The first game of a chess tournament is critical, since it sets the tone for die months to come. It is often a slow and quiet struggle, with the two players preparing themselves for the war and trying to read each other's strategies. This game was different Fischer made a terrible move early on, perhaps the worst of his career, and when Spassky had him on die ropes, he seemed to give up. Yet Spassky knew diat Fischer never gave up. Even when facing checkmate, he fought to the bitter end, wearing the opponent down. This time, diough, he seemed resigned. Then suddenly he broke out a bold move that put the room in a buzz. The move shocked Spassky, but he recovered and managed to win the game. But no one could figure out what Fischer was up to. Had he lost deliberately Or was he rattled Unset-ded Even, as some thought, insane
国际象棋锦标赛的第一局至关重要，因为它奠定了接下来几个月的基调。通常情况下，这是一场缓慢而沉寂的较量，双方棋手都在为这场“战争”做准备，试图揣摩对方的策略。但这局却截然不同。菲舍尔开局就走了一步糟糕的棋，或许是他职业生涯中最糟糕的一步。当斯帕斯基将他逼入绝境时，他似乎放弃了。然而，斯帕斯基深知菲舍尔永不言弃。即使面临将死，他也会战斗到最后一刻，不断消耗对手的体力。这一次，他看起来似乎已经认输了。然而，突然间，他迈出了大胆的一步，让整个房间沸腾起来。这一步让斯帕斯基大吃一惊，但他很快调整过来，最终赢得了比赛。但没有人能弄明白菲舍尔究竟在做什么。他是故意输棋吗？还是他被激怒了？甚至像某些人认为的那样，他疯了？
After his defeat in the first game, Fischer complained all the more loudly about die room, die cameras, and everything else. He also failed to
在第一局失利后，菲舍尔更加大声地抱怨骰子室、骰子摄像头以及其他一切。他也没能……
show up on time for die second game. This time the organizers had had enough: He was given a forfeit. Now he was down two games to none, a position from which no one had ever come back to win a chess championship. Fischer was clearly unhinged. Yet in the third game, as all those who witnessed it remember, he had a ferocious look in his eye, a look that clearly bothered Spassky. And despite the hole he had dug for himself, he seemed supremely confident. He did make what appeared to be another blunder, as he had in the first gamebut his cocky air made Spassky smell a trap. Yet despite die Russian's suspicions, he could not figure out the trap, and before he knew it Fischer had checkmated him. In fact Fischer's unorthodox tactics had completely unnerved his opponent. At the end of the game, Fischer leaped up and rushed out, yelling to his confederates as he smashed a fist into his palm, “I'm crushing him with brute force!”
第二局比赛他准时到场。这次组织者终于忍无可忍了：判他弃权。现在他以0比2落后，在国际象棋锦标赛历史上，从未有人能在这种局面下逆转取胜。菲舍尔显然已经心神不宁。然而，正如所有目睹第三局比赛的人所记得的那样，他眼神中充满了凶狠，这显然让斯帕斯基感到不安。尽管他已经把自己逼入绝境，但他似乎仍然信心十足。他确实犯了一个看似又一次的失误，就像第一局那样，但他那副趾高气扬的样子让斯帕斯基嗅到了陷阱的味道。然而，尽管这位俄罗斯棋手有所怀疑，他却始终没能识破这个陷阱，还没反应过来，菲舍尔就已经将他将死了。事实上，菲舍尔的非正统战术彻底打乱了他的对手。比赛结束时，菲舍尔跳起来冲了出去，一边用拳头猛击自己的手掌，一边向他的同伴们大喊：“我要用蛮力把他碾碎！”
In the next games Fischer pulled moves that no one had seen from him before, moves that were not his style. Now Spassky started to make blunders. After losing the sixth game, he started to cry. One grand master said, “After diis, Spassky's got to ask himself if it's safe to go back to Russia.” After the eighth game Spassky decided he knew what was happening: Bobby Fischer was hypnotizing him. He decided not to look Fischer in the eye; he lost anyway.
接下来的几局棋中，菲舍尔走出了前所未见的招法，这些招法完全不像他的风格。斯帕斯基开始频频失误。输掉第六局后，他哭了起来。一位特级大师说：“今天之后，斯帕斯基应该好好想想，回俄罗斯是否安全。”第八局结束后，斯帕斯基终于明白了是怎么回事：鲍比·菲舍尔对他施了催眠术。他决定不再与菲舍尔对视；结果，他还是输了。
After the fourteenth game he called a staff conference and announced, “An attempt is being made to control my mind.” He wondered whether the orange juice they drank at the chess table could have been drugged. Maybe chemicals were being blown into die air. Finally Spassky went public, accusing the Fischer team of putting something in the chairs that was altering Spassky's mind. The KGB went on alert: Boris Spassky was embarrassing the Soviet Union!
第十四盘棋结束后，他召集了全体工作人员开会，宣布：“有人试图控制我的思想。”他怀疑棋桌旁喝的橙汁里是不是被下了药。或许有人往空气中喷洒了化学物质。最终，斯帕斯基公开指责菲舍尔团队在椅子里放了什么东西，影响了他的心智。克格勃立即进入警戒状态：鲍里斯·斯帕斯基让苏联蒙羞了！
The chairs were taken apart and X-rayed. A chemist found nothing unusual in them. The only things anyone found anywhere, in fact, were two dead flies in a lighting fixture. Spassky began to complain of hallucinations. He tried to keep playing, but his mind was unraveling. He could not go on. On September 2, he resigned. Although still relatively young, he never recovered from diis defeat.
椅子被拆开进行X光检查。化学家没有发现任何异常。事实上，人们唯一找到的东西，是灯具里的两只死苍蝇。斯帕斯基开始抱怨出现幻觉。他试图继续比赛，但他的精神状态正在崩溃。他无法继续下去了。9月2日，他辞职了。尽管当时他还很年轻，但他再也没有从这场失败中恢复过来。
Interpretation
解释
In previous games between Fischer and Spassky, Fischer had not fared well. Spassky had an uncanny ability to read his opponent's strategy and use it against him. Adaptable and patient, he would build attacks that would defeat not in seven moves but in seventy. He defeated Fischer every time mey played because he saw much further ahead, and because he was a brilliant psychologist who never lost control. One master said, “He doesn't just look for the best move. He looks for the move that will disturb the man he is playing.”
在菲舍尔和斯帕斯基之前的对局中，菲舍尔的战绩并不理想。斯帕斯基拥有惊人的洞察力，能够读懂对手的策略并加以利用。他适应性强且耐心十足，精心策划的进攻并非七步就能取胜，而是需要七十步才能结束。他每次都能战胜菲舍尔，因为他的视野远比菲舍尔更开阔，而且他是一位杰出的心理战术家，始终保持着冷静沉着。一位大师曾评价道：“他不仅寻找最佳着法，更寻找能够扰乱对手节奏的着法。”
Fischer, however, finally understood that this was one of the keys to Spassky's success: He played on your predictability, defeated you at your own game. Everything Fischer did for die championship match was an at-
然而，菲舍尔最终明白，这正是斯帕斯基成功的关键之一：他利用你的可预测性，用你的招数击败你。菲舍尔在冠军赛中所做的一切都是为了……
tempt to put the initiative on his side and to keep Spassky off-balance. Clearly the endless waiting had an effect on Spassky's psyche. Most powerful of all, tfiough, were Fischer's deliberate blunders and his appearance of having no clear strategy. In fact, he was doing everything he could to scramble his old patterns, even if it meant losing die first match and forfeiting the second.
他试图掌握主动权，扰乱斯帕斯基的节奏。显然，漫长的等待对斯帕斯基的心理造成了影响。然而，最有效的策略还是菲舍尔的故意失误以及他看似毫无策略的假象。事实上，他正竭尽全力打破自己原有的比赛模式，即便这意味着输掉第一局，甚至放弃第二局也在所不惜。
Spassky was known for his sangfroid and levelheadedness, but for the first time in his life he could not figure out his opponent. He slowly melted down, until at die end he was die one who seemed insane.
斯帕斯基以冷静沉着著称，但生平第一次，他完全摸不透对手。他逐渐崩溃，直到最后，他自己看起来反而像个疯子。
Chess contains die concentrated essence of life: First, because to win you have to be supremely patient and farseeing; and second, because the game is built on patterns, whole sequences of moves that have been played before and will be played again, with slight alterations, in any one match. Your opponent analyzes the patterns you are playing and uses diem to try to foresee your moves. Allowing him notiiing predictable to base his strategy on gives you a big advantage. In chess as in life, when people cannot figure out what you are doing, diey are kept in a state of terrorwaiting, uncertain, confused.
国际象棋蕴含着人生的精髓：首先，要想获胜，你必须极度耐心和远见；其次，因为棋局建立在模式之上，即一系列似曾相识、反复出现的棋步，这些棋步在任何一场对局中都会以细微的变化再次出现。你的对手会分析你使用的模式，并以此来预测你的下一步行动。让他发现你可预测的棋步并以此为基础制定策略，就能让你获得巨大的优势。在国际象棋中，正如在生活中一样，当人们无法理解你的意图时，他们就会陷入一种恐惧、等待、不安和困惑的状态。
Life at court is a serious, melancholy game of chess, which requires us to draw
宫廷生活就像一场严肃而忧郁的棋局，需要我们去博弈。
up our pieces and batteries, form a plan, pursue it, parry that of our
准备好我们的零件和电池，制定计划，执行计划，抵挡我们的攻击
adversary. Sometimes, however, it is better to take risks
对手。然而，有时候，冒险反而更好。
and play the most capricious, unpredictable move.
并采取最反复无常、最难以预测的举动。
Jean de La Bruyere, 1645-1696
让·德·拉布吕耶尔，1645-1696年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Nodiing is more terrifying dian the sudden and unpredictable. That is why
点头比突然且不可预测的点头更可怕。这就是为什么
we are so frightened by earthquakes and tornadoes: We do not know when
我们如此惧怕地震和龙卷风：我们不知道何时会发生
they will strike. After one has occurred, we wait in terror for the next one.
他们会发动袭击。一次袭击过后，我们便提心吊胆地等待下一次。
To a lesser degree, diis is the effect tiiat unpredictable human behavior has
在较小程度上，diis 是不可预测的人类行为所产生的影响。
onus.
责任。
Animals behave in set patterns, which is why we are able to hunt and kill them. Only man has the capacity to consciously alter his behavior, to improvise and overcome the weight of routine and habit. Yet most men do not realize diis power. They prefer die comforts of routine, of giving in to the animal nature that has diem repeating die same compulsive actions time and time again. They do this because it requires no effort, and because diey mistakenly believe that if they do not unsetde others, they will be left alone. Understand: A person of power instills a kind of fear by deliberately unsetding those around him to keep the initiative on his side. You sometimes need to strike witiiout warning, to make others tremble when they least expect it. It is a device that the powerful have used for centuries.
动物的行为遵循固定的模式，正因如此，我们才能猎杀它们。只有人类才有能力有意识地改变自己的行为，随机应变，克服惯性思维的束缚。然而，大多数人却意识不到这种力量。他们更喜欢安于现状，屈服于动物本性，一遍又一遍地重复着同样的强迫性行为。他们这样做是因为无需付出任何努力，也因为他们错误地认为，只要不扰乱他人，就不会有人打扰他们。要知道，有权势的人会故意扰乱周围的人，以此来制造恐惧，从而掌握主动权。有时候，你需要出其不意地出手，让别人在最意想不到的时候感到恐惧。这是权势者几个世纪以来一直在使用的手段。
Filippo Maria, the last of die Visconti dukes of Milan in fifteenth-century Italy, consciously did die opposite of what everyone expected of him. For instance, he might suddenly shower a courtier witii attention, and dien, once die man had come to expect a promotion to higher office,
菲利波·马里亚，十五世纪意大利米兰维斯康蒂家族的最后一位公爵，有意地与所有人对他的期望背道而驰。例如，他可能会突然对一位廷臣格外关照，而当这位廷臣原本期望得到晋升时，他却突然改变了主意。
he allowed him a fair amount of latitude in handling his paintings, then one day, for no apparent reason, he told die man he would no longer give him any work to sell. As Rcasso explained, “Rosenberg would spend the next forty-eight hours trying to figure out why. Was I reserving things for some other dealer I'd go on working and sleeping and Rosenberg would spend his time figuring. In two days he'd come back, nerves jangled, anxious, saying, After all, dear friend, you wouldn't turn me down if I offered you this much [naming a substantially higher figure] for uiose paintings rather than the price I've been accustomed to paying you, would you'”
他给了他相当大的自主权来处理自己的画作，但有一天，毫无征兆地，他告诉这个人，他不再给他任何作品去卖了。正如拉卡索解释的那样，“罗森伯格会花接下来的四十八个小时来琢磨原因。我是不是在为其他经销商预留作品？我继续工作睡觉，而罗森伯格则一直在思考。两天后，他会回来，神经紧绷，焦虑不安地说：‘毕竟，亲爱的朋友，如果我给你这么多钱（他报了一个更高的价格）而不是我以前习惯给你的价格来买这些画，你不会拒绝吧？’”
Unpredictability is not only a weapon of terror: Scrambling your patterns on a day-to-day basis will cause a stir around you and stimulate interest. People will talk about you, ascribe motives and explanations that have nothing to do with the truth, but that keep you constantly in their minds. In the end, die more capricious you appear, die more respect you will garner. Only die terminally subordinate act in a predictable manner.
不可预测性不仅是恐怖的武器：日复一日地打破常规，会在你周围引起轰动，激发人们的兴趣。人们会谈论你，揣测你的动机和解释，这些都与真相无关，但却能让你始终留在他们的记忆中。最终，你越是显得反复无常，就越能赢得尊重。只有那些注定要循规蹈矩的人才会按部就班地行事。
Image: The Cyclone. A wind that cannot be foreseen. Sudden shifts in the barometer, inexplicable changes in direction and velocity. There is no defense: A cyclone sows terror and confusion.
图片：飓风。一种无法预测的风。气压计的突然变化，风向和风速的莫名其妙改变。无处可防：飓风带来恐惧和混乱。
Authority: The enlightened ruler is so mysterious that he seems to dwell nowhere, so inexplicable that no one can seek him. He reposes in nonaction above, and his ministers tremble below. (Han-fei-tzu, Chinese philosopher, third century B.C.)
权威：明君神秘莫测，仿佛无处可寻；难以捉摸，无人能知晓。他高高在上，无为而安，大臣们则在地上战战兢兢。（韩非子，中国哲学家，公元前三世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
Sometimes predictability can work in your favor: By creating a pattern for people to be familiar and comfortable with, you can lull them to sleep. They have prepared everything according to their preconceived notions about you. You can use this in several ways: First, it sets up a smoke screen, a comfortable front behind which you can carry on deceptive actions. Second, it allows you on rare occasions to do something completely against the pattern, unsettling your opponent so deeply he will fall to the ground wimout being pushed.
有时候，可预测性反而对你有利：通过营造一种人们熟悉且舒适的模式，你可以让他们放松警惕。他们会根据对你的既定印象做好一切准备。你可以利用这一点：首先，它可以制造一层烟雾弹，一个舒适的假象，让你可以在其后进行欺骗性行动。其次，它允许你在极少数情况下做出完全出乎意料的事情，让你的对手感到极度不安，以至于他无需任何推动就会崩溃。
In 1974 Muhammad Ali and George Foreman were scheduled to fight for the world heavyweight boxing championship. Everyone knew what would happen: Big George Foreman would try to land a knockout punch while Ali would dance around him, wearing him out. That was Ali's way of fighting, his pattern, and he had not changed it in more than ten years. But in this case it seemed to give Foreman the advantage: He had a devastating punch, and if he waited, sooner or later Ali would have to come to him. Ali, the master strategist, had other plans: In press conferences before the big fight, he said he was going to change his style and punch it out with Foreman. No one, least of all Foreman, believed this for a second. That plan would be suicide on Ali's part; he was playing the comedian, as usual. Then, before the fight, Ali's trainer loosened the ropes around the ring, something a trainer would do if his boxer were intending to slug it out. But no one believed this ploy; it had to be a setup.
1974年，穆罕默德·阿里和乔治·福尔曼即将争夺世界重量级拳击冠军。所有人都知道比赛会如何发展：福尔曼会试图一记重拳KO对手，而阿里则会灵活地绕着他移动，消耗他的体力。这就是阿里的比赛方式，他的惯用套路，十多年来从未改变过。但这一次，这套路似乎对福尔曼更有利：他的重拳威力十足，如果他按兵不动，阿里迟早会主动进攻。然而，作为战略大师的阿里却另有打算：在赛前新闻发布会上，他声称自己将改变风格，与福尔曼展开硬碰硬的较量。没有人相信他，福尔曼也不例外。在他们看来，阿里的这个计划无异于自杀；他一如既往地在扮演一个滑稽的角色。随后，在比赛开始前，阿里的教练放松了拳台周围的绳索——如果教练打算让拳手和福尔曼硬碰硬，他通常会这样做。但没有人相信这种伎俩；这一定是陷阱。
To everyone's amazement, Ali did exacdy what he had said he would do. As Foreman waited for him to dance around, Ali went right up to him and slugged it out. He completely upset his opponent's strategy. At a loss, Foreman ended up wearing himself out, not by chasing Ali but by throwing punches wildly, and taking more and more counterpunches. Finally, Ali landed a dramatic right cross that knocked out Foreman. The habit of assuming that a person's behavior will fit its previous patterns is so strong that not even Ali's announcement of a strategy change was enough to upset it. Foreman walked into a trapthe trap he had been told to expect.
令所有人惊讶的是，阿里真的说到做到。福尔曼原本以为他会像之前那样灵活移动，但阿里却直接冲上前去，展开了激烈的对攻。他彻底打乱了对手的策略。福尔曼束手无策，最终耗尽了体力，他不是在追着阿里打，而是在胡乱挥拳，承受了越来越多的反击。最终，阿里一记势大力沉的右直拳击倒了福尔曼。人们习惯性地认为一个人的行为会遵循他之前的模式，这种习惯根深蒂固，以至于即使阿里宣布改变策略，也无法改变这种习惯。福尔曼走进了一个陷阱——一个他事先被告知会遇到的陷阱。
A warning: Unpredictability can work against you sometimes, especially if you are in a subordinate position. There are times when it is better to let people feel comfortable and settled around you than to disturb them. Too much unpredictability will be seen as a sign of indecisiveness, or even of some more serious psychic problem. Patterns are powerful, and you can terrify people by disrupting them. Such power should only be used judiciously.
警告：不可预测性有时会对你不利，尤其是在你处于下属地位时。有些时候，让周围的人感到舒适安心比打扰他们更好。过多的不可预测性会被视为优柔寡断，甚至会被视为某种更严重的心理问题。模式的力量非常强大，打破这种模式会让人感到恐惧。这种力量应该谨慎使用。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 18
第18条
DO NOT BUILD FORTRESSES
不要建造堡垒
TO PROTECT YOURSELF
保护自己
ISOLATION IS DANGEROUS
隔离是危险的
JUDGMENT
判断
The world is dangerous and enemies are everywhere everyone has to protect themselves. A fortress seems the safest. But isolation exposes you to more dangers than it protects you fromit cuts you off from valuable information, it makes you conspicuous and an easy target. Better to circulate among people, find allies, mingle. You are shielded from your enemies by the crowd.
世界危机四伏，敌人无处不在，每个人都必须保护自己。堡垒看似最安全，但孤立无援反而会让你面临更多危险——它会让你与重要信息隔绝，使你成为众矢之的。最好是融入人群，寻找盟友，与人交往。人群会为你遮风挡雨，保护你免受敌人的侵害。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Ch'in Shih Huang Ti, the first emperor of China (221-210 B.C.), was the mightiest man of his day. His empire was vaster and more powerful than that of Alexander the Great. He had conquered all of the kingdoms surrounding his own kingdom of Ch'in and unified them into one massive realm called China. But in the last years of his life, few, if anyone, saw him.
秦始皇（公元前221-210年），中国第一位皇帝，是当时最强大的人物。他的帝国比亚历山大大帝的帝国还要辽阔强大。他征服了秦国周围的所有王国，并将它们统一为一个名为中国的庞大帝国。但在他生命的最后几年，几乎无人见过他。
The emperor lived in the most magnificent palace built to that date, in the capital of Hsien-yang. The palace had 270 pavilions; all of these were connected by secret underground passageways, allowing the emperor to move through the palace without anyone seeing him. He slept in a different room every night, and anyone who inadvertendy laid eyes on him was instandy beheaded. Only a handful of men knew his whereabouts, and if they revealed it to anyone, they, too, were put to deadi.
皇帝居住在当时最宏伟的宫殿里，这座宫殿位于京城咸阳。宫殿共有270座亭台楼阁，所有亭台楼阁都通过秘密的地下通道相连，使皇帝能够在宫殿内自由穿梭而不被人察觉。他每晚都睡在不同的房间，任何无意中看到他的人都会立即被斩首。只有极少数人知道他的行踪，如果他们泄露给他人，也会被处死。
The first emperor had grown so terrified of human contact that when he had to leave die palace he traveled incognito, disguising himself carefully. On one such trip through the provinces, he suddenly died. His body was borne back to the capital in the emperor's carriage, with a cart packed with salted fish trailing behind it to cover up die smell of the rotting corpseno one was to know of his death. He died alone, far from his wives, his family, his friends, and his courtiers, accompanied only by a minister and a handful of eunuchs.
第一位皇帝极度惧怕与人接触，以至于每次离开皇宫都不得不乔装打扮，隐姓埋名。一次巡视各省时，他突然驾崩。他的遗体被安放在皇帝的马车中运回京城，马车后拖着一辆装满咸鱼的马车，以掩盖尸体腐烂的气味，以免有人察觉到他的死讯。他孤独地死去，远离妻妾、家人、朋友和朝臣，只有一位大臣和几名宦官陪伴在侧。
Interpretation
解释
Shih Huang Ti started off as the king of Ch'in, a fearless warrior of unbridled ambition. Writers of die time described him as a man with “a waspish nose, eyes like slits, the voice of a jackal, and the heart of a tiger or wolf.” He could be merciful sometimes, but more often he “swallowed men up without a scruple.” It was through trickery and violence that he conquered the provinces surrounding his own and created China, forging a single nation and culture out of many. He broke up the feudal system, and to keep an eye on die many members of the royal families that were scattered across the realm's various kingdoms, he moved 120,000 of them to the capital, where he housed the most important courtiers in the vast palace of Hsien-yang. He consolidated the many walls on the borders and built them into me Great Wall of China. He standardized die country's laws, its written language, even die size of its cartwheels.
秦始皇最初是秦王，一位无畏的武士，野心勃勃。当时的作家形容他“鼻子尖尖的，眼睛像竖瞳，嗓音像豺狼，心如虎或狼”。他有时仁慈，但更多时候“毫不留情地吞噬他人”。他凭借计谋和武力征服了周边诸侯国，建立了中国，将众多民族融合为一个统一的国家和文化。他废除了封建制度，为了监视散居在各地的众多皇室成员，他将其中十二万皇室成员迁至都城，并将最重要的朝臣安置在宏伟的仙阳宫中。他整合了边境的城墙，修建了长城。他统一了国家的法律、文字，甚至连车轮的尺寸都进行了规定。
As part of this process of unification, however, the first emperor outlawed the writings and teachings of Confucius, the philosopher whose ideas on the moral life had already become virtually a religion in Chinese culture. On Shih Huang Ti's order, tiiousands of books relating to Confucius were burned, and anyone who quoted Confucius was to be beheaded. This made many enemies for the emperor, and he grew constantiy afraid, even paranoid. The executions mounted. A contemporary, the writer Han-fei-tzu, noted mat “Ch'in has been victorious for four generations, yet has lived in constant terror and apprehension of destruction.”
然而，作为统一进程的一部分，秦始皇下令禁止孔子的著作和教义。孔子的道德思想在中国文化中几乎已成为一种宗教。秦始皇下令焚毁数以万计的孔子著作，任何引用孔子言论的人都将被斩首。这使秦始皇树敌众多，他也因此变得忧心忡忡，甚至疑神疑鬼。处决人数不断攀升。当时的作家韩非子写道：“秦国四代虽胜，却终日生活在恐惧和灭亡的阴影中。”
As die emperor withdrew deeper and deeper into the palace to protect
随着皇帝不断退入宫殿深处以保护自己
INK MASOI K or TIIK Ul:i) l)K V] II
墨水 MASOI C 或 THICK Ul:i) l)K V] II
The “Red Death ” had long devastated the country. No pestilence had ever been so fatal, or so hideous. Blood was its Avatar and its sealthe redness and horror of blood. There were sharp pains, and sudden dizziness, and then profuse bleeding at the pores, with dissolution.... And the whole seizure, progress, and termination of the disease, were the incidents of half an hour.
“红死病”肆虐全国已久。从未有过如此致命、如此骇人的瘟疫。鲜血是它的化身和印记——鲜血的猩红与恐怖。患者会经历剧烈的疼痛、突如其来的眩晕，随后毛孔大量出血，最终消亡……而整个发病、发展和死亡过程，仅仅持续了半个小时。
But the Prince Pros-pero was happy and dauntless and saga-clous. When his dominions were half-depopulated, he summoned to his presence a thousand hale and light-hearted friends from among the knights and dames of his court, and with these retired to the deep seclusion of one of his castellated abbeys. This was an extensive and magnificent structure, the creation of the prince's own eccentric yet august taste. A strong and lofty wall girdled it in. This wall had gates of iron. The courtiers, having entered, brought furnaces and massy hammers and welded the bolts. They resolved to leave means neither of ingress nor egress to the sudden impulses of despair or of frenzy from within. The abbey was amply provisioned. With such
但普罗斯佩罗王子快乐、无畏且富有传奇色彩。当他的领地人口锐减一半时，他从宫廷的骑士和贵妇中召集了一千名身强力壮、性情开朗的朋友，与他们一同隐居到他一座城堡式修道院的深处。这是一座规模宏大、气势恢宏的建筑，体现了王子独特而高贵的品味。坚固高耸的城墙环绕着它，城墙上设有铁门。朝臣们进入修道院后，带来了熔炉和巨大的铁锤，将门闩焊死。他们决心不给修道院留下任何出入的途径，以免内部突然的绝望或疯狂情绪爆发。修道院物资充足。
precautions the courtiers might bid defiance to contagion. The external world could take care of itself. In the meantime it was folly to grieve, or to think. The prince had provided all the appliances of pleasure. There were buffoons, there were improvisator!, there were ballet-dancers, there were musicians, there was Beauty, there was wine. All these and security were within. Without was the “Red Death.” It was toward the close of the fifth or sixth month of his seclusion, and while the pestilence raged most furiously abroad, that the Prince Prospero entertained his thousand friends at a masked ball of the most unusual magnificence. It was a voluptuous scene, that masquerade.... ... And the revel went whirlingly on, until at length there commenced the sounding of midnight upon the clock.... And thus too, it happened, perhaps, that before the last echoes of the last chime had utterly sunk into silence, there were many individuals in the crowd who had found leisure to become aware of the presence of a masked figure which had arrested the attention of no single individual before.... The figure was tall and gaunt, and shrouded from head to foot in the habiliments of the grave. The mask which concealed the visage
朝臣们或许会不顾一切地防范瘟疫。外面的世界自有其应对之道。与此同时，悲伤或思考都是愚蠢的。王子已经准备了一切享乐之物。有小丑，有即兴表演者，有芭蕾舞演员，有音乐家，有美女，有美酒。这一切以及安全感都蕴藏其中。而外面则是“红死病”。在他隐居的第五或第六个月末，瘟疫在外肆虐之时，普洛斯彼罗王子举办了一场极其盛大的化装舞会，款待他的上千位朋友。那场化装舞会真是热闹非凡……狂欢持续不断，直到午夜钟声敲响……或许正是在钟声彻底沉寂之前，人群中许多人才注意到一个戴着面具的身影，此前竟无人察觉……那身影高大而消瘦，从头到脚都裹在丧服里。面具遮住了他的面容……
himself, he slowly lost control of the realm. Eunuchs and ministers enacted political policies without his approval or even his knowledge; they also plotted against him. By the end, he was emperor in name only, and was so isolated that barely anyone knew he had died. He had probably been poisoned by the same scheming ministers who encouraged his isolation.
他自己也逐渐失去了对国家的控制。宦官和大臣们未经他批准甚至不知情就推行政治政策；他们还密谋反对他。到最后，他只是名义上的皇帝，与世隔绝，以至于几乎无人知晓他的死讯。他很可能是被那些怂恿他隐居的阴谋大臣们毒害的。
That is what isolation brings: Retreat into a fortress and you lose contact with the sources of your power. You lose your ear for what is happening around you, as well as a sense of proportion. Instead of being safer, you cut yourself off from the kind of knowledge on which your life depends. Never enclose yourself so far from the streets that you cannot hear what is happening around you, including the plots against you.
这就是孤立带来的后果：退守堡垒，你会失去与力量源泉的联系。你会听不到周围发生的一切，也会失去判断力。你非但没有更安全，反而切断了自己与赖以生存的信息的联系。永远不要把自己封闭得如此远离尘嚣，以至于听不到周围发生的一切，包括针对你的阴谋。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Louis XIV had the palace of Versailles built for him and his court in the 1660s, and it was like no other royal palace in the world. As in a beehive, everything revolved around the royal person. He lived surrounded by the nobility, who were allotted apartments nestied around his, their closeness to him dependent on their rank. The king's bedroom occupied the literal center of the palace and was the focus of everyone's attention. Every morning the king was greeted in this room by a ritual known as the lever.
路易十四于17世纪60年代为自己和他的宫廷建造了凡尔赛宫，它与世界上任何其他皇家宫殿都截然不同。如同蜂巢一般，一切都围绕着国王运转。他被贵族们环绕，贵族们被分配到围绕着他的公寓，他们与国王的亲疏远近取决于他们的地位。国王的卧室位于宫殿的正中心，是所有人的目光焦点。每天早晨，国王都会在这个房间里接受一种被称为“起床仪式”的欢迎。
At eight A.M., the king's first valet, who slept at the foot of the royal bed, would awaken His Majesty. Then pages would open the door and admit those who had a function in the lever. The order of their entry was precise: First came the king's illegitimate sons and his grandchildren, then the princes and princesses of the blood, and then his physician and surgeon. There followed the grand officers of the wardrobe, the king's official reader, and those in charge of entertaining the king. Next would arrive various government officials, in ascending order of rank. Last but not least came those attending the lever by special invitation. By the end of the ceremony, the room would be packed with well over a hundred royal attendants and visitors.
早上八点，睡在国王床脚的首席侍从会唤醒国王陛下。随后，侍从们会打开房门，让那些在觐见仪式中扮演重要角色的人进入。他们的入场顺序十分严谨：首先是国王的私生子和孙辈，然后是王室的王子和公主，接着是御医和外科医生。之后是衣橱的高级官员、国王的御用读经员以及负责招待国王的人员。接下来是各级政府官员，按级别由高到低依次入场。最后，也是同样重要的，是那些受邀参加觐见仪式的人。仪式结束时，房间里会挤满一百多名皇家侍从和宾客。
The day was organized so that all the palace's energy was directed at and passed through the king. Louis was constantly attended by courtiers and officials, all asking for his advice and judgment. To all their questions he usually replied, “I shall see.”
这一天的安排使得宫廷的所有精力都集中在国王身上，并通过他传递。路易国王身边始终簇拥着朝臣和官员，他们都向他征求意见和判断。对于他们提出的所有问题，他通常的回答是：“我再考虑。”
As Saint-Simon noted, “If he turned to someone, asked him a question, made an insignificant remark, the eyes of all present were turned on this person. It was a distinction that was talked of and increased prestige.” There was no possibility of privacy in the palace, not even for the king every room communicated with another, and every hallway led to larger rooms where groups of nobles gathered constantly. Everyone's actions were interdependent, and nothing and no one passed unnoticed: “The king not only saw to it mat all the high nobility was present at his court,” wrote Saint-Simon, "he demanded the same of the minor nobility. At his lever and coucher, at his meals, in his gardens of Versailles, he always looked
正如圣西蒙所言，“如果他转向某人，问他一个问题，或者说一句无关紧要的话，在场所有人的目光都会集中在这个人身上。这是一种值得称道的特权，也提升了他的威望。”在宫殿里，没有隐私可言，即使是国王也不例外。每个房间都与其他房间相连，每条走廊都通往更大的房间，贵族们经常聚集在那里。每个人的行动都相互关联，任何事、任何人都逃不过他的耳目：“国王不仅确保所有高级贵族都在他的宫廷中，”圣西蒙写道，“他也要求低级贵族同样如此。在他的床榻上、卧榻上、用餐时、凡尔赛宫的花园里，他总是注视着所有人。”
about him, noticing everything. He was offended if the most distinguished nobles did not live permanendy at court, and those who showed themselves never or hardly ever, incurred his full displeasure. If one of these desired something, the king would say proudly: 'I do not know him,' and the judgment was irrevocable."
他观察入微，事无巨细。如果最尊贵的贵族不常住在宫廷，他便会感到冒犯；而那些从不露面或很少露面的贵族，更是令他极为不满。如果这些人中有人提出什么要求，国王会傲慢地说：“我不认识他。”而且这番话不容更改。
Interpretation
解释
Louis XIV came to power at the end of a terrible civil war, the Fronde. A principal instigator of the war had been the nobility, which deeply resented me growing power of the throne and yearned for the days of feudalism, when the lords ruled their own fiefdoms and the king had little authority over them. The nobles had lost the civil war, but they remained a fractious, resentful lot.
路易十四是在一场可怕的内战——投石党运动——结束后登上王位的。这场战争的主要挑起者是贵族，他们对王权的日益增长深感不满，并渴望回到封建时代，那时领主们统治着自己的封地，国王对他们几乎没有管辖权。贵族们虽然输掉了内战，但他们仍然是一群充满怨恨、桀骜不驯的人。
The construction of Versailles, then, was far more than the decadent whim of a luxury-loving king. It served a crucial function: The king could keep an eye and an ear on everyone and everything around him. The once proud nobility was reduced to squabbling over the right to help the king put on his robes in the morning. There was no possibility here of privacyno possibility of isolation. Louis XIV very early grasped the truth that for a king to isolate himself is gravely dangerous. In his absence, conspiracies will spring up like mushrooms after rain, animosities will crystallize into factions, and rebellion will break out before he has the time to react. To combat this, sociability and openness must not only be encouraged, they must be formally organized and channeled.
因此，凡尔赛宫的建造远非一位嗜好奢靡的国王一时兴起。它发挥着至关重要的作用：国王可以时刻监视周围的一切。曾经骄傲的贵族们沦落到争夺每天早晨帮助国王穿袍的权利。在这里，隐私和隔离都无从谈起。路易十四很早就意识到，国王自我隔离极其危险。在他不在的时候，阴谋会像雨后春笋般涌现，敌意会凝结成派系，叛乱会在他来不及反应之前爆发。为了应对这种情况，不仅要鼓励社交和开放，更要对其进行正式的组织和引导。
These conditions at Versailles lasted for Louis's entire reign, some fifty years of relative peace and tranquillity. Through it all, not a pin dropped without Louis hearing it.
凡尔赛宫的这种状况持续了路易十四的整个统治时期，大约五十年相对和平与安宁。在这期间，哪怕一根针掉在地上的声音，路易十四都能听到。
Solitude is dangerous to reason, without being favorable to virtue. . . .
孤独不利于理性，也不利于美德的培养……
Remember that the solitary mortal is certainly luxurious,
记住，独居的凡人也是一种奢侈。
probably superstitious, and possibly mad.
可能迷信，也可能疯了。
Dr. Samuel Johnson, 1709-1784
塞缪尔·约翰逊博士，1709-1784年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Machiavelli makes the argument that in a stricdy military sense a fortress is invariably a mistake. It becomes a symbol of power's isolation, and is an easy target for its builders' enemies. Designed to defend you, fortresses actually cut you off from help and cut into your flexibility. They may appear impregnable, but once you retire to one, everyone knows where you are; and a siege does not have to succeed to turn your fortress into a prison. With their small and confined spaces, fortresses are also extremely vulnerable to the plague and contagious diseases. In a strategic sense, the isolation of a fortress provides no protection, and actually creates more problems than it solves.
马基雅维利认为，从严格的军事角度来看，堡垒必然是一个错误。它象征着权力的孤立，也容易成为建造者敌人的攻击目标。堡垒的设计初衷是为了保护自身，但实际上却切断了你与外界的联系，限制了你的灵活性。它们或许看起来坚不可摧，但一旦你退守其中，所有人都知道你的位置；即使围攻没有成功，你的堡垒也会变成一座监狱。由于空间狭小封闭，堡垒也极易遭受瘟疫和传染病的侵袭。从战略角度来看，堡垒的孤立并不能提供任何保护，反而制造了更多问题。
was made so nearly to resemble the counte-nanee of a stiffened corpse that the closest scrutiny must have had difficulty in detecting the cheat. And yet all this might have been endured, if not approved, by the mad revellers around. But the mummer had gone so far as to assume the type of the Red Death. His vesture was dabbled in blood and his broad brow, with all the features of the face, was sprinkled with the scarlet horror.... .. .A throng of the revellers at once threw themselves into the black apartment, and, seizing the mummer, whose tall figure stood erect and motionless within the shadow of the ebony clock, gasped in unutterable horror at finding the grave cerements and corpse-like mask, which they handled with so violent a rudeness, untenanted by any tangible form. And now was acknowledged the presence of the Red Death. He had come like a thief in the night. And one by one dropped the revellers in the blood-bedewed halls of their revel, and died each in the despairing posture of his fall. And the life of the ebony clock went out with that of the last of the gay. And the flames of the tripods expired. And Darkness and Decay and the Red Death held illimitable dominion over all.
他的装扮几乎与一具僵硬尸体的面容如出一辙，即使是最仔细的观察也很难识破其中的欺骗。然而，周围那些疯狂的狂欢者或许能够容忍这一切，甚至可能表示赞同。但这位戏子竟然装扮成了死神。他的衣服沾满了鲜血，宽阔的额头，连同五官，都洒满了猩红的恐怖……一群狂欢者立刻涌入那间黑色的房间，抓住那位高大的戏子——他笔直地站在乌木钟的阴影下，一动不动——他们惊恐地倒吸一口凉气，发现那沉重的墓碑和如同尸体般的面具里空无一物，他们刚才粗暴地摆弄着它们。现在，人们终于承认了死神的到来。他如同夜贼一般悄然而至。于是，狂欢者们一个接一个地倒在血迹斑斑的宴会厅里，在绝望的倒地姿态中死去。乌木钟的生命随着最后一位欢愉者的逝去而停止。三脚架上的火焰也熄灭了。黑暗、腐朽和红色的死神无情地统治着一切。
the masque of the red death, Edgar Allan Poe. 1809-1849
《红死魔的面具》，埃德加·爱伦·坡，1809-1849年
Because humans are social creatures by nature, power depends on social interaction and circulation. To make yourself powerful you must place yourself at the center of things, as Louis XIV did at Versailles. All activity should revolve around you, and you should be aware of everything happening on the street, and of anyone who might be hatching plots against you. The danger for most people comes when they feel threatened. In such times they tend to retreat and close ranks, to find security in a kind of fortress. In doing so, however, they come to rely for information on a smaller and smaller circle, and lose perspective on events around them. They lose maneuverability and become easy targets, and their isolation makes them paranoid. As in warfare and most games of strategy, isolation often precedes defeat and death.
因为人类天生是社会性动物，权力依赖于社会互动和流通。要想获得权力，你必须把自己置于中心，就像路易十四在凡尔赛宫所做的那样。所有活动都应该围绕你展开，你必须对街上发生的一切了如指掌，并警惕任何可能密谋反对你的人。对大多数人来说，危险来自于感到威胁之时。在这种情况下，他们往往会退缩并抱团取暖，在某种堡垒中寻求安全感。然而，这样做会使他们依赖的信息圈子越来越小，并逐渐失去对周围事件的全面了解。他们失去了行动的灵活性，成为容易攻击的目标，而孤立则使他们变得多疑。正如在战争和大多数战略游戏中一样，孤立往往是失败和死亡的先兆。
In moments of uncertainty and danger, you need to fight this desire to turn inward. Instead, make yourself more accessible, seek out old allies and make new ones, force yourself into more and more different circles. This has been the trick of powerful people for centuries.
在充满不确定性和危险的时刻，你必须克服这种封闭自我的冲动。相反，你应该让自己更容易与人接触，寻找旧盟友，结交新朋友，努力融入更多不同的社交圈。几个世纪以来，这一直是成功人士的制胜法宝。
The Roman statesman Cicero was born into the lower nobility, and had little chance of power unless he managed to make a place for himself among the aristocrats who controlled the city. He succeeded brilliantly, identifying everyone with influence and figuring out how they were connected to one another. He mingled everywhere, knew everyone, and had such a vast network of connections that an enemy here could easily be counterbalanced by an ally there.
罗马政治家西塞罗出身于下层贵族，若想在掌控罗马城的贵族阶层中站稳脚跟，便几乎没有机会获得权力。他在这方面做得非常出色，他能识别出所有有影响力的人，并弄清他们之间的联系。他与各色人等交往甚密，认识所有人，拥有如此庞大的关系网，以至于一个敌人很容易就能在另一个地方找到盟友来制衡。
The French statesman Talleyrand played the game the same way. Although he came from one of the oldest aristocratic families in France, he made a point of always staying in touch with what was happening in the streets of Paris, allowing him to foresee trends and troubles. He even got a certain pleasure out of mingling with shady criminal types, who supplied him with valuable information. Every time there was a crisis, a transition of powerthe end of the Directory, the fall of Napoleon, the abdication of Louis XVIIIhe was able to survive and even thrive, because he never closed himself up in a small circle but always forged connections with the new order.
法国政治家塔列朗也遵循同样的策略。尽管他出身于法国最古老的贵族世家之一，但他始终密切关注巴黎街头的动向，这使他能够预见未来的趋势和危机。他甚至乐于与一些形形色色的犯罪分子交往，这些人为他提供了宝贵的情报。每当危机来临，权力更迭——无论是督政府的终结、拿破仑的垮台还是路易十八的退位——他都能安然度过，甚至更上一层楼，因为他从未将自己封闭在狭小的圈子里，而是始终与新秩序建立联系。
This law pertains to kings and queens, and to those of the highest power: The moment you lose contact with your people, seeking security in isolation, rebellion is brewing. Never imagine yourself so elevated that you can afford to cut yourself off from even the lowest echelons. By retreating to a fortress, you make yourself an easy target for your plotting subjects, who view your isolation as an insult and a reason for rebellion.
这条法则适用于君王和王后，以及所有掌权者：一旦你与民众失去联系，寻求孤立以确保安全，叛乱便已酝酿。切勿妄想自己高人一等，可以与最底层民众彻底断绝关系。退守堡垒只会使你成为心怀叵测的臣民的活靶子，他们会将你的孤立视为一种侮辱，并以此为由发动叛乱。
Since humans are such social creatures, it follows that the social arts that make us pleasant to be around can be practiced only by constant exposure and circulation. The more you are in contact with others, the more graceful and at ease you become. Isolation, on the other hand, engenders an awkwardness in your gestures, and leads to further isolation, as people start avoiding you.
人类是社会性动物，因此，那些让我们更受人喜爱的社交技巧只能通过不断的接触和互动来练习。你与他人接触越多，就越能变得优雅自在。相反，孤立会使你的举止显得笨拙，并导致进一步的孤立，因为人们会开始疏远你。
In 1545 Duke Cosimo I de' Medici decided that to ensure the immor-
1545 年，科西莫一世·德·美第奇公爵决定，为了确保不朽——
tality of his name he would commission frescoes for the main chapel of the church of San Lorenzo in Florence. He had many great painters to choose from, and in the end he picked Jacopo da Pontormo. Getting on in years, Pontormo wanted to make these frescoes his chef d'oeuvre and legacy. His first decision was to close the chapel off with walls, partitions, and blinds. He wanted no one to witness the creation of his masterpiece, or to steal his ideas. He would outdo Michelangelo himself. When some young men broke into the chapel out of curiosity, Jacopo sealed it off even further.
为了彰显自己的名声，他委托人为佛罗伦萨圣洛伦佐教堂的主礼拜堂绘制壁画。他有很多优秀的画家可供选择，最终他选择了雅各布·达·蓬托尔莫。蓬托尔莫年事已高，他希望将这些壁画作为自己的巅峰之作和毕生传世之作。他的第一个决定是用墙壁、隔板和百叶窗将礼拜堂完全封闭起来。他不想让任何人目睹他杰作的创作过程，也不想让任何人窃取他的创意。他要超越米开朗基罗。当一些年轻人出于好奇闯入礼拜堂时，雅各布更加严密地将其封锁起来。
Pontormo filled the chapel's ceiling with biblical scenesthe Creation, Adam and Eve, Noah's ark, on and on. At the top of the middle wall he painted Christ in his majesty, raising the dead on Judgment Day. The artist worked on the chapel for eleven years, rarely leaving it, since he had developed a phobia for human contact and was afraid his ideas would be stolen.
蓬托尔莫在教堂的天花板上绘制了圣经故事场景——创世、亚当和夏娃、诺亚方舟等等。在中墙的顶部，他描绘了基督威严的形象，以及他在审判日复活死者的场景。这位艺术家在教堂里工作了十一年，很少离开，因为他患上了人际交往恐惧症，害怕自己的创意被窃取。
Pontormo died before completing the frescoes, and none of diem has survived. But the great Renaissance writer Vasari, a friend of Pontormo's who saw the frescoes shortly after the artist's death, left a description of what they looked like. There was a total lack of proportion. Scenes bumped against scenes, figures in one story being juxtaposed witfi those in another, in maddening numbers. Pontormo had become obsessed with detail but had lost any sense of the overall composition. Vasari left off his description of die frescoes by writing diat if he continued, “I think I would go mad and become entangled in this painting, just as I believe mat in the eleven years of time Jacopo spent on it, he entangled himself and anyone else who saw it.” Instead of crowning Pontormo's career, the work became his undoing.
蓬托尔莫在完成壁画之前就去世了，而且没有一幅壁画流传下来。但伟大的文艺复兴作家瓦萨里是蓬托尔莫的朋友，他在艺术家去世后不久就看到了这些壁画，并留下了对它们样貌的描述。这些壁画完全失去了比例感。场景之间相互碰撞，一个故事中的人物与另一个故事中的人物并列出现，数量多得令人眼花缭乱。蓬托尔莫痴迷于细节，却完全失去了对整体构图的把握。瓦萨里在描述这些壁画时写道，如果他继续下去，“我想我会疯掉，并被这幅画缠住，就像我相信雅各布在这十一年里，把自己和所有看到它的人都缠住一样。” 这件作品非但没有成为蓬托尔莫艺术生涯的巅峰之作，反而成了他的致命伤。
These frescoes were visual equivalents of die effects of isolation on die human mind: a loss of proportion, an obsession with detail combined with an inability to see die larger picture, a kind of extravagant ugliness that no longer communicates. Clearly, isolation is as deadly for the creative arts as for die social arts. Shakespeare is die most famous writer in history because, as a dramatist for die popular stage, he opened himself up to die masses, making his work accessible to people no matter what Uieir education and taste. Artists who hole themselves up in their fortress lose a sense of proportion, tiieir work communicating only to dieir small circle. Such art remains cornered and powerless.
这些壁画如同视觉化的表现，反映了隔离对人类心灵的影响：比例失调，对细节的执着却忽略了整体，最终呈现出一种不再具有感染力的浮夸丑陋。显然，隔离对创意艺术和社交艺术都同样致命。莎士比亚之所以成为历史上最著名的作家，是因为作为一位面向大众的戏剧家，他向大众敞开了大门，使他的作品能够被不同教育背景和品味的人所理解。而那些把自己封闭在堡垒中的艺术家则失去了对比例的把握，他们的作品只能与自己的小圈子产生共鸣。这样的艺术最终只会陷入孤立和无力的境地。
Finally, since power is a human creation, it is inevitably increased by contact with other people. Instead of falling into the fortress mentality, view die world in die following manner: It is like a vast Versailles, with every room communicating with anotiier. You need to be permeable, able to float in and out of different circles and mix witfi different types. That kind of mobility and social contact will protect you from plotters, who will be unable to keep secrets from you, and from your enemies, who will be unable to isolate you from your allies. Always on the move, you mix and mingle in die rooms of die palace, never sitting or settling in one place. No hunter can fix his aim on such a swift-moving creature.
最后，权力是人类创造的，因此必然会因与他人接触而增强。与其陷入堡垒心态，不如这样看待世界：它就像一座巨大的凡尔赛宫，每个房间都与其他房间相连。你需要保持开放的心态，能够自由穿梭于不同的圈子，与形形色色的人交往。这种流动性和社交能力将保护你免受阴谋者的侵害，因为他们无法对你保守秘密；也能保护你免受敌人的攻击，因为他们无法将你与盟友隔离开来。你始终保持移动，在宫殿的各个房间里穿梭往来，从不停留在一处。任何猎人都无法瞄准这样行动敏捷的生物。
Image: The Fortress. High up on the hill, the citadel becomes a symbol of all that is hateful in power and authority. The citizens of the town betray you to the first enemy that comes. Cut off from communication and intelligence, the citadel falls with ease.
图片：要塞。高耸于山顶的城堡，象征着一切令人憎恶的权力与权威。城里的居民会背叛你，投靠第一个来犯之敌。与外界失去联系和情报后，城堡轻易陷落。
Authority: A good and wise prince, desirous of maintaining that character, and to avoid giving the opportunity to his sons to become oppressive, will never build fortresses, so that they may place their reliance upon the good will of meir subjects, and not upon the strength of citadels. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：一位贤明君主，为了维护自身品格，避免子嗣有机会作恶，绝不会建造堡垒，以免依赖臣民的善意，而非坚固的城堡。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
It is hardly ever right and propitious to choose isolation. Without keeping an ear on what is happening in the streets, you will be unable to protect yourself. About the only thing that constant human contact cannot facilitate is thought. The weight of society's pressure to conform, and die lack of distance from other people, can make it impossible to think clearly about what is going on around you. As a temporary recourse, men, isolation can help you to gain perspective. Many a serious thinker has been produced in prisons, where we have nothing to do but think. Machiavelli could write The Prince only once he found himself in exile and isolated on a farm far from the political intrigues of Florence.
选择孤立几乎从来都不是明智之举。如果不留意街头巷尾发生的事情，你将无法保护自己。持续不断的人际交往几乎唯一无法促进的就是思考。社会强加的顺从压力，以及与他人缺乏距离感，都可能使人难以清晰地思考周遭发生的一切。然而，作为一种暂时的应对方式，孤立或许能帮助你获得更广阔的视野。许多严肃的思想家都诞生于监狱之中，在那里，除了思考别无他事可做。马基雅维利只有在被流放并隐居于远离佛罗伦萨政治阴谋的农场之后，才能写出《君主论》。
The danger is, however, that mis kind of isolation will sire all kinds of strange and perverted ideas. You may gain perspective on the larger picture, but you lose a sense of your own smallness and limitations. Also, the more isolated you are, the harder it is to break out of your isolation when you choose toit sinks you deep into its quicksand without your noticing. If you need time to think, then, choose isolation only as a last resort, and only in small doses. Be careful to keep your way back into society open.
然而，危险在于，这种过度的孤立会滋生各种怪异甚至扭曲的想法。你或许能更全面地看待问题，但却会丧失对自身渺小和局限的认知。此外，你越是孤立，就越难挣脱，它会在你不知不觉中将你拖入流沙深处。如果你需要时间思考，那么，只有在万不得已的情况下才选择孤立，而且时间要短。务必时刻保持与社会的联系。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 19
第19条
KNOW WHO YOU'RE
了解你自己
DEALING WITH
处理
DO NOT OFFEND THE
不要冒犯
WRONG PERSON
找错人了
JUDGMENT
判断
There are many different kinds of people in the world, and you can never assume that everyone will react to your strategies in the same way. Deceive or outmaneuver some people and they will spend the rest of their lives seeking revenge. They are wolves in lambs' clothing. Choose your victims and opponents carefully, thennever offend or deceive the wrong person.
世上形形色色的人都有，你永远不能想当然地认为每个人都会对你的策略做出同样的反应。如果你欺骗或智胜了某些人，他们会终生都在寻求报复。他们是披着羊皮的狼。务必谨慎选择你的目标和对手，永远不要得罪或欺骗不该得罪的人。
When you meet a
当你遇到
swordsman, draw your
剑士，拔出你的
sword: Do not recite
剑：不要背诵
poetry to one who is
献给一位
not a poet.
我不是诗人。
From a Ch'an
来自禅宗
Buddhist classic,
佛教经典，
quoted in
引自
thunder in the sky,
天空雷鸣，
translated by
译者
Thomas Cleary, 1993
Thomas Cleary，1993年
OPPONENTS, SUCKERS, AND VICTIMS: Preliminary Typology In your rise to power you will come across many breeds of opponent, sucker, and victim. The highest form of the art of power is the ability to distinguish the wolves from die lambs, the foxes from die hares, the hawks from die vultures. If you make diis distinction well, you will succeed widi-out needing to coerce anyone too much. But if you deal blindly with whomever crosses your padi, you will have a life of constant sorrow, if you even live tiiat long. Being able to recognize types of people, and to act accordingly, is critical. The following are die five most dangerous and difficult types of mark in the jungle, as identified by artistscon and otherwiseof the past.
对手、傻瓜和受害者：初步类型学 在你步步高升的过程中，你会遇到形形色色的对手、傻瓜和受害者。权力艺术的最高境界在于能够区分狼与羔羊、狐狸与野兔、鹰与秃鹫。如果你能很好地做出这种区分，你就能成功，而无需过多地胁迫任何人。但如果你盲目地对待所有冒犯你的人，你的一生将充满痛苦，甚至可能活不长。能够识别不同类型的人并采取相应的行动至关重要。以下是过去和现在的艺术家们所总结出的五种最危险、最难对付的“丛林目标”。
II IK HK\ K\CK OK
II I HK\ K\CK OK
koi'k nv. \
koi'k nv. \
[Lope de] Aguirre's character is amply illustrated in an anecdote from the. chronicle of Garcilaso de la Vega, who related that in 1548 Aguirre was a member of a platoon of soldiers escorting Indian slaves from the mines at Potosl [Bolivia] to a royal treasury depot. The Indians were illegally burdened with great quantities of silver, and a local official arrested Aguirre, sentencing him to receive two hundred lashes in lieu of a fine for oppressing the Indians. "The soldier Aguirre, having received a notification of the sentence, besought the alcalde that, instead of flogging him, he would put him to death, for that he was a gentleman by birth.... All this had no effect on the alcalde, who ordered the executioner to bring a beast, and execute the sentence. The executioner came to the
洛佩·德·阿吉雷的性格在加尔西拉索·德·拉·维加的编年史中有一则轶事得到了充分的展现。维加记载，1548年，阿吉雷是押送印第安奴隶从玻利维亚波托斯尔矿区前往皇家金库的士兵排的一员。这些印第安人被非法强加了大量白银，当地一名官员逮捕了阿吉雷，并判处他鞭笞两百下，以代替因压迫印第安人而缴纳的罚款。士兵阿吉雷在收到判决通知后，恳求市长不要鞭笞他，而是处死他，因为他出身贵族……然而，这一切对市长毫无作用，他命令刽子手牵来一头牲畜，执行死刑。刽子手来到……
The Arrogant and Proud Man. Although he may initially disguise it, tiiis man's touchy pride makes him very dangerous. Any perceived slight will lead to a vengeance of overwhelming violence. You may say to yourself, “But I only said such-and-such at a party, where everyone was drunk. ...” It does not matter. There is no sanity behind his overreaction, so do not waste time trying to figure him out. If at any point in your dealings with a person you sense an oversensitive and overactive pride, flee. Whatever you are hoping for from him isn't worth it.
傲慢自大的男人。虽然他起初可能掩饰不住，但这种男人的自尊心极其敏感，非常危险。任何轻视都会引发他极其暴力的报复。你或许会想：“我只是在聚会上说了些什么，当时大家都喝醉了……”但这都无济于事。他的过激反应毫无理智可言，所以不要浪费时间试图了解他。如果你在与人交往的过程中，察觉到对方极度敏感且自尊心过强，那就赶紧逃离。你对他抱有任何期望，都得不到回报。
The Hopelessly Insecure Man. This man is related to the proud and arrogant type, but is less violent and harder to spot. His ego is fragile, his sense of self insecure, and if he feels himself deceived or attacked, the hurt will simmer. He will attack you in bites tiiat will take forever to get big enough for you to notice. If you find you have deceived or harmed such a man, disappear for a long time. Do not stay around him or he will nibble you to death.
极度缺乏安全感的男人。这类男人与骄傲自大的类型有些相似，但暴力倾向较轻，也更难察觉。他的自尊心很脆弱，缺乏安全感，一旦感到被欺骗或攻击，这种伤害就会像毒瘤一样慢慢发酵。他会像啃噬一样慢慢地攻击你，这种攻击需要很长时间才能让你察觉。如果你发现自己欺骗或伤害了这样的男人，那就尽快消失一段时间。不要待在他身边，否则他会慢慢地、一点一点地折磨你，直到你崩溃。
Mr. Suspicion. Anotiier variant on the breeds above, this is a future Joe Stalin. He sees what he wants to seeusually the worstin other people, and imagines that everyone is after him. Mr. Suspicion is in fact the least dangerous of the three: Genuinely unbalanced, he is easy to deceive, just as Stalin himself was constandy deceived. Play on his suspicious nature to get him to turn against odier people. But if you do become die target of his suspicions, watch out.
多疑先生。这是上述几种人格类型的另一种变体，堪称未来的斯大林。他总是看到自己想看到的——通常是别人身上最糟糕的一面，并且总觉得所有人都在针对他。事实上，多疑先生是这三种人格类型中最不危险的：他确实有些精神失常，很容易被欺骗，就像斯大林本人也经常被欺骗一样。利用他多疑的本性，让他反过来攻击其他人。但如果你真的成了他怀疑的目标，那就得小心了。
The Serpent with a Long Memory. If hurt or deceived, this man will show no anger on the surface; he will calculate and wait. Then, when he is in a position to turn the tables, he will exact a revenge marked by a coldblooded shrewdness. Recognize this man by his calculation and cunning in the different areas of his life. He is usually cold and unaffectionate. Be doubly careful of this snake, and if you have somehow injured him, either crush him completely or get him out of your sight.
这条蛇记忆力惊人。如果受到伤害或欺骗，他表面上不会表现出愤怒；他会暗中算计，伺机而动。一旦时机成熟，他便会以冷酷狡诈的方式进行报复。要辨认出他，就要看他在生活各个方面是否精于算计、诡计多端。他通常冷漠无情。务必格外小心这条蛇，如果你不小心伤害了他，要么彻底除掉他，要么让他永远消失在你的视线之外。
The Plain, Unassuming, and Often Unintelligent Man. Ah, your ears prick up when you find such a tempting victim. But this man is a lot harder
相貌平平、毫不起眼、甚至有些愚钝的男人。啊，当你发现这样一个诱人的猎物时，你的耳朵肯定会竖起来。但这种男人可比你想象的要难对付得多。
to deceive than you imagine. Falling for a ruse often takes intelligence and imaginationa sense of die possible rewards. The blunt man will not take die bait because he does not recognize it. He is diat unaware. The danger widi this man is not mat he will harm you or seek revenge, but merely that he will waste your time, energy, resources, and even your sanity in trying to deceive him. Have a test ready for a marka joke, a story. If his reaction is utterly literal, this is die type you are dealing with. Continue at your own risk.
比你想象的更难骗。上当受骗往往需要智慧和想象力，以及对潜在回报的预判。直率的人不会上当，因为他根本识破了陷阱。他浑然不觉。这种人的危险之处不在于他会伤害你或报复你，而在于他会浪费你的时间、精力、资源，甚至你的理智，让你白白受骗。准备一些试探性的回应——比如讲个笑话或故事。如果他的反应完全是字面意思，那么你遇到的就是这种人。后果自负。
TRANSGRESSIONS OF THE LAW
违法行为
Transgression I
越轨 I
In the early part of the thirteenth century, Muhammad, the shah of Khwarezm, managed after many wars to forge a huge empire, extending west to present-day Turkey and south to Afghanistan. The empire's center was the great Asian capital of Samarkand. The shah had a powerful, well-trained army, and could mobilize 200,000 warriors within days.
十三世纪初，花剌子模沙阿穆罕默德历经多次战争，建立起一个幅员辽阔的帝国，西至今日土耳其，南至阿富汗。帝国的中心是亚洲的伟大都城撒马尔罕。沙阿拥有一支训练有素的强大军队，能在数日内调动20万兵力。
In 1219 Muhammad received an embassy from a new tribal leader to the east, Genghis Khan. The embassy included all sorts of gifts to the great Muhammad, representing the finest goods from Khan's small but growing Mongol empire. Genghis Khan wanted to reopen die Silk Route to Europe, and offered to share it with Muhammad, while promising peace between the two empires.
1219年，穆罕默德接见了来自东方新晋部落首领成吉思汗的使节。使节们带来了琳琅满目的礼物，代表着成吉思汗当时虽小但日益壮大的蒙古帝国中最上等的商品。成吉思汗希望重新开辟通往欧洲的丝绸之路，并提出与穆罕默德共享这条路线，同时承诺两国和平共处。
Muhammad did not know this upstart from the east, who, it seemed to him, was extremely arrogant to try to talk as an equal to one so clearly his superior. He ignored Khan's offer. Khan tried again: This time he sent a caravan of a hundred camels filled with the rarest articles he had plundered from China. Before the caravan reached Muhammad, however, Inalchik, die governor of a region bordering on Samarkand, seized it for himself, and executed its leaders.
穆罕默德并不认识这个来自东方的暴发户，在他看来，此人竟妄图与地位明显高于自己的人平起平坐，实在狂妄至极。他拒绝了可汗的提议。可汗再次尝试：这次他派出了一支由一百头骆驼组成的商队，里面装满了从中国掠夺来的珍稀物品。然而，在商队抵达穆罕默德之前，撒马尔罕边境地区的总督伊纳尔奇克便将其截获，并处决了商队的首领。
Genghis Khan was sure diat this was a mistakethat Inalchik had acted without Muhammad's approval. He sent yet another mission to Muhammad, reiterating his offer and asking that the governor be punished. This time Muhammad himself had one of the ambassadors beheaded, and sent the other two back with shaved headsa horrifying insult in the Mongol code of honor. Khan sent a message to die shah: “You have chosen war. What will happen will happen, and what it is to be we know not; only God knows.” Mobilizing his forces, in 1220 he attacked Inalchik's province, where he seized the capital, captured the governor, and ordered him executed by having molten silver poured into his eyes and ears.
成吉思汗确信这是个错误，伊纳勒奇克的行动未经穆罕默德的许可。他再次派遣使节前往穆罕默德处，重申他的提议，并要求惩罚这位总督。这一次，穆罕默德亲自下令斩首其中一位使节，并将另外两位剃光头遣送回国——这在蒙古人的荣誉准则中是一种骇人的侮辱。汗向即将赴死的沙阿发出信息：“你选择了战争。未来如何，我们不得而知；唯有真主知晓。”1220年，他集结军队，攻打伊纳勒奇克的领地，攻占了都城，俘虏了总督，并下令将熔化的银子灌入其双眼和双耳处死。
Over the next year, Khan led a series of guerrilla-like campaigns against die shah's much larger army. His metiiod was totally novel for the timehis soldiers could move very fast on horseback, and had mastered the art of firing widi bow and arrow while mounted. The speed and flexibility of his forces allowed him to deceive Muhammad as to his intentions and die directions of his movements. Eventually he managed first to sur-
在接下来的一年里，汗对沙阿人数众多的军队发动了一系列游击战。他的战术在当时是全新的——他的士兵骑马行动迅速，并且精通骑射。他部队的速度和灵活性使他能够迷惑穆罕默德，使其无法判断他的意图和行动方向。最终，他成功地首先……
prison, and put Aguirre on the beast.... The beast was driven on, and he received the lashes. ..." When freed, Aguirre announced his intention of killing the official who had sentenced him, the alcalde Esquivel. Esquivel's term of office expired and he fled to Lima, three hundred twenty leagues away, but within fifteen days Aguirre had tracked him there. The frightened judge journeyed to Quito, a trip of four hundred leagues, and in twenty days Aguirre arrived.
监狱，并将阿吉雷押上牲畜……牲畜被驱赶，他则遭受鞭笞……获释后，阿吉雷宣布他要杀死判他死刑的官员，市长埃斯基韦尔。埃斯基韦尔的任期届满后，逃往三百二十里格外的利马，但阿吉雷在十五天内就追踪到了那里。惊恐万分的法官前往四百里格外远的基多，二十天后，阿吉雷抵达。
“When Esquivel heard of his presence,” according to Garcilaso, “he made another journey of five hundred leagues to Cuzco; but in a few days Aguirre also arrived, having travelled on foot and without shoes, saying that a whipped man has no business to ride a horse, or to go where he would be seen by others. In this way, Aguirre followed his judge for three years, and four months.” Wearying of the pursuit, Esquivel remained at Cuzco, a city so sternly governed that he felt he would be safe from Aguirre. He took a house near the cathedral and never ventured outdoors without a sword and a dagger. "However, on a certain Monday, at noon, Aguirre entered his house, and having walked all over it, and having traversed a corridor, a saloon, a chamber, and an inner
据加尔西拉索记载，“埃斯基韦尔得知阿吉雷的行踪后，又跋涉五百里格来到库斯科；但几天后，阿吉雷也到了，他赤脚步行而来，声称一个被鞭打的人不应该骑马，也不应该去人前。就这样，阿吉雷追随他的法官长达三年零四个月。” 埃斯基韦尔厌倦了追逐，便留在了库斯科。这座城市统治严明，他觉得在那里可以免受阿吉雷的伤害。他在大教堂附近租了一间房子，出门总是佩剑匕首。“然而，在一个星期一的中午，阿吉雷闯进了他的房子，在里面四处走动，穿过走廊、客厅、房间和内室。”
chamber where the
房间
judge kept his books,
法官保留了他的账簿。
he at last found him
他终于找到了他
asleep over one of his
睡着了，压在他其中一个身上
books, and slabbed him
书，然后把他钉在石板上

至死。凶手

然后就出去了，但是
when he came to the
当他来到

他走到房子门口。
found that he had
发现他有
forgotten his hat, and
他忘了戴帽子，
had the temerity to
竟敢如此
return and fetch it, and
返回并取回它，然后
then walked down
然后走下去
the street."
街道。
the golden dream:
金色梦想：
seekers of el dorado,
寻找黄金国的人们，
Walker Chapman,
沃克·查普曼
A troublesome Crow seated herself on the back of a Sheep. The Sheep, much against his will, carried her backward and forward for a long time, and at last said, “If you had treated a dog in this way, you would have had your deserts from his sharp teeth.” To this the Crow replied, "I despise the weak, and yield to the strong. I know whom I may bully, and whom I must flatter; and thus I hope to prolong my life to a good old age.
一只烦人的乌鸦落在了绵羊的背上。绵羊很不情愿地驮着它来回走了很久，最后说道：“如果你这样对待一条狗，它锋利的牙齿会咬死你。”乌鸦回答说：“我鄙视弱者，顺从强者。我知道该欺负谁，该奉承谁；这样我才能长寿。”
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop, sixth century b.c.
伊索，公元前六世纪
round Samarkand, then to seize it. Muhammad fled, and a year later died, his vast empire broken and destroyed. Genghis Khan was sole master of Samarkand, the Silk Route, and most of northern Asia. Interpretation
他先是围攻撒马尔罕，然后攻占了它。穆罕默德逃亡，一年后去世，他庞大的帝国分崩离析。成吉思汗成为撒马尔罕、丝绸之路以及北亚大部分地区的唯一统治者。
Never assume that die person you are dealing with is weaker or less important than you are. Some men are slow to take offense, which may make you misjudge the thickness of their skin, and fail to worry about insulting them. But should you offend their honor and their pride, tiiey will overwhelm you with a violence that seems sudden and extreme given their slowness to anger. If you want to turn people down, it is best to do so politely and respectfully, even if you feel their request is impudent or their offer ridiculous. Never reject them with an insult until you know them better; you may be dealing witii a Genghis Khan.
永远不要想当然地认为你面对的人比你弱小或低人一等。有些人不轻易生气，这可能会让你误判他们的承受能力，从而忽略了冒犯他们的风险。但如果你触怒了他们的荣誉和自尊，他们会以看似突如其来的暴力来反击，这与他们平时不易动怒的性格形成了鲜明的对比。如果你想拒绝别人，最好礼貌而尊重地进行，即使你觉得他们的要求无礼或提议荒谬可笑。在更了解对方之前，千万不要用侮辱性的言语拒绝他们；你可能正在与成吉思汗这样的人物打交道。
Transgression II
越轨 II
In the late 1910s some of the best swindlers in America formed a con-artist ring based in Denver, Colorado. In the winter months they would spread across the southern states, plying their trade. In 1920 Joe Furey, a leader of the ring, was working his way through Texas, making hundreds of thousands of dollars with classic con games. In Fort Worth, he met a sucker named J. Frank Norfleet, a cattleman who owned a large ranch. Norfleet fell for the con. Convinced of die riches to come, he emptied his bank account of $45,000 and handed it over to Furey and his confederates. A few days later they gave him his “millions,” which turned out to be a few good dollars wrapped around a packet of newspaper clippings.
1910年代末，美国一些最厉害的骗子在科罗拉多州丹佛市组成了一个诈骗团伙。每到冬季，他们便会分散到南部各州，继续行骗。1920年，该团伙的头目之一乔·弗雷正在德克萨斯州四处行骗，用经典的骗局骗取了数十万美元。在沃斯堡，他遇到了一个名叫J·弗兰克·诺弗利特的冤大头，诺弗利特是个拥有大型牧场的牧场主。诺弗利特果然上当受骗，被骗得一夜暴富，于是掏空了银行账户里的4.5万美元，交给了弗雷和他的同伙。几天后，他们给了他所谓的“百万财富”，结果发现不过是几张用报纸剪报包起来的钞票而已。
Furey and his men had worked such cons a hundred times before, and the sucker was usually so embarrassed by his gullibility that he quietly learned his lesson and accepted the loss. But Norfleet was not like otiier suckers. He went to die police, who told him there was httle they could do. “Then I'll go after those people myself,” Norfleet told the detectives. “I'll get them, too, if it takes die rest of my life.” His wife took over the ranch as Norfleet scoured the country, looking for others who had been fleeced in the same game. One such sucker came forward, and the two men identified one of the con artists in San Francisco, and managed to get him locked up. The man committed suicide rather tiian face a long term in prison.
弗雷和他的手下以前已经骗过上百次这种人了，那些傻瓜通常都会因为自己的轻信而感到羞愧，默默地吸取教训，接受损失。但诺弗利特和其他傻瓜不一样。他去报警，警察告诉他他们无能为力。“那我就亲自去追捕这些人，”诺弗利特对侦探们说，“就算要花我一辈子，我也要把他们绳之以法。”他的妻子接管了农场，而诺弗利特则在全国各地奔走，寻找其他被骗的人。其中一个傻瓜站了出来，两人在旧金山认出了一名骗子，并成功地将他绳之以法。那人宁愿自杀也不愿面对漫长的牢狱之灾。
Norfleet kept going. He tracked down another of the con artists in Montana, roped him like a calf, and dragged him through die muddy streets to the town jail. He traveled not only across the country but to England, Canada, and Mexico in search of Joe Furey, and also of Furey's right-hand man, W. B. Spencer. Finding Spencer in Montreal, Norfleet chased him through the streets. Spencer escaped but the rancher stayed on his trail and caught up with him in Salt Lake City. Preferring the mercy of the law to Norfleet's wrath, Spencer turned himself in.
诺弗利特继续追查。他在蒙大拿州找到了另一个骗子，像套牛犊一样把他套住，拖着他穿过泥泞的街道，来到镇上的监狱。为了找到乔·弗雷以及弗雷的得力助手W·B·斯宾塞，诺弗利特不仅走遍了美国，还远赴英国、加拿大和墨西哥。在蒙特利尔找到斯宾塞后，诺弗利特在大街上追赶他。斯宾塞逃脱了，但这位牧场主紧追不舍，最终在盐湖城抓住了他。斯宾塞宁愿接受法律的宽恕，也不愿承受诺弗利特的怒火，于是自首了。
Norfleet found Furey in Jacksonville, Florida, and personally hauled him off to face justice in Texas. But he wouldn't stop there: He continued on to Denver, determined to break up the entire ring. Spending not only
诺弗利特在佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔找到了弗雷，并亲自将他押送到德克萨斯州接受审判。但他并没有就此罢休：他继续前往丹佛，决心彻底摧毁整个犯罪团伙。他不仅花费了大量时间，还……
large sums of money but another year of his life in the pursuit, he managed to put all of the con ring's leaders behind bars. Even some he didn't catch had grown so terrified of him that they too turned themselves in.
虽然追回了巨额赃款，但也耗费了他整整一年的时间，他最终成功地将诈骗团伙的所有头目绳之以法。甚至有些他没抓到的人，也因为他的恐惧而自首了。
After five years of hunting, Norfleet had single-handedly destroyed the country's largest confederation of con artists. The effort bankrupted him and ruined his marriage, but he died a satisfied man. Interpretation
经过五年的追捕，诺弗利特单枪匹马摧毁了全国最大的骗子联盟。这场行动让他破产，婚姻破裂，但他死时心满意足。
Most men accept the humiliation of being conned with a sense of resignation. They learn their lesson, recognizing that there is no such thing as a free lunch, and that they have usually been brought down by their own greed for easy money. Some, however, refuse to take their medicine. Instead of reflecting on their own gullibility and avarice, they see themselves as totally innocent victims.
大多数男人被骗后都会带着一种无奈的认命感接受羞辱。他们吸取教训，明白天下没有免费的午餐，而他们通常是被自己贪婪的欲望所害。然而，有些人却拒绝接受教训。他们不去反思自己的轻信和贪婪，反而把自己视为完全无辜的受害者。
Men like this may seem to be crusaders for justice and honesty, but they are actually immoderately insecure. Being fooled, being conned, has activated their self-doubt, and they are desperate to repair the damage. Were the mortgage on Norfleet's ranch, the collapse of his marriage, and the years of borrowing money and living in cheap hotels worth his revenge over his embarrassment at being fleeced To the Norfleets of the world, overcoming their embarrassment is worth any price.
像这样的男人表面上似乎是正义和诚实的捍卫者，但实际上却极度缺乏安全感。被愚弄、被欺骗，激发了他们的自我怀疑，他们迫切地想要弥补损失。诺弗利特为了报复被骗的耻辱，甘愿付出牧场的抵押贷款、婚姻的破裂，以及多年来借钱度日、住在廉价旅馆的代价，真的值得吗？对像诺弗利特这样的人来说，克服耻辱的代价是任何代价都值得的。
All people have insecurities, and often the best way to deceive a sucker is to play upon his insecurities. But in the realm of power, everything is a question of degree, and the person who is decidedly more insecure than the average mortal presents great dangers. Be warned: If you practice deception or trickery of any sort, study your mark well. Some people's insecurity and ego fragility cannot tolerate the slightest offense. To see if you are dealing with such a type, test them firstmake, say, a mild joke at their expense. A confident person will laugh; an overly insecure one will react as if personally insulted. If you suspect you are dealing with this type, find another victim.
人人都有不安全感，而欺骗傻瓜的最佳方法往往就是利用他们的不安全感。但在权力领域，一切都取决于程度，那些明显比常人缺乏安全感的人会带来极大的危险。切记：如果你要使用任何形式的欺骗或诡计，务必仔细观察你的目标。有些人极度缺乏安全感，自尊心极弱，容不得丝毫冒犯。要判断你是否遇到了这类人，可以先试探一下，比如开个玩笑。自信的人会一笑置之；而极度缺乏安全感的人则会像受到了侮辱一样反应激烈。如果你怀疑自己遇到了这类人，那就去找另一个目标吧。
Transgression III
越轨三
In the fifth century B.C., Ch'ung-erh, the prince of Ch'in (in present-day China), had been forced into exile. He lived modesdyeven, sometimes, in povertywaiting for the time when he could return home and resume his princely life. Once he was passing through the state of Cheng, where the ruler, not knowing who he was, treated him rudely. The ruler's minister, Shu Chan, saw this and said, “This man is a worthy prince. May Your Highness treat him with great courtesy and thereby place him under an obligation!” But the ruler, able to see only the prince's lowly station, ignored this advice and insulted the prince again. Shu Chan again warned his master, saying, “If Your Highness cannot treat Ch'ung-erh with courtesy, you should put him to death, to avoid calamity in the future.” The ruler only scoffed.
公元前五世纪，秦王（今中国境内）冲锋陷阵，被迫流亡。他生活简朴，有时甚至贫困潦倒，只盼望着重返故土，重拾昔日王室荣华。一次，他途经成国，成国君主不知其身份，对他十分无礼。成国臣舒禅见状，劝道：“此人乃是尊贵的王子，陛下务必以礼相待，以致他欠下陛下一份恩情！”然而成国君主只见王子身份卑微，置若罔闻，再次羞辱了他。舒禅再次劝诫陛下：“陛下若不能以礼相待冲锋，就当处死他，以免日后祸患。”成国君主却嗤之以鼻。
Years later, the prince was finally able to return home, his circumstances gready changed. He did not forget who had been kind to him, and
多年后，王子终于得以返回故乡，他的境遇也发生了翻天覆地的变化。他没有忘记那些曾善待他的人，并且
who had been insolent, during his years of poverty. Least of all did he forget his treatment at the hands of the ruler of Cheng. At his first opportunity he assembled a vast army and marched on Cheng, taking eight cities, destroying the kingdom, and sending the ruler into an exile of his own. Interpretation
他曾在贫困潦倒之时傲慢无礼，更没有忘记成国君主对他的种种不公待遇。一有机会，他就集结大军，进军成国，攻克八城，摧毁成国，并将成国君主流放。
You can never be sure who you are dealing with. A man who is of littie importance and means today can be a person of power tomorrow. We forget a lot in our lives, but we rarely forget an insult.
你永远无法确定你面对的是谁。今天一个微不足道、没什么地位的人，明天可能就成了权势人物。我们一生中会忘记很多事，但我们很少会忘记别人对我们说的侮辱。
How was me ruler of Cheng to know that Prince Ch'ung-erh was an ambitious, calculating, cunning type, a serpent with a long memory There was really no way for him to know, you may saybut since mere was no way, it would have been better not to tempt the fates by finding out. There is notfiing to be gained by insulting a person unnecessarily. Swallow the impulse to offend, even if the other person seems weak. The satisfaction is meager compared to the danger mat someday he or she will be in a position to hurt you.
我身为成国君主，怎会知晓仲二王乃是野心勃勃、心机深沉、诡计多端之人，一条记忆力惊人的毒蛇？或许有人会说，我实在无从知晓，但既然无从知晓，不如就不要冒险探知，以免招致厄运。无谓的侮辱于事无补，即便对方看似软弱，也应克制住冒犯的冲动。与日后他/她可能反过来伤害你的危险相比，这点得意微不足道。
Transgression IV
第四次违规
The year of 1920 had been a particularly bad one for American art dealers. Big buyersdie robber-baron generation of die previous centurywere getting to an age where they were dying off like flies, and no new millionaires had emerged to take dieir place. Things were so bad diat a number of the major dealers decided to pool their resources, an unheard-of event, since art dealers usually get along like cats and dogs.
1920年对美国艺术品经销商来说尤其糟糕。上世纪那些大买家——也就是所谓的“强盗大亨”一代——逐渐老去，如同苍蝇般纷纷离世，而新的百万富翁却没有出现来填补他们的空缺。情况糟糕到一些主要经销商不得不决定联合起来，这在当时是闻所未闻的，因为艺术品经销商之间通常水火不容。
Joseph Duveen, art dealer to the richest tycoons of America, was suffering more man the others mat year, so he decided to go along with this alliance. The group now consisted of the five biggest dealers in the country. Looking around for a new client, they decided mat their last best hope was Henry Ford, then the wealthiest man in America. Ford had yet to venture into the art market, and he was such a big target that it made sense for them to work togedier.
约瑟夫·杜维恩是美国最富有的商业巨头的艺术品经销商，他去年的境况比其他人都要糟糕，所以他决定加入这个联盟。这个联盟现在由全国五大艺术品经销商组成。为了寻找新的客户，他们决定把最后的希望寄托在当时的美国首富亨利·福特身上。福特尚未涉足艺术市场，而且他是一个如此重要的目标，因此他们决定合作。
The dealers decided to assemble a list, “The 100 Greatest Paintings in me World” (all of which they happened to have in stock), and to offer the lot of them to Ford. With one purchase he could make himself the world's greatest collector. The consortium worked for weeks to produce a magnificent object: a three-volume set of books containing beautiful reproductions of the paintings, as well as scholarly texts accompanying each picture. Next they made a personal visit to Ford at his home in Dearborn, Michigan. There mey were surprised by the simplicity of his house: Mr. Ford was obviously an extremely unaffected man.
经销商们决定列出一份名为“世界百幅最伟大的画作”的清单（碰巧他们店里都有这些画作），并打算全部卖给福特。只要福特买下这些画作，他就能成为世界上最伟大的收藏家。为了完成这项壮举，他们花费数周时间，精心制作了一套三卷本的画册，其中不仅收录了这些画作的精美复制品，还配有每幅画作的学术评述。之后，他们亲自拜访了福特位于密歇根州迪尔伯恩的家。福特家的简朴让他们感到惊讶：福特先生显然是一位极其朴实无华的人。
Ford received them in his study. Looking through the book, he expressed astonishment and delight. The excited dealers began imagining the millions of dollars mat would shortly flow into their coffers. Finally, however, Ford looked up from die book and said, “Gendemen, beautiful books like tiiese, with beautiful colored pictures like these, must cost an awful lot!” “But Mr. Ford!” exclaimed Duveen, "we don't expect you to buy these
福特先生在书房里收到了这些书。他翻阅着书页，脸上露出惊讶和欣喜的神情。兴奋的经销商们开始憧憬着数百万美元即将流入他们的腰包。然而，福特先生最终抬起头，说道：“先生们，像这样精美的书，配上如此漂亮的彩色插图，一定价值不菲吧！”“可是福特先生！”杜维恩先生惊呼道，“我们并不指望您购买这些书。”
books. We got tiiem up especially for you, to show you the pictures. These books are a present to you.“ Ford seemed puzzled. ”Gendemen,“ he said, ”it is extremely nice of you, but I really don't see how I can accept a beautiful, expensive present like mis from strangers.“ Duveen explained to Ford that the reproductions in the books showed paintings mey had hoped to sell to him. Ford finally understood. ”But gendemen,“ he exclaimed, ”what would I want widi die original pictures when the ones right here in these books are so beautiful" Interpretation
“这些书。我们特意抽出时间来给你看这些画。这些书是送给你的礼物。”福特似乎有些困惑。“先生，”他说，“你们真是太好了，但我实在不明白我怎么能接受陌生人送的这么漂亮又昂贵的礼物。”杜维恩向福特解释说，书里的复制品是他原本打算卖给他的画作。福特终于明白了。“可是先生，”他惊呼道，“这些书里的画这么漂亮，我为什么还要原作呢？”
Joseph Duveen prided himself on studying his victims and clients in advance, figuring out dieir weaknesses and die peculiarities of dieir tastes before he ever met diem. He was driven by desperation to drop this tactic just once, in his assault on Henry Ford. It took him mondis to recover from his misjudgment, both mentally and monetarily. Ford was the unassuming plain-man type who just isn't worth the botiier. He was the incarnation of those literal-minded folk who do not possess enough imagination to be deceived. From then on, Duveen saved his energies for the Mellons and Morgans of the worldmen crafty enough for him to entrap in his snares.
约瑟夫·杜维恩以事先研究受害者和客户为傲，在见面之前就能摸清他们的弱点和喜好。然而，在对亨利·福特下手时，他却因绝望而放弃了这一策略。他花了整整一个月才从这次误判中恢复过来，无论是精神上还是经济上。福特只是个毫不起眼的普通人，根本不值得他费心。他正是那种思维僵化、缺乏想象力、容易上当受骗的人的典型代表。从那以后，杜维恩便将精力放在了像梅隆和摩根那样狡猾的世家子弟身上，让他们落入他的圈套。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The ability to measure people and to know who you're dealing with is die most important skill of all in gadiering and conserving power. Without it you are blind: Not only will you offend the wrong people, you will choose the wrong types to work on, and will think you are flattering people when you are actually insulting them. Before embarking on any move, take the measure of your mark or potential opponent. Otiierwise you will waste time and make mistakes. Study people's weaknesses, the chinks in dieir armor, dieir areas of bodi pride and insecurity. Know tiieir ins and outs before you even decide whetiier or not to deal widi diem.
在掌控和维护权力方面，最重要的技能莫过于了解他人，洞悉你的对手。否则，你将如同盲人一般：不仅会得罪不该得罪的人，还会选错目标，甚至自以为是在奉承他人，实则是在侮辱他们。在采取任何行动之前，务必先摸清你的目标或潜在对手的底细。否则，你将浪费时间，犯下错误。研究他人的弱点、防线漏洞、自尊心和不安全感所在。在决定是否与他们打交道之前，务必对他们了如指掌。
Two final words of caution: First, in judging and measuring your opponent, never rely on your instincts. You will make the greatest mistakes of all if you rely on such inexact indicators. Notiiing can substitute for gathering concrete knowledge. Study and spy on your opponent for however long it takes; diis will pay off in die long run.
最后两点忠告：首先，在判断和评估对手时，切勿依赖直觉。依赖这种不准确的指标，你将犯下最大的错误。观察可以代替收集确凿的信息。研究和观察你的对手，无论需要多久；从长远来看，这必将有所回报。
Second, never trust appearances. Anyone widi a serpent's heart can use a show of kindness to cloak it; a person who is blustery on die outside is often really a coward. Learn to see through appearances and their contradictions. Never trust die version that people give of themselvesit is utterly unreliable.
第二，永远不要相信外表。心肠歹毒的人会用和善的外表来掩盖；表面张扬的人往往是懦夫。要学会看穿表象及其矛盾之处。永远不要相信人们展现的自我形象——它完全不可靠。
Image: The Hunter. He does not lay the same trap for a wolf as for a fox. He does not set bait where no one will take it. He knows his prey thoroughly, its habits and hideaways, and hunts accordingly.
图片：猎人。他不会用同样的陷阱去捕狼和捕狐狸。他不会把诱饵放在无人问津的地方。他熟知猎物，了解它们的习性和藏身之处，并据此进行狩猎。
Autiiority: Be convinced, that there are no persons so insignificant and inconsiderable, but may, some time or other, have it in their power to be of use to you; which they certainly will not, if you have once shown them contempt. Wrongs are often forgiven, but contempt never is. Our pride remembers it for ever. (Lord Chesterfield, 1694-1773)
权威：请相信，世上没有哪个微不足道、无关紧要的人，在某个时候，他们或许能够对你有所助益；但如果你曾轻视过他们，他们就绝不会如此。过错往往可以被原谅，但轻视却永远不会。我们的骄傲会永远铭记于心。（切斯特菲尔德勋爵，1694-1773）
REVERSAL
逆转
What possible good can come from ignorance about other people Learn to tell die lions from the lambs or pay the price. Obey this law to its fullest extent; it has no reversaldo not bother looking for one.
对他人一无所知能带来什么好处？学会分辨狮子和羔羊，否则必将付出代价。务必完全遵守这条法则；它没有退路，不要费心寻找退路。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 20
法律 20
DO NOT COMMIT TO ANYONE
不要对任何人做出承诺
JUDGMENT
判断
It is the fool who always rushes to take sides. Do not commit to any side or cause but yourself. By maintaining your independence, you become the master of others playing people against one another, making them pursue you.
愚蠢的人总是急于选边站队。不要效忠于任何一方或任何事业，除了你自己。保持独立，你就能掌控他人，让他们互相争斗，最终让他们追随你。
PART I: DO NOT COMMIT TO ANYONE, BUT BE COURTED BY ALL
第一部分：不要对任何人做出承诺，但要接受所有人的追求
If you allow people to feel they possess you to any degree, you lose all power over them. By not committing your affections, they will only try harder to win you over. Stay aloof and you gain the power that comes from their attention and frustrated desire. Play the Virgin Queen: Give them hope but never satisfaction.
如果你让别人觉得他们能占有你，你就会失去对他们的所有控制权。如果你不投入感情，他们只会更加努力地追求你。保持疏离，你就能从他们的关注和渴望得不到满足中汲取力量。扮演纯洁女王：给他们希望，但绝不让他们得到满足。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
When Queen Elizabeth I ascended the throne of England, in 1558, there was much to-do about her finding a husband. The issue was debated in Parliament, and was a main topic of conversation among Englishmen of all classes; they often disagreed as to whom she should marry, but everyone thought she should marry as soon as possible, for a queen must have a king, and must bear heirs for the kingdom. The debates raged on for years. Meanwhile the most handsome and eligible bachelors in the realmSir Robert Dudley, the Earl of Essex, Sir Walter Raleighvied for Elizabeth's hand. She did not discourage them, but she seemed to be in no hurry, and her hints as to which man might be her favorite often contradicted each other. In 1566, Parliament sent a delegation to Elizabeth urging her to marry before she was too old to bear children. She did not argue, nor did she discourage the delegation, but she remained a virgin nonetheless.
1558年，伊丽莎白一世女王登基成为英格兰王后，她的婚事引发了广泛关注。议会就此展开辩论，各阶层英国人也对此议论纷纷；他们对女王应该嫁给谁意见不一，但所有人都认为她应该尽快结婚，因为女王必须有国王，必须为王国诞下继承人。这场争论持续了数年。与此同时，王国中最英俊潇洒、条件优越的单身汉——罗伯特·达德利爵士、埃塞克斯伯爵、沃尔特·雷利爵士——纷纷向伊丽莎白求婚。她并未拒绝他们，但她似乎并不着急，而且她对心仪之人的暗示也常常自相矛盾。1566年，议会派遣代表团觐见伊丽莎白，敦促她在年老体衰、无法生育之前尽快成家。她没有争辩，也没有劝退代表团，但她仍然是处女。
The delicate game that Elizabeth played with her suitors slowly made her the subject of innumerable sexual fantasies and the object of cultish worship. The court physician, Simon Forman, used his diary to describe his dreams of deflowering her. Painters represented her as Diana and other goddesses. The poet Edmund Spenser a^d others wrote eulogies to the Virgin Queen. She was referred to as "th
伊丽莎白与求婚者们玩弄的微妙游戏，逐渐使她成为无数性幻想的对象，并被奉为狂热崇拜的对象。宫廷御医西蒙·福尔曼在日记中描述了他梦见夺走她贞洁的场景。画家们将她描绘成狄安娜和其他女神。诗人埃德蒙·斯宾塞等人为这位童贞女王撰写了颂词。她被誉为“……
Throughout Europe, kings and princes knew that a marriage with Elizabeth would seal an alliance between England and any nation. The king of Spain wooed her, as did the prince of Sweden and the archduke of Austria. She politely refused them all.
整个欧洲的国王和王子们都知道，与伊丽莎白联姻将巩固英国与任何国家之间的联盟。西班牙国王、瑞典王子和奥地利大公都曾向她求婚，但她都礼貌地拒绝了。
The great diplomatic issue of Elizabeth's day was posed by the revolt of the Flemish and Dutch Lowlands, which were then possessions of Spain. Should England break its alliance with Spain and choose France as its main ally on the Continent, thereby encouraging Flemish and Dutch independence By 1570 it had come to seem that an alliance with France would be England's wisest course. France had two eligible men of noble blood, the dukes of Anjou and Alencon, brothers of the French king. Would either of them marry Elizabeth Both had advantages, and Elizabeth kept the hopes of both alive. The issue simmered for years. The duke of Anjou made sev-
伊丽莎白时代最大的外交难题是弗拉芒和荷兰低地的叛乱，当时这两个地区是西班牙的领地。英国是否应该断绝与西班牙的联盟，转而选择法国作为其在欧洲大陆的主要盟友，从而鼓励弗拉芒和荷兰的独立？到1570年，与法国结盟似乎是英国最明智的选择。法国有两位出身高贵的适婚男子，分别是安茹公爵和阿朗松公爵，他们是法国国王的兄弟。他们之中谁会迎娶伊丽莎白？两人各有优势，伊丽莎白也让两人都抱有希望。这个问题持续了数年。安茹公爵做出了一些……
eral visits to England, kissed Elizabeth in public, even called her by pet names; she appeared to requite his affections. Meanwhile, as she flirted with the two brothers, a treaty was signed that sealed peace between France and England. By 1582 Elizabeth felt she could break off the courtship. In the case of the duke of Anjou in particular, she did so witii great relief: For the sake of diplomacy she had allowed herself to be courted by a man whose presence she could not stand and whom she found physically repulsive. Once peace between France and England was secure, she dropped the unctuous duke as politely as she could.
他多次访问英格兰，在公共场合亲吻伊丽莎白，甚至用昵称称呼她；她似乎也回应了他的爱慕之情。与此同时，在她与两位兄弟调情之际，一份缔结了法英和平条约。到了1582年，伊丽莎白觉得可以结束这段追求了。尤其对于安茹公爵，她如释重负地结束了这段关系：为了外交，她竟然允许自己被一个她无法忍受、外表也令她反感的男人追求。一旦法英和平稳固，她便尽可能礼貌地甩掉了这位谄媚的公爵。
By this time Elizabeth was too old to bear children. She was accordingly able to live the rest of her life as she desired, and she died die Virgin Queen. She left no direct heir, but ruled through a period of incomparable peace and cultural fertility.
此时伊丽莎白已年迈，无法生育。因此，她得以随心所欲地度过余生，最终以“童贞女王”之名去世。她没有留下直系继承人，但她统治时期却是英国历史上无与伦比的和平与文化繁荣时期。
Interpretation
解释
Elizabeth had good reason not to marry: She had witnessed die mistakes of Mary Queen of Scots, her cousin. Resisting the idea of being ruled by a woman, the Scots expected Mary to marry and marry wisely. To wed a foreigner would be unpopular; to favor any particular noble house would open up terrible rivalries. In the end Mary chose Lord Darnley, a Catholic. In doing so she incurred the wrath of Scodand's Protestants, and endless turmoil ensued.
伊丽莎白不愿结婚是有充分理由的：她亲眼目睹了表妹苏格兰女王玛丽犯下的种种错误。苏格兰人不愿接受女性统治，他们期望玛丽结婚，而且必须择偶明智。嫁给外国人会不得人心；偏袒某个贵族家族则会引发可怕的纷争。最终，玛丽选择了天主教徒达恩利勋爵。此举激怒了苏格兰的新教徒，由此引发了无休止的动荡。
Elizabeth knew that marriage can often lead to a female ruler's undoing: By marrying and committing to an alliance widi one party or nation, the queen becomes embroiled in conflicts that are not of her choosing, conflicts which may eventually overwhelm her or lead her into a futile war. Also, die husband becomes the de facto ruler, and often tries to do away with his wife the queen, as Darnley tried to get rid of Mary. Elizabeth learned the lesson well. She had two goals as a ruler: to a oid marriage and to avoid war. She managed to combine these goals by umgling die possibility of marriage in order to forge alliances. The moment she committed to any single suitor would have been the moment she lost her power. She had to emanate mystery and desirability, never discouraging anyone's hopes but never yielding.
伊丽莎白深知婚姻往往会导致女性统治者的垮台：一旦与某个政党或国家结盟，女王便会卷入并非她所愿的冲突，这些冲突最终可能令她不堪重负，或将她拖入一场徒劳的战争。此外，丈夫会成为实际统治者，并常常试图除掉妻子——女王，就像达恩利试图除掉玛丽一样。伊丽莎白对此深有体会。作为统治者，她有两个目标：一是避免婚姻，二是避免战争。她巧妙地将这两个目标结合起来，通过限制婚姻的可能性来缔结联盟。一旦她与任何一位求婚者订婚，她的权力便会丧失殆尽。她必须保持神秘和魅力，既不能让任何人的希望落空，也不能轻易妥协。
Through this lifelong game of flirting and withdrawing, Elizabedi dominated die country and every man who sought to conquer her. As the center of attention, she was in control. Keeping her independence above all, Elizabeth protected her power and made herself an object of worship.
伊丽莎白一生都在玩弄调情与疏离的游戏，以此掌控着整个国家以及所有试图征服她的男人。作为万众瞩目的焦点，她掌控着一切。伊丽莎白始终将独立置于首位，以此巩固自己的权力，并将自己塑造成众人崇拜的对象。
I would rather be a beggar and single than a queen and married.
我宁愿做个乞丐，孤身一人，也不愿做个已婚的女王。
Queen Elizabeth I, 1533-1603
伊丽莎白一世女王，1533-1603年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Since power depends greatly on appearances, you must learn the tricks that will enhance your image. Refusing to commit to a person or group is one of these. When you hold yourself back, you incur not anger but a kind
由于权力很大程度上取决于外表，你必须学会一些能提升自身形象的技巧。拒绝向某人或某个团体做出承诺就是其中之一。当你有所保留时，你招致的不是愤怒，而是一种善意。
of respect. You instantly seem powerful because you make yourself un-graspable, rather than succumbing to the group, or to the relationship, as most people do.
