This aura of power only grows with time: As your reputation for independence grows, more and more people will come to desire you, wanting to be the one who gets you to commit. Desire is like a virus: If we see that someone is desired by other people, we tend to find this person desirable too.
你会赢得尊重。你之所以显得强大，是因为你让自己难以捉摸，而不是像大多数人那样屈服于群体或人际关系。这种强大的气场会随着时间的推移而增强：随着你独立声誉的提升，越来越多的人会渴望得到你，想要成为那个让你做出承诺的人。欲望就像病毒：如果我们看到某人被其他人渴望，我们往往也会觉得这个人很有魅力。
The moment you commit, the magic is gone. You become like everyone else. People will try all kinds of underhanded methods to get you to commit. They will give you gifts, shower you with favors, all to put you under obligation. Encourage the attention, stimulate their interest, but do not commit at any cost. Accept the gifts and favors if you so desire, but be careful to maintain your inner aloofness. You cannot inadvertentiy allow yourself to feel obligated to anyone.
一旦你做出承诺，那种魔力就消失了。你会变得和其他人一样。人们会用尽各种卑鄙的手段让你做出承诺。他们会送你礼物，给你各种好处，让你觉得有义务。你可以接受他们的关注，激发他们的兴趣，但无论如何都不要轻易做出承诺。如果你愿意，可以接受礼物和好处，但要小心保持内心的疏离感。你不能让自己在不知不觉中对任何人产生义务感。
Remember, though: The goal is not to put people off, or to make it seem that you are incapable of commitment. Like the Virgin Queen, you need to stir the pot, excite interest, lure people with the possibility of having you. You have to bend to their attention occasionally, thenbut never too far.
但请记住：你的目标不是吓跑别人，也不是让他们觉得你无法做出承诺。就像伊丽莎白一世的处女女王一样，你需要搅动风云，激发他们的兴趣，用拥有你的可能性来吸引他们。你偶尔需要迎合他们的注意，但绝不能做得太过火。
The Greek soldier and statesman Alcibiades played this game to perfection. It was Alcibiades who inspired and led the massive Athenian armada that invaded Sicily in 414 B.C. When envious Athenians back home tried to bring him down by accusing him of trumped-up charges, he defected to the enemy, the Spartans, instead of facing a trial back home. Then, after the Athenians were defeated at Syracuse, he left Sparta for Persia, even though the power of Sparta was now on the rise. Now, however, both die Athenians and the Spartans courted Alcibiades because of his influence with tile Persians; and the Per tans showered him with honors because of his power over the Athenians and the Spartans. He made promises to every side but committed to none, and in die end he held all the cards.
希腊军事家兼政治家阿尔西比亚德斯将这种博弈玩得炉火纯青。公元前414年，正是他鼓舞并率领庞大的雅典舰队入侵西西里岛。当心怀嫉妒的雅典人试图捏造罪名陷害他时，他却投奔了敌人斯巴达，而不是回到家乡接受审判。后来，雅典在叙拉古战败后，他离开斯巴达前往波斯，尽管此时斯巴达的势力正在崛起。然而，由于阿尔西比亚德斯在波斯的影响力，雅典人和斯巴达人都对他趋之若鹜；而波斯人则因为他对雅典人和斯巴达人的影响力而对他百般讨好。他向各方都许诺，却又对任何一方都不兑现，最终，他掌握了所有主动权。
If you aspire to power and influence, try the Alcibiades tactic: Put yourself in the middle between competing powers. Lure one side with the promise of your help; the other side, always wanting to outdo its enemy, will pursue you as well. As each side vies for your attention, you will immediately seem a person of great influence and desirability. More power will accrue to you than if you had rashly committed to one side. To perfect this tactic you need to keep yourself inwardly free from emotional entanglements, and to view all those around you as pawns in your rise to the top. You cannot let yourself become the lackey for any cause.
如果你渴望权力和影响力，不妨试试阿尔西比亚德斯策略：让自己置身于相互竞争的势力之间。用你的帮助来拉拢一方；另一方总是想胜过敌人，也会反过来追求你。当双方都试图吸引你的注意时，你立刻就会显得极具影响力，令人艳羡。相比草率地投靠一方，你将获得更大的权力。要完美运用这一策略，你需要保持内心的自由，不受任何情感纠葛的束缚，并将身边所有人视为你通往巅峰的棋子。你绝不能让自己沦为任何一方的走狗。
In die midst of die 1968 U.S. presidential election, Henry Kissinger made a phone call to Richard Nixon's team. Kissinger had been allied with Nelson Rockefeller, who had unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination. Now Kissinger offered to supply the Nixon camp with valuable inside information on the negotiations for peace in Vietnam that were then going on in Paris. He had a man on die negotiating team keeping him informed of die latest developments. The Nixon team gladly accepted his offer.
1968年美国总统大选期间，亨利·基辛格给理查德·尼克松的团队打了个电话。基辛格曾与纳尔逊·洛克菲勒结盟，后者曾竞选共和党总统候选人提名但最终落败。如今，基辛格主动提出向尼克松阵营提供有关当时正在巴黎举行的越南和平谈判的宝贵内幕消息。他已安排一名人员在谈判团队中，随时向他汇报最新进展。尼克松团队欣然接受了他的提议。
At the same time, however, Kissinger also approached the Democratic nominee, Hubert Humphrey, and offered his aid. The Humphrey people
然而与此同时，基辛格也接触了民主党候选人休伯特·汉弗莱，并表示愿意提供帮助。汉弗莱的支持者们
asked him for inside information on Nixon and he supplied it. “Look,” Kissinger told Humphrey's people, “I've hated Nixon for years.” In fact he had no interest in either side. What he really wanted was what he got: the promise of a high-level cabinet post from both Nixon and Humphrey. Whichever man won the election, Kissinger's career was secure.
他向汉弗莱索要尼克松的内幕消息，汉弗莱也提供了。“听着，”基辛格对汉弗莱的人说，“我恨尼克松很多年了。” 事实上，他对双方都毫无兴趣。他真正想要的，也是他最终得到的：尼克松和汉弗莱都承诺给他一个内阁要职。无论谁赢得大选，基辛格的政治生涯都稳如磐石。
The winner, of course, was Nixon, and Kissinger duly went on to his cabinet post. Even so, he was careful never to appear too much of a Nixon man. When Nixon was reelected in 1972, men much more loyal to him than Kissinger were fired. Kissinger was also the only Nixon high official to survive Watergate and serve under the next president, Gerald Ford. By maintaining a little distance he thrived in turbulent times.
当然，最终的赢家是尼克松，基辛格也顺理成章地进入了内阁。即便如此，他始终小心翼翼，避免给人留下过于亲尼克松的印象。1972年尼克松连任后，许多比基辛格更忠于尼克松的人都被解职了。基辛格也是尼克松政府时期唯一一位在水门事件后幸存下来，并在下一任总统杰拉尔德·福特手下继续任职的高级官员。正是因为与尼克松保持了一定的距离，他才能在动荡的年代里游刃有余。
Those who use this strategy often notice a strange phenomenon: People who rush to the support of others tend to gain little respect in the process, for their help is so easily obtained, while those who stand back find themselves besieged with supplicants. Their aloofness is powerful, and everyone wants them on their side.
那些运用这种策略的人常常会注意到一个奇怪的现象：那些急于伸出援手的人往往得不到多少尊重，因为他们的帮助太容易得到了；而那些袖手旁观的人却发现自己被无数的求助者包围。他们的疏离感反而更有力量，每个人都想得到他们的支持。
When Picasso, after early years of poverty, had become the most successful artist in the world, he did not commit himself to this dealer or that dealer, although they now besieged him from all sides with attractive offers and grand promises. Instead, he appeared to have no interest in their services; this technique drove them wild, and as they fought over him his prices only rose. When Henry Kissinger, as U.S. secretary of state, wanted to reach detente with the Soviet Union, he made no concessions or conciliatory gestures, but courted China instead. This infuriated and also scared the Sovietsthey were already politica'ly isolated and feared further isolation if the United States and China came together. Kissinger's move pushed them to the negotiating table. The tactic has a parallel in seduction: When you want to seduce a woman, Stendhal advises, court her sister first.
毕加索早年生活贫困，后来成为世界上最成功的艺术家。尽管各路画商纷纷抛出诱人的条件和美好的承诺，他却并未对他们做出任何承诺。相反，他似乎对他们的服务毫无兴趣；这种策略令他们抓狂，他们争相拉拢他，他的作品价格反而水涨船高。亨利·基辛格担任美国国务卿时，为了与苏联缓和关系，没有做出任何让步或和解姿态，而是转而拉拢中国。这激怒了苏联，也令他们感到恐惧——苏联在政治上已经孤立无援，担心如果美国和中国结盟，自己会更加孤立。基辛格的举动迫使苏联坐到了谈判桌前。这种策略与诱惑有异曲同工之妙：司汤达建议，如果你想诱惑一个女人，先去追求她的姐妹。
Stay aloof and people will come to you. It will become a challenge for them to win your affections. As long as you imitate the wise Virgin Queen and stimulate their hopes, you will remain a magnet of attention and desire.
保持矜持，人们自然会来找你。赢得你的芳心将成为他们的挑战。只要你效仿那位睿智的贞洁女王，激发他们的希望，你就会一直吸引着人们的目光和渴望。
Image:
图像：
The Virgin Queen.
童贞女王。
The center of attention,
众人瞩目的焦点，
desire, and worship. Never
欲望和崇拜。绝不
succumbing to one suitor or the
屈服于一位追求者或
other, the Virgin Queen keeps
另一个，童贞女王保持
them all revolving around
它们都围绕着
her like planets, unable to
她就像行星一样，无法……
leave her orbit but never
离开她的轨道，但永远不会
getting any closer
越来越近了
to her.
对她来说。
Authority: Do not commit yourself to anybody or anything, for that is to be a slave, a slave to every man. . . . Above all, keep yourself free of commitments and obligations they are the device of another to get you into his power. . . . (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：不要委身于任何人或任何事，因为那等同于成为奴隶，成为所有人的奴隶……最重要的是，要让自己摆脱一切承诺和义务，因为它们是他人用来控制你的手段……（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
PART II: DO NOT COMMIT TO ANYONE-STAY ABOVE THE FRAY
第二部分：不要对任何人做出承诺——置身事外
Do not let people drag you into their petty fights and squabbles. Seem interested and supportive, but find a way to remain neutral; let others do the fighting while you stand back, watch and wait. When the fighting parties are good and tired they will be ripe for the picking. You can make it a practice, in fact, to stir up quarrels between other people, and then offer to mediate, gaining power as the go-between.
不要让别人把你卷入他们的琐碎争吵中。表现得关心和支持，但要设法保持中立；让别人去争斗，而你则在一旁观察等待。当争斗双方筋疲力尽时，你就可以趁机收割。事实上，你可以把挑拨离间、制造矛盾作为一项惯例，然后主动提出调解，以此作为中间人来获取权力。
The kites and the crows made an agreement among themselves that thev should go halves in everything obtained in the forest. One day thev saw a fox that had been wounded by hunters lying helpless under a tree, and gathered round it. The crows said, “ We will take the upper half of the fox. ” “ Then we will take the lower half,”said the kites. The fox laughed at this, and said, “I always thought the kites were superior in creation to the crows; as such they must get the upper half of my body, of which my head, with the brain and other delicate things in it, forms a portion.” “Oh, yes, that is right, ” said the kites, “we will have that part of the fox. ” “ Not at all, ” said the crows, “we must have it, as already agreed. ” Then a war arose between the rival parties, and a great many fell on both sides, and the remaining few escaped with difficulty. The fox continued there for some days,
风筝和乌鸦之间达成协议，森林里的一切所得都平分。一天，它们看到一只被猎人打伤的狐狸无助地躺在树下，便围了上去。乌鸦说：“我们要狐狸的上半身。”风筝说：“那我们拿下下半身。”狐狸听了哈哈大笑，说：“我一直觉得风筝比乌鸦更聪明，所以他们理应得到我上半身，我的头，连同大脑和其他精妙的器官，都属于上半身的一部分。”风筝说：“哦，对，没错，我们要狐狸的下半身。”乌鸦说：“不行，我们必须得到，就像我们之前说好的那样。”于是，双方爆发了战争，许多人战死沙场，只有少数人艰难逃脱。狐狸在那里待了几天。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In the late fifteenth century, the strongest city-states in ItalyVenice, Florence, Rome, and Milanfound themselves constandy squabbling. Hovering above their struggles were the nations of France and Spain, ready to grab whatever they could from the weakened Italian powers. And trapped in the middle was the small state of Mantua, ruled by the young Duke Gianfrancesco Gonzaga. Mantua was strategically located in northern Italy, and it seemed only a matter of time before one of the powers swallowed it up and it ceased to exist as an independent kingdom.
十五世纪末，意大利最强大的城邦——威尼斯、佛罗伦萨、罗马和米兰——陷入了无休止的争斗。法国和西班牙这两个国家则在暗中虎视眈眈，伺机从日渐衰弱的意大利势力手中攫取一切。而夹在中间的，是年轻的公爵詹弗朗切斯科·贡扎加统治下的曼图亚小国。曼图亚地处意大利北部战略要地，似乎被列强吞并、最终不复存在的只是时间问题。
Gonzaga was a fierce warrior and a skilled commander of troops, and he became a kind of mercenary general for whatever side paid him best. In the year 1490, he married Isabella d'Este, daughter of the ruler of another small Italian duchy, Ferrara. Since he now spent most of his time away fron Mantua, it fell to Isabella to rule in his stead.
贡扎加是一位骁勇善战的战士，也是一位技艺精湛的统帅，他后来成为一名雇佣将领，为出价最高的一方效力。1490年，他与费拉拉公国统治者的女儿伊莎贝拉·德·埃斯特结婚。由于他此后大部分时间都待在曼图亚以外的地方，因此由伊莎贝拉代为执政。
Isabella's first true test as ruler came in 1498, when King Louis XII of France was preparing armies to attack Milan. In their usual perfidious fashion, the Italian states immediately looked for ways to profit from Milan's difficulties. Pope Alexander VI promised not to intervene, thereby giving the French carte blanche. The Venetians signaled mat they would not help Milan, eitiierand in exchange for tiiis, they hoped the French would give them Mantua. The ruler of Milan, Lodovico Sforza, suddenly found himself alone and abandoned. He turned to Isabella d'Este, one of his closest friends (also rumored to be his lover), and begged her to persuade Duke Gonzaga to come to his aid. Isabella tried, but her husband balked, for he saw Sforza's cause as hopeless. And so, in 1499, Louis swooped down on Milan and took it widi ease.
伊莎贝拉作为统治者的第一个真正考验发生在1498年，当时法国国王路易十二正集结军队进攻米兰。意大利各城邦一如既往地阴险狡诈，立即寻找机会从米兰的困境中牟利。教皇亚历山大六世承诺不干预，这实际上是给了法国人一张空白支票。威尼斯人则表示他们不会援助米兰，并希望以此换取法国人将曼图亚割让给他们。米兰统治者洛多维科·斯福尔扎突然发现自己孤立无援。他向自己最亲密的朋友之一（据传也是他的情人）伊莎贝拉·德·埃斯特求助，恳求她劝说贡扎加公爵前来援助。伊莎贝拉尽力了，但她的丈夫却犹豫不决，因为他认为斯福尔扎的处境毫无希望。于是，在1499年，路易十二兵临米兰城下，轻而易举地将其攻陷。
Isabella now faced a dilemma: If she stayed loyal to Lodovico, the French would now move against her. But if, instead, she allied herself with France, she would make enemies elsewhere in Italy, compromising Mantua once Louis eventually withdrew. And if she looked to Venice or Rome for help, they would simply swallow up Mantua under the cloak of coming to her aid. Yet she had to do something. The mighty king of France was breathing down her neck: She decided to befriend him, as she had befriended Lodovico Sforza before himwith alluring gifts, witty, intelligent letters, and the possibility of her company, for Isabella was famous as a woman of incomparable beauty and charm.
伊莎贝拉现在面临一个两难的抉择：如果她继续效忠路德维科，法国人就会对她不利。但如果她转而与法国结盟，就会在意大利其他地方树敌，一旦路易最终撤退，曼图亚的处境也会受到影响。如果她向威尼斯或罗马寻求帮助，他们只会借着援助之名吞并曼图亚。然而，她必须有所行动。强大的法国国王正步步紧逼：她决定与他交好，就像她之前与路德维科·斯福尔扎交好那样——用诱人的礼物、机智睿智的信件以及陪伴来拉拢他，因为伊莎贝拉以其无与伦比的美貌和魅力而闻名。
In 1500 Louis invited Isabella to a great party in Milan to celebrate his victory. Leonardo da Vinci built an enormous mechanical lion for the affair: When die lion opened its mouth, it spewed fresh lilies, the symbols of French royalty. At die party Isabella wore one of her celebrated dresses (she had by far the largest wardrobe of any of the Italian princesses), and just as she had hoped, she charmed and captivated Louis, who ignored all the other ladies vying for his attention. She soon became his constant companion, and in exchange for her friendship he pledged to protect Mantua's independence from Venice.
1500年，路易十四邀请伊莎贝拉前往米兰参加盛大的宴会，庆祝他的胜利。达芬奇为此次盛会打造了一尊巨大的机械狮子：狮子张开嘴时，会喷出象征法国王室的新鲜百合花。宴会上，伊莎贝拉身着她最负盛名的礼服之一（她的衣橱远胜于其他意大利公主），正如她所愿，她魅力四射，令路易十四为之倾倒，他完全无视了其他争相博取他欢心的女士们。伊莎贝拉很快成为路易十四的贴身伴侣，作为回报，路易十四承诺保护曼图亚免受威尼斯的威胁。
As one danger receded, however, another, more worrying one arose, this time from die soudi, in the form of Cesare Borgia. Starting in 1500, Borgia had marched steadily northward, gobbling up all the small kingdoms in his path in the name of his father, Pope Alexander. Isabella understood Cesare perfecdy: He could be neidier trusted nor in any way offended. He had to be cajoled and kept at arm's lengdi. Isabella began by sending him giftsfalcons, prize dogs, perfumes, and dozens of masks, which she knew he always wore when he walked die streets of Rome. She sent messengers widi flattering greetings (aldiough these messengers also acted as her spies). At one point Cesare asked if he could house some troops in Mantua; Isabella managed to dissuade him politely, knowing full well diat once die troops were quartered in die city, they would never leave.
然而，当一个危险消退后，另一个更加令人担忧的危险出现了，这次来自南方，那就是切萨雷·博尔吉亚。从1500年开始，博尔吉亚稳步北上，以其父教皇亚历山大的名义吞并沿途所有的小王国。伊莎贝拉对切萨雷了如指掌：他绝对值得信任，而且绝不会轻易被冒犯。她必须哄骗他，并让他时刻保持警惕。伊莎贝拉首先送他礼物——猎鹰、名贵的猎犬、香水和数十副面具，她知道切萨雷在罗马街头行走时总是戴着这些面具。她派信使送去奉承的问候（尽管这些信使也充当了她的间谍）。有一次，切萨雷请求在曼图亚驻扎一些军队；伊莎贝拉巧妙地婉拒了他，因为她非常清楚，一旦军队驻扎在这座城市，他们就永远不会离开。
Even while Isabella was charming Cesare, she convinced everyone around her to take care never to utter a harsh word about him, since he had spies everywhere and would use the slightest pretext for invasion. When Isabella had a child, she asked Cesare to be the godfather. She even dangled in front of him the possibility of a marriage between her family and his. Somehow it all worked, for although elsewhere he seized everything in his path, he spared Mantua.
伊莎贝拉在迷惑切萨雷的同时，也让身边的人都谨言慎行，不敢说他一句坏话，因为他安插了许多眼线，随时可能以任何借口入侵。伊莎贝拉生下孩子后，请切萨雷做孩子的教父。她甚至还向他抛出了两家联姻的橄榄枝。不知怎的，这一切竟然奏效了。尽管切萨雷在其他地方横行无忌，却唯独放过了曼图亚。
In 1503 Cesare's fadier, Alexander, died, and a few years later the new pope, Julius II, went to war to drive die French troops from Italy. When the ruler of FerraraAlfonso, Isabella's brothersided widi the French, Julius decided to attack and humble him. Once again Isabella found herself in the middle: die pope on one side, the French and her brother on the ouier. She dared not ally herself with either, but to offend either would be equally disastrous. Again she played die double game at which she had become so expert. On die one hand she got her husband Gonzaga to fight for the pope, knowing he would not fight very hard. On the other she let French troops pass through Mantua to come to Ferrara's aid. While she publicly complained that the French had “invaded” her territory, she privately supplied diem with valuable information. To make die invasion plausible to Julius, she even had die French pretend to plunder Mantua. It worked once again: The pope left Mantua alone.
1503年，切萨雷的父亲亚历山大去世。几年后，新任教皇尤利乌斯二世发动战争，意图将法国军队逐出意大利。费拉拉的统治者阿方索，也就是伊莎贝拉的兄弟，与法国结盟，尤利乌斯二世决定进攻并羞辱他。伊莎贝拉再次陷入两难境地：一边是教皇，一边是法国人和她的兄弟。她不敢与任何一方结盟，但得罪任何一方都将带来同样灾难性的后果。她再次施展了她早已炉火纯青的两面派伎俩。一方面，她让丈夫贡扎加为教皇而战，因为她知道他不会全力以赴。另一方面，她允许法国军队通过曼图亚前去支援费拉拉。她公开指责法国人“入侵”了她的领土，私下里却向他们提供了宝贵的情报。为了让尤利乌斯二世相信入侵的真相，她甚至让法国人假装洗劫了曼图亚。这招再次奏效：教皇放过了曼图亚。
In 1513, after a lengdiy siege, Julius defeated Ferrara, and die French troops withdrew. Worn out by the effort, the pope died a few montiis later. Widi his death, the nightmarish cycle of batties and petty squabbles began to repeat itself.
1513年，经过漫长的围攻，尤利乌斯一世击败了费拉拉，法军撤退。教皇因精疲力竭，几个月后去世。他死后，那场噩梦般的争吵和琐碎的争执又开始重演。
leisurely feeding on the dead kites and crows, and then left the place hale and hearty, observing, “The weak benefit by the quarrels of the mighty.”
他悠闲地享用着死去的鸢和乌鸦，然后精神抖擞地离开了那里，说道：“弱者因强者的争斗而受益。”
INDIAN FABLES
印度寓言
Men of great abilities are slow to act, for it is easier to avoid occasions for committing yourself than to come well out of a commitment. Such occasions test your judgment; it is safer to avoid them than to emerge victorious from them. One obligation leads to a greater one, and you come very near to the brink of disaster.
真正有能力的人往往行动迟缓，因为避免承担责任远比从责任中全身而退容易得多。这样的机会考验着你的判断力；与其从中凯旋，不如避而远之。一项责任往往会引出更大的责任，让你几乎濒临灾难的边缘。
Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
THE EAGLE AND THE SOW
老鹰与母猪
An eagle built a nest on a tree, and hatched out some eaglets. And a wild sow brought her litter under the tree. The eagle used to fly off after her prey, and bring it back to her young. And the sow rooted around the tree and hunted in the woods, and when night came she would bring her young something to eat. And the eagle and the sow lived in neighborly fashion. And a grimalkin laid her plans to destroy the eaglets and the little sucking pigs. She went to the eagle, and said: “Eagle, you had better not fly very far away. Beware of the sow; she is planning an evil design. She is going to undermine the roots of the tree. You see she is rooting all the time.” Then the grimalkin went to the sow and said: “Sow, you have not a good neighbor. Last evening I heard the eagle saying to her eaglets: 'My dear little eaglets, I am going to treat you to a nice little pig. Just as soon as the sow is gone, I will bring you a little young sucking pig.'” From that time the eagle ceased to fly out after prey, and the sow did not go any more into the forest. The eaglets and the young pigs perished of starvation, and grimalkin feasted on them.
一只鹰在树上筑巢，孵出了几只小鹰。一头野猪把她的幼崽带到树下。鹰常常飞去追逐猎物，然后带回来喂幼崽。野猪在树周围拱土觅食，在树林里打猎，到了晚上就给幼崽带些吃的。鹰和野猪相处融洽。后来，一只小精灵密谋要除掉小鹰和小猪。她走到鹰跟前说：“鹰啊，你最好别飞太远。小心那头野猪，她正在策划一个邪恶的阴谋。她要破坏树根。你看，她一直在拱土。”于是，小精灵走到母猪跟前说：“母猪，你的邻居可不好。昨晚我听到老鹰对它的雏鹰们说：‘亲爱的小雏鹰们，我要给你们带一头美味的小猪。等母猪走了，我就给你们带回一头乳猪。’”从此以后，老鹰不再飞出去捕猎，母猪也不再进森林了。雏鹰和小猪们都饿死了，小精灵们把它们都吃了。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Leo Tolstoy, 1828-1910
列夫·托尔斯泰，1828-1910
A great deal changed in Italy during Isabella's reign: Popes came and went, Cesare Borgia rose and then fell, Venice lost its empire, Milan was invaded, Florence fell into decline, and Rome was sacked by die Hapsburg Emperor Charles V. Through all this, tiny Mantua not only survived but thrived, its court die envy of Italy. Its weakh and sovereignty would remain intact for a century after Isabella's death, in 1539.
伊莎贝拉统治时期，意大利发生了翻天覆地的变化：教皇更迭，切萨雷·博尔吉亚崛起又陨落，威尼斯失去了帝国，米兰遭到入侵，佛罗伦萨走向衰落，罗马则被哈布斯堡王朝的查理五世洗劫一空。然而，在这一切动荡之中，小小的曼图亚不仅幸存下来，而且蓬勃发展，其宫廷令整个意大利艳羡不已。在伊莎贝拉于1539年去世后，曼图亚的国力和主权又保持了近一个世纪之久。
Interpretation
解释
Isabella d'Este understood Italy's political situation with amazing clarity: Once you took the side of any of the forces in the field, you were doomed. The powerful would take you over, the weak would wear you down. Any new alliance would lead to a new enemy, and as this cycle stirred up more conflict, odier forces would be dragged in, until you could no longer extricate yourself. Eventually you would collapse from exhaustion.
伊莎贝拉·德斯特对意大利的政治局势有着惊人的洞察力：一旦你选择站在任何一方，你就注定要失败。强者会吞并你，弱者会拖垮你。任何新的联盟都会带来新的敌人，而随着这种循环不断加剧冲突，更多邪恶势力会被卷入其中，直到你再也无法脱身。最终，你会因精疲力竭而崩溃。
Isabella steered her kingdom on the only course that would bring her safely through. She would not allow herself to lose her head through loyalty to a duke or a king. Nor would she try to stop the conflict that raged around herthat would only drag her into it. And in any case the conflict was to her advantage. If the various parties were fighting to the death, and exhausting tiiemselves in the process, they were in no position to gobble up Mantua. The source of Isabella's power was her clever ability to seem interested in the affairs and interests of each side, while actually committing to no one but herself and her kingdom.
伊莎贝拉带领她的王国走上了唯一能让她安然度过难关的道路。她不会因为效忠某个公爵或国王而丢掉性命。她也不会试图阻止席卷而来的冲突，因为那只会将她卷入其中。而且，无论如何，这场冲突对她都是有利的。如果各方都拼死抵抗，耗尽自身，他们就无力吞并曼图亚。伊莎贝拉力量的源泉在于她巧妙地展现出对各方事务和利益的关注，而实际上她只忠于自己和她的王国。
Once you step into a fight that is not of your own choosing, you lose all initiative. The combatants' interests become your interests; you become tiieir tool. Learn to control yourself, to restrain your natural tendency to take sides and join the fight. Be friendly and charming to each of the combatants, then step back as tiiey collide. With every battle tiiey grow weaker, while you grow stronger widi every battle you avoid.
一旦你卷入一场并非出于自愿的争斗，你就会失去所有主动权。交战双方的利益就会变成你的利益；你会沦为他们的工具。学会控制自己，克制你天生的偏袒一方、加入战斗的冲动。对每位交战者都保持友好和魅力，然后在他们发生冲突时退后一步。每一次战斗都会让你变得更弱，而每一次避免战斗都会让你变得更强。
When the snipe and the mussel struggle, the fisherman gets the benefit.
当鹬和贻贝搏斗时，渔夫就获利了。
Ancient Chinese saying
中国古代谚语
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
To succeed in the game of power, you have to master your emotions. But even if you succeed in gaining such self-control, you can never control die temperamental dispositions of those around you. And tiiis presents a great danger. Most people operate in a whirlpool of emotions, constantiy reacting, churning up squabbles and conflicts. Your self-control and autonomy will only bother and infuriate them. They will try to draw you into die whirlpool, begging you to take sides in tiieir endless battles, or to make peace for them. If you succumb to their emotional entreaties, little by little you will find your mind and time occupied by their problems. Do not allow whatever compassion and pity you possess to suck you in. You can never win in tiiis game; die conflicts can only multiply.
要想在权力游戏中获胜，你必须掌控自己的情绪。但即便你成功做到了这一点，你也永远无法控制周围人的脾气。而这恰恰蕴藏着巨大的危险。大多数人身处情绪的漩涡之中，不断地做出反应，挑起争吵和冲突。你的自制和自主只会让他们感到恼火和愤怒。他们会试图把你拉入漩涡，恳求你在他们无休止的争斗中站队，或者替他们调解。如果你屈服于他们的情感恳求，你的心思和时间就会逐渐被他们的问题占据。不要让你的同情心和怜悯心把你卷入其中。在这场游戏中，你永远无法获胜；冲突只会愈演愈烈。
On the other hand, you cannot completely stand aside, for diat would
另一方面，你也不能完全置身事外，因为迪亚特会
cause needless offense. To play the game properly, you must seem interested in other people's problems, even sometimes appear to take their side. But while you make outward gestures of support, you must maintain your inner energy and sanity by keeping your emotions disengaged. No matter how hard people try to pull you in, never let your interest in tiieir affairs and petty squabbles go beyond the surface. Give them gifts, listen wim a sympathetic look, even occasionally play the charmerbut inwardly keep both the friendly kings and the perfidious Borgias at arm's length. By refusing to commit and thus maintaining your autonomy you retain the initiative: Your moves stay matters of your own choosing, not defensive reactions to the push-and-pull of those around you.
避免不必要的冒犯。要想玩好这场游戏，你必须表现得对别人的问题感兴趣，甚至有时要站在他们一边。但当你做出表面上的支持姿态时，你必须保持内心的平静和理智，让自己的情绪保持抽离。无论别人如何努力拉拢你，都不要让你的关心流于表面，不要让他们的琐事和争吵超出你的掌控。送他们礼物，用同情的眼神倾听，甚至偶尔展现你的魅力，但内心要与那些友善的国王和阴险的博尔吉亚家族都保持距离。通过拒绝承诺，从而保持你的自主性，你就能掌握主动权：你的行动始终由你自己选择，而不是对周围人拉扯的被动反应。
Slowness to pick up your weapons can be a weapon itself, especially if you let other people exhaust themselves fighting, then take advantage of their exhaustion. In ancient China, the kingdom of Chin once invaded the kingdom of Hsing. Huan, the ruler of a nearby province, thought he should rush to Hsing's defense, but his adviser counseled him to wait: “Hsing is not yet going to ruin,” he said, “and Chin is not yet exhausted. If Chin is not exhausted, [we] cannot become very influential. Moreover, the merit of supporting a state in danger is not as great as the virtue of reviving a ruined one.” The adviser's argument won the day, and as he had predicted, Huan later had the glory bodi of rescuing Hsing from the brink of destruction and then of conquering an exhausted Chin. He stayed out of the fighting until the forces engaged in it had worn each other down, at which point it was safe for him to intervene.
迟迟不肯拿起武器本身也是一种武器，尤其是在让对手耗尽体力之后，再趁虚而入。在中国古代，秦国曾入侵兴国。邻近省份的统治者桓认为应该立即出兵支援兴国，但他的谋士劝他等待：“兴国尚未灭亡，”谋士说，“秦国也尚未筋疲力竭。秦国若不疲乏，我们便无法大展拳脚。而且，援助危难之国的功德远不及复兴衰败之国。”谋士的劝说最终占了上风，正如他所预言的那样，桓后来功勋卓著，先是拯救了濒临灭亡的兴国，随后又征服了疲惫不堪的秦国。他一直置身事外，直到交战双方都消耗殆尽，此时他才介入。
That is what holding back from the fray allows you: time to position yourself to take advantage of the situation once one side starts to lose. You can also take the game a step further, by promising your support to both sides in a conflict while maneuvering so that the one to come out ahead in the struggle is you. This was what Castruccio Castracani, ruler of the Italian town of Lucca in the fourteenth century, did when he had designs on the town of Pistoia. A siege would have been expensive, costing both lives and money, but Castruccio knew that Pistoia contained two rival factions, the Blacks and the Whites, which hated one another. He negotiated with die Blacks, promising to help mem against the Whites; then, without their knowledge, he promised the Whites he would help them against the Blacks. And Castruccio kept his promiseshe sent an army to a Black-controlled gate to the city, which the sentries of course welcomed in. Meanwhile another of his armies entered through a White-controlled gate. The two armies united in the middle, occupied the town, killed the leaders of both factions, ended die internal war, and took Pistoia for Castruccio.
这就是置身事外的好处：让你有时间伺机而动，一旦一方开始落败，便可趁机占据上风。你还可以更进一步，承诺支持冲突双方，同时巧妙周旋，最终确保自己在这场斗争中胜出。十四世纪意大利卢卡城的统治者卡斯特鲁乔·卡斯特拉卡尼就曾这样做过，当时他觊觎皮斯托亚城。围城代价高昂，不仅会造成人员伤亡，还会耗费大量金钱，但卡斯特鲁乔深知皮斯托亚城内有两个敌对派系——黑党和白党，他们彼此仇恨。他先与黑党谈判，承诺帮助他们对抗白党；然后，在黑党不知情的情况下，他又向白党承诺会帮助他们对抗黑党。卡斯特鲁乔信守承诺——他派出一支军队前往黑党控制的城门，守卫们自然欣然应允。与此同时，他的另一支军队则从白党控制的城门进入了城内。两军在中部会合，占领了该城，杀死了双方的首领，结束了内战，并为卡斯特鲁乔夺取了皮斯托亚。
Preserving your autonomy gives you options when people come to blowsyou can play the mediator, broker the peace, while really securing your own interests. You can pledge support to one side and the other may have to court you with a higher bid. Or, like Castruccio, you can appear to take bodi sides, then play the antagonists against each odier.
保持自主性能让你在冲突爆发时拥有更多选择——你可以扮演调解人的角色，促成和平，同时真正维护自身利益。你可以公开支持一方，迫使另一方提高条件来拉拢你。或者，像卡斯特鲁乔那样，你可以表面上支持双方，然后利用敌对双方互相攻击。
Oftentimes when a conflict breaks out, you are tempted to side with the stronger party, or the one that offers you apparent advantages in an al-
很多时候，当冲突爆发时，人们会倾向于站在更强大的一方，或者站在那些在表面上能给你带来优势的一方。
I'HE PRICE OF ENVY
嫉妒的代价
While a poor woman stood in the marketplace selling cheeses, a cat came along and carried off a cheese. A dog saw the pilferer and tried to take the cheese away from him. The cat stood up to the dog. So they pitched into each other. The dog barked and snapped; the cat spat and scratched, but they could bring the battle to no decision. “Let's go to the fox and have him referee the matter,” the cat finally suggested.
一位贫穷的妇人在集市上卖奶酪时，一只猫走过来叼走了一块奶酪。一只狗看见了偷奶酪的家伙，也想抢回来。猫和狗对峙起来，于是它们扭打起来。狗狂吠撕咬，猫则吐口水、抓挠，但它们始终无法分出胜负。“不如去找狐狸来当裁判吧。”猫最后提议道。
“Agreed,” said the dog. So they went to the fox. The fox listened to their arguments with a judicious air.
“同意，”狗说。于是他们去找狐狸。狐狸一副深思熟虑的样子，听他们争论起来。
“Foolish animals,” he chided them, “why carry on like that If both of you are willing, I'll divide the cheese in two and you'll both be satisfied.”
“愚蠢的畜生，”他斥责道，“为什么还要这样呢？如果你们两个都愿意，我就把奶酪分成两份，你们两个都会满意的。”
“Agreed,” said the cat and the dog. So the fox took out his knife and cut the cheese in two, but, instead of cutting it lengthwise, he cut it in the width. “My half is smaller!” protested the dog. The fox looked judiciously through his spectacles at the dog's share.
“同意，”猫和狗异口同声地说。于是狐狸拿出刀，把奶酪切成两半，但他没有纵向切，而是横向切了。“我的那份更少！”狗抗议道。狐狸透过眼镜，仔细地打量着狗那份。
“You're right, quite right!” he decided. So he went and bit off a piece of the cat's share.
“你说得对，完全正确！”他心想。于是，他去咬了一口猫分到的那份食物。
“That will make it even!” he said. When the cat saw what the fox did she began to yowl:
“这样就扯平了！”他说。猫看到狐狸的举动，开始嚎叫起来：
"Just look! My part's
“瞧！我的部分是……”
smaller now!"
现在更小了！
The fox again put on
狐狸又装扮起来
his spectacles and
他的眼镜和
looked judiciously at
仔细地看了看
the cat's share.
猫的那份。
“Right you are!” said
“你说得对！”
the fox. "Just a
狐狸。“只是一只
moment, and I'll make
片刻之后，我会……
it right."
没错。
And he went and bit
然后他就去咬了
off a piece from the
从一块
dog's cheese
狗奶酪
This went on so long,
这件事持续了很久，
with the fox nibbling
狐狸啃咬着
first at the dog's and
首先是狗和
then at the cat's share,
然后是猫的那份，
that he finally ate up
他最后把东西都吃光了。
the whole cheese before
整个奶酪之前
their eyes.
他们的眼睛。
A TREASURY OH JEWISH I'OLKLORt,
犹太宝库
Nathan Ausubel, ed., 1948
Nathan Ausubel 编辑，1948 年
liance. This is risky business. First, it is often difficult to foresee which side will prevail in the long run. But even if you guess right and ally yourself with the stronger party, you may find yourself swallowed up and lost, or conveniendy forgotten, when they become victors. Side with the weaker, on the other hand, and you are doomed. But play a waiting game and you cannot lose.
结盟。这是一场冒险之举。首先，往往很难预料哪一方最终会胜出。即便你猜对了，与强势一方结盟，当他们最终获胜时，你也可能发现自己被吞噬、被遗忘，或者被有意无意地遗忘。反之，与弱者结盟，你则注定失败。但如果你采取观望策略，你就不会输。
In France's July Revolution of 1830, after three days of riots, the statesman Talleyrand, now elderly, sat by his Paris window, listening to the pealing bells that signaled the riots were over. Turning to an assistant, he said, “Ah, the bells! We're winning.” “Who's 'we,' mon prince” the assistant asked. Gesturing for the man to keep quiet, Talleyrand replied, “Not a word! I'll tell you who we are tomorrow.” He well knew that only fools rush into a situationthat by committing too quickly you lose your maneuverability. People also respect you less: Perhaps tomorrow, they think, you will commit to another, different cause, since you gave yourself so easily to this one. Good fortune is a fickle god and will often pass from one side to the other. Commitment to one side deprives you of the advantage of time and the luxury of waiting. Let others fall in love with this group or that; for your part don't rush in, don't lose your head.
1830年法国七月革命期间，骚乱持续三天后，年迈的政治家塔列朗坐在巴黎的窗边，聆听着宣告骚乱结束的钟声。他转向一位助手，说道：“啊，钟声！我们赢了。”“‘我们’指的是谁，我的亲王？”助手问道。塔列朗示意他安静，回答道：“别说话！明天我会告诉你我们是谁。”他深知，只有傻瓜才会贸然行事，过早地投入其中会失去回旋余地。人们也会因此对你失去尊重：他们会想，既然你如此轻易地投身于此，或许明天你就会投身于另一个不同的事业。好运如变幻莫测的神，常常在双方之间摇摆不定。一旦投身于一方，你就失去了时间的优势和等待的余地。让别人去爱上这个团体或那个团体吧；你这边不要贸然行事，不要失去理智。
Finally, there are occasions when it is wisest to drop all pretence of appearing supportive and instead to trumpet your independence and self-reliance. The aristocratic pose of independence is particularly important for those who need to gain respect. George Washington recognized this in his work to establish the young American republic on firm ground. As president, Washington avoided the temptation of making an alliance with France or England, despite the pressure on him to do so. He wanted the country to earn the world's respect through its independence. Although a treaty with France might have helped in the short term, in the long run he knew it would be more effective to establish the nation's autonomy. Europe would have to see the United States as an equal power.
最后，有些时候，最明智的做法是放弃一切假装支持的态度，转而高调宣扬自己的独立和自力更生。这种高贵的独立姿态对于那些需要赢得尊重的人来说尤为重要。乔治·华盛顿深谙此道，他致力于为年轻的美利坚共和国奠定坚实的基础。作为总统，尽管面临巨大的压力，华盛顿仍然抵制与法国或英国结盟的诱惑。他希望美国通过独立赢得世界的尊重。虽然与法国缔结条约或许在短期内有所帮助，但他深知，从长远来看，确立国家的自主权才是更有效的策略。欧洲必须将美国视为一个平等的强国。
Remember: You have only so much energy and so much time. Every moment wasted on the affairs of others subtracts from your strength. You may be afraid that people will condemn you as heartless, but in the end, maintaining your independence and self-reliance will gain you more respect and place you in a position of power from which you can choose to help others on your own initiative.
记住：你的精力和时间都是有限的。浪费在别人的事情上的每一刻都会消耗你的力量。你或许害怕别人会指责你冷酷无情，但最终，保持独立和自立会为你赢得更多尊重，让你拥有更大的自主权，从而主动选择帮助他人。
Image: A Thicket of Shrubs. In the forest, one shrub latches on to another, entangling its neighbor with its thorns, the thicket slowly extending its impenetrable domain. Only what keeps its distance and stands apart can grow and rise above the thicket.
图片：灌木丛。在森林里，一株灌木紧紧依附在另一株灌木上，用尖刺缠绕着邻近的植株，灌木丛缓缓扩张，形成难以逾越的领地。只有那些保持距离、特立独行的植物才能在灌木丛中生长，最终脱颖而出。
Authority: Regard it as more courageous not to become involved in an engagement than to win in battle, and where there is already one interfering fool, take care that there shall not be two. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：与其赢得战争，不如不卷入冲突，这样才更勇敢；如果已经有一个多管闲事的蠢人，那就不要再有两个了。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
Both parts of this law will turn against you if you take it too far. The game proposed here is delicate and difficult. If you play too many parties against one another, they will see through the maneuver and will gang up on you. If you keep your growing number of suitors waiting too long, you will inspire not desire but distrust. People will start to lose interest. Eventually you may find it worthwhile to commit to one sideif only for appearances' sake, to prove you are capable of attachment.
这条法则的两面性若运用过头，最终都会反噬自身。这里提出的策略微妙而艰难。如果你挑拨离间，让太多人互相争斗，他们会识破你的伎俩，并联合起来对付你。如果你让越来越多的追求者苦等太久，你激起的不是渴望，而是猜忌。人们会逐渐失去兴趣。最终，你或许会发现，为了面子，为了证明自己有能力投入感情，选择支持其中一方是值得的。
Even men, however, the key will be to maintain your inner independenceto keep yourself from getting emotionally involved. Preserve the unspoken option of being able to leave at any moment and reclaim your freedom if the side you are allied with starts to collapse. The friends you made while you were being courted will give you plenty of places to go once you jump ship.
即使是男人，关键也在于保持内心的独立，避免陷入情感纠葛。要保留随时离开的选项，一旦盟友开始瓦解，你就能重获自由。在被追求期间结交的朋友，在你脱离阵营后会为你提供许多去处。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 21
第21条
PLAY A SUCKER TO CATCH
玩弄傻瓜以抓住
A SUCKERSEEM DUMBER
一个傻瓜看起来更蠢
THAN YOUR MARK
比你的标记
JUDGMENT
判断
No one likes feeling stupider than the next person. The
没有人喜欢觉得自己比别人笨。
trick, then, is to make your victims feel smartand not
因此，诀窍在于让你的受害者觉得自己很聪明，而不是……
just smart, but smarter than you are. Once convinced of
他只是聪明，但比你聪明。一旦确信
this, they will never suspect that you may have ulterior
这样，他们永远不会怀疑你可能另有所图。
motives.
动机。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In the winter of 1872, the U.S. financier Asbury Harpending was visiting London when he received a cable: A diamond mine had been discovered in the American West. The cable came from a reliable sourceWilliam Ralston, owner of the Bank of Californiabut Harpending nevertheless took it as a practical joke, probably inspired by the recent discovery of huge diamond mines in South Africa. True, when reports had first come in of gold being discovered in the western United States, everyone had been skeptical, and those had turned out to be true. But a diamond mine in the West! Harpending showed the cable to his fellow financier Baron Rothschild (one of the richest men in the world), saying it must be a joke. The baron, however, replied, “Don't be too sure about that. America is a very large country. It has furnished the world with many surprises already. Perhaps it has others in store.” Harpending prompdy took the first ship back to the States.
1872年冬，美国金融家阿斯伯里·哈彭丁正在伦敦访问，期间收到一份电报：美国西部发现了一座钻石矿。电报来自可靠的消息来源——加利福尼亚银行的老板威廉·拉尔斯顿，但哈彭丁仍然认为这是一个恶作剧，很可能是受到了近期南非发现巨型钻石矿的启发。的确，当初美国西部发现黄金的消息传来时，所有人都持怀疑态度，而事实证明那些消息是真的。但是，西部竟然发现了钻石矿！哈彭丁把电报拿给他的金融界同行罗斯柴尔德男爵（当时世界上最富有的人之一）看，说这一定是开玩笑。然而，男爵却回答说：“别太肯定。美国是一个幅员辽阔的国家，它已经给世界带来了许多惊喜，或许它还会给我们带来更多惊喜。”哈彭丁立刻搭乘第一班船返回美国。
When Harpending reached San Francisco, tiiere was an excitement in the air recalling the Gold Rush days of the late 1840s. Two crusty prospectors named Philip Arnold and John Slack had been the ones to find the diamond mine. They had not divulged its location, in Wyoming, but had led a highly respected mining expert to it several weeks back, taking a circular route so he could not guess his whereabouts. Once there, the expert had watched as die miners dug up diamonds. Back in San Francisco the expert had taken die gems to various jewelers, one of whom had estimated tfieir worth at $1.5 million.
当哈彭丁抵达旧金山时，空气中弥漫着一股令人兴奋的气息，让人回想起19世纪40年代末的淘金热时期。两位名叫菲利普·阿诺德和约翰·斯莱克的脾气古怪的探矿者发现了钻石矿。他们没有透露矿址的具体位置（位于怀俄明州），而是在几周前带领一位备受尊敬的采矿专家前往那里，并绕了一条弯路，以免专家猜到他们的位置。到达矿址后，专家亲眼目睹了矿工们挖掘钻石的过程。回到旧金山后，专家将这些钻石带给不同的珠宝商，其中一位估价为150万美元。
Harpending and Ralston now asked Arnold and Slack to accompany them back to New York, where the jeweler Charles Tiffany would verify the original estimates. The prospectors responded uneasilythey smelled a trap: How could tiiey trust diese city slickers What if Tiffany and the financiers managed to steal die whole mine out from under them Ralston tried to allay their fears by giving them $100,000 and placing another $300,000 in escrow for them. If the deal went through, they would be paid an additional $300,000. The miners agreed.
哈彭丁和拉尔斯顿邀请阿诺德和斯莱克陪同他们返回纽约，珠宝商查尔斯·蒂芙尼将在那里核实最初的估价。探矿者们感到不安，他们嗅到了陷阱的味道：他们怎么能相信这些城里人？万一蒂芙尼和那些金融家设法把整个矿都骗走了怎么办？拉尔斯顿试图消除他们的疑虑，给了他们10万美元，并为他们存入30万美元的第三方托管账户。如果交易成功，他们将额外获得30万美元。矿工们同意了。
The litde group traveled to New York, where a meeting was held at die mansion of Samuel L. Barlow. The cream of the city's aristocracy was in attendanceGeneral George Brinton McClellan, commander of the Union forces in the Civil War; General Benjamin Buder; Horace Greeley, editor of the newspaper the New York Tribune; Harpending; Ralston; and Tiffany. Only Slack and Arnold were missingas tourists in the city, they had decided to go sight-seeing.
小团体前往纽约，在塞缪尔·L·巴洛的宅邸举行了一次会议。城中名流云集，包括南北战争时期联邦军总司令乔治·布林顿·麦克莱伦将军、本杰明·布德将军、《纽约论坛报》主编霍勒斯·格里利、哈彭丁、拉尔斯顿和蒂芙尼。只有斯莱克和阿诺德缺席，因为他们是游客，决定去观光游览。
When Tiffany announced diat the gems were real and worth a fortune, the financiers could barely control dieir excitement. They wired Roth-schild and other tycoons to tell them about the diamond mine and inviting them to share in the investment. At the same time, they also told the prospectors that they wanted one more test: They insisted tiiat a mining expert of their choosing accompany Slack and Arnold to the site to verify its weahh. The prospectors reluctandy agreed. In the meantime, diey said,
当蒂芙尼宣布这些宝石是真的，而且价值连城时，金融家们几乎无法抑制内心的激动。他们立即致电罗斯柴尔德家族和其他商业巨头，告知他们钻石矿的情况，并邀请他们参与投资。与此同时，他们也告诉勘探者们，他们想要进行一项额外的测试：他们坚持要一位由他们指定的采矿专家陪同斯莱克和阿诺德前往矿址，以验证其价值。勘探者们勉强同意了。与此同时，他们说，
Now, there is nothing of which a man is prouder than of intellectual ability, for it is this that gives him his commanding place in the animal world. It is an exceedingly rash thing to let anyone see that you are decidedly superior to him in this respect, and to let other people see it too.... Hence, while rank and riches may always reckon upon deferential treatment in society, that is something which intellectual ability can never expect: To be ignored is the greatest favour shown to it; and if people notice it at all, it is because they regard it as a piece of impertinence, or else as something to which its possessor has no legitimate right, and upon which he dares to pride himself; and in retaliation and revenge for his conduct, people secretly try and humiliate him in some other way; and if they wait to do this, it is only for a fitting opportunity. A man may be as humble as possible in his demeanour, and yet hardly ever get people to overlook his crime in standing intellectually above them. In the Garden of Roses, Sadi makes the remark: “You should know that foolish people are a hundredfold more averse to meeting the wise than the wise are indisposed for the company of the foolish.”
如今，没有什么比智力更能使人引以为傲，因为正是智力赋予了人在动物世界中至高无上的地位。让别人看出你在这方面明显胜过他人，甚至让其他人也看出这一点，都是极其鲁莽的行为……因此，尽管地位和财富总能换来社会上的恭敬，但智力却永远无法得到这种待遇：被忽视是对智力最大的恩惠；如果人们注意到智力，那是因为他们认为这是一种傲慢无礼的行为，或者认为智力拥有者没有正当的权利，却还敢以此为傲；为了报复这种行为，人们会在暗中想方设法羞辱他；如果他们有所保留，那也只是在等待一个合适的时机。一个人即便举止谦逊，也很难让人忽视他智力超群的事实。在《玫瑰园》中，萨迪说道：“你应该知道，愚人比智者更不愿意与愚人交往，愚人比智者更不愿意与愚人交往。”
On the other hand, it is a real recommendation to be stupid. For just as warmth is agreeable to the body, so it does the mind good to feel its superiority; and a man will seek company likely to give him this feeling, as instinctively as he will approach the fireplace or walk in the sun if he wants to get warm. But this means that he will be disliked on account of his superiority; and if a man is to be liked, he must really be inferior in point of intellect.
另一方面，愚蠢其实是一种真正的建议。正如温暖对身体有益一样，感受到优越感对心灵也有好处；人会本能地寻找能让他产生这种感觉的人，就像他想要取暖时会靠近壁炉或沐浴阳光一样。但这也就意味着他会因为这种优越感而招人厌恶；而如果一个人想要受人喜欢，他的智力就必须真正落后于人。
Arthur
亚瑟
schopeniiauhr,
schopeniiauhr,
1788-1860
they had to return to San Francisco. The jewels that Tiffany had examined they left with Harpending for safekeeping.
他们不得不返回旧金山。蒂芙尼鉴定过的珠宝，他们留给了哈彭丁保管。
Several weeks later, a man named Louis Janin, the best mining expert in the country, met the prospectors in San Francisco. Janin was a born skeptic who was determined to make sure that the mine was not a fraud. Accompanying Janin were Harpending, and several other interested financiers. As with the previous expert, the prospectors led the team through a complex series of canyons, completely confusing them as to their whereabouts. Arriving at the site, the financiers watched in amazement as Janin dug the area up, leveling anthills, turning over boulders, and finding emeralds, rubies, sapphires, and most of all diamonds. The dig lasted eight days, and by the end, Janin was convinced: He told the investors that they now possessed the richest field in mining history. “With a hundred men and proper machinery,” he told them, “I would guarantee to send out one million dollars in diamonds every thirty days.”
几周后，一位名叫路易斯·贾宁的男子——当时全国最顶尖的采矿专家——在旧金山与探矿者们会面。贾宁天生是个怀疑论者，他决心要确认这座矿山并非骗局。陪同贾宁前来的还有哈彭丁和其他几位感兴趣的投资人。和之前的专家一样，探矿者们带领贾宁一行人穿过一系列错综复杂的峡谷，让他们完全摸不着头脑。到达矿址后，投资人们惊奇地看着贾宁挖掘这片区域，夷平蚁丘，翻动巨石，并发现了祖母绿、红宝石、蓝宝石，尤其是钻石。挖掘工作持续了八天，最终，贾宁确信无疑：他告诉投资者们，他们现在拥有了采矿史上最富有的矿藏。“只要有100个人和合适的机械，”他告诉他们，“我保证每30天就能产出价值100万美元的钻石。”
Returning to San Francisco a few days later, Ralston, Harpending, and company acted fast to form a $10 million corporation of private investors. First, however, they had to get rid of Arnold and Slack. That meant hiding their excitementthey certainly did not want to reveal the field's real value. So they played possum. Who knows if Janin is right, they told the prospectors, the mine may not be as rich as we think. This just made the prospectors angry. Trying a different tactic, the financiers told the two men that if they insisted on having shares in the mine, they would end up being fleeced by the unscrupulous tycoons and investors who would run the corporation; better, they said, to take the $700,000 already offeredan enormous sum at the timeand put their greed aside. This the prospectors seemed to understand, and they finally agreed to take the money, in return signing the rights to the site over to the financiers, and leaving maps to it.
几天后，拉尔斯顿、哈彭丁等人回到旧金山，迅速行动，组建了一家由私人投资者组成的价值1000万美元的公司。然而，首先他们必须摆脱阿诺德和斯莱克。这意味着他们必须掩饰内心的兴奋——他们当然不想透露矿区的真实价值。于是，他们装作若无其事。他们告诉勘探者们，谁知道贾宁的说法是否正确，矿藏可能并没有我们想象的那么丰富。这番话激怒了勘探者们。于是，投资人换了一种策略，告诉两人，如果他们坚持要持有矿区的股份，最终会被那些经营公司的无良大亨和投资者榨取钱财；他们说，最好还是接受已经提供的70万美元——在当时这是一笔巨款——并放下贪婪。勘探者们似乎理解了这一点，最终同意接受这笔钱，作为交换，他们将矿区的所有权转让给了投资人，并留下了矿区的地图。
News of the mine spread like wildfire. Prospectors fanned out across Wyoming. Meanwhile Harpending and group began spending the millions they had collected from their investors, buying equipment, hiring the best men in the business, and furnishing luxurious offices in New York and San Francisco.
矿场的消息迅速传开，淘金者们蜂拥而至，涌向怀俄明州各地。与此同时，哈彭丁及其团伙开始挥霍从投资者那里筹集到的数百万美元，购买设备，聘请业内顶尖人才，并在纽约和旧金山购置豪华办公室。
A few weeks later, on their first trip back to the site, they learned the hard trutii: Not a single diamond or ruby was to be found. It was all a fake. They were ruined. Harpending had unwittingly lured the richest men in the world into the biggest scam of the century.
几周后，当他们第一次重返矿址时，他们得知了残酷的真相：一颗钻石或红宝石都没找到。一切都是赝品。他们彻底破产了。哈彭丁无意中将世界上最富有的人骗入了本世纪最大的骗局。
Interpretation
解释
Arnold and Slack pulled off their stupendous con not by using a fake engineer or bribing Tiffany: All of the experts had been real. All of them honestly believed in the existence of the mine and in the value of the gems. What had fooled them all was nothing else than Arnold and Slack themselves. The two men seemed to be such rubes, such hayseeds, so naive, that no one for an instant had believed them capable of an audacious scam. The prospectors had simply observed the law of appearing more stupid than the markthe deceiver's First Commandment.
阿诺德和斯莱克之所以能成功实施这场惊天骗局，并非依靠假工程师或贿赂蒂芙尼：所有所谓的专家都是货真价实的。他们都真心相信矿藏的存在以及宝石的价值。真正骗过所有人的，正是阿诺德和斯莱克自己。这两个人看起来如此愚笨，如此天真，以至于没有人会相信他们能策划出如此大胆的骗局。这两个淘金者只是遵循了“装傻充愣”的法则——骗子的第一法则。
The logistics of the con were quite simple. Months before Arnold and Slack announced the “discovery” of the diamond mine, they traveled to Europe, where they purchased some real gems for around $12,000 (part of the money they had saved from their days as gold miners). They then salted the “mine” with these gems, which the first expert dug up and brought to San Francisco. The jewelers who had appraised these stones, including Tiffany himself, had gotten caught up in the fever and had grossly overestimated their value. Then Ralston gave the prospectors $100,000 as security, and immediately after their trip to New York they simply went to Amsterdam, where they bought sacks of uncut gems, before returning to San Francisco. The second time they salted the mine, there were many more jewels to be found.
骗局的后勤安排非常简单。在阿诺德和斯莱克宣布“发现”钻石矿的几个月前，他们前往欧洲，花费大约12000美元（这是他们以前当金矿工人攒下的积蓄的一部分）购买了一些真正的宝石。然后，他们把这些宝石藏在“矿井”里，由第一位专家挖出来带回旧金山。包括蒂芙尼在内的珠宝商们，都受到了这股热潮的影响，严重高估了这些宝石的价值。之后，拉尔斯顿给了这两位“探矿者”10万美元作为担保，他们刚结束纽约之行就去了阿姆斯特丹，在那里购买了成袋的未切割宝石，然后返回旧金山。第二次在“矿井”里放置宝石时，人们发现的宝石数量更多了。
The effectiveness of the scheme, however, rested not on tricks like these but on the fact that Arnold and Slack played their parts to perfection. On their trip to New York, where they mingled with millionaires and tycoons, they played up their clodhopper image, wearing pants and coats a size or two too small and acting incredulous at everything they saw in the big city. No one believed that these country simpletons could possibly be conning the most devious, unscrupulous financiers of the time. And once Harpending, Ralston, and even Rothschild accepted the mine's existence, anyone who doubted it was questioning the intelligence of the world's most successful businessmen.
然而，这个计划的成功并非依赖于这些花招，而是阿诺德和斯莱克完美地扮演了自己的角色。在纽约之行中，他们与百万富翁和商业巨头们觥筹交错，刻意装出一副乡巴佬的模样，穿着小一两号的裤子和外套，对大都市里的一切都表现得难以置信。没有人相信这两个乡巴佬竟然能骗过当时最狡猾、最不择手段的金融家。一旦哈彭丁、拉尔斯顿，甚至罗斯柴尔德都接受了矿山的存在，任何对此表示怀疑的人，都是在质疑世界上最成功的商人的智商。
In the end, Harpending's reputation was ruined and he never recovered; Rothschild learned his lesson and never fell for another con; Slack took his money and disappeared from view, never to be found. Arnold simply went home to Kentucky. After all, his sale of his mining rights had been legitimate; the buyers had taken the best advice, and if the mine had run out of diamonds, that was their problem. Arnold used the money to greatly enlarge his farm and open up a bank of his own.
最终，哈彭丁的名誉扫地，一蹶不振；罗斯柴尔德吸取了教训，从此不再上当受骗；斯莱克卷款潜逃，从此杳无音信。阿诺德则径直回到了肯塔基州的家。毕竟，他出售采矿权是合法的；买家听取了最佳建议，如果矿场钻石枯竭，那是他们的问题。阿诺德用这笔钱大幅扩建了自己的农场，并开办了自己的银行。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The feeling that someone else is more intelligent than we are is almost intolerable. We usually try to justify it in different ways: “He only has book knowledge, whereas I have real knowledge.” “Her parents paid for her to get a good education. If my parents had had as much money, if I had been as privileged.. . .” “He's not as smart as he thinks.” Last but not least: “She may know her narrow little field better than I do, but beyond that she's really not smart at all. Even Einstein was a boob outside physics.”
感觉别人比自己聪明几乎令人难以忍受。我们通常会用各种理由来为自己辩解：“他只有书本知识，而我拥有真正的知识。”“她父母花钱让她接受了良好的教育。如果我父母有那么多钱，如果我有那么好的条件……”“他没他自己想的那么聪明。”最后，还有一种说法是：“她或许比我更了解她那狭小的领域，但除此之外，她其实一点也不聪明。即使是爱因斯坦，在物理学之外也是个笨蛋。”
Given how important the idea of intelligence is to most people's vanity, it is critical never inadvertendy to insult or impugn a person's brain power. That is an unforgivable sin. But if you can make this iron rule work for you, it opens up all sorts of avenues of deception. Subliminally reassure people that they are more intelligent than you are, or even that you are a bit of a moron, and you can run rings around them. The feeling of intellectual superiority you give them will disarm their suspicion-muscles.
鉴于智力对大多数人的虚荣心至关重要，因此切勿无意中侮辱或贬低他人的智力。这是一种不可饶恕的罪过。但如果你能巧妙地运用这条铁律，就能开辟出各种各样的欺骗途径。潜移默化地让别人觉得他们比你聪明，甚至让你觉得自己有点笨，你就能轻松戏耍他们。你给予他们的智力优越感会消除他们的疑虑。
In 1865 the Prussian councillor Otto von Bismarck wanted Austria to
1865年，普鲁士顾问奥托·冯·俾斯麦希望奥地利……
sign a certain treaty. The treaty was totally in the interests of Prussia and against the interests of Austria, and Bismarck would have to strategize to get the Austrians to agree to it. But the Austrian negotiator, Count Blome, was an avid cardplayer. His particular game was quinze, and he often said mat he could judge a man's character by the way he played quinze. Bismarck knew of tiiis saying of Blome's.
签署某项条约。该条约完全符合普鲁士的利益，而损害奥地利的利益，俾斯麦必须制定策略才能让奥地利人同意。但奥地利谈判代表布洛姆伯爵是一位狂热的纸牌爱好者。他尤其擅长玩十五点牌，而且他常说，他能从一个人玩十五点牌的水平来判断他的品格。俾斯麦知道布洛姆的这句名言。
The night before the negotiations were to begin, Bismarck innocendy engaged Blome in a game of quinze. The Prussian would later write, “That was the very last time I ever played quinze. I played so recklessly that everyone was astonished. I lost several diousand talers [the currency of the time], but I succeeded in fooling [Blome], for he believed me to be more venturesome than I am and I gave way.” Besides appearing reckless, Bismarck also played the widess fool, saying ridiculous tilings and bumbling about with a surplus of nervous energy.
谈判开始前夜，俾斯麦天真地与布洛姆玩起了五点棋。这位普鲁士人后来写道：“那是我最后一次玩五点棋。我下得如此鲁莽，令所有人都大吃一惊。我输掉了几千塔勒（当时的货币），但我成功地骗过了布洛姆，因为他以为我比实际更胆大，结果我输了。”除了表现得鲁莽之外，俾斯麦还装得像个傻瓜，说着荒唐的格子，笨手笨脚地走来走去，显得异常兴奋。
All this made Blome feel he had gathered valuable information. He knew mat Bismarck was aggressivethe Prussian already had that reputation, and the way he played had confirmed it. And aggressive men, Blome knew, can be foolish And rash. Accordingly, when the time came to sign the treaty, Blome thought he had the advantage. A heedless fool like Bismarck, he thought, is incapable of cold-blooded calculation and deception, so he only glanced at the treaty before signing ithe failed to read the fine print. As soon as the ink was dry, a joyous Bismarck exclaimed in his face, “Well, I could never have believed that I should find an Austrian diplomat willing to sign that document!”
这一切让布洛姆觉得他收集到了宝贵的信息。他知道俾斯麦好斗——普鲁士人早已臭名昭著，而俾斯麦的行事作风也印证了这一点。布洛姆知道，好斗的人往往愚蠢鲁莽。因此，到了签署条约的时候，布洛姆认为自己占了上风。他心想，像俾斯麦这样粗心大意的傻瓜，根本不可能进行冷酷的算计和欺骗，所以他只是匆匆扫了一眼条约就签字了——根本没看清细条。墨迹刚干，俾斯麦就得意洋洋地冲着他喊道：“哎呀，我做梦都没想到居然能找到一个愿意签这份文件的奥地利外交官！”
The Chinese have a phrase, “Masquerading as a swine to kill the tiger.” This refers to an ancient hunting technique in which the hunter clothes himself in the hide and snout of a pig, and mimics its grunting. The mighty tiger thinks a pig is coming his way, and lets it get close, savoring the prospect of an easy meal. But it is the hunter who has the last laugh.
中国有句谚语叫“以猪杀虎”。这指的是一种古老的狩猎技巧：猎人披上猪皮，戴上猪鼻子，模仿猪的叫声。强大的老虎会以为是猪来了，便会靠近，满心期待着一顿美餐。但最终笑到最后的却是猎人。
Masquerading as a swine works wonders on those who, like tigers, are arrogant and overconfident: The easier they think it is to prey on you, the more easily you can turn the tables. This trick is also useful if you are ambitious yet find yourself low in the hierarchy: Appearing less intelligent than you are, even a bit of a fool, is the perfect disguise. Look like a harmless pig and no one will believe you harbor dangerous ambitions. They may even promote you since you seem so likable, and subservient. Claudius before he became emperor of Rome, and the prince of France who later became Louis XIII, used this tactic when those above them suspected they might have designs on the dirone. By playing die fool as young men, diey were left alone. When the time came for them to strike, and to act with vigor and decisiveness, they caught everyone off-guard.
对于那些像老虎一样傲慢自大的人来说，伪装成猪的伎俩简直妙不可言：他们越觉得容易对付你，你就越容易扭转乾坤。如果你野心勃勃却身居低位，这招也同样有效：装作不如实际聪明，甚至有点傻气，都是完美的伪装。看起来像一头无害的猪，没人会相信你怀有危险的野心。他们甚至可能因为你看起来如此讨人喜欢、如此顺从而提拔你。克劳狄乌斯在成为罗马皇帝之前，以及后来的法国王子路易十三，都曾用过这招，以防上级怀疑他们心怀不轨。年轻时，他们装傻充愣，无人过问。等到时机成熟，他们果断出击，出其不意地让所有人措手不及。
Intelligence is the obvious quality to downplay, but why stop there Taste and sophistication rank close to intelligence on die vanity scale; make people feel they are more sophisticated tiian you are and dieir guard will come down. As Arnold and Slack knew, an air of complete naivete can work wonders. Those fancy financiers were laughing at diem behind their
智力显然应该被轻描淡写，但为什么止步于此呢？品味和老练在虚荣心排行榜上与智力不相上下；让人们觉得他们比你更有品位，他们的戒备心就会降低。正如阿诺德和斯莱克所知，装出一副天真无邪的样子也能创造奇迹。那些自命不凡的金融家们在背后嘲笑着他们。
backs, but who laughed loudest in the end In general, men, always make people believe they are smarter and more sophisticated than you are. They will keep you around because you make them feel better about themselves, and the longer you are around, the more opportunities you will have to deceive them.
最终谁笑得最响？总的来说，男人总是要让别人觉得他们比你更聪明、更老练。他们会把你留在身边，因为你让他们感觉良好，而你待得越久，就越有机会欺骗他们。
Image:
图像：
The Opossum. In playing
负鼠。玩耍中
dead, the opossum plays stupid.
死后，负鼠装傻。
Many a predator has therefore left it
因此，许多捕食者都离开了这里。
alone. Who could believe that such an
孤身一人。谁会相信这样的事？
ugly, unintelligent, nervous little creature
丑陋、愚笨、神经质的小家伙
could be capable of such deception
可能具备这种欺骗能力
Authority: Know how to make use of stupidity: The wisest man plays this card at times. There are occasions when the highest wisdom consists in appearing not to knowyou must not be ignorant but capable of playing it. It is not much good being wise among fools and sane among lunatics. He who poses as a fool is not a fool. The best way to be well received by all is to clothe yourself in the skin of the dumbest of brutes. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：懂得利用愚昧：最睿智的人有时也会使用这张牌。有些时候，最高的智慧在于装作不知——你并非真的无知，而是要懂得如何运用它。在愚人中保持智慧，在疯子中保持清醒，都无济于事。装傻充愣的人并非真正的傻瓜。要想赢得所有人的喜爱，最好的办法就是披上最愚钝的野兽的皮。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
To reveal the true nature of your intelligence rarely pays; you should get in the habit of downplaying it at all times. If people inadvertently learn the truththat you are actually much smarter than you lookthey will admire you more for being discreet than for making your brilliance show. At the start of your climb to the top, of course, you cannot play too stupid: You may want to let your bosses know, in a subtle way, that you are smarter than the competition around you. As you climb the ladder, however, you should to some degree try to dampen your brilliance.
过分暴露自己的才智往往得不偿失；你应该养成时刻低调行事的习惯。如果人们无意中得知你其实比外表看起来聪明得多，他们更欣赏你的谨慎，而不是你炫耀才华。当然，在你攀登事业巅峰的初期，你不能装得太傻：你或许想用一种委婉的方式让你的老板知道，你比周围的竞争对手更聪明。然而，随着你步步高升，你应该在一定程度上克制自己的才华。
There is, however, one situation where it pays to do the opposite when you can cover up a deception with a show of intelligence. In matters of smarts as in most things, appearances are what count. If you seem to have authority and knowledge, people will believe what you say. This can be very useful in getting you out of a scrape.
然而，有一种情况恰恰相反，那就是你可以用展现智慧来掩盖欺骗行为。在智慧领域，就像在大多数事情上一样，外表至关重要。如果你看起来权威且博学，人们就会相信你的话。这在帮你摆脱困境时非常有用。
The art dealer Joseph Duveen was once attending a soiree at the New York home of a tycoon to whom he had recently sold a Diirer painting for
艺术品经销商约瑟夫·杜维恩曾应邀参加一位纽约富豪家中举办的晚宴，他不久前刚把一幅狄雷尔的画作卖给了这位富豪。
a high price. Among die guests was a young French art critic who seemed extremely knowledgeable and confident. Wanting to impress this man, the tycoon's daughter showed him the Diirer, which had not yet been hung. The critic studied it for a time, then finally said, “You know, I don't think this Diirer is right.” He followed the young woman as she hurried to tell her father what he had said, and listened as the magnate, deeply unsetded, turned to Duveen for reassurance. Duveen just laughed. “How very amusing,” he said. “Do you realize, young man, that at least twenty other art experts here and in Europe have been taken in too, and have said that painting isn't genuine And now you've made the same mistake.” His confident tone and air of authority intimidated the Frenchman, who apologized for his mistake.
价格不菲。宾客中有一位年轻的法国艺术评论家，他看起来学识渊博，自信满满。为了给这位评论家留下深刻印象，这位大亨的女儿给他看了一幅狄雷尔的画，这幅画当时还未挂起来。评论家仔细端详了一会儿，最后说道：“你知道吗，我觉得这幅狄雷尔的画不太对劲。”他跟着那位年轻女子匆匆忙忙地去告诉她父亲，只见这位大亨十分不安，转身向杜维恩寻求安慰。杜维恩只是笑了笑。“真是太有趣了，”他说，“年轻人，你难道不知道，至少还有二十位欧洲和本地的艺术专家也被蒙蔽了，他们都说这幅画不是真迹。现在你也犯了同样的错误。”他自信的语气和权威的气场让这位法国人感到畏惧，他连忙为自己的错误道歉。
Duveen knew that the art market was flooded with fakes, and that many paintings had been falsely ascribed to old masters. He tried his best to distinguish the real from the fake, but in his zeal to sell he often overplayed a work's authenticity. What mattered to him was that the buyer believed he had bought a Diirer, and that Duveen himself convinced everyone of his “expertness” through his air of irreproachable authority. Thus, it is important to be able to play the professor when necessary and never impose such an attitude for its own sake.
杜维恩深知艺术市场充斥着赝品，许多画作被错误地归于古代大师名下。他竭尽所能地辨别真伪，但急于推销，却常常夸大作品的真伪。对他而言，重要的是买家相信自己买到的是狄雷尔的作品，而杜维恩本人则凭借其无可挑剔的权威姿态，让所有人相信他的“专业性”。因此，必要时扮演教授的角色固然重要，但绝不能为了装腔作势而装腔作势。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 22
第22条
USE THE SURRENDER
使用投降
TACTIC: TRANSFORM
战术：变形
WEAKNESS INTO POWER
弱化为力量
JUDGMENT
判断
When you are weaker, never fight for honor's sake; choose surrender instead. Surrender gives you time to recover, time to torment and irritate your conqueror, time to wait for his power to wane. Do not give him the satisfaction of fighting and defeating yousurrender first. By turning the other cheek you infuriate and unsettle him. Make surrender a tool of power.
当你虚弱时，切勿为了荣誉而战；而应选择投降。投降能让你获得恢复的时间，获得折磨和激怒征服者的时间，获得等待他力量衰弱的时间。不要让他享受战胜你的快感——先投降。以德报怨只会激怒他，让他心神不宁。让投降成为你力量的工具。
A man who had climbed upon a certain fig tree, was bending the boughs toward him and plucking the ripe fruit, which he then put into his mouth to destroy and gnaw with his hard teeth. The chestnut, seeing this, tossed its long branches and with tumultuous rustle exclaimed: “Oh Fig! How much less protected by nature you are than I. See how my sweet offspring are set In close array; first clothed in soft wrappers over which is the hard but softly lined husk. And not content with this much care, nature has also given us these, sharp and close-set spines, so that the hand of man cannot hurt us.” Then the fig tree began to laugh, and after the laughter it said: “You know well that man is of such ingenuity that he will bereave even you of your children. But in your case he will do it by means of rods and stones; and when they are felled he will trample them with his feet or hit them with stones, so that your offspring will emerge from their armor crushed and maimed; while I am touched carefully by his hands, and never, like you, with roughness.”
一个人爬上一棵无花果树，弯下枝条，摘下成熟的果实，放进嘴里，用坚硬的牙齿啃咬。栗树见状，甩动长长的枝条，发出沙沙的响声，说道：“哦，无花果！你受到的自然保护远不如我。看看我可爱的果实，排列得多么紧密；先是裹着柔软的外皮，外面又套着坚硬但内里柔软的外壳。大自然还不满足于此，还给了我们这些尖锐而密集的刺，好让人类的手伤不了我们。”于是无花果树笑了起来，笑完后说道：“你很清楚，人类诡计多端，甚至会夺走你的孩子。但对你，他会用棍棒和石头；当他们倒下时，他会用脚践踏他们，或用石头砸碎他们，让你的后代从盔甲中出来时，遍体鳞伤、残缺不全；而我，却被他温柔地抚摸，不像你，被他粗暴对待。”
Leonardo daVinci, 1452-1519
列奥纳多·达·芬奇，1452-1519年
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
The island of Melos is strategically situated in the heart of the Mediterranean. In classical times, die city of Adiens dominated die sea and coastal areas around Greece, but Sparta, in the Peloponnese, had been Melos's original colonizer. During the Peloponnesian War, dien, the Melians refused to ally diemselves with Athens and remained loyal to Mother Sparta. In 416 B.C. the Athenians sent an expedition against Melos. Before launching an all-out attack, however, they dispatched a delegation to persuade die Melians to surrender and become an ally rather than suffer devastation and defeat.
米洛斯岛地处地中海中心，战略位置极其重要。古典时期，雅典城邦主宰着希腊周边的海域和沿海地区，但位于伯罗奔尼撒半岛的斯巴达才是米洛斯岛最初的殖民者。在伯罗奔尼撒战争期间，米洛斯人拒绝与雅典结盟，始终效忠于斯巴达。公元前416年，雅典向米洛斯岛发动远征。然而，在全面进攻之前，雅典派出使团劝说米洛斯人投降并结盟，以免遭受毁灭性的打击和失败。
“You know as well as we do,” the delegates said, “mat die standard of justice depends on die equality of power to compel, and diat in fact die strong do what diey have die power to do and the weak accept what diey have to accept.” When the Melians responded that this denied the notion of fair play, the Athenians said that those in power determined what was fair and what was not. The Melians argued diat diis audiority belonged to die gods, not to mortals. “Our opinion of die gods and our knowledge of men,” replied a member of the Athenian delegation, “lead us to conclude diat it is a general and necessary law of nature to rule whatever one can.”
“你们和我们一样清楚，”代表们说道，“正义的标准取决于强制力的平等，而事实上，强者会为所欲为，弱者则只能接受。”当米洛斯人回应说这否定了公平竞争的理念时，雅典人则表示，掌权者决定什么是公平，什么是不公平。米洛斯人辩称，这种权力属于神，而非凡人。“我们对神的看法以及我们对人的了解，”一位雅典代表团成员回答道，“使我们得出结论：统治力所能及的一切，是普遍且必然的自然法则。”
The Melians would not budge. Sparta, they insisted, would come to their defense. The Athenians countered that die Spartans were a conservative, practical people, and would not help Melos because they had nothing to gain and a lot to lose by doing so.
米洛斯人毫不妥协。他们坚称，斯巴达会前来支援他们。雅典人则反驳说，斯巴达人保守务实，不会帮助米洛斯，因为这样做对他们自己没有任何好处，反而会损失惨重。
Finally the Melians began to talk of honor and die principle of resisting brute force. “Do not be led astray by a false sense of honor,” said die Atiie-nians. “Honor often brings men to ruin when they are faced widi an obvious danger that somehow affects their pride. There is nothing disgraceful in giving way to the greatest city in Hellas when she is offering you such reasonable terms.” The debate ended. The Melians discussed die issue among diemselves, and decided to trust in die aid of the Spartans, the will of the gods, and the lightness of their cause. They politely declined the Athenians' offer.
最后，米洛斯人开始谈论荣誉和抵抗武力的原则。“不要被虚假的荣誉感蒙蔽，”雅典人说道，“当人们面对显而易见的危险，而这种危险又触动了他们的骄傲时，荣誉往往会将人引向毁灭。当希腊最伟大的城邦提出如此合理的条件时，向她们让步并无不妥。”辩论结束了。米洛斯人内部讨论了此事，决定相信斯巴达人的援助、神的旨意以及他们事业的公正性。他们礼貌地拒绝了雅典人的提议。
A few days later the Athenians invaded Melos. The Melians fought nobly, even without the Spartans, who did not come to their rescue. It took several attempts before the Adienians could surround and besiege their main city, but the Melians finally surrendered. The Athenians wasted no timethey put to death all die men of military age diat they could capture, diey sold die women and children as slaves, and diey repopulated die island widi their own colonists. Only a handful of Melians survived.
几天后，雅典人入侵了米洛斯岛。米洛斯人英勇抵抗，即使没有斯巴达人的援助，他们也毫不示弱。雅典人经过多次尝试才包围并围困了米洛斯岛的主城，但米洛斯人最终还是投降了。雅典人毫不犹豫地处决了所有被俘的适龄男子，将妇女儿童卖为奴隶，并用自己的殖民者重新占领了这座岛屿。只有极少数米洛斯人幸存下来。
Interpretation
解释
The Athenians were one of the most eminently practical people in history, and diey made die most practical argument they could with the Melians: When you are weaker, tiiere is nothing to be gained by fighting a useless fight. No one comes to help the weakby doing so uiey would only put diemselves in jeopardy. The weak are alone and must submit. Fighting
雅典人是历史上最务实的民族之一，他们向米洛斯人提出了最务实的论点：弱者无力反抗，打无谓的仗毫无益处。没有人会帮助弱者，这样做只会让自己陷入危险。弱者孤立无援，只能屈服。
gives you nothing to gain but martyrdom, and in the process a lot of people who do not believe in your cause will die.
除了殉道之外，你什么也得不到，而且在这个过程中，很多不认同你事业的人也会死去。
Weakness is no sin, and can even become a strength if you learn how to play it right. Had the Melians surrendered in the first place, they would have been able to sabotage the Athenians in subtle ways, or might have gotten what they could have out of the alliance and then left it when the Athenians themselves were weakened, as in fact happened several years later. Fortunes change and the mighty are often brought down. Surrender conceals great power: Lulling the enemy into complacency, it gives you time to recoup, time to undermine, time for revenge. Never sacrifice that time in exchange for honor in a battle that you cannot win.
软弱并非罪过，若能善加利用，甚至可以转化为优势。如果米洛斯人当初选择投降，他们或许就能以隐蔽的方式破坏雅典的计划，或者从联盟中攫取所需，然后在雅典自身实力削弱时退出——而这在几年后也确实发生了。世事变迁，强者也难逃覆灭。投降蕴藏着巨大的力量：它能让敌人放松警惕，为你争取时间恢复元气、伺机破坏、伺机复仇。切勿为了赢得一场必败之战的荣誉而牺牲这段宝贵的时间。
Weak people never give way when they ought to. Cardinal de Retz, 1613-1679
软弱的人该让步的时候永远不会让步。——雷茨枢机主教，1613-1679
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Sometime in the 1920s the German writer Bertolt Brecht became a convert to the cause of Communism. From then on his plays, essays, and poems reflected his revolutionary fervor, and he generally tried to make his ideological statements as clear as possible. When Hitler came to power in Germany, Brecht and his Communist colleagues became marked men. He had many friends in the United StatesAmericans who sympatiiized with his beliefs, as well as fellow German intellectuals who had fled Hider. In 1941, accordingly, Brecht emigrated to the United States, and chose to settle in Los Angeles, where he hoped to make a living in the film business.
20世纪20年代的某个时候，德国作家贝托尔特·布莱希特皈依了共产主义。从那时起，他的戏剧、散文和诗歌都体现了他的革命热情，他通常力求清晰地表达自己的意识形态观点。希特勒在德国掌权后，布莱希特和他的共产主义同事们成为了被追捕的目标。他在美国有很多朋友——一些同情他信仰的美国人，以及一些逃离希特勒统治的德国知识分子。因此，1941年，布莱希特移居美国，选择在洛杉矶定居，希望在那里从事电影行业。
Over the next few years Brecht wrote screenplays with a pointedly an-ticapitalist slant. He had little success in Hollywood, so in 1947, the war having ended, he decided to return to Europe. That same year, however, the U.S. Congress's House Un-American Activities Committee began its investigation into supposed Communist infiltration in Hollywood. It began to gather information on Brecht, who had so openly espoused Marxism, and on September 19, 1947, only a month before he had planned to leave the United States, he received a subpoena to appear before the committee. In addition to Brecht, a number of other writers, producers, and directors were summoned to appear as well, and this group came to be known as the Hollywood 19.
在接下来的几年里，布莱希特创作了一些带有明显反资本主义倾向的剧本。他在好莱坞发展并不顺利，因此在1947年战争结束后，他决定返回欧洲。然而，就在同一年，美国国会众议院非美活动委员会开始调查所谓的共产主义渗透好莱坞的事件。该委员会开始收集布莱希特的资料，因为他曾公开拥护马克思主义。1947年9月19日，就在他计划离开美国前一个月，他收到了委员会的传票。除了布莱希特之外，还有许多其他编剧、制片人和导演也被传唤，这些人后来被称为“好莱坞十九人”。
Before going to Washington, the Hollywood 19 met to decide on a plan of action. Their approach would be confrontational. Instead of answering questions about their membership, or lack of it, in the Communist Party, they would read prepared statements that would challenge the aumority of the committee and argue that its activities were unconstitutional. Even if this strategy meant imprisonment, it would gain publicity for their cause.
在前往华盛顿之前，“好莱坞十九人”举行会议，商讨行动方案。他们的策略是采取对抗性手段。他们不会回答有关他们是否是共产党员的问题，而是宣读事先准备好的声明，挑战委员会的权威，并论证其活动违宪。即使这种策略意味着牢狱之灾，也能为他们的事业赢得公众关注。
Brecht disagreed. What good was it, he asked, to play the martyr and gain a litde public sympathy if in the process they lost the ability to stage their plays and sell their scripts for years to come He felt certain they were
布莱希特不同意。他问道，扮演殉道者并博取些许公众同情有什么用呢？如果他们因此失去了在未来几年里上演戏剧和出售剧本的能力。他确信他们……
Voltaire was living in exile in London at a time when anti-French sentiment was at its highest. One day walking through the streets, he found himself surrounded by an angry crowd. “Hang him. Hang the Frenchman, ” they yelled. Voltaire calmly addressed the mob with the following words: “Men of England! You wish to kill me because 1 am a Frenchman. Am I not punished enough in not being born an Englishman” The crowd cheered his thoughtful words, and escorted him safely back to his lodgings.
伏尔泰流亡伦敦时，反法情绪正盛。一天，他走在街上，突然被一群愤怒的民众围住。“绞死他！绞死那个法国佬！”他们高喊着。伏尔泰平静地对人群说道：“英国人啊！你们想杀我，就因为我是法国人。难道我没生为英国人还不够受罚吗？” 人群为他这番意味深长的话语欢呼，并护送他安全返回住处。
the little, brown book of anecdotes, Clifton Fadiman, ed., 1985
《小棕皮轶事集》，克利夫顿·法迪曼编，1985年
all more intelligent than the members of the committee. Why lower themselves to the level of tfieir opponents by arguing widi them Why not outfox the committee by appearing to surrender to it while subdy mocking it The Hollywood 19 listened to Brecht politely, but decided to stick to their plan, leaving Brecht to go his own way.
他们比委员会成员都聪明得多。为什么要降低自己的格调，与对手争论呢？为什么不表面上向委员会投降，实际上却暗中嘲讽，从而智胜他们呢？好莱坞十九人礼貌地听了布莱希特的发言，但最终决定坚持自己的计划，让布莱希特独自前行。
The committee finally summoned Brecht on October 30. They expected him to do what others among the Hollywood 19 who had testified before him had done: Argue, refuse to answer questions, challenge the committee's right to hold its hearing, even yell and hurl insults. Much to dieir surprise, however, Brecht was the very picture of congeniality. He wore a suit (something he rarely did), smoked a cigar (he had heard that the committee chairman was a passionate cigar smoker), answered their questions politely, and generally deferred to their authority.
委员会最终于10月30日传唤了布莱希特。他们预料他会像其他几位曾在他面前作证的“好莱坞十九人”一样：争辩、拒绝回答问题、质疑委员会举行听证会的合法性，甚至大声叫嚷、出言不逊。然而，令他们大为惊讶的是，布莱希特表现得非常和蔼可亲。他身着西装（这在他身上实属罕见），抽着雪茄（他听说委员会主席是一位雪茄爱好者），礼貌地回答了他们的问题，并且总体上尊重他们的权威。
Unlike the other witnesses, Brecht answered the question of whether he belonged to the Communist Party: He was not a member, he said, which happened to be the truth. One committee member asked him, “Is it true you have written a number of revolutionary plays” Brecht had written many plays with overt Communist messages, but he responded, “I have written a number of poems and songs and plays in the fight against Hider and, of course, diey can be considered, therefore, as revolutionary because I, of course, was for the overthrow of that government.” This statement went unchallenged.
与其他证人不同，布莱希特回答了关于他是否是共产党员的问题：他说他不是党员，而这恰好也是事实。一位委员会成员问他：“听说你写过很多革命剧作，这是真的吗？”布莱希特确实写过许多带有明显共产主义信息的剧作，但他回答说：“我写过很多诗歌、歌曲和戏剧，都是在反对海德政权的斗争中创作的，所以它们当然可以被视为革命作品，因为我当然支持推翻那个政权。”这一说法没有受到任何质疑。
Brecht's English was more than adequate, but he used an interpreter throughout his testimony, a tactic that allowed him to play subde games with language. When committee members found Communist leanings in lines from English editions of his poems, he would repeat the lines in German for the interpreter, who would then retranslate them; and somehow they would cjome out innocuous. At one point a committee member read one of Brecht's revolutionary poems out loud in English, and asked him if he had written it. “No,” he responded, “I wrote a German poem, which is very different from this.” The audior's elusive answers baffled the committee members, but his politeness and the way he yielded to their authority made it impossible for them to get angry with him.
布莱希特的英语水平完全足够，但他全程都使用翻译，这种策略让他得以巧妙地玩弄语言。当委员会成员从他诗歌的英文版中发现带有共产主义倾向的诗句时，他会用德语重复一遍给翻译听，翻译再重新翻译一遍；而最终的结果却往往显得无害。有一次，一位委员会成员用英语朗读了布莱希特的一首革命诗歌，并问他是否是自己写的。“不是，”他回答说，“我写的是一首德语诗，和这首截然不同。”这位证人的回答含糊其辞，令委员会成员困惑不已，但他彬彬有礼的态度以及对委员会权威的顺从，使得他们无法对他生气。
After only an hour of questioning, the committee members had had enough. “Thank you very much,” said the chairman, “You are a good example to the [other] witnesses.” Not only did diey free him, diey offered to help him if he had any trouble with immigration officials who might detain him for their own reasons. The following day, Brecht left the United States, never to return.
仅仅一个小时的讯问后，委员会成员就忍无可忍了。“非常感谢，”主席说，“你为其他证人树立了榜样。”迪伊不仅释放了他，还表示如果他遇到任何移民官员的阻挠，愿意提供帮助，即使他们出于自身原因拘留了他。第二天，布莱希特离开了美国，再也没有回来。
Interpretation
解释
The Hollywood 19's confrontational approach won them a lot of sympathy, and years later they gained a kind of vindication in public opinion. But they were also blacklisted, and lost valuable years of profitable working time. Brecht, on the other hand, expressed his disgust at the committee more indirectiy. It was not that he changed his beliefs or compromised his values; instead, during his short testimony, he kept die upper hand by ap-
好莱坞十九人的对抗方式赢得了许多人的同情，多年后，他们在公众舆论中获得了某种程度的平反。但他们也因此被列入黑名单，失去了宝贵的几年盈利工作时间。另一方面，布莱希特则以更为间接的方式表达了他对委员会的厌恶。这并非意味着他改变了自己的信仰或妥协了自己的价值观；相反，在他简短的证词中，他通过……始终保持着优势。
pearing to yield while all the time running circles around the committee with vague responses, outright lies that went unchallenged because they were wrapped in enigmas, and word games. In the end he kept die freedom to continue his revolutionary writing (as opposed to suffering imprisonment or detainment in die United States), even while subdy mocking die committee and its authority with his pseudo-obedience.
他表面上似乎要屈服，实际上却用含糊其辞的回答、漏洞百出的谎言（因为这些谎言被包裹在谜语和文字游戏中而无人质疑）以及文字游戏，在委员会面前兜圈子。最终，他保住了继续从事革命写作的自由（而不是像在美国那样遭受监禁或拘留），即便他表面上的服从实际上是在暗中嘲弄委员会及其权威。
Keep in mind die following: People trying to make a show of their authority are easily deceived by die surrender tactic. Your outward sign of submission makes diem feel important; satisfied that you respect them, they become easier targets for a later counterattack, or for the kind of indirect ridicule used by Brecht. Measuring your power over time, never sacrifice long-term maneuverability for the short-lived glories of martyrdom.
记住以下几点：那些试图炫耀权威的人很容易被投降的策略所蒙蔽。你表面上的臣服会让他们觉得自己很重要；他们感到你尊重他们，这反而会让他们更容易成为日后反击的目标，或者成为布莱希特式的间接嘲讽的对象。衡量你的实力时，切勿为了短暂的殉道荣耀而牺牲长远的行动自由。
When the great lord passes, the wise peasant bows deeply and silently farts.
当伟大的领主经过时，睿智的农民深深鞠躬，然后悄无声息地放了个屁。
Ethiopian proverb
埃塞俄比亚谚语
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
What gets us into trouble in the realm of power is often our own overreac-tion to the moves of our enemies and rivals. That overreaction creates problems we would have avoided had we been more reasonable. It also has an endless rebound effect, for die enemy then overreacts as well, much as die Athenians did to die Melians. It is always our first instinct to react, to meet aggression with some other kind of aggression. But die next time someone pushes you and you find yourself starting to react, try this: Do not resist or fight back, but yield, turn die odier cheek, bend. You will find tiiat this often neutralizes dieir behaviorthey expected, even wanted you to react with force and so diey are caught off-guard and confounded by your lack of resistance. By yielding, you in fact control the situation, because your surrender is part of a larger plan to lull them into believing they have defeated you.
在权力领域，我们常常因为对敌人和对手的举动反应过度而陷入困境。这种过度反应会造成一些原本可以避免的问题，如果我们能更理性一些就好了。它还会产生无休止的反弹效应，因为敌人也会随之反应过度，就像雅典人对米洛斯人那样。我们的第一反应总是会以牙还牙，以牙还牙。但是，下次如果有人挑衅你，而你发现自己开始反击时，不妨试试这样做：不要抵抗或反击，而是屈服，转过脸去，低头认输。你会发现，这往往能化解他们的反应——他们原本预期甚至希望你以武力回应，所以他们会因为你的不抵抗而措手不及，感到困惑。通过屈服，你实际上掌控了局面，因为你的投降是更大计划的一部分，目的是让他们误以为已经战胜了你。
This is die essence of the surrender tactic: Inwardly you stay firm, but outwardly you bend. Deprived of a reason to get angry, your opponents will often be bewildered instead. And diey are unlikely to react with more violence, which would demand a reaction from you. Instead you are allowed the time and space to plot the countermoves that will bring them down. In die battle of die intelligent against die brutal and die aggressive, the surrender tactic is die supreme weapon. It does require self-control: Those who genuinely surrender give up their freedom, and may be crushed by the humiliation of their defeat. You have to remember that you only appear to surrender, like the animal that plays dead to save its hide.
这就是投降战术的精髓：内心坚定，外表示弱。失去愤怒的理由后，你的对手往往会感到困惑。他们不太可能以更激烈的暴力回应，从而迫使你做出反应。这样一来，你就有时间和空间来策划反击，最终击败他们。在智慧与残暴侵略的较量中，投降战术是最强大的武器。但这需要极强的自制力：真正投降的人放弃了自由，可能会因战败的耻辱而崩溃。你必须记住，你只是表面上投降，就像动物装死以求自保一样。
We have seen diat it can be better to surrender than to fight; faced witii a more powerful opponent and a sure defeat, it is often also better to surrender than to run away. Running away may save you for the time being, but the aggressor will eventually catch up with you. If you surrender instead, you have an opportunity to coil around your enemy and strike with your fangs from close up.
我们已经看到，投降有时比战斗更好；面对更强大的对手和必败无疑的局面，投降往往也比逃跑更好。逃跑或许能让你暂时脱身，但侵略者最终会追上你。如果你选择投降，你就有机会缠住敌人，近距离用利齿攻击。
In 473 B.C., in ancient China, King Goujian of Yue suffered a horrible defeat from the ruler of Wu in the battle of Fujiao. Goujian wanted to flee, but he had an adviser who told him to surrender and to place himself in the service of the ruler of Wu, from which position he could study the man and plot his revenge. Deciding to follow this advice, Goujian gave the ruler all of his riches, and went to work in his conqueror's stables as the lowest servant. For three years he humbled himself before the ruler, who then, finally satisfied of his loyalty, allowed him to return home. Inwardly, however, Goujian had spent those three years gathering information and plotting revenge. When a terrible drought struck Wu, and the kingdom was weakened by inner turmoil, he raised an army, invaded, and won with ease. That is the power behind surrender: It gives you the time and the flexibility to plot a devastating counterblow. Had Goujian run away, he would have lost this chance.
公元前473年，在中国古代，越王勾健在福寮之战中惨败于吴王。勾健本想逃亡，但他的谋士劝他投降，投靠吴王，以便观察吴王，伺机复仇。勾健听从了谋士的建议，将所有财富献给了吴王，自己则在吴王的马厩里做最卑微的仆人。他在吴王面前卑躬屈膝三年，吴王最终被他的忠诚所折服，才允许他返回故乡。然而，勾健内心却在这三年里不断收集情报，筹谋复仇。当吴国遭遇严重旱灾，国力衰弱，勾健趁机集结军队，入侵吴国，轻松取胜。这就是投降的力量：它赋予你时间和灵活性，让你得以策划毁灭性的反击。如果勾健当时逃跑了，他就错失了这次机会。
When foreign trade began to threaten Japanese independence in the mid-nineteenth century, die Japanese debated how to defeat the foreigners. One minister, Hotta Masayoshi, wrote a memorandum in 1857 that influenced Japanese policy for years to come: “I am therefore convinced that our policy should be to conclude friendly alliances, to send ships to foreign countries everywhere and conduct trade, to copy the foreigners where they are at their best and so repair our own shortcomings, to foster our national strength and complete our armaments, and so gradually subject the foreigners to our influence until in the end all the countries of the world know the blessings of perfect tranquillity and our hegemony is acknowledged throughout the globe.” This is a brilliant application of the Law: Use surrender to gain access to your enemy. Learn his ways, insinuate yourself with him slowly, outwardly conform to his customs, but inwardly maintain your own culture. Eventually you will emerge victorious, for while he considers you weak and inferior, and takes no precautions against you, you are using the time to catch up and surpass him. This soft, permeable form of invasion is often the best, for the enemy has nothing to react against, prepare for, or resist. And had Japan resisted Western influence by force, it might well have suffered a devastating invasion that would have permanendy altered its culture.
十九世纪中叶，当对外贸易开始威胁日本独立时，日本人争论不休，试图击败外国势力。一位名叫堀田正义的大臣在1857年撰写了一份备忘录，这份备忘录对日本未来的政策产生了深远的影响：“因此，我认为我们的政策应该是缔结友好同盟，派遣船只前往世界各地开展贸易，学习外国的优势，弥补自身的不足，增强国力，完善军备，逐步将外国置于我们的影响力之下，最终使世界各国都享受到绝对和平的福祉，我们的霸权得到全球的认可。” 这正是对“以臣服为手段接近敌人”这一法则的精妙运用：了解敌人的行事方式，逐步渗透到敌人之中，表面上顺应敌人的习俗，但内心坚守自身的文化。最终你必将取得胜利，因为当他视你为弱小低等，对你不加防范时，你却利用这段时间迎头赶上，最终超越他。这种软性、渗透性的入侵方式往往最为有效，因为敌人无从应对、准备或抵抗。如果日本当初以武力抵抗西方的影响，很可能遭受毁灭性的入侵，其文化也将因此而彻底改变。
Surrender can also offer a way of mocking your enemies, of turning their power against them, as it did for Brecht. Milan Kundera's novel The Joke, based on the author's experiences in a penal camp in Czechoslovakia, tells the story of how the prison guards organized a relay race, guards against prisoners. For the guards this was a chance to show off their physical superiority. The prisoners knew they were expected to lose, so they went out of their way to obligemiming exaggerated exertion while barely moving, running a few yards and collapsing, limping, jogging ever so slowly while the guards raced ahead at full speed. Both by joining the race and by losing it, they had obliged the guards obediently; but their “overobedience” had mocked the event to the point of ruining it.
