Overobe-diencesurrenderwas here a way to demonstrate superiority in a reverse manner. Resistance would have engaged the prisoners in the cycle of
投降也可以成为嘲弄敌人、反制敌人的一种方式，就像布莱希特那样。米兰·昆德拉的小说《玩笑》取材于作者在捷克斯洛伐克劳改营的经历，讲述了狱警组织了一场接力赛的故事，狱警与囚犯进行比赛。对狱警来说，这是炫耀体力优势的机会。囚犯们知道自己注定要输，所以他们故意装作很卖力的样子，实际上却几乎不动，跑几码就倒下，一瘸一拐，慢吞吞地跑着，而狱警则全速冲刺。他们参与比赛，也输掉比赛，都算是顺从地“服从”了狱警；但他们的“过度服从”却把这场比赛嘲弄得一团糟。在这里，“过度服从”的投降反而成了一种反向展现优势的方式。反抗只会让囚犯陷入这种循环……
violence, lowering them to the guards' level. Overobeying the guards, however, made them ridiculous, yet they could not righdy punish the prisoners, who had only done what they asked.
暴力将他们拉低到与守卫相同的地位。然而，违抗守卫的命令又使守卫显得滑稽可笑，但守卫又不能理直气壮地惩罚那些只是遵从他们命令的囚犯。
Power is always in fluxsince the game is by nature fluid, and an arena of constant struggle, those with power almost always find themselves eventually on the downward swing. If you find yourself temporarily weakened, the surrender tactic is perfect for raising yourself up againit disguises your ambition; it teaches you patience and self-control, key skills in the game; and it puts you in the best possible position for taking advantage of your oppressor's sudden slide. If you run away or fight back, in die long run you cannot win. If you surrender, you will almost always emerge victorious.
权力总是处于不断变化之中——因为游戏本身就是一个瞬息万变、充满斗争的竞技场，所以那些掌握权力的人几乎总会在最终走向衰落。如果你发现自己暂时处于弱势，投降策略是重振旗鼓的绝佳选择。它能掩盖你的野心；它能教会你耐心和自制力，这些都是游戏中至关重要的技能；它还能让你处于最佳位置，利用压迫者突然的衰落。如果你逃跑或反抗，从长远来看你无法取胜。如果你投降，你几乎总是会取得胜利。
Image: An Oak Tree. The oak that resists the wind loses its branches one by one, and with nothing left to protect it, the trunk finally snaps. The oak that bends lives longer, its trunk growing wider, its roots deeper and more tenacious.
图片：一棵橡树。抗风的橡树会一根根地折断枝条，最终失去所有保护，树干折断。而顺风的橡树则寿命更长，树干越长越粗壮，根系也更深更牢固。
Authority: Ye have heard that it hath been said, An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth: But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but whosoever shall smite thee on titiy right cheek, turn to him the other also. And if any man will sue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let them have thy cloak also. And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him twain. (Jesus Christ, in Matthew 5:38-41)
你们听过有话说：“以眼还眼，以牙还牙。”但我告诉你们，不要与恶人作对。有人打你的右脸，连左脸也转过来由他打。有人要告你，要拿你的里衣，连外衣也给他。有人强迫你走一里路，就同他走两里。（耶稣基督，马太福音 5:38-41）
REVERSAL
逆转
The point of surrendering is to save your hide for a later date when you can reassert yourself. It is precisely to avoid martyrdom that one surrenders, but there are times when the enemy will not relent, and martyrdom seems the only way out. Furthermore, if you are willing to die, others may gain power and inspiration from your example.
投降的意义在于保全性命，以便日后重振旗鼓。人们投降正是为了避免殉道，但有时敌人毫不松懈，殉道似乎成了唯一的出路。此外，如果你甘愿赴死，你的榜样或许能激励他人，鼓舞士气。
Yet martyrdom, surrender's reversal, is a messy, inexact tactic, and is as violent as die aggression it combats. For every famous martyr there are thousands more who have inspired neither a religion nor a rebellion, so that if martyrdom does sometimes grant a certain power, it does so unpredictably. More important, you will not be around to enjoy that power, such as it is. And there is finally something selfish and arrogant about martyrs, as if they felt their followers were less important than their own glory.
然而，殉道，这种对投降的反叛，是一种混乱且不精确的策略，其暴力程度不亚于它所对抗的侵略。每出现一位著名的殉道者，就有成千上万的人既没有启发宗教，也没有引发叛乱，因此，即使殉道有时确实能赋予某种力量，这种力量也是不可预测的。更重要的是，你将无法亲身享受这种力量，即便它微不足道。最后，殉道者身上还带有某种自私和傲慢的特质，仿佛他们认为追随者远不如自身的荣耀重要。
When power deserts you, it is best to ignore this Law's reversal. Leave martyrdom alone: The pendulum will swing back your way eventually, and you should stay alive to see it.
当权力离你而去时，最好无视这条法则的逆转。别追求殉道：钟摆终会摆向你这边，你应该活着见证这一刻。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 23
第23条
CONCENTRATE YOUR FORCES
集中你的力量
JUDGMENT
判断
Conserve your forces and energies by keeping them concentrated at their strongest point. You gain more by finding a rich mine and mining it deeper, than by flitting from one shallow mine to anotherintensity defeats extensity every time. When looking for sources of power to elevate you, find the one key patron, the fat cow who will give you milk for a long time to come.
将你的精力和能量集中在最强之处，才能保存它们。与其在各个浅矿之间来回奔波，不如找到一座富矿并深入开采——强度永远胜过广度。当你寻找提升自身的力量源泉时，找到那位关键的庇护者，那头会源源不断地为你产奶的肥牛。
Tin: cookk and
锡：cookk 和

TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In China in the early sixth century B.C., the kingdom of Wu began a war with the neighboring northern provinces of the Middle Kingdom. Wu was a growing power, but it lacked the great history and civilization of the Middle Kingdom, for centuries die center of Chinese culture. By defeating the Middle Kingdom, the king of Wu would instantly raise his status.
公元前六世纪初，中国吴国与邻近的北方诸国——中华民族的北方诸国——爆发了战争。吴国虽然崛起，但缺乏中华民族那样悠久的历史和文明，而中华民族曾是数个世纪以来中国文化的中心。若能击败中华民族，吴王的地位将立即得到提升。
The war began with great fanfare and several victories, but it soon bogged down. A victory on one front would leave the Wu armies vulnerable on another. The king's chief minister and adviser, Wu Tzu-hsiu, warned him that the barbarous state of Yueh, to the south, was beginning to notice the kingdom of Wu's problems and had designs to invade. The king only laughed at such worriesone more big victory and the great Middle Kingdom would be his.
战争伊始，双方都取得了一些胜利，但很快便陷入僵局。在一条战线上取得胜利，却会使吴军在另一条战线上处于劣势。吴王的首席大臣兼顾问吴子修警告他，南方蛮夷的岳国已经开始察觉吴国的困境，并伺机入侵。吴王对此却不以为然，只是笑着说，只要再取得一场大胜，强大的中原之国便将归他所有。
In the year 490, Wu Tzu-hsiu sent his son away to safety in the kingdom of Ch'i. In doing so he sent the king a signal that he disapproved of the war, and that he believed the king's selfish ambition was leading Wu to ruin. The king, sensing betrayal, lashed out at his minister, accusing him of a lack of loyalty and, in a fit of anger, ordered him to kill himself. Wu Tzu-hsiu obeyed his king, but before he plunged the knife into his chest, he cried, “Tear out my eyes, oh King, and fix them on the gate of Wu, so that I may see the triumphant entry of Yueh.”
公元490年，吴子修将儿子送往齐国避难。此举意在向秦王表明他反对这场战争，并认为秦王的野心将导致吴国走向灭亡。秦王察觉到背叛，怒斥吴子修不忠，并下令其自尽。吴子修遵命而行，但在将刀刺入胸膛之前，他喊道：“秦王啊，挖出我的双眼，将它们镶嵌在吴国的城门上，让我亲眼目睹越国凯旋而归。”
As Wu Tzu-hsiu had predicted, within a few years a Yueh army passed beneath the gate of Wu. As the barbarians surrounded the palace, the king remembered his minister's last wordsand felt the dead man's disembodied eyes watching his disgrace. Unable to bear his shame, the king killed himself, “covering his face so that he would not have to meet the reproachful gaze of his minister in the next world.”
正如吴子修所预言的那样，几年之内，越军攻入吴国城下。蛮族包围王宫时，吴王想起大臣临终前的遗言，仿佛看到死者的眼睛注视着自己蒙羞的模样。吴王无法忍受这耻辱，自尽身亡，“蒙面自尽，免得来世再与大臣那责备的目光相接”。
Interpretation
解释
The story of Wu is a paradigm of all the empires that have come to ruin by overreaching. Drunk with success and sick with ambition, such empires expand to grotesque proportions and meet a ruin that is total. This is what happened to ancient Athens, which lusted for the faraway island of Sicily and ended up losing its empire. The Romans stretched the boundaries of their empire to encompass vast territories; in doing so they increased their vulnerability, and the chances of invasion from yet another barbarian tribe. Their useless expansion led their empire into oblivion.
吴国的故事堪称所有因过度扩张而走向衰亡的帝国的典范。这些帝国沉醉于成功，野心勃勃，最终扩张到荒谬的地步，走向彻底的毁灭。古雅典的遭遇便是如此，它觊觎遥远的西西里岛，最终却失去了帝国。罗马人为了囊括广袤的领土而不断扩张，却也因此增加了自身的脆弱性，以及遭受其他蛮族入侵的风险。他们徒劳的扩张最终将帝国推向了灭亡的边缘。
For the Chinese, the fate of the kingdom of Wu serves as an elemental lesson on what happens when you dissipate your forces on several fronts, losing sight of distant dangers for the sake of present gain. “If you are not in danger,” says Sun-tzu, “do not fight.” It is almost a physical law: What is bloated beyond its proportions inevitably collapses. The mind must not wander from goal to goal, or be distracted by success from its sense of purpose and proportion. What is concentrated, coherent, and connected to its past has power. What is dissipated, divided, and distended rots and falls to the ground. The bigger it bloats, the harder it falls.
对中国人来说，吴国的命运犹如一记警钟，告诫人们当兵力分散于多条战线，为眼前的利益而忽视远方的危险时，将会发生什么。“若非危难，”孙子说，“就不要打仗。”这几乎是一条物理定律：膨胀的事物必然会崩塌。人的心思不应在不同的追求之间摇摆不定，也不应因成功而偏离目标和方向。专注、连贯、与过去相连的事物才拥有力量。分散、分裂、膨胀的事物终将腐朽，最终走向衰败。膨胀得越大，衰败得越惨烈。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
The Rothschild banking family had humble beginnings in the Jewish ghetto of Frankfurt, Germany. The city's harsh laws made it impossible for Jews to mingle outside the ghetto, but the Jews had turned this into a virtueit made them self-reliant, and zealous to preserve their culture at all costs. Mayer Amschel, the first of the Rothschilds to accumulate wealth by lending money, in the late eighteenth century, well understood the power that comes from this kind of concentration and cohesion.
罗斯柴尔德银行家族的起源可以追溯到德国法兰克福的犹太人隔离区。当时法兰克福严苛的法律禁止犹太人与外界接触，但他们却将这种限制转化为优势——这造就了他们的自力更生和不惜一切代价保护自身文化的决心。18世纪末，罗斯柴尔德家族中第一个通过放贷积累财富的人——梅耶·阿姆谢尔，深谙这种集中和凝聚力所带来的力量。
First, Mayer Amschel allied himself witii one family, the powerful princes of Thurn und Taxis. Instead of spreading his services out, he made himself these princes' primary banker. Second, he entrusted none of his business to outsiders, using only his children and close relatives. The more unified and tight-knit the family, the more powerful it would become. Soon Mayer Amschel's five sons were running the business. And when Mayer Amschel lay dying, in 1812, he refused to name a principal heir, instead setting up all of his sons to continue the family tradition, so that they would stay united and would resist the dangers of diffusion and of infiltration by outsiders.
首先，迈耶·阿姆舍尔与图恩和塔克西斯两大家族结盟。他没有将业务分散到其他客户，而是让自己成为这些王子的主要银行家。其次，他不将任何业务委托给外人，只让自己的子女和近亲掌管。家族越团结紧密，势力就越强大。不久，迈耶·阿姆舍尔的五个儿子便开始经营家族生意。1812年，迈耶·阿姆舍尔弥留之际，他拒绝指定主要继承人，而是安排所有儿子继承家族传统，以确保家族团结，抵御外来势力的渗透和扩张。
Once Mayer Amschel's sons controlled the family business, they decided mat the key to wealth on a larger scale was to secure a foothold in die finances of Europe as a whole, rather tiian being tied to any one country or prince. Of the five brothers, Nathan had already opened up shop in London. In 1813 James moved to Paris. Amschel remained in Frankfurt, Salomon established himself in Vienna, and Karl, the youngest son, went to Naples. With each sphere of influence covered, they could tighten their hold on Europe's financial markets.
梅耶·阿姆谢尔的儿子们掌控家族企业后，他们认定，要想大规模积累财富，关键在于在整个欧洲金融体系中站稳脚跟，而不是依附于任何一个国家或君主。五兄弟中，内森已在伦敦开设了公司。1813年，詹姆斯迁居巴黎。阿姆谢尔留在法兰克福，所罗门在维也纳站稳脚跟，最小的儿子卡尔则去了那不勒斯。随着各个势力范围的逐步扩大，他们得以进一步巩固对欧洲金融市场的控制。
This widespread network, of course, opened the Rodischilds to the very danger of which their fadier had warned mem: diffusion, division, dissension. They avoided mis danger, and established themselves as the most powerful force in European finance and politics, by once again resorting to the strategy of the ghettoexcluding outsiders, concentrating their forces. The Rothschilds established the fastest courier system in Europe, allowing them to get news of events before all their competitors. They held a virtual monopoly on information. And their internal communications and correspondence were written in Frankfurt Yiddish, and in a code that only the brothers could decipher. There was no point in stealing mis information no one could understand it. “Even the shewdest bankers cannot find their way through the Rothschild maze,” admitted a financier who had tried to infiltrate the clan.
当然，正是这种庞大的网络，让罗迪柴尔德家族面临了他们父亲曾警告过的危险：信息扩散、分裂和纷争。他们避免了这些危险，并通过再次采用“隔离区”策略——将外人拒之门外，集中力量——确立了自己在欧洲金融和政治领域最强大的地位。罗斯柴尔德家族建立了欧洲最快的信使系统，使他们能够比所有竞争对手更早地获取新闻。他们几乎垄断了信息。他们的内部通讯和信件都用法兰克福意第绪语书写，并使用只有兄弟俩才能解读的密码。窃取无人能懂的信息毫无意义。“即使是最精明的银行家也无法在罗斯柴尔德家族的迷宫中找到出路，”一位曾试图渗透该家族的金融家承认道。
In 1824 James Rothschild decided it was time to get married. This presented a problem for the Rothschilds, since it meant incorporating an outsider into the Rothschild clan, an outsider who could betray its secrets. James therefore decided to marry within the family, and chose the daughter of his brother Salomon. The brothers were ecstaticthis was the perfect solution to their marriage problems. James's choice now became the family policy: Two years later, Nathan married off his daughter to
1824年，詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德决定结婚。这对罗斯柴尔德家族来说是个难题，因为这意味着要将一个外人纳入家族，而这个外人可能会泄露家族的秘密。因此，詹姆斯决定在家族内部通婚，他选择了哥哥所罗门的女儿。兄弟俩欣喜若狂，认为这是解决他们婚姻问题的完美方案。詹姆斯的选择也成为了家族的惯例：两年后，内森将女儿嫁给了……
hissing at everyone who passes by, you bring upon yourself the derision of all beholders. 1 confess that I am only formed to move upon the ground; but how graceful is my make! How well turned my limbs! How highly finished my whole body! How great my strength! How astonishing my speed! I had much rather be confined to one element, and be admired in that, than be a goose in all!"
你对着每个路过的人发出嘶嘶声，只会招致所有旁观者的嘲笑。我承认我生来只能在地上行走；但我的身姿多么优美！我的四肢多么匀称！我的整个身体多么完美！我的力量多么强大！我的速度多么惊人！我宁愿被限制在一种元素中，并因此而受人赞赏，也不愿做一只到处都是的鹅！
FABLES FROM BOCCACCIO AND CHAUCER,
薄伽丘和乔叟的寓言故事
Dr. John Aikin, 1747-1822
约翰·艾金博士，1747-1822年
Beware of dissipating your powers; strive constantly to concentrate them. Genius thinks it can do whatever it sees others doing, but it is sure to repent of every ill-judged outlay.
切勿挥霍你的才能；要不断努力集中精力。天才往往认为自己可以做到别人所做的一切，但每一次不明智的付出都必将让他后悔莫及。
Johann von Goethe, 1749-1832
约翰·冯·歌德，1749-1832年
Salomon's son. In die years to come, the five brotiiers arranged eighteen matches among their children, sixteen of these being contracted between first cousins.
所罗门的儿子。在接下来的几年里，这五位兄弟会成员为他们的孩子安排了十八桩婚事，其中十六桩是表兄妹之间的联姻。
“We are like the mechanism of a watch: Each part is essential,” said brother Salomon. As in a watch, every part of the business moved in concert with every other, and the inner workings were invisible to the world, which only saw die movement of the hands. While odier rich and powerful families suffered irrecoverable downturns during the tumultous first half of the nineteenth century, the tight-knit Rothschilds managed not only to preserve but to expand dieir unprecedented wealth.
“我们就像钟表的机械装置：每个部件都至关重要，”所罗门兄弟说道。正如钟表一般，企业的每个环节都与其他环节协调运作，其内部运作不为人知，世人只能看到指针的移动。在动荡的十九世纪上半叶，当其他许多富有而强大的家族遭受无法挽回的衰落时，关系紧密的罗斯柴尔德家族不仅保住了他们空前的财富，而且还使其规模不断扩大。
Interpretation
解释
The Rothschilds were born in strange times. They came from a place diat had not changed in centuries, but lived in an age that gave birth to the Industrial Revolution, die French Revolution, and an endless series of upheavals. The Rotiichilds kept die past alive, resisted Uie patterns of dispersion of their era and for this are emblematic of the law of concentration.
罗斯柴尔德家族诞生于一个特殊的时代。他们来自一个几个世纪以来都未曾改变的地方，却生活在一个孕育了工业革命、法国大革命以及一系列动荡的时代。罗斯柴尔德家族保留了过去的荣光，抵制了时代变迁的趋势，因此成为了集中法则的典范。
No one represents this better than James Rodischild, die son who established himself in Paris. In his lifetime James witnessed die defeat of Napoleon, die restoration of die Bourbon monarchy, the bourgeois monarchy of Orleans, the return to a republic, and finally the enthronement of Napoleo i III. French styles and fashions changed at a relentiess pace during all this turmoil. Without appearing to be a relic of the past, James steered his family as if die ghetto lived on widiin diem. He kept alive his clan's inner cohesion and strength. Only through such an anchoring in die past was die family able to tiirive amidst such chaos. Concentration was die foundation of the Rothschilds' power, wealth, and stability.
没有人比詹姆斯·罗迪柴尔德更能代表这一点，这位在巴黎站稳脚跟的家族之子。詹姆斯一生见证了拿破仑的战败、波旁王朝的复辟、奥尔良的资产阶级君主制、共和国的回归，以及最终拿破仑三世的登基。在所有这些动荡时期，法国的风格和时尚以惊人的速度不断变化。詹姆斯并没有让自己显得墨守成规，而是像一个活在当下的贫民窟一样，带领着他的家族。他维系着家族内部的凝聚力和力量。正是通过这种对过去的深厚根基，这个家族才能在如此混乱的局势中生存下来。专注是罗斯柴尔德家族权力、财富和稳定的基石。
The best strategy is always to be very strong; first in general, then
最好的策略永远是先强大，然后才是真正强大。
at the decisive point. . . . There is no higher and simpler law of strategy
在决定性时刻……没有比这更高尚、更简单的战略法则了。
than that of keeping one's forces concentrated. . . . In short the
比起集中兵力……总之……
first principle is: act with the utmost concentration.
第一原则是：全神贯注地行动。
On War, Carl von Clausewitz, 1 7801831
《战争论》，卡尔·冯·克劳塞维茨，1780-1831年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The world is plagued by greater and greater divisionwitiiin countries, political groups, families, even individuals. We are all in a state of total distraction and diffusion, hardly able to keep our minds in one direction before we are pulled in a thousand others. The modern world's level of conflict is higher tiian ever, and we have internalized it in our own lives.
世界正饱受日益加剧的分裂之苦，国家、政治团体、家庭乃至个人之间都存在着分裂。我们都处于一种完全分散注意力的状态，几乎无法集中精力关注某一方面，就被成千上万其他事物牵扯。现代世界的冲突程度前所未有，而我们早已将这种冲突内化于自身生活之中。
The solution is a form of retreat inside ourselves, to the past, to more concentrated forms of thought and action. As Schopenhauer wrote, “Intellect is a magnitude of intensity, not a magnitude of extensity.” Napoleon knew die value of concentrating your forces at die enemy's weakest spot
解决之道在于回归内心，回归过去，回归更为专注的思考和行动方式。正如叔本华所写：“智力是强度的量级，而非广度的量级。”拿破仑深谙集中兵力攻击敌人弱点的价值。
it was the secret of his success on the battlefield. But his willpower and his mind were equally modeled on this notion. Single-mindedness of purpose, total concentration on the goal, and the use of these qualities against people less focused, people in a state of distractionsuch an arrow will find its mark every time and overwhelm the enemy.
这就是他在战场上取胜的秘诀。他的意志力和思维方式都建立在这一理念之上。一心一意，全神贯注于目标，并将这些特质运用到那些注意力不集中、心不在焉的人身上——这样的箭矢必将百发百中，击溃敌人。
Casanova attributed his success in life to his ability to concentrate on a single goal and push at it until it yielded. It was his ability to give himself over completely to the women he desired that made him so intensely seductive. For the weeks or months that one of these women lived in his orbit, he thought of no one else. When he was imprisoned in the treacherous “leads” of the doge's palace in Venice, a prison from which no one had ever escaped, he concentrated his mind on the single goal of escape, day after day. A change of cells, which meant that months of digging had all been for naught, did not discourage him; he persisted and eventually escaped. “I have always believed,” he later wrote, “that when a man gets it into his head to do something, and when he exclusively occupies himself in that design, he must succeed, whatever the difficulties. That man will become Grand Vizier or Pope.”
卡萨诺瓦将自己的人生成功归功于他能够专注于一个目标并坚持不懈直至达成。他能够完全投入到自己所爱慕的女人身上，这使他极具魅力。当某个女人在他身边度过数周或数月时，他便不再想着其他人。当他被囚禁在威尼斯总督府险恶的“巷道”中——一个从未有人逃脱过的监狱——时，他日复一日地专注于越狱这一目标。即使被转移到另一个牢房，意味着几个月的挖掘都白费了，也没有让他气馁；他坚持不懈，最终成功逃脱。“我一直相信，”他后来写道，“当一个人下定决心要做某件事，并且全身心投入到这件事中时，无论遇到什么困难，他都一定会成功。这样的人会成为大维齐尔，或者教皇。”
Concentrate c 1 a single goal, a single task, and beat it into submission. In the world of power you will constantly need help from other people, usually those more powerful than you. The fool flits from one person to another, believing that he will survive by spreading himself out. It is a corollary of the law of concentration, however, that much energy is saved, and more power is attained, by affixing yourself to a single, appropriate source of power. The scientist Nikola Tesla ruined himself by believing that he somehow maintained his independence by not having to serve a single master. He even turned down J. P. Morgan, who offered him a rich contract. In the end, Tesla's “independence” meant that he could depend on no single patron, but was always having to toady up to a dozen of them. Later in his life he realized his mistake.
专注于一个目标，一项任务，并将其发挥到极致。在权力世界里，你将不断需要他人的帮助，通常是那些比你更有权势的人。愚人四处奔波，以为分散精力就能生存下去。然而，专注法则的必然结果是：将自己集中于一个合适的力量源泉，可以节省大量精力，获得更大的力量。科学家尼古拉·特斯拉就因为误以为不依附于任何主人就能保持独立而自取灭亡。他甚至拒绝了摩根提供的丰厚合同。最终，特斯拉所谓的“独立”意味着他无法依靠任何一位赞助人，反而不得不对十几个人阿谀奉承。晚年，他才意识到自己犯了错。
All the great Renaissance painters and writers wresded with this problem, none more so tilan the sixteenth-century writer Pietro Aretino. Throughout his life Aretino suffered die indignities of having to please diis prince and that. At last, he had had enough, and decided to woo Charles V, promising the emperor the services of his powerful pen. He finally discovered the freedom that came from attachment to a single source of power. Michelangelo found this freedom with Pope Julius II, Galileo with the Medicis. In the end, die single patron appreciates your loyalty and becomes dependent on your services; in the long run the master serves die slave.
所有伟大的文艺复兴时期画家和作家都曾为此苦恼，其中最甚者莫过于十六世纪的作家彼得罗·阿雷蒂诺。阿雷蒂诺一生都在忍受着取悦君主的屈辱。最终，他忍无可忍，决定去讨好查理五世，承诺将用他强大的笔力为皇帝效力。他终于发现了依附于单一权力来源所带来的自由。米开朗基罗在教皇尤利乌斯二世那里找到了这种自由，伽利略在美第奇家族那里也找到了。最终，唯一的赞助人会欣赏你的忠诚，并依赖于你的服务；从长远来看，主人最终会侍奉奴隶。
Finally, power itself always exists in concentrated forms. In any organization it is inevitable for a small group to hold the strings. And often it is not diose widi the tides. In die game of power, only the fool flails about without fixing his target. You must find out who controls die operations, who is the real director behind the scenes. As Richelieu discovered at die beginning of his rise to die top of die French political scene during die
最后，权力本身总是以集中形式存在。在任何组织中，少数人掌控大局是不可避免的。而且，这种掌控往往并非顺应潮流。在权力游戏中，只有傻瓜才会漫无目的地胡乱挥舞手臂。你必须找出谁在控制运作，谁才是幕后的真正掌权者。正如黎塞留在其崛起成为法国政坛顶峰之初所发现的那样。
early seventeenth century, it was not King Louis XIII who decided things, it was the king's mother. And so he attached himself to her, and catapulted through the ranks of the courtiers, all the way to the top.
十七世纪初，真正做决定的不是路易十三国王，而是国王的母亲。因此，他依附于母亲，一路从朝臣中脱颖而出，最终登上权力巅峰。
It is enough to strike oil onceyour wealth and power are assured for a lifetime.
只要你的财富和权力有了保障，一生无忧，那么发现石油就足够了。
Image: The Arrow. You cannot hit two targets
图片：箭。你无法击中两个目标。
with one arrow. If your thoughts stray, you
用一支箭。如果你的思绪游离，你
miss the enemy's heart. Mind and
错失敌人的心脏。思想和
arrow must become one. Only
箭矢必须合二为一。
with such concentration of
如此高的浓度
mental and physical
心理和生理
power can your arrow
力量可以让你箭矢
hit the target and
击中目标并
pierce the
刺穿
heart.
心。
Authority: Prize intensity more than extensity. Perfection resides in quality, not quantity. Extent alone never rises above mediocrity, and it is die misfortune of men with wide general interests that while they would like to have their finger in every pie, they have one in none. Intensity gives eminence, and rises to the heroic in matters sublime. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：重视强度胜于广度。完美在于质量，而非数量。单凭广度永远无法超越平庸，而那些兴趣广泛的人的不幸之处在于，他们虽然想涉猎各个领域，却最终一无所获。强度造就卓越，在崇高的事物上更能成就英雄之举。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
There are dangers in concentration, and moments when dispersion is the proper tactical move. Fighting the Nationalists for control of China, Mao Tse-tung and the Communists fought a protracted war on several fronts, using sabotage and ambush as their main weapons. Dispersal is often suitable for the weaker side; it is, in fact, a crucial principle of guerrilla warfare. When fighting a stronger army, concentrating your forces only makes you an easier targetbetter to dissolve into the scenery and frustrate your enemy with the elusiveness of your presence.
集中兵力存在危险，分散作战有时才是正确的战术选择。毛泽东领导的共产党军队与国民党争夺中国控制权时，在多条战线上进行了旷日持久的战争，并以破坏和伏击为主要战术手段。分散作战通常更适合弱势一方；事实上，它是游击战的关键原则之一。面对更强大的军队，集中兵力只会使自己更容易成为目标——最好是融入周围环境，利用自身的隐蔽性来扰乱敌人的行动。
Tying yourself to a single source of power has one preeminent danger: If that person dies, leaves, or falls from grace, you suffer. This is what happened to Cesare Borgia, who derived his power from his father, Pope Alexander VI. It was the pope who gave Cesare armies to fight with and wars to wage in his name. When he suddenly died (perhaps from poison),
将自己与单一权力来源捆绑在一起，存在一个极其危险的后果：如果这个人去世、离开或失势，你也将遭受损失。切萨雷·博尔吉亚就遭遇了这种情况，他的权力源自其父教皇亚历山大六世。正是这位教皇赐予切萨雷军队，让他以自己的名义发动战争。当他突然去世（或许是中毒身亡）时，
Cesare was as good as dead. He had made far too many enemies over the years, and was now wimout his father's protection. In cases when you may need protection, then, it is often wise to entwine yourself around several sources of power. Such a move would be especially prudent in periods of great tumult and violent change, or when your enemies are numerous. The more patrons and masters you serve the less risk you run if one of them falls from power. Such dispersion will even allow you to play one off against die other. Even if you concentrate on die single source of power, you still must practice caution, and j repare for the day when your master or patron is no longer there to help you.
切萨雷已死无葬身之地。多年来他树敌太多，如今又失去了父亲的庇护。因此，当你需要保护时，明智的做法往往是与多个权力来源建立联系。在动荡不安、剧变频发的时期，或者敌人众多之时，这种做法尤为谨慎。你效忠的庇护者和主宰越多，一旦其中一人失势，你面临的风险就越小。这种分散之道甚至可以让你利用各方势力之间的矛盾。即便你专注于单一的权力来源，也必须保持谨慎，并为你的主宰或庇护者不再庇护你的那一天做好准备。
Finally, being too single-minded in purpose can make you an intolerable bore, especially in die arts. The Renaissance painter Paolo Uccello was so obsessed widi perspective diat his paintings look lifeless and contrived. Whereas Leonardo da Vinci interested himself in everythingarchitecture, painting, warfare, sculpture, mechanics. Diffusion was the source of his power. But such genius is rare, and the rest of us are better off erring on the side of intensity.
最后，过于执着于单一目标会让你变得令人难以忍受，尤其是在艺术领域。文艺复兴时期的画家保罗·乌切洛痴迷于透视法，以至于他的画作显得死气沉沉、矫揉造作。而列奥纳多·达·芬奇则对建筑、绘画、战争、雕塑、机械等各个方面都充满兴趣。博采众长是他力量的源泉。但这样的天才凤毛麟角，我们大多数人最好还是在专注力上多下些功夫。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 24
第24条
PLAY THE PERFECT COURTIER
扮演完美的宫廷侍臣
JUDGMENT
判断
The perfect courtier thrives in a world where everything revolves around power and political dexterity. He has mastered the art of indirection; he flatters, yields to superiors, and asserts power over others in the most oblique and graceful manner. Learn and apply the laws of courtiership and there will be no limit to how far you can rise in the court.
一位完美的朝臣在权力与政治手腕至上的世界里如鱼得水。他精通迂回之术，奉承上级，以最委婉优雅的方式掌控他人。学习并运用朝臣之道，你在朝廷中将如鱼得水，步步高升。
COURT SOCIETY
法院协会
It is a fact of human nature r^t the structure of a court society forms itself around power. In the pasVthe court garnered around the ruler, and had many functions: Besides keeping the ruler amused, it was a way to solidify the hierarchy of royalty, nobility, and the upper classes, and to keep the nobility both subordinate and close to the ruler, so that he could keep an eye on them. The court serves power in many ways, but most of all it glorifies the ruler, providing him with a microcosmic world that must struggle to please him.
人性使然，宫廷社会的结构围绕权力而形成。过去，宫廷围绕着统治者聚集，承担着诸多职能：除了取悦统治者之外，它还巩固了王室、贵族和上层阶级的等级制度，使贵族既服从于统治者又与统治者保持密切联系，以便统治者能够监视他们。宫廷以多种方式服务于权力，但最重要的是，它荣耀统治者，为他提供了一个必须竭力取悦他的微观世界。
To be a courtier was a dangerous game. A nineteenth-century Arab traveler to the court of Darfur, in what is now Sudan, reported that courtiers there had to do whatever the sultan did: If he were injured, they had to suffer me same injury; if he fell off his horse during a hunt, they fell, too. Mimicry like tiiis appeared in courts all over the world. More troublesome was the danger of displeasing the rulerone wrong move spelled death or exile. The successful courtier had to walk a tightrope, pleasing but not pleasing too much, obeying but somehow distinguishing himself from the other courtiers, while also never distinguishing himself so far as to make the ruler insecure.
做朝臣是一场危险的游戏。一位十九世纪前往达尔富尔（今苏丹境内）宫廷的阿拉伯旅行者记载，那里的朝臣必须效仿苏丹的一举一动：苏丹若受伤，他们也必须承受同样的伤痛；苏丹狩猎时若从马上摔下来，他们也必须跟着摔下去。类似的模仿在世界各地的宫廷中屡见不鲜。更棘手的是触怒统治者的危险——一步走错，便可能招致死刑或流放。成功的朝臣必须如履薄冰，既要讨好统治者，又不能过度讨好；既要服从，又要设法与其他朝臣区分开来；同时，又不能过于张扬，以免令统治者感到不安。
Great courtiers diroughout history have mastered the science of manipulating people. They make die king feel more kingly; they make everyone else fear dieir power. They are magicians of appearance, knowing that most things at court are judged by how diey seem. Great courtiers are gracious and polite; their aggression is veiled and indirect. Masters of the word, they never say more dian necessary, getting the most out of a compliment or hidden insult. They are magnets of pleasurepeople want to be around them because they know how to please, yet they neitiier fawn nor humiliate tiiemselves. Great courtiers become the king's favorites, enjoying the benefits of that position. They often end up more powerful than the ruler, for mey are wizards in the accumulation of influence.
纵观历史，伟大的朝臣都精通操纵人心的艺术。他们让君王倍感威严，让所有人畏惧他们的权力。他们是外表的魔术师，深谙宫廷中大多数事情都取决于外表。伟大的朝臣彬彬有礼，他们的攻击性隐藏而间接。他们精于言辞，从不多言，总能将赞美或隐晦的讽刺发挥到极致。他们是快乐的磁石，人们渴望与他们相处，因为他们懂得如何取悦他人，却从不阿谀奉承或自贬身价。伟大的朝臣成为君王的宠臣，享受着这一地位带来的好处。他们最终往往比君王更加强大，因为他们是积累影响力的奇才。
Many today dismiss court life as a relic of the past, a historical curiosity. They reason, according to Machiavelli, “as though heaven, the sun, die elements, and men had changed the order of their motions and power, and were different from what they were in ancient times.” There may be no more Sun Kings but there are still plenty of people who believe the sun revolves around diem. The royal court may have more or less disappeared, or at least lost its power, but courts and courtiers still exist because power still exists. A courtier is rarely asked to fall off a horse anymore, but the laws tiiat govern court politics are as timeless as the laws of power. There is much to be learned, then, from great courtiers past and present.
如今许多人将宫廷生活视为历史遗迹，一种历史奇观。正如马基雅维利所言，他们的理由是“仿佛天地、太阳、元素和人类的运行规律和力量都发生了改变，与古代截然不同”。或许太阳王已不复存在，但仍有许多人相信太阳围绕着地球运转。王室宫廷或许已基本消失，或者至少失去了权力，但宫廷和朝臣依然存在，因为权力依然存在。朝臣如今很少再被要求从马上摔下来，但支配宫廷政治的法则却如同权力法则一样永恒不变。因此，我们可以从古今伟大的朝臣身上学到许多东西。
THE LAWS OF COURT POLITICS
法院政治的法律
Avoid Ostentation. It is never prudent to prattle on about yourself or call too much attention to your actions. The more you talk about your deeds
避免炫耀。喋喋不休地谈论自己或过分强调自己的行为绝非明智之举。你越是谈论自己的所作所为，就越容易招致他人的注意。
the two no(;s
这两个数字
Barbos, the faithful yard-dog who serves his master zealously. happens to see his old acquaintance Joujou, the curly lapdog, seated at the window on a soft down cushion. Sidling fondly up to her, like a child to a parent, he all but weeps with emotion; and there, under the window, he whines, wags his tail, and bounds about. “What sort of life do you lead now, Joujoutka, ever since the master took you into his mansion You remember, no doubt, how we often used to suffer hunger out in the yard. What is your present service like” “It would be a sin in me to murmur against my good fortune, ” answers Joujoutka. “My master cannot make enough of me. I live amidst riches and plenty, and I eat and drink off silver. 1 frolic with the master, and, if I get tired, I take my ease on carpels or on a soft couch. And how do you get on” “I” replies Barbos, letting his tail dangle like a whip, and hanging his head. "I live as J used to do. I suffer from cold and hunger; and here, while guarding my master's house, I have to sleep at the foot of the wall, and I get drenched in the rain. And if 1 bark at the wrong time, I am whipped. But how did you, Joujou, who were
忠心耿耿的管家犬巴博斯，偶然间看见老朋友——卷毛小狗茹茹正坐在窗边柔软的羽绒垫上。他像孩子依偎在父母身边一样，亲昵地凑到茹茹跟前，激动得几乎要哭出来；于是，他趴在窗下，呜咽着，摇着尾巴，蹦蹦跳跳。“茹茹，自从主人把你带进他的宅邸后，你现在过得怎么样？你肯定还记得，我们以前经常在院子里挨饿。你现在的工作怎么样？”“我有什么资格抱怨我的好运呢？”茹茹回答道。 “我的主人怎么也用不着我。我生活在富饶之中，吃喝都用银器。我和主人一起玩耍，累了就躺在扶手椅或软榻上休息。你过得怎么样？”“我，”巴博斯回答道，尾巴像鞭子一样垂着，低着头。“我的生活和以前一样。我挨饿受冻；现在，我守卫着主人的房子，却只能睡在墙脚下，被雨淋透。如果我吠叫的时间不对，就会被鞭打。但是，朱朱，你以前过得怎么样？”
so small and weak, get taken into favor, while I jump out of my skin to no purpose What is it you do “ ” 'What is it you do ' A pretty question to ask!“ replied Joujou, mockingly. ”I walk upon my hind legs."
如此渺小弱小，却能受人宠爱，而我却徒劳无功地跳来跳去。“你到底在做什么？”“你到底在做什么？”朱朱嘲讽地回答道，“真是个好问题！我用后腿走路。”
,
Ivan Kriloff,
伊万·克里洛夫
1768-1844
the more suspicion you cause. You also stir up enough envy among your peers to induce treachery and backstabbing. Be careful, ever so careful, in trumpeting your own achievements, and always talk less about yourself than about other people. Modesty is generally preferable.
你越是引起猜疑，就越容易招致嫉妒。你也会在同辈中激起足够的嫉妒，从而导致背叛和背后捅刀。所以，在吹嘘自己的成就时，务必格外小心，永远少谈自己，多谈他人。谦逊通常是更好的选择。
Practice Nonchalance. Never seem to be working too hard. Your talent must appear to flow naturally, with an ease that makes people take you for a genius rather than a workaholic. Even when something demands a lot of sweat, make it look effortlesspeople prefer to not see your blood and toil, which is another form of ostentation. It is better for them to marvel at how gracefully you have achieved your accomplishment than to wonder why it took so much work.
练习那种漫不经心的态度。永远不要显得太过努力。你的才华必须自然流露，轻松自如，让人觉得你是个天才，而不是工作狂。即使某件事需要付出大量汗水，也要表现得毫不费力——人们不喜欢看到你流血的汗水和辛劳，因为那也是一种炫耀。与其让他们疑惑你为什么付出了那么多努力，不如让他们惊叹于你优雅地完成了任务。
/; is a wise thing to be polite; consequently, it is a stupid thing to be rude. To make enemies by unnecessary and wilful incivility, is just as insane a proceeding as to set your house on fire. For politeness is like a counteran avowedly false coin, with which it is foolish to be stingy. A sensible man will be generous in the use of it.... Wax, a substance naturally hard and brittle, can be made soft by the application of a little warmth, so that it will take any shape you please. In the same way, by being polite and friendly, you can make people pliable and obliging, even though they are apt to be crabbed and malevolent. Hence politeness is to human nature what warmth is to wax.
礼貌待人是明智之举；因此，粗鲁无礼则是愚蠢之举。故意无礼地树敌，就好比放火烧房子一样荒唐。礼貌就像一枚假币，吝啬使用是愚蠢的。明智的人会慷慨地使用它……蜡，一种天然坚硬易碎的物质，只需稍加加热即可软化，从而可以塑造成任何你想要的形状。同样，礼貌友善也能使人变得顺从，即使他们原本脾气暴躁、心怀恶意。因此，礼貌之于人性，正如温暖之于蜡。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
Be Frugal with Flattery. It may seem that your superiors cannot get enough flattery, but too much of even a good thing loses its value. It also stirs up suspicion among your peers. Learn to flatter indirectlyby downplaying your own contribution, for example, to make your master look better.
要克制奉承。你的上司似乎永远不嫌奉承多，但过犹不及，即使是好事也会失去价值，还会引起同僚的怀疑。学会间接奉承，比如淡化自己的贡献，让你的上司看起来更出色。
Arrange to Be Noticed. There is a paradox: You cannot display yourself too brazenly, yet you must also get yourself noticed. In the court of Louis XIV, whoever the king decided to look at rose instandy in the court hierarchy. You stand no chance of rising if the ruler does not notice you in the swamp of courtiers. This task requires much art. It is often initially a matter of being seen, in the literal sense. Pay attention to your physical appearance, then, and find a way to create a distinctivea subtly distinctivestyle and image.
设法引人注目。这其中存在一个悖论：你不能过于张扬，但又必须让自己被人注意到。在路易十四的宫廷里，国王一旦注意到谁，谁就能立刻在宫廷等级制度中脱颖而出。如果统治者没有在熙熙攘攘的朝臣中注意到你，你就没有晋升的机会。这需要高超的技巧。一开始，这往往意味着要被人看到，字面意义上的“看到”。因此，要注重你的外表，并找到一种方法来打造一种独特而微妙的风格和形象。
Alter Your Style and Language According to the Person You Are Dealing With. The pseudo-belief in equalitydie idea that talking and acting the same way with everyone, no matter what their rank, makes you somehow a paragon of civilizationis a terrible mistake. Those below you will take it as a form of condescension, which it is, and those above you will be offended, although they may not admit it. You must change your style and your way of speaking to suit each person. This is not lying, it is acting, and acting is an art, not a gift from God. Learn the art. This is also true for the great variety of cultures found in the modern court: Never assume that your criteria of behavior and judgment are universal. Not only is an inability to adapt to another culture the height of barbarism, it puts you at a disadvantage.
根据你交往的对象调整你的风格和语言。那种认为无论对方地位高低都以同样方式说话做事就能让你成为文明典范的伪善想法，是一个可怕的错误。地位低于你的人会将其视为一种居高临下的姿态（事实也的确如此），而地位高于你的人则会感到被冒犯，尽管他们可能不会承认。你必须根据每个人的情况调整你的风格和说话方式。这并非撒谎，而是表演，而表演是一门艺术，而非上帝的恩赐。学习这门艺术。这同样适用于现代法庭中形形色色的文化：永远不要想当然地认为你的行为和判断标准是普适的。无法适应其他文化不仅是野蛮的体现，还会让你处于不利地位。
Never Be the Bearer of Bad News. The king kills the messenger who brings bad news: This is a cliche but there is truth to it. You must struggle and if necessary lie and cheat to be sure that the lot of the bearer of bad news falls on a colleague, never on you. Bring only good news and your approach will gladden your master.
永远不要成为坏消息的传递者。国王会处死带来坏消息的信使：这虽然是老生常谈，但其中蕴含着真理。你必须竭尽全力，必要时甚至撒谎欺骗，确保坏消息的传递者是你的同事，而不是你。只传递好消息，你的做法才会令你的主人满意。
ISO
ISO
Never Affect Friendliness and Intimacy with Your Master. He does not want a friend for a subordinate, he wants a subordinate. Never approach him in an easy, friendly way, or act as if you are on the best of termsthat is his prerogative. If he chooses to deal with you on this level, assume a wary chumminess. Otherwise err in the opposite direction, and make the distance between you clear.
切勿与你的上司表现得亲近友好。他需要的不是朋友，而是下属。永远不要以轻松友好的方式接近他，也不要表现得好像你们关系很好——这是他的特权。如果他选择以这种方式与你相处，那就保持警惕的亲昵。否则，就应该反其道而行之，明确地与他保持距离。
Never Criticize Those Above You Directly. This may seem obvious, but there are often times when some sort of criticism is necessaryto say nothing, or to give no advice, would open you to risks of another sort. You must learn, however, to couch your advice and criticism as indirectly and as politely as possible. Think twice, or three times, before deciding you have made them sufficiently circuitous. Err on the side of subtlety and gentieness.
永远不要直接批评上级。这看似显而易见，但很多时候，提出批评意见是必要的——保持沉默或不提供建议，会让你面临另一种风险。然而，你必须学会尽可能委婉、礼貌地提出建议和批评。在认为你的措辞足够委婉之前，务必三思。宁可委婉，也要彬彬有礼。
Be Frugal in Asking Those Above You for Favors. Nothing irritates a master more than having to reject someone's request. It stirs up guilt and resentment. Ask for favors as rarely as possible, and know when to stop. Rather than making yourself the supplicant, it is always better to earn your favors, so that the ruler bestows them willingly. Most important: Do not ask for favors on another person's behalf, least of all a friend's.
向上级求助时要谨慎。没有什么比拒绝别人的请求更让上级恼火的了，这会让他感到内疚和怨恨。尽量少求人帮忙，并且要知道何时该停止。与其卑躬屈膝，不如努力赢得恩惠，这样上级才会心甘情愿地赐予。最重要的是：不要替别人求人帮忙，尤其是朋友。
Never Joke About Appearances or Taste. A lively wit and a humorous disposition are essential qualities for a good courtier, and there are times when vulgarity is appropriate and engaging. But avoid any kind of joke about appearance or taste, two highly sensitive areas, especially with those above you. Do not even try it when you are away from them. You will dig your own grave.
切勿拿容貌或品味开玩笑。机智幽默是优秀朝臣的必备素质，有时粗俗的言辞也恰到好处，令人忍俊不禁。但切忌拿容貌或品味开玩笑，因为这是两个极其敏感的领域，尤其是在你的上级面前。即使不在他们面前，也千万不要这么做。否则，你将自掘坟墓。
Do Not Be the Court Cynic. Express admiration for the good work of others. If you constandy criticize your equals or subordinates some of that criticism will rub off on you, hovering over you like a gray cloud wherever you go. People will groan at each new cynical comment, and you will irritate them. By expressing modest admiration for other people's achievements, you paradoxically call attention to your own. The ability to express wonder and amazement, and seem like you mean it, is a rare and dying talent, but one still greatiy valued.
不要做个愤世嫉俗的人。要对别人的出色工作表示赞赏。如果你总是批评你的同僚或下属，这些批评也会潜移默化地影响到你，像乌云一样笼罩着你。人们会对你每一句新的愤世嫉俗的评论感到厌烦，你会惹恼他们。通过对别人的成就表达谦逊的赞赏，你反而会更加引人注目地展现自己的成就。能够真诚地表达惊叹和赞叹，是一种稀有且正在消逝的才能，但仍然弥足珍贵。
Be Self-observant The mirror is a miraculous invention; without it you would commit great sins against beauty and decorum. You also need a mirror for your actions. This can sometimes come from other people telling you what they see in you, but that is not the most trustworthy method: You must be the mirror, training your mind to try to see yourself as others see you. Are you acting too obsequious Are you trying too hard to please Do you seem desperate for attention, giving the impression that you are on the decline Be observant about yourself and you will avoid a mountain of blunders.
要善于自省。镜子是一项神奇的发明；没有它，你会犯下许多有损美感和礼仪的错误。你也需要一面镜子来审视自己的行为。有时，别人会告诉你他们眼中的你，但这并非最可靠的方法：你必须成为自己的镜子，训练你的思维去尝试从别人的角度看待自己。你是否表现得过于谄媚？你是否过于刻意地讨好别人？你是否显得渴望关注，给人一种你正在走下坡路的印象？善于自省，你就能避免犯下无数错误。
Master Your Emotions. As an actor in a great play, you must learn to cry and laugh on command and when it is appropriate. You must be able both to disguise your anger and frustration and to fake your contentment and agreement. You must be the master of your own face. Call it lying if you like; but if you prefer to not play the game and to always be honest and upfront, do not complain when others call you obnoxious and arrogant.
掌控你的情绪。作为一名优秀演员，你必须学会根据指令在合适的时机哭泣和大笑。你必须能够掩饰愤怒和沮丧，也能伪装满意和赞同。你必须掌控自己的表情。你可以称之为撒谎；但如果你不想玩弄这些游戏，而是想始终坦诚直率，那么当别人说你傲慢无礼时，就不要抱怨。
Fit the Spirit of the Times. A slight affectation of a past era can be charming, as long as you choose a period at least twenty years back; wearing the fashions of ten years ago is ludicrous, unless you enjoy the role of court jester. Your spirit and way of thinking must keep up with the times, even if the times offend your sensibilities. Be too forward-thinking, however, and no one will understand you. It is never a good idea to stand out too much in this area; you are best off at least being able to mimic the spirit of the times.
顺应时代精神。略微模仿过去某个时代或许别有一番魅力，但前提是你选择的至少是二十年前的风格；穿着十年前的服饰就显得滑稽可笑，除非你乐于扮演宫廷小丑的角色。你的精神和思维方式必须与时俱进，即便时代潮流有时会冒犯你的审美。然而，过于超前则无人理解。在这方面，过于标新立异绝非明智之举；你最好至少能够模仿时代的精神。
Be a Source of Pleasure. This is critical. It is an obvious law of human nature that we will flee what is unpleasant and distasteful, while charm and the promise of delight will draw us like moths to a flame. Make yourself the flame and you will rise to the top. Since life is otherwise so full of unpleasantness and pleasure so scarce, you will be as indispensable as food and drink. This may seem obvious, but what is obvious is often ignored or unappreciated. There are degrees to this: Not everyone can play the role of favorite, for not everyone is blessed with charm and wit. But we can all control our unpleasant qualities and obscure them when necessary.
成为快乐的源泉。这一点至关重要。人性中有一条显而易见的规律：我们会逃避不愉快和令人厌恶的事物，而魅力和愉悦的承诺则会像飞蛾扑火般吸引我们。让自己成为那团火焰，你就能脱颖而出。因为生活充斥着如此多的不愉快，快乐又如此稀缺，你就会像食物和水一样不可或缺。这或许看似显而易见，但显而易见的道理往往被忽视或低估。当然，这其中也存在程度上的差异：并非每个人都能成为众人瞩目的焦点，因为并非每个人都天生拥有魅力和智慧。但我们都可以控制自身的缺点，并在必要时巧妙地掩盖它们。
A man who knows the court is master of his gestures, of his eyes and
一个了解宫廷的人，能够掌控自己的举止、眼神和……
of his face; he is profound, impenetrable; he dissimulates bad offices,
他面容深邃，难以捉摸；他掩饰不住不良行为。
smiles at his enemies, controls his irritation, disguises his passions,
他面带微笑地面对敌人，克制住自己的怒火，掩饰自己的激情。
belies his heart, speaks and acts against his feelings.
违背内心，言行不一。
Jean de La Bruyere, 16451696
让·德·拉布吕耶尔，1645-1696年
SCENES OF COURT LIFE: Exemplary Deeds and Fatal Mistakes
法庭生活场景：楷模事迹与致命失误
Scene I
第一幕
Alexander the Great, conqueror of the Mediterranean basin and the Middle East through to India, had had the great Aristotle as his tutor and mentor, and throughout his short life he remained devoted to philosophy and his master's teachings. He once complained to Aristotle that during his long campaigns he had no one with whom he could discuss philosophical matters. Aristotle responded by suggesting that he take Callisthenes, a former pupil of Aristotle's and a promising philosopher in his own right, along on the next campaign.
征服了地中海盆地、中东乃至印度的亚历山大大帝，曾以伟大的亚里士多德为师。在他短暂的一生中，他始终致力于哲学研究和学习老师的教诲。他曾向亚里士多德抱怨，在漫长的征战中，他找不到人与他探讨哲学问题。亚里士多德建议他下次征战时带上卡利斯提尼——卡利斯提尼是亚里士多德的学生，也是一位颇有前途的哲学家。
Aristotle had schooled Callisthenes in the skills of being a courtier, but
亚里士多德曾教导卡利斯提尼如何成为一名宫廷侍臣，但是
the young man secretly scoffed at them. He believed in pure philosophy, in unadorned words, in speaking the naked truth. If Alexander loved learning so much, Callisthenes thought, he could not object to one who spoke his mind. During one of Alexander's major campaigns, Callisthenes spoke his mind one too many times and Alexander had him put to death. Interpretation
这位年轻人暗自嘲笑他们。他信奉纯粹的哲学，崇尚朴实无华的语言，主张直言不讳。卡利斯提尼心想，如果亚历山大如此热爱学习，他又怎会反对一个敢于直言的人呢？在亚历山大的一次重大战役中，卡利斯提尼的直言不讳实在太多，最终被亚历山大处死。
In court, honesty is a fool's game. Never be so self-absorbed as to believe that the master is interested in your criticisms of him, no matter how accurate they are.
在法庭上，诚实是徒劳的。千万不要自以为是，以为主人会对你的批评感兴趣，无论你的批评多么准确。
Scene II
第二幕
Beginning in the Han Dynasty two thousand years ago, Chinese scholars compiled a series of writings called the 21 Histories, an official biography of each dynasty, including stories, statistics, census figures, and war chronicles. Each history also contained a chapter called “Unusual Events,” and here, among the listings of earthquakes and floods, there would sometimes suddenly appear descriptions of such bizarre manifestations as two-headed sheep, geese flying backward, stars suddenly appearing in different parts of the sky, and so on. The earthquakes could be historically verified, but the monsters and weird natural phenomena were clearly inserted on purpose, and invariably occurred in clusters. What could this mean
两千年前汉代开始，中国学者编纂了一系列著作，称为《二十一部史》，作为每个朝代的官方传记，内容包括故事、统计数据、人口普查数据和战争史记。每部史书都包含一个名为“奇事”的章节，在这个章节中，除了列举地震和洪水等自然灾害外，有时会突然出现一些奇异现象的描述，例如双头羊、倒飞的鹅、星辰突然出现在天空的不同位置等等。地震事件在历史上是有据可查的，但这些怪兽和奇异的自然现象显然是人为添加的，而且总是成群出现。这究竟意味着什么呢？
The Chinese emperor was considered more than a manhe was a force of nature. His kingdom was the center of the universe, and everything revolved around him. He embodied the world's perfection. To criticize him or any of his actions would have been to criticize the divine order. No minister or courtier dared approach the emperor with even the slightest cautionary word. But emperors were fallible and the kingdom suffered gready by their mistakes. Inserting sightings of strange phenomena into the court chronicles was the only way to warn them. The emperor would read of geese flying backward and moons out of orbit, and realize that he was being cautioned. His actions were unbalancing the universe and needed to change. Interpretation
中国皇帝被视为超越凡人的神明，他如同自然之力。他的王国是宇宙的中心，万物都围绕着他运转。他象征着世界的完美。批评他或他的任何行为，都等同于挑战神圣的秩序。没有哪个大臣或朝臣敢于向皇帝提出哪怕是最轻微的警告。然而，皇帝也会犯错，他们的错误会给王国带来巨大的损失。将奇异现象的目击记录写入宫廷史册，是唯一能够发出警告的方式。皇帝会读到大雁倒飞、月亮偏离轨道等记载，意识到自己受到了警告。他的行为正在扰乱宇宙的平衡，需要做出改变。
For Chinese courtiers, the problem of how to give the emperor advice was an important issue. Over the years, thousands of them had died trying to warn or counsel their master. To be made safely, their criticisms had to be indirectyet if they were too indirect they would not be heeded. The chronicles were their solution: Identify no one person as the source of criticism, make the advice as impersonal as possible, but let the emperor know the gravity of the situation.
对中国朝臣而言，如何向皇帝提出建议是一个至关重要的问题。多年来，成千上万的朝臣为了劝诫或劝谏皇帝而丧命。为了确保安全，他们的批评必须委婉，但如果过于隐晦，又容易被忽视。史书便成了他们的解决之道：不指明批评的具体对象，尽可能使建议客观中立，但又能让皇帝了解事态的严重性。
Your master is no longer the center of the universe, but he still imagines that everything revolves around him. When you criticize him he sees the person criticizing, not the criticism itself. Like the Chinese courtiers, you must find a way to disappear behind the warning. Use symbols and other indirect methods to paint a picture of the problems to come, without putting your neck on the line.
你的主人不再是宇宙的中心，但他仍然认为一切都围绕着他转。当你批评他时，他看到的只是批评者本人，而不是批评的内容。就像中国古代的朝臣一样，你必须找到一种方法，巧妙地隐藏在警告背后。运用象征和其他间接的手段，描绘出即将出现的问题，而不要让自己身陷险境。
Scene III
第三幕
Early in his career, the French architect Jules Mansart received commissions to design minor additions to Versailles for King Louis XIV. For each design he would draw up his plans, making sure they followed Louis's instructions closely. He would then present them to His Majesty.
法国建筑师儒勒·芒萨尔早年曾受路易十四国王委托，为凡尔赛宫设计一些小型扩建工程。每次设计，他都会绘制图纸，确保严格按照路易十四的指示进行，然后呈递给国王陛下。
The courtier Saint-Simon described Mansart's technique in dealing with the king: “His particular skill was to show the king plans that purposely included something imperfect about them, often dealing with the gardens, which were not Mansart's specialty. The king, as Mansart expected, would put his finger exacdy on the problem and propose how to solve it, at which point Mansart would exclaim for all to hear that he would never have seen the problem that the king had so masterfully found and solved; he would burst with admiration, confessing that next to the king he was but a lowly pupil.” At the age of thirty, having used these methods time and time again, Mansart received a prestigious royal commission: Although he was less talented and experienced than a number of other French designers, he was to take charge of the enlargement of Versailles. He was the king's architect from then on. Interpretation
宫廷侍臣圣西蒙描述了芒萨尔与国王打交道的技巧：“他特别擅长向国王展示一些故意带有瑕疵的设计图，这些瑕疵通常与花园有关，而花园并非芒萨尔的专长。正如芒萨尔所料，国王总能一针见血地指出问题所在，并提出解决方案。这时，芒萨尔便会当着众人的面惊叹，说自己从未想到过国王如此巧妙地发现并解决了这个问题；他会满怀钦佩地承认，在国王面前，自己不过是个卑微的学生。”三十岁时，芒萨尔凭借着屡试不爽的技巧，获得了一项重要的皇家委托：尽管他的才华和经验不及其他一些法国设计师，但他仍将负责凡尔赛宫的扩建工程。从此，他成为了国王的御用建筑师。
As a young man, Mansart had seen how many royal craftsmen in the service of Louis XIV had lost their positions not through a lack of talent but through a costly social blunder. He would not make that mistake. Mansart always strove to make Louis feel better about himself, to feed the king's vanity as publicly as possible.
年轻时的曼萨尔亲眼目睹了路易十四麾下许多皇家工匠并非因才华不足而失势，而是因为代价惨重的社交失误。他绝不会重蹈覆辙。曼萨尔始终竭尽所能地让路易十四感觉良好，尽可能公开地迎合国王的虚荣心。
Never imagine that skill and talent are all mat matter. In court the courtier's art is more important than his talent; never spend so much time on your studies that you neglect your social skills. And the greatest skill of all is the ability to make the master look more talented than those around him.
切莫以为技巧和天赋就万事大吉。在宫廷里，臣子的技艺比天赋更为重要；切勿因埋头苦读而忽略了社交能力。而最伟大的技艺莫过于让主人看起来比周围的人更有才华。
Scene IV
第四幕
Jean-Baptiste Isabey had become the unofficial painter of the Napoleonic court. During the Congress of Vienna in 1814, after Napoleon, defeated, had been imprisoned on the island of Elba, the participants in these meetings, which were to decide the fate of Europe, invited Isabey to immortalize the historic events in an epic painting.
让-巴蒂斯特·伊萨贝成为了拿破仑宫廷的非官方画家。1814年维也纳会议期间，战败的拿破仑被囚禁在厄尔巴岛，与会代表邀请伊萨贝用一幅史诗般的画作来记录这些历史事件。这些会议旨在决定欧洲的命运。
When Isabey arrived in Vienna, Talleyrand, the main negotiator for the French, paid the artist a visit. Considering his role in the proceedings, the statesman explained, he expected to occupy center stage in the painting. Isabey cordially agreed. A few days later the Duke of Wellington, the main negotiator for the English, also approached Isabey, and said much the same thing that Talleyrand had. The ever polite Isabey agreed that the great duke should indeed be the center of attention.
伊萨贝抵达维也纳后，法国首席谈判代表塔列朗拜访了他。这位政治家解释说，考虑到他在谈判中的角色，他希望自己能成为画作的中心人物。伊萨贝欣然同意。几天后，英国首席谈判代表威灵顿公爵也前来拜访伊萨贝，并表达了与塔列朗大致相同的意愿。一向彬彬有礼的伊萨贝同意，这位伟大的公爵的确应该成为画作的焦点。
Back in his studio, Isabey pondered the dilemma. If he gave the spotlight to either of the two men, he could create a diplomatic rift, stirring up all sorts of resentment at a time when peace and concord were critical.
回到工作室后，伊萨贝陷入了沉思。如果他把聚光灯放在这两个人中的任何一个身上，都可能造成外交裂痕，在和平与和谐至关重要的时刻，激起各种各样的怨恨。
When the painting was finally unveiled, however, both Talleyrand and Wellington felt honored and satisfied. The work depicts a large hall filled with diplomats and politicians from all over Europe. On one side die Duke of Wellington enters the room, and all eyes are turned toward him; he is the “center” of attention. In the very center of the painting, meanwhile, sits Talleyrand. Interpretation
然而，当这幅画最终揭幕时，塔列朗和惠灵顿都感到无比荣幸和满足。画中描绘了一个大厅，里面挤满了来自欧洲各地的外交官和政治家。惠灵顿公爵从一侧走进房间，所有人的目光都转向他；他是众人瞩目的焦点。与此同时，在画作的正中央，坐着塔列朗。
It is often very difficult to satisfy the master, but to satisfy two masters in one stroke takes die genius of a great courtier. Such predicaments are common in the life of a courtier: By giving attention to one master, he displeases anotfier. You must find a way to navigate mis Scylla and Charybdis safely. Masters must receive tiieir due; never inadvertendy stir up the resentment of one in pleasing another.
取悦一位主人往往难上加难，而要同时取悦两位主人，则需要一位杰出廷臣的智慧。这种困境在廷臣的生活中屡见不鲜：讨好一位主人，往往会触怒另一位主人。你必须找到一条出路，才能在两难境地中游刃有余。主人必须得到应有的赏赐；切勿在取悦一位主人的同时，无意中激起另一位主人的怨恨。
Scene V
第五幕
George Brummell, also known as Beau Brummell, made his mark in die late 1700s by the supreme elegance of his appearance, his popularization of shoe buckles (soon imitated by all the dandies), and his clever way with words. His London house was the fashionable spot in town, and Brummell was the authority on all matters of fashion. If he disliked your footwear, you immediately got rid of it and bought whatever he was wearing. He perfected the art of tying a cravat; Lord Byron was said to spend many a night in front of die mirror trying to figure out die secret behind Brummell's perfect knots.
乔治·布鲁梅尔，又名博·布鲁梅尔，在18世纪末凭借其极致优雅的外表、对鞋扣的推广（很快便被所有纨绔子弟争相效仿）以及妙语连珠而声名鹊起。他在伦敦的住所是城中最时髦的去处，而布鲁梅尔本人则是时尚界的权威。如果他不喜欢你的鞋子，你最好立刻扔掉，买下他穿的那双。他精通领带的系法；据说拜伦勋爵曾无数次对着镜子苦思冥想，试图弄明白布鲁梅尔完美领带结的秘密。
One of Brummell's greatest admirers was the Prince of Wales, who fancied himself a fashionable young man. Becoming attached to the prince's court (and provided witii a royal pension), Brummell was soon so sure of his own authority tiiere that he took to joking about the prince's weight, referring to his host as Big Ben. Since trimness of figure was an important quality for a dandy, this was a withering criticism. At dinner once, when the service was slow, Brummell said to the prince, “Do ring, Big Ben.” The prince rang, but when die valet arrived he ordered the man to show Brummell the door and never admit him again.
布鲁梅尔最崇拜的人之一是威尔士亲王，他自诩为一位时髦的年轻人。布鲁梅尔很快便与亲王的宫廷建立了密切的联系（并获得了皇家年金），他对自己地位的自信与日俱增，甚至开始拿亲王的体重开玩笑，称他为“大本钟”。由于身材匀称是花花公子的重要品质，这无疑是一种尖刻的批评。有一次晚宴上，由于服务迟缓，布鲁梅尔对亲王说：“大本钟，请按铃。”亲王按了铃，但当侍从赶来时，他却命令侍从把布鲁梅尔赶出去，并永远不许他再进来。
Despite falling into die prince's disfavor, Brummell continued to treat everyone around him with the same arrogance. Without the Prince of Wales' patronage to support him, he sank into horrible debt, but he maintained his insolent manners, and everyone soon abandoned him. He died in the most pitiable poverty, alone and deranged. Interpretation
尽管失宠于威尔士亲王，布鲁梅尔依然傲慢地对待身边所有人。失去威尔士亲王的庇护后，他债台高筑，但他依然我行我素，傲慢无礼，最终人人都离他而去。他孤独地死去，精神错乱，穷困潦倒，令人唏嘘。
Beau Brummell's devastating wit was one of die qualities mat endeared him to the Prince of Wales. But not even he, the arbiter of taste and fashion, could get away with a joke about the prince's appearance, least of all to his face. Never joke about a person's plumpness, even indirecdyand particularly when he is your master. The poorhouses of history are filled with people who have made such jokes at their master's expense.
博·布鲁梅尔的机智幽默是他深受威尔士亲王喜爱的原因之一。但即便如此，这位品味和时尚的权威，也不能拿亲王的容貌开玩笑，更不能当面开这种玩笑。永远不要拿别人的身材开玩笑，哪怕是间接的，尤其当他是你的主人时。历史上，那些拿主人的身材开玩笑的人，个个都落得如此下场。
Scene VI
第六幕
Pope Urban VIII wanted to be remembered for his skills in writing poetry, which unfortunately were mediocre at best. In 1629 Duke Francesco d'Este, knowing the pope's literary pretensions, sent the poet Fulvio Testi as his ambassador to the Vatican. One of Testi's letters to the duke reveals why he was chosen: “Once our discussion was over, I kneeled to depart, but His Holiness made a signal and walked to another room where he sleeps, and after reaching a small table, he grabbed a bundle of papers and thus, turning to me witii a smiling face, he said: 'We want Your Lordship to listen to some of our compositions.' And, in fact, he read me two very long Pindaric poems, one in praise of the most holy Virgin, and die other one about Countess Matilde.”
教皇乌尔班八世希望后人记住他的诗歌才华，可惜他的诗作充其量只能算平庸。1629年，弗朗切斯科·德·埃斯特公爵深知教皇的文学野心，便派遣诗人富尔维奥·泰斯蒂作为使节前往梵蒂冈。泰斯蒂写给公爵的一封信揭示了他被选中的原因：“会谈结束后，我跪下准备离开，但教皇陛下示意我离开，然后走到他睡觉的房间，来到一张小桌子旁，拿起一叠纸张，面带微笑地转向我说：‘我们想请陛下听听我们的一些作品。’事实上，他给我朗诵了两首很长的品达风格的诗歌，一首赞美至圣圣母玛利亚，另一首则描写玛蒂尔德伯爵夫人。”
We do not know exactly what Testi thought of these very long poems, since it would have been dangerous for him to state his opinion freely, even in a letter. But he went on to write, “I, following the mood, commented on each line with the needed praise, and, after having kissed His Holiness's foot for such an unusual sign of benevolence [the reading of the poetry], I left.” Weeks later, when the duke himself visited die pope, he managed to recite entire verses of die pope's poetry and praised it enough to make the pope “so jubilant he seemed to lose his mind.” Interpretation
我们并不确切知道泰斯蒂对这些长诗作的看法，因为即便是在信中，他也不敢轻易表达自己的意见。但他接着写道：“我顺应了当时的气氛，对每一行诗句都给予了应有的赞美，并在亲吻了教皇的脚以示对这一非凡善举（朗诵诗歌）的谢意后离开了。”几周后，当公爵亲自拜访教皇时，他竟然能够背诵教皇诗歌的整段诗句，并给予了极高的评价，以至于教皇“欣喜若狂，仿佛失去了理智”。
In matters of taste you can never be too obsequious with your master. Taste is one of die ego's prickliest parts; never impugn or question the master's tastehis poetry is sublime, his dress impeccable, and his manner the model for all.
在品味方面，你永远不能对主人过于谄媚。品味是自我最敏感的部分之一；永远不要质疑或诋毁主人的品味——他的诗歌崇高绝伦，他的衣着无可挑剔，他的举止堪称典范。
Scene VII
第七幕
One afternoon in ancient China, Chao, ruler of Han from 358 to 333 B.C., got drunk and fell asleep in the palace gardens. The court crown-keeper, whose sole task was to look after die ruler's head apparel, passed Uirough the gardens and saw his master sleeping without a coat. Since it was getting cold, die crown-keeper placed his own coat over the ruler, and left.
在中国古代的一个下午，汉朝统治者赵朝（公元前358年至公元前333年在位）喝醉后在宫廷花园里睡着了。负责照看赵朝头饰的宫廷侍卫路过花园时，看到赵朝没有穿外套就睡着了。天色渐冷，侍卫便将自己的外套披在赵朝身上，然后离开了。
When Chao awoke and saw the coat upon him, he asked his attendants, “Who put more clodies on my body” “The crown-keeper,” they replied. The ruler immediately called for his official coat-keeper and had him punished for neglecting his duties. He also called for the crown-keeper, whom he had beheaded. Interpretation
赵王醒来，看到身上的衣袍，便问侍从：“谁给我穿了这么多衣袍？”侍从回答：“是御冠官。”赵王立刻召来御冠官，责罚他玩忽职守。他还召来了御冠官，并已将其斩首。
Do not overstep your bounds. Do what you are assigned to do, to the best of your abilities, and never do more. To think that by doing more you are doing better is a common blunder. It is never good to seem to be trying too hardit is as if you were covering up some deficiency. Fulfilling a task that has not been asked of you just makes people suspicious. If you are a crown-keeper, be a crown-keeper. Save your excess energy for when you are not in die court.
不要越界。尽你所能做好你被指派的事情，切勿多做。认为做得越多就越好是一种常见的错误观念。表现得过于努力绝非好事，这就像是在掩盖某种不足。完成未被要求的任务只会招致怀疑。如果你是王冠守护者，那就做好王冠守护者的工作。把你多余的精力留到不在宫廷的时候再用。
Scene VIII
第八幕
One day, for amusement, the Italian Renaissance painter Fra Filippo Lippi (1406-1469) and some friends went sailing in a small boat off Ancona. There they were captured by two Moorish galleys, which hauled mem off in chains to Barbary, where they were sold as slaves. For eighteen long months Filippo toiled with no hope of returning to Italy.
一天，意大利文艺复兴时期画家弗拉·菲利波·利皮（1406-1469）和几个朋友为了消遣，乘着一艘小船在安科纳附近海域航行。在那里，他们被两艘摩尔人战船俘虏，戴着镣铐被拖到巴巴里，在那里被卖为奴隶。菲利波在那里苦苦劳作了整整十八个月，却丝毫没有返回意大利的希望。
On several occasions Filippo saw the man who had bought him pass by, and one day he decided to sketch this man's portrait, using burnt coalcharcoalfrom the fire. Still in his chains, he found a white wall, where he drew a full-length likeness of his owner in Moorish clothing. The owner soon heard about this, for no one had seen such skill in drawing before in these parts; it seemed like a miracle, a gift from God. The drawing so pleased the owner that he instantly gave Filippo his freedom and employed him in his court. All the big men on the Barbary coast came to see the magnificent color portraits that Fra Filippo then proceeded to do, and finally, in gratitude for the honor in this way brought upon him, Filippo's owner returned the artist safely to Italy. Interpretation
菲利波曾多次见到买下他的那个人路过，有一天，他决定用火堆里的炭火为这个人画一幅肖像。他仍然被锁链束缚着，找到一面白墙，在上面画了一幅主人身着摩尔人服饰的全身像。主人很快就听说了这件事，因为在这一带，从未有人见过如此精湛的绘画技艺；这简直像个奇迹，是上帝的恩赐。主人对这幅画非常满意，立刻释放了菲利波，并让他到自己的宫廷任职。巴巴里海岸所有的大人物都前来欣赏菲利波先生创作的精美彩色肖像画。最后，为了感谢这份荣耀，菲利波的主人将这位艺术家安全地送回了意大利。
We who toil for other people have all in some way been captured by pirates and sold into slavery. But like Fra Filippo (if to a lesser degree), most of us possess some gift, some talent, an ability to do something better than other people. Make your master a gift of your talents and you will rise above other courtiers. Let him take the credit if necessary, it will only be temporary: Use him as a stepping stone, a way of displaying your talent and eventually buying your freedom from enslavement.
我们这些为他人辛勤劳作的人，在某种程度上都曾被海盗掳走，沦为奴隶。但就像弗拉·菲利波（尽管程度可能稍轻），我们大多数人都拥有某种天赋、某种才能，一种比他人更胜一筹的能力。将你的才能作为礼物献给你的主人，你就能超越其他朝臣。如有必要，就让他独揽功劳吧，这只是暂时的：把他当作垫脚石，一个展现你才能的平台，最终赎回你摆脱奴役的自由。
Scene IX
第九幕
Alfonso I of Aragon once had a servant who told the king that the night before he had had a dream: Alfonso had given him a gift of weapons, horses, and clothes. Alfonso, a generous, lordly man, decided it would be amusing to make this dream come true, and promptly gave the servant exactly these gifts.
阿拉贡国王阿方索一世曾有一个仆人，这仆人告诉国王，他前一天晚上做了一个梦：阿方索送给他武器、马匹和衣服。阿方索一世慷慨大方，觉得把这个梦变成现实会很有趣，于是立刻把这些东西一一送给了仆人。
A little while later, the same servant announced to Alfonso that he had had yet another dream, and in this one Alfonso had given him a considerable pile of gold florins. The king smiled and said, “Don't believe in dreams from now on; they lie.” Interpretation
不久之后，那个仆人告诉阿方索，他又做了一个梦，梦里阿方索给了他一大堆金币。国王笑着说：“从今以后不要相信梦了，梦都是骗人的。”
In his treatment of the servant's first dream, Alfonso remained in control. By making a dream come true, he claimed a godlike power for himself, if in a mild and humorous way. In the second dream, however, all appearance of magic was gone; this was nothing but an ugly con game on the servant's part. Never ask for too much, then, and know when to stop. It is the master's prerogative to giveto give when he wants and what he wants, and to do so without prompting. Do not give him the chance to reject your requests. Better to win favors by deserving them, so that they are bestowed without your asking.
在处理仆人的第一个梦境时，阿方索始终掌控着局面。他让梦境成真，以此展现自己如同神明般的力量，尽管方式温和而幽默。然而，在第二个梦境中，所有魔法的迹象都消失了；这不过是仆人精心策划的骗局。因此，永远不要索取过多，并且要懂得适可而止。主人有权在自己想要的时候给予，给予自己想要的东西，而且无需请求。不要给他拒绝你请求的机会。最好通过自身的努力赢得恩惠，这样即使你不开口，恩惠也会自然而然地赐予你。
Scene X
场景 X
The great English landscape painter J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851) was known for his use of color, which he applied with a brilliance and a strange iridescence. The color in his paintings was so striking, in fact, that other artists never wanted his work hung next to theirs: It inevitably made everything around it seem dull.
英国伟大的风景画家J·M·W·特纳（1775-1851）以其对色彩的运用而闻名，他运用色彩时笔触明艳，并赋予画面一种奇特的虹彩光泽。事实上，他画作中的色彩如此引人注目，以至于其他艺术家都不愿将他的作品与自己的作品并排悬挂：因为它必然会让周围的一切都显得黯然失色。
The painter Sir Thomas Lawrence once had the misfortune of seeing Turner's masterpiece Cologne hanging in an exhibition between two works of his own. Lawrence complained bitterly to the gallery owner, who gave him no satisfaction: After all, someone's paintings had to hang next to Turner's. But Turner heard of Lawrence's complaint, and before the exhibition opened, he toned down the brilliant golden sky in Cologne, making it as dull as the colors in Lawrence's works. A friend of Turner's who saw the painting approached the artist with a horrified look: “What have you done to your picture!” he said. “Well, poor Lawrence was so unhappy,” Turner replied, “and it's only lampblack. It'll wash off after the exhibition.” Interpretation
画家托马斯·劳伦斯爵士曾不幸地在一次展览中看到特纳的杰作《科隆》挂在他自己的两幅作品之间。劳伦斯向画廊老板抱怨不已，但老板并未给他任何满意的答复：毕竟，总得有人把自己的画作挂在特纳的旁边。然而，特纳听说了劳伦斯的抱怨，在展览开幕前，他特意淡化了《科隆》中原本耀眼的金色天空，使其变得像劳伦斯作品中的色彩一样黯淡。特纳的一位朋友看到这幅画后，惊恐地走近他问道：“你对你的画做了什么！”特纳回答说：“可怜的劳伦斯太不高兴了，这只是用了点灯黑。展览结束后就洗掉了。”
Many of a courtier's anxieties have to do with the master, with whom most dangers lie. Yet it is a mistake to imagine that the master is the only one to determine your fate. Your equals and subordinates play integral parts also. A court is a vast stew of resentments, fears, and powerful envy. You have to placate everyone who might someday harm you, deflecting their resentment and envy and diverting their hostility onto other people.
许多朝臣的焦虑都与君主有关，因为大多数危险都潜藏在君主身上。然而，认为君主是唯一决定你命运的人，那就大错特错了。你的同僚和下属也扮演着至关重要的角色。宫廷就像一锅巨大的汤，里面充满了怨恨、恐惧和强烈的嫉妒。你必须安抚所有可能在未来伤害你的人，转移他们的怨恨和嫉妒，并将他们的敌意转移到其他人身上。
Turner, eminent courtier, knew that his good fortune and fame depended on his fellow painters as well as on his dealers and patrons. How many of the great have been felled by envious colleagues! Better temporarily to dull your brilliance than to suffer the slings and arrows of envy.
特纳，这位杰出的朝臣，深知自己的好运和名望不仅取决于画商和赞助人，也取决于其他画家。多少伟人因同行的嫉妒而陨落！与其遭受嫉妒的箭矢和攻击，不如暂时收敛锋芒。
Scene XI
第十一场
Winston Churchill was an amateur artist, and after World War II his paintings became collector's items. The American publisher Henry Luce, in fact, creator of Time and Life magazines, kept one of Churchill's landscapes hanging in his private office in New York.
温斯顿·丘吉尔是一位业余画家，二战后他的画作成为收藏家的珍品。事实上，《时代》和《生活》杂志的创始人、美国出版商亨利·卢斯就将丘吉尔的一幅风景画挂在了他在纽约的私人办公室里。
On a tour through the United States once, Churchill visited Luce in his office, and the two men looked at the painting togetiier. The publisher remarked, “It's a good picture, but I think it needs something in the foregrounda sheep, perhaps.” Much to Luce's horror, Churchill's secretary called the publisher the next day and asked him to have the painting sent to England. Luce did so, mortified that he had perhaps offended the former prime minister. A few days later, however, the painting was shipped back, but slighdy altered: a single sheep now grazed peacefully in the foreground. Interpretation
丘吉尔曾在一次美国巡视期间拜访了卢斯，两人一起欣赏了这幅画。出版商卢斯评论道：“这幅画不错，但我认为前景需要添加些什么——或许是只羊。”令卢斯惊恐万分的是，丘吉尔的秘书第二天就打电话给他，要求将画寄回英国。卢斯照做了，懊恼自己可能冒犯了这位前首相。然而，几天后，画作被寄了回来，但略有改动：前景中多出了一只悠闲吃草的羊。
In stature and fame, Churchill stood head and shoulders above Luce, but Luce was certainly a man of power, so let us imagine a slight equality between them. Still, what did Churchill have to fear from an American publisher Why bow to the criticism of a dilettante
丘吉尔的地位和声望都远胜卢斯，但卢斯也是一位权势人物，所以我们不妨假设他们之间略有势均力敌。不过，丘吉尔究竟有什么好怕的呢？他为什么要向一个业余人士的批评低头呢？
A courtin this case the entire world of diplomats and international statesmen, and also of the journalists who court themis a place of mutual dependence. It is unwise to insult or offend the taste of people of power, even if they are below or equal to you. If a man like Churchill can swallow the criticisms of a man like Luce, he proves himself a courtier without peer. (Perhaps his correction of the painting implied a certain condescension as well, but he did it so subtly that Luce did not perceive any slight.) Imitate Churchill: Put in the sheep. It is always beneficial to play the obliging courtier, even when you are not serving a master.
在这种情况下，谄媚整个外交官和国际政治家的世界，以及那些与他们周旋的记者们，是一个相互依存的地方。冒犯或得罪掌权者的品味是不明智的，即便他们的地位低于或与你平起平坐。如果像丘吉尔这样的人能够接受像卢斯这样的人的批评，那么他无疑是一位无与伦比的谄媚者。（或许他对那幅画的修改也带有一丝居高临下的意味，但他处理得如此巧妙，以至于卢斯并未察觉到任何轻视。）效仿丘吉尔：放上羊。扮演一个顺从的谄媚者总是有益的，即使你并非在侍奉主人。
THE DELICATE GAME OF COURTIERSHIP: A Warning Talleyrand was the consummate courtier, especially in serving his master Napoleon. When the two men were first getting to know each other, Napoleon once said in passing, “I shall come to lunch at your house one of these days.” Talleyrand had a house at Auteuil, in the suburbs of Paris. “I should be delighted, mon general,” the minister replied, “and since my house is close to the Bois de Boulogne, you will be able to amuse yourself with a bit of shooting in the afternoon.”
谄媚的微妙游戏：一个警示 塔列朗是一位老练的谄媚者，尤其擅长侍奉他的主人拿破仑。两人初识之时，拿破仑曾随口说道：“我过几天会去你家吃午饭。”塔列朗在巴黎郊区的奥特伊有一处住所。“我非常乐意，将军，”这位大臣回答道，“而且我的房子离布洛涅森林很近，您下午可以去打打猎消遣一下。”
“I do not like shooting,” said Napoleon, “But I love hunting. Are there any boars in the Bois de Boulogne” Napoleon came from Corsica, where boar hunting was a great sport. By asking if there were boars in a Paris park, he showed himself still a provincial, almost a rube. Talleyrand did not laugh, however, but he could not resist a practical joke on the man who was now his master in politics, although not in blood and nobility, since Talleyrand came from an old aristocratic family. To Napoleon's question, then, he simply replied, “Very few, mon general, but I dare say you will manage to find one.”
“我不喜欢射击，”拿破仑说，“但我热爱狩猎。布洛涅森林里有野猪吗？”拿破仑来自科西嘉岛，那里猎野猪是一项盛行的运动。他竟然问巴黎的公园里有没有野猪，这暴露了他仍然是个乡巴佬，几乎像个土包子。塔列朗并没有笑，但他忍不住要捉弄一下这位如今在政治上是他主宰的人——尽管在血统和贵族身份上不如他，因为塔列朗出身于一个古老的贵族家庭。于是，对于拿破仑的问题，他只是简单地回答说：“将军，野猪很少，但我敢说您肯定能找到一头。”
It was arranged that Napoleon would arrive at Talleyrand's house the following day at seven A.M. and would spend the morning there. The “boar hunt” would take place in the afternoon. Throughout the morning the excited general talked nothing but boar hunting. Meanwhile, Talleyrand secretly had his servants go to the market, buy two enormous black pigs, and take them to the great park.
约定拿破仑第二天早上七点抵达塔列朗府邸，并在那里待上一上午。“猎野猪”活动则安排在下午。整个上午，这位兴奋的将军都在谈论猎野猪。与此同时，塔列朗暗中吩咐仆人去市场买了两个巨大的黑猪，然后把它们带到大公园。
After lunch, the hunters and their hounds set off for the Bois de Boulogne. At a secret signal from Talleyrand, the servants loosed one of the pigs. “I see a boar,” Napoleon cried joyfully, jumping onto his horse to give chase. Talleyrand stayed behind. It took half an hour of galloping through the park before the “boar” was finally captured. At the moment of triumph, however, Napoleon was approached by one of his aides, who knew the creature could not possibly be a boar, and feared the general would be ridiculed once the story got out: “Sir,” he told Napoleon, “you realize of course that this is not a boar but a pig.”
午饭后，猎人们带着猎犬前往布洛涅森林。塔列朗发出秘密信号后，仆人们放出一头猪。“我看到一头野猪了！”拿破仑欣喜若狂地喊道，跳上马去追赶。塔列朗则留在原地。他们策马飞奔了半个小时，才终于在公园里抓住了那头“野猪”。然而，就在拿破仑得意洋洋之时，他的一位助手走近他，这位助手知道那不可能是野猪，担心故事传出去后将军会被人嘲笑：“先生，”他告诉拿破仑，“您当然明白这不是野猪，而是一头猪。”
Flying into a rage, Napoleon immediately set off at a gallop for Talleyrand's house. He realized along the way that he would now be the butt of many a joke, and that exploding at Talleyrand would only make him
拿破仑勃然大怒，立刻策马飞奔向塔列朗的住所。他一路上意识到，自己现在肯定会成为众人嘲笑的对象，而对塔列朗发火只会让他更加狼狈。
more ridiculous; it would be better to make a show of good humor. Still, he did not hide his displeasure well.
更荒谬的是，他最好表现得幽默一些。不过，他还是没能很好地掩饰自己的不满。
Talleyrand decided to try to soothe the general's bruised ego. He told Napoleon not to go back to Paris yethe should again go hunting in the park. There were many rabbits there, and hunting them had been a favorite pastime of Louis XVI. Talleyrand even offered to let Napoleon use a set of guns that had once belonged to Louis. With much flattery and cajolery, he once again got Napoleon to agree to a hunt.
塔列朗决定安抚将军受伤的自尊心。他告诉拿破仑不要回巴黎，而是应该再去公园打猎。那里有很多兔子，打猎一直是路易十六最喜欢的消遣。塔列朗甚至提出让拿破仑使用一套路易十六曾经用过的枪支。经过一番奉承和哄骗，他再次说服拿破仑同意去打猎。
The party left for the park in the late afternoon. Along the way, Napoleon told Talleyrand, “I'm not Louis XVI, I surely won't kill even one rabbit.” Yet that afternoon, strangely enough, the park was teeming with rabbits. Napoleon killed at least fifty of them, and his mood changed from anger to satisfaction. At the end of his wild shooting spree, however, the same aide approached him and whispered in his ear, “To tell die truth, sir, I am beginning to believe these are not wild rabbits. I suspect that rascal Talleyrand has played another joke on us.” (The aide was right: Talleyrand had in fact sent his servants back to the market, where tiiey had purchased dozens of rabbits and then had released them in die Bois de Boulogne.)
一行人傍晚时分前往公园。途中，拿破仑对塔列朗说：“我又不是路易十六，我肯定不会杀一只兔子。”然而，那天下午，奇怪的是，公园里兔子成群。拿破仑至少打死了五十只，他的情绪也从愤怒转为满足。然而，在他疯狂射杀之后，那位助手走近他，在他耳边低语道：“说实话，先生，我开始怀疑这些不是野兔。我怀疑那个无赖塔列朗又跟我们开了个玩笑。”（助手说得没错：塔列朗确实派仆人回到市场，买了几十只兔子，然后把它们放生到布洛涅森林里。）
Napoleon immediately mounted his horse and galloped away, mis time returning straight to Paris. He later threatened Talleyrand, warned him not to tell a soul what had happened; if he became the laughingstock of Paris, there would be hell to pay.
拿破仑立刻翻身上马，扬长而去，很快就返回了巴黎。后来，他威胁塔列朗，警告他不要把发生的事情告诉任何人；如果他成了巴黎的笑柄，后果不堪设想。
It took months for Napoleon to be able to trust Talleyrand again, and he never totally forgave him his humiliation.
拿破仑花了几个月的时间才重新信任塔列朗，而且他始终没有完全原谅塔列朗带给他的羞辱。
Interpretation
解释
Courtiers are like magicians: They deceptively play with appearances, only letting those around them see what they want diem to see. With so much deception and manipulation afoot, it is essential to keep people from seeing your tricks and glimpsing your sleight of hand.
朝臣如同魔术师：他们巧妙地玩弄表象，只让周围的人看到他们想让他们看到的。在如此多的欺骗和操纵中，至关重要的是不让人识破你的伎俩，不让他们窥见你的障眼法。
Talleyrand was normally the Grand Wizard of Courtiership, and but for Napoleon's aide, he probably would have gotten away completely with both pleasing his master and having a joke at the general's expense. But courtiership is a subde art, and overlooked traps and inadvertent mistakes can ruin your best tricks. Never risk being caught in your maneuvers; never let people see your devices. If that happens you instandy pass in people's perceptions from a courtier of great manners to a loamsome rogue. It is a delicate game you play; apply the utmost attention to covering your tracks, and never let your master unmask you.
塔列朗通常是朝臣中的高手，若非拿破仑的副官出手，他或许能既讨好主人，又能拿将军开个玩笑，完全不费吹灰之力。但朝臣之道是一门精妙的艺术，稍有疏忽的陷阱和无意的错误就可能毁掉你精心策划的计谋。切勿冒险暴露你的伎俩；切勿让别人看穿你的诡计。一旦失足，人们眼中的你就会立刻从一位彬彬有礼的朝臣变成一个卑鄙无耻的流氓。这是一场微妙的游戏；务必小心翼翼地掩盖你的行踪，绝不能让主人识破你的伪装。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 25
第25条
RE-CREATE YOURSELF
重塑自我
JUDGMENT
判断
Do not accept the roles that society foists on you. Re-create yourself by forging a new identity, one that commands attention and never bores the audience. Be the master of your own image rather than letting others define it for you. Incorporate dramatic devices into your public gestures and actionsyour power will be enhanced and your character will seem larger than life.
不要接受社会强加给你的角色。重塑自我，打造一个引人注目、永不乏味的新形象。掌控自己的形象，而不是让别人来定义它。在你的公开场合举止中融入戏剧化的元素——这将增强你的气场，让你的形象更加鲜明生动。
The man who intends to make his fortune in this ancient capital of the world [Rome] must be a chameleon susceptible of reflecting the colors of the atmosphere that surrounds hima Proteus apt to assume every form, every shape. He must be supple, flexible, insinuating, close, inscrutable, often base, sometimes sincere, sometimes perfidious, always concealing a part of his knowledge, indulging in but one tone of voice, patient, a perfect master of his own countenance, as cold as ice when any other man would be all fire; and if unfortunately he is not religious at hearta very common occurrence for a soul possessing the above requisites he must have religion in his mind, that is to say, on his face, on his lips, in his manners; he must suffer quietly, if he be an honest man, the necessity of knowing himself an arrant hypocrite. The man whose soul would loathe such a life should leave Rome and seek his fortune elsewhere. I do not know whether I am praising or excusing myself, but of all those qualities I possessed but one namely, flexibility.
想要在这座古老的世界之都（罗马）发家致富的人，必须像变色龙一样，能够适应周围环境的氛围，如同普罗透斯一般，能够变换各种形态。他必须灵活、善解人意、亲近、难以捉摸，有时卑鄙，有时真诚，有时背信弃义，总是隐藏着一部分知识，说话总是只有一种语气，耐心十足，完美地掌控着自己的面容，当其他人热情似火时，他却冷若冰霜；如果不幸的是，他内心并不虔诚——对于具备上述条件的人来说，这种情况很常见——那么他必须在思想上，也就是说，在他的脸上、嘴里、举止中，都流露出宗教信仰；如果他是一个诚实的人，就必须默默忍受自己是个彻头彻尾的伪君子的现实。如果一个人的灵魂厌恶这样的生活，就应该离开罗马，去别处寻找机会。我不知道我是在夸奖自己还是在为自己辩解，但我拥有的所有品质中，唯独缺少一项，那就是灵活性。
MEMOIRS,
回忆录
Giovanni Casanova, 1725-1798
乔瓦尼·卡萨诺瓦，1725-1798
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
Julius Caesar made his first significant mark on Roman society in 65 B.C., when he assumed the post of aedile, the official in charge of grain distribution and public games. He began his entrance into the public eye by organizing a series of carefully crafted and well-timed spectacleswild-beast hunts, extravagant gladiator shows, theatrical contests. On several occasions, he paid for these spectacles out of his own pocket. To the common man, Julius Caesar became indelibly associated with these much-loved events. As he slowly rose to attain the position of consul, his popularity among the masses served as the foundation of his power. He had created an image of himself as a great public showman.
公元前65年，尤利乌斯·凯撒就任市政官，负责粮食分配和公共竞技活动，由此在罗马社会崭露头角。他精心策划并巧妙安排了一系列盛大的活动，包括猎杀野兽、奢华的角斗士表演和戏剧比赛，以此进入公众视野。他曾多次自掏腰包支付这些活动的费用。对于普通民众而言，尤利乌斯·凯撒与这些深受喜爱的活动紧密相连。随着他逐步晋升为执政官，他在民众中的威望成为他权力的基石。他成功地将自己塑造成一位伟大的公众表演家。
In 49 B.C., Rome was on the brink of a civil war between rival leaders, Caesar and Pompey. At the height of the tension, Caesar, an addict of the stage, attended a theatrical performance, and afterward, lost in thought, he wandered in die darkness back to his camp at the Rubicon, die river that divides Italy from Gaul, where he had been campaigning. To march his army back into Italy across the Rubicon would mean the beginning of a war with Pompey.
公元前49年，罗马正处于凯撒和庞培两位宿敌之间内战的边缘。在局势最为紧张之际，酷爱戏剧的凯撒观看了一场演出，演出结束后，他心事重重，在夜色中漫步回到位于卢比孔河畔的营地。卢比孔河将意大利与高卢分隔开来，凯撒此前一直在高卢作战。如果他率军渡过卢比孔河返回意大利，就意味着与庞培开战。
Before his staff Caesar argued both sides, forming the options like an actor on stage, a precursor of Hamlet. Finally, to put his soliloquy to an end, he pointed to a seemingly innocent apparition at the edge of the rivera very tall soldier blasting a call on a trumpet, then going across a bridge over the Rubiconand pronounced, “Let us accept this as a sign from die Gods and follow where tiiey beckon, in vengeance on our double-dealing enemies. The die is cast.” All of this he spoke portentously and dramatically, gesturing toward the river and looking his generals in the eye. He knew that these generals were uncertain in their support, but his oratory overwhelmed them widi a sense of die drama of the moment, and of die need to seize the time. A more prosaic speech would never have had the same effect. The generals rallied to his cause; Caesar and his army crossed the Rubicon and by the following year had vanquished Pompey, making Caesar dictator of Rome.
在幕僚面前，凯撒像舞台上的演员一样，将正反两方的选项一一阐述，颇有哈姆雷特的风范。最后，为了结束他的独白，他指向河边一个看似无辜的身影——一个身材高大的士兵正吹着号角，然后走过卢比孔河上的一座桥。他宣布：“让我们把这当作神的旨意，跟随他们的召唤，向那些两面三刀的敌人复仇。大局已定。”他语气庄重而富有戏剧性，一边指向河流，一边直视着将军们的眼睛。他知道这些将军们对支持他犹豫不决，但他雄辩的言辞让他们感受到了此刻的紧迫感，以及把握时机的必要性。平淡的演讲绝不会有同样的效果。将军们纷纷响应他的号召；凯撒率领军队渡过卢比孔河，并在次年击败了庞培，使凯撒成为罗马的独裁者。
In warfare, Caesar always played the leading man with gusto. He was as skilled a horseman as any of his soldiers, and took pride in outdoing diem in feats of bravery and endurance. He entered battle astride die strongest mount, so that his soldiers would see him in die thick of batde, urging diem on, always positioning himself in the center, a godlike symbol of power and a model for them to follow. Of all the armies in Rome, Caesar's was the most devoted and loyal. His soldiers, like die common people who had attended his entertainments, had come to identify with him and with his cause.
在战争中，凯撒总是热情洋溢地扮演着领袖的角色。他的骑术丝毫不逊于任何一名士兵，并以在英勇和耐力方面超越他们为荣。他总是骑着最强壮的战马冲锋陷阵，让士兵们在激烈的战斗中看到他，激励他们奋勇向前。他总是身处战场中央，如同神祇般象征着权力，也成为士兵们效仿的榜样。在罗马的所有军队中，凯撒的军队最为忠诚。他的士兵，就像那些曾参加过他宴会的普通民众一样，都认同他以及他的事业。
After the defeat of Pompey, die entertainments grew in scale. Nodiing like mem had ever been seen in Rome. The chariot races became more spectacular, die gladiator fights more dramatic, as Caesar staged fights to die deadi among the Roman nobility. He organized enormous mock naval batdes on an artificial lake. Plays were performed in every Roman ward. A
庞培战败后，罗马的娱乐活动规模空前盛大。战车比赛更加精彩，角斗士搏斗更加扣人心弦，凯撒甚至在罗马贵族中组织了生死搏斗。他还在人工湖上组织了规模庞大的模拟海战。罗马的每个城区都上演了戏剧。
192 LAW 25
192 法律 25
giant new theater was built that sloped dramatically down the Tarpeian Rock. Crowds from all over the empire flocked to these events, the roads to Rome lined widi visitors' tents. And in 45 B.C., timing his entry into the city for maximum effect and surprise, Caesar brought Cleopatra back to Rome after his Egyptian campaign, and staged even more extravagant public spectacles.
一座巨大的新剧院拔地而起，沿着塔尔佩亚岩陡峭而下。来自帝国各地的民众蜂拥而至，罗马城外的道路两旁挤满了游客的帐篷。公元前45年，凯撒为了达到最佳效果和出其不意，精心安排了自己进入罗马的时间，在埃及战役结束后，他带着克利奥帕特拉回到罗马，并上演了更加盛大的公共庆典。
These events were more than devices to divert the masses; they dramatically enhanced the public's sense of Caesar's character, and made him seem larger than life. Caesar was die master of his public image, of which he was forever aware. When he appeared before crowds he wore the most spectacular purple robes. He would be upstaged by no one. He was notoriously vain about his appearanceit was said that one reason he enjoyed being honored by the Senate and people was that on these occasions he could wear a laurel wreath, hiding his baldness. Caesar was a masterful orator. He knew how to say a lot by saying a litde, intuited die moment to end a speech for maximum effect. He never failed to incorporate a surprise into his public appearancesa startling announcement tiiat would heighten their drama.
这些事件不仅仅是转移民众注意力的手段；它们极大地提升了公众对凯撒的认知，使他显得超越凡人。凯撒深谙自身公众形象之道，并且对此了如指掌。当他出现在人群面前时，总是身着华丽的紫色长袍。他绝不会让自己的风头被任何人抢走。他极其注重外表——据说他喜欢接受元老院和民众的嘉奖，其中一个原因就是，在这些场合他可以戴上月桂花环，掩盖自己的秃顶。凯撒是一位雄辩大师。他深谙言简意赅之道，总能以最恰当的方式结束演讲，达到最佳效果。他总会在公开场合安排一些出人意料的环节——一个惊人的宣布，以此增强戏剧效果。
Immensely popular among the Roman people, Caesar was hated and feared by his rivals. On the ides of MarchMarch 15in die year 44 B.C., a group of conspirators led by Brutus and Cassius surrounded him in die senate and stabbed him to deadi. Even dying, however, he kept his sense of drama. Drawing die top of his gown over his face, he let go of die clodi's lower part so diat it draped his legs, allowing him to die covered and decent.
