Instead of the cat's-paw you show your own mighty hand as a threatening gesture. Play such a card sparingly. If you play it too often, fear will turn into resentment and hatred. Before you know it, such emotions will spark a vigorous opposition that will someday bring you down. Get in the habit of using a cat's-pawit is far safer.
最后，有些时候，坦诚地承担责任反而更有利。如果你拥有权力且地位稳固，有时应该扮演忏悔者的角色：用哀伤的眼神向弱者请求原谅。这是君王为了人民的福祉而展现自身牺牲的惯用伎俩。同样地，有时你可能想要扮演惩罚者的角色，以震慑下属。与其虚张声势，不如亮出你的真面目，以示威胁。但这种手段要谨慎使用。如果过于频繁，恐惧会转化为怨恨和仇恨。不知不觉中，这些情绪会引发强烈的反抗，最终将你拉下马。养成使用虚张声势的习惯要安全得多。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 27
第27条
PLAY ON PEOPLE'S NEED
利用人们的需求
TO BELIEVE TO CREATE A
相信就能创造
CULTLIKE FOLLOWING
狂热追随者
JUDGMENT
判断
People have an overwhelming desire to believe in something. Become the focal point of such desire by offering them a cause, a new faith to follow. Keep your words vague but full of promise; emphasize enthusiasm over rationality and clear thinking. Give your new disciples rituals to perform, ask them to make sacrifices on your behalf. In the absence of organized religion and grand causes, your new belief system will bring you untold power.
人们渴望信仰，这种渴望难以抑制。通过提供一项事业、一种新的信仰，成为他们这种渴望的中心。言辞要含糊不清，但充满承诺；强调热情而非理性思考。赋予你的新信徒仪式，要求他们为你做出牺牲。在缺乏有组织的宗教和宏大事业的情况下，你的新信仰体系将为你带来难以估量的力量。
He was to the charlatan's advantage that the individuals predisposed to credulity should multiply, that the groups of his adherents should enlarge to mass proportions, guaranteeing an ever greater scope for his triumphs. And this was in fact to occur, as science was popularized, from the Renaissance on down through succeeding centuries. With the immense growth of knowledge and its spread through printing in modern times, the mass of the half educated, the eagerly gullible prey of the quack, also increased, became indeed a majority; real power could be based on their wishes, opinions, preferences, and rejections. The charlatan's empire accordingly widened with the modern dissemination of knowledge; since he operated on the basis of science, however much he perverted it, producing gold with a technique borrowed from chemistry and his wonderful balsams with the apparatus of medicine, he could not appeal to an entirely ignorant folk. The illiterate would be protected against his absurdities by their healthy common sense. His choicest audience would be composed of the semiliterate, those who had exchanged their common sense for a little distorted information and had
对江湖骗子来说，易轻信之人越多，其追随者群体越庞大，这对他越有利，也越能确保他获得更大的成功。而随着文艺复兴以来科学的普及，这种情况确实发生了。近代以来，随着知识的飞速增长和印刷术的传播，半吊子、容易受骗的江湖骗子群体也随之壮大，甚至成为多数；真正的权力可以建立在他们的愿望、观点、偏好和拒绝之上。因此，随着现代知识的传播，江湖骗子的势力范围也随之扩大；尽管他以科学为基础，即便他歪曲科学，用化学技术炼金，用医学仪器制造神奇药膏，也无法吸引完全无知的民众。文盲凭借其健全的常识，就能抵御他的荒谬伎俩。他最理想的听众将是那些半文盲，那些用一些扭曲的信息取代了常识的人。
THE SCIENCE OF CHARLATANISM, OR HOW TO CREATE A CULT IN FIVE EASY STEPS In searching, as you must, for the methods that will gain you the most power for the least effort, you will find the creation of a cultlike following one of the most effective. Having a large following opens up all sorts of possibilities for deception; not only will your followers worship you, they will defend you from your enemies and will voluntarily take on the work of enticing others to join your fledgling cult. This kind of power will lift you to another realm: You will no longer have to struggle or use subterfuge to enforce your will. You are adored and can do no wrong.
江湖骗术的科学：五步轻松打造邪教 你必然会寻找那些能让你事半功倍、事半功倍的方法，而建立邪教式的追随者群体无疑是最有效的方法之一。拥有庞大的追随者群体，便能为你开启各种欺骗的可能性；你的追随者不仅会崇拜你，还会保护你免受敌人的攻击，甚至自愿承担起引诱他人加入你这新兴邪教的重任。这种力量会将你提升到一个全新的境界：你不再需要苦苦挣扎或使用诡计来强加你的意志。你受人爱戴，永远不会犯错。
You might think it a gargantuan task to create such a following, but in fact it is fairly simple. As humans, we have a desperate need to believe in something, anything. This makes us eminently gullible: We simply cannot endure long periods of doubt, or of the emptiness that comes from a lack of something to believe in. Dangle in front of us some new cause, elixir, get-rich-quick scheme, or the latest technological trend or art movement and we leap from the water as one to take the bait. Look at history: The chronicles of the new trends and cults that have made a mass following for diem-selves could fill a library. After a few centuries, a few decades, a few years, a few months, they generally look ridiculous, but at the time they seem so attractive, so transcendental, so divine.
你或许认为建立如此庞大的追随者群体是一项艰巨的任务，但实际上却相当简单。作为人类，我们迫切需要信仰，任何信仰都行。这使我们极易轻信他人：我们根本无法忍受长时间的怀疑，也无法忍受缺乏信仰所带来的空虚感。只要在我们面前抛出一些新的事业、灵丹妙药、快速致富的计划，或是最新的科技潮流或艺术运动，我们就会像鱼儿一样争先恐后地跃入水中。纵观历史：那些为“自我”创造大量追随者的新潮流和邪教的编年史足以填满一座图书馆。几个世纪、几十年、几年、几个月之后，它们通常看起来荒谬可笑，但在当时，它们却显得如此诱人、如此超凡脱俗、如此神圣。
Always in a rush to believe in something, we will manufacture saints and faiths out of nothing. Do not let this gullibility go to waste: Make yourself the object of worship. Make people form a cult around you.
我们总是急于相信某些东西，于是凭空捏造出圣人和信仰。不要浪费这种轻信：让自己成为崇拜的对象，让人们围绕你建立个人崇拜。
The great European charlatans of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries mastered the art of cultmaking. They lived, as we do now, in a time of transformation: Organized religion was on the wane, science on the rise. People were desperate to rally around a new cause or faith. The charlatans had begun by peddling health elixirs and alchemic shortcuts to wealth. Moving quickly from town to town, they originally focused on small groupsuntil, by accident, they stumbled on a truth of human nature: The larger the group they gathered around themselves, the easier it was to deceive.
十六、十七世纪欧洲的江湖骗子们精通于制造邪教的艺术。他们和我们一样，生活在一个变革的时代：有组织的宗教日渐衰落，科学蓬勃发展。人们迫切地想要找到新的事业或信仰。这些骗子最初兜售的是保健灵药和致富捷径。他们迅速地从一个城镇转移到另一个城镇，起初只专注于小规模的群体，直到偶然间，他们发现了人性的一个真相：他们聚集的群体越大，就越容易欺骗他人。
The charlatan would station himself on a high wooden platform (hence the term “mountebank”) and crowds would swarm around him. In a group setting, people were more emotional, less able to reason. Had the charlatan spoken to them individually, they might have found him ridiculous, but lost in a crowd they got caught up in a communal mood of rapt attention. It became impossible for them to find the distance to be skeptical. Any deficiencies in the charlatan's ideas were hidden by the zeal of the mass. Passion and enthusiasm swept tiirough the crowd like a contagion, and they reacted violently to anyone who dared to spread a seed of doubt. Both consciously studying this dynamic over decades of experiment and spontaneously adapting to these situations as diey happened, the charlatans perfected the science of attracting and holding a crowd, molding die crowd into followers and die followers into a cult.
江湖骗子会站在高高的木台上（因此得名“江湖术士”），人群会蜂拥而至。在群体环境中，人们更容易情绪化，理性思考能力也随之下降。如果骗子单独与他们交谈，他们或许会觉得他荒谬可笑，但身处人群之中，他们却被一种集体性的、全神贯注的氛围所感染。他们根本无法保持距离，进行怀疑。骗子理论中的任何缺陷都被大众的狂热所掩盖。激情和热情如同瘟疫般席卷人群，任何胆敢散播怀疑种子的人都会遭到猛烈的反击。骗子们通过数十年的实验，有意识地研究这种动态，并根据实际情况灵活调整，最终完善了吸引和维系人群的艺术，将人群塑造成追随者，将追随者塑造成狂热的信徒。
The gimmicks of the charlatans may seem quaint today, but there are thousands of charlatans among us still, using the same tried-and-true methods their predecessors refined centuries ago, only changing die names of their elixirs and modernizing the look of their cults. We find diese latter-day charlatans in all arenas of lifebusiness, fashion, politics, art. Many of them, perhaps, are following in the charlatan tradition without having any knowledge of its history, but you can be more systematic and deliberate. Simply follow die five steps of cultmaking that our charlatan ancestors perfected over the years.
如今，江湖骗子的伎俩或许显得有些古怪，但我们身边仍然有成千上万的骗子，他们沿用着几个世纪前先辈们精心打磨的那些屡试不爽的方法，只不过是换了换灵丹妙药的名字，把他们的“教派”包装得更现代化一些。我们在生活的各个领域——商业、时尚、政治、艺术——都能看到这些现代骗子的身影。或许他们中的许多人只是在不了解其历史的情况下，盲目地继承了骗子的传统，但你可以更加系统、更加有条理地去实践。只需遵循我们那些江湖骗子先辈们多年来不断完善的“教派建立”五步法即可。
Step 1: Keep It Vague; Keep It Simple. To create a cult you must first attract attention. This you should do not through actions, which are too clear and readable, but through words, which are hazy and deceptive. Your initial speeches, conversations, and interviews must include two elements: on uie one hand the promise of somediing great and transformative, and on die other a total vagueness. This combination will stimulate all kinds of hazy dreams in your listeners, who will make dieir own connections and see what they want to see.
第一步：保持模糊；保持简单。要打造一种崇拜，首先必须吸引注意力。而吸引注意力的方式并非通过过于清晰明了的行动，而是通过含糊不清、具有欺骗性的言辞。你最初的演讲、对话和采访必须包含两个要素：一方面，承诺成就一番伟大而具有变革意义的事业；另一方面，保持完全的模糊性。这种组合会激发听众各种朦胧的幻想，让他们自行建立联系，并看到自己想看到的东西。
To make your vagueness attractive, use words of great resonance but cloudy meaning, words full of heat and enthusiasm. Fancy tides for simple things are helpful, as are the use of numbers and the creation of new words for vague concepts. All of these create the impression of specialized knowledge, giving you a veneer of profundity. By the same token, try to make the subject of your cult new and fresh, so diat few will understand it. Done right, the combination of vague promises, cloudy but alluring concepts, and fiery endiusiasm will stir people's souls and a group will form around you.
为了让你的含糊其辞更具吸引力，要使用那些极具感染力但含义模糊的词语，那些充满激情和热忱的词语。用华丽的辞藻来描述简单的事物会很有帮助，使用数字和创造新词来表达模糊的概念也同样有效。所有这些都会给人一种博学多识的印象，让你看起来深不可测。同样地，要努力让你的教义新颖独特，以至于只有少数人能够理解。如果运用得当，模糊的承诺、晦涩却诱人的概念以及炽热的热情结合起来，就能触动人们的灵魂，并为你吸引一群追随者。
Talk too vaguely and you have no credibility. But it is more dangerous to be specific. If you explain in detail the benefits people will gain by following your cult, you will be expected to satisfy mem.
说话含糊不清会失去可信度，但说得太具体反而更危险。如果你详细解释人们加入你的组织能获得哪些好处，他们就会期望你满足他们的需求。
As a corollary to its vagueness your appeal should also be simple. Most people's problems have complex causes: deep-rooted neurosis, interconnected social factors, roots that go way back in time and are exceedingly hard to unravel. Few, however, have the patience to deal with this; most people want to hear that a simple solution will cure their problems. The ability to offer mis kind of solution will give you great power and build you a following. Instead of the complicated explanations of real life, return to die primitive solutions of our ancestors, to good old country remedies, to mysterious panaceas.
作为其模糊性的必然结果，你的诉求也应该简单明了。大多数人的问题都有着复杂的根源：根深蒂固的神经质、相互交织的社会因素，以及可以追溯到很久以前且极其难以解开的根源。然而，很少有人有耐心去处理这些问题；大多数人只想听到一个简单的解决方案就能解决他们的问题。能够提供这种解决方案的能力将赋予你巨大的力量，并为你赢得追随者。与其费尽心思地解释现实生活中的种种复杂问题，不如回归我们祖先的原始方法，回归古老的民间偏方，回归神秘的灵丹妙药。
Step 2: Emphasize the Visual and the Sensual over the Intellectual.
第二步：重视视觉和感官体验，而非理性思考。
Once people have begun to gadier around you, two dangers will present themselves: boredom and skepticism. Boredom will make people go elsewhere; skepticism will allow them the distance to think rationally about whatever it is you are offering, blowing away die mist you have artfully created and revealing your ideas for what tiiey are. You need to amuse the bored, then, and ward off die cynics.
一旦人们开始在你周围闲逛，就会出现两种危险：无聊和怀疑。无聊会让人们转向别处；怀疑会让他们保持距离，理性地思考你所提供的一切，拨开你精心营造的迷雾，看清你的想法究竟是什么。因此，你需要取悦那些感到无聊的人，并抵御那些愤世嫉俗的人。
encountered science and education at some time, though briefly and unsuccessfully.... The great mass of mankind has always been predisposed to marvel at mysteries, and this was especially true at certain historic periods when the secure foundations of life seemed shaken and old values, economic or spiritual, long accepted as certainties, could no longer be relied upon. Then the numbers of the charlatan's dupes multipliedthe “self killers,” as a seventeenth-century Englishman called them.
虽然短暂且不成功，但人类在某个时期都曾接触过科学和教育……绝大多数人总是天生就对神秘事物充满好奇，在某些历史时期尤其如此，那时生活的稳固基础似乎动摇了，长期以来被视为理所当然的旧价值观，无论是经济的还是精神的，都不再可靠。那时，江湖骗子的受害者数量激增——正如一位十七世纪的英国人所称的“自取灭亡者”。
the power of the
力量
charlatan,
庸医，
Grete de Francesco,
格雷特·德·弗朗切斯科
THE OWI. WHO WAS GOD
奥维。谁是上帝
Once upon a starless midnight there was an owl who sat on the branch of an oak tree. Two ground moles tried to slip quietly by, unnoticed. “You!”said the owl. “Who” they quavered, in fear and astonishment, for they could not believe it was possible for anyone to see them in that thick darkness. “You two!” said the owl. The moles hurried away and told the other creatures of the field and forest that the owl was the greatest and wisest of all animals because he could see in the dark
在一个没有星星的午夜，一只猫头鹰栖息在橡树枝上。两只地鼹鼠试图悄悄溜过去，不被它发现。“你们！”猫头鹰说。“谁？”它们颤抖着问道，既害怕又惊讶，因为它们无法相信在如此浓重的黑暗中竟然有人能看到它们。“是你们两个！”猫头鹰说。地鼹鼠赶紧逃走，告诉田野和森林里的其他动物，猫头鹰是所有动物中最伟大、最聪明的，因为它能在黑暗中视物。
and because he could answer any question. “I'll see about that,” said a secretary bird, and he called on the owl one night when it was again very dark. “How many claws am 1 holding up ” said the secretary bird. “Two,” said the owl, and that was right. “Can you give me another expression for 'that is to say' or 'namely'” asked the secretary bird. “To wit,”said the owl. “Why does a lover call on his love” asked the secretary bird. “To woo,” said the owl. The secretary bird hastened back to the other creatures and reported that the owl was indeed the greatest and wisest animal in the world because he could see in the dark and because he could answer any question. “Can he see in the daytime, too” asked a red fox. “ Yes,” echoed a dormouse and a French poodle. “Can he see in the daytime, too” All the other creatures laughed loudly at this silly question, and they set upon the red fox and his friends and drove them out of the region. Then they sent a messenger to the owl and asked him to be their leader. When the owl appeared among the animals it was high noon and the sun was shining brightly. He walked very slowly, which gave him an appearance of great dignity, and he peered about him with large, staring eyes, which gave him an air
因为他能回答任何问题。“我看看，”一只秘书鸟说。一天晚上，天色又黑了，它就去拜访猫头鹰。“我举起了几只爪子？”秘书鸟问。“两只，”猫头鹰答道，答对了。“你能告诉我‘也就是说’或‘即’的另一个说法吗？”秘书鸟问。“就是，”猫头鹰答道。“为什么恋人要呼唤爱人？”秘书鸟问。“为了求爱，”猫头鹰答道。秘书鸟赶紧跑回其他动物那里，告诉它们猫头鹰确实是世界上最伟大、最聪明的动物，因为它能在黑暗中视物，而且能回答任何问题。“它白天也能看见吗？”一只红狐问道。“是的，”一只睡鼠和一只法国贵宾犬异口同声地回答。 “他白天也能看见吗？”其他动物都对这个愚蠢的问题哈哈大笑，它们围攻赤狐和他的朋友们，把他们赶出了这片区域。然后，它们派人去见猫头鹰，请他做它们的首领。猫头鹰出现在动物们中间时，正值正午，阳光灿烂。他走得很慢，显得十分威严；他睁着大大的眼睛环顾四周，显得气宇轩昂。
The best way to do this is through theater, or other devices of its kind. Surround yourself widi luxury, dazzle your followers with visual splendor, fill their eyes with spectacle. Not only will this keep them from seeing the ridiculousness of your ideas, the holes in your belief system, it will also attract more attention, more followers. Appeal to all the senses: Use incense for scent, soothing music for hearing, colorful charts and graphs for die eye. You might even tickle the mind, perhaps by using new technological gadgets to give your cult a pseudo-scientific veneeras long as you do not make anyone really think. Use die exoticdistant cultures, strange customsto create dieatrical effects, and to make the most banal and ordinary affairs seem signs of somediing extraordinary.
最好的方法是通过戏剧或其他类似手段。用奢华环绕自己，用视觉盛宴迷惑追随者，让他们目不暇接。这不仅能让他们忽略你理念的荒谬之处和信仰体系的漏洞，还能吸引更多关注，更多追随者。调动所有感官：用香薰熏香，用舒缓的音乐吸引听觉，用色彩鲜艳的图表刺激视觉。你甚至可以利用一些新奇的科技产品来刺激他们的思维，给你的邪教披上一层伪科学的外衣，只要别让他们真正思考就行。利用异域风情和奇特习俗来营造戏剧效果，让最平凡琐碎的事情看起来都像是某种非凡事件的预兆。
Step 3: Borrow the Forms of Organized Religion to Structure the Group. Your cultlike following is growing; it is time to organize it. Find a way both elevating and comforting. Organized religions have long held unquestioned authority for large numbers of people, and continue to do so in our supposedly secular age. And even if the religion itself has faded some, its forms still resonate with power. The lofty and holy associations of organized religion can be endlessly exploited. Create rituals for your followers; organize diem into a hierarchy, ranking them in grades of sanctity, and giving diem names and tides mat resound with religious overtones; ask diem for sacrifices mat will fill your coffers and increase your power. To emphasize your gadiering's quasi-religious nature, talk and act like a prophet. You are not a dictator, after all; you are a priest, a guru, a sage, a shaman, or any odier word diat hides your real power in the mist of religion.
第三步：借鉴有组织宗教的形式来构建团体。你的信徒群体正在壮大，是时候组织起来了。找到一种既能提升信徒境界又能让他们感到慰藉的方式。有组织的宗教长期以来对大量人群拥有不容置疑的权威，即使在我们这个所谓的世俗时代也是如此。即使宗教本身有所衰落，它的形式仍然具有强大的影响力。有组织宗教崇高而神圣的象征意义可以被无限利用。为你的信徒创造仪式；将他们组织成等级制度，根据神圣程度进行排序，并赋予他们带有宗教色彩的名字和仪式；向他们索取祭品，以充实你的财富并增强你的权力。为了强调你团体的准宗教性质，要像先知一样说话和行事。毕竟，你不是独裁者；你是牧师、大师、圣人、萨满，或者任何更难听的词语，这些词语将你真正的力量隐藏在宗教的迷雾之中。
Step 4: Disguise Your Source of Income. Your group has grown, and you have structured it in a churchlike form. Your coffers are beginning to fill wim your followers' money. Yet you must never be seen as hungry for money and the power it brings. It is at diis moment that you must disguise die source of your income.
第四步：掩盖收入来源。你的团体不断壮大，组织形式也类似教会。信徒的捐款开始充盈你的资金库。然而，你绝不能给人留下贪婪金钱及其权力的印象。此时此刻，你必须掩盖你的收入来源。
Your followers want to believe diat if they follow you all sorts of good things will fall into dieir lap. By surrounding yourself widi luxury you become living proof of the soundness of your belief system. Never reveal that your wealth actually comes from your followers' pockets; instead, make it seem to come from die trum of your mediods. Followers will copy your each and every move in die belief mat it will bring diem the same results, and dieir imitative enthusiasm will blind diem to the charlatan nature of your wealdi.
你的追随者们想要相信，只要他们追随你，各种好事就会纷至沓来。通过让自己沉浸在奢华之中，你便成为了你信仰体系正确性的活生生的证明。永远不要透露你的财富实际上来自追随者的口袋；相反，要让它看起来像是来自你的媒体。追随者们会模仿你的一举一动，因为他们相信这样做会给他们带来同样的结果，而他们模仿的热情会让他们对你财富的骗局本质视而不见。
Step 5: Set Up an Us-Versus-Them Dynamic. The group is now large and diriving, a magnet attracting more and more particles. If you are not careful, though, inertia will set in, and time and boredom will demagnetize die group. To keep your followers united, you must now do what all religions and belief systems have done: create an us-versus-diem dynamic. First, make sure your followers believe they are part of an exclusive
第五步：建立“我们与他们”的对立关系。此时，群体规模庞大且充满活力，如同磁铁般吸引着越来越多的成员。然而，如果不加注意，惯性就会显现，时间和厌倦感也会使群体失去凝聚力。为了保持追随者的团结，你现在必须效仿所有宗教和信仰体系的做法：建立“我们与他们”的对立关系。首先，确保你的追随者相信他们是某个专属群体的一份子。
club, unified by a bond of common goals. Then, to strengdien this bond, manufacture the notion of a devious enemy out to ruin you. There is a force of nonbelievers that will do anything to stop you. Any outsider who tries to reveal the charlatan nature of your belief system can now be described as a member of this devious force.
一个俱乐部，因共同目标而团结在一起。然后，为了加强这种联系，捏造出一个阴险狡诈的敌人，企图摧毁你们。有一群不信教的人会不惜一切代价阻止你们。任何试图揭露你们信仰体系骗局本质的外人，现在都可以被描述为这群阴险狡诈之徒的成员。
If you have no enemies, invent one. Given a straw man to react against, your followers will tighten and cohere. They have your cause to believe in and infidels to destroy.
如果没有敌人，那就捏造一个。有了攻击目标，你的追随者就会更加团结。他们有了信仰，有了要消灭的异教徒。
OBSERVANCES OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Observance I
观察 I
In the year 1653, a twenty-seven-year-old Milan man named Francesco Giuseppe Borri claimed to have had a vision. He went around town telling one and all mat the archangel Michael had appeared to him and announced that he had been chosen to be the capitano generate of the Army of the New Pope, an army that would seize and revitalize the world. The archangel had further revealed that Borri now had the power to see people's souls, and that he would soon discover the philosopher's stonea long-sought-after substance that could change base metals into gold. Friends and acquaintances who heard Borri explain the vision, and who witnessed the change that had come over him, were impressed, for Borri had previously devoted himself to a life of wine, women, and gambling. Now he gave all that up, plunging himself into the study of alchemy and talking only of mysticism and the occult.
1653年，一位名叫弗朗切斯科·朱塞佩·博里（Francesco Giuseppe Borri）的27岁米兰男子声称自己看到了异象。他四处宣扬，说大天使米迦勒显灵于他，并宣布他已被选中成为新教皇军队的统帅，这支军队将征服并复兴世界。大天使还透露，博里现在拥有了洞察人心的能力，并且很快就能发现炼金术士之石——一种人们苦苦寻觅的、能将贱金属转化为黄金的物质。听过博里讲述异象，并亲眼目睹他变化的亲朋好友都印象深刻，因为博里以前沉迷于酒色和赌博。如今，他放弃了这一切，全身心投入炼金术的研究，并且只谈论神秘主义和玄学。
The transformation was so sudden and miraculous, and Borri's words were so filled with enthusiasm, that he began to create a following. Unfortunately the Italian Inquisition began to notice him as wellthey prosecuted anyone who delved into the occultso he left Italy and began to wander Europe, from Austria to Holland, telling one and all that “to those who follow me all joy shall be granted.” Wherever Borri stayed he attracted followers. His method was simple: He spoke of his vision, which had grown more and more elaborate, and offered to “look into” the soul of anyone who believed him (and they were many). Seemingly in a trance, he would stare at this new follower for several minutes, then claim to have seen the person's soul, degree of enlightenment, and potential for spiritual greatness. If what he saw showed promise, he would add the person to his growing order of disciples, an honor indeed.
这种转变如此突然而神奇，博里的言辞又充满热情，以至于他开始拥有一批追随者。不幸的是，意大利宗教裁判所也开始注意到他——他们迫害任何涉足神秘学的人——于是他离开了意大利，开始在欧洲各地游历，从奥地利到荷兰，到处宣扬“追随我的人将获得一切喜乐”。博里所到之处，都吸引着追随者。他的方法很简单：他讲述自己日益精妙的异象，并表示愿意“窥探”任何相信他的人的灵魂（而这样的人很多）。他仿佛进入了一种恍惚状态，会盯着这位新追随者看几分钟，然后声称看到了此人的灵魂、觉悟程度以及灵性成就的潜力。如果他所看到的显示出潜力，他就会将这个人纳入他不断壮大的门徒队伍中，这无疑是一种莫大的荣誉。
The cult had six degrees, into which the disciples were assigned according to what Borri had glimpsed in their souls. With work and total devotion to the cult they could graduate to a higher degree. Borriwhom they called “His Excellency,” and “Universal Doctor”demanded from them die strictest vows of poverty. All the goods and moneys they possessed had to be turned over to him. But diey did not mind handing over their property, for Borri had told them, "I shall soon bring my chemical
这个教派分为六个等级，信徒们根据博里窥见的灵魂状态被分配到不同的等级。通过辛勤工作和对教派的全然奉献，他们可以晋升到更高的等级。博里，他们称他为“阁下”和“宇宙博士”，要求他们发下最严格的贫穷誓言。他们所有的财物都必须上交给他。但他们并不介意交出自己的财产，因为博里告诉他们：“我很快就会带来我的化学药剂。”
of tremendous importance. “He's God!” screamed a Plymouth Rock hen. And the others took up the cry “He's God!”So they followed him wherever he went and when he began to bump into things they began to bump into things, too. Finally he came to a concrete highway and he started up the middle of it and all the other creatures followed him. Presently a hawk, who was acting as outrider, observed a truck coming toward them at fifty miles an hour, and he reported to the secretary bird and the secretary bird reported to the owl. “ There's danger ahead,” said the secretary bird. “ To wit ” said the owl. The secretary bird told him. “A ren 't you afraid ” He asked. “Who”said the owl calmly, for he could not see the truck. “He's God!” cried all the creatures again, and they were still crying “He's God!” when the truck hit them and ran them down. Some of the animals were merely injured, but most of them, including the owl, were killed. Moral: You can fool too many of the people too much of the time.
极其重要。“他是上帝！”一只普利茅斯岩鸡尖叫道。其他的动物也跟着喊：“他是上帝！”于是，它们跟着他，无论他走到哪里，当他开始撞到东西时，它们也跟着撞。最后，他来到一条水泥公路，他沿着公路中央走去，其他的动物都跟着他。这时，一只鹰，作为领头鸟，发现一辆卡车正以每小时五十英里的速度朝他们驶来，它告诉了秘书鸟，秘书鸟又告诉了猫头鹰。“前面有危险，”秘书鸟说。“是吗？”猫头鹰说。秘书鸟告诉了他。“你不害怕吗？”他问。“谁害怕？”猫头鹰平静地说，因为它看不到卡车。“他是上帝！”所有的动物再次喊道，当卡车撞上它们并将它们碾压时，它们还在喊着“他是上帝！”。有些动物只是受了伤，但大多数动物，包括猫头鹰，都死了。寓意：你很容易长时间欺骗太多人。
the thurber carnival, James Thurber , 1894-1961
瑟伯嘉年华，詹姆斯·瑟伯，1894-1961
To become the founder of a new religion one must he psychologically infallible in one's knowledge of a certain average type of souls who have not yet recognized that they belong together.
要成为一个新宗教的创始人，必须在心理上绝对正确，对某种尚未意识到彼此属于同一类灵魂的普通人有深刻的了解。
Friedrich Nietzsche, 1844-1900
弗里德里希·尼采，1844-1900 年
Men are so simple of
男人真是太简单了
mind, and so much
思想，以及很多
dominated by their
受其支配
immediate needs, that a
迫切的需求，
deceitful man will
诡诈的人会
always find plenty who
总能找到很多这样的人
are ready to be
准备好了
deceived.
受骗了。
NicroLO Machiavem.i, 1469-1527
NicroLO Machiavem.i, 1469-1527
111!'. IKMI'LK OF III, VI II ]
111！'。 IKMI'LK OF III, VI II ]
[In the late 1780s] the Scottish quack James Graham .. . was winning a large following and great riches in London.... [Graham] maintained a show of great scientific technique. In 1772 ... he had visited Philadelphia, where he met Benjamin Franklin and became interested in the latter's experiments with electricity. These appear to have inspired the apparatus in the “Temple of Health,”
[18世纪80年代末]苏格兰江湖骗子詹姆斯·格雷厄姆……在伦敦赢得了众多追随者和巨额财富……[格雷厄姆]一直标榜自己拥有高超的科学技术。1772年……他访问了费城，在那里结识了本杰明·富兰克林，并对后者的电学实验产生了浓厚的兴趣。这些实验似乎启发了“健康神庙”中仪器的设计。
studies to a happy conclusion by the discovery of the philosopher's stone, and by this means we shall all have as much gold as we desire."
研究最终以发现贤者之石而圆满结束，通过这种方式，我们都能拥有我们想要的所有黄金。
Given his growing wealtii, Borri began to change his style of living. Renting the most splendid apartment in the city into which he had temporarily setded, he would furnish it with fabulous furniture and accessories, which he had begun to collect. He would drive through the city in a coach studded with jewels, with six magnificent black horses at its head. He never stayed too long in one place, and when he disappeared, saying he had more souls to gather into his flock, his reputation only grew in his absence. He became famous, although in fact he had never done a single concrete thing.
随着财富的增长，博里开始改变他的生活方式。他在暂时居住的城市里租了一套最豪华的公寓，并用他开始收集的精美家具和饰品来装饰它。他会乘坐一辆镶满珠宝的马车穿梭于城市之中，马车由六匹骏美的黑马拉着。他从不在同一个地方久留，每次他声称要召集更多信徒加入他的教众时，他的名声反而与日俱增。他名声大噪，尽管事实上他从未做过任何实质性的事情。
From all over Europe, the blind, the crippled, and the desperate came to visit Borri, for word had spread that he had healing powers. He asked no fee for his services, which only made him seem more marvelous, and indeed some claimed tfiat in this or mat city he had performed a miracle cure. By only hinting at his accomplishments, he encouraged people's imaginations to blow diem up to fantastic proportions. His wealdi, for example, actually came from the vast sums he was collecting from his increasingly select group of rich disciples; yet it was presumed that he had in fact perfected the philosopher's stone. The Church continued to pursue him, denouncing him for heresy and witchcraft, and Borri's response to these charges was a dignified silence; this only enhanced his reputation and made his followers more passionate. Only die great are persecuted, after all; how many understood Jesus Christ in his own time Borri did not have to say a wordhis followers now called the Pope the Antichrist.
来自欧洲各地的盲人、残疾人和绝望之人纷纷前来拜访博里，因为他拥有治愈能力的名声早已传开。他分文不取，这反而让他显得更加神奇，甚至有人声称他在某个城市或某个地方施展了奇迹般的治愈。他只是略微提及自己的成就，便激发了人们的想象力，将之无限放大。例如，他的财富实际上来自他从日益壮大的富裕信徒群体中募集的巨额捐款；然而，人们却认为他实际上已经炼制出了炼金术士的秘方。教会继续追捕他，谴责他是异端和巫师，而博里对这些指控的回应是庄严的沉默；这反而提升了他的声望，也让他的追随者更加狂热。毕竟，只有伟人才会遭受迫害；在耶稣基督的时代，又有多少人真正理解他呢？博里无需多言，他的追随者们就已称教皇为敌基督。
And so Borri's power grew and grew, until one day he left the city of Amsterdam (where he had setded for a while), absconding with huge sums of borrowed money and diamonds that had been entrusted to him. (He claimed to be able to remove the flaws from diamonds through the power of his gifted mind.) Now he was on the run. The Inquisition eventually caught up with him, and for the last twenty years of his life he was imprisoned in Rome. But so great was the belief in his occult powers that to his dying day he was visited by wealthy believers, including Queen Christina of Sweden. Supplying him with money and materials, diese visitors allowed him to continue his search for die elusive philosopher's stone. Interpretation
于是，博里的势力与日俱增，直到有一天，他离开了阿姆斯特丹（他曾在那里居住过一段时间），带着借来的巨额资金和受托保管的钻石潜逃而去。（他声称自己拥有超凡的智慧，能够去除钻石中的瑕疵。）从此，他开始了逃亡生涯。宗教裁判所最终抓住了他，在他生命的最后二十年里，他被囚禁在罗马。然而，人们对他神秘力量的信仰如此坚定，以至于直到他去世，仍有富有的信徒前来探望，其中包括瑞典女王克里斯蒂娜。这些访客为他提供金钱和物资，使他得以继续寻找那块神秘的贤者之石。
Before he formed his cult, Borri seems to have stumbled on a critical discovery. Tiring of his life of debauchery, he had decided to give it up and to devote himself to the occult, a genuine interest of his. He must have noticed, however, mat when he alluded to a mystical experience (rather than physical exhaustion) as die source of his conversion, people of all classes wanted to hear more. Realizing the power he could gain by ascribing the change to sometiiing external and mysterious, he went further widi his manufactured visions. The grander the vision, and the more sacrifices he asked for, die more appealing and believable his story seemed to become.
在创立邪教之前，博里似乎偶然发现了一个关键点。厌倦了放荡不羁的生活，他决定放弃一切，投身于他真正感兴趣的神秘学领域。然而，他一定注意到，当他暗示自己的转变源于某种神秘体验（而非肉体疲惫）时，各阶层的人都渴望了解更多。意识到将这种转变归因于某种外在的神秘力量能够获得力量，他便进一步炮制出种种虚构的幻象。幻象越宏大，他要求的牺牲越多，他的故事就越显得引人入胜、令人信服。
Remember: People are not interested in die trutii about change. They
记住：人们对变革的真相并不感兴趣。
do not want to hear that it has come from hard work, or from anything as banal as exhaustion, boredom, or depression; they are dying to believe in something romantic, otherworldly. They want to hear of angels and out-of-body experiences. Indulge them. Hint at the mystical source of some personal change, wrap it in ethereal colors, and a cuklike following will form around you. Adapt to people's needs: The messiah must mirror the desires of his followers. And always aim high. The bigger and bolder your illusion, the better.
他们不想听到这种改变源于辛勤工作，或是疲惫、厌倦、抑郁之类的平庸之事；他们渴望相信一些浪漫的、超凡脱俗的东西。他们想听天使的故事，想听灵魂出窍的体验。那就迎合他们吧。暗示一下个人改变的神秘来源，用空灵的色彩包装起来，你身边就会聚集起一群狂热的追随者。要适应人们的需求：救世主必须反映信徒的渴望。而且永远要志存高远。你的幻想越宏大、越大胆，效果就越好。
Observance II
遵守第二条
In the mid-1700s, word spread in Europe's fashionable society of a Swiss country doctor named Michael Schiippach who practiced a different kind of medicine: He used the healing powers of nature to perform miraculous cures. Soon well-to-do people from all over the Continent, their ailments both serious and mild, were making the trek to the alpine village of Lang-nau, where Schiippach lived and worked. Trudging tiirough the mountains, these visitors witnessed the most dramatic natural landscapes that Europe has to offer. By the time they reached Langnau, they were already feeling transformed and on their way to health.
18世纪中期，一位名叫米歇尔·希帕赫的瑞士乡村医生在欧洲上流社会声名鹊起。他采用一种与众不同的医疗方法：利用大自然的治愈力量，创造奇迹般的疗效。很快，来自欧洲各地的富裕人士，无论病情轻重，都纷纷跋涉前往希帕赫居住和行医的阿尔卑斯山村朗瑙。这些求医者在山间跋涉，饱览了欧洲最壮丽的自然风光。当他们抵达朗瑙时，已然感到身心焕然一新，重获健康。
Schiippach, who had become known as simply the “Mountain Doctor,” had a small pharmacy in town. This place became quite a scene: Crowds of people from many different countries would cram the small room, its walls lined with colorful bottles filled with herbal cures. Where most doctors of the time prescribed foul-tasting concoctions that bore incomprehensible Latin titles (as medicines often do still), Schiippach's cures had names such as “The Oil of Joy,” “Little Flower's Heart,” or “Against the Monster,” and they tasted sweet and pleasing.
希帕赫，人称“山中医生”，在镇上开了一家小药房。这家药房颇为热闹：来自世界各地的人们挤满了这间小房间，墙上挂满了五颜六色的药瓶，里面装着各种草药。当时大多数医生开的药方味道难闻，药名也晦涩难懂（如今很多药方依然如此），而希帕赫的药方却有着诸如“快乐之油”、“小花之心”或“驱魔药”之类的名字，而且味道香甜可口。
Visitors to Langnau would have to wait patiently for a visit with the Mountain Doctor, because every day some eighty messengers would arrive at the pharmacy bearing flasks of urine from all over Europe. Schiippach claimed he could diagnose what ailed you simply by looking at a sample of your urine and reading a written description of your ailment. (Naturally he read the description very carefully before prescribing a cure.) When he finally had a spare minute (the urine samples took up much of his time), he would call the visitor into his office in the pharmacy. He would then examine this person's urine sample, explaining that its appearance would tell him everything he needed to know. Country people had a sense for these things, he would saytheir wisdom came from living a simple, godly life with none of the complications of urban living. This personal consultation would also include a discussion as to how one might bring one's soul more into harmony with nature.
来到朗瑙的游客必须耐心等待山中医生的诊治，因为每天都有大约八十名信使带着来自欧洲各地的尿液样本来到药房。希帕赫声称，他只需观察尿液样本并阅读一份疾病描述，就能诊断出你的病症。（当然，在开药之前，他会非常仔细地阅读这份描述。）当他终于抽出一点空闲时间（尿液样本占据了他大部分时间）时，他会把游客叫到药房的办公室。然后，他会检查此人的尿液样本，并解释说，尿液的外观会告诉他所有需要知道的信息。他会说，乡下人对这些事情很有感觉——他们的智慧来自于过着简单虔诚的生活，没有城市生活的种种纷扰。这种私人诊疗还包括讨论如何使人的灵魂与自然更加和谐。
Schiippach had devised many forms of treatment, each profoundly unlike the usual medical practices of the time. He was a believer, for instance, in electric shock tiierapy. To those who wondered whether this was in keeping with his belief in the healing power of nature, he would explain that electricity is a natural phenomenon; he was merely imitating the
希帕赫设计了许多疗法，每一种都与当时的常规医疗实践截然不同。例如，他信奉电击疗法。对于那些质疑这是否与他相信自然疗愈力相符的人，他会解释说，电是一种自然现象；他只不过是在模仿……
the fabulous establishment he opened in London for the sale of his elixirs.... In the chief room, where he received patients, stood “the largest air pump in the world ” to assist him in his “philosophical investigations” into disease, and also a “stupendous metallic conductor,” a richly gilded pedestal surrounded with retorts and vials of “etherial and other essences. ” .. .According to J. Ennemoser, who published a history of magic in 1844 at Leipzig, Graham's “house ... united the useful with the pleasurable. Everywhere the utmost magnificence was displayed. Even in the outer court, averred an eye-witness, it seemed as though art, invention, and riches had been exhausted. On the side walls in the chambers an arc-shaped glow was provided by artificial electric light; star rays darted forth; transparent glasses of all colors were placed with clever selection and much taste. All this, the same eyewitness assures us, was ravishing and exalted the imagination to the highest degree.” Visitors were given a printed sheet of rules for healthy living. In the Great Apollo Apartment they might join in mysterious rituals, accompanied by chants: “Hail, Vital Air, aethereal! Magnetic Magic, hail!”And while they hailed the
他在伦敦开设了一家令人叹为观止的场所，专门出售他的灵药……在他接待病人的主房间里，摆放着“世界上最大的气泵”，以辅助他对疾病进行“哲学研究”，还有一个“巨大的金属导体”，一个镀金的基座，周围环绕着装有“以太和其他精华”的蒸馏器和小瓶……据1844年在莱比锡出版魔法史的J·恩内莫瑟（J. Ennemoser）所述，格雷厄姆的“房子……将实用与享乐完美结合。处处都极尽奢华。一位目击者断言，即使在外院，也仿佛艺术、发明和财富都已用尽。房间的侧墙上，人造电灯发出弧形光芒；星光闪烁；各种颜色的透明玻璃杯被巧妙地摆放，极具品味。所有这一切，同一位目击者……”向我们保证，它令人陶醉，并将想象力提升到了极致。” 参观者会收到一份印制的健康生活规则清单。在大阿波罗公寓里，他们可以参与神秘的仪式，伴随着吟唱：“万岁，生命之气，空灵之气！万岁，磁力魔法！”当他们向……致敬时
magic of magnetism, the windows were darkened, revealing a ceiling studded with electric stars and a young and lovely “Rosy Goddess of Health ” in a niche.... Every evening this Temple of Health was crowded with guests; it had become the fashion to visit it and try the great twelve-foot bed of state, the “Grand Celestial Bed, ” said to cure any disease. . . . This bed, according to Ennemoser, “stood in a splendid room, into which a cylinder led from an adjoining chamber to conduct the healing currents ... at the same time all sorts of pleasing scents of strengthening herbs and Oriental incense were also brought in through glass tubes. The heavenly bed itself rested upon six solid transparent pillars; the bedclothes were of purple and sky-blue Atlas silk, spread over a mattress saturated with Arabian perfumed waters to suit the tastes of the Persian court. The chamber in which it was placed he called the Sanctum Sanctorum. ... To add to all this, there were the melodious notes of the harmonica, soft flutes, agreeable voices, and a great organ.”
在磁力的魔力作用下，窗户渐渐暗了下来，露出了点缀着闪烁星光的穹顶，壁龛里供奉着一位年轻貌美的“健康女神”……每天晚上，这座健康神庙都挤满了宾客；来这里体验那张据说能治愈百病的十二英尺长的豪华床——“天赐之床”——已成为一种时尚……据恩内莫瑟描述，这张床“位于一间华丽的房间里，一根圆柱体从隔壁房间通入，用于引导疗愈能量……同时，各种令人愉悦的草药和东方香料的香气也通过玻璃管引入。这张神圣的床本身由六根坚固的透明柱子支撑；床单是紫色和天蓝色的阿特拉斯丝绸，铺在浸透了阿拉伯香水的床垫上，以迎合波斯宫廷的品味。他将放置这张床的房间称为至圣所……此外，还有悠扬的口琴声、柔和的笛声、悦耳的人声以及一架大型管风琴。”
the power of the
力量
charlatan,
庸医，
Crete de Francesco,
弗朗西斯科的克里特岛
power of lightning. One of his patients claimed to be inhabited by seven devils. The doctor cured him with electrical shocks, and as he administered these he exclaimed that he could see the devils flying out of the man's body, one by one. Another man claimed to have swallowed a hay wagon and its driver, which were causing him massive pains in the chest. The Mountain Doctor listened patientiy, claimed to be able to hear the crack of a whip in the man's belly, promised to cure him, and gave him a sedative and a purgative. The man fell asleep on a chair outside the pharmacy. As soon as he awoke he vomited, and as he vomited a hay wagon sped past him (the Mountain Doctor had hired it for die occasion), the crack of its whip making him feel that somehow he had indeed expelled it under die doctor's care.
闪电之力。他的一位病人声称自己被七个魔鬼附身。医生用电击治好了他，在施电时，他惊呼自己能看到魔鬼一个接一个地从病人的身体里飞出来。另一位病人声称自己吞下了一辆运草车和它的车夫，这导致他胸口剧痛。山中医生耐心地听着，声称能听到鞭子抽打在病人腹部的声音，承诺治好他，并给他服用了镇静剂和泻药。病人在药房外的椅子上睡着了。他一醒来就呕吐，就在他呕吐的时候，一辆运草车飞驰而过（山中医生为此租了这辆车），鞭子的抽打声让他感觉自己仿佛真的在医生的治疗下把车吐了出来。
Over die years, the Mountain Doctor's fame grew. He was consulted by the powerfuleven the writer Goethe made die trek to his villageand he became the center of a cult of nature in which everything natural was considered worthy of worship. Schiippach was careful to create effects mat would entertain and inspire his patients. A professor who visited him once wrote, “One stands or sits in company, one plays cards, sometimes with a young woman; now a concert is given, now a lunch or supper, and now a litde ballet is presented. Widi a very happy effect, die freedom of nature is everywhere united widi die pleasures of die beau monde, and if the doctor is not able to heal any diseases, he can at least cure hypochondria and die vapors.” Interpretation
多年来，“山中医生”的名声越来越大。权贵们纷纷前来求诊，就连作家歌德也跋涉到他的村庄。他成为了自然崇拜的中心人物，在这种崇拜中，一切自然之物都被视为值得敬拜。希帕赫精心营造各种氛围，以娱乐和启发他的病人。一位曾拜访过他的教授写道：“人们或站或坐，或与人交往，或打牌，有时还会与年轻女子共度时光；有时欣赏音乐会，有时享用午餐或晚餐，有时还会观看小型芭蕾舞表演。通过这种令人愉悦的效果，自然的自由与上流社会的享乐处处融合，即使医生无法治愈任何疾病，至少也能治愈疑病症和精神疾病。”
Schiippach had begun his career as an ordinary village doctor. He would sometimes use in his practice some of the village remedies he had grown up with, and apparendy he noticed some results, for soon diese herbal tinctures and natural forms of healing became his specialty. And in fact his natural form of healing did have profound psychological effects on his patients. Where die normal drugs of the time created fear and pain, Schiip-pach's treatments were comfortable and soothing. The resulting improvement in die patient's mood was a critical element in the cures he brought about. His patients believed so deeply in his skills that they willed diem-selves into health. Instead of scoffing at their irrational explanations for their ailments, Schiippach used their hypochondria to make it seem that he had effected a great cure.
希帕赫最初只是个普通的乡村医生。他有时会在行医时使用一些他从小就熟悉的民间偏方，而且似乎效果不错，因为很快这些草药酊剂和自然疗法就成了他的专长。事实上，他的自然疗法确实对病人产生了深远的心理影响。当时常用的药物会带来恐惧和痛苦，而希帕赫的疗法却让人感到舒适和舒缓。病人情绪的改善是他治愈疾病的关键因素。他的病人对他的医术深信不疑，甚至凭借意志力就能恢复健康。希帕赫并没有嘲笑他们对自身疾病的非理性解释，反而利用他们的疑病症，让他们觉得自己已经治愈了他们的疾病。
The case of die Mountain Doctor teaches us valuable lessons in die creation of a cultiike following. First, you must find a way to engage people's will, to make dieir belief in your powers strong enough that they imagine all sorts of benefits. Their belief will have a self-fulfilling quality, but you must make sure that it is you, rather than dieir own will, who is seen as the agent of transformation. Find die belief, cause, or fantasy that will make diem believe widi a passion and tiiey will imagine die rest, worshipping you as healer, prophet, genius, whatever you like.
“山中医生”的案例给我们上了宝贵的一课，教我们如何建立狂热的追随者群体。首先，你必须找到一种方法来激发人们的意志，让他们对你的力量深信不疑，以至于他们能想象出各种各样的好处。他们的信念会具有自我实现的特质，但你必须确保，在他们眼中，真正促成转变的是你，而不是他们自己的意志。找到一种信念、事业或幻想，让他们充满激情地相信，然后他们就会开始想象，崇拜你，把你当作治愈者、先知、天才，或者任何你喜欢的称呼。
Second, Schiippach teaches us the everlasting power of belief in nature, and in simplicity. Nature, in reality, is full of much tiiat is terrifying poisonous plants, fierce animals, sudden disasters, plagues. Belief in die
其次，希帕赫教导我们信仰自然和简朴的永恒力量。事实上，自然界充满了许多危险，包括可怕的毒草、凶猛的野兽、突如其来的灾难和瘟疫。信仰自然的力量在于……
healing, comforting quality of nature is really a constructed myth, a romanticism. But the appeal to nature can bring you great power, especially in complicated and stressful times.
大自然具有疗愈和抚慰人心的力量，这其实是一种人为构建的神话，一种浪漫主义。但亲近自然的确能给人带来强大的力量，尤其是在复杂而充满压力的时期。
This appeal, however, must be handled right. Devise a kind of theater of nature in which you, as the director, pick and choose the qualities that fit the romanticism of the times. The Mountain Doctor played the part to perfection, playing up his homespun wisdom and wit, and staging his cures as dramatic pieces. He did not make himself one with nature; instead he molded nature into a cult, an artificial construction. To create a “natural” effect you actually have to work hard, making nature theatrical and delightfully pagan. Otherwise no one will notice. Nature too must follow trends and be progressive.
然而，这种吸引力必须处理得当。要构思一种自然剧场，而你作为导演，可以从中挑选符合时代浪漫主义的特质。山中医生完美地诠释了这一点，他夸大自己朴实的智慧和幽默，并将他的疗愈过程演绎成戏剧。他并没有与自然融为一体；相反，他将自然塑造成一种崇拜，一种人为的建构。要营造一种“自然”的效果，实际上需要付出艰辛的努力，将自然戏剧化，使其充满异域风情。否则，无人会注意到。自然也必须顺应潮流，不断进步。
Observance III
遵守第三条
In 1788, at the age of fifty-five, the doctor and scientist Franz Mesmer was at a crossroads. He was a pioneer in the study of animal magnetismthe belief that animals contain magnetic matter, and that a doctor or specialist can effect miraculous cures by working on this charged substancebut in Vienna, where he lived, his theories had met with scorn and ridicule from the medical establishment. In treating women for convulsions, Mesmer claimed to have worked a number of cures, his proudest achievement being the restoration of sight to a blind girl. But another doctor who examined the young girl said she was as blind as ever, an assessment with which she herself agreed. Mesmer countered that his enemies were out to slander him by winning her over to their side. This claim only elicited more ridicule. Clearly the sober-minded Viennese were the wrong audience for his theories, and so he decided to move to Paris and start again.
1788年，55岁的医生兼科学家弗朗茨·梅斯默正处于人生的十字路口。他是动物磁力研究的先驱——他认为动物体内含有磁性物质，医生或专家可以通过治疗这种带电物质来达到神奇的治愈效果。然而，在他居住的维也纳，他的理论却遭到了医学界的蔑视和嘲笑。梅斯默声称，他在治疗女性抽搐症的过程中治愈了不少病例，其中最令他引以为豪的成就是使一位盲女重见光明。但另一位医生检查后却说她仍然失明，女孩本人也认同这一说法。梅斯默反驳说，他的敌人想通过拉拢女孩来诽谤他。然而，这一说法反而招致了更多的嘲笑。显然，头脑冷静的维也纳人并不适合他的理论，于是他决定搬到巴黎，重新开始。
Renting a splendid apartment in his new city, Mesmer decorated it appropriately. Stained glass in most of the windows created a religious feeling, and mirrors on all the walls produced an hypnotic effect. The doctor advertised that in his apartment he would give demonstrations of the powers of animal magnetism, inviting the diseased and melancholic to feel its powers. Soon Parisians of all classes (but mostiy women, who seemed more attracted to the idea than men did) were paying for entry to witness the miracles that Mesmer promised.
梅斯默在新城市租了一间豪华公寓，并精心布置。大多数窗户都装有彩色玻璃，营造出一种宗教氛围；墙上挂满了镜子，仿佛具有催眠效果。这位医生宣称，他将在公寓里演示动物磁力的神奇力量，邀请患病者和忧郁人士前来体验。很快，巴黎各阶层人士（尤其是女性，她们似乎比男性更热衷于此）纷纷付费前来，亲眼见证梅斯默所承诺的奇迹。
Inside the apartment, the scents of orange blossom and exotic incense wafted through special vents. As the initiates filtered into the salon where the demonstrations took place, they heard harp music and the lulling sounds of a female vocalist coming from another room. In the center of the salon was a long oval container filled with water that Mesmer claimed had been magnetized. From holes in the container's metal lid protruded long movable iron rods. The visitors were instructed to sit around the container, place these magnetized rods on the body part that gave them pains or problems, and then hold hands with their neighbors, sitting as close as possible to one another to help the magnetic force pass between their bodies. Sometimes, too, they were attached to each other by cords.
公寓内，橙花和异域香料的香气从特制的通风口飘散而出。学员们陆续走进举行演示的沙龙，耳边传来竖琴声和女歌手轻柔的歌声，是从另一个房间传来的。沙龙中央摆放着一个长椭圆形的容器，里面装满了水，梅斯默声称这些水已被磁化。容器金属盖上的孔洞里伸出长长的、可移动的铁棒。学员们被要求围坐在容器旁，将这些磁化的铁棒放在身体疼痛或不适的部位，然后与邻座手牵手，尽可能靠近彼此，以便磁力在他们之间传递。有时，他们还会被绳子连接在一起。
Mesmer would leave the room, and “assistant magnetizers”all hand-
梅斯默会离开房间，“辅助磁化师”们都会用手——
In the town of Tarnopol lived a man by the name of Reb Feivel. One day, as he sat in his house deeply absorbed in his Talmud, he heard a loud noise outside. When he went to the window he saw a lot of little pranksters. “Up to some new piece of mischief, no doubt,” he thought.
在塔尔诺波尔镇住着一位名叫雷布·费维尔的人。一天，他正坐在家里，全神贯注地研读《塔木德》，突然听到外面传来一声巨响。他走到窗边，看到一群顽皮的小家伙。“肯定又在搞什么恶作剧了。”他心想。
“Children, run quickly to the synagogue,” he cried, leaning out and improvising the first story that occurred to him. “ You 'II see there a sea monster, and what a monster! It's a creature with five feet, three eyes, and a beard like that of a goat, only it's green!”
“孩子们，快跑到犹太教堂去！”他喊道，探出身子，即兴编造了一个故事。“你们会在那里看到一个海怪，多么可怕的怪物啊！它有五条腿，三只眼睛，还有像山羊一样的胡子，只不过是绿色的！”
And sure enough the children scampered off and Reb Feivel returned to his studies. He smiled into his beard as he thought of the trick he had played on those little rascals. It wasn 't long before his studies were interrupted again, this time by running footsteps. When he went to the window he saw several Jews running. “Where are you running” he called out.
果然，孩子们跑开了，费维尔拉比又继续学习。他一边想着自己捉弄这些小家伙的把戏，一边对着胡须微笑。没过多久，他的学习再次被打断，这次是奔跑的脚步声。他走到窗边，看到几个犹太人正在跑。“你们往哪儿跑？”他喊道。
“To the synagogue!” answered the Jews. “Haven'tyou heard There's a sea monster, there's a creature with five legs, three eyes, and a beard like that of a goat, only it's green!” Reb Feivel laughed with glee, thinking of the trick he had played,
“去犹太会堂！”犹太人回答道。“你们没听说过吗？那里有海怪，一个长着五条腿、三只眼睛、还有山羊胡的怪物，只不过它是绿色的！”费维尔拉比得意地大笑起来，想着他刚才的恶作剧。
and sat down again to his Talmud. But no sooner had he begun to concentrate when suddenly he heard a dinning tumult outside. And what did he see A great crowd of men, women and children, all running toward the synagogue. “What's up” he cried, sticking his head out of the window. “ What a question! Why, don't you know” they answered. “Right in front of the synagogue there 's a sea monster. It's a creature with five legs, three eyes, and a beard like that of a goat, only it's green!” And as the crowd hurried by, Reb Feivel suddenly noticed that the rabbi himself was among them. “Lord of the world!” he exclaimed. “If the rabbi himself is running with them surely there must be something happening. Where there's smoke there's fire!” Without further thought Reb Feivel grabbed his hat, left his house, and also began running. “Who can tell” he muttered to himself as he ran, all out of breath, toward the synagogue.
他又坐下，继续研读《塔木德》。可他刚开始专心，就听到外面传来一阵用餐的喧闹声。他看到什么呢？一大群男女老少，全都朝着犹太会堂跑去。“怎么回事？”他探出头，喊道。“真是个问题！你难道不知道吗？”他们回答说，“就在犹太会堂前面，有个海怪。它有五条腿，三只眼睛，还有像山羊一样的胡子，只不过是绿色的！”人群匆匆而过，费维尔突然发现拉比也在其中。“我的天哪！”他惊呼道，“拉比都和他们一起跑了，肯定出事了。无风不起浪！”费维尔想都没想，抓起帽子，冲出家门，也跑了起来。 “谁知道呢？”他一边气喘吁吁地朝犹太教堂跑去，一边喃喃自语道。
a treasury of
一个宝库
jewish folklore,
犹太民间传说
some and strapping young menwould enter with jars of magnetized water that they would sprinkle on the patients, rubbing the healing fluid on their bodies, massaging it into their skin, moving them toward a trancelike state. And after a few minutes a kind of delirium would overcome the women. Some would sob, some would shriek and tear their hair, others would laugh hysterically. At the height of the delirium Mesmer would reenter the salon, dressed in a flowing silk robe embroidered with golden flowers and carrying a white magnetic rod. Moving around the container, he would stroke and soothe the patients until calm was restored. Many women would later attribute the strange power he had on them to his piercing look, which, they thought, was exciting or quieting the magnetic fluids in their bodies.
一些身材魁梧的年轻男子会带着装满磁化水的罐子进来，将水洒在病人身上，用这种具有疗愈功效的液体摩擦她们的身体，按摩她们的皮肤，使她们进入一种恍惚的状态。几分钟后，一种类似谵妄的状态会笼罩这些女性。有些人会啜泣，有些人会尖叫着撕扯头发，还有些人会歇斯底里地大笑。在她们谵妄状态达到顶峰时，梅斯默会再次走进沙龙，他身着绣着金色花朵的飘逸丝绸长袍，手持一根白色磁棒。他会绕着容器走动，抚摸安抚病人，直到她们恢复平静。许多女性后来将他施加在她们身上的这种奇异力量归因于他锐利的目光，她们认为这种目光能够激发或抑制她们体内的磁性液体。
Within months of his arrival in Paris, Mesmer became the rage. His supporters included Marie-Antoinette herself, the queen of France, wife of Louis XVI. As in Vienna, he was condemned by the official faculty of medicine, but it did not matter. His growing following of pupils and patients paid him handsomely.
梅斯梅尔抵达巴黎几个月后便声名鹊起。他的支持者甚至包括法国王后玛丽·安托瓦内特，即路易十六的妻子。如同在维也纳一样，他遭到了官方医学界的谴责，但这无关紧要。他日益增多的学生和病人支付给他丰厚的报酬。
Mesmer expanded his theories to proclaim that all humanity could be brought into harmony through the power of magnetism, a concept with much appeal during the French Revolution. A cult of Mesmerism spread across the country; in many towns, “Societies of Harmony” sprang up to experiment with magnetism. These societies eventually became notorious: They tended to be led by libertines who would turn their sessions into a kind of group orgy.
梅斯梅尔扩展了他的理论，宣称可以通过磁力使全人类和谐相处，这一概念在法国大革命期间极具吸引力。梅斯梅尔主义风靡全国；许多城镇涌现出“和谐社”，进行磁力实验。这些社团最终臭名昭著：它们往往由放荡不羁之徒领导，这些人会将他们的活动变成某种集体狂欢。
At the height of Mesmer's popularity, a French commission published a report based on years of testing the theory of animal magnetism. The conclusion: Magnetism's effects on the body actually came from a kind of group hysteria and autosuggestion. The report was well documented, and ruined Mesmer's reputation in France. He left the country and went into retirement. Only a few years later, however, imitators sprang up all over Europe and the cult of Mesmerism spread once again, its believers more numerous than ever. Interpretation
在梅斯梅尔最鼎盛时期，一个法国委员会发表了一份报告，该报告基于多年来对动物磁力理论的测试。结论是：磁力对身体的影响实际上源于一种群体歇斯底里和自我暗示。这份报告资料翔实，彻底毁掉了梅斯梅尔在法国的名声。他离开了法国，隐居起来。然而，仅仅几年后，模仿者便在欧洲各地涌现，梅斯梅尔主义再次兴起，信徒人数比以往任何时候都多。
Mesmer's career can be broken into two parts. When still in Vienna, he clearly believed in the validity of his theory, and did all he could to prove it. But his growing frustration and the disapproval of his colleagues made him adopt another strategy. First he moved to Paris, where no one knew him, and where his extravagant theories found a more fruitful soil. Then he appealed to the French love of theater and spectacle, making his apartment into a kind of magical world in which a sensory overload of smells, sights, and sounds entranced his customers. Most important, from now on he practiced his magnetism only on a group. The group provided the setting in which the magnetism would have its proper effect, one believer infecting the other, overwhelming any individual doubter.
梅斯梅尔的职业生涯可以分为两个阶段。在维也纳时，他坚信自己的理论是正确的，并竭尽所能地去证明它。但日益增长的挫败感和同事们的反对迫使他采取了另一种策略。首先，他搬到了巴黎，在那里无人知晓他，他那些异想天开的理论也更容易在那里找到滋养。然后，他迎合了法国人对戏剧和奇观的热爱，将自己的公寓打造成一个充满魔幻色彩的世界，各种气味、景象和声音交织在一起，令顾客们如痴如醉。最重要的是，从那时起，他只在团体中施展他的磁力疗法。团体为磁力疗法发挥其应有的作用提供了环境，信徒之间相互影响，最终征服了所有心存疑虑的人。
Mesmer thus passed from being a confirmed advocate of magnetism to the role of a charlatan using every trick in the book to captivate the pub-
梅斯默就这样从一位坚定的磁力论者变成了一个江湖骗子，用尽各种伎俩来吸引酒吧里的顾客。
lie. The biggest trick of all was to play on the repressed sexuality that bubbles under the surface of any group setting. In a group, a longing for social unity, a longing older than civilization, cries out to be awakened. This desire may be subsumed under a unifying cause, but beneath it is a repressed sexuality that the charlatan knows how to exploit and manipulate for his own purposes.
谎言。最大的伎俩在于利用群体中潜藏的、被压抑的性欲。在群体中，一种对社会团结的渴望——一种比文明更古老的渴望——渴望被唤醒。这种渴望或许被某种团结的目标所掩盖，但在这之下，却隐藏着一种被压抑的性欲，而骗子深谙如何利用和操纵这种性欲，以达到自己的目的。
This is the lesson that Mesmer teaches us: Our tendency to doubt, the distance that allows us to reason, is broken down when we join a group. The warmth and infectiousness of the group overwhelm the skeptical individual. This is the power you gain by creating a cult. Also, by playing on people's repressed sexuality, you lead them into mistaking their excited feelings for signs of your mystical strength. You gain untold power by working on people's unrealized desire for a kind of promiscuous and pagan unity.
这就是梅斯默教给我们的道理：当我们加入一个团体时，我们怀疑的倾向，以及让我们能够理性思考的距离感，都会被打破。团体的热情和感染力会压倒那些心存怀疑的人。这就是你通过建立邪教所获得的力量。此外，通过利用人们压抑的性欲，你可以让他们误以为兴奋的感觉是你神秘力量的体现。通过激发人们对某种放荡不羁、异教式的统一的渴望，你可以获得难以估量的力量。
Remember too that the most effective cults mix religion with science. Take the latest technological trend or fad and blend it with a noble cause, a mystical faith, a new form of healing. People's interpretations of your hybrid cult will run rampant, and they will attribute powers to you that you had never even thought to claim.
还要记住，最有效的邪教往往将宗教与科学结合起来。把最新的科技潮流或时尚与崇高的事业、神秘的信仰或新的疗法融合在一起。人们对你这种混合邪教的解读会迅速传播开来，他们会赋予你一些你从未想过的力量。
Image: The Magnet. An unseen force draws objects to it, which in turn become magnetized themselves, drawing other pieces to them, the magnetic power of toe whole constantly increasing. But take away the original magnet and it all falls apart. Become the magnet, the invisible force that attracts people's imaginations and holds them together. Once they have clustered around you, no power can wrest them away.
图片：磁铁。一种无形的力量吸引着物体，这些物体反过来又会被磁化，进而吸引其他物体，整体的磁力不断增强。但如果最初的磁铁消失，一切都会瓦解。成为磁铁，成为那股吸引人们想象力并将其凝聚在一起的无形力量。一旦人们聚集在你周围，任何力量都无法将他们夺走。
Authority: The charlatan achieves his great power by simply opening a possibility for men to believe what they already want to believe. . . . The credulous cannot keep at a distance; they crowd around the wonder worker, entering his personal aura, surrendering themselves to illusion with a heavy solemnity, like cattle. (Grete de Francesco)
权威：江湖骗子之所以能获得巨大的影响力，仅仅是因为他们让人们更容易相信他们原本就想相信的东西……轻信的人无法保持距离；他们蜂拥而至，围住这位奇迹创造者，进入他的个人光环，像牲畜一样，庄严地将自己交付于幻象之中。（格雷特·德·弗朗切斯科）
REVERSAL
逆转
One reason to create a following is that a group is often easier to deceive than an individual, and turns over to you that much more power. This comes, however, with a danger: If at any moment the group sees through you, you will find yourself facing not one deceived soul but an angry crowd that will tear you to pieces as avidly as it once followed you. The charlatans constantly faced this danger, and were always ready to move out of town as it inevitably became clear that their elixirs did not work and their ideas were sham. Too slow and they paid with their lives. In playing with the crowd, you are playing with fire, and must constantly keep an eye out for any sparks of doubt, any enemies who will turn the crowd against you. When you play with the emotions of a crowd, you have to know how to adapt, attuning yourself instantaneously to all of the moods and desires that a group will produce. Use spies, be on top of everything, and keep your bags packed.
建立追随者群体的一个原因是，群体往往比个人更容易被欺骗，这赋予了你更大的权力。然而，这也伴随着危险：一旦群体识破你的伪装，你面对的将不再是一个被欺骗的灵魂，而是一群愤怒的民众，他们会像曾经追随你一样，将你撕成碎片。江湖骗子们一直面临着这种危险，他们总是随时准备离开，因为他们的灵丹妙药最终会被揭穿，他们的理念终究是骗局。如果行动太慢，他们就会付出生命的代价。玩弄大众就像玩火，你必须时刻警惕任何怀疑的火花，任何可能挑拨离间、让大众反抗你的敌人。当你玩弄大众的情绪时，你必须懂得如何适应，瞬间调整自己以适应群体产生的各种情绪和欲望。安插眼线，掌控一切，并做好随时撤离的准备。
For this reason you may often prefer to deal with people one by one. Isolating them from their normal milieu can have the same effect as putting them in a groupit makes them more prone to suggestion and intimidation. Choose the right sucker and if he eventually sees through you he may prove easier to escape than a crowd.
因此，你可能更倾向于一对一地与人打交道。将他们从日常环境中隔离出来，其效果与将他们置于群体中相同——都会让他们更容易受到暗示和恐吓。选对目标，即使他最终识破了你的伎俩，摆脱他可能也比摆脱一群人要容易得多。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 28
第28条
ENTER ACTION WITH BOLDNESS
大胆行动
JUDGMENT
判断
If you are unsure of a course of action, do not attempt it. Your doubts and hesitations will infect your execution. Timidity is dangerous: Better to enter with boldness. Any mistakes you commit through audacity are easily corrected with more audacity. Everyone admires the bold; no one honors the timid.
如果你对某个行动方案犹豫不决，就不要贸然尝试。你的疑虑和犹豫会影响你的执行。怯懦是危险的：最好大胆行动。任何因大胆而犯下的错误，都可以用更大的勇气来弥补。人人都钦佩勇敢者，没有人会尊重胆怯者。
The path of pleasure never leads to glory! The prodigious achievements of Hercules were the result of high adventure, and though there is little, either in fable or history, to show that he had any rivals, still it is recorded that a knight errant, in company with a fellow adventurer, sought his fortune in a romantic country. He had not traveled far when his companion observed a post, on which was written the following inscription: “Brave adventurer, if you have a desire to discover that which has never been seen by any knight errant, you have only to pass this torrent, and then take in your arms an elephant of stone and carry it in one breath to the summit of this mountain, whose noble head seems blended with the sky.” “But,”said the knight's companion, “the water may be deep as well as rapid, and though, notwithstanding, we should pass it, why should we be encumbered with the elephant What a ridiculous undertaking!” And philosophically and with nice calculation, he observed that the elephant might be carried four steps; but for conveying it to the top of the mountain in one breath, that was not in the power of a mortal, unless it should
享乐之路永不通往荣耀！赫拉克勒斯的伟大成就源于惊险刺激的冒险，尽管无论是传说还是史书都鲜有记载表明他曾有过对手，但据记载，一位游侠骑士与另一位冒险伙伴一同前往一个充满浪漫气息的国度寻觅财富。他没走多远，同伴便看到一根柱子，上面写着如下铭文：“勇敢的冒险家，如果你渴望发现游侠骑士从未见过的奇景，只需渡过这湍急的溪流，然后抱起一头石象，一口气把它抬到这座山巅，那雄伟的山峰仿佛与苍穹融为一体。” “可是，”骑士的同伴说道，“溪水可能既深又急，即便我们能够渡过，又何必拖着这头大象呢？这真是荒谬至极！” 他沉思片刻，又经过一番精妙的计算，指出这头大象只需走四步就能扛过去；但要一口气把它送到山顶，这并非凡人所能做到，除非……
BOLDNESS AND HESITATION: A Brief Psychological Comparison Boldness and hesitation elicit very different psychological responses in their targets: Hesitation puts obstacles in your path, boldness eliminates them. Once you understand this, you will find it essential to overcome your natural timidity and practice the art of audacity. The following are among the most pronounced psychological effects of boldness and timidity.
大胆与犹豫：简要心理对比 大胆和犹豫会引发目标对象截然不同的心理反应：犹豫会设置障碍，而大胆则会扫除障碍。一旦你理解了这一点，你就会发现克服天生的胆怯并练习大胆的艺术至关重要。以下是大胆和胆怯最显著的心理影响。
The Bolder the Lie the Better. We all have weaknesses, and our efforts are never perfect. But entering action with boldness has the magical effect of hiding our deficiencies. Con artists know that the bolder the lie, the more convincing it becomes. The sheer audacity of the story makes it more credible, distracting attention from its inconsistencies. When putting together a con or entering any kind of negotiation, go further than you planned. Ask for the moon and you will be surprised how often you get it.
谎言越大胆越好。我们都有弱点，我们的努力也永远不可能完美无缺。但大胆行动却能神奇地掩盖我们的不足。骗子们深谙此道，谎言越大胆，就越令人信服。故事的荒诞程度本身就使其更具可信度，从而转移人们对其中矛盾之处的注意力。在策划骗局或进行任何谈判时，要比你预想的走得更远。大胆地提出你的要求，你会惊讶地发现，很多时候你都能如愿以偿。
Lions Circle the Hesitant Prey. People have a sixth sense for the weaknesses of others. If, in a first encounter, you demonstrate your willingness to compromise, back down, and retreat, you bring out the lion even in people who are not necessarily bloodthirsty. Everything depends on perception, and once you are seen as the kind of person who quickly goes on die defensive, who is willing to negotiate and be amenable, you will be pushed around without mercy.
狮子围着犹豫不决的猎物转。人们对他人的弱点有着敏锐的直觉。如果在初次见面时，你表现出妥协、退让和撤退的意愿，即使是对那些并非嗜血成性的人来说，也会激起他们内心深处的狮子本能。一切都取决于感知，一旦你被视为那种动辄进入防御状态、愿意谈判和妥协的人，你就会被毫不留情地摆布。
Boldness Strikes Fear; Fear Creates Authority. The bold move makes you seem larger and more powerful than you are. If it comes suddenly, with die stealth and swiftness of a snake, it inspires diat much more fear. By intimidating with a bold move, you establish a precedent: in every subsequent encounter, people will be on the defensive, in terror of your next strike.
大胆之举引发恐惧；恐惧铸就权威。大胆的举动会让你显得比实际更强大、更有威慑力。如果行动来得突然，如蛇般迅捷隐秘，更能震慑他人。通过大胆的举动震慑，你便树立了一个先例：在随后的每一次交锋中，人们都会处于守势，畏惧你的下一次攻击。
Going Halfway with Half a Heart Digs the Deeper Grave. If you
用半颗心走一半的路，只会挖得更深的坟墓。如果你
enter an action with less than total confidence, you set up obstacles in your own path. When a problem arises you will grow confused, seeing options where there are none and inadvertendy creating more problems still. Retreating from the hunter, the timid hare scurries more easily into his snares.
如果你在行动时缺乏十足的信心，就会给自己设置障碍。当问题出现时，你会感到困惑，看到一些根本不存在的选择，反而无意中制造出更多的问题。就像胆怯的兔子在躲避猎人时，更容易落入陷阱一样。
Hesitation Creates Gaps, Boldness Obliterates Them. When you take time to diink, to hem and haw, you create a gap that allows others time to think as well. Your timidity infects people with awkward energy, elicits embarrassment. Doubt springs up on all sides.
犹豫不决会制造隔阂，大胆行动则能消除隔阂。当你犹豫不决、支支吾吾时，你便制造了隔阂，让别人也有时间思考。你的怯懦会传染给周围的人，让他们感到尴尬，甚至产生怀疑。
Boldness destroys such gaps. The swiftness of die move and die energy of the action leave others no space to doubt and worry. In seduction, hesitation is fatalit makes your victim conscious of your intentions. The bold move crowns seduction with triumph: It leaves no time for reflection.
大胆行动能消除这些疑虑。迅捷的举动和强大的气场让对方毫无疑虑和担忧。在诱惑中，犹豫是致命的，它会让你的猎物意识到你的意图。大胆的行动为诱惑画上圆满的句号：它不给对方任何思考的时间。
Audacity Separates You from the Herd. Boldness gives you presence and makes you seem larger than life. The timid fade into the wallpaper, the
胆识让你脱颖而出。大胆赋予你存在感，让你显得卓尔不凡。胆怯者最终会淹没在人群中，黯然失色。
bold draw attention, and what draws attention draws power. We cannot keep our eyes off the audaciouswe cannot wait to see their next bold move.
大胆之举引人注目，而引人注目之物便蕴含力量。我们无法将目光从那些胆大妄为之人身上移开——我们迫不及待地想看看他们下一步的惊人之举。
OBSERVANCES OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Observance I
观察 I
In May of 1925, five of the most successful dealers in the French scrap-metal business found themselves invited to an “official” but “highly confidential” meeting with the deputy director general of the Ministry of Post and Telegraphs at the Hotel Crillon, then the most luxurious hotel in Paris. When the businessmen arrived, it was the director general himself, a Monsieur Lustig, who met diem in a swank suite on the top floor.
1925年5月，法国废金属行业五位最成功的经销商受邀前往巴黎最豪华的酒店——克里翁酒店，与邮政电报部副部长进行一次“官方”但“高度机密”的会面。商人们抵达后，迎接他们的正是部长本人，卢斯蒂格先生，他当天在顶层一间豪华套房里接待了他们。
The businessmen had no idea why they had been summoned to this meeting, and they were bursting with curiosity. After drinks, the director explained. “Gendemen,” he said, “fhis is an urgent matter that requires complete secrecy. The government is going to have to tear down the Eiffel Tower.” The dealers listened in stunned silence as the director explained that the tower, as recendy reported in the news, desperately needed repairs. It had originally been meant as a temporary structure (for the Exposition of 1889), its maintenance costs had soared over the years, and now, in a time of a fiscal crisis, the government would have to spend millions to fix it. Many Parisians considered the Eiffel Tower an eyesore and would be delighted to see it go. Over time, even the tourists would forget about itit would live on in photographs and postcards. “Gendemen,” Lustig said, “you are all invited to make the government an offer for the Eiffel Tower.”
这些商人完全不明白自己为何被召集来参加这次会议，心中充满了好奇。酒过之后，负责人解释道：“先生们，”他说，“这是件紧急的事情，需要绝对保密。政府不得不拆除埃菲尔铁塔。” 商人们震惊地沉默着，负责人解释说，正如最近的新闻报道，这座铁塔急需修缮。它最初是为1889年世博会而建的临时建筑，多年来维护成本飙升，如今正值财政危机时期，政府不得不花费数百万美元来修缮它。许多巴黎人认为埃菲尔铁塔碍眼，乐见其拆除。随着时间的推移，就连游客也会忘记它——它只会留在照片和明信片上。“先生们，”卢斯蒂格说，“请各位都向政府提出购买埃菲尔铁塔的报价。”
He gave the businessmen sheets of government stationery filled with figures, such as the tonnage of the tower's metal. Their eyes popped as they calculated how much tiiey could make from the scrap. Then Lustig led them to a waiting limo, which brought them to the Eiffel Tower. Flashing an official badge, he guided mem through the area, spicing his tour witii amusing anecdotes. At the end of the visit he thanked them and asked them to have fheir offers delivered to his suite within four days.
他递给这些商人几张印满数字的政府信笺，比如埃菲尔铁塔金属的吨位。他们瞪大了眼睛，计算着能从这些废料中赚多少钱。随后，卢斯蒂格领着他们上了一辆等候的豪华轿车，前往埃菲尔铁塔。他亮出公文包，带领他们参观，并穿插着一些有趣的轶事。参观结束时，他向他们道谢，并请他们在四天内将报价送到他的套房。
Several days after the offers were submitted, one of the five, a Monsieur P., received notice that his bid was the winner, and diat to secure fhe sale he should come to the suite at the hotel within two days, bearing a certified check for more than 250,000 francs (the equivalent today of about $1,000,000)a quarter of the toted price. On delivery of the check, he would receive the documents confirming his ownership of the Eiffel Tower. Monsieur P. was excitedhe would go down in history as the man who had bought and torn down the infamous landmark. But by the time he arrived at the suite, check in hand, he was beginning to have doubts about the whole affair. Why meet in a hotel instead of a government building Why hadn't he heard from other officials Was diis a hoax, a scam As he listened to Lustig discuss die arrangements for the scrapping of the tower, he hesitated, and contemplated backing out.
报价提交几天后，五位竞标者之一的P先生收到通知，他的出价中标。通知要求他两天内携带一张超过25万法郎（相当于今天的约100万美元）的保付支票前往酒店套房，以确保交易完成。这笔款项相当于标价的四分之一。支票交付后，他将收到确认其拥有埃菲尔铁塔所有权的证明文件。P先生兴奋不已，他即将名垂青史，成为买下并拆除这座著名地标的人。然而，当他拿着支票抵达套房时，却开始对整件事产生了怀疑。为什么选择在酒店而不是政府大楼见面？为什么其他官员没有联系他？这难道是个骗局？当他听着卢斯蒂格讨论拆除铁塔的安排时，他犹豫了，甚至考虑过退出。
be the dwarf figure of an elephant, fit only to be placed on the top of a stick; and then what honor would there be in such an adventure “There is,”said he, “some deception in this writing. It is an enigma only fit to amuse a child. I shall therefore leave you and your elephant.” The reasoner then departed; but the adventurous man rushed with his eyes closed across the water; neither depth nor violence prevented him, and according to the inscription he saw the elephant lying on the opposite bank. He took it and carried it to the top of the hill, where he saw a town. A shriek from the elephant alarmed the people of the city, who rose in arms; but the adventurer, nothing daunted, was determined to die a hero. The people, however, were awed by his presence, and he was astonished to hear them proclaim him successor to their king, who had recently died. Great enterprises are only achieved by adventurous spirits. They who calculate with too great nicety every difficulty and obstacle which is likely to lie in their way, lose that time in hesitation, which the more daring seize and render available to the loftiest purposes.
如果那只是一头矮小的象，只配放在棍子顶上，那这样的冒险又有什么荣耀可言呢？“这文字里有欺骗，”他说，“它只是个谜，只适合逗弄孩子。所以我就此告辞，你和你的象就此别过。”说完，那位讲道理的人便离开了；而那位冒险家则闭着眼睛，奋力游过河面；水深水浅，波涛汹涌，都阻挡不了他。根据碑文的记载，他看到那头象躺在对岸。他把它抱起来，带到山顶，在那里他看到了一座城镇。象的一声嘶鸣惊动了城里的居民，他们纷纷拿起武器；但这位冒险家毫不畏惧，决心要像个英雄一样死去。然而，人们都被他的气势所震慑，他惊讶地听到他们拥立他为刚刚驾崩的国王的继承人。伟大的事业唯有冒险精神才能成就。那些过于细致地计算前进道路上可能遇到的每一个困难和障碍的人，会因为犹豫而浪费时间，而那些更有胆识的人则会抓住这些时间，并将其用于最崇高的目标。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Jean de La Fontaine, 1621-1695
让·德拉封丹，1621-1695 年
Always set to work without misgivings on the score of imprudence. Fear of failure in the mind of a performer is, for an onlooker, already evidence of failure.... Actions are dangerous when there is doubt as to their wisdom; it would be safer to do nothing.
永远不要因为轻率行事而心存疑虑。对于旁观者而言，表演者心中对失败的恐惧本身就已是失败的证明……当对行动的明智性有所怀疑时，行动便是危险的；此时，什么都不做反而更安全。
Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
In a lowly thatched cottage in the Namsan Valley there lived a poor couple, Mr. and Mrs. Huh Saeng. The husband confined himself for seven years and only read books in his cold room.... One day his wife, all in tears, said to him: “Look here, my good man! What is the use of all your book reading I have spent my youth in washing and sewing for other people and yet I have no spare jacket or skirt to wear and I have had no food to eat during the past three days. I am hungry and cold. I can stand it no more!” ... Hearing these words, the middle-aged scholar closed his book ... rose to his feet and ... without saying another word, he went out of doors. . . .Arriving in the heart of the
在南山山谷一间简陋的茅屋里，住着一对贫穷的夫妇，许生先生和许生太太。丈夫把自己关在房间里七年，只读书……一天，妻子泪流满面地对他说：“我的好丈夫，你看！你读书有什么用？我年轻时靠给别人洗衣缝补为生，如今却连一件外套或裙子都没有，而且这三天都没吃过东西了。我又饿又冷，我再也受不了了！”……听到这番话，这位中年学者合上书……站起身来……一句话也没说，就走出了家门……来到了……
Suddenly, however, he realized that the director had changed his tone. Instead of talking about the tower, he was complaining about his low salary, about his wife's desire for a fur coat, about how galling it was to work hard and be unappreciated. It dawned on Monsieur P. that this high government official was asking for a bribe. The effect on him, though, was not outrage but relief. Now he was sure that Lustig was for real, since in all of his previous encounters with French bureaucrats, they had inevitably asked for a little greasing of the palm. His confidence restored, Monsieur P. slipped the director several thousand francs in bills, then handed him the certified check. In return he received the documentation, including an impressive-looking bill of sale. He left the hotel, dreaming of the profits and fame to come.
然而，他突然意识到，那位主管的语气变了。主管不再谈论那座塔，而是抱怨自己薪水微薄，妻子想要一件皮草大衣，辛勤工作却得不到赏识，令人恼火不已。P先生这才恍然大悟，这位高级官员是在索要贿赂。然而，他并没有感到愤怒，反而松了一口气。现在他确信卢斯蒂格先生所言非虚，因为在他之前与法国官员的所有接触中，他们无一例外都曾索要过一些好处。重拾信心的P先生悄悄塞给主管几千法郎的钞票，然后递上一张保付支票。作为回报，他收到了文件，其中包括一份看起来非常体面的销售单。他离开了酒店，憧憬着即将到来的丰厚利润和显赫名望。
Over the next few days, however, as Monsieur P. waited for correspondence from the government, he began to realize that something was amiss. A few telephone calls made it clear that there was no deputy director general Lustig, and there were no plans to destroy the Eiffel Tower: He had been bilked of over 250,000 francs!
然而，接下来的几天里，P先生在等待政府来信的过程中，开始意识到事情有些不对劲。几个电话让他明白，根本没有副总干事卢斯蒂格这个人，也没有摧毁埃菲尔铁塔的计划：他被骗走了超过25万法郎！
Monsieur P. never went to the police. He knew what kind of reputation he would get if word got out that he had fallen for one of the most absurdly audacious cons in history. Besides the public humiliation, it would have been business suicide. Interpretation
P先生从未报警。他很清楚，如果他落入史上最荒唐、最胆大妄为的骗局之一，名声会变得多么糟糕。除了颜面尽失，这无异于自毁前程。
Had Count Victor Lustig, con artist extraordinaire, tried to sell the Arc de Triomphe, a bridge over the Seine, a statue of Balzac, no one would have believed him. But the Eiffel Tower was just too large, too improbable to be part of a con job. In fact it was so improbable that Lustig was able to return to Paris six months later and “resell” the Eiffel Tower to a different scrap-iron dealer, and for a higher pricea sum in francs equivalent today to over $1,500,000!
如果骗术大师维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵试图出售凯旋门、塞纳河上的桥梁或巴尔扎克的雕像，恐怕没人会相信。但埃菲尔铁塔实在太大了，也太不可思议了，根本不可能成为骗局的一部分。事实上，这事儿太不可思议了，以至于卢斯蒂格六个月后竟然还能回到巴黎，把埃菲尔铁塔“转手”卖给另一个废铁商，而且价格更高——相当于今天的150多万美元！
Largeness of scale deceives the human eye. It distracts and awes us, and is so self-evident that we cannot imagine there is any illusion or deception afoot. Arm yourself with bigness and boldnessstretch your deceptions as far as they will go and then go further. If you sense that the sucker has suspicions, do as the intrepid Lustig did: Instead of backing down, or lowering his price, he simply raised his price higher, by asking for and getting a bribe. Asking for more puts the other person on the defensive, cuts out the nibbling effect of compromise and doubt, and overwhelms with its boldness.
规模庞大会迷惑人眼。它分散我们的注意力，令我们敬畏，而且如此显而易见，以至于我们根本无法想象其中有任何幻象或欺骗。要以宏大的规模和大胆的胆量武装自己，将你的欺骗延伸到极限，然后再进一步。如果你察觉到对方有所怀疑，那就效仿勇敢的卢斯蒂格：他没有退缩，也没有降低价格，而是通过索要贿赂的方式提高了价格。索要更多会让对方产生防御心理，消除妥协和怀疑的蚕食效应，并以其大胆的姿态压倒对方。
Observance II
遵守第二条
On his deathbed in 1533, Vasily III, the Grand Duke of Moscow and ruler of a semi-united Russia, proclaimed his three-year-old son, Ivan IV, as his successor. He appointed his young wife, Helena, as regent until Ivan reached his majority and could rule on his own. The aristocracythe bo-yarssecretly rejoiced: For years the dukes of Moscow had been trying to extend their authority over the boyars' turf. With Vasily dead, his heir a mere three years old, and a young woman in charge of the dukedom, die
1533年，莫斯科大公、半统一俄罗斯的统治者瓦西里三世在临终前，宣布他年仅三岁的儿子伊凡四世为继承人。他任命年轻的妻子海伦娜为摄政，直到伊凡成年并能独立执政为止。贵族们——贵族们——暗自欢喜：多年来，莫斯科公爵们一直试图将他们的权力扩展到贵族们的地盘上。瓦西里去世，他的继承人年仅三岁，而掌管公国的却是一位年轻女子，这无疑为莫斯科公国带来了新的希望。
boyars would be able to roll back the dukes' gains, wrest control of the state, and humiliate the royal family.
贵族们将能够扭转公爵们的胜利果实，夺取国家控制权，并羞辱皇室。
Aware of these dangers, young Helena turned to her trusted friend Prince Ivan Obolensky to help her rule. But after five years as regent she suddenly diedpoisoned by a member of the Shuisky family, the most fearsome boyar clan. The Shuisky princes seized control of the government and threw Obolensky in prison, where he starved to death. At the age of eight, Ivan was now a despised orphan, and any boyar or family member who took an interest in him was immediately banished or killed.
意识到这些危险，年轻的海伦娜求助于她信任的朋友伊万·奥博连斯基王子，希望他能协助自己执政。然而，在她摄政五年后，她突然去世——被最令人闻风丧胆的贵族家族舒伊斯基家族的一名成员毒害。舒伊斯基家族的王子们夺取了政权，并将奥博连斯基投入监狱，最终他被活活饿死。八岁的伊万成了一个受人鄙视的孤儿，任何对他表示关心的贵族或家族成员都会立即被驱逐或处死。
And so Ivan roamed the palace, hungry, ill clothed, and often in hiding from the Shuiskys, who treated him roughly when they saw him. On some days they would search him out, clothe him in royal robes, hand him a scepter, and set him on the thronea kind of mock ritual in which they lampooned his royal pretensions. Then they would shoo him away. One evening several of them chased the Metropolitanthe head of the Russian churchthrough the palace, and he sought refuge in Ivan's room; the boy watched in horror as the Shuiskys entered, hurled insults, and beat the Metropolitan mercilessly.
于是，伊凡在宫中四处游荡，饥寒交迫，衣衫褴褛，常常躲避舒伊斯基兄弟的追捕。他们每次见到他，都会对他施以粗暴的对待。有时，他们会找到他，给他穿上华丽的皇家服饰，递给他一根权杖，让他坐在王座上——这是一种滑稽的仪式，用来嘲讽他妄想成为王室成员。然后，他们又会把他赶走。一天晚上，几个舒伊斯基兄弟追赶着俄罗斯教会的领袖——都主教，都主教只好躲进伊凡的房间。伊凡惊恐地看着舒伊斯基兄弟闯了进来，辱骂并残忍地殴打都主教。
Ivan had one friend in the palace, a boyar named Vorontsov who consoled and advised him. One day, however, as he, Vorontsov, and the newest Metropolitan conferred in the palace refectory, several Shuiskys burst in, beat up Vorontsov, and insulted the Metropolitan by tearing and treading on his robes. Then they banished Vorontsov from Moscow.
伊凡在宫中只有一个朋友，名叫沃龙佐夫的贵族，他安慰并劝诫伊凡。然而有一天，当伊凡、沃龙佐夫和新任都主教在宫廷餐厅商议时，几个舒伊斯基人闯了进来，殴打了沃龙佐夫，并撕扯、践踏都主教的袍子，以此侮辱他。之后，他们将沃龙佐夫驱逐出了莫斯科。
Throughout all this Ivan maintained a strict silence. To the boyars it seemed that their plan had worked: The young man had turned into a terrified and obedient idiot. They could ignore him now, even leave him alone. But on the evening of December 29, 1543, Ivan, now thirteen, asked Prince Andrei Shuisky to come to his room. When the prince arrived, the room was filled with palace guards. Young Ivan then pointed his finger at Andrei and ordered the guards to arrest him, have him killed, and throw his body to the bloodhounds in the royal kennel. Over the next few days Ivan had all of Andrei's close associates arrested and banished. Caught off-guard by his sudden boldness, the boyars now stood in mortal terror of this youth, the future Ivan the Terrible, who had planned and waited for five years to execute this one swift and bold act that would secure his power for decades to come. Interpretation
在此期间，伊凡始终保持沉默。在贵族们看来，他们的计划似乎奏效了：这个年轻人变成了一个惊恐顺从的傻瓜。他们现在可以无视他，甚至可以放任不管。然而，1543年12月29日晚，年仅十三岁的伊凡叫安德烈·舒伊斯基王子到他的房间来。王子到达时，房间里挤满了宫廷卫兵。年轻的伊凡随即指着安德烈，命令卫兵逮捕他，处死他，并将他的尸体扔进皇家犬舍喂猎犬。接下来的几天里，伊凡将安德烈的所有亲信都逮捕并流放了。贵族们被他突如其来的胆大妄为弄得措手不及，此刻他们对这个年轻人——未来的伊凡雷帝——充满了恐惧。他筹划并等待了五年，只为执行这迅速而大胆的行动，从而确保自己未来几十年的统治。
The world is full of boyarsmen who despise you, fear your ambition, and jealously guard their shrinking realms of power. You need to establish your authority and gain respect, but the moment the boyars sense your growing boldness, they will act to thwart you. This is how Ivan met such a situation: He lay low, showing neither ambition nor discontent. He waited, and when the time came he brought the palace guards over to his side. The guards had come to hate the cruel Shuiskys. Once they agreed to Ivan's plan, he struck with the swiftness of a snake, pointing his finger at Shuisky and giving him no time to react.
世上到处都是卑鄙的贵族，他们鄙视你，畏惧你的野心，并嫉妒地守护着日渐萎缩的权力。你需要确立自己的权威，赢得尊重，但一旦贵族们察觉到你日益增长的胆识，他们就会采取行动阻挠你。伊凡就是这样应对这种情况的：他保持低调，既不显露野心，也不流露出不满。他静待时机，时机一到，便将宫廷卫兵拉拢到自己身边。卫兵们早已对残暴的舒伊斯基家族恨之入骨。一旦他们同意了伊凡的计划，他便如蛇般迅捷地出手，指着舒伊斯基，不给他任何反应的时间。
Negotiate with a boyar and you create opportunities for him. A small
与贵族谈判，你就能为他创造机会。一个小
city, he stopped a passing gentleman. “Hello, my friend! Who is the richest man in town” “Poor countryman! Don't you know Bydn-ssi, the millionaire His glittering tile-roofed house pierced by twelve gates is just over there.” Huh Saeng bent his steps to the rich man's house. Having entered the big gate, he flung the guest-room door open and addressed the host: “I need 10,000 yang for capital for my commercial business and I want you to lend me the money.” “Alright, sir. Where shall I send the money”
他走到城里，拦住一位路过的绅士。“你好，朋友！请问城里谁是首富？”“可怜的乡下人！你难道不知道拜登先生，那位百万富翁吗？他那座瓦顶闪闪发光、有十二道门的豪宅就在那边。”许生弯下腰，朝富翁的宅邸走去。他走进大门，一把推开客房的门，对主人说道：“我需要一万日元作为商业资金，想请您借给我。”“好的，先生。我该把钱寄到哪里？”
“To the Ansdng Market in care of a commission merchant.” “ Very well, sir. I will draw on Kim, who does the biggest commission business in the Ansdng Market. You 'II get the money there.”
“送到安斯丁市场，交给佣金商。” “好的，先生。我会找金，他在安斯丁市场做佣金生意最大。您会在那里拿到钱。”
“Good-bye, sir.” When Huh Saeng was gone, all the other guests in the room asked Bydn-ssi why he gave so much money to a beggarlike stranger whose family name was unknown to him. But the rich man replied with a triumphant face: "Even though he was in ragged clothes, he spoke clearly to the point without betraying shame or inferiority, unlike common people who want to borrow money for a bad debt. Such a man as he is either mad or self-confident in doing business. But judging from his dauntless eyes and booming voice he
“再见，先生。”许生走后，房间里的其他客人都问拜登先生，为什么给一个连姓氏都不知道的、衣衫褴褛的陌生人那么多钱。但这位富翁却一脸得意地回答说：“他虽然衣衫褴褛，但说话条理清晰，毫不羞愧，不像那些想借钱来偿还坏账的普通人。像他这样的人，要么是疯了，要么是做生意太自信了。但从他那无所畏惧的眼神和洪亮的声音来看……”
is an uncommon man
是一个不寻常的人
with a superhuman
拥有超人的能力
brain, worthy of my
大脑，配得上我的
trust, I know money
相信我，我懂钱。
and I know men.
我认识男人。
Money often makes a
金钱往往会带来……
man small, but a man
身材矮小，但却是个男人
like him makes big
像他这样的人成就斐然
money. I am only glad
钱。我只高兴
to have helped a big
帮助了很多人
man do big business."
男人做大生意。
BEHIND THE SCENES
幕后花絮
OF ROYAl. PALACES
皇家宫殿
IN KOREA,
在韩国，
Ha Tae-hung, 1983
河泰雄，1983年
Fear, which always magnifies objects, gives a body to all their fancies, which takes for its form whatever they conceive to exist in their enemies' thoughts; so that fearful persons seldom fail to fall into real inconveniences, occasioned by imaginary dangers.... And the duke, whose predominant character was to be always full of fear and of distrust, was, of all men I have ever seen, the most capable of falling into false steps, by the dread he had of falling into them; being in that like unto hares.
恐惧总是会放大事物，使人的所有幻想都具象化，并以敌人心中所想的一切作为其形态；因此，胆小的人常常会因臆想的危险而陷入真正的困境……而那位公爵，其主要性格就是永远充满恐惧和猜忌，在我所见过的所有人中，他是最容易因害怕犯错而犯错的人；在这方面，他就像兔子一样。
Cardinal de Retz, 1613-1679
雷茨枢机主教，1613-1679年
compromise becomes the toehold he needs to tear you apart. The sudden bold move, without discussion or warning, obliterates these toeholds, and builds your authority. You terrify doubters and despisers and gain the confidence of the many who admire and glorify those who act boldly.
妥协成了他撕裂你的跳板。突然而大胆的举动，不经商量，不加警告，便能摧毁这些跳板，并巩固你的权威。你令怀疑者和鄙视者胆寒，赢得众多钦佩和推崇勇于行动者的人的信任。
Observance III
遵守第三条
In 1514 the twenty-two-year-old Pietro Aretino was working as a lowly assistant scullion to a wealthy Roman family. He had ambitions of greatness as a writer, to enflame the world with his name, but how could a mere lackey hope to realize such dreams
1514年，22岁的皮耶特罗·阿雷蒂诺在罗马一个富裕人家做着卑微的厨房帮工。他渴望成为一名伟大的作家，用自己的名字震撼世界，但一个卑微的仆人又怎能奢望实现这样的梦想呢？
That year Pope Leo X received from the king of Portugal an embassy that included many gifts, most prominent among them a great elephant, the first in Rome since imperial times. The pontiff adored this elephant and showered it with attention and gifts. But despite his love and care, the elephant, which was called Hanno, became deathly ill. The pope summoned doctors, who administered a five-hundred-pound purgative to the elephant, but all to no avail. The animal died and the pope went into mourning. To console himself he summoned the great painter Raphael and ordered him to create a life-sized painting of Hanno above the animal's tomb, bearing the inscription, “What nature took away, Raphael has with his art restored.”
那一年，教皇利奥十世收到了葡萄牙国王送来的使节团，其中有许多礼物，最引人注目的是一头巨大的大象，这是自罗马帝国时代以来罗马出现的第一头大象。教皇非常喜爱这头大象，对它关怀备至，并赠送了许多礼物。然而，尽管教皇如此宠爱它，这头名叫汉诺的大象还是病入膏肓。教皇召来医生，医生们给大象服用了重达五百磅的泻药，但一切都无济于事。大象最终死去，教皇陷入了悲痛之中。为了抚慰自己的心灵，他召来伟大的画家拉斐尔，命令他为汉诺的墓碑创作一幅真人大小的画像，并题词：“自然所夺走的，拉斐尔用他的艺术将其恢复。”
Over the next few days, a pamphlet circulated throughout Rome that caused great merriment and laughter. Entitled “The Last Will and Testament of the Elephant Hanno,” it read, in part, “To my heir the Cardinal Santa Croce, I give my knees, so that he can imitate my genuflections. ... To my heir Cardinal Sand Quattro, I give my jaws, so that he can more readily devour all of Christ's revenues. ... To my heir Cardinal Medici, I give my ears, so that he can hear everyone's doings. . . .” To Cardinal Grassi, who had a reputation for lechery, the elephant bequeathed the appropriate, oversized part of his own anatomy.
