接下来的几天里，一份名为《大象汉诺的遗嘱》的小册子在罗马城内流传开来，引起了人们的极大欢笑。小册子部分内容如下：“我将我的膝盖留给我的继承人圣十字枢机主教，以便他能模仿我的屈膝礼……我将我的下颚留给我的继承人桑德·夸特罗枢机主教，以便他能更轻松地吞噬基督的所有收入……我将我的耳朵留给我的继承人美第奇枢机主教，以便他能听到每个人的动向……”至于以好色著称的格拉西枢机主教，大象则将自己身体上尺寸合适的、略微夸张的部位遗赠给了他。
On and on the anonymous pamphlet went, sparing none of the great in Rome, not even the pope. With each one it took aim at their best-known weakness. The pamphlet ended with verse, “See to it that Aretino is your friend / For he is a bad enemy to have. / His words alone could ruin the high pope / So God guard everyone from his tongue.” Interpretation
这本匿名小册子不断刊登，罗马的权贵们无一幸免，就连教皇也不例外。每一篇都直指他们最臭名昭著的弱点。小册子以一首诗结尾：“务必与阿雷蒂诺交好/因为他是个可怕的敌人/他的一句话就能毁掉教皇/愿上帝保佑大家远离他的恶言恶语。”
With one short pamphlet, Aretino, son of a poor shoemaker and a servant himself, hurled himself to fame. Everyone in Rome rushed to find out who this daring young man was. Even the pope, amused by his audacity, sought him out and ended up giving him a job in the papal service. Over the years he came to be known as the “Scourge of Princes,” and his biting tongue earned him the respect and fear of the great, from the king of France to the Hapsburg emperor.
凭借一本小册子，出身贫寒的鞋匠之子、自己也曾是仆人的阿雷蒂诺一举成名。罗马城里人人都争相打听这位胆大妄为的年轻人究竟是谁。就连教皇也被他的胆识所折服，亲自找到他，最终让他进入教廷任职。多年来，他被誉为“君王之鞭”，他那尖锐的言辞赢得了从法国国王到哈布斯堡皇帝等各界名流的敬畏与威慑。
The Aretino strategy is simple: When you are as small and obscure as David was, you must find a Goliath to attack. The larger the target, the more attention you gain. The bolder the attack, the more you stand out
阿雷蒂诺的策略很简单：当你像大卫一样渺小默默无闻时，你必须找到一个巨人歌利亚去攻击。目标越大，你获得的关注就越多。攻击越大胆，你就越引人注目。
from the crowd, and the more admiration you earn. Society is full of those who think daring thoughts but lack the guts to print and publicize them. Voice what the public feelsthe expression of shared feelings is always powerful. Search out the most prominent target possible and sling your boldest shot. The world will enjoy the spectacle, and will honor the underdogyou, that iswith glory and power.
从人群中脱颖而出，你赢得的赞誉就越多。社会上充斥着那些思想大胆却缺乏勇气将其付诸笔端的人。表达公众的感受——共同的情感表达永远充满力量。找到最显眼的目标，然后放出你最勇敢的一击。世界将会欣赏这场盛事，并会以荣耀和力量来敬重你这个弱者。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Most of us are timid. We want to avoid tension and conflict and we want to be liked by all. We may contemplate a bold action but we rarely bring it to life. We are terrified of the consequences, of what others might think of us, of the hostility we will stir up if we dare go beyond our usual place.
我们大多数人都很胆怯。我们想避免紧张和冲突，也想讨人喜欢。我们或许会考虑采取大胆的行动，但很少付诸实践。我们害怕后果，害怕别人怎么看我们，害怕如果我们胆敢越过惯常的界限，会招致怎样的敌意。
Although we may disguise our timidity as a concern for others, a desire not to hurt or offend them, in fact it is the oppositewe are really self-absorbed, worried about ourselves and how others perceive us. Boldness, on the other hand, is outer-directed, and often makes people feel more at ease, since it is less self-conscious and less repressed.
虽然我们可能将怯懦伪装成对他人的关心，不想伤害或冒犯他人，但实际上恰恰相反——我们其实非常自我中心，担心自己以及别人如何看待我们。另一方面，大胆则是一种外向型的特质，它往往让人感到更加自在，因为它更少自我意识，更少压抑。
This can be seen most clearly in seduction. All great seducers succeed through effrontery. Casanova's boldness was not revealed in a daring approach to the woman he desired, or in intrepid words to flatter her; it consisted in his ability to surrender himself to her completely and to make her believe he would do anything for her, even risk his life, which in fact he sometimes did. The woman on whom he lavished this attention understood that he held nothing back from her. This was infinitely more flattering than compliments. At no point during the seduction would he show hesitation or doubt, simply because he never felt it.
这一点在诱惑中体现得最为明显。所有伟大的诱惑者都凭借厚颜无耻而得逞。卡萨诺瓦的胆识并非体现在他大胆接近心仪女子，或用花言巧语奉承她；而是体现在他能够完全臣服于她，让她相信他会为她做任何事，甚至冒生命危险——而事实上，他有时也确实如此。被他如此殷勤对待的女子明白，他对她毫无保留。这比任何赞美都更令人心动。在整个诱惑过程中，他从未流露出丝毫犹豫或怀疑，因为他从未有过这种感觉。
Part of the charm of being seduced is that it makes us feel engulfed, temporarily outside of ourselves and the usual doubts that permeate our lives. The moment the seducer hesitates, the charm is broken, because we become aware of the process, of their deliberate effort to seduce us, of their self-consciousness. Boldness directs attention outward and keeps the illusion alive. It never induces awkwardness or embarrassment. And so we admire the bold, and prefer to be around them, because their self-confidence infects us and draws us outside our own realm of inwardness and reflection.
被诱惑的魅力之一在于它让我们感到被包围，暂时脱离自我，摆脱生活中常见的种种疑虑。一旦诱惑者犹豫不决，魅力便会消散，因为我们会意识到整个过程，意识到他们刻意诱惑我们的努力，意识到他们的自我意识。大胆则将注意力引向外部，维持着这种幻觉。它从不令人尴尬或难堪。因此，我们欣赏大胆的人，更喜欢与他们相处，因为他们的自信会感染我们，将我们从内省和反思的世界中拉出来。
Few are born bold. Even Napoleon had to cultivate the habit on the battlefield, where he knew it was a matter of life and death. In social settings he was awkward and timid, but he overcame this and practiced boldness in every part of his life because he saw its tremendous power, how it could literally enlarge a man (even one who, like Napoleon, was in fact conspicuously small). We also see this change in Ivan the Terrible: A harmless boy suddenly transforms himself into a powerful young man who commands authority, simply by pointing a finger and taking bold action.
天生胆大的人寥寥无几。就连拿破仑也需要在战场上培养这种品质，因为他深知战场上的胆量关乎生死。在社交场合，他笨拙而胆怯，但他克服了这些缺点，在生活的方方面面都展现出胆识，因为他看到了胆识的巨大力量，它能真正地提升一个人的地位（即使像拿破仑这样身材矮小的人也能如此）。我们在伊凡雷帝身上也看到了这种转变：一个无害的男孩突然蜕变为一个威风凛凛的青年，仅仅凭借一根手指和大胆的行动，就足以震慑众人。
You must practice and develop your boldness. You will often find uses for it. The best place to begin is often the delicate world of negotiation, par-
你必须练习并培养你的胆识。你会发现它常常有用武之地。最好的起点往往是微妙的谈判世界，或者说，是谈判的领域。
THE BOY AND THE NETTLE
男孩与荨麻
A boy playing in the fields got stung by a nettle. He ran home to his mother, telling her that he had but touched that nasty weed, and it had stung him. “It was just your touching it, my boy,” said the mother, “that caused it to sting you; the next time you meddle with a nettle, grasp it tightly, and it will do you no hurt.”
一个男孩在田野里玩耍时被荨麻蜇了。他跑回家告诉妈妈，他只是碰了一下那讨厌的杂草，就被蜇了。“孩子，你只是碰了一下，”妈妈说，“所以才被蜇了；下次你再碰荨麻的时候，把它抓紧，就不会被蜇了。”
Do boldly what you do at all.
做你该做的事，就要大胆去做。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop,
伊索
sixth century b.c.
公元前六世纪
HOW TO BE VICTORIOUS IN LOVE
如何在爱情中取得胜利
But with those who have made an impression upon your heart, I have noticed that you are timid. This quality might affect a bour-geoise, but you must attack the heart of a woman of the world with other weapons.... I tell you on behalf of women: there is not one of us who does not prefer a little rough handling to too much consideration. Men lose through blundering more hearts than virtue saves. The more timidity a lover shows with us the more it concerns our pride to goad him on; the more respect he has for our
但对于那些真正打动你的人，我注意到你有些胆怯。这种性格或许会让资产阶级女人感到羞怯，但你必须用其他手段才能赢得世故女人的心……我代表所有女人告诉你：我们女人都更喜欢粗暴一点的对待，而不是过于温柔体贴。男人因轻率行事而失去的芳心，远比美德挽救的要多得多。爱人越是胆怯，我们就越会为了维护自尊而激怒他；他越会尊重我们。
resistance, the more respect we demand of him. We would willingly say to you men: “Ah, in pity's name do not suppose us to be so very virtuous; you are forcing us to have too much of it. ...” We are continually struggling to hide the fact that we have permitted ourselves to be loved. Put a woman in a position to say that she has yielded only to a species of violence, or to surprise: persuade her that you do not undervalue her, and I will answer for her heart. ...A little more boldness on your part would put you both at your ease. Do you remember what M. de la Rochefoucauld told you lately: “A reasonable man in love may act like a madman, but he should not and cannot act like an idiot. ”
反抗越多，我们对他的尊重就越高。我们真想对你们男人说：“啊，看在怜悯的份上，别以为我们多么高尚；你们逼得我们太过分了……”我们一直在努力掩饰自己允许被爱的事实。让一个女人说她只是屈服于某种暴力或惊喜：让她相信你没有低估她，我会替她承担责任……你们再大胆一点，彼此都会更自在。你们还记得拉罗什福科先生最近跟你们说过的话吗：“一个理智的男人在恋爱中可能会像个疯子，但他不应该也不能像个傻瓜。”
life, letters, and
生活、书信和
epicurean philosophy
伊壁鸠鲁哲学
ok ninon de i.enclos,
好的，Ninon 来自 i.enclos，
Ninon de Lenclos,
尼农·德·朗克洛斯
1620-1705
ticularly those discussions in which you are asked to set your own price. How often we put ourselves down by asking for too litde. When Christopher Columbus proposed that the Spanish court finance his voyage to the Americas, he also made the insanely bold demand that he be called “Grand Admiral of the Ocean.” The court agreed. The price he set was the price he receivedhe demanded to be treated with respect, and so he was. Henry Kissinger too knew that in negotiation, bold demands work better than starting off with piecemeal concessions and trying to meet the other person halfway. Set your value high, and then, as Count Lustig did, set it higher.
尤其是在那些需要你自行定价的讨论中。我们常常因为要价过低而贬低自己。当克里斯托弗·哥伦布提议西班牙宫廷资助他前往美洲的航行时，他还提出了一个极其大胆的要求：称他为“海洋大元帅”。宫廷同意了。他定的价格就是他得到的——他要求得到尊重，而他也确实得到了尊重。亨利·基辛格也深谙此道：在谈判中，大胆的要求比一开始就做出零碎的让步，试图与对方各退一步要有效得多。先把你的价值定得高一些，然后像卢斯蒂格伯爵那样，再把它定得更高。
Understand: If boldness is not natural, neither is timidity. It is an acquired habit, picked up out of a desire to avoid conflict. If timidity has taken hold of you, then, root it out. Your fears of the consequences of a bold action are way out of proportion to reality, and in fact the consequences of timidity are worse. Your value is lowered and you create a self-fulfilling cycle of doubt and disaster. Remember: The problems created by an audacious move can be disguised, even remedied, by more and greater audacity.
明白：如果说大胆并非天性，那么胆怯也同样如此。胆怯是一种后天习得的习惯，源于逃避冲突的渴望。如果你已被胆怯所控制，那就必须将其根除。你对大胆行动后果的恐惧远远超出了现实，事实上，胆怯的后果更加严重。它会让你贬低自身价值，并陷入自我怀疑和灾难的恶性循环。记住：大胆行动带来的问题，可以通过更大更大的勇气来掩盖，甚至弥补。
Image: The Lion and the Hare. The lion creates no gaps in his wayhis movements are too swift, his jaws too quick and powerful. The timid hare will do anything to escape danger, but in its haste to retreat and flee, it backs into traps, hops smack into its enemies' jaws.
图片：狮子和兔子。狮子行动迅捷，张开的嘴巴灵活有力，不留任何空隙。胆小的兔子为了躲避危险会不惜一切代价，但在仓皇逃窜的过程中，它却常常落入陷阱，一头扎进敌人的血盆大口。
Authority: I certainly think that it is better to be impetuous than cautious, for fortune is a woman, and it is necessary, if you wish to master her, to conquer her by force; and it can be seen that she lets herself be overcome by the bold rather than by those who proceed coldly. And therefore, like a woman, she is always a friend to the young, because they are less cautious, fiercer, and master her with greater audacity. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：我当然认为冲动比谨慎好，因为命运如妇，若想驾驭她，就必须以武力征服她；显而易见，她更易被勇猛之人而非冷漠之人征服。因此，如同女人一般，命运总是年轻人的朋友，因为他们不那么谨慎，更加勇猛，也更敢于以更大的胆量去征服她。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
Boldness should never be the strategy behind all of your actions. It is a tactical instrument, to be used at the right moment. Plan and think ahead, and make the final element the bold move that will bring you success. In other words, since boldness is a learned response, it is also one that you learn to control and utilize at will. To go through life armed only with audacity would be tiring and also fatal. You would offend too many people, as is proven by those who cannot control their boldness. One such person was Lola Montez; her audacity brought her triumphs and led to her seduction of die king of Bavaria. But since she could never rein in her boldness, it also led to her downfallin Bavaria, in England, wherever she turned. It crossed die border between boldness and the appearance of cruelty, even insanity. Ivan the Terrible suffered the same fate: When the power of boldness brought him success, he stuck to it, to the point where it became a lifelong pattern of violence and sadism. He lost the ability to tell when boldness was appropriate and when it was not.
大胆绝不应成为你所有行动的策略。它是一种战术工具，要在合适的时机使用。要提前计划和思考，最后一步才是真正能为你带来成功的大胆行动。换句话说，大胆是一种后天习得的反应，你也应该学会控制它，并随心所欲地运用它。如果一生只凭胆大妄为，那将令人疲惫不堪，甚至可能致命。你会得罪太多人，那些无法控制自己胆大妄为的人就是最好的证明。洛拉·蒙特斯就是这样一个例子；她的胆大妄为为她带来了成功，并最终让她诱惑了巴伐利亚国王。但由于她始终无法控制自己的胆大妄为，最终也导致了她在巴伐利亚、在英国乃至任何地方的覆灭。她的胆大妄为已经越过了大胆与残忍，甚至是疯狂之间的界限。伊凡雷帝也遭遇了同样的命运：当胆大妄为的力量为他带来成功时，他便沉溺其中，最终演变成一种终生暴力和虐待狂的模式。他失去了判断何时应该大胆行事、何时不应该大胆行事的能力。
Timidity has no place in the realm of power; you will often benefit, however, by being able to feign it. At that point, of course, it is no longer timidity but an offensive weapon: You are luring people in with your show of shyness, all the better to pounce on mem boldly later.
怯懦在权力领域毫无立足之地；然而，你若能巧妙地伪装怯懦，往往反而会从中获益。当然，到了那个时候，怯懦就不再是怯懦，而是一种进攻性武器：你用羞涩的外表引诱他人，以便之后更大胆地出击。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 29
第29条
PLAN ALL THE WAY TO THE END
计划要一直持续到最后
JUDGMENT
判断
The ending is everything. Plan all the way to it, taking into account all the possible consequences, obstacles, and twists of fortune that might reverse your hard work and give the glory to others. By planning to the end you will not be overwhelmed by circumstances and you will know when to stop. Gently guide fortune and help determine the future by thinking far ahead.
结局至关重要。要从头到尾做好规划，考虑到所有可能的后果、障碍和变数，以免你的努力付诸东流，让荣耀落入他人之手。通过周密的计划，你不会被环境所压垮，也懂得何时该止步。深思熟虑，才能巧妙地引导命运，把握未来。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In 1510 a ship set out from the island of Hispaniola (now Haiti and the Dominican Republic) for Venezuela, where it was to rescue a besieged Spanish colony. Several miles out of port, a stowaway climbed out of a provision chest: Vasco Nunez de Balboa, a noble Spaniard who had come to the New World in search of gold but had fallen into debt and had escaped his creditors by hiding in the chest.
1510年，一艘船从伊斯帕尼奥拉岛（今海地和多米尼加共和国）出发前往委内瑞拉，目的是解救一个被围困的西班牙殖民地。出港数英里后，一个偷渡者从一个补给箱里爬了出来：他就是瓦斯科·努涅斯·德·巴尔博亚，一位西班牙贵族，来到新大陆是为了寻找黄金，却欠下了巨额债务，为了躲避债主，他藏身于补给箱中。
Balboa had been obsessed with gold ever since Columbus had returned to Spain from his voyages with tales of a fabulous but as yet undiscovered kingdom called El Dorado. Balboa was one of the first adventurers to come in search of Columbus's land of gold, and he had decided from the beginning that he would be the one to find it, through sheer audacity and single-mindedness. Now diat he was free of his creditors, nothing would stop him.
自从哥伦布远航归来，带回关于一个名为黄金国（El Dorado）的神秘王国的故事后，巴尔博亚就对黄金着迷不已。他是最早一批前来寻找哥伦布口中黄金之国的冒险家之一，从一开始就下定决心要凭借着胆识和执着找到它。如今他已摆脱了债主的纠缠，没有什么能阻止他了。
Unfortunately the ship's owner, a wealthy jurist named Francisco Fernandez de Enciso, was furious when told of the stowaway, and he ordered that Balboa be left on the first island they came across. Before they found any island, however, Enciso received news that the colony he was to rescue had been abandoned. This was Balboa's chance. He told the sailors of his previous voyages to Panama, and of the rumors he had heard of gold in the area. The excited sailors convinced Enciso to spare Balboa's life, and to establish a colony in Panama. Weeks later they named their new setdement “Darien.”
不幸的是，船主弗朗西斯科·费尔南德斯·德·恩西索是一位富有的法学家，得知船上有偷渡者后勃然大怒，下令将巴尔博亚留在他们遇到的第一个岛屿上。然而，在找到任何岛屿之前，恩西索就收到消息，他原本要营救的殖民地已被废弃。这正是巴尔博亚的机会。他向水手们讲述了自己之前前往巴拿马的经历，以及他听说的关于该地区有黄金的传闻。兴奋的水手们说服恩西索饶巴尔博亚一命，并允许他在巴拿马建立殖民地。几周后，他们将新定居点命名为“达连”。
Darien's first governor was Enciso, but Balboa was not a man to let others steal the initiative. He campaigned against Enciso among the sailors, who eventually made it clear that diey preferred him as governor. Enciso fled to Spain, fearing for his life. Months later, when a representative of the Spanish crown arrived to establish himself as the new, official governor of Darien, he was turned away. On his return voyage to Spain, this man drowned; the drowning was accidental, but under Spanish law, Balboa had murdered the governor and usurped his position.
达连的首任总督是恩西索，但巴尔博亚绝非任人唯亲之人。他积极游说水手们反对恩西索，最终水手们明确表示他们更倾向于自己担任总督。恩西索担心自身安危，逃往西班牙。数月后，当西班牙王室的一名代表抵达达连，准备正式就任新任总督时，却遭到了拒绝。此人在返回西班牙的途中溺水身亡；虽然溺水是意外，但根据西班牙法律，巴尔博亚却谋杀了总督，篡夺了他的职位。
Balboa's bravado had got him out of scrapes before, but now his hopes of wealth and glory seemed doomed. To lay claim to El Dorado, should he discover it, he would need the approval of the Spanish king which, as an outlaw, he would never receive. There was only one solution. Panamanian Indians had told Balboa of a vast ocean on the other side of the Central American isthmus, and had said that by traveling south upon this western coast, he would reach a fabulous land of gold, called by a name that to his ears sounded like “Biru.” Balboa decided he would cross the treacherous jungles of Panama and become the first European to bathe his feet in this new ocean. From there he would march on El Dorado. If he did this on Spain's behalf, he would obtain the eternal gratitude of the king, and would secure his own reprieveonly he had to act before Spanish authorities came to arrest him.
巴尔博亚的胆识曾多次让他化险为夷，但如今，他追求财富和荣耀的梦想似乎注定破灭。即便他真的发现了黄金国，想要据为己有也需要得到西班牙国王的许可，而作为一名亡命之徒，他永远不可能获得这样的许可。只有一个办法。巴拿马印第安人曾告诉巴尔博亚，在中美洲地峡的另一边有一片浩瀚的海洋，并说沿着西海岸向南行进，就能到达一个传说中的黄金之地，那里有一个听起来像“比鲁”的名字。巴尔博亚决定穿越巴拿马险恶的丛林，成为第一个踏入这片新海洋的欧洲人。然后，他将从那里向黄金国进军。如果他能代表西班牙完成这项任务，就能赢得国王的永恒感激，也能确保自己获得赦免——他必须在西班牙当局前来逮捕他之前行动。
In 1513, then, Balboa set out, widi 190 soldiers. Halfway across the isthmus (some ninety miles wide at that point), only sixty soldiers re-
1513年，巴尔博亚率领190名士兵出发。行至地峡中部（当时地峡宽约90英里）时，仅有60名士兵返回。
There are very few menand they are the exceptionswho are able to think and feel beyond the present moment.
极少数人能够超越当下去思考和感受，他们是例外。
Carl von Clausewitz, 1780-1831
卡尔·冯·克劳塞维茨，1780-1831年
THK TWO THOCS
THK TWO THOCS
Two frogs dwelt in the same pool The pool being dried up under the summer's heat, they left it, and set out together to seek another home. As they went along they chanced to pass a deep well, amply supplied with water, on seeing which one of the frogs said to the other: “Let us descend and make our abode in this well, it will furnish us with shelter and food.” The other replied with greater caution: “But suppose the water should fail us, how can we get out again from so great a depth ” Do nothing without a regard to the consequences.
两只青蛙住在同一个水池里。夏天酷热难耐，水池干涸了，它们便离开了水池，一起出发寻找新的家园。途中，它们偶然路过一口深井，井水充足。其中一只青蛙对另一只说：“我们下去住吧，井里有地方住，有食物。”另一只青蛙则更加谨慎地回答：“可是，万一井水干涸了，我们怎么从这么深的地方出来呢？” 做事要考虑后果。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop,
伊索
sixth century b.c.
公元前六世纪
LAW 29
第29条
Look to the end, no
看看结局，没有
matter what it is you
不管是什么
are considering. Often
正在考虑。通常
enough, God gives a
够了，上帝赐予
man a glimpse of
男人瞥见
happiness, and then
幸福，然后
utterly ruins him.
彻底毁了他。
the histories,
历史，
Herodotus,
希罗多德
fifth century b.c.
公元前五世纪
In ancient times a king ofTartary was out walking with some of his noblemen. At the roadside was an abdal (a wandering Sufi), who cried out: “Whoever will give me a hundred dinars, I will give him some good advice.” The king stopped, and said: “Abdal, what is this good advice for a hundred dinars'7 ”Sir,“ answered the abdal, ”order the sum to be given to me, and I will tell it you immediately. “ The king did so, expecting to hear something extraordinary. The dervish said to him: ”My advice is this: Never begin anything until you have reflected what will be the end of it.“At this the nobles and everyone else present laughed, saying that the abdal had been wise to ask for his money in advance. But the king said: ” You . have no reason to laugh at the good advice this abdal has given me. No one is
古代，鞑靼国王与几位贵族外出散步。路边站着一位阿卜杜勒（一位云游四方的苏菲派苦行僧），他高声喊道：“谁给我一百第纳尔，我就给他一些忠告。”国王停下脚步，问道：“阿卜杜勒，一百第纳尔能换来什么忠告？”阿卜杜勒回答说：“陛下，吩咐人把钱给我，我马上就告诉你。”国王照做了，期待听到一些非凡的忠告。苦行僧对他说：“我的忠告是：做任何事之前，都不要急于求成，一定要先想清楚结果。”贵族们和在场的所有人都笑了，说阿卜杜勒提前要钱真是明智。但国王说：“你们没有理由嘲笑这位阿卜杜勒给我的忠告。没有人会……”
mained, many having succumbed to the harsh conditionsthe bloodsucking insects, the torrential rainfall, fever. Finally, from a mountaintop, Balboa became the first European to lay eyes on the Pacific Ocean. Days later he marched in his armor into its waters, bearing the banner of Castile and claiming all its seas, lands, and islands in the name of the Spanish throne.
许多人死于恶劣的环境——吸血昆虫、暴雨和高烧。最终，巴尔博亚站在山顶，成为第一个亲眼目睹太平洋的欧洲人。几天后，他身披盔甲，高举卡斯蒂利亚的旗帜，进入太平洋，并以西班牙王室的名义宣布占领太平洋的所有海域、陆地和岛屿。
Indians from the area greeted Balboa with gold, jewels, and precious pearls, the like of which he had never seen. When he asked where these had come from, die Indians pointed south, to the land of the Incas. But Balboa had only a few soldiers left. For the moment, he decided, he should return to Darien, send the jewels and gold to Spain as a token of good will, and ask for a large army to aid him in the conquest of El Dorado.
当地印第安人向巴尔博亚献上黄金、珠宝和珍贵的珍珠，这些珍宝他从未见过。当他询问这些礼物来自何处时，印第安人指向南方，指向印加帝国的土地。但巴尔博亚当时只剩下寥寥几名士兵。他决定，暂时返回达连，将珠宝和黄金作为友好礼物送往西班牙，并请求西班牙派遣一支大军协助他征服黄金国。
When news reached Spain of Balboa's bold crossing of die isthmus, his discovery of the western ocean, and his planned conquest of El Dorado, the former criminal became a hero. He was instandy proclaimed governor of the new land. But before the king and queen received word of his discovery, they had already sent a dozen ships, under the command of a man named Pedro Arias Davila, “Pedrarias,” with orders to arrest Balboa for murder and to take command of the colony. By the time Pedrarias arrived in Panama, he had learned that Balboa had been pardoned, and that he was to share die governorship with the former oudaw.
当巴尔博亚大胆穿越地峡、发现西洋以及计划征服黄金国的消息传到西班牙时，这位昔日的罪犯摇身一变，成了英雄。他立即被拥立为这片新大陆的总督。然而，在国王和王后得知他的发现之前，他们已经派遣了十二艘船，由一位名叫佩德罗·阿里亚斯·达维拉（绰号“佩德拉里亚斯”）的人指挥，奉命逮捕巴尔博亚，并以谋杀罪名接管殖民地。当佩德拉里亚斯抵达巴拿马时，他得知巴尔博亚已被赦免，他将与这位昔日的乌达共同执掌总督之职。
All the same, Balboa felt uneasy. Gold was his dream, El Dorado his only desire. In pursuit of this goal he had nearly died many times over, and to share the wealth and glory with a newcomer would be intolerable. He also soon discovered that Pedrarias was a jealous, bitter man, and equally unhappy with the situation. Once again, the only solution for Balboa was to seize the initiative by proposing to cross the jungle with a larger army, carrying ship-building materials and tools. Once on the Pacific coast, he would create an armada with which to conquer the Incas. Surprisingly enough, Pedrarias agreed to the planperhaps sensing it would never work. Hundreds died in this second march through the jungle, and the timber they carried rotted in die torrential rains. Balboa, as usual, was undauntedno power in the world could thwart his planand on arriving at the Pacific he began to cut down trees for new lumber. But the men remaining to him were too few and too weak to mount an invasion, and once again Balboa had to return to Darien.
尽管如此，巴尔博亚仍然感到不安。黄金是他的梦想，黄金国是他唯一的渴望。为了实现这个目标，他曾多次险些丧命，与一个新来者分享财富和荣耀是他无法容忍的。他很快发现，佩德拉里亚斯是个嫉妒心强、心怀怨恨的人，同样对现状不满。巴尔博亚唯一的解决办法再次是主动出击，提议率领一支更大的军队穿越丛林，携带造船材料和工具。一旦抵达太平洋沿岸，他就要组建一支舰队来征服印加帝国。出乎意料的是，佩德拉里亚斯竟然同意了这个计划——或许他预感到这根本不可能成功。在第二次穿越丛林的行军中，数百人丧生，他们携带的木材也在暴雨中腐烂。巴尔博亚一如既往地毫不气馁——世界上没有任何力量能够阻止他的计划——抵达太平洋沿岸后，他开始砍伐树木，以获取新的木材。但他剩下的人手太少、太弱，无法发动入侵，巴尔博亚不得不再次返回达连。
Pedrarias had in any case invited Balboa back to discuss a new plan, and on the outskirts of the settlement, the explorer was met by Francisco Pizarro, an old friend who had accompanied him on his first crossing of the isthmus. But this was a trap: Leading one hundred soldiers, Pizarro surrounded his former friend, arrested him, and returned him to Pedrarias, who tried him on charges of rebellion. A few days later Balboa's head fell into a basket, along with those of his most trusted followers. Years later Pizarro himself reached Peru, and Balboa's deeds were forgotten.
无论如何，佩德拉里亚斯邀请巴尔博亚回去商讨新的计划。在定居点郊外，这位探险家遇到了老朋友弗朗西斯科·皮萨罗，皮萨罗曾陪同他第一次穿越地峡。但这却是一个陷阱：皮萨罗率领一百名士兵包围了这位昔日的朋友，逮捕了他，并将他押回佩德拉里亚斯处。佩德拉里亚斯以叛乱罪名审判了他。几天后，巴尔博亚的头颅连同他最信任的几名追随者的头颅一起被扔进了一个篮子里。多年后，皮萨罗本人也来到了秘鲁，而巴尔博亚的功绩则被世人遗忘。
Interpretation
解释
Most men are ruled by the heart, not die head. Their plans are vague, and when they meet obstacles they improvise. But improvisation will only bring you as far as the next crisis, and is never a substitute for thinking several steps ahead and planning to the end.
大多数人受感情而非理性支配。他们的计划模糊不清，遇到困难就临时应对。但这种临时应对只能让你撑到下一个危机，永远无法替代深思熟虑、未雨绸缪的计划。
Balboa had a dream of glory and wealth, and a vague plan to reach it. Yet his bold deeds, and his discovery of the Pacific, are largely forgotten, for he committed what in die world of power is the ultimate sin: He went part way, leaving the door open for others to take over. A real man of power would have had the prudence to see the dangers in the distance the rivals who would want to share in the conquests, the vultures that would hover once tiiey heard the word “gold.” Balboa should have kept his knowledge of the Incas secret until after he had conquered Peru. Only then would his wealth, and his head, have been secure. Once Pedrarias arrived on the scene, a man of power and prudence would have schemed to kill or imprison him, and to take over the army he had brought for die conquest of Peru. But Balboa was locked in the moment, always reacting emotionally, never thinking ahead.
巴尔博亚梦想着荣耀和财富，并有一个模糊的计划来实现它。然而，他那些大胆的壮举，以及他对太平洋的发现，大多已被遗忘，因为他犯下了权力世界里最大的罪过：他半途而废，给别人留下了可乘之机。一个真正有权势的人会足够谨慎，预见到远处潜藏的危险——那些觊觎他征服成果的竞争对手，以及那些一旦听到“黄金”二字就会蜂拥而至的秃鹫。巴尔博亚本应将他对印加帝国的了解保密，直到征服秘鲁之后。只有那时，他的财富和人身安全才能得到保障。一旦佩德拉里亚斯出现，一个有权势且谨慎的人就会策划除掉或囚禁他，并夺取他为征服秘鲁而带来的军队。但巴尔博亚却被当下的冲动所蒙蔽，总是凭情绪行事，从不考虑长远。
What good is it to have the greatest dream in die world if others reap the benefits and the glory Never lose your head over a vague, open-ended dreamplan to the end.
即使拥有世界上最伟大的梦想，如果其他人却享受着梦想带来的利益和荣耀，那又有什么用呢？永远不要为了一个模糊不清、没有尽头的梦想计划而失去理智。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In 1863 the Prussian premier Otto von Bismarck surveyed the chessboard of European power as it then stood. The main players were England, France, and Austria. Prussia itself was one of several states in the loosely allied German Federation. Austria, dominant member of the Federation, made sure mat die other German states remained weak, divided and submissive. Bismarck believed that Prussia was destined for something far greater than servant boy to Austria.
1863年，普鲁士首相奥托·冯·俾斯麦审视了当时的欧洲权力格局。主要玩家是英国、法国和奥地利。普鲁士本身是松散联盟德意志联邦的几个邦国之一。作为联邦的主导成员，奥地利确保其他德意志邦国保持软弱、分裂和顺从的状态。俾斯麦坚信，普鲁士的命运远不止于沦为奥地利的附庸。
This is how Bismarck played the game. His first move was to start a war with lowly Denmark, in order to recover the former Prussian lands of Schleswig-Holstein. He knew that tiiese rumblings of Prussian independence might worry France and England, so he enlisted Austria in the war, claiming that he was recovering Schleswig-Holstein for tiieir benefit. In a few months, after the war was decided, Bismarck demanded that the newly conquered lands be made part of Prussia. The Austrians of course were furious, but tiiey compromised: First they agreed to give the Prussians Schleswig, and a year later tiiey sold them Holstein. The world began to see that Austria was weakening and that Prussia was on the rise.
这就是俾斯麦的策略。他的第一步是向弱小的丹麦发动战争，以收复原先属于普鲁士的石勒苏益格-荷尔斯泰因。他深知普鲁士独立的苗头可能会令法国和英国担忧，因此他拉拢奥地利参战，声称收复石勒苏益格-荷尔斯泰因是为了奥地利的利益。几个月后，战争胜负已定，俾斯麦要求将新征服的土地并入普鲁士。奥地利人当然勃然大怒，但最终还是做出了妥协：他们先是同意将石勒苏益格割让给普鲁士，一年后又将荷尔斯泰因卖给了普鲁士。世人开始意识到奥地利正在衰落，而普鲁士正在崛起。
Bismarck's next move was his boldest: In 1866 he convinced King William of Prussia to withdraw from die German Federation, and in doing so to go to war with Austria itself. King William's wife, his son die crown prince, and die princes of the otiier German kingdoms vehemently opposed such a war. But Bismarck, undaunted, succeeded in forcing the conflict, and Prussia's superior army defeated die Austrians in die brutally
俾斯麦的下一步行动最为大胆：1866年，他成功说服普鲁士国王威廉退出德意志联邦，并因此与奥地利开战。威廉国王的妻子、他的儿子皇太子以及其他德意志王国的王子们都强烈反对这场战争。但俾斯麦毫不畏惧，成功地迫使战争爆发，普鲁士凭借其强大的军队，最终残酷地击败了奥地利军队。
unaware of the fact that we should think well before doing anything. But we are daily guilty of not remembering, and the consequences are evil. I very much value this dervish's advice."
我们往往意识不到做任何事之前都应该三思。但我们每天都犯着忘记这一点的错误，而其后果不堪设想。我非常珍视这位苦行僧的忠告。
The king decided to bear the advice always in his mind, and commanded it to be written in gold on the walls and even engraved on his silver plate. Not long afterward a plotter desired to kill the king. He bribed the royal surgeon with a promise of the prime ministership if he thrust a poisoned lancet into the king 's arm. When the time came to let some of the king's blood, a silver basin was placed to catch the blood. Suddenly the surgeon became aware of the words engraved upon it: “Never begin anything until you have reflected what will be the end of it.” It was only then that he realized that if the plotter became king he could have the surgeon killed instantly, and would not need to fulfill his bargain.
国王决定将这番忠告铭记于心，并下令将其用金字镌刻在墙上，甚至刻在他的银盘上。不久之后，一个阴谋家企图刺杀国王。他贿赂皇家御医，承诺如果他用淬毒的柳叶刀刺入国王的手臂，就让他担任宰相。当要放出一些国王的血时，人们放置了一个银盆来接血。突然，御医注意到银盆上刻着这样一句话：“凡事，切勿操之过急。” 这时他才意识到，如果阴谋家当上了国王，他可以立刻处死御医，也就无需履行之前的交易了。
The king, seeing that the surgeon was now trembling, asked him what was wrong with him. And so he confessed the truth, at that very moment. The plotter was seized; and the king sent for all the people who had been present when the abdal gave his advice, and said to them: “Do you still laugh at the dervish”
国王见外科医生浑身颤抖，便问他出了什么事。外科医生当即坦白了一切。阴谋者被抓获；国王召集了所有在场听阿卜杜勒出谋划策的人，对他们说：“你们还在嘲笑那个苦行僧吗？”
caravan of dreams, Idriks Shah, 1968
梦想之旅，伊德里克斯·沙阿，1968年
He who asks fortunetellers the future unwittingly forfeits an inner intimation of coming events that is a thousand times more exact than anything they may say.
向算命先生询问未来的人，不知不觉地失去了对即将发生的事情的内在预感，而这种预感比算命先生所说的任何话都要准确一千倍。
Walter Benjamin, 1892-1940
瓦尔特·本雅明，1892-1940
short Seven Weeks War. The king and the Prussian generals then wanted to march on Vienna, taking as much land from Austria as possible. But Bismarck stopped diemnow he presented himself as on the side of peace. The result was that he was able to conclude a treaty with Austria that granted Prussia and the other German states total autonomy. Bismarck could now position Prussia as die dominant power in Germany and the head of a newly formed North German Confederation.
短暂的七周战争结束后，国王和普鲁士将领们想要进军维也纳，尽可能多地夺取奥地利的领土。但俾斯麦阻止了他们的行动，并表明自己站在和平的一方。最终，他与奥地利缔结了条约，赋予普鲁士和其他德意志邦国完全的自治权。俾斯麦由此得以将普鲁士确立为德国的主导力量，并使其成为新成立的北德意志邦联的首脑。
The French and the English began to compare Bismarck to Attila the Hun, and to fear that he had designs on all of Europe. Once he had started on the path to conquest, there was no telling where he would stop. And, indeed, three years later Bismarck provoked a war with France. First he appeared to give his permission to France's annexation of Belgium, then at die last moment he changed his mind. Playing a cat-and-mouse game, he infuriated die French emperor, Napoleon III, and stirred up his own king against the French. To no one's surprise, war broke out in 1870. The newly formed German federation enthusiastically joined in the war on France, and once again the Prussian military machine and its allies destroyed the enemy army in a matter of months. Aldiough Bismarck opposed taking any French land, the generals convinced him that Alsace-Lorraine would become part of the federation.
法国人和英国人开始将俾斯麦比作匈奴王阿提拉，并担心他觊觎整个欧洲。一旦他踏上征服之路，就无人能预料他会止步于何处。果然，三年后，俾斯麦挑起了与法国的战争。他先是似乎同意法国吞并比利时，然后在最后一刻改变了主意。他玩弄猫捉老鼠的游戏，激怒了法国皇帝拿破仑三世，并煽动自己的国王与法国对抗。不出所料，战争于1870年爆发。新成立的德意志联邦积极加入对法战争，普鲁士的军事机器及其盟友再次在短短几个月内摧毁了敌军。尽管俾斯麦反对吞并任何法国领土，但将军们说服他，阿尔萨斯-洛林将成为联邦的一部分。
Now all of Europe feared the next move of the Prussian monster, led by Bismarck, the “Iron Chancellor.” And in fact a year later Bismarck founded the German Empire, with die Prussian king as the newly crowned emperor and Bismarck himself a prince. But then somediing strange happened: Bismarck instigated no more wars. And while the other European powers grabbed up land for colonies in other continents, he severely limited Germany's colonial acquisitions. He did not want more land for Germany, but more security. For the rest of his life he struggled to maintain peace in Europe and to prevent further wars. Everybody assumed he had changed, mellowing with the years. They had failed to understand: This was the final move of his original plan.
整个欧洲都惧怕普鲁士这头巨兽的下一步行动，而它的首领正是“铁血宰相”俾斯麦。事实上，一年后，俾斯麦建立了德意志帝国，普鲁士国王加冕为新皇帝，而俾斯麦本人则成了王子。但随后发生了一件奇怪的事：俾斯麦不再发动战争。当其他欧洲列强在其他大陆争相扩张殖民地时，他却严格限制了德国的殖民扩张。他想要的不是更多的土地，而是更多的安全。余生，他都致力于维护欧洲的和平，防止战争的再次爆发。所有人都以为他变了，随着岁月的流逝变得温和了。他们却没能理解：这其实是他最初计划的最后一步。
Interpretation
解释
There is a simple reason why most men never know when to come off the attack: They form no concrete idea of their goal. Once they achieve victory they only hunger for more. To stopto aim for a goal and then keep to itseems almost inhuman, in fact; yet nothing is more critical to the maintenance of power. The person who goes too far in his triumphs creates a reaction that inevitably leads to a decline. The only solution is to plan for the long run. Foresee the future with as much clarity as the gods on Mount Olympus, who look through the clouds and see the ends of all tilings.
大多数人永远不知道何时该停止进攻，原因很简单：他们没有明确的目标。一旦取得胜利，他们只会贪得无厌。停下来设定目标并坚持下去，这在当时看来几乎是反人类的；然而，对于维持权力而言，没有什么比这更重要。一个人如果过度沉溺于胜利，必然会引发衰落。唯一的解决之道是制定长远计划。要像奥林匹斯山上的众神那样，透过云层洞悉一切尽头，清晰地预见未来。
From the beginning of his career in politics, Bismarck had one goal: to form an independent German state led by Prussia. He instigated the war with Denmark not to conquer territory but to stir up Prussian nationalism and unite the country. He incited the war with Austria only to gain
从政治生涯伊始，俾斯麦就只有一个目标：建立一个由普鲁士领导的独立德意志国家。他发动对丹麦的战争并非为了征服领土，而是为了激发普鲁士民族主义情绪，实现国家统一。他发动对奥地利的战争也只是为了获取权力。
Prussian independence. (This was why he refused to grab Austrian territory.) And he fomented the war with France to unite the German kingdoms against a common enemy, and thus to prepare for the formation of a united Germany.
普鲁士独立。（这就是他拒绝吞并奥地利领土的原因。）他挑起与法国的战争，目的是联合德意志各王国对抗共同的敌人，从而为统一德国的建立做好准备。
Once this was achieved, Bismarck stopped. He never let triumph go to his head, was never tempted by the siren call of more. He held the reins tightly, and whenever the generals, or the king, or the Prussian people demanded new conquests, he held them back. Nothing would spoil the beauty of his creation, certainly not a false euphoria that pushed those around him to attempt to go past the end that he had so carefully planned.
一旦达成目标，俾斯麦便止步不前。他从不让胜利冲昏头脑，也从不被贪婪的诱惑所动摇。他牢牢掌控着局势，每当将军们、国王或普鲁士人民要求进行新的征服时，他都予以阻止。没有什么能够破坏他精心缔造的辉煌，尤其是那种驱使身边之人越过他精心规划的终点线的虚假狂喜。
Experience shows that, if one foresees from far away the designs to be
经验表明，如果一个人能够从远处预见未来的设计，那么……
undertaken, one can act with speed when the moment comes to execute them.
一旦着手去做，就能在执行的时机到来时迅速行动。
Cardinal Richelieu, 1585-1642
红衣主教黎塞留，1585-1642年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
According to the cosmology of the ancient Greeks, the gods were thought to have complete vision into die future. They saw everything to come, right down to the intricate details. Men, on the other hand, were seen as victims of fate, trapped in the moment and tfieir emotions, unable to see beyond immediate dangers. Those heroes, such as Odysseus, who were able to look beyond the present and plan several steps ahead, seemed to defy fate, to approximate the gods in their ability to determine the future. The comparison is still validthose among us who think further ahead and patiently bring their plans to fruition seem to have a godlike power.
根据古希腊的宇宙观，众神被认为拥有对未来全然的预知能力。他们能预见一切即将发生之事，甚至细致入微。而凡人则被视为命运的受害者，被困于当下和自身的情绪之中，无法洞察眼前的危险之外的事物。那些能够超越当下、未雨绸缪的英雄，例如奥德修斯，似乎能够战胜命运，在预知未来的能力上接近于神明。这种比喻至今仍然适用——我们当中那些能够高瞻远瞩、耐心规划并最终实现目标的人，似乎也拥有着神一般的力量。
Because most people are too imprisoned in the moment to plan with this kind of foresight, the ability to ignore immediate dangers and pleasures translates into power. It is the power of being able to overcome the natural human tendency to react to things as they happen, and instead to train oneself to step back, imagining the larger things taking shape beyond one's immediate vision. Most people believe that tiiey are in fact aware of the future, that they are planning and thinking ahead. They are usually deluded: What they are really doing is succumbing to their desires, to what they want the future to be. Their plans are vague, based on their imaginations rather than their reality. They may believe they are thinking all the way to the end, but they are really only focusing on the happy ending, and deluding themselves by the strength of their desire.
因为大多数人太过沉溺于当下，无法进行这种具有远见的规划，所以能够忽略眼前的危险和享乐就转化为一种力量。这种力量在于能够克服人类与生俱来的、对事物发生时做出反应的倾向，转而训练自己退后一步，想象超越眼前视野的更宏大的图景。大多数人自认为能够预见未来，并进行规划和思考。但他们通常是自欺欺人：他们实际上只是屈服于自己的欲望，屈服于自己对未来的期望。他们的计划模糊不清，基于想象而非现实。他们或许认为自己已经考虑到了最终结果，但实际上他们只关注于美好的结局，并被强烈的欲望蒙蔽了双眼。
In 415 B.C., the ancient Athenians attacked Sicily, believing their expedition would bring them riches, power, and a glorious ending to the sixteen-year Peloponnesian War. They did not consider the dangers of an invasion so far from home; they did not foresee that the Sicilians would fight all the harder since the batdes were in their own homeland, or that all of Athens's enemies would band together against them, or that war would break out on several fronts, stretching their forces way too thin. The Sicilian expedition was a complete disaster, leading to the destruction
公元前415年，古雅典人进攻西西里岛，他们相信这次远征将为他们带来财富、权力，并为长达十六年的伯罗奔尼撒战争画上一个辉煌的句号。然而，他们并未考虑到远征西西里岛的危险；他们没有预料到，西西里人会因为战场位于自己的故土而更加顽强抵抗；他们也没有预料到，雅典的所有敌人会联合起来对抗他们；更没有预料到，战争会在多条战线上爆发，使他们的兵力捉襟见肘。西西里远征最终以彻底的失败告终，并导致了雅典的毁灭。
of one of the greatest civilizations of all time. The Athenians were led into this disaster by their hearts, not their minds. They saw only the chance of glory, not the dangers that loomed in the distance.
这是历史上最伟大文明之一的覆灭。雅典人被他们的情感而非理智引向了这场灾难。他们只看到了荣耀的机会，却看不到远处潜伏的危险。
Cardinal de Retz, the seventeenth-century Frenchman who prided himself on his insights into human schemes and why they mostly fail, analyzed this phenomenon. In the course of a rebellion he spearheaded against the French monarchy in 1651, the young king, Louis XIV, and his court had suddenly left Paris and established themselves in a palace outside the capital. The presence of the king so close to the heart of the revolution had been a tremendous burden on the revolutionaries, and they breathed a sigh of relief. This later proved their downfall, however, since the court's absence from Paris gave it much more room to maneuver. “The most ordinary cause of people's mistakes,” Cardinal de Retz later wrote, “is their being too much frightened at the present danger, and not enough so at that which is remote.”
十七世纪的法国红衣主教雷茨（Cardinal de Retz）以其对人类谋略及其失败原因的深刻洞察而自豪，他曾分析过这一现象。1651年，年轻的路易十四国王领导了一场反对法国君主制的叛乱。叛乱期间，国王及其朝臣突然离开巴黎，迁居至首都郊外的一座宫殿。国王如此靠近革命中心，令革命者倍感压力，他们也因此松了一口气。然而，这最终却成了他们的致命弱点，因为朝廷离开巴黎后，给了他们更大的行动空间。“人们犯错最常见的原因，”雷茨红衣主教后来写道，“就是他们过于惧怕眼前的危险，而对远处的危险却不够警惕。”
The dangers that are remote, that loom in the distanceif we can see them as they take shape, how many mistakes we avoid. How many plans we would instandy abort if we realized we were avoiding a small danger only to step into a larger one. So much of power is not what you do but what you do not dodie rash and foolish actions that you refrain from before they get you into trouble. Plan in detail before you actdo not let vague plans lead you into trouble. Will this have unintended consequences Will I stir up new enemies Will someone else take advantage of my labors Unhappy endings are much more common than happy onesdo not be swayed by the happy ending in your mind.
那些遥远的、潜伏在暗处的危险——如果我们能预见到它们的雏形，就能避免多少错误。如果我们意识到自己为了规避小危险而踏入更大的陷阱，我们该会立即放弃多少计划？很多时候，真正的力量不在于你做了什么，而在于你没做什么——那些鲁莽愚蠢的行为，在你陷入困境之前就克制住了。行动之前要做好详细的计划，不要让模糊的计划把你引入歧途。这样做会带来意想不到的后果吗？我会树敌吗？我的劳动成果会被别人利用吗？不幸的结局远比幸福的结局常见——不要被你脑海中美好的结局所迷惑。
The French elections of 1848 came down to a struggle between Louis-Adolphe Thiers, the man of order, and General Louis Eugene Cavaignac, the rabble-rouser of the right. When Thiers realized he was hopelessly behind in this high-stakes race, he searched desperately for a solution. His eye fell on Louis Bonaparte, grand-nephew of the great general Napoleon, and a lowly deputy in the parliament. This Bonaparte seemed a bit of an imbecile, but his name alone could get him elected in a country yearning for a strong ruler. He would be Thiers's puppet and eventually would be pushed offstage. The first part of the plan worked to perfection, and Napoleon was elected by a large margin. The problem was that Thiers had not foreseen one simple fact: This “imbecile” was in fact a man of enormous ambition. Three years later he dissolved parliament, declared himself emperor, and ruled France for another eighteen years, much to the horror of Thiers and his party.
1848年的法国大选最终演变成秩序派路易·阿道夫·梯也尔和右翼煽动者路易·欧仁·卡瓦尼亚克将军之间的较量。梯也尔意识到自己在这场至关重要的选举中彻底落后，于是拼命寻找出路。他的目光落在了路易·波拿巴身上，这位伟大的将军拿破仑的侄孙，当时只是议会中一个地位卑微的议员。波拿巴看起来有些愚钝，但在一个渴望强权统治的国家，他的名字本身就足以让他当选。他将成为梯也尔的傀儡，最终被排挤出局。计划的第一部分完美奏效，拿破仑以绝对优势当选。问题在于，梯也尔没有预料到一个简单的事实：这个“愚钝”实际上野心勃勃。三年后，他解散了议会，宣布自己为皇帝，并统治法国长达十八年之久，这令梯也尔及其党羽感到无比恐惧。
The ending is everything. It is the end of the action that determines who gets the glory, the money, die prize. Your conclusion must be crystal clear, and you must keep it constantly in mind. You must also figure out how to ward off the vultures circling overhead, trying to live off the carcass of your creation. And you must anticipate the many possible crises that will tempt you to improvise. Bismarck overcame these dangers because he planned to the end, kept on course through every crisis, and
结局至关重要。行动的最终结果决定了谁能获得荣耀、金钱，甚至是死亡的奖赏。你的结论必须清晰明确，并且要时刻牢记。你还必须想办法抵御盘旋在你头顶的秃鹫，它们企图从你创造的成果中汲取养分。你必须预见到各种可能出现的危机，避免被迫即兴发挥。俾斯麦之所以能够克服这些危险，是因为他计划周全，在每一次危机中都坚持既定路线。
never let others steal the glory. Once he had reached his stated goal, he withdrew into his shell like a turtle. This kind of self-control is godlike.
从不让别人窃取荣耀。一旦达到既定目标，他就如同乌龟一般缩回壳里。这种自制力堪比神明。
When you see several steps ahead, and plan your moves all the way to the end, you will no longer be tempted by emotion or by die desire to improvise. Your clarity will rid you of the anxiety and vagueness that are the primary reasons why so many fail to conclude tiieir actions successfully. You see the ending and you tolerate no deviation.
当你能够预见未来数步，并规划好直至终点的每一步时，你将不再受情绪或即兴发挥的欲望所左右。你的清晰思路将消除焦虑和迷茫，而这正是许多人行动失败的主要原因。你预见了结局，并且绝不容忍任何偏差。
Image:
图像：
The Gods on
众神
Mount Olympus.
奥林匹斯山。
Looking down on
俯视
human actions from the
人类行为
clouds, they see in advance the
云朵，他们提前看到了
endings of all the great dreams that
所有伟大梦想的终结
lead to disaster and tragedy. And
导致灾难和悲剧。
they laugh at our inability to see beyond
他们嘲笑我们目光短浅。
the moment, and at how we delude ourselves.
此刻，以及我们如何自欺欺人。
Authority: How much easier it is never to get in than to get yourself out! We should act contrary to the reed which, when it first appears, throws up a long straight stem but afterwards, as though it were exhausted . . . makes several dense knots, indicating that it no longer has its original vigor and drive. We must rather begin gendy and coolly, saving our breath for the encounter and our vigorous thrusts for finishing off the job. In their beginnings it is we who guide affairs and hold them in our power; but so often once they are set in motion, it is they which guide us and sweep us along. (Montaigne, 1533-1592)
权威：与其费力地退出，不如一开始就不要进去！我们应该反其道而行之，就像芦苇一样，初生时挺拔挺拔，但之后却仿佛筋疲力尽……打出几个密实的结，表明它已失去了最初的活力和动力。我们应该谨慎而冷静地开始，把精力留到关键时刻，把全力以赴地完成任务。在事情的初期，是我们引导并掌控着局面；但往往一旦事情开始运转，反过来就是事情引导我们，裹挟我们前行。（蒙田，1533-1592）
REVERSAL
逆转
It is a cliche among strategists that your plan must include alternatives and have a degree of flexibility. That is certainly true. If you are locked into a plan too rigidly, you will be unable to deal with sudden shifts of fortune. Once you have examined the future possibilities and decided on your target, you must build in alternatives and be open to new routes toward your goal.
战略家们常说，计划必须包含备选方案并具备一定的灵活性，这的确是老生常谈。如果计划过于僵化，就无法应对突如其来的变故。一旦审视了未来的可能性并确定了目标，就必须制定备选方案，并对实现目标的新途径保持开放态度。
Most people, however, lose less from overplanning and rigidity than from vagueness and a tendency to improvise constantly in the face of circumstance. There is no real purpose in contemplating a reversal to this Law, then, for no good can come from refusing to think far into the future and planning to the end. If you are clear- and far-thinking enough, you will understand that the future is uncertain, and that you must be open to adaptation. Only having a clear objective and a far-reaching plan allows you that freedom.
然而，大多数人因过度计划和僵化而遭受的损失，远小于因计划不周和临场应变而造成的损失。因此，试图逆转这条法则并无实际意义，因为拒绝长远思考和制定周密计划，最终只会适得其反。如果你足够清晰且具有远见卓识，你就会明白未来充满不确定性，你必须灵活应对。只有拥有明确的目标和长远的计划，才能赋予你这种自由。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 30
法律30
MAKE YOUR
做出你的
ACCOMPLISHMENTS
成就
SEEM EFFORTLESS
看起来毫不费力
JUDGMENT
判断
Your actions must seem natural and executed with ease. All the toil and practice that go into them, and also all the clever tricks, must be concealed. When you act, act effortlessly, as if you could do much more. Avoid the temptation of revealing how hard you workit only raises questions. Teach no one your tricks or they will be used against you.
你的行为必须显得自然流畅，毫不费力。所有为此付出的努力和练习，以及所有巧妙的技巧，都必须隐藏起来。行动时，要表现得毫不费力，仿佛你能做到更多。切勿透露你付出了多少努力——这只会引来质疑。不要将你的技巧传授给任何人，否则它们会被用来对付你。
Date Masamune once sent for Tannyu to decorate a pair of gold screens seven feet high. The artist said he thought black-and-white sketches would suit them, and went home again after considering them carefully. The next morning he came early and made a large quantity of ink into which he dipped a horseshoe he had brought with him, and then proceeded to make impressions of this all over one of the screens. Then, with a large brush, he drew a number of lines across them. Meanwhile Masamune had come in to watch his work, and at this he could contain his irritation no longer, and muttering, “What a beastly mess!” he strode away to his own apartments. The retainers told Tannyu he was in a very bad temper indeed. “He shouldn't look on while I am at work, then, ” replied the painter, “he should wait till it is finished. ” Then he took up a smaller brush and dashed in touches here and there, and as he did so the prints of the horse-shoe turned into crabs, while the big broad strokes became rushes. He then turned to the other screen and splashed drops of ink all over it, and when he had added a few brushstrokes here and there they became a flight of
伊达政宗曾召来唐佑，为一对七尺高的金屏风作画。唐佑认为黑白素描比较合适，仔细考虑后便回家了。第二天清晨，他早早来到，调制了大量墨汁，将随身携带的马蹄铁蘸上墨汁，然后在其中一面屏风上印出各种图案。接着，他又用大毛笔在屏风上画了几笔。这时，政宗进来观看，见状大为恼火，嘟囔着“真是乱七八糟！”便大步走回了自己的寝宫。家臣们告诉唐佑，他当时脾气非常暴躁。 “那他不该在我作画的时候看，”画家答道，“他应该等到画完再看。”说着，他拿起一支小画笔，随意地在画板上点缀了几笔，马蹄铁的印记渐渐变成了螃蟹，而之前那些宽大的笔触则变成了芦苇。接着，他又转向另一块屏风，将墨滴泼洒其上，再添上几笔，墨迹便变成了飞舞的芦苇。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
The Japanese tea ceremony called Cha-no-yu (“Hot Water for Tea”) has origins in ancient times, but it reached its peak of refinement in the sixteenth century under its most renowned practitioner, Sen no Rikyu. Although not from a noble family, Rikyu rose to great power, becoming die preferred tea master of the Emperor Hideyoshi, and an important adviser on aesthetic and even political matters. For Rikyu, the secret of success consisted in appearing natural, concealing the effort behind one's work.
日本茶道，又称“茶之汤”（Cha-no-yu），起源于古代，但在十六世纪，在其最著名的传人千利休的带领下，达到了炉火纯青的境界。千利休虽非出身贵族，却凭借自身实力跻身权势显赫之列，成为丰臣秀吉天皇的御用茶道大师，并在美学乃至政治事务上都扮演着重要的顾问角色。对千利休而言，成功的秘诀在于表现得自然流畅，将背后的努力隐藏起来。
One day Rikyu and his son went to an acquaintance's house for a tea ceremony. On the way in, the son remarked that die lovely antique-looking gate at their host's house gave it an evocatively lonely appearance. “I don't think so,” replied his father, “it looks as though it had been brought from some mountain temple a long way off, and as if die labor required to import it must have cost a lot of money.” If the owner of the house had put mis much effort into one gate, it would show in his tea ceremonyand indeed Sen no Rikyu had to leave die ceremony early, unable to endure the affectation and effort it inadvertently revealed.
一天，利休和儿子去一位熟人家参加茶道。进门时，儿子注意到主人家那扇古色古香的大门，觉得它显得格外孤寂。“我不这么认为，”父亲答道，“它看起来像是从很远的山寺里搬来的，想必搬运它需要花费不少工夫。”如果主人在一扇门上倾注了这么多心血，那他的茶道也会有所体现——千利休果然因为无法忍受这扇门无意间流露出的矫揉造作，不得不提前离席。
On another evening, while having tea at a friend's house, Rikyu saw his host go outside, hold up a lantern in the darkness, cut a lemon off a tree, and bring it in. This charmed Rikyuthe host needed a relish for die dish he was serving, and had spontaneously gone outside to get one. But when the man offered die lemon with some Osaka rice cake, Rikyu realized that he had planned the cutting of the lemon all along, to go with this expensive delicacy. The gesture no longer seemed spontaneousit was a way for die host to prove his cleverness. He had accidentally revealed how hard he was trying. Having seen enough, Rikyu politely declined the cake, excused himself, and left.
又一个晚上，利休在朋友家喝茶时，看到主人走到外面，在黑暗中举起一盏灯笼，从树上摘下一个柠檬，然后带了进来。利休心头一暖，心想主人需要一种佐料来搭配他正在做的菜肴，于是临时起意去摘柠檬。但当主人把柠檬和大阪年糕一起端上来时，利休才意识到，原来主人早就计划好了要摘柠檬，好搭配这道昂贵的甜点。这不再是随意的举动，而是主人炫耀自己聪明才智的一种方式。他无意间暴露了自己的用心。利休见状，礼貌地婉拒了年糕，告辞离去。
Emperor Hideyoshi once planned to visit Rikyu for a tea ceremony. On the night before he was to come, snow began to fall. Thinking quickly, Rikyu laid round cushions that fit exacdy on each of die stepping-stones that led through the garden to his house. Just before dawn, he rose, saw that it had stopped snowing, and carefully removed the cushions. When Hideyoshi arrived, he marveled at the simple beauty of die sightthe per-fecdy round stepping stones, unencumbered by snowand noticed how it called no attention to die manner in which Rikyu had accomplished it, but only to die polite gesture itself.
丰臣秀吉曾计划拜访利休，参加茶道仪式。在他即将到来前夜，天降大雪。利休灵机一动，在通往他府邸的花园踏脚石上，每块踏脚石都铺上了大小合适的圆形坐垫。黎明前，他起身，见雪已停，便小心翼翼地移走了坐垫。秀吉抵达时，被眼前简洁的美景所震撼——完美的圆形踏脚石，没有被积雪遮挡——他注意到，利休的安排并不引人注目，而仅仅体现了一种礼貌的姿态。
After Sen no Rikyu died, his ideas had a profound influence on the practice of the tea ceremony. The Tokugawa shogun Yorinobu, son of die great Emperor Ieyasu, was a student of Rikyu's teachings. In his garden he had a stone lantern made by a famous master, and Lord Sakai Tadakatsu asked if he could come by one day to see it. Yorinobu replied diat he would be honored, and commanded his gardeners to put everything in order for the visit. These gardeners, unfamiliar with the precepts of Cha-no-yu, thought die stone lantern misshapen, its windows being too small for die present taste. They had a local workman enlarge the windows. A few days before Lord Sakai's visit, Yorinobu toured the garden. When he saw die al-
千利休去世后，他的思想对茶道实践产生了深远的影响。德川幕府将军赖信，即伟大的德川家康天皇之子，曾是千利休的学生。赖信的花园里有一座由名匠制作的石灯笼，酒井忠胜曾询问能否前来参观。赖信欣然应允，并吩咐园丁做好一切准备迎接酒井忠胜。这些园丁并不了解茶道的精髓，认为石灯笼造型怪异，窗户太小，不符合当时的审美。于是，他们请当地工匠将窗户扩大。酒井忠胜到访前几天，赖信巡视了花园。当他看到……
tered windows he exploded with rage, ready to impale on his sword the fool who had ruined the lantern, upsetting its natural grace and destroying the whole purpose of Lord Sakai's visit.
他怒不可遏地冲破窗户，准备用剑刺穿那个毁了灯笼的蠢货，破坏了灯笼的自然美感，毁掉了坂井大人此行的全部目的。
When Yorinobu calmed down, however, he remembered that he had originally bought two of the lanterns, and that the second was in his garden on the island of Kishu. At great expense, he hired a whale boat and the finest rowers he could find, ordering them to bring the lantern to him within two daysa difficult feat at best. But the sailors rowed day and night, and with the luck of a good wind they arrived just in time. To Yori-nobu's delight, this stone lantern was more magnificent than the first, for it had stood untouched for twenty years in a bamboo thicket, acquiring a brilliant antique appearance and a delicate covering of moss. When Lord Sakai arrived, later that same day, he was awed by the lantern, which was more magnificent than he had imaginedso graceful and at one with the elements. Fortunately he had no idea what time and effort it had cost Yorinobu to create this sublime effect.
然而，当赖信冷静下来后，他想起自己最初买了两个灯笼，第二个就放在纪州岛的自家花园里。他花费重金租了一艘捕鲸船，并雇佣了当时能找到的最优秀的划桨手，命令他们在两天之内把灯笼运过来——这在当时几乎是不可能完成的任务。但水手们日夜奋战，幸运的是，他们赶在顺风之际及时抵达。令赖信欣喜的是，这个石灯笼比第一个更加精美，因为它在竹林中静静伫立了二十年，散发出古朴典雅的气息，并覆盖着一层细腻的苔藓。当天晚些时候，当堺大人到来时，他也被这盏灯笼深深震撼，它比他想象的还要壮丽——如此优雅，与自然融为一体。幸运的是，他并不知道赖信为了打造这般美妙的景象付出了多少时间和心血。
Interpretation
解释
To Sen no Rikyu, the sudden appearance of something naturally, almost accidentally graceful was the height of beauty. This beauty came without warning and seemed effortless. Nature created such things by its own laws and processes, but men had to create their effects through labor and contrivance. And when they showed the effort of producing the effect, the effect was spoiled. The gate came from too far away, the cutting of the lemon looked contrived.
在千利休看来，自然而然、近乎偶然间流露出的优美之美，乃是极致之美。这种美不期而至，仿佛毫不费力。自然遵循自身的规律和进程创造了这些美，而人类却必须通过辛勤劳作和精心设计才能实现。一旦人类显露出创造美的过程，美便会大打折扣。大门仿佛来自遥远的地方，切柠檬的动作也显得矫揉造作。
You will often have to use tricks and ingenuity to create your effects the cushions in the snow, the men rowing all nightbut your audience must never suspect the work or the thinking that has gone into them. Nature does not reveal its tricks, and what imitates nature by appearing effortless approximates nature's power.
你常常需要运用技巧和巧思来营造效果——比如雪地里的垫子，或者整夜划船的人——但你的观众绝不能察觉到这些效果背后所付出的努力和思考。大自然不会轻易显露它的秘密，而模仿自然、看似毫不费力的表演，恰恰接近了自然的力量。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW II
遵守法律 II
The great escape artist Harry Houdini once advertised his act as “The Impossible Possible.” And indeed those who witnessed his dramatic escapes felt that what he did onstage contradicted commonsense ideas of human capacity.
伟大的逃脱大师哈里·胡迪尼曾将他的表演宣传为“不可能的可能”。事实上，那些亲眼目睹他惊心动魄的逃脱表演的人都觉得，他在舞台上的表现违背了人们对人类能力的常识性认知。
One evening in 1904, an audience of 4,000 Londoners filled a theater to watch Houdini accept a challenge: to escape from a pair of manacles billed as the strongest ever invented. They contained six sets of locks and nine tumblers in each cuff; a Birmingham maker had spent five years constructing them. Experts who examined them said they had never seen anything so intricate, and this intricacy was thought to make them impossible to escape.
1904年的一个晚上，四千名伦敦观众挤满了剧院，观看胡迪尼接受一项挑战：挣脱一副号称史上最坚固的手铐。这副手铐每只手铐内有六组锁和九个拨片；一位伯明翰的工匠耗时五年打造而成。经专家鉴定，他们从未见过如此精巧的手铐，而正是这种精巧的设计，使得挣脱几乎不可能。
The crowd watched the experts secure the manacles on Houdini's wrists. Then the escape artist entered a black cabinet on stage. The minutes
观众们注视着专家们给胡迪尼戴上手铐。随后，这位逃脱大师走进了舞台上的一个黑色柜子。
swallows over willow trees. When Masamune saw the finished work he was as overjoyed at the artist's skill as he had previously been annoyed at the apparent mess he was making of the screens.
燕子飞过柳树。当政宗看到完成的作品时，他对画家的技艺欣喜若狂，这与他之前对画家把屏风弄得一团糟感到恼火截然不同。
CHA-NO-YU!
茶之汤！
THE JAPANESE TEA
日本茶
CEREMONY
仪式
A. L. Sadler, 1962
A. L. Sadler，1962年
There was once a wrestling master who was versed in 360 feints and holds. He took a special liking to one of his pupils, to whom he taught 359 of them over a period of time. Somehow he never got around to the last trick. As months went by the young man became so proficient in the art that he bested everyone who dared to face him in the ring. He was so proud of his prowess that one day he boasted before the sultan that he could readily whip his master, were it not out of respect for his age and gratitude for his tutelage.
从前有一位摔跤大师，精通三百六十种假动作和擒拿技法。他特别偏爱自己的一个弟子，一段时间内一共传授了他三百五十九种技法。不知为何，他始终没能传授最后一个。几个月过去了，这个年轻人技艺日臻精湛，凡是敢于在擂台上挑战他的人，他都轻松取胜。他为自己的实力感到无比自豪，有一天，他竟在苏丹面前吹嘘说，若非出于对师父的尊敬和感激之情，他轻而易举就能打败师父。
The sultan became incensed at this irreverence and ordered an immediate match with the royal court in attendance. At the gong the youth barged forward with a lusty yell, only to be confronted with the unfamiliar 360th feint.
苏丹对这种不敬的行为勃然大怒，下令立即比武，所有朝臣都到场观战。锣声一响，那年轻人便大声叫喊着冲了上前，却不料遭遇了对方不熟悉的360度假动作。
The master seized his former pupil, lifted him high above his head, and flung him crashing to the ground. The sultan and the assembly let out a loud cheer. When the sultan asked the master how he was able to overcome such a strong opponent, the master confessed that he had reserved a secret technique for himself for just such a contingency. Then he related the lamentation of a master of archery, who taught everything he knew. “No one has learned archery from me,” the poor fellow complained, “who has not tried to use me as a butt in the end.”
师傅一把抓住他以前的徒弟，将他高高举过头顶，然后重重地摔在地上。苏丹和众人爆发出热烈的欢呼声。苏丹问师傅是如何战胜如此强大的对手的，师傅坦白说，他一直保留着一种秘技，就是为了应对这种情况。接着，他讲述了一位弓箭大师的哀叹：这位大师倾囊相授，却无一例外地将自己毕生所学倾囊相授。“没有一个从我这里学过箭的人，”这位可怜的家伙抱怨道，“最后没把我当成靶子。”
A STORY OF SAADI,
萨迪的故事
AS TOLD IN
正如《
THE CRAFT OF POWER,
力量的艺术
R.G. H. Siu, 1979
R.G. H. Siu，1979年
went by; the more time passed, the more certain it seemed that these manacles would be die first to defeat him. At one point he emerged from the cabinet, and asked diat die cuffs be temporarily removed so diat he could take off his coatit was hot inside. The challengers refused, suspecting his request was a trick to find out how the locks worked. Undeterred, and without using his hands, Houdini managed to lift die coat over his shoulders, turn it inside out, remove a penknife from his vest pocket widi his teeth, and, by moving his head, cut the coat off his arms. Freed from die coat, he stepped back into the cabinet, the audience roaring with approval at his grace and dexterity.
时间一分一秒地过去；时间越久，他越觉得这些镣铐会是他最先被制服的枷锁。有一次，他从柜子里出来，请求暂时解开手铐，好让他脱掉外套——里面太热了。挑战者们拒绝了，怀疑他的请求是想试探锁的原理。胡迪尼毫不气馁，不用手，就设法把外套披在肩上，翻过来，用牙齿从背心口袋里掏出一把小刀，然后转动头部，割断了袖子上的外套。脱下外套后，他走回柜子里，观众们为他的优雅和灵巧而欢呼雀跃。
Finally, having kept the audience waiting long enough, Houdini emerged from the cabinet a second time, now widi his hands free, die manacles raised high in triumph. To diis day no one knows how he managed me escape. Altfiough he had taken close to an hour to free himself, he had never looked concerned, had shown no sign of doubt. Indeed it seemed by die end diat he had drawn out die escape as a way to heighten die drama, to make the audience worryfor tiiere was no other sign diat die performance had been anydiing but easy. The complaint about die heat was equally part of die act. The spectators of diis and odier Houdini performances must have felt he was toying widi them: These manacles are nothing, he seemed to say, I could have freed myself a lot sooner, and from a lot worse.
最后，在让观众苦等许久之后，胡迪尼第二次从柜子里走了出来，这次他的双手已经挣脱束缚，手铐高高举起，仿佛在庆祝胜利。时至今日，仍然没有人知道他是如何逃脱的。尽管他花了将近一个小时才挣脱束缚，但他脸上却丝毫没有流露出担忧，也没有丝毫怀疑。事实上，到了最后，他似乎故意拖延逃脱的过程，以此来增强戏剧效果，让观众为他捏一把汗——因为除此之外，没有任何其他迹象表明这场表演并非易事。抱怨天气炎热也是表演的一部分。观看过胡迪尼这场以及其他表演的观众一定觉得他是在戏弄他们：这些手铐算什么，他似乎在说，我本来可以更早挣脱，而且摆脱更糟糕的束缚。
Over the years, Houdini escaped from die chained carcass of an embalmed “sea monster” (a half octopus, half whalelike beast diat had beached near Boston); he had himself sealed inside an enormous envelope from which he emerged widiout breaking die paper; he passed tiirough brick walls; he wriggled free from straitjackets while dangling high in die air; he leaped from bridges into icy waters, his hands manacled and his legs in chains; he had himself submerged in glass cases full of water, hands padlocked, while the audience watched in amazement as he worked himself free, struggling for close to an hour apparentiy without breadiing. Each time he seemed to court certain deadi yet survived with superhuman aplomb. Meanwhile, he said nothing about his mediods, gave no clues as to how he accomplished any of his trickshe left his audiences and critics speculating, his power and reputation enhanced by tiieir struggles with die inexplicable. Perhaps the most baffling trick of all was making a ten-tiiou-sand-pound elephant disappear before an audience's eyes, a feat he repeated on stage for over nineteen weeks. No one has ever really explained how he did diis, for in die auditorium where he performed the trick, there was simply nowhere for an elephant to hide.
多年来，胡迪尼曾多次令人叹为观止：他从一具被防腐处理的“海怪”（一种半章鱼半鲸鱼的生物，搁浅在波士顿附近）的铁链束缚中逃脱；他把自己密封在一个巨大的信封里，却毫发无损地走了出来；他穿过砖墙；他从高悬空中挣脱束缚衣；他双手被铐、双腿被铁链锁住，从桥上跃入冰冷的水中；他把自己浸入装满水的玻璃箱中，双手被锁住，观众们目瞪口呆地看着他挣扎近一个小时，似乎没有丝毫喘息之机。每一次，他都仿佛在与死神擦肩而过，却总能以超人的沉着冷静幸存下来。与此同时，他从未提及自己的秘密，也从未透露任何关于他如何完成这些魔术的线索——他让观众和评论家们百思不得其解，而他与这些无法解释的谜团的斗争，反而提升了他的影响力和声誉。或许最令人费解的魔术莫过于让一头十吨重的大象在观众眼前消失，他连续十九周在舞台上重复这一绝技。至今无人能解释他是如何做到的，因为在他表演魔术的礼堂里，根本没有大象可以藏身的地方。
The effortlessness of Houdini's escapes led some to drink he used occult forces, his superior psychic abilities giving him special control over his body. But a German escape artist named Kleppini claimed to know Houdini's secret: He simply used elaborate gadgets. Kleppini also claimed to have defeated Houdini in a handcuff challenge in Holland.
胡迪尼轻松自如的逃脱术让一些人认为他使用了神秘力量，超凡的超能力赋予了他控制身体的特殊能力。但一位名叫克莱皮尼的德国逃脱术表演者声称知道胡迪尼的秘密：他只是使用了精巧的装置。克莱皮尼还声称在荷兰的一次手铐挑战中击败了胡迪尼。
Houdini did not mind all kinds of speculation floating around about
胡迪尼并不在意围绕他的各种猜测。
his methods, but he would not tolerate an outright lie, and in 1902 he challenged Kleppini to a handcuff duel. Kleppini accepted. Through a spy, he found out the secret word to unlock a pair of French combination-lock cuffs that Houdini liked to use. His plan was to choose these cuffs to escape from onstage. This would definitively debunk Houdinihis “genius” simply lay in his use of mechanical gadgets.
他虽然识破了胡迪尼的伎俩，但却无法容忍彻头彻尾的谎言。1902年，他向克莱皮尼发起了手铐决斗的挑战。克莱皮尼接受了挑战。他通过一名眼线，打听到了胡迪尼常用的一副法式密码手铐的密码。他的计划是选择这副手铐在舞台上挣脱。这将彻底揭穿胡迪尼的“天才”不过在于他运用机械装置的说法。
On the night of the challenge, just as Kleppini had planned, Houdini offered him a choice of cuffs and he selected the ones with the combination lock. He was even able to disappear with them behind a screen to make a quick test, and reemerged seconds later, confident of victory.
挑战当晚，正如克莱皮尼所计划的那样，胡迪尼让他选择一副手铐，他选择了带密码锁的那一副。他甚至戴着手铐躲到屏风后面快速测试了一下，几秒钟后就重新出现，信心满满地认为自己必胜。
Acting as if he sensed fraud, Houdini refused to lock Kleppini in the cuffs. The two men argued and began to fight, even wrestling with each other onstage. After a few minutes of this, an apparently angry, frustrated Houdini gave up and locked Kleppini in the cuffs. For the next few minutes Kleppini strained to get free. Something was wrongminutes earlier he had opened the cuffs behind the screen; now the same code no longer worked. He sweated, racking his brains. Hours went by, the audience left, and finally an exhausted and humiliated Kleppini gave up and asked to be released.
胡迪尼装作察觉到克莱皮尼在骗他，拒绝给他戴上手铐。两人争吵起来，甚至在舞台上扭打起来。几分钟后，显然又生气又沮丧的胡迪尼终于放弃了，给克莱皮尼戴上了手铐。接下来的几分钟里，克莱皮尼拼命挣扎，试图挣脱。不对劲儿来了——几分钟前他还在幕后打开过手铐，现在同样的密码却失效了。他汗流浃背，绞尽脑汁。几个小时过去了，观众散去，最终，精疲力竭、羞愧难当的克莱皮尼放弃了抵抗，请求胡迪尼放了他。
The cuffs that Kleppini himself had opened behind the screen with die word “C-L-E-F-S” (French for “keys”) now clicked open only with the word “F-R-A-U-D. ”Kleppini never figured out how Houdini had accomplished this uncanny feat.
克莱皮尼本人在屏风后用“C-L-E-F-S”（法语“钥匙”）这个词打开的手铐，现在只能用“F-R-A-U-D”这个词才能打开。克莱皮尼始终没能弄明白胡迪尼是如何完成这项不可思议的壮举的。
Keep the extent of your abilities unknown. The wise man does not allow his knowledge and abilities to be sounded to the bottom, if he desires to be honored by all. He allows you to know them but not to comprehend them. No one must know the extent of his abilities, lest he be disappointed. No one ever has an opportunity of fathoming him entirely. For guesses and doubts about the extent of his talents arouse more veneration than accurate knowledge of them, be they ever so great.
让你的能力保持神秘。智者若想受人敬仰，便不会让自己的知识和能力被彻底探知。他允许你知晓，却不让你完全理解。任何人都不应知晓他能力的极限，以免失望。没有人有机会完全了解他。因为对他才能的猜测和怀疑，比对他才能的准确了解——无论他的才能多么卓越——更能激发人们的敬畏。
Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
Interpretation
解释
Although we do not know for certain how Houdini accomplished many of his most ingenious escapes, one thing is clear: It was not the occult, or any kind of magic, mat gave him his powers, but hard work and endless practice, all of which he carefully concealed from the world. Houdini never left anything to chanceday and night he studied the workings of locks, researched centuries-old sleight-of-hand tricks, pored over books on mechanics, whatever he could use. Every moment not spent researching he spent working his body, keeping himself exceptionally limber, and learning how to control his muscles and his breathing.
虽然我们无法确切知道胡迪尼是如何完成他那些最精妙绝伦的逃脱术的，但有一点是肯定的：赋予他超凡能力的并非神秘学或任何魔法，而是他孜孜不倦的刻苦训练，而这一切都被他小心翼翼地隐藏了起来。胡迪尼从不抱任何侥幸心理，他日夜钻研锁具的运作原理，研究流传数百年的魔术手法，研读机械学书籍，竭尽所能地钻研一切可以利用的知识。除了研究之外，他把所有时间都用来锻炼身体，保持超乎寻常的柔韧性，并学习如何控制肌肉和呼吸。
Early on in Houdini's career, an old Japanese performer whom he toured with taught him an ancient trick: how to swallow an ivory ball, fhen bring it back up. He practiced this endlessly with a small peeled potato tied to a stringup and down he would manipulate the potato wim his throat muscles, until they were strong enough to move it without the string. The organizers of the London handcuff challenge had searched Houdini's body thoroughly beforehand, but no one could check the inside of his throat, where he could have concealed small tools to help him escape. Even so, Kleppini was fundamentally wrong: It was not Houdini's tools but his practice, work, and research that made his escapes possible.
在胡迪尼职业生涯早期，一位与他一起巡演的日本老艺人教了他一个古老的魔术：吞下象牙球，然后再把它吐出来。他反复练习，用一根绳子系着一个削皮的小土豆，上下拨动喉咙肌肉，直到肌肉足够强壮，可以不用绳子就能控制土豆。伦敦手铐挑战赛的组织者事先对胡迪尼进行了彻底搜身，但没有人能检查他的喉咙内部，那里可能藏有帮助他逃脱的小工具。即便如此，克莱皮尼的观点从根本上是错误的：真正让胡迪尼的逃脱成为可能的，并非他的工具，而是他的练习、工作和研究。
Kleppini, in fact, was completely outwitted by Houdini, who set the whole thing up. He let his opponent learn the code to the French cuffs,
事实上，克莱皮尼完全被胡迪尼耍得团团转，这一切都是胡迪尼一手策划的。他让对手提前知道了法式袖扣的密码。
LAW 30
法律30
then baited him into choosing those cuffs onstage. Then, during the two men's tussle, the dexterous Houdini was able to change the code to “F-R-A-U-D.” He had spent weeks practicing this trick, but the audience saw none of the sweat and toil behind the scenes. Nor was Houdini ever nervous; he induced nervousness in others. (He deliberately dragged out the time it would take to escape, as a way of heightening the drama, and making the audience squirm.) His escapes from death, always graceful and easy, made him look like a superman.
然后，他诱使他当场选择那副手铐。接着，在两人扭打的过程中，身手敏捷的胡迪尼将密码改成了“F-R-A-U-D”。他为此练习了数周，但观众丝毫看不到幕后的汗水和艰辛。胡迪尼本人也从不紧张；他反而让别人感到紧张。（他故意拖延逃脱的时间，以此增强戏剧效果，让观众坐立不安。）他每次死里逃生都优雅轻松，让他看起来像个超人。
As a person of power, you must research and practice endlessly before appearing in public, onstage or anywhere else. Never expose the sweat and labor behind your poise. Some think such exposure will demonstrate their diligence and honesty, but it actually just makes them look weakeras if anyone who practiced and worked at it could do what they had done, or as if they weren't really up to the job. Keep your effort and your tricks to yourself and you seem to have the grace and ease of a god. One never sees the source of a god's power revealed; one only sees its effects.
作为拥有力量的人，在公开露面、登台亮相或其他任何场合之前，都必须进行大量的研究和练习。切勿将你优雅姿态背后的汗水和努力公之于众。有些人认为这种暴露能展现他们的勤奋和诚实，但实际上只会让他们显得软弱——仿佛任何刻苦练习的人都能做到他们所做的一切，或者让他们显得能力不足。将你的努力和技巧隐藏起来，你就能拥有神一般的优雅和从容。人们永远无法窥见神力的源泉，只能看到它所带来的效果。
A line [of poetry] will take us hours maybe;
一行诗可能要花我们几个小时；
Yet if it does not seem a moment's thought,
然而，即便这看起来并非一时兴起，
Our stitching and unstitching has been naught.
我们的缝合和拆线都毫无意义。
Adam's Curse, William Butler Yeats, 1865-1939
亚当的诅咒，威廉·巴特勒·叶芝，1865-1939
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Humanity's first notions of power came from primitive encounters with na-turethe flash of lightning in the sky, a sudden flood, the speed and ferocity of a wild animal. These forces required no thinking, no planningthey awed us by their sudden appearance, their gracefulness, and their power over life and death. And this remains the kind of power we have always wanted to imitate. Through science and technology we have re-created the speed and sublime power of nature, but something is missing: Our machines are noisy and jerky, they reveal their effort. Even the very best creations of technology cannot root out our admiration for things that move easily and effortlessly. The power of children to bend us to their will comes from a kind of seductive charm that we feel in the presence of a creature less reflective and more graceful than we are. We cannot return to such a state, but if we can create the appearance of this kind of ease, we elicit in others the kind of primitive awe that nature has always evoked in humankind.
人类最初对力量的认知源于与自然的原始接触——天空中划过的闪电、突如其来的洪水、野兽的速度与凶猛。这些力量无需思考，无需计划——它们以突如其来的出现、优雅的姿态以及掌控生死的力量令我们敬畏。而这正是我们一直渴望模仿的力量。通过科学技术，我们重现了自然的速度和崇高的力量，但总感觉缺少了些什么：我们的机器噪音大、运转不稳，它们暴露出自身的笨拙。即使是最杰出的科技产物，也无法消除我们对那些轻松自如、毫不费力的事物的向往。孩童能够让我们臣服于他们的意志，源于一种迷人的魅力，这种魅力在我们面对比我们更不善于思考、更优雅的生物时尤为明显。我们无法回到那种状态，但如果我们能够营造出这种轻松自在的假象，就能唤起他人心中那种自然一直以来在人类心中激起的原始敬畏之情。
One of the first European writers to expound on this principle came from that most unnatural of environments, the Renaissance court. In The Book of the Courtier, published in 1528, Baldassare Castiglione describes the highly elaborate and codified manners of the perfect court citizen. And yet, Castiglione explains, the courtier must execute these gestures with what he calls sprezzfltura, the capacity to make the difficult seem easy. He urges the courtier to "practice in all tilings a certain nonchalance which conceals all
最早阐述这一原则的欧洲作家之一，就出身于文艺复兴时期最不自然的环境——宫廷。在1528年出版的《廷臣论》中，巴尔达萨雷·卡斯蒂廖内描述了完美宫廷公民高度精细且规范化的礼仪。然而，卡斯蒂廖内解释说，廷臣必须以他所谓的“sprezzfltura”（意为“轻松自如”）来执行这些举止，即化繁为简的能力。他敦促廷臣“在所有场合都表现出一种漫不经心的态度，以掩盖一切”。
artistry and makes whatever one says or does seem uncontrived and effortless.“ We all admire the achievement of some unusual feat, but if it is accomplished naturally and gracefully, our admiration increases tenfold ”whereas ... to labor at what one is doing and ... to make bones over it, shows an extreme lack of grace and causes everything, whatever its worth, to be discounted."
这种艺术性使人言行举止显得自然流畅，毫不费力。“我们都钦佩某些非凡的成就，但如果完成得自然优雅，我们的钦佩之情会成倍增长。“而……费尽心思去做某件事，并且……还把它搞得一团糟，则显得极其缺乏优雅，使一切，无论其价值如何，都被人轻视。”
Much of the idea of sprezzatura came from the world of art. All the great Renaissance artists carefully kept their works under wraps. Only the finished masterpiece could be shown to the public. Michelangelo forbade even popes to view his work in process. A Renaissance artist was always careful to keep his studios shut to patrons and public alike, not out of fear of imitation, but because to see the making of the works would mar the magic of dieir effect, and their studied atmosphere of ease and natural beauty.
“sprezzatura”（不经意的优雅）的理念很大程度上源于艺术界。所有伟大的文艺复兴艺术家都小心翼翼地将自己的作品严加保密。只有完成的杰作才能向公众展示。米开朗基罗甚至禁止教皇观看他创作过程中的作品。文艺复兴时期的艺术家总是谨慎地将工作室对赞助人和公众关闭，这并非出于害怕被模仿，而是因为目睹作品的创作过程会破坏其效果的魔力，以及作品中精心营造的轻松自然之美。
The Renaissance painter Vasari, also the first great art critic, ridiculed the work of Paolo Uccello, who was obsessed with the laws of perspective. The effort Uccello spent on improving the appearance of perspective was too obvious in his workit made his paintings ugly and labored, overwhelmed by the effort of their effects. We have the same response when we watch performers who put too much effort into dieir act: Seeing them trying so hard breaks the illusion. It also makes us uncomfortable. Calm, graceful performers, on the odier hand, set us at ease, creating the illusion that they are not acting but being natural and themselves, even when everything they are doing involves labor and practice.
文艺复兴时期的画家瓦萨里，同时也是第一位伟大的艺术评论家，曾嘲讽保罗·乌切洛的作品，因为乌切洛痴迷于透视法则。乌切洛在提升透视效果上花费的精力在他的作品中显得过于刻意，反而使他的画作显得丑陋而做作，被其效果所掩盖。当我们观看表演者用力过猛时，也会有同样的感受：他们如此努力反而会破坏表演的幻觉，让我们感到不自在。相反，那些沉着优雅的表演者则能让我们感到放松，营造出一种他们并非在表演，而是自然流露、展现真我的错觉，即便他们的一切表演都凝聚着大量的努力和练习。
The idea of sprezzfltura is relevant to all forms of power, for power depends vitally on appearances and the illusions you create. Your public actions are like artworks: They must have visual appeal, must create anticipation, even entertain. When you reveal the inner workings of your creation, you become just one more mortal among others. What is understandable is not awe-inspiringwe tell ourselves we could do as well if we had the money and time. Avoid the temptation of showing how clever you areit is far more clever to conceal the mechanisms of your cleverness.
“伪装”的概念适用于所有形式的权力，因为权力至关重要地依赖于外表和你所营造的幻象。你的公开行为如同艺术品：它们必须具有视觉吸引力，必须引发期待，甚至要引人入胜。当你揭示作品的内在运作机制时，你便沦为芸芸众生中的一员。易于理解的事物并不令人惊叹——我们会告诉自己，如果我们有金钱和时间，我们也能做到。切勿炫耀你的聪明才智——隐藏你聪明的运作机制才是更明智的做法。
Talleyrand's application of this concept to his daily life greatly enhanced the aura of power that surrounded him. He never liked to work too hard, so he made others do the work for himdie spying, the research, the detailed analyses. With all this labor at his disposal, he himself never seemed to strain. When his spies revealed that a certain event was about to take place, he would talk in social conversation as if he sensed its imminence. The result was that people thought he was clairvoyant. His short pithy statements and witticisms always seemed to summarize a situation perfectly, but diey were based on much research and thought. To those in government, including Napoleon himself, Talleyrand gave the impression of immense poweran effect entirely dependent on the apparent ease with which he accomplished his feats.
塔列朗将这一理念运用到日常生活中，极大地增强了他周身的权力光环。他生性不喜劳作，总是让别人替他做间谍活动、调查研究、进行细致分析等等。有了这些人力物力，他自己似乎从不费力。当他的间谍透露某件事即将发生时，他会在社交场合侃侃而谈，仿佛早已预感到此事。结果，人们都认为他有预知未来的能力。他那些简短精辟的言论和妙语总是能完美地概括局势，但实际上却都基于大量的研究和思考。在包括拿破仑在内的政府官员眼中，塔列朗给人一种权力巨大的印象——这种印象完全源于他完成任务时所展现出的轻松自如。
There is another reason for concealing your shortcuts and tricks:
隐藏捷径和技巧还有另一个原因：
When you let this information out, you give people ideas they can use against you. You lose the advantages of keeping silent. We tend to want the world to know what we have donewe want our vanity gratified by having our hard work and cleverness applauded, and we may even want sympathy for the hours it has taken to reach our point of artistry. Learn to control this propensity to blab, for its effect is often the opposite of what you expected. Remember: The more mystery surrounds your actions, the more awesome your power seems. You appear to be die only one who can do what you doand the appearance of having an exclusive gift is immensely powerful. Finally, because you achieve your accomplishments with grace and ease, people believe that you could always do more if you tried harder. This elicits not only admiration but a touch of fear. Your powers are untappedno one can fathom their limits.
当你泄露这些信息时，就等于给了别人可以用来对付你的把柄。你失去了保持沉默的优势。我们往往渴望让全世界都知道我们的成就——我们渴望自己的努力和才智得到赞扬，从而满足虚荣心；我们甚至可能希望别人同情我们为了达到艺术成就所付出的无数心血。学会控制这种爱说闲话的倾向，因为它的效果往往与你的预期截然相反。记住：你的行为越神秘，你的力量就越显得强大。你似乎是唯一能做到你所做的事情的人——这种拥有独特天赋的假象具有强大的力量。最后，因为你的成就来得优雅从容，人们会相信，如果你更加努力，你还能做得更多。这不仅会让人钦佩，还会让人心生畏惧。你的力量尚未被完全开发——没有人能够洞悉你的极限。
Image: The Racehorse. From up close we would see the strain, the effort to control the horse, the labored, painful breathing. But from the distance where we sit and watch, it is all gracefulness, flying through the air. Keep others at a distance and they will only see the ease with which you move.
图片：赛马。近距离观察，我们会看到骑手竭力控制马匹，以及马匹艰难的呼吸。但从我们坐着观看的距离来看，一切都显得优雅，仿佛在空中飞翔。与他人保持距离，他们只会看到你动作的轻松自如。
Authority: For whatever action [nonchalance] accompanies, no matter how trivial it is, it not only reveals the skill of the person doing it but also very often causes it to be considered far greater than it really is. This is because it makes the onlookers believe that a man who performs well with so much facility must possess even greater skill than he does. (Baldassare Castiglione, 1478-1529)
权威：无论伴随而来的是何种行为（漫不经心），无论多么微不足道，它不仅展现了行为者的技巧，而且常常使人认为该行为远比实际更伟大。这是因为它让旁观者相信，一个如此轻松自如地完成任务的人，其技巧必定远超实际。（巴尔达萨雷·卡斯蒂廖内，1478-1529）
REVERSAL
逆转
The secrecy with which you surround your actions must seem lighthearted in spirit. A zeal to conceal your work creates an unpleasant, almost paranoiac impression: you are taking the game too seriously. Houdini was careful to make the concealment of his tricks seem a game, all part of the show. Never show your work until it is finished, but if you put too much effort into keeping it under wraps you will be like the painter Pontormo, who spent the last years of his life hiding his frescoes from the public eye and only succeeded in driving himself mad. Always keep your sense of humor about yourself.
你对自己行为的保密态度必须显得轻松随意。过分热衷于隐藏作品会给人一种不愉快的、近乎偏执的印象：你把事情看得太认真了。胡迪尼就巧妙地将隐藏魔术的过程包装成一场游戏，一切都是表演的一部分。作品完成之前绝不要公开，但如果你过于执着于保密，就会像画家蓬托尔莫一样，他晚年竭力将自己的壁画藏起来，最终却把自己逼疯了。永远保持你的幽默感。
There are also times when revealing die inner workings of your projects can prove worthwhile. It all depends on your audience's taste, and on
有时候，揭示项目内部运作机制也可能很有价值。这完全取决于受众的口味，以及……
the times in which you operate. P. T. Barnum recognized that his public wanted to feel involved in his shows, and that understanding his tricks delighted them, pardy, perhaps, because implicitly debunking people who kept their sources of power hidden from the masses appealed to America's democratic spirit. The public also appreciated the showman's humor and honesty. Barnum took this to the extreme of publicizing his own humbug-gery in his popular autobiography, written when his career was at its height.
你所处的时代。P·T·巴纳姆深知，他的观众渴望参与到他的表演中，并且乐于了解他的伎俩——或许是出于戏谑——因为揭露那些将权力来源隐藏起来的人，恰恰迎合了美国的民主精神。公众也欣赏这位表演家的幽默和坦诚。巴纳姆甚至将这一点发挥到了极致，在他事业巅峰时期撰写的畅销自传中，公开宣扬了自己的种种骗局。
As long as die partial disclosure of tricks and techniques is carefully planned, rather than the result of an uncontrollable need to blab, it is the ultimate in cleverness. It gives die audience the illusion of being superior and involved, even while much of what you do remains concealed from them.
只要这种对技巧和手法的逐步透露是经过精心策划的，而不是出于无法控制的泄露欲望，那就是最高明的策略。它能让观众产生一种高人一等、参与其中的错觉，即使你所做的很多事情对他们来说仍然是秘密。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 31
第31条
CONTROL THE OPTIONS:
控制选项：
GET OTHERS TO PLAY WITH
让其他人一起玩
THE CARDS YOU DEAL
你发的牌
JUDGMENT
判断
The best deceptions are the ones that seem to give the other person a choice: Your victims feel they are in control, but are actually your puppets. Give people options that come out in your favor whichever one they choose. Force them to make choices between the lesser of two evils, both of which serve your purpose. Put them on the horns of a dilemma: They are gored wherever they turn.
最高明的欺骗是那些看似给对方选择的：你的受害者以为自己掌控一切，实际上却成了你的傀儡。给他们一些无论他们选择哪个都对你有利的选项。迫使他们在两害相权取其轻的选择中做出抉择，而这两个选择都符合你的目的。让他们陷入两难境地：无论他们往哪个方向走，都难逃被伤害的命运。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
From early in his reign, Ivan IV, later known as Ivan the Terrible, had to confront an unpleasant reality: The country desperately needed reform, but he lacked the power to push it through. The greatest limit to his authority came from the boyars, the Russian princely class that dominated the country and terrorized the peasantry.
伊凡四世，即后来的伊凡雷帝，在其统治初期就不得不面对一个棘手的现实：国家亟需改革，但他却无力推行。制约他权威的最大因素来自贵族阶层，这个统治国家、恐吓农民的俄罗斯王公阶级。
In 1553, at the age of twenty-three, Ivan fell ill. Lying in bed, nearing death, he asked the boyars to swear allegiance to his son as the new czar. Some hesitated, some even refused. Then and there Ivan saw he had no power over the boyars. He recovered from his illness, but he never forgot the lesson: The boyars were out to destroy him. And indeed in the years to come, many of the most powerful of them defected to Russia's main enemies, Poland and Lithuania, where they plotted their return and the overthrow of the czar. Even one of Ivan's closest friends, Prince Andrey Kurbski, suddenly turned against him, defecting to Lithuania in 1564, and becoming the strongest of Ivan's enemies.
1553年，23岁的伊凡四世病倒了。卧病在床，奄奄一息之际，他要求贵族们宣誓效忠他的儿子，拥立他为新沙皇。一些贵族犹豫不决，甚至有人拒绝。伊凡四世这才意识到，他对贵族们毫无掌控力。他虽然康复了，但始终铭记于心：贵族们一心想要除掉他。果然，在接下来的几年里，许多权势显赫的贵族叛逃到俄罗斯的主要敌人——波兰和立陶宛，在那里密谋返回俄罗斯，推翻沙皇。就连伊凡四世最亲密的朋友之一，安德烈·库尔布斯基亲王，也突然与他反目，于1564年叛逃到立陶宛，成为伊凡四世最强大的敌人。
When Kurbski began raising troops for an invasion, the royal dynasty seemed suddenly more precarious than ever. With emigre nobles fomenting invasion from the west, Tartars bearing down from the east, and the boyars stirring up trouble within the country, Russia's vast size made it a nightmare to defend. In whatever direction Ivan struck, he would leave himself vulnerable on the other side. Only if he had absolute power could he deal with this many-headed Hydra. And he had no such power.
当库尔布斯基开始征兵备战时，皇室王朝的处境似乎比以往任何时候都更加岌岌可危。流亡贵族从西部煽动入侵，鞑靼人从东部步步逼近，而贵族们也在国内挑起事端，俄罗斯幅员辽阔，防御难度极大。无论伊凡向哪个方向进攻，他都会在另一侧暴露出脆弱的弱点。只有拥有绝对的权力，他才能对付这头多头蛇。而他却没有这样的权力。
Ivan brooded until the morning of December 3, 1564, when the citizens of Moscow awoke to a strange sight. Hundreds of sleds filled the square before the Kremlin, loaded with the czar's treasures and with provisions for the entire court. They watched in disbelief as the czar and his court boarded the sleds and left town. Without explaining why, he established himself in a village south of Moscow. For an entire month a kind of terror gripped the capital, for the Muscovites feared that Ivan had abandoned them to the bloodthirsty boyars. Shops closed up and riotous mobs gathered daily. Finally, on January 3 of 1565, a letter arrived from the czar, explaining that he could no longer bear the boyars' betrayals and had decided to abdicate once and for all.
伊凡一直忧心忡忡，直到1564年12月3日清晨，莫斯科市民醒来时看到了一幕奇景。数百辆雪橇停满了克里姆林宫前的广场，上面满载着沙皇的财宝和整个宫廷所需的物资。他们难以置信地看着沙皇和他的朝臣们登上雪橇，离开了这座城市。他没有解释原因，就搬到了莫斯科南部的一个村庄。整整一个月，首都笼罩在一片恐慌之中，因为莫斯科人担心伊凡已经抛弃了他们，落入了嗜血成性的贵族手中。商店纷纷关门，暴民每天都在聚集。最终，在1565年1月3日，沙皇的一封信送到了莫斯科，信中解释说，他再也无法忍受贵族们的背叛，决定彻底退位。
