Read aloud in public, the letter had a startling effect: Merchants and commoners blamed the boyars for Ivan's decision, and took to the streets, terrifying the nobility with their fury. Soon a group of delegates representing the church, the princes, and the people made the journey to Ivan's village, and begged the czar, in the name of the holy land of Russia, to return to the throne. Ivan listened but would not change his mind. After days of hearing their pleas, however, he offered his subjects a choice: Either they grant him absolute powers to govern as he pleased, with no interference from the boyars, or they find a new leader.
这封信在公众面前朗读后，产生了惊人的效果：商人和平民百姓将伊凡的决定归咎于贵族，他们走上街头，愤怒的情绪令贵族们胆战心惊。不久，一群代表教会、王公和民众的使者前往伊凡的村庄，以俄罗斯圣地的名义恳求沙皇重返王位。伊凡听取了他们的请求，但并未改变主意。然而，在听取了数日的恳求后，他向臣民们提出了一个选择：要么赋予他绝对的权力，让他随心所欲地统治，不受贵族的干涉；要么他们另立一位新的统治者。
Faced with a choice between civil war and the acceptance of despotic power, almost every sector of Russian society “opted” for a strong czar, calling for Ivan's return to Moscow and the restoration of law and order. In
面对内战和接受专制统治之间的选择，俄罗斯社会几乎所有阶层都“选择”了一位强人沙皇，呼吁伊凡四世返回莫斯科，恢复法律和秩序。
The German Chancellor Bismarck, enraged at the constant criticisms from Rudolf Virchow (the German pathologist and liberal politician), had his seconds call upon the scientist to challenge him to a duel. “As the challenged party, I have the choice of weapons, ” said Virchow, “and I choose these. ” He held aloft two large and apparently identical sausages. “One of these,” he went on, “is infected with deadly germs; the other is perfectly sound. Let His Excellency decide which one he wishes to eat, and I will eat the other.” A Imost immediately the message came back that the chancellor had decided to cancel the duel.
德国首相俾斯麦对鲁道夫·维尔肖（德国病理学家兼自由派政治家）的不断批评感到恼火，便命其助手召见这位科学家向他发起决斗挑战。“作为被挑战者，我可以选择武器，”维尔肖说道，“我选择这些。”他高举起两根又大又一模一样的香肠。“其中一根，”他继续说道，“感染了致命细菌；另一根则完全健康。阁下可以决定吃哪一根，而我将吃掉另一根。”几乎立刻，消息传来，首相决定取消决斗。
the little, brown book of anecdotes, Clifton Fadiman, hd., 1985
《小棕皮轶事集》，克利夫顿·法迪曼著，1985年出版
Once upon a time there was a king of Armenia, who, being of a curious turn of mind and in need of some new diversion, sent his heralds throughout the land to make the following proclamation: “Hear this! Whatever man among you can prove himself the most outrageous liar in Armenia shall receive an apple made of pure gold from the hands of His Majesty the King!” People began to swarm to the palace from every town and hamlet in the country, people of all ranks and conditions, princes, merchants, farmers, priests, rich and poor, tall and short, fat and thin. There was no lack of liars in the land, and each one told his tale to the king. A ruler, however, has heard practically every sort of lie, and none of those now told him convinced the king that he had listened to the best of them. The king was beginning to grow tired of his new sport and was thinking of calling the whole contest off without declaring a winner, when there appeared before him a poor, ragged man, carrying a large earthenware pitcher under his arm. “What can I do for you” asked His Majesty. “Sire!” said the poor man, slightly bewil-
从前，亚美尼亚有一位国王，他性情古怪，又想找点乐子，便派使者走遍全国，颁布如下公告：“听好了！你们当中谁能证明自己是亚美尼亚最无耻的骗子，就能从国王陛下手中得到一个纯金打造的苹果！”于是，全国各地的城镇乡村都涌向王宫，各阶层、各阶层的人，王子、商人、农民、祭司，富人、穷人、高矮胖瘦，都来了。这片土地上不乏骗子，每个人都向国王讲述了自己的故事。然而，一位统治者几乎听过各种各样的谎言，如今这些谎言，没有一个能让国王相信自己听到了最精彩的。国王开始对这项新游戏感到厌倦，正打算取消比赛，不宣布胜负。这时，一个衣衫褴褛的穷苦男子出现在他面前，腋下夹着一个大陶罐。“我能为你做些什么？”国王陛下问道。“陛下！”穷苦男子略带困惑地说道。
February, with much celebration, Ivan returned to Moscow. The Russians could no longer complain if he behaved dictatoriallythey had given him this power themselves.
二月，伊凡在一片欢腾中返回莫斯科。俄罗斯人再也不能抱怨他的独裁行为了——因为正是他们自己赋予了他这种权力。
Interpretation
解释
Ivan the Terrible faced a terrible dilemma: To give in to die boyars would lead to certain destruction, but civil war would bring a different kind of ruin. Even if Ivan came out of such a war on top, die country would be devastated and its divisions would be stronger dian ever. His weapon of choice in the past had been to make a bold, offensive move. Now, however, that kind of move would turn against himthe more boldly he confronted his enemies, die worse die reactions he would spark.
伊凡雷帝面临着一个可怕的困境：向贵族屈服必然导致灭亡，但内战则会带来另一种毁灭。即便伊凡最终赢得这场战争，国家也将满目疮痍，分裂也将前所未有地加剧。他过去惯用的手段是采取大胆的进攻。然而，如今这种策略却会适得其反——他越是大胆地对抗敌人，就越会引发更严重的后果。
The main weakness of a show of force is that it stirs up resentment and eventually leads to a response that eats at your audiority Ivan, immensely creative in the use of power, saw clearly that die only padi to die kind of victory he wanted was a false wididrawal. He would not force the country over to his position, he would give it “options”: eidier his abdication, and certain anarchy, or his accession to absolute power. To back up his move, he made it clear diat he preferred to abdicate: “Call my bluff,” he said, “and watch what happens.” No one called his bluff. By withdrawing for just a month, he showed the country a glimpse of die nightmares that would follow his abdicationTartar invasions, civil war, ruin. (All of these did eventually come to pass after Ivan's deadi, in the infamous “Time of die Troubles.”)
武力展示的主要弱点在于它会激起怨恨，最终导致令人痛苦的反噬。伊凡四世在运用权力方面极富创造力，他清楚地认识到，他想要的唯一胜利方式就是虚张声势的退却。他不会强迫国家接受他的立场，而是会给国家提供“选择”：要么接受他的退位，随之而来的是无政府状态；要么接受他独揽大权。为了支持他的策略，他明确表示自己更倾向于退位：“来试试我的虚张声势吧，”他说，“看看会发生什么。”没有人敢于挑战他的底线。仅仅一个月的退却，就让国家窥见了他退位后将要面临的噩梦：鞑靼人的入侵、内战、国家衰败。（所有这些最终都在伊凡四世退位后，在臭名昭著的“动乱时期”一一应验。）
Withdrawal and disappearance are classic ways of controlling the options. You give people a sense of how things will fall apart without you, and you offer diem a “choice”: I stay away and you suffer die consequences, or I return under circumstances that I dictate. In this mediod of controlling people's options, they choose the option that gives you power because die alternative is just too unpleasant. You force their hand, but indirecdy: They seem to have a choice. Whenever people feel tiiey have a choice, they walk into your trap diat much more easily.
退缩和消失是控制他人选择的经典手段。你让人们感受到没有你一切都会崩溃，并给他们一个“选择”：要么我离开，你们承担后果；要么我回来，但条件由我来定。在这种控制他人选择的方式下，他们会选择让你掌控局面的选项，因为其他选择实在太难受了。你强迫他们做出选择，但却是间接的：他们似乎有选择权。一旦人们觉得自己有选择权，就更容易落入你的陷阱。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW II
遵守法律 II
As a seventeenth-century French courtesan, Ninon de Lenclos found diat her life had certain pleasures. Her lovers came from royalty and aristocracy, and diey paid her well, entertained her witii tiieir wit and intellect, satisfied her radier demanding sensual needs, and treated her almost as an equal. Such a life was infinitely preferable to marriage. In 1643, however, Ninon's motiier died suddenly, leaving her, at the age of twenty-three, totally alone in the worldno family, no dowry, notiiing to fall back upon. A kind of panic overtook her and she entered a convent, turning her back on her illustrious lovers. A year later she left the convent and moved to Lyons. When she finally reappeared in Paris, in 1648, lovers and suitors flocked to her door in greater numbers tiian ever before, for she was die wittiest and
作为十七世纪法国的交际花，尼农·德·朗克洛（Ninon de Lenclos）的生活充满乐趣。她的情人来自皇室和贵族，他们慷慨地支付她丰厚的报酬，用他们的智慧和才华逗她开心，满足她极其挑剔的感官需求，并且几乎把她当作平等的人对待。这样的生活远胜于婚姻。然而，1643年，尼农的丈夫突然去世，留下年仅23岁的她孤身一人——没有家人，没有嫁妆，没有任何依靠。一种恐慌攫住了她，她进入了修道院，与那些显赫的情人断绝了关系。一年后，她离开了修道院，搬到了里昂。当她最终于1648年重返巴黎时，前来追求她的情人和追求者比以往任何时候都多，因为她是最机智、最有魅力的。
most spirited courtesan of the time and her presence had been greatly missed.
她是当时最风情万种的交际花，她的离去令人无比惋惜。
Ninon's followers quickly discovered, however, that she had changed her old way of doing things, and had set up a new system of options. The dukes, seigneurs, and princes who wanted to pay for her services could continue to do so, but they were no longer in controlshe would sleep with them when she wanted, according to her whim. All their money bought them was a possibility. If it was her pleasure to sleep with them only once a month, so be it.
然而，尼农的追随者很快发现，她改变了以往的行事方式，建立了一套新的体系。那些愿意为她付费的公爵、领主和王子们可以继续这样做，但他们不再能掌控她——她想什么时候和他们上床就什么时候和他们上床，完全取决于她的心情。他们花的钱换来的只是这种可能性。如果她只想一个月和他们上床一次，那就随她便吧。
Those who did not want to be what Ninon called a payeur could join the large and growing group of men she called her martyrs men who visited her apartment principally for her friendship, her biting wit, her lute-playing, and the company of the most vibrant minds of the period, including Moliere, La Rochefoucauld, and Saint-Evremond. The martyrs, too, however, entertained a possibility: She would regularly select from them a favori, a man who would become her lover without having to pay, and to whom she would abandon herself completely for as long as she so desireda week, a few months, rarely longer. A payeur could not become a favori, but a martyr had no guarantee of becoming one, and indeed could remain disappointed for an entire lifetime. The poet Charleval, for example, never enjoyed Ninon's favors, but never stopped coming to visithe did not want to do without her company.
那些不愿成为尼农所谓的“付费者”的人，可以加入她称之为“殉道者”的庞大且日益壮大的男性群体。这些男性拜访她的公寓，主要是为了获得她的友谊、她辛辣的幽默、她的鲁特琴演奏，以及与当时最活跃的思想家们——包括莫里哀、拉罗什福科和圣埃弗雷蒙——的交往。然而，“殉道者”们也怀有一种希望：她会定期从他们当中挑选一位“宠儿”，一位无需付费即可成为她情人的男人，她会完全委身于他，时间长短由她决定——一周、几个月，很少会更久。付费者无法成为宠儿，而“殉道者”也无法保证一定能成为宠儿，甚至可能终其一生都失望而归。例如，诗人夏尔瓦尔从未得到过尼农的宠爱，但他从未停止过拜访——他不想失去她的陪伴。
As word of this system reached polite French society, Ninon became the object of intense hostility. Her reversal of the position of the courtesan scandalized the queen mother and her court. Much to their horror, however, it did not discourage her male suitorsindeed it only increased their numbers and intensified their desire. It became an honor to be a payeur, helping Ninon to maintain her lifestyle and her glittering salon, accompanying her sometimes to die theater, and sleeping with her when she chose. Even more distinguished were the martyrs, enjoying her company without paying for it and maintaining the hope, however remote, of some day becoming her favori. That possibility spurred on many a young nobleman, as word spread that none among the courtesans could surpass Ninon in the art of love. And so the married and the single, the old and the young, entered her web and chose one of the two options presented to them, both of which amply satisfied her.
当这套制度传遍法国上流社会后，尼农成了众矢之的。她颠覆了交际花的地位，令王太后和她的朝臣们震惊不已。然而，令他们惊恐的是，这非但没有吓退追求者，反而使他们更加趋之若鹜，欲望也更加强烈。成为尼农的“嫖客”成了一种荣耀，他们帮助尼农维持奢华的生活方式和她那灯红酒绿的沙龙，有时陪她去看戏，并在她愿意的时候与她同寝。而那些“殉道者”则更为尊贵，他们不花钱就能享受她的陪伴，并怀着渺茫的希望，盼望有朝一日能成为她的宠儿。这种可能性激励着许多年轻的贵族，因为传言四起，说交际花中无人能在情爱方面胜过尼农。于是，已婚的和单身的，年长的和年轻的，都落入了她的圈套，在摆在他们面前的两种选择中做出抉择，而这两种选择都令她十分满意。

armenian folk-tales and fables, retold by Charles Downing, 1993
亚美尼亚民间故事和寓言，查尔斯·唐宁改编，1993年
Interpretation
解释
The life of the courtesan entailed the possibility of a power that was denied a married woman, but it also had obvious perils. The man who paid for the courtesan's services in essence owned her, determining when he could possess her and when, later on, he would abandon her. As she grew older, her options narrowed, as fewer men chose her. To avoid a life of poverty she had to amass her fortune while she was young. The courtesan's legendary greed, then, reflected a practical necessity, yet also lessened her allure, since the illusion of being desired is important to men, who are often alien-
妓女的生活蕴含着已婚妇女无法企及的权力，但也暗藏着显而易见的危险。嫖客的嫖娼实际上就等于拥有了她，决定着何时占有她，何时又会抛弃她。随着年龄的增长，她的选择越来越少，因为选择她的男人也越来越少。为了避免贫困，她必须在年轻时就积累财富。因此，妓女传说中的贪婪既反映了一种现实的需要，也削弱了她的魅力，因为被渴望的幻觉对男人来说至关重要，而男人往往对她感到陌生。
./. P. Morgan Sr. once told a jeweler of his acquaintance that he was interested in buying a pearl scarf-pin. Just a few weeks later, the jeweler happened upon a magnificent pearl. He had it mounted in an appropriate setting and sent it to Morgan, together with a bill for $5,000. The following day the package was returned. Morgan's accompanying note read: “/ like the pin, but I don't like the price. If you will accept the enclosed check for $4,000, please send back the box with the seal unbroken. ” The enraged jeweler refused the check and dismissed the messenger in disgust. He opened up the box to reclaim the unwanted pin, only to find that it had been removed. In its place was a check for $5,000.
老菲利普·摩根曾告诉一位相识的珠宝商，他想买一枚珍珠领巾别针。几周后，这位珠宝商偶然发现了一颗绝美的珍珠。他将珍珠镶嵌在合适的底座上，连同一张5000美元的账单一起寄给了摩根。第二天，包裹被退回了。摩根附上的纸条写道：“我喜欢这枚别针，但价格太贵了。如果您愿意接受随信附上的4000美元支票，请将包装完好无损的盒子寄回。” 珠宝商勃然大怒，拒收了支票，并愤然打发了送信人。他打开盒子想取回那枚不想要的别针，却发现别针已被拿走，取而代之的是一张5000美元的支票。
the little, brown
那只小小的棕色
book of anhcdoths,
安赫多斯之书，
Clifton Fadiman, h,d.,
克利夫顿·法迪曼，h,d.，
ated if their partner is too interested in their money. As the courtesan aged, then, she faced a most difficult fate.
如果伴侣过于看重她们的钱财，她们就会感到不满。随着年龄增长，妓女的命运也变得异常艰难。
Ninon de Lenclos had a horror of any kind of dependence. She early on tasted a kind of equality with her lovers, and she would not settle into a system that left her such distasteful options. Strangely enough, the system she devised in its place seemed to satisfy her suitors as much as it did her. The payeurs may have had to pay, but the fact that Ninon would only sleep with them when she wanted to gave them a thrill unavailable with every other courtesan: She was yielding out of her own desire. The martyrs' avoidance of the taint of having to pay gave them a sense of superiority; as members of Ninon's fraternity of admirers, they also might some day experience the ultimate pleasure of being her favori. Finally, Ninon did not force her suitors into either category. They could “choose” which side they preferreda freedom that left them a vestige of masculine pride.
尼侬·德·朗克洛对任何形式的依赖都深恶痛绝。她很早就尝到了与情人们平等相处的滋味，因此她不愿接受那种让她感到如此厌恶的制度。奇怪的是，她另辟蹊径设计的这套制度似乎既满足了她的追求者，也满足了她自己。虽然“付费者”们不得不付钱，但尼侬只在她想和他们上床时才与他们同寝，这让他们体验到其他任何妓女都无法提供的刺激：她是出于自己的欲望而屈服。而“殉道者”们则因为不必支付费用而获得了一种优越感；作为尼侬仰慕者兄弟会的成员，他们或许有一天也能体验到成为她宠儿的极致欢愉。最后，尼侬并没有强迫她的追求者们归入任何一类。他们可以“选择”自己更倾向于哪一方——这种自由让他们保留了一丝男性的尊严。
Such is the power of giving people a choice, or rather the illusion of one, for they are playing with cards you have dealt them. Where the alternatives set up by Ivan the Terrible involved a certain riskone option would have led to his losing his powerNinon created a situation in which every option redounded to her favor. From the payeurs she received the money she needed to run her salon. And from the martyrs she gained the ultimate in power: She could surround herself with a bevy of admirers, a harem from which to choose her lovers.
这就是赋予人们选择权的力量，或者更确切地说，是赋予他们选择的假象，因为他们只能玩你发给他们的牌。伊凡雷帝所设下的种种选择都蕴含着一定的风险——任何一个选择都可能导致他失去权力。而尼农则创造了一种局面，在这种局面下，每一个选择都对她有利。她从那些受贿者那里获得了维持沙龙运营所需的资金。而从那些殉道者那里，她获得了至高无上的权力：她可以拥有众多仰慕者，一个可以随意挑选情人的后宫。
The system, though, depended on one critical factor: the possibility, however remote, that a martyr could become a favori. The illusion that riches, glory, or sensual satisfaction may someday fall into your victim's lap is an irresistible carrot to include in your list of choices. That hope, however slim, will make men accept die most ridiculous situations, because it leaves them the all-important option of a dream. The illusion of choice, married to the possibility of future good fortune, will lure the most stubborn sucker into your glittering web.
然而，这套体系依赖于一个关键因素：殉道者有可能成为宠儿，哪怕这种可能性微乎其微。财富、荣耀或感官享受或许有朝一日会落入受害者手中，这种错觉如同胡萝卜般诱人，不容错过。即使希望渺茫，也能让人接受最荒谬的处境，因为它为他们留下了至关重要的梦想选择。选择的幻觉，加上未来好运的可能，足以将最顽固的傻瓜也诱入你精心编织的陷阱。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Words like “freedom,” “options,” and “choice” evoke a power of possibility far beyond the reality of the benefits they entail. When examined closely, the choices we havein the marketplace, in elections, in our jobstend to have noticeable limitations: They are often a matter of a choice simply between A and B, with the rest of the alphabet out of the picture. Yet as long as the faintest mirage of choice flickers on, we rarely focus on the missing options. We “choose” to believe that the game is fair, and that we have our freedom. We prefer not to think too much about the depth of our liberty to choose.
“自由”、“选择”之类的词语，唤起了一种远超其实际益处的无限可能。仔细审视，我们在市场、选举和工作中拥有的选择往往存在明显的局限性：它们通常只是在A和B之间做选择，其他选项都被排除在外。然而，只要选择的幻象还若存在，我们就很少关注那些缺失的选项。我们“选择”相信游戏是公平的，相信我们拥有自由。我们宁愿不去深入思考我们选择的自由究竟有多深。
This unwillingness to probe the smallness of our choices stems from the fact that too much freedom creates a kind of anxiety. The phrase “unlimited options” sounds infinitely promising, but unlimited options would actually paralyze us and cloud our ability to choose. Our limited range of choices comforts us.
我们不愿探究自身选择的局限性，源于过度的自由会引发焦虑。“无限的选择”听起来充满无限诱惑，但实际上，无限的选择会让我们束手无策，蒙蔽我们的选择能力。有限的选择反而让我们感到安心。
This supplies the clever and cunning with enormous opportunities for deception. For people who are choosing between alternatives find it hard to believe they are being manipulated or deceived; they cannot see that you are allowing them a small amount of free will in exchange for a much more powerful imposition of your own will. Setting up a narrow range of choices, then, should always be a part of your deceptions. There is a saying: If you can get the bird to walk into the cage on its own, it will sing that much more prettily.
这为那些聪明狡猾的人提供了巨大的欺骗机会。因为在众多选择中做出抉择的人很难相信自己正被操纵或欺骗；他们看不出你给予他们少量的自由意志，却换取了你更强大的意志强加于他们。因此，设定狭窄的选择范围应该始终是你欺骗手段的一部分。俗话说：如果你能让鸟儿自己走进笼子，它就会唱得更加动听。
The following are among the most common forms of “controlling the options”:
以下是一些最常见的“控制选择权”的方式：
Color the Choices. This was a favored technique of Henry Kissinger. As President Richard Nixon's secretary of state, Kissinger considered himself better informed than his boss, and believed that in most situations he could make the best decision on his own. But if he tried to determine policy, he would offend or perhaps enrage a notoriously insecure man. So Kissinger would propose three or four choices of action for each situation, and would present them in such a way that the one he preferred always seemed the best solution compared to the others. Time after time, Nixon fell for the bait, never suspecting that he was moving where Kissinger pushed him. This is an excellent device to use on the insecure master.
为选择着色。这是亨利·基辛格惯用的伎俩。作为理查德·尼克松总统的国务卿，基辛格自认为比他的老板更了解情况，并且相信在大多数情况下，他自己就能做出最佳决策。但如果他试图左右政策，就会得罪甚至激怒这位出了名缺乏安全感的人。因此，基辛格会针对每种情况提出三到四个行动方案，并以一种巧妙的方式呈现，使他偏爱的方案看起来总是比其他方案更优。尼克松一次又一次地落入圈套，从未怀疑自己正被基辛格牵着鼻子走。这对于缺乏安全感的上司来说，无疑是一招妙用。
Force the Resister. One of the main problems faced by Dr. Milton H. Er-ickson, a pioneer of hypnosis therapy in the 1950s, was the relapse. His patients might seem to be recovering rapidly, but their apparent susceptibility to the therapy masked a deep resistance: They would soon relapse into old habits, blame the doctor, and stop coming to see him. To avoid this, Erick-son began ordering some patients to have a relapse, to make themselves feel as bad as when they first came into go back to square one. Faced with this option, the patients would usually “choose” to avoid the relapse which, of course, was what Erickson really wanted.
强迫抗拒者。20世纪50年代催眠疗法的先驱米尔顿·H·埃里克森博士面临的主要问题之一是复发。他的病人表面上似乎康复迅速，但他们对疗法的明显接受度掩盖了内心深处的抗拒：他们很快就会重蹈覆辙，责怪医生，并停止就诊。为了避免这种情况，埃里克森开始要求一些病人经历一次复发，让他们感觉像刚来时一样糟糕，一切从头开始。面对这种选择，病人通常会“选择”避免复发，而这当然正是埃里克森真正想要的。
This is a good technique to use on children and other willful people who enjoy doing the opposite of what you ask them to: Push them to “choose” what you want them to do by appearing to advocate the opposite.
对于孩子和其他喜欢反其道而行之的人来说，这是一个很好的技巧：通过表面上提倡相反的做法，来迫使他们“选择”你想要他们做的事情。
Alter the Playing Field. In the 1860s, John D. Rockefeller set out to create an oil monopoly. If he tried to buy up the smaller oil companies they would figure out what he was doing and fight back. Instead, he began se-credy buying up the railway companies that transported the oil. When he then attempted to take over a particular company, and met with resistance, he reminded diem of their dependence on the rails. Refusing them shipping, or simply raising their fees, could ruin their business. Rockefeller altered the playing field so that die only options the small oil producers had were die ones he gave diem.
改变游戏规则。19世纪60年代，约翰·D·洛克菲勒着手建立石油垄断。如果他试图收购小型石油公司，这些公司会识破他的意图并进行反抗。于是，他开始秘密收购运输石油的铁路公司。当他试图收购某家公司并遇到阻力时，他会提醒他们铁路运输的依赖性。拒绝运输或提高运费都可能摧毁他们的生意。洛克菲勒改变了游戏规则，使得小型石油生产商唯一的选择就是他提供的那些选项。
In this tactic your opponents know their hand is being forced, but it doesn't matter. The technique is effective against those who resist at all costs.
在这种战术中，你的对手明知自己被迫出手，但这无关紧要。这种技巧对那些不惜一切代价抵抗的人非常有效。
The Shrinking Options. The late-nineteenth-century art dealer Am-broise VoUard perfected this technique.
缩减选择。十九世纪末的艺术品经销商安布鲁瓦兹·沃阿尔完善了这项技术。
Customers would come to Vollard's shop to see some Cezannes. He would show three paintings, neglect to mention a price, and pretend to doze off. The visitors would have to leave without deciding. They would usually come back the next day to see the paintings again, but this time Vollard would pull out less interesting works, pretending he thought they were the same ones. The baffled customers would look at the new offerings, leave to think them over, and return yet again. Once again the same thing would happen: Vollard would show paintings of lesser quality still. Finally the buyers would realize they had better grab what he was showing them, because tomorrow they would have to settle for something worse, perhaps at even higher prices.
顾客们会来到沃拉尔的店里欣赏塞尚的画作。他会拿出三幅画，却不报价格，然后假装打瞌睡。顾客们只好作罢，无法做出决定。他们通常第二天会再来，但这次沃拉尔会拿出一些质量较差的作品，假装以为是同一批。困惑的顾客们看着这些新作品，离开去考虑，然后又回来。同样的事情再次发生：沃拉尔会拿出质量更差的画作。最终，买家们意识到他们最好还是买下他展示的这些，因为明天他们可能就只能买到质量更差，甚至价格更高的画作了。
A variation on this technique is to raise the price every time the buyer hesitates and another day goes by. This is an excellent negotiating ploy to use on the chronically indecisive, who will fall for the idea that they are getting a better deal today than if they wait till tomorrow.
这种技巧的变种是，每当买家犹豫不决、一天天过去时，就提高价格。这对于那些优柔寡断的买家来说是一种绝佳的谈判策略，他们会相信今天比明天更划算。
The Weak Man on the Precipice. The weak are the easiest to maneuver by controlling their options. Cardinal de Retz, die great seventeenth-century provocateur, served as an unofficial assistant to the Duke of Orleans, who was notoriously indecisive. It was a constant struggle to convince the duke to take actionhe would hem and haw, weigh the options, and wait till the last moment, giving everyone around him an ulcer. But Retz discovered a way to handle him: He would describe all sorts of dangers, exaggerating them as much as possible, until the duke saw a yawning abyss in every direction except one: the one Retz was pushing him to take.
悬崖边的弱者。弱者最容易被操控，只要控制他们的选择即可。十七世纪伟大的挑衅者雷茨红衣主教曾担任奥尔良公爵的非正式助手，而这位公爵出了名的优柔寡断。说服公爵采取行动总是难上加难——他总是支支吾吾，权衡利弊，拖到最后一刻才行动，让周围的人都焦头烂额。但雷茨找到了对付他的办法：他会描述各种各样的危险，尽可能地夸大其词，直到公爵看到四面八方都是深不见底的深渊，唯独一个方向例外：那就是雷茨正逼他走向的方向。
This tactic is similar to “Color the Choices,” but widi the weak you have to be more aggressive. Work on their emotionsuse fear and terror to propel them into action. Try reason and they will always find a way to procrastinate.
这种策略类似于“选择颜色”，但对付弱者时，你需要更积极主动。要利用他们的情绪，用恐惧和惊吓来促使他们采取行动。如果试图讲道理，他们总会找到拖延的理由。
Brothers in Crime. This is a classic con-artist technique: You attract your victims to some criminal scheme, creating a bond of blood and guilt between you. They participate in your deception, commit a crime (or think they dosee the story of Sam Geezil in Law 3), and are easily manipulated. Serge Stavisky, the great French con artist of the 1920s, so entangled the government in his scams and swindles that die state did not dare to prosecute him, and “chose” to leave him alone. It is often wise to implicate in your deceptions the very person who can do you the most harm if you fail. Their involvement can be subtieeven a hint of their involvement will narrow their options and buy their silence.
犯罪兄弟。这是骗子常用的伎俩：你引诱受害者参与犯罪计划，在你们之间建立起血缘和罪恶感的纽带。他们参与你的骗局，犯下罪行（或者自以为犯了罪，参见《法律3》中萨姆·吉泽尔的故事），并且很容易被操纵。20世纪20年代法国著名骗子塞尔日·斯塔维斯基的骗局和诈骗行为让政府深陷其中，以至于国家不敢起诉他，而是“选择”放过他。通常，明智的做法是让那些一旦骗局失败就能给你造成最大伤害的人参与其中。他们的参与可以很隐蔽——哪怕只是暗示一下，也能缩小他们的选择范围，让他们保持沉默。
The Horns of a Dilemma. This idea was demonstrated by General William Sherman's infamous march through Georgia during the American Civil War. Although the Confederates knew what direction Sherman was
进退两难。美国内战期间，威廉·谢尔曼将军臭名昭著的佐治亚州进军就体现了这一概念。尽管南方邦联军知道谢尔曼的行军方向，但他们仍然面临着进军的困境。
heading in, they never knew if he would attack from the left or the right, for he divided his army into two wingsand if the rebels retreated from one wing they found themselves facing the other. This is a classic trial lawyer's technique: The lawyer leads the witnesses to decide between two possible explanations of an event, both of which poke a hole in their story. They have to answer the lawyer's questions, but whatever they say they hurt themselves. The key to this move is to strike quickly: Deny the victim the time to think of an escape. As they wriggle between the horns of the dilemma, they dig their own grave.
进军时，他们永远无法预料他会从左翼还是右翼发起进攻，因为他将军队分成两翼——如果叛军从一翼撤退，就会发现自己面对的是另一翼。这是典型的庭审律师技巧：律师引导证人在两种可能的解释中做出选择，而这两种解释都足以戳穿他们证词的漏洞。他们不得不回答律师的问题，但无论他们说什么，都会对自己不利。这一招的关键在于迅速出击：不给受害者任何逃脱的机会。当他们在两难困境中挣扎时，他们实际上是在自掘坟墓。
Understand: In your struggles with your rivals, it will often be necessary for you to hurt mem. And if you are clearly the agent of their punishment, expect a counterattackexpect revenge. If, however, they seem to themselves to be the agents of their own misfortune, they will submit quietly. When Ivan left Moscow for his rural village, the citizens asking him to return agreed to his demand for absolute power. Over the years to come, they resented him less for the terror he unleashed on the country, because, after all, they had granted him his power themselves. This is why it is always good to allow your victims their choice of poison, and to cloak your involvement in providing it to them as far as possible.
明白：在与对手的斗争中，你往往需要伤害他们。如果你明显是惩罚他们的执行者，就要做好被反击、被报复的准备。然而，如果他们似乎是自作自受，他们就会默默屈服。伊凡离开莫斯科回到乡下时，那些请求他回来的村民同意了他要求绝对权力的要求。在随后的岁月里，他们对伊凡给国家带来的恐怖逐渐释怀，因为毕竟是他们自己赋予了他权力。因此，最好让你的受害者自己选择毒药，并尽可能掩盖你提供毒药的行为。
Image: The Horns ofthe Bull. The bullbacks you into the corner with its hornsnota single horn, which youmight be able to escape, but a pair of hornsthat trap you within theirhold. Run right or runlefteither way youmove into their piercingends and are gored.
图片：公牛的角。公牛用它的角把你逼到角落——不是一只角，你或许还能逃脱，而是一对角，把你困在它们的包围之中。向右跑还是向左跑？无论往哪个方向跑，你都会撞上它们尖锐的角尖，被刺穿。
Authority: For the wounds and every other evil that men inflict upon themselves spontaneously, and of their own choice, are in the long run less painful than those inflicted by others. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威观点：因为从长远来看，人们自愿、自主选择而造成的伤害和其他一切恶行，都比他人造成的伤害和恶行要轻微得多。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
Controlling the options has one main purpose: to disguise yourself as the agent of power and punishment. The tactic works best, then, for tiiose whose power is fragile, and who cannot operate too openly without incurring suspicion, resentment, and anger. Even as a general rule, however, it is rarely wise to be seen as exerting power directly and forcefully, no matter how secure or strong you are. It is usually more elegant and more effective to give people the illusion of choice.
控制选择权的主要目的只有一个：将自己伪装成权力和惩罚的执行者。因此，这种策略对那些权力脆弱、无法公开行事而不招致怀疑、怨恨和愤怒的人来说最为有效。然而，即便从一般意义上讲，无论你的权力多么稳固或强大，直接且强硬地行使权力也鲜少明智。通常情况下，更巧妙、更有效的做法是给人一种选择权的错觉。
On the other hand, by limiting other people's options you sometimes limit your own. There are situations in which it is to your advantage to allow your rivals a large degree of freedom: As you watch them operate, you give yourself rich opportunities to spy, gather information, and plan your deceptions. The nineteentii-century banker James Rothschild liked this method: He felt that if he tried to control his opponents' movements, he lost the chance to observe their strategy and plan a more effective course. The more freedom he allowed them in the short term, the more forcefully he could act against them in the long run.
另一方面，限制他人的选择有时也会限制自己的选择。在某些情况下，给予竞争对手较大的自由度反而对你有利：观察他们的行动，你就能获得丰富的机会去侦察、收集信息并策划欺骗。19世纪的银行家詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德就喜欢这种方法：他认为，如果试图控制对手的行动，就会失去观察其策略并制定更有效策略的机会。短期内给予对手的自由越多，从长远来看，他就能越有力地反击他们。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 32
第32条
PLAY TO PEOPLE'S FANTASIES
迎合人们的幻想
JUDGMENT
判断
The truth is often avoided because it is ugly and unpleasant. Never appeal to truth and reality unless you are prepared for the anger that comes from disenchantment. Life is so harsh and distressing that people who can manufacture romance or conjure up fantasy are like oases in the desert: Everyone flocks to them. There is great power in tapping into the fantasies of the masses.
真相往往令人厌恶，因为它丑陋不堪，令人不快。除非你已做好准备面对幻灭带来的愤怒，否则永远不要诉诸真相和现实。生活如此残酷痛苦，那些能够编造浪漫故事或营造幻想的人，就像沙漠中的绿洲：人人都趋之若鹜。迎合大众的幻想蕴藏着巨大的力量。
I IIK ITNKUAI. OF TIIK I.IONKSS
我IIK ITNKUAI。的 TIIK I.IONKSS
The lion having suddenly lost his queen, every one hastened to show allegiance to the monarch, by offering consolation. These compliments, alas, served but to increase the widower's affliction. Due notice was given throughout the kingdom that the funeral would be performed at a certain time and place; the lion's officers were ordered to be in attendance, to regulate the ceremony, and place the company according to their respective rank. One may well judge no one absented himself. The monarch gave way to his grief, and the whole cave, lions having no other temples, resounded with his cries. After his example, all the courtiers roared in their different tones. A court is the sort of place where everyone is either sorrowful, gay, or indifferent to everything, just as the reigning prince may think fit; or if any one is not actually, he at least tries to appear so; each endeavors to mimic the master. It is truly said that one mind animates a thousand bodies, clearly showing that human beings are mere machines. But let us return to our subject. The stag alone shed no tears. How could he, forsooth The death of the queen avenged him; she had
狮王突然失去了王后，众狮纷纷赶来向君主表示效忠，纷纷上前安慰。然而，这些恭维之词却只会加重鳏夫的悲痛。全国上下都已接到通知，葬礼将在特定的时间和地点举行；狮王的官员们奉命出席，主持仪式，并按等级安排宾客。可以肯定的是，无人缺席。君主悲痛欲绝，整个狮穴——狮群别无他处——都回荡着他的嚎啕大哭。所有朝臣都效仿他，用各自不同的音调发出哀嚎。宫廷就是这样一个地方，每个人要么悲伤，要么欢欣，要么对一切都漠不关心，一切都取决于君主的意愿；即便有人并非如此，至少也会努力装作如此；每个人都试图模仿君主。俗话说，一心能操控千身，这清楚地表明人类不过是机器。但我们还是回到正题吧。只有那头雄鹿没有流泪。它怎么可能流泪呢？女王的死为它报了仇；她曾……
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
The city-state of Venice was prosperous for so long that its citizens felt their small republic had destiny on its side. In the Middle Ages and High Renaissance, its virtual monopoly on trade to the east made it die wealthiest city in Europe. Under a beneficent republican government, Venetians enjoyed liberties that few other Italians had ever known. Yet in the sixteenth century dieir fortunes suddenly changed. The opening of the New World transferred power to die Atiantic side of Europeto die Spanish and Portuguese, and later the Dutch and English. Venice could not compete economically and its empire gradually dwindled. The final blow was the devastating loss of a prized Mediterranean possession, the island of Cyprus, captured from Venice by die Turks in 1570.
威尼斯城邦曾长期繁荣昌盛，以至于其公民都觉得自己的小共和国拥有至高无上的命运。在中世纪和文艺复兴盛期，威尼斯几乎垄断了与东方的贸易，使其成为欧洲最富有的城市。在仁慈的共和政府统治下，威尼斯人享有其他意大利人鲜少拥有的自由。然而，到了十六世纪，威尼斯的命运急转直下。新大陆的发现将权力转移到了欧洲的大西洋沿岸，西班牙和葡萄牙人，以及后来的荷兰人和英国人，都占据了主导地位。威尼斯在经济上无力与之竞争，其帝国逐渐衰落。压垮威尼斯的最后一根稻草是失去了其在地中海的珍贵领地——塞浦路斯岛。1570年，土耳其人从威尼斯手中夺取了这座岛屿。
Now noble families went broke in Venice, and banks began to fold. A kind of gloom and depression setded over die citizens. They had known a glittering pasthad eidier lived through it or heard stories about it from their elders. The closeness of the glory years was humiliating. The Venetians half believed diat die goddess Fortune was only playing a joke on them, and that die old days would soon return. For the time being, tiiough, what could they do
如今，威尼斯的贵族家庭纷纷破产，银行也开始倒闭。一种阴郁和沮丧的气氛笼罩着市民。他们曾经历过威尼斯辉煌的过去——有些人亲身经历过，有些人则从长辈那里听过往事。昔日荣光的临近反而让他们感到屈辱。威尼斯人半信半疑地认为，命运女神只是在跟他们开玩笑，往日的辉煌很快就会重现。然而，眼下他们又能怎么办呢？
In 1589 rumors began to swirl around Venice of the arrival not far away of a mysterious man called “II Bragadino,” a master of alchemy, a man who had won incredible wealtii through his ability, it was said, to multiply gold through die use of a secret substance. The rumor spread quickly because a few years earlier, a Venetian nobleman passing through Poland had heard a learned man prophesy that Venice would recover her past glory and power if she could find a man who understood die alchemic art of manufacturing gold. And so, as word reached Venice of die gold this Bragadino possessedhe clinked gold coins continuously in his hands, and golden objects filled his palacesome began to dream: Through him, their city would prosper again.
1589年，威尼斯城内开始流传着一个神秘人物“布拉加迪诺二世”即将抵达不远处的传闻。据说他是一位炼金术大师，凭借一种神秘物质使黄金倍增的能力，积累了惊人的财富。这个传闻迅速传播开来，因为几年前，一位途经波兰的威尼斯贵族曾听一位博学之士预言，如果威尼斯能够找到一位精通炼金术的人，就能重现昔日的辉煌与强盛。于是，当布拉加迪诺拥有巨额黄金的消息传到威尼斯时，他手中金币叮当作响，宫殿里也摆满了金器。一些人开始憧憬：凭借他，威尼斯将再次繁荣昌盛。
Members of Venice's most important noble families accordingly went togetiier to Brescia, where Bragadino lived. They toured his palace and watched in awe as he demonstrated his gold-making abilities, taking a pinch of seemingly worthless minerals and transforming it into several ounces of gold dust. The Venetian senate prepared to debate the idea of extending an official invitation to Bragadino to stay in Venice at the city's expense, when word suddenly reached them that they were competing with the Duke of Mantua for his services. They heard of a magnificent party in Bragadino's palace for the duke, featuring garments with golden buttons, gold watches, gold plates, and on and on. Worried they might lose Bragadino to Mantua, die senate voted almost unanimously to invite him to Venice, promising him the mountain of money he would need to continue living in his luxurious stylebut only if he came right away.
于是，威尼斯最重要的贵族家族成员们一同前往布拉加迪诺居住的布雷西亚。他们参观了他的宫殿，并惊叹地观看他展示炼金术：他能将一小撮看似毫无价值的矿石变成几盎司的金粉。威尼斯元老院正准备讨论是否正式邀请布拉加迪诺留在威尼斯，费用由威尼斯承担，这时他们突然得知，他们正在与曼图亚公爵争夺这位贵宾。他们听说布拉加迪诺的宫殿里正在为公爵举办一场盛大的宴会，宴会上摆满了镶有金扣的华服、金表、金盘等等，不胜枚举。担心布拉加迪诺会落入曼图亚之手，元老院几乎一致投票决定邀请他来威尼斯，并承诺给他一大笔钱，让他继续过上奢华的生活——但前提是他必须立即前来。
Late that year die mysterious Bragadino arrived in Venice. With his piercing dark eyes under thick brows, and the two enormous black mastiffs diat accompanied him everywhere, he was forbidding and impressive. He took up residence in a sumptuous palace on the island of the Giudecca,
那年晚些时候，神秘的布拉加迪诺抵达威尼斯。他浓眉下是一双锐利的黑眼睛，两只巨大的黑色獒犬形影不离地陪伴着他，他给人一种威严而令人印象深刻的感觉。他住在朱代卡岛上一座富丽堂皇的宫殿里。
with the republic funding his banquets, his expensive clothes, and all his other whims. A kind of alchemy fever spread through Venice. On street corners, hawkers would sell coal, distilling apparatus, bellows, how-to books on the subject. Everyone began to practice alchemyeveryone except Bragadino.
共和国资助他的宴会、昂贵的服饰以及他的一切其他奇思妙想。一股炼金术热潮席卷威尼斯。街角的小贩兜售煤炭、蒸馏器具、风箱以及炼金术入门书籍。除了布拉加迪诺，几乎所有人都开始实践炼金术。
The alchemist seemed to be in no hurry to begin manufacturing the gold that would save Venice from ruin. Strangely enough this only increased his popularity and following; people thronged from all over Europe, even Asia, to meet this remarkable man. Months went by, with gifts pouring in to Bragadino from all sides. Still he gave no sign of the miracle that the Venetians confidently expected him to produce. Eventually the citizens began to grow impatient, wondering if he would wait forever. At first the senators warned them not to hurry himhe was a capricious devil, who needed to be cajoled. Finally, though, the nobility began to wonder too, and the senate came under pressure to show a return on the city's ballooning investment.
这位炼金术士似乎并不急于炼制能拯救威尼斯于水火之中的黄金。奇怪的是，这反而增加了他的声望和追随者；人们从欧洲各地，甚至亚洲蜂拥而至，只为一睹这位非凡人物的风采。数月过去，布拉加迪诺收到了来自四面八方的礼物。然而，他仍然没有展现出威尼斯人翘首以盼的奇迹。最终，市民们开始变得不耐烦，怀疑他是否会永远等待下去。起初，元老们警告他们不要催促他——他是个反复无常的家伙，需要哄着。但最终，贵族们也开始感到疑惑，元老院也面临着巨大的压力，必须拿出回报来证明这座城市不断膨胀的投资物有所值。
Bragadino had only scorn for die doubters, but he responded to them. He had, he said, already deposited in the city's mint the mysterious substance with which he multiplied gold. He could use this substance up all at once, and produce double the gold, but the more slowly the process took place, the more it would yield. If left alone for seven years, sealed in a casket, the substance would multiply the gold in the mint thirty times over. Most of the senators agreed to wait to reap the gold mine Bragadino promised. Others, however, were angry: seven more years of this man living royally at the public trough! And many of the common citizens of Venice echoed these sentiments. Finally the alchemist's enemies demanded he produce a proof of his skills: a substantial amount of gold, and soon.
布拉加迪诺对那些怀疑者嗤之以鼻，但他还是回应了他们。他说，他已经将那种能使黄金倍增的神秘物质存放在了威尼斯造币厂。他可以一次性用完这种物质，使黄金翻倍；但这个过程越慢，产量就越高。如果将其密封在一个盒子里，静置七年，造币厂里的黄金就能翻三十倍。大多数元老院议员都同意等待布拉加迪诺承诺的金矿。然而，也有一些人愤怒不已：还要让这个人继续靠公共资源过七年的奢靡生活！许多威尼斯平民百姓也表达了同样的不满。最终，炼金术士的敌人要求他拿出证据来证明自己的能力：大量的黄金，而且要尽快拿出来。
Lofty, apparently devoted to his art, Bragadino responded that Venice, in its impatience, had betrayed him, and would therefore lose his services. He left town, going first to nearby Padua, then, in 1590, to Munich, at the invitation of the Duke of Bavaria, who, like the entire city of Venice, had known great wealth but had fallen into bankruptcy through his own profligacy, and hoped to regain his fortune through the famous alchemist's services. And so Bragadino resumed the comfortable arrangement he had known in Venice, and the same pattern repeated itself.
布拉加迪诺为人高贵，显然一心扑在艺术上。他回应说，威尼斯因急躁而背叛了他，因此将失去他的效力。他离开了威尼斯，先去了附近的帕多瓦，然后在1590年应巴伐利亚公爵之邀前往慕尼黑。巴伐利亚公爵和整个威尼斯城一样，曾经拥有巨额财富，但因挥霍无度而破产，希望借助这位著名炼金术士的帮助重振家业。于是，布拉加迪诺又回到了他在威尼斯时舒适安逸的生活，同样的模式再次上演。
Interpretation
解释
The young Cypriot Mamugna had lived in Venice for several years before reincarnating himself as the alchemist Bragadino. He saw how gloom had settled on the city, how everyone was hoping for a redemption from some indefinite source. While other charlatans mastered everyday cons based on sleight of hand, Mamugna mastered human nature. With Venice as his target from the start, he traveled abroad, made some money through his alchemy scams, and then returned to Italy, setting up shop in Brescia. There he created a reputation that he knew would spread to Venice. From a distance, in fact, his aura of power would be all the more impressive. At first Mamugna did not use vulgar demonstrations to convince peo-
年轻的塞浦路斯人马穆尼亚在威尼斯生活了几年，之后化身为炼金术士布拉加迪诺。他目睹了这座城市笼罩在阴霾之中，每个人都渴望从某个遥不可及的源头获得救赎。其他江湖骗子擅长用障眼法行骗，而马穆尼亚则深谙人性。他从一开始就将威尼斯作为目标，先是游历海外，靠炼金术骗局赚了些钱，然后返回意大利，在布雷西亚安营扎寨。在那里，他建立起自己的名声，他知道这名声会传到威尼斯。事实上，从远处看，他那强大的气场会更加令人印象深刻。起初，马穆尼亚并没有用庸俗的表演来迷惑人们——
formerly strangled his wife and son. A courtier thought fit to inform the bereaved monarch, and even affirmed that he had seen the stag laugh. The rage of a king, says Solomon, is terrible, and especially that of a lion-king. “Pitiful forester!” he exclaimed, “darest thou laugh when all around are dissolved in tears We will not soil our royal claws with thy profane blood! Do thou, brave wolf, avenge our queen, by immolating this traitor to her august manes.”
他曾勒死了自己的妻子和儿子。一位朝臣认为有必要将此事告知悲痛欲绝的君主，甚至声称自己亲眼目睹了那头雄鹿的笑声。所罗门说，君王的愤怒是可怕的，狮王的愤怒更是如此。“可怜的护林员！”他怒吼道，“你竟敢在众人泪流满面之时大笑！我们绝不会用你那亵渎的鲜血玷污我们王室的利爪！勇敢的狼啊，为我们的女王复仇吧，将这叛徒焚烧在她高贵的鬃毛之上！”
Hereupon the stag replied: “Sire, the time for weeping is passed; grief is here superfluous. Your revered spouse appeared to me but now, reposing on a bed of roses; I instantly recognized her. 'Friend,' said she to me, 'have done with this funereal pomp, cease these useless tears. I have tasted a thousand delights in the Elysian fields, conversing with those who are saints like myself. Let the king's despair remain for some time unchecked, it gratifies me.'” Scarcely had he spoken, when every one shouted: “A miracle! a miracle!” The stag, instead of being punished, received a handsome gift. Do hut entertain a king with dreams, flatter him, and tell him a few pleasant fantastic lies: whatever his indignation against you may be, he will swallow the bait, and make you his dearest friend.
于是，雄鹿答道：“陛下，哭泣之时已过，悲伤在此毫无意义。您敬爱的妻子此刻显现于我眼前，正安卧于玫瑰花丛中，我一眼便认出了她。‘朋友，’她对我说，‘别再搞这些葬礼的繁文缛节了，停止这无谓的哭泣吧。我在极乐世界里已尝尽了千种欢愉，与那些与我一样圣洁的人们交谈。就让国王的绝望暂时消散吧，我乐见其成。’”他话音未落，众人齐声高呼：“奇迹！奇迹！”雄鹿非但没有受到惩罚，反而得到了一份丰厚的礼物。所以，只要用美梦款待国王，奉承他，编造一些悦耳动听的谎言，无论他之前对你多么愤怒，他都会上钩，把你变成他最亲密的朋友。
FABLBS,
FABLBS，
Jean de La Fontaine, 1621-1695
让·德拉封丹，1621-1695 年
If you want to tell lies
如果你想说谎
that will be believed,
人们会相信的。
don't tell the truth
不要说实话
that won't.
那不会。
Emperor Tokugawa
德川天皇
Ieyasu of Japan,
日本的德康，
seventeenth century
十七世纪
pie of his alchemic skill. His sumptuous palace, his opulent garments, the clink of gold in his hands, all these provided a superior argument to anything rational. And these established the cycle that kept him going: His obvious wealth confirmed his reputation as an alchemist, so that patrons like the Duke of Mantua gave him money, which allowed him to live in wealth, which reinforced his reputation as an alchemist, and so on. Only once this reputation was established, and dukes and senators were fighting over him, did he resort to the trilling necessity of a demonstration. By then, however, people were easy to deceive: They wanted to believe. The Venetian senators who watched him multiply gold wanted to believe so badly that they failed to notice the glass pipe up his sleeve, from which he slipped gold dust into his pinches of minerals. Brilliant and capricious, he was the alchemist of their fantasiesand once he had created an aura like diis, no one noticed his simple deceptions.
他炼金术的精髓在于他的奢华。他富丽堂皇的宫殿，华丽的服饰，手中金器碰撞的叮当声，这一切都胜过任何理性论证。而这便构成了一个让他不断前行的循环：他显而易见的财富巩固了他作为炼金术士的名声，于是像曼图亚公爵这样的赞助人给他钱，让他过上了富裕的生活，这又进一步巩固了他作为炼金术士的名声，如此循环往复。只有当这种名声确立，公爵和元老们都为他争相效忠时，他才会诉诸于那令人叹为观止的演示。然而，那时人们很容易被蒙蔽：他们渴望相信。那些亲眼目睹他变出黄金的威尼斯元老们如此渴望相信，以至于他们没有注意到他袖子里的玻璃管，他正从中偷偷地将金粉混入他捏的矿石中。他才华横溢，却又反复无常，是他们幻想中的炼金术士——一旦他营造出一种如同迪斯般的光环，就没有人会注意到他拙劣的欺骗。
Such is the power of the fantasies that take root in us, especially in times of scarcity and decline. People rarely believe diat their problems arise from their own misdeeds and stupidity. Someone or something out there is to blamethe other, the world, the godsand so salvation comes from the outside as well. Had Bragadino arrived in Venice armed with a detailed analysis of the reasons behind the city's economic decline, and of the hard-nosed steps that it could take to turn things around, he would have been scorned. The reality was too ugly and the solution too painful mosdy die kind of hard work that the citizens' ancestors had mustered to create an empire. Fantasy, on die other handin this case the romance of alchemywas easy to understand and infinitely more palatable.
这就是幻想的力量，尤其是在资源匮乏和衰落的时代，它在我们心中生根发芽。人们很少相信自己的问题源于自身的过错和愚蠢。总有人或事要为此负责——他人、世界、神明——因此，救赎也来自外部。如果布拉加迪诺带着对威尼斯经济衰落原因的详细分析，以及扭转局面的切实措施来到威尼斯，他一定会遭到嘲笑。现实太过残酷，解决之道也太过痛苦——远非威尼斯人的先辈们为了建立帝国所付出的艰辛努力所能比拟。而幻想，比如炼金术的浪漫故事，则更容易理解，也更令人信服。
To gain power, you must be a source of pleasure for those around youand pleasure comes from playing to people's fantasies. Never promise a gradual improvement through hard work; rather, promise the moon, the great and sudden transformation, the pot of gold.
要想获得权力，你必须成为周围人的快乐源泉，而快乐来自于迎合他人的幻想。永远不要承诺通过努力就能逐步进步；相反，要许诺月亮，许诺巨大而突然的转变，许诺一夜暴富。
No man need despair of gaining converts to the most extravagant hypothesis who has art enough to represent it in favorable colors.
只要有足够的艺术才能将最离奇的假设用美好的色彩呈现出来，任何人都不必对获得人们的认同感到绝望。
David Hume, 1711-1776
大卫·休谟，1711-1776
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Fantasy can never operate alone. It requires the backdrop of the humdrum and the mundane. It is the oppressiveness of reality that allows fantasy to take root and bloom. In sixteenth-century Venice, the reality was one of decline and loss of prestige. The corresponding fantasy described a sudden recovery of past glories through the miracle of alchemy. While the reality only got worse, die Venetians inhabited a happy dream world in which dieir city restored its fabulous wealth and power overnight, turning dust into gold.
幻想永远无法独立存在。它需要平凡琐碎的背景。正是现实的压抑，才使得幻想得以生根发芽、蓬勃绽放。十六世纪的威尼斯，现实是衰落和声望的丧失。与之对应的幻想则描绘了炼金术的奇迹如何让昔日的辉煌一夜之间重现。当现实每况愈下时，威尼斯人却沉浸在一个美好的梦境中：他们的城市一夜之间恢复了昔日的辉煌和权力，点石成金。
The person who can spin a fantasy out of an oppressive reality has access to untold power. As you search for the fantasy that will take hold of the
能够将压抑的现实编织成幻想世界的人，拥有着难以估量的力量。当你寻找那个能够掌控你内心的幻想时……
masses, then, keep your eye on the banal truths that weigh heavily on us all. Never be distracted by people's glamorous portraits of themselves and their lives; search and dig for what really imprisons diem. Once you find that, you have the magical key that will put great power in your hands.
因此，各位，请密切关注那些沉重压在我们每个人身上的平凡真相。永远不要被人们光鲜亮丽的自我形象和生活所迷惑；要深入探寻真正束缚他们的根源。一旦找到它，你就掌握了那把神奇的钥匙，它将赋予你强大的力量。
Aldiough times and people change, let us examine a few of die oppressive realities tiiat endure, and the opportunities for power they provide:
尽管时代和人都在变化，但让我们来审视一下人们正在经历的一些残酷现实，以及它们所提供的权力机会：
The Reality: Change is slow and gradual. It requires hard work, a bit of luck, a fair amount of self-sacrifice, and a lot ofpatience.
现实情况是：改变是缓慢而渐进的。它需要艰苦的努力、一点运气、相当程度的自我牺牲和大量的耐心。
The Fantasy: A sudden transformation will bring a total change in one's fortunes, bypassing work, luck, self-sacrifice, and time in one fantastic stroke.
幻想：一次突如其来的转变将彻底改变一个人的命运，无需工作、运气、自我牺牲和时间，就能一举成功。
This is of course die fantasy par excellence of the charlatans who prowl among us to this day, and was die key to Bragadino's success. Promise a great and total changefrom poor to rich, sickness to healdi, misery to ecstasyand you will have followers.
这当然是至今仍在我们中间游荡的江湖骗子们最擅长的幻想，也是布拉加迪诺成功的关键。承诺彻底改变人生——从贫穷到富有，从疾病到健康，从痛苦到极乐——你就会拥有追随者。
How did the great sixteenth-century German quack Leonhard Thumeisser become the court physician for the Elector of Brandenburg witiiout ever studying medicine Instead of offering amputations, leeches, and foul-tasting purgatives (the medicaments of the time), Thumeisser offered sweet-tasting elixirs and promised instant recovery. Fashionable courtiers especially wanted his solution of “drinkable gold,” which cost a fortune. If some inexplicable illness assailed you, Thumeisser would consult a horoscope and prescribe a talisman. Who could resist such a fantasyhealth and well-being without sacrifice and pain!
十六世纪德国著名庸医莱昂哈德·图迈瑟（Leonhard Thumeisser）是如何在从未接受过医学训练的情况下，成为勃兰登堡选帝侯的宫廷御医的呢？图迈瑟并没有像当时的医生那样，提供截肢、水蛭疗法和难以下咽的泻药，而是兜售口感甘甜的灵丹妙药，并承诺能迅速治愈疾病。时髦的朝臣们尤其渴望得到他那价值连城的“可饮用黄金”。如果你不幸患上某种无法解释的疾病，图迈瑟会为你占卜星象，并为你开出护身符。谁能抵挡住这种无需牺牲和痛苦就能获得健康与幸福的诱惑呢？
The Reality: The social realm has hard-set codes and boundaries. We understand these limits and know that we have to move within the same familiar circles, day in and day out.
现实是：社会领域有着既定的规则和界限。我们理解这些限制，也知道我们日复一日地必须在熟悉的圈子里活动。
The Fantasy: We can enter a totally new world with different codes and the promise of adventure.
幻想：我们可以进入一个全新的世界，拥有不同的规则和冒险的希望。
In the early 1700s, all London was abuzz with talk of a mysterious stranger, a young man named George Psalmanazar. He had arrived from what was to most Englishmen a fantastical land: the island of Formosa (now Taiwan), off the coast of China. Oxford University engaged Psalmanazar to teach die island's language; a few years later he translated the Bible into Formosan, then wrote a bookan immediate best-selleron Formosa's history and geography. English royalty wined and dined die young man, and everywhere he went he entertained his hosts widi wondrous stories of his homeland, and its bizarre customs.
18世纪初，整个伦敦都在热议一位神秘的陌生人，名叫乔治·萨尔马纳扎尔。他来自对大多数英国人来说如梦似幻的福尔摩沙岛（今台湾），位于中国沿海。牛津大学聘请萨尔马纳扎尔教授福尔摩沙语；几年后，他将《圣经》翻译成福尔摩沙语，随后又撰写了一本关于福尔摩沙历史和地理的书籍，该书一经出版便成为畅销书。英国皇室成员热情款待这位年轻人，而他所到之处，都绘声绘色地讲述着故乡的奇闻异事和古怪风俗。
After Psalmanazar died, however, his will revealed diat he was in fact merely a Frenchman widi a rich imagination. Everything he had said about Formosaits alphabet, its language, its literature, its entire culturehe had invented. He had built on die English public's ignorance of die place to concoct an elaborate story that fulfilled their desire for the exotic and
然而，萨尔马纳扎尔死后，他的遗嘱揭示了他实际上只是一个想象力丰富的法国人。他所说的关于福尔摩沙字母、语言、文学乃至整个文化的一切，都是他虚构的。他利用英国公众对这个地方的无知，精心编造了一个故事，满足了他们对异域风情的渴望。
strange. British culture's rigid control of people's dangerous dreams gave him the perfect opportunity to exploit their fantasy.
奇怪。英国文化对人们危险梦想的严格控制，反而给了他利用人们幻想的绝佳机会。
The fantasy of die exotic, of course, can also skirt die sexual. It must not come too close, diough, for the physical hinders die power of fantasy; it can be seen, grasped, and then tired ofthe fate of most courtesans. The bodily charms of die mistress only whet the master's appetite for more and different pleasures, a new beauty to adore. To bring power, fantasy must remain to some degree unrealized, literally unreal. The dancer Mata Hari, for instance, who rose to public prominence in Paris before World War I, had quite ordinary looks. Her power came from the fantasy she created of being strange'and exotic, unknowable and indecipherable. The taboo she worked with was less sex itself than the breaking of social codes.
当然，异域风情的幻想也可以与性有所关联。然而，它绝不能过于接近，因为肉体的存在会削弱幻想的力量；它很容易被看到、被掌控，然后像大多数妓女一样，最终走向厌倦。情妇的肉体魅力只会更加激发主人对更多、更奇特享乐的渴望，让他们想要寻找新的美人来膜拜。为了发挥力量，幻想必须保持某种程度的未实现性，甚至可以说是不真实的。例如，在第一次世界大战前于巴黎声名鹊起的舞蹈家玛塔·哈丽，她的外貌十分普通。她的力量源于她所创造的那种奇异、异域风情、不可知、难以捉摸的幻想。她所触及的禁忌与其说是性本身，不如说是打破社会规范。
Anodier form of die fantasy of the exotic is simply die hope for relief from boredom. Con artists love to play on die oppressiveness of the working world, its lack of adventure. Their cons might involve, say, die recovery of lost Spanish treasure, with the possible participation of an alluring Mexican senorita and a connection to the president of a South American countryanydiing offering release from the humdrum.
另一种对异域风情的幻想，其实就是对摆脱无聊的渴望。骗子们喜欢利用职场的压抑和缺乏冒险精神。他们的骗局可能包括找回失落的西班牙宝藏，或许还会牵扯到一位迷人的墨西哥女郎，以及与某个南美国家总统的某种联系——以此来摆脱单调乏味的生活。
The Reality: Society is fragmented and full of conflict.
现实情况：社会四分五裂，充满冲突。
The Fantasy: People can come together in a mystical union of souls.
幻想：人们可以灵魂神秘地结合在一起。
In the 1920s the con man Oscar Hartzell made a quick fortune out of the age-old Sir Francis Drake swindlebasically promising any sucker who happened to be surnamed “Drake” a substantial share of the long-lost “Drake treasure,” to which Hartzell had access. Thousands across the Midwest fell for the scam, which Hartzell cleverly turned into a crusade against the government and everyone else who was trying to keep the Drake fortune out of the rightful hands of its heirs. There developed a mystical union of the oppressed Drakes, with emotional rallies and meetings. Promise such a union and you can gain much power, but it is a dangerous power diat can easily turn against you. This is a fantasy for demagogues to play on.
20世纪20年代，骗子奥斯卡·哈泽尔利用古老的弗朗西斯·德雷克爵士骗局迅速发家致富。他向所有姓“德雷克”的傻瓜承诺，只要他们碰巧是德雷克，就能分到一大笔失落已久的“德雷克宝藏”，而哈泽尔掌握着这笔宝藏的大量份额。成千上万的中西部居民上当受骗，哈泽尔巧妙地将这场骗局演变成一场反对政府和所有试图阻止德雷克家族继承人获得这笔财富的人的运动。受压迫的德雷克家族成员之间形成了一个神秘的联盟，举行了激动人心的集会和会议。承诺建立这样一个联盟可以让你获得巨大的权力，但这是一种危险的权力，很容易反过来对付你。这不过是蛊惑人心的政客们用来煽动民粹的幻想罢了。
The Reality: Death. The dead cannot be brought back, the past cannot be changed. The Fantasy: A sudden reversal of this intolerable fact.
现实：死亡。死者无法复生，过去无法改变。幻想：突然逆转这一难以接受的事实。
This con has many variations, but requires great skill and subdety.
这种骗局有很多变种，但都需要高超的技巧和隐蔽性。
The beauty and importance of die art of Vermeer have long been recognized, but his paintings are small in number, and are extremely rare. In die 1930s, though, Vermeers began to appear on the art market. Experts were called on to verify diem, and pronounced diem real. Possession of these new Vermeers would crown a collector's career. It was like die resurrection of Lazarus: In a strange way, Vermeer had been brought back to life. The past had been changed.
维米尔艺术之美及其重要性早已为人所知，但他的画作数量稀少，极其罕见。然而，在20世纪30年代，维米尔的作品开始出现在艺术市场上。专家们受邀鉴定这些画作，并宣布其为真品。拥有这些新近出现的维米尔作品，将成为收藏家生涯的巅峰之作。这如同拉撒路的复活：维米尔以一种奇特的方式重获新生。历史被改写了。
Only later did it come out that die new Vermeers were the work of a middle-aged Dutch forger named Han van Meegeren. And he had chosen
后来才发现，那些所谓的维米尔画作其实是一位名叫汉·范·米格伦的中年荷兰伪造者所为。而且，他特意选择了……
Vermeer for his scam because he understood fantasy: The paintings would seem real precisely because the public, and the experts as well, so desperately wanted to believe they were.
维米尔之所以能成功行骗，是因为他懂得幻想：画作之所以看起来逼真，正是因为公众和专家们都迫切地想要相信它们是真实的。
Remember: The key to fantasy is distance. The distant has allure and promise, seems simple and problem free. What you are offering, then, should be ungraspable. Never let it become oppressively familiar; it is the mirage in the distance, withdrawing as die sucker approaches. Never be too direct in describing the fantasykeep it vague. As a forger of fantasies, let your victim come close enough to see and be tempted, but keep him far away enough that he stays dreaming and desiring.
记住：幻想的关键在于距离。遥远的事物充满诱惑和希望，看似简单无忧。因此，你所提供的，应该是遥不可及的。永远不要让它变得令人窒息的熟悉；它就像远处的海市蜃楼，随着傻瓜的靠近而消散。描述幻想时切勿过于直接——保持模糊。作为幻想的制造者，让你的猎物靠近到足以看到并受到诱惑的程度，但又要让他保持足够的距离，让他始终沉浸在幻想和渴望之中。
Image: The Moon. Unattainable, always changing shape, disappearing and reappearing. We look at it, imagine, wonder, and pinenever familiar, continuous provoker of dreams. Do not offer the obvious. Promise the moon.
图片：月亮。遥不可及，形状变幻莫测，时隐时现。我们凝视它，想象它，惊叹它，怀念它那永不熟悉的模样，它不断激发着我们的梦想。不要提供显而易见的东西。要给予月亮应有的承诺。
Authority: A lie is an allurement, a fabrication, that can be embellished into a fantasy. It can be clothed in the raiments of a mystic conception. Truth is cold, sober fact, not so comfortable to absorb. A lie is more palatable. The most detested person in the world is the one who always tells the truth, who never romances. . . . I found it far more interesting and profitable to romance than to tell the truth. (Joseph Weil, a.k.a. “The Yellow Kid,” 1875-1976)
权威：谎言是一种诱惑，一种捏造，可以被美化成幻想。它可以披上神秘主义的外衣。真相是冷酷、清醒的事实，难以接受。谎言则更容易让人接受。世界上最令人厌恶的人，是那些总是说真话、从不讲情面的人……我发现，讲情面比讲真话更有趣、更有利可图。（约瑟夫·韦尔，又名“黄孩子”，1875-1976）
REVERSAL
逆转
If there is power in tapping into the fantasies of the masses, there is also danger. Fantasy usually contains an element of playdie public half realizes it is being duped, but it keeps die dream alive anyway, relishing the entertainment and the temporary diversion from the everyday mat you are providing. So keep it lightnever come too close to the place where you are actually expected to produce results. That place may prove extremely hazardous.
迎合大众的幻想固然蕴含力量，但也暗藏危险。幻想通常带有某种娱乐成分，公众半梦半醒间意识到自己被蒙蔽，却依然沉浸其中，享受着你提供的娱乐和暂时逃离日常生活的乐趣。所以，保持轻松的心态，永远不要过于接近真正需要你拿出成果的领域。那个领域可能极其危险。
After Bragadino established himself in Munich, he found that the sober-minded Bavarians had far less faith in alchemy than the temperamental Venetians. Only the duke really believed in it, for he needed it desperately to rescue him from die hopeless mess he was in. As Bragadino played his familiar waiting game, accepting gifts and expecting patience, the public grew angry. Money was being spent and was yielding no results. In 1592 the Bavarians demanded justice, and eventually Bragadino found himself swinging from the gallows. As before, he had promised and had not delivered, but this time he had misjudged the forbearance of his hosts, and his inability to fulfill tiieir fantasy proved fatal.
布拉加迪诺在慕尼黑站稳脚跟后，发现冷静的巴伐利亚人对炼金术的信仰远不如性情暴躁的威尼斯人。只有公爵真正相信炼金术，因为他迫切需要它来摆脱当时的绝境。布拉加迪诺继续玩着他惯用的等待游戏，接受馈赠，期待着人们的耐心，但民众的愤怒却与日俱增。金钱被挥霍一空，毫无成效。1592年，巴伐利亚人要求伸张正义，最终布拉加迪诺被送上了绞刑架。和以往一样，他许诺了却未能兑现，但这一次，他低估了主人的忍耐力，他无法满足他们的幻想最终酿成了悲剧。
One last tiling: Never make the mistake of imagining that fantasy is always fantastical. It certainly contrasts with reality, but reality itself is sometimes so theatrical and stylized that fantasy becomes a desire for simple things. The image Abraham Lincoln created of himself, for example, as a homespun country lawyer with a beard, made him the common man's president.
最后一点：千万不要误以为幻想总是虚幻的。它固然与现实形成对比，但现实本身有时也充满了戏剧性和程式化，以至于幻想变成了对简单事物的渴望。例如，亚伯拉罕·林肯把自己塑造成一个留着胡须、朴实无华的乡村律师形象，这使他成为了平民的总统。
P. T. Barnum created a successful act with Tom Thumb, a dwarf who dressed up as famous leaders of the past, such as Napoleon, and lampooned them wickedly. The show delighted everyone, right up to Queen Victoria, by appealing to the fantasy of the time: Enough of the vainglorious rulers of history, the common man knows best. Tom Thumb reversed the familiar pattern of fantasy in which the strange and unknown becomes the ideal. But the act still obeyed the Law, for underlying it was the fantasy that the simple man is without problems, and is happier than the powerful and the rich.
P·T·巴纳姆创作了汤姆·拇指的表演，这个侏儒装扮成拿破仑等历史上的著名人物，并对他们进行辛辣的讽刺，取得了巨大的成功。这场表演迎合了当时的幻想，深受大众喜爱，甚至连维多利亚女王也为之倾倒：人们不再崇拜那些虚荣的历史统治者，普通百姓才是最明智的选择。汤姆·拇指颠覆了人们通常的幻想模式，即陌生和未知的事物往往成为理想。但这场表演仍然遵循着某种规律，因为其背后隐藏着一种幻想：普通人没有烦恼，比权贵和富人更幸福。
Both Lincoln and Tom Thumb played the commoner but carefully maintained their distance. Should you play with such a fantasy, you too must carefully cultivate distance and not allow your “common” persona to become too familiar or it will not project as fantasy.
林肯和汤姆·拇指都扮演了平民角色，但都巧妙地保持了距离。如果你也想扮演这样的角色，同样需要谨慎地保持距离，不要让你的“平民”形象变得过于亲切，否则就无法展现出虚构的本质。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 33
第33条
DISCOVER EACH MAN'S THUMBSCREW
找出每个人的“拇指螺丝钉”
JUDGMENT
判断
Everyone has a weakness, a gap in the castle wall. That weakness is usually an insecurity, an uncontrollable emotion or need; it can also be a small secret pleasure. Either way, once found, it is a thumbscrew you can turn to your advantage.
每个人都有弱点，都有防御上的漏洞。这种弱点通常是不安全感、无法控制的情绪或需求；也可能是一些不为人知的秘密乐趣。无论如何，一旦发现，它就成了你可以利用的把柄。
Till', I.ION. IIIK CHAMOIS. AND IT IK FOX
直到'，I.ION。IIIK 羚羊。还有 IK 狐狸
A lion was chasing a chamois along a valley. He had all but caught it, and with longing eyes was anticipating a certain and a satisfying repast. It seemed as if it were utterly impossible for the victim to escape; for a deep ravine appeared to bar the way for both the hunter and the hunted. But the nimble chamois, gathering together all its strength, shot like an arrow from a bow across the chasm, and stood still on the rocky cliff on the other side. Our lion pulled up short. But at that moment a friend of his happened to be near at hand. That friend was the fox. “What!” said he, “with your strength and agility, is it possible that you will yield to a feeble chamois You have only to will, and you will be able to work wonders. Though the abyss be deep, yet, if you are only in earnest, I am certain you will clear it. Surely you can confide in my disinterested friendship. I would not expose your life to danger if I were not so well aware of your strength and dexterity. ” The lion's blood waxed hot, and began to boil in his veins. He flung himself with all his might into space. But he could not clear the chasm; so down he tumbled headlong, and was killed by the fall.
一头狮子正沿着山谷追逐一只羚羊。它几乎就要抓住它了，眼中满是渴望，期待着一顿丰盛的美餐。猎物似乎完全没有逃脱的可能；因为一条深谷挡住了猎人和猎物的去路。但是，敏捷的羚羊积蓄了所有的力量，像离弦之箭般飞跃过峡谷，停在了另一侧的岩石峭壁上。狮子猛地停了下来。就在这时，它的一个朋友恰巧就在附近。那个朋友是狐狸。“什么！”他说道：“以你的力量和敏捷，怎会向一只弱小的羚羊屈服？你只需下定决心，就能创造奇迹。即便深渊深不可测，只要你真心实意，我相信你一定能够跨越它。你完全可以信赖我这纯粹的友谊。如果不是深知你的力量和灵巧，我绝不会让你身陷险境。”狮子的血液沸腾起来，在他血管中翻腾。他使出浑身解数纵身跃入空中。但他却无法越过深渊；于是他头朝下坠落，摔死了。
FINDING THE THUMBSCREW: A Strategic Plan of Action We all have resistances. We live with a perpetual armor around ourselves to defend against change and the intrusive actions of friends and rivals. We would like nothing more than to be left to do tilings our own way. Constantly butting up against these resistances will cost you a lot of energy. One of die most important things to realize about people, though, is that diey all have a weakness, some part of their psychological armor that will not resist, that will bend to your will if you find it and push on it. Some people wear their weaknesses openly, otiiers disguise diem. Those who disguise them are often die ones most effectively undone through that one chink in their armor.
找到制胜法宝：行动策略 我们每个人都有阻力。我们总是给自己筑起一道坚固的盔甲，抵御变化以及朋友和对手的侵扰。我们最渴望的莫过于按照自己的方式行事。然而，不断地与这些阻力对抗会消耗你大量的精力。但关于人，最重要的一点是，每个人都有弱点，他们心理盔甲的某些部分无法抵挡，如果你找到它并加以利用，它就会屈服于你的意志。有些人毫不掩饰自己的弱点，有些人则将其隐藏起来。那些隐藏弱点的人，往往最容易被盔甲上的那道裂缝所击败。
In planning your assault, keep these principles in mind:
在策划进攻时，请牢记以下原则：
Pay Attention to Gestures and Unconscious Signals. As Sigmund Freud remarked, “No mortal can keep a secret. If his lips are silent, he chatters with his fingertips; betrayal oozes out of him at every pore.” This is a critical concept in the search for a person's weaknessit is revealed by seemingly unimportant gestures and passing words.
注意肢体语言和无意识信号。正如西格蒙德·弗洛伊德所说：“没有人能保守秘密。即使他嘴上不说，指尖也会窃窃私语；背叛会从他身体的每一个毛孔渗出。”这是探寻一个人弱点的关键所在——看似无关紧要的肢体语言和不经意的言语，都可能暴露弱点。
The key is not only what you look for but where and how you look. Everyday conversation supplies the richest mine of weaknesses, so train yourself to listen. Start by always seeming interestedthe appearance of a sympathetic ear will spur anyone to talk. A clever trick, often used by the nineteenth-century French statesman Talleyrand, is to appear to open up to the other person, to share a secret with diem. It can be completely made up, or it can be real but of no great importance to youthe important thing is that it should seem to come from the heart. This will usually elicit a response that is not only as frank as yours but more genuinea response that reveals a weakness.
关键不仅在于你寻找什么，还在于你在哪里以及如何寻找。日常对话蕴藏着最丰富的弱点，所以要训练自己倾听。首先，要始终表现得感兴趣——表现出善解人意会促使任何人开口。一个巧妙的技巧，19世纪法国政治家塔列朗经常使用，就是假装向对方敞开心扉，分享一个秘密。这个秘密可以完全虚构，也可以是真实的，但对你来说无关紧要——重要的是，它要显得发自内心。这通常会引出一个不仅和你一样坦诚，而且更加真诚的回应——一个会暴露弱点的回应。
If you suspect that someone has a particular soft spot, probe for it indirectly. If, for instance, you sense diat a man has a need to be loved, openly flatter him. If he laps up your compliments, no matter how obvious, you are on die right track. Train your eye for detailshow someone tips a waiter, what delights a person, die hidden messages in clothes. Find people's idols, die things they worship and will do anything to getperhaps you can be die supplier of tiieir fantasies. Remember: Since we all try to hide our weaknesses, there is little to be learned from our conscious behavior. What oozes out in the littie things outside our conscious control is what you want to know.
如果你怀疑某人有特别的弱点，那就间接地去探寻。例如，如果你感觉到一个男人渴望被爱，那就直接赞美他。如果他欣然接受你的赞美，无论多么明显，你都找对了方向。训练自己观察细节——比如人们给服务员小费的方式，什么能让人感到愉悦，衣服里隐藏的信息。找到人们的偶像，他们崇拜并愿意为之付出一切的事物——也许你可以成为他们幻想的提供者。记住：因为我们都试图隐藏自己的弱点，所以从我们有意识的行为中能了解到的信息很少。你真正想了解的是那些在我们意识控制之外、悄然流露出来的小事。
Find the Helpless Child. Most weaknesses begin in childhood, before die self builds up compensatory defenses. Perhaps the child was pampered or indulged in a particular area, or perhaps a certain emotional need went unfulfilled; as he or she grows older, the indulgence or the deficiency may be buried but never disappears. Knowing about a childhood need gives you a powerful key to a person's weakness.
找到那个无助的孩童。大多数弱点都始于童年，在个体建立起补偿性防御机制之前。或许孩子在某个方面被过度溺爱或纵容，又或许某种情感需求未能得到满足；随着年龄的增长，这种溺爱或缺失或许会被掩埋，但从未真正消失。了解一个人童年的需求，就如同掌握了一把通往其弱点的利器。
One sign of this weakness is that when you touch on it the person will often act like a child. Be on the lookout, then, for any behavior tiiat should
这种弱点的一个表现是，当你触及它时，这个人往往会像个孩子一样。因此，要留意任何可能表明存在这种弱点的行为。
have been outgrown. If your victims or rivals went without something important, such as parental support, when they were children, supply it, or its facsimile. If they reveal a secret taste, a hidden indulgence, indulge it. In either case they will be unable to resist you.
已经不再适合你了。如果你的受害者或竞争对手在童年时期缺乏某些重要的东西，例如父母的关爱，那就弥补他们的缺失，或者提供类似的替代品。如果他们透露了某种秘密的爱好或嗜好，那就满足他们。无论哪种情况，他们都无法抗拒你。
Look for Contrasts. An overt trait often conceals its opposite. People who thump their chests are often big cowards; a prudish exterior may hide a lascivious soul; the uptight are often screaming for adventure; the shy are dying for attention. By probing beyond appearances, you will often find people's weaknesses in the opposite of the qualities they reveal to you.
寻找反差。一种外在的特质往往掩盖着它的反面。那些自以为是的人往往胆小如鼠；矜持的外表下可能隐藏着一颗放荡不羁的心；拘谨的人往往渴望冒险；害羞的人渴望得到关注。通过深入探究表象之下，你常常会发现人们的弱点就隐藏在他们所展现的品质的反面。
Find the Weak Link. Sometimes in your search for weaknesses it is not what but who that matters. In today's versions of the court, there is often someone behind the scenes who has a great deal of power, a tremendous influence over the person superficially on top. These behind-the-scenes powerbrokers are die group's weak link: Win their favor and you indirectly influence the king. Alternatively, even in a group of people acting with the appearance of one willas when a group under attack closes ranks to resist an outsiderthere is always a weak link in the chain. Find die one person who will bend under pressure.
找到薄弱环节。有时，在寻找弱点时，重要的不是弱点是什么，而是弱点是谁。在当今的宫廷中，往往存在一个幕后操纵者，他们拥有巨大的权力，对表面上的掌权者有着巨大的影响力。这些幕后操纵者就是团队的薄弱环节：赢得他们的青睐，你就能间接地影响国王。或者，即使在一个表面上团结一致的群体中——例如，当一个群体受到攻击时会团结起来抵抗外敌——也总会存在一个薄弱环节。找到一个会在压力下屈服的人。
Fill the Void. The two main emotional voids to fill are insecurity and un-happiness. The insecure are suckers for any kind of social validation; as for the chronically unhappy, look for die roots of their unhappiness. The insecure and the unhappy are the people least able to disguise dieir weaknesses. The ability to fill dieir emotional voids is a great source of power, and an indefinitely prolongable one.
填补内心的空虚。需要填补的两大主要情感空虚是缺乏安全感和不快乐。缺乏安全感的人很容易获得任何形式的社会认同；而对于长期不快乐的人，则需要探寻他们不快乐的根源。缺乏安全感和不快乐的人最难掩饰自己的弱点。填补这些情感空虚的能力是一种强大的力量源泉，而且这种力量可以无限延续。
Feed on Uncontrollable Emotions. The uncontrollable emotion can be a paranoid feara fear disproportionate to the situationor any base motive such as lust, greed, vanity, or hatred. People in the grip of these emotions often cannot control diemselves, and you can do the controlling for them.
利用无法控制的情绪。这种无法控制的情绪可能是妄想恐惧——与实际情况不成比例的恐惧——或是任何卑劣的动机，例如欲望、贪婪、虚荣或仇恨。被这些情绪控制的人往往无法自控，而你可以替他们控制自己。
OBSERVANCES OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Observance I
观察 I
In 1615 the thirty-year-old bishop of Lucon, later known as Cardinal Richelieu, gave a speech before representatives of die three estates of France clergy, nobility, and commoners. Richelieu had been chosen to serve as the moudipiece for the clergyan immense responsibility for a man still young and not particularly well known. On all of the important issues of the day, the speech followed the Church line. But near the end of it Richelieu did something that had nodiing to do with the Church and everything to do with his career. He turned to die throne of the fifteen-year-old King Louis XIII, and to die Queen Modier Marie de' Medicis, who sat beside
1615年，年仅三十岁的吕孔主教，后来的红衣主教黎塞留，在法国三个等级——教士、贵族和平民——的代表面前发表了演讲。黎塞留被选中担任教会的代言人，对于一个当时还很年轻、名气也不大的主教来说，这是一项极其重大的责任。在所有重要的议题上，他的演讲都遵循了教会的立场。但在演讲接近尾声时，黎塞留做了一件与教会关系不大，却与他个人的政治生涯息息相关的事。他转向了年仅十五岁的路易十三国王的王座，以及坐在他身旁的王后莫迪埃·玛丽·德·美第奇。
Then what did his dear friend do He cautiously made his way down to the bottom of the ravine, and there, out in the open space and the free air, seeing that the lion wanted neither flattery nor obedience now, he set to work to pay the last sad rites to his dead friend, and in a month picked his bones clean.
那么，他亲爱的朋友做了什么呢？他小心翼翼地走到峡谷底部，在那里，在开阔的空间和自由的空气中，见狮子现在既不想要奉承也不想要服从，便开始为死去的朋友举行最后的悲伤仪式，一个月后，他把狮子的骨头啃得干干净净。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Ivan Kriloff, 1768-1844
伊万·克里洛夫，1768-1844
IRVING l.AZAK
欧文·阿扎克
[Hollywood super-agent] Irving Paul Lazar was once anxious to sell [studio mogul] Jack L. Warner a play. “I had a long meeting with him today,” Lazar explained [to screenwriter Garson Kanin], “but I didn 't mention it, I didn't even bring it up.”
好莱坞超级经纪人欧文·保罗·拉扎尔曾急于向制片厂大亨杰克·L·华纳推销一部剧本。“我今天和他开了个很长的会，”拉扎尔向编剧加森·卡宁解释说，“但我没提这件事，我甚至都没提起过。”
“Why not ” I asked. “Because I'm going to wait until the weekend after next, when I go to Palm Springs.” “I don't understand.” “You don't I go to Palm Springs every weekend, but Warner isn 't going this weekend. He's got a preview or something. So he's not coming down till the next weekend, so that's when I'm going to bring it up.” "Irving, I'm more and
“为什么不行？”我问。“因为我要等到下下个周末，我去棕榈泉的时候再说。”“我不明白。”“你不明白。我每个周末都去棕榈泉，但华纳这周末不去。他有个预演什么的。所以他要到下个周末才会来，到时候我再跟他提这件事。”“欧文，我更……”
LAW 33 273
法律 33 273
more confused.“ ”Look,1' said Irving impatiently, “I know what I'm doing. I know how to sell Warner. This is a type of material that he's uneasy with, so I have to hit him with it hard and suddenly to get an okay.” “But why Palm Springs” “Because in Palm Springs, every day he goes to the baths at The Spa. And that's where I'm going to be when he's there. Now there's a thing about Jack: He's eighty and he's very vain, and he doesn't like people to see him naked. So when I walk up to him naked at The Spa / mean he's nakedwell, I'm naked too, but I don't care who sees me. He does. And I walk up to him naked, and I start to talk to him about this thing, he 'II be very embarrassed. And he'll want to get away from me, and the easiest way is to say ' Yes,' because he knows if he says 'No,' then I'm going to stick with him, and stay right on it, and not give up. So to get rid of me, he'll probably say, 'Yes.'” Two weeks later, I read of the acquisition of this particular property by Warner Brothers. I phoned Lazarand asked how it had been accomplished. “How do you think” he asked. “In the buff, that's how ... just the way I told you it was going to work.”
更困惑了。“听着，”欧文不耐烦地说，“我知道自己在做什么。我知道怎么说服华纳。这种题材他不太能接受，所以我得突然给他来个狠的，才能让他同意。” “但为什么是棕榈泉？”“因为在棕榈泉，他每天都去水疗中心泡澡。他去的时候我也会在那里。杰克这个人有点儿……他八十岁了，很爱慕虚荣，不喜欢别人看到他裸体。所以，如果我在水疗中心赤身裸体地走到他面前——我的意思是，他当时是裸体的，好吧，我也裸体，但我不在乎谁看到我。他却很在乎。如果我赤身裸体地走到他面前，开始跟他谈这件事，他会非常尴尬。他会想方设法躲开我，最简单的办法就是答应我，因为他知道如果他说‘不’，我就会一直缠着他，不肯放弃。所以为了摆脱我，他很可能会答应我。”两周后，我读到了华纳兄弟收购这处房产的消息。我打电话给拉扎兰德，问他是怎么做到的。“你觉得呢？”他问。“一丝不挂，就是这样……就像我之前跟你说的那样。”
hollywood,
好莱坞，
Garson Kanin,
兔子男孩
Louis, as the regent ruling France until her son reached his majority. Everyone expected Richelieu to say the usual kind words to the young king. Instead, however, he looked directly at and only at the queen mother. Indeed his speech ended in long and fulsome praise of her, praise so glowing that it actually offended some in the Church. But the smile on the queen's face as she lapped up Richelieu's compliments was unforgettable.
路易王后作为摄政王，在她儿子成年之前统治法国。所有人都以为黎塞留会像往常一样对年轻的国王说些恭维话。然而，他却只盯着王太后一人。事实上，他的讲话最后是对她长篇大论、溢美之词的赞美，这些赞美之词如此热情洋溢，甚至冒犯了教会中的一些人。但王后欣然接受黎塞留的赞美时脸上的笑容，却令人难忘。
A year later the queen mother appointed Richelieu secretary of state for foreign affairs, an incredible coup for the young bishop. He had now entered the inner circle of power, and he studied the workings of the court as if it were the machinery of a watch. An Italian, Concino Concini, was the queen mother's favorite, or rather her lover, a role that made him perhaps the most powerful man in France. Concini was vain and foppish, and Richelieu played him perfectlyattending to him as if he were the king. Within months Richelieu had become one of Concini's favorites. But something happened in 1617 that turned everything upside down: the young king, who up until then had shown every sign of being an idiot, had Concini murdered and his most important associates imprisoned. In so doing Louis took command of the country with one blow, sweeping the queen mother aside.
一年后，王太后任命黎塞留为外交大臣，这对这位年轻的主教来说无疑是一次惊人的胜利。他由此跻身权力核心，对宫廷的运作了如指掌，如同研究钟表的精密运转。意大利人康奇诺·康奇尼是王太后的宠臣，或者更确切地说，是她的情人，这使他或许成为当时法国最有权势的人。康奇尼虚荣浮夸，而黎塞留则对他百般呵护，如同对待国王一般。短短几个月内，黎塞留就成了康奇尼的宠臣之一。然而，1617年发生的一件事彻底改变了一切：这位此前一直表现得愚钝的年轻国王，下令谋杀了康奇尼，并将他最重要的几位亲信囚禁起来。路易十四借此一举夺得政权，将王太后扫地出门。
Had Richelieu played it wrong He had been close to both Concini and Marie de Medicis, whose advisers and ministers were now all out of favor, some even arrested. The queen mother herself was shut up in the Louvre, a virtual prisoner. Richelieu wasted no time. If everyone was deserting Marie de Medicis, he would stand by her. He knew Louis could not get rid of her, for the king was still very young, and had in any case always been inordinately attached to her. As Marie's only remaining powerful friend, Richelieu filled the valuable function of liaison between the king and his mother. In return he received her protection, and was able to survive the palace coup, even to thrive. Over the next few years the queen mother grew still more dependent on him, and in 1622 she repaid him for his loyalty: Through the intercession of her allies in Rome, Richelieu was elevated to the powerful rank of cardinal.
如果黎塞留的策略失误，后果不堪设想。他曾与孔奇尼和玛丽·德·美第奇关系密切，而如今玛丽的顾问和大臣们都已失势，有的甚至被捕。王太后本人也被软禁在卢浮宫，形同囚徒。黎塞留没有丝毫犹豫。既然所有人都离弃了玛丽·德·美第奇，他就要站在她这边。他知道路易无法摆脱她，因为国王当时还很年轻，而且无论如何，他一直对她格外依恋。作为玛丽唯一剩下的有权势的朋友，黎塞留扮演了国王与其母亲之间重要的联络人角色。作为回报，他得到了玛丽的庇护，得以在宫廷政变中幸存下来，甚至还飞黄腾达。在接下来的几年里，王太后对他的依赖与日俱增，并在1622年回报了他的忠诚：通过她在罗马的盟友的斡旋，黎塞留被擢升为权势显赫的红衣主教。
By 1623 King Louis was in trouble. He had no one he could trust to advise him, and although he was now a young man instead of a boy, he remained childish in spirit, and affairs of state came hard to him. Now that he had taken the throne, Marie was no longer the regent and theoretically had no power, but she still had her son's ear, and she kept telling him that Richelieu was his only possible savior. At first Louis would have none of ithe hated the cardinal with a passion, only tolerating him out of love for Marie. In the end, however, isolated in the court and crippled by his own indecisiveness, he yielded to his mother and made Richelieu first his chief councilor and later prime minister.
到了1623年，路易国王陷入了困境。他没有可以信任的顾问，虽然他已不再是少年，而是青年，但他的心智依然稚嫩，处理国事对他来说十分吃力。如今他已登基，玛丽不再是摄政王，理论上也失去了权力，但她仍然能影响儿子，并不断劝说他，黎塞留是他唯一的救星。起初，路易对此嗤之以鼻——他恨透了这位红衣主教，只是出于对玛丽的爱才勉强容忍他。然而，最终，在宫廷中孤立无援，又被自己的优柔寡断所困扰，他还是屈服于母亲，先是任命黎塞留为首席顾问，后来又任命他为首相。
Now Richelieu no longer needed Marie de Medicis. He stopped visiting and courting her, stopped listening to her opinions, even argued with her and opposed her wishes. Instead he concentrated on the king, making himself indispensable to his new master. All the previous premiers, understanding the king's childishness, had tried to keep him out of trouble; the
如今黎塞留不再需要玛丽·德·美第奇了。他不再拜访她，不再追求她，不再听取她的意见，甚至与她争吵，反对她的意愿。相反，他把全部精力都放在国王身上，使自己成为这位新主人不可或缺的人物。此前所有的首相都了解国王的幼稚，都尽力让他远离麻烦；
shrewd Richelieu played him differendy, deliberately pushing him into one ambitious project after another, such as a crusade against the Huguenots and finally an extended war with Spain. The immensity of these projects only made the king more dependent on his powerful premier, the only man able to keep order in the realm. And so, for the next eighteen years, Richelieu, exploiting the king's weaknesses, governed and molded France according to his own vision, unifying the country and making it a strong European power for centuries to come. Interpretation
精明的黎塞留对他另眼相待，故意让他接连投身于一个又一个雄心勃勃的计划，例如对胡格诺派的十字军东征，以及最终与西班牙的旷日持久的战争。这些计划的庞大规模反而使国王更加依赖他这位权势滔天的首相，因为只有他才能维持王国的秩序。因此，在接下来的十八年里，黎塞留利用国王的弱点，按照自己的设想统治和塑造了法国，统一了国家，并使其成为未来几个世纪的欧洲强国。
Richelieu saw everything as a military campaign, and no strategic move was more important to him than discovering his enemy's weaknesses and applying pressure to them. As early as his speech in 1615, he was looking for the weak link in die chain of power, and he saw that it was die queen mother. Not that Marie was obviously weakshe governed both France and her son; but Richelieu saw that she was really an insecure woman who needed constant masculine attention. He showered her with affection and respect, even toadying up to her favorite, Concini. He knew the day would come when the king would take over, but he also recognized that Louis loved his mother dearly and would always remain a child in relation to her. The way to control Louis, then, was not by gaining his favor, which could change overnight, but by gaining sway over his motiier, for whom his affection would never change.
黎塞留将一切都视为一场军事战役，对他而言，最重要的战略举措莫过于发现敌人的弱点并施加压力。早在1615年的演说中，他就在寻找权力链条中的薄弱环节，而他发现这个薄弱环节正是王太后。并非玛丽王太后明显软弱——她既治理着法国，又治理着她的儿子；但黎塞留看出她其实是一个缺乏安全感的女人，需要男性持续不断的关注。他给予她无微不至的关爱和尊重，甚至对她最宠爱的侍臣康奇尼阿谀奉承。他知道国王终将继承王位，但也明白路易深爱着他的母亲，在她面前永远像个孩子。因此，控制路易的方法并非赢得他的宠信（因为这种宠信可能一夜之间改变），而是掌控他的王太后，因为王太后对王太后的爱永远不会改变。
Once Richelieu had the position he desiredprime ministerhe discarded die queen mother, moving on to die next weak link in the chain: the king's own character. There was a part of him diat would always be a helpless child in need of higher authority. It was on the foundation of the king's weakness that Richelieu established his own power and fame.
黎塞留如愿以偿地成为首相后，便抛弃了王太后，转而攻击下一个薄弱环节：国王自身的性格。国王内心深处始终保留着一个需要更高权威的无助孩子。黎塞留正是凭借国王的软弱，才得以建立起自己的权力和声望。
Remember: When entering the court, find the weak link. The person in control is often not the king or queen; it is someone behind the scenes the favorite, the husband or wife, even flie court fool. This person may have more weaknesses than the king himself, because his power depends on all kinds of capricious factors outside his control.
记住：进入宫廷时，要找到薄弱环节。真正掌权的人往往不是国王或王后，而是幕后人物——可能是宠臣、配偶，甚至是宫廷弄臣。这个人可能比国王本人更有弱点，因为他的权力依赖于各种他无法控制的变幻莫测的因素。
Finally, when dealing with helpless children who cannot make decisions, play on their weakness and push them into bold ventures. They will have to depend on you even more, for you will become the adult figure whom they rely on to get them out of scrapes and to safety.
最后，面对那些无法做决定的无助孩子，要利用他们的弱点，鼓励他们进行大胆的尝试。这样一来，他们会更加依赖你，因为你将成为他们依靠的成年人，帮助他们摆脱困境，确保安全。
Observance II
遵守第二条
In December of 1925, guests at the swankiest hotel in Palm Beach, Florida, watched with interest as a mysterious man arrived in a Rolls-Royce driven by a Japanese chauffeur. Over the next few days they studied this handsome man, who walked widi an elegant cane, received telegrams at all hours, and only engaged in the briefest of conversations. He was a count, they heard, Count Victor Lustig, and he came from one of the wealthiest families in Europebut this was all they could find out.
1925年12月，佛罗里达州棕榈滩一家豪华酒店的客人们饶有兴致地看着一位神秘男子乘坐一辆由日本司机驾驶的劳斯莱斯抵达。接下来的几天里，他们仔细观察着这位英俊的男子：他拄着一根优雅的拐杖，随时接收电报，而且只与人进行简短的交谈。他们听说他是一位伯爵，维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵，出身于欧洲最富有的家族之一——但他们所能了解到的也就仅此而已。
Imagine their amazement, dien, when Lustig one day walked up to one of the least distinguished guests in the hotel, a Mr. Herman Loller,
想象一下，当卢斯蒂格有一天走到酒店里一位最不起眼的客人——赫尔曼·洛勒先生面前时，他们该有多么惊讶。
As time went on I came to look for the little weaknesses.... It's the little things that count. On one occasion, I worked on the president of a large bank in Omaha. The [phony] deal involved the purchase of the street railway system of Omaha, including a bridge across the Mississippi River My principals were supposedly German and I had to negotiate with Berlin. While awaiting word from them I introduced my fake mining-stock proposition. Since this man was rich, I decided to play for high stakes.... Meanwhile, I played golf with the banker, visited his home, and went to the theater with him and his wife. Though he showed some interest in my stock deal, he still wasn 't convinced. I had built it up to the point that an investment of $1,250,000 was required. Of this I was to put up $900,000, the banker $350,000. But still he hesitated. One evening when 1 was at his home for dinner I wore some perfumeCoty's “April Violets.” It was not then considered effeminate for a man to use a dash of perfume. The banker's wife thought it very lovely. “Where did you get it ” “It is a rare blend,” I told her, "especially made for me by a
随着时间的推移，我开始寻找那些细微的漏洞……细节决定成败。有一次，我设计了一个骗局，对象是奥马哈一家大型银行的总裁。这个（虚假的）交易涉及收购奥马哈的有轨电车系统，包括一座横跨密西西比河的大桥。我的委托人假扮成德国人，我需要与柏林方面进行谈判。在等待他们回复期间，我提出了我虚构的矿业股票投资方案。由于这个人很有钱，我决定赌一把……与此同时，我和这位银行家一起打高尔夫，拜访了他的家，还和他及他的妻子一起去看戏。虽然他对我的股票交易表现出了一些兴趣，但他仍然没有被说服。我把投资额提高到125万美元。其中我出资90万美元，银行家出资35万美元。但他仍然犹豫不决。一天晚上，我去他家吃晚饭，喷了些香水——科蒂的“四月紫罗兰”。那时，男人喷点香水并不被认为是娘娘腔。银行家的妻子觉得这香水很迷人。“你从哪儿弄来的？”我告诉她：“这是很特别的一款香水，是一位调香师专门为我调配的。”
French perfumer. Do you like it“ ”I love it,“ she replied. The following day I went through my effects and found two empty bottles. Both had come from France, but were empty. I went to a downtown department store and purchased ten ounces of Coty's ”April Violets.“ I poured this into the two French bottles, carefully sealed them, wrapped them in tissue paper. That evening 1 dropped by the banker's home and presented the two bottles to his wife. ”They were especially put up for me in Cologne, “ / told her. The next day the banker called at my hotel. His wife was enraptured by the perfume. She considered it the most wonderful, the most exotic fragrance she had ever used. I did not tell the banker he could get all he wanted right in Omaha. ”She said,“ the banker added, ”that I was fortunate to be associated with a man like you." From then on his attitude was changed, for he had complete faith in his wife's judgment. ... He parted with $350,000. This, incidentally was my biggest [con] score.
