法国调香师。你喜欢吗？“我太喜欢了，”她回答道。第二天，我整理行李时发现了两个空瓶子。它们都来自法国，但都是空的。我去了市中心的一家百货商店，买了十盎司科蒂的“四月紫罗兰”香水。我把香水倒进两个法国瓶子里，小心地封好，用薄纸包好。那天晚上，我顺道去了银行家家，把这两个瓶子送给了他妻子。“这是科隆特意为我准备的，”我告诉她。第二天，银行家来我住的酒店。他妻子被香水迷住了。她说这是她用过的最美妙、最异域风情的香水。我没有告诉银行家，他想要什么在奥马哈就能买到。“她说，”银行家补充道，“我很幸运能和您这样的人交往。”从那以后，他的态度就变了，因为他完全相信妻子的判断……他给了我35万美元。顺便说一句，这是我最大的一笔诈骗。
“YELLOW KID” WEIL,
“黄孩子”威尔
1875-1976
head of an engineering company, and entered into conversation with him. Loller had made his fortune only recendy, and forging social connections was very important to him. He felt honored and somewhat mtimidated by this sophisticated man, who spoke perfect English with a hint of a foreign accent. Over die days to come, the two became friends.
他是一位工程公司负责人，于是便与他攀谈起来。洛勒发家不久，建立人脉对他来说至关重要。这位举止优雅、英语流利，略带外国口音的男士让他既感到荣幸又有些畏惧。接下来的几天里，两人成了朋友。
Loller of course did most of the talking, and one night he confessed that his business was doing poorly, with more troubles ahead. In return, Lustig confided in his new friend that he too had serious money problemsCommunists had seized his family estate and all its assets. He was too old to learn a trade and go to work. Luckily he had found an answer“a money-making machine.” “You counterfeit” Loller whispered in half-shock. No, Lustig replied, explaining that through a secret chemical process, his machine could duplicate any paper currency with complete accuracy. Put in a dollar bill and six hours later you had two, both perfect. He proceeded to explain how the machine had been smuggled out of Europe, how die Germans had developed it to undermine the British, how it had supported the count for several years, and on and on. When Loller insisted on a demonstration, the two men went to Lustig's room, where the count produced a magnificent mahogany box fitted witii slots, cranks, and dials. Loller watched as Lustig inserted a dollar bill in die box. Sure enough, early die following morning Lustig pulled out two bills, still wet from die chemicals.
当然，洛勒才是话最多的人。一天晚上，他坦白说自己的生意不好做，而且未来还会遇到更多麻烦。作为回应，卢斯蒂格也向这位新朋友吐露了自己的困境——共产党没收了他家的庄园和所有资产。他年纪太大，学不了手艺，也干不了活。幸运的是，他找到了解决办法——一台“造钱机器”。“你是伪钞制造者？”洛勒半信半疑地低声问道。卢斯蒂格回答说，不，他解释说，通过一种秘密的化学工艺，他的机器可以完美复制任何纸币。放一张美元进去，六个小时后就能得到两张，而且都是完美的。他接着解释了这台机器是如何从欧洲走私出来的，德国人是如何开发它来削弱英国的，以及它是如何支撑伯爵多年的，等等等等。洛勒坚持要他演示一下，于是两人去了卢斯蒂格的房间。伯爵拿出一个精美的红木盒子，上面装有插槽、曲柄和拨盘。洛勒看着卢斯蒂格把一张一美元钞票放进印版盒里。果然，第二天一大早，卢斯蒂格就从盒子里掏出了两张钞票，上面还残留着印版化学药剂的湿润。
Lustig gave the notes to Loller, who immediately took the bills to a local bankwhich accepted them as genuine. Now the businessman feverishly begged Lustig to sell him a machine. The count explained diat there was only one in existence, so Loller made him a high offer: $25,000, then a considerable amount (more than $400,000 in today's terms). Even so, Lustig seemed reluctant: He did not feel right about making his friend pay so much. Yet finally he agreed to the sale. After all, he said, “I suppose it matters little what you pay me. You are, after all, going to recover the amount within a few days by duplicating your own bills.” Making Loller swear never to reveal the machine's existence to odier people, Lustig accepted the money. Later the same day he checked out of the hotel. A year later, after many futile attempts at duplicating bills, Loller finally went to the police with the story of how Count Lustig had conned him with a pair of dollar bills, some chemicals, and a worthless mahogany box. Interpretation
卢斯蒂格把钞票交给洛勒，洛勒立即拿着钞票去当地银行，银行确认它们是真钞。现在，这位商人急切地恳求卢斯蒂格卖给他一台机器。卢斯蒂格解释说，这种机器世上只有一台，于是洛勒开出了很高的价钱：25000美元，这在当时是一笔巨款（按今天的价值计算超过40万美元）。即便如此，卢斯蒂格似乎还是有些犹豫：他觉得让朋友付这么多钱不太合适。但最终他还是同意了。毕竟，他说：“我想你付给我多少钱并不重要。反正你几天之内就能通过复制钞票把钱赚回来。”卢斯蒂格让洛勒发誓永远不向其他人透露机器的存在，然后收下了钱。当天晚些时候，他就退房离开了酒店。一年后，在多次复制钞票失败后，洛勒终于向警方报案，讲述了卢斯蒂格伯爵如何用两张一美元钞票、一些化学品和一个毫无价值的红木盒子骗取了他的钱财。
Count Lustig had an eagle eye for other people's weaknesses. He saw them in die smallest gesture. Loller, for instance, overtipped waiters, seemed nervous in conversation with the concierge, talked loudly about his business. His weakness, Lustig knew, was his need for social validation and for die respect that he thought his wealth had earned him. He was also chronically insecure. Lustig had come to the hotel to hunt for prey. In Loller he homed in on the perfect suckera man hungering for someone to fill his psychic voids.
卢斯蒂格伯爵对别人的弱点有着敏锐的洞察力。他甚至能从最细微的举动中发现端倪。比如，洛勒给服务员的小费总是过高，和门房交谈时显得紧张不安，还大声谈论自己的生意。卢斯蒂格知道，他的弱点在于渴望得到社会认可，渴望获得他认为财富理应带来的尊重。此外，他还极度缺乏安全感。卢斯蒂格来到这家酒店就是为了寻找猎物。他认定洛勒就是个完美的冤大头，一个渴望有人填补内心空虚的男人。
In offering Loller his friendship, then, Lustig knew he was offering him the immediate respect of the other guests. As a count, Lustig was also offer-
因此，卢斯蒂格向洛勒示好，也知道这能立即赢得其他宾客的尊重。作为伯爵，卢斯蒂格还获得了——
ing the newly rich businessman access to the glittering world of old wealth. And for the coup de grace, he apparendy owned a machine mat would rescue Loller from his worries. It would even put him on a par with Lustig himself, who had also used the machine to maintain his status. No wonder Loller took the bait.
这使得这位新晋富豪得以进入旧时富豪的奢华世界。更重要的是，他似乎拥有一台机器，可以帮洛勒摆脱困境。这台机器甚至能让他与卢斯蒂格本人比肩，卢斯蒂格也曾利用这台机器来维持自己的地位。难怪洛勒会上钩。
Remember: When searching for suckers, always look for the dissatisfied, me unhappy, the insecure. Such people are riddled with weaknesses and have needs mat you can fill. Their neediness is the groove in which you place your thumbnail and turn diem at will.
记住：寻找冤大头时，永远要找那些不满现状、不快乐、缺乏安全感的人。这些人弱点重重，有很多需求等着你去满足。他们的这种需求就像一个凹槽，你只需轻轻一按，就能轻易得手。
Observance III
遵守第三条
In the year 1559, the French king Henri II died in a jousting exhibition. His son assumed the throne, becoming Francis II, but in the background stood Henri's wife and queen, Catherine de' Medicis, a woman who had long ago proven her skill in affairs of state. When Francis died the next year, Catherine took control of the country as regent to her next son in line of succession, the future Charles IX, a mere ten years old at the time.
1559年，法国国王亨利二世在一场马上比武中身亡。他的儿子继承王位，成为弗朗索瓦二世。然而，亨利二世的妻子兼王后凯瑟琳·德·美第奇早已在幕后掌控大局，她早已展现出卓越的治国才能。次年弗朗索瓦二世驾崩后，凯瑟琳摄政，辅佐她的下一个继承人——当时年仅十岁的查理九世。
The main threats to the queen's power were Antoine de Bourbon, king of Navarre, and his brother, Louis, die powerful prince of Conde, bom of whom could claim the right to serve as regent instead of Catherine, who, after all, was Italiana foreigner. Catherine quickly appointed Antoine lieutenant general of the kingdom, a title that seemed to satisfy his ambition. It also meant that he had to remain in court, where Catherine could keep an eye on him. Her next move proved smarter still: Antoine had a notorious weakness for young women, so she assigned one of her most attractive maids of honor, Louise de Rouet, to seduce him. Now Antoine's intimate, Louise reported all of his actions to Catherine. The move worked so brilliantly that Catiierine assigned another of her maids to Prince Conde, and thus was formed her escadron volant “flying squadron”of young girls whom she used to keep the unsuspecting males in the court under her control.
对女王权力构成主要威胁的是纳瓦拉国王安托万·德·波旁和他的弟弟、强大的孔代亲王路易。路易有权取代身为意大利外邦人的凯瑟琳担任摄政。凯瑟琳迅速任命安托万为王国副将军，这个头衔似乎满足了他的野心。这也意味着他必须留在宫廷，以便凯瑟琳能够监视他。她的下一步行动更加高明：安托万素来好色，于是她指派自己最迷人的侍女之一路易丝·德·鲁埃去引诱他。路易丝成了安托万的密友，并将他的一切行径都汇报给了凯瑟琳。这一招果然奏效，凯瑟琳又指派了另一位侍女去侍奉孔代亲王，就这样，她组建了一支由年轻女孩组成的“飞行中队”，用来控制宫廷中那些毫无防备的男性。
In 1572 Catherine married off her daughter, Marguerite de Valois, to Henri, the son of Antoine and the new king of Navarre. To put a family that had always struggled against her so close to power was a dangerous move, so to make sure of Henri's loyalty she unleashed on him the loveliest member of her “flying squadron,” Charlotte de Beaune Semblancay, baroness of Sauves. Catherine did this even diough Henri was married to her daughter. Within weeks, Marguerite de Valois wrote in her memoirs, “Mme. de Sauves so completely ensnared my husband that we no longer slept together, nor even conversed.”
1572年，凯瑟琳将女儿玛格丽特·德·瓦卢瓦嫁给了安托万之子、新任纳瓦拉国王亨利。让一个一直与她作对的家族如此接近权力中心，无疑是一步险棋。为了确保亨利的忠诚，她将自己“宠妃团”中最美艳动人的夏洛特·德·博讷·桑布朗赛（索沃斯男爵夫人）许配给了亨利。即便亨利已娶了她的女儿，凯瑟琳依然如此行事。几周之内，玛格丽特·德·瓦卢瓦在回忆录中写道：“索沃斯夫人彻底俘获了我的丈夫，我们甚至不再同床共枕，也不再交谈。”
The baroness was an excellent spy and helped to keep Henri under Catherine's thumb. When the queen's youngest son, the Duke of Alencon, grew so close to Henri that she feared the two might plot against her, she assigned the baroness to him as well. This most infamous member of the flying squadron quickly seduced Alencon, and soon the two young men fought over her and tiieir friendship quickly ended, along with any danger of a conspiracy.
这位女男爵是个出色的间谍，帮助凯瑟琳牢牢控制着亨利。当女王最小的儿子阿朗松公爵与亨利走得太近，以至于女王担心两人会密谋反对她时，她也把女男爵派去监视阿朗松。这位飞行中队中最臭名昭著的成员很快就迷住了阿朗松，不久之后，两个年轻人为了她争风吃醋，他们的友谊也迅速破裂，阴谋的危险也随之消失。
And while I am on the subject, there is another fact that deserves mention. It is this. A man shows his character just in the way in which he deals with triflesfor then he is off his guard. This will often afford a good opportunity of observing the boundless egoism of a man's nature, and his total lack of consideration for others; and if these defects show themselves in small things, or merely in his general demeanour, you will find that they also underlie his action in matters of importance, although he may disguise the fact. This is an opportunity which should not be missed. If in the little affairs of every daythe trifles of life ...a man is inconsiderate and seeks only what is advantageous or convenient to himself, to the prejudice of others' rights; if he appropriates to himself that which belongs to all alike, you may be sure there is no justice in his heart, and that he would be a scoundrel on a wholesale scale, only that law and compulsion bind his hands.
既然说到这儿，还有一点值得一提。那就是：一个人的品格往往体现在他处理琐事的方式上，因为那时他卸下了防备。这常常能让我们有机会观察到他天性中无止境的利己主义，以及他对他人漠不关心的态度；如果这些缺点在小事上，或者仅仅体现在他的一贯举止中，你就会发现，即使他可能掩饰不住，这些缺点也同样潜藏在他处理重要事情的背后。这是一个不容错过的机会。如果一个人在日常琐事中——生活中的琐碎之事……都缺乏同理心，只追求对自己有利或方便的东西，损害他人的权利；如果他将属于所有人的东西据为己有，那么你就可以断定，他心中毫无正义可言，他简直就是个彻头彻尾的恶棍，只是法律和强制力限制了他的行为。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
When the two armies [Julius Caesar's and Pompey's] were come into Pharsalia, and both encamped there, Pompey's thoughts ran the same way as they had done before, against fighting.... But those who were about him were greatly confident of success ... as if they had already conquered.... The cavalry especially were obstinate for fighting, being splendidly armed and bravely mounted, and valuing themselves upon the fine horses they kept, and upon their own handsome persons; as also upon the advantage of their numbers, for they were five thousand against one thousand of Caesar's. Nor were the numbers of the infantry less disproportionate, there being forty-five thousand of Pompey's against twenty-two thousand of the enemy. [The next day! whilst the infantry was thus sharply engaged in the main battle, on the flank Pompey 's horse rode up confidently, and opened [his cavalry's] ranks very wide, that they might surround the right wing of Caesar. But before they engaged, Caesar's cohorts rushed out and attacked them, and did not dart their javelins at a distance, nor strike at the thighs and legs, as they usually did in close battle, but aimed at their faces. For thus
当两军（凯撒和庞培的军队）进入法萨利亚并安营扎寨时，庞培的想法和之前一样，依然是抗拒战斗……但他身边的人却信心满满，仿佛胜券在握……骑兵尤其顽强，他们装备精良，骑兵英勇，对自己的骏马和英俊的外表都十分自信；他们也对自己的人数优势引以为傲，因为他们有五千人对凯撒的一千人。步兵的人数也同样悬殊，庞培有四万五千人对敌军两万两千人。[第二天！当步兵正激烈投入主战时，庞培的骑兵从侧翼自信地疾驰而来，将骑兵的阵型拉得极宽，企图包围凯撒的右翼。然而，在交战之前，凯撒的骑兵大队便冲出包围圈，发起攻击。他们没有像近战那样远距离投掷标枪，也没有攻击敌人的大腿和小腿，而是瞄准了敌人的面部。
Interpretation
解释
Catherine had seen very early on the sway mat a mistress has over a man of power: Her own husband, Henri II, had kept one of the most infamous mistresses of them all, Diane de Poitiers. What Catherine learned from the experience was that a man like her husband wanted to feel he could win a woman over widiout having to rely on his status, which he had inherited rather dian earned. And such a need contained a huge blind spot: As long as die woman began die affair by acting as if she had been conquered, die man would fail to notice that as time passed the mistress had come to hold power over him, as Diane de Poitiers did over Henri. It was Cadierine's strategy to turn this weakness to her advantage, using it as a way to conquer and control men. All she had to do was unleash the loveliest women in the court, her “flying squadron,” on men whom she knew shared her husband's vulnerability.
凯瑟琳很早就见识过情妇对权贵男人的影响力：她的丈夫亨利二世就曾拥有过一位臭名昭著的情妇——黛安·德·波蒂埃。凯瑟琳从这段经历中明白，像她丈夫这样的男人渴望赢得女人的心，却又不想依赖自己继承而非靠自身努力获得的地位。而这种需求却隐藏着一个巨大的盲点：只要女人一开始表现得像是被征服了一般，男人就不会察觉到，随着时间的推移，情妇已经反过来掌控了他，就像黛安·德·波蒂埃掌控亨利一样。凯瑟琳的策略正是利用了这种弱点，以此来征服和控制男人。她只需将宫廷中最美丽的女人——她的“飞女郎”——派去勾引那些她知道和她丈夫一样有弱点的男人即可。
Remember: Always look for passions and obsessions that cannot be controlled. The stronger the passion, the more vulnerable die person. This may seem surprising, for passionate people look strong. In fact, however, they are simply filling die stage with dieir theatricality, distracting people from how weak and helpless they really are. A man's need to conquer women actually reveals a tremendous helplessness that has made suckers out of them for thousands of years. Look at the part of a person that is most visibletheir greed, dieir lust, tiieir intense fear. These are the emotions they cannot conceal, and over which diey have the least control. And what people cannot control, you can control for diem.
记住：永远要留意那些无法控制的激情和执念。激情越强烈，人就越脆弱。这或许令人惊讶，因为充满激情的人看起来很强大。然而，事实上，他们只是用戏剧化的表演来掩盖自己内心的软弱和无助。男人征服女人的欲望，实际上暴露了他们内心深处的无助，这种无助让他们在数千年来一直沦为受害者。观察一个人最显而易见的部分——他们的贪婪、欲望和强烈的恐惧。这些是他们无法掩饰的情绪，也是他们最无法控制的。而别人无法控制的东西，你却可以替他们掌控。
Observance IV
第四条规定
Arabella Huntington, wife of die great late-nineteentii-century railroad magnate Collis P. Huntington, came from humble origins and always struggled for social recognition among her wealdiy peers. When she gave a party in her San Francisco mansion, few of die social elite would show up; most of diem took her for a gold digger, not their kind. Because of her husband's fabulous wealdi, art dealers courted her, but widi such condescension they obviously saw her as an upstart. Only one man of consequence treated her differentiy: the dealer Joseph Duveen.
阿拉贝拉·亨廷顿是十九世纪末铁路大亨科利斯·P·亨廷顿的妻子，她出身卑微，始终难以在富裕的同辈人中获得认可。每当她在旧金山的豪宅举办派对，鲜少有上流人士到场；他们大多认为她是个拜金女，与他们格格不入。尽管丈夫家境殷实，艺术品经销商们仍对她趋之若鹜，但他们居高临下的态度显然将她视为暴发户。只有一位举足轻重的人物对她另眼相待：那就是艺术品经销商约瑟夫·杜维恩。
For die first few years of Duveen's relationship witii Arabella, he made no effort to sell expensive art to her. Instead he accompanied her to fine stores, chatted endlessly about queens and princesses he knew, on and on. At last, she diought, a man who treated her as an equal, even a superior, in high society. Meanwhile, if Duveen did not try to sell art to her, he did sub-tiy educate her in his aesdietic ideasnamely, that die best art was the most expensive art. And after Arabella had soaked up his way of seeing things, Duveen would act as if she always had exquisite taste, even tiiough before she met him her aesdietics had been abysmal.
在杜维恩与阿拉贝拉交往的最初几年里，他并没有刻意向她推销昂贵的艺术品。相反，他陪她逛精品店，滔滔不绝地谈论他认识的那些王后和公主。阿拉贝拉心想，终于，他找到了一个在上流社会中平等对待她，甚至比她更胜一筹的男人。与此同时，杜维恩虽然没有直接向她推销艺术品，却也在潜移默化地向她灌输自己的审美理念——最好的艺术就是最昂贵的艺术。阿拉贝拉逐渐接受了他的这种审美观之后，杜维恩便会装出一副她品味高雅的样子，尽管在遇到他之前，她的审美简直糟糕透顶。
When Collis Huntington died, in 1900, Arabella came into a fortune. She suddenly started to buy expensive paintings, by Rembrandt and Velazquez, for exampleand only from Duveen. Years later Duveen sold her Gainsborough's Blue Boy for the highest price ever paid for a work of
1900年，科利斯·亨廷顿去世，阿拉贝拉继承了一大笔遗产。她突然开始大量购买昂贵的画作，例如伦勃朗和委拉斯凯兹的作品，而且只从杜维恩那里购买。多年后，杜维恩以当时艺术品拍卖的最高价售出了她收藏的庚斯博罗的《蓝衣少年》。
art at the time, an astounding purchase for a family that previously had shown litde interest in collecting. Interpretation
在当时，这件艺术品对于一个此前对收藏兴趣寥寥的家庭来说，是一笔惊人的购买。解读
Joseph Duveen instantly understood Arabella Huntington and what made her tick: She wanted to feel important, at home in society. Intensely insecure about her lower-class background, she needed confirmation of her new social status. Duveen waited. Instead of rushing into trying to persuade her to collect art, he subtly went to work on her weaknesses. He made her feel that she deserved his attention not because she was the wife of one of the wealthiest men in the world but because of her own special characterand this completely melted her. Duveen never condescended to Arabella; rather than lecturing to her, he instilled his ideas in her indirectly. The result was one of his best and most devoted clients, and also the sale of The Blue Boy.
约瑟夫·杜维恩立刻就了解了阿拉贝拉·亨廷顿，明白了她的内心世界：她渴望被重视，渴望融入上流社会。她对自己的出身极度缺乏安全感，需要得到认可来巩固自己的社会地位。杜维恩耐心地等待着。他没有急于说服她收藏艺术品，而是巧妙地利用了她的弱点。他让她觉得，她值得他的关注，并非因为她是世界上最富有的人之一的妻子，而是因为她自身独特的个性——这彻底打动了她。杜维恩从不居高临下地对待阿拉贝拉；他没有对她进行说教，而是以间接的方式将自己的理念灌输给她。最终，他收获了一位最忠实、最优秀的客户，同时也促成了《蓝衣少年》的售出。
People's need for validation and recognition, tiieir need to feel important, is the best kind of weakness to exploit. First, it is almost universal; second, exploiting it is so very easy. All you have to do is find ways to make people feel better about their taste, their social standing, meir intelligence. Once the fish are hooked, you can reel them in again and again, for yearsyou are filling a positive role, giving them what they cannot get on their own. They may never suspect that you are turning them like a thumbscrew, and if they do they may not care, because you are making them feel better about themselves, and that is worth any price.
人们渴望被认可和肯定，渴望感受到自身的重要性，这是最容易被利用的弱点。首先，这种渴望几乎是普遍存在的；其次，利用它非常容易。你只需要找到方法，让他们对自己品味、社会地位和智力更有自信。一旦他们上钩，你就可以一次又一次地把他们拉回来。多年来，你扮演着积极的角色，给予他们自己无法获得的东西。他们可能永远不会怀疑你像个螺丝钉一样控制着他们，即使他们怀疑了，也可能毫不在意，因为你让他们感觉良好，而这值得付出任何代价。
Observance V
遵守第五条
In 1862 King William of Prussia named Otto von Bismarck premier and minister for foreign affairs. Bismarck was known for his boldness, his ambitionand his interest in strengthening die military. Since William was surrounded by liberals in his government and cabinet, politicians who already wanted to limit his powers, it was quite dangerous for him to put Bismarck in this sensitive position. His wife, Queen Augusta, had tried to dissuade him, but aKhough she usually got her way with him, this time William stuck to his guns.
1862年，普鲁士国王威廉任命奥托·冯·俾斯麦为首相兼外交大臣。俾斯麦以其大胆、雄心勃勃和加强军备的倾向而闻名。由于威廉的政府和内阁成员大多是自由派人士，他们原本就想限制他的权力，因此将俾斯麦置于如此敏感的职位上对他来说相当危险。他的妻子奥古斯塔王后曾试图劝阻他，但尽管她通常都能左右他的决定，这一次威廉却坚持己见。
Only a week after becoming prime minister, Bismarck made an impromptu speech to a few dozen ministers to convince them of the need to enlarge the army. He ended by saying, “The great questions of the time will be decided, not by speeches and resolutions of majorities, but by iron and blood.” His speech was immediately disseminated throughout Germany. The queen screamed at her husband that Bismarck was a barbaric militarist who was out to usurp control of Prussia, and that William had to fire him. The liberals in the government agreed with her. The outcry was so vehement that William began to be afraid he would end up on a scaffold, like Louis XVI of France, if he kept Bismarck on as prime minister.
俾斯麦就任首相仅一周后，便向几十位大臣发表了一次即兴演讲，力图说服他们扩充军队的必要性。他在演讲结尾说道：“时代的重大问题，并非由多数派的演说和决议决定，而是要靠铁血和鲜血。”他的演讲立即传遍了整个德国。王后对着丈夫威廉大声斥责俾斯麦是一个野蛮的军国主义者，企图篡夺普鲁士的统治权，并要求威廉解雇他。政府中的自由派人士也赞同王后的观点。舆论的强烈反对让威廉开始担心，如果他继续让俾斯麦担任首相，自己最终会像法国国王路易十六一样被送上断头台。
Bismarck knew he had to get to the king before it was too late. He also knew he had blundered, and should have tempered his fiery words. Yet as he contemplated his strategy, he decided not to apologize but to do the exact opposite. Bismarck knew the king well.
俾斯麦知道他必须在为时已晚之前见到国王。他也知道自己犯了错，本该收敛一下那些激烈的言辞。然而，当他思索策略时，他决定不道歉，反而反其道而行之。俾斯麦对国王非常了解。
Caesar had instructed them, in hopes that young gentlemen, who had not known much of battles and wounds, hut came wearing their hair long, in the flower of their age and height of their beauty, would be more apprehensive of such blows, and not care for hazarding both a danger at present and a blemish for the future.
凯撒曾告诫他们，希望那些年轻绅士，虽然不常经历战争和伤痛，却正值青春年华，容貌俊美，留着长发，能够更加畏惧这些打击，而不必在意眼前的危险和未来的污点。
And so it proved, for they were so far from bearing the stroke of the javelins, that they could not stand the sight of them, but turned about, and covered their faces to secure them. Once in disorder, presently they turned about to fly; and so most shamefully ruined all. For those who had beat them back at once outflanked the infantry, and falling on their rear, cut them to pieces. Pompey, who commanded the other wing of the army, when he saw his cavalry thus broken and flying, was no longer himself nor did he now remember that he was Pompey the Great, but, like one whom some god had deprived of his senses, retired to his tent without speaking a word, and there sat to expect the event, till the whole army was routed.
事实证明确实如此，他们不仅无法承受标枪的攻击，甚至连看到标枪的景象都感到恐惧，于是转身捂住脸庞以求自保。他们一度陷入混乱，随即溃逃，最终惨败而亡。那些击退他们的人立刻绕到步兵侧翼，从后方发起攻击，将他们斩杀殆尽。指挥另一侧部队的庞培，看到自己的骑兵溃不成军，顿时失去了理智，忘记了自己是庞培大帝，如同被神明夺去神智一般，一言不发地退回帐篷，静静地等待着败局，直到全军溃败。
THE LIFE OF JULIUS CAESAR.
尤利乌斯·凯撒传。
Plutarch, c. a.d. 46-120
普鲁塔克，约公元46-120年
When the two men met, William, predictably, had been worked into a tizzy by the queen. He reiterated his fear of being guillotined. But Bismarck only replied, “Yes, then we shall be dead! We must die sooner or later, and could there be a more respectable way of dying I should die fighting for the cause of my king and master. Your Majesty would die sealing with your own blood your royal rights granted by God's grace. Whether upon the scaffold or upon the battlefield makes no difference to the glorious staking of body and life on behalf of rights granted by God's grace!” On he went, appealing to William's sense of honor and the majesty of his position as head of the army. How could the king allow people to push him around Wasn't the honor of Germany more important than quibbling over words Not only did the prime minister convince die king to stand up to both his wife and his parliament, he persuaded him to build up the armyBismarck's goal all along. Interpretation
两人见面时，威廉不出所料地被王后激怒得焦头烂额。他再次表达了自己对被送上断头台的恐惧。但俾斯麦只是回答说：“是啊，那样我们岂不都得死！我们迟早都要死，如果还有比这更体面的死法，那就是为我的国王和主人而战。陛下，您将用自己的鲜血捍卫上帝赐予您的王权。无论是在断头台上还是在战场上，对于为上帝赐予的权利而献出生命和身体而言，都毫无区别！”他继续说道，诉诸威廉的荣誉感和他作为军队统帅的威严。国王怎能任由他人摆布？难道德国的荣誉不比斤斤计较更重要吗？首相不仅说服国王对抗王后和议会，还劝说他扩充军队——这正是俾斯麦一直以来的目标。解释
Bismarck knew the king felt bullied by those around him. He knew that William had a military background and a deep sense of honor, and that he felt ashamed at his cravenness before his wife and his government. William secredy yearned to be a great and mighty king, but he dared not express this ambition because he was afraid of ending up like Louis XVI. Where a show of courage often conceals a man's timidity, William's timidity concealed his need to show courage and thump his chest.
俾斯麦知道国王威廉感到被周围的人欺凌。他知道威廉有军人背景，而且荣誉感极强，也知道威廉在妻子和朝臣面前的怯懦令他感到羞愧。威廉内心深处渴望成为一位伟大而强大的国王，但他不敢表达这种野心，因为他害怕落得像路易十六那样的下场。勇敢往往掩盖着一个人的怯懦，而威廉的怯懦恰恰掩盖了他渴望展现勇气、渴望炫耀的内心。
Bismarck sensed the longing for glory beneatii William's pacifist front, so he played to the king's insecurity about his manhood, finally pushing him into diree wars and the creation of a German empire. Timidity is a potent weakness to exploit. Timid souls often yearn to be their oppositeto be Napoleons. Yet they lack the inner strength. You, in essence, can become their Napoleon, pushing them into bold actions that serve your needs while also making them dependent on you. Remember: Look to the opposites and never take appearances at face value.
俾斯麦察觉到威廉的和平主义阵营背后隐藏着对荣耀的渴望，于是他利用国王对自身男子气概的不安全感，最终将他推入残酷的战争，并促成了德意志帝国的建立。怯懦是一种可以被利用的强大弱点。怯懦的人往往渴望成为与自己截然相反的人——拿破仑。然而，他们缺乏内在的力量。从本质上讲，你可以成为他们的拿破仑，驱使他们采取大胆的行动，既满足你的需求，又让他们对你产生依赖。记住：要关注与自己相反的人，永远不要只看表面现象。
Image: The Thumbscrew. Your enemy has secrets that he guards, thinks thoughts he will not reveal. But they come out in ways he cannot help. It is there somewhere, a groove of weakness on his head, at his heart, over his belly. Once you find the groove, put your thumb in it and turn him at will.
图片：拇指夹。你的敌人藏着秘密，心中怀着不愿透露的想法。但这些秘密和想法总会以他无法控制的方式流露出来。他的弱点就藏在某个地方，比如他的头顶、心脏或腹部。一旦你找到那个弱点，就用拇指夹住它，随心所欲地控制他。
Authority: Find out each man's thumbscrew. Tis the art of setting their wills in action. It needs more skill than resolution. You must know where to get at anyone. Every volition has a special motive which varies according to taste. All men are idolaters, some of fame, odiers of self-interest, most of pleasure. Skill consists in knowing these idols in order to bring them into play. Knowing any man's mainspring of motive you have as it were the key to his will. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：找出每个人的软肋。这是引导他们意志的艺术。它需要的技巧远胜于决心。你必须知道如何才能触及任何人。每个人的意志都有其特殊的动机，而动机又因人而异。所有人都崇拜偶像，有些人崇拜名利，有些人崇拜私利，大多数人崇拜享乐。技巧在于了解这些偶像，并加以利用。了解一个人的主要动机，就如同掌握了他意志的钥匙。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
Playing on people's weakness has one significant danger: You may stir up
利用他人的弱点有一个重大危险：你可能会激起……
an action you cannot control.
这是你无法控制的行为。
In your games of power you always look several steps ahead and plan accordingly. And you exploit the fact that other people are more emotional and incapable of such foresight. But when you play on their vulnerabilities, the areas over which they have least control, you can unleash emotions that will upset your plans. Push timid people into bold action and they may go too far; answer their need for attention or recognition and they may need more than you want to give them. The helpless, childish element you are playing on can turn against you.
在你的权力游戏中，你总是能预见未来，并据此制定计划。你利用他人更感性、缺乏远见的弱点。但当你利用他们的弱点，利用他们最无力掌控的领域时，你可能会激起他们的情绪，从而打乱你的计划。逼迫胆怯的人采取大胆行动，他们可能会走得太远；满足他们对关注或认可的需求，他们可能会索取更多。你所利用的无助和幼稚的一面，最终可能会反噬你。
The more emotional the weakness, die greater the potential danger. Know the limits to this game, then, and never get carried away by your control over your victims. You are after power, not die dirill of control.
你的弱点越是情绪化，潜在的危险就越大。所以，要清楚这场游戏的界限，永远不要被对受害者的控制冲昏头脑。你追求的是权力，而不是控制的奴隶。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 34
第34条
BE ROYAL IN YOUR OWN
做你自己的皇室成员
FASHION: ACT LIKE A
时尚：表现得像个
KING TO BE TREATED
国王将接受治疗
LIKE ONE
像一个
JUDGMENT
判断
The way you carry yourself will often determine how you are treated: In the long run, appearing vulgar or common will make people disrespect you. For a king respects himself and inspires the same sentiment in others. By acting regally and confident of your powers, you make yourself seem destined to wear a crown.
你的举止往往决定了别人如何对待你：长此以往，粗俗或庸俗的举止会招致人们对你的轻视。因为君王自尊自爱，也能赢得他人的尊重。举止高贵自信，展现出王者风范，你便会显得天生具备加冕的潜质。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In July of 1830, a revolution broke out in Paris that forced the king, Charles X, to abdicate. A commission of the highest audiorities in the land gathered to choose a successor, and the man they picked was Louis-Philippe, the Duke of Orleans.
1830年7月，巴黎爆发革命，迫使国王查理十世退位。全国最高贵族组成的委员会聚集在一起，选举继任者，他们最终选择了奥尔良公爵路易-菲利普。
From the beginning it was clear that Louis-Philippe would be a different kind of king, and not just because he came from a different branch of the royal family, or because he had not inherited the crown but had been given it, by a commission, putting his legitimacy in question. Rather it was that he disliked ceremony and the trappings of royalty; he had more friends among the bankers than among the nobility; and his style was not to create a new kind of royal rule, as Napoleon had done, but to downplay his status, the better to mix widi the businessmen and middle-class folk who had called him to lead. Thus the symbols that came to be associated with Louis-Philippe were neither the scepter nor the crown, but the gray hat and umbrella with which he would proudly walk the streets of Paris, as if he were a bourgeois out for a stroll. When Louis-Philippe invited James Rothschild, the most important banker in France, to his palace, he treated him as an equal. And unlike any king before him, not only did he talk business with Monsieur Rothschild but that was literally all he talked, for he loved money and had amassed a huge fortune.
从一开始就很明显，路易·菲利普是一位与众不同的国王，这不仅仅是因为他出身于王室的不同分支，也不仅仅是因为他并非继承王位，而是通过某种委任才被授予王位，这使得他的合法性受到质疑。更重要的是，他厌恶繁文缛节和王室的种种排场；他在银行家圈子里的朋友比在贵族圈子里的朋友更多；他的风格并非像拿破仑那样开创一种新的君主统治方式，而是淡化自己的地位，以便更好地融入那些拥护他领导的商人和中产阶级之中。因此，与路易·菲利普联系在一起的象征既不是权杖也不是王冠，而是他那顶灰色的帽子和一把雨伞，他会骄傲地戴着它们漫步在巴黎的街头，就像一个外出散步的资产阶级人士。当路易·菲利普邀请法国最重要的银行家詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德到他的宫殿做客时，他像对待平等的人一样对待他。与他之前的任何一位国王不同，他不仅与罗斯柴尔德先生谈论生意，而且他谈论的也全是生意，因为他热爱金钱，并积累了巨额财富。
As the reign of the “bourgeois king” plodded on, people came to despise him. The aristocracy could not endure the sight of an unkingly king, and within a few years they turned on him. Meanwhile the growing class of the poor, including the radicals who had chased out Charles X, found no satisfaction in a ruler who neither acted as a king nor governed as a man of the people. The bankers to whom Louis-Philippe was die most beholden soon realized that it was they who controlled the country, not he, and they treated him with growing contempt. One day, at the start of a train trip organized for die royal family, James Rothschild actually berated himand in publicfor being late. Once die king had made news by treating the banker as an equal; now the banker treated the king as an inferior.
随着“资产阶级国王”路易·菲利普的统治步履蹒跚，民众开始对他感到厌恶。贵族阶层无法忍受一个没有君主风范的国王，几年之内便对他群起而攻之。与此同时，日益壮大的贫民阶层，包括那些驱逐查理十世的激进分子，也无法接受一个既不称职也不亲民的统治者。路易·菲利普最倚重的银行家们很快意识到，真正掌控国家的是他们，而不是他，于是他们对路易·菲利普的蔑视与日俱增。一天，在为王室安排的火车旅行开始时，詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德竟然当众斥责他迟到。国王曾因平等对待银行家而名噪一时；如今，银行家却把国王视作下属。
Eventually the workers' insurrections that had brought down Louis-Philippe's predecessor began to reemerge, and die king put them down with force. But what was he defending so brutally Not the institution of me monarchy, which he disdained, nor a democratic republic, which his rule prevented. What he was really defending, it seemed, was his own fortune, and die fortunes of the bankersnot a way to inspire loyalty among die citizenry.
最终，推翻路易·菲利普前任的工人起义再次兴起，国王以武力镇压了他们。但他如此残酷地捍卫的究竟是什么？既不是他所鄙夷的君主制，也不是他统治所阻碍的民主共和制。他真正捍卫的，似乎只是他自己的财富，以及银行家们的财富——而不是赢得民众忠诚的方式。
In early 1848, Frenchmen of all classes began to demonstrate for electoral reforms that would make die country truly democratic. By February the demonstrations had turned violent. To assuage the populace, Louis-Philippe fired his prime minister and appointed a liberal as a replacement. But this created the opposite of the desired effect: The people sensed they could push the king around. The demonstrations turned into a full-fledged revolution, with gunfire and barricades in the streets.
1848年初，法国各阶层民众开始举行示威游行，要求进行选举改革，使国家真正实现民主。到了二月，示威活动演变为暴力冲突。为了安抚民众，路易·菲利普解职首相，任命了一位自由派人士接任。然而，此举却适得其反：民众意识到他们可以凌驾于国王之上。示威游行最终演变成一场全面革命，街头枪声四起，街垒林立。
Never lose your self-respect, nor be too familiar with yourself when you are alone. Let your integrity itself be your own standard of rectitude, and be more indebted to the severity of your own judgment of yourself than to all external precepts. Desist from unseemly conduct, rather out of respect for your own virtue than for the strictures of external authority. Come to hold yourself in awe, and you will have no need of Seneca's imaginary tutor.
永远不要失去自尊，独处时也不要过于自恋。让你的正直本身成为你衡量正义的标准，比起一切外在的教条，你更应该重视对自己严厉的评判。摒弃不雅的行为，与其说是出于对外部权威的约束，不如说是出于对自身美德的尊重。学会敬畏自己，你就不再需要塞内卡笔下那位虚构的导师了。
Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
On the night of February 23, a crowd of Parisians surrounded the palace. With a suddenness that caught everyone by surprise, Louis-Philippe abdicated that very evening and fled to England. He left no successor, nor even die suggestion of onehis whole government folded up and dissolved like a traveling circus leaving town.
2月23日夜，大批巴黎市民包围了皇宫。路易·菲利普当晚突然宣布退位，逃往英国，令所有人措手不及。他没有留下任何继承人，甚至连一个继任者的暗示都没有——他的整个政府如同一个巡回马戏团离开城市般，土崩瓦解。
Interpretation
解释
Louis-Philippe consciously dissolved the aura that naturally pertains to kings and leaders. Scoffing at the symbolism of grandeur, he believed a new world was dawning, where rulers should act and be like ordinary citizens. He was right: A new world, without kings and queens, was certainly on its way. He was profoundly wrong, however, in predicting a change in the dynamics of power.
路易·菲利普有意识地消解了君主和领袖与生俱来的威严。他嘲讽了宏伟的象征意义，认为一个新世界正在到来，统治者应该像普通公民一样行事。他的想法是对的：一个没有国王和王后的新世界的确正在到来。然而，他对权力格局变化的预测却大错特错。
The bourgeois king's hat and umbrella amused the French at first, but soon grew irritating. People knew that Louis-Philippe was not really like them at allthat the hat and umbrella were essentially a kind of trick to encourage them in the fantasy that the country had suddenly grown more equal. Actually, though, the divisions of wealth had never been greater. The French expected their ruler to be a bit of a showman, to have some presence. Even a radical like Robespierre, who had briefly come to power during the French Revolution fifty years earlier, had understood this, and certainly Napoleon, who had turned die revolutionary republic into an imperial regime, had known it in his bones. Indeed as soon as Louis-Philippe fled the stage, the French revealed their true desire: They elected Napoleon's grand-nephew president. He was a virtual unknown, but they hoped he would re-create die great general's powerful aura, erasing die awkward memory of die “bourgeois king.”
起初，资产阶级国王的帽子和雨伞让法国人觉得有趣，但很快就变得令人厌烦。人们心知肚明，路易·菲利普其实与他们截然不同——那顶帽子和雨伞本质上是一种障眼法，旨在让他们沉浸在国家突然变得更加平等的幻想中。然而，事实上，财富差距从未如此之大。法国人期待他们的统治者能有点表演天赋，能给人留下深刻印象。即使是像罗伯斯庇尔这样激进的人物，在五十年前的法国大革命期间曾短暂掌权，也明白这一点；而将革命共和国转变为帝国政权的拿破仑，更是对此了如指掌。的确，路易·菲利普一退出政坛，法国人就暴露了他们的真实愿望：他们选举拿破仑的侄孙担任总统。他几乎无人知晓，但人们希望他能重现这位伟大将军的强大气场，抹去“资产阶级国王”那段尴尬的记忆。
Powerful people may be tempted to affect a common-man aura, trying to create the illusion that they and dieir subjects or underlings are basically die same. But the people whom diis false gesture is intended to impress will quickly see through it. They understand that they are not being given more powerthat it only appears as if diey shared in the powerful person's fate. The only kind of common touch that works is die kind affected by Franklin Roosevelt, a style that said the president shared values and goals with the common people even while he remained a patrician at heart. He never pretended to erase his distance from the crowd.
有权势的人或许会试图营造一种平易近人的氛围，试图制造一种假象，即他们与民众或下属本质上并无二致。然而，这种虚假姿态旨在打动的民众很快就会识破。他们明白，这种姿态并没有赋予他们更多权力，而只是让他们感觉自己与权势者共享命运。唯一真正有效的“亲民”方式，是富兰克林·罗斯福式的，这种风格表明，即使罗斯福内心深处仍保留着贵族气质，但他与普通民众拥有共同的价值观和目标。他从未试图抹去与民众之间的距离。
Leaders who try to dissolve that distance through a false chumminess gradually lose the ability to inspire loyalty, fear, or love. Instead they elicit contempt. Like Louis-Philippe, they are too uninspiring even to be worth the guillotinedie best diey can do is simply vanish in the night, as if diey were never there.
试图通过虚假的亲近来消除这种距离感的领导人，会逐渐失去激发忠诚、恐惧或爱戴的能力。相反，他们只会招致鄙夷。就像路易·菲利普一样，他们甚至连被送上断头台都嫌多，他们所能做的最好的事就是消失在夜色中，仿佛从未存在过。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
When Christopher Columbus was trying to find funding for his legendary voyages, many around him believed he came from the Italian aristocracy. This view was passed into history through a biography written after the explorer's death by his son, which describes him as a descendant of a Count
当克里斯托弗·哥伦布为他传奇般的航行寻找资金时，他身边许多人都认为他出身于意大利贵族。这种观点通过他儿子在他去世后撰写的传记流传至今，传记中称他是某位伯爵的后裔。
Colombo of die Casde of Cuccaro in Montferrat. Colombo in turn was said to be descended from the legendary Roman general Colonius, and two of his first cousins were supposedly direct descendants of an emperor of Constantinople. An illustrious background indeed. But it was nodiing more than illustrious fantasy, for Columbus was actually the son of Domenico Colombo, a humble weaver who had opened a wine shop when Christopher was a young man, and who then made his living by selling cheese.
科伦坡家族位于蒙费拉托的库卡罗城堡。据说科伦坡是传奇罗马将军科洛尼乌斯的后裔，他的两位堂兄弟据说是君士坦丁堡皇帝的直系后裔。这的确是一个显赫的出身。但这与其说是显赫的传说，不如说是人们的臆想。事实上，哥伦布的父亲多米尼克·科伦坡只是个卑微的织工，在克里斯托弗年轻时开了一家酒铺，后来靠卖奶酪为生。
Columbus himself had created the myth of his noble background, because from early on he felt that destiny had singled him out for great things, and that he had a kind of royalty in his blood. Accordingly he acted as if he were indeed descended from noble stock. After an uneventful career as a merchant on a commercial vessel, Columbus, originally from Genoa, settled in Lisbon. Using die fabricated story of his noble background, he married into an established Lisbon family that had excellent connections with Portuguese royalty.
哥伦布本人编造了自己贵族出身的神话，因为他从小就觉得自己命中注定要成就一番伟业，而且他身上流淌着某种皇室血统。因此，他表现得好像自己确实是贵族后裔。哥伦布出生于热那亚，在商船上做了一段时间的商人后，定居里斯本。他利用自己编造的贵族出身故事，与里斯本一个与葡萄牙皇室关系密切的显赫家族联姻。
Through his in-laws, Columbus finagled a meeting with the king of Portugal, Joao II, whom he petitioned to finance a westward voyage aimed at discovering a shorter route to Asia. In return for announcing that any discoveries he achieved would be made in the king's name, Columbus wanted a series of rights: the tide Grand Admiral of die Oceanic Sea; die office of viceroy over any lands he found; and 10 percent of die future commerce with such lands. All of these rights were to be hereditary and for all time. Columbus made these demands even diough he had previously been a mere merchant, he knew almost nothing about navigation, he could not work a quadrant, and he had never led a group of men. In short he had absolutely no qualifications for die journey he proposed. Furthermore, his petition included no details as to how he would accomplish his plans, just vague promises.
通过姻亲的关系，哥伦布设法与葡萄牙国王若昂二世会面，并请求国王资助他向西航行，以寻找一条通往亚洲的更短航线。作为交换，哥伦布承诺所有发现都将以国王的名义进行，并要求获得一系列特权：大洋洲的海上大元帅；对其发现的任何土地的总督职位；以及未来与这些土地贸易额的10%。所有这些特权都将是世袭的，永世有效。尽管哥伦布此前只是个商人，对航海几乎一窍不通，不会使用象限仪，也从未带领过任何团队，但他仍然提出了这些要求。简而言之，他完全不具备进行此次航行的任何资格。此外，他的请愿书中没有详细说明他将如何实现计划，只有一些含糊不清的承诺。
When Columbus finished his pitch, Joao II smiled: He politely declined the offer, but left the door open for the future. Here Columbus must have noticed somediing he would never forget: Even as the king turned down die sailor's demands, he treated them as legitimate. He neither laughed at Columbus nor questioned his background and credentials. In fact die king was impressed by die boldness of Columbus's requests, and clearly felt comfortable in the company of a man who acted so confidently. The meeting must have convinced Columbus tiiat his instincts were correct: By asking for the moon, he had instandy raised his own status, for the king assumed that unless a man who set such a high price on himself were mad, which Columbus did not appear to be, he must somehow be worth it.
当哥伦布说完话后，若昂二世微笑着婉拒了哥伦布的提议，但并未排除未来再次合作的可能性。哥伦布当时一定注意到了一些他永远不会忘记的事情：即使国王拒绝了这位水手的要求，他也将其视为合理的。国王既没有嘲笑哥伦布，也没有质疑他的背景和资历。事实上，国王对哥伦布大胆的要求印象深刻，并且显然对这位如此自信的人感到自在。这次会面一定让哥伦布确信自己的直觉是正确的：他提出的“月亮”要求立刻提升了自己的地位，因为国王认为，除非一个如此看重自己的人疯了（而哥伦布看起来并非如此），否则他一定有其价值所在。
A few years later Columbus moved to Spain. Using his Portuguese connections, he moved in elevated circles at the Spanish court, receiving subsidies from illustrious financiers and sharing tables widi dukes and princes. To all these men he repeated his request for financing for a voyage to die westand also for the rights he had demanded from Joao II. Some, such as die powerful duke of Medina, wanted to help, but could not, since they lacked die power to grant him the tides and rights he wanted. But Columbus would not back down. He soon realized that only one person
几年后，哥伦布移居西班牙。凭借他在葡萄牙的人脉，他得以跻身西班牙宫廷的上流社会，接受显赫金融家的资助，并与公爵和王子们共进晚餐。他向这些人再次请求资助他前往西方的航行，以及他向若昂二世提出的要求。一些人，例如权势滔天的梅迪纳公爵，想要提供帮助，但却无能为力，因为他们缺乏足够的权力来授予他想要的航行权和权利。但哥伦布不肯退缩。他很快意识到，只有一个人……
HII'POCLKinKS AT SICYON
嗨，POCLKinKS 在 SICYON
In the next generation the family became much more famous than before through the distinction conferred upon it by Cleisthenes the master of Sicyon. Cleisthenes . .. had a daughter, Agarista, whom he wished to marry to the best man in all Greece. So during the Olympic games, in which he had himself won the chariot race, he had a public announcement made, to the effect that any Greek who thought himself good enough to become Cleisthenes' son-in-law should present himself in Sicyon within sixty daysor sooner if he wishedbecause he intended, within the year following the sixtieth day, to betroth his daughter to her future husband. Cleisthenes had had a race-track and a wrestling-ring specially made for his purpose, and presently the suitors began to arrive every man of Greek nationality who had something to be proud of either in his country or in himself.... Cleisthenes began by asking each [of the numerous suitorsJ in turn to name his country and parentage; then he kept them in his house for a year, to get to know them well, entering into conversation with them sometimes singly, sometimes all together, and testing each of them for his
下一代，由于西锡安城主克里斯提尼的授意，这个家族的名声比以往更加显赫。克里斯提尼……有一个女儿，名叫阿加里斯塔，他想把她嫁给全希腊最优秀的男子。因此，在奥林匹克运动会期间（他本人赢得了战车比赛的冠军），他发布了一则公开公告，任何自认为有资格成为克里斯提尼女婿的希腊人，都应在六十天内，或者如果愿意的话，可以更早地，来到西锡安，因为他打算在第六十天之后的一年内，将女儿许配给她未来的丈夫。克里斯提尼为此专门建造了一条赛马场和一个摔跤场，很快，求婚者们便纷至沓来——所有希腊籍的、无论在国家还是自身方面有值得骄傲的男子……克里斯提尼首先询问了众多求婚者，让他们依次说出自己的国家和出身；然后他把他们留在自己家里一年，以便更好地了解他们，有时单独与他们交谈，有时一起交谈，并考验他们每个人。
manly qualities and temper, education and manners. . .. But the most important test of all was their behaviour at the dinner-table. All this went on throughout their stay in Sieyon, and all the time he entertained them handsomely. For one reason or another it was the two Athenians who impressed Cleisthenes most favourably, and of the two Tisander's son Hippocleides came to be preferred. . . At last the day came which had been fixed for the betrothal, and Cleisthenes had to declare his choice. lie marked the day by the sacrifice of a hundred oxen, and then gave a great banquet, to which not only the suitors but everyone of note in Sieyon was invited. When dinner was over, the suitors began to compete with each other in music and in talking in company. In both these accomplishments it was Hippocleides who proved by far the doughtiest champion, until at last, as more and more wine was drunk, he asked the flute-player to play him a tune and began to dance to it. Now it may well be that he danced to his own satisfaction; Cleisthenes, however, who was watching the performance, began to have serious doubts about the whole business. Presently, after a brief pause, Hippocleides sent for a table; the table was brought, and
男子气概、性情、教养和举止……但最重要的考验莫过于他们在餐桌上的表现。这一切在他们逗留锡安期间持续进行，克里斯提尼始终热情款待他们。不知何故，两位雅典人给克里斯提尼留下了最深刻的印象，其中提桑德的儿子希波克利德斯更受青睐……终于到了订婚的日子，克里斯提尼不得不宣布他的选择。他宰杀了一百头牛来庆祝这一天，然后举行了一场盛大的宴会，不仅邀请了求婚者，还邀请了锡安所有显赫的人物。晚宴结束后，求婚者们开始在音乐和谈吐方面一较高下。在这两项技艺中，希波克利德斯都展现出了远胜于其他人的实力，直到最后，随着酒越喝越多，他让吹笛人为他演奏一首曲子，并开始翩翩起舞。现在，他或许跳得十分尽兴；然而，正在观看表演的克里斯提尼却开始对整件事产生了严重的怀疑。片刻之后，希波克利德斯吩咐人拿来一张桌子；桌子被拿了过来，然后……
could meet his demands: Queen Isabella. In 1487 he finally managed a meeting with the queen, and although he could not convince her to finance me voyage, he completely charmed her, and became a frequent guest in the palace.
能够满足他要求的人是伊莎贝拉女王。1487年，他终于设法与女王会面，虽然他没能说服女王资助他的航行，但他完全征服了女王，并成为宫廷的常客。
In 1492 the Spanish finally expelled the Moorish invaders who centuries earlier had seized parts of the country. With the wartime burden on her treasury lifted, Isabella felt she could finally respond to the demands of her explorer friend, and she decided to pay for three ships, equipment, the salaries of the crews, and a modest stipend for Columbus. More important, she had a contract drawn up that granted Columbus the tides and rights on which he had insisted. The only one she deniedand only in the contract's fine printwas the 10 percent of all revenues from any lands discovered: an absurd demand, since he wanted no time limit on it. (Had the clause been left in, it would eventually have made Columbus and his heirs the wealthiest family on the planet. Columbus never read the fine print.)
1492年，西班牙人终于驱逐了几个世纪前占领该国部分地区的摩尔人入侵者。战时国库的负担减轻后，伊莎贝拉感到终于可以回应她那位探险家朋友的要求了，于是决定支付三艘船的费用、设备、船员的薪水，以及给哥伦布的一笔数额不大的津贴。更重要的是，她拟定了一份合同，授予哥伦布他一直坚持的潮汐权和探险权。她唯一拒绝的，也是在合同细则中提到的，是哥伦布必须从所有发现的土地中获得10%的收入：这是一个荒谬的要求，因为哥伦布希望这笔收入没有时间限制。（如果保留了这一条款，哥伦布及其后代最终将成为地球上最富有的家族。哥伦布从未仔细阅读过合同细则。）
Satisfied that his demands had been met, Columbus set sail mat same year in search of the passage to Asia. (Before he left he was careful to hire the best navigator he could find to help him get there.) The mission failed to find such a passage, yet when Columbus petitioned the queen to finance an even more ambitious voyage the following year, she agreed. By then she had come to see Columbus as destined for great things.
哥伦布确信自己的要求已得到满足，同年便扬帆起航，寻找通往亚洲的航道。（出发前，他特意聘请了当时能找到的最优秀的航海家协助他。）虽然这次航行未能找到航道，但当哥伦布请求女王资助他第二年进行一次更为雄心勃勃的航行时，女王同意了。那时，女王已经认定哥伦布注定要成就一番伟业。
Interpretation
解释
As an explorer Columbus was mediocre at best. He knew less about the sea man did the average sailor on his ships, could never determine the latitude and longitude of his discoveries, mistook islands for vast continents, and treated his crew badly. But in one area he was a genius: He knew how to sell himself. How else to explain how the son of a cheese vendor, a low-level sea merchant, managed to ingratiate himself with the highest royal and aristocratic families
作为一名探险家，哥伦布充其量只能算平庸。他对航海的了解甚至不如船上的普通水手，始终无法确定他所发现地点的经纬度，把岛屿误认为广袤的大陆，而且对待船员也很苛刻。但他在某一方面却堪称天才：他深谙自我推销之道。否则，又该如何解释一个奶酪小贩的儿子，一个地位低下的海上商人，是如何成功地博得最高贵的皇室和贵族家族的青睐呢？
Columbus had an amazing power to charm the nobility, and it all came from the way he carried himself. He projected a sense of confidence mat was completely out of proportion to his means. Nor was his confidence the aggressive, ugly self-promotion of an upstartit was a quiet and calm self-assurance. In fact it was the same confidence usually shown by the nobility themselves. The powerful in the old-style aristocracies felt no need to prove or assert tiiemselves; being noble, tiley knew they always deserved more, and asked for it. With Columbus, then, diey felt an instant affinity, for he carried himself just the way they didelevated above die crowd, destined for greatness.
哥伦布有一种神奇的魅力，能够轻易赢得贵族们的喜爱，而这一切都源于他举手投足间的风度。他散发出的自信，与他实际的实力完全不成比例。这种自信并非暴发户那种咄咄逼人、丑陋不堪的自我推销，而是一种沉稳内敛的自信。事实上，这正是贵族们通常展现出的那种自信。旧式贵族阶层中的权贵们无需证明或标榜自己；身为贵族，他们深知自己理应获得更多，并且会主动争取。因此，他们与哥伦布之间立刻产生了一种亲近感，因为他举手投足间都散发着贵族特有的气质——超凡脱俗，注定要成就一番伟业。
Understand: It is within your power to set your own price. How you carry yourself reflects what you think of yourself. If you ask for little, shuffle your feet and lower your head, people will assume this reflects your character. But tiiis behavior is not youit is only how you have chosen to present yourself to other people. You can just as easily present the Columbus front: buoyancy, confidence, and the feeling that you were born to wear a crown.
明白：你有能力为自己定价。你的举止反映了你如何看待自己。如果你索求甚少，步履蹒跚，低着头，人们会认为这反映了你的性格。但这并非真正的你，而只是你选择向他人展现的形象。你完全可以展现出哥伦布式的自信：昂首阔步，充满自信，仿佛天生就该戴上王冠。
With all great deceivers there is a noteworthy occurrence to which they owe their
所有伟大的骗子都有一件值得注意的事情，他们的成功都归功于此。
power. In the actual act of deception they are overcome by belief in themselves: it is
权力。在实际的欺骗行为中，他们被对自身的信念所征服：这是
this which then speaks so miraculously and compellingly to those around them.
这使得他们能够以如此奇妙和令人信服的方式与周围的人产生共鸣。
Friedrich Nietzsche, 1844-1900
弗里德里希·尼采，1844-1900 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
As children, we start our lives with great exuberance, expecting and demanding everything from the world. This generally carries over into our first forays into society, as we begin our careers. But as we grow older the rebuffs and failures we experience set up boundaries that only get firmer with time. Coming to expect less from the world, we accept limitations that are really self-imposed. We start to bow and scrape and apologize for even the simplest of requests. The solution to such a shrinking of horizons is to deliberately force ourselves in the opposite directionto downplay the failures and ignore the limitations, to make ourselves demand and expect as much as the child. To accomplish this, we must use a particular strategy upon ourselves. Call it the Strategy of the Crown.
孩提时代，我们带着无比的热情开启人生，对世界充满期待和渴望。这种热情通常会延续到我们初入社会、开启职业生涯的阶段。然而，随着年龄的增长，我们经历的挫折和失败会在我们心中筑起一道道界限，而这些界限只会随着时间的推移而愈加牢固。我们对世界的期望值逐渐降低，接受了许多实际上源于自我设限的限制。我们甚至开始对最简单的请求卑躬屈膝、虚情假意。要解决这种视野的萎缩，我们需要有意识地反其道而行之，淡化失败，忽略限制，让自己像孩童般拥有无限的期待和渴望。为了做到这一点，我们必须运用一种特殊的策略。不妨称之为“王冠策略”。
The Strategy of the Crown is based on a simple chain of cause and effect: If we believe we are destined for great things, our belief will radiate outward, just as a crown creates an aura around a king. This outward radiance will infect the people around us, who will think we must have reasons to feel so confident. People who wear crowns seem to feel no inner sense of the limits to what they can ask for or what they can accomplish. This too radiates outward. Limits and boundaries disappear. Use the Strategy of the Crown and you will be surprised how often it bears fruit. Take as an example those happy children who ask for whatever they want, and get it. Their high expectations are their charm. Adults enjoy granting their wishesjust as Isabella enjoyed granting the wishes of Columbus.
“王冠策略”基于一个简单的因果链：如果我们相信自己注定要成就伟业，这种信念就会像王冠为国王营造光环一样向外散发。这种向外散发的光环会感染我们周围的人，让他们觉得我们一定有理由如此自信。那些佩戴王冠的人似乎感觉不到自己所能要求或所能成就的极限。这种感觉也会向外扩散。限制和界限消失了。运用“王冠策略”，你会惊讶于它屡试不爽。想想那些快乐的孩子，他们想要什么就能得到什么。他们美好的愿望就是他们的魅力所在。成年人也乐于满足他们的愿望，就像伊莎贝拉乐于满足哥伦布的愿望一样。
Throughout history, people of undistinguished birththe Theodoras of Byzantium, the Columbuses, the Beethovens, the Disraelishave managed to work the Strategy of the Crown, believing so firmly in their own greatness that it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. The trick is simple: Be overcome by your self-belief. Even while you know you are practicing a kind of deception on yourself, act like a king. You are likely to be treated as one.
纵观历史，出身平凡的人——拜占庭的狄奥多拉、哥伦布、贝多芬、迪斯雷利——都曾运用过“王权策略”，他们坚信自己的伟大，最终成就了自我实现的预言。诀窍很简单：被自信所征服。即使你明知自己是在自欺欺人，也要像国王一样行事。这样，你很可能就会被当作国王对待。
The crown may separate you from other people, but it is up to you to make that separation real: You have to act differently, demonstrating your distance from those around you. One way to emphasize your difference is to always act with dignity, no matter the circumstance. Louis-Philippe gave no sense of being different from other peoplehe was the banker king. And the moment his subjects threatened him, he caved in. Everyone sensed this and pounced. Lacking regal dignity and firmness of purpose, Louis-Philippe seemed an impostor, and the crown was easily toppled from his head.
王冠或许能让你与他人区分开来，但这种区分开来是否真正存在，则取决于你自己：你必须表现得与众不同，以此彰显你与周围人的距离。强调这种差异的一种方法是，无论身处何种境地，都要始终保持尊严。路易·菲利普丝毫没有给人以与众不同的感觉——他不过是个银行家国王。一旦臣民对他构成威胁，他就屈服了。所有人都察觉到了这一点，并纷纷扑向他。由于缺乏君主应有的尊严和坚定的决心，路易·菲利普看起来像个冒牌货，王冠也轻易地从他头上被夺走。
Regal bearing should not be confused with arrogance. Arrogance may seem the king's entitlement, but in fact it betrays insecurity. It is the very opposite of a royal demeanor.
威严的气质不应与傲慢混淆。傲慢看似是君王的特权，实则暴露出内心的不安全感，与王者风范截然相反。
Hippocleides, climbing on to it, danced first some Laeonian dances, next some Attic ones, and ended by standing on his head and beating time with his legs in the air. The Laeonian and Attic dances were bad enough; but Cleisthenes, though he already loathed the thought of having a son-in-law like that, nevertheless restrained himself and managed to avoid an outburst; but when he saw Hippocleides beating time with his legs, he could bear it no longer. “Son of Tisander, ” he cried, “you have danced away your marriage. ”
希波克利德斯爬上去，先跳了几段莱昂舞，接着又跳了几段阿提卡舞，最后倒立起来，双腿在空中打着节拍。莱昂舞和阿提卡舞已经够糟糕了；克里斯提尼虽然一想到要有个这样的女婿就厌恶至极，但他还是克制住了自己，没有爆发；可是当他看到希波克利德斯用腿打节拍时，他再也忍无可忍了。“提桑德之子，”他喊道，“你这是在跳舞毁了你的婚姻！”
the histories, Herodotus, fifth century b.c.
《历史》，希罗多德，公元前五世纪
Haile Selassie, ruler of Ethiopia for forty or so years beginning in 1930, was once a young man named Lij Tafari. He came from a noble family, but there was no real chance of him coming to power, for he was far down the line of succession from die king then on the throne, Menelik II. Nevertheless, from an early age he exhibited a self-confidence and a royal bearing that surprised everyone around him.
海尔·塞拉西，自1930年起统治埃塞俄比亚约四十年，年轻时名叫利吉·塔法里。他出身贵族，但继承王位的机会渺茫，因为他在王位继承顺序上远落后于当时的在位国王梅内利克二世。然而，他从小就展现出一种令周围所有人惊叹的自信和王者风范。
At the age of fourteen, Tafari went to live at the court, where he immediately impressed Menelik and became his favorite. Tafari's grace under fire, his patience, and his calm self-assurance fascinated the king. The other young nobles, arrogant, blustery, and envious, would push this slight, bookish teenager around. But he never got angrydiat would have been a sign of insecurity, to which he would not stoop. There were already people around him who felt he would someday rise to the top, for he acted as if he were already there.
十四岁时，塔法里进入宫廷生活，他立刻给梅内利克留下了深刻的印象，并成为国王最宠爱的臣子。塔法里在逆境中展现出的优雅、耐心和沉稳自信令国王着迷。其他年轻贵族傲慢自大、心怀嫉妒，常常欺负这个身材瘦小、爱读书的少年。但他从不生气——生气在他看来是缺乏安全感的表现，而他绝不会屈尊这样做。他身边的人都觉得他将来必成大器，因为他的表现就像已经身居高位一样。
Years later, in 1936, when the Italian Fascists had taken over Ethiopia and Tafari, now called Haile Selassie, was in exile, he addressed the League of Nations to plead his country's case. The Italians in the audience heckled him with vulgar abuse, but he maintained his dignified pose, as if completely unaffected. This elevated him while making his opponents look even uglier. Dignity, in fact, is invariably the mask to assume under difficult circumstances: It is as if nothing can affect you, and you have all die time in the world to respond. This is an extremely powerful pose.
多年后的1936年，意大利法西斯占领埃塞俄比亚，塔法里（现名海尔·塞拉西）流亡海外。他向国际联盟发表讲话，为自己的祖国辩护。听众席上的意大利人对他破口大骂，但他始终保持着庄严的姿态，仿佛毫不在意。这不仅提升了他的形象，也让他的对手显得更加丑陋。事实上，在困境中，尊严往往是人们应该戴上的面具：仿佛没有什么能影响到你，你拥有充足的时间来应对。这是一种极其强大的姿态。
A royal demeanor has odier uses. Con artists have long known die value of an aristocratic front-, it either disarms people and makes them less suspicious, or else it intimidates them and puts them on the defensiveand as Count Victor Lustig knew, once you put a sucker on the defensive he is doomed. The con man Yellow Kid Weil, too, would often assume die trappings of a man of wealtii, along with die nonchalance diat goes with them. Alluding to some magical method of making money, he would stand aloof, like a king, exuding confidence as if he really were fabulously rich. The suckers would beg to be in on die con, to have a chance at die wealth diat he so clearly displayed.
帝王般的举止还有其他用途。骗子们早就深谙贵族外表的价值——它要么能解除人们的戒备，降低他们的怀疑，要么能震慑他们，让他们转入防御状态。正如维克多·卢斯蒂格伯爵所知，一旦让一个傻瓜陷入防御状态，他就注定要失败。骗子“黄孩子”威尔也常常装扮成富人，并摆出一副与之相配的漫不经心。他会暗示自己有某种神奇的致富方法，然后像国王一样高高在上，散发出一种自信，仿佛他真的富可敌国。那些傻瓜会恳求加入他的骗局，渴望有机会获得他如此明目张胆展示的财富。
Finally, to reinforce die inner psychological tricks involved in projecting a royal demeanor, diere are outward strategies to help you create die effect. First, the Columbus Strategy: Always make a bold demand. Set your price high and do not waver. Second, in a dignified way, go after the highest person in the building. This immediately puts you on die same plane as the chief executive you are attacking. It is die David and Goliath Strategy: By choosing a great opponent, you create the appearance of greatness.
最后，为了强化展现王者风范所需的内在心理技巧，还有一些外在策略可以帮助你营造这种效果。首先是哥伦布策略：始终提出大胆的要求。把价格定得高一些，并且毫不动摇。其次，以一种庄重的方式，直接挑战公司里级别最高的人。这能让你立刻与你攻击的首席执行官处于同一水平线上。这是一种大卫与歌利亚策略：通过选择一个强大的对手，你就能营造出强大的形象。
Third, give a gift of some sort to diose above you. This is the strategy of those who have a patron: By giving your patron a gift, you are essentially saying diat die two of you are equal. It is the old con game of giving so diat you can take. When die Renaissance writer Retro Aretino wanted die Duke of Mantua as his next patron, he knew diat if he was slavish and sycophantic, die duke would diink him unworthy; so he approached die duke with gifts, in this case paintings by the writer's good friend Titian.
第三，要向地位高于你的人赠送礼物。这是那些有赞助人的人的策略：通过赠送礼物，你实际上是在说你们地位平等。这是一种古老的“先付出后索取”的策略。文艺复兴时期的作家雷特罗·阿雷蒂诺想要曼图亚公爵成为他的下一位赞助人时，他知道如果他卑躬屈膝、阿谀奉承，公爵会认为他不够格；所以他带着礼物去拜访公爵，这次是他好友提香的画作。
Accepting the gifts created a kind of equality between duke and writer: The duke was put at ease by the feeling that he was dealing with a man of his own aristocratic stamp. He funded Aretino generously. The gift strategy is subde and brilliant because you do not beg: You ask for help in a dignified way mat implies equality between two people, one of whom just happens to have more money.
接受礼物在公爵和作家之间建立了一种平等关系：公爵感到自在，因为他觉得对方是一位与他地位相当的贵族。他慷慨地资助了阿雷蒂诺。这种馈赠策略既含蓄又巧妙，因为它不显得乞求：以一种体面的方式请求帮助，暗示着两人之间的平等，只不过其中一人恰好拥有更多财富。
Remember: It is up to you to set your own price. Ask for less and that is just what you will get. Ask for more, however, and you send a signal diat you are worth a king's ransom. Even those who turn you down respect you for your confidence, and mat respect will eventually pay off in ways you cannot imagine.
记住：价格由你决定。要价低，你得到的也只能是低价。但要价高，就等于发出了一个信号：你价值连城。即使是拒绝你的人，也会敬佩你的自信，而这份尊重最终会带来你无法想象的回报。
Image: The Crown. Place it upon your head and you assume a different posetranquil yet radiating assurance. Never show doubt, never lose your dignity beneath the crown, or it will not fit. It will seem to be destined for one more worthy. Do not wait for a coronation; the greatest emperors crown themselves.
图片：王冠。将它戴在头上，你便会展现出一种截然不同的姿态——沉稳而又散发着自信的光芒。切勿流露一丝疑虑，切勿在王冠之下丧失尊严，否则它将不再适合你。它似乎注定要属于更配得上它的人。无需等待加冕；最伟大的帝王都是自己加冕的。
Authority: Everyone should be royal after his own fashion. Let all your actions, even though they are not those of a king, be, in their own sphere, worthy of one. Be sublime in your deeds, lofty in your thoughts; and in all your doings show that you deserve to be a king even though you are not one in reality. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：人人皆应以自己的方式展现王者风范。即便你的行为并非君王之举，在其自身领域内，也应堪比君王。你的行为应崇高，你的思想应高尚；你的一切所作所为，都应表明你虽非君王，却配得上君王之位。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
The idea behind the assumption of regal confidence is to set yourself apart from omer people, but if you take this too far it will be your undoing. Never make die mistake of thinking diat you elevate yourself by humiliating people. Also, it is never a good idea to loom too high above the crowdyou make an easy target. And mere are times when an aristocratic pose is eminently dangerous.
装出一副高人一等的自信，是为了让自己显得与众不同，但如果做得太过火，反而会适得其反。千万不要以为羞辱别人就能抬高自己。此外，高高在上也绝非明智之举，那样只会让自己成为众矢之的。而且，摆出一副贵族姿态有时也极其危险。
Charles I, king of England during the 1640s, faced a profound public disenchantment with the institution of monarchy. Revolts erupted throughout the country, led by Oliver Cromwell. Had Charles reacted to the times with insight, supporting reforms and making a show of sacrificing some of his power, history might have been different. Instead he reverted to an even more regal pose, seeming outraged by the assault on his power and on the divine institution of monarchy. His stiff kingliness offended people and spurred on their revolts. And eventually Charles lost his head, literally. Understand: You are radiating confidence, not arrogance or disdain.
17世纪40年代的英格兰国王查理一世面临着民众对君主制的强烈不满。奥利弗·克伦威尔领导的起义席卷全国。如果查理能够洞察时代脉搏，支持改革并公开表示放弃部分权力，历史或许会改写。然而，他却摆出一副更加威严的姿态，似乎对权力以及君主制这一神圣制度遭受的冲击感到义愤填膺。他僵硬的君主作风激怒了民众，并进一步激起了他们的反抗。最终，查理被斩首身亡。请记住：你散发的是自信，而非傲慢或轻蔑。
Finally, it is true that you can sometimes find some power through affecting a kind of earmy vulgarity, which will prove amusing by its extremeness. But to the extent that you win this game by going beyond the limits, separating yourself from other people by appearing even more vulgar than diey are, the game is dangerous: There will always be people more vulgar than you, and you will easily be replaced the following season by someone younger and worse.
最后，诚然，有时通过刻意营造一种粗俗的氛围确实能获得某种力量，这种粗俗的极端性会让人觉得滑稽可笑。但如果你通过超越底线、通过表现得比别人更粗俗来赢得这场游戏，那么这场游戏就很危险了：总会有人比你更粗俗，而且你很容易在下一季就被更年轻、更糟糕的人取代。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 35
第35条
MASTER THE ART OF TIMING
掌握时机的艺术
JUDGMENT
判断
Never seem to be in a hurryhurrying betrays a lack of control over yourself, and over time. Always seem patient, as if you know that everything will come to you eventually. Become a detective of the right moment; sniff out the spirit of the times, the trends that will carry you to power. Learn to stand back when the time is not yet ripe, and to strike fiercely when it has reached fruition.
永远不要显得匆忙——匆忙会暴露你缺乏自控力，而且这种自控力会随着时间的推移而减弱。永远保持耐心，仿佛你知道一切最终都会水到渠成。要像侦探一样，敏锐地捕捉时机；洞察时代精神，把握那些能助你走向成功的趋势。学会时机未成熟时保持观望，并在时机成熟时全力出击。
SKRTORIl'S'S I.KSSON
SKRTORIl'S'S I.KSSON
Sertorius's strength was now rapidly increasing, for all the tribes between the Ebro and the Pyrenees came over to his side, and troops came flocking daily to join him from every quarter. At the same time he was troubled by the lack of discipline and the overconfidenee of these newly arrived barbarians, who would shout at him to attack the enemy and had no patience with his delaying tactics, and he therefore tried to win them over by argument. But when he saw that they were discontented and persisted in pressing their demands regardless of the circumstances, he let them have their way and allowed them to engage the enemy; he hoped that they would suffer a severe defeat without being completely crushed, and that this would make them better disposed to obey his orders in future. The event turned out as he expected and Serto-rius came to their rescue, provided a rallying point for the fugitives, and led them safely back to his camp. His next step was to revive their dejected spirits, and so a few days later he summoned a general assembly. Before it he produced two horses, one of them old and enfeebled, the other large and lusty and
塞托里乌斯的势力迅速壮大，埃布罗河与比利牛斯山脉之间的所有部落都投靠了他，四面八方每天都有军队蜂拥而至。与此同时，这些新来的蛮族缺乏纪律，而且过于自信，这令他十分烦恼。他们会大声叫嚣着让他进攻敌人，对他的拖延战术毫无耐心。因此，他试图用辩论来说服他们。但当他看到他们心怀不满，不顾一切地坚持己见时，他便顺从了他们的意愿，允许他们与敌人交战。他希望他们遭受重创但不会被彻底击溃，这样他们以后会更愿意服从他的命令。事态的发展正如他所预料的那样，塞托里乌斯前来营救，为逃亡者提供了一个集结地，并带领他们安全返回营地。接下来，他要重振他们低落的士气，于是几天后，他召集了一次全体大会。他牵出两匹马来，一匹年老体衰，另一匹高大健壮。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Starting out in life as a nondescript French seminary-school teacher, Joseph Fouche wandered from town to town for most of the decade of the 1780s, teaching mathematics to young boys. Yet he never completely committed himself to the church, never took his vows as a priesthe had bigger plans. Patiently waiting for his chance, he kept his options open. And when the French Revolution broke out, in 1789, Fouche waited no longer: He got rid of his cassock, grew his hair long, and became a revolutionary. For this was the spirit of the times. To miss the boat at this critical moment could have spelt disaster. Fouche did not miss the boat: Befriending the revolutionary leader Robespierre, he quickly rose in the rebel ranks. In 1792 the town of Nantes elected Fouche to be its representative to the National Convention (created that year to frame a new constitution for a French republic).
约瑟夫·富歇最初只是个默默无闻的法国神学院教师，在18世纪80年代的大部分时间里，他辗转于各个城镇，教小男孩们数学。然而，他从未完全投身教会，也从未发誓成为一名神父——他有更大的抱负。他耐心地等待着机会，始终保持开放的心态。1789年法国大革命爆发时，富歇再也没有等待：他脱下长袍，留长发，投身革命。因为这正是时代的精神。在这个关键时刻错失良机，可能会招致灾难。富歇没有错失良机：他与革命领袖罗伯斯庇尔结为好友，迅速在起义军中崭露头角。1792年，南特市选举富歇为该市在国民公会（该公会于当年成立，旨在为法兰西共和国制定新宪法）的代表。
When Fouche arrived in Paris to take his seat at the convention, a violent rift had broken out between die moderates and the radical Jacobins. Fouche sensed that in the long run neitfier side would emerge victorious. Power rarely ends up in the hands of those who start a revolution, or even of tiiose who further it; power sticks to those who bring it to a conclusion. That was the side Fouche wanted to be on.
当富歇抵达巴黎参加国民公会时，温和派和激进的雅各宾派之间已经爆发了激烈的冲突。富歇预感到，从长远来看，温和派最终会取得胜利。权力很少会落入革命的发起者手中，甚至很少会落入那些推动革命的人手中；权力往往掌握在那些最终完成革命的人手中。富歇想要加入的正是这样的一方。
His sense of timing was uncanny. He started as a moderate, for moderates were in the majority. When the time came to decide on whether or not to execute Louis XVI, however, he saw that the people were clamoring for the king's head, so he cast the deciding votefor the guillotine. Now he had become a radical. Yet as tensions came to the boil in Paris, he foresaw the danger of being too closely associated wim any one faction, so he accepted a position in die provinces, where he could lie low for a while. A few months later he was assigned to the post of proconsul in Lyons, where he oversaw the execution of dozens of aristocrats. At a certain moment, however, he called a halt to the killings, sensing tiiat die mood of the country was turningand despite the blood already on his hands, die citizens of Lyons hailed him as a savior from what had become known as the Terror.
他的时机把握堪称绝妙。起初他立场温和，因为温和派在当时占多数。然而，当决定是否处决路易十六时，他发现民众呼声高涨，要求处死国王，于是他投下了决定性的一票，支持将国王送上断头台。此时，他已然成为一名激进派。但随着巴黎局势日趋紧张，他预见到与任何一方走得太近都会带来危险，于是接受了外省的职位，以便暂时隐退。几个月后，他被任命为里昂总督，负责监督处决数十名贵族。然而，在某个时刻，他突然叫停了屠杀，因为他感觉到国家的风向正在转变。尽管他双手沾满鲜血，里昂市民仍然将他奉为救世主，将他们从后来被称为“恐怖统治”的时期中拯救出来。
So far Fouche had played his cards brilliantly, but in 1794 his old friend Robespierre recalled him to Paris to account for his actions in Lyons. Robespierre had been the driving force behind the Terror. He had sent heads on both the right and the left rolling, and Fouche, whom he no longer trusted, seemed destined to provide the next head. Over the next few weeks, a tense struggle ensued: While Robespierre railed openly against Fouche, accusing of him dangerous ambitions and calling for his arrest, the crafty Fouche worked more indirectiy, quietly gaining support among those who were beginning to tire of Robespierre's dictatorial control. Fouche was playing for time. He knew diat the longer he survived, the more disaffected citizens he could rally against Robespierre. He had to have broad support before he moved against the powerful leader. He rallied support among both the moderates and the Jacobins, playing on the widespread fear of Robespierreeveryone was afraid of being die next to go to die guillotine. It all came to fruition on July 27: The convention
到目前为止，富歇的策略可谓高明，但在1794年，他的老朋友罗伯斯庇尔将他召回巴黎，要求他解释在里昂的所作所为。罗伯斯庇尔是恐怖统治的幕后推手，他左右两派都曾被他处死，而富歇，这个他不再信任的人，似乎注定要成为下一个牺牲品。接下来的几周，一场紧张的斗争展开：罗伯斯庇尔公开抨击富歇，指责他野心勃勃，并要求逮捕他；而老谋深算的富歇则采取更为间接的策略，悄悄地争取那些开始厌倦罗伯斯庇尔独裁统治的人们的支持。富歇是在拖延时间。他知道，自己活得越久，就能团结越多不满的民众反对罗伯斯庇尔。他必须获得广泛的支持，才能对这位强大的领袖采取行动。他成功地在温和派和雅各宾派中争取到了支持，利用了人们对罗伯斯庇尔的普遍恐惧——每个人都害怕自己会成为下一个被送上断头台的人。这一切在7月27日得到了证实：国民大会召开了。
turned against Robespierre, shouting down his usual lengthy speech. He was quickly arrested, and a few days later it was Robespierre's head, not Fouche's, that fell into the basket.
他转而反对罗伯斯庇尔，大声打断了他惯常冗长的演讲。他很快被捕，几天后，掉进篮子里的不是富歇的头，而是罗伯斯庇尔的头。
When Fouche returned to the convention after Robespierre's death, he played his most unexpected move: Having led the conspiracy against Robespierre, he was expected to sit with the moderates, but lo and behold, he once again changed sides, joining the radical Jacobins. For perhaps the first time in his life he aligned himself with the minority. Clearly he sensed a reaction stirring: He knew mat the moderate faction that had executed Robespierre, and was now about to take power, would initiate a new round of the Terror, this time against the radicals. In siding widi the Jacobins, then, Fouche was sitting with the martyrs of the days to comethe people who would be considered blameless in the troubles that were on their way. Taking sides with what was about to become the losing team was a risky gambit, of course, but Fouche must have calculated he could keep his head long enough to quietly stir up the populace against the moderates and watch them fall from power. And indeed, although the moderates did call for his arrest in December of 1795, and would have sent him to the guillotine, too much time had passed. The executions had become unpopular with the people, and Fouche survived the swing of the pendulum one more time.
罗伯斯庇尔死后，富歇回到国民公会，做出了最出人意料的举动：作为刺杀罗伯斯庇尔的幕后主使，人们原本以为他会与温和派站在一起，但出乎意料的是，他再次改变立场，加入了激进的雅各宾派。这或许是他一生中第一次与少数派结盟。显然，他预感到一股反抗力量正在酝酿：他知道，处决罗伯斯庇尔的温和派即将掌权，并将发动新一轮恐怖统治，而这一次的目标是激进派。因此，富歇与雅各宾派站在一起，就如同与未来的殉道者——那些在即将到来的动乱中将被视为无辜的人——站在一起。当然，与即将失败的一方结盟是一场冒险的赌博，但富歇一定盘算着，他能够保持冷静，悄悄地煽动民众反对温和派，并看着他们垮台。的确，尽管温和派人士在1795年12月呼吁逮捕他，并打算将他送上断头台，但时间已经过去太久。处决已不再受民众欢迎，富歇再次躲过了这场风波。
A new government took over, the Directoire. It was not, however, a Jacobin government, but a moderate onemore moderate dian the government that had reimposed the Terror. Fouche, the radical, had kept his head, but now he had to keep a low profile. He waited patiently on the sidelines for several years, allowing time to soften any bitter feelings against him, then he approached the Directoire and convinced them he had a new passion: intelligence-gathering. He became a paid spy for the government, excelled at the job, and in 1799 was rewarded by being made minister of police. Now he was not just empowered but required to extend his spying to every corner of Francea responsibility that would greatly reinforce his natural ability to sniff out where die wind was blowing. One of the first social trends he detected, in fact, came in the person of Napoleon, a brash young general whose destiny he right away saw was entwined with the future of France. When Napoleon unleashed a coup d'etat, on November 9, 1799, Fouche pretended to be asleep. Indeed he slept the whole day. For this indirect assistanceit might have been tiiought his job, after all, to prevent a military coupNapoleon kept him on as minister of police in the new regime.
新政府上台，成立了督政府。然而，它并非雅各宾派政府，而是一个比重新实施恐怖统治的政府更为温和的政府。激进分子富歇保住了性命，但现在他必须保持低调。他耐心地在幕后等待了数年，让时间缓和人们对他的敌意，然后他接近督政府，并说服他们他有了新的热情：情报搜集。他成为政府的付费间谍，工作出色，并于1799年被任命为警察部长。现在，他不仅被赋予了权力，而且被要求将他的间谍活动扩展到法国的每个角落——这项职责将极大地增强他敏锐的洞察力，让他能够预知未来的走向。事实上，他察觉到的最早的社会趋势之一，就是拿破仑的出现。拿破仑是一位年轻气盛的将军，富歇一眼就看出他的命运与法国的未来息息相关。 1799年11月9日，拿破仑发动政变时，富歇假装睡着了。事实上，他睡了一整天。或许正是因为他间接协助政变，才使得他得以保住工作，毕竟他的职责是阻止军事政变。拿破仑在新政权中继续让他担任警察部长。
Over the next few years, Napoleon came to rely on Fouche more and more. He even gave this former revolutionary a tide, duke of Otranto, and rewarded him with great wealth. By 1808, however, Fouche, always attuned to the times, sensed that Napoleon was on the downswing. His futile war with Spain, a country mat posed no threat to France, was a sign that he was losing a sense of proportion. Never one to be caught on a sinking ship, Fouche conspired with Talleyrand to bring about Napoleon's downfall. Al-
在接下来的几年里，拿破仑越来越依赖富歇。他甚至将奥特朗托公爵的爵位授予这位昔日的革命者，并给予他巨额财富作为奖赏。然而到了1808年，一向敏锐的富歇察觉到拿破仑的颓势正在蔓延。他与西班牙——一个对法国构不成任何威胁的国家——发动的徒劳战争，正是他失去理智的标志。富歇从不甘于坐以待毙，于是与塔列朗密谋，企图扳倒拿破仑。
possessing a flowing tail, which was remarkable for the thickness and beauty of its hair. By the side of the weak horse stood a tall strong man, and by the side of the powerful horse a short man of mean physique. At a signal the strong man seized the tail of his horse and tried with all his strength to pull it towards him, as if to tear it off while the weak man began to pull the hairs one by one from the tail of the strong horse. The strong man, after tugging with all his might to no purpose and causing the spectators a great deal of amusement in the process, finally gave up the attempt, while the weak man quickly and with very little trouble stripped his horse's tail completely bare. Then Sertorius rose to his feet and said, "Now you can see, my friends and allies, that perseverance is more effective than brute strength, and that there are many difficulties that cannot be overcome if you try to do everything at once, but which will yield if you master them little by little. The truth is that a steady continuous effort is irresistible, for this is the way in which Time captures and subdues the greatest powers on earth. Now Time, you should remember, is a good friend and ally to those who use their intelligence to choose the right moment, but a most dangerous enemy
这匹马有着一条飘逸的尾巴，尾巴上的毛浓密而美丽。在弱马旁边站着一个高大强壮的男人，在强壮的马旁边站着一个身材矮小瘦弱的男人。一声令下，壮汉抓住马尾，使出浑身解数往自己这边拽，仿佛要把它扯下来似的；与此同时，弱汉开始一根一根地拔掉强壮马尾巴上的毛。壮汉使尽全力却徒劳无功，引得围观者哄堂大笑，最终只好放弃；而弱汉则轻而易举地就把马尾上的毛全部拔光了。随后，塞托里乌斯站起身来说道：“现在你们应该明白了，我的朋友和盟友们，坚持不懈比蛮力更有效。许多困难如果试图一口气完成所有事情是无法克服的，但如果你们一点一点地去掌握它们，它们终将迎刃而解。事实上，持续不断的努力是不可阻挡的，因为时间正是以此来征服和驾驭世间最强大的力量。你们应该记住，对于那些运用智慧选择正确时机的人来说，时间是他们的好朋友和盟友；但对于那些运用智慧选择正确时机的人来说，时间却是他们最危险的敌人。”
to those who rush into action at the wrong one."
对于那些在错误的时间点贸然采取行动的人来说。”
life of sertorius,
塞托里乌斯的一生
Plutarch,
普鲁塔克
c. a.d. 46-120
公元46-120年

所以他有了这个家伙

展示了他的军事才能

宫廷里的天才

弱国。如果我依赖

外交方面，我们应该

很快就会被消灭。如果，

这个吞火者，他
will offer his services to
