though die conspiracy failedTalleyrand was fired; Fouche stayed, but was kept on a tight leashit publicized a growing discontent with the emperor, who seemed to be losing control. By 1814 Napoleon's power had crumbled and allied forces finally conquered him.
尽管阴谋失败，塔列朗还是被解职了；富歇留了下来，但受到严密控制，他公开表达了民众对皇帝日益增长的不满，而皇帝似乎正在失去控制。到1814年，拿破仑的权力已经崩溃，盟军最终击败了他。
The next government was a restoration of the monarchy, in the form of King Louis XVIII, brother of Louis XVI. Fouche, his nose always sniffing die air for the next social shift, knew Louis would not last longhe had none of Napoleon's flair. Fouche once again played his waiting game, lying low, staying away from the spodight. Sure enough, in February of 1815, Napoleon escaped from die island of Elba, where he had been imprisoned. Louis XVIII panicked: His policies had alienated die citizenry, who were clamoring for Napoleon's return. So Louis turned to the one man who could maybe have saved his hide, Fouche, the former radical who had sent his brother, Louis XVI, to die guillotine, but was now one of die most popular and widely admired politicians in France. Fouche, however, would not side with a loser: He refused Louis's request for help by pretending that his help was unnecessaryby swearing that Napoleon would never return to power (although he knew otherwise). A short time later, of course, Napoleon and his new citizen army were closing in on Paris.
下一届政府复辟君主制，由路易十八——路易十六的弟弟——统治。富歇一向嗅觉敏锐，时刻关注着社会风云变幻，他知道路易十八不会长久——他缺乏拿破仑那样的魄力。富歇再次采取了守势，低调行事，远离政坛。果然，1815年2月，拿破仑从被囚禁的厄尔巴岛逃脱。路易十八惊慌失措：他的政策疏远了民众，民众强烈要求拿破仑回国。于是，路易十八求助于唯一一个或许能救他一命的人——富歇。富歇曾是激进分子，将他的哥哥路易十六送上了断头台，如今却成了法国最受欢迎、最受尊敬的政治家之一。然而，富歇不愿与失败者为伍：他拒绝了路易的求助，假装自己的帮助毫无必要，并信誓旦旦地保证拿破仑永远不会卷土重来（尽管他心里清楚并非如此）。当然，不久之后，拿破仑和他的新民兵就逼近了巴黎。
Seeing his reign about to collapse, feeling that Fouche had betrayed him, and certain that he did not want this powerful and able man on Napoleon's team, King Louis ordered die minister's arrest and execution. On March 16, 1815, policemen surrounded Fouche's coach on a Paris boulevard. Was this finally his end Perhaps, but not immediately: Fouche told the police that an ex-member of government could not be arrested on the street. They fell for the story and allowed him to return home. Later that day, though, they came to his house and once again declared him under arrest. Fouche noddedbut would the officers be so kind as allow a gentieman to wash and to change his clothes before leaving his house for the last time They gave tiieir permission, Fouche left the room, and the minutes went by. Fouche did not return. Finally the policemen went into the next roomwhere they saw a ladder against an open window, leading down to the garden below.
眼见自己的统治即将崩溃，又觉得富歇背叛了他，并且确信自己不希望这个权势滔天、能力出众的人留在拿破仑的阵营，路易国王下令逮捕并处决这位大臣。1815年3月16日，警察在巴黎一条林荫大道上包围了富歇的马车。这是否就是他的末日？或许是，但并非立刻发生：富歇告诉警察，前政府官员不能在大街上被逮捕。警察信以为真，放他回家了。然而，当天晚些时候，他们又来到富歇的住所，再次宣布逮捕他。富歇点点头，请求警察允许一位绅士在最后一次离开家之前洗漱更衣。警察同意了，富歇离开了房间，时间一分一秒地过去。富歇没有回来。最后，警察走进隔壁房间，看到一架梯子靠在敞开的窗户上，通往下面的花园。
That day and the next the police combed Paris for Fouche, but by men Napoleon's cannons were audible in the distance and die king and all the king's men had to flee the city. As soon as Napoleon entered Paris, Fouche came out of hiding. He had cheated the executioner once again. Napoleon greeted his former minister of police and gladly restored him to his old post. During the 100 days diat Napoleon remained in power, until Waterloo, it was essentially Fouche who governed France. After Napoleon fell, Louis XVIII returned to the throne, and like a cat with nine lives, Fouche stayed on to serve in yet another governmentby tiien his power and influence had grown so great that not even the king dared challenge him.
那天和第二天，警察在巴黎搜捕富歇，但很快就听到了远处拿破仑的炮声，国王和所有臣民不得不逃离这座城市。拿破仑一进巴黎，富歇就从藏身之处走了出来。他又一次侥幸逃脱了刽子手的魔爪。拿破仑迎接了他这位昔日的警察部长，并欣然恢复了他的原职。在拿破仑执政的100天里，直到滑铁卢战役，实际上都是富歇在统治法国。拿破仑战败后，路易十八复辟，富歇如同拥有九条命的猫一般，继续留在政府中任职。到那时，他的权力和影响力已经如此之大，以至于连国王都不敢挑战他。
Interpretation
解释
In a period of unprecedented turmoil, Joseph Fouche thrived through his
在一段前所未有的动荡时期，约瑟夫·福什凭借其……蓬勃发展
mastery of the art of timing. He teaches us a number of key lessons.
他精通时机把握的艺术。他教会了我们许多关键的经验。
First, it is critical to recognize the spirit of the times. Fouche always looked two steps ahead, found the wave mat would carry him to power, and rode it. You must always work with the times, anticipate twists and turns, and never miss the boat. Sometimes the spirit of the times is obscure: Recognize it not by what is loudest and most obvious in it, but by what lies hidden and dormant. Look forward to the Napoleons of the future rather than holding on to the ruins of the past.
首先，把握时代精神至关重要。福歇总是高瞻远瞩，他总能找到通往权力的良机，并乘风破浪。你必须始终顺应时代潮流，预见未来的变迁，绝不错失良机。有时，时代精神晦涩难懂：辨识它，并非看它最喧嚣、最显而易见，而是要关注那些隐藏的、潜藏的因素。与其固守过去的废墟，不如展望未来，迎接未来的拿破仑。
Second, recognizing the prevailing winds does not necessarily mean running with them. Any potent social movement creates a powerful reaction, and it is wise to anticipate what that reaction will be, as Fouche did after the execution of Robespierre. Rather than ride the cresting wave of the moment, wait for the tide's ebb to carry you back to power. Upon occasion bet on the reaction that is brewing, and place yourself in the vanguard of it.
其次，了解潮流趋势并不意味着一定要顺势而为。任何强大的社会运动都会引发强烈的反作用力，明智的做法是预判这种反作用力，就像福歇在罗伯斯庇尔被处决后所做的那样。与其随波逐流，不如等待浪潮退去，重掌大权。有时，也可以押注于正在酝酿的反作用力，并让自己站在它的前沿。
Finally, Fouche had remarkable patience. Without patience as your sword and shield, your timing will fail and you will inevitably find yourself a loser. When the times were against Fouche, he did not struggle, get emotional, or strike out rashly. He kept his cool and maintained a low profile, patiendy building support among the citizenry, the bulwark in his next rise to power. Whenever he found himself in the weaker position, he played for time, which he knew would always be his ally if he was patient. Recognize the moment, then, to hide in die grass or slither under a rock, as well as the moment to bare your fangs and attack.
最后，福什拥有非凡的耐心。若缺乏耐心这把利剑和盾牌，时机便会错失，最终必败无疑。当福什身处逆境时，他从不挣扎，不情绪失控，也不鲁莽行事。他保持冷静，低调行事，耐心地在民众中建立支持，这为他日后重返权力巅峰奠定了坚实的基础。每当他处于劣势时，他便会争取时间，因为他深知，只要保持耐心，时间永远是他的盟友。因此，要懂得何时该藏身草丛或匍匐于岩石之下，也要懂得何时该露出獠牙，发起猛攻。
Space we can recover, time never. Napoleon Bonaparte, 1769-1821
空间可以收回，时间却永远无法挽回。——拿破仑·波拿巴，1769-1821
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Time is an artificial concept diat we ourselves have created to make the limidessness of eternity and die universe more bearable, more human. Since we have constructed the concept of time, we are also able to mold it to some degree, to play tricks with it. The time of a child is long and slow, with vast expanses; the time of an adult whizzes by frighteningly fast. Time, then, depends on perception, which, we know, can be willfully altered. This is die first thing to understand in mastering the art of timing. If the inner turmoil caused by our emotions tends to make time move faster, it follows that once we control our emotional responses to events, time will move much more slowly. This altered way of dealing witii tilings tends to lengdien our perception of future time, opens up possibilities that fear and anger close off, and allows us the patience tiiat is the principal requirement in the art of timing.
时间是我们自己创造的一种人为概念，目的是为了让永恒和宇宙的有限性更容易被接受，更人性化。既然时间的概念是我们构建的，我们也能在一定程度上塑造它，甚至操控它。孩童的时间漫长而缓慢，仿佛拥有无限的广袤；而成年人的时间却飞逝而过，令人胆战心惊。因此，时间取决于感知，而我们知道，感知是可以人为改变的。这是掌握时间艺术的首要前提。如果说我们情绪引发的内心动荡会使时间流逝得更快，那么，一旦我们控制了对事件的情绪反应，时间就会流逝得更慢。这种改变后的时间处理方式会延长我们对未来时间的感知，开启那些被恐惧和愤怒所封闭的可能性，并赋予我们耐心——而耐心正是掌握时间艺术的首要条件。
There are three kinds of time for us to deal with; each presents problems that can be solved with skill and practice. First there is long time: the drawn-out, years-long kind of time that must be managed with patience and gentle guidance. Our handling of long time should be mosdy defensivethis is die art of not reacting impulsively, of waiting for opportunity.
我们需要应对三种时间；每一种都会带来问题，而这些问题都可以通过技巧和实践来解决。首先是漫长的时间：那种漫长的、持续数年的时间，必须用耐心和温和的引导来处理。我们处理漫长的时间应该采取一种更为谨慎的态度——这是一种不冲动行事、等待时机的艺术。
we shall be in trouble." So he had the fellow's feet cut off. Both families did exactly the same thing, but one timed it right, the other wrong. Thus success depends on ... rhythm.
“我们会有麻烦的。”于是他让人砍掉了那人的双脚。两家人都做了同样的事情，但一家把握住了时机，另一家却错失了。因此，成功取决于……节奏。
LlEH TZU, QUOTED IN THE CHINESE LOOKING GLASS,
吕子，引自《中国镜花水月》
Dennis Bloodworth, 1967
丹尼斯·布拉德沃思，1967年
The sultan [of Persia] had sentenced two men to death. One of them, knowing how much the sultan loved his stallion, offered to teach the horse to fly within a year in return for his life. The sultan, fancying himself as the rider of the only flying horse in the world, agreed. The other prisoner looked at his friend in disbelief. “You know horses don 'tfly. What made you come up with a crazy idea like that You're only postponing the inevitable.” “Not so,” said the [first prisoner]. “I have actually given myself four chances for freedom. First, the sultan might die during the year. Second, I might die. Third, the horse might die. And fourth ... I might teach the horse to fly!”
波斯苏丹判处两人死刑。其中一人知道苏丹非常喜爱他的骏马，便提出一年之内教会这匹马飞行，以此换取自己的性命。苏丹自认为拥有世上唯一会飞的马，欣然同意。另一名囚犯难以置信地看着他的朋友。“你知道马不会飞。你怎么会冒出这么疯狂的想法？你只是在拖延不可避免的结局。”“并非如此，”第一个囚犯说道，“我其实给了自己四次重获自由的机会。第一，苏丹可能会在一年内死去。第二，我可能会死去。第三，这匹马可能会死去。第四……我或许能教会这匹马飞行！”
the craft of power.
权力的艺术。
R.G. H. Siu,
R.G. H. Siu，
A fisherman in the month of May stood angling on the bank of the Thames with an artificial fly. He threw his bait with so much art, that a young trout was rushing toward it, when she was prevented by her mother. “Never, ” said she, “my child, be too precipitate, where there is a possibility of danger. Take due time to consider, before you risk an action that may be fatal. How know you whether yon appearance be indeed a fly, or the snare of an enemy Let someone else make the experiment before you. If it be a fly, he will very probably elude the first attack: and the second may be made, if not with success, at least with safety.” She had no sooner spoken, than a gudgeon seized the pretended fly, and became an example to the giddy daughter of the importance of her mother's counsel.
五月的一个夜晚，一位渔夫站在泰晤士河岸边，用假饵垂钓。他抛饵的技巧娴熟，一条小鳟鱼正朝饵游去，却被她的母亲拦住了。“孩子，”母亲说，“切勿操之过急，尤其是在可能存在危险的地方。在冒险行事之前，务必深思熟虑，以免招致致命的后果。你怎么知道那究竟是一只假饵，还是敌人的陷阱呢？不妨让别人先试一试。如果是假饵，它很可能躲过第一次攻击；即使第二次尝试失败，至少也能保证安全。”话音刚落，一条鰕虎鱼便一口咬住了那假饵，给这位轻浮的女儿敲响了警钟，让她明白母亲的忠告有多么重要。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Robert Dodsley, 1703-1764
罗伯特·多兹利，1703-1764年
Next there is forced time: the short-term time that we can manipulate as an offensive weapon, upsetting the timing of our opponents. Finally there is end time, when a plan must be executed with speed and force. We have waited, found the moment, and must not hesitate.
其次是强制时间：我们可以利用这段短暂的时间作为进攻武器，扰乱对手的节奏。最后是终结时间，此时必须迅速有力地执行计划。我们已经等待了许久，时机已到，绝不能犹豫。
Long Time. The famous seventeenth-century Ming painter Chou Yung relates a story that altered his behavior forever. Late one winter afternoon he set out to visit a town that lay across die river from his own town. He was bringing some important books and papers with him and had commissioned a young boy to help him carry them. As tile ferry neared the other side of the river, Chou Yung asked the boatman if they would have time to get to the town before its gates closed, since it was a mile away and night was approaching. The boatman glanced at the boy, and at the bundle of loosely tied papers and books“Yes,” he replied, “if you do not walk too fast.”
很久以前。十七世纪明代著名画家周永讲述了一个彻底改变他一生的故事。一个冬日午后，他动身前往河对岸的一个小镇。他带着一些重要的书籍和文件，并雇了一个男孩帮他搬运。渡船驶近河对岸时，周永问船夫，由于小镇距离他家有一英里远，而且夜幕即将降临，他们能否在关门前到达。船夫看了看男孩，又看了看那捆松散捆扎的文件和书籍，回答说：“可以，只要你别走得太快。”
As they started out, however, the sun was setting. Afraid of being locked out of the town at night, prey to local bandits, Chou and the boy walked faster and faster, finally breaking into a run. Suddenly the string around the papers broke and the documents scattered on the ground. It took them many minutes to put the packet together again, and by the time they had reached the city gates, it was too late.
然而，他们出发时，太阳已经西沉。周和男孩害怕晚上被锁在城外，成为当地土匪的猎物，于是加快了脚步，最后跑了起来。突然，捆着文件的绳子断了，文件散落在地上。他们花了很长时间才把文件重新整理好，等他们跑到城门口时，已经太晚了。
When you force the pace out of fear and impatience, you create a nest of problems that require fixing, and you end up taking much longer than if you had taken your time. Hurriers may occasionally get there quicker, but papers fly everywhere, new dangers arise, and they find themselves in constant crisis mode, fixing the problems that they themselves have created. Sometimes not acting in the face of danger is your best moveyou wait, you deliberately slow down. As time passes it will eventually present opportunities you had not imagined.
当你出于恐惧和急躁而强行加快速度时，你会制造出一系列需要解决的问题，最终花费的时间远比放慢脚步要长得多。急躁的人或许偶尔能更快到达目的地，但文件会四处乱飞，新的危险也会不断出现，他们会发现自己始终处于危机模式，疲于应对自己制造的问题。有时，面对危险不采取行动才是最佳选择——等待，刻意放慢脚步。随着时间的推移，它最终会为你带来意想不到的机会。
Waiting involves controlling not only your own emotions but those of your colleagues, who, mistaking action for power, may try to push you into making rash moves. In your rivals, on the other hand, you can encourage this same mistake: If you let them rush headlong into trouble while you stand back and wait, you will soon find ripe moments to intervene and pick up the pieces. This wise policy was the principal strategy of the great early-seventeenth-century emperor Tokugawa Ieyasu of Japan. When his predecessor, the headstrong Hideyoshi, whom he served as a general, staged a rash invasion of Korea, Ieyasu did not involve himself. He knew the invasion would be a disaster and would lead to Hideyoshi's downfall. Better to stand patientiy on the sidelines, even for many years, and men be in position to seize power when the time is rightexactly what Ieyasu did, with great artistry.
等待不仅意味着控制自己的情绪，还要控制同僚的情绪。他们可能会误把行动等同于权力，从而怂恿你做出鲁莽的举动。另一方面，你也可以鼓励你的对手犯同样的错误：如果你让他们一头扎进麻烦，而你则袖手旁观，静待时机，你很快就会找到合适的时机介入，收拾残局。这种明智的策略正是17世纪初日本伟大的天皇德川家康的主要战略。当他的前任，那位他曾效力的、性情暴躁的丰臣秀吉，发动了对朝鲜的鲁莽入侵时，家康并没有亲自参与。他知道这次入侵将会是一场灾难，并会导致秀吉的垮台。与其如此，不如耐心地在一旁观望，即使长达数年，也要让那些有能力的人在时机成熟时夺取政权——家康正是如此，而且他运用了高超的策略。
You do not deliberately slow time down to live longer, or to take more pleasure in the moment, but the better to play the game of power. First, when your mind is uncluttered by constant emergencies you will see further into the future. Second, you will be able to resist the baits that people
你并非刻意放慢时间以求长寿或享受当下，而是为了更好地玩转权力游戏。首先，当你的思绪不再被持续不断的紧急情况所困扰时，你就能看得更远。其次，你将能够抵制人们的诱惑。
dangle in front of you, and will keep yourself from becoming another impatient sucker. Third, you will have more room to be flexible. Opportunities will inevitably arise that you had not expected and would have missed had you forced the pace. Fourth, you will not move from one deal to the next without completing die first one. To build your power's foundation can take years; make sure that foundation is secure. Do not be a flash in the pansuccess that is built up slowly and surely is the only kind that lasts.
在你面前摆放着诱饵，它能让你避免成为另一个急躁的傻瓜。第三，你将拥有更大的灵活性。你意想不到的机会必然会出现，而如果你强行加快节奏，这些机会就会错失。第四，你不会在完成第一个交易之前就急于进行下一个交易。建立你的实力基础可能需要数年时间；确保这个基础牢固。不要昙花一现——只有稳步积累的成功才能持久。
Finally, slowing time down will give you a perspective on the times you live in, letting you take a certain distance and putting you in a less emotionally charged position to see the shapes of things to come. Hurriers will often mistake surface phenomena for a real trend, seeing only what they want to see. How much better to see what is really happening, even if it is unpleasant or makes your task harder.
最后，放慢时间的脚步能让你以更客观的视角看待你所处的时代，让你与现实保持一定的距离，并以更冷静的心态去洞察未来的走向。急于求成的人常常会将表面现象误认为真正的趋势，只看到自己想看到的。与其如此，不如看清真相，即使真相令人不快或增加任务难度。
Forced Time. The trick in forcing time is to upset the timing of othersto make them hurry, to make diem wait, to make diem abandon their own pace, to distort dieir perception of time. By upsetting the timing of your opponent while you stay patient, you open up time for yourself, which is half the game.
强迫时间。强迫时间的诀窍在于扰乱对手的节奏，让他们匆忙行事，让他们等待，让他们放弃自己的节奏，扭曲他们对时间的感知。通过扰乱对手的节奏，同时保持耐心，你就能为自己赢得时间，而这本身就是游戏的一半。
In 1473 the great Turkish sultan Mehmed the Conqueror invited negotiations with Hungary to end the off-and-on war the two countries had waged for years. When the Hungarian emissary arrived in Turkey to start the talks, Turkish officials humbly apologizedMehmed had just left Istanbul, the capital, to battie his longtime foe, Uzun Hasan. But he urgently wanted peace with Hungary, and had asked that die emissary join him at the front.
1473年，伟大的土耳其苏丹穆罕默德二世（征服者穆罕默德）邀请匈牙利进行谈判，以结束两国断断续续持续多年的战争。当匈牙利使节抵达土耳其开始谈判时，土耳其官员谦卑地表示歉意。穆罕默德二世刚刚离开首都伊斯坦布尔，前往前线与他的宿敌乌尊·哈桑作战。但他迫切希望与匈牙利媾和，并要求使节与他一同前往前线。
When the emissary arrived at die site of die fighting, Mehmed had already left it, moving eastward in pursuit of his swift foe. This happened several times. Wherever the emissary stopped, the Turks lavished gifts and banquets on him, in pleasurable but time-consuming ceremonies. Finally Mehmed defeated Uzun and met witii die emissary. Yet his terms for peace widi Hungary were excessively harsh. After a few days, the negotiations ended, and the usual stalemate remained in place. But this was fine widi Mehmed. In fact he had planned it diat way all along: Plotting his campaign against Uzun, he had seen tiiat diverting his armies to die east would leave his western flank vulnerable. To prevent Hungary from taking advantage of his weakness and his preoccupation elsewhere, he first dangled the lure of peace before his enemy, dien made them waitall on his own terms.
当使者抵达战场时，穆罕默德已离开，向东追击他迅捷的敌人。这种情况反复发生。无论使者走到哪里，土耳其人都会以盛大的宴席款待他，虽然仪式繁复，却也令人愉悦。最终，穆罕默德击败了乌尊，并与使者会面。然而，他向匈牙利提出的和平条件却过于苛刻。几天后，谈判破裂，双方陷入僵局。但这对于穆罕默德来说正合心意。事实上，他早已预料到这种情况：在策划对乌尊的战役时，他就意识到将军队调往东方会使他的西翼门户大开。为了防止匈牙利趁他虚弱和分心之际趁虚而入，他先是向敌人抛出和平的诱饵，然后让他们按照自己的条件等待。
Making people wait is a powerful way of forcing time, as long as tiiey do not figure out what you are up to. You control the clock, they linger in limboand rapidly come unglued, opening up opportunities for you to strike. The opposite effect is equally powerful: You make your opponents hurry. Start off your dealings with diem slowly, dien suddenly apply pressure, making diem feel tiiat everydiing is happening at once. People who lack the time to think will make mistakesso set their deadlines for them.
让人们等待是一种有效的拖延时间的方法，只要他们没弄明白你的意图。你掌控着时间，他们就会陷入焦躁不安的状态，最终崩溃，为你创造反击的机会。反之亦然：你可以迫使对手匆忙行事。一开始与他们接触时要放慢节奏，然后突然施加压力，让他们感觉一切都在同时发生。缺乏思考时间的人容易犯错，所以要为他们设定截止日期。
This was the technique Machiavelli admired in Cesare Borgia, who, during negotiations, would suddenly press vehementiy for a decision, upsetting his opponent's timing and patience. For who would dare make Cesare wait
马基雅维利非常欣赏切萨雷·博尔吉亚的这种谈判技巧：在谈判中，切萨雷会突然强势地要求对方做出决定，打乱对手的节奏和耐心。因为谁敢让切萨雷久等呢？
Joseph Duveen, the famous art dealer, knew that if he gave an indecisive buyer like John D. Rockefeller a deadlinethe painting had to leave the country, another tycoon was interested in itdie client would buy just in time. Freud noticed that patients who had spent years in psychoanalysis without improvement would miraculously recover just in time if he fixed a definite date for the end of the therapy. Jacques Lacan, the famous French psychoanalyst, used a variation on this tactiche would sometimes end the customary hour session of therapy after only ten minutes, without warning. After this happened several times, the patient would realize that he had better make maximum use of the time, rather than wasting much of the hour with a lot of talk that meant nothing. The deadline, then, is a powerful tool. Close off the vistas of indecision and force people to make up their damn minds or get to the pointnever let them make you play on their excruciating terms. Never give them time.
著名艺术品经销商约瑟夫·杜维恩深谙此道：如果他给像约翰·D·洛克菲勒这样优柔寡断的买家设定一个最后期限——比如画作必须离开美国，或者有其他大亨对它感兴趣——客户就能及时出手。弗洛伊德注意到，那些接受多年精神分析治疗却毫无进展的病人，如果他设定一个明确的治疗结束日期，就能奇迹般地及时康复。法国著名精神分析学家雅克·拉康也采用了类似的策略——他有时会在治疗进行到十分钟时就结束通常一小时的疗程，而且不加任何预兆。几次之后，病人就会意识到，与其浪费大量时间进行毫无意义的谈话，不如充分利用时间。由此可见，最后期限是一种强有力的工具。堵住犹豫不决的漏洞，迫使人们下定决心，或者直奔主题——永远不要让他们按照他们那令人痛苦的条件来行事。永远不要给他们时间。
Magicians and showmen are experts in forcing time. Houdini could often wriggle free of handcuffs in minutes, but he would draw the escape out to an hour, making the audience sweat, as time came to an apparent standstill. Magicians have always known that the best way to alter our perception of time is often to slow down the pace. Creating suspense brings time to a terrifying pause: The slower the magician's hands move, the easier it is to create the illusion of speed, making people think the rabbit has appeared instantaneously. The great nineteenth-century magician Jean-Eugene Robert-Houdin took explicit notice of this effect: “The more slowly a story is told,” he said, “the shorter it seems.”
魔术师和表演者都是操控时间的专家。胡迪尼通常只需几分钟就能挣脱手铐，但他会把逃脱过程拖延一个小时，让观众屏息凝神，仿佛时间静止了一般。魔术师们一直深谙，改变我们对时间感知的最佳方法往往是放慢节奏。制造悬念能让时间陷入一种令人恐惧的停滞：魔术师的手越慢，就越容易营造出速度的错觉，让人觉得兔子是瞬间出现的。伟大的十九世纪魔术师让-欧仁·罗伯特-胡迪尼曾明确地注意到这种效果：“故事讲得越慢，”他说，“感觉就越短。”
Going slower also makes what you are doing more interestingthe audience yields to your pace, becomes entranced. It is a state in which time whizzes delightfully by. You must practice such illusions, which share in the hypnotist's power to alter perceptions of time.
放慢节奏也能让你的表演更有趣——观众会顺应你的节奏，沉浸其中。在这种状态下，时间仿佛飞逝而过，令人愉悦。你必须练习这种幻觉，它与催眠师改变人们对时间感知的能力有着异曲同工之妙。
End Time. You can play the game with die utmost artistrywaiting patiently for the right moment to act, putting your competitors off their form by messing with their timingbut it won't mean a thing unless you know how to finish. Do not be one of those people who look like paragons of patience but are actually just afraid to bring things to a close: Patience is worthless unless combined with a willingness to fall ruthlessly on your opponent at the right moment. You can wait as long as necessary for the conclusion to come, but when it comes it must come quickly. Use speed to paralyze your opponent, cover up any mistakes you might make, and impress people with your aura of authority and finality.
终结时刻。你可以玩转这场游戏，以精湛的技艺耐心等待最佳时机，扰乱对手的节奏，但如果你不知道如何终结比赛，这一切都毫无意义。不要成为那些看似耐心十足，实则害怕结束战斗的人：耐心若不与在关键时刻毫不留情地击败对手的决心相结合，便毫无价值。你可以等待足够长的时间，直到决胜时刻到来，但当它到来时，必须迅速结束。用速度麻痹对手，掩盖你可能犯下的任何错误，并以你的权威和终结力给人留下深刻印象。
With the patience of a snake charmer, you draw the snake out with calm and steady rhythms. Once the snake is out, though, would you dangle your foot above its deadly head There is never a good reason to allow the
你像耍蛇人一样耐心地用平静而稳定的节奏引诱蛇出来。然而，一旦蛇出来了，你难道会把脚悬在它致命的脑袋上方吗？永远没有理由允许这种情况发生。
slightest hitch in your endgame. Your mastery of timing can really only be judged by how you work with end timehow you quickly change the pace and bring things to a swift and definitive conclusion.
收官阶段哪怕出现最轻微的失误。你对时机的掌控能力，真正能体现在你如何处理收官阶段——如何迅速改变节奏，并迅速而果断地结束战斗。
Image: The Hawk. Patiently and silently it circles the sky, high above, all-seeing with its powerful eyes. Those below have no awareness that they are being tracked. Suddenly, when the moment arrives, the hawk swoops down with a speed that cannot be defended against; before its prey knows what has happened, the bird's viselike talons have carried it up into the sky.
图片：雄鹰。它耐心而静默地盘旋在高空，用它那双锐利的眼睛洞察一切。下方的生物丝毫没有察觉自己正被追踪。突然，时机一到，雄鹰便以迅雷不及掩耳之势俯冲而下；猎物还没反应过来，就被它利爪抓起，飞向天空。
Authority: There is a tide in the affairs of men, / Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; / Omitted, all the voyage of their life / Is bound in shallows and in miseries. {Julius Caesar, William Shakespeare, 1564-1616)
权威：人生如潮，/若把握涨潮，/则可走向成功；/若错失良机，/则一生航程/皆困于浅滩与苦难。（《尤利乌斯·凯撒》，威廉·莎士比亚，1564-1616）
REVERSAL
逆转
There is no power to be gained in letting go of the reins and adapting to whatever time brings. To some degree you must guide time or you will be its merciless victim. There is accordingly no reversal to this law.
放任自流、随波逐流并不能带来任何力量。在某种程度上，你必须引导时间，否则你将成为它无情的牺牲品。因此，这条法则没有逆转的余地。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 36
第36条
DISDAIN THINGS YOU CANNOT HAVE: IGNORING THEM IS THE BEST REVENGE
鄙视你得不到的东西：忽略它们就是最好的报复
JUDGMENT
判断
By acknowledging a petty problem you give it existence and credibility. The more attention you pay an enemy, the stronger you make him; and a small mistake is often made worse and more visible when you try to fix it. It is sometimes best to leave things alone. If there is something you want but cannot have, show contempt for it. The less interest you reveal, the more superior you seem.
承认一个微不足道的问题，就等于赋予它存在和可信度。你越关注敌人，他就越强大；试图弥补的小错误，往往会让情况变得更糟、更显眼。有时候，最好的办法就是置之不理。如果你想要某样东西却得不到，那就表现出对它的轻蔑。你表现得越冷漠，就越显得高人一等。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
The Mexican rebel leader Pancho Villa started out as the chief of a gang of bandits, but after revolution broke out in Mexico in 1910, he became a kind of folk herorobbing trains and giving the money to the poor, leading daring raids, and charming the ladies with romantic escapades. His exploits fascinated Americanshe seemed a man from another era, part Robin Hood, part Don Juan. After a few years of bitter fighting, however, General Carranza emerged as the victor in the Revolution; the defeated Villa and his troops went back home, to the northern state of Chihuahua. His army dwindled and he turned to banditry again, damaging his popularity. Finally, perhaps out of desperation, he began to rail against die United States, die gringos, whom he blamed for his troubles.
墨西哥叛军领袖潘乔·比利亚最初只是个土匪团伙的首领，但在1910年墨西哥革命爆发后，他摇身一变，成为一位民间英雄：抢劫火车并将赃款分发给穷人，领导大胆的劫掠行动，还以浪漫的风流韵事赢得女士们的喜爱。他的事迹令美国人着迷——他仿佛来自另一个时代，既有罗宾汉的影子，又有唐璜的魅力。然而，经过几年的激烈战斗，卡兰萨将军最终赢得了革命的胜利；战败的比利亚和他的军队返回了位于北部的奇瓦瓦州。他的军队日渐衰弱，他不得不重操旧业，再次走上土匪之路，这严重损害了他的声望。最终，或许是出于绝望，他开始抨击“美国”、“白人”，将自己的困境归咎于他们。
In March of 1916, Pancho Villa raided Columbus, New Mexico. Rampaging through the town, he and his gang killed seventeen American soldiers and civilians. President Woodrow Wilson, like many Americans, had admired Villa; now, however, the bandit needed to be punished. Wilson's advisers urged him to send troops into Mexico to capture Villa. For a power as large as the United States, they argued, not to strike back at an army that had invaded its territory would send the worst kind of signal. Furthermore, they continued, many Americans saw Wilson as a pacifist, a principle the public doubted as a response to violence; he needed to prove his mettle and manliness by ordering the use of force.
1916年3月，潘乔·维拉袭击了新墨西哥州的哥伦布镇。他和他的团伙在镇上横冲直撞，杀害了17名美国士兵和平民。伍德罗·威尔逊总统和许多美国人一样，曾经钦佩维拉；然而现在，这个匪徒必须受到惩罚。威尔逊的顾问们敦促他派兵进入墨西哥抓捕维拉。他们认为，对于美国这样一个大国来说，对入侵其领土的军队不进行反击，会发出最糟糕的信号。此外，他们还指出，许多美国人认为威尔逊是和平主义者，而公众对这种原则能否应对暴力表示怀疑；他需要通过下令使用武力来证明自己的勇气和魄力。
The pressure on Wilson was strong, and before the month was out, with the approval of the Carranza government, he sent an army of ten thousand soldiers to capture Pancho Villa. The venture was called the Punitive Expedition, and its leader was the dashing General John J. Pershing, who had defeated guerrillas in the Philippines and Native Americans in the American Southwest. Certainly Pershing could find and overpower Pancho Villa.
威尔逊面临的压力巨大，不到一个月，在卡兰萨政府的批准下，他便派遣了一万名士兵去抓捕潘乔·比利亚。这次行动被称为“惩罚性远征”，其指挥官是英勇无畏的约翰·J·潘兴将军，他曾在菲律宾击败过游击队，也曾在美国西南部击败过印第安人。潘兴将军肯定能够找到并制服潘乔·比利亚。
The Punitive Expedition became a sensational story, and carloads of U.S. reporters followed Pershing into action. The campaign, they wrote, would be a test of American power. The soldiers carried the latest in weaponry, communicated by radio, and were supported by reconnaissance from the air.
惩罚性远征成了轰动一时的新闻，大批美国记者跟随潘兴将军奔赴战场。他们写道，这场战役将是对美国实力的一次考验。士兵们携带了最先进的武器，通过无线电进行通讯，并得到空中侦察的支援。
In the first few months, the troops split up into small units to comb the wilds of northern Mexico. The Americans offered a $50,000 reward for information leading to Villa's capture. But the Mexican people, who had been disillusioned with Villa when he had returned to banditry, now idolized him for facing mis mighty American army. They began to give Pershing false leads: Villa had been seen in this village, or in that mountain hideaway, airplanes would be dispatched, troops would scurry after them, and no one would ever see him. The wily bandit seemed to be always one step ahead of the American military.
最初几个月，部队分成若干小队，在墨西哥北部荒野展开搜捕。美国人悬赏五万美元，征集抓捕比利亚的情报。但墨西哥人民此前对比利亚重操旧业、重操旧业感到失望，如今却因他敢于对抗强大的美军而将他奉为偶像。他们开始向潘兴提供虚假线索：有人说在某个村庄或某个山间藏身处见过比利亚，于是美军派出飞机，士兵们四处搜寻，却始终不见踪影。这个狡猾的匪徒似乎总是能先美军一步。
By the summer of that year, the expedition had swelled to 123,000 men. They suffered through the stultifying heat, the mosquitoes, the wild terrain. Trudging over a countryside in which they were already resented,
到那年夏天，探险队人数已膨胀至12.3万人。他们忍受着令人窒息的酷热、蚊虫叮咬和崎岖的地形。他们跋涉在一片早已令当地人厌恶的土地上，
THE FOX AND TKR CHAPKS
狐狸和TKR CHAPKS
A starving fox ...
一只饥饿的狐狸……
saw a cluster
看到一群
Of luscious-looking
看起来非常诱人
grapes of purplish
紫红色的葡萄
luster
光泽
Dangling above him on
悬在他上方
a trellis-frame.
格架。
He would have dearly
他非常希望
liked them for his
他喜欢他们。
lunch,
午餐，
But when he tried and
但当他尝试时
failed to reach the
未能到达
bunch:

"Ah well, it's more than
“啊，这不止是……”
likely they're not
很可能不是
sweet
甜的

fools to eat!"
傻瓜们要吃掉！

与其抱怨发牢骚，不如说“他们还没成熟”，这难道不是明智之举吗？
FABLES,
寓言故事
Jean de La Fontaine, 1621-1695
让·德拉封丹，1621-1695 年
Once when G K. Chesterton's economic views were abused in print by George Bernard Shaw, his friends waited in vain for him to reply. Historian Hilaire Belloc reproached him. “My dear Belloc,” Chesterton said, “I have answered him. To a man of Shaw's wit, silence is the one unbearable repartee.”
有一次，乔治·萧伯纳在报刊上抨击了G·K·切斯特顿的经济观点，切斯特顿的朋友们徒劳地等待着他的回应。历史学家希莱尔·贝洛克责备他。“亲爱的贝洛克，”切斯特顿说，“我已经回应过他了。对于像萧伯纳那样机智的人来说，沉默才是最令人难以忍受的反击。”
the little, brown book of anecdotes, Clifton Fadiman, ed., 1985
《小棕皮轶事集》，克利夫顿·法迪曼编，1985年
An ass had once by some accident lost his tail, which was a grievous affliction to him; and he was everywhere seeking after it, being fool enough to think he could get it set on again. He passed through a meadow, and afterwards got into a garden. The gardener seeing him, and not able to endure the mischief he was doing in trampling down his plants, fell into a violent rage, ran to the ass, and never standing on the ceremony of a pillory, cut off both his ears, and beat him out of the ground. Thus the ass, who bemoaned the loss of his tail, was in far greater affliction when he saw himself without ears.
从前，有一头驴不小心失去了尾巴，这让它痛苦不堪；它到处寻找尾巴，愚蠢地以为自己能把它重新接上。它穿过一片草地，后来又走进了一个花园。园丁看到它，实在忍无可忍，被它践踏花草，勃然大怒，冲到驴跟前，连示众的礼节都没遵守，就割掉了它的双耳，把它从地里打了出来。就这样，这头驴，原本为失去尾巴而哀叹，如今却发现自己失去了双耳，痛苦更加深重了。
FABLES, PlLPAY,
寓言，PlLPAY，
India, fourth century
印度，四世纪
iiii: I'uomov ox
iiii：伊奥莫夫牛
Once, when the Toku-daiji minister of the right was chief of the imperial police, he was holding a meeting of his staff at the middle gate when an ox belonging to an official named Akikane got loose and wandered into the ministry building. It climbed up on
有一次，右德大司担任警察总长时，正在中门召集部下开会，这时一位名叫秋兼的官员的一头牛挣脱了缰绳，溜进了内务部。它爬上了……
they infuriated bodi the local people and the Mexican government. At one point Pancho Villa hid in a mountain cave to recover from a gunshot wound he received in a skirmish with the Mexican army; looking down from his aerie, he could watch Pershing lead the exhausted American troops back and forth across the mountains, never getting any closer to their goal.
他们激怒了当地民众和墨西哥政府。潘乔·维拉曾一度躲进山洞疗伤，他在与墨西哥军队的一次小规模冲突中身负枪伤；从他的藏身之处向下望去，他看到潘兴率领疲惫不堪的美军在群山间来回穿梭，却始终无法接近他们的目标。
All the way into winter, Villa played his cat-and-mouse game. Americans came to see the affair as a kind of slapstick farcein fact they began to admire Villa again, respecting his resourcefulness in eluding a superior force. In January of 1917, Wilson finally ordered Pershing's withdrawal. As the troops made their way back to American territory, rebel forces pursued them, forcing the U.S. Army to use airplanes to protect its rear flanks. The Punitive Expedition was being punished itselfit had turned into a retreat of the most humiliating sort.
整个冬天，维拉都在玩着他那套猫捉老鼠的游戏。美国人开始把这场战役看作一场闹剧——事实上，他们开始重新欣赏维拉，敬佩他躲避优势兵力的机智。1917年1月，威尔逊最终下令潘兴撤退。当部队撤回美国领土时，叛军紧追不舍，迫使美军动用飞机掩护后方。惩罚性远征本身也受到了惩罚——它变成了一场极其屈辱的撤退。
Interpretation
解释
Woodrow Wilson organized the Punitive Expedition as a show of force: He
伍德罗·威尔逊组织了惩罚性远征，意在展示武力：他
would teach Pancho Villa a lesson and in the process show the world that
这将给潘乔·维拉一个教训，并在此过程中向世界表明：
no one, large or small, could attack the mighty United States and get away
无论大小，任何人都无法攻击强大的美国而全身而退。
with it. The expedition would be over in a few weeks, and Villa would be
随着它一起。探险将在几周后结束，维拉也将……
forgotten.
被遗忘了。
That was not how it played out. The longer the expedition took, the more it focused attention on the Americans' incompetence and on Villa's cleverness. Soon what was forgotten was not Villa but the raid that had started it all. As a minor annoyance became an international embarrassment, and the enraged Americans dispatched more troops, die imbalance between die size of the pursuer and the size of die pursuedwho still managed to stay freemade the affair a joke. And in the end this white elephant of an army had to lumber out of Mexico, humiliated. The Punitive Expedition did the opposite of what it set out to do: It left Villa not only free but more popular than ever.
事情的发展并非如此。远征拖得越久，就越凸显美国人的无能和维拉的机敏。很快，人们遗忘的不再是维拉，而是那场引发一切的突袭。原本的小麻烦演变成国际丑闻，愤怒的美国人增派了更多军队，追击者和被追击者人数的巨大差距——后者最终得以逃脱——使得这场行动沦为一场闹剧。最终，这支臃肿不堪的军队不得不灰溜溜地撤出墨西哥，颜面尽失。惩罚性远征的结果与预期截然相反：它不仅让维拉重获自由，反而使他比以往任何时候都更加受人拥戴。
What could Wilson have done differendy He could have pressured the Carranza government to catch Villa for him. Alternatively, since many Mexicans had tired of Villa before the Punitive Expedition began, he could have worked quietly with diem and won their support for a much smaller raid to capture the bandit. He could have organized a trap on the American side of the border, anticipating the next raid. Or he could have ignored die matter altogether for the time being, waiting for the Mexicans themselves to do away with Villa of their own accord.
威尔逊本可以采取哪些不同的做法？他可以向卡兰萨政府施压，让他们帮他抓捕比利亚。或者，由于许多墨西哥人在惩罚性远征开始前就已经厌倦了比利亚，他本可以与他们秘密合作，争取他们的支持，发动一次规模小得多的突袭来抓捕这个匪徒。他本可以在美墨边境设下埋伏，伺机抓捕下一个目标。或者，他也可以暂时完全忽略此事，等待墨西哥人自行除掉比利亚。
Remember: You choose to let things bother you. You can just as easily choose not to notice the irritating offender, to consider the matter trivial and unworthy of your interest. That is the powerful move. What you do not react to cannot drag you down in a futile engagement. Your pride is not involved. The best lesson you can teach an irritating gnat is to consign it to oblivion by ignoring it. If it is impossible to ignore (Pancho Villa had in fact killed American citizens), then conspire in secret to do away with it, but
记住：你可以选择让某些事情困扰你。你也可以选择无视那些烦人的事物，认为它们无关紧要，不值得你费心。这才是关键所在。你不去理会的事物不会让你陷入徒劳的纠缠。你的自尊心不会受到影响。你能教给烦人的小虫子的最好方法就是忽略它，让它彻底消失。如果实在无法忽略（比如潘乔·维拉确实杀害了美国公民），那就秘密策划除掉它，但……
never inadvertently draw attention to the bothersome insect that will go away or die on its own. If you waste time and energy in such entanglements, it is your own fault. Learn to play the card of disdain and turn your back on what cannot harm you in the long run.
永远不要无意中引起那些烦人的昆虫的注意，它们最终要么自行消失，要么自行死去。如果你在这种纠缠中浪费时间和精力，那完全是咎由自取。学会不屑一顾，对那些长远来看不会伤害你的事物置之不理。
Just thinkit cost your government $130 million to try to get me. I took them
想想看，你们政府为了抓我花了1.3亿美元。我把他们都抓走了。
over rough, hilly country. Sometimes for fifty miles at a stretch they had no water.
在崎岖不平的丘陵地带。有时，他们连续五十英里都没有水。
They had nothing but the sun and mosquitoes.... And nothing was gained.
他们除了太阳和蚊子什么也没有……而且一无所获。
Pancho Villa, 1878-1923
潘乔·维拉，1878-1923年
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In the year 1527, King Henry VIII of England decided he had to find a way to get rid of his wife, Catherine of Aragon. Catherine had failed to produce a son, a male heir who would ensure the continuance of his dynasty, and Henry thought he knew why: He had read in the Bible the passage, “And if a man shall take his brother's wife, it is an unclean thing: he hath uncovered his brother's nakedness; they shall be childless.” Before marrying Henry, Catherine had married his older brother Arthur, but Arthur had died five months later. Henry had waited an appropriate time, then had married his brother's widow.
1527年，英格兰国王亨利八世决定必须想办法摆脱他的妻子阿拉贡的凯瑟琳。凯瑟琳未能诞下儿子，也就是能够确保王朝延续的男性继承人，亨利自认为知道原因：他曾在《圣经》中读到过这样一段话：“人若娶他兄弟的妻子，这是不洁的事，因为他揭了他兄弟的下体；他们必无子嗣。”在嫁给亨利之前，凯瑟琳曾嫁给他的哥哥亚瑟，但亚瑟五个月后便去世了。亨利等待了一段时间后，便娶了哥哥的遗孀。
Catherine was the daughter of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella of Spain, and by marrying her Henry had kept alive a valuable alliance. Now, however, Catherine had to assure him that her brief marriage with Arthur had never been consummated. Otherwise Henry would view their relationship as incestuous and their marriage as null and void. Catherine insisted that she had remained a virgin through her marriage to Arthur, and Pope Clement VII supported her by giving his blessing to the union, which he could not have done had he considered it incestuous. Yet after years of marriage to Henry, Catherine had failed to produce a son, and in the early 1520s she had entered menopause. To the king this could only mean one thing: She had lied about her virginity, their union was incestuous, and God had punished them.
凯瑟琳是西班牙国王费迪南德和王后伊莎贝拉的女儿，亨利通过娶她维系了一段重要的联盟。然而，凯瑟琳现在必须向他保证，她与亚瑟的短暂婚姻从未圆房。否则，亨利会认为他们的关系是乱伦，他们的婚姻无效。凯瑟琳坚称自己在与亚瑟的婚姻期间一直保持处女之身，教皇克莱门特七世也支持她的说法，祝福了这段婚姻——如果他认为这是乱伦，他不可能这样做。然而，与亨利结婚多年后，凯瑟琳始终未能生育儿子，并在16世纪20年代初进入更年期。在国王看来，这只能说明一件事：她谎称自己是处女，他们的婚姻是乱伦，上帝惩罚了他们。
There was another reason why Henry wanted to get rid of Catherine: He had fallen in love with a younger woman, Anne Boleyn. Not only was he in love with her, but if he married her he could still hope to sire a legitimate son. The marriage to Catherine had to be annulled. For this, however, Henry had to apply to the Vatican. But Pope Clement would never annul the marriage.
亨利想除掉凯瑟琳还有另一个原因：他爱上了一位年轻女子安妮·博林。他不仅爱她，而且如果娶了她，他仍然有机会生下一个合法的儿子。因此，他与凯瑟琳的婚姻必须被宣告无效。然而，为此亨利必须向梵蒂冈提出申请。但教皇克莱门特二世绝不会批准这段婚姻。
By the summer of 1527, rumors spread throughout Europe that Henry was about to attempt the impossibleto annul his marriage against Clement's wishes. Catherine would never abdicate, let alone voluntarily enter a nunnery, as Henry had urged her. But Henry had his own strategy: He stopped sleeping in the same bed with Catherine, since he considered her his sister-in-law, not his lawful wife. He insisted on calling her Princess
到了1527年夏天，谣言传遍欧洲，说亨利八世即将做出不可能之举，违背克莱门特国王的意愿，宣布与凯瑟琳的婚姻无效。凯瑟琳绝不会退位，更不会像亨利八世劝她的那样自愿入修道院。但亨利八世自有妙计：他不再与凯瑟琳同床共枕，因为他视她为弟媳，而非合法妻子。他坚持称她为公主。
the dais where the chief was seated and lay there, chewing its cud. Everyone was sure that this was some grave portent, and urged that the ox be sent to a yin-yang diviner. However, the prime minister, the father of the minister of the right, said, “An ox has no discrimination. It has legsthere is nowhere it won't go. It does not make sense to deprive an underpaid official of the wretched ox he needs in order to attend court.” He returned the ox to its owner and changed the matting on which it had lain. No untoward event of any kind occurred afterward. They say that if you see a prodigy and do not treat it as such, its character as a prodigy is destroyed.
首领坐的台座上，一头牛倒在地上，反刍着。众人都认为这是不祥之兆，纷纷劝说将牛送去占卜阴阳师那里。然而，宰相，也就是右臣的父亲，却说：“牛没有专一，它有腿，哪里都去。剥夺一个佃农朝廷所需的那头可怜的牛，实在说不过去。”他把牛还给了主人，并换了牛躺过的垫子。此后，再无任何不祥之事发生。俗话说，如果你看到一个神童却不把它当神童看待，那么它作为神童的特质就会消失。
essays in idleness,
闲散随笔
Kenko,
健光
Japan,
日本，
fourteenth century
十四世纪
And in this view it is advisable to let everyone of your acquaintance whether man or womanfeel now and then that you could very well dispense with their company. This will consolidate friendship. Nay, with most people there will be no harm in occasionally mixing a grain of disdain with your treatment of them; that will make them value your friendship all the more. Chi non stima vien stimato, as a subtle Italian proverb has itto disregard is to win regard. But if we really think very highly of a person, we should conceal it from him like a crime. This is not a very gratifying thing to do, but it is right. Why, a dog will not bear being treated too kindly, let alone a man!
因此，不妨时不时地让你的熟人，无论男女，都感受到你完全可以不必和他们来往。这反而会巩固友谊。不，对大多数人来说，偶尔在对待他们时带点轻蔑并无坏处；这反而会让他们更加珍惜你们的友谊。正如一句精妙的意大利谚语所说：“Chi non stima vien stimato”（轻视才能赢得尊重）。但如果我们真的非常欣赏一个人，就应该像犯罪一样对他隐瞒。这样做或许并不令人愉快，但却是正确的。要知道，就连狗都受不了被人太好，更何况是人！
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
A monkey was carrying two handfuls of peas. One little pea dropped out. He tried to pick it up, and spilt twenty. He tried to pick up the twenty, and spilt them all. Then he lost his temper, scattered the peas in all directions, and ran away.
一只猴子手里拿着两把豌豆。一颗小豌豆掉了出来。它想捡起来，结果掉了二十颗。它又想捡起这二十颗，结果全都掉了。猴子气得火冒三丈，把豌豆撒得到处都是，然后跑开了。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Leo Tolstoy, 1828-1910
列夫·托尔斯泰，1828-1910
Dowager of Wales, her title as Arthur's widow. Finally, in 1531, he banished her from court and shipped her off to a distant casde. The pope ordered him to return her to court, on pain of excommunication, the most severe penalty a Catholic could suffer. Henry not only ignored diis threat, he insisted that his marriage to Cadierine had been dissolved, and in 1533 he married Anne Boleyn.
威尔士太后，这是她作为亚瑟王遗孀的头衔。最终，在1531年，亨利八世将她逐出宫廷，流放到一个偏远的城堡。教皇命令他必须将她送回宫廷，否则将处以绝罚，这是天主教徒所能遭受的最严厉的惩罚。亨利八世不仅无视教皇的威胁，还坚称他与卡迪琳的婚姻已经解除，并于1533年迎娶了安妮·博林。
Clement refused to recognize the marriage, but Henry did not care. He no longer recognized the pope's autiiority, and proceeded to break with the Roman Catholic Church, establishing the Church of England in its stead, with the king as the head of the new church. And so, not surprisingly, the newly formed Church of England proclaimed Anne Boleyn England's rightful queen.
克莱门特拒绝承认这桩婚姻，但亨利毫不在意。他不再承认教皇的权威，并脱离了罗马天主教会，取而代之的是建立英国国教，国王自任新教会的最高领袖。因此，不出所料，新成立的英国国教宣布安妮·博林为英格兰合法的王后。
The pope tried every threat in the book, but nothing worked. Henry simply ignored him. Clement fumedno one had ever treated him so contemptuously. Henry had humiliated him and he had no power of recourse. Even excommunication (which he constantly threatened but never carried out) would no longer matter.
教皇使尽浑身解数，威胁他，却都无济于事。亨利根本不理会他。克莱门特怒不可遏，从未有人如此轻蔑地对待他。亨利羞辱了他，他却无力反抗。就连教皇不断威胁要将他逐出教会（但从未付诸行动）也无济于事了。
Catherine too felt the devastating sting of Henry's disdain. She tried to fight back, but in appealing to Henry her words fell on deaf ears, and soon they fell on no one's. Isolated from die court, ignored by die king, mad widi anger and frustration, Cadierine slowly deteriorated, and finally died in January of 1536, from a cancerous tumor of the heart.
凯瑟琳也感受到了亨利轻蔑的刺痛。她试图反击，但她的请求却无人理睬，很快便无人理会。被宫廷孤立，被国王忽视，凯瑟琳因愤怒和沮丧而日渐衰弱，最终于1536年1月因心脏肿瘤去世。
Interpretation
解释
When you pay attention to a person, the two of you become partners of sorts, each moving in step to die actions and reactions of the otiier. In the process you lose your initiative. It is a dynamic of all interactions: By acknowledging otiier people, even if only to fight with them, you open yourself to dieir influence. Had Henry locked horns with Cadierine, he would have found himself mired in endless arguments tiiat would have weakened his resolve and eventually worn him down. (Cadierine was a strong, stubborn woman.) Had he set out to convince Clement to change his verdict on the marriage's validity, or tried to compromise and negotiate with him, he would have gotten bogged down in Clement's favorite tactic: playing for time, promising flexibility, but actually getting what popes always got dieir way.
当你关注一个人时，你们就成了某种伙伴，彼此步调一致，互相影响对方的行动和反应。在这个过程中，你会失去主动权。这是所有互动中都存在的动态：通过关注他人，即使只是为了与他们争吵，你也会让自己受到他们的影响。如果亨利与凯迪琳针锋相对，他就会陷入无休止的争论，这会削弱他的决心，最终让他精疲力竭。（凯迪琳是个坚强而固执的女人。）如果他试图说服克莱门特改变对婚姻有效性的裁决，或者试图与他妥协谈判，他就会落入克莱门特最常用的伎俩：拖延时间，承诺灵活变通，但实际上却总是如教皇们一贯所为。
Henry would have none of this. He played a devastating power gametotal disdain. By ignoring people you cancel diem out. This unset-ties and infuriates thembut since they have no dealings witii you, diere is notiiing they can do.
亨利根本不吃这一套。他玩弄权力游戏，完全蔑视他人。通过无视他人，你就等于抵消了他们的存在。这会激怒他们，让他们恼羞成怒，但既然他们与你没有任何瓜葛，他们也无能为力。
This is the offensive aspect of the law. Playing the card of contempt is immensely powerful, for it lets you determine the conditions of die conflict. The war is waged on your terms. This is the ultimate power pose: You are the king, and you ignore what offends you. Watch how tins tactic infuriates peoplehalf of what they do is to get your attention, and when you withhold it from them, they flounder in frustration.
这就是法律的进攻性一面。打出蔑视这张牌威力无穷，因为它能让你掌控冲突的局面。战争由你掌控。这是终极的权力姿态：你是王者，你对冒犯你的事物置之不理。看看这种策略如何激怒他人——他们一半的行为都是为了引起你的注意，而当你拒绝给予他们关注时，他们便会因挫败感而不知所措。
MAN: Kick himhe'll forgive you. Flatter himhe may or may not
男：踢他一脚，他会原谅你。奉承他，他可能原谅，也可能不原谅。
see through you. But ignore him and he'll hate you.
他看穿你了。但如果你不理他，他会恨你。
Idries Shah, Caravan of Dreams, 1968
伊德里斯·沙阿，《梦想之旅》，1968年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Desire often creates paradoxical effects: The more you want something, the more you chase after it, the more it eludes you. The more interest you show, the more you repel the object of your desire. This is because your interest is too strongit makes people awkward, even fearful. Uncontrollable desire makes you seem weak, unworthy, pathetic.
欲望常常会产生悖论式的效果：你越渴望某样东西，越是追逐它，它就越是遥不可及。你表现出的兴趣越浓厚，反而越会把心仪之物拒之门外。这是因为你的兴趣太过强烈，会让人感到尴尬，甚至恐惧。无法控制的欲望会让你显得软弱、无能、可怜。
You need to turn your back on what you want, show your contempt and disdain. This is the kind of powerful response mat will drive your targets crazy. They will respond with a desire of their own, which is simply to have an effect on youperhaps to possess you, perhaps to hurt you. If they want to possess you, you have successfully completed the first step of seduction. If they want to hurt you, you have unsettled them and made them play by your rules (see Laws 8 and 39 on baiting people into action).
你需要放弃自己的欲望，表现出你的轻蔑和鄙夷。这种强有力的回应会让你的目标对象抓狂。他们会产生自己的欲望，那就是想要影响你——或许是占有你，或许是伤害你。如果他们想要占有你，你就成功完成了诱惑的第一步。如果他们想要伤害你，你已经扰乱了他们的心神，让他们按照你的规则行事（参见关于引诱他人行动的第8条和第39条法则）。
Contempt is the prerogative of the king. Where his eyes turn, what he decides to see, is what has reality; what he ignores and turns his back on is as good as dead. That was the weapon of King Louis XIVif he did not like you, he acted as if you were not there, maintaining his superiority by cutting off the dynamic of interaction. This is the power you have when you play the card of contempt, periodically showing people mat you can do without them.
蔑视是君王的特权。他的目光投向何处，他选择看到什么，什么就是现实；他忽视和背弃的，就如同死物一般。这就是路易十四的武器：如果他不喜欢你，他就会装作你不存在，通过切断互动来维持他的优越感。当你打出蔑视这张牌时，你也拥有这种力量，时不时地向人们展示，没有他们你也能过得很好。
If choosing to ignore enhances your power, it follows that the opposite approachcommitment and engagementoften weakens you. By paying undue attention to a puny enemy, you look puny, and the longer it takes you to crush such an enemy, the larger the enemy seems. When Athens set out to conquer tlie island of Sicily, in 415 B.C., a giant power was attacking a tiny one. Yet by entangling Athens in a long-drawn-out conflict, Syracuse, Sicily's most important city-state, was able to grow in stature and confidence. Finally defeating Athens, it made itself famous for centuries to come. In recent times, President John F. Kennedy made a similar mistake in his attitude to Fidel Castro of Cuba: His failed invasion at the Bay of Pigs, in 1961, made Castro an international hero.
如果选择忽视能增强你的力量，那么与之相反的做法——投入和参与——往往会削弱你的力量。过分关注一个弱小的敌人，反而会让你显得渺小；而你花费的时间越长，敌人就越显得强大。公元前415年，雅典试图征服西西里岛，当时一个强大的国家正在攻击一个弱小的国家。然而，通过与雅典陷入旷日持久的冲突，西西里最重要的城邦叙拉古得以提升自身地位和信心。最终击败雅典后，叙拉古名扬四海，影响了后世。近代，美国总统约翰·F·肯尼迪在对待古巴领导人菲德尔·卡斯特罗的态度上也犯了类似的错误：1961年猪湾入侵的失败，反而使卡斯特罗成为了国际英雄。
A second danger: If you succeed in crushing the irritant, or even if you merely wound it, you create sympathy for the weaker side. Critics of Franklin D. Roosevelt complained bitterly about the money his administration spent on government projects, but their attacks had no resonance with the public, who saw the president as working to end die Great Depression. His opponents thought they had an example that would show just how wasteful he had become: his dog, Fala, which he lavished with favors and attention. Critics railed at his insensitivityspending taxpayers' money on a dog while so many Americans were still in poverty. But Roosevelt had a response: How dare his critics attack a defenseless little dog
第二个危险：如果你成功地压制了那个令人恼火的因素，或者哪怕只是让它受了点轻伤，你也会博得人们对弱势一方的同情。富兰克林·罗斯福的批评者们对他的政府在公共项目上的花费怨声载道，但他们的攻击并没有引起公众的共鸣，因为公众认为总统正在努力结束大萧条。他的反对者们认为他们找到了一个例子，可以证明他有多么挥霍无度：他的爱犬法拉，他给予它无微不至的关爱和照顾。批评者们猛烈抨击他冷酷无情，竟然把纳税人的钱花在一条狗身上，而当时还有那么多美国人生活在贫困之中。但罗斯福的回应是：他的批评者们怎么敢攻击一条毫无防备的小狗呢？
As some make gossip out of everything, so others make much ado about everything. They are always talking big, [and] take everything seriously, making a quarrel and a mystery of it. You should take very few grievances to heart, for to do so is to give yourself groundless worry. It is a topsyturvy way of behaving to take to heart cares which you ought to throw over your shoulder. Many things which seemed important [at the time] turn out to be of no account when they are ignored; and others, which seem trifling, appear formidable when you pay attention to them. Things can easily be settled at the outset, but not so later on. In many cases, the remedy itself is the cause of the disease: to let things be is not the least satisfactory of life's rules.
有些人喜欢把所有事都当成八卦，有些人则喜欢把所有事都大惊小怪。他们总是夸夸其谈，把所有事都看得太重，甚至为此争吵不休，疑神疑鬼。你应该尽量少把委屈放在心上，因为那样只会给自己带来无谓的忧虑。把本该抛诸脑后的烦恼放在心上，这是一种本末倒置的行为。许多当时看似重要的事情，如果置之不理，就会发现根本无关紧要；而另一些看似微不足道的事情，一旦引起重视，就会显得棘手。事情在开始时很容易解决，但事后却很难处理。很多时候，解决问题的办法本身就是问题的根源：顺其自然并非人生准则中最令人满意的一条。
Baltasar GraciAn, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
There was a certain
有一种
original man who
最初的那个人
desired to catch his
想抓住他
own shadow. He makes
他制造了自己的影子。他制造
a step or two toward it,
朝着这个方向迈出一两步，
but it moves away from
但它逐渐远离了
him. He quickens his
他加快了速度。
pace; it does the same.
节奏；它也是如此。
At last he takes to
最后他开始
running; but the
跑步；但是
quicker he goes, the
他走得越快，
quicker runs the
更快的跑步
shadow also, utterly
阴影也完全
refusing to give itself
拒绝献身
up, just as if it had been
起来，就像它曾经是
a treasure. But see! our
一件珍宝。但是看！我们的
eccentric friend
古怪的朋友
suddenly turns round,
突然转身，
and walks away from
然后转身离开
it. And presently he
它。而现在他
looks behind him; now
他回头看了看；现在
the shadow runs
影子奔跑
after him.
他之后。
Ladies fair, I have
女士们，我……
often observed ... that
经常观察到……
Fortune treats us in a
命运对待我们的方式
similar way. One man
类似的方式。一个人
tries with all his might
他竭尽全力
to seize the goddess,
抓住女神，
and only loses his time
他只是浪费时间。
and his trouble.
以及他的麻烦。
Another seems, to all
另一个似乎对所有人来说
appearance, to be
外表，是
running out of her
跑出她的
sight; but, no: she
视线；但是，不：她
herself takes a pleasure
她自己也乐在其中
in pursuing him.
在追捕他的过程中。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Ivan Kriloff, 1768-1844
伊万·克里洛夫，1768-1844
His speech in defense of Fala was one of the most popular he ever gave. In this case, the weak party involved was the president's dog and the attack backfiredin the long run, it only made the president more sympadietic, since many people will naturally side with the “underdog,” just as the American public came to sympathize with the wily but outnumbered Pan-cho Villa.
他为法拉辩护的演讲是他发表过的最受欢迎的演讲之一。在这种情况下，弱势一方是总统的亲信，而攻击最终适得其反，反而让总统更受同情，因为许多人自然会站在“弱者”一边，就像美国公众开始同情狡猾但寡不敌众的潘乔·比利亚一样。
It is tempting to want to fix our mistakes, but the harder we try, the worse we often make them. It is sometimes more politic to leave them alone. In 1971, when the New York Times published die Pentagon Papers, a group of government documents about the history of U.S. involvement in Indochina, Henry Kissinger erupted into a volcanic rage. Furious about die Nixon administration's vulnerability to diis kind of damaging leak, he made recommendations that eventually led to the formation of a group called die Plumbers to plug die leaks. This was the unit that later broke into Democratic Party offices in the Watergate Hotel, setting off the chain of events that led to Nixon's downfall. In reality the publication of the Pentagon Papers was not a serious direat to the administration, but Kissinger's reaction made it a big deal. In trying to fix one problem, he created an-otiier: a paranoia for security that in die end was much more destructive to the government. Had he ignored the Pentagon Papers, the scandal they had created would eventually have blown over.
我们总是忍不住想要弥补自己的错误，但往往越是努力，错误就越严重。有时候，置之不理反而更明智。1971年，《纽约时报》刊登了五角大楼文件，这是一组关于美国在印度支那军事行动历史的政府文件，亨利·基辛格勃然大怒。他对尼克松政府如此容易受到此类破坏性泄密事件的影响感到愤怒，并提出了一系列建议，最终促成了一个名为“管道工”的小组的成立，旨在堵住这些漏洞。正是这个小组后来闯入了水门酒店的民主党办公室，引发了一系列最终导致尼克松下台的事件。事实上，五角大楼文件的发表本身对尼克松政府并没有构成严重的威胁，但基辛格的反应却将其放大。他试图解决一个问题，却制造了另一个问题：一种对安全的过度担忧，最终对政府造成了更大的破坏。如果他当初对五角大楼文件置之不理，那么这些文件引发的丑闻最终也会平息下来。
Instead of inadvertendy focusing attention on a problem, making it seem worse by publicizing how much concern and anxiety it is causing you, it is often far wiser to play die contemptuous aristocrat, not deigning to acknowledge die problem's existence. There are several ways to execute this strategy.
与其无意间将注意力集中在某个问题上，并通过公开表达你的担忧和焦虑而使问题显得更加严重，不如扮演一个傲慢的贵族，不屑一顾地承认问题的存在。执行这种策略的方法有很多种。
First there is the sour-grapes approach. If there is something you want but that you realize you cannot have, the worst thing you can do is draw attention to your disappointment by complaining about it. An infinitely more powerful tactic is to act as if it never really interested you in the first place. When the writer George Sand's supporters nominated her to be the first female member of the Academie Francaise, in 1861, Sand quickly saw that the academy would never admit her. Instead of whining, though, she claimed she had no interest in belonging to this group of worn-out, overrated, out-of-touch windbags. Her disdain was die perfect response: Had she shown her anger at her exclusion, she would have revealed how much it meant to her. Instead she branded the academy a club of old menand why should she be angry or disappointed at not having to spend her time with them Crying “sour grapes” is sometimes seen as a reflection of the weak; it is actually the tactic of the powerful.
首先是“酸葡萄心理”。如果你想要某样东西，却发现得不到，最糟糕的做法就是抱怨，以此来暴露你的失望。一个更有效的策略是装作你一开始就对它不感兴趣。1861年，当作家乔治·桑的支持者提名她成为法兰西学院的首位女性成员时，桑很快意识到学院绝不会接纳她。然而，她并没有抱怨，而是声称自己对加入这个由一群老朽、被高估、脱离现实的空谈家组成的团体毫无兴趣。她的蔑视堪称完美的回应：如果她表现出对被拒之门外的愤怒，就会暴露出这件事对她有多么重要。相反，她将学院斥为一群老家伙的俱乐部——她为什么要因为不必和他们共事而感到愤怒或失望呢？“酸葡萄心理”有时被视为弱者的表现；但实际上，它是强者的策略。
Second, when you are attacked by an inferior, deflect people's attention by making it clear that die attack has not even registered. Look away, or answer sweetly, showing how litde the attack concerns you. Similarly, when you yourself have committed a blunder, the best response is often to make less of your mistake by treating it lightly.
其次，当受到不如你的人的攻击时，要转移人们的注意力，让他们觉得你根本没注意到这种攻击。你可以移开视线，或者温和地回应，表明你对这种攻击毫不在意。同样地，当你自己犯错时，最好的应对方式往往是轻描淡写地处理，从而减轻错误的影响。
The Japanese emperor Go-Saiin, a great disciple of the tea ceremony,
日本天皇后西院，茶道的忠实信徒，
owned a priceless antique tea bowl that all the courtiers envied. One day a guest, Dainagon Tsunehiro, asked if he could carry the tea bowl into the light, to examine it more closely. The bowl rarely left the table, but the emperor was in good spirits and he consented. As Dainagon carried the bowl to the railing of the verandah, however, and held it up to the light, it slipped from his hands and fell on a rock in the garden below, smashing into tiny fragments.
皇帝拥有一只价值连城的古董茶碗，令所有朝臣都艳羡不已。一天，一位名叫大纳言常弘的客人请求将茶碗拿到光亮处仔细端详。这只茶碗平时很少离开餐桌，但皇帝心情不错，便答应了。然而，当大纳言将茶碗拿到阳台栏杆边，举到光亮处时，茶碗却从他手中滑落，掉在花园里的一块石头上，摔得粉碎。
The emperor of course was furious. “It was indeed most clumsy of me to let it drop in this way,” said Dainagon, with a deep bow, “but really there is not much harm done. This Ido tea-bowl is a very old one and it is impossible to say how much longer it would have lasted, but anyhow it is not a thing of any public use, so I think it rather fortunate that it has broken thus.” This surprising response had an immediate effect: The emperor calmed down. Dainagon neither sniveled nor overapologized, but signaled his own worth and power by treating his mistake with a touch of disdain. The emperor had to respond with a similar aristocratic indifference; his anger had made him seem low and pettyan image Dainagon was able to manipulate.
天皇自然勃然大怒。“我的确失手让它摔在地上，”大纳言深深鞠了一躬，说道，“不过也没什么大碍。这只伊都茶碗年代久远，不知还能保存多久，反正它也不是供人使用的，所以我觉得摔碎了也算幸运。”这番出人意料的回应立竿见影：天皇顿时平静了下来。大纳言既没有哭哭啼啼，也没有过度道歉，而是以一种略带轻蔑的态度对待自己的过失，彰显了自己的身份和地位。天皇也只能以类似的贵族式冷漠回应；他的愤怒让他显得卑微而吝啬，而大纳言却巧妙地利用了这一点。
Among equals this tactic might backfire: Your indifference could make you seem callous. But with a master, if you act quickly and without great fuss, it can work to great effect: You bypass his angry response, save him the time and energy he would waste by brooding over it, and allow him the opportunity to display his own lack of pettiness publicly.
在地位平等的人之间，这种策略可能会适得其反：你的冷漠可能会显得你冷酷无情。但对付大师，如果你行动迅速且不张扬，就能取得显著成效：你绕过了他的愤怒反应，节省了他因耿耿于怀而浪费的时间和精力，并让他有机会公开展现自己不斤斤计较的品格。
If we make excuses and denials when we are caught in a mistake or a deception, we stir the waters and make the situation worse. It is often wiser to play things the opposite way. The Renaissance writer Pietro Aretino often boasted of his aristocratic lineage, which was, of course, a fiction, since he was actually the son of a shoemaker. When an enemy of his finally revealed the embarrassing truth, word quickly spread, and soon all of Venice (where he lived at the time) was aghast at Aretino's lies. Had he tried to defend himself, he would have only dragged himself down. His response was masterful: He announced that he was indeed the son of a shoemaker, but this only proved his greatness, since he had risen from the lowest stratum of society to its very pinnacle. From then on he never mentioned his previous lie, trumpeting instead his new position on the matter of his ancestry.
如果我们在犯错或说谎时找借口、否认，只会火上浇油，让情况变得更糟。通常，反其道而行之才是更明智的做法。文艺复兴时期的作家彼得罗·阿雷蒂诺经常吹嘘自己的贵族血统，这当然是虚构的，因为他实际上是一个鞋匠的儿子。当他的一个敌人最终揭露了这个令人尴尬的真相时，消息迅速传开，很快，整个威尼斯（他当时居住的地方）都对阿雷蒂诺的谎言感到震惊。如果他试图为自己辩解，只会让自己更加狼狈。他的回应堪称妙招：他宣布自己确实是鞋匠的儿子，但这反而证明了他的伟大，因为他从社会底层攀升到了顶峰。从此以后，他再也没有提及之前的谎言，而是大肆宣扬自己关于出身的新说法。
Remember: The powerful responses to niggling, petty annoyances and irritations are contempt and disdain. Never show that something has affected you, or that you are offendedthat only shows you have acknowledged a problem. Contempt is a dish that is best served cold and without affectation.
记住：对那些琐碎的烦恼和恼怒，最有效的应对方式是蔑视和鄙夷。永远不要表现出你受到了影响，或者你感到被冒犯——那样只会显得你承认了问题的存在。蔑视就像一道冷菜，最好是冷冰冰地端上来，不加任何矫饰。
Image:
图像：
The Tiny
小小
Wound.
伤口。
It is small but painful and irritating. You try all sorts of medicaments, you complain, you scratch and pick at the scab. Doctors only make it worse, transforming the tiny wound into a grave matter. If only you had left the wound alone, letting time heal it and freeing yourself of worry.
它虽小，却疼痛难忍，令人烦恼。你尝试了各种药物，抱怨个不停，还不停地抓挠结痂。医生们却只会让情况更糟，把小伤口夸大成大问题。要是你当初没管它，让时间慢慢愈合，让自己不再为此担忧就好了。
Authority: Know how to play the card of contempt. It is the most politic kind of revenge. For there are many of whom we should have known nothing if their distinguished opponents had taken no notice of them. There is no revenge like oblivion, for it is the entombment of the unworthy in the dust of their own nothingness. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：要懂得如何打出蔑视这张牌。这是最巧妙的报复。因为若非那些杰出的对手对他们视而不见，我们或许根本不会知道这些人的存在。没有什么比被遗忘更能报复人心，因为那是将不配之人埋葬在他们自身虚无的尘埃之中。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
You must play the card of contempt with care and delicacy. Most small troubles will vanish on their own if you leave diem be; but some will grow and fester unless you attend to them. Ignore a person of inferior stature and the next time you look he has become a serious rival, and your contempt has made him vengeful as well. The great princes of Renaissance Italy chose to ignore Cesare Borgia at the outset of his career as a young general in the army of his father, Pope Alexander VI. By the time they paid attention it was too latedie cub was now a lion, gobbling up chunks of Italy. Often, tlien, while you show contempt publicly you will also need to keep an eye on the problem privately, monitoring its status and making sure it goes away. Do not let it become a cancerous cell.
你必须谨慎巧妙地运用蔑视这张牌。大多数小麻烦，如果你置之不理，它们会自行消失；但有些麻烦，如果你不去处理，就会滋生蔓延，最终恶化。如果你忽视一个地位低下的人，下次再看他时，他可能已经成为一个强大的对手，而你的蔑视也会让他心生怨恨。文艺复兴时期意大利的那些大君们，在切萨雷·博尔吉亚年轻时，选择对他不予理睬，当时他只是他父亲——教皇亚历山大六世军队中的一名年轻将军。等到他们注意到他时，已经为时过晚，这只幼狮已经长成了一头雄狮，吞噬着意大利的大片领土。通常情况下，即使你在公开场合表现出蔑视，你也需要在私下里密切关注问题，观察它的进展，确保它最终消失。不要让它变成癌细胞。
Develop the skill of sensing problems when they are still small and taking care of them before they become intractable. Learn to distinguish between the potentially disastrous and the mildly irritating, the nuisance that will quietiy go away on its own. In eidier case, though, never completely take your eye off it. As long as it is alive it can smolder and spark into life.
培养在问题初期就察觉并解决它们的能力，以免它们变得难以处理。学会区分潜在的灾难性问题和轻微的烦恼，后者会悄然自行消失。但无论如何，都不要完全放任不管。只要它还存在，就可能暗流涌动，最终爆发。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 37
第37条
CREATE COMPELLING SPECTACLES
创造引人入胜的奇观
JUDGMENT
判断
Striking imagery and grand symbolic gestures create the aura of powereveryone responds to them. Stage spectacles for those around you, then, full of arresting visuals and radiant symbols that heighten your presence. Dazzled by appearances, no one will notice what you are really doing.
引人注目的画面和宏大的象征性姿态营造出一种强大的气场，人人都会被其所吸引。因此，要为周围的人打造精彩纷呈的舞台表演，运用震撼的视觉效果和耀眼的符号来提升你的存在感。然而，人们往往被表象所迷惑，而不会注意到你真正的意图。
ANTONY ANDCI.KOI'VIHA
安东尼·安德西·科伊·维哈
She relied above all upon her physical presence and the spell and enchantment which it could create.... She came sailing up the river Cydnus in a barge with a poop of gold, its purple sails billowing in the wind, while her rowers caressed the water with oars of silver which dipped in time to the music of the flute, accompanied by pipes and lutes. Cleopatra herself reclined beneath a canopy of cloth of gold, dressed in the character of Aphrodite, as we see her in paintings, while on either side to complete the picture stood boys costumed as Cupids who cooled her with their fans. Instead of a crew the barge was lined with the most beautiful of her waiting-women attired as Nereids and Graces, some at the rudders, others at the tackle of the sails, and all the while an indescribably rich perfume, exhaled from innumerable censers, was wafted from the vessel to the riverbanks. Great multitudes accompanied this royal progress, some of them following the queen on both sides of the river from its very mouth, while others hurried down from the city of Tarsus to gaze at the sight. Gradually the crowds drifted away from the marketplace,
她最倚仗的莫过于自身的魅力，以及这种魅力所能营造的魔力……她乘着一艘金色船首的驳船，沿着库德诺斯河逆流而上，紫色的船帆在风中猎猎作响。船夫们用银桨轻柔地划动着船身，船桨随着笛声的节奏轻轻摆动，笛声和鲁特琴声也随之响起。克利奥帕特拉本人斜倚在金色的华盖之下，身着阿芙洛狄忒的装束，正如我们在画作中所见。两侧站着装扮成丘比特的男孩，用扇子为她拂去身上的凉意，更添几分神韵。驳船上没有船员，取而代之的是她最美丽的侍女们，她们装扮成涅瑞伊得斯和格蕾丝，有的掌舵，有的操纵帆索。无数香炉散发出浓郁得难以言喻的香气，从船上飘向河岸。大批民众跟随王后巡游，有些人从河口就沿着河两岸一路跟随，而另一些人则从塔尔苏斯城匆匆赶来观看。人群渐渐从集市散去。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
In the early 1780s, word spread through Berlin of the strange and spectacular medical practice of a Dr. Weisleder. He performed his miracles in an enormous converted beer hall, outside which Berliners began to notice ever longer lines of peoplethe blind, the lame, anyone with an illness incurable by normal medicine. When it leaked out that the doctor worked by exposing the patient to the rays of the moon, he soon became dubbed The Moon Doctor of Berlin.
18世纪80年代初，魏斯莱德医生的奇特行医方式在柏林广为流传。他在一座由啤酒馆改建而成的巨大建筑里行医，柏林人开始注意到，啤酒馆外总是排着越来越长的队伍——盲人、跛子，以及所有患有常规医学无法治愈的疾病的人。后来，当人们得知这位医生是通过让病人暴露在月光下进行治疗时，他很快就被冠以“柏林月光医生”的称号。
Sometime in 1783, it was reported that Dr. Weisleder had cured a well-to-do woman of a terrible ailment. He suddenly became a celebrity. Previously only the poorest Berliners had been seen waiting outside the beer hall in their rags; now magnificent carriages were parked outside, and gentlemen in frock coats, and ladies with enormous coiffures, lined the street as sunset drew near. Even folk with the mildest of ailments came, out of sheer curiosity. As they waited in line, the poorer clients would explain to the gentlemen and ladies that the doctor only practiced when the moon was in its increscent phase. Many would add that they themselves had already been exposed to die healing powers he called forth from the rays of the moon. Even those who felt cured kept coming back, drawn by this powerful experience.
1783年的某一天，据说魏斯莱德医生治愈了一位富裕妇女的重病。他一夜之间成了名人。此前，只有最贫穷的柏林人才会衣衫褴褛地在啤酒馆外等候；如今，华丽的马车停在外面，身着礼服的绅士和梳着夸张发型的女士们在夕阳西下时分，沿着街道排起了长队。就连一些患有轻微疾病的人也出于好奇前来就诊。在排队等候时，那些贫穷的病人会向绅士淑女们解释说，这位医生只在月牙形时行医。许多人还会补充说，他们自己也曾亲身感受到过他从月光中召唤出的神奇治愈力量。即使是那些感觉已经痊愈的人，也被这种神奇的体验所吸引，一次又一次地前来就诊。
Inside the beer hall, a strange and stirring spectacle greeted the visitor: Packed into the entrance hall was a crowd of all classes and ethnic backgrounds, a veritable Tower of Babel. Through tall windows on the northern side of the hall, silvery moonlight poured in at odd angles. The doctor and his wife, who, it seemed, was also able to effect the cure, practiced on the second floor, which was reached by a stairway, at the end of the hall. As the line edged closer to the stairs, the sick would hear shouts and cries from above, and word would spread of, perhaps, a blind gentleman suddenly able to see.
走进啤酒馆，映入眼帘的是一幅奇异而震撼的景象：入口大厅里挤满了各阶层、各族裔的人，宛如一座巴别塔。银色的月光透过大厅北侧的高窗，以奇特的角度倾泻而入。医生和他的妻子——她似乎也拥有治愈疾病的能力——在二楼行医，二楼位于大厅尽头，需拾级而上。随着队伍向楼梯方向移动，病人会听到楼上传来的喊叫声和哭喊声，消息也随之传开，或许是一位盲人突然重见光明。
Once upstairs, the line would fork in two directions, toward a northern room for the doctor, a southern one for his wife, who worked only on the ladies. Finally, after hours of anticipation and waiting in line, the gentlemen patients would be led before the amazing doctor himself, an elderly man with a few stalks of wild gray hair and an air of nervous energy. He would take the patient (let us say a young boy, brought in by his father), uncover the afflicted body part, and lift the boy up to the window, which faced the light of the moon. He would rub the site of the injury or illness, mumble something unintelligible, look knowingly at the moon, and then, after collecting his fee, send the boy and his father on their way. Meanwhile, in the south-facing room, his wife would be doing the same with the ladieswhich was odd, really, since the moon cannot appear in two places at once; it cannot have been visible, in other words, from both windows. Apparendy the mere thought, idea, and symbol of the moon were enough, for the ladies did not complain, and would later remark confidently that the wife of the Moon Doctor had the same healing powers as he.
到了楼上，队伍会分成两条路，一条通往北面的房间，那是医生的诊室；另一条通往南面的房间，那是他妻子的诊室，她只给女士看病。最终，经过几个小时的翘首期盼和排队等待，男士们会被带到那位令人敬畏的医生面前。他是一位上了年纪的老人，几缕灰白的头发蓬乱不堪，浑身散发着一种紧张而又充满活力的气息。他会抱起病人（比如说一个由父亲带来的小男孩），揭开患处的皮，然后把男孩抱到窗边，窗外月光皎洁。他会揉搓患处，咕哝几句含糊不清的话，意味深长地望一望月亮，然后收完诊费，让男孩和他的父亲离开。与此同时，在朝南的房间里，他的妻子也在为女士们做着同样的事情——这其实很奇怪，因为月亮不可能同时出现在两个地方；换句话说，它不可能同时出现在两个窗户里。显然，仅仅是月亮的意象、概念和象征就足够了，因为女士们没有抱怨，后来还自信地表示，月亮医生的妻子拥有和他一样的治愈能力。
Interpretation
解释
Dr. Weisleder may have known nothing about medicine, but he understood human nature. He recognized that people do not always want words, or rational explanations, or demonstrations of the powers of science; they want an immediate appeal to their emotions. Give them that and they will do the restsuch as imagine they can be healed by the light reflected from a rock a quarter million miles away. Dr. Weisleder had no need of pills, or of lengtfry lectures on the moon's power, or of any silly gadgetry to amplify its rays. He understood that the simpler the spectacle the betterjust the moonlight pouring in from the side, the stairway leading to the heavens, and the rays of the moon, whether directly visible or not. Any added effects might have made it seem that the moon was not strong enough on its own. And the moon was strong enoughit was a magnet for fantasies, as it has been throughout history. Simply by associating himself with the image of the moon, the doctor gained power.
韦斯莱德医生或许不懂医学，但他深谙人性。他明白，人们并非总是需要言语、理性解释或科学力量的证明；他们渴望的是直接的情感共鸣。只要满足了这一点，他们就会自行其是——比如想象自己能被二十五万英里之外的岩石反射的光芒治愈。韦斯莱德医生无需药丸，也无需冗长的月球能量讲座，更无需任何愚蠢的装置来增强月光。他明白，景象越简单越好——仅仅是月光从侧面倾泻而下，通往天际的阶梯，以及月光，无论是否直接可见。任何附加效果都可能让人觉得月亮本身的力量不够强大。而月亮的力量已经足够强大——它如同历史上的常态，是激发人们幻想的磁石。仅仅通过将自己与月亮的形象联系起来，这位医生就获得了力量。
Remember: Your search for power depends on shortcuts. You must always circumvent people's suspicions, their perverse desire to resist your will. Images are an extremely effective shortcut: Bypassing the head, the seat of doubt and resistance, they aim straight for the heart. Overwhelming the eyes, they create powerful associations, bringing people together and stirring their emotions. With the white light of the moon in their eyes, your targets are blinded to the deceptions you practice.
记住：你对权力的追求依赖于捷径。你必须时刻规避人们的猜疑，以及他们反抗你意志的邪恶欲望。图像是一种极其有效的捷径：它们绕过了怀疑和抗拒的根源——头脑，直击人心。它们震撼人心，唤起强烈的联想，将人们凝聚在一起，激起他们的情感。当月光洒在他们眼中时，你的目标人物便会被你所施展的欺骗蒙蔽。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW II
遵守法律 II
In 1536 the future king Henri II of France took his first mistress, Diane de Poitiers. Diane was thirty-seven at the time, and was the widow of the grand seneschal of Normandy. Henri, meanwhile, was a sprightly lad of seventeen, who was just beginning to sow his wild oats. At first their union seemed merely platonic, with Henri showing an intensely spiritual devotion to Diane. But it soon became clear tiiat he loved her in every way, preferring her bed to that of his young wife, Catherine de' Medicis.
1536年，未来的法国国王亨利二世迎娶了他的第一位情妇黛安娜·德·波瓦捷。黛安娜当时37岁，是诺曼底大总管的遗孀。而亨利则是一位17岁的英俊少年，正值青春年少，开始放荡不羁。起初，他们的关系似乎只是柏拉图式的，亨利对黛安娜表现出一种强烈的精神追求。但很快，人们便发现他爱上了她的一切，甚至宁愿与她同床共枕，也不愿与年轻的妻子凯瑟琳·德·美第奇同床。
In 1547 King Francis died and Henri ascended to the throne. This new situation posed perils for Diane de Poitiers. She had just turned forty-eight, and despite her notorious cold baths and rumored youth potions, she was beginning to show her age; now that Henri was king, perhaps he would return to the queen's bed, and do as other kings had donechoose mistresses from the bevy of beauties who made the French court the envy of Europe. He was, after all, only twenty-eight, and cut a dashing figure. But Diane did not give up so easily. She would continue to enthrall her lover, as she had enthralled him for the past eleven years.
1547年，弗朗索瓦国王驾崩，亨利二世继位。这一新的局面给黛安娜·德·波蒂埃带来了危险。她刚刚年满四十八岁，尽管她以冷水浴和传闻中的青春灵药而闻名，但她已开始显露岁月的痕迹；如今亨利二世登基，或许他会重回王后的床榻，像其他国王一样，从众多令法国宫廷艳羡的美人中挑选情妇。毕竟，他才二十八岁，风度翩翩。但黛安娜并没有轻易放弃。她将继续令她的情人着迷，就像过去十一年里她令他着迷一样。
Diane's secret weapons were symbols and images, to which she had always paid great attention. Early on in her relationship with Henri, she had created a motif by intertwining her initials with his, to symbolize their union. The idea worked like a charm: Henri put this insignia everywhere on his royal robes, on monuments, on churches, on the facade of the
黛安娜的秘密武器是符号和图像，她一直非常重视这些。在她与亨利交往初期，她就将自己的名字首字母与亨利的名字首字母交织在一起，创造了一个象征他们结合的图案。这个主意非常奏效：亨利将这个标志运用到他所有的地方，比如他的皇家礼服、纪念碑、教堂，以及……
where Antony awaited the queen enthroned on his tribunal, until at last he was left sitting quite alone. And the word spread on every side that Aphrodite had come to revel with Dionysus for the happiness of Asia. Antony then sent a message inviting Cleopatra to dine with him. But she thought it more appropriate that he should come to her, and so, as he wished to show his courtesy and goodwill, he accepted and went. He found the preparations made to receive him magnificent beyond words, but what astonished him most of all was the extraordinary number of lights. So many of these, it is said, were let down from the roof and displayed on all sides at once, and they were arranged and grouped in such ingenious patterns in relation to each other, some in squares and some in circles, that they created as brilliant a spectacle as can ever have been devised to delight the eye.
安东尼端坐在他的宝座上，等待着女王的到来，直到最后只剩下他一个人。消息迅速传遍四方，说阿芙洛狄忒前来与狄俄尼索斯一同狂欢，为亚洲带来幸福。安东尼随即派人邀请克利奥帕特拉与他共进晚餐。但克利奥帕特拉认为他应该亲自前往，于是，为了表示礼貌和善意，他欣然应允，前往赴宴。他发现迎接他的准备工作无比壮丽，但最令他惊叹的还是那数量惊人的灯光。据说，无数的灯光从屋顶垂下，同时照亮四面八方，它们彼此之间排列组合，巧妙绝伦，有的呈方形，有的呈圆形，构成了一幅美轮美奂的景象，令人叹为观止。
life of antony, Plutarch, c. a.d. 46-120
安东尼传，普鲁塔克，约公元46-120年
In the Middle Ages the symbolist attitude was much more in evidence. ... Symbolism appears as a sort of short cut of thought. Instead of looking for the relation
中世纪时期，象征主义倾向更为明显。……象征主义似乎是一种思维捷径。它无需探究事物之间的关联。
between two things by following the hidden detours of their causal connexions, thought makes a leap and discovers their relation not in the connexion of cause and effects, but in a connexion of signification. ... Symbolist thought permits an infinity of relations between things. Each thing may denote a number of distinct ideas by its different special qualities, and a quality may have several symbolic meanings. The highest conceptions have symbols by the thousand. Nothing is too humble to represent and glory the sublime. The walnut signifies Christ: the sweet kernel is His divine nature, the green and pulpy outer peel is His humanity, the wooden shell between is the cross. Thus all things raise his thoughts to the eternal.. .. Every precious stone, besides its natural splendour sparkles with the brilliance of its symbolic values. The assimilation of roses and virginity is much more than a poetic comparison, for it reveals their common essence. As each notion arises in the mind the logic of symbolism creates an harmony of ideas.
通过追溯两件事物之间因果关系的隐秘路径，思维得以飞跃，发现它们之间的关系并非建立在因果关系之上，而是建立在意义关系之上。……象征主义思维允许事物之间存在无限的关系。每件事物都可以通过其不同的特殊属性来指代许多不同的概念，而一个属性本身也可以具有多种象征意义。最高的理念拥有数不胜数的象征。没有什么卑微的事物不足以代表和颂扬崇高。核桃象征着基督：甜美的果仁代表祂的神性，绿色多汁的外皮代表祂的人性，中间的木质外壳则代表十字架。因此，万物都将祂的思想提升到永恒……每一颗宝石，除了其天然的光辉之外，还闪耀着其象征价值的光芒。玫瑰与贞洁的结合远非简单的诗意比喻，因为它揭示了它们共同的本质。当每一个概念在脑海中浮现时，象征主义的逻辑便创造出一种理念的和谐。
THE WANING OF THE
衰落
MIDDLE AGES,
中世纪，
JOHAN HUIZINGA,
约翰·惠津加
Louvre, then the royal palace in Paris. Diane's favorite colors were black and white, which she wore exclusively, and wherever it was possible the insignia appeared in these colors. Everyone recognized the symbol and its meaning. Soon after Henri took the throne, however, Diane went still further: She decided to identify herself with the Roman goddess Diana, her namesake. Diana was the goddess of the hunt, the traditional royal pastime and the particular passion of Henri. Equally important, in Renaissance art she symbolized chastity and purity. For a woman like Diane to identify herself with tiiis goddess would instantly call up those images in the court, giving her an air of respectability. Symbolizing her “chaste” relationship with Henri, it would also set her apart from the adulterous liaisons of royal mistresses past.
卢浮宫，以及后来的巴黎皇宫。黛安娜最喜欢的颜色是黑白两色，她只穿这两种颜色的衣服，而且凡是可能的地方，她的徽章也都以这两种颜色出现。每个人都能认出这个符号及其含义。然而，亨利登基后不久，黛安娜更进一步：她决定将自己与罗马女神狄安娜（Diana）联系起来，而狄安娜正是她名字的由来。狄安娜是狩猎女神，狩猎是传统的皇室消遣，也是亨利的挚爱。同样重要的是，在文艺复兴时期的艺术中，她象征着贞洁和纯洁。像黛安娜这样的女人如果将自己与这位女神联系起来，会立刻在宫廷中唤起人们对这些形象的联想，从而赋予她一种尊贵的气质。这象征着她与亨利之间“纯洁”的关系，也使她与以往那些与亨利有染的皇室情妇们截然不同。
To effect this association, Diane began by completely transforming her casde at Anet. She razed the building's structure and in its place erected a magnificent Doric-columned edifice modeled after a Roman temple. It was made in white Normandy stone flecked with black silex, reproducing Diane's trademark colors of black and white. The insignia of her and Henri's initials appeared on the columns, the doors, the windows, the carpet. Meanwhile, symbols of Dianacrescent moons, stags, and hounds adorned the gates and facade. Inside, enormous tapestries depicting episodes in the life of the goddess lay on the floors and hung on the walls. In the garden stood the famous Goujon sculpture Diane Chasseresse, which is now in the Louvre, and which had an uncanny resemblance to Diane de Poitiers. Paintings and other depictions of Diana appeared in every corner of the casde.
为了实现这一目标，黛安娜首先彻底改造了她在阿内特的宅邸。她拆除了原有的建筑结构，并在原址上建造了一座宏伟的多立克柱式建筑，其造型仿照罗马神庙。建筑采用白色诺曼底石材，点缀着黑色燧石，再现了黛安娜标志性的黑白配色。她和亨利的姓名首字母缩写出现在柱子、门窗和地毯上。同时，黛安娜的象征——新月、雄鹿和猎犬——装饰着大门和立面。宅邸内部，描绘女神生平事迹的巨幅挂毯铺在地板上，悬挂在墙上。花园里矗立着著名的古容雕塑《狩猎女神黛安娜》，现藏于卢浮宫，这尊雕塑与黛安娜·德·波瓦捷有着惊人的相似之处。宅邸的每个角落都装饰着黛安娜的绘画和其他形象。
Anet overwhelmed Henri, who soon was trumpeting the image of Diane de Poitiers as a Roman goddess. In 1548, when the couple appeared together in Lyons for a royal celebration, the townspeople welcomed them with a tableau vivant depicting a scene with Diana the huntress. France's greatest poet of die period, Pierre de Ronsard, began to write verses in honor of Dianaindeed a kind of cult of Diana sprang up, all inspired by the king's mistress. It seemed to Henri that Diane had given herself a kind of divine aura, and as if he were destined to worship her for the rest of his life. And until his death, in 1559, he did remain faithful to hermaking her a duchess, giving her untold wealth, and displaying an almost religious devotion to his first and only mistress.
阿内特彻底征服了亨利，他很快便将黛安娜·德·波蒂埃奉为罗马女神。1548年，这对情侣一同出现在里昂参加皇家庆典时，当地居民以一幅描绘狩猎女神黛安娜的活人画迎接他们。法国当时最伟大的诗人皮埃尔·德·龙萨尔开始创作赞美黛安娜的诗歌——事实上，一种对黛安娜的崇拜兴起，这一切都源于国王的情妇。在亨利看来，黛安娜仿佛拥有某种神圣的光环，仿佛他注定要终生崇拜她。直到1559年去世，他始终忠于她，册封她为公爵夫人，赐予她巨额财富，并对他这位唯一的情妇表现出近乎宗教般的虔诚。
Interpretation
解释
Diane de Poitiers, a woman from a modest bourgeois background, managed to captivate Henri for over twenty years. By the time he died she was well into her sixties, yet his passion for her only increased with the years. She knew the king well. He was not an intellectual but a lover of die outdoorshe particularly loved jousting tournaments, with their bright pennants, brilliandy caparisoned horses, and beautifully dressed women. Henri's love of visual splendor seemed childlike to Diane, and she played on this weakness of his at every opportunity.
出身于普通中产阶级家庭的黛安娜·德·波蒂埃，却让亨利八世为之倾倒了二十余年。亨利八世去世时，她已年过六旬，但国王对她的爱恋却与日俱增。黛安娜深谙国王的为人。他并非知识分子，却酷爱户外活动——尤其钟情于马上比武，那些色彩鲜艳的旗帜、华丽的骏马和衣着考究的女子，都令他着迷。在黛安娜看来，亨利八世对视觉盛宴的追求如同孩童般天真，她也总是抓住机会，利用他这一弱点。
Most astute of all was Diane's appropriation of the goddess Diana. Here she took the game beyond physical imagery into the realm of the psychic symbol. It was quite a feat to transform a king's mistress into an emblem of power and purity, but she managed it. Without the resonance of the goddess, Diane was merely an aging courtesan. With the imagery and symbolism of Diana on her shoulders, she seemed a mythic force, destined for greatness.
黛安娜最精明之处在于她对女神狄安娜的挪用。她将游戏从具象的象征提升到了精神符号的层面。将一位国王的情妇转化为力量与纯洁的象征，这绝非易事，但她做到了。若没有女神的感召力，黛安娜不过是一位年迈的交际花。而肩负起狄安娜的形象和象征意义，她便仿佛化身为一股神话般的力量，注定成就伟业。
You too can play with images like these, weaving visual clues into an encompassing gestalt, as Diane did with her colors and her insignia. Establish a trademark like these to set yourself apart. Then take the game further: Find an image or symbol from the past that will neatly fit your situation, and put it on your shoulders like a cape. It will make you seem larger man life.
你也可以像黛安娜那样，玩转这类图像，将视觉线索编织成一个完整的整体，就像她运用色彩和徽章那样。建立这样的标志，让自己脱颖而出。然后更进一步：找到一个与你自身情况完美契合的过往图像或符号，把它披在肩上，就像披风一样。这会让你在生活中显得更加强大。
Because of the light it shines on the other stars which make up a kind of
因为它的光芒照耀着构成某种星体的其他恒星
court around it, because of the just and equal distribution of its rays to
围绕着它的庭院，因为它的光线分布公正平等。
all alike, because of the good it brings to all places, producing life, joy
都一样，因为它给所有地方带来美好，创造生命和欢乐。
and action, because of its constancy from which it never varies, I chose
而行动，因为它始终如一，永不改变，所以我选择了它。
the sun as the most magnificent image to represent a great leader.
太阳是象征伟大领袖的最壮丽形象。
Louis XIV, the Sun King, 1638-1715
路易十四，太阳王，1638-1715年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Using words to plead your case is risky business: Words are dangerous instruments, and often go astray. The words people use to persuade us virtually invite us to reflect on them with words of our own; we mull them over, and often end up believing the opposite of what they say. (That is part of our perverse nature.) It also happens that words offend us, stirring up associations unintended by the speaker.
用言语为自己辩护是一件冒险的事：言语是危险的工具，常常会误入歧途。人们用来劝说我们的话语，实际上是在邀请我们用自己的语言去思考；我们会反复琢磨，最终往往会得出与他们所说相反的结论。（这是我们天性中某种难以捉摸的倾向。）有时，言语也会冒犯我们，唤起说话者原本无意的联想。
The visual, on the other hand, short-circuits the labyrinth of words. It strikes with an emotional power and immediacy that leave no gaps for reflection and doubt. Like music, it leaps right over rational, reasonable thoughts. Imagine the Moon Doctor trying to make a case for his medical practice, trying to convince the unconverted by telling them about the healing powers of the moon, and about his own special connection to a distant object in the sky. Fortunately for him, he was able to create a compelling spectacle that made words unnecessary. The moment his patients entered the beer hall, the image of the moon spoke eloquently enough.
