另一方面，视觉元素则能绕过文字的迷宫。它以强大的情感力量和直接的冲击力直击人心，不留任何反思和怀疑的余地。如同音乐一般，它直接超越了理性思考。试想一下，那位“月亮医生”试图推销他的医术，试图说服那些尚未信服的人，向他们讲述月亮的治愈力量，以及他与遥远天体之间特殊的联系。幸运的是，他创造了一场引人入胜的奇观，让语言变得多余。当他的病人踏入啤酒馆的那一刻，月亮的影像便已胜过千言万语。
Understand: Words put you on the defensive. If you have to explain yourself your power is already in question. The image, on the other hand, imposes itself as a given. It discourages questions, creates forceful associations, resists unintended interpretations, communicates instantly, and forges bonds that transcend social differences. Words stir up arguments and divisions; images bring people together. They are the quintessential instruments of power.
须知：语言会让你处于防御状态。如果你需要解释自己，你的权力就已经受到质疑。而图像则不然，它以一种理所当然的方式呈现自身。它抑制质疑，创造强有力的联想，抵御误解，即时传递信息，并建立超越社会差异的纽带。语言会引发争论和分裂；图像则能将人们凝聚在一起。它们是权力的本质工具。
The symbol has the same force, whether it is visual (the statue of
符号的力量是相同的，无论是视觉上的（雕像）还是其他形式的符号。
There was a man named Sakamotoya Hechigwan who lived in upper Kyoto.... When [Emperor] Hideyoshi gave his great Cha-no-yu [tea ceremony] meeting at Kitano in the tenth month of 1588, Hechigwan set up a great red umbrella nine feet across mounted on a stick seven feet high. The circumference of the handle he surrounded for about two feet by a reed fence in such a way that the rays of the sun were reflected from it and diffused the colour of the umbrella all around. This device pleased Hideyoshi so much that he remitted Hechigwan's taxes as a reward.
京都上城住着一位名叫坂本屋边治官的人……1588年十月，丰臣秀吉在北野举行盛大的茶道会时，边治官支起一把直径九尺、高七尺的红色大伞。伞柄周围两尺左右用芦苇篱笆围起来，阳光透过篱笆反射，使伞面呈现出柔和的红色。丰臣秀吉对此十分满意，便免除了边治官的赋税。
CHA-NO-YU:
茶之汤：
THE JAPANESE TEA
日本茶
CEREMONY,
仪式，
A. L. Sadler, 1962
A. L. Sadler，1962年
Diana) or a verbal description of something visual (the words “the Sun King”). The symbolic object stands for something else, something abstract (such as the image “Diana” standing for chastity). The abstract concept purity, patriotism, courage, loveis full of emotional and powerful associations. The symbol is a shortcut of expression, containing dozens of meanings in one simple phrase or object. The symbol of the Sun King, as explained by Louis XIV, can be read on many layers, but the beauty of it is that its associations required no explanation, spoke immediately to his subjects, distinguished him from all other kings, and conjured up a kind of majesty that went far beyond the words themselves. The symbol contains untold power.
可以是戴安娜的形象），也可以是对某种视觉事物的文字描述（例如“太阳王”）。这个象征物代表着其他事物，一些抽象的概念（例如“戴安娜”的形象代表贞洁）。纯洁、爱国、勇气、爱这些抽象概念充满了情感和强大的联想。符号是一种表达的捷径，一个简单的短语或物体就蕴含着数十种含义。正如路易十四所解释的，太阳王的象征可以从多个层面解读，但它的精妙之处在于，它的联想无需解释，就能直接与臣民沟通，使他与其他所有君王区别开来，并唤起一种远超文字本身的威严。这个符号蕴含着无穷的力量。
The first step in using symbols and images is to understand the primacy of sight among the senses. Before the Renaissance, it has been argued, sight and the other sensestaste, touch, and so onoperated on a relatively equal plane. Since then, however, the visual has come to dominate the others, and is the sense we most depend on and trust. As Gracian said, “The truth is generally seen, rarely heard.” When the Renaissance painter Fra Filippo Lippi was a captured slave among the Moors, he won his freedom by sketching a drawing of his master on a white wall with a piece of charcoal; when the owner saw the drawing, he instantly understood the power of a man who could make such images, and let Fra Lippi go. That one image was far more powerful than any argument the artist could have made with words.
运用符号和图像的第一步，是理解视觉在五感中的首要地位。有人认为，在文艺复兴之前，视觉与其他感官——味觉、触觉等等——的地位相对平等。然而，自那以后，视觉逐渐占据主导地位，成为我们最依赖和信任的感官。正如格拉西安所说：“真理通常可见，却鲜少可闻。”文艺复兴时期的画家弗拉·菲利波·利皮曾是摩尔人的奴隶，他用炭笔在白墙上画了一幅主人的素描，以此赢得了自由。当主人看到这幅画时，立刻意识到能创作出如此精美图像的人的力量，于是释放了弗拉·利皮。这幅画的力量远胜于艺术家用语言所能表达的任何论点。
Never neglect the way you arrange things visually. Factors like color, for example, have enormous symbolic resonance. When the con artist Yellow Kid Weil created a newsletter touting the phony stocks he was peddling, he called it the “Red Letter Newsletter” and had it printed, at considerable expense, in red ink. The color created a sense of urgency, power, and good fortune. Weil recognized details like these as keys to deceptionas do modern advertisers and mass-marketers. If you use “gold” in the title of anything you are trying to sell, for example, print it in gold. Since the eye predominates, people will respond more to the color than to the word.
永远不要忽视视觉呈现方式。例如，色彩就具有巨大的象征意义。骗子“黄孩子”威尔（Yellow Kid Weil）为了推销他兜售的虚假股票，创办了一份名为“红字通讯”（Red Letter Newsletter）的简报，并花费巨资用红色油墨印刷。红色营造出一种紧迫感、力量感和好运感。威尔和现代广告商、大众营销人员一样，都深谙此类细节是欺骗的关键。例如，如果你在推销的产品名称中使用了“黄金”一词，那就用金色印刷。因为视觉是主导因素，人们对颜色的反应远比对文字的反应更强烈。
The visual contains great emotional power. The Roman emperor Con-stantine worshipped the sun as a god for most of his life; one day, though, he looked up at die sun, and saw a cross superimposed on it. The vision of the cross over the sun proved to him the ascendancy of the new religion, and he converted not just himself but the whole Roman Empire to Christianity soon thereafter. All the preaching and proselytizing in the world could not have been as powerful. Find and associate yourself with the images and symbols that will communicate in this immediate way today, and you will have untold power.
这幅画面蕴含着巨大的情感力量。罗马皇帝君士坦丁一生大部分时间都将太阳奉为神明；然而有一天，他抬头望向太阳，却看到一个十字架叠加在太阳之上。这十字架的景象向他证明了新宗教的胜利，此后不久，他不仅自己皈依了基督教，还将整个罗马帝国都纳入了基督教的怀抱。世上所有的布道和劝人皈依都无法与之匹敌。今天，找到并与那些能够以这种直接方式传递信息的图像和符号建立联系，你将拥有无穷的力量。
Most effective of all is a new combinationa fusion of images and symbols that have not been seen together before, but that through their association clearly demonstrate your new idea, message, religion. The creation of new images and symbols out of old ones in this way has a poetic effect viewers' associations run rampant, giving them a sense of participation.
最有效的方法莫过于将从未同时出现过的图像和符号进行全新的组合——通过它们之间的关联，清晰地展现你的新理念、新信息或新宗教信仰。这种利用旧图像和符号创造新图像和符号的方式，会产生一种诗意的效果，激发观众的无限联想，让他们产生参与感。
Visual images often appear in a sequence, and the order in which they appear creates a symbol. The first to appear, for instance, symbolizes power; the image at the center seems to have central importance.
视觉图像通常按顺序出现，而它们的出现顺序构成了一种象征意义。例如，最先出现的图像象征着权力；位于中心的图像似乎具有核心地位。
Near the end of World War II, orders came down from General Eisenhower that American troops were to lead die way into Paris after its liberation from the Nazis. The French general Charles de Gaulle, however, realized that this sequence would imply that the Americans now commanded die fate of France. Through much manipulation, de Gaulle made certain that he and the French Second Armored Division would appear at the head of the liberating force. The strategy worked: After he had successfully pulled off this stunt, the Allies started treating him as the new leader of an independent France. De Gaulle knew tiiat a leader has to locate himself literally at die head of his troops. This visual association is crucial to the emotional response that he needs to elicit.
二战末期，艾森豪威尔将军下令，美军将在巴黎从纳粹手中解放后率领部队进入巴黎。然而，法国将军戴高乐意识到，这一安排会让人觉得美国人已经掌握了法国的命运。戴高乐经过一番精心策划，确保自己和法国第二装甲师出现在解放部队的最前列。这一策略奏效了：成功完成这一“壮举”后，盟军开始将他视为独立法国的新领袖。戴高乐深知，一位领袖必须身先士卒，站在部队的最前列。这种视觉上的联系对于激发民众的情感共鸣至关重要。
Things change in die game of symbols: It is probably no longer possible to pose as a “sun king,” or to wrap the mande of Diana around you. Yet you can associate yourself with such symbols more indirecdy. And, of course, you can make your own mydiology out of figures from more recent history, people who are comfortably dead but still powerfully associative in die public eye. The idea is to give yourself an aura, a stature tiiat your normal banal appearance simply will not create. By herself Diane de Poitiers had no such radiant powers; she was as human and ordinary as most of us. But the symbol elevated her above die human lot, and made her seem divine.
在符号游戏中，一切都在变化：你或许再也无法像“太阳王”那样装扮自己，也无法披上戴安娜的外衣。然而，你可以用更间接的方式与这些符号建立联系。当然，你也可以从近代史上的人物身上构建自己的符号体系，这些人虽然已经去世，但在公众眼中仍然具有强大的象征意义。其目的是赋予自己一种光环，一种你平凡外表所无法企及的地位。戴安娜·德·波蒂埃本人并没有如此耀眼的光芒；她和我们大多数人一样，只是一个普通人。但符号将她从凡人的命运中解放出来，使她看起来像是一位神。
Using symbols also has a courtier-like effect, since diey are often gentler dian brutish words. The psychotherapist Dr. Milton H. Erickson always tried to find symbols and images that would communicate to die patient in ways that words could not. When dealing witii a severely troubled patient, he would not question him directiy but would talk about something irrelevant, such as driving tiirough the desert in Arizona, where he practiced in the 1950s. In describing this he would eventually come to an appropriate symbol for what he suspected was tile man's problem. If he felt the patient was isolated, say, Dr. Erickson would talk of a single iron-wood tree, and how its isolation left it battered by the winds. Making an emotional connection with die tree as a symbol, die patient would open up more readily to the doctor's probing.
使用符号也具有一种类似侍臣般的温文尔雅的效果，因为它们通常比粗暴的言语更柔和。心理治疗师米尔顿·H·埃里克森博士总是试图找到能够以言语无法企及的方式与患者沟通的符号和意象。当面对一位极度困扰的患者时，他不会直接询问，而是会谈论一些无关紧要的事情，比如他上世纪50年代在亚利桑那州沙漠中驾车的经历。在描述这段经历的过程中，他最终会找到一个合适的符号来表达他怀疑的患者的问题。例如，如果他感觉患者感到孤立无援，埃里克森博士就会谈到一棵孤零零的铁木树，以及它如何因孤立而饱受风吹雨打。通过与这棵树建立情感联系，患者会更容易敞开心扉，接受医生的探询。
Use die power of symbols as a way to rally, animate, and unite your troops or team. During die rebellion against the French crown in 1648, those loyal to the king disparaged the rebels by comparing them to the slingshots (in French, frondes) that little boys use to frighten big boys. Cardinal de Retz decided to turn this disparaging term into die rebels' symbol: The uprising was now known as the Fronde, and die rebels as frondeurs. They began to wear sashes in tiieir hats that symbolized the slingshot, and the word became tiieir rallying cry. Widiout it the rebellion might well have petered out. Always find a symbol to represent your causedie more emotional associations, the better.
运用符号的力量来鼓舞士气、激励士气、团结你的队伍或团队。在1648年法国反抗王室的起义中，效忠国王的人贬低起义者，将他们比作小男孩用来吓唬大男孩的弹弓（法语为“frondes”）。雷茨枢机主教决定将这个贬义词变成起义者的象征：起义从此被称为“投石党运动”（Fronde），起义者被称为“投石党人”（frondeurs）。他们开始在帽子上佩戴象征弹弓的绶带，而“投石党”一词也成为了他们的战斗口号。如果没有这个口号，起义很可能就此偃旗息鼓。始终要找到一个能够代表你事业的符号——越能唤起情感共鸣的符号越好。
The best way to use images and symbols is to organize tiiem into a
使用图像和符号的最佳方法是将它们组织成一个整体。
grand spectacle that awes people and distracts them from unpleasant realities. This is easy to do: People love what is grand, spectacular, and larger than life. Appeal to their emotions and they will flock to your spectacle in hordes. The visual is the easiest route to their hearts.
一场令人叹为观止的盛大演出，能让人暂时忘却烦恼的现实。这很容易做到：人们热爱宏伟、壮观、超乎寻常的事物。只要能触动他们的情感，他们就会蜂拥而至。视觉冲击是通往他们心灵最便捷的途径。
Image: The Cross and the Sun. Crucifixion and total radiance. With one imposed over the other, a new reality takes shape a new power is in the ascendant. The symbolno explanation necessary.
图片：十字架与太阳。受难与完全的光辉。二者交融，新的现实由此形成，新的力量正在崛起。其象征意义无需赘述。
Authority: The people are always impressed by the superficial appearance of things.... The [prince] should, at fitting times of the year, keep the people occupied and distracted with festivities and spectacles. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：人民总是容易被事物的表面现象所打动……君主应该在一年中的适当时节，用各种庆典和表演来分散人民的注意力。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
No power is made available by ignoring images and symbols. There is no
忽视图像和符号并不能赋予力量。
possible reversal to this law.
这项法律有可能被推翻。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 38
第38条
THINK AS YOU LIKE
随心所欲地想
BUT BEHAVE LIKE
但要表现得像个孩子一样
OTHERS
其他的
JUDGMENT
判断
If you make a show of going against the times, flaunting your unconventional ideas and unorthodox ways, people will think that you only want attention and that you look down upon them. They will find a way to punish you for making them feel inferior. It is far safer to blend in and nurture the common touch. Share your originality only with tolerant friends and those who are sure to appreciate your uniqueness.
如果你刻意标新立异，炫耀你那些非传统的想法和不拘一格的做法，人们会认为你只是想博取关注，并且瞧不起他们。他们会想方设法惩罚你，因为你让他们感到自卑。融入人群，保持平易近人才是更稳妥的做法。只与那些宽容的朋友和真正欣赏你独特之处的人分享你的个性。
It is easy to run into danger by trying to swim against the stream. Only a Socrates could attempt to do that. Disagreement is regarded as offensive because it is a condemnation of the views of others; the numbers of the disgruntled grow. on account either of some matter that has been the object of censure or of some person who has praised it: Truth is for the few, error is as usual as it is vulgar. Nor is the wise man to be recognized by what he says in the marketplace, for he speaks there not with his own voice, but with that of universal folly, however much his inmost thoughts may gainsay it: The wise man avoids being contradicted as sedulously as he avoids contradicting; the publicity of censure is withheld from that which readily provokes it. Thought is free; it cannot and should not be coerced; retire into the sanctuary of your silence and if you sometimes allow yourself to break it, do so under the aegis of a discreet few.
逆流而上很容易陷入危险。只有苏格拉底才会尝试这样做。异议被视为冒犯，因为它谴责他人的观点；不满的人越来越多，无论是因为某些事情受到了批评，还是因为有人赞扬了它：真理只属于少数人，谬误却像庸俗一样普遍。智者不能从他在市集上的言论来辨别，因为他在那里说的不是自己的声音，而是普遍的愚昧，无论他内心的想法如何反驳：智者谨慎地避免被反驳，就像他谨慎地避免反驳别人一样；对那些容易招致谴责的人，不会公开谴责。思想是自由的；它不能也不应该被强迫；退隐到你沉默的圣殿中，如果你偶尔允许自己打破沉默，也要在少数谨慎之人的庇护下进行。
Baltasar Gractan, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉克坦，1601-1658年
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Around the year 478 B.C., the city of Sparta sent an expedition to Persia led by die young Spartan nobleman Pausanias. The city-states of Greece had recently fought off a mighty invasion from Persia, and now Pausanias, along with allied ships from Atiiens, had orders to punish the invaders and win back the islands and coastal towns that the Persians had occupied. Bodi die Athenians and the Spartans had great respect for Pausaniashe had proven himself as a fearless warrior, with a flair for the dramatic.
公元前478年左右，斯巴达城邦派遣了一支远征军前往波斯，由年轻的斯巴达贵族保萨尼亚斯率领。希腊城邦不久前刚刚击退了波斯的猛烈入侵，如今，保萨尼亚斯率领着来自雅典的盟军舰队，奉命惩罚入侵者，夺回被波斯人占领的岛屿和沿海城镇。雅典人和斯巴达人都非常敬重保萨尼亚斯，他已证明自己是一位无畏的战士，并且极具戏剧天赋。
With amazing speed, Pausanias and his troops took Cyprus, then moved on to the mainland of Asia Minor known as the Hellespont and captured Byzantium (modern-day Istanbul). Now master of part of the Persian empire, Pausanias began to show signs of behavior that went beyond his normal flamboyance. He appeared in public wearing pomades in his hair and flowing Persian robes, and accompanied by a bodyguard of Egyptians. He held lavish banquets in which he sat in the Persian manner and demanded to be entertained. He stopped seeing his old friends, entered into communication with die Persian King Xerxes, and all in all affected the style and manner of a Persian dictator.
保萨尼亚斯率领军队以惊人的速度攻占了塞浦路斯，随后进军小亚细亚大陆的赫勒斯滂海峡，并攻克了拜占庭（今伊斯坦布尔）。如今，他已是波斯帝国的一部分统治者，但其行为举止却开始显露出与以往截然不同的浮夸作风。他公开露面时，头发抹着发油，身着飘逸的波斯长袍，身边簇拥着埃及卫队。他举办奢华的宴会，以波斯人的礼仪入座，并要求宾客尽兴。他不再与昔日好友来往，反而与波斯国王薛西斯建立了联系，总而言之，他举手投足间都散发着波斯独裁者的气息。
Clearly power and success had gone to Pausanias's head. His army Athenians and Spartans alikeat first thought this a passing fancy: He had always been a bit exaggerated in his gestures. But when he flaunted his disdain for die Greeks' simple way of life, and insulted the common Greek soldier, they began to feel he had gone too far. Although there was no concrete evidence for mis, rumors spread diat he had gone over to the odier side, and that he dreamed of becoming a kind of Greek Xerxes. To quell die possibility of mutiny, the Spartans relieved Pausanias of his command and called him home.
显然，权力和成功冲昏了保萨尼亚斯的头脑。起初，他的军队，无论是雅典人还是斯巴达人，都认为这只是一时的冲动：他向来举止有些夸张。但当他公然蔑视希腊人简朴的生活方式，侮辱普通的希腊士兵时，他们开始觉得他做得太过分了。虽然没有确凿的证据，但谣言四起，说他已经倒戈，梦想成为希腊的薛西斯。为了平息叛乱的可能性，斯巴达人解除了保萨尼亚斯的指挥权，把他召回了希腊。
Pausanias, however, continued to dress in the Persian style, even in Sparta. After a few months he independently hired a trireme and returned to the Hellespont, telling his compatriots he was going to continue the fight against the Persians. Actually, however, he had different plansto make himself ruler of all Greece, with the aid of Xerxes himself. The Spartans declared him a public enemy and sent a ship to capture him. Pausanias surrendered, certain that he could clear himself of the charges of treason. It did come out during die trial diat during his reign as commander he had offended his fellow Greeks time and again, erecting monuments, for instance, in his own name, rather than in those of the cities whose troops had fought alongside him, as was the custom. Yet Pausanias proved right: Despite die evidence of his numerous contacts with die enemy, die Spartans refused to imprison a man of such noble birth, and let him go.
然而，即使身在斯巴达，保萨尼亚斯依然穿着波斯服饰。几个月后，他独自租了一艘三列桨战船，返回赫勒斯滂海峡，告诉同胞他将继续与波斯人作战。但实际上，他另有图谋，打算在薛西斯王的帮助下，成为全希腊的统治者。斯巴达人宣布他为公敌，并派船前去抓捕他。保萨尼亚斯投降了，他确信自己能够洗清叛国罪名。在审判期间，人们发现，在他担任统帅期间，他曾多次冒犯希腊同胞，例如，他没有按照惯例以与他并肩作战的城邦的名义，而是以自己的名义建造纪念碑。然而，事实证明保萨尼亚斯是对的：尽管有证据表明他与敌人有诸多接触，斯巴达人仍然拒绝监禁这样一位出身高贵的人，最终释放了他。
Now thinking himself untouchable, Pausanias hired a messenger to take a letter to Xerxes, but the messenger instead took the letter to the Spartan authorities. These men wanted to find out more, so they had the messenger arrange to meet Pausanias in a temple where they could hide and listen behind a partition. What Pausanias said shocked diemdiey had never heard such contempt for their ways spoken so brazenly by one of their ownand they made arrangements for his immediate arrest.
保萨尼亚斯自以为无人敢惹，便雇人送信给薛西斯，结果信使却把信送到了斯巴达官员那里。这些人想探听更多，便让信使安排保萨尼亚斯在神庙里与他见面，他们躲在隔板后面偷听。保萨尼亚斯的话令他们震惊不已——他们从未听过自己人如此明目张胆地蔑视他们的习俗——于是他们立即下令逮捕他。
On his way home from the temple, Pausanias got word of what had happened. He ran to another temple to hide, but the authorities followed him there and placed sentries all around. Pausanias refused to surrender. Unwilling to forcibly remove him from the sacred temple, the authorities kept him trapped inside, until he eventually died of starvation.
保萨尼亚斯从神庙回家途中得知了发生的事情。他逃到另一座神庙躲藏，但官府的人也追了过来，并在周围布设了哨兵。保萨尼亚斯拒绝投降。官府的人不愿强行将他从神圣的神庙中带走，便将他困在里面，直到他最终饿死。
Interpretation
解释
At first glance it might seem that Pausanias simply fell in love with another culture, a phenomenon as old as time. Never comfortable with the asceticism of the Spartans, he found himself enthralled by the Persian love of luxury and sensual pleasure. He put on Persian robes and perfumes with a sense of deliverance from Greek discipline and simplicity.
乍看之下，保萨尼亚斯似乎只是爱上了另一种文化，这种现象由来已久。他始终无法适应斯巴达人的苦行主义，却被波斯人对奢华和感官享乐的追求深深吸引。他穿上波斯长袍，喷洒香水，仿佛从希腊的严苛纪律和简朴生活中解脱出来。
This is how it appears when people adopt a culture in which they were not raised. Often, however, there is also something else at play: People who flaunt their infatuation with a different culture are expressing a disdain and contempt for their own. They are using the outward appearance of the exotic to separate themselves from the common folk who unques-tioningly follow the local customs and laws, and to express their sense of superiority. Otherwise they would act with more dignity, showing respect for those who do not share their desires. Indeed their need to show their difference so dramatically often makes them disliked by the people whose beliefs they challenge, indirecdy and subtly, perhaps, but offensively nonetheless.
这就是人们接受一种他们未曾成长过的文化时所表现出的现象。然而，通常还有另一种因素在起作用：那些炫耀自己对异域文化迷恋的人，其实是在表达对自身文化的蔑视和轻蔑。他们利用异域风情的外表，将自己与那些毫不质疑地遵循当地习俗和法律的普通民众区分开来，并以此来表达自己的优越感。否则，他们会表现得更加得体，尊重那些与他们志趣相投的人。事实上，他们如此戏剧性地展现自身差异，往往会招致那些被他们挑战信仰的人们的反感——这种反感或许是间接的、微妙的，但无论如何，都令人感到冒犯。
As Thucydides wrote of Pausanias, “By his contempt for the laws and his imitation of foreign ways he had made himself very widely suspected of being unwilling to abide by normal standards.” Cultures have norms that reflect centuries of shared beliefs and ideals. Do not expect to scoff at such things with impunity. You will be punished somehow, even if just through isolationa position of real powerlessness.
正如修昔底德在谈到保萨尼亚斯时所写：“他蔑视法律，效仿异域风俗，因此广受怀疑，认为他不愿遵守正常的社会规范。” 文化拥有反映数百年共同信仰和理想的规范。不要指望可以肆意嘲笑这些规范而不受惩罚。你终将受到某种惩罚，即使只是被孤立——一种真正无能为力的处境。
Many of us, like Pausanias, feel the siren call of the exotic, the foreign. Measure and moderate diis desire. Flaunting your pleasure in alien ways of thinking and acting will reveal a different motiveto demonstrate your superiority over your fellows.
我们许多人，就像保萨尼亚斯一样，都会被异域风情和异域文化所吸引。但要适度地控制这种欲望。炫耀你对异域思维和行为方式的喜爱，只会暴露你别有用心，想要炫耀自己比同胞优越。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
During the late sixteenth century, a violent reaction against the Protestant Reformation erupted in Italy. The Counter-Reformation, as it was called, included its own version of the Inquisition to root out all deviations from the Catholic Church. Among its victims was the scientist Galileo, but an important thinker who suffered even greater persecution was the Dominican monk and philosopher Tommaso Campanella.
十六世纪末，意大利爆发了一场反对新教改革的激烈运动。这场被称为反宗教改革的运动，建立了类似宗教裁判所的机构，旨在根除一切偏离天主教教义的异端邪说。科学家伽利略是这场运动的受害者之一，但遭受更严重迫害的思想家是多明我会修士兼哲学家托马索·康帕内拉。
A follower of the materialist doctrine of the Roman philosopher Epicurus, Campanella did not believe in miracles, or in heaven and hell. The Church had promoted such superstitions, he wrote, to control the common folk by keeping them in fear. Such ideas verged on atheism, and Campanella expressed them incautiously. In 1593 the Inquisition threw him
作为罗马哲学家伊壁鸠鲁唯物主义学说的追随者，康帕内拉不相信奇迹，也不相信天堂和地狱。他写道，教会宣扬这些迷信是为了通过恐吓来控制民众。这种观点近乎无神论，而康帕内拉的表达也显得过于直白。1593年，他被宗教裁判所开除。
Bene vixit, qui bene latuit “He lives well who conceals himself well.”
“善于隐藏自己的人才能过得好。”
a.d. 18
公元18年
Ovid, c. 43 B.C.
奥维德，约公元前 43 年
Wise men [should be] like coffers with double bottoms: Which when others look into, being opened, they see not all that they hold.
智者应像双层底的宝库：当别人打开宝库窥视时，却看不到里面所有的宝物。
Sir Walter Raleigh, 1554-1618
沃尔特·雷利爵士，1554-1618
WHK.N THK WATKHS WERE CHANCED
WHK.N THK 观看机会
Once upon a time Khidr, the teacher of Moses, called upon mankind with a warning. At a certain date, he said, all the water in the world which had not been specially hoarded, would disappear. It would then be renewed, with different water, which would drive men mad. Only one man listened to the meaning of this advice. He collected water and went to a secure place where he stored it, and waited for the water to change its character.
从前，摩西的老师赫兹尔曾警告世人，在某个特定的日子，世上所有未被特别储存的水都会消失。之后，水会重新出现，但会变成另一种水，使人发疯。只有一个人听从了赫兹尔的劝告。他收集水，带到一个安全的地方储存起来，等待水质的改变。
On the appointed date the streams stopped running, the wells went dry, and the man who had listened, seeing this
到了约定的日子，溪流断流，水井干涸，那个一直听从预言的人，看到这一切……
LAW 38 319
法律 38 319
happening, went to his retreat and drank his preserved water. When he saw, from his security, the waterfalls again beginning to flow, this man descended among the other sons of men. He found that they were thinking and talking in an entirely different way from before; yet they had no memory of what had happened, nor of having been warned. When he tried to talk to them, he realized that they thought that he was mad, and they showed hostility or compassion, not understanding. At first he drank none of the new water, but went back to his concealment, to draw on his supplies, every day. Finally, however, he took the decision to drink the new water because he could not bear the loneliness of living, behaving and thinking in a different way from everyone else. He drank the new water, and became like the rest. Then he forgot all about his own store of special water, and his fellows began to look upon him as a madman who had miraculously been restored to sanity.
事情发生后，他回到自己的隐居处，喝下了储存的水。当他从隐蔽处看到瀑布再次奔流时，他便来到其他人中间。他发现他们的想法和说话方式与之前截然不同；然而，他们既不记得发生了什么，也不记得曾有人警告过他们。当他试图与他们交谈时，他意识到他们认为他疯了，他们表现出敌意或同情，却不理解他。起初，他没有喝任何新水，而是每天回到隐蔽处，取用自己的储备。然而，最终他还是决定喝下新水，因为他无法忍受与其他人截然不同的生活方式、行为方式和思维方式带来的孤独。他喝下了新水，变得和其他人一样。之后，他完全忘记了自己储存的特殊水源，他的同伴们开始把他看作一个奇迹般恢复理智的疯子。
TALES OF
故事
the dervishes,
苦行僧们，
Idries Shah,
伊德里斯·沙阿
into prison for his heretical beliefs. Six years later, as a form of partial release, he was confined to a monastery in Naples.
他因异端信仰而入狱。六年之后，作为部分释放，他被流放到那不勒斯的一座修道院。
Southern Italy was controlled by Spain at the time, and in Naples Campanella became involved in a plot to fight and throw out mese invaders. His hope was to establish an independent republic based on his own ideas of Utopia. The leaders of the Italian Inquisition, working with their Spanish counterparts, had him imprisoned again. This time diey also tortured him, to discover the true nature of his impious beliefs: He was subjected to the infamous la veglia, a torture in which he was suspended by his arms in a squatting position a few inches above a seat studded with spikes. The posture was impossible to sustain, and in time die victim would end up sitting on the spikes, which would tear his flesh at the slightest contact.
当时意大利南部由西班牙控制，在拿波里，坎帕内拉参与了一场旨在击退西班牙入侵者的阴谋。他希望建立一个基于他理想乌托邦的独立共和国。意大利宗教裁判所的领导人与西班牙同行联手，再次将他投入监狱。这一次，他们对他施以酷刑，以探明他邪恶信仰的真相：他遭受了臭名昭著的“拉维利亚”（la veglia）酷刑，这种酷刑将他双臂吊起，呈蹲姿，下方是一个布满尖刺的座椅，距离座椅仅几英寸。这种姿势根本无法保持，最终受害者会坐在尖刺上，哪怕最轻微的接触也会撕裂他的血肉。
During these years, however, Campanella learned something about power. Facing the prospect of execution for heresy, he changed his strategy: He would not renounce his behefs, yet he knew he had to disguise their outward appearance.
然而，在这些年里，康帕内拉对权力有了更深的理解。面对因异端罪名而被处决的可能，他改变了策略：他不会放弃自己的主张，但他知道必须掩盖这些主张的本质。
To save his life, Campanella feigned madness. He let his inquisitors imagine that his beliefs stemmed from an incontrollable unsoundness of mind. For a while the tortures continued, to see if his insanity was faked, but in 1603 his sentence was commuted to life in prison. The first four years of this he spent chained to a wall in an underground dungeon. Despite such conditions, he continued to writealthough no longer would he be so foolish as to express his ideas directiy.
为了保命，康帕内拉装疯卖傻。他让审判官们以为他的信仰源于无法控制的精神错乱。酷刑持续了一段时间，以检验他的精神错乱是否是装的，但在1603年，他的刑罚被改为终身监禁。最初的四年，他被锁链拴在地下地牢的墙上。尽管条件如此恶劣，他仍然笔耕不辍——只是不再像以前那样愚蠢地直接表达自己的思想。
One book of Campanella's, The Hispanic Monarchy, promoted the idea diat Spain had a divine mission to expand its powers around the world, and offered the Spanish king practical, Machiavelli-type advice for achieving this. Despite his own interest in Machiavelli, the book in general presented ideas completely the opposite to his own. The Hispanic Monarchy was in fact a ploy, an attempt to show his conversion to orthodoxy in the boldest manner possible. It worked: In 1626, six years after its publication, die pope finally let Campanella out of prison.
康帕内拉的著作《西班牙君主制》宣扬西班牙肩负着向世界扩张的神圣使命，并为西班牙国王提供了一系列切实可行的、类似马基雅维利式的建议来实现这一目标。尽管康帕内拉本人对马基雅维利颇感兴趣，但这本书总体上呈现的观点却与他自己的思想截然相反。《西班牙君主制》实际上是康帕内拉的一次策略，旨在以最大胆的方式展现他皈依正统教义的决心。而这一策略奏效了：1626年，也就是该书出版六年之后，教皇终于释放了康帕内拉。
Shortly after gaining his freedom, Campanella wrote Atheism Conquered, a book attacking free-thinkers, Machiavellians, Calvinists, and heretics of all stripes. The book is written in the form of debates in which heretics express their beliefs and are countered by arguments for the superiority of Catholicism. Campanella had obviously reformedhis book made that clear. Or did it
获得自由后不久，康帕内拉写了《征服无神论》一书，抨击自由思想家、马基雅维利主义者、加尔文主义者以及各种异端。这本书以辩论的形式写成，异端们阐述他们的信仰，而天主教的优越性则遭到反驳。康帕内拉显然已经改过自新——他的书清楚地表明了这一点。或者，事实真的如此吗？
The arguments in the mouths of the heretics had never before been expressed with such verve and freshness. Pretending to present their side only to knock it down, Campanella actually summarized die case against Catholicism with striking passion. When he argued the other side, supposedly his side, on the other hand, he resorted to stale cliches and convoluted rationales. Brief and eloquent, the heretics' arguments seemed bold and sincere. The lengthy arguments for Catholicism seemed tiresome and unconvincing.
异端分子的论点从未如此生动鲜活地表达过。康帕内拉假装陈述己方观点，实则以惊人的激情概括了反对天主教的论点。然而，当他陈述另一方观点（即他自己的观点）时，却诉诸陈词滥调和晦涩难懂的论证。异端分子的论点简洁有力，显得大胆而真诚。而天主教冗长的论证则显得枯燥乏味，缺乏说服力。
Catholics who read the book found it disturbing and ambiguous, but
读过这本书的天主教徒觉得它令人不安且含义模糊，但是
they could not claim it was heretical, or that Campanella should be returned to prison. His defense of Catholicism, after all, used arguments they had used themselves. Yet in the years to come, Atheism Conquered became a bible for atheists, Machiavellians and libertines who used the arguments Campanella had put in their mouths to defend their dangerous ideas. Combining an outward display of conformity witii an expression of his true beliefs in a way that his sympathizers would understand, Campanella showed that he had learned his lesson.
他们无法声称这是异端邪说，也无法要求将康帕内拉重新送回监狱。毕竟，他为天主教辩护时所用的论点，正是他们自己曾经使用过的。然而，在接下来的几年里，《征服无神论》却成了无神论者、马基雅维利主义者和自由主义者的圣经，他们借用康帕内拉提出的论点来捍卫自己危险的思想。康帕内拉表面上表现得顺从，但同时又以一种同情者能够理解的方式表达了自己的真实信仰，这表明他已经吸取了教训。
Interpretation
解释
In the face of awesome persecution, Campanella devised three strategic moves that saved his hide, freed him from prison, and allowed him to continue to express his beliefs. First he feigned madnessthe medieval equivalent of disavowing responsibility for one's actions, like blaming one's parents today. Next he wrote a book that expressed the exact opposite of his own beliefs. Finally, and most brilliantiy of all, he disguised his ideas while insinuating them at the same time. It is an old but powerful trick: You pretend to disagree with dangerous ideas, but in die course of your disagreement you give diose ideas expression and exposure. You seem to conform to die prevailing orthodoxy, but diose who know will understand die irony involved. You are protected.
面对残酷的迫害，康帕内拉设计了三项策略，最终保住了性命，使他免于牢狱之灾，并得以继续表达自己的信仰。首先，他装疯卖傻——这相当于中世纪逃避责任的方式，就像今天人们推卸父母的责任一样。其次，他写了一本书，表达了与自己信仰截然相反的观点。最后，也是最高明的一步，他巧妙地掩饰了自己的想法，同时又暗中暗示。这是一个古老却有效的伎俩：你假装反对某些危险的观点，但在反对的过程中，你却让这些观点得以表达和传播。你表面上似乎顺应了主流正统观念，但真正了解内情的人会明白其中的讽刺意味。这样，你就得到了保护。
It is inevitable in society that certain values and customs lose contact with dieir original motives and become oppressive. And mere will always be those who rebel against such oppression, harboring ideas far ahead of their time. As Campanella was forced to realize, however, there is no point in making a display of your dangerous ideas if diey only bring you suffering and persecution. Martyrdom serves no purposebetter to live on in an oppressive world, even to dirive in it. Meanwhile find a way to express your ideas subdy for diose who understand you. Laying your pearls before swine will only bring you trouble.
社会中某些价值观和习俗不可避免地会脱离其最初的动机，最终变得压迫人心。总会有人反抗这种压迫，怀揣着远超时代的思想。然而，正如康帕内拉被迫认识到的那样，如果你的危险思想只会给你带来苦难和迫害，那么展示它们就毫无意义。殉道毫无意义——还不如继续生活在这个压迫的世界里，哪怕只是开车行驶。与此同时，找到一种方式，向那些理解你的人表达你的想法。对牛弹琴只会给你带来麻烦。
For a long time I have not said what I believed, nor do I ever believe
很长一段时间以来，我没有说出我的真实想法，而且我永远也不会相信。
what I say, and if indeed sometimes I do happen to tell the truth,
我所说的话，如果有时我确实说了真话的话，
I hide it among so many lies that it is hard to find.
我把它藏在很多谎言之中，很难找到。
Niccolo Machiavelli, in a letter to Francesco Guicciardini, May 17, 1521
尼科洛·马基雅维利 (Niccolo Machiavelli)，1521 年 5 月 17 日致弗朗西斯科·吉恰尔迪尼 (Francesco Guicciardini) 的一封信
Never combat any man's opinion; for though you reached the age of Methuselah, you would never have done setting him right upon all the absurd things that he believes-It is also well to avoid correcting people's mistakes in conversation, however good your intentions may be; for it is easy to offend people, and difficult, if not impossible to mend them.
永远不要反驳任何人的观点；因为即使你到了玛土撒拉的年纪，你也永远无法纠正他所有荒谬的想法。同样，无论你的意图多么良好，最好也避免在谈话中纠正别人的错误；因为冒犯别人很容易，而弥补错误却很难，甚至是不可能的。
If you feel irritated by the absurd remarks of two people whose conversation you happen to overhear, you should imagine that you are listening to the dialogue of two fools in a comedy. Probatum est. The man who comes into the world with the notion that he is really going to instruct it in matters of the highest importance, may thank his stars if he escapes with a whole skin.
如果你无意中听到两个人的对话，并因他们的荒谬言论而感到恼火，你应该想象自己正在听一部喜剧中两个傻瓜的对话。Probatum est。一个带着“我要教导世人一些至关重要的事情”的想法来到世上的人，如果能毫发无损地活着离开这个世界，就该感谢上苍了。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
We all tell lies and hide our true feelings, for complete free expression is a social impossibility. From an early age we learn to conceal our thoughts, telling die prickly and insecure what we know they want to hear, watching carefully lest we offend diem. For most of us tiiis is naturalthere are ideas and values diat most people accept, and it is pointless to argue. We believe what we want to, men, but on die outside we wear a mask.
我们都会说谎，都会隐藏自己的真实感受，因为完全的自由表达在社会中是不可能的。从小我们就学会掩饰自己的想法，对那些敏感又缺乏安全感的人说些他们想听的话，小心翼翼地避免冒犯他们。对我们大多数人来说，这很自然——有一些观点和价值观是大多数人都能接受的，争论毫无意义。我们信什么就信什么，伙计们，但在外面，我们都戴着面具。
There are people, however, who see such restraints as an intolerable infringement on their freedom, and who have a need to prove the superi-
然而，有些人却认为这种限制是对其自由的不可容忍的侵犯，并且他们需要证明……的优越性。
“Look around you,”
“看看你周围，”
said the citizen. "This is
这位市民说道：“这是
the largest market in
最大的市场
the world. "
世界。
“Oh surely not,” said
“哦，肯定不是，”他说。
the traveller.
旅行者。
"Well, perhaps not
“嗯，或许不是。”
the largest," said the
“最大的，”他说。
citizen, "but much
公民，“但是很多
the best."
最好的。”
"You are certainly
你当然是
wrong there, " said the
“错了，”他说。
traveller. "I can tell
旅行者。“我能看出来
you. ..."
你。 ...”
They buried the
他们埋葬了
stranger in the dusk.
黄昏中的陌生人。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Robert Louis Stevenson, 1850-1894
罗伯特·路易斯·史蒂文森，1850-1894年
If Machiavelli had had
如果马基雅维利有
a prince for disciple,
一位王子为门徒，
the first thing he would
他首先会做什么
have recommended
已推荐
him to do would have
让他去做这件事将会……
been to write a book
曾写过一本书
against Machiavellism.
反对马基雅维利主义。
Voltaire, 1694-1778
伏尔泰，1694-1778
ority of their values and beliefs. In the end, though, their arguments convince only a few and offend a great deal more. The reason arguments do not work is that most people hold their ideas and values widiout thinking about them. There is a strong emotional content in their beliefs: They really do not want to have to rework their habits of thinking, and when you challenge them, whether directly through your arguments or indirecdy through your behavior, they are hostile.
他们重视自身的价值观和信仰。然而，最终，他们的论点只能说服少数人，却冒犯了更多的人。论点失效的原因在于，大多数人持有自己的观念和价值观时并未经过深思熟虑。他们的信念中蕴含着强烈的情感：他们真的不想改变自己的思维习惯，当你挑战他们时，无论是直接通过论点还是间接通过行为，他们都会表现出敌意。
Wise and clever people learn early on that they can display conventional behavior and mouth conventional ideas widiout having to believe in diem. The power these people gain from blending in is that of being left alone to have die thoughts tfiey want to have, and to express diem to the people they want to express them to, without suffering isolation or ostracism. Once tiiey have established themselves in a position of power, they can try to convince a wider circle of the correctness of dieir ideas perhaps working indirecdy, using Campanella's strategies of irony and insinuation.
聪明睿智的人很早就明白，他们可以表现得循规蹈矩，说一些看似理所当然的话，而无需真正相信这些话。这些人从融入群体中获得的权力在于，他们可以不受干扰地思考自己想思考的事情，并向自己想表达的人表达这些想法，而不会遭受孤立或排斥。一旦他们确立了自己的权力地位，他们就可以尝试说服更广泛的群体接受他们的想法，或许会采取间接的方式，运用康帕内拉的反讽和暗示策略。
In the late fourteenth century, the Spanish began a massive persecution of die Jews, murdering Uiousands and driving others out of the country. Those who remained in Spain were forced to convert. Yet over die next three hundred years, die Spanish noticed a phenomenon diat disturbed them: Many of die converts lived dieir outward lives as Cadiolics, yet somehow managed to retain their Jewish beliefs, practicing the religion in private. Many of these so-called Marranos (originally a derogatory term, being the Spanish for “pig”) attained high levels of government office, married into die nobility, and gave every appearance of Christian piety, only to be discovered late in life as practicing Jews. (The Spanish Inquisition was specifically commissioned to ferret diem out.) Over the years they mastered die art of dissimulation, displaying crucifixes liberally, giving generous gifts to churches, even occasionally making anti-Semitic remarksand all die while maintaining their inner freedom and beliefs.
十四世纪末，西班牙人开始对犹太人进行大规模迫害，屠杀犹太人，并将其他人驱逐出境。留在西班牙的犹太人被迫改信基督教。然而，在接下来的三百年里，西班牙人注意到一种令他们不安的现象：许多改信基督教的人表面上过着卡迪奥教徒的生活，却设法保留了他们的犹太信仰，私下里继续信奉犹太教。这些所谓的“马兰诺人”（最初是一个贬义词，在西班牙语中意为“猪”）中，许多人身居要职，与贵族联姻，表面上虔诚地信奉基督教，直到晚年才被发现是犹太教徒。（西班牙宗教裁判所专门负责调查这些人。）多年来，他们精通了伪装的艺术，大量佩戴十字架，慷慨地向教堂捐赠，甚至偶尔发表反犹太言论——所有这些都是为了维护他们内心的自由和信仰。
In society, the Marranos knew, outward appearances are what matter. This remains true today. The strategy is simple: As Campanella did in writing Atheism Conquered, make a show of blending in, even going so far as to be the most zealous advocate of the prevailing orthodoxy. If you stick to conventional appearances in public few will believe you think differendy in private.
马兰诺人深谙社会之道，外表至关重要。时至今日，这一道理依然适用。他们的策略很简单：正如坎帕内拉在《征服无神论》一书中所做的那样，装出一副融入主流社会的样子，甚至不惜成为当时主流正统观念最狂热的拥护者。只要你在公众场合保持循规蹈矩的形象，就很少有人会相信你在私下里持有不同的看法。
Do not be so foolish as to imagine that in our own time the old orthodoxies are gone. Jonas Salk, for instance, thought science had gotten past politics and protocol. And so, in his search for a polio vaccine, he broke all die rulesgoing public widi a discovery before showing it to the scientific community, taking credit for die vaccine widiout acknowledging die scientists who had paved die way, making himself a star. The public may have loved him but scientists shunned him. His disrespect for his community's orthodoxies left him isolated, and he wasted years trying to heal die breach, and struggling for funding and cooperation.
不要愚蠢地以为，在我们这个时代，旧的正统观念已经消失殆尽。例如，乔纳斯·索尔克就认为科学已经超越了政治和规章制度。因此，在寻找脊髓灰质炎疫苗的过程中，他打破了所有规则，在向科学界展示之前就公开了自己的发现，并将疫苗的功劳据为己有，却不承认那些为此铺平道路的科学家们，从而让自己成为了明星。公众或许喜欢他，但科学家们却对他避之不及。他对科学界正统观念的蔑视使他孤立无援，他浪费了数年时间试图弥合裂痕，并为资金和合作而苦苦挣扎。
Bertolt Brecht underwent a modern form of Inquisitionthe House
贝尔托·布莱希特经历了现代形式的宗教裁判所审判。
Un-American Activities Committeeand approached it with considerable canniness. Having worked off and on in die American film industry during World War II, in 1947 Brecht was summoned to appear before the committee to answer questions on his suspected Communist sympathies. Other writers called before die committee made a point of attacking its members, and of acting as belligerently as possible in order to gain sympadry for themselves. Brecht, on die other hand, who had actually worked steadfastly for the Communist cause, played the opposite game: He answered questions wim ambiguous generalities that defied easy interpretation. Call it the Campanella strategy. Brecht even wore a suita rare event for him and made a point of smoking a cigar during the proceedings, knowing that a key committee member had a passion for cigars. In the end he charmed the committee members, who let him go scot-free.
非美活动调查委员会传唤布莱希特，他以相当精明的策略应对。二战期间，布莱希特曾在美国电影业断断续续地工作。1947年，他被传唤到该委员会接受质询，以查明他是否同情共产主义。其他被传唤的作家都刻意攻击委员会成员，并尽可能地表现得咄咄逼人，以博取同情。而布莱希特，这位曾坚定地为共产主义事业效力的人，却反其道而行之：他用模棱两可、难以解读的泛泛之谈来回答问题。这可以称之为“康帕内拉策略”。布莱希特甚至穿了一套西装——这对他来说实属罕见——并在听证会上特意抽了一支雪茄，因为他知道一位重要的委员会成员酷爱雪茄。最终，他凭借魅力征服了委员会成员，得以全身而退。
Brecht then moved to East Germany, where he encountered a different kind of Inquisition. Here the Communists were in power, and they criticized his plays as decadent and pessimistic. He did not argue with them, but made small changes in the performance scripts to shut them up. Meanwhile he managed to preserve the published texts as written. His outward conformity in both cases gave him die freedom to work unhindered, without having to change his thinking. In the end, he made his way safely through dangerous times in different countries through the use of litde dances of orthodoxy, and proved he was more powerful than the forces of repression.
布莱希特随后移居东德，在那里他遭遇了另一种形式的“宗教裁判所”。东德由共产党执政，他们批评他的剧作颓废悲观。他没有与他们争辩，而是对演出剧本做了些许改动以堵住他们的嘴。与此同时，他设法保留了已出版的剧本原貌。在这两种情况下，他表面上的顺从反而使他得以自由创作，无需改变自己的思想。最终，他凭借着对正统观念的巧妙运用，在不同国家的动荡时期安然度过，并证明自己比任何镇压势力都更加强大。
Not only do people of power avoid the offenses of Pausanias and Salk, they also learn to play the clever fox and feign the common touch. This has been die ploy of con artists and politicians throughout die centuries. Leaders like Julius Caesar and Franklin D. Roosevelt have overcome their natural aristocratic stance to cultivate a familiarity with the common man. They have expressed tiiis familiarity in little gestures, often symbolic, to show the people that their leaders share popular values, despite their different status.
掌权者不仅避免重蹈保萨尼亚斯和索尔克的覆辙，还学会了装腔作势，假装平易近人。这几个世纪以来一直是骗子和政客的惯用伎俩。像尤利乌斯·凯撒和富兰克林·罗斯福这样的领袖，克服了与生俱来的贵族姿态，努力与普通民众建立亲近感。他们通过一些细微的、往往带有象征意义的举动来表达这种亲近，向民众表明，尽管地位不同，他们的领袖也拥有与民众相同的价值观。
The logical extension of this practice is die invaluable ability to be all things to all people. When you go into society, leave behind your own ideas and values, and put on the mask diat is most appropriate for die group in which you find yourself. Bismarck played this game successfully for yearsmere were people who vaguely understood what he was up to, but not clearly enough that it mattered. People will swallow die bait because it flatters them to believe that you share their ideas. They will not take you as a hypocrite if you are carefulfor how can they accuse you of hypocrisy if you do not let them know exactly what you stand for Nor will they see you as lacking in values. Of course you have valuesdie values you share witii diem, while in their company.
这种做法的逻辑延伸就是能够迎合所有人的宝贵能力。当你进入社会时，抛开你自己的想法和价值观，戴上最适合你所处群体的面具。俾斯麦多年来成功地玩弄了这种把戏——人们隐约明白他的意图，但又不够清楚，所以无关紧要。人们会上钩，因为相信你与他们的想法一致会让他们感到受宠若惊。如果你小心谨慎，他们就不会认为你是伪君子——如果你不让他们清楚地知道你的立场，他们又怎么能指责你虚伪呢？他们也不会认为你缺乏价值观。当然，你有自己的价值观——在他们面前，你会与他们分享这些价值观。
Authority: Do not give dogs what is holy; and do not dirow your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under foot and turn to attack you. (Jesus Christ, Matthew 7:6)
权威：不要把圣物给狗，也不要把你们的珍珠丢在猪面前，恐怕它们践踏了珍珠，转过来咬你们。（耶稣基督，马太福音 7:6）
Image: The Black The herd shuns the SheeD black sheep, uncertain whether or not it belongs with them. So it straggles behind, or wanders away from the herd, where it is cornered by wolves and promptly devoured. Stay with the herd there is safety in numbers. Keep your differences in your thoughts and not in your fleece.
图片：黑羊 羊群排斥黑羊，不确定它是否属于羊群。于是它落在后面，或者远离羊群，最终被狼群围困，迅速被吞噬。待在羊群里，人多势众才安全。把分歧留在心里，别让分歧影响你的羊毛。
REVERSAL
逆转
The only time it is worth standing out is when you already stand out when you have achieved an unshakable position of power, and can display your difference from others as a sign of the distance between you. As president of the United States, Lyndon Johnson would sometimes hold meetings while he sat on the toilet. Since no one else either could or would claim such a “privilege,” Johnson was showing people that he did not have to observe the protocols and niceties of others. The Roman emperor Caligula played the same game: He would wear a woman's negligee, or a bathrobe, to receive important visitors. He even went so far as to have his horse elected consul. But it backfired, for the people hated Caligula, and his gestures eventually brought his overthrow. The truth is that even those who attain the heights of power would be better off at least affecting the common touch, for at some point they may need popular support.
只有当你已经拥有牢不可破的权力地位，能够通过展现与他人的不同来拉开距离时，才值得特立独行。美国总统林登·约翰逊有时会在马桶上召开会议。由于其他人既不能也不愿享有这种“特权”，约翰逊便以此向世人表明，他不必遵守他人的礼仪和客套。罗马皇帝卡利古拉也玩过类似的把戏：他会穿着女式睡衣或浴袍来接见重要来宾。他甚至让自己的马当选为执政官。但这最终适得其反，因为民众憎恨卡利古拉，他的这些举动最终导致了他的垮台。事实上，即使是那些身居高位的人，最好也至少要展现出一些亲民的一面，因为他们迟早都需要民众的支持。
Finally, there is always a place for the gadfly, the person who successfully defies custom and mocks what has grown lifeless in a culture. Oscar Wilde, for example, achieved considerable social power on this foundation: He made it clear that he disdained the usual ways of doing things, and when he gave public readings his audiences not only expected him to insult them but welcomed it. We notice, however, that his eccentric role eventually destroyed him. Even had he come to a better end, remember that he possessed an unusual genius: Without his gift to amuse and delight, his barbs would simply have offended people.
最后，总会有“牛虻”一席之地，他们成功地挑战传统，嘲讽文化中那些死气沉沉的事物。例如，奥斯卡·王尔德正是凭借这一点获得了相当大的社会影响力：他明确表示自己鄙视墨守成规，当他公开朗诵时，听众不仅期待他出言不逊，而且还欣然接受。然而，我们注意到，他这种特立独行的性格最终毁了他。即便他最终的结局更好，也别忘了他拥有非凡的天赋：如果没有他那逗人发笑的才能，他的尖刻讽刺只会冒犯他人。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 39
第39条
STIR UP WATERS TO CATCH FISH
搅动水面以捕获鱼类
JUDGMENT
判断
Anger and emotion are strategically counterproductive. You must always stay calm and objective. But if you can make your enemies angry while staying calm yourself you gain a decided advantage. Put your enemies off-balance: Find the chink in their vanity through which you can rattle them and you hold the strings.
愤怒和情绪在策略上是适得其反的。你必须始终保持冷静和客观。但如果你能激怒敌人，同时自己保持冷静，你就能获得明显的优势。扰乱敌人的阵脚：找到他们虚荣心的弱点，通过这个弱点动摇他们的信心，你就能掌控局面。
The Kyoto Shoshidai Itakura Suwo-no-kami Shigemune was very fond of Cha-no-yu (the tea ceremony), and used to grind his own tea while sitting in the court as judge. And the reason was this. He once asked a friend of his who was his companion in Cha-no-yu, a tea merchant named Eiki, to tell him frankly what was the public opinion about him. “Well,”said Eiki, “they say that you gel irritated with those who don't give their evidence very clearly and scold them, and so people are afraid to bring lawsuits before you and if they do, the truth does not come out.” “Ah, I am glad you have told me that,” replied Shigemune, “for now that I consider it, I have fallen into the habit of speaking sharply to people in this way, and no doubt humble folk and those who are not ready in speech get flurried and are unable to put their case in the best light. I will see to it that this does not occur in the future.” So after this he had a tea mill placed before him in court and in front of it the paper-covered shoji were drawn to, and Shigemune sat behind them and ground the tea and thus kept his mind calm while he heard the cases. And he could
京都司司台板仓诹访守重宗酷爱茶道，常在法庭上亲自研磨茶叶。原因有二：他曾问一位茶道伙伴，一位名叫荣贵的茶叶商人，人们是如何评价他的。荣贵说：“据说你对那些不善于陈述事实的人很不耐烦，会斥责他们，所以人们不敢在你面前告状，即使告了，真相也难以水落石出。”重宗答道：“啊，幸亏你这么说。现在想想，我确实养成了这样严厉对待他人的习惯，想必那些谦卑之人或不善言辞的人会因此慌乱，无法充分陈述案情。我以后一定会注意，不再让这种情况发生。”于是，之后他在法庭上摆放了一台磨茶机，前面摆放着用纸盖着的障子门，重宗就坐在障子门后磨茶，以此来保持心境平和，同时审理案件。他可以
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In January of 1809, an agitated and anxious Napoleon hurried back to Paris from his Spanish wars. His spies and confidants had confirmed a rumor that his foreign minister Talleyrand had conspired against him with Fouche, the minister of police. Immediately on arriving in the capital the shocked emperor summoned his ministers to the palace. Following them into the meeting right after their arrival, he began pacing up and down, and started rambling vaguely about plotters working against him, speculators bringing down the stock market, legislators delaying his policiesand his own ministers undermining him.
1809年1月，焦躁不安的拿破仑匆匆从西班牙战场返回巴黎。他的间谍和亲信证实了一个传言：外交大臣塔列朗与警察大臣富歇密谋反对他。震惊的拿破仑一抵达首都，便立即召集大臣们到宫中。他们到达后，他紧随其后进入会议室，开始来回踱步，语无伦次地谈论着有人密谋反对他、投机者打压股市、立法者阻挠他的政策，以及他自己的大臣们暗中破坏他的权力。
As Napoleon talked, Talleyrand leaned on the mantelpiece, looking completely indifferent. Facing Talleyrand directly, Napoleon announced, “For these ministers, treason has begun when they permit themselves to doubt.” At the word “treason” the ruler expected his minister to be afraid. But Talleyrand only smiled, calm and bored.
拿破仑讲话时，塔列朗倚在壁炉架上，神情漠然。拿破仑直视着塔列朗，宣布道：“对这些大臣来说，一旦他们心存疑虑，叛国之举便已开始。”听到“叛国”二字，这位君主本以为他的大臣会感到恐惧。然而，塔列朗只是微笑，神态平静而百无聊赖。
The sight of a subordinate apparently serene in the face of charges that could get him hanged pushed Napoleon to the edge. There were ministers, he said, who wanted him dead, and he took a step closer to Talleyrand who stared back at him unfazed. Finally Napoleon exploded. “You are a coward,” he screamed in Talleyrand's face, “a man of no faidi. Nothing is sacred to you. You would sell your own father. I have showered you with riches and yet there is nothing you would not do to hurt me.” The other ministers looked at each other in disbeliefthey had never seen this fearless general, the conqueror of most of Europe, so unhinged.
看到下属面对足以让他被绞死的指控却依然镇定自若，拿破仑怒不可遏。他说，有些大臣想要他的命，于是他朝塔列朗走近一步，塔列朗却面无表情地回望着他。最终，拿破仑爆发了。“你是个懦夫！”他对着塔列朗的脸咆哮道，“你是个没胆量的人！你什么都不怕！你连自己的父亲都卖了！我给了你那么多财富，你却为了伤害我什么都做得出来！”其他大臣面面相觑，难以置信——他们从未见过这位无所畏惧的将军，这位征服了欧洲大部分地区的君主，如此失控。
“You deserve to be broken like glass,” Napoleon continued, stamping. “I have the power to do it, but I have too much contempt for you to bother. Why didn't I have you hanged from die gates of the Tuileries But there is still time for that.” Yelling, almost out of bream, his face red, his eyes bulging, he went on, “You, by the way, are nothing but shit in a silk stocking. ... What about your wife You never told me that San Carlos was your wife's lover” “Indeed, sire, it did not occur to me that this information had any bearing on Your Majesty's glory or my own,” said Talleyrand calmly, completely unflustered. After a few more insults, Napoleon walked away. Talleyrand slowly crossed the room, moving with his characteristic limp. As an attendant helped him with his cloak, he turned to his fellow ministers (all afraid they would never see him again), and said, “What a pity, gende-men, that so great a man should have such bad manners.”
“你活该像玻璃一样被打碎，”拿破仑跺着脚继续说道，“我有能力这么做，但我太鄙视你了，懒得动手。我为什么没把你吊死在杜伊勒里宫的大门上？不过现在还来得及。”他几乎是声嘶力竭地吼道，脸涨得通红，双眼凸出，继续说道：“顺便说一句，你不过是披着丝袜的屎……你妻子呢？你从来没告诉我圣卡洛斯是你妻子的情人。”“陛下，我确实没想过这件事会与陛下的荣耀或我的荣耀有任何关系，”塔列朗平静地说道，丝毫没有慌乱。又骂了几句之后，拿破仑转身离开。塔列朗迈着他标志性的跛脚，缓缓地穿过房间。当侍从帮他穿好斗篷时，他转向他的同僚大臣们（他们都害怕再也见不到他了），说道：“真是可惜，各位，如此伟大的人物竟然如此缺乏教养。”
Despite his anger, Napoleon did not arrest his foreign minister. He merely relieved him of his duties aj id banished him from die court, believing that for this man humiliation would be punishment enough. He did not realize that word had quickly spread of his tiradeof how the emperor had completely lost control of himself, and how Talleyrand had essentially humiliated him by maintaining his composure and dignity. A page had been turned: For the first time people had seen die great emperor lose his cool under fire. A feeling spread that he was on die way down. As Talleyrand later said, “This is the beginning of the end.”
尽管拿破仑怒不可遏，但他并没有逮捕外交大臣。他只是解除了外交大臣的职务，并将他逐出宫廷，认为对这个人来说，羞辱就足以惩罚他了。他没有意识到，关于皇帝如何彻底失控，以及塔列朗如何凭借沉着冷静和尊严羞辱了他，他的怒斥之词很快就传开了。历史翻开了新的一页：人们第一次看到这位伟大的皇帝在枪林弹雨中失态。一种预感开始蔓延，认为他正在走向衰落。正如塔列朗后来所说：“这是末日的开始。”
Interpretation
解释
This was indeed the beginning of the end. Waterloo was still six years ahead, but Napoleon was on a slow descent to defeat, crystallizing in 1812 with his disastrous invasion of Russia. Talleyrand was the first to see the signs of his decline, especially in the irrational war with Spain. Sometime in 1808, die minister decided that for the future peace of Europe, Napoleon had to go. And so he conspired with Fouche.
这的确是末日的开端。滑铁卢战役还要六年才会到来，但拿破仑已然走向衰败，1812年入侵俄国的灾难性后果更是将其推向了崩溃的边缘。塔列朗是第一个察觉到拿破仑衰落迹象的人，尤其是在那场不理智的西班牙战争中。早在1808年，这位大臣就认定，为了欧洲未来的和平，拿破仑必须下台。于是，他与富歇密谋。
It is possible that the conspiracy was never anything more than a ploya device to push Napoleon over the edge. For it is hard to believe that two of the most practical men in history would only go halfway in their plotting. They may have been only stirring the waters, trying to goad Napoleon into a misstep. And indeed, what they got was the tantrum mat laid out his loss of control for all to see. In fact, Napoleon's soon-famous blowup that afternoon had a profoundly negative effect on his public image.
或许这场阴谋根本就不是阴谋，而只是个诱饵，目的是激怒拿破仑。很难相信历史上最务实的两个人会只做一半的计划。他们可能只是在搅浑水，试图激怒拿破仑，让他犯错。而他们最终得到的，正是拿破仑的暴怒，让他彻底失控，暴露无遗。事实上，那天下午拿破仑那场后来广为人知的暴怒，对他的公众形象造成了极其负面的影响。
This is the problem with the angry response. At first it may strike fear and terror, but only in some, and as the days pass and the storm clears, other responses emergeembarrassment and uneasiness about the shouter's capacity for going out of control, and resentment of what has been said. Losing your temper, you always make unfair and exaggerated accusations. A few such tirades and people are counting the days until you are gone.
这就是愤怒回应的问题所在。起初，它或许会引发恐惧和惊骇，但仅限于部分人。随着时间的推移，风暴逐渐平息，其他反应也会随之而来——对怒吼者失控能力的尴尬和不安，以及对对方言论的怨恨。一旦失去理智，你总是会做出不公平且夸张的指责。几次这样的咆哮过后，人们就开始盼着你赶紧离开。
In the face of a conspiracy against him, a conspiracy between his two most important ministers, Napoleon certainly had a right to feel angry and anxious. But by responding so angrily, and so publicly, he only demonstrated his frustration. To show your frustration is to show that you have lost your power to shape events; it is the helpless action of the child who resorts to a hysterical fit to get his way. The powerful never reveal this kind of weakness.
面对针对他的阴谋，尤其是两位最要好的大臣之间的阴谋，拿破仑当然有理由感到愤怒和焦虑。但他如此愤怒、如此公开地回应，只会暴露他的挫败感。表现出挫败感就等于表明你失去了掌控局势的能力；这就像孩子歇斯底里地哭闹以求得满足时那样无助。真正强大的人绝不会流露出这种软弱。
There were a number of tilings Napoleon could have done in this situation. He could have thought about the fact that two eminently sensible men had had reason to turn against him, and could have listened and learned from them. He could have tried to win them back to him. He could even have gotten rid of them, making their imprisonment or death an ominous display of his power. No tirades, no childish fits, no embarrassing after-effects-just a quiet and definitive severing of ties.
在这种情况下，拿破仑有很多种处理方式。他可以想想，两个极其明智的人有理由背叛他，他本可以倾听他们的意见并从中吸取教训。他本可以尝试挽回他们的心。他甚至可以除掉他们，让他们身陷囹圄或命丧黄泉，以此彰显自己的权力。无需咆哮，无需幼稚的举动，无需留下任何尴尬的后果——只需悄无声息地彻底断绝关系。
Remember: Tantrums neither intimidate nor inspire loyalty. They only create doubts and uneasiness about your power. Exposing your weakness, these stormy eruptions often herald a fall.
记住：发脾气既不能震慑人心，也不能赢得忠诚。它只会让人对你的力量产生怀疑和不安。这些暴怒的爆发暴露了你的弱点，往往预示着你的失败。
easily see whether his composure was ruffled or not by looking at the tea, which would not fall evenly ground to the proper consistency if he got excited. And so justice was done impartially and people went away from his court satisfied.
只需看看茶水，就能轻易判断他是否心神不宁。如果他激动起来，茶水就不会均匀地研磨成合适的浓稠度。因此，正义得以公正执行，人们离开他的法庭时都心满意足。
cha-no-yu:
茶之汤：
the japanese tea
日本茶
ceremony
仪式
A.L.Sadler,
A.L.萨德勒
If possible, no animosity should be felt for anyone.... To speak angrily to a person, to show your hatred by what you say or by the way you look, is an unnecessary proceedingdangerous, foolish, ridiculous, and vulgar.
如果可能，最好不要对任何人怀有敌意……对人怒气冲冲，用言语或眼神表达仇恨，都是不必要的——危险的、愚蠢的、可笑的、粗俗的。
Anger or hatred should never be shown otherwise than in what you do; and feelings will be all the more effective in action, in so far as you avoid the exhibition of them in any other way. It is only the coldblooded animals whose bite is poisonous.
愤怒或仇恨只能通过行动来表达；你越是避免以其他方式流露情感，就越能有效地运用它们。只有冷血动物的咬伤才有毒。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer.
叔本华。
1788-1860
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
By the late 1920s, Haile Selassie had nearly achieved his goal of assuming total control over Ethiopia, a country he felt needed strong and unified leadership. As regent to the empress Zauditu (stepdaughter of the late queen) and heir to the throne, Selassie had spent several years weakening the power of Ethiopia's various warlords. Now only one real obstacle stood
到了20世纪20年代末，海尔·塞拉西几乎实现了他完全掌控埃塞俄比亚的目标。他认为埃塞俄比亚需要一个强有力的统一领导。作为皇后扎乌迪图（已故女王的继女）的摄政王和王位继承人，塞拉西花费数年时间削弱了埃塞俄比亚各军阀的势力。现在，只剩下一个真正的障碍了。
THK MONKEY AND THE WASP
THK 猴子和黄蜂
A monkey, whilst munching a ripe pear, was pestered by the bare-faced importunities of a wasp, who, nolens volens, would have a part. After threatening the monkey with his anger if he further hesitated to submit to his demand, he settled on the fruit; but was as soon knocked off by the monkey. The irritable wasp now had recourse to invectiveand, after using the most insulting language, which the other calmly listened to, he so worked himself up into violent passion that, losing all consideration of the penalty, he flew to the face of the monkey, and stung him with such rage that he was unable to extricate his weapon, and was compelled to tear himself away, leaving it in the woundthus entailing on himself a lingering death, accompanied by pains much greater than those he had inflicted.
一只猴子正在津津有味地啃着熟透的梨，一只黄蜂却毫不掩饰地纠缠不休，它非要插手不可。黄蜂威胁猴子，如果猴子再不肯屈服，它就要发火。猴子这才停下手里的活，黄蜂立刻把梨打了下来。恼怒的黄蜂开始破口大骂，用尽各种侮辱性的语言，猴子却平静地听着。黄蜂越骂越激动，完全不顾后果，猛地飞到猴子脸上，狠狠地蛰了它一下。猴子无法拔出蛰，只好挣扎着飞走，蛰在伤口里，最终痛苦地死去，所受的折磨远比它加诸于猴子身上的要大得多。
FABLF.S,
FABLF.S，
Jonathan Birch, 1783-1847
乔纳森·伯奇，1783-1847
in his way: the empress and her husband, Ras Gugsa. Selassie knew the royal couple hated him and wanted to get rid of him, so to cut short their plotting he made Gugsa the governor of the northern province of Begemeder, forcing him to leave the capital, where the empress lived.
挡在他面前的就是皇后和她的丈夫拉斯·古格萨。塞拉西知道这对皇室夫妇恨他，想除掉他，所以为了阻止他们的阴谋，他任命古格萨为北部贝格梅德省的总督，迫使他离开皇后居住的首都。
For several years Gugsa played the loyal administrator. But Selassie did not trust him: He knew that Gugsa and the empress were plotting revenge. As time passed and Gugsa made no move, the chances of a plot only increased. Selassie knew what he had to do: draw Gugsa out, get under his skin, and push him into action before he was ready.
多年来，古格萨一直扮演着忠诚的管理者角色。但塞拉西并不信任他：他知道古格萨和皇后正在密谋复仇。随着时间的流逝，古格萨迟迟没有行动，阴谋发生的可能性反而越来越大。塞拉西知道自己必须做什么：引诱古格萨现身，激怒他，在他毫无防备的情况下迫使他采取行动。
For several years, a northern tribe, the Azebu Gallas, had been in virtual rebellion against the throne, robbing and pillaging local villages and refusing to pay taxes. Selassie had done nothing to stop them, letting them grow stronger. Finally, in 1929, he ordered Ras Gugsa to lead an army against these disobedient tribesmen. Gugsa agreed, but inwardly he seethedhe had no grudge against the Azebu Gallas, and the demand that he fight them hurt his pride. He could not disobey die order, but as he worked to put together an army, he began to spread an ugly rumorthat Selassie was in cahoots with the pope, and planned to convert the country to Roman Catholicism and make it a colony of Italy. Gugsa's army swelled, and some of the tribes from which its soldiers came secredy agreed to fight Selassie. In March of 1930 an enormous force of 35,000 men began to march, not on the Azebu Gallas but south, toward the capital of Addis Ababa. Made confident by his growing strength, Gugsa now openly led a holy war to depose Selassie and put the country back in the hands of true Christians.
多年来，北方的阿泽布·加拉斯部落实际上一直在反抗王室，他们抢劫掠夺当地村庄，拒缴赋税。塞拉西对此置之不理，任由他们势力壮大。最终，在1929年，他命令拉斯·古格萨率军镇压这些不服从的部落民。古格萨答应了命令，但他内心却怒火中烧——他与阿泽布·加拉斯并无仇恨，被要求与他们作战令他颜面尽失。他无法违抗命令，但在组建军队的过程中，他开始散布谣言，说塞拉西与教皇勾结，计划将国家皈依罗马天主教，使其成为意大利的殖民地。古格萨的军队不断壮大，一些士兵的来源部落也秘密同意与塞拉西作战。 1930年3月，一支由35000人组成的庞大军队开始进军，但他们并非向阿泽布·加拉斯进军，而是向南进军，目标是首都亚的斯亚贝巴。古格萨的实力日益增强，信心倍增，他公开发动圣战，意图推翻塞拉西，将国家重新交到真正基督徒手中。
He did not see the trap that had been laid for him. Before Selassie had ordered Gugsa to fight the Azebu Gallas, he had secured the support of the Ethiopian church. And before the revolt got underway, he had bribed several of Gugsa's key allies not to show up for battle. As the rebel army marched south, airplanes flew overhead dropping leaflets announcing that the highest church officials had recognized Selassie as die true Christian leader of Ethiopia, and that tiiey had excommunicated Gugsa for fomenting a civil war. These leaflets severely blunted the emotions behind the holy crusade. And as batde loomed and the support that Gugsa's allies had promised him failed to show up, soldiers began to flee or defect.
他没有察觉到为自己设下的陷阱。在塞拉西命令古格萨与阿泽布·加拉斯人作战之前，他已经获得了埃塞俄比亚教会的支持。在起义爆发之前，他还贿赂了古格萨的几位重要盟友，让他们不要参战。随着叛军南下，飞机在空中空盘旋，散发传单，宣称教会最高官员已承认塞拉西为埃塞俄比亚真正的基督教领袖，并因古格萨煽动内战而将其逐出教会。这些传单严重削弱了这场“圣战”背后的热情。随着战事临近，古格萨盟友承诺的支持却迟迟没有兑现，士兵们开始逃跑或叛逃。
When the batde came, the rebel army quicky collapsed. Refusing to surrender, Ras Gugsa was killed in die fighting. The empress, distraught over her husband's death, died a few days later. On April 30, Selassie issued a formal proclamation announcing his new tide: Emperor of Ethiopia.
军队到来后，叛军迅速溃败。拉斯·古格萨拒绝投降，最终在战斗中阵亡。皇后因丈夫的死而悲痛欲绝，几天后也去世了。4月30日，塞拉西发布正式公告，宣布他登基称帝：埃塞俄比亚皇帝。
Interpretation
解释
Haile Selassie always saw several moves ahead. He knew that if he let Ras Gugsa decide die time and place of the revolt, the danger would be much greater than if he forced Gugsa to act on Selassie's terms. So he goaded him into rebellion by offending his manly pride, asking him to fight people he had no quarrel with on behalf of a man he hated. Thinking everything out
海尔·塞拉西总是能预见到很多步。他知道，如果让拉斯·古格萨决定起义的时间和地点，危险性会比强迫古格萨按照他的意愿行事大得多。因此，他通过冒犯古格萨的男子气概来激怒他，让他为了一个自己憎恨的人去与素不相识的人作战，从而促使他发动叛乱。他深思熟虑，步步为营。
ahead, Selassie made sure that Gugsa's rebellion would come to nothing, and mat he could use it to do away with his last two enemies.
塞拉西事先确保古格萨的叛乱不会成功，这样他就可以借此除掉他最后的两个敌人。
This is the essence of the Law: When the waters are still, your opponents have the time and space to plot actions that they will initiate and control. So stir the waters, force the fish to the surface, get them to act before they are ready, steal the initiative. The best way to do this is to play on uncontrollable emotionspride, vanity, love, hate. Once die water is stirred up, the little fish cannot help but rise to the bait. The angrier they become, the less control they have, and finally they are caught in the whirlpool you have made, and they drown.
这就是法则的精髓：当水面平静时，你的对手就有时间和空间去策划他们将要发起和掌控的行动。所以，搅动水面，迫使鱼儿浮出水面，让他们在准备不足的情况下采取行动，夺取主动权。最好的方法是利用人们难以控制的情绪——骄傲、虚荣、爱、恨。一旦水面被搅动，小鱼儿就无法抗拒地游向诱饵。他们越愤怒，就越失去控制，最终被你制造的漩涡吞噬，溺亡而亡。
A sovereign should never launch an army out of anger, a leader should never start a war out of wrath.
君主绝不应因愤怒而发动军队，领袖绝不应因怒火而发动战争。
Sun-tzu, fourth century B. c.
孙子，公元前四世纪
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Angry people usually end up looking ridiculous, for their response seems out of proportion to what occasioned it. They have taken things too seriously, exaggerating the hurt or insult that has been done to them. They are so sensitive to slight that it becomes comical how much diey take personally. More comical still is their belief that their outbursts signify power. The truth is the opposite: Petulance is not power, it is a sign of helplessness. People may temporarily be cowed by your tantrums, but in the end they lose respect for you. They also realize they can easily undermine a person with so little self-control.
易怒的人往往显得滑稽可笑，因为他们的反应似乎与起因不成比例。他们把事情看得太重，夸大了自己受到的伤害或侮辱。他们对轻微的冒犯极其敏感，以至于他们把多少事都当成针对自己，这本身就很可笑。更可笑的是，他们竟然认为自己的爆发代表着力量。事实恰恰相反：任性并非力量，而是无助的表现。人们或许会被你的坏脾气暂时震慑，但最终他们会失去对你的尊重。他们也会意识到，一个如此缺乏自制力的人很容易被他们击败。
The answer, however, is not to repress our angry or emotional responses. For repression drains us of energy and pushes us into strange behavior. Instead we have to change our perspective: We have to realize that nothing in the social realm, and in the game of power, is personal.
然而，答案并非压抑我们的愤怒或情绪反应。因为压抑会耗尽我们的精力，并迫使我们做出怪异的行为。相反，我们必须改变视角：我们必须认识到，在社会领域和权力游戏中，没有什么是个人恩怨。
Everyone is caught up in a chain of events that long predates the present moment. Our anger often stems from problems in our childhood, from the problems of our parents which stem from their own childhood, on and on. Our anger also has roots in the many interactions with others, the accumulated disappointments and heartaches that we have suffered. An individual will often appear as the instigator of our anger but it is much more complicated, goes far beyond what that individual did to us. If a person explodes with anger at you (and it seems out of proportion to what you did to them), you must remind yourself that it is not exclusively directed at you do not be so vain. The cause is much larger, goes way back in time, involves dozens of prior hurts, and is actually not worth the bother to understand. Instead of seeing it as a personal grudge, look at the emotional outburst as a disguised power move, an attempt to control or punish you cloaked in the form of hurt feelings and anger.
每个人都身处一连串远早于当下的事件之中。我们的愤怒往往源于童年的创伤，源于父母童年的创伤，如此往复。我们的愤怒也根植于与他人的无数次互动，以及我们累积的失望和心痛之中。某个人常常看似是我们愤怒的始作俑者，但事情远比这复杂得多，远远超出了这个人对我们所做的一切。如果有人对你大发雷霆（而且看起来与你对他的所作所为不成比例），你必须提醒自己，这并非仅仅针对你——别太自负。其根源更为深远，可以追溯到很久以前，牵涉到无数过往的伤害，实际上并不值得费心去理解。与其将其视为个人恩怨，不如将这种情绪爆发视为一种伪装的权力游戏，一种试图控制或惩罚你的手段，而这种手段却披着受伤和愤怒的外衣。
This shift of perspective will let you play the game of power with more clarity and energy. Instead of overreacting, and becoming ensnared in peo-
这种视角转变将使你能够更清晰、更有活力地玩转权力游戏。你不会再反应过度，也不会再陷入人际交往的泥潭。
DITCH HIGH PRIEST
沟渠大祭司
Kin'yo, an officer of the second rank, had a brother called the High Priest Ryogaku, an extremely bad-tempered man. Next to his monastery grew a large nettle-tree which occasioned the nickname people gave him, the Nettle-tree High Priest. “That name is outrageous,” said the high priest, and cut down the tree. The stump still being left, people referred to him now as the Stump High Priest. More furious than ever, Ryogaku had the stump dug up and thrown away, but this left a big ditch. People now called him the Ditch High Priest.
二品官金阳有个兄弟叫良岳，是位脾气极其暴躁的大僧。寺院旁边长着一棵巨大的荨麻树，因此人们给他起了个绰号叫“荨麻树大僧”。“这名字太过分了！”大僧骂道，然后把树砍倒了。树桩留下后，人们又叫他“树桩大僧”。良岳更加愤怒，命人把树桩挖走扔掉，结果留下了一条大沟。人们又叫他“沟渠大僧”。
ESSAYS IN IDLENESS, KENKO,
闲散随笔，KENKO
Japan,
日本，
fourteenth century
十四世纪
pie's emotions, you will turn their loss of control to your advantage: You keep your head while they are losing theirs.
你要利用馅饼的情绪，将他们的失控转化为你的优势：当他们失去理智时，你保持冷静。
During an important batde in the War of the Three Kingdoms, in die third century A.D., advisers to die commander Ts'ao Ts'ao discovered documents showing that certain of his generals had conspired with die enemy, and urged him to arrest and execute diem. Instead he ordered the documents burned and die matter forgotten. At this critical moment in the battle, to get upset or demand justice would have reverberated against him: An angry action would have called attention to die generals' disloyalty, which would have harmed die troops' morale. Justice could waithe would deal with the generals in time. Ts'ao Ts'ao kept his head and made the right decision.
在公元三世纪三国战争的一场重要战役中，曹操的谋士们发现了一些文件，显示他的一些将领与敌人勾结，并敦促他逮捕并处决他们。然而，曹操并没有这样做，而是下令焚毁这些文件，让此事不了了之。在如此关键的时刻，如果他因此而愤怒或要求惩处，反而会适得其反：愤怒的举动会暴露将领们的不忠，从而打击军队的士气。而惩处可以稍后再做，总有机会处理这些将领。曹操保持了冷静，做出了正确的决定。
Compare this to Napoleon's response to Talleyrand: Instead of taking the conspiracy personally, the emperor should have played the game like Ts'ao Ts'ao, carefully weighing die consequences of any action he took. The more powerful response in the end would have been to ignore Talleyrand, or to bring the minister gradually back to his side and punish him later.
这与拿破仑对塔列朗的回应截然不同：皇帝本应像曹操那样，谨慎权衡每一步行动的后果，而不是将阴谋视为个人恩怨。最终，更有效的做法是无视塔列朗，或者逐步将这位大臣拉拢到自己身边，然后再予以惩罚。
Anger only cuts off our options, and die powerful cannot thrive witii-out options. Once you train yourself not to take matters personally, and to control your emotional responses, you will have placed yourself in a position of tremendous power: Now you can play with die emotional responses of odier people. Stir die insecure into action by impugning their manhood, and by dangling die prospect of an easy victory before tiieir faces. Do as Houdini did when challenged by die less successful escape artist Kleppini: Reveal an apparent weakness (Houdini let Kleppini steal the combination for a pair of cuffs) to lure your opponent into action. Then you can beat him with ease. Widi the arrogant too you can appear weaker tiian you are, taunting diem into a rash action.
愤怒只会限制我们的选择，而强大的人如果没有选择就无法生存。一旦你训练自己不把事情看得太重，并控制好自己的情绪反应，你就能掌握巨大的力量：现在你可以玩弄他人的情绪。通过质疑他们的男子气概，并在他们面前晃动轻松取胜的诱惑，激起他们内心的不安。就像胡迪尼面对不太成功的逃脱大师克莱皮尼的挑战时那样：暴露一个明显的弱点（胡迪尼故意让克莱皮尼偷走手铐的密码），引诱对手采取行动。然后你就能轻松击败他。即使你很傲慢，你也可以表现得比实际更弱，以此来激怒他们，诱使他们做出鲁莽的举动。
Sun Pin, commander of die armies of Ch'i and loyal disciple of Sun-tzu, once led his troops against the armies of Wei, which outnumbered him two to one. “Let us light a hundred thousand fires when our army enters Wei,” suggested Sun Pin, “fifty thousand on die next day, and only thirty thousand on the third.” On the tiiird day the Wei general exclaimed, “I knew the men of Ch'i were cowards, and after only three days more than half of diem have deserted!” So, leaving behind his slow-moving heavy infantry, the general decided to seize the moment and move swiftly on die Ch'i camp with a lightiy armed force. Sun Pin's troops retreated, luring Wei's army into a narrow pass, where tiiey ambushed and destroyed diem. Widi die Wei general dead and his forces decimated, Sun Pin now easily defeated the rest of his army.
齐军统帅孙平，孙子兵法的忠实弟子，曾率军迎战兵力是自己二倍的魏军。孙平提议：“我们进魏城时，先点燃十万堆火，第二天点燃五万堆，第三天点燃三万堆。”到了第三天，魏将领惊呼：“我就知道齐军是懦夫，才三天，他们就逃亡过半！”于是，魏将领抛弃了行动迟缓的重步兵，决定抓住机会，率领轻装部队迅速突袭齐军营地。孙平的部队撤退，将魏军引诱到一处狭窄的隘口，在那里设下埋伏，将其歼灭。魏将领阵亡，魏军损失惨重，孙平轻松击败了魏军的残余部队。
In the face of a hot-headed enemy, finally, an excellent response is no response. Follow the Talleyrand tactic: Notiiing is as infuriating as a man who keeps his cool while others are losing theirs. If it will work to your advantage to unsetde people, affect die aristocratic, bored pose, neimer mocking nor triumphant but simply indifferent. This will light tiieir fuse.
面对脾气暴躁的敌人，最好的应对方式莫过于不予回应。效仿塔列朗的策略：无所作为与那些在他人失去理智时仍保持冷静的人一样令人恼火。如果激怒他人对你有利，那就摆出一副高傲、百无聊赖的姿态，既不嘲讽也不得意，只是表现得漠不关心。这反而会点燃他们的怒火。
When they embarrass themselves with a temper tantrum, you will have gained several victories, one of these being that in the face of their childishness you have maintained your dignity and composure.
当他们因为发脾气而让自己难堪时，你将获得几项胜利，其中之一是，面对他们的幼稚行为，你保持了尊严和镇定。
Image: The Pond of Fish. The waters are clear and calm, and the fish are well below the surface. Stir the waters and they emerge. Stir it some more and they get angry, rising to the surface, biting whatever comes near-including a freshly baited hook.
图片：鱼塘。池水清澈平静，鱼儿潜伏在水面之下。搅动池水，它们便浮出水面。再搅动一下，它们便会变得愤怒，跃出水面，攻击任何靠近的东西——包括刚挂好鱼饵的鱼钩。
Authority: If your opponent is of a hot temper, try to irritate him. If he is arrogant, try to encourage his egotism. . . . One who is skilled at making the enemy move does so by creating a situation according to which the enemy will act; he entices the enemy with something he is certain to take. He keeps the enemy on the move by holding out bait and then attacks him with picked troops. (Sun-tzu, fourth century B.C.)
权威：如果你的对手脾气暴躁，就激怒他；如果他傲慢自大，就助长他的傲慢……善于诱敌的人，会制造敌人必然会采取的行动；他会用敌人必得的东西引诱敌人，用诱饵牵制敌人，然后以精锐部队攻击敌人。（孙子，公元前四世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
When playing with people's emotions you have to be careful. Study the
玩弄他人感情时要格外小心。好好研究一下……
enemy beforehand: Some fish are best left at the bottom of the pond.
先发制人：有些鱼最好留在池塘底部。
The leaders of the city of Tyre, capital of ancient Phoenicia, felt confident they could withstand Alexander the Great, who had conquered the Orient but had not attacked their city, which stood well protected on the water. They sent ambassadors to Alexander saying that although they would recognize him as emperor they would not allow him or his forces to enter Tyre. This of course enraged him, and he immediately mounted a siege. For four months the city withstood him, and finally he decided that the struggle was not worth it, and that he would come to terms with the Tyrians. But they, feeling that they had already baited Alexander and gotten away with it, and confident that they could withstand him, refused to
古腓尼基首都推罗城的统治者们自信满满，认为自己能够抵挡住征服东方却未曾进攻过这座临水而居、防御工事坚固的城市的亚历山大大帝。他们派遣使节觐见亚历山大，表示虽然承认他是皇帝，但绝不允许他及其军队进入推罗。这自然激怒了亚历山大，他立即下令围城。推罗城顽强抵抗了四个月之久，最终亚历山大认为这场战争得不偿失，决定与推罗人谈判。然而，推罗人自认为已经成功激怒了亚历山大，并且自信能够抵挡住他的进攻，因此拒绝与他谈判。
negotiatein fact diey killed his messengers.
谈判实际上导致他们杀死了他的信使。
This pushed Alexander over die edge. Now it did not matter to him how long the siege lasted or how large an army it needed; he had die resources, and would do whatever it took. He remounted his assault so strenuously mat he captured Tyre witiiin days, burned it to the ground, and sold its people into slavery.
这使亚历山大彻底失去了斗志。现在，围城持续多久、需要多大兵力对他来说都无关紧要了；他拥有足够的资源，并且会不惜一切代价。他重新发动进攻，如此猛烈，几天之内就攻占了推罗，将其夷为平地，并将城中居民卖为奴隶。
You can bait the powerful and get mem to commit and divide their forces as Sun Pin did, but test die waters first. Find die gap in tiieir strengm. If mere is no gapif diey are impossibly strongyou have nodiing to gain and everydiing to lose by provoking diem. Choose carefully whom you bait, and never stir up die sharks.
你可以像孙彬那样引诱强者，让他们投入兵力并分散兵力，但要先试探他们的底线。找到他们实力上的差距。如果没有差距——如果他们强大到无法阻挡——那么挑衅他们就毫无益处，只会损失惨重。谨慎选择你的目标，切勿招惹鲨鱼。
Finally mere are times when a well-timed burst of anger can do you good, but your anger must be manufactured and under your control. Then you can determine exacdy how and on whom it will fall. Never stir up reactions mat will work against you in the long run. And use your tiiunder-bolts rarely, to make diem die more intimidating and meaningful. Whedier purposefully staged or not, if your outbursts come too often, they will lose Uieir power.
最后，只有少数情况下，适时的愤怒爆发才能对你有利，但你的愤怒必须精心策划并完全受你控制。这样你才能精准地决定愤怒的走向和对象。永远不要激起那些最终会对你不利的反应。而且，要谨慎使用你的怒火，让每一次爆发都更具威慑力和意义。无论你的怒火爆发是有意为之还是无意之举，如果过于频繁，它们都会失去效力。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 40
第40条
DESPISE THE FREE LUNCH
不屑于免费午餐
JUDGMENT
判断
What is offered for free is dangerousit usually involves either a trick or a hidden obligation. What has worth is worth paying for. By paying your own way you stay clear of gratitude, guilt, and deceit. It is also often wise to pay the full pricethere is no cutting corners with excellence. Be lavish with your money and keep it circulating, for generosity is a sign and a magnet for power.
免费的东西往往很危险，通常都暗藏陷阱或隐瞒着某种义务。有价值的东西值得付费。自掏腰包，才能避免感恩、愧疚和欺骗。支付全价通常也是明智之举——卓越品质不容偷工减料。慷慨解囊，让金钱流通，因为慷慨是力量的象征和磁石。
HI Hill) THKASI HI.
嗨，希尔）THKASI 嗨。
Many weak-minded persons in cities hope to discover property under the surface of the earth and to make some profit from it. In the Maghrib there are many Berber “students” who are unable to make a living by natural ways and means. They approach well-to-do people with papers that have torn margins and contain either non-Arabic writing or what they claim to be the translation of a document written by the owner of buried treasures, giving the clue to the hiding place. In this way, they try to get their sustenance by [persuading the well-to-do] to send them out to dig and hunt for treasure. Occasionally, one of these treasure hunters displays strange information or some remarkable trick of magic with which he fools people into believing his other claims, although, in fact, he knows nothing of magic and its procedures.... The things that have been said about /treasure hunting] have no scientific basis, nor are they based upon [factual] information. It should be realized that although treasures are found, this happens rarely and by chance, not by systematic search.... Those who are deluded or afflicted by these things must take refuge in God
城市里许多意志薄弱的人都希望发现埋藏在地下的宝藏并从中牟利。在马格里布地区，有很多柏柏尔“学生”无法靠正当手段谋生。他们拿着一些边缘破损的纸张接近富裕人家，这些纸张上要么是非阿拉伯文字，要么是他们声称是埋藏宝藏主人留下的文件的译文，上面写着宝藏的藏匿地点。他们以此为生，试图说服富裕人家派他们去挖掘和寻宝。有时，这些寻宝者会展示一些奇怪的信息或一些神奇的魔术，以此蒙骗人们相信他们的其他说法，尽管实际上他们对魔术及其原理一无所知……以上关于寻宝的说法既没有科学依据，也没有事实依据。应当明白，虽然宝藏确实存在，但这很少发生，而且是偶然的，并非通过系统性的寻找就能获得……那些受这些迷惑或困扰的人，应当皈依上帝。
MONEY AND POWER
金钱与权力
In the realm of power, everything must be judged by its cost, and everything has a price. What is offered for free or at bargain rates often comes with a psychological price tagcomplicated feelings of obligation, compromises with quality, the insecurity those compromises bring, on and on. The powerful learn early to protect their most valuable resources: independence and room to maneuver. By paying the full price, they keep themselves free of dangerous entanglements and worries.
在权力领域，一切都必须以其成本来衡量，任何事物都有代价。免费或低价提供的事物往往带有心理上的代价——复杂的责任感、对品质的妥协、妥协带来的不安全感等等。强者很早就学会保护他们最宝贵的资源：独立性和回旋余地。通过付出全部代价，他们才能避免陷入危险的纠葛和忧虑之中。
Being open and flexible with money also teaches the value of strategic generosity, a variation on the old trick of “giving when you are about to take.” By giving the appropriate gift, you put the recipient under obligation. Generosity softens people upto be deceived. By gaining a reputation for liberality, you win people's admiration while distracting them from your power plays. By strategically spreading your wealth, you charm the other courtiers, creating pleasure and making valuable allies.
金钱上的开放和灵活也教会了人们策略性慷慨的价值，这是一种“欲取必先”的古老技巧的变体。通过赠送合适的礼物，你可以让接受者产生义务感。慷慨会让人变得容易受骗。通过赢得慷慨的名声，你可以赢得人们的钦佩，同时转移他们对你权力游戏的注意力。通过策略性地分配财富，你可以讨好其他朝臣，创造愉悦并结交宝贵的盟友。
Look at the masters of powerthe Caesars, the Queen Elizabeths, the Michelangelos, the Medicis: Not a miser among them. Even the great con artists spend freely to swindle. Tight purse strings are unattractivewhen engaged in seduction, Casanova would give completely not only of himself but of his wallet. The powerful understand that money is psychologically charged, and that it is also a vessel of politeness and sociability. They make the human side of money a weapon in their armory.
看看那些权势滔天的人——凯撒、伊丽莎白女王、米开朗基罗、美第奇家族：他们之中没有一个吝啬鬼。即使是最厉害的骗子，为了行骗也挥金如土。在诱惑他人时，吝啬鬼毫无魅力可言。卡萨诺瓦不仅会倾尽所有，还会毫不犹豫地掏空钱包。有权势的人明白，金钱具有强大的心理效应，它也是礼貌和社交的载体。他们将金钱的人性一面转化为自己武器库中的利器。
For everyone able to play with money, thousands more are locked in a self-destructive refusal to use money creatively and strategically. These types represent the opposite pole to the powerful, and you must learn to recognize themeither to avoid their poisonous natures or to turn their inflexibility to your advantage:
有些人善于玩转金钱，而另一些人则深陷于自我毁灭的泥潭，拒绝创造性地、策略性地运用金钱。这些人与强势群体截然相反，你必须学会识别他们，要么避开他们有害的本性，要么利用他们的固执为己所用。
The Greedy Fish. The greedy fish take the human side out of money. Cold and ruthless, they see only the lifeless balance sheet; viewing others solely as either pawns or obstructions in their pursuit of wealth, they trample on people's sentiments and alienate valuable allies. No one wants to work with the greedy fish, and over the years they end up isolated, which often proves their undoing.
贪婪之鱼。贪婪之鱼将金钱中的人性一面剥离殆尽。他们冷酷无情，眼中只有冰冷的资产负债表；他们视他人为追逐财富的棋子或绊脚石，践踏他人的情感，疏远宝贵的盟友。没有人愿意与贪婪之鱼共事，久而久之，他们最终孤立无援，而这往往是他们走向毁灭的根源。
Greedy fish are the con artist's bread and butter: Lured by the bait of easy money, they swallow the ruse hook, line, and sinker. They are easy to deceive, for they spend so much time dealing with numbers (not with people) that they become blind to psychology, including their own. Either avoid them before they exploit you or play on their greed to your gain.
贪婪之人是骗子的摇钱树：他们被轻松赚钱的诱惑所吸引，全盘接受骗局。他们很容易被欺骗，因为他们把太多时间花在与数字打交道（而不是与人交往）上，以至于对心理习以为常，甚至对自己的心理也缺乏了解。要么在他们利用你之前远离他们，要么利用他们的贪婪为自己谋利。
The Bargain Demon. Powerful people judge everything by what it costs, not just in money but in time, dignity, and peace of mind. And this is exactly what Bargain Demons cannot do. Wasting valuable time digging for bargains, they worry endlessly about what they could have gotten elsewhere for a litde less. On top of that, the bargain item they do buy is often shabby; perhaps it needs costly repairs, or will have to be replaced twice as
讨价还价的恶魔。有权势的人衡量一切的标准都是成本，不仅是金钱，还有时间、尊严和内心的平静。而这正是讨价还价的恶魔所无法做到的。他们浪费宝贵的时间去寻找便宜货，却总是纠结于自己本可以花更少的钱买到什么。更糟糕的是，他们买到的便宜货往往质量低劣；或许需要昂贵的维修，或者需要更换两次。
fast as a high-quality item. The costs of these pursuitsnot always in money (though the price of a bargain is often deceptive) but in time and peace of minddiscourage normal people from undertaking mem, but for the Bargain Demon the bargain is an end in itself.
速度堪比高品质商品。追求这些的代价并非总是金钱（尽管便宜货的价格往往具有欺骗性），而是时间和心安，这让普通人望而却步，但对于讨价还价的恶魔来说，讨价还价本身就是目的。
These types might seem to harm only themselves, but their attitudes are contagious: Unless you resist them they will infect you with the insecure feeling that you should have looked harder to find a cheaper price. Don't argue with them or try to change diem. Just mentally add up the cost, in time and inner peace if not in hidden financial expense, of the irrational pursuit of a bargain.
这些人看似只会伤害自己，但他们的态度却极具传染性：除非你抵制他们，否则他们会让你产生不安全感，觉得自己应该更努力地寻找更便宜的价格。不要和他们争论，也不要试图改变他们的想法。只需在心里默默计算一下，这种非理性地追求低价所带来的代价——时间的损失、内心的平静的丧失，甚至可能包括隐性的经济损失。
from their inability to make a living and their laziness in this respect. They should not occupy themselves with absurdities and untrue stories.
他们之所以沉迷于此，是因为他们无力谋生，而且在这方面也十分懒惰。他们不应该把时间浪费在荒谬和不实的故事上。
THE MUOADDIMAH, IBN KhALDUN,
穆阿迪玛，伊本·哈尔顿
1332-1406
The Sadist. Financial sadists play vicious power games with money as a way of asserting their power. They might, for example, make you wait for money that is owed you, promising you that the check is in the mail. Or if they hire you to work for diem, they meddle in every aspect of the job, haggling and giving you ulcers. Sadists seem to think that paying for something gives them the right to torture and abuse the seller. They have no sense of the courtier element in money. If you are unlucky enough to get involved with this type, accepting a financial loss may be better in the long run than getting entangled in their destructive power games.
虐待狂。金融虐待狂会利用金钱玩弄恶毒的权力游戏，以此来巩固自己的权力。例如，他们可能会让你苦等应得的款项，并承诺支票正在邮寄途中。或者，如果他们雇佣你按日计酬，他们会插手工作的方方面面，讨价还价，让你痛苦不堪。虐待狂似乎认为，付钱就赋予了他们折磨和虐待卖家的权利。他们完全不理解金钱中蕴含的礼仪和尊重。如果你不幸与这类人打交道，从长远来看，接受经济损失或许比卷入他们破坏性的权力游戏要好得多。
