The Indiscriminate Giver. Generosity has a definite function in power: It attracts people, softens diem up, makes allies out of diem. But it has to be used strategically, with a definite end in mind. Indiscriminate Givers, on the other hand, are generous because they want to be loved and admired by all. And their generosity is so indiscriminate and needy mat it may not have the desired effect: If they give to one and all, why should die recipient feel special Attractive as it may seem to make an Indiscriminate Giver your mark, in any involvement with this type you will often feel burdened by their insatiable emotional needs.
不加选择的施予者。慷慨在权力中确实发挥着作用：它能吸引人，软化人心，结交盟友。但慷慨必须策略性地运用，并带有明确的目标。而不加选择的施予者则不同，他们慷慨是因为他们渴望被所有人爱戴和仰慕。他们的慷慨如此不加选择且需求过多，以至于可能无法达到预期效果：如果他们对每个人都施予，那么接受者又有什么资格感到自己很特别呢？尽管与不加选择的施予者交往似乎很有吸引力，但与这类人交往时，你常常会感到被他们永无止境的情感需求所困扰。
TRANSGRESSIONS OF THE LAW
违法行为
Transgression I
越轨 I
After Francisco Pizarro conquered Peru, in 1532, gold from the Incan Empire began to pour into Spain, and Spaniards of all classes started dreaming of the instant riches to be had in the New World. The story soon spread of an Indian chief to the east of Peru who once each year would ritually cover himself in gold dust and dive into a lake. Soon word of mouth transformed El Dorado, the “Golden Man,” into an empire called El Dorado, wealthier than the Incan, where the streets were paved and the buildings inlaid with gold. This elaboration of die story did not seem implausible, for surely a diief who could afford to waste gold dust in a lake must rule a golden empire. Soon Spaniards were searching for El Dorado all over northern South America.
1532年，弗朗西斯科·皮萨罗征服秘鲁后，印加帝国的黄金开始涌入西班牙，西班牙各阶层人士都开始梦想着在新大陆一夜暴富。很快，一个关于秘鲁东部一位印第安酋长的故事传开，据说他每年都会举行仪式，全身涂满金粉，然后潜入湖中。口口相传，埃尔多拉多——“黄金人”——逐渐演变成一个名为埃尔多拉多的帝国，比印加帝国还要富裕，街道铺满金箔，建筑镶嵌着黄金。这种对故事的夸张描述似乎并非毫无道理，毕竟，一个能把金粉挥霍在湖里的酋长，必然统治着一个黄金帝国。不久之后，西班牙人便开始在南美洲北部各地寻找埃尔多拉多。
THE MISKR
密斯克
A miser, to make sure of his property, sold all that he had and converted it into a great lump of gold, which he hid in a hole in the ground, and went continually to visit and inspect it. This roused the curiosity of one of his workmen, who, suspecting that there was a treasure, when his master's back was turned, went to the spot, and stole it away. When the miser returned and found the place empty, he wept and tore his hair. But a neighbor who saw him in this extravagant grief, and learned the cause of it, said: “Fret thyself no longer, but take a stone and put it in the same place, and think that it is your lump of gold; for, as you never meant to use it, the one will do you as much good as the other.”
一个守财奴为了确保自己的财产安全，变卖了所有家产，换成了一大块金子，藏在一个地洞里，并经常去查看。这引起了他一个工人的好奇心。工人怀疑洞里藏着宝藏，趁主人不注意，偷偷溜到洞口，把金子偷走了。守财奴回来后发现洞里空无一物，便痛哭流涕，揪着头发。一位邻居看到他如此悲伤，得知缘由后，说道：“别再难过了，拿一块石头放在原来的洞里，就当它是你的金子；反正你也没打算用它，这两块石头对你来说都一样。”
The worth of money is not in its possession, but in its use.
金钱的价值不在于拥有它，而在于如何使用它。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop,
伊索
sixth century b.c.
公元前六世纪
There is a popular saying in Japan that goes “Tada yori takai mono wa nai,” meaning: “Nothing is more costly than something given free of charge.”
日本有一句流行的说法是“Tada yori takai mono wa nai”，意思是：“没有什么比免费的东西更昂贵。”
THE UNSPOKEN WAY, MlCHIHIRO
未言之道，千寻
Matsumoto, 1988
松本，1988
Yusuf lbn Jafar el-Amudl used to take sums of money, sometimes very large ones, from those who came to study with him. A distinguished legalist visiting him once said: “I am enchanted and impressed by your teachings, and I am sure that you are directing your disciples in a proper manner. But it is not in accordance with tradition to take money for knowledge. Besides, the action is open to misinterpretation.” El-Amudi said: "I have never sold any knowledge. There is no money on earth sufficient to pay for it. As for misinterpretation, the abstaining from taking money will not prevent it, for it will find some other object. Rather should you know that a man who takes money may be greedy for money, or he may not. But a man who takes nothing at all is under the gravest
优素福·伊本·贾法尔·阿穆迪过去常常向前来拜师学艺的人收取金钱，有时数额巨大。一位德高望重的法学家曾拜访他，说道：“我被您的教诲深深吸引，也对您印象深刻，我相信您引导弟子的方式是正确的。但是，收取金钱来获取知识并不符合传统。此外，这种行为很容易被误解。”阿穆迪回答说：“我从未出售过任何知识。世上没有任何金钱能够换取知识。至于误解，不收取金钱并不能阻止它，因为误解会找到其他途径。你应该明白，收取金钱的人可能贪婪，也可能不贪婪。但一个什么都不收的人，却面临着最严重的后果。”
In February of 1541, the largest expedition yet in diis venture, led by Pizarro's brother Gonzalo, left Quito, in Ecuador. Resplendent in their armors and colorful silks, 340 Spaniards headed east, along with 4,000 Indians to carry supplies and serve as scouts, 4,000 swine, dozens of llamas, and close to 1,000 dogs. But the expedition was soon hit by torrential rain, which rotted its gear and spoiled its food. Meanwhile, as Gonzalo Pizarro questioned die Indians diey met along the way, diose who seemed to be widiholding information, or who had not even heard of die fabulous kingdom, he would torture and feed to the dogs. Word of the Spaniards' mur-derousness spread quickly among the Indians, who realized that the only way to avoid Gonzalo's wrath was to make up stories about El Dorado and send him as far away as possible. As Gonzalo and his men followed die leads die Indians gave diem, dien, they were only led farther into deep jungle.
1541年2月，皮萨罗的兄弟贡萨洛率领着迄今为止规模最大的探险队从厄瓜多尔的基多出发。340名西班牙人身着华丽的盔甲和色彩鲜艳的丝绸，向东进发，同行的还有4000名印第安人负责运送补给和担任侦察兵，以及4000头猪、数十只羊驼和近1000条狗。然而，探险队很快就遭遇了暴雨，雨水腐蚀了他们的装备，也使食物变质。与此同时，贡萨洛·皮萨罗盘问沿途遇到的印第安人，那些似乎有所隐瞒或甚至从未听说过这个神秘王国的人，他都会对他们进行折磨，然后把他们喂狗。西班牙人的残暴行径很快在印第安人中传开，他们意识到，避免贡萨罗怒火的唯一办法就是编造关于黄金国的故事，把他赶到尽可能远的地方。贡萨罗和他的手下循着印第安人提供的线索，却被引得越陷越深，最终被带入了丛林深处。
The explorers' spirits sagged. Their uniforms had long since shredded; their armor rusted and they threw it away; their shoes were torn to pieces, forcing Uiem to walk barefoot; the Indian slaves they had set out with had either died or deserted them; diey had eaten not only the swine but the hunting dogs and llamas. They lived on roots and fruit. Realizing that they could not continue this way, Pizarro decided to risk river travel, and a barge was built out of rotting wood. But die journey down die treacherous Napo River proved no easier. Setting up camp on die river's edge, Gonzalo sent scouts ahead on the barge to find Indian settlements with food. He waited and waited for the scouts to return, only to find out they had decided to desert the expedition and continue down the river on their own.
探险队员们的士气低落。他们的制服早已破烂不堪；盔甲锈迹斑斑，他们也将其丢弃；鞋子破烂不堪，迫使乌伊姆赤脚行走；与他们一同出发的印第安奴隶要么已经死去，要么已经抛弃了他们；他们不仅吃掉了猪，还吃掉了猎犬和羊驼。他们只能靠根茎和水果勉强维生。意识到这样下去行不通，皮萨罗决定冒险沿河而下，并用腐朽的木头建造了一艘驳船。然而，沿着险恶的纳波河顺流而下的旅程也并非一帆风顺。冈萨罗在河岸边扎营，派出侦察兵乘驳船先行，寻找有食物的印第安人定居点。他苦苦等待侦察兵归来，却发现他们已经决定放弃探险，独自沿河而下。
The rain continued without end. Gonzalo's men forgot about El Dorado; diey wanted only to return to Quito. Finally, in August of 1542, a little over a hundred men, from an expedition originally numbering in the thousands, managed to find their way back. To the residents of Quito they seemed to have emerged from hell itself, wrapped in tatters and skins, dieir bodies covered in sores, and so emaciated as to be unrecognizable. For over a year and a half diey had marched in an enormous circle, two tiiou-sand miles by foot. The vast sums of money invested in die expedition had yielded nothingno sign of El Dorado and no sign of gold. Interpretation
雨下个不停。贡萨罗的部下早已忘记了黄金国，他们只想返回基多。最终，在1542年8月，一支最初有数千人的探险队中，只剩下一百多人，才勉强找到了返回的路。在基多居民眼中，他们仿佛是从地狱里走出来的，浑身裹着破烂的衣衫和兽皮，遍体鳞伤，骨瘦如柴，面目全非。一年半的时间里，他们一直在原地打转，徒步走了两万多英里。投入到这次探险中的巨额资金却一无所获——既没有黄金国的踪迹，也没有黄金的踪迹。
Even after Gonzalo Pizarro's disaster, the Spaniards launched expedition after expedition in search of El Dorado. And like Pizarro the conquistadors would burn and loot villages, torture Indians, endure unimaginable hardships, and get no closer to gold. The money they spent on such expeditions cannot be calculated; yet despite die futility of the search, the lure of the fantasy endured.
即使在贡萨洛·皮萨罗惨败之后，西班牙人仍然一次又一次地发动探险，寻找传说中的黄金国。和皮萨罗一样，征服者们烧杀抢掠村庄，折磨印第安人，忍受难以想象的苦难，却始终无法接近黄金。他们在这些探险上花费的金钱无法估量；然而，尽管寻宝徒劳无功，但对黄金的幻想却始终萦绕在人们心头。
Not only did die search for El Dorado cost millions of livesboth Indian and Spanishit helped bring the ruin of die Spanish empire. Gold became Spain's obsession. The gold diat did find its way back to Spainand a lot didwas reinvested in more expeditions, or in die purchase of luxuries, ratiier dian in agriculture or any other productive endeavor. Whole Spanish towns were depopulated as dieir menfolk left to hunt gold. Farms
对黄金国的追寻不仅夺去了数百万印第安人和西班牙人的生命，也加速了西班牙帝国的衰落。黄金成了西班牙人的执念。金矿最终回到了西班牙，其中很多被用于更多的探险或购买奢侈品，而不是用于农业或其他生产活动。许多西班牙城镇因男丁外出淘金而人口锐减。
fell into ruin, and die army had no recruits for its European wars. By the end of the seventeenth century, the entire country had shrunk by more than half of its population; the city of Madrid had gone from a population of 400,000 to 150,000. With diminishing returns from its efforts over so many years, Spain fell into a decline from which it never recovered.
国家陷入衰败，军队也因缺乏新兵而无力参与欧洲战争。到十七世纪末，整个国家的人口减少了一半以上；马德里的人口也从40万锐减至15万。由于多年来的努力收效甚微，西班牙陷入了从此一蹶不振的衰落之中。
Power requires self-discipline. The prospect of wealdi, particularly easy, sudden wealth, plays havoc with the emotions. The suddenly rich believe that more is always possible. The free lunch, die money that will fall into your lap, is just around the corner.
权力需要自律。财富的诱惑，尤其是唾手可得的暴富，会严重影响人的情绪。一夜暴富者总觉得可以赚更多。仿佛天上掉馅饼、唾手可得的财富就在眼前。
In this delusion the greedy neglect everything power really depends on: self-control, the goodwill of others, and so on. Understand: Widi one exceptiondeathno lasting change in fortune comes quickly. Sudden wealdi rarely lasts, for it is built on nothing solid. Never let lust for money lure you out of the protective and enduring fortress of real power. Make power your goal and money will find its way to you. Leave El Dorado for suckers and fools.
在这种错觉中，贪婪者忽略了权力真正依赖的一切：自制力、他人的善意等等。要明白：除了死亡之外，财富的持久改变不会来得很快。一夜暴富很少能长久，因为它建立在不坚实的基础之上。永远不要让对金钱的贪婪引诱你离开真正权力那坚固的堡垒。把权力作为你的目标，金钱自然会向你涌来。把黄金国留给傻瓜和傻子吧。
Transgression II
越轨 II
In the early eighteenth century, no one stood higher in English society than the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough. The duke, having led successful campaigns against die French, was considered Europe's premier general and strategist. And his wife, the duchess, after much maneuvering, had established herself as die favorite of Queen Anne, who became ruler of England in 1702. In 1704 die duke's triumph at die Battle of Blenheim made him die toast of England, and to honor him die queen awarded him a large plot of land in die town of Woodstock, and die funds to create a great palace mere. Calling his planned home die Palace of Blenheim, die duke chose as his architect the young John Vanbrugh, a kind of Renaissance man who wrote plays as well as designed buildings. And so construction began, in die summer of 1705, with much fanfare and great hopes.
十八世纪初，在英国社会，无人能比马尔伯勒公爵和公爵夫人地位更高。公爵曾率军成功对抗法国，被誉为欧洲首屈一指的将军和战略家。而他的妻子，公爵夫人，经过一番周旋，最终成为安妮女王的宠臣。安妮女王于1702年登基成为英国女王。1704年，公爵在布伦海姆战役中取得胜利，成为全英国的宠儿。为了表彰他的功绩，女王赐予他在伍德斯托克镇的一大片土地，并拨款建造一座宏伟的宫殿。公爵将这座计划中的宫殿命名为布伦海姆宫，并聘请了年轻的约翰·范布勒担任建筑师。范布勒是一位文艺复兴时期的全才，他不仅设计建筑，还创作戏剧。于是，在盛大的庆典和人们的殷切期盼中，宫殿于1705年夏天动工兴建。
Vanbrugh had a dramatist's sense of architecture. His palace was to be a monument to Marlborough's brilliance and power, and was to include artificial lakes, enormous bridges, elaborate gardens, and other fantastical touches. From day one, however, die duchess could not be pleased: She thought Vanbrugh was wasting money on yet another stand of trees; she wanted die palace finished as soon as possible. The duchess tortured Vanbrugh and his workmen on every detail. She was consumed with petty matters; aldiough die government was paying for Blenheim, she counted every penny. Eventually her grumbling, about Blenheim and other things too, created an irreparable rift between her and Queen Anne, who, in 1711, dismissed her from the court, ordering her to vacate her apartments at the royal palace. When die duchess left (fuming over the loss of her position, and also of her royal salary), she emptied die apartment of every fixture down to the brass doorknobs.
范布勒对建筑有着戏剧家般的敏锐眼光。他设计的宫殿旨在彰显马尔伯勒的才华与权力，其中包括人工湖、宏伟的桥梁、精致的花园以及其他奇幻的元素。然而，从一开始，公爵夫人就无法满意：她认为范布勒又在浪费钱种树；她希望宫殿尽快完工。公爵夫人对范布勒及其工匠的每一个细节都吹毛求疵。她为琐事缠身；尽管布伦海姆宫的建造费用由政府承担，她却精打细算，一分一分地斤斤计较。最终，她对布伦海姆宫以及其他事情的抱怨，导致她与安妮女王之间产生了无法弥合的裂痕。1711年，安妮女王将她逐出宫廷，并命令她搬离在王宫的住所。公爵夫人离开时（她对失去职位和王室薪水感到怒不可遏），她把公寓里的所有东西都搬了出来，甚至连黄铜门把手也不放过。
Over the next ten years, work on Blenheim would stop and start, as the funds became harder to procure from die government. The duchess
在接下来的十年里，布伦海姆宫的修缮工作时断时续，因为从政府那里筹集资金变得越来越困难。公爵夫人
suspicion of robbing the disciple of his soul. People who say, 'I take nothing,' may be found to take away the volition of their victim."
怀疑有人会夺走门徒的灵魂。那些声称“我什么也不拿”的人，可能会被发现夺走了受害者的意志。
the dermis probe, Idries Shah, 1970
真皮探针，伊德里斯·沙阿，1970年
TDK MAIS WHO
TDK MAIS WHO
LOVED MONEY BETTEK
爱钱贝特克
THAN LIFE
比生命更美好
In ancient times there was an old woodcutter who went to the mountain almost every day to cut wood. It was said that this old man was a miser who hoarded his silver until It changed to gold, and that he cared more for gold than anything else in all the world. One day a wilderness tiger sprang at him and though he ran he could not escape, and the tiger carried him off in its mouth.
很久以前，有个老樵夫几乎每天都去山上砍柴。据说他是个守财奴，把银子都攒起来，直到银子变成了金子，而且他视金子胜过世上任何东西。有一天，一只野虎突然向他扑来，他拼命奔跑却无济于事，被老虎叼走了。
The woodcutter's son saw his father's danger, and ran to save him if possible. He carried a long knife, and as he could run faster than the tiger, who had a man to carry, he soon overtook them. His father was not much hurt, for the tiger held him by his clothes. When the old woodcutter saw his son about to stab the tiger he called out in great alarm: "Do not spoil the tiger's skin! Do not spoil the tiger's skin! If you can kill him without cutting holes in his
樵夫的儿子见父亲身处险境，便跑去救他。他带着一把长刀，由于他跑得比背着人的老虎快，很快就追上了他们。他的父亲伤得不重，因为老虎咬住了他的衣服。老樵夫看到儿子正要刺老虎，惊恐地喊道：“别伤了虎皮！别伤了虎皮！如果你能在不伤到他身上任何部位的情况下杀死他，那就太好了！”
skin we ean get many
我们可以获得很多皮肤
pieces of silver for it.
用银子换。
Kill him, but do not cut
杀了他，但不要割伤他
his body."
他的身体。
While the son was
儿子当时
listening to his father's
听着他父亲的话
instructions the tiger
老虎的指示
suddenly dashed off
突然冲了出去
into the forest, carrying
进入森林，携带
the old man where the
老人在哪里
son could not reach
儿子联系不上
him, and he was soon
他，而且他很快就……
killed.
被杀。
“Chinese table,”
“中国桌子”，
various kables
各种电缆
from various places,
来自不同地方
Diane di Prima, ed.,
黛安娜·迪·普里玛（Diane di Prima）编，
It is written in the histories of the prophets that Moses was sent to Pharaoh with many miracles, wonders and honors. Now the daily ration for Pharaoh's table was 4,000 sheep, 400 cows, 200 camels, and a corresponding amount of chickens, fish, beverages, fried meats, sweets, and other things. All the people of Egypt and all his army used to eat at his table every day. For 400 years he had claimed divinity and never ceased providing this food. When Moses prayed, saying, “O Lord, destroy Pharaoh,” God answered his prayer and said, “/ shall destroy him in water, and I shall bestow all his wealth and that of his soldiers on you and your peoples. ” Several
先知书上记载，摩西奉命前往法老那里，行了许多神迹奇事，并获得了许多荣耀。当时，法老每日的筵席是四千只羊、四百头牛、两百头骆驼，以及相应数量的鸡、鱼、饮料、油炸肉类、甜点和其他食物。埃及所有的百姓和法老的军队每天都来法老的餐桌上吃饭。四百年来，法老一直自诩为神，从未停止过提供这些食物。摩西祷告说：“耶和华啊，求你毁灭法老。”上帝应允了他的祷告，说：“我必用水毁灭他，我必将他和他士兵所有的财富赐给你和你的百姓。”
thought Vanbrugh was out to ruin her. She quibbled over every carload of stone and bushel of lime, counted every extra yard of iron railing or foot of wainscot, hurling abuse at the wasteful workmen, contractors, and surveyors. Marlborough, old and weary, wanted noming more than to settle into the palace in his last years, but the project became bogged down in a swamp of litigation, the workmen suing the duchess for wages, the duchess suing the architect right back. In die midst of this interminable wrangling, the duke died. He had never spent a night in his beloved Blenheim.
她认为范布勒一心想毁了她。她对每一车石料、每一蒲式耳石灰都斤斤计较，对每一码多出来的铁栏杆、每一英尺多出来的护墙板都精打细算，对浪费的工人、承包商和测量员破口大骂。年迈疲惫的马尔伯勒在晚年更渴望获得提名，而不是安顿在宫殿里。然而，这项工程却陷入了旷日持久的诉讼泥潭，工人们起诉公爵夫人索要工资，公爵夫人则反过来起诉建筑师。就在这场没完没了的争吵中，公爵去世了。他从未在他挚爱的布伦海姆宫过夜。
After Marlborough's death, it became clear mat he had a vast estate, worm over £2 millionmore man enough to pay for finishing die palace. But the duchess would not relent: She held back Vanbrugh's wages as well as the workmen's, and finally had the architect dismissed. The man who took his place finished Blenheim in a few years, following Vanbrugh's designs to the letter. Vanbrugh died in 1726, locked out of the palace by the duchess, unable to set foot in his greatest creation. Foreshadowing the romantic movement, Blenheim had started a whole new trend in architecture, but had given its creator a twenty-year nightmare. Interpretation
马尔伯勒去世后，人们才意识到他拥有一大笔遗产，超过200万英镑，足以支付完成布伦海姆宫的费用。但公爵夫人不肯让步：她不仅扣留了范布勒的工资，还扣留了工人的工资，最终解雇了这位建筑师。接替他的建筑师几年后便完成了布伦海姆宫的建造，完全按照范布勒的设计图纸进行。1726年，范布勒去世，被公爵夫人锁在宫殿外，无法踏入他最伟大的作品。布伦海姆宫预示着浪漫主义运动的到来，开创了建筑领域的新潮流，但也给它的创造者带来了长达二十年的噩梦。
For die Duchess of Marlborough, money was a way to play sadistic power games. She saw the loss of money as a symbolic loss of power. With Vanbrugh her contortions went deeper still: He was a great artist, and she envied his power to create, to attain a fame outside her reach. She may not have had his gifts, but she did have the money to torture and abuse him over the pettiest detailsto ruin his life.
对马尔伯勒公爵夫人而言，金钱是她玩弄虐待式权力游戏的工具。她将失去金钱视为权力的象征性丧失。而对于范布勒，她的这种扭曲心理更是变本加厉：他是一位伟大的艺术家，她嫉妒他创作的能力，嫉妒他所拥有的她无法企及的声望。她或许没有他那样的天赋，但她却拥有足够的金钱，可以就一些鸡毛蒜皮的小事折磨他、虐待他，毁掉他的一生。
This kind of sadism, however, bears an awful price. It made construction that should have lasted ten years take twenty. It poisoned many a relationship, alienated the duchess from the court, deeply pained the duke (who wanted only to live peacefully in Blenheim), created endless lawsuits, and took years off Vanbrugh's life. Finally, too, posterity had the last word: Vanbrugh is recognized as a genius while the duchess is forever remembered for her consummate cheapness.
然而，这种虐待狂式的做法付出了惨痛的代价。原本十年就能完工的工程，却拖延了二十年。它破坏了许多人际关系，使公爵夫人与宫廷关系疏远，令只想在布伦海姆平静生活的公爵痛苦不堪，引发了无休止的诉讼，并缩短了范布勒的寿命。最终，历史也给出了答案：范布勒被公认为天才，而公爵夫人则永远因其吝啬而臭名昭著。
The powerful must have grandeur of spiritthey can never reveal any pettiness. And money is the most visible arena in which to display either grandeur or pettiness. Best spend freely, then, and create a reputation for generosity, which in the end will pay great dividends. Never let financial details blind you to the bigger picture of how people perceive you. Their resentment will cost you in the long run. And if you want to meddle in the work of creative people under your hire, at least pay diem well. Your money will buy their submission better tiian your displays of power.
强者必须拥有高尚的品格，绝不能流露出任何卑劣。而金钱，恰恰是展现这种品格或高尚或卑劣的最直观的舞台。因此，最好慷慨解囊，树立慷慨的名声，最终必将获得丰厚的回报。切勿让财务细节蒙蔽双眼，忽视人们对你的看法。他们的怨恨最终会让你付出代价。如果你想干预手下创意人员的工作，至少要支付丰厚的报酬。金钱比你的权力炫耀更能赢得他们的服从。
OBSERVANCES OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Observance I
观察 I
Pietro Aretino, son of a lowly shoemaker, had catapulted himself into fame as a writer of biting satires. But like every Renaissance artist, he needed to find a patron who would give him a comfortable lifestyle while not inter-
出身卑微的鞋匠之子皮耶特罗·阿雷蒂诺凭借辛辣的讽刺作品一举成名。但和所有文艺复兴时期的艺术家一样，他需要找到一位赞助人，既能让他过上舒适的生活，又不会干涉他的创作。
fering with his work. In 1528 Aretino decided to attempt a new strategy in the patronage game. Leaving Rome, he established himself in Venice, where few had heard of him. He had a fair amount of money he had managed to save, but little else. Soon after he moved into his new home, however, he threw open its doors to rich and poor, regaling them with banquets and amusements. He befriended each and every gondolier, tipping mem royally. In the streets, he spread his money liberally, giving it away to beggars, orphans, washerwomen. Among the city's commoners, word quickly spread that Aretino was more than just a great writer, he was a man of powera kind of lord.
1528年，阿雷蒂诺决定在赞助人游戏中尝试一种新的策略。他离开罗马，定居威尼斯，当时几乎无人知晓他的名字。他积攒了一笔可观的积蓄，但除此之外几乎一无所有。然而，搬进新家后不久，他就敞开大门，款待富人和穷人，举办盛宴，款待他们。他与每一位贡多拉船夫都成了朋友，并慷慨地给予他们小费。在街头，他大手大脚地分发钱财，施舍给乞丐、孤儿和洗衣妇。很快，在威尼斯的平民百姓中，阿雷蒂诺不仅是一位伟大的作家，更是一位权势滔天的人物——一位真正的领主——的消息便迅速传开。
Artists and men of influence soon began to frequent Aretino's house. Within a few years he made himself a celebrity; no visiting dignitary would think of leaving Venice without paying him a call. His generosity had cost him most of his savings, but had bought him influence and a good name a cornerstone in the foundation of power. Since in Renaissance Italy as elsewhere the ability to spend freely was the privilege of the rich, the aristocracy thought Aretino had to be a man of influence, since he spent money like one. And since the influence of a man of influence is worth buying, Aretino became the recipient of all sorts of gifts and moneys. Dukes and duchesses, wealthy merchants, and popes and princes competed to gain his favor, and showered him with all kinds of presents.
艺术家和权贵们很快便开始频繁出入阿雷蒂诺的府邸。短短几年内，他就成了名流；凡是到访威尼斯的显贵，都一定会去拜访他。他的慷慨几乎耗尽了他所有的积蓄，但也为他赢得了影响力和美名——这无疑是他权力的基石。在文艺复兴时期的意大利，如同其他地方一样，挥金如土是富人的特权，因此贵族们认为阿雷蒂诺必定是一位权贵，因为他花钱如流水。而权贵的影响力是可以花钱买到的，所以阿雷蒂诺收到了各种各样的礼物和金钱。公爵夫人、富商、教皇和王子们都争相讨好他，并向他赠送了琳琅满目的礼物。
Aretino's spending habits, of course, were strategic, and the strategy worked like a charm. But for real money and comfort he needed a great patron's bottomless pockets. Having surveyed the possibilities, he eventually set his sights on the extremely wealthy Marquis of Mantua, and wrote an epic poem that he dedicated to the marquis. This was a common practice of writers looking for patronage: In exchange for a dedication they would get a small stipend, enough to write yet another poem, so that they spent their lives in a kind of constant servility. Aretino, however, wanted power, not a measly wage. He might dedicate a poem to the marquis, but he would offer it to him as a gift, implying by doing so that he was not a hired hack looking for a stipend but that he and the marquis were equals.
阿雷蒂诺的消费习惯当然是经过深思熟虑的，而且这策略非常奏效。但要想真正拥有财富和舒适的生活，他需要一位财力雄厚的赞助人。在考察了各种可能性之后，他最终将目光投向了极其富有的曼图亚侯爵，并创作了一首史诗献给侯爵。这在当时的作家中是一种常见的做法：他们以献诗作为交换，获得一笔微薄的津贴，足以让他们继续创作另一首诗，从而终其一生都处于一种奴性的状态。然而，阿雷蒂诺想要的是权力，而不是微薄的报酬。他或许也会将一首诗献给侯爵，但他会将其作为礼物赠予侯爵，以此表明他并非一个受雇于人、寻求津贴的写手，而是与侯爵地位平等。
Aretino's gift-giving did not stop there: As a close friend of two of Venice's greatest artists, the sculptor Jacopo Sansovino and the painter Titian, he convinced these men to participate in his gift-giving scheme. Aretino had studied the marquis before going to work on him, and knew his taste inside and out; he was able to advise Sansovino and Titian what subject matter would please the marquis most. When he then sent a Sansovino sculpture and a Titian painting to the marquis as gifts from all three of them, the man was beside himself with joy.
阿雷蒂诺的馈赠远不止于此：作为威尼斯两位最伟大的艺术家——雕塑家雅各布·桑索维诺和画家提香的挚友，他成功说服这两位参与到他的馈赠计划中。在为侯爵效力之前，阿雷蒂诺曾仔细研究过他，对他的品味了如指掌；他能够为桑索维诺和提香推荐最能取悦侯爵的题材。当他三人联手，分别向侯爵赠送桑索维诺的雕塑和提香的画作时，侯爵欣喜若狂。
Over die next few months, Aretino sent other giftsswords, saddles, the glass that was a Venetian specialty, tilings he knew the marquis prized. Soon he, Titian, and Sansovino began to receive gifts from the marquis in return. And the strategy went further: When the son-in-law of a friend of Aretino's found himself in jail in Mantua, Aretino was able to get the marquis to arrange his release. Aretino's friend, a wealthy merchant, was a man of great influence in Venice; by turning the goodwill he had built up
接下来的几个月里，阿雷蒂诺又送去了其他礼物——剑、马鞍、威尼斯特产玻璃器皿，以及他知道侯爵珍视的瓷砖。很快，他和提香、桑索维诺也开始收到侯爵的回礼。而这一策略远不止于此：当阿雷蒂诺一位朋友的女婿在曼图亚被捕入狱时，阿雷蒂诺设法让侯爵安排他获释。阿雷蒂诺的这位朋友是一位富商，在威尼斯颇具影响力；他利用自己积累的人脉关系，成功地帮助侯爵释放了他。
years passed by after this promise, and Pharaoh, doomed to ruin, continued to live in all his magnificence. Moses was impatient for God to destroy Pharaoh quickly, and he could not endure to wait any longer. So he fasted for forty days and went to Mount Sinai, and in his communing with god he said, "O Lord, Thou didst promise that Thou wouldst destroy Pharaoh, and still he has forsaken none of his blasphemies and pretensions. So when wilt Thou destroy him1'
许下这个承诺之后，岁月流逝，注定要灭亡的法老依然过着他那奢华的生活。摩西急切盼望上帝尽快毁灭法老，他再也无法忍受等待。于是他禁食四十天，前往西奈山，在与上帝交谈时，他说：“主啊，你曾应许要毁灭法老，但他至今仍没有放弃他的亵渎和狂妄。那么，你何时才要毁灭他呢？”
A voice came from The Truth saying, “O Moses, you want Me to destroy Pharaoh as quickly as possible, but a thousand times a thousand of My servants want Me never to do so, because they partake of his bounty and enjoy tranquillity under his rule. By My power I swear that as long as he provides abundant food and comfort for My creatures, I shall not destroy him.” Moses said, “Then when will Thy promise be fulfilled ” God said, “My promise will be fulfilled when he withholds his provision from My creatures. If ever he begins to lessen his bounty, know that his hour is drawing near. ”
真理之声传来：“摩西啊，你希望我尽快毁灭法老，但我的千千万万仆人却不愿我这样做，因为他们享受着他的恩惠，在他的统治下安居乐业。我以我的力量起誓，只要他继续为我的子民提供充足的食物和舒适的生活，我就不会毁灭他。”摩西问道：“那么，你的承诺何时才能实现呢？”上帝说：“当他停止向我的子民提供供给时，我的承诺就会实现。如果他开始减少恩惠，你就知道他的末日将至。”
It chanced that one day Pharaoh said to Haman, "Moses has gathered the Sons of Israel about him and is causing us disquiet. We know not what will be
有一天，法老对哈曼说：“摩西召集以色列人到他那里去，使我们心神不宁。我们不知道将会发生什么事。”
the issue of his affair with us. We must keep our stores full lest at any time we be without resources. So we must halve our daily rations and keep the saving in reserve." He deducted 2,000 sheep, 200 cows, and a 100 camels, and similarly every two or three days reduced the ration. Moses then knew that the promise of The Truth was near to fulfillment, for excessive economy is a sign of decline and a bad omen. The masters of tradition say that on the day when Pharaoh was drowned only two ewes had been killed in his kitchen. Nothing is better than generosity... .If a man is rich and desires, without a royal charter, to act like a lord; if he wants men to humble themselves before him, to revere him and call him lord and prince, then tell him every day to spread a table with victuals. All those who have acquired renown in the world, have gained it mainly through hospitality, while the miserly and avaricious are despised in both WorldStar, BOOK OF government or rules for kings, Nizam al-Mulk, eleventh century
他与我们之间的婚外情问题。我们必须保持仓库充足，以免随时出现物资短缺。所以我们必须将每日口粮减半，并将节省下来的钱存起来。”他减少了2000只羊、200头牛和100头骆驼，之后每隔两三天就减少一次口粮。摩西这时知道，真理的应许即将实现，因为过度节俭是衰落的征兆，也是不祥之兆。传统大师们说，法老被淹死的那天，他的厨房里只宰杀了两只母羊。慷慨是最好的……如果一个人富有，却想在没有王室特许状的情况下像个领主一样行事；如果他想让人们在他面前谦卑，敬畏他，称他为领主和王子，那就告诉他每天都要摆上一桌丰盛的食物。所有在世上赢得声誉的人，主要都是靠热情好客，而吝啬贪婪的人则在《世界之星》、《政府之书》或《君王守则》、《尼扎姆·穆尔克》等书中都受到鄙视。十一世纪
with the marquis to use, Aretino had now bought this man's indebtedness, too, and he in turn would help Aretino when he could. The circle of influence was growing wider. Time and again, Aretino was able to cash in on the immense political power of the marquis, who also helped him in his many court romances.
有了侯爵的帮助，阿雷蒂诺不仅替他偿还了债务，侯爵也会在力所能及的范围内帮助阿雷蒂诺。他的影响力范围越来越大。阿雷蒂诺一次又一次地利用侯爵巨大的政治影响力，侯爵也帮助他处理了许多宫廷恋情。
Eventually, however, the relationship became strained, as Aretino came to feel that the marquis should have requited his generosity better. But he would not lower himself to begging or whining: Since the exchange of gifts between the two men had made them equals, it would not seem right to bring up money. He simply withdrew from the marquis's circle and hunted for other wealthy prey, settling first on the French king Francis, then the Medicis, the Duke of Urbino, Emperor Charles V, and more. In the end, having many patrons meant he did not have to bow to any of them, and his power seemed comparable to that of a great lord. Interpretation
然而，最终两人关系变得紧张，因为阿雷蒂诺觉得侯爵应该更好地回报他的慷慨。但他不愿卑躬屈膝地乞求或哀求：既然两人之间的礼物交换已经使他们地位平等，那么谈钱似乎并不合适。他干脆退出了侯爵的圈子，转而寻找其他富有的猎物，先是法国国王弗朗索瓦一世，然后是美第奇家族、乌尔比诺公爵、查理五世皇帝等等。最终，拥有众多赞助人意味着他不必向任何人低头，他的权力似乎堪比一位大领主。
Aretino understood two fundamental properties of money: First, that it has to circulate to bring power. What money should buy is not lifeless objects but power over people. By keeping money in constant circulation, Aretino bought an ever-expanding circle of influence tfiat in the end more than compensated him for his expenses.
阿雷蒂诺深谙金钱的两个基本属性：首先，金钱必须流通才能带来权力。金钱应该购买的不是毫无生气的物品，而是对人的权力。通过保持金钱的持续流通，阿雷蒂诺不断扩大自己的影响力范围，最终获得的收益远远超过了他的支出。
Second, Aretino understood the key property of the gift. To give a gift is to imply that you and the recipient are equals at the very least, or that you are the recipient's superior. A gift also involves an indebtedness or obligation; when friends, for instance, offer you something for free, you can be sure they expect something in return, and that to get it they are making you feel indebted. (The mechanism may or may not be entirely conscious on their part, but this is how it works.)
其次，阿雷蒂诺理解礼物的关键属性。赠送礼物至少意味着你和接受者地位平等，或者你比接受者更优越。礼物也包含一种亏欠或义务；例如，当朋友免费赠送你东西时，你可以肯定他们期望有所回报，而为了得到回报，他们会让你感到亏欠。（这种机制或许并非完全出于他们的本意，但这就是它的运作方式。）
Aretino avoided such encumbrances on his freedom. Instead of acting like a menial who expects the powerful to pay his way in life, he turned the whole dynamic around; instead of being indebted to the powerful, he made the powerful indebted to him. This was the point of his gift-giving, a ladder that carried him to the highest social levels. By the end of his life he had become the most famous writer in Europe.
阿雷蒂诺避免了此类束缚他自由的因素。他没有像个卑微的仆人那样指望权贵为他铺路，而是彻底扭转了这种关系；他没有对权贵感恩戴德，而是让权贵对他心存感激。这正是他馈赠的意义所在，一份助他攀上社会顶峰的阶梯。在他生命的尽头，他已成为欧洲最著名的作家。
Understand: Money may determine power relationships, but those relationships need not depend on the amount of money you have; they also depend on the way you use it. Powerful people give freely, buying influence rather than things. If you accept the inferior position because you have no fortune yet, you may find yourself in it forever. Play the trick that Aretino played on Italy's aristocracy: Imagine yourself an equal. Play the lord, give freely, open your doors, circulate your money, and create the facade of power through an alchemy that transforms money into influence.
明白：金钱或许决定权力关系，但这种关系并非取决于你拥有多少财富，也取决于你如何使用它。有权势的人慷慨解囊，购买的是影响力而非物质。如果你因为尚未积累财富而接受低人一等的地位，你可能会永远深陷其中。不妨效仿阿雷蒂诺对意大利贵族施展的伎俩：想象自己与贵族平起平坐。扮演领主的角色，慷慨解囊，敞开大门，流通你的财富，通过一种将金钱转化为影响力的“炼金术”，营造出权力的假象。
Observance II
遵守第二条
Soon after Baron James Rothschild made his fortune in Paris in the early 1820s, he faced his most intractable problem: How could a Jew and a German, a total outsider to French society, win the respect of the xenophobic French upper classes Rothschild was a man who understood powerhe
19世纪20年代初，詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德男爵在巴黎发迹后不久，便面临着他最棘手的问题：一个犹太人和德国人，一个完全与法国社会格格不入的人，如何才能赢得排外的法国上流社会的尊重？罗斯柴尔德深谙权力之道。
knew that his fortune would bring him status, but that if he remained socially alienated neither his status nor his fortune would last. So he looked at the society of die time and asked what would win their hearts.
他知道财富会给他带来地位，但如果他继续与社会疏离，他的地位和财富都无法长久。于是他观察当时的社会，思考什么才能赢得人心。
Charity The French couldn't care less. Political influence He already had that, and if anything it only made people more suspicious of him. The one weak spot, he decided, was boredom. In the period of the restoration of the monarchy, the French upper classes were bored. So Rothschild began to spend astounding sums of money on entertaining them. He hired the best architects in France to design his gardens and ballroom; he hired Marie-Antoine Careme, the most celebrated French chef, to prepare die most lavish parties Paris had ever witnessed; no Frenchman could resist, even if the parties were given by a German Jew. Rothschild's weekly soirees began to attract bigger and bigger numbers. Over the next few years he won the only thing that would secure an outsider's power: social acceptance. Interpretation
慈善事业？法国人根本不在乎。政治影响力？他早已拥有，但这反而让人们更加怀疑他。他认定，自己唯一的弱点就是无聊。在君主制复辟时期，法国上流社会百无聊赖。于是，罗斯柴尔德开始挥金如土，款待他们。他聘请法国最优秀的建筑师设计花园和舞厅；他聘请法国最著名的厨师玛丽-安托万·卡雷姆，筹办巴黎有史以来最奢华的宴会；没有哪个法国人能够抵挡得住，即便宴会是由一位德国犹太人举办的。罗斯柴尔德每周的晚宴吸引了越来越多的人。在接下来的几年里，他赢得了唯一能确保一个局外人权力的东西：社会认可。
Strategic generosity is always a great weapon in building a support base, particularly for die outsider. But die Baron de Rodischild was cleverer still: He knew it was his money mat had created the barrier between him and the French, making him look ugly and untrustworthy. The best way to overcome this was literally to waste huge sums, a gesture to show he valued French culture and society over money. What Rothschild did resembled the famous podatch feasts of the American Northwest: By periodically destroying its wealth in a giant orgy of festivals and bonfires, an Indian tribe would symbolize its power over other tribes. The base of its power was not money but its ability to spend, and its confidence in a superiority diat would restore to it all diat die podatch had destroyed.
战略性的慷慨始终是建立支持基础的有力武器，尤其对于局外人而言更是如此。但罗迪柴尔德男爵更加精明：他深知，正是他挥霍无度的财富在他与法国民众之间筑起了一道屏障，让他显得丑陋且不可信赖。克服这一障碍的最佳方法就是挥霍巨资，以此表明他更看重法国的文化和社会，而非金钱。罗迪柴尔德的做法与美国西北部著名的“波达奇盛宴”（podatch feasts）颇为相似：印第安部落通过定期举办盛大的节日和篝火晚会来挥霍财富，以此象征其对其他部落的统治地位。他们的权力基础并非金钱，而是挥霍的能力，以及对自身优越性的自信——相信这种优越性能够弥补“波达奇盛宴”所造成的损失。
In the end, the baron's soirees reflected his desire to mingle not just in France's business world but in its society. By wasting money on his pot-latches, he hoped to demonstrate that his power went beyond money into the more precious realm of culture. Rothschild may have won social acceptance by spending money, but die support base he gained was one diat money alone could not buy. To secure his fortune he had to “waste” it. That is strategic generosity in a nutshelldie ability to be flexible with your wealdi, putting it to work, not to buy objects, but to win people's hearts.
最终，男爵的晚宴反映了他不仅渴望融入法国商界，更渴望融入法国上流社会。他挥霍金钱举办宴会，意在表明他的影响力超越了金钱，延伸至更为珍贵的文化领域。罗斯柴尔德或许凭借金钱赢得了社会认可，但他所获得的拥护基础却是金钱无法买到的。为了巩固财富，他不得不“挥霍”它。这正是战略性慷慨的精髓所在——灵活运用财富，使其发挥作用，并非为了购买物品，而是为了赢得人心。
Observance III
遵守第三条
The Medicis of Renaissance Florence had built dieir immense power on the fortune diey had made in banking. But in Florence, centuries-old republic diat it was, die idea diat money bought power went against all the city's proud democratic values. Cosimo de' Medici, die first of die family to gain great fame, worked around diis by keeping a low profile. He never flaunted his wealdi. But by die time his grandson Lorenzo came of age, in the 1470s, the family's wealdi was too large, and tiieir influence too noticeable, to be disguised any longer.
文艺复兴时期佛罗伦萨的梅第奇家族凭借其在银行业积累的巨额财富，建立起了庞大的权力。但在佛罗伦萨这座拥有数百年历史的共和国中，金钱可以买到权力的观念与这座城市引以为傲的民主价值观背道而驰。家族中第一个声名显赫的科西莫·德·梅第奇通过保持低调来规避这种压力。他从不炫耀自己的财富。但到了15世纪70年代，当他的孙子洛伦佐成年时，家族的财富已经过于庞大，影响力也过于显眼，再也无法掩盖。
Lorenzo solved die problem in his own way by developing die strategy of distraction diat has served people of wealdi ever since: He became
洛伦佐用他自己的方式解决了这个问题，他发展出了一种分散注意力的策略，这种策略自此一直为韦尔迪的人们服务：他变成了
THE FLAME-COLORED CLOAK
火焰色斗篷
During the campaign of Cambyses in Egypt, a great many Greeks visited that country for one reason or another: some, as was to be expected, for trade, some to serve in the army, others, no doubt, out of mere curiosity, to see what they could see. Amongst the sightseers was Aeaces's son Sylo-son, the exiled brother of Poly crates of Samos. While he was in Egypt, Syloson had an extraordinary stroke of luck: he was hanging about the streets of Memphis dressed in a flame-colored cloak, when Darius, who at that time was a member of Cambyses's guard and not yet of any particular importance, happened to catch sight of him and, seized with a sudden longing to possess the cloak, came up to Syloson and made him an offer for it.
在冈比西斯征战埃及期间，许多希腊人出于各种原因造访埃及：一些人，不出所料，是为了经商；一些人是为了参军；还有一些人，无疑是出于好奇，想看看那里有什么。在这些观光客中，有一位名叫西洛松的希腊人，他是埃阿克塞斯的儿子，也是萨摩斯岛波利克拉特斯的流亡兄弟。西洛松在埃及期间，运气极好：他身披一件火焰色的斗篷，在孟菲斯的街头闲逛时，恰巧被当时还只是冈比西斯卫队成员、地位尚不显赫的大流士所吸引。大流士突然对这件斗篷垂涎三尺，便上前向西洛松提出购买。
His extreme anxiety to get it was obvious enough to Syloson, who was inspired to say: “1 am not selling this for any money, but if you must have it, I will give it to you for free.” Darius thereupon thanked him warmly and took it. Syloson at the moment merely thought he had lost it by his foolish good nature; then came the death of Cambyses and the revolt of the seven against the Magus, and Darius ascended the throne. Syloson now
西洛森看出他极度渴望得到它，于是说道：“我不会以任何价格出售它，但如果你非要不可，我可以免费送给你。” 大流士听后热情地道谢并接过它。西洛森当时只觉得自己因为一时糊涂的好心而失去了它；随后冈比西斯驾崩，七圣徒起兵反抗巫师，大流士登上了王位。西洛森现在
had the news that the man whose request for the flame-colored cloak he had formerly gratified in Egypt had become king of Persia. He hurried to Susa, sat down at the entrance of the royal palace, and claimed to be included in the official list of the king's benefactors. The sentry on guard reported his claim to Darius, who asked in surprise who the man might be. “For surely,” he said, “as I have so recently come to the throne, there cannot be any Greek to whom 1 am indebted for a service. Hardly any of them have been here yet, and I certainly cannot remember owing anything to a Greek. But bring him in all the same, that I may know what he means by this claim. ” The guard escorted Syloson into the royal presence, and when the interpreters asked him who he was and what he had done to justify the statement that he was the king's benefactor, he reminded Darius of the story of the cloak, and said that he was the man who had given it him. “Sir, ” exclaimed Darius, "you are the most generous of men; for while I was still a person of no power or consequence you gave me a presentsmall indeed, but deserving then as much gratitude from me as would the most splendid of gifts today. I will give you in return more silver and gold than you can count, that you may
他得知，当年在埃及受他恩赐的那位男子已成为波斯国王。他急忙赶到苏萨，坐在王宫门口，声称自己名列国王的恩人名单。守卫将他的话禀告了大流士。大流士惊讶地问他是谁。“我登基不久，”他说，“肯定不会有任何希腊人让我欠下人情。希腊人几乎都没来过这里，我当然也记不起欠过希腊人什么。不过，还是把他带进来，让我看看他这话是什么意思。” 守卫押着西洛森觐见国王。翻译问他是谁，又做了什么来证明自己是国王的恩人，他便向大流士提起那件斗篷的故事，说斗篷就是他送给国王的。 “大人，”大流士惊叹道，“您真是最慷慨的人！在我还是个无足轻重的小人物时，您曾送给我一份礼物，虽然微不足道，但那时我所感激的，丝毫不亚于今天收到的最贵重的礼物。我将回赠您数不尽的金银，以表谢意。”
the most illustrious patron of the arts that history has ever known. Not only did he spend lavishly on paintings, he created Italy's finest apprentice schools for young artists. It was in one of these schools that the young Michelangelo first caught the attention of Lorenzo, who invited the artist to come and live in his house. He did the same with Leonardo da Vinci. Once under his wing, Michelangelo and Leonardo requited his generosity by becoming loyal artists in his stable.
他是历史上最杰出的艺术赞助人。他不仅在绘画上挥金如土，还创办了意大利最优秀的年轻艺术家学徒学校。正是在其中一所学校里，年轻的米开朗基罗引起了洛伦佐的注意，洛伦佐邀请他到自己家中居住。他对达·芬奇也做了同样的事情。在洛伦佐的庇护下，米开朗基罗和达·芬奇都以忠诚的艺术家身份回报了他的慷慨。
Whenever Lorenzo faced an enemy, he would wield the weapon of patronage. When Pisa, Florence's traditional enemy, threatened to rebel against it in 1472, Lorenzo placated its people by pouring money into its university, which had once been its pride and joy but had long ago lost its luster. The Pisans had no defense against this insidious maneuver, which simultaneously fed tfieir love of culture and blunted their desire for battle. Interpretation
每当洛伦佐面对敌人，他都会运用赞助这一手段。1472年，佛罗伦萨的宿敌比萨威胁要反抗佛罗伦萨，洛伦佐便向比萨大学投入巨资，以此安抚当地民众。比萨大学曾是比萨的骄傲，但早已失去了往日的光彩。比萨人对这种阴险的策略毫无招架之力，这种策略既激发了他们对文化的热爱，又削弱了他们的战斗欲望。
Lorenzo undoubtedly loved the arts, but his patronage of artists had a practical function as well, of which he was keenly aware. In Florence at die time, banking was perhaps die least admired way of making money, and was certainly not a respected source of power. The arts were at the other pole, the pole of quasi-religious transcendence. By spending on die arts, Lorenzo diluted people's opinions of the ugly source of his wealth, disguising himself in nobility. There is no better use of strategic generosity man mat of distracting attention from an unsavory reality and wrapping oneself in the mantle of art or religion.
洛伦佐无疑热爱艺术，但他对艺术家的赞助也具有实际意义，这一点他非常清楚。在当时的佛罗伦萨，银行业或许是最不为人所敬重的赚钱方式，也绝非受人尊重的权力来源。艺术则截然相反，它代表着一种近乎宗教般的超脱。通过对艺术的投入，洛伦佐淡化了人们对他财富来源丑陋本质的看法，将自己伪装成贵族。没有什么比巧妙地运用慷慨更能转移人们对不光彩现实的注意力，并将自己包裹在艺术或宗教的外衣之下了。
Observance IV
第四条规定
Louis XIV had an eagle eye for the strategic power of money. When he came to the throne, the powerful nobility had recendy proven a thorn in the monarchy's side, and seethed with rebelliousness. So he impoverished diese aristocrats by making them spend enormous sums on maintaining their position in the court. Making them dependent on royal largesse for their livelihood, he had them in his claws.
路易十四深谙金钱的战略力量。他登基之时，权势显赫的贵族阶层刚刚成为君主制的一根眼中钉，叛乱之风愈演愈烈。于是，他让这些贵族挥霍无度，维持其在宫廷中的地位，从而使他们陷入贫困。通过让他们依赖王室的恩赐才能生存，路易十四便将他们牢牢掌控在手中。
Next Louis brought the nobles to their knees with strategic generosity. It would work like this: Whenever he noticed a stubborn courtier whose influence he needed to gain, or whose troublemaking he needed to squelch, he would use his vast wealth to soften the soil. First he would ignore his victim, making the man anxious. Then the man would suddenly find that his son had been given a well-paid post, or that funds had been spent liberally in his home region, or mat he had been given a painting he had long coveted. Presents would flow from Louis's hands. Finally, weeks or months later, Louis would ask for die favor he had needed all along. A man who had once vowed to do anything to stop the king would find he had lost the desire to fight. A straightforward bribe would have made him rebellious; this was far more insidious. Facing hardened earth in which nothing could take root, Louis loosened the soil before he planted his seeds. Interpretation
接下来，路易运用策略性的慷慨让贵族们俯首帖耳。具体做法是这样的：每当他发现某个顽固的朝臣需要拉拢，或是需要平息其纷争时，他就会利用自己雄厚的财富来软化对方。起初，他会冷落对方，让对方焦虑不安。然后，对方会突然发现自己的儿子被授予了高薪职位，或者家乡的财政得到了慷慨的资助，又或者收到了一幅梦寐以求的画作。路易的馈赠纷至沓来。最终，几周或几个月后，路易会提出对方一直以来真正需要的恩惠。一个曾经誓死捍卫国王的人，会发现自己已经失去了反抗的欲望。直接的贿赂只会激起他的反叛；而这种策略则更加阴险狡诈。面对寸土寸金、难以生根发芽的局面，路易先松土，再播下种子。
Louis understood that there is a deep-rooted emotional element in our attitude to money, an element going back to childhood. When we are chil-
路易斯明白，我们对金钱的态度中存在着根深蒂固的情感因素，这种因素可以追溯到童年时期。当我们还是孩子的时候——
dren, all kinds of complicated feelings about our parents center around gifts; we see die giving of a gift as a sign of love and approval. And that emotional element never goes away. The recipients of gifts, financial or otherwise, are suddenly as vulnerable as children, especially when the gift comes from someone in authority. They cannot help opening up; their will is loosened, as Louis loosened the soil.
孩子们对父母的各种复杂情感都围绕着礼物展开；我们把送礼物视为爱和认可的象征。这种情感因素从未消失。收到礼物的人，无论是金钱上的还是其他形式的，都会突然变得像孩子一样脆弱，尤其当礼物来自权威人士时。他们不由自主地敞开心扉；他们的意志被打破，就像路易松动了土壤一样。
To succeed best, the gift should come out of the blue. It should be remarkable for the fact that a gift like it has never been given before, or for being preceded by a cold shoulder from the giver. The more often you give to particular people, the blunter this weapon becomes. If they don't take your gifts for granted, becoming monsters of ingratitude, they will resent what appears to be charity. The sudden, unexpected, one-time gift will not spoil your children; it will keep them under your thumb.
要想达到最佳效果，礼物最好出其不意。它应该特别之处在于，此前从未有人送过类似的礼物，或者送礼者之前曾冷落过对方。你越频繁地送礼给特定的人，这招就越显得苍白无力。如果他们不把你的礼物视为理所当然，变得忘恩负义，他们就会对这种看似施舍的行为心生怨恨。突如其来的、意料之外的、一次性的礼物并不会宠坏你的孩子；它只会让他们对你言听计从。
Observance V
遵守第五条
The antique dealer Fushimiya, who lived in the city of Edo (former name for Tokyo) in the seventeenth century, once made a stop at a village teahouse. After enjoying a cup of tea, he spent several minutes scrutinizing the cup, which he eventually paid for and took away with him. A local artisan, watching this, waited until Fushimiya left the shop, then approached the old woman who owned the teahouse and asked her who tiiis man was. She told him it was Japan's most famous connoisseur, antique dealer to die lord of Izumo. The artisan ran out of the shop, caught up with Fushimiya, and begged him to sell him the cup, which must clearly be valuable if Fushimiya judged it so. Fushimiya laughed heartily: “It's just an ordinary cup of Bizen ware,” he explained, “and it is not valuable at all. The reason I was looking at it was that the steam seemed to hang about it strangely and I wondered if there wasn't a leak somewhere.” (Devotees of the Tea Ceremony were interested in any odd or accidental beauty in nature.) Since die artisan still seemed so excited about it, Fushimiya gave him the cup for free.
十七世纪，居住在江户（今东京）的古董商伏宫，曾到访一家乡村茶馆。他品茗之后，仔细端详起一只茶杯，最终付钱买下并带走。一位当地工匠目睹了这一切，待伏宫离开茶馆后，便上前询问茶馆老板娘此人是谁。老板娘告诉他，此人是日本最著名的鉴赏家，出云藩主，也是古董商。工匠闻言，立刻跑出茶馆，追上伏宫，恳求他将茶杯卖给自己。伏宫如此评价，想必这只茶杯价值连城。伏宫爽朗地大笑起来：“这只是一只普通的备前烧茶杯，”他解释道，“一点也不值钱。我之所以会注意到它，是因为蒸汽似乎在杯壁上凝结得有些奇怪，我就想是不是哪里漏气了。”（茶道爱好者对自然界中任何奇特或偶然的美都感兴趣。）由于制杯匠人仍然兴致勃勃，伏宫便将茶杯免费送给了他。
The artisan took die cup around, trying to find an expert who would appraise it at a high price, but since all of them recognized it as an ordinary teacup he got nowhere. Soon he was neglecting his own business, thinking only of die cup and die fortune it could bring. Finally he went to Edo to talk to Fushimiya at his shop. There the dealer, realizing that he had inadvertently caused this man pain by making him believe the cup had great worth, paid him 100 ryo (gold pieces) for the cup as a kindness. The cup was indeed mediocre, but he wanted to rid the artisan of his obsession, while also allowing him to feel tiiat his effort had not been wasted. The artisan thanked him and went on his way.
工匠拿着那只杯子四处求助，想找个专家鉴定，希望能得到高价，但所有人都认为它只是一只普通的茶杯，他一无所获。很快，他便荒废了自己的生意，满脑子想的都是那只杯子以及它能带来的财富。最后，他去了江户，拜访了伏宫的店铺。伏宫意识到自己无意中让工匠误以为杯子价值连城，给他带来了痛苦，便出于好心，付给他100两金币买下了那只杯子。那只杯子的确很普通，但伏宫想帮工匠摆脱执念，也想让他觉得自己的努力没有白费。工匠道谢后便离开了。
Soon word spread of Fushimiya's purchase of the teacup. Every dealer in Japan clamored for him to sell it, since a cup he had bought for 100 ryo must be worth much more. He tried to explain the circumstances in which he had bought die cup, but the dealers could not be dissuaded. Fushimiya finally relented and put die cup up for sale.
很快，伏宫买下这只茶杯的消息就传开了。日本各地的茶商都争相劝他出售，因为他只花了100两就买到的这只茶杯，肯定价值不菲。伏宫试图解释自己购买这只茶杯的缘由，但茶商们依然不为所动。最终，伏宫只好妥协，将这只茶杯挂牌出售。
During the auction, two buyers simultaneously bid 200 ryo for the teacup, and then began to fight over who had bid first. Their fighting
拍卖过程中，两名买家同时出价200两竞拍这只茶杯，随后两人开始争论谁先出价。他们的争吵
never regret that you onee did a favor to Darius the son of Hystaspes.“ ”My lord,“ replied Syloson, ”do not give me gold or silver, but recover Samos for me, my native island, which now since Oroetes killed my brother Poly-crates is in the hands of one of our servants. Let Samos be your gift to mebut let no man in the island be killed or enslaved." Darius consented to Syloson's request, and dispatched a force under the command of Otanes, one of the seven, with orders to do everything that Syloson had asked.
“你永远不要后悔你曾帮助过希斯塔斯佩斯的儿子大流士。”西洛森答道：“我的大人，不要给我金银，只要帮我夺回萨摩斯岛——我的故乡。自从奥罗埃特斯杀死了我的兄弟波吕克拉特斯之后，萨摩斯岛就落入了我们一个仆人的手中。萨摩斯岛就作为你的礼物送给我吧，但岛上任何人都不得被杀或被奴役。”大流士同意了西洛森的请求，并派遣了一支由七勇士之一的奥塔涅斯率领的军队，命令他们执行西洛森提出的所有要求。
the histories, Herodotus, fifth century b.c.
《历史》，希罗多德，公元前五世纪
Money is never spent to so much advantage as when you have been cheated out of it; for at one stroke you have purchased prudence.
被骗走的钱反而是最划算的消费方式；因为你一下子就买到了谨慎。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
Kung-yi Hsiu, premier of Lu, was fond offish. Therefore, people in the whole country conscientiously bought fish, which they presented to him. However, Kung-yi would not accept the presents. Against such a step his younger brother remonstrated with him and said: “You like fish, indeed. Why don't you accept the present offish ” In reply, he said: “It is solely because I like fish that I would not accept the fish they gave me. Indeed, if I accept the fish, I will be placed under an obligation to them. Once placed under an obligation to them, I will some time have to bend the law. If I bend the law, I will be dismissed from the premiership. After being dismissed from the premiership, I might not be able to supply myself with fish. On the contrary, if I do not accept the fish from them and am not dismissed the premiership, however fond of fish, I can always supply myself with fish.”
吕国的行政院长修恭宜喜爱鱼，因此全国百姓都自觉地买鱼献给他。然而，修恭宜却不肯接受。他的弟弟劝他道：“你的确喜欢鱼，为什么不收下这些鱼呢？”修恭宜回答说：“正因为我喜欢鱼，所以才不收。收了鱼，我就欠了他们人情。欠了人情，就难免要违背法律。违背法律，就会被免去行政院长的职位。被免去行政院长的职位，恐怕就吃不到鱼了。反之，不收鱼，即使再喜欢鱼，也总能吃到鱼。”
Chinese philosopher, third century b.c.
中国哲学家，公元前三世纪
tipped over a table and the teacup fell to the ground and broke into several pieces. The auction was clearly over. Fushimiya glued and mended the cup, then stored it away, dunking the affair finished. Years later, however, the great tea master Matsudaira Fumai visited the store, and asked to see the cup, which by then had become legendary. Fumai examined it. “As a piece,” he said, “it is not up to much, but a Tea Master prizes sentiment and association more than intrinsic value.” He bought the cup for a high sum. A glued-together work of less than ordinary craftsmanship had become one of the most famous objects in Japan. Interpretation
茶杯从桌子上掉下来，摔碎成了几块。拍卖显然就此结束。伏宫将茶杯粘好修补，然后收了起来，这件事也就此作罢。然而，多年后，伟大的茶道大师松平文舞造访了伏宫的店铺，并要求看看那只当时已名声大噪的茶杯。文舞仔细端详后说道：“就其本身而言，它并不出众，但茶道大师更看重的是情感和联想，而非其内在价值。”他以高价买下了这只茶杯。一件工艺平庸、用胶水粘合而成的茶杯，竟成为了日本最著名的物品之一。
The story shows, first, an essential aspect of money: That it is humans who have created it and humans who instill it with meaning and value. Second, with objects as with money, what the courtier most values are the sentiments and emotions embedded in themthese are what make them worth having. The lesson is simple: The more your gifts and your acts of generosity play with sentiment, the more powerful mey are. The object or concept that plays with a charged emotion or hits a chord of sentiment has more power than the money you squander on an expensive yet lifeless present.
这个故事首先揭示了金钱的一个本质：金钱是由人类创造的，也是人类赋予其意义和价值的。其次，对于物品，正如金钱一样，朝臣最看重的是其中蕴含的情感——正是这些情感赋予了物品价值。道理很简单：你的礼物和慷慨之举越能触动人心，就越有力量。能够引发强烈情感或引起共鸣的物品或理念，比你挥霍在昂贵却毫无生气的礼物上更有力量。
Observance VI
第六项观察
Akimoto Suzutomo, a wealthy adherent of the tea ceremony, once gave his page 100 ryo (gold pieces) and instructed him to purchase a tea bowl offered by a particular dealer. When the page saw the bowl, he doubted it was worth that much, and after much bargaining got the price reduced to 95 ryo. Days later, after Suzutomo had put the bowl to use, the page proudly told him what he had done.
秋元铃友是一位富有的茶道爱好者。他曾给了自己的侍从一百两金币，让他去某个商人那里购买一个茶碗。侍从看到茶碗后，觉得不值这么多钱，经过一番讨价还价，最终以九十五两的价格成交。几天后，铃友用上了茶碗，侍从得意地向他讲述了自己的所作所为。
“What an ignoramus you are!” replied Suzutomo. “A tea bowl that anyone asks 100 pieces of gold for can only be a family heirloom, and a thing like that is only sold when the family is pressed for money. And in that case tiiey will be hoping to find someone who will give even 150 pieces for it. So what sort of fellow is it who does not consider their feelings Quite apart from that, a curio that you give 100 ryo for is something worth having, but one that has only cost 95 gives a mean impression. So never let me see that tea bowl again!” And he had die bowl locked away, and never took it out. Interpretation
“你真是个无知的人！”铃友说道，“一个茶碗，要价一百两金币，只能是家传之宝，这种东西只有在家道中落时才会卖掉。即便如此，他们也希望能找到愿意出一百五十两金币的人。你这种人怎么能不顾及别人的感受呢？更何况，一件价值一百两的古董值得收藏，而一件只值九十五两的，实在是太寒酸了。所以，永远别让我再看到那个茶碗！”说完，他就把茶碗锁了起来，再也没拿出来过。
When you insist on paying less, you may save your five ryo, but die insult you cause and the cheap impression you create will cost you in reputation, which is the thing the powerful prize above all. Learn to pay the full priceit will save you a lot in the end.
当你执意少付钱时，或许能省下那五两，但你造成的侮辱和廉价的印象会让你损失声誉，而声誉才是最重要的。学会支付全价，最终你会省下很多钱。
Observance VII
第七项规定
Sometime near the beginning of die seventeenth century in Japan, a group of generals whiled away the time before a big battle by staging an incense-smelling competition. Each participant anted up a prize for the contest's winnersbows, arrows, saddles, and odier items a warrior would covet.
大约在十七世纪初的日本，一群将军在大战前夕举办了一场闻香比赛来消磨时间。每位参赛者都拿出奖金，作为比赛获胜者的奖品——弓箭、马鞍以及其他武士梦寐以求的物品。
The great Lord Date Masamune happened to pass by and was induced to participate. For a prize, he offered the gourd that hung from his belt. Everyone laughed, for no one wanted to win this cheap item. A retainer of die host finally accepted the gourd.
恰巧路过的伊达政宗大人也参与了游戏。他拿出挂在腰间的葫芦作为奖品。大家都笑了，因为没人想要这个廉价的玩意儿。最后，主人的一名家臣接受了葫芦。
When die party broke up, however, and the generals were chatting outside the tent, Masamune brought over his magnificent horse and gave it to the retainer. “There,” he said, “a horse has come out of the gourd.” The stunned generals suddenly regretted their scorn at Masamune's gift. Interpretation
然而，宴会散去后，众将围坐在帐篷外闲聊，政宗牵来他那匹骏马，送给了家臣。“瞧，”他说，“一匹马从葫芦里蹦了出来。”众将震惊不已，顿时后悔之前对政宗礼物的轻蔑。
Masamune understood the following: Money gives its possessor the ability to give pleasure to others. The more you can do this, the more you attract admiration. When you make a horse come out of a gourd, you give the ultimate demonstration of your power.
政宗明白：金钱赋予拥有者取悦他人的能力。你越能做到这一点，就越能赢得赞赏。当你能让马从葫芦里变出来时，你就展现了你力量的极致。
Image: The River. To protect yourself or to save the resource, you dam it up. Soon, however, the waters become dank and pestilent. Only the foulest forms of life can live in such stagnant waters; nothing travels on them, all commerce stops. Destroy the dam. When water flows and circulates, it generates abundance, wealth, and power in ever larger circles. The River must flood periodically for good things to flourish.
图片：河流。为了保护自己或节约资源，人们筑坝拦水。然而，不久之后，河水便变得污浊不堪，滋生细菌。只有最肮脏的生物才能在如此死寂的水中生存；任何交通工具都无法通行，所有商业活动都停滞不前。拆除水坝吧。当水流动循环时，它会在更大的范围内创造丰饶、财富和力量。河流必须周期性泛滥，美好的事物才能繁荣发展。
/ took money only from those who could afford it and were willing to go in with me in schemes they fancied would fleece others. They wanted money for its own sake. I wanted it for the luxuries and pleasures it would afford me. They were seldom concerned with human nature. They knew littleand cared lessabout their fellow men. If they had been keener students of human nature, if they had given more time to companionship with their fellows and less to the chase of the almighty dollar, they wouldn 't have been such easy marks.
我只从那些付得起钱，并且愿意和我一起参与他们认为能坑害他人的计划的人那里拿钱。他们想要钱只是为了钱本身。我想要钱是为了它能带给我的奢侈和享乐。他们很少关心人性。他们对同胞知之甚少，也漠不关心。如果他们更热衷于研究人性，如果他们把更多的时间花在与同伴的交往上，而不是追逐金钱，他们就不会那么容易上当受骗了。
“Yellow Kid” Weil, 1875-1976
“黄孩子”威尔，1875-1976
Authority: The great man who is a miser is a great fool, and a man in high places can have no vice so harmful as avarice. A miserly man can conquer neither lands nor lordships, for he does not have a plentiful supply of friends with whom he may work his will. Whoever wants to have friends must not love his possessions but must acquire friends by means of fair gifts; for in the same way that the lodestone subtly draws iron to itself, so the gold and silver that a man gives attract the hearts of men. (The Romance of the Rose, Guillaume de Lorris, c. 1200-1238)
权威：吝啬的伟人是愚蠢的，身居高位者最有害的恶习莫过于贪婪。吝啬之人既无法征服土地，也无法赢得领地，因为他缺乏可以助其实现愿望的朋友。想要结交朋友，切不可贪恋自己的财产，而应以慷慨的馈赠来赢得友谊；正如磁石能巧妙地吸引铁器一样，人所赠予的金银也能吸引人心。（《玫瑰传奇》，纪尧姆·德·洛里斯，约1200-1238年）
REVERSAL
逆转
The powerful never forget that what is offered for free is inevitably a trick. Friends who offer favors without asking for payment will later want something far dearer than the money you would have paid them. The bargain has hidden problems, both material and psychological. Learn to pay, then, and to pay well.
有权有势的人永远不会忘记，免费的东西往往都是陷阱。那些不求回报地提供帮助的朋友，日后会索要远比你当初愿意支付的金额更昂贵的回报。这种交易背后隐藏着诸多问题，既有物质上的，也有心理上的。所以，要学会付出，并且要慷慨地付出。
On the other hand, this Law offers great opportunities for swindling and deception if you apply it from the other side. Dangling the lure of a free lunch is the con artist's stock in trade.
另一方面，如果从另一个角度运用这条法则，它就为诈骗和欺骗提供了绝佳的机会。以免费午餐为诱饵是骗子的惯用伎俩。
No man was better at this than the most successful con artist of our age, Joseph Weil, a.k.a. “The Yellow Kid.” The Yellow Kid learned early that what made his swindles possible was his fellow humans' greed. “This desire to get something for nothing,” he once wrote, “has been very costly to many people who have dealt with me and with other con men. . . . When people learnas I doubt they willthat they can't get something for nothing, crime will diminish and we shall all live in greater harmony.” Over the years Weil devised many ways to seduce people with the prospect of easy money. He would hand out “free” real estatewho could resist such an offerand then the suckers would learn they had to pay $25 to register the sale. Since the land was free, it seemed worth the high fee, and the Yellow Kid would make thousands of dollars on the phony registration. In exchange he would give his suckers a phony deed. Other times, he would tell suckers about a fixed horse race, or a stock that would earn 200 percent in a few weeks. As he spun his stories he would watch the sucker's eyes open wide at the thought of a free lunch.
没有人比我们这个时代最成功的骗子约瑟夫·韦尔（又名“黄孩子”）更擅长此道。黄孩子很早就明白，他行骗之所以能得逞，是因为人们的贪婪。“这种不劳而获的欲望，”他曾写道，“让许多与我和其他骗子打过交道的人付出了惨痛的代价……当人们明白——我怀疑他们不会明白——他们不可能不劳而获时，犯罪就会减少，我们所有人都会生活在更加和谐的环境中。”多年来，韦尔想出了许多方法，用轻松赚钱的诱惑来引诱人们。他会赠送“免费”的房产，谁能抵挡得住这种诱惑，谁就会发现，他们必须支付25美元才能办理房产登记。由于土地是免费的，这笔高额费用似乎也值得，黄孩子便能从这虚假的登记中赚取数千美元。作为交换，他会给这些傻瓜一份伪造的地契。有时，他会给那些傻瓜编造关于假赛马或者几周内就能涨200%的股票的故事。他一边讲故事，一边看着那些傻瓜一想到能白吃一顿饭就瞪大了眼睛。
The lesson is simple: Bait your deceptions with the possibility of easy money. People are essentially lazy, and want wealth to fall in their lap rather than to work for it. For a small sum, sell them advice on how to make millions (P. T. Barnum did this later in life), and that small sum will become a fortune when multiplied by thousands of suckers. Lure people in with the prospect of easy money and you have the room to work still more deceptions on them, since greed is powerful enough to blind your victims to anything. And as the Yellow Kid said, half the fun is teaching a moral lesson: Greed does not pay.
道理很简单：用轻松赚钱的诱惑来引诱别人上当受骗。人性本懒，总想坐享其成，而不是辛勤劳作。花一小笔钱，就能让他们学会如何赚到数百万美元（P·T·巴纳姆晚年就这么做过），而这笔钱一旦乘以成千上万的受害者，就能变成一笔巨款。用轻松赚钱的诱惑引诱人们上当，你就有空间对他们施展更多骗局，因为贪婪的力量足以蒙蔽受害者的双眼。正如黄孩子所说，乐趣的一半在于传授道德教训：贪婪不会带来好结果。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 41
第41条
AVOID STEPPING INTO A GREAT MAN'S SHOES
避免模仿伟人
JUDGMENT
判断
What happens first always appears better and more original than what comes after. If you succeed a great man or have a famous parent, you will have to accomplish double their achievements to outshine them. Do not get lost in their shadow, or stuck in a past not of your own making: Establish your own name and identity by changing course. Slay the overbearing father, disparage his legacy, and gain power by shining in your own way.
先发生的事情总是显得比后来的更好、更有创意。如果你继承了伟人的衣钵，或者拥有一个名门望族的父母，你必须取得他们双倍的成就才能超越他们。不要迷失在他们的阴影下，也不要困于并非你亲手缔造的过去：改变方向，建立属于你自己的名声和身份。摆脱专横的父亲，贬低他的成就，以你自己的方式绽放光芒，赢得力量。
Many would have shone like the very phoenix in their occupations if others had not preceded them. Being first is a great advantage; with eminence, twice as good. Deal the first hand and you will win the upper ground. . . . Those who go first win fame by right of birth, and those who follow are like second sons, contenting themselves with meager portions.... Solomon opted wisely for pacifism, yielding warlike things to his father. By changing course he found it easier to become a hero.... And our great Philip II governed the entire world from the throne of his prudence, astonishing the ages. If his unconquered father was a model of energy, Philip was a paradigm of prudence.... This sort of novelty has helped the well-advised win a place in the roll of the great. Without leaving their own art, the ingenious leave the common path and take, even in professions gray with age, new steps toward eminence. Horace yielded epic poetry to Virgil, and Martial the lyric to Horace. Terence opted for comedy, Persius for satire, each hoping to be first in his genre. Bold fancy never succumbed to facile imitation.
如果不是前人先行，许多人本可以在各自的领域如凤凰涅槃般熠熠生辉。先行者固然优势巨大，而卓越者则更胜一筹。先发制人，方能占据上风……先行者天生享有盛名，而后行者则如同次子，只能满足于微薄的份额……所罗门明智地选择了和平主义，将战争的重任交给了他的父亲。正是这种转变，让他更容易成为英雄……而我们伟大的腓力二世则凭借其审慎的决策，统治了整个世界，令世人惊叹。如果说他那所向披靡的父亲是精力充沛的典范，那么腓力二世则是审慎的化身……这种创新精神帮助那些深谋远虑的人跻身伟人之列。他们不拘泥于本色，而是另辟蹊径，即使在那些日渐式微的行业中，也能迈出通往卓越的新步伐。贺拉斯将史诗让给了维吉尔，马提亚尔则将抒情诗让给了贺拉斯。泰伦斯选择了喜剧，珀尔修斯选择了讽刺诗，他们都渴望成为各自领域的先驱。大胆的想象力从未屈服于简单的模仿。
a pocket mirror
口袋镜
for heroes,
献给英雄们，
Baltasar Gracian,
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安
translated by
译者
Christopher Maurer,
克里斯托弗·毛雷尔
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
When Louis XIV died, in 1715, after a glorious fifty-five-year reign, all eyes focused on his great-grandson and chosen successor, the future Louis XV. Would the boy, only five at the time, prove as great a leader as the Sun King Louis XIV had transformed a country on the verge of civil war into the preeminent power in Europe. The last years of his reign had been difficulthe had been old and tiredbut it was hoped that the child would develop into the kind of strong ruler who would reinvigorate the land and add to the firm foundation that Louis XIV had laid.
1715年，路易十四在位五十五年后驾崩，举世瞩目，所有人的目光都聚焦在他的曾孙兼指定继承人——未来的路易十五身上。这位当时年仅五岁的男孩，能否像太阳王路易十四一样，成为一位伟大的君主？路易十四曾将一个濒临内战的国家，一跃成为欧洲的霸主。他统治的最后几年并不轻松——他年老体衰——但人们仍然寄希望于这个孩子能够成长为一位强有力的统治者，重振国家，并在路易十四奠定的坚实基础上更进一步。
To this end the child was given the best minds of France as his tutors, men who would instruct him in the arts of statecraft, in the methods that the Sun King had perfected. Nodiing was neglected in his education. But when Louis XV came to die throne, in 1726, a sudden change came over him: He no longer had to study or please others or prove himself. He stood alone at the top of a great country, widi wealth and power at his command. He could do as he wished.
为此，路易十五被安排由法国最杰出的智者担任他的导师，传授他治国之道，以及太阳王路易十五所完善的治国之道。他的教育可谓面面俱到。然而，1726年路易十五登基后，他的人生发生了翻天覆地的变化：他不再需要学习，不再需要取悦他人，也不再需要证明自己。他独自屹立于一个伟大国家的顶端，拥有无尽的财富和权力。他可以随心所欲。
In die first years of his reign, Louis gave himself over to pleasure, leaving the government in the hands of a trusted minister, Andre-Hercule de Fleury. This caused little concern, for he was a young man who needed to sow his wild oats, and de Fleury was a good minister. But it slowly became clear that this was more than a passing phase. Louis had no interest in governing. His main worry was not France's finances, or a possible war with Spain, but boredom. He could not stand being bored, and when he was not hunting deer, or chasing young girls, he whiled away his time at the gambling tables, losing huge sums in a single night.
路易十四统治初期，沉溺于享乐，将政务交给了信任的大臣安德烈-赫尔库勒·德·弗勒里。这并未引起太多担忧，因为他正值青春年少，需要放纵一下，而德·弗勒里也是一位能干的大臣。但渐渐地，人们发现这并非一时兴起。路易十四对治理国家毫无兴趣。他最担心的并非法国的财政状况，也并非可能与西班牙开战，而是无聊。他无法忍受无聊，除了狩猎和追逐年轻女子之外，他便将时间浪费在赌桌上，一夜之间便输得精光。
The court, as usual, reflected the tastes of the ruler. Gambling and lavish parties became the obsession. The courtiers had no concern with the future of Francethey poured their energies into charming the king, angling for titles that would bring them life pensions, and for cabinet positions demanding litde work but paying huge salaries. Parasites flocked to the court, and the state's debts swelled.
宫廷一如既往地反映了统治者的喜好。赌博和奢靡的宴会成了他们的痴迷。朝臣们对法国的未来漠不关心，他们竭尽全力讨好国王，觊觎能带来终身养老金的爵位，以及那些工作轻松却薪水丰厚的内阁职位。寄生虫蜂拥而至，国家债务也随之飙升。
In 1745 Louis fell in love with Madame de Pompadour, a woman of middle-class origin who had managed to rise dirough her charms, her intelligence, and a good marriage. Madame de Pompadour became the official royal mistress; she also became France's arbiter of taste and fashion. But the Madame had political ambitions as well, and she eventually emerged as the country's unofficial prime ministerit was she, not Louis, who wielded hiring-and-firing power over France's most important ministers.
1745年，路易十四爱上了蓬帕杜夫人。蓬帕杜夫人出身中产阶级，凭借美貌、智慧和美满的婚姻，一步步攀升至上流社会。她成为路易十四的官方情妇，同时也是法国品味和时尚的风向标。然而，蓬帕杜夫人也怀有政治野心，最终成为法国的非正式首相——真正掌握法国重要大臣任免权的并非路易十四，而是她。
As he grew older Louis only needed more diversion. On the grounds of Versailles he built a brothel, Pare aux Cerfs, which housed some of die prettiest young girls of France. Underground passages and hidden staircases gave Louis access at all hours. After Madame de Pompadour died, in 1764, she was succeeded as royal mistress by Madame du Barry, who soon came to dominate the court, and who, like de Pompadour before her, began to meddle in affairs of state. If a minister did not please her he would find himself fired. All of Europe was aghast when du Barry, the daughter of a baker, managed to arrange the firing of Etienne de Choiseul, the foreign
随着年龄增长，路易十四的消遣需求也越来越大。他在凡尔赛宫内建造了一座名为“鹿苑”（Pare aux Cerfs）的妓院，里面住着法国一些最漂亮的年轻女孩。地下通道和隐蔽的楼梯让路易十四可以随时出入。1764年蓬帕杜夫人去世后，杜巴丽夫人继承了王室情妇的位置。她很快便掌控了宫廷，并像之前的蓬帕杜夫人一样，开始干预国事。如果哪个大臣不讨她喜欢，就会被解雇。当身为面包师之女的杜巴丽夫人设法安排解雇了外国大臣艾蒂安·德·舒瓦瑟尔时，整个欧洲都震惊了。
minister and France's most able diplomat. He had shown her too littie respect. As time went by, swindlers and charlatans made their nests in Versailles, and enticed Louis's interest in astrology, the occult, and fraudulent business deals. The young and pampered teenager who had taken over France years before had only grown worse with age.
他是法国最杰出的外交官，也是当时的部长。他对她不够尊重。随着时间的流逝，骗子和江湖术士在凡尔赛宫安家落户，并诱使路易对占星术、神秘学和欺诈性商业交易产生兴趣。多年前那个年轻气盛、娇生惯养的少年，随着年龄的增长，变得越来越糟糕。
The motto that became attached to Louis's reign was “Apres moi, le deluge”- “After me the flood,” or, Let France rot after I am gone. And indeed when Louis did go, in 1774, worn out by debauchery, his country and his own finances were in horrible disarray. His grandson Louis XVI inherited a realm in desperate need of reform and a strong leader. But Louis XVI was even weaker than his grandfather, and could only watch as the country descended into revolution. In 1792 the republic introduced by the French Revolution declared the end of the monarchy, and gave die king a new name, “Louis the Last.” A few months later he kneeled on the guillotine, his about-to-be-severed head stripped of all the radiance and power that die Sun King had invested in the crown.
路易十六的统治时期被冠以“Apres moi, le deluge”（我死后，洪水泛滥）的格言，或者说，让法国在我死后腐朽。的确，当路易十六于1774年驾崩时，他已因放荡不羁而精疲力竭，国家和个人财政都陷入了可怕的混乱。他的孙子路易十六继承了一个亟需改革和强权统治的王国。然而，路易十六比他的祖父更加软弱，只能眼睁睁地看着国家滑向革命的深渊。1792年，法国大革命建立的共和国宣告了君主制的终结，并赋予国王一个新的称号——“末代路易”。几个月后，他跪在断头台上，即将被斩首的头颅，失去了太阳王赋予王冠的所有光辉和权力。
Interpretation
解释
From a country that had descended into civil war in die late 1640s, Louis XIV forged the mightiest realm in Europe. Great generals would tremble in his presence. A cook once made a mistake in preparing a dish and committed suicide rather than face the king's wrath. Louis XIV had many mistresses, but their power ended in the bedroom. He filled his court with the most brilliant minds of die age. The symbol of his power was Versailles: Refusing to accept die palace of his forefathers, die Louvre, he built his own palace in what was then the middle of nowhere, symbolizing that diis was a new order he had founded, one without precedent. He made Versailles the centerpiece of his reign, a place that all the powerful of Europe envied and visited with a sense of awe. In essence, Louis took a great voidthe decaying monarchy of Franceand filled it with his own symbols and radiant power.
路易十四从17世纪40年代末陷入内战的法国，一手缔造了欧洲最强大的王国。就连伟大的将军们在他面前也胆战心惊。一位厨师曾因烹饪失误，宁愿自杀也不愿承受国王的怒火。路易十四情妇众多，但她们的权力仅限于闺房。他将当时最杰出的人才招入麾下。凡尔赛宫是他权力的象征：他拒绝接受祖辈的宫殿——卢浮宫，而是在当时的荒郊野外建造了自己的宫殿，象征着他开创了一个前所未有的新秩序。他将凡尔赛宫作为其统治的核心，令欧洲所有权贵艳羡不已，并怀着敬畏之心前来朝拜。从本质上讲，路易十四填补了法国君主制衰落的巨大空白，并用他自己的象征和耀眼的权力将其填满。
Louis XV, on the other hand, symbolizes the fate of all those who inherit somediing large or who follow in a great man's footsteps. It would seem easy for a son or successor to build on die grand foundation left for them, but in the realm of power the opposite is true. The pampered, indulged son almost always squanders the inheritance, for he does not start with die father's need to fill a void. As Machiavelli states, necessity is what impels men to take action, and once die necessity is gone, only rot and decay are left. Having no need to increase his store of power, Louis XV inevitably succumbed to inertia. Under him, Versailles, the symbol of the Sun King's authority, became a pleasure palace of incomparable banality, a kind of Las Vegas of die Bourbon monarchy. It came to represent all that the oppressed peasantry of France hated about their king, and during die Revolution they looted it with glee.
另一方面，路易十五象征着所有继承巨额遗产或追随伟人脚步之人的命运。对于儿子或继承人来说，在前人留下的宏伟基础上继续发展似乎轻而易举，但在权力领域，事实恰恰相反。被娇惯、被纵容的儿子几乎总是挥霍遗产，因为他并非出于填补父亲权力空缺的需要而继承。正如马基雅维利所言，需求驱使人们采取行动，一旦需求消失，剩下的只有腐朽和衰败。由于无需扩张权力，路易十五不可避免地陷入了惰性。在他的统治下，象征着太阳王权威的凡尔赛宫沦为一座平庸至极的享乐宫殿，如同波旁王朝的拉斯维加斯。它最终成为法国受压迫的农民憎恨国王一切的象征，并在法国大革命期间，他们欣喜若狂地洗劫了凡尔赛宫。
Louis XV had only one way out of the trap awaiting the son or successor of a man like the Sun King: to psychologically begin from nothing, to
路易十五只有一条路可以摆脱等待着像太阳王那样的人的儿子或继承人的陷阱：那就是在心理上从零开始，重新开始。
LIFE OF PERICLES
伯里克利的一生
As a young man Pericles was inclined to shrink from facing the people. One reason for this was that he was considered to bear a distinct resemblance to the tyrant Pisistratus, and when men who were well on in years remarked on the charm of Pericles' voice and the smoothness and fluency of his speech, they were astonished at the resemblance between the two. The fact that he was rich and that he came of a distinguished family and possessed exceedingly powerful friends made the fear of ostracism very real to him, and at the beginning of his career he took no part in politics but devoted himself to soldiering, in which he showed great daring and enterprise. However, the time came when Aristides was dead, Themistocles in exile, and Cimon frequently absent on distant campaigns. Then at last Pericles decided to attach himself to the people's party and to take up the cause of the poor and the many instead of that of the rich and the few, in spite of the fact that this was quite contrary to his own temperament, which was thoroughly aristocratic. He was afraid, apparently, of being suspected of aiming at a dictatorship; so that when he saw that
年轻时的伯里克利不愿与人接触。其中一个原因是，人们认为他长得酷似僭主庇西特拉图。一些上了年纪的人在欣赏伯里克利悦耳的嗓音和流畅的演讲时，也惊讶于两人之间的相似之处。由于他家境富裕，出身名门，且拥有众多权势显赫的朋友，因此他非常害怕被排斥。在事业初期，他并未涉足政治，而是投身军旅，展现出非凡的勇气和魄力。然而，随着阿里斯提德去世、地米斯托克利流亡以及西蒙频繁远征在外，他逐渐意识到自己对政治的渴望。最终，伯里克利决定加入人民党，转而支持穷人和多数人的利益，而不是富人和少数人的利益，尽管这与他骨子里的贵族气质截然相反。显然，他害怕被怀疑意图建立独裁统治；因此，当他看到……
Cimon '.v sympathies were strongly with the nobles and that Cimon was the idol of the aristocratic party, Pericles began to ingratiate himself with the people, partly for self-preservation and partly by way of securing power against his rival. He now entered upon a new mode of life. He was never to be seen walking in any street except the one which led to the market-place and the council chamber.
由于西蒙对贵族抱有强烈的同情，而且西蒙又是贵族党的偶像，伯里克利开始讨好民众，部分是为了自保，部分是为了巩固权力以对抗他的对手。他从此过上了新的生活。除了通往集市和议事厅的那条街，人们再也看不到他在任何其他街道上行走。
the life of pericles,
伯里克利的一生
Plutarch,
普鲁塔克
c. a.d. 46-120
公元46-120年
How beneficial poverty may sometimes be to those with talent, and how it may serve as a powerful goad to make them perfect or excellent in whatever occupation they might choose, can be seen very clearly in the actions of Pietro Perugino. Wishing by means of his ability to attain some respectable rank, after leaving disastrous calamities behind in Perugia and coming to Florence, he remained there many months in poverty, sleeping in a chest, since he had no other bed; he turned night into day, and with the greatest zeal continually applied himself to
贫穷有时对有才华的人来说是多么有益，它如何能成为激励他们精益求精、追求卓越的强大动力，在彼得罗·佩鲁吉诺的生平事迹中体现得淋漓尽致。他渴望凭借自己的才华获得体面的地位，于是在佩鲁贾经历了种种灾难后来到佛罗伦萨。在那里，他过着清贫的生活，因为没有其他床铺，只能睡在箱子里，度过了数月之久。他昼夜颠倒，孜孜不倦地努力学习。
denigrate the past and his inheritance, and to move in a totally new direction, creating his own world. Assuming you have the choice, it would be better to avoid the situation altogether, to place yourself where there is a vacuum of power, where you can be the one to bring order out of chaos without having to compete with another star in the sky. Power depends on appearing larger than other people, and when you are lost in die shadow of the father, the king, the great predecessor, you cannot possibly project such a presence.
贬低过去和他的传承，另辟蹊径，开创属于他自己的世界。假设你有选择，最好完全避开这种情况，把自己置于权力真空地带，在那里你可以从混乱中建立秩序，而无需与天上的其他明星竞争。权力取决于是否显得比其他人更强大，而当你被父亲、国王、伟大先辈的阴影所笼罩时，你根本无法展现出这样的存在感。
But when they began to make sovereignty hereditary, the children quickly
但当他们开始实行世袭制时，孩子们很快就……
degenerated from their fathers; and, so far from trying to equal their father's
他们自相残杀，远不如他们的父辈；而且，他们非但没有努力追赶他们的父辈，反而更加堕落。
virtues, they considered that a prince had nothing else to do than to excel
他们认为，君主除了追求卓越之外别无他事。
all the rest in idleness, indulgence, and every other variety of pleasure.
其余时间都用于游手好闲、放纵享乐。
Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527
尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527 年
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
Alexander the Great had a dominant passion as a young manan intense dislike for his father, King Philip of Macedonia. He hated Philip's cunning, cautious style of ruling, his bombastic speeches, his drinking and whoring, and his love of wrestling and of other wastes of time. Alexander knew he had to make himself the very opposite of his domineering father: He would force himself to be bold and reckless, he would control his tongue and be a man of few words, and he would not lose precious time in pursuit of pleasures that brought no glory. Alexander also resented the fact that Philip had conquered most of Greece: “My father will go on conquering till there is nothing extraordinary left for me to do,” he once complained. While other sons of powerful men were content to inherit wealth and live a life of leisure, Alexander wanted only to outdo his father, to obliterate Philip's name from history by surpassing his accomplishments.
年轻时的亚历山大大帝心中怀有一种强烈的执念——对他的父亲，马其顿国王腓力二世，恨之入骨。他厌恶腓力二世狡诈谨慎的统治方式、夸夸其谈的演说、酗酒寻欢作乐的习惯，以及他对摔跤和其他消遣的痴迷。亚历山大深知自己必须与专横跋扈的父亲截然相反：他要强迫自己变得大胆无畏，谨言慎行，并且绝不将宝贵的时间浪费在那些毫无荣耀可言的享乐上。亚历山大也对腓力二世征服了希腊的大部分地区感到愤恨：“我的父亲会一直征服下去，直到我再也无事可做为止。”他曾这样抱怨道。当其他权贵之子满足于继承财富、过着悠闲的生活时，亚历山大却一心只想超越他的父亲，通过超越他的成就，将腓力二世的名字从历史上抹去。
Alexander itched to show others how superior he was to his father. A Thessalian horse-dealer once brought a prize horse named Bucephalus to sell to Philip. None of the king's grooms could get near the horseit was far too savageand Philip berated the merchant for bringing him such a useless beast. Watching the whole affair, Alexander scowled and commented, “What a horse they are losing for want of skill and spirit to manage him!” When he had said this several times, Philip had finally had enough, and challenged him to take on die horse. He called the merchant back, secretly hoping his son would have a nasty fall and learn a bitter lesson. But Alexander was die one to teach the lesson: Not only did he mount Bucephalus, he managed to ride him at full gallop, taming the horse that would later carry him all die way to India. The courtiers applauded wildly, but Philip seethed inside, seeing not a son but a rival to his power.
亚历山大渴望向世人证明自己比父亲更胜一筹。一位色萨利马贩曾带来一匹名叫布塞法勒斯的名驹，想卖给腓力二世。国王的侍从们根本无法驾驭这匹马——它性情暴烈，难以驯服。腓力二世斥责商人带来如此无用的牲畜。亚历山大目睹了这一切，怒气冲冲地说道：“他们竟然因为缺乏驾驭技巧和精神而错失良驹！” 亚历山大反复说道，腓力二世终于忍无可忍，向他发起挑战。他召回了商人，暗自希望儿子能摔个狗啃泥，好好教训他一顿。然而，亚历山大却给了腓力二世一个教训：他不仅骑上了布塞法勒斯，还策马疾驰，驯服了这匹后来驮着他远征印度的骏马。朝臣们欢呼雀跃，而腓力二世内心却怒火中烧，他看到的不是儿子，而是一个权力的竞争对手。
Alexander's defiance of his father grew bolder. One day die two men had a heated argument before die entire court, and Philip drew his sword as if to strike his son; having drunk too much wine, however, the king stumbled. Alexander pointed at his father and jeered, "Men of Macedonia,
亚历山大对父亲的反抗愈发大胆。一天，两人在整个朝廷面前激烈争吵，腓力拔剑欲刺向儿子；然而，由于饮酒过量，国王踉跄了一下。亚历山大指着父亲嘲讽道：“马其顿人啊，
see there the man who is preparing to pass from Europe to Asia. He cannot pass from one table to another without falling."
瞧，那人正准备从欧洲前往亚洲。他连从一张桌子走到另一张桌子都做不到，总是摔倒。
When Alexander was eighteen, a disgrunded courtier murdered Philip. As word of the regicide spread through Greece, city after city rose up in rebellion against their Macedonian rulers. Philip's advisers counseled Alexander, now the king, to proceed cautiously, to do as Philip had done and conquer through cunning. But Alexander would do tilings his way: He marched to the furthest reaches of the kingdom, suppressed the rebellious towns, and reunited the empire with brutal efficiency.
亚历山大十八岁时，一位心怀不满的朝臣刺杀了腓力二世。弑君的消息传遍希腊，各城纷纷起义，反抗马其顿统治者。腓力二世的谋士们劝告如今已是国王的亚历山大谨慎行事，效仿腓力二世，以计谋征服。但亚历山大却坚持己见：他进军王国最遥远的边陲，镇压叛乱的城镇，以残酷的手段重新统一了帝国。
As a young rebel grows older, his struggle against the father often wanes, and he gradually comes to resemble the very man he had wanted to defy. But Alexander's loathing of his father did not end with Philip's death. Once he had consolidated Greece, he set his eyes on Persia, the prize that had eluded his father, who had dreamed of conquering Asia. If he defeated the Persians, Alexander would finally surpass Philip in glory and fame.
随着年轻叛逆者年龄渐长，他对父亲的反抗往往会逐渐减弱，最终变得和自己曾经想要反抗的那个人越来越像。但亚历山大对父亲的憎恨并没有随着腓力二世的去世而结束。在统一希腊之后，他将目光投向了波斯——他父亲梦寐以求却未能征服的宝地，而他的父亲一直渴望征服亚洲。如果他能击败波斯人，亚历山大最终将在荣耀和名望上超越腓力二世。
Alexander crossed into Asia with an army of 35,000 to face a Persian force numbering over a million. Before engaging die Persians in battle he passed through the town of Gordium. Here, in the town's main temple, there stood an ancient chariot tied with cords made of die rind of the cornel tree. Legend had it that any man who could undo these cordsthe Gordian knotwould rule the world. Many had tried to untie the enormous and intricate knot, but none had succeeded. Alexander, seeing he could not possibly untie die knot with his bare hands, took out his sword and widi one slash cut it in half. This symbolic gesture showed the world that he would not do as otiiers, but would blaze his own path.
亚历山大率领三万五千人的军队渡海进入亚洲，迎战人数超过百万的波斯大军。在与波斯人交战之前，他途经戈尔迪乌姆城。城中主神庙里，矗立着一辆古老的战车，战车被山茱萸树皮制成的绳索紧紧捆绑。传说，任何能够解开这些绳索——戈尔迪之结——的人，都将统治世界。许多人都曾尝试解开这个巨大而复杂的绳结，但都无功而返。亚历山大见自己徒手无法解开这个绳结，便拔出宝剑，一剑将其斩断。这一象征性的举动向世人表明，他不会随波逐流，而是要开辟属于自己的道路。
Against astounding odds, Alexander conquered the Persians. Most expected him to stop thereit was a great triumph, enough to secure his fame for eternity. But Alexander had die same relationship to his own deeds as he had to his father: His conquest of Persia represented die past, and he wanted never to rest on past triumphs, or to allow the past to outshine the present. He moved on to India, extending his empire beyond all known limits. Only his disgrunded and weary soldiers prevented him from going farther.
亚历山大以惊人的毅力征服了波斯。大多数人认为他会就此止步——这是一场伟大的胜利，足以让他名垂青史。但亚历山大对待自己的功绩，正如他对待父亲一样：征服波斯代表着过去，他绝不想沉湎于过去的辉煌，也不愿让过去掩盖现在。他继续进军印度，将帝国版图扩张到前所未有的疆界。只有那些心怀不满、疲惫不堪的士兵阻止了他继续扩张。
Interpretation
解释
Alexander represents an extremely uncommon type in history: the son of a famous and successful man who manages to surpass the fatfier in glory and power. The reason this type is uncommon is simple: The father most often manages to amass his fortune, his kingdom, because he begins with litUe or nothing. A desperate urge impels him to succeedhe has nothing to lose by cunning and impetuousness, and has no famous fatiier of his own to compete against. This kind of man has reason to believe in himselfto believe that his way of doing things is the best, because, after all, it worked for him.
亚历山大代表了历史上极其罕见的人物类型：一位名声显赫、功成名就之人的儿子，最终在荣耀和权力上超越了父亲。这种类型之所以罕见，原因很简单：父亲往往白手起家，最终积累起巨额财富和王国。一种不顾一切的成功欲望驱使着他——他凭借狡诈和鲁莽行事，没有什么可失去的，也没有像父亲那样显赫的人物需要与之竞争。这类人有理由相信自己——相信自己的行事方式是最好的，毕竟，这种方式对他自己是有效的。
When a man like this has a son, he becomes domineering and oppressive, imposing his lessons on the son, who is starting off life in circumstances totally different from diose in which the father himself began.
像这样的男人有了儿子之后，就会变得专横跋扈、专制独裁，把自己的人生信条强加给儿子。而儿子的人生起点与父亲当初的起点截然不同。
the study of his profession. After painting had become second nature to him, Pietro's only pleasure was always to be working in his craft and constantly to be painting. And because he always had the dread of poverty before his eyes, he did things to make money which he probably would not have bothered to do had he not been forced to support himself. Perhaps wealth would have closed to him and his talent the path to excellence just as poverty had opened it up to him, but need spurred him on since he desired to rise from such a miserable and lowly position // not perhaps to the summit and supreme height of excellence, then at least to a point where he could have enough to live on. For this reason, he took no notice of cold, hunger, discomfort, inconvenience, toil or shame if he could only live one day in ease and repose; and he would always sayand as if it were a proverb that after bad weather, good weather must follow, and that during the good weather houses must be built for shelter in times of need.
