他潜心钻研自己的技艺。绘画对他而言已如呼吸般自然，彼得罗唯一的乐趣便是潜心钻研，笔耕不辍。由于他始终对贫困心怀恐惧，为了谋生，他做了许多原本可能根本不会去做的事情。或许财富会像贫困为他开启通往卓越的道路一样，为他和他的才华关闭这条道路，但正是这种需要激励着他不断前行，因为他渴望摆脱这种卑微的境地——或许无法攀上艺术的巅峰，至少也要达到足以维持生计的地步。正因如此，只要能过上一天安逸舒适的生活，他便对寒冷、饥饿、不适、不便、辛劳和羞辱毫不在意；他总是说——仿佛这是一句谚语——风雨过后必有晴天，晴天时更要筑起房屋，以备不时之需。
lives of the artists, Giorgio Vasari, 1511-1574
艺术家传，乔尔乔·瓦萨里，1511-1574
The slightest acquaintance with chess shows one that it is a play-substitute for the art of war and indeed it has been a favorite recreation of some of the greatest military leaders, from William the Conqueror to Napoleon. In the contest between the opposing armies the same principles of both strategy and tactics are displayed as in actual war, the same foresight and powers of calculation are necessary, the same capacity for divining the plans of the opponent, and the rigor with which decisions are followed by their consequences is, if anything, even more ruthless. More than that, it is plain that the unconscious motive actuating the players is not the mere love of pugnacity characteristic of all competitive games, but the grimmer one of father-murder. It is true that the original goal of capturing the king has been given up, but from the point of view of motive there is, except in respect of crudity, not appreciable change in the present goal of sterilizing him in immobility.... “Checkmate ” means literally “the king is dead.” ... Our knowledge of the unconscious motivation of chess-playing tells us that what it represented could only have been the wish to overcome the father in an acceptable way.... It is no doubt signifi-
稍加了解国际象棋便可知，它是一种战争艺术的娱乐替代品，事实上，从征服者威廉到拿破仑，许多伟大的军事领袖都喜爱国际象棋。在对立双方的较量中，战略和战术的原则与实战如出一辙，同样需要远见卓识和精于算计，同样需要洞察对手的计划，而决策及其后果的残酷程度，甚至更甚。不仅如此，显而易见，驱动棋手下棋的潜意识动机并非所有竞技游戏中常见的好斗之心，而是更为阴暗的弑父之念。诚然，俘虏国王的最初目标已经放弃，但从动机的角度来看，除了手段粗暴之外，如今使他丧失行动能力的目标并没有发生显著变化……“将死”的字面意思是“国王死了”。……我们对下棋无意识动机的了解告诉我们，它所代表的只能是希望以一种可以接受的方式战胜父亲……这无疑意义重大——
Instead of allowing the son to go in a new direction, the father will try to put him in his own shoes, perhaps secredy wishing die boy will fail, as Philip half wanted to see Alexander thrown from Bucephalus. Fathers envy Uieir sons' youdi and vigor, after all, and their desire is to control and dominate. The sons of such men tend to become cowed and cautious, terrified of losing what their fadiers have gained.
父亲不会让儿子走上新的道路，而是会试图让他走自己的路，或许暗自希望儿子失败，就像腓力二世曾希望看到亚历山大被布塞法勒斯推下王座一样。毕竟，父亲们嫉妒儿子的活力和魄力，他们渴望控制和支配。这样的父亲的儿子往往会变得畏缩不前、小心谨慎，害怕失去父亲所拥有的一切。
The son will never step out of his father's shadow unless he adopts die ruthless strategy of Alexander: disparage die past, create your own kingdom, put die father in die shadows instead of letting him do the same to you. If you cannot materially start from ground zeroit would be foolish to renounce an inheritanceyou can at least begin from ground zero psychologically, by throwing off the weight of die past and charting a new direction. Alexander instinctively recognized that privileges of birth are impediments to power. Be merciless with the past, tiiennot only widi your fadier and his fadier but widi your own earlier achievements. Only the weak rest on their laurels and dote on past triumphs; in the game of power there is never time to rest.
儿子若不效仿亚历山大的冷酷策略，就永远无法摆脱父亲的阴影：贬低过去，建立自己的王国，让父亲黯然失色，而不是让他反过来影响自己。如果无法从物质层面起步——放弃继承权固然愚蠢——至少可以在心理层面从零开始，摆脱过去的重负，开辟新的道路。亚历山大本能地认识到，出身特权是权力的绊脚石。对待过去要毫不留情，不仅要对待你的父亲和祖父，也要对待你早期的成就。只有弱者才会安于现状，沉湎于过去的辉煌；在权力游戏中，没有喘息之机。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In many ancient kingdoms, for example Bengal and Sumatra, after die king had ruled for several years his subjects would execute him. This was done partly as a ritual of renewal, but also to prevent him from growing too powerfulfor the king would generally try to establish a permanent order, at the expense of other families and of his own sons. Instead of protecting die tribe and leading it in times of war, he would attempt to dominate it. And so he would be beaten to deadi, or executed in an elaborate ritual. Now that he was no longer around for his honors to go to his head, he could be worshipped as a god. Meanwhile die field had been cleared for a new and youdiful order to establish itself.
在许多古代王国，例如孟加拉和苏门答腊，国王统治数年后会被臣民处死。这部分是一种更新的仪式，也是为了防止国王权力过大——因为国王通常会试图建立永久的统治，而这往往以牺牲其他家族甚至自己儿子的利益为代价。他不会保护部族并在战时领导他们，而是试图统治他们。因此，他要么被殴打致死，要么被以繁复的仪式处死。如今他已不在人世，荣誉不再让他骄傲自满，他可以被奉为神明。与此同时，新的秩序得以建立，一片新的天地也随之展开。
The ambivalent, hostile attitude towards the king or father figure also finds expression in legends of heroes who do not know their fadier. Moses, the archetypal man of power, was found abandoned among die bulrushes and never knew his parents; without a father to compete widi him or limit him, he could attain the heights of power. Hercules had no earthly father he was the son of the god Zeus. Later in his life Alexander the Great spread the story that the god Jupiter Ammon had sired him, not Philip of Mace-don. Legends and rituals like diese eliminate the human fadier because he symbolizes the destructive power of die past.
对国王或父亲形象的矛盾甚至敌对态度，也体现在那些不知父亲是谁的英雄传说中。摩西，这位权力的典型代表，被发现遗弃在芦苇丛中，从未见过自己的父母；没有父亲与他竞争或约束他，他才能达到权力的巅峰。赫拉克勒斯没有尘世的父亲，他是宙斯神的儿子。后来，亚历山大大帝散布谣言，说他的父亲是朱庇特·阿蒙神，而不是马其顿的腓力二世。诸如此类的传说和仪式抹去了人类父亲的存在，因为父亲象征着过去带来的破坏性力量。
The past prevents the young hero from creating his own worldhe must do as his father did, even after that father is dead or powerless. The hero must bow and scrape before his predecessor and yield to tradition and precedent. What had success in the past must be carried over to die present, even tiiough circumstances have greatiy changed. The past also weighs die hero down with an inheritance that he is terrified of losing, making him timid and cautious.
过去阻碍了这位年轻英雄创造属于自己的世界——他必须效仿父亲，即便父亲已逝或无能为力。英雄必须对前辈毕恭毕敬，恪守传统和先例。过去行之有效的方法必须沿用至今，即便世事变迁。过去也给英雄带来了沉重的负担，一份他害怕失去的遗产，使他变得胆怯谨慎。
Power depends on die ability to fill a void, to occupy a field diat has
力量取决于填补空白、占据领域的能力。
been cleared of the dead weight of the past. Only after the father figure has been properly done away widi will you have die necessary space to create and establish a new order. There are several strategies you can adopt to accomplish thisvariations on the execution of die king that disguise the violence of die impulse by channeling it in socially acceptable forms.
摆脱了过去的沉重包袱。只有彻底清除父亲的形象之后，你才能拥有必要的空间来创建和建立新的秩序。你可以采取多种策略来实现这一点——这些策略可以伪装暴力冲动，将其转化为社会可接受的形式。
Perhaps the simplest way to escape the shadow of the past is simply to belittle it, playing on die timeless antagonism between the generations, stirring up me young against die old. For diis you need a convenient older figure to pillory. Mao Tse-tung, confronting a culture that fiercely resisted change, played on the suppressed resentment against the overbearing presence of me venerable Confucius in Chinese culture. John F. Kennedy knew the dangers of getting lost in the past; he radically distinguished his presidency from diat of his predecessor, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and also from die preceding decade, die 1950s, which Eisenhower personified. Kennedy, for instance, would not play die dull and fadierly game of golf a symbol of retirement and privilege, and Eisenhower's passion. Instead he played football on die White House lawn. In every aspect his administration represented vigor and youth, as opposed to die stodgy Eisenhower. Kennedy had discovered an old truth: The young are easily set against the old, since diey yearn to make their own place in the world and resent the shadow of tiieir fathers.
或许摆脱过去阴影最简单的方法就是贬低它，利用代际间由来已久的矛盾，煽动年轻人对抗老年人。为此，你需要一个方便的、可以随意嘲讽的老人形象。毛泽东面对的是一个强烈抵制变革的文化，他利用了中国文化中人们对孔子权威的压抑不满。约翰·F·肯尼迪深知沉湎于过去的危险；他彻底改变了自己的总统任期，使其与前任德怀特·D·艾森豪威尔的任期截然不同，也与艾森豪威尔所代表的那个年代——20世纪50年代——截然不同。例如，肯尼迪不会去打高尔夫球——这项运动象征着退休和特权，也是艾森豪威尔的爱好。相反，他会在白宫草坪上踢足球。他的政府在各个方面都展现出活力和青春，与艾森豪威尔的保守沉闷形成鲜明对比。肯尼迪发现了一个古老的真理：年轻人很容易与老年人对立，因为他们渴望在世界上占有一席之地，并且憎恨父辈的阴影。
The distance you establish from your predecessor often demands some symbolism, a way of advertising itself publicly. Louis XIV, for example, created such symbolism when he rejected the traditional palace of die French kings and built his own palace of Versailles. King Philip II of Spain did die same when he created his center of power, die palace of El Esco-rial, in what was then die middle of nowhere. But Louis carried the game further: He would not be a king like his fadier or earlier ancestors, he would not wear a crown or carry a scepter or sit on a dirone, he would establish a new kind of imposing autiiority widi symbols and rituals of its own. Louis made his ancestors' rituals into laughable relics of the past. Follow his example: Never let yourself be seen as following your predecessor's paui. If you do you will never surpass him. You must physically demonstrate your difference, by establishing a style and symbolism that sets you apart.
你与前任之间划清界限往往需要某种象征意义，一种公开宣示自身的方式。例如，路易十四就创造了这种象征意义，他摒弃了法国国王传统的宫殿，建造了自己的凡尔赛宫。西班牙国王腓力二世也做了同样的事情，他在当时的荒郊野外建造了自己的权力中心——埃斯科里亚尔宫。但路易十四更进一步：他不会像他的父亲或更早的先辈那样做国王，他不会戴王冠，不会手持权杖，也不会坐在王座上，他要建立一种全新的、令人敬畏的权威，并拥有自己独特的象征和仪式。路易十四将他祖先的仪式变成了可笑的过时遗物。效仿他的做法：永远不要让自己被视为在追随前任的脚步。如果你这样做，你永远无法超越他。你必须通过建立一种与众不同的风格和象征意义，以实际行动来展现你的不同。
The Roman emperor Augustus, successor to Julius Caesar, understood this moroughly. Caesar had been a great general, a dieatrical figure whose spectacles kept the Romans entertained, an international emissary seduced by die charms of Cleopatraa larger-than-life figure. So Augustus, despite his own theatrical tendencies, competed with Caesar not by trying to outdo him but by differentiating himself from him: He based his power on a return to Roman simplicity, an austerity of both style and substance. Against die memory of Caesar's sweeping presence Augustus posed a quiet and manly dignity.
罗马皇帝奥古斯都，凯撒的继承人，对此深有体会。凯撒曾是一位伟大的将军，一位极具戏剧性的人物，他的种种壮举令罗马人津津乐道；他也是一位被埃及艳后克利奥帕特拉的魅力所吸引的国际使节。因此，尽管奥古斯都自身也带有戏剧化的倾向，但他与凯撒的竞争并非在于超越他，而在于与他划清界限：他将权力建立在回归罗马式的简朴之上，一种风格与实质都力求严谨的风格。与凯撒那气势磅礴的形象形成鲜明对比的是，奥古斯都展现出一种沉稳而庄重的男子气概。
The problem widi the overbearing predecessor is that he fills die vistas before you widi symbols of die past. You have no room to create your own name. To deal witii diis situation you need to hunt out the vacuumsthose
专横跋扈的前任的问题在于，他用过去的象征填满了你眼前的景象。你没有空间去创造属于自己的名声。为了应对这种情况，你需要找到那些真空地带。
cant that [nineteenth-century chess champion Paul] Morphy's soaring odyssey into the higher realms of chess began just a year after the unexpectedly sudden death of his father, which had been a great shock to him, and we may surmise that his brilliant effort of sublimation was, like Shakespeare's Hamlet and Freud's The Interpretation of Dreams, a reaction to this critical event....
不能说[十九世纪国际象棋冠军保罗·]莫菲在国际象棋更高境界的辉煌征程始于他父亲意外猝然离世一年之后，这对他来说是一个巨大的打击，我们可以推测，他卓越的升华努力，就像莎士比亚的《哈姆雷特》和弗洛伊德的《梦的解析》一样，是对这一重大事件的一种回应……
Something should now be said about the reception Morphy's successes met with, for they were of such a kind as to raise the question whether his subsequent collapse may not have been influenced through his perhaps belonging to the type that Freud has described under the name of Die am Erfolge scheitern (“Those wrecked by success”).... Couched in more psychological language, was Morphy affrighted at his own presumptuousness when the light of publicity was thrown on [his great success] Freud has pointed out that the people who break under the strain of too great success do so because they can endure it only in imagination, not in reality. To castrate the father in a dream is a very different matter from doing it in reality. The real situation provokes the unconscious guilt in its full force, and the penalty may be mental collapse.
现在应该谈谈莫菲的成功所受到的反响，因为这种反响不禁让人怀疑，他后来的崩溃是否与他属于弗洛伊德所描述的“被成功摧毁的人”（Die am Erfolge scheitern）这一类型有关……用更心理学的语言来说，当公众的聚光灯照耀下，莫菲是否对自己的狂妄自大感到恐惧？弗洛伊德指出，那些因过度成功而崩溃的人，是因为他们只能在想象中承受这种压力，而无法在现实中承受。在梦中阉割父亲与在现实中阉割父亲截然不同。现实情况会充分激发潜意识中的罪恶感，而其后果可能是精神崩溃。
THE PROBLEM OF PAUL MORPHY,
保罗·墨菲的问题
Ernest Jones, 1951
欧内斯特·琼斯，1951年
areas in culture that have been left vacant and in which you can become the first and principal figure to shine.
文化领域中存在着一些空白地带，你可以在其中成为第一个也是最重要的闪耀人物。
When Pericles of Athens was about to launch a career as a statesman, he looked for the one thing that was missing in Athenian politics. Most of the great politicians of his time had allied themselves with the aristocracy; indeed Pericles himself had aristocratic tendencies. Yet he decided to tiirow in his hat with the city's democratic elements. The choice had nothing to do with his personal beliefs, but it launched him on a brilliant career. Out of necessity he became a man of the people. Instead of competing in an arena filled with great leaders both past and present, he would make a name for himself where no shadows could obscure his presence.
当雅典的伯里克利即将开启他的政治生涯时，他一直在寻找雅典政坛所缺失的那一部分。当时大多数伟大的政治家都与贵族结盟；事实上，伯里克利本人也带有贵族倾向。然而，他却决定与城邦的民主力量携手并进。这一选择与他的个人信仰无关，却开启了他辉煌的政治生涯。出于无奈，他成为了人民的领袖。他没有选择在云集了古今伟大领袖的竞技场上竞争，而是选择在一个没有任何阴影遮蔽他存在的领域里，为自己赢得声誉。
When the painter Diego de Velazquez began his career, he knew he could not compete in refinement and technique with the great Renaissance painters who had come before him. Instead he chose to work in a style that by the standards of the time seemed coarse and rough, in a way that had never been seen before. And in mis style he excelled. There were members of the Spanish court who wanted to demonstrate their own break with the past; the newness of Velazquez's style thrilled them. Most people are afraid to break so boldly with tradition, but mey secretly admire those who can break up the old forms and reinvigorate the culture. This is why there is so much power to be gained from entering vacuums and voids.
画家迭戈·德·委拉斯凯兹开始他的艺术生涯时，他深知自己无法在技法和技巧上与之前的文艺复兴时期伟大画家相媲美。因此，他选择了一种在当时看来粗犷不羁、前所未见的风格进行创作。而他恰恰凭借这种风格脱颖而出。西班牙宫廷中有些人渴望展现自己与传统的决裂；委拉斯凯兹风格的新颖性令他们兴奋不已。大多数人不敢如此大胆地打破传统，但他们或许内心深处却钦佩那些能够打破旧有模式、重振文化的人。正因如此，填补空白和空白往往蕴藏着巨大的力量。
There is a kind of stubborn stupidity that recurs throughout history, and is a strong impediment to power: The superstitious belief that if the person before you succeeded by doing A, B, and C, you can re-create their success by doing the same thing. This cookie-cutter approach will seduce the uncreative, for it is easy, and appeals to their timidity and their laziness. But circumstances never repeat themselves exactly.
历史上反复出现一种顽固的愚蠢，它严重阻碍了权力的获取：那就是迷信地认为，如果前人通过做了A、B、C而获得成功，那么你只要照搬同样的做法就能复制他们的成功。这种千篇一律的方法会诱使缺乏创造力的人，因为它简单易行，迎合了他们的胆怯和懒惰。然而，世事难料，情况永远不会完全相同。
When General Douglas MacArthur assumed command of American forces in the Philippines during World War II, an assistant handed him a book containing the various precedents established by the commanders before him, the methods that had been successful for them. MacArthur asked the assistant how many copies there were of this book. Six, the assistant answered. “Well,” the general replied, “you get all those six copies together and burn themevery one of them. I'll not be bound by precedents. Any time a problem comes up, I'll make the decision at onceimmediately.” Adopt this ruthless strategy toward the past: Burn all the books, and train yourself to react to circumstances as they happen.
二战期间，道格拉斯·麦克阿瑟将军接管驻菲律宾美军指挥权时，一位助手递给他一本书，书中记录了历任指挥官制定的各种先例，以及他们行之有效的作战方法。麦克阿瑟问助手这本书有多少册。助手回答说有六册。“好吧，”将军说，“你把这六册都拿来，全部烧掉。我不会受制于任何先例。一旦出现问题，我会立即做出决定。” 对过去采取这种毫不留情的策略：烧掉所有书籍，并训练自己根据实际情况灵活应对。
You may believe that you have separated yourself from the predecessor or father figure, but as you grow older you must be eternally vigilant lest you become the father you had rebelled against. As a young man, Mao Tse-tung disliked his father and in the struggle against him found his own identity and a new set of values. But as he aged, his father's ways crept back in. Mao's father had valued manual work over intellect; Mao had scoffed at this as a young man, but as he grew older he unconsciously returned to his father's views and echoed such outdated ideas by forcing a whole generation of Chinese intellectuals into manual labor, a nightmarish mistake that
你或许认为自己已经与前辈或父亲形象划清界限，但随着年龄增长，你必须时刻警惕，以免变成你曾经反抗的那种父亲。毛泽东年轻时厌恶父亲，并在与父亲的斗争中找到了自我认同和一套新的价值观。但随着年龄增长，父亲的思想又悄然回归。毛泽东的父亲重视体力劳动胜过智力；毛泽东年轻时对此嗤之以鼻，但随着年龄增长，他却在不知不觉中接受了父亲的观点，并通过强迫整整一代中国知识分子从事体力劳动来重复这些过时的思想，这是一个噩梦般的错误。
cost his regime dearly. Remember: You are your own father. Do not let yourself spend years creating yourself only to let your guard down and allow the ghost of the pastfather, habit, historyto sneak back in.
这让他的政权付出了惨痛的代价。记住：你就是你的父亲。不要让自己花费数年时间塑造自我，却又放松警惕，让过去的父亲、习惯和历史的幽灵再次悄然潜入。
Finally, as noted in the story of Louis XV, plenitude and prosperity tend to make us lazy and inactive: When our power is secure we have no need to act. This is a serious danger, especially for those who achieve success and power at an early age. The playwright Tennessee Williams, for instance, found himself skyrocketed from obscurity to fame by the success of The Glass Menagerie. “The sort of life which I had had previous to this popular success,” he later wrote, “was one that required endurance, a life of clawing and scratching, but it was a good life because it was the sort of life for which the human organism is created. I was not aware of how much vital energy had gone into this struggle until the struggle was removed. This was security at last. I sat down and looked about me and was suddenly very depressed.” Williams had a nervous breakdown, which may in fact have been necessary for him: Pushed to the psychological edge, he could start writing with the old vitality again, and he produced A Streetcar Named Desire. Fyodor Dostoyevsky, similarly, whenever he wrote a successful novel, would feel that the financial security he had gained made the act of creation unnecessary. He would take his entire savings to the casino and would not leave until he had gambled away his last penny. Once reduced to poverty he could write again.
最后，正如路易十五的故事所揭示的那样，富足和繁荣往往会使我们变得懒惰和不作为：当我们的权力稳固时，我们就无需行动。这尤其对于那些早早获得成功和权力的人来说，是一个严重的危险。例如，剧作家田纳西·威廉姆斯凭借《玻璃动物园》的成功，从默默无闻一跃成为名人。“在获得这种大众认可之前，我的生活，”他后来写道，“需要忍耐，需要拼搏奋斗，但这是一种美好的生活，因为这是人类身体所适应的生活。直到奋斗结束，我才意识到自己在这种奋斗中消耗了多少精力。这才是真正的安全感。我坐下来环顾四周，突然感到非常沮丧。”威廉姆斯精神崩溃了，而这或许对他来说是必要的：被逼到心理崩溃的边缘，他才能重新焕发活力，创作出《欲望号街车》。同样，陀思妥耶夫斯基每当写出一部成功的小说后，都会觉得经济上的保障让他觉得创作变得没有必要了。他会把所有积蓄都带到赌场，直到输光最后一分钱才肯离开。一旦身无分文，他就能重新开始写作。
It is not necessary to go to such extremes, but you must be prepared to return to square one psychologically rather than growing fat and lazy with prosperity. Pablo Picasso could deal with success, but only by constantly changing the style of his painting, often breaking completely with what had made him successful before. How often our early triumphs turn us into a kind of caricature of ourselves. Powerful people recognize these traps; like Alexander the Great, they struggle constantly to re-create themselves. The father must not be allowed to return; he must be slain at every step of the way.
不必走极端，但你必须做好心理准备，随时回到原点，而不是在成功中变得懒惰懈怠。毕加索能够应对成功，但他只能通过不断改变绘画风格来做到，常常彻底抛弃之前让他成功的元素。我们早期的成功常常会让我们变成自己的某种讽刺形象。强者深谙这些陷阱；就像亚历山大大帝一样，他们不断努力重塑自我。绝不能让父亲的影子再次出现；必须在前进的每一步都将其斩除。
Image: The Father. He casts a giant shadow over his children, keeping them in thrall long after he is gone by tying them to the past, squashing their youthful spirit, and forcing them down the same tired path he followed himself. His tricks are many. At every crossroads you must slay the father and step out of his shadow.
图片：父亲。他如同巨大的阴影笼罩着他的孩子们，即便在他离世之后，也依然将他们束缚于过去，扼杀他们的青春活力，强迫他们走上他自己走过的那条疲惫不堪的道路。他的诡计数不胜数。在每一个人生的十字路口，你都必须战胜父亲，走出他的阴影。
Authority: Beware of stepping into a great man's shoesyou will have to accomplish twice as much to surpass him. Those who follow are taken for imitators. No matter how much they sweat, they will never shed that burden. It is an uncommon skill to find a new path for excellence, a modern route to celebrity. There are many roads to singularity, not all of them well traveled. The newest ones can be arduous, but they are often shortcuts to greatness. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：切勿妄图继承伟人的衣钵，否则你将付出双倍的努力才能超越他。追随者往往被视为模仿者。无论他们多么努力，都无法摆脱这沉重的负担。找到一条通往卓越的新路径，一条通往名望的现代之路，是一种难得的技能。通往卓越的道路有很多条，但并非所有道路都人迹罕至。最新的道路或许艰辛，但它们往往是通往伟大的捷径。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
The shadow of a great predecessor could be used to advantage if it is chosen as a trick, a tactic that can be discarded once it has brought you power. Napoleon III used the name and legend of his illustrious grand-uncle Napoleon Bonaparte to help him become first president and then emperor of France. Once on the throne, however, he did not stay tied to the past; he quickly showed how different his reign would be, and was careful to keep the public from expecting him to attain the heights that Bonaparte had attained.
如果巧妙利用前人的光环，便可为己所用，这种策略一旦为自己带来权力，便可弃之不用。拿破仑三世就曾利用其显赫的叔祖父拿破仑·波拿巴的名声和传奇，助其成为法国首任总统，最终加冕为皇帝。然而，登基之后，他并未固守过去；他迅速展现出与前任截然不同的统治风格，并谨慎地避免民众对他抱有波拿巴那样的期望。
The past often has elements worth appropriating, qualities that would be foolish to reject out of a need to distinguish yourself. Even Alexander the Great recognized and was influenced by his father's skill in organizing an army. Making a display of doing things differently from your predecessor can make you seem childish and in fact out of control, unless your actions have a logic of their own.
过去往往蕴藏着值得借鉴的元素，那些为了标新立异而摒弃的品质实属愚蠢。就连亚历山大大帝也认识到并深受其父组织军队的能力的影响。刻意标新立异，与前人行事，除非你的行为自有其逻辑，否则只会显得幼稚，甚至失控。
Joseph II, son of the Austrian empress Maria Theresa, made a show of doing the exact opposite of his motherdressing like an ordinary citizen, staying in inns instead of palaces, appearing as the “people's emperor.” Maria Theresa, on the other hand, had been regal and aristocratic. The problem was that she had also been beloved, an empress who ruled wisely
奥地利女皇玛丽亚·特蕾莎之子约瑟夫二世，刻意与母亲截然相反，他衣着朴素，不住宫殿，而是住在客栈，以“人民的皇帝”自居。而玛丽亚·特蕾莎则是一位高贵典雅的女皇。问题在于，她也深受爱戴，是一位英明的女皇。
after years of learning the hard way. If you have the kind of intelligence and instinct mat will point you in the right direction, playing the rebel will not be dangerous. But if you are mediocre, as Joseph II was in comparison to his mother, you are better off learning from your predecessor's knowledge and experience, which are based on something real.
经过多年的摸索学习，如果你拥有足够的智慧和直觉，能够指引你走向正确的方向，那么扮演叛逆者的角色并不会很危险。但如果你平庸无奇，就像约瑟夫二世与他母亲相比那样，那么你最好还是学习前任的知识和经验，因为这些知识和经验都是建立在真实历史基础上的。
Finally, it is often wise to keep an eye on the young, your future rivals in power. Just as you try to rid yourself of your father, they will soon play the same trick on you, denigrating everything you have accomplished. Just as you rise by rebelling against the past, keep an eye on those rising from below, and never give them the chance to do die same to you.
最后，密切关注年轻人——你未来的权力对手——往往是明智之举。正如你试图摆脱父亲的影响，他们很快也会对你故伎重演，诋毁你的一切成就。正如你通过反抗过去而崛起，也要警惕那些从底层崛起的人，永远不要给他们机会以牙还牙。
The great Baroque artist and architect Pietro Bernini was a master at sniffing out younger potential rivals and keeping mem in his shadow. One day a young stonemason named Francesco Borromini showed Bernini his architectural sketches. Recognizing his talent immediately, Bernini in-standy hired Borromini as his assistant, which delighted the young man but was actually only a tactic to keep him close at hand, so that he could play psychological games on him and create in him a kind of inferiority complex. And indeed, despite Borromini's brilliance, Bernini has the greater fame. His strategy with Borromini he made a lifelong practice: Fearing mat the great sculptor Alessandro Algardi, for example, would eclipse him in fame, he arranged it so that Algardi could only find work as his assistant. And any assistant who rebelled against Bernini and tried to strike out on his own would find his career ruined.
伟大的巴洛克艺术家和建筑师彼得罗·贝尼尼（Pietro Bernini）善于发现年轻的潜在竞争对手，并将他们牢牢控制在自己的阴影之下。一天，一位名叫弗朗切斯科·博罗米尼（Francesco Borromini）的年轻石匠向贝尼尼展示了他的建筑草图。贝尼尼一眼就看出他的才华，立即聘请博罗米尼担任自己的助手。博罗米尼对此欣喜若狂，但这实际上只是贝尼尼为了将他留在身边而设下的圈套，以便对他进行心理操控，并让他产生自卑情结。事实上，尽管博罗米尼才华横溢，贝尼尼的名声却远胜于他。他对博罗米尼的这种策略贯穿了他的一生：例如，他担心伟大的雕塑家亚历山德罗·阿尔加迪（Alessandro Algardi）会超越自己，于是安排阿尔加迪只能担任他的助手。任何反抗贝尼尼、试图独立发展的助手，其职业生涯都将就此终结。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 42
第42条
STRIKE THE SHEPHERD
击打牧羊人
AND THE SHEEP
还有绵羊
WILL SCATTER
会散落
JUDGMENT
判断
Trouble can often be traced to a single strong individualthe stirrer, the arrogant underling, the poisoner of goodwill. If you allow such people room to operate, others will succumb to their influence. Do not wait for the troubles they cause to multiply, do not try to negotiate with themthey are irredeemable. Neutralize their influence by isolating or banishing them. Strike at the source of the trouble and the sheep will scatter.
麻烦往往源于某个强势人物——煽动者、傲慢的下属、破坏善意的人。如果你放任这些人作恶，其他人也会受到他们的影响。不要等到他们造成的麻烦不断扩大，也不要试图与他们谈判——他们无可救药。要通过孤立或驱逐来消除他们的影响力。从源头上打击麻烦，祸患自然会四散奔逃。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW I
遵守法律 I
Near the end of the sixth century B.C., the city-state of Athens overthrew the series of petty tyrants who had dominated its politics for decades. It established instead a democracy that was to last over a century, a democracy that became the source of its power and its proudest achievement. But as the democracy evolved, so did a problem the Athenians had never faced: How to deal with those who did not concern themselves with the cohesion of a small city surrounded by enemies, who did not work for its greater glory, but thought of only themselves and their own ambitions and petty intrigues The Athenians understood that these people, if left alone, would sow dissension, divide the city into factions, and stir up anxieties, all of which could lead to the ruin of their democracy.
公元前六世纪末，雅典城邦推翻了统治其政坛数十年的一系列僭主，取而代之的是一个持续了一个多世纪的民主政体。这个民主政体不仅成为雅典的权力之源，也成为其最引以为傲的成就。然而，随着民主政体的演进，一个雅典人从未面临过的问题也随之出现：如何应对那些漠视这座四面楚歌的小城邦的团结，不为城邦的荣耀而奋斗，只顾自身野心和阴谋诡计的人？雅典人明白，如果放任这些人不管，他们就会散播纷争，分裂城邦，煽动焦虑，最终导致民主的覆灭。
Violent punishment no longer suited the new, civilized order that Athens had created. Instead the citizens found another, more satisfying, and less brutal way to deal with the chronically selfish: Every year they would gather in the marketplace and write on a piece of earthenware, an ostrakon, the name of an individual they wanted to see banished from the city for ten years. If a particular name appeared on six thousand ballots, that person would instantly be exiled. If no one received six thousand votes, the person with the most ostraka recording his name would suffer the ten-year “ostracism.” This ritual expulsion became a kind of festival what a joy to be able to banish those irritating, anxiety-inducing individuals who wanted to rise above the group they should have served.
暴力惩罚已不再适合雅典建立的新兴文明秩序。于是，公民们找到了一种更令人满意、也更温和的方式来处理那些长期自私自利之徒：每年，他们都会聚集在集市上，在一块陶片（即陶片）上写下他们想要驱逐出城十年之人的名字。如果某个名字出现在六千张选票上，此人便会被立即驱逐。如果没有人获得六千张选票，那么获得最多陶片的人将遭受十年的“陶片放逐”。这种仪式性的驱逐逐渐演变成一种节日——能够驱逐那些令人厌烦、焦虑不安、妄图凌驾于他们本应服务的群体之上的人，真是一件令人欣喜的事情。
In 490 B.C., Aristides, one of the great generals of Athenian history, helped defeat the Persians at the battle of Marathon. Meanwhile, off the battlefield, his fairness as a judge had earned him the nickname “The Just.” But as the years went by the Athenians came to dislike him. He made such a show of his righteousness, and this, they believed, disguised his feelings of superiority and scorn for the common folk. His omnipresence in Athenian politics became obnoxious; the citizens grew tired of hearing him called “The Just.” They feared that this was just the type of manjudgmental, haughtywho would eventually stir up fierce divisions among them. In 482 B.C., despite Aristides' invaluable expertise in the continuing war with the Persians, they collected the ostraka and had him banished.
公元前490年，雅典历史上最伟大的将领之一阿里斯提德在马拉松战役中帮助雅典击败了波斯人。与此同时，在战场之外，他作为法官的公正无私为他赢得了“公正者”的美誉。然而，随着时间的推移，雅典人开始厌恶他。他过分强调自己的正义，而雅典人认为这掩盖了他高人一等的优越感和对平民百姓的蔑视。他在雅典政坛的无处不在令人反感；公民们厌倦了听到他被称为“公正者”。他们担心，正是这种爱评判人、傲慢自大的人最终会挑起他们之间的激烈分裂。公元前482年，尽管阿里斯提德在与波斯人的持续战争中发挥了不可估量的作用，雅典人还是没能保住他的名誉，并将他驱逐出境。
After Aristides' ostracism, the great general Themistocles emerged as the city's premier leader. But his many honors and victories went to his head, and he too became arrogant and overbearing, constantly reminding the Athenians of his triumphs in battle, the temples he had built, the dangers he had fended off. He seemed to be saying mat without him the city would come to ruin. And so, in 472 B.C., Themistocles' name was filled in on the ostraka and the city was rid of his poisonous presence.
阿里斯提德被放逐后，伟大的将军地米斯托克利崛起，成为雅典城的领袖。然而，他所获得的诸多荣誉和胜利使他骄傲自满，变得傲慢专横，不断向雅典人炫耀他在战场上的辉煌战绩、他建造的庙宇以及他击退的种种危险。他似乎在说，没有他，这座城市就会走向衰败。于是，公元前472年，地米斯托克利的名字被刻在陶片上，这座城市也摆脱了他的毒害。
The greatest political figure in fifth-century Athens was undoubtedly Pericles. Although several times threatened with ostracism, he avoided that fate by maintaining close ties with the people. Perhaps he had learned a lesson as a child from his favorite tutor, the incomparable Damon, who
公元前五世纪雅典最伟大的政治人物无疑是伯里克利。尽管他曾多次面临被放逐的威胁，但他通过与民众保持密切联系而避免了这种命运。或许他小时候就从他最喜欢的家庭教师、无与伦比的达蒙那里学到了一些东西。
The struggle now became fiercer than ever around the royal litter [of Atahualpa, king of the Incan empire]. It reeled more and more, and at length, several of the nobles who supported it having been slain, it was overturned, and the Indian prince would have come with violence to the ground, had not his fall been broken by the efforts of Pizarro and some other of the cavaliers, who caught him in their arms. The imperial borla was instantly snatched from his temples by a soldier, and the unhappy monarch, strongly secured, was removed to a neighboring building where he was carefully guarded. All attempt at resistance now ceased. The fate of the Inca [Atahualpa] soon spread over town and country. The charm that might have held the Peruvians together was dissolved. Every man thought only of his own safety. Even the [IncanJ soldiery encamped on the adjacent fields took the alarm, and, learning the fatal tidings, were seen flying in every direction before their pursuers, who in the heat of triumph showed no touch of mercy. At length night, more pitiful than man, threw her friendly mantle over the fugitives, and the
围绕着印加帝国国王阿塔瓦尔帕的王轿，争斗愈演愈烈。王轿摇摇欲坠，最终，几名扶持王轿的贵族被杀后，王轿彻底倾覆。若非皮萨罗和其他几名骑士及时出手，将阿塔瓦尔帕抱在怀中，这位印度王子恐怕早已摔倒在地。一名士兵立即从阿塔瓦尔帕的太阳穴上扯下王冠，将这位不幸的君主严加看守，转移到附近的一栋建筑中。一切抵抗都已停止。印加王阿塔瓦尔帕的命运很快传遍了城镇乡村。原本维系秘鲁人团结的纽带也随之瓦解。每个人都只想着自己的安危。就连驻扎在邻近田野的印加士兵也察觉到了警报，得知噩耗后，四散奔逃，躲避追兵。追兵们得意忘形，没有丝毫怜悯之心。最终，比人更怜悯的夜幕降临，将她友善的斗篷披在了逃亡者身上。
scattered troops of Pizarro rallied once more at the sound of the trumpet in the bloody square of Cajamarca.... [Atahualpa] was reverenced as more than a human. He was not merely the head of the state, but the point to which all its institutions converged as to a common centerthe keystone of the political fabric which must fall to pieces by its own weight when that was withdrawn. So it fared on the [execution] of Atahualpa. His death not only left the throne vacant, without any certain successor, but the manner of it announced to the Peruvian people that a hand stronger than that of their Incas had now seized the scepter, and that the dynasty of the Children of the Sun had passed away forever.
在卡哈马卡血腥广场上，号角声再次响起，皮萨罗的残余部队重新集结……[阿塔瓦尔帕]被尊崇得超越了凡人。他不仅是国家元首，更是所有国家机构汇聚的中心——政治结构的基石，一旦失去他，整个政治体系便会因自身的重量而分崩离析。阿塔瓦尔帕的[处决]正是如此。他的死不仅使王位空缺，没有确定的继承人，而且他的死也向秘鲁人民宣告：一只比印加人更强大的手已经握住了权杖，“太阳之子”王朝就此终结。
THE CONQUEST OF PERU,
征服秘鲁
William H. Prescott, 1847
威廉·H·普雷斯科特，1847年
excelled above all other Athenians in his intelligence, his musical skills, and his rhetorical abilities. It was Damon who had trained Pericles in die arts of ruling. But he, too, suffered ostracism, for his superior airs and his insulting manner toward the commoners stirred up too much resentment.
他的才智、音乐才能和雄辩能力都远超其他雅典人。正是达蒙教导伯里克利治国之道。但他自己也遭到了排斥，因为他傲慢的态度和对平民的侮辱激起了太多人的反感。
Toward the end of the century there lived a man named Hyperbolus. Most writers of the time describe him as the city's most worthless citizen: He did not care what anyone thought of him, and slandered whomever he disliked. He amused some, but irritated many more. In 417 B.C., Hyperbolus saw an opportunity to stir up anger against the two leading politicians of the time, Alcibiades and Nicias. He hoped that one of the two would be ostracized and that he would rise in mat man's place. His campaign seemed likely to succeed: The Athenians disliked Alcibiades' flamboyant and carefree lifestyle, and were wary of Nicias' wealth and aloofness. They seemed certain to ostracize one or die other. But Alcibiades and Nicias, although they were otherwise enemies, pooled their resources and managed to turn the ostracism on Hyperbolus instead. His obnoxious-ness, they argued, could only be terminated by banishment.
公元前417年，雅典城里住着一个名叫许珀波罗斯的人。当时的大多数作家都把他描述为城里最无用的公民：他毫不在乎别人怎么看他，只要不喜欢的人，他就会诽谤他们。他逗乐了一些人，但惹恼了更多的人。公元前417年，许珀波罗斯看到了一个机会，可以煽动民众对当时两位主要政治人物阿尔西比亚德斯和尼西亚斯的愤怒。他希望其中一人会被放逐，而他自己则取而代之。他的计划似乎很有可能成功：雅典人厌恶阿尔西比亚德斯浮夸放荡的生活方式，也对尼西亚斯的财富和冷漠心存戒备。他们似乎注定要放逐其中一人，或者让另一人死去。然而，阿尔西比亚德斯和尼西亚斯虽然素来不和，却联手合作，最终成功地将放逐的矛头指向了许珀波罗斯。他们认为，只有将他驱逐出境才能消除他的令人厌恶的行为。
Earlier sufferers of ostracism had been formidable, powerful men. Hyperbolus, however, was a low buffoon, and with his banishment the Athenians felt that ostracism had been degraded. And so they ended the practice that for nearly a hundred years had been one of die keys to keeping the peace within Athens.
此前被放逐的人都是令人敬畏的权贵。然而，希珀博鲁斯却是个卑微的小丑，他的放逐让雅典人感到放逐制度的尊严受到了损害。于是，他们废除了这项近百年来一直是雅典维持和平的关键之一的制度。
Interpretation
解释
The ancient Athenians had social instincts unknown todaydie passage of centuries has blunted them. Citizens in the true sense of the word, the Athenians sensed the dangers posed by asocial behavior, and saw how such behavior often disguises itself in otiier forms: the holier-than-thou attitude that silendy seeks to impose its standards on others; overweening ambition at the expense of the common good; the flaunting of superiority; quiet scheming; terminal obnoxiousness. Some of Uiese behaviors would eat away at the city's cohesion by creating factions and sowing dissension, odiers would ruin the democratic spirit by making the common citizen feel inferior and envious. The Athenians did not try to reeducate people who acted in these ways, or to absorb them somehow into the group, or to impose a violent punishment that would only create other problems. The solution was quick and effective: Get rid of them.
古雅典人拥有当今世人所不了解的社交本能——几个世纪的流逝使这种本能变得迟钝。作为真正意义上的公民，雅典人能够感知到反社会行为带来的危险，并洞察到此类行为常常以各种形式伪装：自以为是、暗中试图将自身标准强加于人的态度；不顾公共利益的野心；炫耀优越感；暗中算计；以及令人厌恶的行为。某些行为会通过制造派系和散播纷争来侵蚀城邦的凝聚力，而另一些行为则会通过使普通公民感到自卑和嫉妒来破坏民主精神。雅典人并没有试图去改造那些行为不端的人，也没有试图将他们融入群体，更没有施加只会引发其他问题的暴力惩罚。他们的解决办法既快捷又有效：清除他们。
Within any group, trouble can most often be traced to a single source, the unhappy, chronically dissatisfied one who will always stir up dissension and infect the group widi his or her ill ease. Before you know what hit you the dissatisfaction spreads. Act before it becomes impossible to disentangle one strand of misery from anodier, or to see how die whole thing started. First, recognize troublemakers by their overbearing presence, or by their complaining nature. Once you spot them do not try to reform them or appease diemmat will only make things worse. Do not attack diem, whether directly or indirecdy, for diey are poisonous in nature and
在任何群体中，麻烦往往都源于同一个人：那个总是心怀不满、长期抱怨的人。他/她会挑起纷争，并将自己的不满情绪传染给整个群体。还没等你反应过来，不满就已经蔓延开来。趁着还没来得及厘清所有问题的根源，或者还没来得及弄清一切是如何开始的，就应该采取行动。首先，要通过他们盛气凌人的表现或抱怨的性格来识别麻烦制造者。一旦发现他们，不要试图去改造他们或安抚他们，那样只会让事情变得更糟。不要直接或间接地攻击他们，因为他们本质上就是毒瘤。
will work underground to destroy you. Do as the Adienians did: Banish them before it is too late. Separate them from the group before they become the eye of a whirlpool. Do not give diem time to stir up anxieties and sow discontent; do not give them room to move. Let one person suffer so that the rest can live in peace.
他们会暗中策划毁灭你们。效仿阿迪尼亚人的做法：趁为时已晚，将他们驱逐。在他们成为漩涡中心之前，将他们与你们隔离开来。不要给他们时间煽动恐慌、散播不满；不要给他们任何行动的空间。让一个人受苦，其他人才能安居乐业。
When the tree falls, the monkeys scatter.
树倒了，猴子们四散奔逃。
Chinese saying
中国谚语
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW II
遵守法律 II
In 1296 the cardinals of die Catholic Church met in Rome to select a new pope. They chose Cardinal Gaetani, for he was incomparably shrewd; such a man would make die Vatican a great power. Taking the name Boniface VIII, Gaetani soon proved he deserved the cardinals' high opinion of him: He plotted his moves carefully in advance, and stopped at nodiing to get his way. Once in power, Boniface quickly crushed his rivals and unified the Papal States. The European powers began to fear him, and sent delegates to negotiate widi him. The German King Albrecht of Austria even yielded some territory to Boniface. All was proceeding according to the pope's plan.
1296年，天主教枢机主教们齐聚罗马，选举新教皇。他们选择了盖塔尼枢机主教，因为他足智多谋，这样的人定能使梵蒂冈成为一个强大的国家。盖塔尼取名博尼法斯八世，很快就证明了他不负枢机主教们的盛情：他事先精心策划，不只是点头示意就能达到目的。博尼法斯掌权后，迅速镇压了对手，统一了教皇国。欧洲列强开始畏惧他，纷纷派遣代表与他谈判。奥地利国王阿尔布雷希特甚至向博尼法斯割让了一些领土。一切都在按照教皇的计划进行。
One piece did not fall into place, however, and diat was Tuscany, the richest part of Italy. If Boniface could conquer Florence, Tuscany's most powerful city, die region would be his. But Florence was a proud republic, and would be hard to defeat. The pope had to play his cards skillfully.
然而，有一块拼图并未到位，那就是意大利最富饶的地区——托斯卡纳。如果博尼法斯能够征服托斯卡纳最强大的城市佛罗伦萨，这片地区就将归他所有。但佛罗伦萨是一个骄傲的共和国，难以攻克。教皇必须巧妙地周旋。
Florence was divided by two rival factions, the Blacks and die Whites. The Whites were the merchant families diat had recendy and quickly risen to power and weakh; the Blacks were the older money. Because of their popularity widi die people, die Whites retained control of the city, to the Blacks' increasing resentment. The feud between the two grew steadily more bitter.
佛罗伦萨被两个敌对派系——黑帮和白帮——所分裂。白帮是新兴的商人家族，他们迅速崛起，势力强大；黑帮则是世代相传的富人。由于白帮在民众中享有很高的声望，他们牢牢掌控着这座城市，这令黑帮日益不满。两派之间的仇恨与日俱增，愈演愈烈。
Here Boniface saw his chance: He would plot to help the Blacks take over the city, and Florence would be in his pocket. And as he studied die situation he began to focus on one man, Dante Alighieri, die celebrated writer, poet, and ardent supporter of die Whites. Dante had always been interested in politics. He believed passionately in die republic, and often chastised his fellow citizens for their lack of spine. He also happened to be the city's most eloquent public speaker. In 1300, die year Boniface began plotting to take over Tuscany, Dante's fellow citizens had voted him in to Florence's highest elected position, making him one of the city's six priors. During his six-mondi term in die post, he had stood firmly against the Blacks and against all of die pope's attempts to sow disorder.
博尼法斯看到了机会：他可以密谋帮助黑党夺取佛罗伦萨，让这座城市落入他的掌控之中。在研究局势的过程中，他开始将目光投向一个人——但丁·阿利吉耶里，这位著名的作家、诗人，也是白党的坚定支持者。但丁一直对政治很感兴趣。他坚信共和国，并经常斥责他的同胞缺乏骨气。他恰好也是城里最雄辩的演说家。1300年，也就是博尼法斯开始密谋吞并托斯卡纳的那一年，但丁的同胞们投票选举他担任佛罗伦萨的最高民选职位，使他成为该城六位执政官之一。在他担任执政官的六个月期间，他坚定地反对黑党，也反对教皇一切煽动动乱的企图。
By 1301, however, Boniface had a new plan: He called in Charles de Valois, powerful brother of die king of France, to help bring order to Tuscany. As Charles marched through northern Italy, and Florence seedied widi anxiety and fear, Dante quickly emerged as die man who could rally
然而到了1301年，博尼法斯二世有了新的计划：他召来了法国国王的弟弟、权势滔天的查理·德·瓦卢瓦，帮助他整顿托斯卡纳的秩序。查理率军横扫意大利北部，佛罗伦萨笼罩在焦虑和恐惧之中，但丁迅速崛起，成为能够振奋人心的人物。
THE WOLVES AND THE SHEEP
狼与羊
Once upon a time, the wolves sent an embassy to the sheep, desiring that there might be peace between them for the time to come. “Why,” said they, “should we be for ever waging this deadly strife Those wicked dogs are the cause of all; they are incessantly barking at us, and provoking us. Send them away, and there will be no longer any obstacle to our eternal friendship and peace.” The silly sheep listened, the dogs were dismissed, and the flock, thus deprived of their best protectors, became an easy prey to their treacherous enemy.
从前，狼群派使节去拜访绵羊，希望彼此之间能永远和平相处。“为什么，”狼群说，“我们要永远争斗不休呢？那些恶犬才是罪魁祸首；它们不停地吠叫，挑衅我们。把它们赶走，我们之间的友谊与和平就不会再有任何障碍了。” 愚蠢的绵羊们听从了狼群的劝告，恶犬被赶走了。羊群失去了最好的保护者，成了奸诈敌人的猎物。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop,
伊索
sixth century b.c.
公元前六世纪
[Themistocles's] fellow citizens reached the point at which their jealousy made them listen to any slander at his expense, and so [he] was forced to remind the assembly of his achievements until they could bear this no longer. He once said to those who were complaining of him: “Why are you tired of receiving benefits so often from the same men” Besides this he gave offense to the people when he built the temple of Artemis, for not only did he style the goddess Artemis Aristohoule, or Artemis wisest in counselwith the hint that it was he who had given the best counsel to the Athenians and the Greeksbut he chose a site for it near his own house at Melite.... So at last the Athenians banished him. They made use of the ostracism to humble his great reputation and his authority, as indeed was their habit with any whose power they regarded as oppressive, or who had risen to an eminence which they considered out of keeping with the equality of a democracy.
忒弥斯托克利的同胞们嫉妒成性，对任何诋毁他的言论都深信不疑，因此他不得不反复向民众提及自己的功绩，直到他们再也无法忍受。他曾对那些抱怨他的人说：“你们为何总是厌倦从同一批人那里得到好处？”此外，他建造阿尔忒弥斯神庙也触怒了民众，因为他不仅称女神阿尔忒弥斯为“阿里斯托霍尔”（Aristohoule），意指“最睿智的阿尔忒弥斯”，暗示是他为雅典人和希腊人提供了最佳建议，而且还选择在靠近自己位于梅利特的住所的地方建造神庙……最终，雅典人将他放逐。他们利用陶片放逐法来削弱他显赫的声望和权威，这实际上是他们对待任何他们认为权力压迫或地位与民主平等原则不符的人的惯用伎俩。
the life of
生活
themistocles,
地米斯托克利
Plutarch,
普鲁塔克
c. a.d. 46-120
公元46-120年
the people, arguing vehemently against appeasement and working desperately to arm the citizens and to organize resistance against die pope and his puppet French prince. By hook or by crook, Boniface had to neutralize Dante. And so, even as on the one hand he threatened Florence with Charles de Valois, on the other he held out the olive branch, the possibility of negotiations, hoping Dante would take the bait. And indeed the Florentines decided to send a delegation to Rome and try to negotiate a peace. To head the mission, predictably, they chose Dante.
民众强烈反对绥靖政策，并竭尽全力武装民众，组织抵抗，对抗教皇及其傀儡法国王子。博尼法斯必须想方设法阻止但丁。因此，一方面他以查理·德·瓦卢瓦威胁佛罗伦萨，另一方面又伸出橄榄枝，提出谈判的可能性，希望但丁会上钩。佛罗伦萨人果然决定派遣代表团前往罗马，尝试和平谈判。不出所料，他们选择了但丁担任代表团团长。
Some warned the poet that the wily pope was setting up a trap to lure him away, but Dante went to Rome anyway, arriving as the French army stood before the gates of Florence. He felt sure that his eloquence and reason would win the pope over and save the city. Yet when the pope met die poet and the Florentine delegates, he instandy intimidated them, as he did so many. “Fall on your knees before me!” he bellowed at their first meeting. “Submit to me! I tell you that in all truth I have nothing in my heart but to promote your peace.” Succumbing to his powerful presence, the Florentines listened as the pope promised to look after dieir interests. He then advised them to return home, leaving one of their members behind to continue the talks. Boniface signaled that the man to stay was to be Dante. He spoke with the utmost politeness, but in essence it was an order.
有人警告诗人，狡猾的教皇设下陷阱引诱他离开，但但丁还是前往罗马，抵达时，法军已兵临佛罗伦萨城下。他坚信自己的雄辩和理性能够赢得教皇的信任，拯救这座城市。然而，当教皇与诗人及佛罗伦萨代表会面时，他立刻像对待其他人一样，令他们感到畏惧。“跪下！”教皇在初次会面时咆哮道，“臣服于我！我向你们保证，我心中只有促进你们的和平。”佛罗伦萨人屈服于教皇的威严，聆听他承诺维护他们的利益。随后，教皇建议他们返回家乡，留下一名代表继续谈判。博尼法斯示意留下的人是但丁。教皇的语气极其礼貌，但本质上却是命令。
And so Dante remained in Rome. And while he and the pope continued their dialogue, Florence fell apart. With no one to rally the Whites, and with Charles de Valois using the pope's money to bribe and sow dissension, the Whites disintegrated, some arguing for negotiations, others switching sides. Facing an enemy now divided and unsure of itself, the Blacks easily destroyed them widiin weeks, exacting violent revenge on them. And once the Blacks stood firmly in power, the pope finally dismissed Dante from Rome.
于是，但丁留在了罗马。在他与教皇继续对话的同时，佛罗伦萨却分崩离析。由于无人能够团结白军，加上查理·德·瓦卢瓦利用教皇的钱财行贿挑拨离间，白军内部瓦解，一些人主张谈判，另一些人则倒戈。面对一个四分五裂、摇摆不定的敌人，黑军在短短几周内便轻易将其摧毁，并对其进行了残酷的报复。黑军牢牢掌握权力后，教皇最终将但丁逐出了罗马。
The Blacks ordered Dante to return home to face accusations and stand trial. When the poet refused, the Blacks condemned him to be burned to death if he ever set foot in Florence again. And so Dante began a miserable life of exile, wandering through Italy, disgraced in the city that he loved, never to return to Florence, even after his death.
黑衣人命令但丁返回佛罗伦萨，接受指控和审判。诗人拒绝后，黑衣人判他若再踏入佛罗伦萨，必将被处以火刑。于是，但丁开始了悲惨的流放生活，在意大利各地流浪，在他深爱的城市里蒙受耻辱，甚至死后也再未回到佛罗伦萨。
Interpretation
解释
Boniface knew that if he only had a pretext to lure Dante away, Florence would crumble. He played die oldest card in the bookthreatening with one hand while holding out the olive branch with the otherand Dante fell for it. Once the poet was in Rome, the pope kept him there for as long as it took. For Boniface understood one of the principal precepts in the game of power: One resolute person, one disobedient spirit, can turn a flock of sheep into a den of lions. So he isolated the troublemaker. Without the backbone of the city to keep them together, the sheep quickly scattered.
博尼法斯深知，只要找到一个借口引诱但丁离开，佛罗伦萨就会分崩离析。他使出了最老套的伎俩——一手威胁，一手伸出橄榄枝，但丁果然上当了。诗人抵达罗马后，教皇便将他留在那里，直到他想离开为止。因为博尼法斯深谙权力游戏的一条铁律：一个意志坚定的人，一个桀骜不驯的灵魂，就能将一群绵羊变成一群狮子。于是，他孤立了这个麻烦制造者。失去了维系城市的脊梁，这群绵羊很快就四散奔逃。
Learn the lesson: Do not waste your time lashing out in all directions at what seems to be a many-headed enemy. Find the one head that mat-
吸取教训：不要浪费时间向四面八方攻击看似多头的敌人。找到那个与你对抗的头。
tersthe person with willpower, or smarts, or, most important of all, charisma. Whatever it costs you, lure this person away, for once he is absent his powers will lose their effect. His isolation can be physical (banishment or absence from the court), political (narrowing his base of support), or psychological (alienating him from the group through slander and insinuation). Cancer begins with a single cell; excise it before it spreads beyond cure.
这个人要么意志坚定，要么聪明过人，或者，最重要的是，魅力非凡。无论付出什么代价，都要把他引开，因为一旦他离开，他的影响力就会消失。他的孤立可以是肉体上的（放逐或被逐出宫廷），政治上的（缩小他的支持基础），或是心理上的（通过诽谤和影射使他与群体疏远）。癌症始于一个细胞；在它扩散到无法治愈之前将其切除。
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
In the past, an entire nation would be ruled by a king and his handful of ministers. Only the elite had any power to play witii. Over the centuries, power has gradually become more and more diffused and democratized. This has created, however, a common misperception that groups no longer have centers of powerthat power is spread out and scattered among many people. Actually, however, power has changed in its numbers but not in its essence. There may be fewer mighty tyrants commanding the power of life and death over millions, but there remain thousands of petty tyrants ruling smaller realms, and enforcing tiieir will dirough indirect power games, charisma, and so on. In every group, power is concentrated in the hands of one or two people, for this is one area in which human nature will never change: People will congregate around a single strong personality like planets orbiting a sun.
过去，一个国家由一位国王和少数大臣统治。只有精英阶层才拥有实权。几个世纪以来，权力逐渐分散化和民主化。然而，这也造成了一种普遍的误解，认为群体不再有权力中心，权力分散在许多人手中。事实上，权力只是数量上发生了变化，但其本质并未改变。或许掌握数百万人生杀大权的强大暴君减少了，但仍然有成千上万的小暴君统治着较小的领地，并通过间接的权力游戏、个人魅力等手段来推行他们的意志。在任何群体中，权力都集中在一两个人手中，因为这是人性中永远不会改变的一点：人们会像行星围绕太阳运转一样，聚集在一位强大的领袖周围。
To labor under the illusion diat tiiis kind of power center no longer exists is to make endless mistakes, waste energy and time, and never hit the target. Powerful people never waste time. Outwardly they may play along with the gamepretending that power is shared among manybut inwardly they keep their eyes on the inevitable few in die group who hold the cards. These are die ones they work on. When troubles arise, they look for die underlying cause, the single strong character who started the stirring and whose isolation or banishment will settle die waters again.
如果继续抱持着这种权力中心已不复存在的幻想，只会犯下无休止的错误，浪费精力和时间，最终一事无成。真正有权势的人从不浪费时间。表面上，他们或许会随波逐流，假装权力在众人之间共享，但内心深处，他们始终紧盯着少数几个掌握实权的人。这些人才是他们真正关注的对象。一旦出现问题，他们就会寻找根本原因，找到那个引发骚乱的强势人物，并设法孤立或驱逐他，以平息事态。
In his family-dierapy practice, Dr. Milton H. Erickson found that if the family dynamic was unsettled and dysfunctional there was inevitably one person who was the stirrer, the troublemaker. In his sessions he would symbolically isolate tins rotten apple by seating him or her apart from the others, if only by a few feet. Slowly the odier family members would see the physically separate person as the source of their difficulty. Once you recognize who the stirrer is, pointing it out to odier people will accomplish a great deal. Understanding who controls die group dynamic is a critical realization. Remember: Stirrers dirive by hiding in the group, disguising their actions among the reactions of others. Render their actions visible and diey lose dieir power to upset.
米尔顿·H·埃里克森博士在他的家庭治疗实践中发现，如果家庭关系不稳定且功能失调，那么必然会有一个挑拨离间、制造麻烦的人。在治疗过程中，他会象征性地将这个“害群之马”隔离出来，让他/她与其他家庭成员分开坐，哪怕只是几英尺远。慢慢地，其他家庭成员会将这个被隔离的人视为问题的根源。一旦你识别出谁是挑拨离间的人，并指出这一点对其他人大有裨益。理解谁在掌控群体动力至关重要。记住：挑拨离间者通过隐藏在群体中，将自己的行为掩盖在其他人的反应之中来达到目的。一旦他们的行为暴露出来，他们就会失去扰乱秩序的能力。
A key element in games of strategy is isolating die enemy's power. In chess you try to corner the king. In die Chinese game of go you try to isolate the enemy's forces in small pockets, rendering them immobile and ineffectual. It is often better to isolate your enemies than to destroy
策略游戏的关键要素之一是孤立敌军。在国际象棋中，你试图将敌王逼入绝境。在围棋中，你则试图将敌军分散到各个小区域，使其无法移动，丧失战斗力。孤立敌人往往比摧毁敌人更有效。
themyou seem less brutal. The result, though, is the same, for in die game of power, isolation spells deadi.
你看起来没那么残暴。然而，结果却是一样的，因为在权力游戏中，孤立就意味着死亡。
The most effective form of isolation is somehow to separate your victims from their power base. When Mao Tse-tung wanted to eliminate an enemy in the ruling elite, he did not confront the person directly; he silently and stealthily worked to isolate die man, divide his allies and turn diem away from him, shrink his support. Soon the man would vanish on his own.
最有效的孤立手段莫过于设法将目标与其权力基础割裂开来。毛泽东想要铲除统治精英中的敌人时，他不会直接与此人对抗；而是暗中策划，孤立此人，离间其盟友，使其疏远，削弱其支持。很快，此人便会自行消失。
Presence and appearance have great import in die game of power. To seduce, particularly in the beginning stages, you need to be constantly present, or create die feeling that you are; if you are often out of sight, die charm will wear off. Queen Elizabedi's prime minister, Robert Cecil, had two main rivals: die queen's favorite, die Earl of Essex, and her former favorite, Sir Walter Raleigh. He contrived to send them both on a mission against Spain; with them away from the court he managed to wrap his tentacles around die queen, secure his position as her top adviser and weaken her affection for Raleigh and the earl. The lesson here is twofold: First, your absence from the court spells danger for you, and you should never leave die scene in a time of turmoil, for your absence can botii symbolize and induce a loss of power; second, and on die odier hand, luring your enemies away from the court at critical moments is a great ploy.
在权力游戏中，存在感和形象至关重要。要想吸引他人，尤其是在初期阶段，你需要时刻出现在对方面前，或者至少营造出你无处不在的氛围；如果你经常不在场，你的魅力就会消退。伊丽莎白女王的首相罗伯特·塞西尔有两个主要的竞争对手：女王的宠臣埃塞克斯伯爵和她之前的宠臣沃尔特·雷利爵士。他设法将他们二人派往西班牙执行任务；趁他们不在宫廷之际，他成功地控制了女王，巩固了自己作为女王首席顾问的地位，并削弱了女王对雷利和伯爵的感情。这其中蕴含着两层教训：首先，你离开宫廷意味着危险，在动荡时期你绝不应该离开，因为你的缺席既可能象征着权力的丧失，也可能导致权力的丧失；其次，在关键时刻将你的敌人引离宫廷是一种高明的策略。
Isolation has other strategic uses. When trying to seduce people, it is often wise to isolate them from dieir usual social context. Once isolated they are vulnerable to you, and your presence becomes magnified. Similarly, con artists often look for ways to isolate their marks from their normal social milieux, steering them into new environments in which diey are no longer comfortable. Here they feel weak, and succumb to deception more easily. Isolation, then, can prove a powerful way of bringing people under your spell to seduce or swindle diem.
孤立还有其他策略用途。在试图引诱他人时，将他们从日常社交环境中隔离出来往往是明智之举。一旦被隔离，他们就更容易受到你的控制，你的存在感也会被放大。同样，骗子也常常想方设法将目标人物从正常的社交环境中隔离出来，引导他们进入一个不再舒适的新环境。在这种环境中，他们会感到脆弱，更容易上当受骗。因此，孤立可以成为一种强大的手段，让你能够控制他人，从而达到引诱或诈骗的目的。
You will often find powerful people who have alienated themselves from the group. Perhaps their power has gone to their heads, and they consider themselves superior; perhaps they have lost the knack of communicating with ordinary folk. Remember: This makes them vulnerable. Powerful though they be, people like diis can be turned to use.
你常常会发现一些身居高位的人与群体格格不入。或许是权力冲昏了头脑，让他们自视甚高；或许是他们失去了与普通人沟通的能力。记住：这让他们变得脆弱。即便他们权势滔天，这样的人也可以被利用。
The monk Rasputin gained his power over Czar Nicholas and Czarina Alexandra of Russia through dieir tremendous isolation from the people. Alexandra in particular was a foreigner, and especially alienated from everyday Russians; Rasputin used his peasant origins to insinuate himself into her good graces, for she desperately wanted to communicate witii her subjects. Once in the court's inner circle, Rasputin made himself indispensable and attained great power. Heading straight for the center, he aimed for die one figure in Russia who commanded power (the czarina dominated her husband), and found he had no need to isolate her for the work was already done. The Rasputin strategy can bring you great power: Always search out people who hold high positions yet who find tiiem-
僧侣拉斯普京之所以能掌控俄罗斯沙皇尼古拉二世和皇后亚历山德拉，是因为他们与民众的极度隔绝。尤其是亚历山德拉，她身为外国人，与普通俄罗斯民众格格不入；拉斯普京利用自己农民出身，博得了她的欢心，因为她迫切希望与臣民沟通。一旦进入宫廷核心圈子，拉斯普京便让自己变得不可或缺，并获得了巨大的权力。他直奔权力中心，目标是俄罗斯唯一一位真正掌握实权的人物（皇后凌驾于她的丈夫之上），结果发现无需再孤立她，因为一切早已完成。拉斯普京的策略也能为你带来巨大的权力：永远寻找那些身居高位却又不愿与人交往的人。
selves isolated on the board. They are like apples falling into your lap, easily seduced, and able to catapult you into power yourself.
那些孤立于董事会之外的人，就像落入你怀里的苹果，很容易被诱惑，并能将你推上权力巅峰。
Finally, the reason you strike at the shepherd is because such an action will dishearten the sheep beyond any rational measure. When Hernando Cortes and Francisco Pizarro led their tiny forces against the Aztec and Incan empires, they did not make the mistake of fighting on several fronts, nor were they intimidated by die numbers arrayed against them; they captured the kings, Moctezuma and Atahualpa. Vast empires fell into tiieir hands. With die leader gone the center of gravity is gone; there is nothing to revolve around and everything falls apart. Aim at the leaders, bring them down, and look for the endless opportunities in the confusion that will ensue.
最后，你之所以要攻击牧羊人，是因为这种行为会极大地打击羊群的士气。当埃尔南·科尔特斯和弗朗西斯科·皮萨罗率领他们人数不多的军队对抗阿兹特克和印加帝国时，他们没有犯多线作战的错误，也没有被敌军的人数优势所吓倒；他们俘虏了国王蒙特祖玛和阿塔瓦尔帕。庞大的帝国落入了他们的手中。领袖倒下，重心就消失了；没有了可以依靠的对象，一切都分崩离析。瞄准领袖，扳倒他们，然后在随之而来的混乱中寻找无穷无尽的机会。
Image: A Flock of Fatted
图片：一群肥羊
Sheep. Do not waste precious
羊。不要浪费宝贵的资源。
time trying to steal a sheep or two; do
花时间试图偷一两只羊；做
not risk life and limb by setting upon
不要冒着生命危险去攻击
the dogs that guard the flock. Aim at the
守护羊群的狗。瞄准……
shepherd. Lure him away and the dogs
牧羊人。把他和狗引开。
will follow. Strike him down and the flock will
将会跟随。击倒他，羊群就会
scatteryou can pick them off one by one.
散落一地，你可以一个一个地把它们挑出来。
Authority: If you draw a bow, draw the strongest. If you use an arrow, use the longest. To shoot a rider, first shoot his horse. To catch a gang of bandits, first capture its leader. Just as a country has its border, so the killing of men has its limits. If the enemy's attack can be stopped [with a blow to the head], why have any more dead and wounded than necessary (Chinese poet Tu Fu, Tang dynasty, eighth century)
权威：若你拉弓，就拉最强的；若你用箭，就用最长的；要射杀骑兵，先射杀他的马；要抓捕一伙强盗，先抓住他们的首领。正如一个国家有其边界，杀戮也有其限度。如果敌人的进攻能够被阻止（一击毙命），为何要造成不必要的伤亡呢？（中国诗人杜甫，唐代，八世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
“Any harm you do to a man should be done in such a way mat you need not fear his revenge,” writes Machiavelli. If you act to isolate your enemy, make sure he lacks the means to repay the favor. If you apply this Law, in other words, apply it from a position of superiority, so that you have nothing to fear from his resentment.
马基雅维利写道：“你若要伤害他人，务必确保自己不必担心遭到报复。” 如果你采取行动孤立敌人，务必确保他无力报复。换句话说，如果你要运用这条法则，就必须占据优势地位，这样你才不必惧怕他的怨恨。
Andrew Johnson, Abraham Lincoln's successor as U.S. president, saw Ulysses S. Grant as a troublesome member of his government. So he isolated Grant, as a prelude to forcing him out. This only enraged the great general, however, who responded by forming a support base in the Republican party and going on to become the next president. It would have been far wiser to keep a man like Grant in the fold, where he could do less harm, than to make him revengeful. And so you may often find it better to keep people on your side, where you can watch them, than to risk creating an angry enemy. Keeping them close, you can secretly whit-tie away at their support base, so that when the time comes to cut them loose they will fall fast and hard without knowing what hit them.
安德鲁·约翰逊，亚伯拉罕·林肯的继任者，美国总统，视尤利西斯·S·格兰特为政府中的眼中钉。于是，他孤立格兰特，企图将其赶下台。然而，这反而激怒了这位伟大的将军，格兰特随即在共和党内建立起自己的支持基础，最终当选为下一任总统。与其激怒格兰特，让他心怀怨恨，不如将他留在自己阵营，让他少惹麻烦。因此，你常常会发现，与其冒着树立一个愤怒的敌人，不如将人留在自己身边，以便观察他们的动向。将他们留在身边，你就可以暗中削弱他们的支持基础，这样，当时机成熟，将他们抛弃时，他们就会措手不及，迅速而惨痛地倒下。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 43
第43条
WORK ON THE HEARTS AND MINDS OF OTHERS
努力赢得他人的心灵和思想
JUDGMENT
判断
Coercion creates a reaction that will eventually work against you. You must seduce others into wanting to move in your direction. A person you have seduced becomes your loyal pawn. And the way to seduce others is to operate on their individual psychologies and weaknesses. Soften up the resistant by working on their emotions, playing on what they hold dear and what they fear. Ignore the hearts and minds of others and they will grow to hate you.
胁迫只会适得其反，最终对你不利。你必须引导他人，让他们心甘情愿地向你靠拢。被你引导的人会成为你忠实的棋子。而引导他人的方法在于利用他们的心理和弱点。通过触动他们的情感，利用他们珍视的东西和恐惧，来软化那些抗拒的人。忽视他人的内心，他们最终会恨你。
Thinking of the means by which he could most effectively persuade the Persians to revolt, [Cyrus's] deliberations led him to adopt the following plan, which he found best suited to his purpose. He wrote on a roll of parchment that Astyages had appointed him to command the Persian army; then he summoned an assembly of the Persians, opened the roll in their presence and read out what he had written. “And now, he added, I have an order for you: every man is to appear on parade with a billhook. ...” The order was obeyed. All the men assembled with their billhooks, and Cyrus's next command was thai before the day was out they should clear a certain piece of rough land full of thorn-bushes, about eighteen or twenty furlongs square. This too was done, whereupon Cyrus issued the further order that they should present themselves again on the following day, after having taken a bath. Meanwhile, Cyrus collected and slaughtered all his father's goats, sheep, and oxen in preparation for entertaining the whole Persian army at a banquet, together with the best wine and bread he could procure. The next day the guests assembled, and were
为了找到最能有效说服波斯人起义的方法，居鲁士深思熟虑后，决定采取以下方案，他认为这最符合自己的目的。他在一卷羊皮纸上写道，阿斯提阿格斯任命他统领波斯军队；然后他召集波斯人开会，当着他们的面打开羊皮纸，宣读了上面的内容。“现在，”他补充道，“我有一个命令要下达：每个人都要带着镰刀列队集合……”命令被执行。所有士兵都带着镰刀集合完毕，居鲁士的下一个命令是，在当天结束之前，他们要清理一块长满荆棘的崎岖土地，大约十八到二十弗隆见方。这项任务也完成了，之后居鲁士又下令，让他们沐浴更衣后，第二天再次集合。与此同时，居鲁士收集并宰杀了他父亲所有的山羊、绵羊和牛，准备宴请整个波斯军队，并准备了最好的葡萄酒和面包。第二天，宾客们齐聚一堂，……
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Near the end of the reign of Louis XV, all of France seemed desperate for change. When the king's grandson and chosen successor, die future Louis XVI, married the fifteen-year-old daughter of die empress of Austria, die French caught a glimpse of die future diat seemed hopeful. The young bride, Marie-Antoinette, was beautiful and full of life. She instantiy changed the mood of die court, which was rank with Louis XV's debaucheries; even the common people, who had yet to see her, talked excitedly of Marie-Antoinette. The French had grown disgusted widi the series of mistresses who had dominated Louis XV, and diey looked forward to serving dieir new queen. In 1773, when Marie-Antoinette publicly rode through the streets of Paris for the first time, applauding crowds swarmed around her carriage. “How fortunate,” she wrote her mother, “to be in a position in which one can gain widespread affection at so littie cost.”
路易十五统治末期，整个法国似乎都渴望变革。当国王的孙子，也就是未来的路易十六，迎娶了奥地利皇后的十五岁女儿时，法国人看到了充满希望的未来曙光。年轻的新娘玛丽·安托瓦内特美丽动人，活力四射。她立刻改变了宫廷的氛围，此前宫廷充斥着路易十五的放荡不羁；即使是那些尚未见过她的平民百姓，也对玛丽·安托瓦内特赞不绝口。法国人早已厌倦了路易十五那些风流成性的情妇，他们渴望侍奉他们的新王后。1773年，玛丽·安托瓦内特首次公开乘坐马车穿过巴黎街头，她的马车周围挤满了欢呼雀跃的人群。 “多么幸运啊，”她写信给母亲说，“能够以如此小的代价获得广泛的喜爱。”
In 1774 Louis XV died and Louis XVI took the tiirone. As soon as Marie-Antoinette became queen she abandoned herself to die pleasures she loved die mostordering and wearing die most expensive gowns and jewelry in die realm; sporting die most elaborate hair in history, her sculpted coiffures rising as much as diree feet above her head; and dirowing a constant succession of masked balls and fetes. All of these whims she paid for on credit, never concerning herself widi die cost or who paid die bills.
1774年，路易十五驾崩，路易十六继位。玛丽·安托瓦内特一登基，便沉溺于自己最爱的享乐之中：订购并穿着当时最昂贵的礼服和珠宝；梳着史上最精致的发型，精心雕琢的发髻高耸入云，足足有三尺之高；并不断参加各种化装舞会和盛宴。所有这些奢靡之举，她都用赊账支付，从不计较花费，也从不关心谁来买单。
Marie-Antoinette's greatest pleasure was the creation and designing of a private Garden of Eden at die Petit Trianon, a chateau on die grounds of Versailles with its own woods. The gardens at die Petit Trianon were to be as “natural” as possible, including moss applied by hand to the trees and rocks. To heighten the pastoral effect, the queen employed peasant milkmaids to milk die finest-looking cows in the realm; launderers and cheese-makers in special peasant outfits she helped design; shepherds to tend sheep with silk ribbons around their necks. When she inspected die barns, she would watch her milkmaids squeezing milk into porcelain vases made at the royal ceramic works. To pass die time, Marie-Antoinette would gatiier flowers in the woods around die Petit Trianon, or watch her “good peasants” doing tiieir “chores.” The place became a separate world, its community limited to her chosen favorites.
玛丽·安托瓦内特最大的乐趣在于打造和设计她位于凡尔赛宫内的小特里亚农宫——一座拥有私人林地的城堡。小特里亚农宫的花园力求尽可能“自然”，甚至连树木和岩石上都铺满了手工苔藓。为了增强田园风情，王后雇佣了农家女工来挤全国最漂亮的奶牛；洗衣工和奶酪制作工身着她亲自设计的农家服饰；牧羊人则在羊群脖子上系着丝带。每当她视察牛棚时，都会观看女工们将牛奶挤入皇家陶瓷厂制作的瓷瓶中。闲暇时，玛丽·安托瓦内特会在小特里亚农宫周围的林地里采摘鲜花，或者观看她的“好农夫们”做着他们的“杂务”。这里仿佛成了一个与世隔绝的世界，只有她最宠爱的人才能进入。
Widi each new whim, the cost of maintaining the Petit Trianon soared. Meanwhile, France itself was deteriorating: There was famine and widespread discontent. Even socially insulated courtiers seemed with resentmentdie queen treated them like children. Only her favorites mattered, and diese were becoming fewer and fewer. But Marie-Antoinette did not concern herself widi this. Not once throughout her reign did she read a minister's report. Not once did she tour die provinces and rally the people to her side. Not once did she mingle among die Parisians, or receive a delegation from diem. She did none of tiiese tilings because as queen she felt die people owed her their affection, and she was not required to love diem in return.
随着她每一项新的心愿，小特里亚农宫的维护费用都飙升。与此同时，法国本身也在衰败：饥荒肆虐，民怨沸腾。就连那些与世隔绝的朝臣也似乎对女王将他们视作孩童而心生怨恨。只有她宠信的人才受重视，而这些人却越来越少。但玛丽·安托瓦内特对此毫不在意。在她统治期间，她从未阅读过任何大臣的报告。她从未巡视过各省，也从未动员民众支持她。她从未与巴黎市民互动，也从未接见过来自巴黎的使节。她之所以不做这些，是因为作为女王，她认为人民理应爱戴她，而她没有义务以爱来回报他们。
In 1784 die queen became embroiled in a scandal. As part of an elaborate swindle, die most expensive diamond necklace in Europe had been
1784年，女王卷入了一场丑闻。作为一场精心策划的骗局的一部分，欧洲最昂贵的钻石项链被……
purchased under her name, and during the swindlers' trial her lavish lifestyle became public: People heard about the money she spent on jewels and dresses and masked dances. They gave her the nickname “Madame Deficit,” and from then on she became the focus of the people's growing resentment. When she appeared in her box at the opera the audience greeted her witii hisses. Even the court turned against her. For while she had been running up her huge expenditures, the country was headed for ruin.
那些房产都是以她的名义购买的，在诈骗犯审判期间，她奢靡的生活方式被公之于众：人们听说了她挥霍无度地购买珠宝、华服和参加化装舞会。人们给她起了个绰号叫“赤字夫人”，从此她成了民众日益增长的怨恨的焦点。当她出现在歌剧院的包厢里时，观众们都发出嘘声。就连法庭也与她决裂。因为在她挥霍无度的同时，国家却正走向衰败。
Five years later, in 1789, an unprecedented event took place: the beginning of die French Revolution. The queen did not worrylet the people have dieir Uttle rebellion, she seemed to think; it would soon quiet down and she would be able to resume her life of pleasure. That year die people marched on Versailles, forcing the royal family to quit the palace and take residence in Paris. This was a triumph for die rebels, but it offered die queen an opportunity to heal the wounds she had opened and establish contact witii die people. The queen, however, had not learned her lesson: Not once would she leave the palace during her stay in Paris. Her subjects could rot in hell for all she cared.
五年后，1789年，一件史无前例的事件发生了：法国大革命爆发了。女王似乎并不担心民众的这场小规模叛乱；她觉得叛乱很快就会平息，她就能继续过她享乐的生活。那一年，民众进军凡尔赛宫，迫使王室离开宫殿，迁居巴黎。这对叛军来说是一次胜利，但也给了女王一个机会来弥合她所造成的创伤，并与民众建立联系。然而，女王并没有吸取教训：在巴黎期间，她一次也没有离开过宫殿。她的臣民下地狱，她根本不在乎。
In 1792 the royal couple was moved from the palace to a prison, as the revolution officially declared die end of die monarchy. The following year Louis XVI was tried, found guilty, and guillotined. As Marie-Antoinette awaited die same fate, hardly a soul came to her defensenot one of her former friends in die court, not one of Europe's odier monarchs (who, as members of dieir own countries' royal families, had all die reason in die world to show that revolution did not pay), not even her own family in Austria, including her brother, who now sat on the throne. She had become the world's pariah. In October of 1793, she finally knelt at the guillotine, unrepentant and defiant to die bitter end.
1792年，随着革命正式宣告君主制的终结，这对皇室夫妇被从宫殿转移到监狱。次年，路易十六受审、被判有罪并被送上断头台。玛丽·安托瓦内特等待着同样的命运，却几乎无人为她辩护——无论是她昔日在宫廷中的朋友，还是欧洲其他君主（他们作为各自国家皇室成员，有充分的理由表明革命毫无益处），甚至连她在奥地利的家人，包括如今已登上王位的哥哥，都对她避之不及。她成了世人唾弃的对象。1793年10月，她最终跪在断头台前，毫无悔意，执拗地走向了悲惨的结局。
Interpretation
解释
From early on, Marie-Antoinette acquired the most dangerous of attitudes: As a young princess in Austria she was endlessly flattered and cajoled. As die future queen of the French court she was the center of everyone's attention. She never learned to charm or please other people, to become attuned to dieir individual psychologies. She never had to work to get her way, to use calculation or cunning or die arts of persuasion. And like everyone who is indulged from an early age, she evolved into a monster of in-sensitivity.
玛丽·安托瓦内特从小就养成了最危险的习性：在奥地利做公主时，她被无休止地奉承和哄骗；成为未来的法国王后后，她更是万众瞩目的焦点。她从未学会如何取悦他人，如何了解他人的心理。她从未需要付出努力去达成目的，也从未需要运用算计、狡诈或任何说服的技巧。就像所有从小被溺爱的人一样，她最终变成了一个冷酷无情的怪物。
Marie-Antoinette became the focus of an entire country's dissatisfaction because it is so infuriating to meet with a person who makes no effort to seduce you or attempt to persuade you, even if only for die purpose of deception. And do not imagine diat she represents a bygone era, or diat she is even rare. Her type is today more common than ever. Such types live in dieir own bubbletiiey seem to feel tiiey are born kings and queens, and that attention is owed them. They do not consider anyone else's nature, but bulldoze over people with the self-righteous arrogance of a Marie-Antoinette. Pampered and indulged as children, as adults tiiey still believe
玛丽·安托瓦内特之所以成为全国不满的焦点，是因为遇到一个既不刻意讨好你，也不试图说服你，哪怕只是为了欺骗你的人，实在令人恼火。别以为她代表着一个逝去的时代，或者她很罕见。如今，像她这样的人比以往任何时候都多。这类人生活在自己的小世界里，似乎觉得自己生来就是国王或王后，理应受到所有人的关注。他们不考虑他人的感受，像玛丽·安托瓦内特那样，以自以为是的傲慢态度践踏他人。他们从小被娇惯，长大后依然如此。
told to sit down on the grass and enjoy themselves. After the meal Cyrus asked them which they preferred yesterday's work or today's amusement; and they replied that it was indeed a far cry from the previous day's misery to their present pleasures. This was the answer which Cyrus wanted; he seized upon it at once and proceeded to lay bare what he had in mind. “Men of Persia,” he said, “listen to me: obey my orders, and you will be able to enjoy a thousand pleasures as good as this without ever turning your hands to menial labor; but, if you disobey, yesterday 's task will be the pattern of innumerable others you will be forced to perform. Take my advice and win your freedom. 1 am the man destined to undertake your liberation, and it is my belief that you are a match for the Medes in war as in everything else. It is the truth I tell you. Do not delay, but fling off the yoke of Astyages at once.”
他们被吩咐坐在草地上尽情享用。饭后，居鲁士问他们更喜欢昨天的劳作还是今天的娱乐；他们回答说，与昨天的苦难相比，今天的快乐简直天壤之别。这正是居鲁士想要的答案；他立刻抓住这一点，并开始阐述自己的意图。“波斯人，”他说，“听我说：服从我的命令，你们就能享受到无数像这样的快乐，而无需再从事任何苦役；但是，如果你们不服从，昨天的劳作将成为你们被迫重复的无数苦役的模板。听从我的劝告，赢得你们的自由。我就是注定要解放你们的人，我相信你们在战争中，在其他任何方面，都能与米底人匹敌。我说的都是实话。不要犹豫，立刻摆脱阿斯提阿格斯的枷锁。”
The Persians had long resented their subjection to the Medes. At last they had found a leader, and welcomed with enthusiasm the prospect of liberty.... On the present occasion the Persians under Cyrus rose against the Medes and from then onwards were masters of Asia.
波斯人长期以来一直不满于受米底人的统治。最终，他们找到了领袖，并欣喜地迎接自由的曙光……这一次，波斯人在居鲁士的领导下起兵反抗米底人，从此成为亚洲的霸主。
the histories, Herodotus, fifth century b.c..
《历史》，希罗多德，公元前五世纪。
'I UK
“我英国
The north wind and the
北风和
sun were disputing
太阳正在争论
which was the stronger,
哪个更强？
and agreed to

victor whichever of

traveler of his clothing.
旅行者穿着他的衣服。
The wind tried first.
风率先尝试了。
But its violent gusts
但它的狂风
only made the man
只造就了这个人
hold his clothes tightly
他紧紧抓住自己的衣服

cold made him so

他感到很不自在。
put on an extra wrap.

最终，风
got tired of it and
厌倦了，
handed him over to the

太阳。太阳首先升起。
with a moderate

温暖，这使得

那人脱下他的

fiercely, till, unable

FABLES,
寓言故事
Aesop, sixth century b.c.
伊索，公元前六世纪
that everything must come to them; convinced of their own charm, they make no effort to charm, seduce, or gently persuade.
他们认为一切都必须主动找上门来；他们深信自己的魅力，因此不费心思去讨好、诱惑或温柔地劝说。
In the realm of power, such attitudes are disastrous. At all times you must attend to those around you, gauging their particular psychology, tailoring your words to what you know will entice and seduce them. This requires energy and art. The higher your station, the greater the need to remain attuned to the hearts and minds of those below you, creating a base of support to maintain you at the pinnacle. Without that base, your power will teeter, and at the slightest change of fortune those below will gladly assist in your fall from grace.
在权力领域，这种态度是灾难性的。你必须时刻关注周围的人，揣摩他们的心理，并根据他们的喜好调整言辞，以博取他们的好感。这需要精力和技巧。你的地位越高，就越需要了解下属的内心想法，建立起稳固的后盾，才能让你始终屹立于权力之巅。没有这个后盾，你的权力就会摇摇欲坠，一旦形势稍有变化，下属就会乐于助你跌落神坛。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
In A.D. 225, Chuko Liang, master strategist and chief minister to the ruler of Shu in ancient China, confronted a dangerous situation. The kingdom of Wei had mounted an all-out attack on Shu from the north. More dangerous still, Wei had formed an alliance with the barbarous states to the south of Shu, led by King Menghuo. Chuko Liang had to deal with this second menace from the south before he could hope to fend off Wei in the north.
公元225年，蜀国大臣朱可亮面临着严峻的形势。魏国从北方对蜀国发动了全面进攻。更危险的是，魏国还与蜀国南方的蛮族诸侯国结盟，其中以孟隍王为首。朱可亮必须先平定南方的威胁，才能有希望抵御北方的魏国。
As Chuko Liang prepared to march south against the barbarians, a wise man in his camp offered him advice. It would be impossible, this man said, to pacify the region by force. Liang would probably beat Menghuo, but as soon as he headed north again to deal with Wei, Menghuo would reinvade. “It is better to win hearts,” said the wise man, “than cities; better to battie with hearts than with weapons. I hope you will succeed in winning the hearts of these people.” “You read my thoughts,” responded Chuko Liang.
楚可梁准备南下讨伐蛮族时，营中一位智者向他提出建议。智者说，武力征服这片地区是不可能的。梁或许能击败孟火，但只要他再次北上对付魏国，孟火就会卷土重来。“与其攻城略地，不如赢得民心；与其兵器相搏，不如以情取胜。我希望你能赢得这些百姓的民心。”“你真是说到我心坎里了。”楚可梁答道。
As Liang expected, Menghuo launched a powerful attack. But Liang laid a trap and managed to capture a large part of Menghuo's army, including the king himself. Instead of punishing or executing his prisoners, however, he separated the soldiers from their king, had their shackles removed, regaled them with food and wine, and then addressed them. “You are all upright men,” he said. “I believe you all have parents, wives, and children waiting for you at home. They are doubtless shedding bitter tears at your fate. I am going to release you, so that you can return home to your loved ones and comfort them.” The men thanked Liang with tears in their eyes; then he sent for Menghuo. “If I release you,” asked Liang, “what will you do” “I will pull my army together again,” answered the king, “and lead it against you to a decisive battle. But if you capture me a second time, I will bow to your superiority.” Not only did Liang order Menghuo released, he gave him a gift of a horse and saddle. When angry lieutenants wondered why he did this, Liang told them, “I can capture that man as easily as I can take something out of my pocket. I am trying to win his heart. When I do, peace will come of itself here in the south.”
正如梁所料，孟火发动了猛烈的进攻。但梁设下陷阱，俘虏了孟火军队的大部分兵力，包括孟火王本人。然而，梁并没有惩罚或处死这些俘虏，而是将士兵们与孟火王分开，解开了他们的镣铐，款待他们，然后对他们说：“你们都是正直的人，”他说，“我相信你们的家中都有父母、妻子和孩子在等着你们。他们一定在为你们的遭遇而流下痛苦的眼泪。我要释放你们，让你们能够回家与亲人团聚，安慰他们。”士兵们含着泪感谢梁；梁随后召见了孟火。“如果我释放了你，”梁问，“你打算做什么？”“我会重新集结军队，”孟火王回答说，“率领军队与你决一死战。但如果你再次俘虏我，我将臣服于你的威严。”梁不仅下令释放了孟火王，还赠予他一匹骏马和一副马鞍。当愤怒的副官们质问他为何这样做时，梁告诉他们：“抓捕那个人就像从口袋里掏东西一样容易。我只是想赢得他的心。一旦我做到了，南方自然就会和平。”
As Menghuo had said he would, he attacked again. But his own officers, whom Liang had treated so well, rebelled against him, captured him, and turned him over to Liang, who asked him again die same question as
正如孟火所言，他再次发动进攻。但他手下那些被梁武善待的部下却反叛了他，俘虏了他，并将他交给梁武。梁武再次向他提出了同样的问题。
before. Menghuo replied that he had not been beaten fairly, but merely betrayed by his own officers; he would fight again, but if captured a third time he would bow to Liang's superiority.
孟火回答说，他并非被公平击败，而是被自己的部下出卖；他会再次战斗，但如果第三次被俘，他将向梁的统治低头。
Over the following months Liang outwitted Menghuo again and again, capturing him a third, a fourth, and a fifth time. On each occasion Meng-huo's troops grew more dissatisfied. Liang had treated mem with respect; they had lost their heart for fighting. But every time Chuko Liang asked Menghuo to yield, the great king would come up with another excuse: You tricked me, I lost through bad luck, on and on. If you capture me again, he would promise, I swear I will not betray you. And so Liang would let him go.
接下来的几个月里，梁祖屡次智胜孟火，第三次、第四次、第五次将他俘虏。孟火的军队每次都更加不满。梁祖待他们十分恭敬，他们早已丧失了战斗的斗志。但每当梁祖要求孟火投降时，这位大王总会找各种借口：你欺骗了我，我运气不好输了，等等。他发誓，如果你再俘虏我，我发誓绝不背叛你。于是梁祖便会放他走。
When he captured Menghuo for the sixth time, he asked the king the same question again. “If you capture me a sevendi time,” die king replied, “I shall give you my loyalty and never rebel again.” “Very well,” said Liang. “But if I capture you again, I will not release you.”
当他第六次俘虏孟火时，他又问了王同样的问题。“如果你能俘虏我七次，”王答道，“我将效忠于你，永不再叛。”“很好，”梁说，“但如果我再次俘虏你，我绝不会放了你。”
Now Menghuo and his soldiers fled to a far corner of their kingdom, the region of Wuge. Defeated so many times, Menghuo had only one hope left: He would ask the help of King Wutugu of Wuge, who had an immense and ferocious army. Wutugu's warriors wore an armor of tightly woven vines soaked in oil, then dried to an impenetrable hardness. Wifh Menghuo at his side, Wutugu marched diis mighty army against Liang, and this time the great strategist seemed frightened, leading his men in a hurried retreat. But he was merely leading Wutugu into a trap: He cornered the king's men in a narrow valley, then lit fires set all around them. When the fires reached the soldiers Wutugu's whole army burst into flamethe oil in their armor, of course, being highly flammable. All of them perished.
孟火和他的士兵逃到了王国的偏远角落——武格地区。屡战屡败的孟火只剩下一个希望：他要向武格王武图古求助，武图古拥有一支庞大而凶猛的军队。武图古的战士身穿一种用藤蔓紧密编织而成的盔甲，藤蔓浸透油后晾干，变得坚不可摧。在孟火的协助下，武图古率领这支强大的军队向梁国进军。这一次，这位伟大的战略家似乎有些害怕，率领士兵仓皇撤退。但他其实是在设下陷阱：武图古将国王的军队围困在一个狭窄的山谷中，然后在他们周围点燃了大火。当火焰蔓延到士兵身上时，武图古的整支军队瞬间燃起熊熊大火——盔甲上的油当然是易燃的。他们全部葬身火海。
Liang had managed to separate Menghuo and his entourage from the carnage in the valley, and the king found himself a captive for the seventh time. After this slaughter Liang could not bear to face his prisoner again. He sent a messenger to the captured king: “He has commissioned me to release you. Mobilize another army against him, if you can, and try once more to defeat him.” Sobbing, the king fell to the ground, crawled to Liang on his hands and knees, and prostrated himself at his feet. “Oh great minister,” cried Menghuo, “yours is the majesty of Heaven. We men of the south will never again offer resistance to your rule.” “Do you now yield” asked Liang. “I, my sons, and my grandsons are deeply moved by Your Honor's boundless, life-giving mercy. How could we not yield”
梁将孟火及其随从从山谷的屠杀中隔离开来，孟火第七次沦为俘虏。经历了这场屠杀，梁再也无法忍受面对俘虏。他派人去见被俘的孟火：“他已嘱咐我释放你。你若能，就再召集一支军队来对抗他，再试一次。”孟火泣不成声，跪倒在地，手脚并用地爬到梁面前，匍匐在他脚下。“伟大的臣子啊！”孟火喊道，“您拥有天上的威严。我们南方人再也不会反抗您的统治了。”“你现在投降了吗？”梁问道。“我和我的儿子、我的孙子们都深受您无私仁慈的感动。我们怎能不投降呢？”
Liang honored Menghuo with a great banquet, reestablished him on the throne, restored his conquered lands to his rule, then returned north with his army, leaving no occupying force. Liang never came backhe had no need to: Menghuo had become his most devoted and unshakable ally.
梁为孟火设下盛大宴席，拥立他复辟，归还他征服的土地，然后率军北上，不留任何占领军。梁再也没有回来——他无需回来：孟火已成为他最忠诚、最坚定的盟友。
Interpretation
解释
Chuko Liang had two options: Try to defeat the barbarians in the south with one crushing blow, or patiendy and slowly win them to his side over time. Most people more powerful man their enemy grab the first option and never consider die second, but the truly powerful think far ahead: The
楚可梁有两个选择：要么一举歼灭南方的蛮族，要么耐心等待，慢慢地将他们拉拢到自己阵营。大多数比敌人强大的人都会选择第一种方案，根本不会考虑第二种，但真正强大的人会考虑得更长远：
The men who have changed the universe have never gotten there by working on leaders, but rather by moving the masses. Working on leaders is the method of intrigue and only leads to secondary results. Working on the masses, however, is the stroke of genius that changes the face of the world.
那些改变世界的人，从来都不是靠操纵领导人，而是靠动员群众。操纵领导人是阴谋诡计，只能带来次要的结果。而动员群众，才是改变世界格局的妙招。
Napoleon Bonaparte, 1769-1821
拿破仑·波拿巴，1769-1821年
This long and painful pursuit of Dariusfor in eleven days he marched 33 hundred furlongsharassed his soldiers so that most of them were ready to give it up, chiefly for want of water. While they were in this distress, it happened that some Macedonians who had fetched water in skins upon their mules from a river they had found out came about noon to the place where Alexander was, and seeing him almost choked with thirst, presently filled a helmet and offered it him.... Then he took the helmet into his hands, and looking round about, when he saw all those who were near him stretching their heads out and looking earnestly after the drink, he returned it again with thanks
这场漫长而艰辛的追击——亚历山大在十一天内行进了三千三百弗隆——令他的士兵疲惫不堪，以至于他们中的大多数人都想放弃，主要原因是缺水。就在他们如此痛苦的时候，恰巧一些马其顿人用骡子驮着皮囊，从他们找到的一条河里取了水，大约在中午时分来到亚历山大所在的地方。他们看到亚历山大几乎渴得喘不过气来，便立即装满一顶头盔递给他……亚历山大接过头盔，环顾四周，看到周围的人都伸长脖子，渴望着水，便感激地把头盔还给了他们。
without tasting a drop of it. “For,”said he, “if I alone should drink, the rest will be out of heart.” The soldiers no sooner took notice of his temperance and magnanimity upon this occasion, but they one and all cried out to him to lead them forward boldly, and began whipping on their horses. For whilst they had such a king they said they defied both weariness and thirst, and looked upon themselves to be little less than immortal.
他一滴水也没喝。“因为，”他说，“如果只有我一个人喝，其他人都会失去斗志。”士兵们立刻注意到他此刻的节制和宽宏大量，便齐声高呼，让他带领他们勇往直前，并开始鞭策战马。他们说，有了这样一位君主，他们便能无惧疲惫和干渴，觉得自己几乎是不死之身。
the life of
生活
alexander tiik great,
亚历山大大帝池塘
Plutarch,
普鲁塔克
c. a. n. 46-120
c. a. n. 46-120
first option may be quick and easy, but over time it brews ugly emotions in the hearts of the vanquished. Their resentment turns to hatred; such animosity keeps you on edgeyou spend your energy protecting what you have gained, growing paranoid and defensive. The second option, though more difficult, not only brings you peace of mind, it converts a potential enemy into a pillar of support.
第一种方法或许快捷简便，但久而久之会在战败者心中滋生恶毒的情绪。他们的怨恨会演变成仇恨；这种敌意会让你时刻处于紧张状态——你耗费精力去保护你所获得的一切，变得疑神疑鬼、防备心极强。第二种方法虽然更难，但不仅能让你内心平静，还能将潜在的敌人转化为你的支柱。
In all your encounters, take a step backtake the time to calculate and attune yourself to your targets' emotional makeup and psychological weaknesses. Force will only strengthen their resistance. With most people the heart is the key: They are like children, ruled by their emotions. To soften them up, alternate harshness with mercy. Play on their basic fears, and also their lovesfreedom, family, etc. Once you break them down, you will have a lifelong friend and fiercely loyal ally.
在所有交往中，都要退后一步，花时间去揣摩并了解目标的心理弱点和情感构成。强硬只会增强他们的抵抗力。对大多数人来说，心才是关键：他们就像孩子一样，受情绪左右。要想软化他们的心，就要交替运用严厉和仁慈。利用他们最基本的恐惧，以及他们对自由、家庭等的渴望。一旦你成功瓦解了他们的心理防线，你就会拥有一个终生的朋友和一位无比忠诚的盟友。
Governments saw men only in mass; but our men, being irregulars, were not
各国政府只看到成群的士兵；但我们的士兵是非正规军，他们并非如此。
formations, but individuals. . . . Our kingdoms lay in each man's mind.
组织形式固然重要，但个人才是关键……我们的王国存在于每个人的思想之中。
Seven Pillars ofWisdom, T. E. Lawrence, 1888-1935
《智慧七柱》，T·E·劳伦斯，1888-1935
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
