In the game of power, you are surrounded by people who have absolutely no reason to help you unless it is in their interest to do so. And if you have nothing to offer their self-interest, you are likely to make them hostile, for tfiey will see in you just one more competitor, one more waster of their time. Those that overcome this prevailing coldness are the ones who find the key that unlocks the stranger's heart and mind, seducing him into their corner, if necessary softening him up for a punch. But most people never learn this side of die game. When they meet someone new, rather than stepping back and probing to see what makes this person unique, they talk about themselves, eager to impose their own willpower and prejudices. They argue, boast, and make a show of their power. They may not know it but they are secretly creating an enemy, a resister, because there is no more infuriating feeling than having your individuality ignored, your own psychology unacknowledged. It makes you feel lifeless and resentful.
在权力游戏中，你身边的人除非出于自身利益，否则根本没有理由帮助你。如果你无法为他们带来任何利益，你很可能会招致他们的敌意，因为他们只会把你视为又一个竞争对手，又一个浪费他们时间的人。那些能够克服这种普遍存在的冷漠的人，才能找到打开陌生人心灵之门的钥匙，将他们引诱到自己阵营，必要时甚至会先削弱他们的力量，以便一击制胜。但大多数人永远学不会这套游戏规则。当他们遇到新朋友时，他们不会退后一步，探究对方的独特之处，而是滔滔不绝地谈论自己，急于将自己的意志和偏见强加于人。他们争辩、吹嘘，炫耀自己的权力。他们或许没有意识到，自己正在暗中树立一个敌人，一个阻力，因为没有什么比个性被忽视、心理被漠视更令人恼火的了。这会让你感到麻木和怨恨。
Remember: The key to persuasion is softening people up and breaking them down, gently. Seduce them with a two-pronged approach: Work on their emotions and play on their intellectual weaknesses. Be alert to both what separates them from everyone else (their individual psychology) and what they share with everyone else (their basic emotional responses). Aim at the primary emotionslove, hate, jealousy. Once you move their emotions you have reduced their control, making them more vulnerable to persuasion.
记住：说服的关键在于循序渐进地软化和瓦解对方的防线。要用双管齐下的方法来吸引他们：既要触动他们的情感，又要利用他们的认知弱点。既要留意他们与众不同的地方（他们的个体心理），也要留意他们与其他人共同的地方（他们的基本情感反应）。瞄准最基本的情感——爱、恨、嫉妒。一旦你触动了他们的情感，就削弱了他们的控制力，使他们更容易被说服。
When Chuko Liang wanted to dissuade an important general of a rival kingdom from entering into an alliance with Ts'ao Ts'ao, Liang's dreaded enemy, he did not detail Ts'ao Ts'ao's cruelty, or attack him on moral grounds. Instead Liang suggested that Ts'ao Ts'ao was really after the gen-
当朱可梁想要劝阻敌国的一位重要将领与他所惧怕的敌人曹操结盟时，他并没有详述曹操的残暴，也没有从道德层面攻击他。相反，朱可梁暗示曹操真正想要的是这位将军。
eral's beautiful young wife. This hit die general in the gut, and won him over. Mao Tse-tung similarly always appealed to popular emotions, and spoke in the simplest terms. Educated and well-read himself, in his speeches he used visceral metaphors, voicing the public's deepest anxieties and encouraging diem to vent meir frustrations in public meetings. Radier than arguing die practical aspects of a particular program, he would describe how it would affect them on die most primitive, down-to-earth level. Do not believe diat diis approach works only with die illiterate and unschooledit works on one and all. All of us are mortal and face the same dreadful fate, and all of us share die desire for attachment and belonging. Stir up these emotions and you captivate our hearts.
埃拉尔年轻貌美的妻子。这深深打动了这位将军，赢得了他的心。毛泽东也同样善于唤起民众的情感，并以最浅显易懂的方式进行演讲。他本人受过良好的教育，博览群书，在演讲中运用生动形象的比喻，表达民众最深层的焦虑，并鼓励他们在公共集会上发泄不满。他更倾向于描述某个方案的实际操作层面，而不是从最原始、最实际的角度去探讨它将如何影响民众。不要以为这种方法只对文盲和未受过教育的人有效，它适用于所有人。我们都是凡人，都面临着同样的命运，我们也都渴望归属感和依恋。唤起这些情感，你就能俘获我们的心。
The best way to do this is with a dramatic jolt, of the kind that Chuko Liang created when he fed and released prisoners who expected only the worst from him. Shaking diem to the core, he softened their hearts. Play on contrasts like this: Push people to despair, dien give them relief. If diey expect pain and you give them pleasure, you win meir hearts. Creating pleasure of any kind, in fact, will usually bring you success, as will allaying fears and providing or promising security.
最好的办法就是制造戏剧性的冲击，就像楚可梁那样，他给那些对他抱有最坏期望的囚犯提供食物并释放他们。他震撼了他们的内心，软化了他们的心。要善用这种对比：先把人逼到绝望，再给他们带来解脱。如果他们期待痛苦，而你却给他们快乐，你就能赢得他们的心。事实上，创造任何形式的快乐通常都会带来成功，消除恐惧、提供或承诺安全感也是如此。
Symbolic gestures are often enough to win sympadiy and goodwill. A gesture of self-sacrifice, for examplea show that you suffer as those around you dowill make people identify witii you, even if your suffering is symbolic or minor and dieirs is real. When you enter a group, make a gesture of goodwill; soften the group up for the harsher actions that will follow later.
象征性的举动往往足以赢得同情和好感。例如，自我牺牲的举动——表现出你和周围的人一样承受痛苦——会让人们产生认同感，即使你的痛苦只是象征性的或微不足道的，而他们的痛苦却是真实的。当你加入一个群体时，先做出善意的举动；这能为之后更严厉的行动缓和群体的情绪。
When T. E. Lawrence was fighting the Turks in die deserts of die Middle East during World War I, he had an epiphany: It seemed to him that conventional warfare had lost its value. The old-fashioned soldier was lost in the enormous armies of the time, in which he was ordered about like a lifeless pawn. Lawrence wanted to turn this around. For him, every soldier's mind was a kingdom he had to conquer. A committed, psychologically motivated soldier would fight harder and more creatively than a puppet.
当T·E·劳伦斯在一战期间于中东沙漠与土耳其军队作战时，他突然顿悟：在他看来，传统的战争方式已经失去了价值。老式的士兵在当时庞大的军队中迷失了方向，如同行尸走肉般被指挥。劳伦斯决心扭转这种局面。在他看来，每个士兵的内心都是一个需要征服的王国。一个意志坚定、心理素质极佳的士兵，会比一个傀儡更加顽强、更具创造力地战斗。
Lawrence's perception is still more true in die world today, where so many of us feel alienated, anonymous, and suspicious of authority, all of which makes overt power plays and force even more counterproductive and dangerous. Instead of manipulating lifeless pawns, make mose on your side convinced and excited by die cause you have enlisted diem in; this will not only make your work easier but it will also give you more leeway to deceive tilem later on. And to accomplish diis you need to deal with tiieir individual psychologies. Never clumsily assume that the tactic that worked on one person will necessarily work on anodier. To find tile key diat will motivate diem, first get tiiem to open up. The more they talk, die more they reveal about their likes and dislikesdie handles and levers to move diem widi.
劳伦斯的见解在当今世界依然适用，因为我们中的许多人感到疏离、匿名，并且对权威抱有怀疑，所有这些都使得公开的权力游戏和强迫行为更加适得其反，也更加危险。与其操纵毫无生气的棋子，不如让更多人相信你，并因你的招募而兴奋不已；这不仅会让你的工作更轻松，还能让你在日后有更多机会欺骗他们。而要做到这一点，你需要了解他们的个人心理。千万不要想当然地认为对一个人有效的策略对另一个人也一定有效。要找到能够激励他们的关键策略，首先要让他们敞开心扉。他们说得越多，就越会透露自己的喜好和厌恶——这就是引导他们的把柄和杠杆。
The quickest way to secure people's minds is by demonstrating, as simply as possible, how an action will benefit them. Self-interest is the
赢得人心的最快方法是尽可能简单地展示某项行动将如何使他们受益。利己主义是……
strongest motive of all: A great cause may capture minds, but once die first flush of excitement is over, interest will flagunless there is something to be gained. Self-interest is the solider foundation. The causes that work best use a noble veneer to cover a blatant appeal to self-interest; the cause seduces but the self-interest secures the deal.
最强大的动机是：伟大的事业或许能激发人们的热情，但最初的兴奋过后，除非有利可图，否则人们的兴趣就会消退。私利才是根本。那些最成功的事业，往往披着高尚的外衣，掩盖其赤裸裸的私利诉求；事业本身具有吸引力，但私利才是促成交易的关键。
The people who are best at appealing to people's minds are often artists, intellectuals, and those of a more poetic nature. This is because ideas are most easily communicated through metaphors and imagery. It is always good policy, men, to have in your pocket at least one artist or intellectual who can appeal concretely to people's minds. Kings have always kept a stable of writers in meir barn: Frederick the Great had his Voltaire (until tiiey quarreled and separated), Napoleon won over Goethe. Conversely, Napoleon Ill's alienation of writers such as Victor Hugo, whom he exiled from France, contributed to his growing unpopularity and eventual downfall. It is dangerous, then, to alienate those who have powers of expression, and useful to pacify and exploit them.
最善于打动人心的人往往是艺术家、知识分子以及那些更具诗意的人。这是因为思想最容易通过比喻和意象来传达。各位，身边至少有一位能以具体方式打动人心的艺术家或知识分子，永远都是明智之举。历代君王都喜欢在自己的宫廷里养着一群作家：腓特烈大帝曾拥有伏尔泰（直到两人反目成仇），拿破仑也曾与歌德合作。反之，拿破仑三世疏远了像维克多·雨果这样的作家，并将他们驱逐出法国，这加剧了他日益增长的不得人心，最终导致了他的垮台。因此，疏远那些拥有表达能力的人是危险的，而安抚和利用他们则是有益的。
Finally, learn to play the numbers game. The wider your support base the stronger your power. Understanding that one alienated, disaffected soul can spark a blaze of discontent, Louis XIV made sure to endear himself to die lowest members of his staff. You too must constantiy win over more allies on all levelsa time will inevitably come when you will need diem.
最后，要学会玩转人脉。你的支持基础越广，你的权力就越大。路易十四深知，一个心怀不满的人就能引发一场轩然大波，因此他竭力讨好最底层的幕僚，甚至让他们为国捐躯。你也必须不断在各个层面赢得更多盟友——总有一天，你会需要他们的支持。
Image: The Keyhole. People build walls to keep you out; never force your way in you will find only more walls within walls. There are doors in these walls, doors to the heart and mind, and they have tiny keyholes. Peer through the keyhole, find the key that opens the door, and you have access to their will with no ugly signs of forced entry.
图片：钥匙孔。人们筑起高墙将你拒之门外；切勿强行闯入，否则只会发现层层叠叠的墙。这些墙上其实有门，通往心灵的门，门上都留有细小的钥匙孔。透过钥匙孔窥视，找到开启这扇门的钥匙，你便能洞悉他们的意志，而不会留下任何强行闯入的痕迹。
Authority: The difficulties in the way of persuasion lie in my knowing the heart of the persuaded in order thereby to fit my wording into it. . . . For this reason, whoever attempts persuasion before the throne, must carefully observe the sovereign's feelings of love and hate, his secret wishes and fears, before he can conquer his heart. (Han-fei-tzu, Chinese philosopher, third century B.C.)
权威：劝说的难点在于了解被劝说者的内心，从而使我的言辞契合其心意……因此，凡欲劝说君主者，必须仔细观察君主的爱恨情仇、隐秘的愿望与恐惧，方能赢得其心。（韩非子，中国哲学家，公元前三世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
There is no possible reversal to this Law.
这条法律没有逆转的可能。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 44
第44条法律
DISARM AND INFURIATE WITH THE MIRROR EFFECT
利用镜像效应解除武装并激怒对方
JUDGMENT
判断
The mirror reflects reality, but it is also the perfect tool for deception: When you mirror your enemies, doing exactly as they do, they cannot figure out your strategy. The Mirror Effect mocks and humiliates them, making them overreact. By holding up a mirror to their psyches, you seduce them with the illusion that you share their values; by holding up a mirror to their actions, you teach them a lesson. Few can resist the power of the Mirror Effect.
镜子反映现实，但它也是欺骗的完美工具：当你模仿敌人，做着和他们一模一样的事情时，他们就无法识破你的策略。“镜像效应”嘲弄并羞辱他们，使他们反应过度。通过映照他们的内心，你让他们产生一种错觉，以为你与他们拥有相同的价值观；通过映照他们的行为，你给他们上了一课。很少有人能抵挡住“镜像效应”的力量。
MIRROR EFFECTS: Preliminary Typology
镜像效应：初步类型学
Mirrors have the power to disturb us. Gazing at our reflection in the mirror, we most often see what we want to seethe image of ourselves with which we are most comfortable. We tend not to look too closely, ignoring the wrinkles and blemishes. But if we do look hard at the reflected image, we sometimes feel that we are seeing ourselves as others see us, as a person among other people, an object rather than a subject. That feeling makes us shudderwe see ourselves, but from the outside, minus the thoughts, spirit, and soul that fill our consciousness. We are a thing.
镜子有一种令人不安的力量。凝视镜中的自己，我们通常看到的只是我们想看到的——我们最熟悉、最自在的形象。我们往往不会仔细观察，忽略皱纹和瑕疵。但如果我们认真审视镜中的自己，有时会感觉自己仿佛置身于他人的视角，如同芸芸众生中的一个个体，一个客体而非主体。这种感觉令我们不寒而栗——我们看到的只是外在的自己，失去了充盈我们意识的思想、精神和灵魂。我们沦为一件物品。
In using Mirror Effects we symbolically re-create this disturbing power by mirroring the actions of other people, mimicking their movements to unsettle and infuriate them. Made to feel mocked, cloned, objectlike, an image without a soul, they get angry. Or do the same thing slightly differ-endy and they might feel disarmedyou have perfectly reflected their wishes and desires. This is the narcissistic power of mirrors. In either case, the Mirror Effect unsettles your targets, whether angering or entrancing them, and in mat instant you have die power to manipulate or seduce them. The Effect contains great power because it operates on the most primitive emotions.
运用镜像效应，我们象征性地重现这种令人不安的力量：通过镜像他人的行为，模仿他们的动作，使他们感到不安和愤怒。让他们觉得自己被嘲笑、被克隆、像个物体、像个没有灵魂的影像，他们会感到愤怒。或者，用略微不同的方式做同样的事情，他们可能会感到束手无策——你完美地反映了他们的愿望和欲望。这就是镜子的自恋力量。无论哪种情况，镜像效应都会让你的目标感到不安，无论是激怒他们还是迷惑他们，你都能瞬间拥有操纵或诱惑他们的力量。这种效应蕴含着强大的力量，因为它作用于最原始的情感。
There are four main Mirror Effects in the realm of power:
在权力领域中，存在四种主要的镜像效应：
The Neutralizing Effect. In ancient Greek mythology, the Gorgon Medusa had serpents for hair, protruding tongue, massive teeth, and a face so ugly that anyone who gazed at her was turned into stone, out of fright. But the hero Perseus managed to slay Medusa by polishing his bronze shield into a mirror, men using the reflection in the mirror to guide him as he crept up and cut off her head without looking at her directly. If the shield in this instance was a mirror, the mirror also was a kind of shield: Medusa could not see Perseus, she saw only her own reflected actions, and behind this screen the hero stole up and destroyed her.
中和效应。在古希腊神话中，戈耳工美杜莎长着蛇发、伸出的舌头、巨大的牙齿，以及一张丑陋无比的脸，任何直视她的人都会被吓得变成石头。但英雄珀尔修斯却凭借着将青铜盾牌打磨成镜子的本领，成功地杀死了美杜莎。人们借助镜子中的倒影引导珀尔修斯，他悄悄靠近，在不直视美杜莎的情况下，砍下了她的头颅。如果说盾牌在这里是一面镜子，那么这面镜子本身也是一种屏障：美杜莎看不到珀尔修斯，她只能看到自己倒映的动作，而英雄正是在这面屏障的掩护下，悄无声息地接近并消灭了她。
This is me essence of the Neutralizing Effect: Do what your enemies do, following their actions as best you can, and they cannot see what you are up tothey are blinded by your mirror. Their strategy for dealing with you depends on your reacting to them in a way characteristic of you; neutralize it by playing a game of mimicry with them. The tactic has a mocking, even infuriating effect. Most of us remember the childhood experience of someone teasing us by repeating our words exactiyafter a while, usually not long, we wanted to punch diem in the face. Working more subdy as an adult, you can still unsettie your opponents diis way; shielding your own strategy widi the mirror, you lay invisible traps, or push your opponents into the trap they planned for you.
这就是中和效应的精髓：模仿敌人的行动，尽可能地效仿他们的策略，他们就无法看穿你的意图——他们被你的模仿蒙蔽了双眼。他们对付你的策略取决于你如何以自己的方式回应他们；通过模仿他们来中和他们的策略。这种策略具有嘲讽甚至激怒的效果。我们大多数人都记得小时候被人嘲笑的经历，他们会一字不差地重复我们说过的话——过了一会儿，通常不会太久，我们就会想揍他们一顿。成年后，你可以更巧妙地运用这种方法来扰乱对手；用模仿来掩盖你的策略，你可以设置无形的陷阱，或者把对手推入他们为你设下的陷阱。
This powerful technique has been used in military strategy since the days of Sun-tzu; in our own time it often appears in political campaigning. It is also useful for disguising those situations in which you have no particular strategy yourself. This is the Warrior's Mirror.
这种强大的技巧自孙子时代起就被应用于军事战略；在当今时代，它也经常出现在政治竞选中。它还能有效地掩盖你自身缺乏特定战略的情况。这就是武士之镜。
A reverse version of the Neutralizing Effect is the Shadow: You
中和效应的反向版本是阴影：你
THE MERCHANT AND HIS ITilEND
商人和他的伊蒂伦德
A certain merchant once had a great desire to make a long journey. Now in regard that he was not very wealthy, “It is requisite,” said he to himself, “that before my departure 1 should leave some part of my estate in the city, to the end that if I meet with ill luck in my travels, I may have wherewithal to keep me at my return.” To this purpose he delivered a great number of bars of iron, which were a principal part of his wealth, in trust to one of his friends, desiring him to keep them during his absence; and then, taking his leave, away he went. Some time after, having had but ill luck in his travels, he returned home; and the first thing he did was to go to his friend, and demand his iron: but his friend, who owed several sums of money, having sold the iron to pay his own debts, made him this answer: “ Truly, friend,” said he, “I put your iron into a room that was close locked, imagining it would have been there as secure as my own gold; but an accident has happened which no one could have suspected, for there was a rat in the room which ate it all up.” The merchant, pretending ignorance, replied, "It is a terrible misfortune to me indeed; but I know of
从前，有个商人很想远行。他觉得自己并不富裕，于是心想：“出发前，我必须在城里留下一部分财产，以防旅途不顺，回来时还能勉强糊口。”为此，他把一大批铁条——这可是他财富的主要部分——托付给一位朋友保管，嘱咐他自己外出期间保管好。然后，他告别朋友，启程前往。过了一段时间，他旅途不顺，只好返回家乡。他做的第一件事就是去找他的朋友，要回他的铁。但他的朋友欠了不少钱，为了还债，已经把铁卖了，于是这样回答他：“朋友，真的，”他说，“我把你的铁放进一个上了锁的房间里，以为它在那里会像我的金子一样安全；可是出了谁也想不到的意外，房间里有一只老鼠，把它全吃光了。”商人装作不知情，回答说：“这对我来说真是个大不幸；但我知道……”
old that rats love iron extremely; I have suffered by them many times before in the same manner, and therefore can the better bear my present affliction.“ This answer extremely pleased the friend, who was glad to hear the merchant so well inclined to believe that a rat had eaten his iron; and to remove all suspicions, desired him to dine with him the next day. The merchant promised he would, but in the meantime he met in the middle of the city one of his friend's children; the child he carried home, and locked up in a room. The next day he went to his friend, who seemed to be in great affliction, which he asked him the cause of, as if he had been perfectly ignorant of what had happened. ”O, my dear friend,“ answered the other, ”I beg you to excuse me, if you do not see me so cheerful as otherwise I would be; I have lost one of my children; I have had him cried by sound of trumpet, but I know not what is become of him. “ ”Of“ replied the merchant, ”1 am grieved to hear this; for yesterday in the evening, as I parted from hence, I saw an owl in the air with a child in his claws; but whether it were yours I cannot tell.“ ”Why, you most foolish and absurd creature!,' replied the friend, "are you not ashamed to tell such an egregious lie An owl, that weighs at
“老鼠酷爱铁器，这是老生常谈了；我以前也多次遭受过同样的折磨，因此更能忍受目前的痛苦。”这番话让朋友十分高兴，他很高兴听到商人如此相信是老鼠吃了他的铁器；为了消除所有疑虑，他邀请商人第二天共进晚餐。商人答应了，但在此期间，他在城里遇到了朋友的一个孩子；他把孩子带回家，锁在房间里。第二天，他去看望朋友，朋友看起来非常难过，他便问他发生了什么事，仿佛自己对此一无所知。“哦，我亲爱的朋友，”朋友回答说，“请你原谅我，如果我看起来不像平时那样高兴；我失去了一个孩子；我让人吹响号角为他报丧，但我不知道他现在怎么样了。” “哦，”商人答道，“听到这个消息我很伤心；因为昨天晚上我离开这里的时候，看到一只猫头鹰爪子上抓着一个孩子；但我不知道那是不是你的孩子。”“你这个愚蠢可笑的家伙！”朋友答道，“你难道不觉得撒这么弥天大谎很丢脸吗？一只猫头鹰，体重……”
shadow your opponents' every move without their seeing you. Use the Shadow to gather information that will neutralize their strategy later on, when you will be able to thwart their every move. The Shadow is effective because to follow the movements of others is to gain valuable insights into their habits and routines. The Shadow is the preeminent device for detectives and spies.
在对手不知情的情况下，暗中监视他们的一举一动。利用“影子”收集情报，为日后瓦解他们的策略做好准备，届时你将能够挫败他们的每一个行动。“影子”之所以有效，是因为跟踪他人的行动能够让你深入了解他们的习惯和惯例。“影子”是侦探和间谍的必备利器。
The Narcissus Effect. Gazing at an image in the waters of a pond, the Greek youth Narcissus fell in love with it. And when he found out that the image was his own reflection, and that he therefore could not consummate his love, he despaired and drowned himself. All of us have a similar problem: We are profoundly in love with ourselves, but since this love excludes a love object outside ourselves, it remains continuously unsatisfied and unfulfilled. The Narcissus Effect plays on this universal narcissism: You look deep into the souls of odier people; fathom their inmost desires, their values, their tastes, their spirit; and you reflect it back to them, making yourself into a kind of mirror image. Your ability to reflect their psyche gives you great power over them; they may even feel a tinge of love.
纳西索斯效应。希腊青年纳西索斯凝视着池塘水中的倒影，爱上了它。当他发现那倒影是自己的化身，因此无法与自己相爱时，他绝望地投水自尽。我们每个人都面临着类似的问题：我们深深地爱着自己，但由于这种爱排除了自身之外的爱慕对象，它始终无法得到满足和圆满。纳西索斯效应正是利用了这种普遍存在的自恋倾向：你深入观察他人的灵魂，洞悉他们内心深处的渴望、价值观、品味和精神；并将这一切反射给他们，使自己成为他们的镜像。你能够反映他们的心理，这赋予了你强大的影响力；他们甚至可能对你产生一丝爱意。
This is simply the ability to mimic another person not physically, but psychologically, and it is immensely powerful because it plays upon the unsatisfied self-love of a child. Normally, people bombard us with their experiences, their tastes. They hardly ever make the effort to see things through our eyes. This is annoying, but it also creates great opportunity: If you can show you understand another person by reflecting their inmost feelings, they will be entranced and disarmed, all the more so because it happens so rarely. No one can resist this feeling of being harmoniously reflected in the outside world, even though you might well be manufacturing it for their benefit, and for deceptive purposes of your own.
这其实就是一种模仿他人的能力，不是在身体上，而是在心理上。这种能力威力无穷，因为它利用了孩童时期那种未被满足的自爱。通常，人们会向我们灌输他们的经历和喜好，却很少尝试从我们的角度看待事物。这固然令人恼火，但也创造了绝佳的机会：如果你能通过反映他人内心深处的感受来展现你的理解，他们就会被深深吸引，卸下防备，尤其因为这种情况如此罕见。没有人能够抗拒这种在外部世界和谐共鸣的感觉，即便你很可能是为了他们的利益，或者出于你自己的某种欺骗目的而刻意营造这种感觉。
The Narcissus Effect works wonders in both social life and business; it gives us both the Seducer's and the Courtier's Mirror.
纳西索斯效应在社交生活和商业中都发挥了奇效；它既能让我们看清诱惑者的面容，也能让我们看清朝臣的面容。
The Moral Effect The power of verbal argument is extremely limited, and often accomplishes the opposite of what is intended. As Gracian remarks, “The truth is generally seen, rarely heard.” The Moral Effect is a perfect way to demonstrate your ideas through action. Quite simply, you teach others a lesson by giving them a taste of their own medicine.
道德效应：口头论证的力量极其有限，而且常常适得其反。正如格拉西安所言，“真理通常为人所见，却鲜为人听。” 道德效应是运用行动来阐述观点的绝佳方式。简而言之，就是以其人之道还治其人之身，让别人尝尝苦头。
In the Moral Effect, you mirror what other people have done to you, and do so in a way that makes them realize you are doing to them exacdy what they did to you. You make them feel that their behavior has been unpleasant, as opposed to hearing you complain and whine about it, which only gets their defenses up. And as they feel the result of dieir actions mirrored back at them, they realize in the profoundest sense how they hurt or punish others with their unsocial behavior. You objectify the qualities you want them to feel ashamed of and create a mirror in which they can gaze at their follies and learn a lesson about themselves. This technique is often used by educators, psychologists, and anyone who has to deal with un-
在道德效应中，你要以牙还牙，模仿他人对你的行为，并让他们意识到你正在以牙还牙。你要让他们感受到自己的行为令人不快，而不是仅仅听你抱怨，那样只会让他们更加防备。当他们感受到自己行为的后果被反射回来时，他们会从最深刻的意义上意识到，他们的反社会行为是如何伤害或惩罚他人的。你要将你想让他们感到羞耻的品质客观化，并创造一面镜子，让他们审视自己的愚蠢，从中吸取教训。这种技巧常被教育者、心理学家以及任何需要处理反社会行为的人使用。
pleasant and unconscious behavior. This is the Teacher's Mirror. Whether or not there is actually anydiing wrong witii the way people have treated you, however, it can often be to your advantage to reflect it back to them in a way that makes them feel guilty about it.
愉悦且无意识的行为。这就是“老师的镜子”。无论别人对待你的方式是否真的有错，以某种方式将他们的行为反映出来，让他们感到内疚，通常对你是有利的。
The Hallucinatory Effect Mirrors are tremendously deceptive, for they create a sense that you are looking at the real world. Actually, though, you are only staring at a piece of glass, which, as everyone knows, cannot show the world exactly as it is: Everything in a mirror is reversed. When Alice goes dirough the looking glass in Lewis Carroll's book, she enters a world that is back-to-front, and more than just visually.
幻觉效应：镜子极具欺骗性，因为它们会让你产生一种正在观察真实世界的错觉。但实际上，你看到的只是一块玻璃，而众所周知，玻璃无法真实地反映世界：镜子里的一切都是颠倒的。在刘易斯·卡罗尔的书中，当爱丽丝穿过镜子时，她进入了一个颠倒的世界，而且这种颠倒不仅仅体现在视觉上。
The Hallucinatory Effect comes from creating a perfect copy of an object, a place, a person. This copy acts as a kind of dummypeople take it for the real thing, because it has the physical appearance of the real thing. This is the preeminent technique of con artists, who strategically mimic the real world to deceive you. It also has applications in any arena that requires camouflage. This is the Deceiver's Mirror.
幻觉效应源于对物体、地点或人物的完美复制。这种复制品就像一个假人，人们会把它当成真品，因为它拥有与真品几乎相同的外观。这是骗子最常用的伎俩，他们巧妙地模仿现实世界来欺骗你。它也适用于任何需要伪装的领域。这就是“骗子的镜子”。
OBSERVANCES OF MIRROR EFFECTS
对镜面效应的观察
Observance I
观察 I
In February of 1815, the emperor Napoleon escaped from the island of Elba, where he had been imprisoned by die allied forces of Europe, and returned to Paris in a march that stirred the French nation, rallying troops and citizens of all classes to his side and chasing his successor, King Louis XVIII, off the throne. By March, however, having reestablished himself in power, he had to face the fact that France's situation had gravely changed. The country was devastated, he had no allies among the other European nations, and his most loyal and important ministers had deserted him or left the country. Only one man remained from die old regimeJoseph Fouche, his former minister of police.
1815年2月，拿破仑皇帝从被欧洲盟军囚禁的厄尔巴岛逃脱，返回巴黎。他发起的进军鼓舞了整个法国，各阶层的军队和民众都团结在他身边，并迫使他的继承人路易十八国王下台。然而，到了3月，尽管他重新掌权，却不得不面对法国局势已发生巨大变化的现实。国家满目疮痍，他在欧洲各国中已无盟友，他最忠诚、最重要的几位大臣也纷纷离他而去或离开了法国。旧政权中只剩下一人——约瑟夫·富歇，他之前的警察部长。
Napoleon had relied on Fouche to do his dirty work throughout his previous reign, but he had never been able to figure his minister out. He kept a corps of agents to spy on all of his ministers, so that he would always have an edge on them, but no one had gotten anything on Fouche. If suspected of some misdeed, the minister would not get angry or take the accusation personallyhe would submit, nod, smile, and change colors chameleonlike, adapting to tiie requirements of die moment. At first diis had seemed somewhat pleasant and charming, but after a while it frustrated Napoleon, who felt outdone by this slippery man. At one time or another he had fired all of his most important ministers, including Talleyrand, but he never touched Fouche. And so, in 1815, back in power and in need of help, he felt he had no choice but to reappoint Fouche as his minister of police.
在拿破仑之前的统治时期，他一直依赖富歇替他处理脏活累活，但他始终没能摸透这位大臣的底细。他安插了一批间谍监视所有大臣，以便始终掌握他们的把柄，但没有人能查到富歇的底细。如果被怀疑做了什么不轨之事，富歇既不会生气，也不会把指控当成针对他个人的攻击——他会顺从、点头、微笑，像变色龙一样变换脸色，以适应当时的需要。起初，这看起来颇为讨喜，但过了一段时间，这让拿破仑感到恼火，他觉得自己被这个狡猾的人耍得团团转。他曾先后解雇过所有最重要的大臣，包括塔列朗，但他从未动过富歇。因此，在1815年，重掌政权且急需人手时，他觉得自己别无选择，只能再次任命富歇为警察部长。
Several weeks into his new reign, Napoleon's spies told him they be-
拿破仑新政权建立几周后，他的间谍告诉他，他们……
most not above two or three pounds, can he carry a boy that weighs above fifty“ ”Why, “ replied the merchant, ”do you make such a wonder at that As if in a country where one rat can eat a hundred tons ' weight of iron, it were such a wonder for an owl to carry a child that weighs not over fifty pounds in all!" The friend, upon this, found that the merchant was no such fool as he took him to be, begged his pardon for the cheat which he designed to have put upon him, restored him the value of his iron, and so had his son again. ,
“它最多也就两三磅重，怎么可能叼得着一个五十多磅重的男孩呢？”“为什么，”商人回答说，“你对此感到如此惊讶？仿佛在一个老鼠能吃掉一百吨铁的国家里，猫头鹰叼着一个总重不超过五十磅的孩子是多么不可思议似的！”朋友听后，发现商人并不像他想象的那样愚蠢，便为自己原本打算欺骗他的行为道歉，归还了铁的价值，儿子也因此回到了他身边。
India,
印度，
fourth century
四世纪
When you have come to grips and are striving together with the enemy, and you realize that you cannot advance, you “soak in” and become one with the enemy. You can win by applying a suitable technique while you are mutually entangled. ... You can win often decisively with the advantage of knowing how to “soak ” into the enemy, whereas, were you to draw apart, you would lose the chance to win.
当你与敌人交锋并肩作战，却发现无法取胜时，就应该“融入”敌人，与敌人融为一体。在彼此纠缠的过程中，运用合适的技巧，你就能取得胜利。……懂得如何“融入”敌人，往往能让你取得决定性的胜利；而一旦与敌人分离，你就会错失胜利的机会。
a book of five rings, Miyamoto Musashi, Japan, seventeenth century
《五轮书》，宫本武藏著，日本，十七世纪
One day Mr. Fox decided to fork out And invite old Mrs. Stork out. The dinner wasn 't elaborate Being habitually mean, He didn 't go in for haute cuisine In fact it consisted of a shallow plate Of thin gruel. Within a minute Our joker had lapped his plate clean; Meanwhile his guest. fishing away with her beak, Got not a morsel in it. To pay him back for this cruel Practical joke, the stork invited The fox to dinner the following week. “I should be delighted,” He replied; “ When it comes to friends I never stand upon pride. ” Punctually on the day he ran To his hostess's house and at once began Praising everything: “What taste! What chic! And the fooddone just to a turn!” Then sat down with a hearty appetite (Foxes are always ready to eat) And savored the delicious smell of meat. It was minced meat and servedto serve him right! In a long-necked, narrow-mouthed urn. The stork, easily stooping, Enjoyed her fill With her long bill; His snout, though,
有一天，狐狸先生决定请鹳太太吃饭。晚餐并不丰盛，因为他向来吝啬，所以对高级料理不感兴趣。事实上，晚餐只有一小碟稀粥。不到一分钟，这位爱开玩笑的狐狸先生就把盘子舔得干干净净；而他的客人，用喙四处觅食，却一口也没吃到。为了报复他这个残酷的恶作剧，鹳太太邀请狐狸下周来家吃饭。“我非常乐意，”他回答说，“在朋友面前，我从不骄傲自满。”到了约定的日子，他准时跑到鹳太太家，立刻开始赞美一切：“多么美味！多么精致！而且菜肴做得恰到好处！”然后，他大快朵颐地坐了下来（狐狸总是胃口大开），贪婪地嗅着肉的香味。那是肉馅，盛在一个长颈窄口的瓮里，真是“盛宴”！鹳鸟轻松地俯身，用她长长的喙饱餐了一顿；然而，他的鼻子，
lieved Fouche was in secret contact with ministers of foreign countries, including Metternich of Austria. Afraid that his most valuable minister was betraying him to his enemies, Napoleon had to find out the truth before it was too late. He could not confront Fouche directlyin person the man was as slippery as an eel. He needed hard proof.
拿破仑相信富歇与包括奥地利梅特涅在内的多国大臣秘密接触。他担心自己最得力的臣子会背叛自己，投靠敌人，必须在为时已晚之前查明真相。他无法当面质问富歇——此人狡猾如鳗鱼。他需要确凿的证据。
This seemed to come in April, when the emperor's private police cap tured a Viennese gentleman who had come to Paris to pass information on to Fouche. Ordering the man brought before him, Napoleon threatened to shoot him then and mere unless he confessed; the man broke down and admitted he had given Fouche a letter from Metternich, written in invisible ink, arranging for a secret meeting of special agents in Basel. Napoleon accordingly ordered one of his own agents to infiltrate this meeting. If Fouche was indeed planning to betray him, he would finally be caught red-handed and would hang.
这件事似乎在四月份发生了。当时，皇帝的私人警察抓获了一位维也纳绅士，此人来到巴黎是为了向富歇传递情报。拿破仑下令将此人带到自己面前，威胁说除非他认罪，否则就立即处决他。此人崩溃了，承认他曾给富歇一封梅特涅用隐形墨水写的信，信中安排了一次在巴塞尔举行的秘密特工会议。于是，拿破仑命令自己的一名特工潜入这次会议。如果富歇真的打算背叛他，那么他最终将被当场抓获并处以绞刑。
Napoleon waited impatiently for the agent's return, but to his bewilderment the agent showed up days later reporting that he had heard nothing that would implicate Fouche in a conspiracy. In fact it seemed that the other agents present suspected Fouche of double-crossing them, as if he were working for Napoleon all along. Napoleon did not believe this for an instantFouche had somehow outwitted him again.
拿破仑焦急地等待着特工的归来，但令他困惑的是，几天后特工才出现，并报告说他没有听到任何能证明富歇参与阴谋的线索。事实上，在场的其他特工似乎都怀疑富歇背叛了他们，仿佛他一直都在为拿破仑效力。拿破仑对此深表怀疑，他根本不相信富歇又一次耍了他。
The following morning Fouche visited Napoleon, and remarked, “By me way, sire, I never told you tiiat I had a letter from Metternich a few days ago; my mind was so full of things of greater moment. Besides, his emissary omitted to give me die powder needed to make die writing legible. . . . Here at lengdi is the letter.” Sure that Fouche was toying widi him, Napoleon exploded, “You are a traitor, Fouche! I ought to have you hanged.” He continued to harangue Fouche, but could not fire him without proof. Fouche only expressed amazement at die emperor's words, but inwardly he smiled, for all along he had been playing a mirroring game. Interpretation
第二天早上，富歇拜访了拿破仑，说道：“陛下，顺便提一下，我几天前收到了梅特涅的来信，却一直没告诉您；我当时满脑子都是更重要的事。而且，他的使者忘了给我粉末，不然信上的字迹就看不清了……信就在这儿。”拿破仑确信富歇在耍他，勃然大怒：“富歇，你这个叛徒！我真该把你绞死！”他继续斥责富歇，但没有证据，他无法处死他。富歇对皇帝的话只是感到惊讶，但内心却暗自窃喜，因为他一直以来都在玩着一场镜像游戏。
Fouche had known for years that Napoleon kept on top of those around him by spying on them day and night. The minister had survived this game by having his own spies spy on Napoleon's spies, dius neutralizing any action Napoleon might take against him. In the case of die meeting in Basel, he even turned die tables: Knowing about Napoleon's double agent, he set it up so that it would appear as if Fouche were a loyal double agent too.
多年来，富歇一直知道拿破仑日夜监视着身边的人。这位大臣之所以能在这场博弈中幸存下来，是因为他安排自己的间谍监视拿破仑的间谍，从而化解了拿破仑可能对他采取的任何行动。在巴塞尔的那次会议上，他甚至反败为胜：他知道拿破仑有双面间谍，于是精心策划，让自己看起来像是拿破仑的忠实双面间谍。
Fouche gained power and flourished in a period of great tumult by mirroring those around him. During the French Revolution he was a radical Jacobin; after die Terror he became a moderate republican; and under Napoleon he became a committed imperialist whom Napoleon ennobled and made die duke of Otranto. If Napoleon took up the weapon of digging up dirt on people, Fouche made sure he had die dirt on Napoleon, as well as on everyone else. This also allowed him to predict die emperor's plans and desires, so that he could echo his boss's sentiments before he had even uttered diem. Shielding his actions witii a mirror strategy, Fouche could also plot offensive moves widiout being caught in die act.
在动荡的年代，富歇通过模仿周围人的立场而获得权力并迅速崛起。法国大革命期间，他是一名激进的雅各宾派；恐怖统治结束后，他转变为温和的共和主义者；在拿破仑统治时期，他成为一名坚定的帝国主义者，并被拿破仑册封为奥特朗托公爵。如果拿破仑开始利用挖掘他人黑料的手段，富歇也会确保自己掌握拿破仑以及其他所有人的黑料。这使他能够预判皇帝的计划和意图，甚至在皇帝开口之前就回应其意愿。凭借这种镜像策略，富歇还能在不被发现的情况下策划进攻行动。
This is the power of mirroring those around you. First, you give people
这就是模仿周围人的力量。首先，你给予别人
the feeling that you share their thoughts and goals. Second, if they suspect you have ulterior motives, the mirror shields you from them, preventing them from figuring out your strategy. Eventually this will infuriate and unsettle them. By playing the double, you steal their thunder, suck away dieir initiative, make them feel helpless. You also gain die ability to choose when and how to unsettle themanother avenue to power. And the mirror saves you mental energy: simply echoing die moves of others gives you the space you need to develop a strategy of your own.
你会感觉自己与他们拥有共同的想法和目标。其次，如果他们怀疑你另有所图，镜像机制可以保护你免受他们的窥探，防止他们识破你的策略。最终，这会激怒他们，让他们感到不安。通过模仿，你可以抢占先机，削弱他们的主动权，让他们感到无助。你还能获得选择何时以及如何扰乱他们的能力——这是通往权力的另一条途径。镜像机制还能为你节省精力：仅仅模仿他人的行动就能为你创造空间，让你制定自己的策略。
Observance II
遵守第二条
Early on in his career, the ambitious statesman and general Alcibiades of Athens (450-404 B.C.) fashioned a formidable weapon that became the source of his power. In every encounter widi odiers, he would sense dieir moods and tastes, then carefully tailor his words and actions to mirror their inmost desires. He would seduce diem with the idea that dieir values were superior to everyone else's, and that his goal was to model himself on them or help them realize dieir dreams. Few could resist his charm.
雄心勃勃的雅典政治家兼将军阿尔西比亚德斯（公元前450-404年）在其职业生涯早期便打造了一种强大的武器，这成为他权力的源泉。在与他人的每一次接触中，他都能感知到他们的情绪和喜好，然后精心调整自己的言行，以迎合他们内心深处的渴望。他会用“他们的价值观高于一切”这样的理念来诱惑他们，并声称自己的目标是效仿他们或帮助他们实现梦想。很少有人能够抵挡住他的魅力。
The first man to fall under his spell was die philosopher Socrates. Alcibiades represented the opposite of the Socratic ideal of simplicity and uprightness: He lived lavishly and was completely unprincipled. Whenever he met Socrates, however, he mirrored the older man's sobriety, eating simply, accompanying Socrates on long walks, and talking only of philosophy and virtue. Socrates was not completely fooledhe was not unaware of Alcibiades' otiier life. But diat only made him vulnerable to a logic that flattered him: Only in my presence, he felt, does this man submit to a virtuous influence; only I have such power over him. This feeling intoxicated Socrates, who became Alcibiades' fervent admirer and supporter, one day even risking his own life to rescue the young man in battle.
第一个被他迷惑的人是哲学家苏格拉底。阿尔西比亚德斯与苏格拉底崇尚的简朴正直截了当：他生活奢靡，毫无原则。然而，每当他见到苏格拉底，他都会模仿这位长者的节俭，饮食简朴，陪伴苏格拉底漫步，谈论的也只有哲学和美德。苏格拉底并非完全被蒙蔽——他并非对阿尔西比亚德斯的另一面一无所知。但这反而让他更容易被一种奉承他的逻辑所迷惑：他觉得，只有在我面前，这个人才会屈服于美德的影响；只有我才能对他产生这样的影响。这种感觉令苏格拉底陶醉，他成了阿尔西比亚德斯的狂热崇拜者和支持者，甚至有一天，他冒着生命危险在战场上救下了这位年轻人。
The Adienians considered Alcibiades dieir greatest orator, for he had an uncanny ability to tune in to his audience's aspirations, and mirror their desires. He made his greatest speeches in support of die invasion of Sicily, which he diought would bring great wealth to Adiens and limidess glory to himself. The speeches gave expression to young Adienians' thirst to conquer lands for themselves, rather than living off die victories of their ancestors. But he also tailored his words to reflect older men's nostalgia for die glory years when Adiens led die Greeks against Persia, and dien went on to create an empire. All Athens now dreamed of conquering Sicily; Alcibiades' plan was approved, and he was made the expedition's commander.
阿迪埃尼亚人视阿尔西比亚德斯为他们最伟大的演说家，因为他拥有敏锐的洞察力，能够把握听众的愿望，并迎合他们的渴望。他最精彩的演说都是为了支持入侵西西里岛，他认为这将为阿迪埃尼亚人带来巨大的财富，并为自己赢得无上的荣耀。这些演说表达了年轻的阿迪埃尼亚人渴望征服属于自己的土地，而不是仅仅依靠祖先的胜利。但他的言辞也迎合了老一辈人对阿迪埃尼亚人率领希腊人对抗波斯并建立帝国的辉煌岁月的怀念。整个雅典都梦想着征服西西里岛；阿尔西比亚德斯的计划获得了批准，他被任命为远征军的指挥官。
While Alcibiades was leading die invasion of Sicily, however, certain Adienians fabricated charges against him of profaning sacred statues. He knew his enemies would have him executed if he returned home, so at die last minute he deserted the Adienian fleet and defected to Athens's bitter enemy, Sparta. The Spartans welcomed this great man to their side, but diey knew his reputation and were wary of him. Alcibiades loved luxury; die Spartans were a warrior people who worshipped austerity, and they were afraid he would corrupt their youth. But much to dieir relief, the Al-
然而，当阿尔西比亚德率军入侵西西里岛时，一些阿迪埃尼亚人捏造罪名，指控他亵渎神像。他知道如果返回家乡，敌人会处死他，因此在最后一刻，他抛弃了阿迪埃尼亚舰队，投奔了雅典的宿敌斯巴达。斯巴达人欢迎这位伟人加入他们的阵营，但他们也了解他的名声，对他心存戒备。阿尔西比亚德热爱奢华，而斯巴达人是崇尚节俭的尚武民族，他们担心他会败坏年轻人的风气。但令他们欣慰的是，阿尔西比亚德并没有……
being the wrong shape and size, He had to return to his den
由于形状和大小都不合适，他只好返回自己的巢穴。
Empty-bellied, tail dragging, ears drooping,
肚子空空，尾巴拖在地上，耳朵耷拉着。
As red in the face as a fox who's been caught by a hen.
脸涨得通红，就像被母鸡抓住的狐狸一样。
selected fables, Jean de La Fontaine, 1621-1695
寓言精选，让·德拉封丹，1621-1695 年
When I wish to find out how wise, or how stupid, or how good, or how wicked is any one, or what are his thoughts at the moment, I fashion the expression of my face, as accurately as possible, in accordance with the expression of his, and then wait to see what thoughts or sentiments arise in my mind or heart, as if to match or correspond with the expression.
当我想要了解一个人的智慧、愚蠢、善良、邪恶，或者他此刻的想法时，我会尽可能准确地模仿他的表情，然后等待我的脑海或心中升起与他的表情相匹配或呼应的想法或感受。
Edgar Allan Poe, 1809-1849
埃德加·爱伦·坡，1809-1849年
Lorenzo [de' Medici] lost no opportunity of increasing the respect which Pope Innocent now felt for him and of gaining his friendship, if possible his affection. He took the trouble to discover the Pope's tastes and indulged them accordingly. He sent him ... casks of his favourite wine.... He sent him courteous, flattering letters in which he assured him, when the Pope was ill, that he felt his sufferings as though they were his own, in which he encouraged him with such fortifying statements as “a Pope is what he wills to be, ” and in which, as though incidentally, he included his views on the proper course of papal policies. Innocent was gratified by Lorenzo's attentions and convinced by his arguments.... So completely, indeed, did he come to share his opinions that, as the disgruntled Ferrarese ambassador put it, “the Pope sleeps with the eyes of the Magnificent Lorenzo. ”
洛伦佐·德·美第奇不放过任何机会，以增进教皇英诺森三世对他的敬重，并赢得他的友谊，如果可能的话，更要赢得他的爱戴。他费尽心思了解教皇的喜好，并尽力满足他。他送给教皇……成桶的他最爱的葡萄酒……他写给教皇彬彬有礼、奉承奉承的信件，在教皇生病时，他向教皇保证，他感同身受，如同自己也经历着同样的痛苦；他还用诸如“教皇想成为什么样的人，就成为什么样的人”之类的鼓舞人心的话语激励教皇；此外，他还顺带提及了自己对教皇政策的看法。英诺森三世对洛伦佐的殷勤感到欣慰，也被他的论证所说服……事实上，他完全认同了洛伦佐的观点，以至于正如那位不满的费拉拉大使所说，“教皇入睡时，眼里只有伟大的洛伦佐。”
the house
房子
of medici:
医生们：
its rise and fall,
它的兴衰
Christopher Hibbert,
克里斯托弗·希伯特
cibiades who arrived in Sparta was not at all what they expected: He wore his hair untrimmed (as they did), took cold baths, ate coarse bread and black broth, and wore simple domes. To the Spartans this signified mat he had come to see their way of life as superior to the Athenian; greater than they were, he had chosen to be a Spartan rather than being born one, and should thus be honored above all others. They fell under his spell and gave him great powers. Unfortunately Alcibiades rarely knew how to rein in his charmhe managed to seduce the king of Sparta's wife and make her pregnant. When this became public he once more had to flee for his life.
抵达斯巴达的阿尔西比亚德斯与他们预想的截然不同：他留着未经修剪的头发（和他们一样），洗冷水澡，吃粗面包和黑肉汤，头戴简陋的圆顶帽。在斯巴达人看来，这表明他已经认同他们的生活方式优于雅典；他比他们更伟大，因为他选择成为一名斯巴达人，而非生来就是斯巴达人，因此理应受到众人的尊敬。他们被他深深吸引，赋予他强大的力量。不幸的是，阿尔西比亚德斯很少懂得如何控制自己的魅力——他竟然勾引了斯巴达国王的妻子，并让她怀了孕。此事曝光后，他不得不再次逃亡。
This time Alcibiades defected to Persia, where he suddenly went from Spartan simplicity to embracing die lavish Persian lifestyle down to the last detail. It was of course immensely flattering to the Persians to see a Greek of Alcibiades' stature prefer their culture over his own, and they showered him with honors, land, and power. Once seduced by the mirror, they failed to notice that behind this shield Alcibiades was playing a double game, se-credy helping the Athenians in their war with Sparta and thus reingratiat-ing himself with the city to which he desperately wanted to return, and which welcomed him back with open arms in 408 B.C. Interpretation
这一次，阿尔西比亚德斯叛逃到了波斯，他突然从斯巴达的简朴生活转变为无一不沉浸于波斯的奢华生活方式。当然，看到像阿尔西比亚德斯这样地位的希腊人更倾向于他们的文化而非自己的文化，对波斯人来说无疑是莫大的荣幸，他们给予他荣誉、土地和权力。然而，他们被表象所迷惑，却没有注意到，在这层伪装之下，阿尔西比亚德斯其实在玩弄两面派的把戏：他暗中帮助雅典人对抗斯巴达，以此重新赢得他梦寐以求想要返回的那座城市的信任。公元前408年，雅典张开双臂欢迎他回来。
Early in his political career, Alcibiades made a discovery that changed his whole approach to power: He had a colorful and forceful personality, but when he argued his ideas strongly with other people he would win over a few while at the same time alienating many more. The secret to gaining ascendancy over large numbers, he came to believe, was not to impose his colors but to absorb the colors of those around him, like a chameleon. Once people fell for the trick, the deceptions he went on to practice would be invisible to them.
在政治生涯早期，阿尔西比亚德斯有了一个发现，彻底改变了他对权力的态度：他个性鲜明、强势，但当他与他人激烈辩论时，虽然能赢得少数人的支持，却也疏远了更多的人。他逐渐意识到，赢得大众支持的秘诀不在于强加自己的个性，而在于像变色龙一样吸收周围人的个性。一旦人们上当受骗，他之后所施展的种种欺骗手段就难以被识破。
Understand: Everyone is wrapped up in their own narcissistic shell. When you try to impose your own ego on them, a wall goes up, resistance is increased. By mirroring them, however, you seduce them into a kind of narcissistic rapture: They are gazing at a double of their own soul. This double is actually manufactured in its entirety by you. Once you have used the mirror to seduce them, you have great power over them.
明白吗？每个人都包裹在自己自恋的外壳里。当你试图将自己的自我强加于人时，他们会竖起一道墙，抵触情绪也会随之高涨。然而，通过镜像式的呈现，你却能诱使他们陷入一种自恋的狂喜之中：他们仿佛看到了自己灵魂的镜像。而这个镜像，实际上完全是由你一手打造的。一旦你利用这面镜子诱惑了他们，你就拥有了掌控他们的巨大力量。
It is worth noting, however, the dangers in the promiscuous use of the mirror. In Alcibiades' presence people felt larger, as if their egos had been doubled. But once he left, they felt empty and diminished, and when they saw him mirroring completely different people as totally as he had mirrored them, they felt not just diminished but betrayed. Alcibiades' overuse of the Mirror Effect made whole peoples feel used, so that he constandy had to flee from one place to another. Indeed Alcibiades so angered the Spartans that they finally had him murdered. He had gone too far. The Seducer's Mirror must be used with caution and discrimination.
然而，值得注意的是，滥用镜子会带来危险。在阿尔西比亚德斯面前，人们感觉自己更加强大，仿佛自我膨胀了一倍。但一旦他离开，人们便感到空虚和渺小。当他们看到他像映照自己一样，完全映照出其他人的模样时，他们不仅感到渺小，更感到被背叛。阿尔西比亚德斯过度使用“镜子效应”，使整个民族都感到被利用，以至于他不得不不断逃亡。事实上，阿尔西比亚德斯激怒了斯巴达人，最终被他们处死。他做得太过分了。“诱惑之镜”必须谨慎使用，并加以区分。
Observance III
遵守第三条
In 1652 the recendy widowed Baroness Mancini moved her family from
1652年，新近丧夫的曼奇尼男爵夫人带着家人搬离了……
Rome to Paris, where she could count on the influence and protection of
从罗马到巴黎，在那里她可以依靠……的影响和保护
her brother Cardinal Mazarin, the French prime minister. Of the baroness's five daughters, four dazzled the court with their beauty and high spirits. These infamously charming nieces of Cardinal Mazarin became known as the Mazarinettes, and soon found themselves invited to all the most important court functions.
她的哥哥是法国首相马扎林红衣主教。男爵夫人的五个女儿中，有四个以美貌和活泼的性格令宫廷为之倾倒。这些魅力四射的马扎林红衣主教的侄女们被称为“马扎林小姐”，很快就受邀参加所有最重要的宫廷活动。
One daughter, Marie Mancini, did not share this good fortune, for she lacked the beauty and grace of her sisterswho, along with her mother and even Cardinal Mazarin, eventually came to dislike her, for they felt she spoiled the family image. They tried to persuade her to enter a convent, where she would be less of an embarrassment, but she refused. Instead she applied herself to her studies, learning Latin and Greek, perfecting her French, and practicing her musical skills. On the rare occasions when the family would let her attend court affairs, she trained herself to be an artful listener, sizing people up for their weaknesses and hidden desires. And when she finally met the future King Louis XIV, in 1657 (Louis was seventeen years old, Marie eighteen), she decided that to spite her family and uncle, she would find a way to make this young man fall in love with her.
女儿玛丽·曼奇尼就没有那么幸运了，因为她缺乏姐妹们的美貌和优雅。她的姐妹们，连同她的母亲，甚至马扎林红衣主教，最终都对她心生厌恶，因为他们觉得她玷污了家族的名声。他们试图劝她进入修道院，这样她就不会那么令人尴尬，但她拒绝了。相反，她潜心学习，钻研拉丁语和希腊语，精进法语，并磨练自己的音乐才能。在家族难得允许她参加宫廷事务的时候，她会训练自己成为一个善于倾听的人，洞察他人的弱点和隐藏的欲望。1657年，当她终于见到未来的国王路易十四时（路易十七岁，玛丽十八岁），她决定要报复她的家人和叔叔，想办法让这位年轻人爱上自己。
This was a seemingly impossible task for such a plain-looking girl, but Marie studied the future king closely. She noticed that her sisters' frivolity did not please him, and she sensed that he loathed the scheming and petty politicking that went on all around him. She saw that he had a romantic na-turehe read adventure novels, insisted on marching at the head of his armies, and had high ideals and a passion for glory. The court did not feed these fantasies of his; it was a banal, superficial world that bored him.
对于一个相貌平平的女孩来说，这似乎是一项不可能完成的任务，但玛丽仔细观察着未来的国王。她注意到姐姐们的轻浮令他不悦，也察觉到他厌恶周遭充斥的阴谋诡计和琐碎的政治斗争。她看出他天性浪漫——他阅读冒险小说，坚持亲自率领军队征战沙场，拥有崇高的理想和对荣耀的渴望。宫廷生活无法满足他的这些幻想；那是一个平庸肤浅的世界，令他感到厌倦。
The key to Louis's heart, Marie saw, would be to construct a mirror reflecting his fantasies and his youthful yearnings for glory and romance. To begin with she immersed herself in the romantic novels, poems, and plays that she knew the young king read voraciously. When Louis began to engage her in conversation, to his delight she would talk of the things that stirred his soulnot this fashion or that piece of gossip, but rather courtly love, the deeds of great knights, the nobility of past kings and heroes. She fed his thirst for glory by creating an image of an august, superior king whom he could aspire to become. She stirred his imagination.
玛丽明白，要打开路易的心扉，就要打造一面镜子，映照出他心中的幻想，以及他年轻时对荣耀和浪漫的渴望。于是，她开始沉浸在那些她知道年轻国王如饥似渴阅读的浪漫小说、诗歌和戏剧中。当路易开始与她交谈时，令他欣喜的是，她谈论的都是能触动他灵魂的事物——不是时尚潮流或八卦闲谈，而是宫廷爱情、伟大骑士的功绩、以及过往君王和英雄的高贵品格。她塑造了一个威严高贵、令人敬仰的君王形象，一个他可以努力成为的榜样，以此来满足他对荣耀的渴望。她激发了他的想象力。
As the future Sun King spent more and more time in Marie's presence, it eventually became clear that he had fallen in love with the least likely young woman of the court. To the horror of her sisters and mother, he showered Marie Mancini with attention. He brought her along on his military campaigns, and made a show of stationing her where she could watch as he marched into battle. He even promised Marie that he would marry her and make her queen.
随着未来的太阳王与玛丽相处的时间越来越长，他爱上宫廷里最不可能的年轻女子这一事实也逐渐显露出来。令玛丽的姐妹和母亲震惊的是，他对玛丽·曼奇尼百般殷勤。他带着她参加军事征战，并特意安排她站在可以观看他冲锋陷阵的地方。他甚至向玛丽承诺，他会娶她为妻，让她成为王后。
Mazarin, however, would never allow the king to marry his niece, a woman who could bring France no diplomatic or royal alliances. Louis had to marry a princess of Spain or Austria. In 1658 Louis succumbed to the pressure and agreed to break off the first romantic involvement of his life. He did so with much regret, and at the end of his life he acknowledged that he never loved anyone as much as Marie Mancini.
然而，马扎林绝不允许国王迎娶他的侄女，因为这个女人无法为法国带来任何外交或王室联盟。路易必须娶一位西班牙或奥地利的公主。1658年，路易迫于压力，同意结束他生命中的第一次恋情。他为此深感遗憾，并在生命的尽头承认，他从未像爱玛丽·曼奇尼那样深爱过任何人。
Wittgenstein had an extraordinary gift for divining the thoughts of the person with whom he was engaged in discussion. While the other struggled to put his thought into words, Wittgenstein would perceive what it was and state it for him. This power of his, which sometimes seemed uncanny, was made possible, I am sure, by his own prolonged and continuous researches.
维特根斯坦有一种非凡的天赋，能够洞悉与他讨论的人的想法。当对方还在努力用语言表达自己的想法时，维特根斯坦却能洞察其意并替他表达出来。这种有时看似不可思议的能力，我确信是他长期不懈的研究造就的。
LUDWIO WITTGENSTEIN: A MEMOIR,
路德维奥·维特根斯坦：回忆录
Norman Malcolm. 1958
诺曼·马尔科姆，1958年
The doctor should be opaque to his patients, and like a mirror, should show them nothing but what is shown to him.
医生应该对病人保持神秘，像一面镜子，只向病人展示病人能看到的东西。
Sigmund Freud, 1856-1939
西格蒙德·弗洛伊德，1856-1939
Interpretation
解释
Marie Mancini played the seducer's game to perfection. First, she took a step back, to study her prey. Seduction often fails to get past the first step because it is too aggressive; the first move must always be a retreat. By studying the king from a distance Marie saw what distinguished him from otiiershis high ideals, romantic nature, and snobbish disdain for petty politics. Marie's next step was to make a mirror for these hidden yearnings on Louis's part, letting him glimpse what he himself could bea godlike king!
玛丽·曼奇尼将诱惑者的伎俩玩得炉火纯青。首先，她后退一步，仔细观察她的猎物。诱惑往往止步于第一步，因为过于激进；第一步必须是退让。通过远距离观察国王，玛丽发现了他与众不同之处：崇高的理想、浪漫的天性以及对琐碎政治的傲慢不屑。玛丽的下一步是让路易内心深处的渴望映照出一面镜子，让他瞥见自己也能成为一位神一般的君王！
This mirror had several functions: Satisfying Louis's ego by giving him a double to look at, it also focused on him so exclusively as to give him the feeling that Marie existed for him alone. Surrounded by a pack of scheming courtiers who only had their own self-interest at heart, he could not fail to be touched by this devotional focus. Finally Marie's mirror set up an ideal for him to live up to: the noble knight of the medieval court. To a soul both romantic and ambitious, nothing could be more intoxicating than to have someone hold up an idealized reflection of him. In effect it was Marie Mancini who created the image of die Sun Kingindeed Louis later admitted the enormous part she had played in fashioning his radiant self-image.
这面镜子有多重功能：它满足了路易的虚荣心，让他得以欣赏镜中的自己；同时，它也如此专注于他，以至于他感觉玛丽的存在仿佛只为他一人。身处一群只顾自身利益、阴谋诡计的朝臣之中，他怎能不被这面镜子所深深打动？最后，玛丽的镜子为他树立了一个理想：中世纪宫廷中高贵的骑士。对于一个既浪漫又雄心勃勃的人来说，没有什么比有人举起一面映照着他理想化形象的镜子更令人陶醉的了。事实上，正是玛丽·曼奇尼塑造了“太阳王”的形象——路易后来也承认，她在塑造他光彩照人的自我形象方面发挥了至关重要的作用。
This is the power of the Seducer's Mirror: By doubling the tastes and ideals of the target, it shows your attention to his or her psychology, an attention more charming than any aggressive pursuit. Find out what sets the other person apart, then hold up the mirror that will reflect it and bring it out of diem. Feed their fantasies of power and greatness by reflecting their ideals, and they will succumb.
这就是诱惑之镜的力量：它能放大目标对象的品味和理想，展现你对其心理的关注，这种关注比任何咄咄逼人的追求都更具魅力。找出对方的独特之处，然后举起这面镜子，将其映照出来，使其焕发光彩。通过映照他们的理想来满足他们对权力和伟大的幻想，他们就会臣服。
Observance IV
第四条规定
In 1538, with the death of his mother, Helena, the eight-year-old future czar Ivan IV (or Ivan the Terrible) of Russia became an orphan. For the next five years he watched as the princely class, the boyars, terrorized the country. Now and then, to mock the young Ivan, they would make him wear a crown and scepter and place him on the throne. When the little boy's feet dangled over the edge of the chair, they would laugh and lift him off it, handing him from man to man in the air, making him feel his helplessness compared to them.
1538年，母亲海伦娜去世，年仅八岁的未来沙皇伊凡四世（或称伊凡雷帝）成了孤儿。接下来的五年里，他亲眼目睹了贵族阶层——博雅尔——在全国横行霸道。为了戏弄年幼的伊凡，他们会让他戴上王冠和权杖，把他放在王座上。当小男孩的双脚悬在椅子边缘时，他们会哈哈大笑，把他从椅子上抱下来，在空中把他从一个男人手中传到另一个人手中，让他感受到与他们相比是多么的无助。
When Ivan was thirteen, he boldly murdered the boyar leader and ascended to the dirone. For the next few decades he struggled to subdue the boyars' power, but they continued to defy him. By 1575 his efforts to transform Russia and defeat its enemies had exhausted him. Meanwhile, his subjects were complaining bitterly about his endless wars, his secret police, the unvanquished and oppressive boyars. His own ministers began to question his moves. Finally he had had enough. In 1564 he had temporarily abandoned the throne, forcing his subjects to call him back to power. Now he took the strategy a step further, and abdicated.
伊凡十三岁时，他大胆地谋杀了贵族首领，登上了帝位。在接下来的几十年里，他竭力压制贵族的势力，但他们始终不肯屈服。到了1575年，他改造俄罗斯、击败敌人的努力已经让他精疲力竭。与此同时，他的臣民们对他的无休止战争、秘密警察以及那些不屈不挠、压迫成性的贵族怨声载道。就连他的大臣们也开始质疑他的决策。最终，他忍无可忍。1564年，他曾一度放弃王位，迫使臣民拥立他复辟。如今，他更进一步，直接退位了。
To take his place Ivan elevated a general of his, Simeon Bekbulatovich,
为了接替他的位置，伊凡提拔了他的一位将军，西蒙·贝克布拉托维奇。
to the throne. But although Simeon had recently converted to Christianity, he was by birth a Tartar, and his enthronement was an insult to Ivan's subjects, since Russians looked down on the Tartars as inferiors and infidels. Yet Ivan ordered that all Russians, including the boyars, pledge obedience to their new ruler. And while Simeon moved into the Kremlin, Ivan lived in a humble house on Moscow's outskirts, from which he would sometimes visit the palace, bow before the throne, sit among the other boyars, and humbly petition Simeon for favors.
西蒙登上了王位。尽管他最近皈依了基督教，但他生来就是鞑靼人，他的登基对伊凡的臣民来说是一种侮辱，因为俄罗斯人一直瞧不起鞑靼人，视他们为低等民族和异教徒。然而，伊凡下令所有俄罗斯人，包括贵族，都要向这位新君主宣誓效忠。西蒙搬进克里姆林宫后，伊凡则住在莫斯科郊外一间简陋的房子里，他有时会从那里前往宫殿，向王座鞠躬，与其他贵族坐在一起，谦卑地向西蒙请求恩惠。
Over time it became clear that Simeon was a kind of king's double. He dressed like Ivan, and acted like Ivan, but he had no real power, since no one would really obey him. The boyars at the court who were old enough to remember taunting Ivan when he was a boy, by placing him on the throne, saw the connection: They had made Ivan feel like a weak pretender, so now he mirrored them by placing a weak pretender of his own on the throne.
随着时间的推移，西蒙其实是伊凡的替身这一点逐渐显露出来。他穿着打扮像伊凡，举止也像伊凡，但却没有实权，因为根本没人会真正服从他。那些年纪足以记得当年他们把伊凡推上王位来嘲弄他的宫廷贵族们，如今明白了其中的联系：他们曾让伊凡觉得自己是个软弱的僭位者，如今伊凡也以牙还牙，扶上了一个同样软弱的僭位者。
For two long years Ivan held the mirror of Simeon up to the Russian people. The mirror said: Your whining and disobedience have made me a czar widi no real power, so I will reflect back to you a czar with no real power. You have treated me disrespectfully, so I will do the same to you, making Russia the laughingstock of the world. In 1577, in the name of the Russian people, the chastised boyars once again begged Ivan to return to the throne, which he did. He lived as czar until his death, in 1584, and the conspiracies, complaining, and second-guessing disappeared along with Simeon. Interpretation
整整两年，伊凡四世将西蒙的形象映照在俄罗斯人民面前。镜子映照出：你们的抱怨和不服从使我成为一个没有实权的沙皇，所以我也会映照出一个没有实权的沙皇。你们曾对我无礼，所以我也会以牙还牙，让俄罗斯成为世界的笑柄。1577年，受辱的贵族们再次以俄罗斯人民的名义恳求伊凡四世重返王位，他答应了。他一直统治到1584年去世，而阴谋、抱怨和猜忌也随着西蒙的去世而消失。
In 1564, after threatening to abdicate, Ivan had been granted absolute powers. But these powers had slowly been chipped away as every sector of societythe boyars, the church, the governmentvied for more control. Foreign wars had exhausted the country, internal bickering had increased, and Ivan's attempts to respond had been met widi scorn. Russia had turned into a kind of boisterous classroom in which the pupils laughed openly at the teacher. If he raised his voice or complained, he only met more resistance. He had to teach them a lesson, give them a taste of meir own medicine. Simeon Bekbulatovich was the mirror he used to do so.
1564年，伊凡四世以退位相威胁，最终被授予绝对权力。然而，随着社会各界——贵族、教会、政府——争夺更多控制权，他的权力逐渐被蚕食殆尽。对外战争令国家疲惫不堪，内部纷争不断，伊凡四世的应对之策却遭到了无情的嘲讽。俄罗斯仿佛变成了一间喧闹的教室，学生们肆意嘲笑老师。如果老师提高音量或提出异议，只会遭到更大的阻力。他必须给他们一个教训，让他们尝尝自己种下的苦果。西蒙·贝克布拉托维奇就是他用来教训他们的镜子。
After two years in which the throne had been an object of ridicule and disgust, the Russian people learned their lesson. They wanted their czar back, conceding to him all the dignity and respect that the position should always have commanded. For the rest of his reign, Russia and Ivan got along fine.
在经历了两年皇位沦为笑柄和厌恶之源之后，俄罗斯人民吸取了教训。他们拥护他们的沙皇，并给予他这个职位本应享有的所有尊严和尊重。在伊凡统治的剩余时间里，俄罗斯与伊凡相处融洽。
Understand: People are locked in their own experiences. When you whine about some insensitivity on their part, they may seem to understand, but inwardly they are untouched and even more resistant. The goal of power is always to lower people's resistance to you. For mis you need tricks, and one trick is to teach them a lesson.
要明白：人们往往被困在自己的经验之中。当你抱怨他们某些不体贴的行为时，他们表面上可能表示理解，但内心深处却并未受到影响，甚至更加抵触。权力的目的始终在于降低人们对你的抵触情绪。为此，你需要一些技巧，其中之一就是给他们一个教训。
Instead of haranguing people verbally, then, create a kind of mirror of their behavior. In doing so you leave them two choices: They can ignore
因此，与其用言语攻击他人，不如以其人之道还治其人之身。这样做会给他们留下两种选择：他们可以无视你。
you, or they can start to think about themselves. And even if tfiey ignore you, you will have planted a seed in their unconscious that will eventually take root. When you mirror their behavior, incidentally, do not be afraid to add a touch of caricature and exaggeration, as Ivan did by entiironing a Tartarit is the little spice in die soup mat will open dieir eyes and make diem see the ridiculousness in dieir own actions.
你，或者他们，可能会开始反思自己。即使他们无视你，你也会在他们的潜意识里种下一颗种子，最终生根发芽。顺便一提，当你模仿他们的行为时，不要害怕加入一些夸张和讽刺的成分，就像伊万那样，把鞑靼人当成汤里的点睛之笔，这会让他们大开眼界，意识到自己行为的荒谬之处。
Observance V
遵守第五条
Dr. Milton H. Erickson, a pioneer in strategic psychodierapy, would often educate his patients powerfully but indirectly by creating a kind of mirror effect. Constructing an analogy to make patients see the trutii on their own, he would bypass their resistance to change. When Dr. Erickson treated married couples complaining of sexual problems, for instance, he often found that psychotherapy's tradition of direct confrontation and problem-airing only heightened the spouses' resistance and sharpened their differences. Instead, he would draw a husband and wife out on other topics, often banal ones, trying to find an analogy for die sexual conflict.
米尔顿·H·埃里克森博士是策略性心理治疗的先驱，他常常通过一种镜像效应，以一种强有力却又间接的方式教育他的病人。他构建类比，引导病人自己发现真相，从而绕过他们对改变的抵触情绪。例如，当埃里克森博士治疗抱怨性问题的已婚夫妇时，他常常发现，心理治疗传统的直接对抗和问题宣泄方式只会加剧夫妻双方的抵触情绪，并使他们之间的分歧更加尖锐。相反，他会引导夫妻谈论其他话题，通常是一些琐碎的话题，试图从中找到与性冲突相类比的例子。
In one couple's first session, the pair were discussing their eating habits, especially at dinner. The wife preferred die leisurely approacha drink before the meal, some appetizers, and then a small main course, all at a slow, civilized pace. This frustrated the husbandhe wanted to get dinner over quickly and to dig right into the main course, the bigger the better. As the conversation continued, the couple began to catch glimpses of an analogy to their problems in bed. The moment they made tiiis connection, however, Dr. Erickson would change the subject, carefully avoiding a discussion of the real problem.
在一对夫妇的第一次咨询中，他们讨论了彼此的饮食习惯，尤其是晚餐。妻子喜欢悠闲的用餐方式：餐前小酌一杯，吃些开胃菜，然后享用一小份主菜，一切都以缓慢而优雅的节奏进行。这让丈夫感到沮丧——他只想尽快结束晚餐，然后直接大快朵颐，而且越丰盛越好。随着谈话的深入，这对夫妇开始意识到，这种饮食习惯与他们性生活中的问题有着某种相似之处。然而，每当他们意识到这一点时，埃里克森博士就会巧妙地转移话题，避免深入探讨真正的问题。
The couple diought Erickson was just getting to know them and would deal widi the problem direcdy die next time he saw diem. But at die end of diis first session, Dr. Erickson directed them to arrange a dinner a few nights away tiiat would combine each person's desire: The wife would get the slow meal, including time spent bonding, and the husband would get the big dishes he wanted to eat. Widiout realizing they were acting under the doctor's gende guidance, the couple would walk into a mirror of their problem, and in the mirror they would solve their problems themselves, ending die evening just as the doctor had hopedby mirroring the improved dinner dynamics in bed.
这对夫妇以为埃里克森医生只是在了解他们，下次见面时会直接处理他们的问题。但在第一次咨询结束时，埃里克森医生指导他们安排几天后的一次晚餐，这次晚餐要兼顾双方的愿望：妻子可以享用一顿慢食，包括增进感情的时间；丈夫则可以吃到他想吃的大餐。这对夫妇并没有意识到自己是在医生的指导下行事，他们走进了自己问题的镜子，并在镜子中找到了解决之道。正如医生所希望的那样，他们在晚餐后的关系也得到了改善，并在床上重现了这种美好的氛围。
In dealing with more severe problems, such as die schizophrenic's mirror fantasy world of his or her own construction, Dr. Erickson would always try to enter the mirror and work within it. He once treated a hospital inmate who believed he was Jesus Christdraping sheets around his body, talking in vague parables, and bombarding staff and patients widi endless Christian proselytizing. No therapy or drugs seemed to work, until one day Dr. Erickson went up to die young man and said, “I understand you have had experience as a carpenter.” Being Christ, the patient had to say that he had had such experience, and Erickson immediately put him to work building bookcases and otiier useful items, allowing him to wear his Jesus garb. Over the next weeks, as the patient worked on diese projects,
在处理更严重的问题时，例如精神分裂症患者构建的镜像幻想世界，埃里克森医生总是试图进入这个镜像世界，并在其中进行治疗。他曾治疗过一位自认为是耶稣基督的住院病人，这位病人用床单裹住身体，说着含糊不清的寓言，并没完没了地向医护人员和其他病人传教。任何疗法和药物似乎都无效，直到有一天，埃里克森医生走到这位年轻人面前说：“我听说你以前做过木匠。” 病人自认为是基督，不得不承认自己有过这样的经历，埃里克森医生立刻让他动手制作书架和其他实用物品，并允许他穿上耶稣的服装。在接下来的几周里，当病人忙于这些项目时，
his mind became less occupied with Jesus fantasies and more focused on his labor. As the carpentry work took precedence, a psychic shift took effect: The religious fantasies remained, but faded comfortably into the background, allowing the man to function in society. Interpretation
他的思绪不再沉浸于对耶稣的幻想，而是更多地专注于自己的劳动。随着木工活占据主导地位，一种心理上的转变发生了：宗教幻想依然存在，但却自然而然地退居幕后，使他能够更好地融入社会。
Communication depends on metaphors and symbols, which are the basis of language itself. A metaphor is a kind of mirror to the concrete and real, which it often expresses more clearly and deeply than a literal description does. When you are dealing with the intractable willpower of other people, direct communication often only heightens their resistance.
沟通依赖于隐喻和符号，而它们本身就是语言的基础。隐喻就像一面镜子，映照出具体而真实的事物，它往往比直白的描述更清晰、更深刻地表达出来。当你面对他人顽固的意志时，直接沟通往往只会加剧他们的抵触情绪。
This happens most clearly when you complain about people's behavior, particularly in sensitive areas such as their lovemaking. You will effect a far more lasting change if, like Dr. Erickson, you construct an analogy, a symbolic mirror of the situation, and guide the other through it. As Christ himself understood, talking in parables is often the best way to teach a lesson, for it allows people to realize the truth on tfieir own.
当你抱怨别人的行为，尤其是在性生活等敏感领域时，这种情况最为明显。如果你像埃里克森博士那样，构建一个类比，一个象征性的情境镜像，并引导对方理解，就能带来更持久的改变。正如基督所理解的，用寓言来讲解往往是最佳的教学方式，因为它能让人们自己领悟真理。
When dealing with people who are lost in the reflections of fantasy worlds (including a host of people who do not live in mental hospitals), never try to push them into reality by shattering their mirrors. Instead, enter meir world and operate inside it, under their rules, gently guiding them out of the hall of mirrors tiiey have entered.
当面对那些沉浸在幻想世界（包括许多并非精神病院患者）中的人时，切勿试图通过打破他们的幻想之镜将他们拉回现实。相反，应该进入他们的世界，按照他们的规则行事，温和地引导他们走出他们已经进入的镜厅。
Observance VI
第六项观察
The great sixteenth-century Japanese tea master Takeno Sho-o once passed by a house and noticed a young man watering flowers near his front gate. Two things caught Sho-o's attentionfirst, the graceful way the man performed his task; and, second, the stunningly beautiful rose of Sharon blossoms that bloomed in the garden. He stopped and introduced himself to the man, whose name was Sen no Rikyu. Shoo wanted to stay, but he had a prior engagement and had to hurry off. Before he left, however, Rikyu invited him to take tea with him the following morning. Sho-o happily accepted.
十六世纪日本茶道大师竹野正王曾路过一户人家，看到一位年轻人在门前浇花。正王被两件事吸引：一是年轻人优雅的浇花姿态；二是花园里盛开的木槿花，美得令人惊艳。他停下脚步，上前与年轻人攀谈，得知他名叫千利休。正王很想留下来，但因另有安排，不得不匆匆离开。临别前，利休邀请他第二天早上一起喝茶。正王欣然应允。
When Sho-o opened the garden gate the next day, he was horrified to see that not a single flower remained. More than anything else, he had come to see the rose of Sharon blossoms that he had not had the time to appreciate the day before; now, disappointed, he started to leave, but at the gate he stopped himself, and decided to enter Sen no Rikyu's tea room. Immediately inside, he stopped in his tracks and gazed in astonishment: Before him a vase hung from the ceiling, and in the vase stood a single rose of Sharon blossom, the most beautiful in the garden. Somehow Sen no Rikyu had read his guest's thoughts, and, with this one eloquent gesture, had demonstrated that this day guest and host would be in perfect harmony.
第二天，翔王打开花园大门时，却惊愕地发现园中竟一朵花都没剩下。他此行的主要目的，是想欣赏昨天因时间所限而错过的木槿花；如今，他失望地转身要走，却在门口停住了脚步，决定走进千利休的茶室。一进门，他就停住了脚步，目瞪口呆地望着眼前的景象：一只花瓶从天花板垂下，瓶中插着一朵木槿花，正是花园里最美的一朵。千利休似乎看穿了客人的心思，这一个举动便足以表明，今日的客人与主人将会相得益彰。
Sen no Rikyu went on to become the most famous tea master of all, and his trademark was this uncanny ability to harmonize himself with his guests' tfioughts and to think one step ahead, enchanting them by adapting to their taste.
千利休后来成为最著名的茶道大师，他的标志性特点是能够与客人的口味和谐相处，并能预先想到下一步，通过调整自己的茶道来吸引客人。
One day Rikyu was invited to tea by Yamashina Hechigwan, an ad-
有一天，利休应山科边千官的邀请去喝茶。
mirer of the tea ceremony but also a man with a vivid sense of humor. When Rikyu arrived at Hechigwan's home, he found the garden gate shut, so he opened it to look for the host. On the other side of the gate he saw that someone had first dug a ditch, then carefully covered it over widi canvas and earth. Realizing that Hechigwan had planned a practical joke, he obligingly walked right into the ditch, muddying his clothes in the process.
他不仅精通茶道，而且极富幽默感。利休来到赫奇湾家时，发现花园大门紧闭，便推门而入，想看看主人是谁。门后，他看到有人先挖了一条沟，然后小心翼翼地用帆布和泥土将其覆盖。利休意识到赫奇湾是在跟他开玩笑，便顺从地走进了沟里，弄得衣服沾满了泥巴。
Apparently horrified, Hechigwan came running out, and hurried Rikyu to a bath mat for some inexplicable reason stood already prepared. After bathing, Rikyu joined Hechigwan in the tea ceremony, which both enjoyed immensely, sharing a laugh about the accident. Later Sen no Rikyu explained to a friend that he had heard about Hechigwan's practical joke beforehand, “But since it should always be one's aim to conform to the wishes of one's host, I fell into the hole knowingly and thus assured the success of the meeting. Tea is by no means mere obsequiousness, but there is no tea where the host and guest are not in harmony with one another.” Hechigwan's vision of the dignified Sen no Rikyu at the bottom of a ditch had pleased him endlessly, but Rikyu had gained a pleasure of his own in complying with his host's wish and watching him amuse himself in this way. Interpretation
显然被吓坏了的宮奇关跑了出来，急忙拉着利休走到一张不知为何早已准备好的浴垫旁。沐浴之后，利休与宮奇关一起参加了茶道仪式，两人都非常享受，还就刚才的意外开怀大笑。后来，千利休向一位朋友解释说，他事先听说了宮奇关的恶作剧，“但既然顺从主人的意愿总是没错的，我就故意掉进坑里，这样才确保了会面的成功。茶道绝非仅仅是奉承，但主人与客人之间若不和谐，便谈不上真正的茶道。”宮奇关看到庄重的千利休掉进沟底，心中无比愉悦，而利休也从顺从主人的意愿并看着他自娱自乐中获得了自己的乐趣。
Sen no Rikyu was no magician or seerhe watched those around him acutely, plumbing the subde gestures that revealed a hidden desire, then producing that desire's image. Although Sho-o never spoke of being enchanted by the rose of Sharon blossoms, Rikyu read it in his eyes. If mirroring a person's desires meant falling into a ditch, so be it. Rikyu's power resided in his skillful use of the Courtier's Mirror, which gave him the appearance of an unusual ability to see into other people.
千利休并非魔术师或先知，他只是敏锐地观察着周围的人，探究那些隐藏欲望的细微举动，然后将这些欲望的影像呈现出来。尽管翔王从未提及自己被木槿花迷惑，利休却从他的眼神中读懂了一切。如果映照他人的欲望意味着坠入深渊，那也无妨。利休的力量源于他对宫廷镜的娴熟运用，这使他拥有了洞察他人内心的非凡能力。
Learn to manipulate die Courtier's Mirror, for it will bring you great power. Study people's eyes, follow their gesturessurer barometers of pain and pleasure than any spoken word. Notice and remember the detailsthe doming, the choice of friends, the daily habits, the tossed-out remarks that reveal hidden and rarely indulged desires. Soak it all in, find out what lies under the surface, then make yourself the mirror of their unspoken selves. That is the key to this power: The other person has not asked for your consideration, has not mentioned his pleasure in the rose of Sharon, and when you reflect it back to him his pleasure is heightened because it is unasked for. Remember: The wordless communication, the indirect compliment, contains the most power. No one can resist the enchantment of the Courtier's Mirror.
学会操控“廷臣之镜”，它将赋予你强大的力量。观察人们的眼神，追随他们的肢体语言——这比任何言语都更能准确地反映他们的痛苦与快乐。留意并记住那些细节：他们的眼神、朋友的选择、日常习惯，以及那些不经意间流露出的、鲜少被满足的欲望。将这一切铭记于心，探寻表象之下的真相，然后让自己成为他们未曾言说的自我之镜。这便是力量的关键：对方并未寻求你的关注，也未曾提及他对木槿花的喜爱，而当你将这份喜爱反射给他时，他的喜悦会因这份未经请求的馈赠而倍增。记住：无声的交流，间接的赞美，蕴含着最强大的力量。没有人能够抵挡“廷臣之镜”的魔力。
Observance VII
第七项规定
Yellow Kid Weil, con artist extraordinaire, used the Deceiver's Mirror in his most brilliant cons. Most audacious of all was his re-creation of a bank in Muncie, Indiana. When Weil read one day that the Merchants Bank in Muncie had moved, he saw an opportunity he could not pass up.
“黄孩子”威尔，这位骗术高超的骗子，在他最精妙的骗局中都使用了“骗子之镜”。其中最胆大妄为的莫过于他在印第安纳州芒西市重建了一家银行。有一天，威尔读到芒西的商业银行搬迁的消息，他意识到这是一个千载难逢的机会。
Weil rented out the original Merchants building, which still contained bank furniture, complete with teller windows. He bought money bags,
韦尔租下了原先的商人大厦，里面还保留着银行的家具，包括柜台窗口。他买了钱袋，
stenciled a bank's invented name on them, filled them with steel washers, and arrayed them impressively behind the teller windows, along with bundles of boodlereal bills hiding newspaper cut to size. For his bank's staff and customers Weil hired gamblers, bookies, girls from local bawdy houses, and other assorted confederates. He even had a local thug pose as a bank dick.
他用模板印上银行虚构的名字，在纸币里塞满钢垫圈，然后把它们和成捆的钞票（里面藏着裁好的报纸）一起，气势十足地摆放在柜台窗口后面。为了营造银行员工和顾客的假象，韦尔雇佣了赌徒、赌博经纪人、当地妓院的妓女以及其他形形色色的同伙。他甚至还让一个当地的恶棍假扮银行职员。
Claiming to be the broker for a certificate investment the bank was offering, Weil would fish the waters and hook the proper wealthy sucker. He would bring this man to the bank and ask to see the president. An “officer” of the bank would tell them that they had to wait, which only heightened the realism of the conone always has to wait to see the bank president. And as they waited the bank would bustle with banklike activity, as call girls and bookies in disguise floated in and out, making deposits and withdrawals and tipping their hats to the phony bank dick. Lulled by this perfect copy of reality, the sucker would deposit $50,000 into the fake bank without a worry in the world.
威尔自称是银行某项投资凭证的经纪人，四处寻找合适的有钱冤大头。他会把这些人带到银行，要求见行长。一位“银行职员”会告诉他们需要等待，这反而更加强化了骗子们总是要等很久才能见到银行行长的真实感。在等待期间，银行里会热闹非凡，伪装成银行职员的应召女郎和赌博经纪人进进出出，存取款项，并向假银行行长脱帽致敬。被这完美的现实假象所迷惑，冤大头们会毫不犹豫地向这家假银行存入五万美元。
Over the years Weil did the same thing with a deserted yacht club, an abandoned brokerage office, a relocated real estate office, and a completely realistic gambling club. Interpretation
多年来，韦尔用同样的方式描绘了一个废弃的游艇俱乐部、一个废弃的经纪公司、一个搬迁的房地产办公室，以及一个完全逼真的赌场。解读
The mirroring of reality offers immense deceptive powers. The right uniform, the perfect accent, the proper propsthe deception cannot be deciphered because it is enmeshed in a simulation of reality. People have an intense desire and need to believe, and their first instinct is to trust a well-constructed facade, to mistake it for reality. After all, we cannot go around doubting the reality of everything we seethat would be too exhausting. We habitually accept appearances, and this is a credulity you can use.
对现实的模仿具有强大的欺骗力。合适的制服、完美的口音、恰当的道具——这些欺骗手段难以识破，因为它们与对现实的模拟交织在一起。人们有着强烈的信念和需求，他们的第一反应就是相信精心构建的表象，并将其误认为是现实。毕竟，我们不可能质疑所见的一切——那太累了。我们习惯性地接受表象，而这种轻信正是你可以利用的。
In this particular game it is the first moment that counts the most. If your suckers' suspicions are not raised by their first glance at the mirror's reflection, they will stay suppressed. Once they enter your hall of mirrors, they will be unable to distinguish the real from the fake, and it will become easier and easier to deceive them. Remember: Study the world's surfaces and learn to mirror them in your habits, your manner, your clothes. Like a carnivorous plant, to unsuspecting insects you will look like all the other plants in the field.
在这个游戏中，第一印象至关重要。如果你的“冤大头”们第一眼看到镜子里的自己时没有起疑心，他们就会一直蒙在鼓里。一旦他们进入你的“镜厅”，就无法分辨真假，你也就更容易欺骗他们。记住：观察世界的表象，并将之反映在你的习惯、举止和衣着中。就像食肉植物一样，在毫无防备的昆虫眼中，你看起来就像田野里的其他植物一样。
Authority: The task of a military operation is to accord deceptively with the intentions of the enemy . . . get to what they want first, subtly anticipate them. Maintain discipline and adapt to the enemy. .. . Thus, at first you are like a maiden, so the enemy opens his door; then you are like a rabbit on the loose, so the enemy cannot keep you out. (Sun-tzu, fourth century B.C.)
孙子兵法：军事行动的任务在于巧妙地顺应敌人的意图……先发制人，巧妙地预判敌人的行动。保持纪律，适应敌人……如此，起初你如同少女，敌人便为你敞开大门；随后你如同脱缰的野兔，敌人便无法阻挡你。（孙子，公元前四世纪）
Image: The Shield of Perseus. It is polished into a reflecting mirror. Medusa cannot see you, only her own hideousness reflected back at her. Behind such a mirror you can deceive, mock, and infuriate. With one blow you sever Medusa's unsuspecting head.
图片：珀尔修斯的盾牌。它被打磨成一面镜子。美杜莎看不到你，只能看到自己丑陋的倒影。透过这面镜子，你可以欺骗、嘲弄、激怒她。只需一击，你就能斩下毫无防备的美杜莎的头颅。
A WARNING: BEWARE OF MIRRORED SITUATIONS Mirrors contain great power but also dangerous reefs, including the mirrored situationa situation that seems to reflect or closely resemble a previous one, mostly in style and surface appearance. You can often back into such a situation without fully understanding it, while those around you understand it quite well, and compare it and you to whatever happened before. Most often you suffer by the comparison, seeming either weaker than the previous occupant of your position or else tainted by any unpleasant associations that person has left behind.
警告：警惕镜像情境。镜子蕴含着强大的力量，但也暗藏着危险的陷阱，镜像情境便是其中之一——它指的是一种看似反映或与先前情境极为相似的情境，尤其是在形式和表面表现上。你常常会在不完全理解的情况下陷入这种情境，而你周围的人却对此了如指掌，并将你和当前的情境与之前发生的事情进行比较。通常情况下，你会因为这种比较而感到痛苦，要么觉得自己不如之前担任你这个职位的人，要么觉得自己受到了那个人留下的不愉快经历的影响。
In 1864 the composer Richard Wagner moved to Munich at the behest of Ludwig II, known variously as the Swan King or the Mad King of Bavaria. Ludwig was Wagner's biggest fan and most generous patron. The strength of his support turned Wagner's headonce established in Munich under the king's protection, he would be able to say and do whatever he wanted.
1864年，作曲家理查德·瓦格纳应路德维希二世之邀移居慕尼黑。路德维希二世也被称为“天鹅王”或“疯王”。他是瓦格纳最忠实的拥趸和最慷慨的赞助人。国王的鼎力支持让瓦格纳有些飘飘然——一旦在慕尼黑站稳脚跟，得到国王的庇护，他便可以为所欲为。
Wagner moved into a lavish house, which the king eventually bought for him. This house was but a stone's throw from the former home of Lola Montez, the notorious courtesan who had plunged Ludwig IPs grandfather into a crisis that had forced him to abdicate. Warned that he could be infected by this association, Wagner only scoffed“I am no Lola Montez,” he said. Soon enough, however, the citizens of Munich began to resent the favors and money showered on Wagner, and dubbed him “the second Lola,” or “Lolotte.” He unconsciously began to tread in Lola's footsteps spending money extravagantly, meddling in matters beyond music, even dabbling in politics and advising the king on cabinet appointments. Meanwhile Ludwig's affection for Wagner seemed intense and undignified for a king-just like his grandfather's love for Lola Montez.
瓦格纳搬进了一栋豪华宅邸，这栋房子最终是国王为他购置的。这栋房子距离臭名昭著的交际花萝拉·蒙特斯的故居仅咫尺之遥。正是萝拉·蒙特斯让路德维希二世的祖父陷入危机，最终被迫退位。有人警告瓦格纳可能会受到这种关系的影响，但他却嗤之以鼻：“我可不是萝拉·蒙特斯。”然而不久之后，慕尼黑的市民开始对瓦格纳获得的优待和金钱感到不满，并给他起了个绰号叫“第二个萝拉”，或者叫“萝洛特”。他不知不觉地开始效仿萝拉，挥金如土，涉足音乐之外的事务，甚至参与政治，为国王的内阁任命出谋划策。与此同时，路德维希对瓦格纳的喜爱显得既浓烈又有失国王的身份——就像他祖父对萝拉·蒙特斯的迷恋一样。
Eventually Ludwig's ministers wrote him a letter: “Your Majesty now stands at a fateful parting of the ways: you have to choose between the love and respect of your faithful people and the 'friendship' of Richard Wagner.” In December of 1865, Ludwig politely asked his friend to leave and never return. Wagner had inadvertently placed himself in Lola Montez's reflection. Once there, everything he did reminded the stolid Bavarians of that dread woman, and there was nothing he could do about it.
最终，路德维希的臣子们给他写了一封信：“陛下，您如今正站在一个生死攸关的分岔路口：您必须在忠臣的爱戴与尊敬，和理查德·瓦格纳的‘友谊’之间做出选择。”1865年12月，路德维希礼貌地请他的朋友离开，并且永远不要回来。瓦格纳无意间让自己出现在了洛拉·蒙特斯的记忆中。一旦进入那个世界，他的一举一动都会让那些冷漠的巴伐利亚人想起那个可怕的女人，而他对此却无能为力。
Avoid such association-effects like the plague. In a mirrored situation you have little or no control over the reflections and recollections that will be connected to you, and any situation beyond your control is dangerous. Even if the person or event has positive associations, you will suffer from not being able to live up to them, since the past generally appears greater than the present. If you ever notice people associating you with some past event or person, do everything you can to separate yourself from that memory and to shatter the reflection.
务必像躲避瘟疫一样躲避这种联想效应。在镜像情境中，你几乎无法控制那些与你相关的镜像和回忆，而任何超出你掌控的情况都是危险的。即使这个人或事与你有着积极的联想，你也会因为无法达到他们的期望而感到痛苦，因为过去通常比现在更美好。如果你发现有人将你与过去的某个事件或人物联系起来，务必尽一切努力将自己与那段记忆剥离开来，打破这种镜像效应。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 45
第45条
PREACH THE NEED
宣扬这种需求
FOR CHANGE, BUT
为了改变，但是
NEVER REFORM
永不改革
TOO MUCH AT ONCE
一次性处理太多事情
JUDGMENT
判断
Everyone understands the need for change in the abstract, but on the day-to-day level people are creatures of habit. Too much innovation is traumatic, and will lead to revolt. If you are new to a position of power, or an outsider trying to build a power base, make a show of respecting the old way of doing things. If change is necessary, make it feel like a gentle improvement on the past.
每个人都明白从理论上讲变革的必要性，但在日常生活中，人们却习惯于墨守成规。过度的创新会带来冲击，甚至引发反抗。如果你刚刚身居要职，或者是一个试图建立权力基础的局外人，那就应该表现得尊重旧有的行事方式。如果变革势在必行，那就让它看起来像是对过去的温和改进。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Sometime in die early 1520s, King Henry VIII of England decided to divorce his wife, Catfierine of Aragon, because she had failed to bear him a son, and because he had fallen in love with die young and comely Anne Boleyn. The pope, Clement VII, opposed die divorce, and threatened die king widi excommunication. The king's most powerful minister, Cardinal Wolsey, also saw no need for divorceand his halfhearted support of die king cost him his position and soon his life.
大约在16世纪20年代初期，英格兰国王亨利八世决定与妻子阿拉贡的凯特琳离婚，因为她未能为他诞下儿子，而且他爱上了年轻貌美的安妮·博林。教皇克莱门特七世反对离婚，并威胁要将国王逐出教会。国王最有权势的大臣沃尔西枢机主教也认为没有必要离婚，他对国王的勉强支持最终使他失去了地位，并很快丢掉了性命。
One man in Henry's cabinet, Thomas Cromwell, not only supported him in his desire for a divorce but had an idea for realizing it: a complete break widi die past. He convinced die king mat by severing ties widi Rome and making himself the head of a newly formed English church, he could divorce Cadierine and marry Anne. By 1531 Henry saw diis as die only solution. To reward Cromwell for his simple but brilliant idea, he elevated diis son of a blacksmitii to die post of royal councillor.
亨利八世内阁中的一位大臣托马斯·克伦威尔不仅支持他离婚的愿望，还提出了一个实现方案：彻底与过去决裂。他成功说服国王，只要断绝与罗马的联系，并自立为新成立的英国教会的领袖，他就可以与凯瑟琳离婚，迎娶安妮。到了1531年，亨利八世认为这是唯一的解决办法。为了嘉奖克伦威尔这个看似简单却极具创意的想法，他擢升这位铁匠之子为皇家顾问。
By 1534 Cromwell had been named die king's secretary, and as me power behind die dirone he had become die most powerful man in England. But for him die break widi Rome went beyond die satisfaction of die king's carnal desires: He envisioned a new Protestant order in England, wim die power of die Cadiolic Church smashed and its vast wealdi in the hands of die king and die government. In diat same year he initiated a complete survey of die churches and monasteries of England. And as it turned out, die treasures and moneys diat die churches had accumulated over me centuries were far more tiian he had imagined; his spies and agents came back widi astonishing figures.
到1534年，克伦威尔已被任命为国王的秘书，作为幕后掌权者，他已成为英格兰最有权势的人。但对他而言，与罗马决裂远不止满足国王的肉欲：他设想在英格兰建立一个新的新教秩序，摧毁天主教会的权力，将其庞大的财富置于国王和政府的掌控之中。同年，他发起了一项对英格兰所有教堂和修道院的全面调查。结果发现，这些教堂几个世纪以来积累的财富和金钱远远超出了他的想象；他的间谍和特工带回了令人震惊的数字。
To justify his schemes, Cromwell circulated stories about die corruption in die English monasteries, dieir abuse of power, their exploitation of die people tiiey supposedly served. Having won Parhament's support for breaking up die monasteries, he began to seize meir holdings and to put diem out of existence one by one. At die same time, he began to impose Protestantism, introducing reforms in religious ritual and punishing tiiose who stuck to Cadiolicism, and who now were called heretics. Virtually overnight, England was converted to a new official religion.
为了给他的计划辩护，克伦威尔散布关于英国修道院腐败、滥用权力以及剥削本应服务于他们的人民的故事。在赢得教区支持解散修道院后，他开始没收修道院的财产，并逐一将其摧毁。与此同时，他开始推行新教，改革宗教仪式，惩罚那些坚持天主教教义的人，这些人现在被称为异端。几乎一夜之间，英国就皈依了新的官方宗教。
A terror fell on die country. Some people had suffered under die Catiiolic Church, which before die reforms had been immensely powerful, but most Britons had strong ties to Cadiolicism and to its comforting rituals. They watched in horror as churches were demolished, images of die Madonna and saints were broken in pieces, stained-glass windows were smashed, and die churches' treasures were confiscated. Widi monasteries diat had succored die poor suddenly gone, the poor now flooded die streets. The growing ranks of die beggar class were further swelled by former monks. On top of all diis, Cromwell levied high taxes to pay for his ecclesiastical reforms.
恐怖笼罩了整个国家。一些人曾饱受天主教会的压迫，在改革之前，天主教会势力极其强大；但大多数英国人与天主教及其令人慰藉的仪式有着紧密的联系。他们惊恐地看着教堂被拆毁，圣母像和圣徒像被砸碎，彩色玻璃窗被砸碎，教堂的珍宝被没收。曾经救济穷人的修道院突然消失，穷人涌上街头。不断壮大的乞丐队伍又因前僧侣的涌入而进一步壮大。雪上加霜的是，克伦威尔还征收重税来支付他的教会改革费用。
In 1535 powerful revolts in die North of England tiireatened to topple Henry from his throne. By die following year he had suppressed die rebellions, but he had also begun to see die costs of Cromwell's reforms. The king himself had never wanted to go diis farhe had only wanted a di-
1535年，英格兰北部爆发了声势浩大的叛乱，意图推翻亨利八世的王位。到第二年，亨利八世镇压了叛乱，但也开始意识到克伦威尔改革的代价。国王本人从未想过要走得这么远——他只想……
WHKRK CHRISTMAS CAME FROM Celebrating the turn of the year is an ancient custom. The Romans celebrated the Saturnalia, the festival of Saturn, god of the harvest, between December 17 and 23. It was the most cheerful festival of the year. All work and commerce stopped, and the streets were filled with crowds and a carnival atmosphere. Slaves were temporarily freed, and the houses were decorated with laurel branches. People visited one another, bringing gifts of wax candles and little clay figurines.
