圣诞节起源于……庆祝新年是一种古老的习俗。罗马人在12月17日至23日庆祝农神节（Saturnalia），即农神萨图恩（Saturn）的节日，他是丰收之神。这是全年最欢乐的节日。所有工作和商业活动都停止了，街道上挤满了人，到处洋溢着嘉年华的气氛。奴隶们被暂时释放，房屋上装饰着月桂枝。人们互相拜访，赠送蜡烛和小陶俑等礼物。
Long before the birth of Christ, the Jews celebrated an eight-day Festival of Lights [at the same season], and it is believed that the Germanic peoples held a great festival not only at midsummer but also at the winter solstice, when they celebrated the rebirth of the sun and honored the great fertility gods Wotan and Freyja, Donar (Thor) and Freyr. Even after the Emperor Constantine (a.d. 306-337) declared Christianity to be Rome's official imperial religion, the evocation of light and fertility as an important component of pre-Christian midwinter celebrations could not be entirely suppressed. In the year 274 the Roman Emperor Aure-lian (a.d. 214-275) had established an official
早在基督诞生之前，犹太人就在同一季节庆祝为期八天的光明节。据信，日耳曼民族不仅在仲夏节，也在冬至节举行盛大的节日，庆祝太阳的重生，并祭祀伟大的生育之神沃坦、弗蕾雅、多纳尔（托尔）和弗雷。即使在君士坦丁大帝（公元306-337年）宣布基督教为罗马的国教之后，光明与生育作为前基督教时期仲冬节庆的重要组成部分的象征，也未能被完全消除。公元274年，罗马皇帝奥勒良（公元214-275年）设立了官方的……
cult of the sun-god Mithras, declaring his birthday, December 25, a national holiday. The cult of Mithras, the Aryan god of light, had spread from Persia through Asia Minor to Greece, Rome, and as far as the Germanic lands and Britain. Numerous ruins of his shrines still testify to the high regard in which this god was held, especially by the Roman legions, as a bringer of fertility, peace, and victory. So it was a clever move when, in the year a.d. 354, the Christian church under Pope Liberius (352-366) co-opted the birthday of Mithras and declared December 25 to be the birthday of Jesus Christ.
太阳神密特拉的崇拜，以及将其诞辰日12月25日定为国定假日，都源于罗马帝国。密特拉是雅利安人的光明之神，其崇拜从波斯经小亚细亚传播到希腊、罗马，远至日耳曼地区和不列颠。众多密特拉神庙遗址至今仍见证着人们对这位神祇的崇敬，尤其是在罗马军团中，他们视其为丰饶、和平与胜利的象征。因此，公元354年，基督教教会在教皇利伯留（352-366年在位）的领导下，巧妙地借用了密特拉的诞辰日，并将12月25日定为耶稣基督的诞辰。
NEUEZURCHER ZEITUNG,
新苏黎世报
Anne-Susanne
安妮-苏珊娜
RlSCHKE,
RlSCHKE，
December 25, 1983
1983年12月25日
vorce. It was now Cromwell's turn to watch uneasily as die king began slowly to undo his reforms, reinstating Catiiolic sacraments and odier rituals that Cromwell had oudawed.
现在轮到克伦威尔不安地看着国王开始慢慢地推翻他的改革，恢复克伦威尔废除的天主教圣礼和其他仪式。
Sensing his fall from grace, in 1540 Cromwell decided to regain Henry's favor with one throw of the dice: He would find the king a new wife. Henry's third wife, Jane Seymour, had died a few years before, and he had been pining for a new young queen. It was Cromwell who found him one: Anne of Cleves, a German princess and, most important to Cromwell, a Protestant. On Cromwell's commission, the painter Holbein produced a flattering portrait of Anne; when Henry saw it, he fell in love, and agreed to marry her. Cromwell seemed back in favor.
意识到自己失宠，克伦威尔在1540年决定孤注一掷，以求重获亨利八世的宠信：他要为国王物色一位新王后。亨利八世的第三任妻子简·西摩几年前去世，他一直渴望一位年轻的新王后。克伦威尔为他找到了合适的人选：克莱沃的安妮，一位德国公主，而且对克伦威尔来说最重要的是，她是一位新教徒。克伦威尔委托画家霍尔拜因为安妮绘制了一幅美化肖像；亨利八世看到这幅画后，立刻爱上了她，并同意娶她为妻。克伦威尔似乎又重新获得了国王的宠信。
Unfortunately, however, Holbein's painting was highly idealized, and when die king finally met die princess she did not please him in die least. His anger against Cromwellfirst for the ill-conceived reforms, now for saddling him widi an unattractive and Protestant wifecould no longer be contained. In June of mat year, Cromwell was arrested, charged as a Protestant extremist and a heretic, and sent to die Tower. Six weeks later, before a large and enthusiastic crowd, the public executioner cut off his head.
然而不幸的是，霍尔拜因的画作过于理想化，当国王最终见到公主时，她丝毫没有让他满意。他对克伦威尔的愤怒——先是因为他那些考虑不周的改革，现在又因为他娶了一个相貌平庸的新教徒妻子——再也无法抑制。那年六月，克伦威尔被捕，被控为新教极端分子和异端，并被送往伦敦塔。六周后，在众多热情高涨的民众面前，刽子手砍下了他的头颅。
Interpretation
解释
Thomas Cromwell had a simple idea: He would break up die power and wealdi of the Church and lay die foundation for Protestantism in England. And he would do tfiis in a mercilessly short time. He knew his speedy reforms would cause pain and resentment, but he tiiought diese feelings would fade in a few years. More important, by identifying himself with change, he would become die leader of die new order, making die king dependent on him. But mere was a problem in his strategy: Like a billiard ball hit too hard against the cushion, his reforms had reactions and caroms he did not envision and could not control.
托马斯·克伦威尔的想法很简单：他要瓦解英国教会的权力和财富，为英国的基督教新教奠定基础。而且他要在极短的时间内完成这一切。他知道，他迅速的改革会带来痛苦和怨恨，但他认为这些情绪会在几年内消散。更重要的是，通过将自己与变革联系起来，他将成为新秩序的领袖，使国王对他产生依附。然而，他的策略存在一个问题：就像台球用力过猛撞击台边一样，他的改革产生了他始料未及且无法控制的反弹和影响。
The man who initiates strong reforms often becomes the scapegoat for any kind of dissatisfaction. And eventually me reaction to his reforms may consume him, for change is upsetting to the human animal, even when it is for die good. Because die world is and always has been full of insecurity and mreat, we latch on to familiar faces and create habits and rituals to make the world more comfortable. Change can be pleasant and even sometimes desirable in the abstract, but too much of it creates an anxiety that will stir and boil beneatii die surface and dien eventually erupt.
发起强力改革的人往往会成为各种不满情绪的替罪羊。最终，人们对他改革的反应可能会吞噬他自己，因为改变对人类来说总是令人不安的，即便改变是为了更好的未来。由于这个世界一直充满不安全感和焦虑，我们依附于熟悉的面孔，建立习惯和仪式，以使世界更加舒适。从理论上讲，改变可能是令人愉悦的，有时甚至是可取的，但过多的改变会引发焦虑，这种焦虑会在表面激起并最终爆发。
Never underestimate die hidden conservatism of those around you. It is powerful and entrenched. Never let die seductive charm of an idea cloud your reason: Just as you cannot make people see the world your way, you cannot wrench diem into die future with painful changes. They will rebel. If reform is necessary, anticipate die reaction against it and find ways to disguise the change and sweeten die poison.
永远不要低估身边人隐藏的保守主义。它根深蒂固，力量强大。永远不要让某种理念的诱惑蒙蔽了你的理智：正如你无法强迫别人接受你的观点一样，你也无法用痛苦的变革将他们强行拉入未来。他们会反抗。如果改革势在必行，就要预料到人们的反对，并想办法掩盖变革的本质，淡化其负面影响。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
As a young Communist in the 1920s, Mao Tse-tung understood better dian
作为一名20世纪20年代的年轻共产党员，毛泽东对民主有了更深刻的理解。
any of his colleagues die incredible odds against a Communist victory in
他的任何一位同事去世，都意味着共产党取得胜利的几率微乎其微。
China. With their small numbers, limited funds, lack of military experience, and small arsenal of weapons, the Party had no hope of success unless it won over China's immense peasant population. But who in the world was more conservative, more rooted in tradition, than the Chinese peasantry The oldest civilization on the planet had a history that would never loosen its power, no matter how violent the revolution. The ideas of Confucius remained as alive in the 1920s as they had been in the sixdi century B.C., when the philosopher was alive. Despite the oppressions of the current system, would the peasantry ever give up the deep-rooted values of die past for the great unknown of Communism
中国。由于人数少、资金有限、缺乏军事经验、武器库简陋，共产党若不能赢得中国庞大的农民群体的支持，就毫无成功的希望。然而，世界上还有谁比中国农民更保守、更根深蒂固于传统呢？地球上最古老的文明拥有着深厚的历史底蕴，无论革命多么残酷，它都从未动摇过自身的根基。孔子的思想在20世纪20年代依然鲜活如初，如同公元前6世纪这位哲学家在世时一样。尽管身处压迫之下，农民们是否会为了共产主义的未知未来而放弃根深蒂固的传统价值观呢？
The solution, as Mao saw it, involved a simple deception: Cloak the revolution in the clothing of the past, making it comforting and legitimate in people's eyes. One of Mao's favorite books was the very popular medieval Chinese novel The Water Margin, which recounts the exploits of a Chinese Robin Hood and his robber band as they struggle against a corrupt and evil monarch. In China in Mao's time, family ties dominated over any other kind, for the Confucian hierarchy of father and oldest son remained firmly in place; but The Water Margin preached a superior value die fraternal ties of the band of robbers, the nobility of the cause that unites people beyond blood. The novel had great emotional resonance for Chinese people, who love to root for the underdog. Time and again, then, Mao would present his revolutionary army as an extension of the robber band in The Water Margin, likening his struggle to the timeless conflict between the oppressed peasantry and an evil emperor. He made the past seem to envelop and legitimize the Communist cause; the peasantry could feel comfortable witii and even support a group with such roots in the past.
在毛泽东看来，解决之道在于一个简单的欺骗：将革命披上过去的外衣，使其在民众眼中显得安心且合法。毛泽东最喜欢的书之一是风靡一时的中国古代小说《水浒传》，这部小说讲述了中国版的罗宾汉和他的盗匪团伙反抗腐败暴君的故事。在毛泽东时代的中国，家族关系凌驾于其他一切关系之上，儒家父子至上的等级制度根深蒂固；但《水浒传》宣扬盗匪团伙之间兄弟情谊的至高价值，以及超越血缘将人们团结在一起的崇高事业。这部小说深深触动了中国人的情感，他们总是喜欢为弱者加油鼓劲。因此，毛泽东一次又一次地将他的革命军队比作《水浒传》中的盗匪团伙，将他的斗争比作受压迫的农民与暴君之间亘古不变的斗争。他让过去似乎能够包容和合法化共产主义事业；农民们可以安心地接受甚至支持一个有着如此深厚历史根基的团体。
Even once the Party came to power, Mao continued to associate it with the past. He presented himself to the masses not as a Chinese Lenin but as a modern Chuko Liang, the real-life third-century strategist who figures prominently in the popular historical novel The Romance of the Three Kingdoms. Liang was more man a great generalhe was a poet, a philosopher, and a figure of stern moral rectitude. So Mao represented himself as a poet-warrior like Liang, a man who mixed strategy with philosophy and preached a new ethics. He made himself appear like a hero from the great Chinese tradition of warrior statesmen.
即使在党掌权之后，毛泽东仍然将党与过去联系起来。他向群众展示的不是中国列宁，而是现代的楚可梁——这位真实存在的三世纪战略家在著名历史小说《三国演义》中占据重要地位。楚可梁不仅是一位伟大的将军，更是一位诗人、哲学家和道德高尚的典范。因此，毛泽东将自己塑造成像楚可梁一样的诗人战士，一位将战略与哲学相结合、倡导新伦理的人物。他把自己塑造成中国伟大武士政治家传统中的英雄。
Soon, everything in Mao's speeches and writings had a reference to an earlier period in Chinese history. He recalled, for example, the great Emperor Ch'in, who had unified the country in the third century B.C. Ch'in had burned the works of Confucius, consolidated and completed the building of the Great Wall, and given his name to China. Like Ch'in, Mao also had brought the country together, and had sought bold reforms against an oppressive past. Ch'in had traditionally been seen as a violent dictator whose reign was short; the brilliance of Mao's strategy was to turn this around, simultaneously reinterpreting Ch'in, justifying his rule in die eyes of present-day Chinese, and using him to justify the violence of the new order that Mao himself was creating.
很快，毛泽东的演讲和著作中处处都与中国历史上的某个时期有所关联。例如，他提到了公元前三世纪统一中国的秦始皇。秦始皇焚毁了孔子的著作，巩固并完成了长城的修建，并将自己的名字赋予了中国。与秦始皇一样，毛泽东也统一了国家，并寻求对压迫性的过去进行大胆的改革。传统上，秦始皇被视为一位统治短暂的残暴独裁者；毛泽东策略的精妙之处在于扭转了这种看法，一方面重新诠释了秦始皇，在当代中国人眼中为其统治辩护，另一方面又利用秦始皇来为毛泽东自己正在建立的新秩序中的暴力行为辩护。
After the failed Cultural Revolution of the late 1960s, a power struggle
20世纪60年代末文化大革命失败后，爆发了一场权力斗争。
emerged in die Communist Party in which Mao's main foe was Lin Rao, once a close friend of his. To make clear to die masses die difference between his philosophy and Lin's, Mao once again exploited die past: He cast his opponent as representing Confucius, a philosopher Lin in fact would constantiy quote. And Confucius signified die conservatism of die past. Mao associated himself, on die odier hand, widi die ancient philosophical movement known as Legalism, exemplified by die writings of Han-fei-tzu. The Legalists disdained Confucian ediics; tiiey believed in die need for violence to create a new order. They worshiped power. To give himself weight in die struggle, Mao unleashed a nationwide propaganda campaign against Confucius, using die issues of Confucianism versus Legalism to whip die young into a kind of frenzied revolt against die older generation. This grand context enveloped a ratiier banal power struggle, and Mao once again won over die masses and triumphed over his enemies.
毛泽东在共产党内崛起，他的主要对手是林饶，而林饶曾是他的挚友。为了向群众阐明他与林饶的哲学理念之间的差异，毛泽东再次利用历史：他将对手描绘成孔子的代表，而林饶实际上经常引用孔子的思想。孔子象征着过去的保守主义。另一方面，毛泽东将自己与古代哲学运动——法家联系起来，法家的代表人物是韩非子的著作。法家鄙视儒家的教诲；他们认为必须诉诸暴力才能建立新的秩序。他们崇尚权力。为了在斗争中增强自己的影响力，毛泽东发起了一场全国性的反孔宣传运动，利用儒家与法家之争煽动年轻人对老一辈进行狂热的反抗。在这种宏大背景下，一场相对平凡的权力斗争悄然展开，毛泽东再次赢得了群众的支持，战胜了他的敌人。
Interpretation
解释
No people had a more profound attachment to die past tiian die Chinese. In die face of tiiis enormous obstacle to reform, Mao's strategy was simple: Instead of struggling against die past, he turned it to his advantage, associating his radical Communists witii die romantic figures of Chinese history. Weaving the story of die War of die Three Kingdoms into die struggle between die United States, die Soviet Union, and China, he cast himself as Chuko Liang. As die emperors had, he welcomed die cultiike adoration of the masses, understanding tiiat die Chinese could not function witiiout some kind of father figure to admire. And after he made a terrible blunder widi die Great Leap Forward, trying to force modernization on die country and failing miserably, he never repeated his mistake: From men on, radical change had to be cloaked in die comfortable clotiies of die past.
没有哪个民族比中国人对过去的感情更深厚。面对改革的巨大阻力，毛泽东的策略很简单：他没有与过去抗争，而是利用过去，将激进的共产党人与中国历史上的浪漫人物联系起来。他将三国战争的故事融入中美苏三国斗争的史实中，把自己塑造成楚可梁。他像历代皇帝一样，欣然接受民众的崇拜，因为他明白中国人如果没有某种可以崇拜的“父亲”形象就无法正常运转。在“大跃进”运动中，他试图强行推行现代化，结果惨败，犯下了可怕的错误。此后，他再也没有重蹈覆辙：从他上任之初，任何激进的变革都必须披上舒适的“过去”外衣。
The lesson is simple: The past is powerful. What has happened before seems greater; habit and history give any act weight. Use tiiis to your advantage. When you destroy die familiar you create a void or vacuum; people fear die chaos tiiat will flood in to fill it. You must avoid stirring up such fears at all cost. Borrow the weight and legitimacy from die past, however remote, to create a comforting and familiar presence. This will give your actions romantic associations, add to your presence, and cloak die nature of die changes you are attempting.
道理很简单：过去的力量不容小觑。过去发生的事情似乎更胜一筹；习惯和历史赋予任何行为以分量。要善加利用。当你摧毁熟悉的一切时，就会造成空虚或真空；人们害怕混乱会涌入填补这个空缺。你必须不惜一切代价避免引发这种恐惧。无论过去多么遥远，都要借用过去的分量和合法性，营造一种令人感到舒适和熟悉的氛围。这将赋予你的行为浪漫的色彩，增强你的存在感，并掩盖你试图改变的本质。
It must be considered that there is nothing more difficult to carry out,
必须考虑到，没有什么比这更难执行的了。
nor more doubtful of success, nor more dangerous to handle,
既不比成功更令人怀疑，也不比处理起来更危险。
than to initiate a new order of things.
而不是建立新的秩序。
Niccolb Machiavelli, 1469-1527
尼科尔布·马基雅维利，1469-1527 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Human psychology contains many dualities, one of diem being tiiat even while people understand die need for change, knowing how important it is for institutions and individuals to be occasionally renewed, tiiey are also ir-
人类心理包含许多二元性，其中之一是，即使人们理解变革的必要性，知道机构和个人定期更新的重要性，他们仍然会感到不安。
ritated and upset by changes that affect diem personally. They know diat change is necessary, and that novelty provides relief from boredom, but deep inside they cling to the past. Change in die abstract, or superficial change, tiiey desire, but a change that upsets core habits and routines is deeply disturbing to diem.
他们会因直接影响到自身的变化而感到不安和焦虑。他们知道生活需要改变，新鲜感能让他们摆脱无聊，但内心深处，他们仍然依恋过去。抽象的、表面的变化或许能让他们感到满足，但任何扰乱核心习惯和日常规律的变化都会让他们感到极度不安。
No revolution has gone widiout a powerful later reaction against it, for in the long run die void it creates proves too unsettling to die human animal, who unconsciously associates such voids witii deatii and chaos. The opportunity for change and renewal seduces people to the side of die revolution, but once dieir enthusiasm fades, which it will, tiiey are left witii a certain emptiness. Yearning for die past, diey create an opening for it to creep back in.
任何革命都难免会遭到强烈的后续反弹，因为从长远来看，革命造成的空虚感对人类而言过于令人不安，因为人类会不自觉地将这种空虚感与死亡和混乱联系起来。变革和复兴的契机吸引人们加入革命，但一旦他们的热情消退（而这终将发生），他们便会感到一种莫名的空虚。对过去的怀念，反而为过去的卷土重来创造了可乘之机。
For Machiavelli, die prophet who preaches and brings change can only survive by taking up arms: When die masses inevitably yearn for the past, he must be ready to use force. But me armed prophet cannot last long unless he quickly creates a new set of values and rituals to replace die old ones, and to soodie die anxieties of diose who dread change. It is far easier, and less bloody, to play a kind of con game. Preach change as much as you like, and even enact your reforms, but give diem die comforting appearance of older events and traditions.
在马基雅维利看来，宣扬变革的先知只有诉诸武力才能生存：当民众不可避免地怀念过去时，他必须准备好使用武力。但这位武装先知若不迅速建立一套新的价值观和仪式来取代旧的，并安抚那些惧怕变革者的焦虑，便无法长久。玩弄一种欺骗游戏要容易得多，也少流血。你可以尽情宣扬变革，甚至推行改革，但要让他们感受到旧时事件和传统的慰藉。
Reigning from A.D. 8 to A.D. 23, die Chinese emperor Wang Mang emerged from a period of great historical turbulence in which die people yearned for order, an order represented for diem by Confucius. Some two hundred years earlier, however, Emperor Ch'in had ordered die writings of Confucius burned. A few years later, word had spread diat certain texts had miraculously survived, hidden under die scholar's house. These texts may not have been genuine, but they gave Wang his opportunity: He first confiscated diem, dien had his scribes insert passages into them diat seemed to support me changes he had been imposing on die country. When he released the texts, it seemed diat Confucius sanctioned Wang's reforms, and die people felt comforted and accepted diem more easily.
公元8年至23年在位的中国皇帝王莽，正值中国历史上的一段动荡时期，人民渴望秩序，而孔子正是这种秩序的象征。然而，大约两百年前，秦始皇曾下令焚毁孔子的著作。几年后，有消息传出，一些经文奇迹般地保存了下来，藏在一位学者的宅邸之下。这些经文或许并非真迹，但它们为王莽提供了机会：他先是没收了这些经文，然后让文士在其中插入一些似乎支持他推行改革的段落。当他将这些经文公之于众时，人们误以为孔子认可了王莽的改革，这让人民感到安心，也更容易接受这些改革。
Understand: The fact diat die past is dead and buried gives you die freedom to reinterpret it. To support your cause, tinker with die facts. The past is a text in which you can safely insert your own lines.
明白：过去已成往事，这赋予你重新诠释它的自由。为了支持你的论点，你可以对事实进行加工。过去就像一部文本，你可以安全地在其中插入自己的笔触。
A simple gesture like using an old title, or keeping die same number for a group, will tie you to die past and support you with die autiiority of history. As Machiavelli himself observed, die Romans used tiiis device when tiiey transformed dieir monarchy into a republic. They may have installed two consuls in place of die king, but since die king had been served by twelve lictors, they retained die same number to serve under the consuls. The king had personally performed an annual sacrifice, in a great spectacle that stirred die public; die republic retained diis practice, only transferring it to a special “chief of die ceremony, whom tiiey called die King of die sacrifice.” These and similar gestures satisfied die people and kept diem from clamoring for the monarchy's return.
像使用旧头衔或保持团体人数不变这样简单的举动，就能将你与过去联系起来，并以历史的权威性来支撑你。正如马基雅维利本人所观察到的，罗马人在将君主制转变为共和制时就运用了这种策略。他们或许用两位执政官取代了国王，但由于国王曾由十二位刽子手侍奉，他们保留了相同数量的刽子手在执政官之下任职。国王曾亲自主持一年一度的祭祀仪式，这一盛大的场面震撼了民众；共和国保留了这一习俗，只是将其移交给一位特殊的“仪式总管”，他被称为“祭祀之王”。这些以及类似的举措安抚了民众，使他们没有要求恢复君主制。
Anodier strategy to disguise change is to make a loud and public display of support for the values of die past. Seem to be a zealot for tradition
另一种掩盖变革的策略是高调公开地支持过去的价值观，表面上似乎是传统的狂热拥护者。
and few will notice how unconventional you really are. Renaissance Florence had a centuries-old republic, and was suspicious of anyone who flouted its traditions. Cosimo de' Medici made a show of enthusiastic support for the republic, while in reality he worked to bring the city under the control of his wealthy family. In form, die Medicis retained the appearance of a republic; in substance, they rendered it powerless. They quietly enacted a radical change, while appearing to safeguard tradition.
很少有人会注意到你其实有多么特立独行。文艺复兴时期的佛罗伦萨拥有数百年历史的共和国，对任何藐视其传统的人都抱有戒心。科西莫·德·美第奇表面上热情拥护共和国，实际上却致力于将这座城市置于其富裕家族的控制之下。美第奇家族在形式上保留了共和国的表象；在实质上，他们却使其丧失了权力。他们悄然推行了一场彻底的变革，同时又表面上维护着传统。
Science claims a search for truth that would seem to protect it from conservatism and the irrationality of habit: It is a culture of innovation. Yet when Charles Darwin published his ideas of evolution, he faced fiercer opposition from his fellow scientists than from religious authorities. His theories challenged too many fixed ideas. Jonas Salk ran into the same wall with his radical innovations in immunology, as did Max Planck with his revolutionizing of physics. Planck later wrote of the scientific opposition he faced, “A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die, and a new generation grows up that is familiar witii it.”
科学声称追求真理，这似乎能使其免受保守主义和非理性习惯的侵蚀：它是一种创新文化。然而，当查尔斯·达尔文发表进化论时，他所面临的来自同行科学家的反对比来自宗教权威的反对更为激烈。他的理论挑战了太多根深蒂固的观念。乔纳斯·索尔克在免疫学领域的革新也遭遇了同样的困境，马克斯·普朗克在物理学领域进行革命性变革时也遇到了同样的阻力。普朗克后来写道，他所面临的科学反对“并非通过说服反对者并让他们幡然醒悟而取得胜利，而是因为反对者最终会消亡，而熟悉这一真理的新一代会成长起来。”
The answer to this innate conservatism is to play die courtier's game. Galileo did this at the beginning of his scientific career; he later became more confrontational, and paid for it. So pay lip service to tradition. Identify the elements in your revolution that can be made to seem to build on the past. Say the right things, make a show of conformity, and meanwhile let your theories do their radical work. Play with appearances and respect past protocol. This is true in every arenascience being no exception.
应对这种与生俱来的保守主义的办法是玩弄朝臣之道。伽利略在其科学生涯初期就这么做了；后来他变得更加激进，并为此付出了代价。所以，口头上要尊重传统。找出你革命中那些可以伪装成建立在过去基础上的元素。说些得体的话，装出一副循规蹈矩的样子，同时让你的理论发挥其激进的作用。玩弄表面功夫，尊重过去的规矩。这适用于任何领域，科学也不例外。
Finally, powerful people pay attention to the Zeitgeist. If tiieir reform is too far ahead of its time, few will understand it, and it will stir up anxiety and be hopelessly misinterpreted. The changes you make must seem less innovative than they are. England did eventually become a Protestant nation, as Cromwell wished, but it took over a century of gradual evolution.
最后，有权势的人会关注时代精神。如果他们的改革过于超前，鲜有人能理解，反而会引发焦虑，并被彻底误解。你所做的改变必须显得不那么创新。英国最终如克伦威尔所愿成为一个新教国家，但这经历了一个多世纪的渐进演变。
Watch the Zeitgeist. If you work in a tumultuous time, there is power to be gained by preaching a return to the past, to comfort, tradition, and ritual. During a period of stagnation, on the other hand, play the card of reform and revolutionbut beware of what you stir up. Those who finish a revolution are rarely those who start it. You will not succeed at this dangerous game unless you are willing to forestall die inevitable reaction against it by playing with appearances and building on die past.
密切关注时代精神。如果身处动荡时期，宣扬回归过去、回归舒适、回归传统和回归仪式，便能获得力量。相反，在停滞时期，则可打出改革和革命的牌，但要警惕你所激起的波澜。革命的终结者往往并非革命的发起者。除非你愿意通过玩弄表面功夫和沿袭过去来阻止不可避免的反抗，否则你无法在这场危险的游戏中获胜。
Authority: He who desires or attempts to reform the government of a state, and wishes to have it accepted, must at least retain the semblance of the old forms; so that it may seem to the people that there has been no change in the institutions, even though in fact they are entirely different from the old ones. For the great majority of mankind are satisfied with appearances, as though they were realities. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：凡欲改革国家政府并希望改革成果被民众接受者，至少必须保留旧制度的表象；如此，民众才会觉得制度未曾改变，即便实际上已与旧制度截然不同。因为绝大多数人满足于表象，视之为现实。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
Image: The Cat.
图片：猫。
Creature of habit, it loves the
它习惯于按部就班，喜欢……
warmth of the familiar. Upset its
熟悉的温暖。扰乱了它
routines, disrupt its space, and it will
日常活动会扰乱它的空间，而且它会
grow unmanageable and psychotic.
变得难以控制且精神错乱。
Placate it by supporting its rituals. If
通过支持它的仪式来安抚它。如果
change is necessary, deceive the cat by
改变是必要的，欺骗猫咪
keeping the smell of the past alive;
让过去的芬芳永存；
place objects familiar to it in
放置它熟悉的物品
strategic locations.
战略位置。
REVERSAL
逆转
The past is a corpse to be used as you see fit. If what happened in the recent past was painful and harsh, it is self-destructive to associate yourself with it. When Napoleon came to power, the French Revolution was fresh in everyone's minds. If the court that he established had borne any resemblance to the lavish court of Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette, his courtiers would have spent all their time worrying about their own necks. Instead, Napoleon established a court remarkable for its sobriety and lack of ostentation. It was the court of a man who valued work and military virtues. This new form seemed appropriate and reassuring.
过去就像一具尸体，任你处置。如果近期发生的事情痛苦不堪，那么与它纠缠不清无异于自取灭亡。拿破仑掌权时，法国大革命的记忆犹新。如果他建立的宫廷与路易十六和玛丽·安托瓦内特的奢华宫廷有任何相似之处，他的朝臣们恐怕会终日忧心忡忡，提心吊胆。然而，拿破仑建立的宫廷却以朴素低调著称。这是一个重视勤勉和军事美德的人的宫廷。这种新的宫廷形式似乎合情合理，令人安心。
In other words, pay attention to the times. But understand: If you make a bold change from the past, you must avoid at all costs the appearance of a void or vacuum, or you will create terror. Even an ugly recent history will seem preferable to an empty space. Fill diat space immediately with new rituals and forms. Soothing and growing familiar, these will secure your position among the masses.
换句话说，要关注时代。但要明白：如果你要对过去做出大胆的改变，就必须不惜一切代价避免出现空白或真空，否则会引发恐慌。即使是丑陋的近代史也比一片空白要好。要立即用新的仪式和形式填补空白。这些仪式和形式要温和亲切，才能巩固你在群众中的地位。
Finally, the arts, fashion, and technology would seem to be areas in which power would come from creating a radical rupture with the past and appearing cutting edge. Indeed, such a strategy can bring great power, but it has many dangers. It is inevitable that your innovations will be outdone by someone else. You have little controlsomeone younger and fresher moves in a sudden new direction, making your bold innovation of yesterday seem tiresome and tame today. You are forever playing catch-up; your power is tenuous and short-lived. You want a power built on something more solid. Using the past, tinkering with tradition, playing with convention to subvert it will give your creations something more than a momentary appeal. Periods of dizzying change disguise the fact that a yearning for the past will inevitably creep back in. In the end, using the past for your own purposes will bring you more power than trying to cut it out completelya futile and self-destructive endeavor.
最后，艺术、时尚和科技领域似乎都蕴藏着权力，而权力的来源在于与过去彻底决裂，并展现出前卫的姿态。的确，这样的策略能够带来巨大的权力，但也伴随着诸多危险。你的创新终将被他人超越，这是不可避免的。你几乎无法掌控局面——更年轻、更有活力的人可能会突然转向新的方向，让你昨日的大胆创新在今天显得平庸乏味。你永远都在追赶；你的权力脆弱而短暂。你需要的是一种建立在更坚实基础上的权力。利用过去，对传统进行改造，玩转传统以颠覆它，才能赋予你的作品超越短暂吸引力的持久价值。令人眼花缭乱的变革掩盖了一个事实：对过去的渴望终将悄然回归。最终，利用过去为己所用，比试图彻底摒弃过去——一种徒劳且自我毁灭的尝试——更能为你带来力量。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 46
第46条
NEVER APPEAR TOO PERFECT
永远不要表现得过于完美
JUDGMENT
判断
Appearing better than others is always dangerous, but most dangerous of all is to appear to have no faults or weaknesses. Envy creates silent enemies. It is smart to occasionally display defects, and admit to harmless vices, in order to deflect envy and appear more human and approachable. Only gods and the dead can seem perfect with impunity.
表现得比别人优秀总是危险的，但最危险的莫过于表现得完美无瑕。嫉妒会制造无声的敌人。偶尔展现一些缺点，承认一些无伤大雅的小恶习，是明智之举，这样可以化解嫉妒，让自己显得更有人情味、更平易近人。只有神明和亡灵才能毫无顾忌地展现完美。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
Joe Orton met Kenneth HaJliwell at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, London, in 1953, where bodi had enrolled as acting students. They soon became lovers and moved in together. Halliwell, twenty-five at the time, was seven years older than Orton, and seemed the more confident of the two; but neither had much talent as actors, and after graduating, having settled down together in a dank London apartment, they decided to give up acting and collaborate as writers instead. Halliwell's inheritance was enough to keep them from having to find work for a few years, and in the beginning, he was also the driving force behind the stories and novels they wrote; he would dictate to Orton, who would type the manuscripts, occasionally interjecting his own lines and ideas. Their first efforts attracted some interest from literary agents, but it sputtered. The promise they had shown was leading nowhere.
1953年，乔·奥顿在伦敦皇家戏剧艺术学院结识了肯尼斯·哈利韦尔，当时奥顿正在那里学习表演。两人很快坠入爱河并同居。哈利韦尔当时25岁，比奥顿大7岁，看起来也更自信一些；但两人都没有什么表演天赋，毕业后，他们在伦敦一间阴暗潮湿的公寓里安顿下来，决定放弃演戏，转而合作写作。哈利韦尔的遗产足以让他们在几年内不用为生计奔波，而且在创作初期，他也是故事和小说的主要推动者；他会口述给奥顿，奥顿则负责打字，偶尔也会加入一些自己的台词和想法。他们的早期作品吸引了一些文学经纪人的注意，但很快就销声匿迹了。他们展现出的潜力最终未能转化为现实。
Eventually the inheritance money ran out, and the pair had to look for work. Their collaborations were less enthusiastic and less frequent. The future looked bleak.
最终，继承的遗产用完了，两人不得不另谋生路。他们的合作热情大减，频率也降低了。未来一片黯淡。
In 1957 Orton began to write on his own, but it wasn't until five years later, when the lovers were jailed for six montfis for defacing dozens of library books, that he began to find his voice (perhaps not by chance: This was the first time he and HaJliwell had been separated in nine years). He came out of prison determined to express his contempt for English society in uie form of theatrical farces. He and Halliwell moved back in together, but now the roles were reversed: Orton did the writing while Halliwell put in comments and ideas.
1957年，奥顿开始独自写作，但直到五年后，他和哈利韦尔因损毁数十本图书馆书籍而被判入狱六个月，他才开始找到自己的创作风格（或许并非偶然：这是他和哈利韦尔九年来第一次分开）。出狱后，他决心以戏剧闹剧的形式表达他对英国社会的蔑视。他和哈利韦尔重归于好，但角色互换：奥顿负责写作，而哈利韦尔则提出意见和想法。
In 1964 Joe Orton completed his first full-length play, Entertaining Mr. Sloane. The play made it to London's West End, where it received brilliant reviews: A great new writer had emerged from nowhere. Now success followed s access, at a dizzying pace. In 1966 Orton had a hit with his play Loot, and his popularity soared. Soon commissions came in from all sides, including from the Beatles, who paid Orton handsomely to write them a film script.
1964年，乔·奥顿完成了他的第一部完整剧作《款待斯隆先生》。该剧在伦敦西区上演，并获得了极高的评价：一位才华横溢的新锐作家横空出世。此后，成功如潮水般涌来，令人目眩神迷。1966年，奥顿凭借剧作《战利品》一炮而红，人气飙升。很快，各方邀约纷至沓来，其中包括披头士乐队，他们慷慨地支付奥顿一笔费用，请他为他们创作电影剧本。
Everything was pointing upwards, everything except Orton's relationship with Kenneth Halliwell. The pair still lived togedier, but as Orton grew successful, HaJliwell began to deteriorate. Watching his lover become the center of attention, he suffered die humiliation of becoming a kind of personal assistant to the playwright, his role in what had once been a collaboration growing smaller and smaller. In the 1950s he had supported Orton with his inheritance; now Orton supported him. At a party or among friends, people would naturally gravitate towards Ortonhe was charming, and his mood was almost always buoyant. Unlike the handsome Orton, Halliwell was bald and awkward; his defensiveness made people want to avoid him.
一切都在好转，唯独奥顿与肯尼斯·哈利韦尔的关系出现了裂痕。两人依然住在一起，但随着奥顿事业的成功，哈利韦尔的境况却每况愈下。眼看着爱人成为众人瞩目的焦点，他却屈辱地沦为剧作家的私人助理，曾经的合作关系也日渐式微。上世纪五十年代，他曾用遗产资助奥顿；如今，奥顿反过来资助他。在聚会或朋友聚会上，人们自然而然地会围着奥顿转——他魅力四射，总是兴高采烈。与英俊的奥顿不同，哈利韦尔秃顶，举止笨拙；他的防备心让人避之不及。
With Orton's success the couple's problems only worsened. Halliwell's moods made their life together impossible. Orton claimed to want to leave him, and had numerous affairs, but would always end up returning to his
随着奥顿的成功，这对夫妇的问题反而愈演愈烈。霍利韦尔喜怒无常，让他们的共同生活举步维艰。奥顿声称想要离开他，并且有过多次婚外情，但最终总是会回到他身边。
A greedy man and an envious man met a king. The king said to them, “One of you may ask something of me and 1 will give it to him, provided I give twice as much to the other.” The envious person did not want to ask first for he was envious of his companion who would receive twice as much, and the greedy man did not want to ask first since he wanted everything that was to be had. Finally the greedy one pressed the envious one to be the first to make the request. So the envious person asked the king to pluck out one of his eyes.
一个贪婪的人和一个嫉妒的人遇见了国王。国王对他们说：“你们俩可以各自向我求点什么，我会满足他，但前提是我要给另一个人双倍的报酬。”嫉妒的人不敢先开口，因为他嫉妒同伴能得到双倍的报酬；贪婪的人也不敢先开口，因为他想要得到一切。最后，贪婪的人逼着嫉妒的人先开口。于是，嫉妒的人请求国王挖出他的一只眼睛。
Jewish parable, the seven deadly sins, Solomon Schimmel, 1992
犹太寓言，七宗罪，所罗门·施梅尔，1992年
An admirer who feels that he cannot be happy by surrendering himself elects to become envious of that which he admires. So he speaks another languagethe thing which he really admires is called a stupid, insipid and queer sort of thing. Admiration is happy self-surrender; envy is unhappy self-assertion.
一个仰慕者如果觉得全然臣服无法获得快乐，便会选择嫉妒自己所仰慕的事物。于是，他用另一种语言来表达——他真正仰慕的事物被他称为愚蠢、乏味、怪异的东西。仰慕是快乐的自我臣服；嫉妒是不快乐的自我主张。
SqIren Kierkegaard, 1813-1855
艾琳·克尔凯郭尔，1813-1855
It takes great talent and
这需要极高的天赋和
skill to conceal one's
善于隐藏自己的
talent and skill.
天赋和技能。
La Rochefoucauld, 1613-1680
拉罗什福科，1613-1680
KNVYTOUMKNTS ACI.Al'HOS
KNVYTOUMKNTS ACI.Al'HOS
The goddess Minerva made her way to the house of Envy, a house filthy with dark and noisome slime. It is hidden away in the depths of the valleys, where the sun never penetrates, where no wind blows through; a gloomy dwelling, permeated by numbing chill, ever fireless, ever shrouded in thick darkness. When Minerva reached this spot she stopped in front of the house ... and struck the doors with the tip of her spear, and at the blow they flew open and revealed Envy within, busy at a meal of snake's flesh, the food on which she nourished her wickedness. At the sight, Minerva turned her eyes away. But the other rose heavily from the ground, leaving the half-eaten corpses, and came out with dragging steps. When she saw the goddess in all the brilliance of her beauty, in her flashing armor, she groaned.... Envy's face was sickly pale, her whole body lean and wasted, and
女神密涅瓦来到嫉妒之屋，那是一座肮脏不堪、污秽不堪的宅邸，藏身于山谷深处，阳光永远无法穿透，微风也吹不进来；这是一座阴森恐怖的住所，寒气逼人，永无火光，永远笼罩在浓重的黑暗之中。密涅瓦到达此处后，在宅邸前停了下来……用长矛尖猛击大门，大门应声而开，露出了里面的嫉妒，她正忙着享用蛇肉，那是她滋养邪恶的食物。看到这番景象，密涅瓦别过脸去。但嫉妒却沉重地从地上爬起来，留下那些被啃食了一半的蛇尸，拖着脚步走了出来。当她看到女神光彩照人、身披闪亮盔甲的模样时，她呻吟了一声……嫉妒的脸色苍白得病态，整个人瘦骨嶙峋，憔悴不堪，
old friend and lover. He tried to help Halliwell launch a career as an artist, even arranging for a gallery to show his work, but the show was a flop, and this only heightened HalliwelPs sense of inferiority. In May of 1967, the pair went on a brief holiday together in Tangier, Morocco. During the trip, Orton wrote in his diary, “We sat talking of how happy we felt. And how it couldn't, surely, last. We'd have to pay for it. Or we'd be struck down from afar by disaster because we were, perhaps, too happy. To be young, good-looking, healthy, famous, comparatively rich and happy is surely going against nature.”
老朋友兼情人。他曾试图帮助哈利韦尔开启艺术生涯，甚至安排画廊举办他的作品展，但展览惨败，这反而加剧了哈利韦尔的自卑感。1967年5月，两人一同前往摩洛哥丹吉尔短暂度假。旅途中，奥顿在日记中写道：“我们坐着谈论着我们感到多么幸福。以及这种幸福肯定不会长久。我们终究要为此付出代价。或者，我们会因为太过幸福而被远方的灾难击垮。年轻、英俊、健康、有名、相对富有且幸福，这难道不是违背自然规律吗？”
Halliwell outwardly seemed as happy as Orton. Inwardly, though, he was seething. And two months later, in the early morning of August 10, 1967, just days after helping Orton put the finishing touches to the wicked fa' ce What the Butler Saw (undoubtedly his masterpiece), Kenneth Halliwell bludgeoned Joe Orton to death with repeated blows of a hammer to the head. He then took twenty-one sleeping pills and died himself, leaving behind a note that read, “If you read Orton's diary all will be explained.”
哈利韦尔表面上看起来和奥顿一样快乐。然而，他内心却怒火中烧。两个月后，1967年8月10日清晨，就在几天前，他刚刚帮助奥顿完成了那部邪恶的影片《管家所见》（无疑是他的杰作），肯尼斯·哈利韦尔用锤子反复猛击乔·奥顿的头部，将其残忍杀害。随后，他吞服了21片安眠药，也随之死去，留下了一张字条：“如果你读过奥顿的日记，一切都会真相大白。”
Interpretation
解释
Kenneth Halliwell had tried to cast his deterioration as mental illness, but what Joe Orton's diaries revealed to him was the truth: It was envy, pure and simple, that lay at the heart of his sickness. The diaries, which Halliwell read on the sly, recounted the couple's days as equals and their struggle for recognition. After Orton found success, the diaries began to describe HalliwelPs brooding, his rude comments at parties, his growing sense of inferiority. All of this Orton narrated with a distance that bordered on contempt.
肯尼斯·哈利韦尔曾试图将自己的病情恶化归咎于精神疾病，但乔·奥顿的日记却向他揭示了真相：他病根的，纯粹是嫉妒。哈利韦尔偷偷阅读的日记，记录了两人曾经平等相处的日子，以及他们为获得认可而奋斗的历程。奥顿功成名就之后，日记开始描写哈利韦尔的阴郁、他在聚会上的粗鲁言辞，以及他日益增长的自卑感。奥顿以一种近乎轻蔑的疏离视角叙述了这一切。
The diaries made clear Halliwell's bitterness over Orton's success. Eventually the only thing that would have satisfied him would have been for Orton to have a failure of his own, an unsuccessful play perhaps, so that they could have commiserated in their failure, as they had done years before. When the opposite happenedas Orton grew only more successful and popularHalliwell did the only thing that would make them equals again: He made them equals in death. With Orton's murder, he became almost as famous as his friendposthumously.
日记清楚地表明了霍利韦尔对奥顿成功的怨恨。最终，唯一能让他感到满足的，就是奥顿也遭遇一次失败——比如一部失败的戏剧——这样他们就能像多年前那样，在失败中互相安慰。然而事与愿违，奥顿的事业和人气与日俱增。霍利韦尔做了唯一能让他们再次平等的事情：在死后与他们平等。随着奥顿的遇害，他死后几乎与朋友一样声名显赫。
Joe Orton only partly understood his lover's deterioration. His attempt to help Halliwell launch a career in art registered for what it was: charity and guilt. Orton basically had two possible solutions to the problem. He could have downplayed his own success, displaying some faults, deflecting Halliwell's envy; or, once he realized the nature of the problem, he could have fled as if Halliwell were a viper, as in fact he wasa viper of envy. Once envy eats away at someone, everything you do only makes it grow, and day by day it festers inside him. Eventually he will attack.
乔·奥顿对爱人的堕落只有部分了解。他试图帮助霍利韦尔开启艺术生涯，但最终却暴露了其本质：出于慈善和愧疚。奥顿基本上只有两种解决办法。他可以淡化自己的成功，展现一些缺点，以此转移霍利韦尔的嫉妒；或者，一旦他意识到问题的本质，他可以像躲避毒蛇一样逃离霍利韦尔，因为事实上，霍利韦尔就是一条嫉妒的毒蛇。一旦嫉妒侵蚀了一个人，你所做的一切都只会让它滋长，日复一日地在他心中溃烂。最终，他会发起攻击。
Only a minority can succeed at the game of life, and that minority inevitably arouses the envy of those around them. Once success happens your way, however, the people to fear the most are those in your own circle, the friends and acquaintances you have left behind. Feelings of inferi-
只有少数人能在人生这场游戏中取得成功，而这少数人必然会招致周围人的嫉妒。然而，一旦你获得成功，最需要提防的却是你身边的人，那些被你抛在身后的朋友和熟人。自卑感——
ority gnaw at them; the thought of your success only heightens their feelings of stagnation. Envy, which the philosopher Kierkegaard calls “unhappy admiration,” takes hold. You may not see it but you will feel it somedayunless, that is, you learn strategies of deflection, little sacrifices to the gods of success. Either dampen your brilliance occasionally, purposefully revealing a defect, weakness, or anxiety, or attributing your success to luck; or simply find yourself new friends. Never underestimate the power of envy.
嫉妒如影随形，你的成功只会加剧他们停滞不前的感觉。哲学家克尔凯郭尔称之为“不幸的钦佩”的嫉妒，便会悄然滋生。你或许现在还看不到它，但总有一天你会感受到它——除非你学会一些应对策略，哪怕只是向成功之神献上一些小小的祭品。你可以偶尔收敛一下你的光芒，故意暴露一些缺点、弱点或焦虑，或者把成功归功于运气；又或者干脆结交一些新朋友。永远不要低估嫉妒的力量。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
The merchant class and the craft guilds to which medieval Florence owed its prosperity had created a republic that protected them from oppression by the nobility. Since high office could only be held for a few months, no one could gain lasting dominance, and although this meant that the political factions struggled constantly for control, the system kept out tyrants and petty dictators. The Medici family lived for several centuries under this system without making much of a mark. They had modest origins as apothecaries, and were typical middle-class citizens. Not until the late fourteenth century, when Giovanni de' Medici made a modest fortune in banking, did they emerge as a force to be reckoned with.
中世纪佛罗伦萨的繁荣得益于商人阶级和行会，他们建立了一个共和国，使他们免受贵族的压迫。由于高官任期只有几个月，没有人能够长期掌权。虽然这意味着各政治派别之间不断争夺权力，但这一制度有效地阻止了暴君和小独裁者的出现。美第奇家族在这一制度下生活了几个世纪，却鲜为人知。他们出身卑微，最初是药剂师，是典型的中产阶级公民。直到十四世纪末，乔瓦尼·德·美第奇在银行业积累了一笔可观的财富后，他们才开始崛起，成为一股不可忽视的力量。
Upon Giovanni's death, his son Cosimo took over the family business, and quickly demonstrated his talent for it. The business prospered under his control and the Medicis emerged as one of the preeminent banking families of Europe. But they had a rival in Florence: Despite the city's republican system, one family, the Albizzis, had managed over the years to monopolize control of the government, forging alliances that allowed them to constantiy fill important offices with their own men. Cosimo did not fight this, and in fact gave the Albizzis his tacit support. At the same time, while the Albizzis were beginning to flaunt their power, Cosimo made a point of staying in the background.
乔瓦尼去世后，他的儿子科西莫接管了家族企业，并很快展现出卓越的才能。在他的领导下，企业蓬勃发展，美第奇家族也跻身欧洲首屈一指的银行家族之列。然而，他们在佛罗伦萨却面临着一个强劲的对手：尽管佛罗伦萨实行共和制，但阿尔比齐家族多年来却牢牢掌控着政府，通过结成联盟，不断地将自己的亲信安插到重要职位上。科西莫对此并未采取任何行动，反而默许了阿尔比齐家族的权力扩张。与此同时，当阿尔比齐家族开始炫耀其权力时，科西莫却刻意保持低调。
Eventually, however, the Medici wealth could not be ignored, and in 1433, feeling threatened by the family, the Albizzis used their government muscle to have Cosimo arrested on charges of conspiring to overthrow the republic. Some in the Albizzi faction wanted Cosimo executed, others feared this would spark a civil war. In the end they exiled him from Florence. Cosimo did not fight the sentence; he left quietly. Sometimes, he knew, it is wiser to bide one's time and keep a low profile.
然而，美第奇家族的财富最终还是不容忽视。1433年，阿尔比齐家族感到受到威胁，便动用政府权力，以密谋推翻共和国的罪名逮捕了科西莫。阿尔比齐派系内部有人想处决科西莫，也有人担心这会引发内战。最终，他们将他驱逐出佛罗伦萨。科西莫没有抗争，而是悄然离去。他明白，有时候，保持低调、静观其变才是明智之举。
Over the next year, the Albizzis began to stir up fears that they were setting up a dictatorship. Meanwhile, Cosimo, using his wealth to advantage, continued to exert influence on Florentine affairs, even from exile. A civil war broke out in the city, and in September of 1434 the Albizzis were toppled from power and sent into exile. Cosimo immediately returned to Florence, his position restored. But he saw that he now faced a delicate situation: If he seemed ambitious, as the Albizzis had, he would stir up opposition and envy that would ultimately threaten his business. If he stayed on
在接下来的一年里，阿尔比齐家族开始散布谣言，声称他们正在建立独裁政权。与此同时，科西莫利用自己的财富，即使身处流亡，也继续对佛罗伦萨的事务施加影响。佛罗伦萨爆发了内战，1434年9月，阿尔比齐家族被推翻并流放。科西莫立即返回佛罗伦萨，恢复了地位。但他意识到自己现在面临着一个棘手的局面：如果他像阿尔比齐家族那样显得野心勃勃，就会引发反对和嫉妒，最终危及他的事业。如果他继续留在佛罗伦萨，可能会引发政治动荡。
she squinted horribly; her teeth were discolored and decayed, her poisonous breast of a greenish hue, and her tongue dripped venom. Only the sight of suffering could bring a smile to her lips. She never knew the comfort of sleep, but was kept constantly awake by care and anxiety, looked with dismay on men's good fortune, and grew thin at the sight. Gnawing at others, and being gnawed, she was herself her own torment. Minerva, in spite of her loathing, yet addressed her briefly: “Instill your poison into one of Cecrop 's daughters her name is Aglauros. This is what I require of you.” Without another word she pushed against the ground with her spear, left the earth, and soared upwards. From the corner of her eye the other watched the goddess out of sight, muttering and angry that Minerva \s plan should be successful. Then she took her staff, all encircled with thorny briars, wrapped herself in dark clouds, and set forth. Wherever she went she trampled down the flowery fields, withered up the grass, seared the treeto'ps, and with her breath tainted the peoples, their cities and their homes, until at length she came to Athens, the home of wit and wealth, peaceful and prosperous. She could scarcely refrain from weeping when she saw no cause for tears.
她眯起眼睛，面目狰狞；牙齿变色腐烂，胸口泛着青绿色的毒液，舌头滴着毒液。只有看到痛苦，她才能露出笑容。她从未体验过安眠的舒适，忧虑和焦虑让她终日无法入睡，她对男人的好运感到沮丧，并因此日渐消瘦。她折磨别人，也被别人折磨，她自己就是自己的痛苦。尽管憎恨她，米涅瓦还是简短地对她说：“把你的毒注入刻克洛普的女儿之一体内，她的名字叫阿格劳罗斯。这是我对你的命令。”说完，她一言不发，用长矛猛地一蹬地面，腾空而起，直冲云霄。她用眼角余光瞥着远处的女神，愤怒地低语着，希望米涅瓦的计划能够成功。于是她拿起一根缠满荆棘的杖，裹上乌云，出发了。她所到之处，都践踏着鲜花盛开的田野，使青草枯萎，灼烧着树梢，她的气息玷污了人们、他们的城市和家园，直到最后她来到了雅典——这座充满智慧和财富、和平繁荣的城市。她几乎无法抑制住泪水，尽管她并没有看到任何值得哭泣的理由。
Then entering the chamber of Cecrop 's daughter, she carried out Minerva's orders. She touched the girl's breast with a hand dipped in malice, filled her heart with spiky thorns, and breathing in a black and evil poison dispersed it through her very bones, instilling the venom deep in her heart. That the reason for her distress might not be far to seek, she set before Aglauros' eyes a vision of her sister, of that sister's fortunate marriage [with the god Mercury I, and of the god in all his handsomeness; and she exaggerated the glory of it all. So Aglauros was tormented by such thoughts, and the jealous anger she concealed ate into her heart. Day and night she sighed, unceasingly wretched, and in her utter misery wasted away in a slow decline, as when ice is melted by the fitful sun. The fire that was kindled within her at the thought of her sister's luck and good fortune was like the burning of weeds which do not burst into flames, but are none the less consumed by smoldering fire.
于是，她进入了刻克洛普之女的房间，执行了密涅瓦的命令。她用沾满恶意的手触碰了女孩的胸膛，在她的心脏里扎满了尖刺，并吸入了一种黑色的邪恶毒液，使其渗透到女孩的骨骼深处，毒液深深地注入她的心脏。为了让阿格劳罗斯更容易找到她痛苦的原因，她向她展示了她姐姐的景象，姐姐与墨丘利一世神幸福的婚姻，以及墨丘利一世英俊的模样；她夸大了这一切的荣耀。阿格劳罗斯因此饱受折磨，她隐藏的嫉妒之怒啃噬着她的心。她日夜叹息，痛苦不堪，在极度的痛苦中慢慢消逝，如同冰雪被时断时续的阳光融化一般。想到妹妹的好运和幸福，她心中燃起的怒火就像燃烧的杂草，虽然不会瞬间燃起火焰，但也会被闷烧的火焰吞噬。
metamorphosrs, Ovid, 43 b.c.-c. a.d. 18
变形记，奥维德，公元前43年-公元18年左右
the sidelines, on die other hand, he would leave an opening for another faction to rise up as die Albizzis had, and to punish the Medicis for their success.
另一方面，他会给其他派系一个机会，让他们像阿尔比齐家族那样崛起，并惩罚美第奇家族的成功。
Cosimo solved me problem in two ways: He secretiy used his wealth to buy influence among key citizens, and he placed his own allies, all cleverly enlisted from the middle classes to disguise their allegiance to him, in top government positions. Those who complained of his growing political clout were taxed into submission, or dieir properties were bought out from under them by Cosimo's banker allies. The republic survived in name only. Cosimo held the strings.
科西莫用两种方法解决了我的问题：他暗中利用财富收买关键人物，并将自己的盟友安插到政府要职——这些盟友都是他巧妙地从中产阶级中拉拢而来，以掩盖他们对他的真实效忠。那些抱怨他日益增长的政治影响力的人，要么被征收重税迫使屈服，要么他们的财产被科西莫的银行家盟友收购。共和国名存实亡，科西莫才是真正的幕后操纵者。
While he worked behind the scenes to gain control, however, publicly Cosimo presented anomer picture. When he walked through the streets of Florence, he dressed modestly, was attended by no more dian one servant, and bowed deferentially to magistrates and elder citizens. He rode a mule instead of a horse. He never spoke out on matters of public import, even though he controlled Florence's foreign affairs for over thirty years. He gave money to charities and maintained his ties to Florence's merchant class. He financed all kinds of public buildings that fed die Florentines' pride in dieir city. When he built a palace for himself and his family in nearby Fiesole, he turned down the ornate designs that Brunelleschi had drawn up for him and instead chose a modest structure designed by Michelozzo, a man of humble Florentine origins. The palace was a symbol of Cosimo's strategyall simplicity on the outside, all elegance and opulence within.
然而，尽管科西莫在幕后运作以巩固权力，但他在公众面前却展现出截然不同的形象。当他漫步在佛罗伦萨的街头时，衣着朴素，身边只有一位仆人，并恭敬地向官员和长者鞠躬。他骑骡子而不是骑马。尽管他掌控佛罗伦萨的外交事务长达三十余年，却从未就重大公共事务发表过任何意见。他慷慨解囊，捐助慈善机构，并与佛罗伦萨的商人阶层保持着密切联系。他资助兴建各种公共建筑，增强了佛罗伦萨人对这座城市的自豪感。当他在附近的菲耶索莱为自己和家人建造宫殿时，他拒绝了布鲁内莱斯基为他设计的华丽方案，而是选择了出身佛罗伦萨平民的米开罗佐设计的朴素建筑。这座宫殿象征着科西莫的策略——外表简洁，内里却极尽奢华。
Cosimo finally died in 1464, after ruling for thirty years. The citizens of Florence wanted to build him a great tomb, and to celebrate his memory with elaborate funeral ceremonies, but on his deathbed he had asked to be buried without “any pomp or demonstration.” Some sixty years later, Machiavelli hailed Cosimo as the wisest of all princes, “for he knew how extraordinary things that are seen and appear every hour make men much more envied than those that are done in deed and are covered over with decency.”
科西莫在位三十年后，于1464年去世。佛罗伦萨的市民们想为他建造一座宏伟的陵墓，并以隆重的葬礼来纪念他，但他临终前却要求“一切从简”。大约六十年后，马基雅维利称赞科西莫是所有君主中最睿智的，“因为他深知，那些每时每刻都能看到的非凡之事，比那些默默无闻、掩藏于体面之下的事迹，更能令人艳羡。”
Interpretation
解释
A close friend of Cosimo's, the bookseller Vespasiano da Bisticci, once wrote of him, “And whenever he wished to achieve something, he saw to it, in order to escape envy as much as possible, that the initiative appeared to come from others, and not from him.” One of Cosimo's favorite expressions was, “Envy is a weed that should not be watered.” Understanding the power envy has in a democratic environment, Cosimo avoided die appearance of greatness. This does not mean tiiat greatness should be suffocated, or that only the mediocre should survive; only tiiat a game of appearances must be played. The insidious envy of the masses can actually be deflected quite easily: Appear as one of them in style and values. Make alliances with those below you, and elevate them to positions of power to secure their support in times of need. Never flaunt your wealth, and carefully conceal
科西莫的挚友，书商韦斯帕西亚诺·达·比斯蒂奇曾这样评价他：“每当他想有所成就时，为了尽可能避免引起嫉妒，他总是设法让别人觉得这是他自己的功劳，而不是他自己的。”科西莫最喜欢的一句话是：“嫉妒就像杂草，不该浇水。”他深知嫉妒在民主环境中的强大力量，因此避免给人留下伟大的印象。但这并不意味着应该扼杀伟大，或者只有平庸之辈才能生存；而是说，我们需要玩一场“表象游戏”。其实，要巧妙地化解民众的嫉妒：在风格和价值观上与他们保持一致；与地位低于你的人结盟，提拔他们到权力位置，以便在需要时获得他们的支持；永远不要炫耀财富，并小心地隐藏起来。
the degree to which it has bought influence. Make a display of deferring to others, as if they were more powerful than you. Cosimo de' Medici perfected this game; he was a consummate con artist of appearances. No one could gauge the extent of his powerhis modest exterior hid the truth.
它所获得的影响力程度。装出一副顺从他人的样子，仿佛他们比你更有权势。科西莫·德·美第奇将这种伎俩发挥到了极致；他是一位伪装大师。没有人能真正了解他的权力大小——他谦逊的外表掩盖了真相。
Never be so foolish as to believe that you are stirring up admiration by flaunting the qualities that raise you above others. By making others aware of their inferior position, you are only stirring up “unhappy admiration,” or envy, which will gnaw away at them until they undermine you in ways you cannot foresee. The fool dares the gods of envy by flaunting his victories. The master of power understands that die appearance of superiority over others is inconsequential next to the reality of it.
千万不要愚蠢到以为炫耀自己凌驾于他人之上的特质就能博得他人的钦佩。你让别人意识到自己的不足，只会激起他们“不快乐的钦佩”，也就是嫉妒，这种嫉妒会像毒瘤一样啃噬着他们，最终让他们以你无法预料的方式反噬你。愚人炫耀胜利，无异于挑战嫉妒之神。真正掌握权力的人明白，表面上的优越感与真正的实力相比，根本微不足道。
Of all the disorders of the soul, envy is the only one no one confesses to.
在所有心灵疾病中，嫉妒是唯一一种无人承认的疾病。
Plutarch, c. A.D. 46-120
普鲁塔克，约公元46-120年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The human animal has a hard time dealing with feelings of inferiority. In the face of superior skill, talent, or power, we are often disturbed and ill at ease; this is because most of us have an inflated sense of ourselves, and when we meet people who surpass us they make it clear to us mat we are in fact mediocre, or at least not as brilliant as we had thought. This disturbance in our self-image cannot last long wimout stirring up ugly emotions. At first we feel envy: If only we had die quality or skill of the superior person, we would be happy. But envy brings us neither comfort nor any closer to equality. Nor can we admit to feeling it, for it is frowned upon socially to show envy is to admit to feeling inferior. To close friends, we may confess our secret unrealized desires, but we will never confess to feeling envy. So it goes underground. We disguise it in many ways, like finding grounds to criticize the person who makes us feel it: He may be smarter tiian I am, we say, but he has no morals or conscience. Or he may have more power, but that's because he cheats. If we do not slander him, perhaps we praise him excessivelyanother of envy's disguises.
人类很难应对自卑感。面对比自己更优秀的技能、才华或能力，我们常常感到不安和不自在；这是因为我们大多数人都高估了自己的能力，而当我们遇到比自己更优秀的人时，他们会让我们意识到自己其实很平庸，或者至少没有自己想象的那么出色。这种自我认知上的动摇不会持续太久，必然会激起负面情绪。起初，我们会感到嫉妒：如果我们拥有比自己优秀的人的品质或技能，我们就会感到快乐。但嫉妒既不能给我们带来安慰，也不能让我们更接近平等。我们也不能承认自己有这种感觉，因为在社交场合，表现出嫉妒就等于承认自己感到自卑，这令人不齿。我们或许会向亲密的朋友吐露自己未实现的秘密愿望，但我们绝不会承认自己有嫉妒的情绪。于是，这种感觉就被我们压抑在心底。我们用各种方式掩饰嫉妒，比如找借口批评让我们产生这种感觉的人：我们说，他可能比我聪明，但他没有道德和良知。或者，他可能更有权势，但那是因为他作弊。如果我们不诽谤他，或许会过分赞美他——这也是嫉妒的另一种伪装。
There are several strategies for dealing widi the insidious, destructive emotion of envy. First, accept the fact diat there will be people who will surpass you in some way, and also tile fact that you may envy them. But make that feeling a way of pushing yourself to equal or surpass them someday. Let envy turn inward and it poisons the soul; expel it outward and it can move you to greater heights.
应对嫉妒这种阴险狡诈、极具破坏性的情绪，有几种策略。首先，要接受这样一个事实：总会有人在某些方面超越你，你也可能会嫉妒他们。但要把这种感觉转化为一种动力，激励自己有朝一日能够与他们比肩甚至超越他们。让嫉妒滋生于内心，它会毒害你的灵魂；而将它向外驱散，它就能助你攀登更高峰。
Second, understand that as you gain power, those below you will feel envious of you. They may not show it but it is inevitable. Do not naively accept the facade they show youread between the lines of their criticisms, their little sarcastic remarks, the signs of backstabbing, the excessive praise that is preparing you for a fall, the resentful look in the eye. Half the problem with envy comes when we do not recognize it until it is too late.
其次，你要明白，随着你权力的增长，下属会嫉妒你。他们或许不会表露出来，但这不可避免。不要天真地接受他们伪装的姿态——要看穿他们批评的弦外之音，那些冷嘲热讽，那些背后捅刀的迹象，那些看似奉承实则暗藏玄机的过分赞美，以及他们眼中流露出的怨恨。嫉妒的一大问题在于，我们往往在为时已晚时才意识到它的存在。
Finally, expect tiiat when people envy you they will work against you
最后，你要做好心理准备，当人们嫉妒你时，他们会想方设法与你作对。
The envious hides as carefully as the secret, lustful sinner and becomes the endless inventor of tricks and stratagems to hide and mask himself Thus he is able to pretend to ignore the superiority of others which eats up his heart, as if he did not see them, nor hear them, nor were aware of them, nor had ever heard of them. lie is a master simulator. On the other hand he tries with all his power to connive and thus prevent any form of superiority from appearing in any situation. And if they do, he casts on them obscurity, hypercriticism, sarcasm and calumny like the toad that spits poison from its hole. On the other hand he will raise endlessly insignificant men, mediocre people, and even the inferior in the same type of activities.
嫉妒者如同暗藏邪念的罪人一般，小心翼翼地隐藏自己，并不断发明各种诡计和计谋来掩饰和伪装自己。这样，他就能假装对那些令他痛苦不堪的他人优越感视而不见，仿佛他从未见过、听过、甚至从未听说过他们。他是个伪装大师。另一方面，他竭尽全力地阴谋诡计，阻止任何形式的优越感在任何情况下出现。如果优越感真的出现了，他就会像蟾蜍从洞里喷毒液一样，用晦涩难懂的语言、尖刻的批评、讽刺和诽谤来攻击他们。与此同时，他还会扶持无数无足轻重之辈、平庸之辈，甚至在同类活动中出类拔萃之辈。
Arthur
亚瑟
Schopenhauer,
叔本华，
1788-1860
For not many men, the proverb says, can love a friend who fortune prospers without feeling envy; and about the envious brain, cold poison clings and doubles all the pain life brings him. His own woundings he must nurse, and feels another's gladness like a curse.
俗话说，很少有人能真心爱一个事业有成的朋友而不心生嫉妒；而嫉妒之心，如同被冰冷的毒药缠绕，加倍地折磨着他，让他承受着人生所有的痛苦。他只能独自承受伤痛，却将他人的喜悦视作诅咒。
Aeschylus, c. 525-456 B.C.
埃斯库罗斯，约公元前525-456年
JOSKI'II AM) IIIS C.O.VI'
JOSKI'II AM) IIIS C.O.VI'
Now Israel loved
现在以色列爱
Joseph more than all
约瑟夫比所有人都更甚
his children, because he
他的孩子们，因为他
was the son of his old
是他老父亲的儿子
age; and he made him a
年龄；他使他成为一个
coat of many colors....
五彩斑斓的外衣……
And his brothers
还有他的兄弟们
envied him.... And
我羡慕他……
when they saw him afar
当他们远远地看见他时
off they conspired
他们密谋离开
against him to slay
反对他，要杀了他
him. And now they said
他。现在他们说
to one another,
彼此之间，
"Behold, this dreamer
“瞧，这位梦想家
cometh. Come now
来了。现在就来。
therefore, and let us
因此，让我们
slay him, and cast him
杀了他，然后把他扔掉
into some pit, and we
掉进某个坑里，然后我们
shall say, some evil
可以说，一些邪恶
beast hath devoured
野兽吞噬了
him; and we shall see
他；我们将会看到
what will become of his
他的命运将会如何？
dreams. "
梦想。
old testament, genesis 37:3-20
旧约圣经，创世记 37:3-20
[When Pope Julius first saw Michelangelo's
当教皇尤利乌斯第一次看到米开朗基罗的作品时
design for his tomb] it
他的陵墓设计]
pleased him so much
他非常高兴
that he at once sent him
他立刻派他去了。
to Carrara to quarry
去卡拉拉采石场
the necessary marbles,
所需的弹珠，
instructing Alamanno
指导阿拉曼诺
Salviati, of Florence, to
佛罗伦萨的萨尔维亚蒂
pay him a thousand
付他一千美元
ducats for this purpose.
为此需要杜卡特金币。
Michelangelo stayed in
米开朗基罗留了下来
these mountains more than eight months with
这些山脉，我花了八个多月的时间才到达。
two workmen and his horse, and without any
两名工人和他的马，没有任何
other provision except food.... Enough
除了食物以外的其他物资……足够了
marbles quarried and chosen, he took them to
他采石、挑选大理石，然后把它们带走
the sea-coast, and left
海岸线，然后向左走
insidiously. They will put obstacles in your path that you will not foresee, or that you cannot trace to their source. It is hard to defend yourself against this kind of attack. And by the time you realize that envy is at the root of a person's feelings about you, it is often too late: Your excuses, your false humility, your defensive actions, only exacerbate the problem. Since it is far easier to avoid creating envy in the first place than to get rid of it once it is there, you should strategize to forestall it before it grows. It is often your own actions that stir up envy, your own unawareness. By becoming conscious of those actions and qualities that create envy, you can take the teeth out of it before it nibbles you to death.
他们会阴险地在你前进的道路上设置障碍，而这些障碍你却无法预料，也无法追溯其根源。这种攻击很难防范。等你意识到嫉妒是别人对你产生负面情绪的根源时，往往为时已晚：你的借口、虚假的谦逊、你的防御行为只会让问题更加恶化。与其等到嫉妒滋生后再去消除它，不如防患于未然，避免嫉妒的产生。很多时候，正是你自己的行为和无知激起了嫉妒。通过意识到那些会引发嫉妒的行为和特质，你就能在嫉妒彻底吞噬你之前，将其扼杀在摇篮里。
Kierkegaard believed that there are types of people who create envy, and are as guilty when it arises as those who feel it. The most obvious type we all know: The moment something good happens to them, whetiier by luck or design, they crow about it. In fact they get pleasure out of making people feel inferior. This type is obvious and beyond hope. There are others, however, who stir up envy in more subtle and unconscious ways, and are partly to blame for their troubles. Envy is often a problem, for example, for people with great natural talent.
克尔凯郭尔认为，有些人会制造嫉妒，而当他们产生嫉妒时，他们与那些感受到嫉妒的人一样有罪。最显而易见的一种类型我们都认识：一旦他们遇到好事，无论是出于运气还是刻意为之，他们都会大肆炫耀。事实上，他们从让别人感到自卑中获得快感。这种人显而易见，无可救药。然而，还有一些人以更微妙、更无意识的方式煽动嫉妒，他们也应为自身的困境承担部分责任。例如，嫉妒常常是那些天赋异禀的人面临的问题。
Sir Walter Raleigh was one of the most brilliant men at the court of Queen Elizabeth of England. He had skills as a scientist, wrote poetry still recognized as among the most beautiful writing of the time, was a proven leader of men, an enterprising entrepreneur, a great sea captain, and on top of all this was a handsome, dashing courtier who charmed his way into becoming one of the queen's favorites. Wherever he went, however, people blocked his path. Eventually he suffered a terrific fall from grace, leading even to prison and finally the executioner's axe.
沃尔特·雷利爵士是英国伊丽莎白女王宫廷中最杰出的人物之一。他不仅是一位杰出的科学家，还创作了至今仍被公认为当时最美诗篇之一的诗歌。他是一位久经考验的领袖，一位富有进取心的企业家，一位伟大的航海家，除此之外，他还是一位英俊潇洒、风度翩翩的朝臣，凭借其魅力赢得了女王的宠信。然而，无论他走到哪里，都处处受阻。最终，他遭遇了巨大的挫败，甚至锒铛入狱，最终被送上了断头台。
Raleigh could not understand the stubborn opposition he faced from the other courtiers. He did not see that he had not only made no attempt to disguise the degree of his skills and qualities, he had imposed them on one and all, making a show of his versatility, thinking it impressed people and won him friends. In fact it made him silent enemies, people who felt inferior to him and did all they could to ruin him the moment he tripped up or made the slightest mistake. In the end, the reason he was executed was treason, but envy will use any cover it finds to mask its destructiveness.
雷利无法理解其他朝臣为何如此顽固地反对他。他没有意识到，自己不仅没有掩饰自己的才华和能力，反而将它们展现给所有人，炫耀自己的多才多艺，以为这样就能给人留下深刻印象，赢得朋友。事实上，这反而为他招致了无声的敌人，这些人自视甚高，一旦他犯错或稍有不慎，便会想方设法除掉他。最终，他被处决的原因是叛国罪，但嫉妒会利用一切掩护来掩盖其破坏性。
The envy elicited by Sir Walter Raleigh is the worst kind: It was inspired by his natural talent and grace, which he felt was best displayed in its full flower. Money others can attain; power as well. But superior intelligence, good looks, charmthese are qualities no one can acquire. The naturally perfect have to work the most to disguise their brilliance, displaying a defect or two to deflect envy before it takes root. It is a common and naive mistake to think you are charming people with your natural talents when in fact they are coming to hate you.
沃尔特·雷利爵士所招致的嫉妒是最恶劣的那种：这种嫉妒源于他与生俱来的才华和优雅，而他认为只有将这些天赋和优雅发挥到极致才能最好地展现出来。金钱和权力其他人可以获得，但超凡的智慧、俊朗的外表和迷人的魅力——这些都是任何人都无法后天习得的。那些天生完美的人反而需要付出更多努力来掩饰自己的才华，故意表现出一两个缺点，以防嫉妒滋生。很多人天真地以为自己能用天赋吸引他人，而实际上，他们却在逐渐憎恨自己。
A great danger in the realm of power is the sudden improvement in fortunean unexpected promotion, a victory or success mat seems to come out of nowhere. This is sure to stir up envy among your former peers.
权力领域的一大危险在于命运的突然转变——意想不到的晋升、胜利或成功似乎凭空而来。这必然会引起昔日同僚的嫉妒。
When Archbishop de Retz was promoted to the rank of cardinal, in 1651, he knew full well that many of his former colleagues envied him.
1651 年，当德雷茨大主教晋升为枢机主教时，他非常清楚他的许多前同事都嫉妒他。
Understanding die foolishness of alienating those below him, de Retz did everything he could to downplay his merit and emphasize the role of luck in his success. To put people at ease, he acted humbly and deferentially, as if nothing had changed. (In reality, of course, he now had much more power than before.) He wrote that these wise policies “produced a good effect, by lessening the envy which was conceived against me, which is the greatest of all secrets.” Follow de Retz's example. Subtly emphasize how lucky you have been, to make your happiness seem more attainable to other people, and die need for envy less acute. But be careful not to affect a false modesty diat people can easily see through. This will only make mem more envious. The act has to be good; your humility, and your openness to those you have left behind, have to seem genuine. Any hint of insincerity will only make your new status more oppressive. Remember: Despite your elevated position, it will do you no good to alienate your former peers. Power requires a wide and solid support base, which envy can silendy destroy.
德雷茨深知疏远下属的愚蠢之处，因此竭尽所能淡化自己的功绩，强调运气在他成功中所起的作用。为了让人们感到自在，他表现得谦逊恭敬，仿佛一切如常。（当然，实际上，他现在的权力比以前大得多。）他写道，这些明智的策略“产生了良好的效果，减少了人们对我的嫉妒，而嫉妒是最大的秘密。” 效仿德雷茨的做法。巧妙地强调你的幸运，让别人觉得你的幸福触手可及，从而减少嫉妒的产生。但要小心，不要装出一副很容易被人识破的虚假谦逊。那样只会招致更多的嫉妒。你的行为必须真诚；你的谦逊，以及你对那些被你抛弃的人的坦诚，都必须显得发自内心。任何虚伪的迹象只会让你的新地位更加令人生畏。记住：即便你身居高位，疏远昔日同僚也于事无补。权力需要广泛而稳固的支持基础，而嫉妒却能悄无声息地将其摧毁。
Political power of any kind creates envy, and one of the best ways to deflect it before it takes root is to seem unambitious. When Ivan the Terrible died, Boris Godunov knew he was the only one on the scene who could lead Russia. But if he sought the position eagerly, he would stir up envy and suspicion among the boyars, so he refused die crown, not once but several times. He made people insist mat he take die throne. George Washington used the same strategy to great effect, first in refusing to keep the position of Commander in Chief of the American army, second in resisting the presidency. In both cases he made himself more popular than ever. People cannot envy the power that tiiey themselves have given a person who does not seem to desire it.
任何形式的政治权力都会招致嫉妒，而避免嫉妒滋生的最佳方法之一就是表现得不怀好意。伊凡雷帝去世后，鲍里斯·戈杜诺夫深知自己是当时唯一能够领导俄罗斯的人。但如果他急于求成，就会在贵族中引起嫉妒和猜忌，因此他拒绝了王位，而且不止一次。他让人们恳求他继承王位。乔治·华盛顿也运用了同样的策略，并取得了巨大的成功：首先，他拒绝继续担任美国陆军总司令；其次，他拒绝担任总统。在这两种情况下，他都使自己比以往任何时候都更受欢迎。人们不会嫉妒一个似乎并不渴望权力的人所拥有的权力。
According to me Elizabeman statesman and writer Sir Francis Bacon, the wisest policy of the powerful is to create a kind of pity for themselves, as if their responsibilities were a burden and a sacrifice. How can one envy a man who has taken on a heavy load for the public interest Disguise your power as a kind of self-sacrifice rather than a source of happiness and you make it seem less enviable. Emphasize your troubles and you turn a potential danger (envy) into a source of moral support (pity). A similar ploy is to hint that your good fortune will benefit those around you. To do this you may need to open your purse strings, like Cimon, a wealdiy general in ancient Athens who gave lavishly in all kinds of ways to prevent people from resenting the influence he had bought in Atiienian politics. He paid a high price to deflect dieir envy, but in the end it saved him from ostracism and banishment from the city.
依我之见，伊丽莎白时代的政治家兼作家弗朗西斯·培根爵士认为，权贵最明智的策略是博取他人的同情，仿佛他们的责任是一种负担和牺牲。谁又能嫉妒一个为公众利益承担重任的人呢？将你的权力伪装成一种自我牺牲，而非幸福的源泉，就能让它显得不那么令人羡慕。强调你的困境，就能将潜在的危险（嫉妒）转化为精神支持（同情）。类似的策略是暗示你的好运将惠及周围的人。为此，你可能需要慷慨解囊，就像古雅典的富豪将军西蒙那样。他慷慨解囊，以各种方式施舍，以避免人们因他在雅典政坛的影响力而心生怨恨。他为此付出了高昂的代价来化解他人的嫉妒，但最终这使他免于被放逐出城。
The painter J. M. W. Turner devised another way of giving to deflect the envy of his fellow artists, which he recognized as his greatest obstacle to his success. Noticing diat his incomparable color skills made them afraid to hang their paintings next to his in exhibitions, he realized that their fear would turn to envy, and would eventually make it harder for him to find galleries to show in. On occasion, dien, Turner is known to have temporarily dampened the colors in his paintings with soot to earn him the goodwill of his colleagues.
画家J·M·W·特纳想出了另一种方法来化解同行艺术家的嫉妒，因为他意识到这是他成功路上最大的障碍。他注意到，自己无与伦比的色彩技巧让其他艺术家不敢在展览中与他的作品并排展出，他意识到他们的恐惧会变成嫉妒，最终会让他更难找到画廊展出作品。因此，据说特纳有时会用烟灰暂时浸湿画作的颜料，以此来博得同行的好感。
one of his men to have them embarked. He himself returned to Rome.
他派手下安排他们登船。他自己则返回了罗马。
... The quantity of marbles was immense, so that, spread over the piazza, they were the admiration of all and a joy to the pope, who heaped immeasurable favors upon Michelangelo; and when he began to work upon them again and again went to see him at his house, and talked to him about the tomb and other things as with his own brother. And in order that he might more easily go to him, the pope ordered that a drawbridge should be thrown across from the Corri-dore to the rooms of Michelangelo, by which he might visit him in private.
……大理石的数量极其庞大，铺满广场，令所有人叹为观止，也令教皇欣喜不已。教皇对米开朗基罗恩宠有加，并多次前往他的住所探望，如同对待亲兄弟一般，与他谈论陵墓和其他事宜。为了方便教皇探望，教皇下令在科里多雷广场和米开朗基罗的住所之间架设一座吊桥，以便他可以私下拜访米开朗基罗。
These many and frequent favors were the cause (as often is the case at court) of much envy, and, after the envy, of endless persecution, since Bramante, the architect, who was loved by the pope, made him change his mind as to the monument by telling him, as is said by the vulgar, that it is unlucky to build one's tomb in one's lifetime, and other tales. Fear as well as envy stimulated Bramante, for the judgment of Michelangelo had exposed many of his errors.... Now because he had no doubt that Michelangelo knew these errors of his, he always sought to remove him from Rome, or, at least, to deprive him of the
这些频繁的恩惠（如同宫廷中常见的情况一样）引起了许多人的嫉妒，而嫉妒之后，便是无休止的迫害。因为深受教皇喜爱的建筑师布拉曼特，用一些俗语（俗称“生前建造陵墓不吉利”）来劝说教皇改变主意，比如告诉教皇，生前建造陵墓是不吉利的，等等。恐惧和嫉妒驱使着布拉曼特，因为米开朗基罗的评价暴露了他的许多错误……如今，由于他确信米开朗基罗也知道他的这些错误，他总是想方设法将米开朗基罗赶出罗马，或者至少剥夺他……
favor of the pope, and of the glory and usefulness that he might have acquired by his industry. He succeeded in the matter of the tomb. There is no doubt that if Michelangelo had been allowed to finish it, according to his first design, having so large afield in which to show his worth, no other artist, however celebrated (be it said without envy) could have wrested from him the high place he would have held.
他渴望得到教皇的赏识，以及凭借勤奋所能获得的荣耀和功绩。在陵墓的建造上，他取得了成功。毫无疑问，如果米开朗基罗能够按照最初的设计完成陵墓，拥有如此广阔的创作空间来展现他的才华，那么任何其他艺术家，无论多么声名显赫（恕我直言，绝无嫉妒之意），都无法撼动他原本应有的地位。
Did ever anybody seriously confess to envy Something there is in it universally felt to be more shameful than even felonious crime. And not only does everybody disown it, but the better sort are inclined to incredulity when it is in earnest imputed to an intelligent man. But since lodgment is in the heart not the brain, no degree of intellect supplies a guarantee against it.
真有人会坦然承认自己嫉妒吗？嫉妒中某些东西，普遍被认为比重罪还要可耻。不仅人人都否认自己嫉妒，就连那些品行高尚的人，如果有人认真地指责一个聪明人嫉妒，他们也往往难以置信。但是，嫉妒根植于人心而非脑海，因此，再高的智力也无法保证人人都能免于嫉妒。
billy budd,
比利·巴德
Herman Melville,
赫尔曼·梅尔维尔
1819-1891
To deflect envy, Gracian recommends that the powerful display a weakness, a minor social indiscretion, a harmless vice. Give those who envy you someming to feed on, distracting them from your more important sins. Remember: It is the reality that matters. You may have to play games with appearances, but in the end you will have what counts: true power. In some Arab countries, a man will avoid arousing envy by doing as Cosimo de Medici did by showing his wealth only on the inside of his house. Apply this wisdom to your own character.
为了化解嫉妒，格拉西安建议有权势的人展现一些弱点，一些轻微的社交失礼，一些无伤大雅的恶习。给那些嫉妒你的人一些把柄，让他们无暇顾及你更严重的罪过。记住：重要的是本质。你或许需要玩弄一些表面功夫，但最终你将拥有真正重要的东西：真正的权力。在一些阿拉伯国家，人们会效仿科西莫·德·美第奇的做法，只在室内炫耀财富，以避免引起嫉妒。将这种智慧运用到你自身的品格塑造中。
Beware of some of envy's disguises. Excessive praise is an almost sure sign that die person praising you envies you; they are either setting you up for a fallit will be impossible for you to live up to their praiseor they are sharpening their blades behind your back. At the same time, those who are hypercritical of you, or who slander you publicly, probably envy you as well. Recognize their behavior as disguised envy and you keep out of the trap of mutual mud-slinging, or of taking their criticisms to heart. Win your revenge by ignoring tiieir measly presence.
要警惕嫉妒的种种伪装。过度的赞美几乎可以肯定是嫉妒你的表现；他们要么是在设局陷害你——你根本无法达到他们的赞美——要么就是在背后磨刀霍霍。同时，那些对你吹毛求疵、公开诽谤你的人，很可能也是在嫉妒你。认清他们伪装的嫉妒，你就能避免陷入互相攻击的陷阱，也不会把他们的批评放在心上。用无视他们的存在来赢得报复吧。
Do not try to help or do favors for those who envy you; they will think you are condescending to them. Joe Orton's attempt to help Halliwell find a gallery for his work only intensified his lover's feelings of inferiority and envy. Once envy reveals itself for what it is, the only solution is often to flee the presence of the enviers, leaving them to stew in a hell of their own creation.
不要试图帮助或包庇那些嫉妒你的人；他们会觉得你是在居高临下地对待他们。乔·奥顿试图帮霍利韦尔找画廊，结果反而加剧了他爱人的自卑和嫉妒之情。一旦嫉妒的本质暴露出来，唯一的解决办法往往就是远离嫉妒者，让他们在自己一手造成的痛苦深渊中煎熬。
Finally, be aware that some environments are more conducive to envy than others. The effects of envy are more serious among colleagues and peers, where there is a veneer of equality. Envy is also destructive in democratic environments where overt displays of power are looked down upon. Be extrasensitive in such environments. The filmmaker Ingmar Bergman was hounded by Swedish tax authorities because he stood out in a country where standing out from the crowd is frowned on. It is almost impossible to avoid envy in such cases, and there is little you can do but accept it graciously and take none of it personally. As Thoreau once said, “Envy is die tax which all distinction must pay.”
最后，请注意，有些环境比其他环境更容易滋生嫉妒。在同事和同侪之间，由于表面上的平等，嫉妒的影响更为严重。在民主环境中，公开炫耀权力会受到鄙视，因此嫉妒也具有破坏性。在这样的环境中，要格外敏感。电影导演英格玛·伯格曼就曾因在瑞典特立独行而遭到税务部门的追捕，因为在瑞典，特立独行并不被人所接受。在这种情况下，几乎不可能避免嫉妒，你所能做的就是坦然接受，不要把它放在心上。正如梭罗所说：“嫉妒是所有杰出人士都必须缴纳的税。”
Image: A Garden of Weeds. You may not feed them but they spread as you water the garden. You may not see how, but they take over, tall and ugly, preventing anything beautiful from flourishing. Before it is too late, do not water indiscriminately. Destroy the weeds of envy by giving them
图片：杂草丛生的花园。你或许不施肥，但它们却在你浇水时蔓延。你或许看不见，但它们会逐渐占据主导，变得又高又丑，阻碍一切美好事物的生长。趁现在还来得及，不要随意浇水。用施肥来消灭嫉妒的杂草。
nothing to feed on.
没有食物可供食用。
Authority: Upon occasion, reveal a harmless defect in your character. For the envious accuse the most perfect of sinning by having no sins. They become an Argus, all eyes for finding fault with excellenceit is their only consolation. Do not let envy burst with its own venomaffect some lapse in valor or intellect, so as to disarm it beforehand. You thus wave your red cape before the Horns of Envy, in order to save your immortality. (Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658)
权威：偶尔，要显露出你性格中无伤大雅的缺点。因为嫉妒者会指责最完美的人没有罪过，反而犯了罪。他们如同阿耳戈斯一般，一心只想挑剔完美者的缺点——这是他们唯一的慰藉。不要让嫉妒的毒液爆发——在勇气或智慧上有所懈怠，以此来先发制人，解除它的攻击。如此，你便能在嫉妒的犄角前挥舞你的红色斗篷，以保全你的永生。（巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658）
REVERSAL
逆转
The reason for being careful with the envious is that they are so indirect, and will find innumerable ways to undermine you. But treading carefully around them will often only make their envy worse. They sense that you are being cautious, and it registers as yet another sign of your superiority. That is why you must act before envy takes root.
之所以要小心提防那些心怀嫉妒的人，是因为他们手段隐晦，会想方设法地削弱你。但小心翼翼地对待他们往往只会加剧他们的嫉妒。他们会察觉到你的谨慎，并将其视为你优越感的又一体现。因此，你必须在嫉妒滋生之前就采取行动。
Once envy is there, however, whether through your fault or not, it is sometimes best to affect the opposite approach: Display the utmost disdain for those who envy you. Instead of hiding your perfection, make it obvious. Make every new triumph an opportunity to make the envious squirm. Your good fortune and power become their living hell. If you attain a position of unimpeachable power, their envy will have no effect on you, and you will have the best revenge of all: They are trapped in envy while you are free in your power.
然而，一旦嫉妒滋生，无论是否出于你的过错，有时最好的办法恰恰相反：对那些嫉妒你的人表现出极度的蔑视。与其隐藏你的完美，不如让它昭然若揭。让每一次新的胜利都成为让嫉妒者痛苦不堪的机会。你的好运和权力将成为他们的人间炼狱。如果你获得了绝对的权力，他们的嫉妒将对你毫无影响，你将获得最完美的复仇：他们深陷嫉妒的泥沼，而你则在权力的掌控中自由翱翔。
This is how Michelangelo triumphed over die venomous architect Bramante, who turned Pope Julius against Michelangelo's design for his tomb. Bramante envied Michelangelo's godlike skills, and to this one triumphthe aborted tomb projecthe thought to add another, by pushing the pope to commission Michelangelo to paint the murals in the Sistine Chapel. The project would take years, during which Michelangelo would accomplish no more of his brilliant sculptures. Furthermore, Bramante considered Michelangelo not nearly as skilled in painting as in sculpture. The chapel would spoil his image as the perfect artist.
这就是米开朗基罗战胜心怀叵测的建筑师布拉曼特的办法。布拉曼特曾唆使教皇尤利乌斯反对米开朗基罗为他设计的陵墓。布拉曼特嫉妒米开朗基罗神一般的技艺，除了陵墓项目夭折之外，他还想再添一笔，那就是怂恿教皇委托米开朗基罗为西斯廷教堂绘制壁画。这项工程耗时数年，在此期间，米开朗基罗再也没有创作出任何杰出的雕塑作品。此外，布拉曼特认为米开朗基罗的绘画技艺远不及雕塑。西斯廷教堂的壁画会损害他作为完美艺术家的形象。
Michelangelo saw the trap and wanted to turn down the commission, but he could not refuse the pope, so he accepted it without complaint. Then, however, he used Bramante's envy to spur him to greater heights, making the Sistine Chapel his most perfect work of all. Every time Bramante heard of it or saw it, he felt more oppressed by his own envydie sweetest and most lasting revenge you can exact on die envious.
米开朗基罗看穿了其中的陷阱，想要拒绝委托，但他无法拒绝教皇，只好默默接受了。然而，他却利用布拉曼特的嫉妒激励自己攀登更高的艺术高峰，最终创作出了他最完美的作品——西斯廷教堂。每当布拉曼特听到或看到西斯廷教堂时，他都会感到更加嫉妒，这种嫉妒之情也愈发强烈。这便是你能对嫉妒者施加的最甜蜜、最持久的报复。
Know how to triumph over envy and malice. Here contempt, although prudent, counts, indeed, for little; magnanimity is better. A good word concerning one who speaks evil of you cannot be praised too highly: there is no revenge more heroic than that brought about by those merits and attainments which frustrate and torment the envious. Every stroke of good fortune is a further twist of the rope round the neck of the ill-disposed and the heaven of the envied is hell for the envious. To convert your good fortune into poison for your enemies is held to be the most severe punishment you can inflict on them. The envious man dies not only once but as many times as the person he envies lives to hear the voice of praise; the eternity of the latter's fame is the measure of the former's punishment: the one is immortal in his glory, the latter in his misery. The trumpet of fame which sounds immortality for the one heralds death for the other, who is sentenced to be choked to death on his own envy.
要懂得如何战胜嫉妒和恶意。在此，轻蔑虽是明智之举，却也微不足道；宽宏大量才是上策。对那些诋毁你的人说一句好话，无论怎样赞扬都不为过：没有什么比用那些令嫉妒者沮丧和痛苦的功绩和成就来复仇更英勇的了。每一次好运的降临，都如同绞索般勒紧了心怀恶意者的脖子；被嫉妒者的天堂，正是嫉妒者的地狱。将你的好运化作毒药，用来对付你的敌人，被认为是你能给予他们的最严厉的惩罚。嫉妒者不仅要死一次，而是要死无数次，只要他嫉妒的人活着听到赞扬的声音；后者名垂青史，便是前者所受惩罚的尺度：前者在荣耀中永垂不朽，后者在苦难中永生不灭。名利的号角为一个人吹响了永生的号角，却预示着另一个人的死亡，后者将因自己的嫉妒而窒息而死。
Baltasar Gracian, 1601-1658
巴尔塔萨·格拉西安，1601-1658年
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 47
第47条
DO NOT GO PAST THE MARK YOU AIMED FOR;
不要超过你设定的目标；
IN VICTORY, LEARN WHEN TO STOP
胜利之后，要学会何时止步。
JUDGMENT
判断
The moment of victory is often the moment of greatest peril. In the heat of victory, arrogance and overconfi-dence can push you past the goal you had aimed for, and by going too far, you make more enemies than you defeat. Do not allow success to go to your head. There is no substitute for strategy and careful planning. Set a goal, and when you reach it, stop.
胜利的时刻往往也是最危险的时刻。在胜利的喜悦中，傲慢和过度自信会让你偏离既定目标，而得意忘形只会让你树敌更多。切勿让成功冲昏头脑。策略和周密的计划无可替代。设定目标，达成目标后，就此止步。
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
In 559 B.C., a young man named Cyrus gathered an immense army from die scattered tribes of Persia and marched against his grandfadier Astyages, king of the Medes. He defeated Astyages with ease, had himself crowned king of Medea and Persia, and began to forge the Persian Empire. Victory followed victory in quick succession. Cyrus defeated Croesus, ruler of Lydia, then conquered the Ionian islands and odier smaller kingdoms; he marched on Babylon and crushed it. Now he was known as Cyrus the Great, King of the World.
公元前559年，一位名叫居鲁士的年轻人从波斯各地分散的部落中集结了一支庞大的军队，向他的祖父、米底国王阿斯提阿格斯进军。他轻松击败了阿斯提阿格斯，加冕为米底和波斯的国王，并开始建立波斯帝国。此后，他接连取得胜利。居鲁士击败了吕底亚国王克罗伊索斯，征服了爱奥尼亚群岛和其他一些小王国；他进军巴比伦，将其摧毁。此时，他被称为居鲁士大帝，世界之王。
After capturing the riches of Babylon, Cyrus set his sights on the east, on the half-barbaric tribes of the Massagetai, a vast realm on the Caspian Sea. A fierce warrior race led by Queen Tomyris, the Massagetai lacked the riches of Babylon, but Cyrus decided to attack them anyway, believing himself superhuman and incapable of defeat. The Massagetai would fall easily to his vast armies, making his empire immense.
在夺取巴比伦的财富之后，居鲁士将目光投向东方，瞄准了位于里海沿岸的半蛮族马萨格泰人。马萨格泰人由女王托米丽斯领导，是一个骁勇善战的民族。尽管他们不像巴比伦那样拥有丰富的财富，但居鲁士仍然决定进攻他们，因为他自认为拥有超凡的力量，所向披靡。他相信马萨格泰人会轻易被他庞大的军队征服，从而使他的帝国疆域更加辽阔。
In 529 B.C., then, Cyrus marched to the wide river Araxes, gateway to the kingdom of the Massagetai. As he set up camp on die western bank, he received a message from Queen Tomyris: “King of the Medes,” she told him, “I advise you to abandon this enterprise, for you cannot know if in the end it will do you any good. Rule your own people, and try to bear the sight of me ruling mine. But of course you will refuse my advice, as the last diing you wish for is to live in peace.” Tomyris, confident of her army's strength and not wishing to delay the inevitable batde, offered to withdraw die troops on her side of the river, allowing Cyrus to cross its waters safely and fight her army on the eastern side, if diat was his desire.
公元前529年，居鲁士进军至宽阔的阿拉克斯河，这里是通往马萨格泰王国的门户。当他在西岸扎营时，收到了米底王后托米丽斯的来信：“米底国王，”她对他说，“我劝你放弃这次远征，因为你无法预知它最终是否对你有利。统治你自己的子民，试着忍受我统治我的子民吧。当然，你不会接受我的劝告，因为你最不愿看到的就是和平。”托米丽斯对自己军队的实力充满信心，也不愿拖延这场不可避免的战争，于是提出，如果居鲁士愿意，她可以撤回河对岸的军队，让居鲁士安全渡河，在东岸与她的军队决战。
Cyrus agreed, but instead of engaging the enemy directly he decided to play a trick. The Massagetai knew few luxuries. Once Cyrus had crossed the river and made his camp on the eastern side, he set the table for an elaborate banquet, full of meat, delicacies, and strong wine. Then he left his weakest troops in the camp and withdrew die rest of the army to the river. A large Massagetai detachment soon attacked the camp and killed all of the Persian soldiers in a fierce batde. Then, overwhelmed by die fabulous feast that had been left behind, they ate and drank to dieir hearts' content. Later, inevitably, they fell asleep. The Persian army returned to the camp that night, killing many of die sleeping soldiers and capturing die rest. Among the prisoners was dieir general, a youth named Spargapises, son of Queen Tomyris.
居鲁士同意了，但他并没有直接与敌人交战，而是决定耍个花招。马萨革泰人素来不谙世事。居鲁士渡过河，在东岸扎营后，摆设了一场丰盛的宴席，摆满了肉类、美味佳肴和烈酒。然后，他留下兵力较弱的部队在营地，其余的军队则撤退到河边。不久，一支庞大的马萨革泰分遣队突袭了营地，在一场激烈的战斗中杀死了所有波斯士兵。之后，他们被留下的丰盛宴席所吸引，尽情地吃喝玩乐。后来，不出所料，他们都睡着了。当晚，波斯军队返回营地，杀死了许多熟睡的士兵，俘虏了其余的人。俘虏中包括他们的将军，一个名叫斯帕尔加皮塞斯的年轻人，他是托米丽斯女王的儿子。
When die queen learned what had happened, she sent a message to Cyrus, chiding him for using tricks to defeat her army. “Now listen to me,” she wrote, “and I will advise you for your own good: Give me back my son and leave my country with your forces intact, and be content with your triumph over a third part of the Massagetai. If you refuse, I swear by the sun our master to give you more blood dian you can drink, for all your gluttony.” Cyrus scoffed at her: He would not release her son. He would crush these barbarians.
当王后得知此事后，她给居鲁士送去一封信，斥责他用诡计击败了她的军队。“现在听我说，”她写道，“我劝你，为了你好：把我的儿子还给我，带着你的军队离开我的国家，就满足于你征服了马萨格泰三分之一的领土吧。如果你拒绝，我以太阳神的名义发誓，我会让你喝下更多的血，以惩罚你的贪婪。”居鲁士对她嗤之以鼻：他不会放了她的儿子。他要彻底消灭这些蛮族。
The queen's son, seeing he would not be released, could not stand the
女王的儿子见自己不会被释放，便无法忍受……
Till-. V.MMM.OHIOl'S COCKI'.KKI.
直到-。V.MMM.OHIOl的COCKI'.KKI。
Two cockerels fought on a dungheap. One cockerel was the stronger: he vanquished the other and drove him from the dungheap. All the hens gathered around the cockerel, and began to laud him. The cockerel wanted his strength and glory to be known in the next yard. He flew on lop of the barn, flapped his wings, and crowed in a loud voice: “Look at me, all of you. I am a victorious cockerel. No other cockerel in the world has such strength as I.” The cockerel had not finished, when an eagle killed him, seized him in his claws, and carried him to his nest.
两只公鸡在粪堆上打架。其中一只更强壮，它打败了另一只，把它赶出了粪堆。所有的母鸡都围在公鸡身边，开始赞美它。公鸡想让它的威名传遍隔壁院子。它飞上谷仓，拍打着翅膀，大声啼叫：“看啊，你们都看！我是一只凯旋的公鸡！世界上没有哪只公鸡比我更强壮！”公鸡还没说完，一只老鹰就把它抓了起来，用爪子抓住它，带回了巢穴。
TABLES,
桌子，
Leo Tolstoy, 1828-1910
列夫·托尔斯泰，1828-1910
In all your cross-examinations .... most important of all, let me repeal the injunction to be ever on the alert for a good place to stop. Nothing can be more important than to cU)se your examination with a triumph. So many lawyers succeed in catching a witness in a serious contradiction; but, not satisfied with this, go on asking questions, and taper off their examination until the effect upon the jury of their former advantage is lost altogether.
在所有交叉询问中……最重要的是，我要重申，务必时刻警惕，寻找合适的时机结束询问。没有什么比以一场胜利结束询问更重要的了。许多律师成功地让证人露出明显的矛盾；但是，他们并不满足于此，继续提问，逐渐减弱询问力度，直到之前的优势完全丧失，陪审团也无从知晓。
the art 0^ cross-examination, Francis L.Wfi.lman, 1913
交叉询问的艺术，弗朗西斯·L·威尔曼，1913年
We read of many instances of this kind; for the general who by his valor has conquered a state for his master, and won great glory for himself by his victory over the enemy, and has loaded his soldiers with rich booty, acquires necessarily with his own soldiers, as well as with those of the enemy and with the subjects of the prince, so high a reputation, that his very victory may become distasteful, and a cause for apprehension to his prince. For as the
