我们读到过许多这样的例子；因为一位将军凭借英勇为君主征服了一个国家，并通过战胜敌人为自己赢得了巨大的荣耀，并使他的士兵满载而归，他必然会在自己的士兵、敌人的士兵以及君主的臣民中赢得极高的声望，以至于他的胜利本身都可能令君主感到厌恶，甚至担忧。因为正如……
humiliation, and so he killed himself. The news of her son's death overwhelmed Tomyris. She gathered all the forces that she could muster in her kingdom, and whipping them into a vengeful frenzy, engaged Cyrus's troops in a violent and bloody battle. Finally, the Massagetai prevailed. In their anger they decimated the Persian army, killing Cyrus himself.
他因受辱而自杀。儿子的死讯令托米丽斯悲痛欲绝。她集结了王国中所有的力量，煽动他们陷入复仇的狂热之中，与居鲁士的军队展开了一场血腥的激战。最终，马萨格泰人取得了胜利。他们怒火中烧，重创波斯军队，甚至杀死了居鲁士本人。
After the battle, Tomyris and her soldiers searched the battlefield for Cyrus's corpse. When she found it she cut off his head and shoved it into a wineskin full of human blood, crying out, “Though I have conquered you and live, yet you have ruined me by treacherously taking my son. See nowI fulfill my tiireat: You have your fill of blood.” After Cyrus's death, the Persian Empire quickly unraveled. One act of arrogance undid all of Cyrus's good work.
战后，托米丽丝和她的士兵在战场上寻找居鲁士的尸体。找到尸体后，她砍下他的头颅，塞进一个装满人血的皮囊里，高声喊道：“我虽战胜了你们，得以存活，但你们却背信弃义地夺走了我的儿子，毁了我。看哪，我终于发泄了我的怒火：你们血流成河！”居鲁士死后，波斯帝国迅速瓦解。他的一次傲慢之举，毁掉了他毕生的功绩。
Interpretation
解释
There is nothing more intoxicating man victory, and nothing more dangerous.
没有什么比人类的胜利更令人陶醉，也没有什么比胜利更危险。
Cyrus had built his great empire on the ruins of a previous one. A hundred years earlier, the powerful Assyrian Empire had been totally destroyed, its once splendid capital of Nineveh but ruins in the sand. The Assyrians had suffered this fate because they had pushed too far, destroying one city-state after another until mey lost sight of the purposes of their victories, and also of the costs. They overextended themselves and made many enemies who were finally able to band together and destroy them.
居鲁士建立起他庞大的帝国，而这帝国正是建立在先前帝国的废墟之上。一百年前，强大的亚述帝国彻底覆灭，其曾经辉煌的都城尼尼微如今只剩下沙砾中的残垣断壁。亚述人之所以落得如此下场，是因为他们扩张过度，一个接一个地摧毁城邦，最终迷失了胜利的初衷，也忽略了代价。他们过度扩张，树敌众多，最终这些敌人联合起来，将他们彻底摧毁。
Cyrus ignored the lesson of Assyria. He paid no heed to the warnings of oracles and advisers. He did not worry about offending a queen. His many victories had gone to his head, clouding his reason. Instead of consolidating his already vast empire, he pushed forward. Instead of recognizing each situation as different, he thought each new war would bring the same result as the one before as long as he used the methods he knew: ruthless force and cunning.
居鲁士无视亚述的教训，对神谕和谋士的警告置若罔闻，也丝毫不担心得罪王后。连连的胜利冲昏了他的头脑，蒙蔽了他的理智。他非但没有巩固已然庞大的帝国，反而一意孤行。他没有认识到每场战争的差异，而是认为只要沿用他惯用的手段——武力与诡计——每场战争都会带来同样的结果。
Understand: In the realm of power, you must be guided by reason. To let a momentary thrill or an emotional victory influence or guide your moves will prove fatal. When you attain success, step back. Be cautious. When you gain victory, understand the part played by the particular circumstances of a situation, and never simply repeat the same actions again and again. History is littered with the ruins of victorious empires and die corpses of leaders who could not learn to stop and consolidate their gains.
明白：在权力领域，你必须以理性为指导。让一时的快感或情绪化的胜利影响或左右你的行动，最终只会导致致命的后果。当你取得成功时，要适时退后一步，保持谨慎。当你取得胜利时，要理解具体情况所起的作用，切勿简单地重复同样的行动。历史上充斥着胜利帝国的废墟和那些无法学会收敛锋芒、巩固既得利益的领袖的尸体。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
No single person in history has occupied a more delicate and precarious position than the king's mistress. She had no real or legitimate power base to fall back on in times of trouble; she was surrounded by packs of envious courtiers eagerly anticipating her fall from grace; and finally, since die source of her power was usually her physical beauty, for most royal mistresses mat fall was inevitable and unpleasant.
历史上没有任何一个人的处境比国王的情妇更加微妙和危险。她没有任何真正合法的权力基础可以在危难之际依靠；她身边围绕着一群嫉妒她的朝臣，他们都渴望看到她失宠；最后，由于她的权力来源通常是她的美貌，因此对于大多数皇家情妇来说，失宠是不可避免的，而且是痛苦的。
King Louis XV of France began to keep official mistresses in the early days of his reign, each woman's good fortune rarely lasting more than a few years. But men came Madame de Pompadour, who, when she was a middle-class child of nine named Jeanne Poisson, had been told by a fortune-teller that she would someday be the king's favorite. This seemed an absurd dream, since die royal mistress almost always came from the aristocracy. Jeanne nevertheless believed herself destined to seduce the king, and doing so became her obsession. She applied herself to the talents the king's favorite had to havemusic, dancing, acting, horseback riding and she excelled in every one of them. As a young woman, she married a man of the lower nobility, which gave her an entree to the best salons in Paris. Word quickly spread of her beauty, talent, charm, and intelligence.
法国国王路易十五在其统治初期便开始拥有官方情妇，但每位女性的好运往往都维持不了几年。然而，蓬帕杜夫人却是个例外。她原名让娜·泊松，九岁时还是个中产阶级女孩，一位算命先生曾预言她将来会成为国王的宠儿。这在当时看来简直是天方夜谭，因为王室情妇几乎都出身贵族。然而，让娜坚信自己命中注定要诱惑国王，并为此痴迷不已。她潜心钻研国王宠儿必须具备的才能——音乐、舞蹈、表演、骑马，并且每一项都表现出色。年轻时，她嫁给了一位出身低微的贵族，这使她得以出入巴黎最顶级的沙龙。她的美貌、才华、魅力和智慧很快便传遍四方。
Jeanne Poisson became close friends with Voltaire, Montesquieu, and other great minds of the time, but she never lost sight of the goal she had set herself as a girl: to capture the heart of the king. Her husband had a chateau in a forest where the king would often go hunting, and she began to spend a lot of time there. Studying his movements like a hawk, she would make sure he would “happen” to come upon her while she was out walking in her most alluring dress, or riding in her splendid coach. The king began to take note of her, making her gifts of die game he caught in the hunt.
珍妮·泊松与伏尔泰、孟德斯鸠以及其他当时的伟大思想家结下了深厚的友谊，但她始终没有忘记少女时代给自己定下的目标：赢得国王的心。她的丈夫在森林里有一座城堡，国王经常去那里狩猎，珍妮也开始经常去那里。她像老鹰一样观察着国王的动向，确保自己穿着最迷人的裙子漫步或乘坐华丽的马车时，国王“碰巧”会遇到她。国王开始注意到她，并将狩猎中捕获的猎物作为礼物送给她。
In 1744 Louis's current mistress, the Duchesse de Chateauroux, died. Jeanne went on the offensive. She placed herself everywhere he would be: at masked balls at Versailles, at the opera, wherever their paths would cross, and wherever she could display her many talents: dancing, singing, riding, coquetry. The king finally succumbed to her charms, and in a ceremony at Versailles in September of 1745, diis twenty-four-year-old daughter of a middle-class banking agent was officially inaugurated as the king's mistress. She was given her own room in the palace, a room the king could enter at any time via a hidden stairway and back door. And because some of the courtiers were angry that he had chosen a woman of low origins, he made her a marquise. From now on she would be known as Madame de Pompadour.
1744年，路易十四的现任情妇沙托鲁公爵夫人去世。珍妮开始积极争取。她出现在路易十四的每一个角落：凡尔赛宫的化装舞会、歌剧院，凡是他们相遇的地方，凡是她能展现才艺的地方——舞蹈、歌唱、骑术、风情万种。国王最终被她的魅力所折服。1745年9月，在凡尔赛宫举行的一场仪式上，这位24岁的中产阶级银行代理人的女儿正式成为国王的情妇。她在宫中拥有自己的房间，国王可以随时通过隐蔽的楼梯和后门进入。由于一些朝臣不满他选择了一位出身低微的女子，国王封她为侯爵夫人。从此以后，她被称为蓬帕杜夫人。
The king was a man whom die slightest feeling of boredom would oppress out of proportion. Madame de Pompadour knew that keeping him under her spell meant keeping him amused. To that end she put on constant theatrical productions at Versailles, in which she starred. She organized elaborate hunting parties, masked balls, and whatever else it would take to keep him diverted outside the bedroom. She became a patroness of the arts, and the arbiter of taste and fashion for all of France. Her enemies at the court only grew in number with each new success, but Madame de Pompadour thwarted diem in a totally novel way for a king's mistress: with extreme politeness. Snobs who resented her for her low birth she won over with charm and grace. Most unusual of all, she befriended die queen, and insisted mat Louis XV pay more attention to his wife, and treat her more kindly. Even the royal family begrudgingly gave her their support. To
国王是个极其敏感的人，哪怕一丝丝的无聊都会让他烦躁不已。蓬帕杜夫人深知，要想让他臣服于自己，就必须让他保持愉悦。为此，她在凡尔赛宫不断上演戏剧，并亲自出演。她精心策划狩猎聚会、化装舞会，以及一切能让国王在卧室之外也能消遣的活动。她成为了艺术的赞助人，以及整个法国品味和时尚的仲裁者。随着她不断取得新的成就，她在宫廷中的敌人也越来越多，但蓬帕杜夫人以一种对国王情妇而言前所未有的方式化解了这一切：她极其礼貌。那些因她出身低微而对她心怀不满的势利眼，也被她用魅力和优雅征服。最不同寻常的是，她与王后交好，并坚持要求路易十五更加关注他的妻子，对她更加友善。就连王室成员也勉强地给予了她支持。
nature of men is ambitious as well as suspicious, and puts no limits to one's good fortune, it is not impossible that the suspicion that may suddenly be aroused in the mind of the prince by the victory of the general may have been aggravated by some haughty expressions or insolent acts on his part; so that the prince will naturally be made to think of securing himself against the ambition of his general. And to do this, the means that suggest themselves to him are either to have the general killed, or to deprive him of that reputation which he has acquired with the prince's army and the people, by using every means to prove that the general's victory was not due to his skill and courage, but to chance and the cowardice of the enemy, or to the sagacity of the other captains who were with him in that action.
人性既野心勃勃又疑心重重，一旦取得好运便不会止步。因此，将军的胜利或许会令君主心生疑虑，而将军傲慢的言辞或无礼的行为更会加剧这种疑虑。于是，君主自然会考虑如何防范将军的野心。为了达到这个目的，君主会想到的办法要么是除掉将军，要么是想方设法抹杀将军在军队和民众中赢得的威望，证明将军的胜利并非源于他的才能和勇气，而是出于运气、敌人的怯懦，或是其他将领的机智。
NiccolO Machiavelli, 1469-1527
尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527 年
A man who was famous as a tree climber was guiding someone in climbing a tall tree. He ordered the man to cut the top branches, and, during this time, when the man seemed to be in great danger, the expert said nothing. Only when the man was coming down and had reached the height of the eaves did the expert call out, “Be careful! Watch your step coming down!” I asked him, “Why did you say that At that height he could jump the rest of the way if he chose. ” “That's the point, ” said the expert. “As long as the man was up at a dizzy height and the branches were threatening to break, he himself was so afraid I said nothing. Mistakes are always made when people get to the easy places. ” This man belonged to the lowest class, but his words were in perfect accord with the precepts of the sages. In football too, they say that after you have kicked out of a difficult place and you think the next one will be easier you are sure to miss the ball.
一位以爬树闻名的男子正在指导他人爬一棵高树。他命令那人砍掉树梢的树枝，期间，那人似乎身处险境，这位高手却一言不发。直到那人下树，走到屋檐边时，他才喊道：“小心！小心脚下！”我问他：“你为什么这么说？他要是愿意，完全可以跳下去。”“关键就在这里，”高手说道，“当那人身处令人眩晕的高度，树枝摇摇欲坠时，他自己也吓得魂飞魄散，所以我才没说什么。人们总是在安逸的时候犯错。”这个人出身卑微，但他的话却与圣贤的教诲不谋而合。足球界也有类似的说法：当你踢出一个难踢的球后，如果觉得下一个球会更容易，那你肯定会踢丢。
essays in idleness,
闲散随笔
Kenko,
健光
Japan,
日本，
fourteenthcentury
十四世纪
crown her glory, die king made her a duchess. Her sway was felt even in politics: Indeed she became the untided minister of foreign affairs.
国王册封她为公爵夫人，为她加冕荣耀。她的影响力甚至延伸到了政界：事实上，她成为了首任外交大臣。
In 1751, when Madame de Pompadour was at the height of her power, she experienced her worst crisis. Physically weakened by die responsibilities of her position, she found it increasingly difficult to meet die king's demands in bed. This was usually the point at which die mistress would meet her end, struggling to maintain her position as her beauty faded. But Madame de Pompadour had a strategy: She encouraged the king to set up a kind of brothel, Pare aux Cerfs, on the grounds of Versailles. There die middle-aged king could have liaisons widi die most beautiful young girls in the realm.
1751年，蓬帕杜夫人正值权势巅峰之际，却遭遇了人生中最严重的危机。由于身负重任，她的身体日渐衰弱，越来越难以满足国王在床上的需求。通常情况下，情妇的末日就在此时到来，随着美貌的消逝，她苦苦挣扎，难以维持自己的地位。但蓬帕杜夫人早有妙计：她怂恿国王在凡尔赛宫内设立一处名为“鹿苑”（Pare aux Cerfs）的妓院。在那里，年迈的国王可以与全国最美丽的年轻女孩寻欢作乐。
Madame de Pompadour knew tiiat her charm and her political acumen had made her indispensable to the king. What did she have to fear from a sixteen-year-old who had none of her power and presence What did it matter if she lost her position in the bedroom, as long as she remained the most powerful woman in France To secure tiiat position she became still closer friends with the queen, with whom she started attending church. Although her enemies at the court conspired to have her toppled from her official position as king's mistress, die king kept her on, for he needed her calming effect. It was only when her part in the disastrous Seven Years' War drew much criticism on her that she slowly wididrew from public affairs.
蓬帕杜夫人深知，她的魅力和政治手腕使她对国王来说不可或缺。一个十六岁的少女，既没有她那样的权势和气场，她又有什么可惧怕的呢？只要她仍然是法国最有权势的女人，失去在国王寝宫的地位又有什么关系呢？为了巩固自己的地位，她与王后的关系更加密切，甚至开始与王后一同去教堂。尽管宫廷中的敌人密谋将她从国王情妇的职位上拉下来，国王仍然留用了她，因为他需要她带来的安抚作用。直到她在灾难性的七年战争中扮演的角色招致诸多批评之后，她才逐渐退出政坛。
Madame de Pompadour's healdi had always been delicate, and she died at the age of forty-three, in 1764. Her reign as mistress had lasted an unprecedented twenty years. “She was regretted by all,” wrote the Due de Croy, “for she was kindly and helpful to everyone who approached her.”
蓬帕杜夫人一直体弱多病，于1764年去世，享年43岁。她作为女主人的统治持续了前所未有的20年。“所有人都对她感到惋惜，”德·克罗伊写道，“因为她对每个接近她的人都和蔼可亲、乐于助人。”
Interpretation
解释
Aware of die temporariness of her power, die king's mistress would often go into a kind of frenzy after capturing die king: She would try to accumulate as much money as possible to protect her after her inevitable fall. And to extend her reign as long as possible, she would be rutiiless widi her enemies in the court. Her situation, in odier words, seemed to demand from her a greed and vindictiveness diat would often be her undoing. Madame de Pompadour succeeded where all others had failed because she never pressed her good fortune. Instead of bullying die courtiers from her powerful position as die king's mistress, she tried to win their support. She never revealed die slightest hint of greed or arrogance. When she could no longer perform her physical duties as mistress, she did not fret at the tiiought of someone replacing her in bed. She simply applied some strategyshe encouraged the king to take young lovers, knowing that the younger and prettier they were, the less of a direat they posed, since diey could not compare to her in charm and sophistication and would soon bore die monarch.
深知权力的短暂，这位国王的情妇在俘虏国王后往往会陷入一种近乎疯狂的状态：她会竭尽所能地积攒财富，以备不时之需。为了尽可能延长自己的统治，她会毫不留情地对待朝廷中的敌人。换句话说，她的处境似乎迫使她变得贪婪和报复心极强，而这往往也是她的致命弱点。蓬帕杜夫人之所以能做到其他人都做不到的事，是因为她从未滥用自己的好运。她没有利用自己作为国王情妇的权力欺压朝臣，而是努力赢得他们的支持。她从未流露出丝毫的贪婪或傲慢。即使当她无法再履行情妇的职责时，她也从不担心有人会取代她在床上的位置。她只是运用了一些策略——鼓励国王与年轻的情人交往，因为她知道情人越年轻漂亮，对国王的威胁就越小，因为她们在魅力和风度上无法与她相提并论，很快就会让国王感到厌倦。
Success plays strange tricks on die mind. It makes you feel invulnerable, while also making you more hostile and emotional when people chal-
成功会让人产生奇怪的错觉。它会让你觉得自己刀枪不入，同时也会让你在别人挑战你时变得更加敌对和情绪化。
lenge your power. It makes you less able to adapt to circumstance. You come to believe your character is more responsible for your success than your strategizing and planning. Like Madame de Pompadour, you need to realize that your moment of triumph is also a moment when you have to rely on cunning and strategy all the more, consolidating your power base, recognizing the role of luck and circumstance in your success, and remaining vigilant against changes in your good fortune. It is the moment of victory when you need to play the courtier's game and pay more attention dian ever to the laws of power.
挑战你的权力。这会让你更难适应环境。你会开始认为，你的性格比你的战略和计划更能决定你的成功。就像蓬帕杜夫人一样，你需要意识到，你的胜利时刻也是你更需要依靠谋略和策略的时刻，你需要巩固你的权力基础，认识到运气和环境在你成功中所扮演的角色，并时刻警惕好运的变迁。胜利的时刻，你需要像宫廷侍臣一样周旋，比以往任何时候都更加关注权力的法则。
The greatest danger occurs at the moment of victory. Napoleon Bonaparte, 1769-1821
最大的危险往往出现在胜利的那一刻。——拿破仑·波拿巴，1769-1821
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
Power has its own rhythms and patterns. Those who succeed at the game are the ones who control the patterns and vary them at will, keeping people off balance while they set the tempo. The essence of strategy is controlling what comes next, and the elation of victory can upset your ability to control what comes next in two ways. First, you owe your success to a pattern that you are apt to try to repeat. You will try to keep moving in the same direction without stopping to see whether this is still die direction that is best for you. Second, success tends to go to your head and make you emotional. Feeling invulnerable, you make aggressive moves diat ultimately undo die victory you have gained.
权力自有其节奏和模式。那些在权力游戏中胜出的人，正是那些能够掌控这些模式并随心所欲地改变它们的人，他们能让对手摸不着头脑，同时又能掌控节奏。策略的本质在于控制下一步的走向，而胜利的喜悦会从两个方面扰乱你对下一步走向的掌控。首先，你的成功源于一种你倾向于重复的模式。你会试图继续朝着同一个方向前进，而不会停下来思考这是否仍然是最适合你的方向。其次，成功往往会使你骄傲自满，变得情绪化。你会觉得自己所向披靡，从而采取激进的行动，最终导致你失去已经获得的胜利。
The lesson is simple: The powerful vary dieir rhythms and patterns, change course, adapt to circumstance, and learn to improvise. Radier than letting their dancing feet impel them forward, they step back and look where they are going. It is as if dieir bloodstream bore a kind of antidote to the intoxication of victory, letting them control their emotions and come to a kind of mental halt when they have attained success. They steady tiiem-selves, give themselves the space to reflect on what has happened, examine the role of circumstance and luck in tiieir success. As they say in riding school, you have to be able to control yourself before you can control the horse.
道理很简单：强者会改变节奏和模式，调整方向，适应环境，并学会随机应变。他们不会任由脚步推动自己前进，而是会后退一步，审视前路。仿佛他们的血液里流淌着某种解药，能够抑制胜利的狂喜，让他们在成功之后能够控制自己的情绪，保持一种心境平和的状态。他们会让自己冷静下来，给自己留出反思的空间，审视环境和运气在成功中所扮演的角色。正如马术学校里常说的，你必须先控制自己，才能控制马。
Luck and circumstance always play a role in power. This is inevitable, and actually makes die game more interesting. But despite what you may think, good luck is more dangerous tiian bad luck. Bad luck teaches valuable lessons about patience, timing, and the need to be prepared for the worst; good luck deludes you into die opposite lesson, making you mink your brillliance will carry you dirough. Your fortune will inevitably turn, and when it does you will be completely unprepared.
运气和境遇在权力中总是扮演着重要角色。这是不可避免的，实际上也让游戏更加精彩。但与你想象的不同，好运比坏运更危险。坏运教会你关于耐心、时机把握以及未雨绸缪的宝贵经验；好运则会让你误以为你的才华足以让你渡过难关。你的命运终将逆转，而当它来临时，你将毫无准备。
According to Machiavelli, this is what undid Cesare Borgia. He had many triumphs, was actually a clever strategist, but had the bad luck to have good luck: He had a pope for a fatiier. Then, when he had bad luck for realhis father's deamhe was unprepared for it, and the many ene-
根据马基雅维利的说法，这就是切萨雷·博尔吉亚的覆灭之源。他曾取得诸多胜利，实际上是一位精明的战略家，但却不幸地拥有了好运：他的父亲是教皇。然而，当他真正遭遇厄运——父亲去世时，他却毫无准备，随之而来的是诸多威胁。
mies he had made devoured him. The good luck diat elevates you or seals your success brings the moment for you to open your eyes: The wheel of fortune will hurtle you down as easily as up. If you prepare for the fall, it is less likely to ruin you when it happens.
他所创造的罪恶最终吞噬了他。好运降临，它提升你的地位或巩固你的成功，也为你带来睁开双眼的时刻：命运之轮既能让你飞黄腾达，也能让你跌落谷底。如果你为跌倒做好准备，那么当它真正发生时，你就更不容易被击垮。
People who have a run of success can catch a kind of fever, and even when they themselves try to stay calm, the people below diem often pressure diem to go past their mark and into dangerous waters. You have to have a strategy for dealing with these people. Simply preaching moderation will make you look weak and small-minded; seeming to fail to follow up on a victory can lessen your power.
那些连连成功的人容易得意忘形，即便他们自己努力保持冷静，下属也常常施压，迫使他们越过既定目标，走向危险的境地。你必须制定策略来应对这些人。仅仅宣扬节制会让你显得软弱无能、目光短浅；如果看起来没有乘胜追击，也会削弱你的影响力。
When the Athenian general and statesman Pericles led a series of naval campaigns around the Black Sea in 436 B.C., his easy triumphs en-flamed die Adienians' desire for more. They dreamed of conquering Egypt, overrunning Persia, sailing for Sicily. On the one hand Pericles reined in these dangerous emotions by warning of the perils of hubris. On the other hand he fed them by fighting small battles that he knew he could win, creating the appearance that he was preserving the momentum of success. The skill with which Pericles played this game is revealed by what happened when he died: The demagogues took over, pushed Adiens into invading Sicily, and in one rash move destroyed an empire.
公元前436年，雅典将军兼政治家伯里克利率领一系列黑海战役，他轻松取得的胜利激起了亚得尼亚人更大的野心。他们梦想征服埃及、攻占波斯、远航西西里。一方面，伯里克利警告人们傲慢自大的危险，以此来抑制这种危险的情绪。另一方面，他又通过发动一些他确信能够取胜的小规模战役来助长这种情绪，营造出他仍在保持胜利势头的假象。伯里克利玩弄这种政治游戏的高明之处，在他去世后发生的事情中显露无疑：蛊惑人心的政客们趁机夺权，迫使亚得尼亚人入侵西西里，并在一次鲁莽的行动中摧毁了一个帝国。
The rhydim of power often requires an alternation of force and cunning. Too much force creates a counterreaction; too much cunning, no matter how cunning it is, becomes predictable. Working on behalf of his master, die shogun Oda Nobunaga, the great sixteenth-century Japanese general (and future emperor) Hideyoshi once engineered a stunning victory over the army of the formidable General Yoshimoto. The shogun wanted to go further, to take on and crush yet another powerful enemy, but Hideyoshi reminded him of the old Japanese saying: “When you have won a victory, tighten the strings of your helmet.” For Hideyoshi this was die moment for the shogun to switch from force to cunning and indirection, setting his enemies against one another through a series of deceptive alliances. In diis way he would avoid stirring up needless opposition by appearing overly aggressive. When you are victorious, tiien, lie low, and lull the enemy into inaction. These changes of rhydim are immensely powerful.
权力的节奏往往需要武力与计谋的交替运用。武力过猛会招致反噬；计谋过度，无论多么高明，都会变得容易被识破。十六世纪日本伟大的将军（未来的天皇）丰臣秀吉，曾奉其主君织田信长之命，策划了一场惊天动地的胜利，击败了强大的义元将军的军队。信长意欲更进一步，再接再厉，征服并击溃另一个强大的敌人，但秀吉提醒他一句古老的日本谚语：“胜利之后，要收紧头盔的带子。”对秀吉而言，此时正是他从武力转向计谋和迂回策略的良机，他通过一系列欺骗性的联盟，让敌人自相残杀。这样，他就能避免因过于咄咄逼人而激起不必要的反抗。胜利之后，要保持低调，让敌人放松警惕。节奏的这些变化具有极其强大的力量。
People who go past the mark are often motivated by a desire to please a master by proving their dedication. But an excess of effort exposes you to die risk of making the master suspicious of you. On several occasions, generals under Philip of Macedon were disgraced and demoted immediately after leading dieir troops to a great victory; one more such victory, Philip thought, and the man might become a rival instead of an underling. When you serve a master, it is often wise to measure your victories carefully, letting him get die glory and never making him uneasy. It is also wise to establish a pattern of strict obedience to earn his trust. In the fourth century B.C., a captain under die notoriously severe Chinese general Wu Ch'i charged ahead before a batde had begun and came back with several
那些做得过火的人，往往是出于取悦主人、证明自己忠诚的愿望。但过分努力反而会让你失去主人的信任。马其顿的腓力二世麾下，曾有数位将领在率军取得重大胜利后立即被降职，蒙受耻辱；腓力二世心想，如果再来一次这样的胜利，那人恐怕会从下属变成自己的竞争对手。侍奉主人时，明智的做法是谨慎衡量自己的胜利，让主人独享荣耀，切勿让他感到不安。此外，建立一套严格的服从模式来赢得主人的信任也至关重要。公元前四世纪，中国以严苛著称的将领吴奇麾下的一名将领，在战斗开始前就冲锋陷阵，结果带回了数枚金币。
enemy heads. He tiiought he had shown his fiery enthusiasm, but Wu Ch'i was unimpressed. “A talented officer,” die general said with a sigh as he ordered the man beheaded, “but a disobedient one.”
敌军首级。他以为自己已经展现了那股热情，但吴奇却不为所动。“一个有才华的军官，”将军叹了口气，下令将那人斩首，“可惜是个不听话的军官。”
Another moment when a small success can spoil the chances for a larger one may come if a master or superior grants you a favor: It is a dangerous mistake to ask for more. You will seem insecureperhaps you feel you did not deserve this favor, and have to grab as much as you can when you have the chance, which may not come again. The proper response is to accept the favor graciously and withdraw. Any subsequent favors you should earn without having to ask for them.
另一个小的成功可能会错失更大成功的机会的例子是：当你的上司或上级帮了你一个忙时，索取更多是一个危险的错误。你会显得缺乏安全感——或许你会觉得自己不配得到这份恩惠——因此想要抓住机会，因为这样的机会可能不会再有第二次。正确的做法是优雅地接受恩惠，然后悄然离去。之后任何恩惠都应该靠实力赢得，而不是主动索取。
Finally, the moment when you stop has great dramatic import. What comes last sticks in the mind as a kind of exclamation point. There is no better time to stop and walk away than after a victory. Keep going and you risk lessening the effect, even ending up defeated. As lawyers say of cross-examination, “Always stop with a victory.”
最后，你停下来的那一刻具有极大的戏剧性意义。最后发生的事情会像一个惊叹号一样深深地印在人们的脑海中。没有什么比胜利之后更适合停下来离开的了。继续下去，你可能会削弱胜利的效果，甚至最终以失败告终。正如律师们在交叉询问中所说的那样：“永远在胜利之后结束。”
Image: Icarus Falling from the Sky. His father Daedalus fashions wings of wax that allow the two men to fly out of the labyrinth and escape the Minotaur. Elated by the triumphant escape and the feeling of flight, Icarus soars higher and higher, until the sun melts the wings and he hurtles to his death.
图片：伊卡洛斯坠落。他的父亲代达罗斯用蜡制作了一对翅膀，使父子二人得以飞出迷宫，逃脱弥诺陶洛斯的魔爪。伊卡洛斯因成功逃脱和飞翔的快感而欣喜若狂，越飞越高，直到太阳融化了翅膀，他才坠落身亡。
Authority: Princes and republics should content themselves with victory, for when they aim at more, they generally lose. The use of insulting language toward an enemy arises from the insolence of victory, or from the false hope of victory, which latter misleads men as often in their actions as in their words; for when this false hope takes possession of the mind, it makes men go beyond the mark, and causes them to sacrifice a certain good for an uncertain better. (Niccolo Machiavelli, 1469-1527)
权威：君主和共和国应当满足于胜利，因为贪得无厌往往会导致失败。对敌人使用侮辱性语言，要么源于胜利的傲慢，要么源于对胜利的虚假幻想。后者常常误导人们的言行；因为当这种虚假幻想占据了人们的心灵，就会驱使他们越界，为了不确定的更好而牺牲确定的利益。（尼科洛·马基雅维利，1469-1527）
REVERSAL
逆转
As Machiavelli says, either destroy a man or leave him alone entirely. Inflicting half punishment or mild injury will only create an enemy whose bitterness will grow with time, and who will take revenge. When you beat an enemy, then, make your victory complete. Crush him into nonexistence. In the moment of victory, you do not restrain yourself from crushing the enemy you have defeated, but rather from needlessly advancing against others. Be merciless with your enemy, but do not create new enemies by overreaching.
正如马基雅维利所说，要么彻底消灭一个人，要么就完全放过他。轻描淡写地惩罚或轻微伤害只会树立一个敌人，随着时间的推移，他的怨恨会与日俱增，最终会伺机报复。因此，当你击败敌人时，务必做到彻底的胜利，将他彻底摧毁。在胜利的那一刻，你不仅要继续消灭已经击败的敌人，更要避免盲目地攻击其他敌人。对你的敌人要毫不留情，但不要因为过度扩张而树立新的敌人。
There are some who become more cautious than ever after a victory, which they see as just giving them more possessions to worry about and protect. Your caution after victory should never make you hesitate, or lose momentum, but rather act as a safeguard against rash action. On the other hand, momentum as a phenomenon is gready overrated. You create your own successes, and if they follow one upon the otiier, it is your own doing. Belief in momentum will only make you emotional, less prone to act strategically, and more apt to repeat the same memods. Leave momentum for those who have nothing better to rely upon.
有些人胜利后反而变得比以往任何时候都更加谨慎，他们认为胜利只会让他们拥有更多需要担忧和保护的东西。胜利后的谨慎绝不应让你犹豫不决或失去势头，而应成为防止鲁莽行事的保障。另一方面，势头这种现象被严重高估了。你的成功是自己创造的，如果成功接踵而至，那也是你自己努力的结果。迷信势头只会让你变得情绪化，更难进行战略性决策，更容易重复同样的模式。把势头留给那些别无依靠的人吧。
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
LAW 48
第48条
ASSUME FORMLESSNESS
假定无形
JUDGMENT
判断
By taking a shape, by having a visible plan, you open yourself to attack. Instead of taking a form for your enemy to grasp, keep yourself adaptable and on the move. Accept the fact that nothing is certain and no law is fixed. The best way to protect yourself is to be as fluid and formless as water; never bet on stability or lasting order. Everything changes.
一旦你确立某种形态，制定出一个清晰可见的计划，你就等于向敌人敞开了大门。与其让敌人轻易摸清你的套路，不如保持灵活机动。要接受世事无常、没有一成不变的法则这一事实。保护自己的最佳方式就是像水一样流动无形；永远不要寄希望于稳定或永恒的秩序。一切都在变化。
In martial arts, it is important that strategy he unfathomable, that form he concealed, and that movements he unexpected, so that preparedness against than he impossible. What enables a good general to win without fail is always having unfathomable wisdom and a modus operandi that leaves no tracks. Only the formless cannot be affected. Sages hide in unfath-omability, so their feelings cannot he observed; they operate in formlessness, so their lines cannot be crossed.
在武术中，策略深不可测、姿态隐秘、动作出其不意至关重要，这样才能使对手难以防备。一位优秀的将领之所以能够屡战屡胜，是因为他始终拥有深不可测的智慧和不留痕迹的行事方式。唯有无形之物才能不受影响。圣贤隐匿于深不可测之中，因此他们的情感不为人知；他们行事无形，因此他们的路线不为人所触及。
China,
中国，
“What crime have I committed that I should be thus mutilated by my own master ” pensively exclaimed Jowlcr, a young mastiff. “Here's a pretty condition for a dog of my pretentions! How can I show my face among my friends'/ Oh! king of beasts, or rather their tyrant, who would dare to treat you thus ” His complaints were not unfounded, for that very morning, his master, despite the piercing shrieks of our young friend, had
“我究竟犯了什么罪，竟被自己的主人如此虐待？”年轻的獒犬乔尔克忧心忡忡地喊道，“这可真不像我这副德行！我怎能面见我的朋友们？哦！百兽之王，或者更确切地说，是百兽之王的暴君，竟敢如此对待你！”他的抱怨并非空穴来风，因为就在那天早上，尽管他发出凄厉的惨叫，他的主人还是……
TRANSGRESSION OF THE LAW
违反法律
By the eighth century B.C., the city-states of Greece had grown so large and prosperous that they had run out of land to support dieir expanding populations. So they turned to the sea, establishing colonies in Asia Minor, Sicily, the Italian peninsula, even Africa. The city-state of Sparta, however, was landlocked and surrounded by mountains. Lacking access to the Mediterranean, the Spartans never became a seafaring people; instead they turned on the cities around diem, and, in a series of brutal, violent conflicts lasting more than a hundred years, managed to conquer an immense area diat would provide enough land for dieir citizens. This solution to dieir problem, however, brought a new, more formidable one: How could diey maintain and police dieir conquered territories The subordinate peoples diey ruled now outnumbered diem ten to one. Surely Uiis horde would take a horrible revenge on diem.
公元前八世纪，希腊城邦发展壮大，繁荣昌盛，以至于土地不足以养活不断增长的人口。于是，他们转向海洋，在小亚细亚、西西里岛、意大利半岛，甚至非洲建立殖民地。然而，斯巴达城邦却是一个内陆国家，四周群山环绕。由于无法通往地中海，斯巴达人从未发展成为航海民族；相反，他们转而攻击周边城邦，经过一百多年的残酷战争，最终征服了一片广袤的土地，足以供养他们的公民。然而，这一解决方案却带来了一个新的、更为严峻的问题：他们如何才能维持和统治这些被征服的领土？他们统治的附属民族如今人口已是他们的十倍。可以肯定的是，乌伊的军队会对他们进行可怕的报复。
Sparta's solution was to create a society dedicated to die art of war. Spartans would be tougher, stronger, and fiercer dian dieir neighbors. This was die only way diey could ensure dieir stability and survival.
斯巴达的解决办法是建立一个致力于战争艺术的社会。斯巴达人将比他们的邻国更加强悍、更强大、更勇猛。这是他们确保自身稳定和生存的唯一途径。
When a Spartan boy reached the age of seven, he was taken from his mother and placed in a military club where he was trained to fight and underwent the strictest discipline. The boys slept on beds of reeds; diey were allotted only one outer garment to wear for an entire year. They studied none of die arts; indeed, the Spartans banned music, and permitted only slaves to practice die crafts diat were necessary to sustain diem. The only skills die Spartans taught were diose of warfare. Children seen as weaklings were left to die in a cavern in die mountains. No system of money or trading was allowed in Sparta; acquired wealtii, diey believed, would sow selfishness and dissension, weakening dieir warrior discipline. The only way a Spartan could earn a living was tiirough agriculture, mosdy on state-owned lands, which slaves, called helots, would work for him.
斯巴达男孩七岁时，会被从母亲身边带走，送入军事俱乐部接受战斗训练，并接受极其严格的纪律约束。男孩们睡在芦苇床上，一年只穿一件外衣。他们不学习任何技艺；事实上，斯巴达人禁止音乐，只允许奴隶从事维持生计所需的手工艺。斯巴达人教授的唯一技能是战争技巧。被视为弱小的孩子会被遗弃在山洞里等死。斯巴达不允许任何货币或贸易体系；他们认为，财富的积累会滋生自私和纷争，削弱战士的纪律。斯巴达人唯一的谋生之道是农业，主要是在国有土地上耕作，由被称为希洛人的奴隶为他们劳作。
The Spartans' single-mindedness allowed tiiem to forge die most powerful infantry in the world. They marched in perfect order and fought widi incomparable bravery. Their tight-knit phalanxes could vanquish an army ten times dieir size, as diey proved in defeating die Persians at Thermopylae. A Spartan column on die march would strike terror in die enemy; it seemed to have no weaknesses. Yet although die Spartans proved tiiem-selves mighty warriors, tiiey had no interest in creating an empire. They only wanted to keep what diey had already conquered and to defend it against invaders. Decades would pass witiiout a single change in the system diat had succeeded so well in preserving Sparta's status quo.
斯巴达人的专注使他们打造了世界上最强大的步兵。他们行军整齐划一，作战英勇无比。他们紧密的方阵能够击败比自己规模大十倍的敌军，正如他们在温泉关击败波斯人所证明的那样。斯巴达纵队行军时令敌人胆寒，似乎没有任何弱点。然而，尽管斯巴达人证明了自己是强大的战士，但他们对建立帝国却毫无兴趣。他们只想守住已经征服的土地，并抵御外敌入侵。数十年过去了，维持斯巴达现状的这套体系却丝毫没有改变。
At die same time tiiat die Spartans were evolving dieir warlike culture, anotiier city-state was rising to equal prominence: Atiiens. Unlike Sparta, Adiens had taken to die sea, not so much to create colonies as for purposes of trade. The Adienians became great merchants; dieir currency, me famous “owl coins,” spread mroughout die Mediterranean. Unlike die rigid Spartans, die Adienians responded to every problem with consummate creativity, adapting to die occasion and creating new social forms and new
在斯巴达人发展其尚武文化的同时，另一个城邦也崛起，达到了同样的高度：阿迪亚人。与斯巴达不同，阿迪亚人热衷于航海，其目的并非建立殖民地，而是为了贸易。阿迪亚人成为了伟大的商人；他们的货币，著名的“猫头鹰硬币”，在整个地中海地区流通。与固执的斯巴达人不同，阿迪亚人以极富创造力的方式应对每一个问题，适应环境，创造新的社会形态和新的……
arts at an incredible pace. Their society was in constant flux. And as their power grew, they came to pose a threat to the defense-minded Spartans.
他们的艺术发展日新月异，社会也始终处于不断变化之中。随着势力的增长，他们对崇尚防御的斯巴达人构成了威胁。
In 431 B.C., the war that had been brewing between Athens and Sparta for so long finally erupted. It lasted twenty-seven years, but after many twists of fortune, the Spartan war machine finally emerged victorious. The Spartans now commanded an empire, and this time uiey could not stay in their shell. If they gave up what they had gained, the beaten Athenians would regroup and rise against them, and the long war would have been fought for naught.
公元前431年，雅典和斯巴达之间酝酿已久的战争终于爆发。这场战争持续了27年，历经无数波折，最终斯巴达的战争机器取得了胜利。斯巴达人如今统治着一个帝国，这一次他们再也不能固步自封。如果他们放弃已取得的成就，战败的雅典人就会重整旗鼓，再次起兵反抗，那么这场漫长的战争就将毫无意义。
After the war, Athenian money poured into Sparta. The Spartans had been trained in warfare, not politics or economics; because they were so unaccustomed to it, wealth and its accompanying ways of life seduced and overwhelmed them. Spartan governors were sent to rule what had been Athenian lands; far from home, they succumbed to the worst forms of corruption. Sparta had defeated Athens, but the fluid Athenian way of life was slowly breaking down its discipline and loosening its rigid order. And Athens, meanwhile, was adapting to losing its empire, managing to thrive as a cultural and economic center.
战后，大量雅典资金涌入斯巴达。斯巴达人接受的是军事训练，而非政治或经济；由于他们对此一无所知，财富及其带来的生活方式诱惑并最终吞噬了他们。斯巴达总督被派往曾经属于雅典的领土进行统治；远离家乡的他们，最终堕入了最恶劣的腐败之中。斯巴达虽然战胜了雅典，但雅典灵活多变的生活方式正在逐渐瓦解其纪律，动摇其僵化的秩序。与此同时，雅典也在适应失去帝国的局面，并成功地发展成为文化和经济中心。
Confused by a change in its status quo, Sparta grew weaker and weaker. Some thirty years after defeating Athens, it lost an important batde with the city-state of Thebes. Almost overnight, this once mighty nation collapsed, never to recover.
由于现状的改变，斯巴达感到困惑，国力日渐衰弱。在击败雅典约三十年后，它在与底比斯城邦的一场重要战役中战败。几乎一夜之间，这个曾经强大的国家就此崩溃，从此一蹶不振。
Interpretation
解释
In the evolution of species, protective armor has almost always spelled disaster. Although there are a few exceptions, the shell most often becomes a dead end for the animal encased in it; it slows the creature down, making it hard for it to forage for food and making it a target for fast-moving predators. Animals that take to the sea or sky, and that move swiftly and unpredictably, are infinitely more powerful and secure.
在物种进化过程中，保护性的盔甲几乎总是带来灾难。尽管也有少数例外，但大多数情况下，甲壳会成为被包裹其中的动物的死胡同；它会减缓动物的速度，使其难以觅食，并使其成为快速移动的捕食者的目标。那些生活在海洋或天空中，行动迅速且难以预测的动物，则要强大得多，也安全得多。
In facing a serious problemcontrolling superior numbersSparta reacted like an animal that develops a shell to protect itself from the environment. But like a turtle, the Spartans sacrificed mobility for safety. They managed to preserve stability for three hundred years, but at what cost They had no culture beyond warfare, no arts to relieve the tension, a constant anxiety about the status quo. While their neighbors took to the sea, learning to adapt to a world of constant motion, the Spartans entombed themselves in their own system. Victory would mean new lands to govern, which tfiey did not want; defeat would mean the end of their military machine, which they did not want, either. Only stasis allowed them to survive. But nothing in the world can remain stable forever, and the shell or system you evolve for your protection will someday prove your undoing.
面对兵力优势带来的严峻挑战，斯巴达人的反应如同动物进化出坚硬的外壳来保护自己免受环境侵害。然而，如同乌龟一般，斯巴达人为了安全牺牲了机动性。他们成功地维持了三百年的稳定，但代价是什么呢？除了战争，他们没有其他文化，没有艺术来缓解紧张，始终处于对现状的焦虑之中。当他们的邻国转向海洋，学会适应不断变化的世界时，斯巴达人却把自己封闭在了自身的体系之中。胜利意味着新的领土需要征服，而他们并不想要；失败则意味着军事机器的终结，而他们同样不愿看到这种情况发生。只有停滞才能让他们生存下去。然而，世间万物终有尽头，你为了保护自己而进化出的外壳或体系，终有一天会成为你的致命弱点。
In the case of Sparta, it was not the armies of Athens that defeated it, but the Athenian money. Money flows everywhere it has the opportunity to go; it cannot be controlled, or made to fit a prescribed pattern. It is inherently chaotic. And in the long run, money made Athens the conqueror,
就斯巴达而言，击败它的并非雅典的军队，而是雅典的金钱。金钱会流向任何有机会的地方；它无法被控制，也无法被强行套用某种既定模式。它本质上是混乱的。最终，金钱使雅典成为了征服者。
barbarously cut off his long pendent ears. Jowler expected nothing less than to give up the ghost. As he advanced in years, he perceived that he gained more than he had lost by his mutilation; for, being naturally inclined to fight with others, he would often have returned home with this part disfigured in a hundred places. A quarrelsome dog always has his ears lacerated. The less we leave others to lay hold of the better. When one has but one point to defend, it should be protected for fear of accident. Take for example Master Jowler, who, being armed with a spiked collar, and having about as much ear as a bird, a wolf would be puzzled to know where to tackle him.
他那长长的垂耳被残忍地割掉了。乔勒当时以为自己必死无疑。随着年龄增长，他意识到自己从这残缺中得到的比失去的更多；因为他天性好斗，如果没有这残缺，他常常会带着满身伤痕的耳朵回家。好斗的狗耳朵总是伤痕累累。我们越少让别人有机可乘越好。如果只有一点需要保护，就应该严加守护，以免发生意外。就拿乔勒来说吧，他戴着带刺的项圈，耳朵却只有鸟耳朵那么大，狼都不知道该从哪里下手。
FABLES,
寓言故事
Jean de La Fontaine, 1621-1695
让·德拉封丹，1621-1695 年
One seductive and ultimately always fatal path has been the development of protective armor. An organism can protect itself by concealment, by swiftness in flight, by effective counterattack, by uniting for attack and defense with other individuals of its species and also by encasing itself within bony plates and spines.... Almost always the experiment of armor failed. Creatures adopting it tended to become unwieldy. They had to move relatively slowly. Hence they were forced to live mainly on vegetable food; and thus in general they were at a disadvantage as compared with foes living on more rapidly “profitable ” animal food: The repeated failure of protective armor shows that, even at a somewhat low evolutionary level, mind triumphed over mere matter. It is this sort of triumph which has been supremely exemplified in Man.
一条诱人却最终总是致命的道路是进化出防护盔甲。生物可以通过隐蔽、快速飞行、有效反击、与同类联合攻防以及用骨板和棘刺包裹自身来保护自己……然而，盔甲的尝试几乎总是失败的。采用盔甲的生物往往变得笨重，行动也相对缓慢。因此，它们被迫主要以植物性食物为生；与那些以生长速度更快、更“有利可图”的动物性食物为生的敌人相比，它们通常处于劣势：防护盔甲的屡次失败表明，即使在进化程度较低的阶段，精神也战胜了物质。而人类正是这种胜利的最佳例证。
SCIENTIFIC THEORY AND RELIGION,
科学理论与宗教
E. W. Barnes, 1933
E. W. Barnes，1933年
by infiltrating the Spartan system and corroding its protective armor. In the battle between the two systems, Adiens was fluid and creative enough to take new forms, while Sparta could grow only more rigid until it cracked.
通过渗透斯巴达系统并腐蚀其防护装甲。在两个系统的较量中，阿迪恩斯系统灵活多变，不断变换形态，而斯巴达系统却只能变得越来越僵硬，直至最终崩溃。
This is the way the world works, whether for animals, cultures, or individuals. In the face of the world's harshness and danger, organisms of any kind develop protectiona coat of armor, a rigid system, a comforting ritual. For the short term it may work, but for the long term it spells disaster. People weighed down by a system and inflexible ways of doing things cannot move fast, cannot sense or adapt to change. They lumber around more and more slowly until they go the way of the brontosaurus. Learn to move fast and adapt or you will be eaten.
这就是世界的运行方式，无论对动物、文化还是个人而言皆是如此。面对世界的严酷和危险，任何生物都会发展出保护机制——一层盔甲、一套僵化的体系、一种令人感到慰藉的仪式。短期来看，这或许有效，但从长远来看，却预示着灾难。被体系和僵化的行事方式束缚的人们行动迟缓，无法感知或适应变化。他们步履蹒跚，越来越缓慢，最终步雷龙的后尘。学会快速行动并适应环境，否则就会被吃掉。
The best way to avoid diis fate is to assume formlessness. No predator alive can attack what it cannot see.
避免这种命运的最佳方法是让自己变得无形。任何活着的捕食者都无法攻击它看不见的东西。
OBSERVANCE OF THE LAW
遵守法律
When World War II ended and the Japanese, who had invaded China in 1937, had finally been thrown out, the Chinese Nationalists, lead by Chiang Kai-shek, decided the time had come to annihilate the Chinese Communists, their hated rivals, once and for all. They had almost succeeded in 1935, forcing the Communists into the Long March, the grueling retreat mat had gready diminished their numbers. Although the Communists had recovered somewhat during the war against Japan, it would not be difficult to defeat them now. They controlled only isolated areas in the countryside, had unsophisticated weaponry, lacked any military experience or training beyond mountain fighting, and controlled no important parts of China, except areas of Manchuria, which they had managed to take after die Japanese retreat. Chiang decided to commit his best forces in Manchuria. He would take over its major cities and from those bases would spread through this northern industrial region, sweeping the Communists away. Once Manchuria had fallen the Communists would collapse.
二战结束后，1937年入侵中国的日本人终于被赶出中国。蒋介石领导的国民党认为，是时候彻底消灭他们憎恨的对手——中国共产党了。1935年，国民党几乎成功了，迫使共产党开始了长征，艰苦的撤退极大地削弱了他们的兵力。尽管共产党在抗日战争期间有所恢复，但现在击败他们并不难。他们只控制着农村的零星地区，武器装备简陋，除了山地作战之外缺乏任何军事经验和训练，除了在日军撤退后占领的满洲部分地区外，他们没有控制中国的重要领土。蒋介石决定将他的精锐部队投入满洲。他计划占领满洲的主要城市，并以此为据点，向整个北部工业区推进，彻底击溃共产党。一旦满洲陷落，共产党就会崩溃。
In 1945 and '46 the plan worked perfectly: The Nationalists easily took the major Manchurian cities. Puzzlingly, though, in the face of this critical campaign, the Communist strategy made no sense. When the Nationalists began their push, the Communists dispersed to Manchuria's most out-of-the-way corners. Their small units harassed the Nationalist armies, ambushing them here, retreating unexpectedly tiiere, but tiiese dispersed units never linked up, making them hard to attack. They would seize a town only to give it up a few weeks later. Forming neither rear guards nor vanguards, they moved like mercury, never staying in one place, elusive and formless.
1945年和1946年，这个计划完美奏效：国民党轻松拿下满洲的主要城市。然而，令人费解的是，面对这场关键战役，共产党的战略却显得毫无意义。国民党发起进攻时，共产党却分散到满洲最偏远的角落。他们的小股部队骚扰国民党军队，伺机伏击，然后出其不意地撤退，但这些分散的部队从未汇合，难以被击溃。他们攻占一座城镇，几周后又会放弃。他们既不组成后卫，也不组成先锋，行动如水银般变幻莫测，从不停留在原地，行踪飘忽不定，毫无章法。
The Nationalists ascribed this to two things: cowardice in die face of superior forces and inexperience in strategy. Mao Tse-tung, die Communist leader, was more a poet and philosopher than a general, whereas Chiang had studied warfare in die West and was a follower of die German military writer Carl von Clausewitz, among others.
国民党将此归咎于两点：面对优势兵力时的怯懦和战略经验的缺乏。毛泽东，这位共产党领导人，与其说是一位将军，不如说是一位诗人和哲学家；而蒋介石曾在西方学习战争，并且是德国军事作家卡尔·冯·克劳塞维茨等人的追随者。
Yet a pattern did eventually emerge in Mao's attacks. After the Nationalists had taken the cities, leaving the Communists to occupy what was generally considered Manchuria's useless space, the Communists started using that large space to surround the cities. If Chiang sent an army from one city to reinforce anotiier, die Communists would encircle the rescuing army. Chiang's forces were slowly broken into smaller and smaller units, isolated from one another, their lines of supply and communication cut. The Nationalists still had superior firepower, but if diey could not move, what good was it
然而，毛泽东的进攻最终还是呈现出一种模式。国民党攻占城市后，共产党便占据了当时普遍认为的满洲无用之地。共产党开始利用这片广袤的空地包围城市。如果蒋介石派兵从一座城市增援另一座城市，共产党就会包围这支前来救援的军队。蒋介石的部队逐渐被分割成越来越小的单位，彼此孤立，补给线和通讯线也被切断。国民党虽然仍然拥有强大的火力，但如果无法行动，又有什么用呢？
A kind of terror overcame the Nationalist soldiers. Commanders comfortably remote from the front lines might laugh at Mao, but the soldiers had fought the Communists in die mountains, and had come to fear their elusiveness. Now these soldiers sat in their cities and watched as their fast-moving enemies, as fluid as water, poured in on them from all sides. There seemed to be millions of them. The Communists also encircled the soldiers' spirits, bombarding diem with propaganda to lower their morale and pressure them to desert.
一种恐惧笼罩着国民党士兵。那些远离前线的指挥官或许会嘲笑毛泽东，但士兵们曾在山地与共产党作战，早已对共产党的狡猾和诡谲心生畏惧。如今，这些士兵坐在城里，眼睁睁地看着如流水般迅捷的敌人从四面八方涌来。敌人似乎有千千万万之众。共产党还从精神上对士兵们进行围攻，铺天盖地的宣传试图打击他们的士气，迫使他们开小差。
The Nationalists began to surrender in their minds. Their encircled and isolated cities started collapsing even before being directly attacked; one after another fell in quick succession. In November of 1948, the Nationalists surrendered Manchuria to the Communistsa humiliating blow to the technically superior Nationalist army, and one that proved decisive in the war. By the following year the Communists controlled all of China.
国民党军队在思想上开始崩溃。他们被包围的孤立城市甚至在遭到直接攻击之前就开始瓦解；一座接一座地迅速陷落。1948年11月，国民党向共产党投降，放弃了满洲——这对技术上占优的国民党军队来说是一次耻辱性的打击，也是决定战争走向的关键一击。到第二年，共产党控制了整个中国。
Interpretation
解释
The two board games that best approximate tile strategies of war are chess and the Asian game of go. In chess the board is small. In comparison to go, the attack comes relatively quickly, forcing a decisive batde. It rarely pays to withdraw, or to sacrifice your pieces, which must be concentrated at key areas. Go is much less formal. It is played on a large grid, with 361 intersectionsnearly six times as many positions as in chess. Black and white stones (one color for each side) are placed on the board's intersections, one at a time, wherever you like. Once all your stones (52 for each side) are on the board, the object is to isolate die stones of your opponent by encircling diem.
最接近战争策略的棋类游戏是国际象棋和围棋。国际象棋的棋盘较小。与围棋相比，国际象棋的进攻节奏相对较快，迫使双方迅速展开决胜局。撤退或牺牲棋子往往得不偿失，棋子必须集中在关键区域。围棋则随意得多。围棋的棋盘很大，有361个交叉点——几乎是国际象棋的六倍。黑白棋子（双方各一种颜色）依次放置在棋盘的交叉点上，位置随意。双方各52颗棋子放置完毕后，目标是通过包围对方的棋子来孤立对方。
A game of gocalled wei-chi in Chinacan last up to three hundred moves. The strategy is more subtie and fluid than chess, developing slowly; the more complex the pattern your stones initially create on die board, the harder it is for your opponent to understand your strategy. Fighting to control a particular area is not worth the trouble: You have to think in larger terms, to be prepared to sacrifice an area in order eventually to dominate the board. What you are after is not an entrenched position but mobility. With mobility you can isolate the opponent in small areas and men encircle them. The aim is not to kill off the opponent's pieces directiy, as in chess, but to induce a kind of paralysis and collapse. Chess is linear, position oriented, and aggressive; go is nonlinear and fluid. Aggression is indi-
在中国被称为围棋的棋局可以持续三百步之久。围棋的策略比国际象棋更加微妙灵活，发展缓慢；棋子在棋盘上最初形成的图案越复杂，对手就越难理解你的策略。争夺某个特定区域并不值得：你必须从更宏观的角度思考，做好牺牲一部分区域的准备，最终才能掌控整个棋盘。你追求的不是固守阵地，而是行动的灵活性。有了灵活性，你可以将对手孤立在狭小的区域内，然后由棋子将其包围。围棋的目标不是像国际象棋那样直接消灭对手的棋子，而是使其陷入瘫痪和崩溃。国际象棋是线性的、注重位置的、进攻性的；围棋则是非线性的、灵活的。进攻性是……
The sage neither seeks to follow the ways of the ancients nor establishes any fixed standard for all times but examines the things of his age and then prepares to deal with them. There was in Sung a man, who tilled a field in which there stood the trunk of a tree. Once a hare, while running fast, rushed against the trunk, broke its neck, and died. Thereupon the man cast his plough aside and watched that tree, hoping that he would get another hare. Yet he never caught another hare and was himself ridiculed by the people of Sung. Now supposing somebody wanted to govern the people of the present age with the policies of the early kings, he would be doing exactly the same thing as that man who watched the tree.
圣人既不墨守古道，也不设立一成不变的准则，而是审视当下的种种，并着手应对。宋国有一位农夫，耕地时田里长着一棵树干。一天，一只野兔飞奔而来，撞上树干，折断了脖子，当场毙命。农夫便放下犁，守着那棵树，盼望能再抓到一只野兔。然而，他再也没抓到过野兔，反而被宋国百姓嘲笑。如今，若有人想用古王的政策治理当代，他所作所为就和那位守树的农夫如出一辙了。
Han-fei-tzu, Chinese philosopher, third century b.c.
韩非子，中国哲学家，公元前三世纪
General Rommel surpassed Patton as a creative intellect.... Rommel shunned military formalism. He made no fixed plans beyond those intended for the initial clash; thereafter, he tailored his tactics to meet specific situations as they arose. He was a lightning-fast decisionmaker, physically maintaining a pace that matched his active mentality. In a forbidding sea of sand, he operated in a free environment. Once Rommel ruptured the British lines in Africa, he had the whole northern part of the continent opened to him. Comparatively free from the hamstringing authority of Berlin, disregarding orders even from Hitler himself on occasion, Rommel implemented one successful operation after another until he had most of North Africa under his control and Cairo trembling at his feet.
隆美尔将军的创造力超越了巴顿……隆美尔摒弃了军事形式主义。除了最初交锋的计划外，他不制定任何固定方案；之后，他会根据实际情况调整战术。他决策迅速，行动也与他活跃的思维相匹配。在荒凉的沙漠中，他却拥有自由的作战环境。一旦隆美尔突破了英军在非洲的防线，整个非洲北部便向他敞开了大门。由于相对摆脱了柏林的束缚，隆美尔有时甚至无视希特勒的命令，他接连成功地实施了一系列军事行动，最终控制了北非的大部分地区，开罗也在他的脚下瑟瑟发抖。
THE ART OF WINNING WARS,
战争的艺术
James Mrazek, 1968
詹姆斯·姆拉泽克，1968年
rect until the end of the game, when the winner can surround the opponent's stones at an accelerated pace.
直到游戏结束，获胜者可以加速包围对手的棋子。
Chinese military strategists have been influenced by go for centuries. Its proverbs have been applied to war time and again; Mao Tse-tung was an addict of wei-chi, and its precepts were ingrained in his strategies. A key wei-chi concept, for example, is to use the size of the board to your advantage, spreading out in every direction so mat your opponent cannot fadiom your movements in a simple linear way.
几个世纪以来，围棋对中国军事战略家产生了深远的影响。围棋的格言被反复应用于战争；毛泽东酷爱围棋，其理念深深融入了他的战略之中。例如，围棋的一个关键概念就是利用棋盘的大小，向各个方向展开布局，使对手无法简单地通过直线来预测你的走法。
“Every Chinese,” Mao once wrote, “should consciously throw himself into this war of a jigsaw pattern” against the Nationalists. Place your men in a jigsaw pattern in go, and your opponent loses himself trying to figure out what you are up to. Either he wastes time pursuing you or, like Chiang Kai-shek, he assumes you are incompetent and fails to protect himself. And if he concentrates on single areas, as Western strategy advises, he becomes a sitting duck for encirclement. In die wei-chi way of war, you encircle the enemy's brain, using mind games, propaganda, and irritation tactics to confuse and dishearten. This was the strategy of the Communistsan apparent formlessness mat disoriented and terrified their enemy.
毛泽东曾写道：“每个中国人都要自觉地投身于这场与国民党的拼图式战争。” 将你的部队像拼图一样部署，你的对手就会迷失方向，试图弄清你的意图。他要么浪费时间追击你，要么像蒋介石那样，认为你无能，从而放弃自卫。如果他像西方战略建议的那样，集中兵力攻击单一区域，就会成为包围的活靶子。在这种围攻方式中，你要包围敌人的大脑，运用心理战、宣传和骚扰战术来迷惑和瓦解敌人。这就是共产党的战略——看似无形的行动使敌人感到迷茫和恐惧。
Where chess is linear and direct, the ancient game of go is closer to the kind of strategy that will prove relevant in a world where battles are fought indirectiy, in vast, loosely connected areas. Its strategies are abstract and multidimensional, inhabiting a plane beyond time and space: die strategist's mind. In this fluid form of warfare, you value movement over position. Your speed and mobility make it impossible to predict your moves; unable to understand you, your enemy can form no strategy to defeat you. Instead of fixing on particular spots, diis indirect form of warfare spreads out, just as you can use the large and disconnected nature of die real world to your advantage. Be like a vapor. Do not give your opponents anything solid to attack; watch as diey exhaust themselves pursuing you, trying to cope with your elusiveness. Only formlessness allows you to truly surprise your enemiesby die time they figure out where you are and what you are up to, it is too late.
国际象棋是线性且直接的，而古老的围棋则更接近于在当今世界间接交战、在广袤无垠、联系松散的区域展开的战略。围棋的策略抽象而多维，超越时空，存在于战略家的思维层面。在这种流动性的战争形式中，移动比位置更重要。你的速度和机动性使对手无法预测你的行动；由于无法理解你，敌人也无法制定任何策略来击败你。这种间接的战争形式并非着眼于特定地点，而是向四周扩散，正如你可以利用现实世界的广袤和分散性来获得优势一样。像雾一样。不要给你的对手留下任何可以攻击的实体；看着他们疲于奔命地追击你，试图应对你的难以捉摸。只有无形才能真正出其不意地攻击敌人——当他们弄清楚你的位置和意图时，一切都为时已晚。
When you want to fight us, we don't let you and you can't find us. But when
当你想和我们打架的时候，我们不会让你得逞，你也找不到我们。但是当
we want to fight you, we make sure that you can't get away and we hit you
我们想和你打，我们保证你逃不掉，我们会揍你。
squarely . . . and wipe you out. . . . The enemy advances, we retreat; the enemy
正面……并将你们消灭……敌人进，我们退；敌人
camps, we harass; the enemy tires, we attack; the enemy retreats, we pursue.
敌军营地，我们骚扰；敌军疲倦，我们进攻；敌军撤退，我们追击。
Mao Tse-tung, 1893-1976
毛泽东，1893-1976 年
KEYS TO POWER
权力之钥
The human animal is distinguished by its constant creation of forms. Rarely expressing its emotions directiy, it gives them form through language, or dirough socially acceptable rituals. We cannot communicate our emotions widiout a form.
人类的显著特征在于其不断创造形式。人类很少直接表达情感，而是通过语言或社会认可的仪式赋予情感以形式。没有形式，我们就无法传达情感。
The forms that we create, however, change constantiyin fashion, in
然而，我们所创造的形式却随着时间推移而不断变化。
style, in all those human phenomena representing the mood of the moment. We are constantly altering the forms we have inherited from previous generations, and these changes are signs of life and vitality. Indeed, the tilings that don't change, the forms that rigidify, come to look to us like death, and we destroy them. The young show this most clearly: Uncomfortable with the forms that society imposes upon them, having no set identity, they play with their own characters, trying on a variety of masks and poses to express themselves. This is the vitality that drives the motor of form, creating constant changes in style.
风格，存在于所有代表当下情绪的人类现象之中。我们不断地改变着从前人那里继承而来的形式，而这些改变正是生命力和活力的象征。的确，那些一成不变的模式，那些僵化的形式，在我们看来如同死亡，最终会被我们摧毁。年轻人最能清晰地展现这一点：他们不适应社会强加于身的形式，没有固定的身份认同，于是他们扮演着自己的角色，尝试着各种不同的面具和姿态来表达自我。正是这种活力驱动着形式的演变，创造了风格的不断变化。
The powerful are often people who in their youth have shown immense creativity in expressing something new through a new form. Society grants them power because it hungers for and rewards this sort of newness. The problem comes later, when they often grow conservative and possessive. They no longer dream of creating new forms; their identities are set, their habits congeal, and their rigidity makes them easy targets. Everyone knows their next move. Instead of demanding respect they elicit boredom: Get off the stage! we say, let someone else, someone younger, entertain us. When locked in the past, the powerful look comicalthey are overripe fruit, waiting to fall from the tree.
那些有权势的人，往往年轻时就展现出非凡的创造力，能够以全新的形式表达新事物。社会赋予他们权力，是因为社会渴望并奖励这种创新。问题在于，当他们长大后变得保守和固执时，权力便开始出现。他们不再梦想创造新的形式；他们的身份已经定型，习惯已经固化，而他们的僵化使他们成为众矢之的。每个人都知道他们的下一步行动。他们不再赢得尊重，反而令人感到厌倦：我们说：“滚下台吧！让别人，让更年轻的人来娱乐我们吧。”当权力被困在过去时，它看起来滑稽可笑——就像熟透的果实，等待着从树上掉落。
Power can only thrive if it is flexible in its forms. To be formless is not to be amorphous; everything has a formit is impossible to avoid. The formlessness of power is more like that of water, or mercury, taking the form of whatever is around it. Changing constantly, it is never predictable. The powerful are constantly creating form, and their power comes from the rapidity with which they can change. Their formlessness is in the eye of the enemy who cannot see what they are up to and so has nothing solid to attack. This is the premier pose of power: ungraspable, as elusive and swift as the god Mercury, who could take any form he pleased and used this ability to wreak havoc on Mount Olympus.
权力唯有灵活多变才能蓬勃发展。无形并非无定形；万物皆有形，这是无法回避的。权力的无形更像是水或水银，随心所欲地变换形态。它不断变化，难以预测。强者不断创造形态，其力量源于其变化之迅捷。敌人眼中的无形，使他们无法看透其意图，也就无从下手。这便是权力的至高姿态：难以捉摸，如同墨丘利神一般变幻莫测、迅捷无比。墨丘利神可以随心所欲地变换形态，并以此在奥林匹斯山上掀起腥风血雨。
Human creations evolve toward abstraction, toward being more mental and less material. This evolution is clear in art, which, in this century, made the great discovery of abstraction and conceptualism; it can also be seen in politics, which over time have become less overtly violent, more complicated, indirect and cerebral. Warfare and strategy too have followed this pattern. Strategy began in the manipulation of armies on land, positioning them in ordered formations; on land, strategy is relatively two dimensional, and controlled by topography. But all the great powers have eventually taken to the sea, for commerce and colonization. And to protect their trading lanes they have had to learn how to fight at sea. Maritime warfare requires tremendous creativity and abstract thinking, since the lines are constantly shifting. Naval captains distinguish themselves by their ability to adapt to the literal fluidity of the terrain and to confuse the enemy with an abstract, hard-to-anticipate form. They are operating in a third dimension: the mind.
人类的创造物朝着抽象化、精神化而非物质化的方向发展。这种演变在艺术领域尤为明显，本世纪艺术界取得了抽象艺术和概念艺术的伟大发现；在政治领域，这种演变也同样可见，政治随着时间的推移变得不那么公开暴力，而更加复杂、间接和理性。战争和战略也遵循着同样的模式。战略起源于陆地上军队的调动，将其部署成有序的阵型；在陆地上，战略相对来说是二维的，受地形地貌的限制。但所有强国最终都转向了海洋，以进行贸易和殖民扩张。为了保护其贸易航线，他们必须学会如何在海上作战。海战需要极强的创造力和抽象思维能力，因为战线瞬息万变。海军将领的卓越之处在于他们能够适应地形的瞬息万变，并以抽象的、难以预测的形式迷惑敌人。他们是在第三个维度——思维——中运作的。
Back on land, guerrilla warfare too demonstrates this evolution toward abstraction. T. E. Lawrence was perhaps the first modern strategist to de-
回到陆地上，游击战也体现了这种向抽象化的演变。T·E·劳伦斯或许是第一位将现代战略去抽象化的战略家。
CHAHACTKH
CHAHACTKH
To carry out the instinctual inhibition demanded by the modern world and to be able to cope with the energy stasis which results from this inhibition, the ego has to undergo a change. The ego, i.e., that part of the person that is exposed to danger, becomes rigid, as we say, when it is continually subjected to the same or similar conflicts between need and a fear-inducing outer world. It acquires in this process a chronic, automatically functioning mode of reaction, i.e., its “character. ” ft is as if the affective personality armored itself, as if the hard shell it develops were intended to deflect and weaken the blows of the outer world as-well as the clamoring of the inner needs. This armoring makes the person less sensitive to unpleasure, but also restricts his libidinal and aggressive motility and thus reduces his capacity for achievement and pleasure. We say the ego has become less flexible and more rigid, and that the ability to regulate the energy economy depends on the extent of the armoring.
为了满足现代社会对本能抑制的要求，并应对由此产生的能量停滞，自我必须发生改变。自我，也就是人格中暴露于危险的那一部分，当它持续受到相同或类似的内在需求与令人恐惧的外部世界之间的冲突时，就会变得僵化。在这个过程中，它会形成一种慢性的、自动运作的反应模式，也就是它的“性格”。这就像情感人格给自己穿上了盔甲，它所形成的坚硬外壳旨在抵挡和削弱外部世界的冲击以及内在需求的喧嚣。这种盔甲使人对不快感不那么敏感，但也限制了其力比多和攻击性的运动，从而降低了其成就和快乐的能力。我们说，自我变得不那么灵活，更加僵化，而调节能量的能力取决于这种盔甲的程度。
Wiihelm Reich, 1897-1957
威廉·赖希，1897-1957年
velop the theory behind this kind of warfare, and to put it into practice. His ideas influenced Mao, who found in his writings an uncanny Western equivalent to wei-chi. Lawrence was working with Arabs fighting for tiieir territory against the Turks. His idea was to make the Arabs blend into die vast desert, never providing a target, never collecting together in one place. As the Turks scrambled to fight this vaporous army, diey spread themselves thin, wasting energy in moving from place to place. They had the superior firepower but die Arabs kept the initiative by playing cat and mouse, giving die Turks nothing to hold on to, destroying their morale. “Most wars were wars of contact.... Ours should be a war of detachment,” Lawrence wrote. “We were to contain the enemy by die silent tiireat of a vast unknown desert, not disclosing ourselves till we attacked.”
他阐述了这种战争的理论，并将其付诸实践。他的思想影响了毛泽东，毛泽东在他的著作中发现了一种与“围剿”概念惊人相似的西方战术。劳伦斯当时正与阿拉伯人合作，对抗土耳其人，争夺他们的领土。他的理念是让阿拉伯人融入广袤的沙漠，不给他们留下任何目标，也不让他们聚集在一起。当土耳其人疲于应对这支“云雾缭绕”的军队时，他们分散了兵力，疲于奔命地四处转移。尽管土耳其人拥有更强大的火力，但阿拉伯人通过猫捉老鼠的游戏保持了主动权，让土耳其人无处可依，最终摧毁了他们的士气。“大多数战争都是接触战争……而我们的战争应该是分离战争，”劳伦斯写道。“我们要通过在广袤无垠的未知沙漠中进行无声的游击战来牵制敌人，在发起进攻之前绝不暴露自己。”
This is the ultimate form of strategy. The war of engagement has become far too dangerous and cosdy; indirection and elusiveness yield far better results at a much lower cost. The main cost, in fact, is mentalthe dunking it takes to align your forces in scattered patterns, and to undermine the minds and psychology of your opponents. And nothing will infuriate and disorient them more tiian formlessness. In a world where wars of detachment are the order of die day, formlessness is crucial.
这才是战略的终极形式。正面交锋的战争已经变得过于危险和昂贵；迂回和隐蔽的策略能以更低的成本带来更好的结果。事实上，主要的代价是精神上的消耗——将部队分散部署，并瓦解对手的心理和思维。没有什么比无序更能激怒和扰乱对手。在一个以分散作战为常态的世界里，无序至关重要。
The first psychological requirement of formlessness is to train yourself to take nothing personally. Never show any defensiveness. When you act defensive, you show your emotions, revealing a clear form. Your opponents will realize they have hit a nerve, an Achilles' heel. And diey will hit it again and again. So train yourself to take nothing personally. Never let anyone get your back up. Be like a slippery ball tilat cannot be held: Let no one know what gets to you, or where your weaknesses he. Make your face a formless mask and you will infuriate and disorient your scheming colleagues and opponents.
无形状态的首要心理要求是训练自己不去将任何事放在心上。永远不要表现出任何防御姿态。当你表现出防御姿态时，你便暴露了自己的情绪，从而暴露了你的真实面目。你的对手会意识到他们击中了你的痛处，你的阿喀琉斯之踵。他们会一次又一次地攻击它。所以，训练自己不去将任何事放在心上。永远不要让任何人激怒你。要像一个滑溜溜的球，让人无法抓住：不要让任何人知道什么会触动你，或者你的弱点在哪里。让你的脸变成一张无形的面具，你就会激怒并扰乱那些阴险狡诈的同事和对手。
One man who used diis technique was Baron James Rothschild. A German Jew in Paris, in a culture decidedly unfriendly to foreigners, Rothschild never took any attack on him personally or showed he had been hurt in any way. He furthermore adapted himself to the political climate, whatever it wasthe stiffly formal Restoration monarchy of Louis XVIII, die bourgeois reign of Louis-Philippe, die democratic revolution of 1848, tiie upstart Louis-Napoleon crowned emperor in 1852. Rotiischild accepted them one and all, and blended in. He could afford to appear hypocritical or opportunistic because he was valued for his money, not his politics; his money was die currency of power. While he adapted and thrived, outwardly never showing a form, all die otiier great families tilat had begun die century immensely wealthy were ruined in the period's complicated shifts and turns of fortune. Attaching tiiemselves to the past, they revealed their embrace of a form.
运用这种策略的人之一是詹姆斯·罗斯柴尔德男爵。作为一名生活在巴黎的德国犹太人，在当时对外国人极不友好的文化氛围中，罗斯柴尔德从未将任何攻击视为针对他个人的攻击，也从未表现出任何受伤之感。此外，他还能适应各种政治环境，无论是路易十八时期僵化的复辟君主制、路易·菲利普时期的资产阶级统治、1848年的民主革命，还是1852年路易·拿破仑加冕为帝，罗斯柴尔德都欣然接受，并融入其中。他可以肆意妄为，甚至显得虚伪或投机，因为他的价值在于他的财富，而非他的政治手腕；金钱才是权力的通行货币。在他适应环境并蓬勃发展的同时，他从未显露出任何姿态，而其他所有在本世纪初都极其富有的显赫家族，都在那个时代错综复杂的命运变迁中走向了衰败。他们将自己与过去联系在一起，这表明他们拥抱某种形式。
Throughout history, the formless style of ruling has been most adeptiy practiced by die queen who reigns alone. A queen is in a radically different position from a king; because she is a woman, her subjects and courtiers are likely to doubt her ability to rule, her strengdi of character. If she favors
纵观历史，这种无序的统治方式最常被独揽大权的女王所运用。女王的地位与国王截然不同；因为她是女性，她的臣民和朝臣往往会质疑她的统治能力和性格坚韧。如果她偏袒……
one side in some ideological struggle, she is said to be acting out of emotional attachment. Yet if she represses her emotions and plays die authoritarian, in the male fashion, she arouses worse criticism still. Either by nature or by experience, then, queens tend to adopt a flexible style of governing that in die end often proves more powerful than the more direct, male form.
在某种意识形态斗争中，如果她站在一方，人们会说她是出于情感依恋而行事。然而，如果她压抑自己的情感，像男性那样采取专制统治，则会招致更严厉的批评。因此，无论是出于天性还是后天经验，女王们往往倾向于采取一种灵活的统治方式，而这种方式最终往往比直接的男性统治方式更有效。
Two female leaders exemplifying die formless style of rule are Queen Elizabeth of England and Empress Catherine the Great of Russia. In die violent wars between Catholics and Protestants, Elizabeth steered a middle course. She avoided alliances that would commit her to one side, and that over time would harm the country. She managed to keep her country at peace until it was strong enough for war. Her reign was one of the most glorious in history because of her incredible capacity to adapt and her flexible ideology.
两位女性统治者堪称无拘无束的典范，她们分别是英国女王伊丽莎白二世和俄罗斯女皇叶卡捷琳娜二世。在天主教徒和新教徒之间激烈的战争中，伊丽莎白采取了折中路线。她避免与任何一方结盟，以免被迫偏袒任何一方，最终损害国家利益。她成功地维持了国家的和平，直到国家强大到足以发动战争。她卓越的适应能力和灵活的思想理念，使她的统治成为历史上最辉煌的时期之一。
CaUierine die Great too evolved an improvisatory style of governing. After she deposed her husband, Emperor Peter II, taking sole control of Russia in 1762, no one thought she would survive. But she had no preconceived ideas, no philosophy or theory to dictate her policies. Although a foreigner (she came from Germany), she understood Russia's moods, and how it was changing over the years. “One must govern in such a way that one's people think they themselves want to do what one commands them to do,” she said, and to do this she had to be always a step ahead of their desires and to adapt to their resistance. By never forcing die issue, she reformed Russia in a strikingly short period of time.
凯瑟琳大帝也发展出了一种即兴的统治风格。1762年，她废黜了丈夫彼得二世皇帝，独揽俄国大权，当时无人认为她能长久统治下去。但她没有任何先入为主的观念，也没有任何哲学或理论来指导她的政策。尽管她来自德国，是个外国人，但她了解俄国的民情，也了解俄国这些年来的变化。“统治者必须让人民心甘情愿地服从统治者的命令，”她说。为了做到这一点，她必须始终领先于人民的意愿，并适应他们的抵触情绪。正是因为她从不强迫人民接受任何事，她才得以在极短的时间内完成俄国的改革。
This feminine, formless style of ruling may have emerged as a way of prospering under difficult circumstances, but it has proved immensely seductive to those who have served under it. Being fluid, it is relatively easy for its subjects to obey, for they feel less coerced, less bent to their ruler's ideology. It also opens up options where an adherence to a doctrine closes them off. Without committing to one side, it allows the ruler to play one enemy off anodier. Rigid rulers may seem strong, but with time their inflexibility wears on the nerves, and their subjects find ways to push them from the stage. Flexible, formless rulers will be much criticized, but they will endure, and people will eventually come to identify witii them, since diey are as tiieir subjects arechanging widi die wind, open to circumstance.
这种女性化、无拘无束的统治风格或许是在困境中求得生存之道，但它对那些在其统治下效力的人却有着巨大的吸引力。由于其灵活性，臣民相对容易服从，因为他们感到较少受到胁迫，较少受制于统治者的意识形态。它也为那些因恪守教条而受限的人提供了更多选择。不偏袒任何一方，统治者便可周旋于不同的敌人之间。僵化的统治者或许看似强硬，但随着时间的推移，他们的固执会令人厌烦，臣民最终会找到办法将他们赶下台。灵活无拘的统治者会饱受诟病，但他们能够长久生存，人们最终会认同他们，因为他们如同他们的臣民一样，随风而变，灵活应变。
Despite upsets and delays, die permeable style of power generally triumphs in the end, just as Athens eventually won victory over Sparta tiirough its money and its culture. When you find yourself in conflict with someone stronger and more rigid, allow diem a momentary victory. Seem to bow to tiieir superiority. Then, by being formless and adaptable, slowly insinuate yourself into their soul. This way you will catch them off guard, for rigid people are always ready to ward off direct blows but are helpless against the subde and insinuating. To succeed at such a strategy you must play die chameleonconform on die surface, while breaking down your enemy from the inside.
尽管会遭遇挫折和延误，但这种灵活多变的权力模式最终往往会取得胜利，正如雅典最终凭借财富和文化战胜斯巴达一样。当你与更强大、更固执的人发生冲突时，不妨先让他们暂时获胜，表面上顺从他们的权威。然后，通过灵活变通，慢慢渗透到他们的内心深处。这样你就能出其不意地击败他们，因为固执的人总是能抵挡直接的攻击，却对潜移默化、潜移默化的手段束手无策。要想成功运用这种策略，你必须像变色龙一样，表面上顺从，同时从内部瓦解你的敌人。
For centuries the Japanese would accept foreigners graciously, and appeared susceptible to foreign cultures and influences. Joao Rodriguez, a Portuguese priest who arrived in Japan in 1577 and lived there for many years, wrote, “I am flabbergasted by the Japanese willingness to try and accept everything Portuguese.” He saw Japanese in die streets wearing Portuguese clothing, with rosary beads at their necks and crosses at their hips. This might seem like a weak, mutable culture, but Japan's adaptability actually protected the country from having an alien culture imposed by military invasion. It seduced the Portuguese and other Westerners into believing the Japanese were yielding to a superior culture when actually the foreign culture's ways were merely a fashion to be donned and doffed. Under the surface, Japanese culture thrived. Had the Japanese been rigid about foreign influences and tried to fight them off, they might have suffered the injuries that the West inflicted on China. That is the power of formlessnessit gives the aggressor nothing to react against, nothing to hit.
几个世纪以来，日本人一直热情地接纳外国人，似乎很容易受到外来文化和影响。1577年抵达日本并在那里生活多年的葡萄牙神父若昂·罗德里格斯写道：“日本人愿意尝试接受葡萄牙的一切，这让我感到震惊。”他看到街上的日本人穿着葡萄牙服饰，脖子上挂着念珠，腰间别着十字架。这或许会让人觉得日本文化软弱易变，但实际上，正是日本的这种适应能力保护了它免受军事入侵带来的外来文化强加。它诱使葡萄牙人和其他西方人相信，日本人正在向一种更优越的文化屈服，而实际上，外来文化的习俗只不过是一种可以随意穿脱的时尚。在表面之下，日本文化蓬勃发展。如果日本人对外国影响采取强硬态度并试图抵制，他们或许会遭受西方对中国造成的创伤。这就是无形的力量——它让侵略者无处可反抗，无处可击。
In evolution, largeness is often the first step toward extinction. What is immense and bloated has no mobility, but must constantly feed itself. The unintelligent are often seduced into believing that size connotes power, die bigger the better.
在进化过程中，体型庞大往往是走向灭绝的第一步。庞大臃肿的生物行动不便，必须不断觅食。愚昧之人常常被误导，认为体型越大越强大，死得越大越好。
In 483 B.C., King Xerxes of Persia invaded Greece, believing he could conquer the country in one easy campaign. After all, he had the largest army ever assembled for one invasionthe historian Herodotus estimated it at over more than five million. The Persians planned to build a bridge across the Hellespont to overrun Greece from the land, while tiieir equally immense navy would pin the Greek ships in harbor, preventing their forces from escaping to sea. The plan seemed sure, yet as Xerxes prepared the invasion, his adviser Artabanus warned his master of grave misgivings: “The two mightiest powers in the world are against you,” he said. Xerxes laughedwhat powers could match his gigantic army “I will tell you what they are,” answered Artabanus. “The land and the sea.” There were no safe harbors large enough to receive Xerxes' fleet. And die more land die Persians conquered, and die longer their supply lines stretched, the more ruinous the cost of feeding tiiis immense army would prove.
公元前483年，波斯国王薛西斯入侵希腊，他自认为只需一场战役就能轻松征服这个国家。毕竟，他集结了历史上规模最大的军队——据历史学家希罗多德估计，人数超过五百万。波斯人计划在赫勒斯滂海峡上架设桥梁，从陆路入侵希腊，同时利用其同样强大的海军将希腊船只困在港口，阻止其军队逃往海上。计划看似万无一失，然而就在薛西斯准备入侵之际，他的顾问阿尔塔巴努斯却警告他，情况十分不妙：“世界上两个最强大的势力都与你为敌。”薛西斯大笑起来——有什么势力能与他庞大的军队匹敌？“我会告诉你，”阿尔塔巴努斯回答道，“陆地和海洋。”当时没有足够大的安全港口可以容纳薛西斯的舰队。波斯人征服的土地越多，他们的补给线拉得越长，供养这支庞大军队的成本就越高昂。
Thinking his adviser a coward, Xerxes proceeded with the invasion. Yet as Artabanus predicted, bad weadier at sea decimated the Persian fleet, which was too large to take shelter in any harbor. On land, meanwhile, the Persian army destroyed everything in its path, which only made it impossible to feed, since the destruction included crops and stores of food. It was also an easy and slow-moving target. The Greeks practiced all kinds of deceptive maneuvers to disorient the Persians. Xerxes' eventual defeat at the hands of die Greek allies was an immense disaster. The story is emblematic of all Uiose who sacrifice mobility for size: The flexible and fleet of foot will almost always win, for they have more strategic options. The more gigantic the enemy, the easier it is to induce collapse.
薛西斯认为他的顾问是个懦夫，于是继续发动入侵。然而，正如阿尔塔巴努斯所预言的那样，海上恶劣的天气使波斯舰队损失惨重，庞大的舰队根本无法在任何港口找到庇护。与此同时，在陆地上，波斯军队所到之处，寸草不生，粮食和粮食储备也遭到破坏，导致他们无法获得补给。此外，波斯军队行动缓慢，很容易成为攻击目标。希腊人运用各种欺骗战术来迷惑波斯人。薛西斯最终被希腊盟军击败，这是一场巨大的灾难。这个故事象征着所有为了追求规模而牺牲机动性的军队：灵活敏捷的部队几乎总是能够获胜，因为他们拥有更多的战略选择。敌人越庞大，就越容易被击溃。
The need for formlessness becomes greater the older we get, as we grow more likely to become set in our ways and assume too rigid a form.
随着年龄的增长，我们对无拘无束的需求也越来越大，因为我们更容易固守成规，采取过于僵化的形式。
We become predictable, always the first sign of decrepitude. And predictability makes us appear comical. Although ridicule and disdain might seem mild forms of attack, they are actually potent weapons, and will eventually erode a foundation of power. An enemy who does not respect you will grow bold, and boldness makes even the smallest animal dangerous.
我们变得墨守成规，这往往是衰败的先兆。而墨守成规会让我们显得滑稽可笑。虽然嘲笑和蔑视看似温和的攻击，但它们实际上是强有力的武器，最终会侵蚀权力的根基。一个不尊重你的敌人会变得胆大妄为，而胆大妄为会让最弱小的动物也变得危险。
The late-eighteenth-century court of France, as exemplified by Marie-Antoinette, had become so hopelessly tied to a rigid formality that the average Frenchman thought it a silly relic. This depreciation of a centuries-old institution was the first sign of a terminal disease, for it represented a symbolic loosening of the people's ties to monarchy. As the situation worsened, Marie-Antoinette and King Louis XVI grew only more rigid in their adherence to the pastand quickened their path to the guillotine. King Charles I of England reacted similarly to the tide of democratic change brewing in England in the 1630s: He disbanded Parliament, and his court rituals grew increasingly formal and distant. He wanted to return to an older style of ruling, with adherence to all kinds of petty protocol. His rigidity only heightened the desire for change. Soon, of course, he was swept up in a devastating civil war, and eventually he lost his head to the executioner's axe.
以玛丽·安托瓦内特为代表的十八世纪末法国宫廷，已经彻底沦为僵化繁文缛节的附庸，以至于普通法国人都认为它不过是愚蠢的遗物。这种对延续数百年的制度的贬低，是君主制走向衰败的最初征兆，因为它象征着民众与君主制之间联系的松动。随着局势的恶化，玛丽·安托瓦内特和路易十六对传统的固守愈发僵化，加速了他们走向断头台的进程。英国国王查理一世在17世纪30年代面对英国酝酿的民主变革浪潮，也做出了类似的反应：他解散了议会，宫廷礼仪也变得日益繁文缛节，与民众疏离。他渴望回归旧有的统治方式，恪守各种繁琐的礼节。他的僵化反而加剧了人们对变革的渴望。当然，不久之后，他就被卷入了一场毁灭性的内战，最终被刽子手砍下了头颅。
As you get older, you must rely even less on the past. Be vigilant lest the form your character has taken makes you seem a relic. It is not a matter of mimicking the fashions of youththat is equally worthy of laughter. Rather your mind must constantly adapt to each circumstance, even the inevitable change that the time has come to move over and let those of younger age prepare for their ascendancy. Rigidity will only make you look uncannily like a cadaver.
随着年龄增长，你更应该减少对过去的依赖。要警惕，以免你的性格让你看起来像个老古董。这并非是要你模仿年轻时的时尚——那种做法同样令人发笑。相反，你的思想必须不断适应各种环境，即使是不可避免的变化，比如该让位给年轻人，让他们为未来的发展做好准备。僵化只会让你看起来像个死人。
Never forget, though, that formlessness is a strategic pose. It gives you room to create tactical surprises; as your enemies struggle to guess your next move, they reveal their own strategy, putting them at a decided disadvantage. It keeps the initiative on your side, putting your enemies in the position of never acting, constantly reacting. It foils their spying and intelligence. Remember: Formlessness is a tool. Never confuse it with a go-with-the-flow style, or with a religious resignation to the twists of fortune. You use formlessness, not because it creates inner harmony and peace, but because it will increase your power.
但切记，无形是一种战略姿态。它能让你创造战术上的惊喜；当你的敌人苦苦思索你的下一步行动时，他们自身的策略也会暴露无遗，从而陷入明显的劣势。它能让你始终掌握主动权，使你的敌人永远无法主动出击，只能被动应对。它能挫败他们的间谍活动和情报搜集。记住：无形是一种工具。切勿将其与随波逐流或对命运的盲目顺从混淆。你运用无形，并非为了获得内心的和谐与平静，而是为了增强你的力量。
Finally, learning to adapt to each new circumstance means seeing events through your own eyes, and often ignoring the advice that people constantly peddle your way. It means that ultimately you must throw out the laws that others preach, and the books they write to tell you what to do, and the sage advice of the elder. “The laws that govern circumstances are abolished by new circumstances,” Napoleon wrote, which means diat it is up to you to gauge each new situation. Rely too much on other people's ideas and you end up taking a form not of your own making. Too much respect for other people's wisdom will make you depreciate your own. Be brutal with the past, especially your own, and have no respect for the philosophies that are foisted on you from outside.
最后，学会适应每一种新情况意味着用自己的视角看待事物，并且常常忽略人们不断向你灌输的建议。这意味着最终你必须抛弃他人宣扬的法则、他们撰写的指导你行事的书籍，以及长辈的至理名言。“支配旧情况的法则会被新的情况所废除，”拿破仑写道，这意味着你需要自己去判断每一种新情况。过分依赖他人的想法，最终你会变成一个并非由你塑造的模样。过分尊重他人的智慧，会让你贬低自己的智慧。要对过去毫不留情，尤其是你自己的过去，并且对强加于你的外在哲学不屑一顾。
Image: Mercury. The winged messenger,
图片：墨丘利。这位长着翅膀的信使。
god of commerce, patron saint of thieves, gamblers, and all those who deceive through
商业之神，盗贼、赌徒以及所有行骗者的守护神
swiftness. The day Mercury was born he invented die lyre; by that evening he had stolen the cattle of Apollo. He would scour the world, assuming
迅捷无比。墨丘利出生那天就发明了竖琴；当天晚上，他就偷走了阿波罗的牛。他将走遍世界，自称……
whatever form he desired. Like the liquid metal
无论他想要什么形态，就像液态金属一样。
named after him, he embodies the elusive, the ungraspablethe power of formlessness.
他以自己的名字命名，体现了难以捉摸、不可捉摸的无形之力。
Authority: Therefore the consummation of forming an army is to arrive at formlessness. Victory in war is not repetitious, but adapts its form endlessly. ... A military force has no constant formation, water has no constant shape: The ability to gain victory by changing and adapting according to the opponent is called genius. (Sun-tzu, fourth century B.C.)
权威：因此，组建军队的最终目标是达到无形。战争的胜利并非一成不变，而是不断变化。……军队没有固定的阵型，水也没有固定的形状：能够根据对手的变化而改变和适应并取得胜利的能力，称为天才。（孙子，公元前四世纪）
REVERSAL
逆转
Using space to disperse and create an abstract pattern should not mean forsaking the concentration of your power when it is valuable to you. Formlessness makes your enemies hunt all over for you, scattering their own forces, mental as well as physical. When you finally engage them, though, hit them with a powerful, concentrated blow. That is how Mao succeeded against the Nationalists: He broke their forces into small, isolated units, which he then could easily overwhelm with a strong attack. The law of concentration prevailed.
利用空间分散兵力，营造抽象图案，并不意味着放弃集中力量的重要性。无形的阵型会让敌人四处搜寻，分散他们的精力和体力。但当你最终与他们交战时，务必集中火力，给予他们强有力的打击。毛泽东正是凭借这种策略战胜了国民党：他将国民党军队分割成一个个孤立的小单位，然后集中火力将其击溃。集中兵力的法则最终奏效。
When you play with formlessness, keep on top of the process, and keep your long-term strategy in mind. When you assume a form and go on the attack, use concentration, speed, and power. As Mao said, “ When we fight you, we make sure you can't get away.”
当你无形时，要掌控过程，并牢记你的长远战略。当你成形并发起进攻时，要运用专注、速度和力量。正如毛泽东所说：“我们与你交战，确保你无处可逃。”
#↩
48 Laws of Power
《权力的48条法则》
SELECTED BIBLIOGRAPHY
精选书目
Aesop. Fables of Aesop. Translated by S. A. Hanford. New York: Penguin
伊索寓言。S. A. Hanford 译。纽约：企鹅出版社。
Books, 1954. Bloodworth, Dennis and Ching Ping. The Chinese Machiavelli. New York:
书籍，1954年。布拉德沃思，丹尼斯和程平。《中国马基雅维利》。纽约：
Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1976. Bowyer, J. Barton. Cheating: Deception in War and Magic, Games and Sports,
